column2: Communities representing about 88 per cent of the population of New York State will require outside financial assistance in" handling' their relief work during the rest of 1932 and 1933, Charles H. Johnson, State Commissioner of Social Welfare, told the New York section of the Women's Department of the National Civic Federation yesterday afternoon at a meeting at the home of Mrs. Gilbert H. Montague, 152 East Fiftyseventh Street.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Thursday, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The northeastern executive committee of the new Manchurian State announced today that it would be nominally a republic for the time being with Henry Pu Yi, former boy Emperor of China, as "provisional chief executive."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The comment and letters published in THE TIMES in relation to General O'Ryan's article in the current number of The Air Law Review, were most interesting. However, they appear to be directed mainly to one aspect of the subject of death and injuries arising out of transportation by air.

Strength in United States Government bonds, in a few foreign loans and in New York rapid transit and traction issues featured yesterday's dealings in the listed bond market. Trading was considerably more active than on the previous day. Of the eleven active issues of United States Government bonds only the Treasury 3 1/5s held unchanged, while the others gained 3-32 to 14-32 point.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 24 -- The expected sale of Newark's issue of $5,000,000 of permanent bonds again today failed to materialize, and at the City Commission's meeting Mayor Jerome T. Congleton announced that he had received an "ultimatum" that unless the city reduced its budget $2,000,000 from last year's total the New York banking syndicate that was preparing to bid for the entire issue would not take it.

The price of copper for export was reduced a quarter cent a pound yesterday by custom smelters under the elastic temporary rules of Copper Exporters, Inc., which permit such price cutting. Custom smelters quoted 6 3/8 cents a pound, c.i.f., European base ports, although the official price of Copper Exporters was unchanged at 6 5/8 cents and the domestic price remained at 6 1/4 cents.
Tammany Hall expects Governor Roosevelt to appoint a Tammany man to succeed Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, the district leader whom he removed from office yesterday.

Lower prices dominated commodity markets again yesterday, the reaction carrying sugar and silk to new all-time lows, cocoa, rubber and lard also giving ground. Moderate strength was shown in the grains, cotton and coffee, which turned up slightly. As a group, metals alone remained steady.

QUEBEC, Feb. 24 (Canadian Press). -- Despite the fact that he won two out of three laps and broke the course record, victory was snatched from Shorty Russick today by Emil St. Goddard, who won the Eastern International Dog Derby for the fifth time.

While trading was again slow on the Stock Exchange yesterday, the market displayed increasing firmness with little of the nervousness of the day before. The moderate advances were attributed to reports of a more hopeful attitude toward foreign economic problems.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 24 (AP) -- The baby who may be Chauncey Guilford Smith had been cared for in a suburb here at the home of Mrs. Howard Amerine, a friend of Mrs. Smith, who said that Mrs. Smith left the child with her when she went to Cleveland on Monday, intending to return today.

A quarterly periodical to be called The Historical Magazine of the Protestant Episcopal Church will appear next month. It will be published under the auspices of the Church Historical Society, which has headquarters at Philadelphia.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 24 (AP) -- The City Commission adopted Newark's 1932 municipal budget of $21,729,888 at a public hearing today. This is a drop of 11 points in the tax rate, which will be $3.87.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 24 -- When the Republican State Committee meets here on Friday it will have before it for action a recommendation that the New Jersey delegation to the national convention be pledged both to the renomination of President Hoover and to the inclusion in the national platform of a plank calling for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor, his wife and their 12-year-old son were found yesterday morning in a semi-conscious condition in their home, 35 Seventy-eighth Street, Brooklyn, as the result of gas fumes from a heater in the cellar. They were revived after three tanks of oxygen had been used by a police emergency squad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Secretary Mills announced today an issue of $100,000,000 in Treasury bills next Monday to retire short - term bills maturing March 2. Bids on these 91-day bills will be received at Federal Reserve banks and branches up to 2 P. M. on the day of issue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The defense of short selling on the New York Stock Exchange before the House Judiciary subcommittee yesterday by Richard Whitney, president of the Exchange, apparently has not checked the movement in Senatorial circles for an investigation and regulation of the stock market.

The most interesting development of the day in money came after the close of the market when the Reserve Bank announced that the rediscount rate had been cut to 3 per cent, superseding the 3 1/2 which had been running since Oct. 16 last. The change, unexpected at this time, proved the only diversion of an otherwise quiet market in which quotations in all sections remained steady.

The five-story apartment house at 449 West Nineteenth Street has been sold by Amy F. and Margaret Bishop to the Chelsea-Moore Corporation. The building is on a lot 25 by 92 feet and by its purchase the Chelsea-Moore Corporation now controls a plot 100 by 92 feet at this point.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The action of Japan in proceeding to lay down four new 8,500-ton cruisers of the light or six-inch-gun type is not construed by Admiral William V. Pratt, Chief of Naval Operations, as a violation of the one-year naval construction holiday entered into Nov. 1, 1931, by the United States, Great Britain, France, Italy and Japan.

New York with a seacoast line three miles less than that of New Jersey has several salt air and seabathing State parks for the recreation of the people. One of these, Jones Beach, which for the whiteness, firmness and extent of its selfbeaten sand has few equals anywhere, is visited by thousands of holiday makers every Summer day.a

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 25 (Canadian Press). -- Government officials hero look forward to an increase in French purchases of Canadian wheat as a result of the rise in the proportion of foreign wheat allowed in the flour in France.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Japan is sending five divisions as reinforcements to Shanghai, which will bring her forces in that area to about 100,000 men, according to authoritative information here today.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday are again below those of the preceding week as well as of the corresponding week last year, according to Dun's Review. The total for twenty-two leading cities in the last week was $4,015,018,000, or 40 per cent less than a year ago.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Holding that a boycott of Japan would have been effective in preventing bloodshed in China, Edward A. Filene of Boston, advocated immediate adherence by the United States to such a wove by the League of Nations in an address today before the Southeastern Conference of International Relations Clubs at Rollins College.

Many luncheons and theatre parties for juniors will be given today in connection with the first performance of "Pinocchio" this afternoon at the Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, by the Junior League Players. "Pinocchio," the second offering this season in the series of children's plays, will be staged in the Great Hall of the clubhouse and will be repeated tomorrow morning and in the afternoon.

MONCURE, N.C., Feb. 25 -- A headon collision between two New York automobiles on a curve one mile north of here this morning resulted in the death of Mrs. Joseph Hardy, 52, of 375 Park Avenue, New York City.

Under an agreement made by the American Tobacco Company with a committee representing the minority stockholders of the American Cigar Company, which will be submitted to stockholders of the latter company for ratification at a special meeting on March 15, the American Cigar Company will sell or lease to American Tobacco all its assets except cash, investments and notes receivable, which are carried at a book value of $6,630,000, it was announced yesterday.

The directors of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation approved yesterday a plan to reduce the number of common shares by two-thirds. The stockholders will vote on the proposal at the annual meeting on April 12. The preliminary statement for 1931, issued after the meeting of directors, showed earnings of 51 cents a share on the common stock, against 60 cents in 1930.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Norris anti-injunction bill was attacked by Senator Hebert of Rhode Island during Senate debate today, on the ground that yellow-dog contracts, which it would outlaw, have been held constitutional.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25 -- More than a score of stars from the operatic, musical comedy, screen and vaudeville stages, augmented by volunteers from the social colony, took part in the annual entertainment given tonight at the Paramount Theatre for the benefit of the underprivileged children's fund of the Kiwanis Club.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Creation of a State Bridge Authority to regulate all toll bridges outside the metropolitan area is provided in a bill introduced today by Senator Hewitt, chairman of the Finance Committee.

Except for continued unsettlement in the silk and rubber markets, which resulted in new low prices, there was a moderately higher level for most other commodities. Coffee, sugar, cocoa, hides, flour, cotton and lard all moved higher. Steadiness prevailed in other lines.

With eight sessions on various phases of safety work, attended by about 2,000 persons yesterday, the third annual Greater New York Safety Conference closed its two-day meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania with a total attendance of 4,600.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Mrs. William F. Howe of Boston, who gained the national title early this month, and three other seeded players advanced into the semi-final round in the women's fourth annual invitation squash racquets tournament at the Racquet and Swimming Club today.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Governor Roosevelt has commuted to life imprisonment the death sentences imposed on four New York City murderers now at Sing Sing.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- British Government funds advanced further on the Stock Exchange today, the War Loan rising to u100 7-16. Sterling was easier after an early rise, the New York rate closing at $3.48 1/8.

The world depression has slowed down Russia's Five-Year Plan, but while it may not attain all its objectives it will succeed in gaining a considerable number of them, Walter Arnold Rukeyser, who filled two contracts as a consulting engineer in Russia, declares in his book, "Working for the Soviets: An American Engineer in Russia," published today by Covici, Friede.

White Plains, N.Y. The city of White Plains, N.Y., awarded yesterday a new issue of $2,334,000 of 6 per cent bonds, due in two years and callable after one year, to the Bowery Savings Bank. The price paid was par.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Secretary Stimson today awaited foreign reaction to his declaration of Far Eastern policy as set forth in his letter to Senator Borah, confident that the world would approve the American stand. The Congressional reaction continued favorable, no objection being raised.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Akron was defended before the House Naval Committee today of charges that the airship was unsafe.

When Benedick said he would die a bachelor, he didn't think he would live to be married. So when the Massachusetts Roosevelt-for-President League opened for business last June, it didn't think that Governor SMITH would be a candidate again. It publicly declared at the time that should he be, it would support him.

The Treasury Department's monthly report of the general stocks of all kinds of money in the United States as of Feb. 1 shows the following principal changes during January. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted, gold released from earmark is added:

Bond prices continued irregular on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with domestic corporation issues generally showing better strength than foreign loans. United States Government bonds, as a group, extended their advance, with gains for the day of 1-32 to 9-32 point, with the fourth Liberty 4 1/4s closing above par for the first time this year and the Treasury 4 1/4s above 103.

Not only many prominent New Yorkers, but also well-known persons from other cities, have booked passage on the Britannic, which will sail at midnight tonight for a sixteen-day Caribbean cruise sponsored by the Frontier Nursing Service.

More than 300 bankers of New York State, representing the five geographical groups of the Savings Banks Association of New York, went on record yesterday as in favor of legislation that would enable them to establish a savings bank clearing house or central bank for the aid of weaker banks in emergencies.

None of the 1932 crop of murder plays has turned out to be quite so genial and shrewd as "Riddle Me This!" which was acted at the John Golden last evening. Daniel N. Rubln, who once wrote a good drama entitled "Devils," has put this detective play together as though he enjoyed using his wits and intelligence.

PARIS, Feb. 25 -- There was general improvement on the Bourse today, with orders considerably more numerous. Reopening of the Berlin Boerse and Wall Street's steadiness contributed to the firmness, but buying by private investors was the principal factor in the day's advance.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 25 -- "The solution for minimizing football fatalities and injuries lies in better medical supervision, under the control of a health department," said Dr. Mal Stevens, Yale football coach and president of the American Football Coaches Association, today in a communication to The Yale Daily News.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Robert Isham Randolph, the chief of Chicago's secret six, told a House committee today he always drove "with the doors of my car locked and my gun in a position to shoot."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Gus Novotny of La Grange, Ill, made a brilliant effort to hold off T. Philip Perkins of New York, defending champion, in the third round of the Dixie amateur golf championship over the Miami Country Club course today, losing by 2 up and 1 to play.

The proposal at Albany to levy a 10 per cent tax on tickets for public amusements to raise the $19,000,000 fund required for the State's unemployment relief brought immediate and vigorous opposition from all branches of the legitimate theatre yesterday.
Housing deals provided the bulk of realty trading in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday. Several taxpayer structures also changed hands.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A quotation from the annual report of the Rev. Dr. Millard L. Robinson, general secretary of toe Bible Society, in THE TIMES, may mislead readers concerning the vital question of the Bible in the public schools of New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- State Department officials did not take seriously today a statement from Dr. Pedro Jose Zepeda that General Sandino was prepared to attack Managua.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit during the week ended Feb. 24, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,775,000,000, a decrease of $20,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $862,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

WOOSTER, Ohio, Feb. 25 -- Ernes L. Jahncke, Assistant Secretary o the Kavy, took to Ohio tonight the interparty warfare over credit for economic legislation and declared in an address before the Young Men's Republican Club of Wayne County that entire credit for initiating all the plans for the rehabilitation of industry must go to President Hoover.

GENEVA, Feb. 25 -- Secretary of State Stimson's letter to Senator Borah on the Far Eastern policy of the United States bad a stimulating effect in League of Nations quarters. It was generally described as a most important development.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Thirty-one undergraduates of Princeton University and four alumni were elected to membership in the Phi Beta Kappa Society at the meeting of the Princeton Chapter here today. Twenty-five of the undergraduates were seniors and six were juniors.

Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee, went to Cincinnati yesterday seeking ideas for improving the New York City Government and bent, It was believed, on attacking Tammany Hall as an influence in national politics.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Wise Anne, owned by W.C. Weant, and a 2-yearold daughter of Wise Counsellor and Zillah, was the winner of the Nursery Stakes No. 2, exclusively for fillies, which was the feature at Hialeah Park here today. It was Wise Anne's fourth start and her third consecutive victory, stamping her as one of the best fillies shown at the meeting. In her debut she ran second.

Abolition of the present method of naming postmasters under a "virtual spoils system" was urged upon President Hoover yesterday in the fiftieth annual report of the Council of the National Civil Service Reform League, submitted at the league's annual meeting in the City Club, 55 West, Forty-fourth Street.

BOSTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The family of Elizabeth B. Cook, 20-year-old heiress of Brookline and Almond, N. Y., who died mysteriously in the Mediterranean on Feb. 7. today expressed the conviction that she died of pneumonia.

The James Monroe High School basketball team strengthened its hold on first place in the Bronx division P.S.A.L. race, by defeating Morris High, 34 to 19, in the Monroe gymnasium yesterday for its fifth victory in as many league contests.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Edgar Wallace, famous novelist and playwright, was buried today. After a service in the church at Little Marlow conducted by the vicar, the Rev. G. Mildred, he was laid at rest in the village churchyard.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Julia Peterkin, the novelist, received an ovation tonight when she appeared in the Town Theatre as Hedda Gabler in Ibsen's play.

An exhibition of recent work in several mediums by Raphael Soyer is current at L'Elan Galleries, 50 East Fifty-second Street. On the main floor are grouped a few oils, while on the floor above one finds watercolors and drawings. Of particular interest are the drawings, notably those done in pen-and-ink.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Closing fast in the stretch, A. Pelleteri's Fiddler won the six-furlong substitute race, which was the best offering on the Fair Grounds card today.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 25 -- The driver, passenger and owner of an automobile that was in collision early this morning with a Nassau County police car at Hempstead Turnpike and Holland Avenue, Elmont, L.I., killing Patrolmen Alvln Borgwardt and Milton E. Verity of the Valley Stream Precinct, were arrested five hours after the accident by New York City and Nassau police.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Secretary of State Stimson's letter to Senator Borah on the Far Eastern situation will figure prominently in the House of Commons Monday night when the Labor Opposition will again raise the question of the Sino-Japanese clash and reiterate their protests against Japanese aggression and violation of treaties.

The 1932 American Davis Cup campaign, which is expected to constitute the most dangerous challenge yet offered by the United States for the reclamation of the trophy since it was lost to France in 1927, will be directed by Bernon S. Prentice of New York.

Sammy Fuller, Boston lightweight, and Ray Miller of Chicago will clash in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Both boxers are eager for an opportunity to clash with Tony Canzoneri, world's champion.

The output of electricity by the power and light utilities of the United States has declined to a new low record for the current business depression, allowing for seasonal fluctuations. The seasonally adjusted daily average for the week ended Feb. 20 is 218,300,000 kilowatt-hours, as against 221,200,000 kilowatt-hours for the preceding week and 237,400,000 kilowatt-hours for the corresponding week last year.

A black leather valise, containing more than $13,000 worth of jewelry which its owner had given up as lost since its disappearance on Feb. 17, was found yesterday morning by an unemployed farmhand as he trudged wearily along the Albany Road near Hartsdale.

With the termination on March 1 of the ten-year voting trust agreement for common stock of Julius Kayser Co., the trust certificates will be exchanged for common shares, which will be listed on the Stock Exchange in place of the trust certificates.

With a relatively firm market in Liverpool and a continued trade demand here, prices of cotton advanced 7 to 10 points at the opening yesterday of the Cotton Exchange here. Partial reactions followed under realizing and Southern selling, but the offerings were comparatively light and prices firmed again in the late trading, as demand did not slacken.

BERLIN, Feb. 25 -- Chancellor Bruening smote his political adversaries today in a fashion which not only won him rousing plaudits from the major parties in the Reichstag but also brought the issues in the coining Presidential election into clear relief.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP). -- One railroad today objected to being included in any consolidation scheme and the Detroit Board of Commerce asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to arrange for the Baltimore Ohio to enter Detroit over its own rails.

Elected yesterday as president of the Real Estate Board of New York, Anton L. Trunk made an address to the board of governors in which he urged a "concerted revolt of the electorate of New York City against mounting municipal extravagance" and suggested the formation of a city-wide civic committee that would seek to pledge all candidates to a platform of drastic economy.
Dr. Gerhart Hauptmann, Germany's most distinguished man of letters, arrived in New York last night aboard the Europa of the North German Lloyd Line.

Lord Wakefield, who is having a new speed, boat, Miss England III, built with the aim of making 130 miles an hour, has challenged for the British International Trophy, otherwise known as the Harmsworth Trophy. Information, to that effect was received yesterday from London.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 26 -- The Chinese forces at 2 o'clock this morning [Friday] claimed a victory over the Japanese near Miaoshin, where a four-hour artillery battle was followed by a Chinese infantry charge which drove the Japanese back at Hsiaotsangmiao.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- More than 400 exhibits, including such varied subjects as a school motor bus, lead pencils and moving pictures of the life of George Washington, were viewed at the Washington Auditorium this week by more than 15,000 persons, including 8,000 delegates to the annual convention of the National Education Association.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 25 -- Judge G. H. Howard of Atlanta, who qualified for the primary with the announcement that he would cast the support given to him to Speaker Garner, stated today that "under no circumstances or conditions" would he withdraw from the race.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 25 -- Extensive works to insure permanent stability of all Vatican buildings will be begun in April and will be carried through with the greatest possible dispatch to remove the threat of collapse of other sections of the palaces.

More than 5,000 civic leaders from all parts of the country have signed petitions modeled on the one launched by President A. Lawrence Lowell of Harvard calling for the concurrence of the United States in a world boycott of Japan, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the American Committee on the Far East Crisis at the Hotel Commodore.

The downward trend in brokers' loans was resumed this week with a drop of $10,000,000 reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank for the week ended on Wednesday. Last week loans advanced $13,000,000, terminating a sequence of twenty-three reductions.

Yesterday's reduction of the Reserve Bank rate from 3 1/2 per cent to 3 is the first change since the rate rose successively from 1 1/2 to 2 1/2 on Oct. 8, and from 2 1/2 to 3 1/2 on Oct. 15. That fortnight has been marked by $207,000,000 gold withdrawals, nearly all for Europe, and by $124,700,000 "ear-markings."

Among the passengers sailing for Europe tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa are Silas H. Strawn, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and also of the International Chamber of Commerce. Serge Rachmaninoff, pianist; the Grand Duchess Marie of Russia; the Right Rev. James de Wolf Perry, presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church in the United States, and Caroline Thomas, American violinist and formerly soloist with the St. Louis Symphony.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The swan song of British free trade was sung in the House of Commons tonight when it passed, by a vote of 442 to 62, the bill imposing a 10 per cent duty on all imports into Great Britain, with certain notable exceptions.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Prices of wheat averaged lower today on the Board of Trade here, but at no time were they more than 3/4 cent below yesterday's final quotations. Commission-house support was good on the break, and while pressure increased around 62 cents a bushel for the May, the close was at about the best figures at net losses of 1/8 to 3/8 cent.

PRINCETON, N.J., Friday, Feb. 26 -- Herbert Orrin Crisler, present director of athletics at the University of Minnesota, has signed a contract to become head football coach at Princeton University, according to word received early this morning by Thurston J. Davies, supervisor of sports.

Assured that ample free gold to meet foreign withdrawals would be made available by the Glass-Steagall bill, the Federal Reserve authorities resumed yesterday aggressive efforts to combat deflation by reducing the rediscount rate of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York from 3 1/2 per cent to 3 per cent.
BRUNSWICK, Germany, Feb. 25 -- Adolf Hitler became a German citizen today through his appointment to the post of Attache at the Berlin Legation of the State of Brunswick.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- "Baby bonds," to be issued in the campaign to check hoarding, will bear interest at 2 per cent, Secretary Mills today notified Colonel Frank Knox, chairman of the Citizens Reconstruction Corporation. Mr. Mills plans to issue the bonds about March 7.

Marine Park in Brooklyn will be, when completed, the largest recreation centre in the world with a capacity of about 50,000 players in various athletic sports and accommodations for more than 350,000 spectators, according to the estimates contained in a contract report which Charles Downing Lay, architect, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Bolivia threatened today to withdraw from the discussions of the Chaco non-aggression pact unless Paraguay retracted her demands for Bolivian, withdrawal from most of the Chaco area.

Floyd L. Carlisle was elected chairman of the board of trustees of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York at the organization meeting of trustees yesterday. He is the first man to hold this office since 1914, as the title lapsed with the resignation of the late Harrison E. Gawtry in that year.

ROME, Feb. 25 -- Secretary of State Stimson's letter to Senator Borah on the Far East issues brought many favorable comments in official circles. All comments stressed the importance of the letter if considered as the possible forerunner of a stronger American policy in the Far East.
LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The check to Japan's army at Shanghai, even if it turns out to be merely temporary, has been emphatic enough to create something like a military sensation. Preconceived notions about the relative fighting merits of the Japanese and the Chinese soldier are upset.

Net income of the New York Steam Corporation, a subsidiary of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York, was $2,019,581 in 1931, equal, after preferred dividends, to $3.83 a share earned on 360,000 common shares, comparing with $1,703,471, or $2.95 a share on the same number of shares, in 1930.
BERLIN, Feb. 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 23 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

TOKYO, Feb. 25 -- Since Ambassador Katsuji Debuchi's interview with Japanese correspondents in the United States, the emphatic messages sent by correspondents from New York have shocked, newspaper readers into realizing how strongly American opinion is swinging against Japan.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: The signs of the times give indicaion that the nominee of the Democratic party will be the next President of the United States. The selection of the right man as the Democratic leader is, therefore, of vital importance to every citizen.

Fifty-five physicians of Brooklyn and Queens were charged with violating the conditions of the medicinal whisky prescription permits in informations filed yesterday with the clerk of the United States District Court in Brooklyn. It was said the physicians would be notified to appear in court within a few days to plead to the charges.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Washington Stemmler Jr. of 37 East Sixty-fourth Street gave a dinner last night for Miss Elizabeth Van Rensselaer Voislawski and Joseph Van Beuren Wittman, whose engagement has been announced.

BERLIN, Feb. 25 -- On excellent authority it can be stated that Germany's entire commercial debt will be paid in full, no matter what pressure may be brought to divert the available funds to other purposes.

During the month of January, 92 per cent of the prohibition cases in the Federal courts terminated in convictions. Director WOODCOCK calls this "an unprecedented figure" and offers his congratulations to "every one in the bureau."

New York's two members of President Hoover's Cabinet, Secretary of State Henry L. Stimson and Secretary of the Treasury Ogden L. Mills, apparently will not attend the Republican National Convention as delegates-at-large.

A development of first importance in the case against Joseph A Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, the nature of which is undisclosed, is expected this morning when the trial convenes again before Judge George L. Donnellan and a jury in General Sessions.

Funds totaling approximately $250,000 were announced yesterday at the final report luncheon of the Musicians Emergency Aid at the St. Regis Hotel. Dr. Walter Damrosch, chairman of the organization, announced that final figures for the drive were not available, but that the estimate included funds from the sale of some of the tickets for the benefit to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House on March 6.
HAVANA, Feb. 25 (AP) -- F.A. Carreaud's The Spaniard, a recent arrival from Miami, was an easy winner of the fourth race, a six-furlong sprint, which topped the card at Oriental Park today.

Opposition to any extension of the so-called public-enemy law, as now drawn, beyond its present limit of March 1 of this year was expressed yesterday in the third report of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York committee on criminal courts, law and procedure.

The last concert in the first series for children and young people by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society will be held tomorrow morning at Carnegie Hall, and the children who have turned in the best notebooks for the season will receive prizes. Ernest Schelling conducts these concerts.

BERLIN, Feb. 25 -- After having been closed for almost five months, the Berlin Boerse reopened its doors today for two hours of trading which was accompanied by all the outward excitement of a big day.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- The broad rule laid down by Governor Roosevelt in ousting Sheriff Thomas M. Fariey that a public official should at all times be in a position to establish his personal as well as public probity will be applied by the Governor in his selection of Parley's successor.

Somewhat resentful at Governor Roosevelt for removing Thomas M. Farley, leader of the Fourteenth Assembly District, from the office of Sheriff, Tammany prepared yesterday to make the best of what its leaders regarded as a bad situation by trying to pick a member of their organization whom the Governor would appoint to fill the vacancy.

The program of Antoni Sala, Spanish 'cellist, who gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, began with an early Brahms sonata and included Saint-Saens concerto in A minor, a Porpora sonata in four movements, Turin's "Farruca" and Albeniz's "Malaguena."

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey for 1931 shows net income of $30,540,752 after taxes, charges, depreciation and underlying dividends, equal, after dividends on the preferred stocks, to $3 85 a share earned on 5,503,193 no-par common shares outstanding at the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Charges that he had declined to appear before a House committee considering two governmental reorganization bills were countered tonight by Secretary Hurley with an assertion he would be glad to testify and otherwise cooperate.

Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel in the Bronx reserved decision yesterday in the injunction suit brought by Nathaniel Doragoff, a motion-picture machine operator, against Samuel Kaplan as president of the Motion Picture Machine Operators' Union of Greater New York, Local 306, of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Hands of the United States and Canada.

A National Theatre Conference, which will serve professional, semi-professional and amateur theatres, including university groups, was formed at the drama conference held last week under the auspices of the University of Iowa at Iowa City.

BERLIN, Feb. 25 -- A beer strike had achieved tonight what no Presidential decree or governmental proclamation of political truce had been able to accomplish, when after twenty hours of "drought" the political interest of the population of Berlin was virtually dried up.

A noticeable increase in Manhattan business space leasing marked brokers' reports yesterday, following a period of inactivity in this type of trading, due in some measure to the interruption of two holidays.

Two subsidiaries have been formed to take over the manufacturing business of the Phelps Dodge Corporation in an internal reorganization of the company. They are the National Electric Products Corporation, which will have offices in Pittsburgh, and the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation, with offices in this city.

The entire voting stock of the Federal Water Service Corporation and sundry other securities were sold at auction yesterday by Adrian H. Muller Son, and all were acquired by or on behalf of banking institutions which had held the same securities as collateral against defaulted loans of the Tri-Utilities Corporation and certain of its subsidiaries.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 25 -- The first reaction in informed circles here to Secretary Stimson's letter to Senator Borah is a belief that Mr. Stimson is preparing the way for intervention in China by the United States. It is also thought the letter will have an important effect on decisions taken by the League of Nations.

MUKDEN, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Several thousand Soviet Russian soldiers are moving down toward the Manchurian frontier, presumably because of Moscow's apprehension over Japanese troop movements in Northeastern Manchuria, the Rengo (Japanese) News Agency reported from Harbin today.

The first thirteen railroads to report earnings for January showed net operating incomes of $3,405,000, against $5,946,000 in January, 1931, a drop of 42.7 per cent, and against $9,298,000 in January, 1930, a fall of 63.3 per cent. In December their net incomes amounted to $7,058,000, against $9,683,000 in December, 1930, a decline of 27.1 per cent.

IT was all right for Sam Miles to lead the conversation on Sir Malcolm Campbell's little turn of speed on the Daytona Beach sands because Sam is something important in the auto industry, but when he branched off from that and took up the running of the mile on foot -- from Slade, 1877, down to Venzke, 1932 -- it was time to examine his credentials. Luckily he had a friend to identify him.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 26 -- The Cabinet approved an extraordinary appropriation of 22,000,000 yen (at present $7,040,000) today to meet additional military expenses in connection with the Japanese expedition to Shanghai.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25 -- An order from Mayor Edward H. Armstrong of Daytona Beach late today prevented Sir Malcolm Campbell from driving his Blue Bird racing car down a rain-drenched beach in an attack on his yesterday's record of 253.968 miles an hour.

The annual St. Valentine s Kettledrum in aid of the Samaritan Home for the Aged will be held today in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The attractions arranged principally for children will include a Punch and Judy show, movies, a grab bag, and the sale of toys and candy.

Villa Lewaro, palatial home at Irvington-on-Hudson of the late Mme. C.J. Walker, originator of an anti-kink hair tonic for Negroes, has been purchased by the Companions of the Forest of America, a national non-sectarian fraternal organization, and will be turned into a haven for ''tired mothers and their dependents."

Navigation interests operating on the Hudson River protested against the severity of rules drafted by the army engineers as a means of protecting workmen and apparatus engaged in the dredging and maintenance of the deep-water canal of the upper river at a hearing yesterday warning before Colonel Gustave R. Lukesh at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street.

Harry F. Wolf, national amateur titleholder from the New York A.C., was eliminated from the world's open squash tennis championship at the Hotel Shelton last night, leaving the field in the possession of the professionals.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 25 -- Though the text of Secretary Stimson's letter to Senator Borah has not yet been received by the Japanese Legation here, official reaction in Japanese circles is that the document probably will merely serve to prolong the struggle.

The city of Newark received no bid yesterday for its Issue of $5,000,000 long-term bonds from the single New York banking group which for several days had been considering making ing a tender. Today the group will meet at the offices of the Bankers Trust Company and "probably decide once and for all" whether it will buy the bonds.

Acute weakness in special issues was blamed by Wall Street for yesterday's reactionary tendencies on the Stock Exchange. Auburn fell 13 points from its opening price and then closed with a net loss of 7 points. The general list moved sedately and the average of the losses was small.
MUKDEN, Feb. 25 -- Tension along the Siberian border was heightened today by reports that 50,000 Soviet soldiers had been shifted from Nikolevsk to the Manchurian frontier.
CANBERRA, Feb. 25 -- A new tariff schedule was tabled in the Commonwealth Parliament today by which the government announced it would "heartily cooperate in promoting reciprocal trade in the empire."

The Boston Bruins, forced to trail from the very first period of their National Hockey League game with the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night, uncovered a desperate rally in the closing minutes of the third period and brought about a tie which an extra ten-minute period failed to dissolve.

Three institutions in Harlem shan 565,000 under the will of William T Koch, son of the founder of H.C Koch Co.. one of Harlem's first department stores, which was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mr. Koch, who retired front business two years ago, died on Feb. 19 at the Harbor Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Plans to maintain the business of American ships in the international trade while that trade is reduced by world conditions were considered by officials of the Shipping Board and representatives of American steamship lines and shipbuilders at a conference in the office of Chairman T.V. O'Connor today.

Opposing any curtailment in vocational education as an economy move, Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, in a letter yesterday to officials of the city's school system, urged that all existing industrial, technical, continuation and evening schools be operated to capacity.

Faster than the most devastating hurricane Sir MALCOLM CAMPBELL sweeps over the sands of Daytona Beach in his Blue Bird and establishes a new world's record of 253.968 miles an hour. A measured mile is covered in less than a quarter of a minute.

TOKYO, Feb. 25 -- Informed of Secretary of State Stimson's letter to Senator Borah only by the press versions, Japanese officials this afternoon confined their comment to denials that any sort of barter had been made at the Washington arms conference of 1921-22 as between the naval limitation agreements and the Nine-Power Pacific treaty.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date and the ratio of reserve to be at the highest. The reserve ratio at the New York Bank also reached a new high point for the year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The applications of the Knickerbocker Broadcasting Company, operating station WMCA, and of the city of New York, operating WNYC, for license renewals and sharing time on 570 kilocycles, were reported favorably to the Radio Board today by Ellis A. Yost, chief examiner.

Play in the Class B national squash tennis championship tournament started last night with an entry of sixty-four on the Columbia University Club courts and seeded stars triumphed in decisive fashion save one.

While on his way to attend the daily line-up of criminals in Police Headquarters yesterday forenoon, Detective John McGovern of the Hamilton Avenue Station. Brooklyn, saw two men on a street car who were wanted for homicide in the killing of an ex-convict last July 12.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb 25 -- The court contest among the children of Thomas A. Edison over the distribution of his $12,000,000 estate, which was threatened after his will was filed last October, has been abandoned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Speaker Garner today joined other members of his party in advocating a general manufacturers' sales tax and practically announced that it would be the basic part of the new revenue bill which, he predicted, will be presented to the House for consideration within ten days.

Suit for $300,000 damages, an accounting and receivership was filed yesterday in Supreme Court by Alien P. Cunningham, a stockholder, against the Students' Travel Club, Inc., of 665 Fifth Avenue, and five of its directors and former directors.

A speeding cedan, zigzagging down West End Avenue shortly after midnight, struck and seriously injured a woman pedestrain, compelled a motorcycle patrolman to swerve from the roadway to the sidewalk where i his machine was wrecked and ended its erratic tour by colliding head-on with another sedan.

The services of James C. Colgate to Colgate University, from his days as a freshman there to his present post as president of the board of trustees, were extolled by prominent educators and other persons at a testimonial dinner last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Mayor Walker was asked yesterday to direct criminal action against ten city employes on the ground that they had benefited from the acquisition of land for public purposes by the city.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "Wasteful and Inefficient" prompts me to express some thoughts which have been preying on my mind for some time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- After hearing a message from President Hoover stating that "the very first obligation upon the national resources is the undiminished financial support of the public schools," the Department of Superintendence of the National Education Association closed its sixty-second annual convention here today.

The Block Community Organization, said to be the largest relief campaign ever devised in this city, will probably be completed in about a month when at least 10,000 blocks will be canvassed under the direction of 100,000 "Block-Aiders," it was announced yesterday by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the organization, which is being sponsored by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.
GENEVA, Feb. 25 -- Everybody had a reason to be satisfied with this first day of real work toward disarmament.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted:

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 26 -- Japanese authorities said two Japanese airplanes bombed the Chinese airdrome at Hangchow, 100 miles southwest of Shanghai, today and shot down two Chinese planes in an air battle.

On leaving the apparently misnamed city of Concord for Washington, Senator MOSES of New Hampshire declared that in Congress "partisan wrangling looms in the offing." As if overcome with melancholy by the thought, he added that he foresaw "attempts to gain partisan advantage."

Bear Admiral H.A. Wiley, U.S. N., retired, addressing the Propeller Club yesterday at 56 Broad Street, cited the record of Japan in her dealings with China as an argument in support of his plea for a strong nationalist attitude on the part of the government.

Coach Richard J. Glendon made several transfers yesterday in the Columbia varsity and junior varsity crews and it is believed that more changes will be brought about before the Lions open their season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- After hearing a message from President Hoover stating that "the very first obligation upon the national resources is the undiminished financial support of the public schools," the Department of Superintendence of the National Education Association closed its sixty-second annual convention here today.

Bear Admiral H.A. Wiley, U.S. N., retired, addressing the Propeller Club yesterday at 56 Broad Street, cited the record of Japan in her dealings with China as an argument in support of his plea for a strong nationalist attitude on the part of the government.

Coach Richard J. Glendon made several transfers yesterday in the Columbia varsity and junior varsity crews and it is believed that more changes will be brought about before the Lions open their season.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Mrs. Jessie E. Stone of 10 Centre Avenue, mother of Dr. Harold A. Stone, New Rochelle, dentist, died today. Mrs. Stone, widow of Harry E. Stone, was horn sixty-five years ago in England, a daughter of the late Edwin and Elizabeth (Winn) Gay.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Citing the "top-heavy" 1932 Princeton varsity football schedule as a "first-class example of the need for intelligent direction in Princeton athletics," William W. Roper, former head football coach, advocated the creation of the office of dean of athletics at Princeton in a letter published in the current Alumni Weekly.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 25 -- Miss Sarah Palfrey of Boston, the defending champion, and Miss Betty Nuthall of England, gained the final round of women's singles in the Bermuda tennis championships today.

Always a prominent factor in the race for the team championship of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A., Harvard again will bring a strong squad to New York on March 5 for the eleventh annual championship meet to be held on the new six-lap track of the 258th Field Artillery Armory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- More than 25,000 Federal taxpayers, individual and corporate, were notified today by the Treasury Department that their tax payments for 1930 showed deficiencies and that remittances must be made within sixty days or appeal taken to the Board of Tax Appeals.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Musterng its greatest show of strength, thus far, the wet "bloc" of the House today obtained 110 signatures on a petition to force a direct vote on the liquor question.

Consecrated and unselfish leadership is required as a means of bringing justice, brotherhood and peace into the world, according to the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, who gave the first of a series of Lenten addresses over radio Station WABC yesterday afternoon.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 26 -- Chinese who, since November, have looked toward America more hopefully than toward Geneva were elated by Secretary Stimson's statement of policy to Senator Borah, some even envisaging a possibility that tHe United States might take up arms and eject Japan unless Tokyo quickly modifies her position at Shanghai.

The student council of Hunter College elected a new editor-in-chief and a new associate editor to replace the executives of The Hunter Bulletin, the college's weekly newspaper, who resigned two weeks ago as a protest against a decision regarding The Bulletin's advertising policy issued by Dr. James M. Kieran, president of the college.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 25 -- American officials tried to start a movement of United States nationals out of the Astor House, one of Shanghai's best-known hotels, which faces Soochow Creek and is in the zone of dangers, Dut most of the hotel residents decided to stay where they were.

"Pure Ignorance, Madam." Because Secretary STIMSON declared all the treaties of the Washington Conference to be related to each other, a spokesman for the Japanese Foreign Office accuses him of "ignorance of the history of the Washington Conference."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The controversy over the New York Legislature's right to set up new Congressional districts by concurrent resolution was laid before the Federal Supreme Court today in a petition seeking a review of the decision in which the New York State Supreme Court held the resolution method invalid.

Stocks moved sluggishly yesterday in dull trading on the New York Curb Exchange, and at the end most of the more active issues were unchanged from the preceding day's close. Domestic bonds were irregular while foreign issues were quiet, but fairly steady as to quotations.

Two New York robberies, one In which $90,000 in jewelry was taken, were chalked up yesterday by the police against Joe Filkowski, Cleveland fugitive arrested Wednesday In front of the Somerset Hotel in West Forty-seventh Street.

CLEARWATER Fla., Feb. 25 -- A new face at third base in Brooklyn this year already has become a possibility with the training season only four days old and without any serious infield practice having been held. Bobby Reis of Astoria, who first appeared in a Robin uniform three years ago at the age of 18, is making the bid for Wally Gilbert's post.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 25 -- Speaker Garner will be in the Nebraska Presidential primary in April despite a telegraphic request today from Representative Sam Rayburn, of Texas, that the Speaker's name not be entered in the primary campaign. The decision was reached today by the executive committee of the Nebraska Garner-for-President Club and announced by Chairman Grenville P. North of the organization.

PARIS, Feb. 25 -- While the Paris press on the whole seems either to have missed or ignored the importance of the letter that Secretary of State Stimson wrote yesterday to Senator Borah reaffirming the policy of the "open door" in China, official circles fully realized its weight.

In her recital in Town Hall last night Sadah Suchari, violinist, presented the Cesar Franck sonata, the Chaconne of Bach, Lalo's "Symphonie Espagnole" and a group of short pieces including Ravel, works of de Falla, Dohnanyi and Sarasate.

Awards in architecture, painting, sculpture and craftsmanship were made last night at the members' reception preceding the formal opening of the forty-seventh annual exhibition of the Architectural League of New York in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society Building.

DAIREN, Manchuria, Feb. 26. -- The Japanese detachment under General Tamon has been unable to advance against the Chinese irregulars in the Imienpo district, it is reported, because of Soviet opposition to their use of the rolling stock of the Chinese Eastern Railway.
LONDON, Feb. 26. -- Six of Japan's most respected citizen, statesmen, none of whom holds office in the present government, today cabled to London a strong defense of the Japanese policy in China.

With a view to removing one of the principal objections of the United States Department of Justice to the relationships of the Radio Corporation of America and other leading manufacturers of radio equipment, consideration is being given to the termination on April 30 of the contract between the General Motors Radio Corporation and the Radio Corporation of America under which the former company has manufactured radio receivers since 1929.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26 (AP). -- E. F. Prichard's Weideleen easily won the six-furlong Evangeline Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

In the second edition of "The Origin of Species" Charles Darwin made a single significant concession to the fundamentalists of his day. Paul V. Victorius declares in Part Nine of The Colophon, a book collectors quarterly, issued today.

Charles Tevish, owner of the Saratoga Wet Wash Laundry Company, 1,939 Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn, testified yesterday before Referee Nathan Friedman in the State Building, 80 Centre Street, that he had lost several customers and had been unable to obtain supplies regularly because he had refused to join the Laundry Board of Trade.
A Washington Heights housing deal and leases of entire buildings in other sections of Manhattan comprised realty activity in this borough yesterday.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26. -- Although he failed in his main objective of boosting his world's one-mile record, Sir Malcolm Campbell today bettered three more automobile speed marks, increasing his total of new world's standards to five within three days.

Under a revision of the rules of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday, lenders of stocks will receive fifteen minutes additional time in which to recall their loans. The change is technical, but carries special significance at this time, when short selling and the attendant stock-borrowing process are the subject of controversy.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26. -- Temple lost its first home game of the basketball season tonight when Carnegie Tech won a sensational contest. 27 to 22. The Owls had a record of ten victories in a row on the home court, the last defeat here being in the St. John's game of 1931.

The adjusted index of carded cotton cloth production has risen to the highest level since May 3, 1930, the figure for the week ended Feb. 20 being 97.6, as against 95.4 for the preceding week and 83.5 for the corresponding week last year. There are two main reasons for the rise.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Feb. 26. -- Extradition of Maxwell A. Cox from California for prosecution for alleged embezzlement is in the hands of the National Surety Company, according to officials of the trust company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In these days when it is customary to refer with an air of amused tolerance to so-called "reform" movements, the following may be worthy of note in connection with the appointment to the United States Supreme Court of Judge Cardozo -- an appointment unique in the absence of criticism and in the breadth of its approval.

Representation of the United States at the League of Nations Assembly on March 3, called to consider the conflict between China and Japan, was urged yesterday in a statement by the League of Nations Association, as formulated by its board of directors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The output of motor vehicles in the United States in January declined 2,197 units below December, according to figures made public today by the Department of Commerce.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 26. -- A new device which automatically counts the alpha, particles of radium, that travel at the rate of 12,000 miles per second, was described here today before the joint meeting of the American Physical Society and the Optical Society of America, being held at Harvard University.

BERLIN, Felo. 26 (AP). -- Three times in quick succession the Reichstag voted confidence in the Bruening government, or individual Ministers, today. Then it defeated three opposition motions regarding procedure, whereupon the National Socialists called the meeting a "monkey show" and walked out.

A total of 100,431 jobs have been found in eleven days by the United Action for Employment 'Campaign, which is waging "a war against depression," it was announced yesterday at national headquarters at the Biltmore Hotel.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 26. -- Warning the people of the United States that Tammany Hall is "reaching out" to extend its influence to the nation, Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, pleaded in a speech here tonight for country-wide support of his present attack on the New York City administration.

Under the stimulus of a fresh de dine in the price of copper, which brought quotations yesterday to a low a level as they ever have reached, leaders of the industry renewed their efforts to effect an agreement with the Belgian Congo copper interests looking to a more drastic curtailment of production.

A judgment for $14,988.83 against Dudley Field Malone in favor of Otto H. Kahn was entered in the New York County Court yesterday by County Clerk Daniel Finn on the certification of attorneys for Mr. Kahn that Mr. Malone or his attorneys had failed to file an answer on Jan. 4, last, in a suit charging that Mr. Malone had defaulted in payments on a note for $40,000.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Miss Palfrey played close to the best tennis of her career today to defeat Miss Nuthall, England's No. 1 ranking star, to retain the singles title.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Colgate clinched the Triangular League basketball championship tonight, swamping Penn State in a second half scoring drive, 42-31. The victory was the third straight in league play. Syracuse won the league title last year.

A tentative understanding on all points in dispute between the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union and two employers' associations -- "inside" shop manufacturers and the jobbers -- was announced late last night at the Hotel Commodore.
DUBLIN, Feb. 26. -- The Irish Labor party decided today to support Eamon de Valera's proposal to abolish the oath of allegiance to the King now required of members of the Dail.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 26. -- George S. Burgess, vice president and secretary of the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce, condemned today methods of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation formed by President Hoover.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Whether the Middle West Utilities Company will follow the example of other large utility holding companies in reducing its capitalization has became a live topic in La Salle Street. The recent actions of Niagara Hudson Power and Electric Bond and Share in announcing plans for reducing the number of shares of capital stock has brought the matter to the fore again.

Sir Thomas Beecham, noted British conductor and composer, said yesterday that American music is held in high opinion abroad, and in England some critics declare that no English orchestra can equal the best efforts of the American orchestras of the first rank.
Joking With Difficulty. It is hard enough nowadays for even WILL ROGERS to make a good joke, but it seems to be still harder to persuade the objects of his cynical laughter that he is not serious.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26. -- A demand by the Soviet Union that Japan explain alleged troop movements in Manchuria and the reported incitement of "White" Russian activities there became known today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26. -- Seeing no possibility of real disarmament "as long as we have the Versailles treaty," Senator Borah in an interview published in the forthcoming March issue of The Presbyterian Magazine, official organ of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, asserts that treaty "must be rewritten either peaceably or forcibly."

Railroads in the United States established in 1931 a record for fuel economy, according to the American Railway Association. During the year they used an average of 119 pounds of fuel to move 1,000 tons of freight and equipment, including locomotive and tender, one mile.

A slight quickening of the pace of general business from the low levels recently reached and a continued improvement in sentiment were the features of the last week, according to the reviews of the mercantile agencies. Bradstreet's says in part:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The large and steadily growing losses of creditors in bankruptcy cases, which increased from $144,000,000 in 1921 to $911,000,000 in 1931, will be brought to the attention of Congress next week, probably Monday or Tuesday, by President Hoover in a special message.

The total vote at the end of the second week of The Literary Digest's nation-wide prohibition poll, as announced in today's issue of the magazine, shows continued overwhelming sentiment for repeal, but with a slight gain in the dry vote, as compared with last week's count.

CUMBERLAND, Md., Feb. 26. -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, retired, upon completing a two-day lecture engagement here tonight, confirmed reports that he would head another expedition to the South Pole. No time has been set pending arrangement of details.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26. -- Two important social events today were the teas given by Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury in honor of Mr. Stotesbury's eighty-third birthday and by Mrs. Dodge Stoane in celebration of her anniversary. Three hundred invitations were issued to the Stotesbury reception, held in the grounds and patio of El Mirasol, and a large group was invited to Concha Marina, Mrs. Sloane's villa.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26. -- In line with, the belief of John McGraw that a great many games are lost in a season because certain skilled performers frequently fall down on trivial plays, the training activities of the Giants at Wrigley Field today took on a different character.

An opening advance of 2 to 4 points on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday was checked by Southern selling or realizing, and prices later worked lower while offerings became more numerous in the late trading. March contracts, after selling up to 7 cents a pound at the start, closed at 6.91, while October sold from 7.55 cents to 7.44.

Trying Berlin, the song writer, returned to the lower east side for a visit yesterday afternoon and found it changed. He also found out that at least one group of the neighborhood's new generation -- boys under 12 years of age -- prefer the "old tunes" to his latest musical compositions.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 26. -- The Paraguayan Foreign Minister, Dr. Arbo, arrived today and was received by President Justo. He was also entertained by the Argentine Foreign Minister.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Authority to issue and pledge $39,599,750 of general and refunding mortgage bonds as security for a loan of $31,727,750 to be obtained from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, is sought in an application filed by the St. Louis-Southwestern Railway Company with the corporation and the Interstate Commerce Commission Jan. 25.

Exercises to mark the breaking of ground for the erection of a reproduction of Mount Vernon in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, will be held there tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock, it was announced yesterday by William J. Mackin, Brooklyn civic worker and a member of the Washington Bicentennial Commission, which has arranged the celebration.

Reports of a southwesterly hurricane encountered between Cape Race and Sable Island which left the decks and rigging forward coated with ice were given here yesterday by the North German Lloyd liner Europa and the Hamburg American liner Hamburg.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Charges of "racketeering" by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers were denied today before the House Patents Committee.

PRINKIPO, Princes' Island, Turkey, Feb. 26. -- Leon Trotsky, in one of the few interviews he has granted since his exile from Russia, told The Associated Press today he believed Joseph Stalin's rule at Moscow was crumbling and that the Trotsky principles were hastening the process.

The first-place Textile High. School basketball team assured itself of at least a tie for the Manhattan division P.S.A.L. title by defeating George Washington High, 19 to 15, yesterday, in the latter's gymnasium. It was Textile's seventh triumph in eight league contests. The winners led at the half, 12 to 5.

With every appearance of complete harmony, the Republican State Committee at a meeting at the National Republican Club endorsed yesterday the administration of President Hoover and elected eleven delegates at large and eleven alternates at large to the Republican National Convention.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- With all the resources known to science, New York and Washington specialists are uniting in a last desperate effort to save the life of N'Gi, the baby gorilla of the National Zoological Park, who was stricken with pneumonia more than a week ago and is dangerously ill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Retail food prices declined 4 1-3 per cent in fifty-one cities in the month ended Jan. 15 and averaged 17 2-3 per cent lower for the year, the Labor Department announced today.

Edward J. Atwell, secretary to Borough President John A. Lynch and former Sheriff of Richmond County, was arrested in Port Richmond, S.I., last night together with a business associate and was arraigned before a Federal commissioner in Brooklyn for violation of the Volstead act.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 26. -- In high good humor, Andrew Mellon, who resigned as Secretary of the Treasury to become an Ambassador, said today he is not worried over the question as to whether one should wear knee breeches at the Court of St. James's.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- A formula for Philippine independence, under which the United States would retain military and naval privileges in the islands, was agreed upon by the Senate Committee on Territories and Insular Affairs today.

"The Blonde Captive, a motion picture record of Dr. Paul Withington's expedition among little known tribes of Australia, was presented at the Liberty Theatre last night under the sponsorship of William, M. Pizor, who has converted the theatre into a motion picture house.

Eight municipal bond issues and one public utility loan, aggregating $13,072,000, composed this week's new financing. Last week the new financing consisted of the single issue of $25,000,000 of bonds of the Brooklyn Edison Company. A year ago new bonds in the amount of $23,036,000 were placed on the market in the week.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Two bills providing for the establishment of a system of compulsory unemployment insurance were introduced today by Senator Mastick and Assemblyman Steingut, Democrtaic leader in the Lower House. They follow the recommendations made in a report by experts named by Governor Roosevelt and the Executives of six other large Industrial States.

Because they believe that the terms of the proposed contract for independent operation of the new city subway system call for the operator to gamble on the chance of receiving any compensation during the early stages of operation, traction companies, management corporations and others interested in submitting proposals are expected to suggest modifications in the "contract and lease" recently published by the Board of Transportation.

An angry mob chased a landlord through the streets and attacked the police and a city marshal's crew of furniture movers yesterday when twenty families striking for rent reductions were evicted from five buildings on Longfellow Avenue, the Bronx.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 26 (AP). -- A bluff old captain who knows his ship, his men and his Lakes, beamed satisfaction today as he received a gold Congressional medal, awarded for his life-saving exploits in thirty-seven years of seafaring.

OYSTER BAT, L.I., Feb. 26. -- Railroad associates of William Shannon Seaman, oldest conductor on the Oyster Bay branch of the Long Island Railroad, known to thousands of commuters, including Wall Street brokers and industrial leaders, and an intimate of the late President Roosevelt, planned today a gala celebration for the veteran railroad man on Monday.

The Federal Reserve Bank pursue yesterday its credit-expansion policy by following up Thursday's reduction in the rediscount rate here with a slash in the rate at which bankers' bills are bought by the system. The cut in the bill-buying rate was one-eighth of 1 per cent on short bill and one-quarter of 1 per cent on longer maturities.

Oceanographers will be vastly interested in the report from the scientists on board the U.S.S. S-48 and Chewink of the International Scientific Expedition that a new profile of the Bartlett Deep has been established, and that a depth of about 4,000 fathoms, or four miles, has been sounded.

District Attorney Crain acquiesced yesterday to the immediate return to Cleveland of Joseph Filkowski for trial in the slaying of a contractor in a payroll robbery two years ago. Four Cleveland detectives, accompanied by Captain of Detectives McVeigh, told Mr. Crain they were certain that Filkowski would be convicted of first-degree murder.

The forty-seventh annual exhibition of the Architectural League of New York opens to the public today in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, remaining through March 12. The awards were announced in yesterday's news account.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The refusal of Chairman Claude R. Porter of the Interstate Commerce Commission to admit in evidence a statement by Commissioner Joseph B. Eastman relative to holding-company control of railroads featured today's hearing on the four-party plan of Eastern railroad consolidation.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 26. -- The Yale class of '33 tonight held its junior promenade in Woolsey Hall. It was attended by about 600 couples.

VIENNA, Feb. 26. -- Revision of the treaty of Versailles according to President Wilson's "fourteen points" and reorganization of the League of Nations to end all danger of "entanglements," and thus induce the United States to enter it, were proposed today by Count Coudenhove Kalergi, originator of the Pan-European movement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Warm exchanges between spokesmen for the two major parties marked the bipartisan truce today, accompanied by attack and counter-attack in the political sectors of the economic rehabilitation and prohibition fronts.

"Das Rheingold" was presented yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House the third performance in the annual Wagner matinee cycle. It was the only production of the season of this opera that is the prologue to the trilogy of the "Ring," and the approach might very easily have become ritualistic.

The city of Newark sold its issue of $5,000,000 of long-term bonds yesterday to a banking group headed by the Bankers Trust Company, the National City Company and the Guaranty Company of New York, obtained extensions from New Jersey banks on short-term loans of $1,000,000 and $800,000 maturing respectively yesterday and today, and, at the behest of the bankers, cut its budget appropriations by $968,715, and the budget itself by $532,500.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 26. -- The dollar in relation to the Mexican peso advanced today to 2.88 as against a par value of a little more than two for one, due, it is reported, to speculation on the local market and reluctance of national and foreign banks to show their hands during the period of uncertainty following the appointment of the new Finance Minister, Alberto Pani, as successor to Luis Montes de Oca.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 27. -- Heavy artillery roared along the Chapei front during the night following a day in which Japanese planes inflicted damage upon China's air forces at Hangchow, more than 100 miles south of Shanghai, and bombed the Shihtzelin forts northwest of Woosung.
NEW YORK. The final After-Dinner Dance for this season will be held tonight in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Several dinners will precede it. Mrs. Herman David Ruhm Jr. heads the committee.

When the boon companion of CHARLES II read to him the characterization of the King as one who never said a foolish thing and never did a wise one, the jovial monarch replied: "Quite true; my words are "my own, but my acts are my Ministers."

While upholding most of the changes embodied in the new football rules as beneficial, Andy Kerr, Colgate University coach, predicted here yesterday that officials would hesitate to enforce many of the rules and declared that spectators "will see the same kind of game played next Fall that they did last year."

BERLIN, Feb. 26. --The Reichstag concluded its brief pre-Easter session today by approving March 13 as the date for the Presidential election and April 10 for a second ballot if no candidate obtained a majority, and then voting its confidence in the Bruening government by a margin of twenty-five votes.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26. -- An increase of nearly ten times in the efficiency of photographic astronomical telescopes was promised today by Professor G.W. Ritchey, who is building a new instrument for the United States Naval Observatory in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Faced with the prospect of danger to foreigners in the International Settlement at Shanghai, the foreign powers have perfected plans for speedy evacuation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Defense counsel told Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close today in an action to collect $21,000 on a confession of judgment from Mrs. Fredericka I. Hall of Mount Vernon that Dwight E. Potter of 10 West Fortyeighth Street, New York, the plaintiff in the proceeding, had induced Mrs. Hall to purchase five inexpensive paintings for $42,000 with the understanding that they were by old masters.

Business was at a low ebb on the Stock Exchange yesterday, the turnover amounting to less than 900,000 shares. This figure measures Wall Street's interest in the market. Price movements were irregular, but the tone was easy most of the day and the averages were a trifle lower at the close.

The Bank of United States, as plaintiff in a foreclosure action involving a lien of $5,467,896 on the twenty-seven-story San Remo Towers apartments on Central Park West, bid $1,021,000 for the property at auction yesterday. The sale was conducted by Joseph P. Day in the Vesey Street Exchange.

Bonds listed on the Stock Exchange responded mildly yesterday to the cut in the Reserve Bank's discount rate announced after the close of the market on Thursday. THE NEW YORK TIMES averages on both foreign and domestic "bonds moved up moderately, while seven of the eleven long-term United States Government issues advanced 1-32 to 12-32 point.

PARIS, Feb. 26. -- The proposed changes in the French electoral system whose passage by the Chamber of Deputies last week resulted in the defeat of the Laval Government were rejected today without a dissenting; vote in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- House wets waged an uphill fight today to obtain the remaining signatures necessary on a petition to force a record vote on the prohibition issue, but by tonight had only 122 names.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 26. -- "Mr. Stimson's arresting letter to Senator Borah has produced lively satisfaction because it is felt that the United States, which has been exercising almost unbelievable forbearance and patience, has at long last recognized the world menace of Japanese militarism," said Dr. T.V. Soong this morning.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES is to be congratulated for the editorial "Japan's Miscalculations," which explains the Shanghai blunder from an impartial standpoint.

Stocks made little progress in either direction yesterday. Measured by the price averages for selected groups, there was an inconsequential net decline. Trading, however, was extremely dull and the market on the Stock Exchange was simply allowed to drift aimlessly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today sustained charges by the city of Newark that its port development was being hindered by the Pennsylvania Railroad's refusal to grant it privileges accorded to other Eastern ports in the loading of lumber.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Local bulls, Bided by commission houses, tried today to advance wheat prices on the Board of Trade here to a new high mark on the current movement, but outside buying failed to follow the upturn and selling that developed at a fraction under 63 cents a bushel for May was sufficient to check the advance.

When the Mary Powell came down the river, spouting smoke and fire; when Broadway was Bloomingdale Road and then the Boulevard, when cool beer at a nickel a glass could be quaffed on a hot day in the grove of the Lion Brewery, and when "Johnny" Curry's father had a farm at Amsterdam and Sixtieth, were the subjects discussed at last night's session of the West Side Boys' Association at 1,946 Broadway.

CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I., Feb. 26. -- Dr. George A. Smith, superintendent of the Central Islip State Hospital for the Insane, who established the institution thirty-seven years ago as a branch of the old Manhattan State Hospital, completed today his fiftieth year in the service of the State of New York as a medical officer.

Two sales and a purchase by New Yorkers were included in the variety of New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday. Among the sellers was Jennie E. Thorley of the Hotel Plaza in this city, who conveyed to Lendert and Mary Bowman the two threestory brick flats at 233-35 Park Avenue, southeast corner of Third Street, and the one-story frame taxpayer at 215 Third Street, Hoboken.

Prices were generally lower yesterday, with the most significant reaction occurring in spot silk which sold down to a new low at $1.62 1/2. The futures trading in that staple was irregular in price trend. Lead was also weak, losing 3/4 cent to 3 1/2 cents. Elsewhere the grains, hides and cotton were lower, while coffee and sugar were firm.

John f. Curry, leader of Tammany, and John H. McCooey. Brooklyn Democratic leader, had lunch with former Governor Smith yesterday in the Empire State Club. The conference after the luncheon lasted about two hours.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26. -- Wilmer Alllson, Austin, Texas, won his quarter-final singles match against Arthur Hendrix, Tampa. 6-1, 6-3, and went on to the doubles with J. Gilbert Hall, East Orange, N.J., to defeat Julius Seligson, New York, and Theodore Drewes, St. Petersburg, Fla., 6-3, 6-1, 6-0, in the Pan-American tennis championships on the Flamingo courts today.
