William H. Nichols, chairman of the board of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, who died in February, 1930, in Honolulu, left a gross estate of 59,647,629 and a net estate ot $9,137,140, an appraisal filed yesterday in the New York County Surrogate's office revealed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Approved by Congress today without a dissenting vote, the Glass - Steagall credit-expansion bill reached the White House at 6:08 o'clock tonight and will be signed by President Hoover tomorrow.

New York City obtained yesterday its fourth loan under the $151,000,000 revolving credit agreement entered into in January with the group of thirty-four banks headed by J.P. Morgan Co., the Chase National Bank and the National City Bank. Yesterday's loan amounted to $18,000,000.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Skeptics who wagged their heads when H.O. Crisler came to Minnesota as football coach two years ago clamored that he remain as he prepared today to assume similar duties at Princeton.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted:

A recent article by Professor LASKI on "The American College President" discussed, incidentally, the shortcomings and limitations of college trustees: they can rarely be well informed; they can advise about investments; they can give general encouragement or warning about policies placed before them; they can perhaps put the president into touch with possible sources of revenue; and may even help at times through a particular knowledge of some man or department.

The American Steamship Owners' Association announced yesterday that it had forwarded a protest to the United States Senate against legislation which was passed by the House on Wednesday and submitted to the Senate, designed to increase passport rates and restrict the periods in which passports would be effective.

More than 200 penal institutions in eleven Kastern States will be visited by Salvation Army officers tomorrow, which the organization will observe as Prison Sunday. A Salvation Army officer will conduct services at each institution, Lieut. Col. W.F. Palmer will be at Randall's Island here and Colonel William C. Arnold, chief secretary, will be at Sing Sing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- An investigation of the New York Stock Exchange designed to reveal the names of supposed "bear raiders" appeared certain tonight. The Senate Committee on Banking and Currency will meet tomorrow morning to make a decision and, if an inquiry is voted, to determine the procedure.

COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday-3 1/2 to 3 3/4 per cent for the best names. Thursday-3 3/2 to 4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper. ooo Men's Wear Results Fair. Retail sales of men's wear did not show much improvement during the week over the poor performances of previous weeks of the month, although a slight upturn was registered in the last day or so, according to reports yesterday.

Reuben. L. Haskell, whose recent nomination to the vacancy on the State Transit Commission was made by Governor Roosevelt and later confirmed unanimously by the State Senate, was sworn in yesterday in the library of the Brooklyn Supreme Court by Justice Lewis L. Fawcett in the presence of Mrs. Haskell, their daughter, Louise, and about fifty friends.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 26. -- Waite Hoyt, one of the greatest right-handed pitchers ever to wear a Yankee uniform, probably will wear a Robin uniform before the training season is many days older. Hoyt has been offered a contract, Manager Max Carey announced today.

Evidence that a juror at the trial of Joseph A. Broderick, State Super intendent of Banks, made misleading statements in the examination that led to his selection caused Judge George L. Donnellan in General Session to grant yesterday morning a defense motion for a mistrial.

Vladimir Horowitz, the Russian pianist, chose an all-Liszt program in which to take his leave of New York last evening at Carnegie Hall. His fifth American tour in as many short years will end with appearances in Rock Island, St. Louis, Nashville, Dallas and Havana during March. Last night was his seventh event in town this season and his third solo recital.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Asserting that the people of the State were mandated to give aid to the 2,500,000 residents suffering from effects of unemployment, Governor Roosevelt called tonight for support for the proposed new tax increases to continue the State's relief program.

RAY CONGER ran 1,500 meters in 3:55 in the Olympic trials of 1928 on the cinder track in the Harvard Stadium. That's the record for this continent and this hemisphere. Gene Venzke will try to step the distance a little faster in the Knights of Columbus games at the Garden this evening. To put it mildly, the followers of track and field sports are stirred up over the prospect.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 27. -- The Japanese advanced last night against terrific machine-gun fire and almost completely surrounded Kiangwan for the express purpose of bottling up the Chinese and starving them out.
TOKYO, Feb.26. -- Japanese military chiefs have been warned by the country's leading bankers of increasing financial difficulties for the nation should the present military operations be protracted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The newly constructed League of Nations radio station at Nyon, near Geneva, is powerful enough to flash 250 words a minute anywhere in the world, the Department of Commerce has been informed. The station has extra territorial rights against censorship and began functioning Feb. 3. when it opened Geneva's first direct service to Shanghai.
Sammy Fuller, rugged Italian lightweight from Boston, punched his way to a victory over Ray Miller, Chicago's left-hook specialist, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- The discovery of a large swimming pool with circulatory water system in a 1,500-year-old, royal palace among the ruins of the ancient city of Kish is described in a report received today at the Field Museum of Natural History from Professor Stephen Langdon, director of the Field Museum-Oxford University joint expedition to Mesopotamia.

PARIS, Feb. 26. -- The movement toward recovery extended today to all sections of the Bourse and there was active trading throughout the session. Exchanges centred mainly on domestic shares, with the internationals moderately joining in improvement.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 26. -- The Chinese Government hereafter will pay out only $103,000,000 Mexican a war in servicing domestic loans instead of the $199,000,000 Mexican hitherto called for. Besides prolonging the maturity of the government's domestic issues, practically doubling the time of amortization, the government hereafter may cut interest to a maximum of 6 per cent on all domestic loans, although some were issued at 9 per cent.

A new world's record is almost a certainty for Gene Venzke tonight. The miler with his almost incredible time of 4:10 will race at a new distance in the thirteenth annual track and field games of the Knights of Columbus at Madison Square Garden and should romp off with the Columbian 1,500-meter invitation in faster figures than ever have been made before indoors.

Japanese Government bonds sold on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday at the lowest prices since their issuance, and yen in the foreign exchange market touched 31 5/8, a level which would require the dusting off of records of, many years to duplicate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- A noticeable improvement has taken place in the banking situation in two weeks, according to reports received by the Federal Reserve Board and by J.W. Pole, Controller of the Currency. For eight days there have been no national bank failures, a new record for many months, while there has been an appreciable decline in failures of other member and State banks for ten days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Plans to impose a 2 per cent general sales tax on practically every manufacturer in the United States with an annual turnover of $10,000 or more, were virtually completed by a Ways and Means subcommittee today.

Manhattan Prep clinched runner-up honors in the Manhattan division C.H.S.A.A. basketball race by defeating St. Ann's Academy, 18 to 13, in the Manhattan College gymnasium yesterday. It was Manhattan Prep's final game of the season. St. Ann's led, 12 to 8, at the half.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 27. -- Ambassador Kioki Hirota at Moscow today communicated to Tokyo the Russian demands for explanations of Japanese troops in Manchuria and the questions asked of Mr. Hirota by L.M. Karakhan, Assistant Foreign Commissar, including the query concerning the Japanese request for seventeen trains of fifty cars, each to transport troops to Imienpo and Pogranichnaya.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- Secretary Stimson's letter to Senator Borah is described by The London Economist as "the most, important diplomatic document relating to the Far Eastern crisis that has been made public since the crisis began."

New State and municipal security issues scheduled for award next week amount to only $7,357,864, the smallest total for a week so far this year. This week's revised total was $24,684,672. The weekly average for the year thus far is $17,033,732. The largest issue listed for next week is $1,000,000 State of Oregon highway bonds, on which bidders may name the interest rate up to the legal maximum of 6 per cent.

BERLIN, Feb. 26. -- The second-day trading on the Boerse was extremely quiet because of technical difficulties as the result of the prohibition against the publication of prices and the approaching month-end, which caused sales of speculation. Banks were firm, notably the Reichsbank, and also textiles and breweries, but the business was small.

HONOLULU, Feb. 26 (AP). -- A story of convicts carrying the keys to their cells and the outer gates of the penitentiary, and of prisoners leaving for night or week-end visits, is told in a report of the Hawaiian prison directors to Governor Lawrence M. Judd.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Ernie Schaaf of Boston overwhelmed the pride of Georgia, W.L. (Young) Stribling, in their savage ten-round battle in the Chicago Stadium tonight, and established himself as a potential threat to the world's heavyweight championship.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 26 (AP). -- American women in the International Settlement are meeting the emergency of war by figuratively donning the Red Cross and dressing the wounds of "the poor devils" who come out of the battle line into Shanghai hospitals.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Governor Roosevelt today signed two bills for tax increases which are expected to bring an additional $76,000,000 into the State Treasury by July 1, 1933. One measure increases the gasoline tax by 1 cent, effective next Tuesday, and is expected to yield $21,000,000 by the end of the next fiscal year.
Stocks were dull and slightly lower on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, but bonds showed increased activity, especially in the foreign group which closed with more gains than losses.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26. -- Culminating an investigation of the running of a ringer under the name of "Gailmont" at Hialeah Park Tuesday, the Miami Jockey Club today suspended John P. Crawford and Willis Kane, owners, Trainer A.F. Tavenner and five horses.

HAVANA, Feb. 26. -- The Cuban Sugar Institute today openly broke with Thomas L. Chadbourne, author of the sugar restriction plan bearing his name, blaming him for all the ills of the Cuban sugar producers. Members of the institute charge Mr. Chadbourne is supporting a program of drastic restriction in favor of outside interests.

Improvement in clinic service, home supervision and diagnostic work resulted in great progress here last year in the control of tuberculosis, Godias J. Drolet, statistician for the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, said yesterday afternoon at the twenty-third annual convention of the Association of Tuberculosis Clinics, held at 315 Madison Avenue.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 26. -- The gift of Gunston Hall, ancestral Fairfax County home of George Mason, author of the Virginia bill of rights, to the Commonwealth of Virginia by its owner, Louis Hertle, was announced today by Governor Pollard. It is to be held and maintained as a perpetual memorial to the memory of the Virginia patriot.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 26. -- The first chance in the last three days for foreign correspondents to visit the Japanese lines came this afternoon when a group was taken to the Japanese headquarters one and one-half miles behind the lines. There a map was shown to the correspondents and they listened to the reading of a formal communique which might have been just as effectively read at the Japanese Consulate.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- The demand for British Government funds showed no signs of diminishing today and all the issues continued to advance sharply on the Stock Exchange. The funding loan, which is tax-free to foreigners, jumped 1 5/8 to u94 1/8, while the 4 per cent consols advanced 1 1/2 to u90 1/2.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26. -- The whole-hearted support of the undergraduate body of Princeton University was assured Herbert O. Crisler in his capacity as head football coach at Princeton is the editorial columns of today's Issue of The Daily princetonian, student newspaper.

An elderly man, well dressed and apparently cultured, sat on a bench in Washington Square yesterday morning in the warm sunshine, surrounded by playing children. A moment later he was dead and a wisp of smoke curled upward from a small calibre pistol clutched in his hand.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26. -- Maxwell A. Cox, former vice president of the Irvington Trust Company of Irvington, N.J., was arrested here today on a fugitive warrant charging embezzlement f $11,800 from his bank.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26. -- The consistent Prince Tokalon, which has had an extraordinarily successful Florida campaign, scored again at Hialeah Park today when he won the Victor Hugo purse by the narrow margin of a head. It was the sixth Florida start for the gelded son of Prince Pal and Dulce Tokalon, and he now has won five times and finished second the other time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Another spectacular tale of sufferings from the new "kidnapping racket" in the mid-West was unfolded today before the House Judiciary Committee by Sergeant Leroy Steffens, "ace detective" for Chicago's "secret six."

The Committee of One Thousand, of which William Jay Schieffelin is chairman, has just started an enrolment of voters as a preliminary step toward naming an independent ticket in the municipal campaign in 1933. Dr. Schieffelin, as chairman of the Citizens Union, has participated in many past fusion movements.

MEDINA, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Homer Luther, for years vice president and director of the Union Bank here, died yesterday in his Winter home, Los Angeles, at the age of 73. He was born in Sacramento, Cal., and was brought to Knowlesville, N.Y., by his parents in a covered wagon.

Led by the Misses Lisa Lindstrom and Iris Jakobb, the New York University girls' swimming team recorded its twenty-ninth consecutive victory in triumphing over Hunter College, 32 1/2 to 19 1/2, in the Sixtieth Street pool last night. The Violet girls captured five first places in the six events.

The St. Valentine's Kettledrum yesterday afternoon at the Plaza drew a large gathering of juveniles, for this annual event in aid of the Samaritan Home for the Aged is arranged with their entertainment in view. The Kettledrum has been an annual event in society for more than half a century, and has been attended by at least three generations of children.

The National Civil Service Reform League calls on President HOOVER to end forthwith the use of Presidential postmasters as "virtually spoils of the party in power." This is a hope more pious than realizable. Whatever pressure may be brought on the Administration is not likely to have any effect in this direction until after the election.
W.K. Rice of the Harvard Club reached the third round of the national Class B squash tennis championship at the Columbia University Club last night, a bracket ahead of the rest of the field.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 26. -- Criticism of the United States Senate for ignorance and petty politics "in delaying official entrance into the World Court" was voiced today by President Hamilton Holt at the ninth annual Southeastern Conference of the International Relations Clubs.

Reports of railroad earnings for January show that the freight surcharge that became effective on Jan. 4 did not offset sufficiently the continuing decrease in traffic to halt the decline in gross earnings. Even with this aid the New York Central reported a net operating income of $1,207,144 in January, the smallest total for a month in many years.

Against the predictions of dire failure with which the cables from Geneva are humming there is one effective defense available to those who can remember ten years back or even two years back. This is the comforting thought that on past performances the prospect for a disarmament conference is not for failure but success.

WASHINGTON Feb. 26. -- At a conference of importers, treasury officials and representatives of the House and Senate at the Customs Bureau today, it was announced that Secretary Mills would seek a Congressional resolution to permit the entry of imports where there is a disagreement on their value.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- What the world thinks of Secretary Stimson's letter to Senator Borah on the Sino-Japanese controversy was appraised by the President and Mr. Stimson late today. They found that the letter had created a good impression. Press dispatches and confidential communications to the department were spnead out, and the diplomatic situation was voted satisfactory for the immediate present.

Suspicion that collusion is practissd by a group of contractors who bid for electrical work and equipment on schoolhouses and other public buildings, for the purpose of raising prices, was voiced by Mayor Walker in yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 26. -- Because Frank M. Steadman, examiner from the Naturalization Bureau of the Federal Department of Labor, was not satisfied with the answer to a question relative to the bearing of arms in defense of the United States, action on William Hewitt Dewar's application for citizenship papers was deferred today for a hearing by Judge Alfred A. Stein in Naturalization Court.

Sidney Lenz and Commander Winfield Liggett Jr., holders of many auction championships who had been derided recently by some of the younger experts as passe since the advent of contract bridge, emerged the victors early this morning at the close of the five day gruelling struggle for the Julian Goldman trophy, premier event in the annual Eastern Bridge championships at the Hotel Roosevelt.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 26. -- The men every tourist knows -- the Chinese coolies -- have been impressed into service by the Japanese in Shanghai's war.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The ultimate success of the League of Nations as an instrumentality for the prevention of war depends not on the extent to which it has been perfected at a given time, but on the attitude of its members and supporters through both success and failure.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 26. -- George Little, formerly director of the Department of Physical Education at the University of Wisconsin, has been appointed director of the Division of Physical Education at Rutgers University, it was announced today by Dr. Philip M. Brett, acting president of the board of trustees.

TOKYO, Feb. 13. -- Fighting over in Manchuria, the Japanese turned at once to the more interesting con structive stage of their policy in Manchuria. There also the army takes a leading part. It was therefore to General Araki, the new Minister of War, that the writer went with fourteen questions on future policy in Manchuria.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In John Corbin's capital article in THE NEW YORK TIMES comparing liquor conditions here and in England, there is one statement which needs qualifying.

William G. Philip, builder, has sold a new English-type dwelling at Wynmor Road and Palmer Avenue, in the Heathcote section of Scarsdaie, through Frederick Fox Co. The buyer is a New York shipping man.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Almost certain approval of the Norris anti-injunction bill was in the air today as the Senate brushed aside all modifying amendments and voted to outlaw the "yellow dog" labor contracts.

Dr. Gerhart Hauptmann, distinguished German author, responding yesterday to the city's formal tribute when he was received at City Hall by Mayor Walker and a large committee representing German-American groups and organizations, predicted that the world would solve its economic and ethical difficulties.

Prospects for seven additional judgeships in the city court, advocated by Presiding Justice Edward B. La Fetra as the surest means of clearing the enormous congestion in the calendars of that court, faded yesterday at a hearing held by the Commission on the Administration of Justice of New York State at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

The University of Pittsburgh swimming team came from behind to upset New York University, 30 to 29, in the London Terrace seventy-five-root pool yesterday. Trailing, 24-to-26, as it entered the final event, the Panther team annexed first and third places to triumph.

That Progressive dream-child, the Third Party, never was and is not It shall be born, said the faithful. It must be born. The country can't be saved without it. Time after time they sought in vain for a doorstep on which to lay the babe of their hallucination.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Congressional action was completed today on the resolution to authorize a $10,000,000 revolving fund for loans to agricultural credit corporations.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 26 (AP). -- President Hoover exercised his veto power today for the first time this session, returning to Congress a bill to confer upon a former soldier who was discharged "without honor" the benefits accorded to those honorably discharged.

Attacking radio's "blatant claim to being a medium of education," Henry R. Luce, managing editor of Time magazine, asserted yesterday that the more than 20,000 letters of protest received by the publication since it announced that it would no longer sponsor its Friday night "March of Time" broadcasts constitute a challenge to the radio systems to improve the quality of their broadcasts at their own expense.

Charged with having beaten a defenseless civilian repeatedly over the head with a blackjack and then having fired three shots at him, Patrolmon Robert W. Hild of the East Thirty-fifth Street station was disarmed by a fellow-policeman shortly after 9 o'clock last night at Third Avenue and Forty-first Street.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 26. -- Holding that "the sovereign right of the people to write the platform is paramount to that of the candidate," the Republican State Committee adopted today a resolution endorsing President Hoover for renomination and recommending inclusion in the national platform of a plank for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

The downward sweep in values continued in evidence again yesterday. The outstanding price change was that in eggs, which declined 2 1/2 cents to a new low price for the year, butter easing off in sympathy 3/4 cent. Grains, cotton, rubber, silk and sugar were others to react, while steadiness prevailed in coffee and cocoa. Hides were irregular.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 27 -- Continental Shares, Inc., reports for 1931 receipts of $2,659,253 in dividends and interest, which, after payment of interest and general expenses, left a net profit of $53,223 exclusive of security transactions. A loss of $7,254,263 on sales of securities and a depreciation of $76,750,220 in market values of investments make a total shrinkage of $84,004,483.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 28 -- Japanese transports landed thousands of troops between Woosung and the boundaries of the International Settlement last night, according to reports made by Chinese spies in Pootung, across the Whangpoo River from Shanghai.

UNCLE BOB SHERWOOD, the last of Barnum's clowns, has set down his reminiscence of circus life in a book appropriately entitled "Hold YerHosses! The Elephants Are Coming!" to be published in May by the Macmillan Company.

WHEN these columns were declaring several days ago that "There's Always Juliet" was the best comedy of manners recently produced in this neighborhood one exception should have been made. "Brief Moment" was produced in this neighborhood us recently as Nov. 9, and was still on view as recently as last evening, and although these columns may be forgetful, fidelity is their ideal.

THE Radio Corporation of America and its associates will be tried under the anti-trust laws on grounds of their intercorporate relationship and other charges, regardless of whether they release their patents through an open pool, according to the testimony of Assistant to the Attorney General, John Lord O'Brian, head of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, before the House Appropriations Committee.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Feb. 27 -- The first step toward the establishment of a national political party to be known as the Jobless party, led by the Rev. James R. Cox of Pittsburgh, was made today when papers pre-empting the name in this State were filed in the county court.

LONDON, Feb. 11 YEARS ago, under the auspices of Sir Herbert Beerbohm Tree, His Majesty's Theatre, which enjoys, as a great building at the corner of Pall Mall, an exceptional prestige, was devoted to the works of Shakespeare.

The life of an eight-day baby girl, suffering from internal hemorrhages, was saved yesterday, according to attending physician, by the quick thinking of her parents and the aid of the Police Department in providing a motorcycle escort to conduct an automobile bearing the infant from her home in the Sheepshead Bay district of Brooklyn to the Long Island College Hospital, at Henry and Pacific Streets.

TIMID IN TRAFFIC. THERE may be some New York taxi drivers rounding street comers who hold unofficial records, but Sir Malcolm Campbell still has the undisputed official title for the fastest traveling overhand.
HYDE PARK, Feb. 27 -- Governor Roosevelt considers unfair and unsound the attack made on his attitude toward Tammany Hall by Samuel Seabury.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Senator Watson. Republican Senate leader, told his colleagues today that Congress would probably adjourn the first week in June, in time for the national conventions, instead of refcessing for the conventions and resuming late in the Summer, as suggested in some quarters.

THROUGH the imaginative use of the microphone and the camera. Josef von Sternberg has succeeded in giving a really remarkable conception of a fastmoving train in "Shanghai Express." a film featuring Marlene Dietrich which is now at the Rialto.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Feb. 27 -- The Williams swimming team defeated Wesleyan today, 48 to 29, in a meet in which Swayze and Beatty of Williams established New England intercollegiate records in the 100-yard free stye and the 440-yard free style, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Sentiment is increasing among the League of Nations powers for the Assembly at its meeting next Thursday to take action in support of the Far East stand of Secretary Stimson, according to summaries of press reports and of official opinions which were received by the State Department today from Great Britain and various European countries.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 22 -- The 1931-32 cotton crop now being picked in Brazil is officially estimated by the cotton bureau of the Ministry of Agriculture as 250,737,560 pounds, compared with 235,840,000 pounds for the 1930-31 crop and 240,680,000 pounds for the 1929-30 crop.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27 -- Keen, alert and high-speed tactics on the offensive, which returned to fashion in major league baseball last year with the advent of a less lively ball, are not to be exploited exclusively by the champion Cardinals this season. Not at least so far as the Giants are concerned, a point clearly outlined today by John McGraw as he prepared to receive the remainder of his squad of players due tomorrow.
Leo A. Rosenberg of Bayonne sold a two-family house at 273 Boyd Avenue, near Mallory Avenue, Jersey City to William Hay, coal dealer, who intends to occupy it. J.I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.
TORONTO, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Minus the services of their star, Joe Primear the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight de feated the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 2. in a National Hockpy League game.

Four bridge team's battled on divided fronts yesterday to clear up the unfinished business of the Eastern tournament. They met in the semi-final rounds of the team-of-four championship and, at the close of play, two teams had fallen by the wayside limiting the competition to The Bridge World team and the "Four Horsemen."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Should not more thought be given to consideration of the radically different elements in the present depression, from those of any previous depression? My personal relation to business began in 1866 in New York City, and I recall the preliminary bomb in the development of "fear" psychology prior to the 1873 crisis.

The week ended yesterday with all markets at a standstill. In stocks and bonds, it rounded out a week of inactivity, with uncertain variation of values and no sign of definite trend in either direction. Yesterday's transactions on the Stock Exchange were not only the smallest of the year to date, but the smallest of any Saturday since the early August dog-days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Leland B. Morris of Philadelphia, Consul General at Athens, has been placed in charge of the legation there pending the appointment of a Minister, when he will resume his duties as Consul General.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 27 -- Close competition marked the shoot at the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. The best work was done by S. Isaac, who broke forty-nine targets. T.B. Pettit Jr., L.W. Hall, and T. Bedell, each with forty-eight, tied for the second prize.

SOUTH AMERICAN civilization challenges comparison with our own. On two virgin continents discovered toward the close of the fifteenth century the white races have built up economic and social systems both inspired by Europe but differing widely in many respects.

Bewildering the Violet with a whirlwind passing attack. City College brought its 1931-32 basketball season to a brilliant close last night by conquering the New York University quintet. 33 -- 21. before 5,000 fans at the 102d Engineers Armory.

DAME MAY WHITTY, who plays the nurse to the modern Juliet -- that would he Edna Best -- in Gilbert Miller's production of Mr. van Druten's "There's Always Juliet," at the Empire, has acted in this country only twice before, although the record of her career in England runs on for pages in Mr. Parker's invaluable "Who's Who in the Theatre."

Friends of Governor Roosevelt were resentful yesterday of Samuel Seabury's indirect attack on his candidacy in his Cincinnati address, but among Tammany leaders amusement and concern at the possible effect of the speech on the selection of a successor to Thomas M. Farley as Sheriff of New York County were the principal reactions.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Williams entertained tonight with a dinner for twenty-one guests, followed by a larger party to which thirty additional persons were invited. Among those present were:

CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Chuckles which have been emanating from the clubhouse for several days after each workout grew louder today as the members of the first Robin squad contemplated the imminent arrival of the second contingent and the surprise that is in store for the regulars when they are started through their first series of the "Carey calesthenics."

BERLIN, Feb. 26 -- Germany at present Is in the throes of the most critical political campaign she has had since she became a republic and Berlin is the storm centre of that campaign, but no outsider coming here just now would know it.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- When one says that there has never been such an economic crisis as the one which we are going through now, it is not true. In the first place, "never" is very long measured in time and must have its "ever" in history. And in the second place, every 2,000 years, when we come into a new astrological house, such a crisis takes place.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26 -- According to a reliable Communist authority, the struggle which has been going on in the party for several months is ended.

DETROIT. MORALE is higher in the automobile industry than it has been for two years. One hears this fact proclaimed on all sides in Detroit these days, with particular emphasis upon the point that the new esprit de corps is not confined to one quarter but extends from the top of the industry to the bottom.

MR. COWARD, in case the matter comes up, is en route from South America to Los Angeles and will be in New York by April. There is a good chance, so the wiseacres say, that Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne will act with him in New York and London next season in a new Coward play.

AND now it is almost March, which means that, with the technical advent of Spring only three weeks away and with the stage in the Lenten doldrums, this hard-pressed theatrical season has just about passed the three-quarters mark.

DALLAS, Feb. 25 -- The best available opinions of those in touch with this district's unemployment problem indicate that it is now at its worst. Estimates of the number of unemployed have ranged from under 200,000 to above 400,000, with the smaller figure thought to be nearer the fact.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- If quota lions on the New York Stock Exchange would go up and stay up, the "bear" hunt in Wall Street which is being organized by the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency might be equipped with blank cartridges. But as things stand the administration is anxious for a real safari, the President having several times made it clear that he thinks the market is being raided by professionals.

TOKYO, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Japan is ready to use her air rorce and her navy in interior China to prevent the Chinese from reinforcing their line at Shanghai, it was learned today on high authority. The navy will be ordered to stop troop movements down the Yangtse River and air raids will be employed to discourage the Chinese from bringing up reinforcements by land.

Recommendations for the slmplification of foreclosure suits for the purpose of sharply reducing the costs and time required for such actions under the present system in New York State were offered yesterday by the City Club to the State Commission to Investigate the Administratlon of Justice.
Los Nanduces Uplifters, making their first appearance of the season in the squadron A ring, won the feature of last night's indoor polo competition from Fort Hamilton, 9 to 4 1/2.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Capturing four of the eight first places, St. Benedict's Prep of Newark retained the prep school indoor track and field championship in the eleventh annual New Jersey State interscholastic title meet conducted by St. Benedict's in the 110th Regiment Armory tonight.
LONDON, Feb. 27 (Canadian Press) -- The fourth highest position in the Anglican hierarchy became vacant today by the death of the Right Rev. Frank Theodore Woods, Bishop of Winchester since 1924.

MADRID, Feb. 27 -- Former King Alfonso, from his retreat in France, in a manifesto dated on his birthday, Jan. 23, but reaching Spain only today, declared open war on the Spanish republican regime, which seemed little perturbed. The manifesto charged the regime had clearly created a state of anarchy and instituted a virtual dictatorship and had upset the spiritual and material life of the nation, throwing it open to communism.

LAURENCE BINYON, deputy keeper in the British Museum, an authority on Oriental prints and the author of books on Oriental art, the editor of "The Golden Treasury of Modern Lyrics" and "Poems of Blake," is one of the bettter-known academic poets in England.

SAO PAULO, Feb. 2 -- Brazil's efforts to keep coffee prices high when the market was falling has brought about a situation for which the only solution seems to be the expenditure of $39,000,000 by April 30 for the purchase and destruction of excess stocks and the destruction of between 300 and 400 million coffee trees in the State of Sao Paulo.

Confronted by two robbers in the vestibule of the building of the Colonial Life Insurance Company at 309 First Street, Hoboken, as she returned yesterday morning from a bank with a $300 payroll, Miss Clara Berk, 27 years old, a cashier for the company, was beaten until she fainted and then robbed of her purse containing the payroll envelopes.

The united States is still potentially the wealthiest country in the world. So far from suffering a shortage of the necessary raw materials of agriculture and industry, it is burdened with a glut. Those materials which are not present in superabundance within the country are clamoring for admission from the countries which have always been the source ou their supply.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 -- For the first time in its history the Florida Derby was won by a filly when George D. Widener's Evening, a daughter of St. James and Crepuscule, galloped home to an easy victory in the event today.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter printed in your issue of Feb. 20 should not pass unchallenged, though it is only one of those sporadic outbursts in favor of giving opera in English.
For the second week in a row, Fordham's basketball team swept through in the closing minute of play to grasp a victory, halting the Manhattan five, 28 to 26, last night in the Maroon gym.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 27 -- There is no need for the proposed $1,750,000, authorized by the residents of the county, at the present time, Philip F. Wiedersum, County Controller, declared today, giving the statement as one of his reasons for refusing to authorize the sale of bonds for projects that were not of pressing need.
PARIS. SINCE the first of the year there has been intensive showing of American work. At the Galerie Jeune Peinture, Sam Putnam organized an international exhibition in which Americans predominated.

Trading in the over-the-counter market was irregular yesterday. Chain-store shares were firm. Industrial and public utility issues continued inactive, the price changes being confined to Industrial Acceptance preferred, Bunker Hill, Texas Power Light, Rochester Gas Electric B and Dayton Power Light.

THE way of the Communist is hard, even in Russia, if that way be the baffling path whereon music, most refractory of the Muses, is to be led into the Communist fold. The other arts, according to the Russian correspondent of Musica d'Oggi, have all been shepherded in -- literature, theatre, decorative arts.

AT the beginning of the present century the atom was a miniature solar system -- something that any one could imagine. In the centre was the nucleus, and surrounding it were electrons, the number varying with the position of the element in the periodic table of Mendelejev.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Albert Kleinman, 32, a real estate dealer, was arrested today on a telegraphic warrant sent by Chief Inspector John O'Brien of New York. The charge is larceny.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- State income taxpayers will receive for the making out of their 1931 returns last year's blanks with slips attached, showing the rate to be paid this year. The increase to be paid on 1931 incomes as the result of the 100 per cent advance over 1930 rates authorized by the Legislature will be explained by the slips.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) -- A one-armed grocer who turned bandit leader was killed and T. Philip Perkins, former British amateur golf champion, and five others were wounded shortly before 3 A.M. today in an attempt by a robber band to hold up the gambling casino of the fashionable Embassy night club.

Colonel Stimson's letter to Senator Borah anent the Far Eastern situation has assumed an importance which may prove to be even beyond that which the Secretary of State and the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee attached to it.

The last After-Dinner Dance of this season's series was held last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. This subscription series, which was organized several years ago, was under the direction of Mrs. Herman David Ruhm Jr. Assisting her were Mrs. Frederic G. Hoppin, Mrs. Gilbert Colgate Jr., Mrs. Armitage Watkins, Mrs. Cortlandt S. Van Rensselaer Jr., Mrs. William Curtis Pierce, Mrs. John Rutherfurd, Mrs. Leighton Coleman and Miss Martha Rosalie Humphrey.

The municipal hospitals which treat workmen's compensation insurance cases, and five of the important private hospitals of the city, will charge $5.50 a day, plus extras, for the care of such cases on and after March 1, it was disclosed yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- The trend of prices on the Bourse was higher in active trading today. It was noted that not only the professional speculators, but a class regarded here as prudent investors were participating in the day's transactions. The Comite des Forges stock moved steadily upward.

JAPAN'S program of expansion, steadily developed since 1868 entered a new phase on Sept. 18 of last year. With one military sucess after another in Manchuria, that phase soon appeared to be nearing completion. Within five months the Japanese have established there, new form of government satisfactory to their purposes.
In its new coach, H.O. Crisler, Princeton, goes back, though in a very roundabout way, to its dearest rival, Yale, for football coaching.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 27 -- Construction of a 15,000,000-volt X-ray tube, which less than a few months ago was considered an impossible dream, will be begun within the next ten days by Massachusetts Institute of Technology, it was revealed here today by Karl T. Compton, president of the institute, at the close of the joint annual meeting of the American Physical Society and the Optical Society of America.

Members of the Commission on the Administration of Justice of New York State, led by Senator Waiter W. Westall. chairman, disclosed yesterday that they were in favor of creating a judicial council in this State, following a hearing at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

Off duty and in civilian clothes, Patrolman Joseph Keebler, who was transferred recently from the East 104th Street station to a precinct in the far reaches of Queens, returned last night to his old beat and voluntarily began the rounds of the stores which he had been accustomed to guard.

Norman Thomas described yesterday the "so-called Hoover program" for reconstruction as "classical proof of the class nature of our government, of economic interest so short-sighted that it even gives us bad economies unnecessarily from its own standpoint.''

HAMILTON. Bermuda -- With the greatest tennis week in Bermuda's history now a thing of the past, thoughts of the athletically inclined colonists are turning toward golf and yachting, the two major sports remaining on the schedule.

A NARROW muddy road in Brittany. A high-powered car of foreign make rushes past a group of peasants carrying home their baskets of apples and spatters them with mud. The oldest peasant shouts at the motorists: "Dirty engines, dirty American civilization."

New York City is spending $78,000 a day on home relief for more than 90,000 persons out of 115,000 who have applied for help, Mary L. Gibbons, director of the Home Relief Bureau of the Department of Public Welfare, declared in an address yesterday before 2,500 members of the bureau's staff at a meeting at Stuyvesant High School.

AWING of the Sterling Hall of Medicine at Yale might well be called the "Darwin Arms" instead of "Laboratories of Comparative Psychology." On the roof is a penthouse which Professor Robert M. Yerkes designed for anthropoid apes.

Proposals to reduce the par value of shares of the Barnsdall Corporation from $25 to $5, so that all investments in oil and gas leases may be carried on the books at the nominal figure of $1 and the item of "depletion" may be eliminated from the profit and loss account, will be presented to stockholders at a special meeting in Wilmington, Del., on March 22.

LISBON, Feb. 10 -- Last Summer Portugal awarded an Italian firm a contract for the construction of several small destroyers and the conditions required that 10 per cent of the purchase price should be deposited guaranteeing the fulfillment of the contract.

The New York Central Railroad in the last two years reduced its annual passenger train, operations by 11,000,000 passenger-train miles without impairing service, L.W. Landman, general passenger traffic manager said yesterday. In making this adjustment, he added, the company had anticipated in great measure a recommendation made by the Interstate Commerce Commission that the railroads help to solve their problems by reducing superfluous passenger facilities.

Senior high school swimmers of the Manhattan-Bronx division twice clipped the season's record for 100 yards free-style at the weekly series of dual meets for the championship of the Public Schools Athletic League in the seventy-five-foot pool of George Washington High School yesterday.

THE subject of forged inscriptions in books holds a peculiar fascination for bookmen. Just which particular aspect of the question predominates. It is difficult to Bay. Whether it is admiration for the cunning of the forger, amusement over the innocence of the deceived, envy of the skill of the discoverer, or just the dramatic interest of the episode, these stories always seem to command wide popularity.

A $1,000,000 hotel, to be known as Rangfemore Hall, will be erected soon in Stockbridgre, Mass., by the Highbury Land Company of this city, which plans also a housing development for its 208 acres in the Berkshires, acquired from River View Estates, it was announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27 -- Sazerac, 3-year-old colt owned by A.B. Letellier, New Orleans sportsman, won the $3,000 added Derby Trial Handicap, feature at the Fair Grounds today, with Bertjohn second and Crystal Prince third.

THE Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra's next concert, Wednesday night, will Introduce Sir Thomas Beecham, the well known English conductor of opera and symphony, to American audiences for the first time since 1928, when he directed four concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony and also appeared with the Philadelphia and Boston Symphony Orchestras.

THIS is a word of suggestion to transportation enterprises. A neophyte among the playwrights submits herewith, without charge, as a slogan: "Write a play and see the country." Any one with an overwhelming love for Pullman cars, lower berths, hotel rooms, taxicabs and scenery should sign a contract with a producer forthwith, and his traveling future is almost certainly assured.

One of the most significant events of the past week, as bearing on the Japanese imbroglio in China, was the report about American sentiment sent to Tokyo by Ambassador DEBUGHI at Washington. He has notably had embarrassments in the discharge of his duties in this country.

PEIPINO. WHETHER China will gyrate impotently, whether the country, traduced by politicians and mllitarists, will plunge downward into oblivion as impatient foreigners within her boundaries gloomily prophesy, or whether, gathering momentum with each disillusioning crisis, it will move forward to a place of power among the modern nations, no one knows.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Overcoming a ten-goal handicap It the first two periods and repulsing a Princeton attack in the final chukker, the Tale indoor polo team defeated the Princeton riders today, 20 to 16. Mike Phipps of Yale was the outstanding player of the game, scoring nine goals.

The terms of the tentative agreement reached between the Ladies' Garment Workers' Union and the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers' Association, Inc., the "inside shop" employers, were approved yesterday by the members of the manufacturers' association at a meeting at the Hotel McAlpin.

ONE hundred and thirty-one years ago next Spring eleven hair trunks containing 740 books which had just arrived from London were being unpacked in a room in the then uncompleted Capitol in the raw young city of Washington.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 27 -- The Lehigh freshman five defeated the Lafayette yearlings tonight, 34 to 25. The Brown and White led throughout.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- With the resort season at Augusta rapidly reaching its peak, a full calendar of society and sports events is provided for the guests at the Winter resorts of this region. Opening tomorrow is the match play for the Bon Air-Vanderbilt Cups and the Forest Hills Cups.

HERE are collected." says Mr. Keynes, "the croakings of twelve years -- the croakings of a Cassandra who could never influence the course of events in time." Now, much that was prophesied having come to pass, Cassandra has taken scissors and paste-brush and made a book of essays.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27 -- The Harvard hockey team gained the edge over the Yale sextet in the annual series by capturing the first game tonight, 4 to 1. A spirited rally in the final session when the Crimson tallied three times enabled Harvard to take the measure of the Bulldog skaters.

On Wagon Roads. THE world was rather well arranged to accommodate vehicles drawn by assorted quadrupeds -- and then came the automobile. And it has proved exceedingly tedious and difficult to rearrange the world to accommodate motor-driven cars and trucks.

RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 25 -- North Carolina has for many years prided itself upon the fact that its judiciary has been singularly free from any breath of scandal, and the entire State was shocked by two recent occurrences, one involving a Superior Court judge and the other a Solicitor, resulting in indictments on serious charges.

Moscow. LAST Sunday in our notes on the general art situation in Russia we considered the present status of the ikon. When it comes to portraits, the observer may find a good example of what is now regarded as the outrageous wastefulness of the Czarist regime in the portrait of Prince A.B. Kurakin, the so-called Diamond Prince and a favorite of Paul I.

Seven men charged with the kidnapping of two men yesterday afternoon from an automobile at West End Avenue and Seventy-fifth Street were arrested last night following a raid by detectives of the West Sixty-eighth Street station upon a room in the Hotel Alba at 203 West Fifty-fourth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent excitement engendered in the press regarding the arrest of Herr Otto Boettcher, president of the Memel Council, by the Lithuanian Governor Merkys on the ground of treasonable activities has served to emphasize one feature, and that is the by no means diminished propensity of the German Reich to present its side in this or any other international question confronting it.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 25 -- A volley fired last week by gendarmes into an excited crowd of Inhabitants in the small Hungarian farming village of Pacsa who had gathered to demonstrate against the auctioning of cattle seized for tax arrears did more than kill two of the demonstrators.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25 -- If it be true that people appreciate most that which they pay most dearly for Mississippians are going to esteem highly the present State adminstration, for Governor Mike Sennett Conner is going to make them pay on the spot for their past follies and extravagances.

DETROIT, Feb. 27 -- When Henry Ford gives the word for mass production on his new V-eight and improved model-A-four cars throughout the vast organization of the Ford Motor Company, as he will do probably next week, there will be revealed, well under way, one of the greatest epics of modern world industry.

With winning names enrolled in their published honor lists, some 3,000 children who constitute the youngest regular subscribers of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra celebrated the completion of their ninth season of concerts in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Liberal Republicans view the New Jersey Republican Committee's declaration for a prohibition repeal plank in the national platform as strengthening the moves of the party wets for such a stand at Chicago.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The speeches of the principal delegates at the Conference on Disarmament at Geneva, in a sense, show a surprising measure of unanimity. For each expresses the national Interest. Unfortunately, the interests of the several nations do not coincide.

THE full naked truth about the Philippines has not," says Senator Hawes in his introduction to this book, "heretofore been given to the American people. They are entitled to have it; it is unfair to persuade or permit them to reach conclusions based on false impressions for purely selfish motives."

ALTHOUGH progress is being made on the Mexican section of the Pan-American Highway, which eventually will connect the United States at Laredo, Texas, with Guatemala and the Isthmus of Panama, construction has not progressed to the point where it is feasible to attempt a trip all the way to Mexico City and beyond.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Grotesquely, none of our many present-day public medical campaigns seem to include "heart disease." Yet the difference between organic and mere functional heart trouble is important and should be publicly pointed out.

BOSTON, Feb. 27 -- Five meet records were broken and two equaled in the thirteenth annual Harvard-Cornell-Dartmouth track and field meet in the Garden tonight as the Crimson's well-balanced squad captured the team honors. A crowd of 4,000 saw Harvard amass 57 1/2 points.

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- An art exhibition, in which all American war veterans living in France were invited to participate, is being held here at Pershing Hall, Paris headquarters of the American Legion. The exposition includes 183 works of art by forty men and women.

GENEVA, Feb. 26 -- Judging from the press and politicians there seems to be a widespread belief in the United States that the League of Nations has been weighed in the balances of the Far Eastern conflict and the world depression and found wanting as a means of assuring peace and prosperity.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Dr. Herbert Adams Gibbons, historian and authority on international affairs, who recently returned from a long stay in the Orient, denounced today the movement for an economic boycott of Japan and declared his astonishment at the "hysteria" of the leaders in the campaign.

A.H. WOODS, as every student of the Woods tradition knows, used to have a habit of juggling with play titles. A piece that would start out as "Home Fires" in New Haven would bob up as "Under the Star and Crescent" in Boston and would finally land on Broadway as "Lacing Ella's Corset."

SINCE the first rigid airship developed by Count Zeppelin rose from the waters of Lake Constance more than thirty years ago one of the problems, the solution of which has not kept pace with the evolution of the airship itself, has been that of terminals, of docking and "undocking."

WASHINGTON AGLEAMING moon flickers against the big silvery wing, shines on the heavy glass of the cabin windows and seems to jump across and out the opposite window with the speed of lightning. Far over to the east it glistens again, this time beating upon the blue waters of Chesapeake Bay.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 -- Stanford University has gladdened the hearts of its alumni by deciding against turning post-graduate and wrecking its athletic machine. A.P. Giannini is back from his Transamerica Elba. The San Francisco Symphony Orchestra seems in a fair way of being saved from the scrap pile.

THOSE who watched a new television receiver in New York last week were convinced seeing by radio is not ready for the home unless some inventor has made a radical discovery which he has not demonstrated.

THIS is a small book that awakens great expectations. Though brief, it deals with a big theme and on this theme three minds focus ideas. The symposium is presented, moreover, by a great university as a contribution to thought at a moment of far-reaching transition.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Remarkable improvement in the physical condition and mechanical operation of George Pipgras and Charlie Ruffing, veteran right-hand pitching aces, and display of exceptional promise on the part of recruit right-hander Johnny Allen were estimnted by Manager Joe McCarthy as the chief constructive features developed by the first week of Yankee Spring training here.

EAST VIEW, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- Since the Wicks bill for emergency relief went into effect Nov. 1 over $134,000 has been spent for home relief by Westchester towns, according to figures filed with the Westchester County Department of Public Welfare, under whose supervision home relief is administered.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Although the latest figures tabulated by the Bureau of Statistics of the Illinois Department of Labor indicate 2.8 per cent decrease in employment in Illinois for the period from Dec. 15 to Jan. 15, a more encouraging report cornea from the Governor's Emergency Commission concerning the situation in Chicago and its immediate neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Hampered in their hobby by restrictions against the use of illustrations of United States stamps in catalogues, stamp collectors of this country have started a study of laws on the subject to see whether they are "absurd and ineffectual" or actually contribute to the protection of these "securities" against forgery.

The annual championship fencing tournament of the Athletic Association of Private Schools, to be held at the Trinity School on March 16 and 18, is expected to draw the largest entry in the event's history.

Messages from the pulpits of the city today will include discussions of social service and missionary problems, lessons from the lives of Old Testament characters and modern leaders of thought and applications of religious doctrines to everyday living.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The discovery in Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge University, London, by James Chadwick of the "neutron," a particle so minute it carries no electrical charge and hailed as the greatest, find in the scientific world since the electron, the proton and the X-ray, was announced today by The Baltimore Sun in a dispatch from The Manchester Guardian.

THERE has been an encouraging sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "Face the Music," a new musical comedy, on Wednesday night at the New Amsterdam Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Boys' Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Bank debits increased outside New York City during the week ended Feb. 20, but were less than in the corresponding period last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made pubic today by the Department of Commerce.

ANDOVER, Mass., Feb. 27 -- Dorman's shattering of the school record for the 600-yard run featured the annual track meet today between Andover and the Harvard freshmen, which was won by the Crimson cubs by 44 to 37.

ERNST LUBITSCH, the German maestro of the camera, is not possessed of the qualities usually associated with a maestro. In town from Hollywood for the opening of "One Hour With You," the new Chevalier picture, Herr Lubitsch presented himself as a small, live man with a pleasant foreign accent and dancing black eyes.

TODAY 12:00 M -- David A. Brown, chairman of the China Famine Relief, will consider various phases of the Sino-Japanese situation when he speaks at WMCA's studio today. Mr. Brown, who has spent considerable time in the Orient, has selected "Behind the Japanese Screen" as the title of his talk.

FOR those in any degree acquainted with Trotsky's career and his writings it is not at all easy to think of him in the act of doing justice to a defeated opponent or being charitable to an opinion or a policy that runs counter to his own.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was very much Interested the other night in a lecture by one of the experts of the New York Zoo who had been in Australasia collecting birds of paradise and who explained how these birds had associated together in dancing.
DAIREN, Manchuria, Feb. 27 -- A new Manchurian State bank is to open March 31 with a paid up capital of $20,000,000 (Mexican) and branches in all important cities and towns.

THE Washington Conference was essentially a disarmament conference, aimed to promote the possibility of peace in the world not only through the cessation of competition in naval armament but also by the solution of various other disturbing problems which threatened the peace of the world, particularly in the Far East.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27 -- No general change is expected in the Yale athletic program, according to the present outlook, although organization of intramural sports is expected to be under way within a year, it was stated today by Yale athletic officials.

This is a book of haphazard -- not scientific -- exploration. Gory, hardboiled and reckless, it is a grand yarn that gives the "lowdown" on the jungle.

For the second time of the Winter season Madison Square Garden will be given over to the six-day bicycle riders this week. Starting tonight, thirty cyclists will engage in a long, wearying quest of victory in New York's fifty-second international contest.

In The London Times's review of the past financial year, published during the present month, England's abandonment of gold payments is discussed by Mr. HARTLEY WITHERS, former editor of The London Economist and an experienced writer on British finance. In regard to some of the considerations involved in that action, he is more frank than most other British authorities on the subject have been.

Except for New Hampshire and Massachusetts, every one of the twenty-two States bordering on the nation's seaboards participated in the intercoastal trade carried by American ships during the last year, according to the United States Shipping Board.

The seven remaining seeded players came through the second-round matches in the national Class B squash tennis championship at the Columbia Club yesterday with flying colors, only one of them being at all hard pressed.

As the month draws to a close, It becomes apparent that it will prove a disappointment to retail merchants, according; to the market report especially prepared for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. Spring business, the report says, has not yet had an opportunity to get Under way, and the volume of orders has shown a material decrease, which is reflected in the current lull in wholesale markets.

PASADENA. UNIQUE among modern institutions of learning is the International School of Advanced Science at Pasadena, which is just concluding its annual two months' Winter term. One need only say that here Einstein is both professor and pupil to suggest that this is such a school as the sun has rarely shone upon.

PARIS, Feb. 13 IT is rare for a playwright to attempt to dramatize an abstract poetical idea, and rarer still for him to succeed. Simon Gantillon, who in "Maya" was able to indicate some of the most spiritual aspects of the surrender of woman to man behind its most abject and humiliating and animal expression, has attempted, in his new play, "Bifur," to find a very different symbol for almost the same thing.

LUCERNE. Que., Feb. 27 UP).Dartmouth captured the first two places In the figure skating event tonight to take the lead in the annual championship meet' of "the Intercollegiate Winter Sports Union of North America.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Sir Ernest Benn. offered this week the first six of a series of new novels by wellknown authors to be published at the price of ninepence-18 cents at par. This is admittedly an experimental and revolutionary development in the English publishing world.

DECIPHERING the inscriptions on stone relics dug up by archaeologists requires considerable ingenuity and specialized knowledge. A sentence of old Latin, abbreviated, on a loculus -- in this case a small marble box for the ashes of a dead person -- was recently translated by experts at the Metropolitan Museum and a story involving "human interest" resulted.
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Terry Druggan, Chicago "beer baron," entered the Federal prison annex today to serve a thirty months' sentence for failure to pay his income tax.

Chief Judge Benjamin N. Cardozo has summoned the Court of Appeals to meet in special session in Albany next Thursday, at which a decision is expected on whether State Senator John A. Hastings can be sent to jail for contempt of the Hofstadter committee while the Legislature is in session.
Frank Ward, world's open squash tennis champion since 1926, successfully defended his title yesterday at the Hotel Shelton.

PARIS, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Former King Alfonso XIII and his uncle, Alfonso Carlos, traditional pretender to the Spanish throne, have issued a call to Spanish people, the Havas News Agency repotted today, to join together to overthrow the new republic in Spain.
The text of former Governor Smith's address yesterday at a meeting of the National Democratic Club follow:

ONE of the more serious enterprises arranged for the Lenten season is the series of Monday night lectures by Dom Urban Butler, O.S.B., of St. John's Priory, Bath, England, to be given in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Good Shepherd Auxiliary.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 25 -- The City Charter Committee, the civic organization which fought for, obtained and continues to fight for good government in Cincinnati, learned early that women are an integral part of politics. It also learned that campaigns should be conducted upon principles, rather than personalities; that men and women do not follow leaders, but causes.

THIS book is Fascism's own apologia in which the Duce's lieutenants to the number of almost forty, each writing of a branch of its work, of which he has special knowledge, tell of its achievements. Its editor is one of the Duce's trusted spokesmen, who is the founder and editor of La Rassegna Itallana, a monthly magazine accounted the most important periodical of Fascist Italy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A serious aggravation of the already strained financial situation of the Japanese Government will result from the flotation of domestic loans which are believed necessitated by the constantly increasing costs of its military operations in China, according to a cablegram received today by the Department of Commerce from Halleck A. Butts.

THE posthumous publications from the pen of D.H. Lawrence are growing in number. Not so long ago came "The Man Who Died,'' a strange mingling of allegory, fantasy and ethical fire that revolved around the figure of the risen Christ.

IN organizing his New York Philharmonic Dance Group, von Grona approaches a big undertaking with great temerity, for his idea, if it proves to be successful, may very easily effect something of a revolution in the concert dance business in New York.

THIS book represents another voice in the great chorus of protest against the materialism and the aimless self-seeking of the modem world. It represents an attempt to strike down beneath the garish surface to those fundamentals which alone can give purpose and meaning to existence: it endeavors to extricate the permanent values from amid the merely meretricious, the solid and basic realities from amid those which are only apparent and ephemeral.
PARIS, Feb. 26 -- Now that France has emerged from the political crisis, which had turned all eyes to internal affairs, Paris again is beginning to take stock of the great international questions.

Unemployment continues to be widespread throughout the country Watch-Tower correspondents of THE TIMES report. Here and there some recovery is observed but this is believed to be seasonal and unenduring. Energetic measures of relief, however, appear to be alleviating acute distress.

ORIGINALITY and distinction in decoration mark the up-to-date dialog table. A variety of colors in china and glass appears. White and green or delicate flowers are replaced, except for very formal occasions, by bright-hued blossoms which often are in contrast with one another and with the colors of the accessories.

The pxperiment of the F.W. Woolworth Company in retailing articles at 20 cents will be officially launched this week in most of the 100 stores chosen for the initial test, it was stated yesterday by H.T. Parson, presidpnt of the company. Shipments of the new marchandise have been steadily going forward, and as fast as the goods arrive they "Will be put on sale in units in the San Francisco, Denver, Dallas and Atlanta districts.

When the Euneva, Corporation, William H. Amend. secretary, bought from Myles J. Walsh, the southeast corner of Avenue A ano Fifth street, 92 by 100 feet. the buyer gave to William J. and Alfred J. Amend a mortgage for $29.237, payable, ten years hence at 6 per cent, and subject to a first mortgage for $100.000.

With a total volume only slightly in excess of 400,000 shares on the Stock Exchange, the market came almost to a standstill yesterday. Wall Street on the whole welcomed the lethargy as evidence that selling was drying up. Not only was business extremely dull, but fluctuations were confined to very narrow range.

DIMENSIONS are only too apt to steal away our brains when we come to matters of art. Something large is important, what is small we can afford to Ignore. A "layman" was once speaking of a collection in which were a few large reproductive etchings in addition to original etching's by Alden Weir, Childe Hassam and other Americans, also a priceless Meryon, "The Palaces" by Whistler, one of the small Rembrandt landscapes.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 25 -- The demand of Charles M. Thomas, Oregon State Public Utilities Commissioner, that jurisdiction of the lower branches of the Federal courts be restricted in cases involving appeals of utilities from orders of the commission, accompanied by the statement that if not restricted, Oregon would launch an extensive program of public ownership, has thrown a new subject of controversy into the general field of public utility regulation.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Japanese Manchurian forces struck a sharp blow in defense of the new Northeastern Federated State today by attacking and defeating a force of Chinese insurgents under General Wang Teh-lin. The battle took place twenty-five miles northwest of Tunhua after the burning of a bridge on the Kirin-Tunhua Railway by the Chinese.

A rally in the third period enabled the Savage girls' basketball team to triumph over the New Tork University girls, 36 to 12. at the winning sextet's court yesterday. The teams were deadlocked at the half, 10-10, after the Violet had gained a 7-to-1 advantage in the first quarter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Congress has been greatly stirred by Mr. Stimson's sudden change of tactics in the Far Eastern crisis. One hears very little else discussed at both ends of the Capitol, though it is now several days since the Secretary of State gave up writing to Tokyo and started in to address his notes to Senator Borah.

With only one of Its components showing a rise, the index of business activity has dropped to a new low record for the current depression. The preliminary index for the week ended Feb. 20 is 61.2, as against 62.3 for the preceding week and 76.7 for the corresponding week last year.
WEST POINT, N.T., Feb. 27 -- Columbia won a closely contested meet from Army today, the Blue and White swimmers scoring by 37-34 by virtue of their victory in the final event, the 400-yard relay.

The Radio Corporation of America is actively engaged, directly and through subsidiaries, in simplifying its capital structure and coordinating operations in the various pursuits in which the subsidiaries are engaged. The operation, in the main, affects the structure of the parent company itself and of the RCA Victor Company, principal manufacturing and sales unit in the group.

Confidence Is Needed. A dollar in the bank is worth from five to ten times as much as it is in your or my pocket. By the same token a stock in a holding company is, potentially, worth ten times as much as it is in your or my tin box. The minute you begin legislating against arithmetic you get in trouble.

BIRMINGHAM, Feb. 25 -- The voice that led 173 roll-calls at Madison Square Garden in 1924 with "Alabama casts twenty-four votes for Underwood" is going to lead again at Chicago in June when the Democratic party assembles in national convention.

The recent decision by Mayor Walker and the Board of Estimate to discuss transit unification with the Transit Commission and representatives of the B.M.T. and Interborough at conferences apart from the public hearings on the commission's tentative $474,500,000 plan has the support of four of the city's leading business and civic organizations.
Sugar and wool tops were the only commodities in the local futures markets which declined in price last week. Offsetting their losses were gains in silver, cocoa, coffee and hides.

Four examples of school buildings designed in the modern style of architecture, stressing freedom of planning and an abundance of windows, are attracting the attention of educators visiting the architectural exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, 730 Fifth Avenue.

VIENNA, Feb. 9 -- "Gott verlasst keinen deutschen" -- "God never deserts a German" -- is an honored German proverb which many German-Austrian inventors are recalling today on receipt of the unexpected good tidings that after a lapse of from twelve to sixteen years, they are to receive together a sum totalling one million dollars for their inventions.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Lieut. Commander C.E. Rosendahl, captain of the navy dirigible Akron, vigorously denied tonight published reports that he had taken the ship out of the hangar Monday under pressure from Rear Admiral William A. Moffett at Washington.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga. -- In addition to the regular weekly events, trap and skeet tournaments on Monday and Thursday; a cruise to Cabin Bluff, the Sea Island shooting preserve on the mainland, on Tuesday; archery, bowling-on-the-green competitions on Wednesday and Saturday, and the dinner dances at the Cloister on Monday, Wednesday and Saturday evenings, there are several other events scheduled for the present week.

VARIOUS philanthropic organizations have arranged card parties in conjunction with luncheon and supper parties, musicales and other entertainments in the near future as a means of augmenting their funds for charitable work.

Athletes whose competitive days are behind them and those of the younger generation who are still participating in tests of skill, speed and stamina, exchanged views recently on the relative rigors of various sports. The consensus of the group, based on the experience of those taking part in the informal but keen discussion, was that basketball is the sport which takes the greatest toll of stamina.

An exhibition in Schermerhorn Hall, Columbia University, called, "Depressions the World Has Lived Through," conducted under the auspices of the Rare Book Department of the Columbia Library, displays volumes which indicate that the present depression bears a remarkably close resemblance to others that the world has survived in the past 200 years.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Viscount Cecil of Cheiwood presided at an emergency meeting of the general council of the League of Nations Union today to discuss the situation in the Far East and mobilize all the resources of the Union for the cessation of hostilities at Shanghai and for the vindication of the League covenant.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 -- According to official statistics employment in the seven States embraced in this Federal Reserve district hit a new low in January. Data for February are not yet available. Those in closest touch with the situation express a hope rather than a conviction that this month will be no worse than last.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 27 (AP) -- American residents of Shanghai received detailed instructions from the United States Consulate today on what to do in the event it becomes necessary to evacuate the city. Consular authorities sent out registration cards on which each citizen was asked to note his address, telephone number and other necessary data.

CHRIST CHURCH, New Zealand, Feb. 27 (AP) -- South Africa and New Zealand began their first cricket test match today. New Zealand batted first and scored 293, after which South Africa tallied 29 runs without losing a wicket before stumps were drawn for the day.
WASHINGTON, D.C. SHOULD there be an unbiased technical agency to pass upon the safety of new motor car designs and appliances before they are manufactured and submitted to the public for purchase?

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- After a close study of the "economies" effected by the Republican-controlled Legislature through the elimination from the budget-bill of items amounting to $21,000,000, Governor Roosevelt today returned that measure to the law-making body with a memorandum in which he sharply condemned what had been done as lacking in wisdom and regard for the proper functioning of the State Government.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 -- Al Hapke of Yale shattered the tank record in the 220-yard free style as the Elis defeated Pennsylvania in an Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet in Hutchinson Pool today, 47 to 24. It was Yale's fourth straight conquest in the association.

Time was when the physicist blushed because he was omniscient and excused his inability to explain the world deterministically for lack of necessary facts. Now he glories in his ignorance. EDDINGTON is especially happy. "In the pres"ent theory of the physical universe we "have at last reached something which "a reasonable man might almost be"lieve."

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 28 -- Japanese airplanes bombed the Chinese positions on the Chapei-Kiaingwan battlefront today as both sides rused reinforcements toward Kiangwan, centre point of the line from Shanghai to Woosung, in preparation for a new battle.

AFTER a survey trip over very familiar ground to him, Captain Frank M. Hawks is satisfied that his doctrine of speed is winning new followers in aviation. In the course of a four weeks' tour over the system of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., Hawks found that American transport operators were looking toward a still faster pace with the advent of new planes now being considered for purchase.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Murray Whiting Ferris gave a dinner last night at the Plaza for Count Clarence von Rosen of Stockholm, Sweden; his daughter, Countess Maude von Rosen, and Mrs. Kurt Ruhrseitz.
