BALTIMORE, Feb. 27 -- A petition asking President Hoover and Congress to signify that the United States will concur in the economic measures which may be taken by the League of Nations to restore peace in the Far East has been signed by the members of Johns Hopkins university faculty.

PASADENA, Cal., Feb. 27 -- International affairs and peace were discussed before the representatives of eleven Southern California Universities here tonight by Dr. Albert Einstein, Dr. Robert A. Millikan and Dr. Charles A. Bear.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Memories of campaign days in the Philippines were combined with satire on current political topics tonight as several hundred veterans celebrated the Annual Wallow of the Military Order of the Carabao.

ELKINS, W. Va., Feb. 25 -- Considerable impetus was given to the movement for Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt at a mass meeting of Democrats from all sections of the State at Huntingdon last Saturday. The meeting was suggested by Democratic leaders, including United States Senator M.M. Neely and the two Democratic members of the Congressional delegation, Lynn S. Hornor of the Third District and Joe L. Smith of the Sixth District.

LAKE PLACID. BOBSLEDDING, new to the American continent in its modern racing aspect, is among the most thrilling and daring of international amateur sports. It is an expatriate American sport which attained its majority on the bob runs of the Alps; it came back two years ago to the country of its origin.

JOHN BARRYMORE, appearing with his brother Lionel in "Arsene Lupin" at the Capitol, is not simply a rogue in his new characterization, but a French rogue. That made a difference. Like a good actor, he examined the records of the Paris Surete the Gallic Scotland Yard while preparing himself for the role of Lupin in the screen translation of the play by Maurice Le Blanc and Francis de Croisset.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Forecasts of sensational disclosures about "bear raiding" on the New york Stock Exchange failed to materialize today, when the Senate Banking and Currency Committee met to consider complaints voiced yesterday by Senator Walcott of Connecticut after a visit to the White House.

YOUNG men of society will experiance a complete reversal of custom tomorrow night when they find themselves the guests of honor at the Third Leap-Year Assembly, which will be held in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- As military experts in Washington see the Shanghai conflict today, both the Japanese and Chinese forces are showing signs of weariness, and they would not be surprised at a sudden ending of the undeclared war.

SOME twenty-five years ago, though it hardly seems so long, a very young actress whose stage name was Elsie Janis and whose real name was Elsie Bierbower flashed upon New York and soon had most of the town more or less at her feet.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 27 -- The Mexico City suburb of Azcapotzalco was threatened with destruction early today as the result of a fire due to the breakage of the Aguila Oil Company's twelve-inch pipe through which petroleum is pumped from Tampico to this city.

Joseph Fahys was found dead of a shot in the head yesterday on the floor of the bathroom in his home at 3,018 Johnson Avenue, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Lying beside him was the service pistol he used in France. Although members of his family insisted that he must have shot himself accidentally while cleaning the weapon, police listed his death as suicide.

Announcement yesterday of the sale of the former Seth Low home at 30 East Sixty-fourth Street, south west corner of Madison Avenue, with the adjoining house at 28, formerly owned by Irving T. Bush, provided not only the most interesting realty news of the week but also, outside of foreclosure sales, the most important realty transaction of the year.

MADRID, Feb. 25 -- Less than one year ago Spain was just a second rate monarchy with a picturesque King and an old "black legend" of air castles and bullfighters a la Carmen. Today she is trying an experiment in advanced precepts and teetering on the edge of greater extremities with the next few months to decide pretty well which way the weight will fall.

WASHINGTON. OGDEN MILLS has moved his office from the east end to the west end of the great gray stone structure which stretches along Fifteenth Street. As I entered the large room with its blue walls and mahogany furniture and the new Secretary of the Treasury looked up from the great desk at which he sat, inadvertently I thought of his predecessor.

IN "Lorenzo in Taos" we have been given a book that is autobiographical in that the volume contains many letters from D.H. Lawrence, but one that is more expressly biographical, because it is a narrative by Mabel Dodge Luhan of the years spent by Lawrence and his wife in New Mexico, whither they had journeyed at Mrs. Luhan's suggestion.

DEVOTEES of the Bronte circle will be delighted with this little volume. In addition to the story there is an intelligent and informative preface and a facsimile of the title page in the familiar handwriting. The manuscript was written when Charlotte was 18, and has lain, since it was picked up in Brussels in 1892, along with other of the voluminous Bronte juvenilia in the British Museum.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 27 -- Mrs. Blanche H. Karsch of Memphis, who was taken from an orphanage on lower Fifth Avenue in New "York City in 1881 to become the ward of a Catholic nun, received clear title today to the $3,500,000 estate left by her foster mother, Mrs. Kate E. Hamilton, sister of the nun.

The past year was one of unusual adversity in the petroleum industry; prices dropped to the lowest levels since 1915. profits were small, failures of companies were many, and the industry was at a loss to regulate its affairs intelligently, according to the annual petroleum review of J. Edward Jones.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Wheat traders are regarded as having adopted policy of watchful waiting, and no material activity developed today on either side of the market on the Board of Trade. Prices held within a range of about 3/4 cent and closed unchanged to 1/4 cent higher than yesterday after being off around 1/2 cent early.
The Glass-Steagall act provides for a very large increase in Federal Reserve notes to a maximum amount of $2,936,075,000. The machinery by which this result can be accomplished works as follows:

BOGOTA, Feb. 27 -- From Fusagasuga, where President Enrique Olaya Herrera is summering, he telegraphed General Augustin Morales Olaya. Minister of Government in Bogota, yesterday, condemning public manifestations in several State capitals by Liberal political groups, apparently militarily organized.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 25 -- The unemployment condition in the Northern Ohio "American Ruhr" this month is alternately estimated to be a little worse than at any time in the year previous or a little better than the "worst," which some unemployment agencies place at mid-January.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 27 -- Dartmouth defeated Princeton, 3 -- 2, in a spirited hockey duel today. The Tigers tied the Green twice, then Captain Bill Morton lifted a blue-line shot, with a minute and a quarter to go, into the net and won the game.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The conferees on the Norris "lame duck" resolution, to change the dates when the terms of the President Vice President and members of Congress would end, and on which the Congress would meet, reached complete agreement today and will submit their report to the Senate and House on Monday.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Having established new world's automobile speed records for five different distances, Sir Malcolm Campbell of England is preparing to return home, but he has accepted tentatively an invitation to come back next year in an effort to boost the marks still higher.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- Army's speedy pololsts rode to another victory today, defeating a fast-traveling Harvard trio in a well-played game by a score of 14 to 8. The Cadets were led in their attack by George Grunert who scored eight of the victors' goals.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 27 -- Samuel Seabury refused to comment today on declaration in New York that he had adopted an attitude opposed to Governor Roosevelt and was seeking the Presidential nomination or the office of Mayor of New York.

With the production of gold declining, "limited bimetalism at no fixed ratio seems to offer a possible solution that meets all requirements, "according to Francis H. Brownell, chairman of the American Smelting and Refining Company. This plan is "not only logical in itself, but is in the nature of a compromise between the gold extremists and the free silver advocates," he adds.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Dr. James Chadwick, working in Cavendish Laboratory at Cambridge, has discovered the neutron -- one of the ultimate patricles of nature. The discovery, first made public today, was hailed by scientists here as the most important achievement in experimental physics since Lord Rutherford demonstrated the nuclei structure of the atom in 1911.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27 -- Dances were given this afternoon by the Yale College chapters of Psi Upsilon and Delta Kappa Epsilon and by the Sheffield Scientific School societies, the Cloister, St. Anthony, the Colony, Vernon Hall, St. Elmo, Frank Hall, York Hall and Sachem Hall, and the Yale University society, Book and Bond.

OUR excavations at Jericho have quickly yielded results. We began by making a systematic search for the tombs of the Bronze Agre, of which one remarkable example had been found in the previous year, anticipating that their contents would provide a firm basis for interpreting the city's history and might enrich our knowledge of the civilization of Canaan.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27 -- The New York University freshman track team was defeated by the Yale cubs today, 65 to 42. Fatseas of the Violets was high individual scorer, tallying 13 points. Brown of the Elis won the high jump and pole vault.

Corporate structures are being overhauled in wholesale fashion these days and the movement, rapidly gathering momentum, is cutting deeply into the total of listed shares. Already in 1932 thirty-six companies have made capital readjustments designed to reduce the number of shares outstanding or to write down the book value of stocks.

With the stock market displaying an irregularly lower trend last week, the financial community once more turned to the bond market for inspiration. Prices in all the bond groups, United States Government and foreign and domestic corporation, averaged almost steadily higher and the trading pace was more nearly normal than in the case of stocks.

Because THE NEW YORK TIMES, in referring to ALFRED SMITH'S announced willingness to be a Presidential candidate again this year, expressed the hope that the "abhorrent and un-American dragging of religion into politics" would not soon be witnessed again, the charge has been made that it has surrendered to anti-Catholic bigotry.

AN unusually large number of plays and novels are being adapted to the screen for forthcoming Metro -- Goldwyn-Mayer productions. Each of the six pictures now under way at Culver City is derived from a play or novel. In one case, that of "Grand Hotel," a novel and play by the same author were used in making the screen adaptation.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 27 -- Observance of the centenary of the writing of "America" assumes added significance in Minneapolis because the oldest grandchild of the Rev. Samuel Francis Smith, the author, lives here and for several years was custodian of the original manuscript.

MIAMI BEACH -- Although still more than a month away, arrangements for the State American Legion Convention to take place at Miami Beach April 7-9 are already commanding the attention of sojourners from the North. Many visitors will extend their stay here and attend the reception to be accorded by Miami Beach to the Florida boys who served the country during the World War.

THE value of Professor Rappard's book is as might be expected, out of all proportion to its length. That is as it should be and rarely is in an age whose formula for attaining knowledge is to read less and less about more and more.

PORTRAITS by artists of Brooklyn and Manhattan are on view at the Grant Studios, Remsen Street, Brooklyn, until March 11. Portraits in lithography, etching, oils and water-colors, as well as sculpture, by Eleanor Bannister, Wilford S. Conrow, Frederick Detwiller, Adam Dabrowski, Joseph Margolies, Frederick T. Weber, Agnes Richmond and the late Charles M. Shean, are included.

Southern selling and week-end realizing were reflected yesterday by early declines on the Cotton Exchange here, but the comparatively moderate offerings were absorbed by continued trade buying and covering, causing recoveries in prices in the late trading.

In the opening chapter of TROTSKY'S history of the Russian Revolution of 1917, of which the first volume is reviewed in another section today, there occurs a single sentence of less than a dozen words which provides a truer perspective for the Five-Year Plan than is to be found in many an entire volume dealing with that subject.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The British people are in the grip of a treasurehunt that is less heroics but no less astonishing than the great gold rush of the Forty-niners.

ROME THE first fortnight of the Royal Opera season in Rome registered a local novelty with Pizzetti's ustere biblical drama, "Debora e Jaele." Marinuzzi, like Toscanini, is a stanch defender of Tldebrando da Parma, and to his championship is no doubt due the risky idealistic venture of bringing out his "problem-opera" in such unreceptive surroundings as the Royal Opera and its retrograde clientele.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- Vassar College honor lists were announced today by President MacCracken as follows:
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 27 -- The Dartmouth basketball team staged a late season come-back by upsetting the fast Cornell five tonight, 40 to 29, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basket-ball League game.

MUCH significance may be attached to the amendment to the air-commerce regulations drafted recently by Colonel Clarence M. Young, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aeronautics, and submitted by him to airline operators for criticism.

Having completed their rounds of the notable exhibitions on the Atlantic seaboard during the month of February, Western dog fanciers are homeward hound to prepare for their swing around the mid-Western circuit that will hold their attention until the beginning of the outdoor season.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 -- Behind the professions of alarm with which the Soviet is greeting the new "war" threat to the Socialist Fatherland by the White Guard invasion of Eastern Siberia under Japanese auspices," there is now audible a sterner not of anger and self-confidence.

AN attempt to turn the trick practiced by Stevenson and others of offering a fictional account of picaresque adventure as if it were a genuine record is the motive power behind the story of Jonathan Drew, "taken down" by Christopher Ward.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Indicating that the treasury has abandoned hope of a retroactive income tax increase to apply to 1931 incomes, the Internal Revenue Bureau today issued a statement urging that taxpayers file their returns promptly on the basis of the 1928 revenue act rates, which were applicable last year.
HAMILTON, Ont., Feb. 27 (AP) -- William Southam, founder and for forty years active head of the publishing and printing companies bearing his name, died here tonight. He was 88 years old.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Several packages of securities, which the police assert were stolen from the Irvington (N.J.) Trust Company by Maxwell A. Cox. former vice president, were turned over to the authorities today by Mrs. Marie Marx.

THIS latest addition to the "Intimate Guides" series of the John Day Company comes as a contribution to the bicentennial Washington celebration and in time to serve the needs of the long procession of tourists whose Mecca will be the national capital throughout this bicentennial year.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Howard E. Coffin, wife of the motor capitalist who developed this resort island and also Sapelo Island, on which their home is located, will be buried on Monday in Christ Church Cemetery at Frederica, St. Simon's Island.

NEW School for Social Research -- Lithographs, linoleum cuts and woodcuts by Gan Kolski, an exceedingly able technician, with a keen eye for dramatic values. Of special interest to students of the graphic arts. Opened Feb. 20, closes March 5. Reviewed Feb. 24.

HONOLULU, Feb. 27 -- Recent assaults on white women in Honolulu and the murder of a Hawaiian which followed are the inevitable result, of conditions brewing in the inland of, Oahu for years. There was a time when any white woman was safe in any part of the islands, and as long as she uses ordinary discretion she is still as safe as in any American mainland city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A report showing that articles had been received covering 75 per cent of persons to be included in the Dictionary of American Biography was made at the annual meeting of its management committee today by Dr. Dumas Malone, editor-in-chief.

Gene Venzke glanced over his shoulder on the last lap of the Columbian 1,500-meter invitation race it Madison Square Garden last night, but it was so much wasted effort. America's greatest miler had left his opponents far behind as he raced to a new world's indoor record of 3:53.4 for the Olympic equivalent of the mile in the thirteenth annual Knights of Columbus athletic carnival.

HAIL COLUMBIA" is a picture book of American history not only by right of Its illustrations but because it is written in a fashion that puts before the reader a succession of pictures even more arresting and vivid than its twenty delightful full-page drawings.

PARIS, Feb. 26 -- As far as Americans are concerned Paris is now the principal French Winter resort. This does not mean that the Riviera and other sunshine points around the Mediterranean are not attracting some of our countrymen, but the permanent American colony as well as transient visitors are inclined to remain near the capital to keep in touch with the economic and political developments.

Italian furniture of the sixteenth to eighteenth century, together with early velvets, damasks, brocades, tapestries and art objects selected from the stock of Louis Co. of NewYork, will be auctioned Friday and Saturday at the American. Art Associatlon-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

Declaring that the only hope of change in the prohibition laws lies in the Democratic party, former Governor Alfred E. Smith, in a speech at the forum of the National Democratic Club, announced yesterday his intention of fighting for the adoption of a home-rule prohibition control plank by the national convention.

TAUDENI! To most people the name, with its musical sound, means nothing. Yet it donates, in the depths of the Sahara, one of the blackest spots in human misery. It was in Timbuctoo several years ago that we first heard of it.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- With the ushering in of Spring the calendar here will be crowded with many colorful social and sports events. Golf will lead in the field of outdoor activities with the fourth annual Women's Mid-South Thirty-six-Hole Medal Tournament set for March 23-24.

FIVE years have passed since publication of Wilson MacDonald's "Out of the Wilderness," and in the interval his verse has won popularity in his native Canada and has been kindly received by scattered groups in the United States.

THE "automatic" copyright has many "pitfalls for the innocent infringer," and could be "almost perpetual," Louis Caldwell, representing the National Association of Broadcasters and former general counsel of the Federal Radio Commission, asserted before the House Committee on Patents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A prediction that a "civil disobedience campaign" in the Philippines and an Economic boycott" of the United States by the Filipinos would follow passage of the proposed Senate independence hill was made today by Dr. Hilario C. Moncado, founder of the New Philippine Modernist party.

LONDON, Feb. 16, 1932 THERE was a time when conductors could be taken to task for their neglect of color and bias for mezzoforte. Then came a race of conductors who made the welkin ring, and every symphonic movement, every overture seemed but a preparation for a climax to which all else was subservient.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 25 -- During the past week the lid has been lifted off the primary campaign for Democratic nominations to the United States Senate. Prior to the announcement by Bert E. Haney, former United States Shipping Board commissioner, that he would not run the Democrats had been delaying their preparations to send forward an opponent to Senator Frederick Steiwer.

The Bureau of Child Guidance of New York City, which will open its first clinic next month, is an "important reflection of the Board of Education's change in attitude toward its pupils," Dr. Leon "W. Goldrich, director of the new bureau, believes.

Butter. Receipts, 6.193 packages. The absence of buying support gave the market during the early trading a very weak tone and before business got under way prices declined 3/4c. The lower figures awakened a little better demand and the market closed steady on the basis of 22 1/2c for extras.

STOCKHOLM. AGAIN the Bernadottes! The descendants of Henri Bernadotte, the bourgeois lawyer of Pau, and his wife Jeanne have been poets and painters for the last hundred years. Thanks to the great Marshal Bernadotte, son of Henri and Jeanne, they have also been kings of Sweden but they have never been content to stand perched on their pedestals in the museum of history as the members of more ancient dynasties are.

The most striking of the reports of railroad earnings for January, which were issued yesterday was that of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad. This company reported an increase in net operating income for the month, as compared with January, 1931, the first increase announced by that or any other important line in many months.

IN London, not more than a penny bus ride from Charing Cross, there is a rooming house, 14 Drakesferry Road, in the front-room window of which there hangs a neatly lettered card -- "Apartments to Let."

The Bronx Tigers defeated the league-leading Providence Reds, 5 to 3, in a Canadian-American Hockey League engagement at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 3,500 saw the Tigers exhibit a sustained pace of furious skating which enabled them to hold on to second place while graining on the invaders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- President Hoover signed the Glass-Steagall credit expansion bill at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon and at the same time issued a statement saying that credit for the passage of the bill belonged to Democratic as well as Republican leaders and all the members of the Senate and House.

PINEHURST -- Every sport provided by Pinehurst will be in full operation this week as the Spring season program is expanded to meet the requirements of the increasing number of vacationists at the resort.
HAVANA, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Soldiers and police reserves will be ready tomorrow when Cuba's 700,000-odd qualified electors initiate the long-heralded reorganization of the three old political parties.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 27 -- The Harvard swimming team remained undefeated by topping Dartmouth, 41-30, today. It was the first Harvard swimming team to come to Hanover and, led by Benton Wood, the Crimson showed a well-rounded outfit.

THIS biography of the man who was the first really to "Fordize" journalism in the United States is of a semiauthorized character. Yet the distance which separates it from the usual pious headstone that often masquerades as biography could only be encompassed by sevenleague boots.

Class A stockholders of the Roxy Theatres Corporation, who because of the recent passing of the dividend on their stock are entitled to elect a majority of the board of directors, are being asked to form a voting trust to meet the problem of $1.500,000 bond maturities falling due in July and to negotiate film contracts with the Fox Film Corporation to replace those that will expire in about a month.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Representatives of several investment banking houses have been called before a Senate committee formed to inquire into long-term loans made to foreign borrowers. Critical questioning has sought to emphasize unethical features of certain issues; through innuendo familiar to politics, doubt has thereby been cast upon the wisdom and cleanliness of the entire foreign lending process.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Blair Academy and Lawrenceville School tied for the prep school swmiming championship of New Jersey today in a keenly contested meet in which each scored 31 points. Rutgers Prep finished third with 25.

DENVER, Feb. 27 -- A growing tendency of the people of the United States to interest themselves in international affairs, and particularly in the nation's foreign policy, has found expression in the Rocky Mountain States through Denver University's Foundation for the Advancement of the Social Sciences, now in its sixth year.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- There is no definite sign so far of a broad upward trend in the employment situation in the Philadelphia Federal Reserve district, embracing forty-eight counties of Eastern Pennsylvania, nine counties of Southern New Jersey and the State of Delaware.

BOSTON, Feb. 25 -- Rhode Island never ratified the Eighteenth Amendment. On the contrary, the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations sent its Attorney General to the United States Supreme Court to argue against the consitutionality of the amendment.

MONTREAL -- The Park Tobogganning Club now has two chutes open on the western slope of Mount Royal, and members and visitors from out of town are making the most of the remainder of the season, which only started this month.

The total of bonds called for redemption in February prior to their maturity dates was increased slightly last week. One industrial issue was added to the list, together with a few State and municipal loans. Including these additions, bonds redeemed in February now aggregate $36,491,000, compared with $70,718,000 in January and with $54,508,000 in February, 1931.

Students representing twenty-eight colleges and universities will meet at Brown University next Thursday for a three-day session of the New England Model League of Nations Asembly. The exact procedure of the League, of Nations will be followed. with delegate representing the various countries belonging to the League being seated just as they are at Geneva.

Mayor CERMAK of Chicago is taking a week's vacation. One cannot blame him for seeking a respite from the cares of an office beset with unprecedented difficulties. The city's plight seems to have been growing increasingly serious, with the stream of taxes shrunk to a trickle and hundreds of employes clamoring for back pay.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- British Government funds continued active on the Stock Exchange today. Prices advanced at the opening, but profit-taking caused a decline to the overnight levels. Industrials generally were firm, although early strength in the textiles was not maintained.

The question of whether a change of venue will be asked in the case of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banking, who is scheduled to go on trial again March 14 in the Court of General Sessions on a charge of neglect of duty in delaying to close the Bank of United States, will be decided tomorrow or Tuesday.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 25 -- The riotous cheers heard in Cleveland just now are from the throats of Democrats eyeing hungrily more than 4,000 city jobs to which their leader, Mayor Ray T. Miller, and their organization fell heir this week.

Eventual world-wide restoration of the gold standard was predicted last night by Dr. Edwin E. Kemmerer. economist, in an address at a dinner of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking at the Waklorf-Astoria Hotel. Dr. Kemmerer also asserted that the large gold holding of the United State and France were explained by the fact that they provided safe repositories for gold.

The first half of the program which Josef Lhevinne, pianist, presented yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall consisted of Brahms -- the romance in F major, and the sonata in F minor No. 5. They were followed by Liszt, the Chopin polonaise in F sharp minor, two Scriabin mazurkas and an etude in major thirds, and Balakireff's "Islamey."

Bond prices pointed higher yesterday in the brief trading period on the Stock Exchange. Leading foreign loans showed the most strength, United States Government bonds ended generally higher and domestic corporation issues were about evenly balanced.

A MILLION jobs for a million men is the goal set by the War Against Depression Campaign Committee. Its drive opened on Feb. 15, and already more than 90,000 jobs have been found for unemployed throughout the country.

THIS translation performs a very great service to English-speaking students and admirers of Italian literature. While from the purely technical point of view de Sanctis's work is something less than a history of literature, in the broader sense it is something infinitely greater.

HAVANA, Feb. 27 -- Charging that Thomas I. Chadbourne, author of the Chadbourne plan, has not only attempted to assume control of Cuba's sugar industry but has discredited the Sugar Institute before the International Council, sugar mill owners are circulating a petition demanding that the American be removed from the presidency of the National Sugar Exporting Corporation.

ONE of the many Lenten projects that is enlisting the aid of prominent men and women is the concert to be given on Saturday night at the County Centre at White Plains by the Manhattan Symphony Orchestra, under the auspices of the Social Service Committee of Grasslands Hospital of Valhalla, N.Y. Julia Peters will be the soloist of the evening.

THE Spinsters' supper dance and entertainment, an annual event of much interest to younger members of society, will be held Friday night in the ballroom of the Park Lane. The dance committee -- calling itself the Spinsters -- is composed of graduates of the Spence School, representing the classes of the past four years.

HAVANA -- Benefits sponsored by prominent members of both Cuban and American society for victims of the recent earthquake, which almost destroyed the historic city of Santiago de Cuba, hold important place on the Havana society and sports calendars for the coming week.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Daily News, published by Frank Knox, chairman of President Hoover's citizen's reconstruction organization to end hoarding, commenting today on Henry Ford's plan for a vast automobile building and marketing program, said:

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Britain's great radium "bomb" has been, exploded. The experimental instrument for deep radium therapy, containing four grams of the precious element, in which about $200,000 has been expended by the National Radium Commission, has not yielded satisfactory results.

ABOUT two years ago metallurgists and engineers began to discuss hopefully the possibilities of beryllium. Here was a metal which had been known for more than a hundred years. It was about a third lighter than aluminum and much more resistant to corrosion and chemical action.

PALM BEACH -- Contrary to former seasons when the first week of March brought strong indications of the swift decline of a brief and brilliant season, the plans for this week, repeating the precedent established last year, display signs of a continuance of activities which will, in all probability, run until the first of April.

More than 350 nigh schools reported last week that they were well along in their quest for student champions to enter the National Oratorical Contest, conducted in this region by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Picturesque community events are planned in various localities in connection with the approaching district eliminations.

TOKYO, Feb. 27 (AP) --There is no likelihood that Japan will court another international crisis with Russia, government spokesmen said today in commenting on the questions addressed by Russia to Japan in regard to Japanese military operations in Northern Manchuria.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 27 -- George W. Page, State Bank Commissioner; Emory L. Coblentz, former State Senator, and other officials of the Central Trust Company of Frederick City, which with its eleven branches in western and central Maryland closed last September, were indicted today by the Howard County grand jury.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Governor Roosevelt's special message to the Legislature today relating to Long Island park and parkway funds read as follows:

A new high record of earnings in the thirty-year history of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation and its predecessor is revealed in the annual report for 1931, which shows a net income of $1,205,159 after depreciation, interest and taxes, equivalent, after preferred dividends, to $1.84 a share on 360,756 participating shares and 186,000 founders' shares.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Business conditions remain unimproved in most foreign markets, but there has been an increased demand for some American products in the Far East as a result of the Chinese boycott of Japanese goods, according to the weekly survey of business abroad issued by the Department of Commerce.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 27 -- Governor Roosevelt of New York received more votes than any other Presidential possibility in a straw ballot which has just been, completed in President Hoover's home State by The Des Moines Register-Tribune. Governor Roosevelt's margin over President Hoover was fifty-three votes.

THE big bear hunt in Wall Street has been resumed with fresh energy, spurred on by warnings from the White House and by threats of stern measures in Congress. By implication at least, President Hoover has given the Stock Exchange to understand that it must stop "bear raiding" or face the consequences of legislative regulation.

ARMED minions of the law, cruising through the city's are now snatching alarms streets in radio-equipped cars, from the air. These vigilant patrols are no longer entirely dependent upon alarm boxes, the telephone and signal lights, now that the New York police transmitter WPEG is on the air twenty-four hours a day.

HOW increased production in automobile factories may aid unemployment is indicated by a report from the Packard Motor Car Company stating that the putting to work of more than 8,000 persons on full time in the company's factory means that between 5,000 and 6,000 additional employes have returned to work on full-time schedules in the plants of companies providing materials for Packard cars.

NORMAN blood, which has had forty years to recover from its unfavorable comparison to simple faith in the verse of the late Lord Tennyson, is having new doubt cast upon it in England. This time it is not a poet's flight of fancy but the open skepticism of the Society of Genealogists of Great Britain.

WITH little more than a month left until Easter, the stores have been putting more effort into the task of clearing out Winter merchandise. The week did not bring much increase in sales volume but some interest was reported in the Spring designs now being introduced on a larger scale.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- N'gi, 6-year-old gorilla of the National Zoological Park, had improved somewhat today under medical treatment for bronchial pneumonia, from which he has been suffering more than a week.

NATIONALISM and interntionalism as opposed Ideals have come prominently t the fore, with two debates which these grave issues were thrashed out. One of the battles was fought last Tuesday evening at the Whitney Museum of American Art; the other at the New School for Social Research on Thursday evening -- too late in the week, unfortunately, to permit our making any use of the returns here.
To the Dramatic Editor: Intellectual property is being imperiled from different and newly active sources. These menaces seriously concern not only authors and inventors but also the public at large.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 -- Philadelphia blanked New York, 6 to 0, in the annual Intercity Court Tennis Doubles match today at the Racquet Club. New York has yet to score a victory in this series.

Morris, Richmond Hill and Textile remained undefeated by scoring their third victories in the second annual city P.S.A.L. championship fencing tournament at the Washington Irving High School yesterday during the third Saturday of the competition.

WHIPPING as a punishment for criminals was revived in a New Jersey court recently, when a Judge sentenced three boys to receive ten lashes each with a belt. The legality of the sentence was immediately attacked, raising a question: Where does flogging as a legal punishment survive?
VIENNA, Feb. 27 -- Almost $30,000,000 worth of Austrian schillings are now hoarded, mostly in the form of 1,000-schilling notes, according to oficial figures today.

Opposition to the proposed bill before Congress dealing with "Federalized education" was recorded yesterday by a group of Catholic women of national prominence at the semiannual meeting of the directors of the Catholic Daughters of America, held at the headquarters of the organization.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- Rear Admiral Colby Mitchell Chester, retired, oldest living Admiral of the United States Navy, will be 88 on Monday, but it was only for the celebration of his twenty-first birthday that his son, Arthur Cheater, began planning tonight at the Chester home on Locust Avenue here.

Powerful elements in the United States are agitating for inflation to restore at least a part of the values lost in the past two years, says Bernhard Ostrolenk, Professor of Economics at the College of the City of New York, in March Current History.

To the Art Editor: IT is characteristic of a condition of spiritual unemployment always more widespread in America than physical unemployment at its worst that the significance of the Stieglitz exhibition of photography at An American Place should be completely missed by our art reporters.

A PROPOSAL before the Geneva Disarmament Conference for the abolition of peacetime conscription, or compulsory military service, has directed attention to the extent to which this form of war preparedness is practiced today. The United States and Great Britain, with their traditional aversion to conscription, have long maintained in peacetime small professional armies recruited by voluntary enlistment.

THANKS to the inevitable procrastination a growing pile of single records encourages, and the surprisingly interesting, if slightly curtailed, run of complete sets we have been enjoying during the past few weeks, the occasional resume of vocals has been put off for rather longer than usual, with the result that the accumulation contains much that is worth inspection.

THERE are a bleased quietude and garruious charm about Maria Edgeworth's letters that make them peculiarly engrossing on a snowy night when one is seated before a good logblaze in a large fireplace. Maria was small, bright and quick-witted, observant, humorous and intelligent.

IN the annals of Ireland a new chapter opens. The fourth election held under the completed Constitution of the Free State has resulted in a victory for the Republicans. After lasting into its tenth year, the Presidency of William T. Cosgrave is thus brought, in effect, to an end, and the succession falls to Eamon de Valera.

HAVANA, Feb. 24 -- Government finance in Cuba must be divorced from politics if the republic is to put her fiscal house in order, Dr. E.R. A. Seligman, world-known American economist, whose report and recommendations for the reform of the entire fiscal system of the island is now being studied by the Cuban Government, told the American Chamber of Commerce in Cuba at a luncheon given in his honor recently.

NOW that Ernest B. Schoedsack is back from India. Paramount is thinking about its production of "The Lives of a Bengal Lancer," for which Mr. Schoedsack made the native outdoor scenes on his recent expedition. John Cromwell has been assigned to direct the film version of Francis Yeats-Brown's adventure biography in collaboration with Mr. Schoedsack.

LONDON WHO owns the sky? The owner of the property beneath it. This is English law, according to Lord Dunedin, who is a member of the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council. As the Judicial Committee is, in effect, the supreme court of the empire, it may be taken that its members are the highest of all legal authorities in England.

JOHN and Lionel Barrymore are together at the Capitol in "Ar Lupin." From a Paris stage piece on which Maurice LeBlanc, author of the Lupin dective stories. Collaborated with Francis de Criosset. John is the wily Parisian crook and Lionel is the equally wily French detective in the story.

PARIS, Feb. 26 -- The police and public of Paris were startled this week by a daylight bank hold-up in the central district of the city, executed with typical American gangster methods. The bandits, who escaped unimpeded with $5,000 in banknotes, are believed to be foreigners; and the Parisian press is viewing with alarm the prospect of such enterprises, which have been uncommonly few in the past, being transplanted into France.

At the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Glee Club contest held last night in Carnegie Hall. Yale University won first place with a lead of 16 points. New York University, winner of last year's contest, Princeton, Columbia and Rutgers clubs followed in the order named.
GENEVA, Feb. 27 -- Unanimity still marks the work of the Disarmament Conference, at least as far as its organization goes.

THE extra day of leap year comes up for its quadrennial dele of attention. The civil calendar tacks it on to the end of February. The ancient Romans slipped it in between the 24th and the 25th, and the ecclesiastical calendar carries on the custom in many countries.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 27 -- Williams closed its home season with a Litte Three victory over Amherat tonight, winning, 31 to 20. The Purple completed the series with four straight victories.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27 -- Yale's wrestlers won the Varsity meet from Princeton, 15 1/2 to 10 1/2, today. Captain Edsie Rotan, intercollegiate unlimited-weight champion, clinched the victory by throwing Speer in less than two minutes in the final bout.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 27 (AP) -- District Attorney Walter C. Newcomb said today he would open a John Doe investigation in City Court Monday to determine whether graft exists in the Buffalo Common Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- With party lines broken, the House by a vote of 205 to 109 today passed the Almon relief bill of the Democrats authorizing the appropriation of $132,500,000 for emergency highway construction to increase employment.

ATLANTA, Feb. 25 -- Although relief agencies still are confronted with a critical situation in the task of providing for thousands of jobless, the unemployment situation today in a majority of industrial centres in the Sixth Federal Reserve District has shown a vast improvement in recent weeks, and leaders in all lines of business are of the opinion that a definite upward trend is under way.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- A subscription leap year dance was held tonight at the Pelham Country Club. The dance was preceded by a dinner.

F. Morgan Palmer of the Princeton Club successfully started his campaign in defense of his Class B Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association title by defeating F.M. Lockwood of the Plainfleld Country Club, 15-7, 15-7, 17-15, as the third annual tourney got under way yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From Paris, in the writing of Jules Sauerwein, has come another blast against democracy and Parliaments. In this latest of strictures it is pointed out that Central Europe is abandoning parliamentarianism for the more trim dictatorship form.
After thirty years of unprecedented growth, elementary public school population has turned the corner and is definitely on the decrease, it was indicated yesterday.

FOR the forty-third item in the repertory of New York's long opera season, the coming eighteenth week brings back Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Sadko." Personal Incidents of interest will be the return of Gigli and the debut of a new Italian tenor, Francesco Merli.

TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 28 -- The streets in the neighborhood of the Tokyo barracks are all flag-bedecked and are periodically filled with cheering crowds as young men return from civil life to rejoin their regiments. Great enthusiasm was shown everywhere.

WHILE the export division of the American aeronautical industry has at times been described as small, our manufacturers are surely and steadily taking key positions in the markets of the world. The latest testimony to this effect comes from Peter Salvo, Dalmatian native and a pilot during the World War.

ATHUR M. LOEW vice president of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in charge of this company's foreign affairs, was still glowing with excitement and wind-burn after his sixteen-thousand-mile trip by plane through Mexico, Central and South America, when he sat down to a chat with an interviewer last week.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 19 -- Nanking, the ancient Ming dynasty city, now the capital of Nationalist China, which is trying to develop a modern government inside the largest system of city walls in the country, is most frequently mentioned in news from China but for some time the great political centre has not been Nanking but Fengwha, a district in Che-kiang Province where General Chiang Kaishek's home town is located.

BELLEAIR, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Billy Burke, national open golf champion, who is Winter pro at Belleair, showed the way today in the first thirty-six holes of the annual Florida West Coast open championship.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 27 -- The economic boycott as an anti-war measure is "fraught with dangers," John Martin, Professor of International Relations at Rollins College, told delegates at the annual Southeastern Conference of International Relations Clubs at Rollins today.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Led by the United States liner President Harding on her first special visit, a great race of foreign ships to land cargoes before the free-trade deadline at 5 P. M. Monday is expected to make this the busiest week-end in the history of the Port of London.

Prospects for reconstruction of the Tri-Utilities Corporation vanished last week with the acquisition by banks of the entire voting stocks of the Federal Water Service Corporation. With the Peoples Light and Power Corporation already segregated from the original reorganization plan, it now appears likely that Federal Water Service will remain outside the plan and that a separate reorganization for the Oklahoma Natural Gas Corporation and the American Natural Gas Corporation will be necessary.

ALL of you who have been suffering from sleepless nights because of your concern over high, high waist-lines and your inability to wear them, and wondering what in the world you were going to do about that Spring suit you wanted to order, can now calm yourselves and even go back to drinking coffee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- An appeal for the re-establishment of silver to its former position in the monetary systems of the world will be presented to the House within a few days by the Committee on Coinage. Weights and Measures, through its chairman.

However insignificant a distance of two blocks may be to the pedestrian, it constitutes a wide gulf in the world of architecture, it seemed here yesterday when it became known that the work of two architects of advanced modern ideas who are featured in the current exhibition of architecture at the Museum of Modern Art, 730 Fifth Avenue, had been rejected at the Architectural League's annual show at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.
POCAHONTAS, Va., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Hope for the lives of thirty-six miners, trapped by an explosion in the Pocahontas Fuel Company's Boissevain mine, virtually is abandoned tonight.

FIVE new groups of cars, In twenty-seven models, comprising the Nash Motors Company's line for this year, were introduced yesterday. They include four straight-eights and a six. Among the eights, the "Ambassador" is said to develop 125 horsepower and has a wheelbase of 142 inches; the "Advanced," on a 133-inch wheelbase, develops 125 horsepower; the "Special" on a 128-inch wheelbase, 100 horsepower; and the "Standard," on 121-inch wheelbase, 85 horsepower.

Small industrial plants have made steady progress since the start of the depression and in many instances are showing better results at the present time than their large competitors, according to opinions expressed yesterday in business circles. This statement is borne out by reports from commodity suppliers, machinery and equipment producers and an analysis of electric power consumption figures for last year.

Submission for approval within the next few clays of the draft of a new bill which eliminates the conflicts of views between retailers and manufacturers is expected to pave the way for design copyright protection, according to views expressed here yesterday. Harmonizing of the viewpoints has meant the withdrawal of the Vestal bill.
SEVERAL attempts have been made to write stage plays with the radio studio as the scene of action. Difficulties have been encountered.

W.A. Flinn led a field of thirty-four gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He took the High Scratch Cup by breaking 97 targets. The High Handicap Cup went to C.W. Stevens, who scored in a shootoff against H.L. Fleeman, P. Sleppy. G.N. Hersey. C.F. Morgan and G.A. Wylie.

Only one of the three Nye bills to amend the The Federal Trade Commission act and to establish a Federal trade court has any possibility of being reported on favorably by the Senate Judiciary Committee, trade association executives who attended the hearings in Washington during the week reported yesterday.

This being an Olympic year, the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships will take on added importance when this glittering panorama of speed and skill is unfolded on Saturday in a new setting, the 258th Field Artillery Armory on Kingsbridge Road.

LONDON A MAN who spends his life in looking after millions of sick silkworms is to be found in the Nilgiri Hills of India. He carries on this queer occupation in a small building on which the words "Sanitarium for Silkworms" are painted.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27 -- While approving compulsory automobile insurance against liability for injury or death, the Committee to Study Compensation for Automobile Accidents in the Connecticut section of its report, made public today, recommends a plan "with limited liability and without regard to fault analogous to that of the workmen's compensation laws."

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- A.P. Deacon was both high-scratch and high-handicap gunner in the shoot over the traps of the Country Club Beach today. He had a card of 41, 10-50. As he took the scratch cup, the handicap prize went to J. Lambden Jr., the only other gunner to have a full card of 50 targets.

THE special meeting of the International Amateur Athletic Federation, called for Berlin, April 3, has the track and field followers of France stirred up. The story along the boulevards is that the meeting will take up "deux questions a I'ordre du jour:

AMERICAN historians, by and large, have tended to neglect the repressed classes who, however meagerly, have played a part in the upbuilding of our society. The reasons are easily understandable; the poor, the exploited, the laboring classes are always with us, and to most of us are less interesting, less colorful than political leaders or bourgeois captains of industry.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27 -- A fighting Princeton basketball team moved into first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League standing by turning back Columbia, 29 to 27, before a crowd of 2,000 persons in the Tiger gymnasium tonight.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 27 -- A test recently made by Dr. Sidney A. Cook, head of the Department of psychology at New Jersey College for Women, to ascertain the attitude of the modern college girl toward marital problems, revealed that there are conservatives as well as radicals among the younger generation.

THE opening of the new American Embassy at Tokyo added another house to the list of our government-owned ambassadorial residences. A half-dozen years ago there were but fourteen embassies and legations owned by the United States in the fifty-one capitals served by our Ambassadors and Ministers.

American students in many colleges, and to some extent in schools of lower rank, are making an acquaintance with world affairs through participation in the League of Nations model assembly, a session of which will be held at Brown University, at Providence, R.I., beginning on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The declaration of ex-Governor Smith that he will fight for the Raskob home rule prohibition plank at the Democratic National Convention, met with a cool reception from leading Democrats reached tonight. Some of the expressions were:

That the run on the dollar has ended, after continuing with varying intensity since last September when the suspension of gold payments by the Bank of England shattered confidence abroad in the safety of foreign balances, is the belief of leading bankers and foreign exchange experts here.

Two fatal bullet wounds, inflicted in a mysterious manner, were discovered lost night in the body of Roderick Roberts, 60 years old, two hours after he had toppled dead on the floor of the offices of a surgical appliance firm, known as Roberts Quinn. Inc., of which he was senior member and founder, at 339 Bridge Street. Brooklyn.

THOUGH envious managers often cite their stagehands as the coolest headed of the theatre's business men, with a Sixth sense that compels them to collect for a split second of over time. It now turns out that the backstage boys are human, after all, (Well, then, as human as actors, if you insist on a touch of overstatement.)

William McCord, 41 years old, of 202 Park Place, Brooklyn, a member of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, was held in $1,000 bail for examination on March 1 when he was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Steers in Coney Island Court on a charge of feloniously assaulting Michael Clohessy, an electrician employed by The New York Times Company.

The steel industry should begin to show the effects of reviving confidence, increasing automobile orders and the thoroughly liquidated state of all lines of business toward the end of March, Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the National Steel Corporation, one of the largest steel units in the country, said here yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 25 -- Agitation for a State income tax, now assuming the proportions of a major State issue, is very clearly one of the by-products of the economic depression. Farmers and other owners of real estate, finding their taxes going up at the same time that their incomes were going down, have become acutely tax conscious.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Democratic plan to combine the War and Navy Departments in a Department of National Defense, as proposed by Representative Byrns of Tennessee, was delayed again today when the House Committee on Expenditures failed to act upon a subcommittee revision of the program and adjourned by a vote of 11 to 9.

LONDON. IT was recently reported that burglars had broken into a Reigate bookshop and stolen "complete sets of works by Hardy, Kipling and Barrie." This suggested to The Observer a novel and interesting competition.

ROME, Feb. 26 -- In these days when, nobody seems able to talk of anything but the depressed conditions of business and the mounting figures of unemployment it is a real relief to encounter a responsible statesman who declares in all earnestness that the crisis does not exist, at least so far as his own country is concerned.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, C.Z., Feb. 20 -- Completion of the Canal Zone's link in the inter-American highway is scheduled for May 5, the date set for the formal opening of the Thatcher Highway, connecting Balboa, which is adjacent to Panama City, with the national highway system of Panama near the Canal Zone boundary at Arraijan.

DALLAS, Feb. 25 -- Whoever first observed that the Democrats can always be depended upon to do the wrong thing at the right time must have had his eye on Texas. Not even the possibility that a native son may be nominated for the Presidency brings harmony in the party.

Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, whom the Republican State Committee failed to elect a delegate-at-large to the Republican National Convention on Friday, will attend the convention as a delegate from the Twentieth Congressional District.

There is one large factor which hovers over the whole acene of American, life and education. It is the persistent democratic aspiration of Americans to give themselves a more kindly civilization and to train a nation of cooperative men and women to operate it.

RICHMOND, Feb. 25 -- There has been no improvement in the unemployment situation in the Fifth Federal Reserve District in recent months, but conservative forecasters are hopeful that establishment of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and passage of the Glass-Steagall banking bill will give an impetus to business which will carry the country out of the depression.

SO runs the gracious inscription at Chequers Court. Buckinghamshire, commemorating the gift of Lord and Lady Lee in 1921. It was a gift truly munificent, for not only was it presented to the British nation to be used as the official country residence of future Premiers but it was endowed with an ample grant for its maintenance, so that no Prime Minister with limited financial resources should be debarred from enjoying its pleasures.

Not many years ago a main device to which educators looked to make schooling swifter, surer and happier was the so-called system of "ability grouping." The ordinary heterogeneous school class -- Tom, Dick and Harry -- was divided up into two or three sections on the basis of the children's rating on intelligence or achievement tests, or sometimes merely according to school marks.

MEMEL, Feb. 27 -- Heavily shrouded in snow and ice, the so-called autonomous district of Memel, on the eastern shore of the Baltic -- which is largely German, but is ruled by Lithuania -- is anxiously waiting to learn just how autonomous it is going to be.

ROME, Feb. 26 -- In these days when, nobody seems able to talk of anything but the depressed conditions of business and the mounting figures of unemployment it is a real relief to encounter a responsible statesman who declares in all earnestness that the crisis does not exist, at least so far as his own country is concerned.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, C.Z., Feb. 20 -- Completion of the Canal Zone's link in the inter-American highway is scheduled for May 5, the date set for the formal opening of the Thatcher Highway, connecting Balboa, which is adjacent to Panama City, with the national highway system of Panama near the Canal Zone boundary at Arraijan.

DALLAS, Feb. 25 -- Whoever first observed that the Democrats can always be depended upon to do the wrong thing at the right time must have had his eye on Texas. Not even the possibility that a native son may be nominated for the Presidency brings harmony in the party.

Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, whom the Republican State Committee failed to elect a delegate-at-large to the Republican National Convention on Friday, will attend the convention as a delegate from the Twentieth Congressional District.

There is one large factor which hovers over the whole acene of American, life and education. It is the persistent democratic aspiration of Americans to give themselves a more kindly civilization and to train a nation of cooperative men and women to operate it.

BOSTON, Feb. 26 HEREABOUT the wiseacres of the theatre are finding an immediate and unforeseen application of Bernard Shaw's new title, "Too True to Be Good." The mood of the public toward "Three's a Crowd" is the inciting cause.

Manufacturers anxious for more volume are pruning "fixed charges" in order to reduce production costs in the present stage of the business depression, it was learned here yesterday. The new trend in price competition was revealed in bids submitted to purchasing executives for large industrial and public utility corporations last, week and caused widespread comment among business executive.

Although more than three months away, top-ranking women tennis players already are turning their thoughts to this year's Wightman Cup match with the English, to be staged on the famous courts of Wimbledon on June 10 and 11. The coming meeting will be the tenth since the competition was inaugurated with a 7-0 American victory in 1923.

BERLIN, Feb. 27 -- For one hour tonight Adolf Hitler stirred the largest crowd of his followers ever assembled here into frenzies of enthusiasm, cheering his first Presidential campaign speech at the Sport-palast, Berlin's Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- After scanning Samuel Seabury's address on New York City's governmental conditions, made last night to the Cincinnati Charter Committee, political Washington accepted him as a candidate for something.

ARCHITECTURAL LEAGUE -- The forty-seventh annual exhibition, held this year in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building. 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. On alternate years this exhibition is assembled at the Grand Central Palace.

PROMINENT men and women as well as debutantes of this and recent seasons are aiding in the arrangements for the Abstract Ball for the benefit of Contemporary Arts, an organization for artists, which will take place on the night of March 11 in the ballroom of the Plaza.

BERLIN, Feb. 28 -- Adolf Hitler summoned foreign correspondents to his headquarters at the Kaiserhof today to protest against his opponents' practice of predicting terrorism and disturbance to Germany's foreign relations and credit in the event that the National Socialists were victorious in the Presidential election March 13.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- The fact that imports of gold from New York to Paris have slackened this week is not taken here as indicating a change in the Bank of France's policy, but merely as reflecting the decision to increase the freight costs for transport of gold by shipping companies.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 28 -- Pope Pius XI told the world in a radio broadcast today that its love of the fleshpots is the source of "so many disputes and wars that have always afflicted and continue today to afflict the world" with such grief and suffering "as perhaps never have been encountered in history."
A Chinese and a Japanese stood side by side yesterday to tell Americans something of the backgrounds of their countries as a basis for judging the present Far Eastern clash.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The great collection of bronzes, pictures and porcelains formed over half a century by the late Sir William Bennett is being dispatched to the United States for auction. Sir William's fame as a connoisseur is known throughout the United States and Europe and his collection includes objects of remarkable quality.

Another plan for the liquidation of the assets of the closed Bank of United States has been submitted to Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banking, and Governor Roosevelt, it was announced yesterday by J.A.H. Hopkins of 15 East Fortieth Street.

"God" and "worship" are two words in our religion that it may become necessary to discard for new terms because of the implications and meanings that have accrued to them since the days when the world was filled with kings and emperors, Dr. Jesse Herman Holmes, professor of philosophy at Swarthmore College, declared in a talk yesterday morning at the Friends Meeting House, 221 East Fifteenth Street.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 28 -- Steel demand, taken as a whole, has varied so little lately that more interest is being taken now in the price-stabilization movement than in the amount of production. On the inception of the movement about a month ago, sellers visualized it as of great importance, but they have been rather uncommunicative in the last week as to the success thus far achieved and the possibilities.

E.H. Locatelli was the high-scratch gunner at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He took the shoot by breaking 95 targets. F.J. Ryan and C.F. Morgan tied for the High Handicap Cup, each returning a full card of 100.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 27 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 63.7, which compares with 63.7 a week ago, 63.6 two weeks ago, 64.2 three weeks ago and 64.5 four weeks ago. The present year's highest average to date was 66.3, in the first week of January; the average of two weeks ago was the lowest.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- With delegates for former Governor Smith being sought in Massachusetts, the position to be taken by Governor Roosevelt in the Bay State primaries was the subject of a conference at the Executive's home over the week-end.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In recent comment upon panacea for existing business ills Mr. Cortelyou, president of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York, stated that prosperity which is "forced" is never lasting. No doubt this is wise counsel and largely true, though much would depend upon the meaning of the word "forced."

COPENHAGEN, Feb. 28 -- According to information reaching here tonight, the Finnish Government at an emergency meeting resolved not to yield to the conditions demanded by the Lapuans, and if the Fascist forces arrive in Helsingfors they will be met by the city's garrison, which the government thinks is reliable.
MANILA, Monday, Feb. 29 -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt arrived here this morning to take over his new duties as Governor General of the Philippine Islands.

Catherine Reiner, soprano, who made her New York debut two seasons ago, gave a recital of songs last night in Town Hall. Miss Reiner's program mingled with the familiar Brahms and Strauss such exotics as two excerpts from Alban Berg's "Wozzeck" and a group of Hungarian folk songs harmonized by Szabados.

MANILA, Monday, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Flower-bedecked boats, airplanes, troops and a great crowd of Americans and Filipinos greeted Theodore Roosevelt when he arrived here today to take office as Governor-General of the Philippine Islands.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Release of hoarded funds throughout Chicago and the West is reported to have been noticeable this past week; also an improved sentiment, with small, scattered revival of demand in various lines of business and industry. There is no rush for goods of any kind, but employment is slightly better and the disposition is to look for moderate gains which are to be fairly maintained as the season advances.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- L.M. Karakhan, Acting Foreign Commissar, today informed Koki Hirota, Japanese Ambassador, that Soviet Russia would consent to the movement of a limited number of Japanese troops over the Chinese Eastern Railway from Harbin eastward in Manchuria.

The Neutron Is Discovered. "Neutron" is a term proposed some years ago for just such a union of proton and electron as Dr. CHADWICK has discovered. Lord RUTHERFORD's endorsement of its importance leaves no doubt that, in addition to the proton, electron and photon, we must henceforth reckon with a new unit.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Condemnation of a system under which insurance companies carrying workmen's compensation insurance are maintaining and operating private clinics for the treatment of injured workmen covered in their policies, is contained in a preliminary report filed with Governor Roosevelt by his Committee to Review Medical and Hospital Problems in Connection with Workmen's Compensation Insurance.

The fifty-second international six-day bicycle race got under way at Madison Square Garden last night when Frank Fay, vaudeville and motion picture actor, fired the shot that sent fifteen teams off on their whirl to nowhere.

GENEVA, Feb. 28 -- An analysis of all the proposals which have been laid before the Disarmament Conference indicates that many months of debate will be needed before there can be a possibility of drafting any convention limiting or reducing the armaments now existing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- An increase of $1,772,766,839 in State expenditures on government from 1917 to 1930 was shown in statistics made public today by the Census Bureau.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28 (AP) -- In a driving finish John A. Marsch's Prince Atheling, with J. McCoy up, won the feature race on the Fair Grounds welfare program of eight events today. Officials estimated that $20,000 would be turned over to the unemployment committee from receipts of the Sunday card.

F. Morgan Palmer of the Princeton Club, defending titleholder, defeated Percy Jennings Jr. of the Yale Club to gain the third round in the annual Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B tournament at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 28 -- While their countrymen are engaged in a life and death struggle on the Chapei-Woosung battle front, Chinese and Japanese professional dancing partners swing rund and round in an American-owned cabaret with all comers at 8 cents, gold, a dance.

Truth revealed from all sources should be recognized with full intellectual honesty, particularly when the source of it is the Bible, said the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, in a sermon at a confirmation servise yesterday morning in Grace Church, Tenth Street and Broadway.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 -- The almost severely business-like quiet which had settled over the routine camp life of the Giants the past few days was rudely disturbed today with the arrival of the second squad of players consisting mainly of the regular infielders and outfielders upon whom John McGraw will pin his 1932 pennant hopes.

The "smart behavior" of modern youth is not modern at all, for some of its "fads and fancies" go back to more than 4500 B.C., the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin, pastor of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Rates for electric current charged to the domestic and small commercial consumers "are perhaps twice as high as they should be." Morris Llewellyn Cooke, trustee of the New York State Power Authority, declares in an article published in the March number of The Survey Graphic.

Current low construction costs and an unwillingness on the part of property owners in this city to risk failure of the Legislature to pass the multiple dwelling law moratorium are factors in pushing building alterations, according to Allen E. Beals in the Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Democrats will unloose a bitter attack on Samuel Seabury when the Republican bill appropriating $250,000 more for the Hofstadter committee comes up for final action in the Assembly tomorrow night.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Chinese and Japanese artillery in Chapei and beyond toward Kiangwan shook the countryside today in a bombardment that punctuated circulating reports of further efforts toward a peace between the rival armies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, tonight asserted that 8,300,000 were out of employment on Feb. 1 and that a large part of the present shortage of jobs was due to the displacement of men by machines and modern efficiency methods.

The Deal Club bridge team of P. Hal Sims. Willard S. Karn, Oswald Jacoby and David Burnstine, which in the last year has won the nickname of the "Four Horsemen" from the roughshod way in which it has ridden down all opposition, won the Curt Reisinger Trophy yesterday, emblematic of the Eastern championship for contract bridge teams of four.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Hoover is opposed to the Almon relief bill to appropriate $132,500,000 for emergency highway construction to increase employment, which passed the House yesterday by a vote of 205 to 109.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The United States at the beginning of 1932 had more idle shipping tonnage than any other country in the world. Government and privately-owned ships of the United States laid up on Jan. 1 totaled 3,031,000 tons, an increase of 457,000 tons or 18 per cent over the preceding year, according to a survey of world shipping trends by A.E. Sanderson, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- The dressed meat trade in Chicago last week ruled irregular, with beef prices the lowest since July, fresh lamb prices the highest since early in November, and pork loins unchanged to 1/2 cent lower than the previous week.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 29 -- Kiangwan village is now held by the Japanese. The Chinese admit this but deny they were forced out by their foes. The Chinese assert they had to evacuate the village because of the dead and the debris, while the Japanese say the Chinese were forced out by an attack Saturday afternoon.
MANILA, Feb. 28 -- Seventeen important government officials were arrested in a gambling raid this afternoon at the Club Carambola, where the Nacionalista convention is going on.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Feb. 28 -- Two stake events marked a pro- gram of ten races at the Agua Caliente track today, with the $2,500 added Fashion Stakes at one mile and a furlong for 3-year-olds and upward attracting a field of six veteran campaigners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee will seek to learn this week whether a small group of professional speculators on Wall Street have been deliberately driving down security prices and the extent of the practice.

Net income of the New York Telephone Company after taxes, charges and depreciation amounted to $35,323,950 for 1931, equal after preferred dividends to $9.08 a share earned on 3,713,000 common shares, compared with $30,479,028, or $9.25 a share earned on 3,120,500 common shares in 1930.

February has witnessed further improvement in business sentiment, due in part to the measures taken by the government to strengthen the financial situation, and also to the natural reaction from the "overdrawn pessimism" that resulted from the series of false starts and subsequent disappointments in 1931, according to the Guaranty Trust Company in its latest issue of The Guaranty Survey.

An army of volunteer workers is now wanted by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee. The latest effort to help unemployed men and their families is based on a combination of large-scale organization and neighborly interest which should prove highly effective.

CAMBRIDGE, England, Feb. 28 -- Dr. James Chadwick, 41-year-old Cambridge physicist, explained today to this correspondent the experiments which led last week to the discovery of a new type of ultimate particle, consisting of a proton and an electron bound together without an electric charge and hence called a "neutron."
America has little to learn from Soviet Russia's system of morals, Rabbi Louis I. Newman told the congregation of Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday morning".

Satan finds some mischief still for idle hands to do, in prison as well as in the community of free men. As long ago as 1796 Governor JAY remarked that the abolition of capital punishment, then a comparatively common method of dealing with crime, would require the construction of suitable institutions for the confinement of prisoners, with employment as a necessary incident.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28 -- The last corn crop was underestimated by 39,400,000 bushels, it has been officially declared, making exportable corn at date 22,182,200 bushels, with wheat at 106,690,570 bushels and flaxseed 59,899,480 bushels. Heavy shipments of all grains are reported for last week, larger than the total in the corresponding week in 1931.
PARIS, Feb. 28 -- The new Franco-Italian trade agreement which has been under negotiation since Feb. 15 will be signed soon, it was announced tonight.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- For the first time in a long stretch of years more Democrats than Republicans have enrolled in this State, until a decade ago reckoned safely Republican.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Catcher Bill Dickey, who ceased being a holdout on Friday when he came to terms with the Yankees, joined his team-mates at their hotel today. He will be in uniform at tomorrow's practice.

BERLIN, Feb. 27 -- Although the Boerse building was reopened for trading in stocks on Thursday, transactions remained unofficial and the prohibition against publishing the prices quoted continues. The reopening proved a success, if measured by the large attendance, and the volume of trading was also considerable.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- Newton D. Baker, the second Presidential possibility to visit Detroit in a week, dedicated the new George Washington memorial window in Central Woodward Avenue Church today. The auditorium was crowded. The Washington window is a community project rather than a congregational undertaking, and flanks a similar window in memory of Abraham Lincoln.

POCAHONTAS, Va., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Twenty bodies had been found in the blast-torn Boissevain Mine tonight, the result of rescue workers' battle against gas, slate and fallen timber to reach thirty-eight men trapped by an explosion yesterday.

BELLEAIR, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Billy Burke, national open champion, broke one of the traditions of the links today when he succeeded Gene Sarazen as winner of the Florida West Coast open golf championship and the plant memorial trophy. The course was his own Bellair links, where he holds forth in Winter, and victories by home pros are rare indeed.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Mrs. Charles Albert Smylie 3d entertained tonight with a buffet supper at her home in Cocoanut Row in celebration of the birthday of George Singer, who, with Mrs. Singer, is her house guest. Attending were:

At the Criterion yesterday afternoon the pupils of the Walden School with their parents enjoyed a revival for one show only of Chaplin's old picture, "The Gold Rush." It was a joy to hear the shrieks of laughter when Chaplin put in his first appearance as a lone prospector walking along a snow-covered ledge and followed for a while by an imposing-looking brown bear.

The working out of an apprenticeship plan in the State's prisons similar to that employed in free industry is recommended in the report submitted to the Legislature by the Advisory Committee on Prison Industries, of which George Cordon Battle is chairman.

For many years nearly all marriages in this country have been, as far as the State is concerned, "trial marriages," the Right Rev. John F. Noll, Roman Catholic Bishop of Fort Wayne, Ind., declared yesterday in a radio address over a nation-wide hook-up of the Columbia Broadcating System.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 29 -- Under the heading "Americans Misunderstand the Real Situation at Shanghai" the Asahi publishes this morning in Japanese a summary of an editorial appearing yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES on the Far Eastern situation. As translated it says:
