The American Power Boat Association announced yesterday that a State-wide movement had been begun under its leadership in opposition to the Thayer bill in the State Senate, designed to regulate the operation, licensing and registration of motor boats on the State waterways.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Completion this week of the new tax bill, designed to produce more than $1,000,000,000, was predicted today by its framers. They said the measure would reach the House for action the first of next week.

BERLIN, Feb. 26 -- Although Chancellor Bruening repeated in the Reichstag on Thursday the assertion that stability of the mark is the central objective of his policy on prices, financial journals have this week commented pessimistically on the mark's position, in view of the dwindling export surpluses.

HONOLULU, Feb. 28 -- Honolulu is the largest military post on American soil and also one of the most favored pleasure resorts. The influx of military service men and tourists was followed by incidents which did not tend to raise the respect of Hawaiians or Orientals toward the haole, or white man.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28 -- Despite the general holiday last Monday, trade in the cotton market during the remainder of the week was fairly active and prices ruled steady with a range of only 23 points. While the market was influenced by the fluctuations of stocks, it was controlled mainly by developments within itself, and traders clung to the waiting policy which has characterized their operations for several weeks.

It is hard to make out from the message to Spaniards sent by the former King exactly what plan he expects to put into effect. He calls upon all his former subjects to unite with him to restore the monarchy, and asks them to rally to the "banner" which he says he is raising.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 28 -- Their vari-colored sails silhouetted against the light-topped rocks of the harbor, seven dinghies and three dories were sailed today in the Frostbite Yacht Club's weekly regatta. The racing was under a bleak, overcast sky.

At last the Irish Labor party has consented to Mr. DE VALERA'S scheme to take the oath of allegiance out of the Free State Constitution. Hitherto the Labor leaders have been cold to the efforts of Fianna Fail to monkey with the Anglo-Irish treaty. The point about the oath has never interested them much because it seems mere hair-splitting to men whose chief concerns are practical.
NEW YORK. Count Serge Fleury of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs is expected on the Ile de France and will be at the Delmonico.

BERLIN, Feb. 28 -- Consider the somewhat unexciting Presidential campaign now in progress in Germany from Adolf Hitler's viewpoint. With his entrance into the race for the Presidency he faces the unpleasant obligation of contending against an aged man who will not hit back by an active campaign.

GENEVA, Feb. 28 -- Intense diplomatic activity prevailed here today following the secret note sent by Japan yesterday to each of the twelve neutrals represented on the League of Nations Council -- not to the Council itself -- suggesting terms for a possible armistice at Shanghai.

The buying lull that characterized the wholesale apparel markets recently continued during last week, as retailers awaited favorable weather to spur consumer response to new Spring merchandise. While retail stocks are in a fairly good condition, it was thought that wholesalers could not easily meet an improved demand created by the advent of propitious weather.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- Two Philadelphia students at Haverford College are the winners of Clementine Cope Fellowships, coveted prizes of Haverford seniors. Both fellowships are based on high scholarship ability and require the winner to study at an approved American or foreign university.

The dangers confronting this country are not from possible enemies outside but from social injustice and lack of social and economic planning inside, declared the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday in Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 28 -- With large numbers of the second squad of Robins arriving today and tomorrow, Floyd Caves Herman, at once the idol and the despair of Flatbush fandom, became the lone holdout of the 1932 season.

Sometimes, among the mixed motives which always exist for such changes, reduction of a bank rate is equivalent to the hauling down of a danger-signal. This was manifestly true when Europe's central banks reduced their very high rates at the end of 1929; they knew that the collapse of the American speculation had ended Wall Street's ravenous absorption of European capital.

The highest recognition that Columbia College can give for non-athletic activities outside the classroom, the gold King's Crown, has been awarded to twenty students, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin A. Hubbard, graduate treasurer of King's Crown.

Martha Graham presented her new group cycle of dances entitled "Ceremonials" at the Guild Theatre yester afternoon, with the fates apparently conspiring against her. Struggling against illness herself, with several members of her group unable to appear, she found it impossible to pull the performance up to the level which she has established.
William A. Brady, theatrical producer, and a score of Broadway stage luminaries broadcast their protests against the proposed State theatre tax last night over Station WOR.

Textile High School's basketball team still leads the city's P.S.A.L. quintets in team scoring in the P.S. A.L. race, the Manhattan division leaders having tallied a total of 255 points in their eight games to date. Newtown, the defending Queens division and city P.S.A.L. titleholder, retains second place with 219 points in five league contests, all of which the Queens leaders have won.

With the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race rapidly drawing to a close, Earl Nikkel, speedy Yale forward, still is setting the pace for individual scorers in the circuit, and if he can maintain his form in the Elis' two remaining circuit games has a good chance of capturing the laurels for the season.

Two precedents were shattered yesterday afternoon when Dr. Thomas Tertius Noble, organist of St. Thomas's Church and a noted composer of church music, was doubly honored at the evensong service at St. Thomas in recognition of his work and more than fifty years of service to the Church of England and its allied branch, the Protestant Episcopal Church in America.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 26 -- The really outstanding feature in the financial world of Europe this week was the fall in the price paid for gold. This development was believed to be connected with the enactment of the Glass-Steagall bill in America. Since the United States is the principal free-gold country, the gold price is practically fixed by the rate of dollar exchange.

BERLIN, Feb. 26 -- The improvement in the Reichsbank's status continues. The statement for the third week of February shows that, com- pared with the corresponding week in January, discounts have been reduced 263 million marks and circulation of the Reichsbank's own notes by 195 millions.

The first American biography of Mozart, who composed music when he was 4 years old, wrote the two operas that have remained continuously alive longer than any others, "Figaro" and "Don Giovanni," and died in 1791 a pauper at the age of 35, has been written by Marcia Davenport, the daughter of Alma Gluck and stepdaughter of Efrem Zimbalist, and will be published by Scribners tomorrow.

Beniamino Gigli, the Metropolitan Opera tenor, made his season's sec- ond appearance in recital at Car- negie Hall yesterday afternoon, Jacqueline Salomons, violinist, was the assisting artist, and Miguel Sandoval provided the piano accompaniments.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Financial markets here are reacting very vigorously to the recent reduction of the Bank of England rate. Even a further reduction in the bank rate this week had been talked of, but such haste to cheapen money and possibly encourage speculation is considered inadvisable.

Frederick Jagel, an American tenor of many parts in his five seasons at the Metropolitan, and in the last week twice called on to rescue other men's roles in the opera repertoire, made a rare appearance on the concert platform yesterday at the Town Hall.

Harvard's smashing triumph in the triangular meet in Boston on Saturday and Gene Venzke's amazing world's, record breaking feat at 1,500 meters in New York were significant week-end developments in the track world.

Almond-eyed girls and women, most of them wearing pajama-like costumes the color of moonstone, turquoise, beryl and jade, marched through the crooked streets of Chinatown yesterday making shrill appeals for war funds in the first public demonstration of Chinese women this city has ever seen.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- After a brief cessation, withdrawal of French balances from London has recommenced. The extraordinary persistence of the French banks in this policy is still regarded as something of a mystery, but to financial London it has now become almost a matter of indifference.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 28 -- A group of 250 starving unemployed persons arrived here yesterday after trudging nearly seventy-five miles from Puebla to ask Federal authorities for help.

BRUSSELS. Feb. 28 -- The cause of the "poison fog" deaths in the Meuse Valley in Belgium in December, 1930, was reported today by official investigators to have been gas emanations from factories which unusual weather conditions made to accumulate under a 'ceiling" of fog.

No industry is eagerly offering itself for taxation, though all admit the necessity of taxing some one in order to get needed revenue. It is particularly hard to face the prospects of a tax from Washington and another from Albany when a 10 per cent tax on tickets above three dollars already exists, as is the case with the theatre.

Taking two first places against Columbia and thus keeping his undefeated record intact, Walter Spence of Rutgers displaced Harold Kramer of C.C.N.Y. as the leader in the race for individual scoring honors in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association.

The ravages of unemployment in reducing standards of living are described in a report made public yesterday by the Welfare Council. It is based on investigations conducted by 900 experienced social workers and public health nurses who have made a total of nearly 1,000,000 visits to the homes of the poor during the current depression.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senator Moses re-entered the political fray today with a charge that Speaker Garner's recent declaration that President Hoover had led the country into the greatest panic in history marked the beginning of the Speaker's formal campaign for the Presidency.

Bruno Walter's farewell concert of the season with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and with Yelli d'Aranyi as solo violinist was given yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House before a capacity audience that showed unmistakably its enthusiasm for his performance and, if applause may be interpreted so specifically, its regret at his departure.
HELSINGFORS, Finland, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A concentration of thousands of Lapuans within forty miles of Helsingfors tonight led to an order to confine all troops to barracks.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Disappearance of the snow covering of the Winter wheat belt and a few days of warm sunshine have disclosed a considerable area in Western Nebraska and Kansas, Eastern Colorado and Northwestern Oklahoma where the condition of the crop is materially below normal.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, won the singles championship of the second annual Pan-American tennis tournament today by defeating George Lott, Chicago, defending champion, in straight sets, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4.

Under gray skies a small group that included public officials, clergymen and officials of the Washington Bicentennial Commission stood yesterday afternoon as the American flag was raised to its staff on the site in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, where a replica of Mount Vernon will be erected.

A conditional endorsement of the policy of economic boycott to restore peace in the Far East if every other means fail was issued yesterday by the administrative committee of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America for submission to the churches.

Just nine years ago there appeared in Chapel Hill, N.C., the seat of our earliest State university, a weekly paper that has an almost unique place in American journalism. Its editor is also its publisher and its printer, in the sense of "running a printing business" so as to get his paper printed.

The Hofstadter committee has undertaken an investigation to discover how Owney Madden was able to remain at liberty on parole in view of his public reputation as a racketeer, it became known yesterday when it was revealed that the Attorney General's office has been called upon to produce all records in his case.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Word has just reached me from Germany of the death at Neubeckum, Westphalia, on Feb. 12, of Professor Wilhelm Ludwig Schreiber. He was one of the greatest scholars on all subjects connected with fifteenth century printing and I believe he was everywhere recognized as the foremost authority on, and the codifier of our knowledge of the woodcuts of that period.

Gerhart Hauptmann was honored last night at dinner by the Lotos Club as "the foremost literary light of the world," and he replied in a German address in which he explained "the tremendous meaning of the word American throughout the world."

William Steiner of the 258th Field Artillery, winner of the recent Bellerose fifteen-mile marathon, led home the field in the thirteen-mile scratch race conducted by the Manhattan Athletic League yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 29 -- Preliminary peace negotiations between Japan and China, which ended after 1 o'clock this morning, were held aboard Admiral Sir Howard Kelly's flagship, H.M.S. Kent, with Admiral Kelly as host. Consul General Murai and Yosuke Matsuoka, former vice president of the South Manchuria Railway, represented Japan.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 28 -- The Soviet Government has offered $50,000 a year to Robert P. Lamont Jr., Colorado ranchman and son of the Secretary of Commerce, to develop Russia's live stock industry, directing the breeding of cattle throughout the Soviet Union.

The medals given annually by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects "to stimulate improvement of apartment house design" have been awarded this year to Vincent Astor, as owner of 120 East End Avenue, and to the Phipps Houses, Inc., owners of the Phipps Houses at Fiftieth Street and Thirty-ninth Avenue, Long Island City.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28 -- A smart field of seven has been named for the Gables Handicap, one-mile feature race on the opening card of an eighteen-day meeting which will begin at Tropical Park tomorrow under the auspices of the Gables Racing Association.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Despite the practical certainty that Alphonse Capone will soon be taken to Leavenworth Penitentiary and the reduction in the number of "public enemies" by the Federal Government's income tax offensive, citizens of Chicago have doubts that lawlessness has been curbed.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- An unconfirmed report says Japan is considering the advisability of modifying concessions under which American missionaries are now allowed to maintain schools in Korea.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Premier Andre Tardieu, who is making another flying visit to Geneva tonight, found time during his brief sojourn in Paris this week-end to initiate two of the principal projects he hopes to undertake as Minister of Foreign Affairs: the establishment of a working economic understanding with Germany and the renewal of close collaboration with Great Britain.

Texas Guinan, Edith Barrett and Helen Rowland, the last named a child actress, will play three stages in the life of Aimee Semple McPherson, the evangelist, in a dramatization of Nancy Barr Mavity's biography, "Sister Aimee," which Charles Hopkins will present at his theatre after the run of "They Don't Mean Any Harm."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Differences of opinion have arisen regarding the compensation, if any, that Washington received as Commander-in-Chief of the Continental forces during the Revolution, Charles H. Callahan, in his exhaustive work. "Washington the Man and the Mason," makes it abundantly clear that Washington served with no remuneration whatever, save his actual expenses.

In a message accompanying the quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share sent out to stockholders yesterday, W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, declared that "quarterly dividends cannot be continued unless there is a material increase in the company's income."
DUBLIN, Feb. 28 -- Indications that Eamon De Valera's government will come into office without undue excitement are now prevalent.

A record-equaling feat by Miss Eleanor Holm of the Women's Swimming Association, a surprising performance by her 13-year club mate, Miss Janice Lifson, and a conclusive victory in the national A.A.U. junior 220-yard free-style championship by Miss Jean McCullough of the Dragon Club, competing unattached, were features of a water carnival in the 75-foot W.S.A. pool yesterday.

HONOLULU, Feb. 28 -- Another assault on the wife of a navy man, which may tremendously affect the entire situation here and has again aroused excitement among naval officers and reduced the civilian authorities to speechless rage, occurred Saturday night in the Waikiki section.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- Izvestia and Pravda today feature the same dispatch from Washington under the respective headlines "The anti-Japanese campaign in the United States" and "The growth of anti-Japanese sentiment in the United States."
A demand for residential properties in the metropolitan area was indicated in real estate transactions announced over the week-end.

A special guard of detectives and uniformed patrolmen has been assigned by Commissioner Mulrooney far the robbery trial of Reynolds Forsbrey, 46 years old, a former convict, and two others which is to open today before Judge Nott and a jury in General Sessions.

The prediction that the States of the Far West would send to the Democratic National Convention delegations that would be virtually solid for the nomination of Governor Roosevelt was made here yesterday by J. Bruce Kremer, national committeeman from Montana.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Feb. 28 -- Representatives of the Lido Country Club won the second leg of the home-and-home five-man team competition against the Engineers Club of Roslyn today. The shoot was at 250 targets, and the home gunners registered 232, the Engineers' team 219.

The Maccabee Association of America held its final tryouts for the selection of a track and field team to represent America in the Jewish Olympic Games at Palestine next month with the staging of six events yesterday at Betsy Head Park in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- With the export trade of the United States already at the level of 1914, Federal Government experts are awaiting the result of the establishment by Great Britain, principal purchaser of American goods abroad, of a 10 per cent general tariff, which becomes effective Tuesday.

LAKE TAHOE, Cal., Feb. 28 -- A ski invader from the East, Anton Lekang of the Norway Ski Club, New York, soared to a championship crown in the Division A jumping contests of the National Ski Association tournament today.

HAVANA, Feb. 28 -- The first reorganization in many years of Cuba's political parties took place today when adherents of the three principal groups, the Liberals, Conservatives and Populists, went to the polls to elect ward and municipal delegates who will direct the destinies of their respective political organizations.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Feb. 28 -- A grave political crisis engineered by organized Fascist elements under the auspices of the Lapuan movement has developed tonight throughout Finland. The Lapuan leaders have ordered the mobilization of all their forces and have announced that a Lapuan army will march on Helsingfors tomorrow.

Greater elasticity in the State housing laws would be of tremendous help in the development of the cooperative housing movement here, speakers declared yesterday at the Winter conference of the Eastern States Cooperative League in the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- A limestone slab on which is carved a portrait of King Seneferu, the Egyptian Pharaoh credited with building the great pyramid at Meydum about 5,000 years ago, has been discovered by the Rowe expedition, according to an announcement today by Horace H.F. Jayne, director of the University of Pennsylvania Museum.

Frank Knapp and Norman Anton were the stars in the 6-to-2 victory registered by the New York A.C. sextet over the Hudson Valley Hock- ey Club in an amateur hockey game at the New York Coliseum yesterday.

St. Bartholomew's, one of the wealthiest churches in the city, has cut the salaries of its personnel 10 per cent, it was ascertained last evening. The reduction is to go into effect tomorrow and will involve the entire staff of the organization, from the rector, the Rev. Dr. Robert Norwood, down the line.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Agitation from some sources for a world economic boycott against Japanese goods is causing uneasiness here and the Commerce Department today made public figures showing that such a move would have a tremendous back lash on the United States' export trade and in silk manufacturing States.

The final addresses in the New York University speaking contest were delivered yesterday afternoon over Station WOR. There were six finalists, talking on various phases of "The College Boy's Attitude on World Problems." and the radio audience was invited to vote upon them.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 28 -- A survey reveals that many plants over Ohio will resume operations this week and recall employes.

The crack of a pistol and the whine of a bullet in the murky, misty street of Newark's Chinatown last night revived a mystery of twenty long years. It dealt with the passing or the return to life of Mock Duck, an almost legendary tong leader of a generation ago, who combined Oriental wiles with Occidental directness and who disappeared from the New York scene in 1912.

The events leading up to and including those of that bloody October dawn in 1929 which saw six striking textile workers shot down on the picket line in Marion, N.C., came to the stage on Saturday night in "Mill Shadows," an earnest and moderate document by Tom Tippett.

BOSTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Announcement of the discovery at Cambridge University of the "neutron" was viewed tonight by Professor Arthur H. Compton of the University of Chicago as promising to pave the way to a more rapid advance in scientific study of the atom.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- N'Gi, the National Zoological Park's gorilla, has turned the corner in his fight for life, and is now believed to be on the road to recovery from the bronchial pneumonia from which he has been suffering ten days.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 28 -- Benjamin Brinton Greer, until last September president of the New York Air Brake Company and before that vice president of the Chicago, Milwaukee St. Paul Railroad, committed suicide early this morning by shooting himself through the heart in his home near here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The government's far-flung prosperity drive, unquestionably the most elaborate program for business stabilization and stimulation ever attempted, will gain impetus this week through the signing of the Glass-Steagall credit expansion bill by President Hoover.

Milton Aborn, whose Civic Light Opera Company will end its Manhattan engagement next Saturday night, will begin a season of grand opera in English at popular prices on March 28 at Erlanger's Theatre if he can come to satisfactory terms with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, he said yesterday.

PASADENA, Cal., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Dr. Robert A. Millikan, discoverer of the cosmic ray, said today that he thought the weight given for the neutron, reported as just discovered by Dr. James Chadwick of Cambridge University, was much too great.

Institutionalized religions are responsible for the economic and spiritual "bankruptcy" of modern society because they persist in espousing "rugged individualism" in religious affairs and condone it as an economic philosophy, Algernon D. Black asserted yesterday morning in an address to the New York Society for Ethical Culture.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The London dock district in the Thames estuary was jammed today with ships from all parts of the world which hoped to pass customs before 5 P.M. Monday, when Great Britain will erect her 10 per cent tariff wall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A three-point plan for United States action in the Far Eastern crisis -- culminating in an economic boycott -- was urged on President Hoover today by the Board of Temperance and Social Service of the Methodist Episcopal Church South.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Some crimes, such as arson and homicide, are more prevalent in the rural communities of New York State than in New York City, according to a statement made in the "Summary and Comment" attached to the Report and Criminal Statistics for 1930 recently presented to the Legislature and made public today by Dr. Walter N. Thayer Jr., State Commissioner of Correction.

BOSTON, Feb. 28 -- A North Atlantic gale and a collision in the fog-shrouded waters of Nantucket Sound sent two vessels to the bottom today, but their crews, totaling twenty-six men, were rescued. Radio reports of the Coast Guard received at Eastern division headquarters here told the news.

A group of nearly 100 prominent economists, social workers and publicists issued a statement yesterday urging immediate action in the enactment of a compulsory unemployment insurance law in this State.

After a rather light week, as regards openings, the local art galleries announce many new shows for the week at hand. About thirty exhibitions, thus far, are scheduled to open between now and Saturday.

The Shanghai situation continues to hold the spotlight at the Newsreel Theatre. This time there are scenes of actual combat, attack and counter-attack, and the camera also shows the arrival of the Thirty-first United States Infantry. Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Minister, calls for disarmament at Geneva and a Japanese spokesman at the same conference declares that his country wants peace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (Science Service) -- The neutron, the physical concept brought into prominence by research reported by Dr. James Chadwick of Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, is a close combination of two other more familiar parts of the atomic structure, the electron and the proton.

HAVANA, Feb. 28 (AP) -- In Ciego de Avila, Camaguey Province, supporters of Enrique Villena and Enrique Recio, candidates for the Liberal nomination for Governor, fought with pistols, hammers and other weapons. An unascertained number of persons was injured.

The mystery surrounding the fatal shooting of Roderick Roberts, 68-year-old surgical instrument dealer, who was found dead Saturday night in his office at 339 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, with a single bullet wound through the heart, remained impenetrable last night when police, alter more than twenty-four hours of questioning persons connected with the dead man and his affairs, admitted that their clues led to no definite solution.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 29 (AP). -- G.T.S. Stevens of Middlesex bowled in splendid form today to capture eight wickets of the colony of Jamaica's cricket team in its first innings for 87 runs. His bowling, cheered by a crowd of 5,000, played a big part in holding the Jamaica score to 228 runs.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 29. -- A list of twenty best books for boys was announced today by Professor Earl Reed Silvers, director of the Department of Public Information at Rutgers and the author of many boys' books.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was Juror No. 8 in the case of the People of the State of New York against Joseph Broderick. This morning Judge Donnellan declared a mistrial, requested by the defendant on the ground that Juror No. 2 failed to volunteer information about himself.

LONDON, Feb. 29. -- A wide-open race in the Grand National Steeplechase, which will be run over the historic Aintree course at Liverpool March 18, was indicated today by the call-over of betting odds at the Victoria Club.

BERLIN, Feb. 29. -- The 'Nationalist Opposition, as it has called itself -- composed of Dr. Alfred Hugenberg's German National or Nationalist party and Adolf Hitler's National Socialists, plus the soldiers' organization known as the Stahlhelm, or Steel Helmet -- achieved at the great demonstration, at Bad Harzburg last Fall a certain unity against the Bruening Government.
Withdrawals of gold by France, numerous large changes in earmarked holdings and increased shipments of the metal from Japan featured the shifting of gold supplies here in February.

HAVANA, Feb. 29. -- Although most of Cuba is advocating withdrawal from the international sugar agreement and for an unrestricted sugar crop the Sugar Institute, official organization representing the sugar industry here, decided today to continue with the accord and announced that a delegate would be sent to the next meeting of the conference in Paris on March 14.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the beat cash-and--carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted:

With the total of bonds called for redemption in February before their maturity dates, about half that of the previous month, the upward trend in the amount of these retirements, which had been increasing steadily throughout the past six months, ended.
Details of Manhattan leases are given in papers just recorded in the Register's office.

Gerhart Hauptmann, German poet and dramatist, received yesterday from Columbia University the honorary degree of "Doctor of Letters, at a ceremony in the Library Building on the Morningside Heights campus, Sebastien Charlety, rector of the University of Paris, received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws.

MOSCOW, Feb. 29. -- The Soviet Union has awarded $6,000 to the American Hector O. Hamilton, as one of the three architects to win first prize in a contest for a design for the "palace of the Soviets," which will soon be erected in Moscow. The two others winning first honors were Russians, I. V. Zholtoffsky and B. M. lofan, who received 12,000 rubles each.

GENEVA, Feb. 29. -- The Council of the League of Nations through a hasty public meeting and the press reports of it today brought worldwide pressure on China and even more on Japan to accept a plan for an armistice and a round-table conference to stop the Shanghai bloodshed.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 1/2 to 3 3/4 per cent for the best names.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 29. -- California weather, which for ten consecutive days had provided the Giants' training camp with ideal atmospheric conditions, went slightly into reverse today as the second squad came out on Wrigley Field for its first workout in company with the battery men, who already have had more than a week's start.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, March 1. -- Although both Chinese and Japanese official circles admit the continuance of parleys designed to reach a truce in the fighting here, to be followed by negotiations for a fundamental settlement of the Shanghai question, both sides are extremely secretive and both are using tactics which indicate they are not ready for an enduring settlement based upon a compromise of the opposing views.

Plans for an intensive campaign in New England for the election of delegates pledged to former Governor Alfred E. Smith for the Democratic nomination for President were discussed yesterday by supporters of Mr. Smith in a series of conferences.

BOSTON. Mass., Feb. 29. -- Since Bernard Shaw wrote it, let us regard it as a fully-articulate play. It is labeled "Too True to Be Good," and it was acted for the first time on any stage at the Colonial Theatre this evening. To a peripatetic theatregoer, sitting patiently out front, it sounds like the conversation of an elderly gentleman feeling comfortable on the veranda after a carnivorous dinner.

CLEAR WATER, Fla., Feb. 29. -- There were some sore muscles among the regulars who reported for their first workout this morning after they had finished absorbing the Carey system, but it is doubtful if the ligaments of the veteran Jack Quinn and Waite Hoyt annoyed them to any appreciable degree.
MANILA, Feb. 29. -- Manila's reaction to the arrival this morning of Colonel Theodore Roosevelt and to his inaugural address as Governor General later in the day appeared solidly favorable.

Wholesale firms and department store showed a larger decline in sales in January than in November and December, while chain stores declined in about the same proportion in the New York Federal Reserve district, according to reports issued by the Federal Reserve agent in New York, which say in part:

LONDON, Feb. 29. -- Further details were received in London today of tire excavations in which Sir Flinders Petrie is uncovering Tel-el-Ajjul, great seaport city of ancient Palestine, ten miles from Gaza.

The fundamental principle on which the entire system of the Russian Government rests is that women and children be protected by the State, Alice Withrow Field, a wealthy resident of this country, writes after a long sociological and psychological study of the condition of women and children in Russia.

Governor Roosevelt telephoned a message yesterday for the opening yesterday afternoon of an exhibition of Washingtonians at Arnold, Constable Co., which, was arranged by Monroe Douglas Robinson, nephew of President Roosevelt. The Governor's message, which was read by Mr. Robinson, follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The Atlantic will be practically swept clear of American combatant ships under orders issued by the Navy Department today transferring the units of the training and special service squadrons to the San Pedro-San Diego area of the Pacific.

Lew Fonseca, manager of the White Sox, spent most of last week wondering what had become of Lucius Luke Appling, his youthful shortstop. It seems that it is Luke's quaint habit to get lost on the way to the training camp. That would be nothing in the life of a left-handed pitcher, but a right-handed infielder is not supposed to indulge in such eccentricities.
The first in a series of "opera nights" took place in the Seaglade of the St. Regis last night, when Rafaelo Diaz sang during the dinner and supper hours arias from operas and also English songs.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29. -- Several million dollars which bad been treated as assets of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company under the Mitten regime were deducted from that column by the reorganized board of directors in making public its first annual report today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The first step in a Senatorial investigation of short selling on the New York Stock Exchange was taken today when the Senate Banking and Currency Committee invited William R. Perkins, an attorney of New York City, to testify before that committee tomorrow.

"Although judgment as to the sufficiency of the Glass-Steagall act and the other steps which have been taken in support of credit cannot yet be final," says the March review of economic conditions by the National City Bank of New York, "the improvement cited is clearly an important one, touching upon the business situation at its weakest point.

Studies of several plans for improving the seven blocks of cityowned land in Chrystie and Forsyth Streets with model apartments are now in the final stages, and announcement of some definite program considered practicable for this long-delayed project, may be expected from the city administration shortly, according to John H. Tennant, Deputy City Planning Commissioner.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 29. -- General Ken Wang of China, who was arrested by the Japanese Army as a spy, was graduated from Princeton University in 1915 with honors from the Department of History and Politics. He was ranked fourteenth in a class of 116 for the degree of Bachelor of Literature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Opponents of legislation to permit producers of branded goods to fix retail prices told the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today that such a measure would increase the cost of living and foster monopolies.

Dr. Irving Langmuir, distinguished research scientist and associate director of the laboratories of the General Electric Company at Schenectady, received yesterday the $10,000 award and gold medal offered annually by Popular Science Monthly "for notable scientific achievement."

Jerry Lang of the Columbia University Club, well-known lawn tennis player, and N. H. Aronsohn of the Princeton Club provided two unexpected victories last night in the national Class B squash tennis championship on the Columbia courts.

HELSINGFORS, England, Feb. 29 (AP). -- A Facist march on the capital today encountered government troops twenty-five miles away and a clash of arms ensued, but its outcome was not immediately apparent because of crippled communications.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 29. -- Although Harvard's varsity basketball team made a fine start and a better finish, its in-between punch was lacking and it lost a thrilling game to the University of Pittsburgh in the Harvard Athletic Building tonight. The score was 28 -- 25.

The dress strike yesterday presented the anomalous situation of the union members ratifying the tentative agreement reached with one group of manufacturers and arranging to return to work today, but remaining deadlocked with the second manufacturers' group.

ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 29. -- Governor Roosevelt has appointed John E. Sheehy, Tammany leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District and close friend of Tammany Leader John F. Curry, as Sheriff of New York County to succeed Thomas M. Farley, whom the Governor removed from office a week ago after a hearing on charges preferred by Samuel Seabury, counsel of the Hofstadter committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP). -- A vigorous protest was voiced before the House Agricultural Committee today by representatives of the Cotton Exchange and traders against a bill empowering the Secretary of Agriculture to limit or prohibit short selling on the commodity exchanges.
Izzy Presaer, notorious New York gunman and racketeer, was fount shot dead last night in an abandonee automobile in front of a factory a 605 North Third Street, Newark, N. J.

TODAY a dark-haired young man with a pleasant smile and a determined-looking chin comes out of the West to take over one of the most difficult assignments in the field of college sports. Herbert Orrin Crisler of the Universities of Chicago and Minnesota is in New Jersey, arranging the last details of his transfer to Princeton University as head coach of football.

The work of wrecking the old tenements on the southeast corner of Market and Henry Streets, the site of the first unit of Fred F. French's new housing project designed to rehabilitate a large part of the lower east side slum district adjacent to the East River between Manhattan and Brooklyn Bridges, will be started this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Loans from the Reconstruction Finance Correction totaling $221,578,961 have been requested by twenty-four railroad companies, and of twelve applications for an aggregate of $165,267,909 reviewed the Interstate Commerce Commission has approved loans of $51,545,175.
HONOLULU, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Two men, one a paroled convict, were held today by police in their investigation of the latest of a series of sex crimes that have aroused Honolulu in recent months.

Recent developments points definitely in the direction of improvement in the economic situation and return of prosperity, General W. W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, told members of the New York Zone Transportation Club at their annual dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

Rallying strongly in the second half after trailing by 11 -- 6, the James Monroe High School basketball team scored its sixth consecutive victory in the Bronx Division P.S.A.L. tournament yesterday, defeating Theodore Roosevelt, 18 to 16, on the Monroe court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Charging dramatic critics with "knowing nothing and ruining the legitimate theatre by posing as know-it-alls," the House Patents Committee today voted unanimously to invite them to explain what the committee chairman called their destructive criticism.
Cruises around the world, trips to Europe or short holiday jaunts on the high seas are now possible on the instalment plan.

An imperative need for refinancing of defaulted real estate bond issues is the most acute problem now faced by the mortgage market, in the opinion of Brooks. Harvey Co., Inc., mortgage brokers, who are convinced that no marked improvement in the basic real estate situation can occur until the problem has been solved.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Feb. 29 (AP). -- They placed a floral wreath on the tousled black hair of a local youth who made good, perched him atop an automobile and paraded him up High Street tonight while four bands played, red torches flared and at least half of the 20,000 inhabitants rendered vocal homage.

LONDON, Feb. 29. -- The tone on the Stock Exchange was cheerful today. British Government funds were still in good demand, but prices closed below the highest of the day, the war loan finishing at u100 3/4.
LONDON, Feb. 29. -- At 5 P.M. today Britain's historic free-trade policy ended after eighty years.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 29. -- Unemployment faces more than 5,000 foreigners in this city and thousands in other parts of Mexico with the coming into effect tomorrow of the new labor law which provides that at least 90 per cent of the employes of the industrial, financial and commercial concerns in the country must be Mexican citizens.

The trial of Reynolds Forsbrey, slayer and former life termer in Auburn Prison, and two other men, charged with holding up the office of the Baltimore and Ohio Coach Company at 35 West Thirty-third Street on Dec. 16, began in Judge Nott's part of General Sessions yesterday with the selection of a jury from a special panel of talesmen.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 29 (AP). -- Kansas officials termed the case in the United States Supreme Court a "most important" victory in their efforts to force a reduction in gas rates charged by concerns affiliated with the Cities Service Company.

ALBANY, Feb. 29. -- The problems of taxation, and especially the method of raising the $19,000,000 required for additional State relief for the unemployed was one of the chief topics of discussion at the Capitol today. Strong opposition is developing to the proposed amusement levy of 10 per cent, although the midwinter session of the Mayor's conference lined up behind the measure.

Dan Callahan, 22 years old, who was paroled from the New York City Reformatory just before Christmas, was shot and killed yesterday and a 23-year-old companion was slightly hurt in a free-for-all fight between two detectives and a parole office and three youthful criminals in a third-floor apartment at 142 West Forty-sixth Street.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Feb. 29. -- Edgar T. Appleby of New York, holder of the title, won a four-hour battle by 300 to 296 from Ray V. Fessenden of Madison, Wia., Western, champion, in the national amateur 18.2 balkline championship tournament tonight.

Fumes from a coal-burning furnace in the basement overcame seven persons in a double five-story converted apartment house at 156 West Sixty-fifth Street last night. All were revived either by physicians or pulmotors in charge of three emergency squads from the Consolidated Gas Company.

DAIREN, Manchuria, Tuesday, March 1. -- Late information from Harbin indicates that the Japanese failed to obtain the permission of the Soviet authorities to transport troops over the Chinese Eastern Railway, notwithstanding yesterday's dispatches from Moscow.

Conferences of the world's leading copper producers were resumed here yesterday, but failed to produce an agreement on further curtailment of production and on new rules for Copper Exporters, Inc., which controls the sale of the metal abroad.

HELSINGFORS, Finland. Feb. 29. -- All the forces of the government were called into action today to protect the capital against the Invasion of the Lapuan-Fascist "army," which was concentrating at Mantsala, about forty miles north of here, to attempt to force its various demands on the government.

Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee, returned to his office yesterday and lost no time in asserting that his Cincinnati speech attacking Tammany Hall as a menace to the nation was not inspired by political ambition.
HONOLULU, Feb. 29. -- Every possible kind of rumor and opinion can be heard on the Massie case. There have been stories of confessions, equally emphatic denials and every kind of slander.

Five men, accused as leaders of a Building trades racket which several years ago resulted in the destruction by fire of $3,000,000 worth of building work in the Bronx, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on the charge that they failed to report to the government their incomes from extortion.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 29. -- The election of members of the sophomore class at Princeton University to the upper-class eating clubs in Prospect Street began today, opening what is known as "Bicker Week." A total of 368 had been elected tonight.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 29. -- General Tsai Ting-chai, youthful and scholarly commander of China's Nineteenth Route Army, is a veteran of 170 military campaigns, although he is only 39 years old.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange extended its recovery moderately yesterday, led by the foreign group, in which gains by Japanese, German and Argentine bonds were prominent. Domestic railroad issues were helped by the news that eight roads had received authority from the Interstate Commerce Commission to obtain loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Mrs. Harriet Scudder Keator, organist of St. Andrews Methodist Episcopal Church at 122 West Seventy-sixth Street, died at her home at 305 West End Avenue last night. She was widely known among musicians in the East, having served for some years as president of the New Jersey Council of the National Association of Organists.
Call and time loan Interest rates remained stationary throughout February and were slightly below those of the previous month on an average, but above the rates prevailing a year ago.

In yesterday's generally inactive markets, the upward trend of bonds was the more noteworthy incident. Domestic securities in that market moved again with irregularity, but foreign securities as a rule went higher, carrying further last week's general trend toward recovery.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am profoundly concerned about the agitation started at the instance of President Lowell of Harvard, Newton D. Baker and hundreds of other more or less well-known individuals to prejudge the merits of the Japanese question.

HAVANA, Feb. 29 (AP). -- First indications -- and they were only indirect ones -- that the Liberals of President Gerardo Machado were winning in Sunday's municipal primary elections, came today from Havana returns.

The only way to put the hotel and restaurant business back on a prosperous basis is to modify the Volstead act and permit the sale of wines and beer and thus win back the patronage that the speakeasies have taken away, speakers asserted yesterday afternoon at a mass meeting under the auspices of the recently organized Hotel, Restaurant, Club and Allied Industries Association in the Astor.
Chester W. Drummon and Matthew J. Looram have retired from the firm of J.L. McCormack Co., members of the New York Curb Exchange. Thomas W. Hollingsworth has become resident partner in Philadelphia.

Alabama reported the employment of 2,282 men and women in five communities, the largest number of new jobs found in one day since the beginning of the United Action Group's campaign for a million jobs, it was announced yesterday at the national headquarters of the war against depression at the Hotel Biltmore.

The first sixty railroads to report earnings for January showed net operating incomes of $9,958,000, against $30,092,000 in January, 1931, a drop of 66.9 per cent, and against $47,998,000 in January, 1930, a fall of 79.2 per cent. In December their net income was $24,740,000, against $43,740,000 in December, 1930, a drop of 44.8 per cent.

The third Leap Year Assembly of a series organized in 1924 was held last night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. It was one of the largest dances of the late Winter and, befitting the extra day of the year, was almost an exact counterpart of those subscription dances arranged annually for young women of society -- the Junior, Knickerbocker and Friday assemblies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The text of President Hoover's message to Congress recommending the strengthening of the procedure of the judicial system reads as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Denying that the Democratic highway emergency bill authorizing an expenditure of $132,500,000 before June 30, 1933, would fail to relieve the unemployment situation, Representative Lindsay Warren of North Carolina, today termed a statement made yesterday by Secretary Hyde a "piece of unmitigated gall."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- President Hoover in a special message to Congress today urged the passage, step by step, of legislation for "substantial Improvement" in the administration of justice.
TOKYO, Tuesday, March 1. -- There is an unbroken silence in official circles here regarding the delicate peace negotiations at Shanghai-u hopeful sign-and press comment If cautious but favorable.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29. -- The harmful effects of hoarded money were described to the people today by Calvin Coolidge in a message released through the Chicago branch of the Citizens Reconstruction Organization.
BERLIN, Feb. 29. -- The German Reichstag's one characteristic in common with the Congress of the United States is that no broadcasting of speeches is permitted from its floor.

An Ancient Hoarding. The report of the archaeological finds in Egypt, by the field director of the University of Pennsylvania Museum, includes mention of hoarding as futile as some that is occurring today.
President HOOVER sent to Congress yesterday his promised message on revision, of the criminal laws and improvement in court procedure.

MADRID, Feb. 29. -- A fantastic plan for a civil war to restore the Bourbon court, based on the recementing of factions which caused bloody strife in the nineteenth century, was the centre of new Monarchist activities and discussions here today. These discussions give definite terms to a previously rumored agreement between Basque anti-Republicans and Alfonsist Liberals of Central and Southern Spain.

Two knockout blows were struck last night in the West Fifty-fourth Street Night Court when one of thirty prisoners in the detention pen became insubordinate and punched a court attendant. Two plain-clothes patrolmen came to the rescue of the fallen attendant in time to prevent a riot in the court.

BERLIN, Feb. 29. -- Prices on the Boerse fluctuated today, but the market as a whole showed considerable power of resistance. The turnover was small. All the electric securities continued to decline, spreading a certain pessimism throughout the market. Trading still is far from normal, as there are no official quotations.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange during February was the lightest for any month since last August. The total for the month amounted to 31,718,556 shares, compared with 34,342,456 shares in January and 64,145 shares in the same month a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The United States gave its approval and promise of cooperation in advance to the Council of the League of Nations in the suggestions made to China and Japan today for peace at Shanghai. This was announced this afternoon at the State Department after a week-end devoted intensively by Secretary Stimson to the problem.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Solicitor General Thacher in his report on the bankruptcy situation which the President sent to Congress today asserts that the law, as now written, does not attain its objective. He said it encourages and facilitates fraud on the part of insolvent debtors and permits the exploitation of its own process, while the administration of the law is expensive, slow-moving and unsatisfactory to the business community.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Progress in framing the new tax bill was so rapid today as to cause its authors to predict that the complete draft would be ready for action of the Ways and Means Committee by Wednesday.

Former Sheriff Thomas M. Farley announced yesterday, at the close the first session of his trial for grand larceny in General Sessions, that he was preparing to seek legal relief from the order under which he was removed from office by Governor Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- By the dispatch of an open letter to Secretary Stimson today, demanding that he announce his attitude on a wet plank at the Republican National Convention, Representative La Guardia of New York City laid the prohibition issue at the inner door of the Hoover Administration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Solicitor General Thacher's report to President Hoover on bankruptcies showed that the number of cases concluded quadrupled in the last decade.

The six-day bicycle race coursed into its second twenty-four-hour session at Madison Square Garden last night, while a crowd of 8,000 persons looked on. Fired by the stirring riding of the opening night, the teams engaged in the busy whirl continued to blaze around the pine saucer, each combination intent upon procuring the position at the head of the pack.

The freighter Gypsum Queen, the loss of which caused the Canadian reparations commission to pay $71,000 in the belief that she was disabled by a German, submarine in July, 1915, and abandoned off the coast of Ireland, was actually wrecked by natural forces at sea, according to witnesses who appeared yesterday before Chief Justice Horace Harvey of Alberta at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

About a dozen modern hymns were tried for the first time by about 200 Methodist Episcopal ministers of the metropolitan area yesterday morning at the headquarters of the Methodist Book Concern, 150 Fifth Avenue.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 29. -- Mrs. Roy Pollard's Uluniu captured the featured Gables Handicap as the Gables Racing Association reopened its gates at Tropical Park today for its second meeting. Splendid weather and ideal racing conditions attracted a large crowd, which cheered the victory of Uluniu, the favorite.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 29 (AP). -- United States Senator Daniel O. Hastings of Delaware was appointed receiver today in Chancery Court for General Theatres Equipment, Inc., of New York, a holding company controlling Fox Film Corporation, Fox Theatres Corporation and other interests.

Formation of a huge International investment trust, with capital of at least u50,000,000 to be subscribed by investors of such large gold-holding countries as the United States, France and India, is recommended as the surest way in which to bring England and otter important countries back to the gold standard by J. H. Clifford Johnstonr president of the Guardian Investment Trust Company, Ltd., of England.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 29. -- Jesse Hill, recruit purchased by the Yankees from the Hollywood team of the Pacific Coast League, reported to Managrer McCarthy today with his salary differences adjusted and ready to try for a position in the outfield.

Although strongly opposed to some of the major provisions of the Transit Commission's tentative $474,500,000 subway unification plan the B. M.T. and Interborough will file appearances at the first public hearing, to be held today in the commission's offices at 270 Madison.

The Architectural League of New York has taken no action on the resignations of George Howe and William Lescaze, who withdrew from the organization last week because work which they had submitted for the annual exhibition of the league, now in progress, was rejected.

Two college presidents, a woman leader in civic affairs and several of the city's leading business and professional men were among the eleven district chairmen appointed yesterday to direct the work of organizing individual city blocks for the aid of the unemployed.

Those who were young in the latter part of the nineteenth century had repeated in their ears the lines of Senator INGALLS of Kansas, reminding them that if they doubted or hesitated when opportunity "knocked unbidden at the gate," they would be condemned to failure, penury and woe, for "the master of human destinies " would return no more.

Governor ROOSEVELT long ago put his finger on what is today the weakest spot in the whole American system of government The Federal Government has been overloaded and stands in need of trimming and fitting. The cities have not all lived down their ancient ill-repute, but at least they manage today to discharge hundreds of functions of which Lord BRYCE never dreamed, and sometimes tbey' do it in quite the modern manner.

The loan exhibition of American portraits by contemporary American artists, sponsored by Mrs. William Randolph Hearst and held for the benefit of the Free Milk Coffee Stations for the unemployed, opened with a reception yesterday afternoon at the American Art-Anderson Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Every borough in the city except Manhattan will pay a higher full tax rate than last year, according to Controller Charles W. Berry, who announced yesterday the borough rates to be added to the basic rate of 2.59, which was announced last week.

Difficulties between Jews and Arabs in Palestine are being satisfactorily adjusted, Lord Snell of Plumstead, former Under-Secretary of State for India in the MacDonald Labor Government, declared yesterday afternoon at a reception given by Mrs. Portia Willis Berg, at 14 East Sixtieth Street, under the auspices of the Fellowship of Faiths.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Inside details of the methods employed by the government in "cleaning up" the Al Capone gang at Chicago were disclosed tonight in a nation-wide radio broadcast by David Burnet, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, whose branch of the Treasury Department conducted the investigation which brought about the conviction of the gangsters as income-tax evaders.

ROSELLE, N. J., Feb. 29. -- Augustus Smith, for many years a member of the New Jersey State commission of Commerce and Navigation, president of the Bergen Point Iron Works, Bayonne, and an inventor and civil engineer, died suddenly of heart disease at his home in Raritan Road here this morning.
MOSCOW, Feb. 29. -- "However the Shanghai operations turn out, one thing can now be said with confidence: the legend about the invincible Japanese army is shattered."

The program given by the London String Quartet at Town Hall last night had the merits of variety, novelty and brevity that left a large audience clamoring for more. They played quartets by Haydn, Malipiero and Beetaoven. The Haydn and Malipiero were first performances in New York.

Immediate and detailed survey of the air route to Europe by way of Canada, Greenland, Iceland, the Faroe Islands and England, with a view to establishing a transatlantic mail line, awaits only the sanction of the government of Iceland of a bill just introduced in the Parliament there.

TOKYO, Feb. 29. -- The immediate States of the tension in Northern Manchuria is reported to have been removed by the submission of General Ting Chao to the new Kirin provincial government. On the strength of this, according to messages from Mukden, General Honjo has countermanded the 125-mile Japanese march upon Imienpo.

Vicki Baum's "And Life Goes On", another of her tales of packed hours in the life of many people tangled in the net of one primary happening, published by Doubleday, Doran, is the Book-of-the-Month Club choice for March. The scene is the Old-World town of Lohwinkel, the events are those following an accident there.

The presiding Bishop and other Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church have taken a 10 per cent salary cut along with the rank and file of that denomination's workers to meet the $1,000,000 deficit of the national church organization, it was revealed yesterday.

WARSAW, Fab. 29. -- A plan to establish a monarchy in Poland, with the young Crown Prince Michael of Rumania as the prospective King of a united kingdom of Poland and Rumania, was discussed at a meeting of prominent pro-Pilsudski Conservatives, the Socialist newspaper Robotnik revealed today.

With all the simulated ferocity of opposing helmeted and cuirassed " supe " soldiers on the stage, Democratic and Republican champions are glaring and mouthing and flinging out taunts, defiances, swelling words and " claims." These harmless demonstrations please the demonstrators and amuse those whom they don't bore.

In the Cuban elections on Sunday, which were to lay the foundation for reorganization of the Liberal, Conservative and Popular parties, the Liberals, supporting the administration of President MACHADO, naturally scored heavily. Since the collapse of the revolt in August he has skillfully used his advantage to strengthen his party.

TORONTO, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Nine "public enemies of savings" were enumerated today by Laurence H. Sloan, vice president of Standard Statistics Company of New York in an address before the Canadian Club. Partly because of their own efforts, but more because of "bull luck," the people of North America had a better chance of working out for themselves an ultimate economic Utopia than had any other people, Sloan said.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29. -- Prices of hogs advanced 5 to 15 cents today to a new high for the month, due to light receipts. The latter were the smallest with one exception since last October. The quality, while better than last Saturday, was regarded as unusually poor for a Monday, and medium weights finished weak.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter recently appearing in THE TIMES -- "Rediscounting the Dollar" -- is deserving of careful consideration. The effect that hoarding is having on every one is very marked, and the result of this movement seems to be definitely in the direction of slowing the business revival.

BASLE, Switzerland, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Arrangements have been virtually completed, it was learned today, to renew the $100,000,000 central bank credit to Germany from March 4, when it expires, to June 4, with 10 per cent amortization.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 29. -- The Board of Supervisors approved today the apportionment of county and State taxation upon the eighteen towns and four cities, the apportionment of sewer taxes upon the several sewer districts, and obtained from Fred Telford, head of the Bureau of Public Personnel Administration of Chicago, his report recommending methods of management in Westchester County departments.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 29 (AP). -- American trade has been hard hit by the Shanghai hostilities, and there is no prospect of any material improvement soon Julean Arnold, United States commercial attache, estimated today that 75 per cent of the cargoes coming into Shanghai for more than a month had been placed in bonded warehouses and could not he moved.

The committee of St. Louis South-western Railway stockholders headed by J.F.B. Mitchell of Wood, Low Co., sent to the stockholders yesterday a letter advising them that if they wished to accept the offer of merger with the Southern Pacific Company they should deposit their stock with the Guaranty Trust Company.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 29 (AP). -- A notice of intention to appeal to the Federal Circuit Court in an effort to recover more than $150,000 they claim they loaned the defunct Guaranty Building and Loan Association was filed today by John Barrymore, the actor, and his wife, Dolores Costello.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Starting with nearly 200 runs contributed by the opening batsmen, South Africa had placed itself in a strong position when its first innings in the test cricket match with New Zealand were completed today.

COPENHAGEN, Feb. 29. -- Politicen's correspondent, who this morning tried to get through the rebel front line in Finland, said the out-posts of the rebels had moved a few miles nearer Helsingfors and overhead government airplanes were scouting.

ALBANY, Tuesday, March 1. -- After a long debate, featured by Democratic attacks on Samuel Seabury's Cincinnati speech, the Assembly early this morning passed the bill appropriating $250,000 for continuing the Hofstadter Committee's inquiry in New York City.
Applications to list securities on the two local stock exchanges in February consisted, principally, of listing additional bonds and stocks by companies already having issues on the boards.

MONTREAL, Feb. 29 (Canadian Press). -- Harvey (Busher) Jackson, left wing of the Toronto Maple Leafs, has forged to the front among the National Hockey League point-makers, according to the scoring list issued tonight from the office of President Frank Calder.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 29. -- Judge David A. Wilson, former postmaster, has been selected by Governor Cross as the Democratic State chairman and is slated to be the unanimous choice of the State committee at a harmony meeting here March 11.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 29. -- The longest term bonds ever sold by Nassau County will be issued this week to redeem tax anticipatory notes and prevent the country from defaulting on payment, it was made known today. The issue will be for $4,500,000 for seven years, bearing interest at 6 per cent, the highest rate ever paid by the county.

A third rival camp was added, to the confused structure of contract bridge yesterday when George Reith, bridge expert and chief exponent of the one-over-one system of bidding, opened his first annual convention for bridge teachers at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Union Pacific Railroad and the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway would merge with certain of their respective subsidiaries under plans to be submitted to stockholders at their next annual meetings. The Union Pacific proposes to merge its subsidiaries by lease, while the Rock Island would go further and completely absorb lines which it already operates under lease, thus enlarging the basis for its first and refunding mortgage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The political truce between the Republicans and Democrats in Congress on the administration's economic program has apparently ended, according to Senator Connally, Democrat, of Texas, who said so in a speech in the Senate today.

BURLINGTON, III., Feb. 29 (AP). -- Although one robber was shot at the wheel of a bandit car today while his three confederates were robbing the Burlington State Bank of $1,500, all four men escaped in their bullet-scarred automobile.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29. -- The State University of New Jersey, now operated in conjunction with Rutgers at New Brunswick, is the ultimate beneficiary of the bulk of a $128,000 estate left by Edward Randolph Wood, lawyer and business man, who died on Feb. 14 in his ninety-second year.
ALBANY, Feb. 29. -- Following is the text of Governor Roosevelt's specail message to the Legislature urging appointment of a commission to make a survey of local government:

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, March 1. -- Japanese sailors resumed the fighting on the Chapel front today and pushed the advances they made Monday in the area of the Japanese cemetery a total of 1,500 feet, while the Japanese army lines adjoining the sailors' front captured the small villages of Yenkachal and Choukachal.
MANILA, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt fulfilled one of his father's cherished ambitions today when he became Governor General of the Philippine Islands.

Dividends declared by corporations in February were smaller in the aggregate than a year ago, reflecting poor earnings. The total of payments ordered by 792 corporations was 5374,032,531, compared with $468,257,250 for 972 corporations a year before.

Mme, Luisa Tetrazzini sat back luxuriously in a Nile-green armchair in her suite at the Hotel Ritz Towers yesterday, and discussed singers and singing, past and present. She arrived from Buffalo recently, and on Friday will make her first appearance before a New York audience in more than ten years.

A sentence of three months in the workhouse was imposed in Special Sessions yesterday on Joseph H. Hoadley, 68 years old, formerly a conspicuous figure in the financial district, for tendering a worthless check for $1,037 last year on a Went Fifty-eighth Street restaurant owner in payment for food and loans.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Making the second start of his career, Walter D., a 3-year-old owned by W. Diebold, today won the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds. In his only other start, four days ago, the son of Dress Parade finished third.

In the face of a gale in the English Channel, many small ships struggled into British ports yesterday in a last-minute effort to unload their cargoes before the new tariff became effective. With the opening of the Custom Houses this morning England ceases to be a free-trade country.

Price trend in commodities continued lower yesterday. The most significant reaction was that in sugar, which dropped to the record low of 0.80, for the March contract. However, a strong closing carried the list up 3 to 5 points over Saturday. Copper, rubber and eggs also established new lows. Losses elsewhere were reported in the grains, cotton, coffee, cocoa and butter. Steadiness prevailed in other articles.

The Boy Scouts blew whistles yesterday afternoon, doga barked, a parrot screamed, several turtles scraped their shells against cardboard boxes and then Mr. and Mrs. John Held Jr., the cartoonist and his wife, were ushered into the auditorium of the Kips Bay Boys' Club at 301 East Fifty-second Street.

GENEVA, Feb. 29. -- Despite the setting up last week of five committees to deal with the various aspects of the disarmament problem it has not yet been decided at which end that problem can first be tackled.

Dividends declared by corporations in February were smaller in the aggregate than a year ago, reflecting poor earnings. The total of payments ordered by 792 corporations was 5374,032,531, compared with $468,257,250 for 972 corporations a year before.

Mme, Luisa Tetrazzini sat back luxuriously in a Nile-green armchair in her suite at the Hotel Ritz Towers yesterday, and discussed singers and singing, past and present. She arrived from Buffalo recently, and on Friday will make her first appearance before a New York audience in more than ten years.

A sentence of three months in the workhouse was imposed in Special Sessions yesterday on Joseph H. Hoadley, 68 years old, formerly a conspicuous figure in the financial district, for tendering a worthless check for $1,037 last year on a Went Fifty-eighth Street restaurant owner in payment for food and loans.

Governor ROOSEVELT has recommended the findings of the Committee on Workmen's Compensation Insurance to the prompt attention of the Legislature. The members of the committee are well qualified for the study of conditions prevailing under the present compensation law.

PINEHUBST, N.C., Feb. 29. -- Lieut. Commander Frederick Holmes of the U.S.S. Milwaukee almost provided a major upset in the Spring golf tournament quarter-finals today when he took Eric D. Thomson of Springfield, Mass., the medalist, to the nineteenth hole before acknowledging defeat.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29. -- The wheat market continues to hold within narrow limits, but the undertone on the Board of Trade was easier today, due to scattered selling because of fears that tomorrow's private estimates of farm reserves would be bearish. Liverpool was also easy, and nothing in the news prompted enthusiastic buying.

Reorganization of the property and business of the Indiana Limestone Company has been recommended to the present security holders by protective committees representing the bonds, debentures and preferred and common stocks.

LONDON, Feb. 29. -- The first reference in the House of Commons to Secretary of State Stimson's letter to Senator Borah was made tonight by Seymour Cocks, a Labor member, who quoted extracts from both this letter and Mr. Stimson's note to Tokyo of Jan. 7 in a speech urging the British Government to adopt the United States' policy with reference to Manchuria.

CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 29 (AP). -- Word that Charles Kelly was arrested yesterday and that he had confessed was received today from the Chief of Police of Bermuda by Lawrence T. Doran, chief of the Camden County detectives.

A decrease in the number of disciplinary cases and an improved attitude toward school life in general are some results of the aid that needy school children are receiving through the school relief fund, it was reported yesterday to Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, at a meeting of district superintendents at the Board of Education Building.

Rallies from an opening decline on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday were attributed to trade buying and covering promoted by reports of a continued steady spot basis in the South and opening advances in the stock market, but prices eased later under a little Southern selling and realizing or liquidation.

Polly and Dolly, the sister-team of pelicans at the Central Park Zoo, who literally leaped into the socalled public eye yesterday because they were celebrating their thirty-sixth birthday, cannot -- as the saying goes -- take it. Despite all their years and experience right out in the open, they are still just two shy little things.

Wall Street's Interest in the stock market was still restricted yesterday. The total volume on the Stock Exchange was only about 900,000 shares, and price movements failed to reveal any positive trend, suggesting that speculators were engaged in a mild tug of war.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 29. -- As the result of a suggestion made today at a Senate hearing on four bills giving the Public Utility Commission jurisdiction over operation of motor trucks, the question may be studied by a legislative committee in conjunction with the utility board before any action is taken on the measure.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 29. -- Dick McGraw, Cornell centre, won tonight's Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game with Yale by throwing the most spectacular basket of the contest with exactly three seconds of play remaining.

New financing in February was virtually at a standstill. In the first half of the month no new bonds were floated by New York firms, and the few offerings in the closing weeks consisted of Canadian, public utility. State and municipal issues. Only one small stock issue was marketed.

Copyright. 1932, by The Associated Press. SHANGHAI, Tuesday, March 1. -- The staff of General Yoshinori Shirakawa, who has been expected to become Commander-in-Chief of the Japanese forces here, landed today at Woosung from a cruiser. Japanese officers said General Shirakawa had come ashore at an undivulged spot.

More than 200 representatives of business and civic organizations, as well as bankers and industrialists, assembled yesterday in the great hall of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street, and opened President Hoover's antihoarding campaign in this city and vicinity.
No transactions were recorded yesterday on the Real Estate Securities Exchange.

The shooting of Roderick Roberts, 68 years old, of 622 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, who was found dead Saturday night in the front office of his surgical instrument concern at 339 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, remained a mystery yesterday.

Wall Street's Interest in the stock market was still restricted yesterday. The total volume on the Stock Exchange was only about 900,000 shares, and price movements failed to reveal any positive trend, suggesting that speculators were engaged in a mild tug of war.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 29. -- As the result of a suggestion made today at a Senate hearing on four bills giving the Public Utility Commission jurisdiction over operation of motor trucks, the question may be studied by a legislative committee in conjunction with the utility board before any action is taken on the measure.

More than 200 representatives of business and civic organizations, as well as bankers and industrialists, assembled yesterday in the great hall of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street, and opened President Hoover's antihoarding campaign in this city and vicinity.
No transactions were recorded yesterday on the Real Estate Securities Exchange.

The shooting of Roderick Roberts, 68 years old, of 622 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, who was found dead Saturday night in the front office of his surgical instrument concern at 339 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, remained a mystery yesterday.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted:
The Columbia University basketball team, displaying a strong attack which functioned effectively throughout, overwhelmed the St. Stephen's quintet, 52 to 13, in the Columbia gym last night.

President Hoover's request to reform the bankruptcy laws and the major provisions embodied in Attorney General Thacher's bill to amend the present statutes were endorsed here yesterday by credit men as being important steps in reducing the huge losses to business incurred through commercial failures.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Debentures of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation amounting to $200,000,000 will be issued within a short time, Governor Eugene Meyer of the Federal Reserve Board and chairman of the directorate of the corporation, said today.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S appointment of Mr. JOHN E. SHEEHY to be Sheriff of New York County in place of THOMAS M. FARLEY, removed, gives fresh point to the saying that circumstances alter cases. Under ordinary conditions little or no criticism would be made of this selection by the Governor.

To the Editor of The New York Times : I am writing about a deplorable situation that now exists in many of our local hospitals having ambulance services. In general these institutions accept as many free and part-pay cases as the state of their finances permit.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of $2,102,000 to the Western Pacific Railroad wag approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. It was one of the few cases in which the commission sanctioned the full amount requested.
