The pamplet report of the Engineers Public Service Company for 1931 shows a net income of $6,440,955 after taxes, charges, depreciation, subsidiary preferred dividends and minority interest. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $2.15 a share earned on 1,909,734 common shares.

MOSCOW, March 1. -- Interesting light on Lenin's standards, and therefore on those of the Soviet, since his writings are more and more becoming Bolshevist gospel, is thrown by a hitherto unpublished letter in today's Pravda, written from Zurich in October, 1916, on the subject of the assassination of Premier Sturgk of Austria by Fritz Adler.

Financial markets lapsed yesterday into greater inactivity. With only 730,000 shares changing hands on the Stock Exchange, the day was a reminiscence of 1921 and 1922, before Wall Street had ever heard of 5,000,000 -share markets such as became commonplace in 1929.

A defense of Japan's military activity at Shanghai as being based on self-protection was sent yesterday by the Denkikyokai, the Electrical Association of Japan, through the New York offices of Mitsui Co., Ltd., to members of the electrical trade and professional organizations in the United States.

Limiting itself to four witnesses, the prosecution in the trial of Thomas M. Farley, former Sheriff, for grand larceny, established yesterday that while in office he took $118.74 from the interest on a fund entrusted to his official care.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 1 -- Herbert O. Crisler, Princeton's new football coach, arrived today to discuss plans for taking over his duties, which he will assume as soon as he is able to arrange for his departure from the University of Minnesota, where he has been athletic director.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 1 -- Harry Hooper, former major league outfielder, coach of the Princeton varsity baseball team, held the first practice for the Tigers today and thirty members of the 1931 squad answered the call. A veteran pitching staff, with Captain Bowman as the star; two catchers and several infielders form the nucleus around which Coach Hooper will mold the 1932 team.

Leaders in many fields gathered last night at New York University's first all-university dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria as part of the university's centennial. More than 1,600 alumni were present as thirty-four of their number received the newly created alumni meritorious service award from Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown.

Implementing of the Kellogg pact by a protocol or treaty which would provide for consultative action by the signatory nations and the application of economic sanctions as means of preventing or stopping armed conflict are urged by the Committee on Economic Sanctions headed by President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University in a report submitted yesterday.
GENEVA, March 1 -- It is not because everybody does not want to get started that this world disarmament conference does not start.
The national Class B squash tennis championship, in progress at the Columbia University Club, came down to the semi-finals last night with both the first and second seeded players out of the running.

Miniature representations of former Broadway musical successes, with the running time of each one reduced to an hour and twenty minutes, will be offered in the Publix circuit of motion picture houses by Joe DeMilt, veteran theatrical man. Two shows, already acquired by Mr. DeMilt from Schwab Mandel, are "Follow Thru," the musical comedy by Laurence Schwab, B.G. DeSylva, Lew Brown and Ray Henderson, and "The New Moon," the operetta by Oscar Hammerstein 2d.

The first dividend reduction by an Important New York bank since the financial crisis began was announced yesterday when directors of the National City Bank declared a quarterly payment to stockholders of 75 cents, thus placing the shares of the bank on a $3 annual dividend basis, compared with $4, which had been paid since October, 1929.

RENO, Nev., March 1 -- Mrs. Viola Wilson Lon, wife of Bert Lown, orchestra leader and former business associate of Rudy Valee, has arrived here and plans to sue for divorce on charges of cruelty. It is understood that the couple have agreed on a property settlement and the custody of a 5-year-old daughter, Virginia.

William Longfelder, vice president of H. Kohnstamm Co., laundry supply house at 87 Park Place, recalled as a witness yesterday in the public inquiry by State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. into the laundry industry in New York City, testified he had suggested the removal of signs advertising low rates from the wagons of a Brooklyn laundry owner.

The faults of Mary Todd Lincoln were pathological; perhaps as early as 1861 she was a case for a psychiatrist, and the bitter criticism that fell to her while her husband was being virtually enshrined served definitely to accentuate her abnormality, Dr. W.A. Evans writes in "Mrs. Abraham Lincoln," which Alfred A. Knopf will bring out this week.

In the course of his travels Mayor CURLEY of Boston has talked politics with more than 250 Democrats, selected from various parts of the country, and found 95 per cent of them in favor of the nomination of Governor ROOSEVELT. Returned to Massachusetts, he finds the picture reversed.

Trading on the Stock Exchange was less active yesterday and the price movements were irregular. Wall Street was only casually interested in the proceedings. The railway shares lost ground slightly; the industrial, utility and miscellaneous groups made a trifling gain, if the averages be used as a yardstick.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, March 1 (Canadian Press) -- Collapsing in its second innings on a wearing wicket, New Zealand was defeated by South Africa today in the test cricket match by an innings and twelve runs. South Africa scored 451, and New Zealand 293 and 146 for an agregate of 439.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES on Wednesday, March 2, 1853, published the following article as a paid advertisement:

Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr. was born at the home of Mrs. Lindbergh's father, the late Ambassador Dwight W. Morrow, in Englewood, N.J., on June 22, 1930. It was Mrs. Lindbergh's twenty-fourth birthday and an occasion for double celebration.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 1 -- The announcement that Nassau County intended to float a seven-year bond issue of $4,500,000 brought today a flood of requests from New York City banks for parts of the issue. The competition was so keen, that the bonds may be sold at less than 6 per cent, the intended interest rate, it was said at the office of County Controller Philip Wiedersum.

Following the expiration Monday night of the temporary rules under which Copper Exporters, Inc., had been functioning since Jan. 1, new provisional rules were put in effect yesterday extending the operations of the export sales body until tomorrow.

The reported "rush" of the British to sell gold ornaments and pocket-pieces in the bullion market is one of those odd incidents which occur spasmodically in depreciatedmoney countries. No one took seriously yesterday's dispatches purporting to estimate the amount thus made available for monetary reserves at u1,000,000,000.

Sentiment regarding the most severe of the Baumes laws has changed a good deal since it was enacted. By sending a fourth offender to prison for life the sponsors of that legislation thought they were placing on the statute books a provision which would act as a deterrent to other evildoers.

AMHERST, Mass., March 1 -- Violation of rules of Amherst College prohibiting student use of automobiles except within certain limits resulted today in the suspension for a year of Jeremiah Ingersoll, son of Raymond V. Ingersoll, political adviser to Governor Roosevelt of New York.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 1 (AP) -- The pendulum swung today in the favor of the colony of Jamaica in its cricket match with Lord Tennyson's team of touring English county and international players before a crowd of 4,000.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Immediate full payment of World War veterans' adjusted service certificates was proposed to the Senate today by Senator Thomas of Oklahoma under a bond issue plan which he said would greatly increase the money in circulation.

The efforts of Louis Taube to have his bail of $10,000 reduced went awry yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Aaron Levy doubled it on his own initiative after Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee, explained Taube's importance as a witness.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- An investigation of the New York Stock Exchange was recommended today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee. A subcommittee, headed by Senator Walcott, Republican, of Connecticut, immediately began drafting a resolution requesting authority for such an investigation from the Senate.

Volunteers in the block community organization of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee will make about 1,000,000 visits on behalf of families in extreme need of assistance but who have not been helped so far, according to the plans now being completed by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the block organization, and his assistants, it was announced yesterday.

Number of Buyers Here Gained. Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed an increase compared with the preceding week, but still remained under the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

The Horace Mann School for Boys scored a 37-to-13 basketball triumph over Montclair Academy at Horace Mann yesterday At half-time the winners led, 21 to 3. It was Horace Mann's seventh straight victory.

Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr., 20-month-old son of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, was kidnapped between 8:30 and 10 o'clock last night from his crib in the nursery on the second floor of his parents' home at Hopewell, near Princeton, N.J.

Reggie McNamara and his husky partner, Bill Peden, continued to delight their followers by their fine riding in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden last night. The Australian-Canadian combination, known as the championship team because of the presence of McNamara, exhibited the same form which enabled it to remain well up among the leaders since the start of the grind last Sunday night.
SHANGHAI, Wednesday, March 2. -- The Chinese were routed this morning by the Japanese in the most sanguinary battle since the World War.

Approval of legislation to compel commercial banks and trust companies to segregate thrift accounts is recorded in a report made public yesterday by the committee on State legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. The proposed legislation is one of ten bills endorsed in the report, which disapproves thirty others.

The sixteen-story apartment building on the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street, half a block on the avenue and 132 1/2 feet on the street, was bought at a foreclosure sale by the 50 East Seventy-seventh Street Corporation, Morris Jarcho, president, in an action by Samuel A. Telsey versus the Calvin-Morris Corporation and others.

The interest being taken by the average layman, the cooperation of judges, lawyers and litigants, and the adequate use of the present machinery will do more to ease the congestion in the civil courts than additional justices, Judge Frederick E. Crane of the New York State Court of Appeals said yesterday, the eve of his sixty-third birthday.

Copyrighted, 1932. by The Associated Press. HOPEWELL, N.J., Wednesday, March 2. -- Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr., 20-month-old son of the flying Colonel, was kidnapped last night from his nursery in the Lindbergh country home near here. The child, clad in a blue sleeping robe, was put to bed at the usual hour, 7:30 P.M.

SHANGHAI, March 1 -- "Japan wants a truce just now merely to aid her diplomacy, which seeks completely to sterilize the meeting of the League of Nations Assembly on Thursday," according to Eugene Chen. "After that session ends, Tokyo will demand such impossible terms as not even Nanking under Chiang Kai-shek will dare to accept."
The Centenary of Utica. Utica began to celebrate its centenary at midnight yesterday. The mind goes back to another celebration in which Governor CLINTON, "the father of the canal," was honored.

In fifteen episodic scenes Preston Sturges spins out the romance of a dance hall hostess, "Child of Manhattan," which was put on at the Fulton last evening. Mr. Sturges has considerable talent, as his "Strictly Dishonorable" persuaded all of us to believe.

John E. Sheehy, the Tammany district leader selected by Governor Roosevelt to succeed Thomas M. Farley as Sheriff of New York County, said yesterday he would impound the interest on official funds pending legal determination of its ownership.

A downward revision in bill rates of 1/8 on all maturities from 90 days forward was the only development of importance recorded in the day's money market. It was the first reduction in the 90-day rate since midJanuary, this maturity having been passed over in the adjustment which followed the Reserve Bank change last Friday.

The British Treasury has notified American banks that on Friday it will pay off and cancel $150,000,000 of the $200,000,000 one -- year credit obtained by it on last Aug. 28 for the defense of the pound sterling.

The new intercoastal steamship conference which was formed last month and was accepted by all lines operating between ports on the Atlantic and Pacific coasts, after nearly a year of disagreement and rate reductions, started to function yesterday.

Ninety-seven parcels of realty in this city, valued at about $4,250,000, will be offered at forced sale next week, according to the Foreclosure Service Company. The figures show a decrease from the same week a year ago, when 120 properties valued at about $10,000,000 were scheduled to be sold.

GENEVA, March 1. -- Naotake Sato this evening gave Joseph Paul-Boncour, President of the League Council, Tokyo's definite acceptance of the latter's so-called "President's plan" for a Shanghai truce and a round-table discussion. Mr. Sato added that the "details" -- which is to say, the truce -- were to be worked out in Shanghai.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith yesterday gave Frank J. Donahue, chairman of the Democratic Massachusetts State Committee, power of attorney to consent to candidates to the Democratic National Convention to pledge themselves to vote for his nomiantion for President.

BERLIN, March 1 -- The radio broadcast of Dr. Gerhart Hauptmann's oration on Goethe was received excellently here, excepting ten minutes' interruption, which was serious enough to eliminate that part of the address.

Aaron Sapiro, who went to California last Fall with Mayor Walker and Frank P. Walsh to plead for the release of Tom Mooney from San Quentin prison, is under consideration for appointment to the newly created Board of Taxicab Control and may become its first chairman, it was disclosed yesterday.
SHANGHAI, Wednesday, March 2. -- China's army broke and fled today from the Chapei-Kiangwan line in front of Japan's mounting force of arms and men.

Ruth Breton, Sigismond Stojowski and Nino Martini, stars of a "surprise" concert, were warmly greeted by an audience assembled for the sixth of the Columbia concert series in Carnegie Hall last night. They more than earned that welcome. The trio replaced a recital by Richard Crooks.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,138,050 barrels, compared with 2,108,050 in the preceding week, a rise of 30,000 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. The daily average east of California was 1,638,850 barrels, against 1,600,750, a gain of 38,100 barrels.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 1 -- Charles H. Clark, traction expert and inventor, died last night at his residence in his sixty-fourth year.

Bond prices continued steady generally on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with trading quiet. The market for United States Government bonds, which had been firm for some time, relaxed slightly, eight of the eleven active issues selling off 2-32 to 6-32 point and the three others advancing 1-32 to 2-32 point.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP). -- The principle of feeding the hungry with wheat from the Farm Board's bulging bins was embraced today by House Democratic leaders, and they made preparations to pass on Thursday a Senate bill devoting 40,000,000 bushels to this purpose.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 -- Captain John S. Wilbur of the Yale football team headed a group of one hundred candidates for the eleven tonight at a meeting where plans for the Spring practice were outlined by Head Coach Dr. Marvin Stevens, Line Coach Adam Walsh and Rex Root, assistant coach.

PENNS GROVE, N.J., March 1 -- Fire swept eight blocks in the heart of this borough's residential and business section today, leaving in its wake hundreds of homeless, the debris of forty-five dwellings, six business buildings and a church and more than thirty other damaged structures.

The Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation, about one-third owned by the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, reports a net income of $1,943,003 for 1931 after taxes, charges and depreciation. This was equal after preferred dividends to $1.01 a share earned on 1,500,000 common shares.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 2 -- Dispatches to the navy office yesterday aroused hopes of an early victory at Shanghai, but reports received this morning do not confirm yesterday's confident expectations. The first communique read:

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Wheat broke about a cent a bushel early today on the Board of Trade on selling that some traders regarded as liquidation by an Eastern professional, but the market ran into support around 60 cents for May from holders of bids and on resting orders. A fair rally followed, although the close was at net losses of 3/8 to 5/8 cent.

A study of independent retailers in eleven lines of business in Illinois towns, covering the five years ending July, 1930, shows a surprising turnover. The investigation was made by PAUL D. CONVERSE of the department of business organization and operation of the University of Illinois.

Income tax payers in the financial district in great numbers are daily calling on William Duggan, collector of internal revenue at the Custom House, to ask consideration under the provision of the Federal income tax law which provides for an extension of time if a taxpayer can satisfy the Bureau of Internal Revenue that the payment of the tax due on March 15 would work severe hardship or be practically impossible.
Sydenham Hospital, Manhattan Avenue and 124th Street, will open on March 10 a moderate-rate unit for the patients of any doctor in Manhattan and the Bronx, subject to hospital regulations.

Continuing a series of "historical" exhibitions begun a few weeks ago with the fine group of paintings by the Hudson River School artists, the Macbeth Gallery has now on view ten canvases by George Fuller, who was born in 1822 and who died in 1884.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Representative Sirovich of New York, chairman of the House Committee on Patents, who yesterday accused dramatic critics of incompetency and blighting the theatre, today addressed letters to eighteen reviewers in New York City, Chicago, Boston, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh inviting them to appear here on March 14 to testify regarding their influence on stage productions.

Approximately fifty dress contractors signed individual agreements yesterday with the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union on the terms of peace arranged between the union and the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers' Association, Inc., the "inside" shop group.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 1 -- After holding a fourteen-point lead at half time, the Princeton varsity basketball team repulsed a last-minute rally by Lafayette tonight to win by 34 to 29.

Three members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers were held for examination on March 11 by Magistrate Frederick Hughes in Coney Island court yesterday on the charge of feloniously assaulting Michael C. Clohessy of 2,500 Hubbard Street, Brooklyn, an electrician employed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A good-will flight and a good-will mission, both identified with international politics, brought Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Miss Anne Spencer Morrow together, and remained the background of their courtship until their marriage, May 27, 1929.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Norris bill to curb the use of injunctions in labor disputes and outlaw "yellow dog" contracts was passed by the Senate today by a vote of 75 to 5.

TORONTO, March 1 -- The scoring might of the Toronto Maple Leafs curbed for two periods by the New York Americans, broke out tonight in a last-session drive that took the Leafs back into a tie for first place in the National Hockey League's international section.

John J. McElligott, who obtained the highest rating in the recent competitive civil service test for the position of Fire Chief, was promoted to that office yesterday by Fire Commissioner Dorman in his office in the Municipal Building.

A brief filed yesterday in the Supreme Court in behalf of Owen (Owney) Madden and three other exconvicts who are facing return to Sing Sing as parole violators contended that Madden had been fully discharged from the custody of the Parole Board; that he had not violated the terms of his parole, and that he was no longer amenable to the jurisdiction of the board.
HELSINGFORS, Finland, March 1 -- Leaders of the Lapuan-Fascist revolt are believed tonight to be "on the run," their army melting and their cause lost, mainly for want of public sympathy.

The centennial of the death of GOETHE falls within a month from the bicentennial of the birth of WASHINGTON. At Columbia University the commemoration in this country began with an eloquent tribute by GERHART HAUPTMANN, Germany's eminent dramatic poet.

The Transit Commission held yesterday its first public hearing on the $474,500,000 unification proposal published last December. An adjournment was taken until April 4 after the appearances of counsel for the B.M.T. and Interborough had been noted and various civic and business groups had indicated their intention to participate.

INDEPENDENCE, Kan., March 1 (AP) -- Ratification of the Prairie-Sinclair oil merger, creating the Consolidated Oil Corporation, a half-billion dollar concern, was voted here today by the stockholders of the Prairie companies. The consolidation combines the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation, the Prairie Oil and Gas Company and the Prairie Pipe Line Company, operating in the Southwest and mid-West.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- Manager Joe McCarthy today announced that Tony Lazzeri, veteran infield star of the Yankees, has agreed to salary terms and is en route to the training camp.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 20 totaled 572,606 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 10,141 more than the preceding week, 140,550 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 254,954 cars fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON, March 1 -- As a sequel to last night's completion of the tariff legislation with royal assent for the new import duties, Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced to the House of Commons today the membership of the tariff commission created by the bill.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Railroad representatives today urged the Interstate Commerce Commission to ask Congress to provide complete regulation for commercial motor vehicles throughout the country.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 1 -- The Assembly passed two major amendments to the stringent Baumes laws today as the two houses pushed their way through heavy calendars.

The current year got off to a good start toward a new health record, according to figures made public yesterday by statisticians for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. January, with a death rate of 8.7 per 1,000, showed an improvement of 7.6 per cent over January, 1927, when the previous low of 9.4 was established.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- As the members of the Assembly of the League of Nations gather at Geneva for the meeting, beginning Thursday, which will consider China's complaint that Japan has broken treaties by her military activities in Manchuria and at Shanghai, the position of the government of the United States remains Unaffected by the peace discussions at Shanghai or by any other new factors in the situation.

Some Southern selling and considerable realizing or liquidation were absorbed on declines of 4 or 5 points on the Cotton Exchange here in yesterday's earlier trading. Prices steadied later, although buyers were not aggressive. May contracts, after selling off from 6.98 cents a pound to 6.93, closed at 6.96 cents, while October, after declining from 7.37 cents to 7.30, ended at 7.34.

The work of the younger architects who entered the competition for the design of a proposed Palace of the Soviets in Moscow seems to have made a strong appeal to the Soviet Government, for the New Jersey architect who shares first prize is only 27 years old and two New York architects who share a second prize are 32 and 27 years of age.

Textile High School's basketball team clinched the Manhattan division P.S.A.L. championship by downing Seward Park High, 29 to 24, yesterday in the latter's gymnasium. Textile held a 13-to-6 lead at the half.

THERE should be a real scramble for first place in the mile relay at the "indoor intercollegiates" in the big Kingsbridge. Armory on Saturday night. It's a poor relay race that doesn't have some, drama in it, and this one should provide a few extra thrills for the spectators and college cheering sections.
Realty trading in Manhattan yesterday was featured by sales and leases of apartment houses and smaller residential properties. The day's transactions were well distributed throughout the borough.
HONOLULU, March 1 -- It is necessary to go back some time to show the efforts made to clean up Honolulu which finally resulted in the present laws.

The Board of Aldermen formally fixed the basic tax rate for the city this year at 2.59 yesterday, after Alderman Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d had filed a minority report warning that next year's rate would be possibly as high as 2:80 if economies were not effected.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, March 2 -- Japan's counterproposals to China concerning the reaching of a truce in the Shanghai area reveal unexpected concessions, according to a statement made this morning by a Japanese Legation spokesman.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- An outright vote on whether the House shall consider a proposal to return liquor control to the States was assured today when the necessary 145 members had signed a petition to cite the Judiciary Committee for discharge from further study of the measure.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga., March 1 -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover and party arrived at the hunting preserve of Howard E. Coffin at Cabin Bluff, Camden County, at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The party went ashore and took a three-mile stroll to a little village named Shellbine, on the Satilia River, located on the 60,000-acre game preserve of Mr. Coffin.

The home of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, near Hopewell, N.J., from which their 20 months old son, Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr., was kidnapped last night, is on Sourland Mountain, about ten miles north of Princeton in the centre of the Colonel's 350-acre estate.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 1 -- In compliment to their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. E. Coe Kerr of Millneck, L.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Brinkley Smithers of Locust Valley, L.I., Mr. and Mrs. Christopher D. Smithers entertained tonight with a dinner for twenty-two persons at Pelican Point.

Dr. Gerhart Hauptmann, hailed by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, who introduced him, as "the master of dramatic art of our epoch," delivered an oration yesterday in commemoration of the one hundredth anniversary of Goethe's death. More than 1,200 persons filled the McMillin Academic Theatre at Columbia University to hear him speak, and his address, in polished, literary German, was broadcast to radio audiences here and in his own country.
The slow fires of resentment which for several days had been burning in the breasts of a discharged Brooklyn jury moved the members yesterday to concerted action in defense of their intelligence.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- The kidnapping of the young son of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh conies at a time when civic and law enforcement officials of a half dozen States, aroused at the depredations of organized extortionists, are clamoring for Federal intervention.

MIAMI, Fla., March 1 -- Seven victories in his past ten starts is the impressive record of Jaz Age, owned and trained by J. Parmalee, which captured the Miami Shores Claiming Handicap, feature at Tropical Park, today. In his three losing starts Jaz Age was second twice and third once, giving him one of the most consistent records of any horse of his class racing in Florida this season.

Although 21 per cent fewer than in January, commercial failures in this country last month numbered 2,732, setting a new high record for a February, according to R.G. Dun Co. The total was 6.6 per cent greater than the previous record of 2,563 for a February, reported last year.
"Birds In a Bush," a comedy by R. B. Lackey, is announced for immediate production on Broadway by Allan C. Dalzell, who has been press agent and company manager for a number of plays.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 -- For the second time in a week the Yale 500-yard relay swimming team, consisting of Al Hapke, Donald Fobes, Jack Brines, Bradford Butler and Lloyd Osborne, tonight broke the world's record, covering the distance in 4 minutes 30 seconds, clipping a full second from its own mark.

The United Gas Public Service Company has announced its capitalization as of Jan. 31, giving effect to the issuance of $4,587,000 of twenty-year debentures due in 1952 to retire an equal amount of twenty-year 6 per cent debentures due in 1951, and conversion of $18,753,000 of twenty-year 6 per cent debentures due in 1951 and of virtually all the company's floating debt to the United Gas Corporation into additional $6 dividend second preferred stock.

CHATHAM, N.Y., March 1 -- An unusual method of attracting new residents and fostering business and building activity will be tried out immediately by the Chatham Chamber of Commerce, which announced today that it had acquired fifty acres of land to be given away by the organization to prospective home builders in plots of an acre each.

PARIS, March 1 -- Andre Tardieu, Premier and Foreign Minister, returned to Paris from Geneva this morning. By nightfall, with his characteristic energy, he had succeeded in launching his new Ministry well on its way.

The higher State tax on transfers of stocks, 4 cents a share, which is twice the previous rate, became effective yesterday. A contraction in trading accompanied the change, and the volume of business on the Stock Exchange was lowered to approximately 800,000 shares, one of the smallest turnovers in recent years.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, March 2 -- Reddening of the night skies over North Szechuan Road and the Chapei areas by two spreading fires prompted a midnight excursion by THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent in an attempt to penetrate near the Japanese bluejacket front lines to locate definitely the seat of conflagrations in an area seemingly reduced to ashes weeks ago, but the rigorous system of Japanese guards foiled all attempts to enter this zone.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- American exports to Shanghai, along with those of other nations, are being seriously hampered due to current hostilities in that area, according to information received at the Departments of Commerce and Agriculture.

The Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate closed yesterday the public hearings on pending applications for bus franchises in Manhattan, thus paving the way for early consideration of actual awards for Manhattan and Queens. The Queens application hearings were closed last week.

LONDON, March 1 -- A strong appeal for Anglo-American cooperation in the Far East was made here today by Dwight Davis, former Secretary of War, who recently returned from his post as Governor General of the Philippine Islands.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Governor Roosevelt called upon the Legislature today to enact a measure which would specifically prohibit Sheriffs or other public officers from retaining interest on custodian funds passing through their hands.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, March 2. -- Immediate pressure for early passage of the measure making kidnapping a Federal offense is held certain to be the result of the kidnapping of Colonel Lindbergh's son.
NEWARK, N.J., March 1 -- Five teams advanced in the preliminary games of the fourteenth New Jersey State basketball tournament, in which play began tonight.

ROME, March 1 -- Sculptures believed to have been made by prehistoric men of the Bronze Age have been discovered in a valley of the Upper Adige. They consist of two large stone blocks cut in rudimentary fashion to represent weird human figures and presumably are idols.

LOS ANGELES, March 1 -- Amid perspiring pitchers who were bearing down magnificently today with the return of a blazing sun and a clear blue California sky John McGraw conducted an infield drill that must have been even more gratifying to him than the excellent condition of the hurlers and the imposing array of outfielders.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Acceptance by the administration of the new tax measure, including a general sales tax applicable to practically every manufacturing industry in the country, was assured today by Secretary Mills.
HONOLULU, March 1 -- Another assault case here today was followed by swift police action which resulted in the capture of the assailant within a few hours.

BUDAPEST, March 1 -- A warning that Hungary's foreign creditors might lose everything unless they were prepared to make a considerable reduction in interest rates on their loans was the high point of a speech made by Premier Count Karolyi today before adjourning Parliament for a month.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., March 1 -- Edgar T. Appleby of New York, present holder of the title, remained in a tie for first place in the national amateur balkline billiard tournament by defeating Homer T. Galey of Tulsa, Okla., 300 to 284, in fiftynine innings today.

The problem of when a kidnapping is not a kidnapping was solved -- at least, to the satisfaction of the alleged kidnappers -- in West Side Court by Magistrate Van Amringe yesterday when he released from custody seven men charged with abducting Abraham Rosenberg and Eugene Murphy from an automobile at Seventy-fifth Street and West End Avenue on Saturday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Unless your various Presidential candidates stop assuming that the voters of this country are all mind readers, we shall have to depend upon the manufacturers of the ouija board to solve the problem. Each voter must buy a ouija board, that is certain.
NEW YORK. Mrs. James Roosevelt will give a reception on March 8 at 47 East Sixty -fifth Street for Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Roosevelt, who were married on Jan. 16, in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -- Ten relatives of Mrs. Anne Weightman Walker Penfield, widow of Frederic Courtland Penfield, Ambassador to Austria-Hungary during the early years of the World War, will share the bulk of her estate of $15,000,000 to $20,000,000 under the terms of her will, filed with the Register of Wills here today.

When the twenty-fifth anniversary of the foundation of the International Institute of Agriculture, as the result of the pioneer work of DAVID LUBIN, was celebrated in Rome in October of 1930, America was officially absent. This appeared tragic to those aware of the part LUBIN, who came to America as a child, had had in bringing into existence this world organization representing man's common interest in the industry which is basic to all others.

A man and his sister were suffocated by smoke and several presidents in a tenement at 169 East 110th Street narrowly escaped the same fate early this morning when a fire, which apparently started on the top floor of the five-story building, sent a dense pall of smoke through the entire house, trapping, tenants in their apartments and necessitating fast rescue work by the firemen.

MEMEL, March 1 -- With the dominant parties in the Memel Landtag unable to come to terms with the Governor, it is generally held probable that the body will be dissolved and that an election will be called for next month.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Governor Roosevelt and the Republicans in the Legislature both appear unwilling tonight to assume responsibility for originating tax legislation to raise the $15,500,000 to $19,500,000 necessary if the State is to continue unemployment relief through next Winter.

PARIS, March 1 -- Profit-taking developed on the Bourse today after yesterday's activity, and with the exception of some leaders the market was irregular. Sales in most instances were easily absorbed and the transactions extended to a large variety of shares.
BERLIN, March 1 -- Business at the Boerse was even more quiet today than yesterday. The smallest transactions therefore immediately showed reflection in changing prices.

State of California. The State of California yesterday failed to receive any bids for its issue of $1,225,000 4 1/2 per cent veterans' welfare bonds, the unsold portion of an issue of $6,000,000. It plans to reoffer the block on March 10.

The annual report of the Connecticut Electric Service Company, a subsidiary of the United Gas Improvement Company, shows a consolidated net profit of $4,227,090 for 1931 after depreciation, charges, taxes, subsidiary preferred dividends and minority interest.

Boxing, plain and fancy, with a little side-arm slugging thrown in, was demonstrated last night by the younger set of the Kips Bay Boys' Club. The juvenile audience, of an unusually peaceful nature, made no further demands than "Kill him, Joe," "Knock his head off, Murphy" and "Just a few teeth, Pasquale."

The first-degree robbery trial of Reynolds Forsbrey, slayer and former life-term convict, who was released on a commuted sentence last July by Governor Roosevelt, took an unexpected turn in General Sessions yesterday when two of his co-defendants, George Daoust, 29 years old, and John Biros, also 29, pleaded guilty to second-degree robbery.

The Bank of France resumed yesterday the repatriation of its holdings of earmarked gold with a shipment of $12,504,900 on the De Grasse, while the National Bank of Belgium continued the transfer of its earmarked holdings by shipping $3,591,000 gold.

In a preliminary test match to try out various line-ups before the polo championships, the trio headed by Winston Guest, noted internationalist, defeated the Puncheon Club team, comprised of Yale players, at Squadron A Armory last night, 12-to-8 1/2.

The Elshuco Trio, composed of Karl Kraeuter, violin; Willem Willeke, 'cello, and Aurelio Giorni, piano, gave its fourth concert of the season last night in the Engineering Auditorium. Their assisting artists were Conrad Held and Harry Sacher. They played Chausson's piano trio in G minor, Brahm's piano quartet in C minor, and Schubert's piano quintet (the "Forellen") in A major.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 1 -- Leading the outstanding tournament field of the Winter season by five strokes. Miss Virginia Van Wie of Chicago won the qualifying medal in the Florida East Coast championship today with a round of 38 -- 37 -- 75.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The view that the fixing by manufacturers of the prices for which branded articles may be sold at retail would deal a serious blow to newspaper advertising was expressed today to a Senate committee by Representative Cox, Democrat, of Georgia.

SHANGHAI, March 1 (AP) -- The Japanese had "legal reasons," they said today, to "recognize as a spy" Ken Wang, Chinese graduate of West Point, who was arrested by the Japanese in the lobby of the Astor House Saturday and was released today.
HOPEWELL, N.J., March 2 (AP). -- A chubby, golden-haired boy closely resembling his famous father--that is the description given Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr.
NEW ORLEANS, March 1 (AP) -- A string of eight successive victories was broken today when C.V. Whitney's Chimney Sweep led Dick Morris home in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds.

LONDON, March 2. -- Great Britain has no intention of supporting the United States if it should refuse to recognize the new government of Manchuria, it became known in London today, and is unwilling to accept the implications of Secretary Stimson's recent letter to Senator Borah.

ALBANY, March 2. -- All the resources of the State police system, in pursuance to instructions from Governor Roosevelt, are enlisted tonight in a State-wide effort to find the son of Colonel Lindbergh and his kidnappers.

LOS ANGELES, March 2. -- No baseball training camp, it seems, is ever complete without somebody being unaccountably missing, and the one the Giants have pitched here on the edge of the Pacific slope is no exception.

NEW ORLEANS, March 2 (AP). -- Mrs. M.B. Price's Silverdale, 6-yearold daughter of The Porter, won her third race of the Winter season when she accounted for the Glenwood Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

Representatives of six leading banks and banking houses in this city that have been active in marketing obligations of Tennessee will meet today to formulate plans to help the State to meet $9,000,000 of shortterm notes which will mature on April 29.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., March 2. -- Edgar T. Appleby of New York, defending titleholder, suffered his first setback in the drive to retain his crown when he was defeated by Dale H. Goslin of Los Angeles, the youthful Pacific Southwest champion, by 300 to 282 in thirty innings, in the national amateur 18.2 balkline championship tournament tonight.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 2 (AP). -- An answer denying all allegations of insolvency was filed in Chancery Court today by Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., to the receivership suit filed against the concern several weeks ago by M.P.V. Newcastle, a stockholder.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, March 2. -- President Pehr Evind Svinhufvud announced tonight he had reorganized the Cabinet. In the new line-up General K.L. Oesch will share the Ministry of the Interior with Baron E. von Born. The division of the Ministry was made in order to place a military man in it because of the revolt of the Lapuans.

PARIS, March 2. -- Alarmed by threats of additional import restrictions affecting Franco-American trade, a committee headed by Charles G. Loeb, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Paris, today called on the French Minister of Commerce, Louis Rollin.

In yesterday's TIMES Miss ELISABETH MARBURY, Democratic National Committeewoman for New York, made what we must be forgiven for calling a temerarious, almost a revolutionary, suggestion. She wants all the candidates for President to speak up like little men, plainly tell their views on important policies, domestic and foreign.

Members and the board of governors of the International Garden Club gave a reception yesterday afternoon at the clubhouse, the historic Bartow mansion in Pelham Bay Park, for Andre Chevrillon, member of the French Academy, who came here for the Washington bicentennial celebration and participated in the ceremonies at New York University.

IT was during the quiet dinner hour at the six-day race that the trap was sprung. The riders off duty were eating or taking their ease in those piano cases that serve as temporary bungalows facing the straightaways of the wooden saucer. The stout Mr. Harry Mendel, assistant to John Chapman, said casually:

More than 500 men -- The entire police force and some of the firemen -- were conducting a house-to-house search in Newark last night on what seemed to be the most promising clue to the whereabouts of the Lindbergh baby. The canvass started in the afternoon, after a postman had intercepted a card addressed to the flier, saying "Baby safe. Instructions later.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems the complaint of the American public anent the ineffectiveness and backwardness of our courts of law is persistent and perennial.

Augmented by thousands of civilian volunteers, every law-enforcing agency of the Eastern half of the United States and Canada swung into united action yesterday in the most intensive manhunt in the history of crime of this continent. It was estimated last night that more than 100,000 peace officers and cooperating citizens were making the search for Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. and his abductors their dominating concern.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 2. -- Blair Academy, scoring only two field goals, lost a basketball game to Hun School today, 24 to 19. The ability of Christensen and other Blair players to convert free tosses into tallies kept the game close. At the end of the third period Hun was leading by 14 to 13, out then Pickens sank a series of shots from the floor to make victory certain.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- News that General Butler would oppose Senator Davis in the Pennsylvania Senatorial primaries stirred Republicans here today and was coincident with a conference of David A. Reed, Pennsylvania's senior Senator, with the party leaders from the Keystone State and other Commonwealths.

While the rate of steel operations remains virtually unchanged at about 26 per cent of ingot capacity, the steel industry has been encouraged in the last week by "prospects of heavy releases from the Ford Motor Company." This potential business has created a more cheerful frame of mind among producers, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age.

The entire nation extended its sympathy to Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh yesterday. From President Hoover down, all were awaiting anxiously the latest news of the kidnapped child. They talked about it in the streets, in homes and in their offices.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange made further upward strides yesterday in keeping with the brisk demand for the new issues which have been placed on the market this week. The foreign bond average of THE NEW YORK TIMES reached 90.24, a new high for the year, the previous high being that of 89.92 on Jan. 16.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2. -- The first formal infield practice of the Yankee training season developed into an intensive two-man drill today featuring the highly rated keystone combination of Jack Saltzgaver and Frank Crosetti. Manager McCarthy devoted more than half an hour to them individually after almost all the other Yankees had sought the showers.

Plight of the Engineers. Last Autumn the four leading engineering societies decided to carry out their own unemployment relief program, since the regular agencies were unable to give the proper aid to a class of men who find it hard to ask charity, even though they may face destitution.

A protest "against the recent occurrences in Harlan and Bell Counties, Kentucky," which "show that the constituted authorities are clearly taking sides in a industrial struggle and have themselves thrown Kentucky into a condition of open class warfare," signed by 175 educators, was made public yesterday by the National Committee for the Defense of Political Prisoners.
NEW YORK. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. John J. Byrne of 300 Park Avenue will sail Saturday on the Volendam to pass a month in Havana.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Ernest Lee Jahncke, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, asserted in a radio talk today that President Hoover had "inaugurated" a program for economic relief "so efficient and vital" that it alone stands as a memorial not only to him but also to the wisdom of the public which chose a man capable of accomplishing this stupendous task.

The New York Steam Corporation filed yesterday an application with the New York Public Service Commission for authority to issue $10,000,000 of 5 1/2 per cent first-mortgage bonds at a price not less than 95 per cent of face value in order to refund bank loans and capitalize new construction paid for out of the company's treasury.

Copyright, 1932, by N.A.N.A., Inc. HOPEWELL, N.J., March 2. -- If little Charles Augustus Lindbergh, in his strange surroundings, is as gallant as his mother, then he is a very gallant little fellow indeed. Life for Anne Morrow Lindbergh since her marriage to the Lone Eagle of the air has been made up of the things that snarl and snap nerve wires.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Thomas F. Campbell, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, after a conference with President Hoover today, said that a consolidation of the personnel agencies of the Federal Government as recommended to Congress by the President, would effect a saving of more than $630,000 annually and bring about increased governmental efficiency.

GENEVA, March 2. -- While fighting continues near Shanghai, mankind's first world-wide effort to end actual war and enforce two worldwide covenants requiring peaceful settlement of disputes will begin here tomorrow morning. The League of Nations Assembly will meet then in extraordinary session to hear China's appeal to the world community against Japan.

MADRID, March 2. -- So angry are the Monarchists of Spain with Alfonso for what they term the stupidity of his recent manifesto expressing a desire to return to Spain as King that their leaders are turning their backs on him.

Interrupting his trial for grand larceny in General Sessions, Thomas M. Farley, former Sheriff, returned last night to Flower Hospital for further treatment of the burns suffered before he was removed from office by Governor Roosevelt. He planned to remain at the hospital until Monday.

John J. Fitzgerald, former chairman of the House Committee on Appropriations and former counsel to the Board of Transportation, was inducted into office as a county judge in Brooklyn yesterday. The ceremony was held in the Kings County Court, where a large delegation of friends assembled to participate with speeches and presentations.
The Manhattan swimming team lost to City College, 31 -- 19, at the Jasper pool yesterday in its final dual meet of the season. The Lavender natators finished first in four of the six events.
Editorial comment in New York and elsewhere on the Lindbergh kidnapping case follows:

The last of the season s newcomers, Francesco Merli, Italian, tenor, made his first appearance at the Metropolitan Opera House and his first in this country last night. The role of Rhadames -- the opera, of course, was "Aida" -- is a severe test for a debut, but he brought to his task a large and varied experience and presence of mind.

The United States liner Leviathan will return after a fifteen-year absence to the German-American transatlantic trade, operating between New York and Bremen, when she re-enters the service on April 26, according to an announcement yesterday by the Roosevelt Steamship Company, operators.

HOPEWELL, N.J., March 2. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh took personal charge of the hunt for his infant son, Charles Augustus Jr., today, transforming his pretty mountain home near here into field headquarters for an army of searchers.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, March 2. -- With halibut moving swiftly to market, the Pacific Coast industry is in a chaotic condition due to a struggle for tonnage between the port of Seattle, backed by American railway and steamship lines, and the Canadian port of Prince Rupert, supported by railroads and interests of the Dominion.

Builders and owners of manufacturing buildings in New York City have been subjected to a good deal of inconvenience in recent years by a provision of the State labor law requiring the use of none but selfclosing fireproof windows with the panes of glass limited In size in those portions of the buildings which are designed for use for showroom and office purposes.

An Increase of $8,797,200 in the amount of gold earmarked for foreign account was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The earmarking, which represented a loss of that amount to the gold stocks of the country, put a damper on hopes aroused by Tuesday's large release from earmarking that foreign central banks had reversed their policy of converting dollar balances into gold.

More Orders as Spring Trade Gains Retailers are now beginning to obtain a somewhat better consumer reaction to current offerings of women's Spring apparel, it was reported in the wholesale markets here yesterday. As the improvement progresses, it was said, visiting merchandise managers are tending to expand buying allotments and prospects for considerable pre-Easter activity during the weeks directly ahead have brightened considerably.

ALBANY, March 2. -- Political leaders from over the State gathered in the Senate Chamber tonight to pay tribute to Senator Bernard M. Drowning, who was Democratic leader thera until his death last year. New York City and both political parties were represented.

Expressing the belief that the chances are against France retaining the Davis Cup this year and in favor of the United States succeeding England in the role of challenger, Jean Borotra, French Davis Cup ace and international tennis idol, arrived on board the Ile de France yesterday to defend his national indoor crown and represent his country in the Franco-American team match at the Seventh Regiment Armory this month.

An exhibition of skeletons, illustrating the structure of typical carnivorous mammals, ranging from tiny American weasels to the great tigers of India, has been placed on view in the Hall of Osteology at Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, says a recent bulletin from that institution.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 2 (AP). -- Everett L. Thompson of West Orange, N.J., filed a bill in Chancery Court today against Pie Bakeries, Inc., formerly Pie Bakeries of America. Inc., asking that the court declare the plan for recapitalization of Pie Bakeries of America, Inc., adopted by stockholders last September, null and void and of no effect upon himself.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- Federal, State and city law enforcers and crimefighting organizations here today joined police of the nation in pledging cooperation in the search for the kidnappers of Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 2 (AP). -- In an all-English final, Fred Perry today won the men's tennis championship of Bermuda, defeating H.G.N. Lee, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4.

LONDON, March 2. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today that the restrictions on the purchase of foreign exchange which were imposed at the time of the flight from the pound last Summer would be withdrawn tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Federal regulation of motor trucks operating in interstate commerce was opposed by the New York Merchants' Association during a hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission today.
The radio facilities of the nation were pressed into service yesterday to assist the authorities in the widespread search for Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.
Columbia's infield and outfield aspirants joined the Lion battery men in practice in the Morningside gymnasium yesterday. It was a veteran array that reported to Coach Andy Coakley.

Reynolds Forsbrey, 46-year-old slayer and former life-term convict, whose sentence was commuted last July by Governor Roosevelt, was found guilty of robbery in the first degree yesterday afternoon by a jury in Judge Nott's part of General Sessions.

Collateral loans by member firms of the New York Stock Exchange increased $12,645,816 in February, or from $512,017,942 on Jan. 30 to $524,663,758 at the end of February, according to the report by the Exchange. This is the first gain reported by the Stock Exchange in brokers' loans since last August.

Pig iron production in February, as reported yesterday by The Iron Age, gained almost 6 per cent over that of January, figured on the daily rate, the first increase since April, 1931. Last month's daily output was 33,251 gross tons, against 31,380 in January.

The directors of the Chase National Bank declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share, placing the stock of the bank on a $3 annual dividend basis, compared with a $4 basis previously. The National City Bank took similar action on Tuesday.

KEANSBURG, N.J., March 2. -- A fire of unknown origin, swept by a stiff ocean breeze, destroyed five bungalows, four Boardwalk concessions and several bathhouses here early this morning, causing a loss of more than $30,000. The entire Summer colony was threatened by sparks which fell on roofs and dry grass.

Holders of $35,000,000 Colombian 6 per cent external sinking fund gold bonds due in 1961 have been notified by Hallgarten Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co., fiscal agents, that the republic has delivered to them $486,000 principal amount of bonds that have been redeemed through the sinking fund, leaving $32,691,500 par value outstanding.

The kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., topping a long list of kidnappings in recent years, serves to emphasize the fact that abduction for ransom has become "a big money crime," taking its place beside the liquor, vice and drug traffic among the prominent "rackets" of the country.

In Congress and in various State Legislatures now in session, indignation over the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby took the form yesterday of proposals to make kidnapping punishable by death, on the principle that it is worse than murder. Kidnapping now is punishable by death in Missouri, by sentences up to life in other States, and not at all under Federal statutes.

The bold kidnapping of Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr., infant son of the noted aviator, remained as much a mystery last night as when the child's nurse first discovered he had been stolen from his crib in his parents' country home near Hopewell, N.J., Tuesday evenings.

The special committee or City Court justices appointed to investigate charges presented by Samuel Seabury against Harry C. Perry, chief clerk of the City Court, recommended in a report submitted yesterday to the Board of Justices that the charge concerning gambling and homicide in Perry's district club be dismissed, but that an explanation be required from Perry as to his deposits and other dealings with banks.

What is expected to prove an impetus to the development of the long delayed housing project between Chrystie and Forsyth Streets was given at a meeting of the East Side Chamber of Commerce in the assembly hall of the Bowery Savings Bank last night when the chamber endorsed a $6,000,000 project presented to it by William Lescaze, of the architectural firm of Howe Lescaze of New York and Philadelphia.

Motors roared yesterday and planes took off from half a dozen airports in New York and New Jersey as pilots flew to search the woods and roads in a wide area about Hopewell, N.J., for clues that might help their fellow-pilot, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, to find the kidnappers of his son.

PITTSBURGH, March 2. -- Florenz Ziegfeld, whose musical comedy "Hot-Cha" is in the second and last week of its preliminary engagement here, was confined to his hotel today with a severe case of influenza.

Unleashing their most sustained attack in the first period, when five goals were scored, the Bronx Tigers gained undisputed possession of second place in the Canadian-American Hockey League last night by turning back the Springfield Indians, 6 to 1, at the New York Coliseum.

MOSCOW, March 2. -- Soviet Russia takes a characteristically skeptical attitude toward the Geneva proposals for a Shanghai peace. The newspaper Izvestia runs a five-column headline, "Imperialists preparing to deal at China's expense," with the subhead "Powers protect own interests."

LONDON, March 2. -- Sir Thomas Lawrence's famous portrait of Master Charles William Lambton known as "The Red Boy" will be included in the fourteen-day sale to be held by direction of Lord Durham at Lambton Castle beginning April 18.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Loans to four railroads previously approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission were announced today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. They were $7,500,000 to the Southern, $274,550 to the Alabama, Tennessee Northern, $3,629,000 to the Chicago Eastern Illinois, and $2,102,000 to the Western Pacific.
BERLIN, March 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 29 shows the following changes for the week in reichsmarks:

The Graham-Paige Motors Corporation produced 2,095 cars in February, compared with approximately, 2,500 in the correspnoding month a year ago. In January the company shipped 2,537 units. Retail sales from Jan. 1 through Feb. 20, according to the company, were 12 per cent larger than in the corresponding period of 1931.
SHANGHAI, Thursday, March 3. -- Japanese forces pushed on westward over the entire Shanghai-Woosung front today behind the retreating Chinese army.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The per capita property tax collected in Schenectady, N.Y., was $47.36 in 1930, compared with $50.32 in 1929 and $17.80 in 1917, according to a summary of financial statistics of the city corporation issued today by the Census Bureau.

The attention, of realty interests was focused yesterday on the automobile trades centre in the Columbus Circle section, where the purchase of a land fee was announced, along with a report of negotiations for the sale of the blockfront to the north, comprising the east side of Broadway between Fifty-eighth and Fiftyninth Streets.

LONDON, March 2. -- The kidnapping or Colonel Lindbergh's baby has aroused the sympathy and indignation of every one here. Kidnappers are not uncommon in the United States, The Daily News remarks editorially, but it is "the ruthlessness rather than the audacity of this outrage which provokes wonder -- the callous indifference to human feeling that unbridled money lust can produce."

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- A resolution providing that American ratification of the World Court protocol must be with the understanding that the court will not entertain any request for an advisory opinion in any dispute in which the United States claims an interest, unless this coun try consents, was unanimously adopted today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Prediction that the time is soon comingwhen air commerce laws will have to be enforced by the Interstate Commerce Commission or some other similar body created for the purpose was made today by Colonel Paul Henderson, vice president of the United Air Lines, in testimony before the House Postoffice Committee.

Just as the mile event has been the outstanding test during the regular indoor season, so the one-mile title race promises to be one of the features of the eleventh annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships at the 258th Field Artillery Armory in the Bronx on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- West Indies cruise agreements were modified by the Shipping Board today to prohibit free fares between New York and Boston or other ports. The purpose is to prevent steamship lines from absorbing the cost of transporting passengers between New York and other points of origin or destination, prior to embarkation upon, or after debarkation from a cruise covered by the agreement.

Leon Golden, 51 years old, of 225 East 168th Street, the Bronx, a fourth offender, who was convicted two weeks ago with two other men of kidnapping a man for a $50,000 ransom, received a life term of imprisonment yesterday from Judge Nott in General Sessions.
LONDON, March 2. -- The world's first building devoted entirely to polar research will be built soon at Cambridge as a memorial to Captain Robert Falcon Scott of South Pole fame.

The three-ring transit circus came to town again this week, though the performance in one ring was little more than a rehearsal. Not much could be done by the Transit Commission, with its ex-ringmaster still in California, and it accordingly ad- journed the public hearings on its unification plan until April.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Although most of the New York dramatic critics have ridiculed his attack on their capabilities, Representative W. I. Sirovich, chairman of the House Committee on Patents, was cheered today by a letter from M.L. Erlanger and editorial comment by Arthur Brisbane.

Wets and Drys have renewed their legislative battle over prohibition on two fronts. In Washington opponents of the law have managed to obtain enough signatures to the Beck-Linthicum petition to assure them of a record vote in the House of Representatives on resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Beginning this week and continuing for three months book and job pressmen and assistants will work a maximum of four eight-hour days each week at 7 per cent below the basic wage in order to distribute work among the unemployed and to provide jobs for at least 600 idle members, according to an agreement between the workers and the employers, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Presented to the full Ways and Means Committee today for the first time, the new tax bill immediately struck a snag which threatened to dash the hopes of those who were trying to get it before the House before the end of the week.

People who catch colds regularly in Winter may enjoy occasional moments of hope that a cure will be found when they read the periodical announcements of scientific attacks on the malady. But till now such hopes have been pathetically shortlived.

MIAMI, March 2. -- Jockey Hank Mills added a double to His score then he won at Tropical Park today with Batty and Timour, the former taking the Fort Lauderdale Purse, fourth on the program. Batty is owned and trained by A. Ketchell and won by a length, returning the substantial price of $28.30 for $2.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just received a request from the Consumers' League of New York to contribute toward economic reform, as the league is "pressing for compulsory unemployment insurance administered by the State to be enacted into law this year."

CHICAGO, March 2. -- Hogs made a slow start at about steady prices in the market here today, but strength developed, and the closing sales on butcher stock were generally 5 to 10 cents higher. City butchers and small packers were aggressive buyers, the strength in pork loins having some effect on the trade.

Foreign correspondents were urged not to take news developments in the United States "too seriously" by Ivy Lee, publicity counsel to various corporations, at the annual dinner' last night of the Association of Foreign Press Correspondents at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Another entertainment in the series of "Evenings Abroad" in aid of the Charity Organization Society took place last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis. It was called "A Night in the Orient." Murals depicting events in the Ming dynasty, painted by artists of the American Woman's Association; miniature rickshaws and Japanese gardens, embroidered screens and lanterns were used in the decorations.

With district organization of the Block Community Organization 74 per cent complete in four boroughs, indications yesterday were that by the end of the week virtually all of the 153 districts would be organized, it was announced by Wilton LloydSmith, chairman of the new activity of the Gibson committee, which is enrolling "block-aiders" to assist in the work of unemployment relief.

Four matches at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn, last night brought the Class B singles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association to the semi-final round, with Marshall MacLeod and G.J. Leness of the Harvard Club, F.M. Palmer of the Princeton Club and S.L. Scott of the Yale Club as the survivors.

Although Wall Street reserved judgment for a time, the decision of the British Government to repay three-fourths of its banking credit in New York proved, finally, to be a stimulating market influence; or so the commission-house comment interpreted the day's development.

The kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby was traced to prohibition, by Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, in the course of an attack on the dry laws yesterday at the Anti-Prohibition Institute of the New York State Division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, at the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- Nearly $55,000,000 was slashed today from budget estimates of $1.041,395,000 for running the government's thirty independent offices by the House Appropriations Committee in reporting the supply bill for the coming fiscal year.

The General Realty and Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries report for 1931 a net income of $1,246,776 after expenses and State taxes but before giving effect to reductions as a result of an appraisal in September and to net loss from disposition of real estate and security investments carried to surplus.

Activity was increased somewhat yesterday on the New York Curb Exchange, the leading securities moving moderately higher in most instances. Gains marked the stocks of Electric Bond and Share, Cities Service, American Gas and Electric, Middle West Utilities, American Superpower and Atlas Utilities.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- When the House Ways and Means Committee met today to consider a tentative draft of the tax bill, it was found the estimated yield of the proposed 2 per cent rate for the sales tax as revised would be only $517,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- A new constitutional amendment was put before the States today for ratification, the first since 1924, when the Norris proposal to abolish the "lame duck" session of Congress received the Senate's final approval by 73 votes to 3 and was dispatched to the State Department for submission to the States.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 2. -- Kidnappers carried away a 12-year-old boy on his way to school at Niles today while the police throughout the Eastern States were attempting to pick up the trail of the abductors of Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 2. -- Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., women's national champion, and Miss Virginia Van Wie of Chicago, the medalist, unexpectedly were carried to the sixteenth greens in their first-round matches today in the Florida East Coast golf championship on the St. Augustine links.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Encouraged by their success in getting the necessary 145 signatures on a petition to force a direct vote on the prohibition question, House wets today introduced a bill for 2.75 per cent beer.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- Mrs. Lester S. Carroll, widow of a vice president of the American Locomotive Company, died suddenly today at the home of her daughter, Mrs. John R. Merriman, in Evanston. Mrs. Carroll was born here fifty-four years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- All criminal-detection agencies of the government went into action today to aid in the recovery of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's son and to bring to justice the criminals who kidnapped him. From the White House to the halls of Congress the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby assumed, from the moment it became known, major importance.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 2. -- Eric D. Thomson of Springfield, Mass., the medalist, won the twentyeighth annual Spring golf tournament today, defeating Robert G. Morrison of Pittsburgh in the final toy the score of 1 up.
BEVERLY HILLS, Cal., March 2. -- Why don't lynching parties widen their scope and take in kidnappings? They are ten times more premeditated and performed by more normal people.

Directors of the Lehigh Valley Railroad took no action yesterday on the quarterly dividend of $1.25 on the $5 cumulative preferred stock due at this time, thereby interrupting a dividend record maintained since 1903. The stock, which is of $50 par value, paid $5 extra in 1911, 1912 and 1913.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 2. -- One of the largest and most interesting social events of today was the dinner with which Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener and Joseph E. Widener entertained at their South Ocean Boulevard villa. The guests included:

SHANGHAI, March 2. -- The Hongkew and Yangtzsepoo districts of Shanghai, where 15,000 Japanese civilians still reside, were made gay late this afternoon when news of the Chinese retreat was spread abroad.

HOPEWELL, N.J., March 2. -- The footprints of the kidnapper of the Lindbergh baby where traced to the edge of a forest near the Lindbergh home this morning by two trappers and several of the State police. The prints ended abruptly at the edge of the woods.

ALBANY, March 2. -- An unsuccessful effort to bring out of committee bills which would provide for segregation of thrift accounts in commercial banks, and permit women to serve on juries, created a flurry of excitement In the Assembly today.

The Electric Power and Light Corporation reports for 1931 net income of $9,886,057 after all taxes, charges and reserves. This was equal after all preferred dividends to $1.21 a share earned on 3,317,201 common shares outstanding at the end of the year and to $2.01 on the average number outstanding during the year.
BOSTON, March 2. -- Mrs. Catherine McGowan Cunniff, wife of Judge P. Sarsfield Cunniff of the Waltham District Court, is dead after a brief illness.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- A general inquiry into the business of stock exchanges is provided in a resolution prepared today by a subcommittee of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee. The resolution will be presented to the full committee tomorrow, and immediate approval is expected.

Tammany's state of delegates to the Democratic National Convention was made public yesterday afternoon at Tammany Hall. It revealed that Leader John F. Curry was adhering to the agreement reached in Albany last month, at the conference of city and up-State party leaders, to name a neutral state, one that would not commit the party organization to the Presidential aspirations of any one candidate this far in advance of the convention on June 27.

In view of the swift decision with which the Government of President SVINHUFVUD at Helsingfors has met the challenge of the Lapuan or Fascist element in the provinces, it is of interest to glance back at the news of January, 1931, dealing with the imminent Presidential election in Finland.

NEWARK, N.J., March 2. -- Favorites came through with victories in the preliminary round of the New Jersey State basketball tournament held throughout the State tonight. The six victors tonight will go into the first round next week in Class A high school competition.

Mrs. Clarence H. Mackay is to sing and award prizes at the last of the young people's concerts given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall on Saturday morning, March 12. Mrs. Mackay, who is the former concert and opera singer, Anna Case, will make on that occasion her first New York appearance in a musical event since her marriage to the chairman of the board of directors of the PhilharmonicSymphony Society.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, March 3. -- After attempting to rally on its third fortified line, about ten miles west of Shanghai, the Chinese Nineteenth Route Army was in full retreat this morning toward Quinsan, thirty miles from this city on the Shanghai-Nanking railroad.

HAVANA, March 2(AP). -- A.G. Tarn's Abstain, unable to win a race since early In January, staged a brilliant stretch run to account for the mile and fifty yard claiming event, which was the best race on the Oriental Park program today.

Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande" will be sung at the Metropolitan on Thursday of next week, for the first time in the current season. Mr. Hasselmans will conduct and Mmes. Bori and Bourskaya, Messrs, Johnson, Whitehill, Rothier and Ananian will be the singing actors. The opera is the forty-fourth staged by Gatti this season, with "Sonnambula" and "Parsifal" soon to follow.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Moving rapidly forward to a record peacetime deficit of probably more than $2,500,000,000, the excess of government expenditures over receipts during the first eight months of the current fiscal year amounted to $1,781,017,400 on March 1, according to figures available at the Treasury Department today.
TOKYO, March 2 (AP). -- The Japanese Cabinet encountered opposition today in its effort to obtain authorization for a bond issue of 22,000,000 yen ($7,040,000) to finance the campaign at Shanghai.

Easier time money was the feature. The quotation for all dates dropped 1/4, to 3@3 1/2 per cent, loans being made at the outside figure, which is the lowest in six weeks. All other sections of the market continued quiet, with rates for call loans, commercial paper and acceptances unchanged.

Prices of cotton were generally higher yesterday, and after holding quiet but steady in the earlier trad- ing on the Cotton Exchange here they became active and firm in the late afternoon on covering and trade buying promoted by the strength of wheat and stocks and a favorable construction of the financial news from London.
Several apartment houses and taxpayers were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday in addition to scattered dwelling deals.

The Fifty Prints of the Year will be on public exhibition at the Art Centre, beginning tomorrow. For this evening a private view has been arranged, one feature of which will be an address delivered by one of the two jurors, John Taylor Arms. The other juror is Max Weber.

Another turn of the orchestral kaleidoscope in New York has brought a new guest conductor into the field of vision, Sir Thomas Beecham from London, who for a short time will conduct the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra. He is not a stranger to America, nor to the audience of the Philharmonic Symphony.

An investigation into the methods of raising and handling the funds contributed by teachers in the city's schools to the Board of Education's School Relief Fund was begun yesterday by the Hofstadter Legislative committee.

SHANGHAI, March 2. -- When General Tsai Ting-chai's charges become generally known -- that reinforcements for the Chinese defenders of Shanghai were withhel -- they are sure to have serious repercussions upon the Cantonese faction and Chinese patriotic organizations generally, here and abroad.

So far as speculative Wall Street is concerned, nothing is regarded as more abnormal and abhorrent than a market which stands motionless. This may have been the reason for yesterday's interruption of the fiveday spell of complete inactivity with a rather emphatic general recovery.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the beat cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted:
ALBANY, March 2. -- The wets in the Legislature won a victory in the Assembly today, but suffered a reverse in the Senate.
The steady pace adhered to by the riders in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden showed no signs of diminishing last night as the teams swung into their fourth twenty-four-hour cycle.

Not a single representative of the B.M.T., the Interborough or any other agency qualified to operate rapid transit lines entered a formal appearance yesterday at the public hearing held by the Board of Transportation on the form of contract for independent operation of the new city subway system.
