President Hoover's administration has steadily developed better relations in the Americas and out of the depression has risen "a new era of foreign relationships on the solid tripod of wiser diplomacy, more intelligent financing and profitable commercial exchange," Wallace Thompson writes in "Greater America: An Interpretation of Latin America in Relation to Anglo-Saxon America," published by Dutton.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 2. -- Two of the favorites were eliminated from competition in the Palm Beach golf championship today when Jack Butler, local star, and John B. Ryerson of Cooperstown, N.Y., were beaten in the second round on the course of the Palm Beach Golf Club.

A diplomat of the Old School has passed on, Dr. HILL had a deep background of acquaintance with the affairs of peoples and nations before he entered upon his first diplomatic post. He also had a valuable preparatory experience in the administration of a college and a university, beginning when he was a very young man, for he was president of his own college five years after graduation, and then of Rochester University.

Spurred by the world interest in the son of Colonel Lindbergh and by Commissioner Mulrooney's characterization of the kidnapping as "a vicious outrage," the entire New York Police Department plunged yesterday into the hunt for the child and the persons who took him.

The Morningside Heights Players of Columbia University will present, as their fourth production of the season, "All the King's Horses" during the week of March 7 in Earl Hall, Broadway and 117th Street. Performances will begin at 8:30 P.M.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 2. -- The Princeton varsity swimming team scored its sixth successive victory of the season tonight by defeating Columbia, 57 to 14. The Lions gained only one first place and one second place in the individual events.

The Samuel J. Tilden High School basketball team clinched the Section 2, Brooklyn Division, P.S.A.L. title by defeating Manual Training High School 29 to 16, on the Central Methodist Episcopal court in Brooklyn yesterday. The victory gave Tilden a record of five triumphs and no defeats.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 2 (AP). -- The colony of Jamaica cricket team today scored a splendid victory over Lord Tennyson's team of English players, winning by five wickets.
In several important respects banking conditions showed substantial improvement in February, says the current monthly review of credit and business published by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., March 2. -- Cortlandt Field Bishop of Lenox tonight confirmed a report that the American Art Galleries had acquired some of the art treasures formerly owned by the late Lord Curzon of Kedleston.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2. -- Major General Smedley D. Butler, with the backing of Governor Pinchot, announced his candidacy today for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate at the April primaries.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Retirement insurance for railway employes, administered by a Federal board but without expense to the government, was proposed in a bill introduced today by Senator Wagner of New York.

PARIS, March 2 (AP). -- Andre Tardieu, the new Premier, and Walter E. Edge, American Ambassador, had an hour and ten minute conversation today, but all they would say afterward was that "outstanding problems" had been discussed. It was understood the questions of war debts, French import quota restrictions and double taxation were discussed and that no definite decision was reached.

There was a decided change for the better in commodity prices yesterday, which reversed the movement of the last week. Good-size gains were reported in the grains, cotton, rubber, coffee, sugar, cocoa, silk and tin. Moderate losses were found in cash corn and zinc, while all other articles remained steady.

It is new not in its nature but in its rapid development and intensity. Abduction for the sake of extorting a ransom is old enough. There have been famous cases of it in Mexico and in Turkey, leading to diplomatic intervention. Men and children have been kidnapped in the United States, but until lately mat crime has been only occasional and sporadic.

With reports that the 500,000 members of the American Legion Auxiliary were speeding up their campaign, the national headquarters of the war aaginst depression at the Hotel Biltmore announced yesterday that nearly $11,000,000 has been pledged in seventeen communities to pay the wages of additional labor employed as a result of the campaign.

LONDON, March 2. -- The example of the thirteen disunited States in America 150 years ago was cited today in a letter to The London Times advocating international unity on the subject of disarmament. The letter was signed by H.G. Wells, H. Wickham Steed, Professor Gilbert Murray, Sir George Paish, George Nickoll Barnes, who was a British delegate to the Paris peace conference in 1919, and Lord Charnwood, a biographer of Lincoln.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 2. -- "Yes, sir, I'm sore," was the reply of the famous Hack Wilson at the close of one of the most active first days he ever spent in a training camp today.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity shows an upturn to 28.9 for the week ended Feb. 27 from 27.7 for the preceding week. A year ago it was 58.9. Steel demand has shown great irregularity during the past week, according to The American Metal Market, increasing in some lines and districts and decreasing in other products and sections.

About 250 of the 400 draftsmen, architects and engineers employed by the Bureau of Construction and Maintenance of the Board of Education may be suspended today for an indefinite period as an economy measure.

In the wake of the recently opened exhibition of modern European photography at the Julien Levy Gallery and of the Stieglitz semi-centennial, come two more photographic shows to bear witness to the growing importance of photography as a fine art.

Mme. Marcella Sembrich, who made her debut at the Metropolitan in 1883, and Mme. Ernestine Schumann-Heink, who appeared at the same opera house for the first time in 1891, will take part in the "Auld Lang Syne" number which will be part of the finale of the "Operatic Surprise Party" to be presented at the Metropolitan on Sunday evening for the benefit of the Musicians' Emergency Aid.
A Jersey City factory deal by New Yorkers featured the New Jersey realty market report yesterday. Housing properties comprised the bulk of trading.

HAVANA, March 3. -- President Machado has no authority to decree restriction of the sugar crop now being ground, according to the decision of Dr. Octavio Averhoff, the Secretary of Justice, who has been studying the controversy between the Sugar Institute, which recommended a crop of 3,061,000 tons, and the National Sugar Exporting Corporation, headed by Thomas L. Chadbourne, which urged restriction to 2,300,000 tons.

NEW ORLEANS, March 3 (AP). -- A Pelleteri's Dollar Princess, a. 3-year-old daughter of Snob II and Yankee Princess, easily accounted for the feature $800 Panzerata Purse, an all owance affair for 3-year-olds and upward, today at the Fair Grounds.

PARIS, March 3. -- The American Chamber of Commerce of Paris announced today its cooperation with a group of French importers of American radio sets in instituting a law-suit attacking the constitutionality of the quota system of restricting American imports, instituted by the French Government about six months ago.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The readiness of Japan to negotiate with China and neutral interested countries the future status of the International Settlement and foreign, rights at Shanghai, now that the Chinese forces have withdrawn, was asserted at the State Department today by Katsuji Debuchi, the Japanese Ambassador, during a call upon Secretary Stimson.

An official statement on behalf of the Governor's committee to review medical and hospital problems in connection with workmen's compensation insurance, explaining why the commission opposed granting the right to a patient to select his own doctor, was made public yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the commission, also president of Beekman Street Hospital.

Figures issued by the New York Central Railroad yesterday indicate that railroads generally have been forced by reduced earnings to allow the numbers of their locomotives and cars in disrepair to mount to record figures. Nevertheless, traffic is so light that the amount of equipment kept serviceable is adequate to the demand.

An application for the listing of 2,118,959 shares of capital stock of the North American Aviation, Inc., of $5 par value each, has been made to the New York Stock Exchange. The new shares will replace the present shares, which have a fixed capital of $12.50 each.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 3. -- Dr. Robert C. Clothier, former dean at the University of Pittsburgh, began, his duties today as fourteenth president of Rutgers University, succeeding Dr. John M. Thomas, who resigned in October, 1930, to enter the insurance business.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Traders in wheat were disappointed today over the action of that grain on the Board of Trade, a firm start being followed by selling on resting orders, hedging and spreading sales. The result was that prices reacted about a cent from the top and closed 1/4 to 1/2 cent lower on the day.

ALBANY, March 3. -- Assemblyman Willis H. Sargent, Republican, of Onondaga, announced today that he intended to introduce a bill to ratify the Norris "lame duck" amendment to the Federal Constitution.
LONDON, March 3. -- The estimated expenditures of the British navy, army and air forces for the fiscal year 1932 total $521,821,500 at the par of the pound.

The pamphlet report for 1931 of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore shows net Income of $7,197,484 after depreciation, taxes and charges, equal to $5.21 a share on 1,167,137 common shares after preferred dividends, against $7,262,617, or $5.28 share earned on 1,164,897 common shares in 1930.

Despite charges that the State Barge Canal was obsolete and that further expenditures for its development would be a waste of public money, the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at its monthly meeting yesterday adopted resolutions calling on the Federal Government to appropriate funds for its maintenance and operation.

GENEVA, March 3. -- The world, with the exceptions of the United States, Soviet Russia and a few others, met here all day today in its first League of Nations Assembly to act on a real war. When night fell the fifty nations leagued to stop wars who were present did not know whether their task had lessened or grown during the first day.

After running up and down the ladder stocks closed yesterday at just about the level of the afternoon before. Business on the Stock Exchange was also approximately the same as on Wednesday. Wall Street gave the market considerable support in the early dealing's and it looked for a time as if the gains were to be extended substantially.

WASHINGTON, March 3.-- Marking further progress toward stabilization, bank failures in February were only about one-third of those in January, when 334 institutions closed. Moreover the month indicated a substantial reduction, in hoarding.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. No other Important item in the system reached a new high or low figure. The following tables show for various items the highest and lowest points reached thus far in 1932 and in a series of years past.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reports for 1931 a net income of $166,666,534, compareing with $165,544,707 earned in 1930, a gain of $1,121,827 and a new high, record. The earnings last year were equal to $9.05 a share on an average number of 18,419,461 shares outstanding, against $10.44 a sharft on an average of 15,856,696 shares in 1930.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Secretary Stimson will submit to the States on Tuesday for immediate action the amendment to the Constitution as proposed in the Norris lamedurk resolution, which the State Department received from Congress today.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 2, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,728,000,000, a decrease of $47,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $807,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Denying that President Hoover was entitled to all the credit for the program for economic rehabilitation of the country, Jouett Shouse, chairman of the Democratic; Executive Committee, in a radio address over the National Broadcasting System tonight, pictured Mr. Hoover as a "monumental failure" as Chief Executive. He declared that today "the Democratic prospects are brighter than they have been at any time in twenty years."

PARIS, March 3. -- The Bourse today was entering into another session of frantic buying when at mid-session it was learned that the Comptoir Descompte National, one of France's largest credit institutions, had decided to cut its dividend rate. This placed a decided damper on the soaring French shares and they dropped at the close to about the opening prices after having attained important advances.
MEXICO CITY, March 3. -- An increase will be made soon in Mexican oil production and distribution, according to Abelardo Rodriguez, Minister of Industry and Commerce.

S. W. Straus Co. has invited the recently organized real estate bondholders' committee, of which George E. Roosevelt is chairman, to act on behalf of bondholders in certain of the issues distributed by the Straus organization which are now in default.

WITH the baseball owners and managers doing the bartering and buying, there are some odd bargains made in the Ivory bazaar each year. There's the case of Walte Hoyt, for instance. The Singing Undertaker is only 32 years old, and yet he must be classified as "old ivory" from a technical standpoint. He has been wearing the spangles long enough to earn his service stripes.

SHANGHAI, Friday, March 4. -- Severe fighting is understood to have been renewed between Chinese and Japanese forces in the vicinity of Nanziang, continuing all night, and the Chinese Government was officially notified this morning that a new engagement started at 4 A. M. in the area between Kiating and the old second-line positions of the Chinese at Tachang.

An elderly, woman in black mailed letter addressed to Colonel Lindbergh in a Boston branch postoffice yesterday, and within a few minutes police and postal officials were in conference, telegraph and teletype instruments were flashing signals and police reserves were struggling with crowds outside the building.

Roger de la Fresnaye died at the age of 40, cut off before he had brought his art to full maturity. No one visiting the Marie Harriman Gallery (61 East Fifty-seventh Street), where a group of the French artist's drawings and water-colors is now being exhibited, can fail to discern here an intelligent mind, an imaginative and sensitive feeling for form and color, together with draftsmanship of a high order.

At a conference yesterday of Commodore H. M. Baker with other members of the Frostbite Yacht Club, it was decided to hold regattas tomorrow and Sunday on Manhasset Bay off the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, Port Washington, L. I.

Except for the continued softness in time money, which was quoted at 3@3 1/2 per cent, for all dates, there was little else of interest in the day's market. Stock Exchange call loans held at 2 1/2 per cent and street trades at 2 1/4. Commercial paper and acceptances were dull but steady in quotation.

Richard Boleslavski, the Hollywood motion-picture director, whose first book, "Way of the Lancer," is the March selection of the Literary Guild, told yesterday of his year of "talking" the book. Mrs. Helen Woodward, author of "Through Many Windows," collaborated with him.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP). -- Opposition of Philadelphia interests to the proposal to merge the Reading Company and the Central Railroad of New Jersey lines in the Baltimore Ohio system, as part of Eastern consolidation proposals, was expressed today at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 8. -- Harvard's three varsity crews took to the Charles River today for the first time this year, with Coach Charles J. Whiteside directing the oarsmen over a two and one-half mile upstream row and back.

After fighting a 52-mile westerly gale for forty-eight hours and 60-foot waves which stove in the No. 1 hatch forward and smashed fourteen windows on the upper decks, the Furness liner Monarch of Bermuda docked yesterday afternoon, twenty-seven hours late on a normal 40-hour trip.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 3. -- Under a blazing sun, the hottest of the season. Max Carey's ambitious Robins played a game today -- the first of the training season -- and the regulars were beaten by the Yannigans, 9 to 2, in six innings.

OTTAWA, March 3. -- Denying the charge that he had "financed his sister's honeymoon out of the public treasury," Prime Minister Bennett today said that he cared nothing for personal attacks made upon him, but that he did object to the insinuation that the Prime Minister had stolen from government funds.
SHANGHAI, March 3. -- A conservative estimate of the casualties among Japanese and Chinese in the fighting around Shanghai in the last thirty-five days is 23,000 killed and wounded.

CLEAN, N. Y., March 3 (AP). -- Peter Harris, 22, released from Elmira Reformatory Feb. 26, rode through Olean on a freight train early today, engaged in a running gun fight with police, and then circled back into the city, where, police said, he shot and fatally wounded Mike Vessil, 29.

The latest outbreak of the drama in Greenwich Village, "Park Avenue, Ltd.," the work of one Deborah Beirne, was staged last night at the Provincetown Playhouse. At the risk of arousing the ire of Representative Sirovich and offending the United States Government, it must be stated at the outset that it was an exceedingly bad play.

Weston Stewart, 46 years old, of 300 West Thirty-eighth Street, was arrested yesterday afternoon by detectives of the Lost Property Bureau as he was attempting to dispose of an assortment of jewelry in a second-hand jewelry store at 309 West Forty-second Street.

The field in the six day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden was further reduced yesterday, due to two serious accidents, and last night the crowd of 8,000 persons who attended the grind saw only eight of the original fifteen pairs of riders participate in their gruelling journey around the giant pine saucer.

ALBANY, March 3 (AP). -- Those who attending the annual "stunt" dinner of the New York Legislative Correspondents' Association tonight saw "Joseph B. Ely" of Massachusetts nominate "Franklin JD. Roosevelt" for the Democratic Presidential candidacy and heard "J. Thomas Heflin" acclaim his "Pal. Alfred E. Smith," for the nomination.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 3. -- Trust funds totaling $400,000, as well as other gifts, were provided for in the will of Willard N. Baylls of Huntington, senior member of the law firm of Baylis Sanborn of 141 Broadway, Manhattan, who died on Feb. 19.

LONDON, March 3. -- Business again was brisk and the tone cheerful on the Stock Exchange today, although in the afternoon some prices reacted on profit-taking. The decision to maintain, the bank rate came as a big disappointment, particularly to the gild-edge market, but there was little reaction in quotations here; in fact, the conversion 3 1/2 per cent loan rose to u82 5/8 and the war loan to u101 1/16.

Outstanding among leasing contracts announced yesterday was by the John Wanamaker Department Store involving the entire store at the northeast corner of Park Avenue and Forty-ninth Street in the new Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Wanamaker's will use the Waldorf store as a sales salon for its "Au Quatrieme" and "Belmaison" features.
ALBANY, March 3. -- Following is the text of the Court of Appeals ruling in the Doyle case:

LOS ANGELES, March 3. -- The temperatures of the weather and John McGraw moved in slightly opposite directions today, the former going down and the latter showing another sharp increase when, for the third successive day, a steady stream of incoming motor cars failed to reveal Memphis Bill Terry either in person or in pictures.

Only five of the six matches scheduled in the opening round of the national squash tennis championship at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, Brooklyn, were played yesterday, the contest between G. Brackenbridge of the Princeton Club and B. H. O'Connor of the Crescents being postponed until tomorrow.

ROME, March 3. -- A further exchange of Italo-Vatican courtesies occurred today when King Victor Emmanuel conferred on Cardinal Pacelli, the Papal Secretary of State, the Order of the Annunziata. This is the highest Italian decoration, entitling the wearers to rank as cousins of the sovereign.

Reynolds Forsbrey, slayer and former life-term convict, who was convicted last Wednesday of first-degree robbery in a hold-up, and will receive a mandatory life term of imprisonment as a fourth offender when he is arraigned next Wednesday before Judge Nott in General Sessions, asserted in the Tombs yesterday he was found guilty on a frame-up.

BOSTON, March 3. -- Following a half-hour debate, during which the simulated calls of several birds were critically listened to, the House of Representatives yesterday refused to adopt the veery as the official bird of Massachusetts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to THE TIMES Ranulph Kingsley condemned the proposed amendment to the pistol law, in which he stated "excusing up-State pistol permit holders from being fingerprinted and photographed is short-sighted folly.

BAY SHORE, L. I., March 3. -- Five more men formerly connected with the United States Coast Guard in Suffolk County had started jail sentences of one year each for crimes committed during their terms of service, it was announced here this evening by Eugene Osborne.
ALBANY, March 3. -- Governor Roosevelt appealed today for concerted effort toward fire prevention as a means of aiding in economic recovery.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 3. -- Gentaro Akiyama, 39, Japanese butler, was convicted of first-degree murder today by a Supreme Court jury for slaying his employer and benefactor, J. William Schatz, a wealthy manufacturer. His sister-in-law, Sadako Otsuka, 26, former maid in the Schatz home, was convicted of second-degree murder.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 3. -- More than thirty tables were in play at the benefit bridge tea given today by members of the Animal Rescue League at the Bath and Tennis Club. A program of music and dance numbers concluded the affair.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The humorous replies of New York dramatic critics to his charge that some of them were more experienced in prize fight and baseball reporting than in criticizing dramatic stage productions led Representative Sirovich of New York today to challenge two writers to "listen to a speech" he expects to deliver in the House Tuesday and to "write it for their respective papers."

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conducting, came to town last night for the fourth concert of the season's Carnegie Hall evening series. The program was made up of Bach's Suite No. 2, in B minor, for flute and strings; Brahms's Fourth symphony, and as a novelty, at least for this city, Aaron Copland's "Symphonic Ode."

KOKNTGSBERG, Germany, March 3. -- In this old cultural capital of Germany's easternmost province, where Immanuel Kant developed his "Critique of Pure Reason," the foreign observer discovers with some surprise that the best informed local opinion considers it doubtful if President von Hindenburg will carry his home province in the Presidential election.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Informal discussions increased among Senators today over the Reed resolution attached to the World Court protocols by the Committee on Foreign Relations yesterday. They posed the following conundrum to one another:
PARIS, March 3 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs :
LONDON, March 3 (AP). -- Tightening of British export credits to Soviet Russia was indicated today in a government announcement in the House of Commons.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 3. -- Being forced to the eighteenth green to win, Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L. I., women's national golf champion, completed her second hard match in the Florida East Coast championship on the St. Augustine links today, scoring by 1 up over Mrs. Leo Federman of the Glen Oaks Club, Great Neck, L. I.

A rise of $19,399,000 in holdings of United States Government securities was shown in yesterday's report of the Federal Reserve System, revealing that the central banking authorities have at once begun to utilize the increased powers of open-market operations made available by the passage of the Glass-Steagall bill.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 3. -- Leaders of the Roosevelt-for-President movement in Georgia decided at meeting here yesterday to celebrate a "Roosevelt Day" in the State on March 19, four days before the preferential primary. There will be barbecues and public speeches at rallies in all counties.
An Assistant Needs Assistance. The Assistant Secretary of the Navy went to sea in a bow -- and a very fragile one -- in his address Wednesday evening in praise of the President.

TORONTO, March 3. -- Professor James T. Shotwell of Columbia University told an audience at Toronto University here today that distrust among nations was a chief cause for wars. Delivering the second of the Marfleet lectures, in which he discussed the part played by the United States in international affairs. Professor Shotwell said that the United States Senate hampered the President in foreign relations.

E. K. Nadel announces the early production of "Personalities." a vaudeville revue. Several years ago Mr. Nadel, a vaudeville and picture producer presented "Keep Kool" which had a Summer run on Broadway.

BALTIMORE, March 3. -- David Sigismund Melamet, founder and director of the Baltimore Opera Society, which flourished for several years; composer, teacher and director of other Baltimore musical organizations, died here today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Carl W. Schmidt. His age was 71.

After the progress that has been made in musical-comedy producing this past year the old journeyman brand seems a little more depressing than ever, "Marching By," which was screamed at the Forty-sixth Street last evening, is one of the hackneyed breed.
As another day went by without definite word of Colonel Lindbergh's baby the sympathy and anxiety of the public throughout the world were increasingly evident yesterday.

Although the total vote at the end of the third week of The Literary Digest's nation-wide prohibition poll, which will be published in tomorrow's issue of the magazine, continued to show an overwhelming sentiment for repeal, a gain of more than 3 per cent in the dry vote as compared with last week's total was listed.
The identities of two brokers who recently proposed to purchase Stock Exchange memberships, one at $140,000 and the other at $126,000 was disclosed yesterday by the Exchange.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 3. -- More than 100 students representing twenty-eight colleges and universities in New England assembled here at Brown University today to meet as a model assembly of the League of Nations tomorrow and Saturday.

Wednesday's advances of prices on the Cotton Exchange were followed yesterday by partial reactions. Trade buying continued, partly from abroad, but demand was less than on the previous day, and slight early gains met Southern selling or realizing. May contracts, after selling up to 7.19 cents a pound in the first few minutes, reacted to 7.06, while October eased from 7.55 cents to 7.43.

The housing project approved by the East Side Chamber of Commerce, for the development of the seven blocks between Chrystie and Forsyth Streets, extending from First Street to Canal Street, is of concern to the entire city, since it owns the land upon which it is proposed to erect these model houses.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 3. -- Albert R. Hakes, schoolboy star of Dunkirk, N. Y., lost by 5 and 4 to William H. Hyde of Ridgrway, Pa., in the semi-final round of the Palm Beach championship over the course of the Palm Beach Country Club today.

The Alumnae Association of Trinity College will hold a bridge party and fashion show tomorrow afternoon in the Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the college's building fund. Members of the association will act as manikins in the fashion show.

GENEVA, N.Y., March 3 (AP). -- Thomas Hillhouse Chew, banker and philanthropist, a member of one of Geneva's oldest families, died suddenly at the Geneva General Hospital tonight after a brief illness. He was 74 years old.

A resolution memorializing Congress to enact Federal legislation for the crime of kidnapping was adopted unanimously yesterday by the Kentucky House of Representatives at Frankfort, The Associated Press reported. The resolution was sponsored by Representative Herman Handmaker of Louisville.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The Republican party's attitude on a wet plank in the 1932 platform will be influenced by the House vote to be taken March 14 on the Linthicum-Beck resolution to return liquor control to the States, according to some wet leaders.

BERLIN, March 3. -- Berliners grave a sigh of relief today when on their way to work they saw and heard the beer-wagon horses galloping through the streets and the beer barrels being unloaded. The beer, strike was off.

Final details in the new supplemental agreement under which union pressmen have accepted a 7 per cent wage cut and a readjustment in working hours to provide work for their unemployed members will be worked out at a conference to be held today between committees representing the New York Pressmen's and Assistants' Union and the Printers' League Section of the New York Employing Printers' Association.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 3 (AP). -- Warm words from a cold clime reached "Murray for President" headquarters today. A letter from C. B. Skidmore at Ketchikan, Alaska, said Alaska's six delegates to the Democratic convention were "lined up" for Governor William H. Murray.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 3 (AP). -- A crowd of more than one hundred men and women forced their way into the Executive Mansion late today, frightened members of Governor Ruby Laffoon'g household and slightly damaged the furnishings during a demonstration here against the Governor's 1 per cent general sales tax proposal.

The Rev. Dr. Edward C. Russell, rector of St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church, St. Ann's Avenue and 140th Street, the Bronx, suggested yesterday at a meeting of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce that the church, because of its patriotic associations, be listed as a national shrine.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- The teaching of free love in a course at Columbia University was charged today by the Women's Auxiliary of the Episcopal Church in Chicago, which voted to endorse a letter of protest, written by Mrs, Charles Spencer Williamson, and addressed to President Butler.
FARGO, N. D., March 3 (AP). -- Two former Texas boys who ran away from home met again today after a separation of thirty-four years.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The House resolution authorizing the commissioning of 261 members of the senior class at Annapolis, who otherwise would be returned to civil life, affects the future of thirty-seven New Yorkers, including twelve from Greater New York, eleven New Jersey youths and five Connecticut midshipmen.

PASADENA, Cal., March 3 (AP). -- Dr. Albert E. Einstein, in an interview tonight on the eve of departing for his home in Germany, said he "could write a book" about the results of his second visit to this country.

Exhibiting the same brilliant type of game which had featured his previous play in the tournament, W. J. Hall of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club gained the final round in the national Class B squash tennis championship at the Columbia Club last night.

BERLIN, March 3. -- The plans of Premier Tardieu of France to sponsor a Danubian federation in response to Austria's plea for financial and economic help are being watched with keen interest in political quarters here, although the Foreign Office has not yet been officially informed.

PASSAIC, N.J., March 3 -- Announcement was made by The Passaic Daily News and The Passaic Daily Herald that the two papers would combine forces and publish as The Herald-News on April 4. The paper will be printed in the present home of The Daily News in Prospect Street.

Captain Sir Malcolm Campbell, who made the world's automobile record of 253.968 miles an hour at Daytona Beach, sails tonight for England in the Cunarder Berengaria with his racing car Blue Bird. Also on board will be:

The New York police, working in cooperation with the New Jersey authorities in the hunt for the Lindbergh baby and his captors, spent another day of intense activity tracing down a multitude of clues and admitted last night that they had found no definite information on the case in this city.

Recovery in prices for domestic bonds continued yesterday, presumably again in response to visible evidence of the protective activities of the Reconstruction Corporation. Some of the comments on the day's very numerous 2 to 3 point advances in that quarter of the market remarked that the rise was most noticeable in the junior bonda of railways.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Friday, March 4. -- Investigations of the recent shootings on the Russo-Rumanian frontier in Bessarabia have revealed the full story of the tragedy on the frozen Dniester, which had long kept its secret as to the Soviet peasants who attempted to escape to Rumania.
Another day passed yesterday with no definite clue to the where-abouts of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's infant son or his kidnappers despite a nation-wide search.

As a result of a conference of the world's copper producers held here yesterday, the old rules for Copper Exporters, Inc., which were abandoned on Jan. 1, were restored to effectiveness until the conclusion of the meetings being held to arrange a basis for stabilizing the industry.

The organization of a new membership corporation to be called the Metropolitan Opera Association to continue the presentation of opera at the Metropolitan Opera House is under consideration and probably will be consummated by the end of this month, it became known yesterday.

Following Jean Borotra's statement that he believes the Davis Cup will leave France this year, Pierre Etcbebaster, world's open court tennis champion, declared yesterday that the United States should regain the trophy at Auteuil in July.

Mrs. Elsie Greenleaf, 35 years old, was found shot dead yesterday forenoon in an apartment at the Hotel Greystone, 214 West Ninety-first Street, which she and her husband, Gerald Greenleaf, former manager of the Hotel El Mirasol, Santa Barbara, Cal., had occupied since last September.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 1/2 to 3 3/4 per cent for the best names.

TRENTON. N. J., March 3. -- Governor Moore visited the Lindbergh home today, and on his return promised that "something will happen very soon." He would not say in what direction the investigation into the kidnapping is going, nor on what he based his prediction.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless other-wise noted:

SHANGHAI, March 3. -- Behind a diversity of activities, aims and views affecting the question of peace negotiations with Japan it is obvious that an enormous wave of feeling against Chiang Kai-shek is sweeping the country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial "Q.E.D." you express surprise that no echoes of disapproval were audible or visible in the editorial columns of Southern Democratic newspapers or in the utterances of Southern leaders over Governor Roosevelt's bold advocacy of State liquor control in his Buffalo speech.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The regional sales agency plan of coal operators to stabilize that industry probably will get into the Federal courts soon for a test of its legality, the office of Attorney General Mitchell stated today. The operators, it was indicated, virtually have decided to put the plan into effect so that the government may bring an action in the courts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since the tenement house law was enacted thirty years ago, every year has seen attempts on the part of old-law tenement owners to strip the statute of some of the essential provisions which protect the tenement dwellers.

Rochester, N. Y. The city of Rochester, N. Y., plans to enter the market on March 15 with a new issue of $6,160,000 of bonds to refund short-term obligations outstanding. It will consist of $1,815,000 for high schools, $650,000 for veterans' memorial bridge, $650,000 for municipal building, $2,655,000 for welfare work and the balance for financing local improvements, according to Controller Argetsinger.

Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, joined yesterday as an active worker in the Block Community Organization's campaign for relief of unemployed. The object of the campaign is to organize 10,000 city blocks in New York to supplement the relief work being done through other channels.

PARIS, March 3. -- Americans must not think they are the only ones interested in the kidnapping of Colonel Charles A. Lundbergh's baby. The French press is unanimously according a generous amount of front-page space to all the details it can get. In fact the crime is one of the chief

MINEOLA, L.I., March 3. -- Isaac Guggenheim, capitalist, who died on Oct. 10, 1922, left a gross estate of $12,162,970, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed with Surrogate Leone D. Howell today. Deductions total $1,999,856, leaving a net estate of $10,163,113.

PARIS, March 3. -- The Financial Commission of the League of Nations opened here today one of the most important meetings it has ever held in an effort to solve the knotty problem of how financial support can be obtained for countries of Central Europe whose credits are exhausted and yet who must have money.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- By a vote of 344 to 2 the House late today passed the Norbeck joint resolution authorizing the free distribution of 40,000,000 bushels of government-owned wheat through the American Red Cross and organizations for the relief of distress.

For the tenth consecutive year the net income of the International Business Machines Corporation increased in 1931. The annual report, made public yesterday, shows a net income of $7,422,386 after taxes and charges, equivalent to $11.08 a share on 669,852 shares, against a net of $7,357,816, or $10.98 a share on the same share basis in 1930, and $11.53 a share on the 637,954 shares actually outstanding at the end of that year.

SHANGHAI, March 3 (AP). -- During the battle at Woosung, which led to the fall of the forts this morning, guns on nine Japanese war vessels in the river blazed continuously, pouring a steady rain of high explosive shells on the battered forts. At least two dozen field artillery guns and a squadron of bombing planes joined their thunderous fire to that of the warships.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 3. -- While Westchester police units were questioning scores of motorists and searching likely places for the kidnappers of the Lindbergh child, the women of the county started a militant movement today to cooperate with the police in the search.

Gold transactions reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York were at a greatly reduced rate, compared with recent movements. Exports consisted of $23,200 gold sent to England and imports were $55,800 from the Straits Settlements.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Declaring the present system of awarding air mail contracts and extending established lines lines is "vicious" and developing into a monopoly in contrast to the spirit of the Watres air mail act, Representative Maas of Minnesota told the House Postoffice Committee today that the existing laws should be changed.

DETROIT, March 3. -- The lengthy home winning streak of the Detroit Falcons ended tonight when the New York Rangers, backed by spectacular goal tending by John Ross Roach, downed the Detroit team, 2 to 1, in a dazzling National Hockey League match before 7,000 spectators.

In a minority report filed yesterday in her capacity as representative of the general public on the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Unemployment, Mrs. Rebecca Kohut disagreed with the report of the majority of the committee, which, while endorsing the principle of compulsory unemployment insurance, recommended delay in enacting legislation.

MONTREAL, March 3 (AP). -- The Montreal Canadiens gain undisputed possession, of first place in the International Division of the National Hockey League and the championship of the city for the 1931-32 season tonight by defeating the Maroons, 2 to 1.

NILES, Ohio, March 3. -- A demand for a $10,000 ransom for his 12-year-old son, kidnapped on the way from school yesterday, was received today, it was reported, by James De Jute, accompanied by a threat to send the boy's body "back in instalments" unless the ransom is paid within twenty-four hours.

ALBANY, March 3. -- A decision of the Court of Appeals today gave to State Senator John A. Hastings a partial victory in his fight over a thirty-day jail sentence for refusing to appear before the Hofstadter Committee. The court's ruling was based merely on the finding that faulty procedure had been used in efforts to punish him for contempt.

LONDON, March 3. -- A scheme for partial reorganization of the Royal Mail Steam Packet and associated shipping companies on which voting trustees have been working for two years was issued tonight. Without making any important change in the capital and structure of the various companies, the scheme provides for a moratorium under the control of the creditors concerned which can be terminated after Dec. 31, 1934, by a vote of specified majorities.
ALBANY, March 3. -- Two bills to put teeth in the Martin stock fraud act were passed by the Senate today as the two houses ranged through heavy calendars, mostly of local measures.
HOPEWELL, N. J., March 3. -- For a given amount of metal, gold or silver, or for a given amount of printed paper, the outstanding crime of this generation has been committed.

A survey of point-scoring possibilities for the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships, at the 258th Field Artillery Armory tomorrow, was made yesterday by officials of the I. C. A. A. A. A. after taking an informal consensus of leading coaches.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Losses from stock and bond transactions deductible from gross income in the preparation of Federal tax returns would be limited in amount to profits from similar dealings in the same year under a drastic revision of the capital net gains and losses provision of the revenue act approved today by a subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee.

More than 125,000 unemployed in this city are now receiving assistance from the Home Relief Bureau of the Department of Public Welfare, It was revealed yesterday by Mtss Mary L. Gibbons, director of the bureau, at a meeting of the New York Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association, in the Park Lane Hotel, 299 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Federal activities in the nation-wide effort to rescue the Lindbergh baby and bring the kidnappers to justice centred today in New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Connecticut and Delaware. Attorney General Mitchell was in close touch with the situation and he kept President Hoover informed of all developments.

BERLIN, March 3. -- There was a slight rise in stock prices at today's session of the Boerse, but the volume of trading was still extremely small. Bonds also recovered. Interest was concentrated on Burbach Potash, which closed about 7 per cent higher for the day after an early advance of 13 per cent.

The Newtown High School basketball team, defending city P. S. A. L. champion, strengthened its hold on first place in the Queens Division by halting the Far Rockaway High quintet, 36 to 24, on the winner's floor yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The adverse effects of the Sino-Japanese military operations at Shanghai on trade and commerce are reflected in a decline of nearly $4,000,000 in January in the value of American exports to China.

About half the staff of the Bureau of Construction and Maintenance of the Board of Education remained in doubt yesterday over the prospect of employment, but city officials withheld their expected order for the indefinite suspension of about 250 draftsmen, engineers and architects employed by the bureau.

BERLIN, March 3. -- The Federal Election Commissioner today approved the nominations of the following five candidates for the Presidency of the German Republic, to be decided by popular vote March 13:
MOSCOW, March 3. -- Official Russia from Joseph Stalin down to the ranks of communism today met the exiled Leon Trotsky's prediction of the fall of M. Stalin in silence.

Flans to aid the State of Tennessee to meet $9,000,000 of short-term obligations which will mature on April 29 were discussed yesterday by representatives of the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, Lehman Brothers, the National City Company, the Guaranty Company of New York and the Bankers Trust Company at a special meeting.

Bank clearings in the last week continued to show a sharp decline from the figures for the corresponding period of 1931, although there was the usual improvement over the preceding week normally expected at the beginning of a month when banks make their monthly settlements.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 3. -- Harvard's athletes gained a higher scholastic average than any other group in the recent midyear examinations, it was announced today by Henry W. Clark, assistant athletic director.
ALBANY, March 3. -- Judge Cardozo's opinion in the Hastings case was as follows:

ALBANY, N. Y., March 3. -- Chief Judge Benjamin N. Cardozo of the Court of Appeals, who is soon to take his seat upon the bench of the United States Supreme Court of Washington, today bade his associate judges farewell, in the presence of court attaches in the consultation room.
President Hoover's anti - hoarding campaign was called a war against fear and doubt in an address last night by General James G. Harbord, chairman In this State for the campaign.

Senator Huey P. Long of Louisiana came to the city yesterday for a stay at the Waldorf-Astoria, declared that any good Democrat could win the Presidential election, quoted the Scriptures to show that the country was in trouble because it had departed from the statutes of the Lord, asserted that the remedy for the depression was an equitable distribution of wealth, and restored the old-fashioned Waldorf sandwich to the hotel menu.

Fair weather and placid water lured the Columbia rowing squad to the wide stretches of the Hudson River yesterday and the Lions went through a six-mile workout. The last mile was at a racing clip, the varsity, junior varsity and freshman eights battling for honors.

As a result of inquiries received at the local district offices of the State Income Tax Bureau, 80 Centre Street, officials supplemented instructions yesterday for the use of Form 203 sent out to taxpayers. Revision of the law, doubling the State income tax rate, is explained by the notice as necessitating a revision of the rates appearing in the forms printed before enactment of the new law.

An editorial in today's issue of The New York Law Journal, discussing a legal phase of the Lindbergh kidnapping, points out that an interesting question might arise if a State Legislature should attempt to pass a law creating a new crime, based upon the retention of a kidnapped person, if detained in the possession of his captors after the passage of the act.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee late today asked authorization to make a comprehensive investigation of Stock Exchanges in a resolution which it adopted without a dissenting vote. It was introduced in the Senate by Senator Norbeck, of North Dakota, chairman of the committee.

On the whole, it is well that the United States Senate Banking and Currency Committee should take up, in the spirit of the resolution submitted by it to the Senate, formal inquiry into the methods and principles, cause and effect, use and abuse of Stock Exchange machinery for buying or selling on credit.
HAVANA, March 3 (AP). -- J. E. Smallman's Nelson made a show of his field in the fifth and feature race at Oriental Park today.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Two potential angles of the Lindbergh baby kidnapping case. both of which might be important, developed tonight, following an exchange of telegraphic messages between New Jersey police and the local detective bureau.

Great music has the power to shift the axis of reality, to obliterate the petty or the personal and in their stead unfold a world to which we come, not as strangers but as exiles half-remembering; a domain reopened to us when genius speaks, and fading only slowly after it is again silent.

When Congress is drafting appropriation bills it is necessary to remember that the hand is sometimes quicker than the eye. Frequently, with much ado about economy, the House of Representatives boldly strikes a number of items from the budget submitted by the President.

The unusual spectacle of two teams fighting uphill battles to victory after losing the first two sets was provided at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday as the national amateur court tennis doubles championship got under way with Jay Gould and William C. Wright of Philadelphia as the defending titleholders.

For the first time in the history of Queens County Court of Special Sessions a defendant, Mrs. Lillie Flam of 2.910 Wallace Avenue, the Bronx, was convicted yesterday on the charge of lending an air rifle to a minor. This offense, under the terms of Section 1,896 of the penal code, is punishable by a maximum penalty of three years in a penitentiary.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3. -- A new track record was created in the Pompano Handicap, five and one-half furlong feature at Tropical Park today, when C. L. King's Panetian scored easily by three lengths in 1:04 4-5. Panetian, the gelded son of Galetian and Pan Maid, recently was purchased by Mr. King from George D. Widener.

To the Editor of The New York Time: THE TIMES editorial "The State's Backyard," as well as W. A. Warn's article on the speech of Governor Roosevelt on subsidiary government, is excellent-so far as both go. But there is more to the problem.

With the entire radio facilities of the nation placed at the disposal of the police and the news bureaus, the Lindbergh kidnapping occupied the limelight on the, dial yesterday. A deluge of telephone calls came to the metropolitan broadcasting stations and regularly scheduled programs were relegated to a secondary place in the day's broadcasting activities.

The General Foods Corporation reported yesterday net earnings for 1931 of $18,153,719, equivalent to $3.44 a share on 5,275,667 shares of common stock outstanding. This compares with 1930 earnings of $19,085,595, or $3.63 a share on 5,256,843 shares outstanding.
The weekly report of the Bank of France, issued yesterday, disclosed that the gold holdings of that institution now exceed by about $3,400,000 the gold reserves of the Federal Reserve System.

Bond prices went forward again yesterday on the Stock Exchange, except United States Government Issues, which finished irregularly lower. A representative group of foreign loans entered new high ground for the year, led by the heavily traded United Kingdom 5 1/2s, due in 1937, which crossed par and closed at 99 3/4, with a net gain of a half point.
QUINCY, Mass., March 3. -- H. Everett Crane, president of the Quincy Savings Bank, died suddenly here today in the office of a hay and grain company of this city which he headed.

A gradual abandonment of old-law tenements in the last four years and a continued demand for new-law tenements is disclosed in a survey by the Tenement House Commission, results of which were made public yesterday by Commissioner William F. Deegan.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 3. -- The speedboat Pueblos of Newport, with a $60,000 cargo of liquor and seven men aboard, was seized by the Coast Guard today near where her sister ship, the Choctows of Bridgepott, was taken with a $75,000 cargo on Feb. 7.

CAMBRIDGE, March 3. -- Harvard University has granted 221 degrees in its annual mid-year award. Twenty-three were bachelors of arts, nine bachelors of science, sixty-three masters of arts, twenty-eight doctors of philosophy, two associates in arts, one master of science in engineering, two bachelors of science in engineering, seventy masters of education, three masters in architecture and twenty masters in business administration.

Judge Nott in General Sessions yesterday postponed until next Thursday sentencing Max Lipsky, 32 years old, of 460 Grand Street, one of three men convicted by a jury last week of the kidnapping of Sidney Mann, meat market owner at 90 First Avenue, for a $50,000 ransom.

Electric power production, adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, shows a further substantial decline, the seasonally adjusted daily average for the week ended Feb. 27 being 215,400,000 kilowatt-hours, a new low record for the depression, as against 218,300,000 kilowatt-hours for the preceding week and 232,600,000 kilowatt-hours for the corresponding week last year.

HOPEWELL, N. J., March 3. -- Mobilized into one coordinated unit, the State, county and local police forces of New Jersey were being directed tonight in their hunt for the kidnapped infant son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh from a well-equipped central headquarters set up in the aviator's secluded home.

An English political writer expressed surprise a few weeks age when the news came that President HOOVER was certain to be renominated by the Republican party. Innocently, he explained that he had been given to understand that Mr. HOOVER was "the most unpopular man in the United States."

Stocks moved in a narrow range, with trading dull, on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday. Gains outnumbered losses, although some of the leading issues were lower. Domestic bonds were more active, with gains more numerous than losses, while the foreign bonds were in moderate demand, with substantial gains appearing in many issues.

Commodity values yesterday lost part of the gain picked up in Wednesday's business, the grains, cotton, sugar and silk moving lower, with irregularity in coffee, hides and rubber. Cocoa moved against the trend, closing 13 to 15 points higher. In the metals, tin was strong, but elsewhere no changes were registered.

TOKYO, March 3. -- Now that the Japanese Army has vindicated its supremacy by driving the Chinese back over the 12 1/2-mile line fixed in General Uyeda's ultimatum, the Japanese spokesman said today no further advance would be made and no fresh demands would be put forward in consequence of the victory.
LONDON, March 3 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
In these days of deficit the canon of the philosopher Barkis should be consoling to the veritists:

Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter Legislative Committee, yesterday characterized the decision of the Court of Appeals concerning State Senator John A. Hastings of Brooklyn as a sweeping definition of the committee's powers. A Supreme Court action will be begun at once, Mr. Seabury added, to bring Senator Hastings before the committee.

Irving Ben Cooper, assistant counsel with Samuel Seeabury in the Hofstadter legislative investigation; John S. Sumner, superintendent for the Society for the Suppression of Vice, and Police Sergeant Christopher Confrey were among witnesses called yesterday in Judge Corrigan's part of General Sessions at the trial of Patrolman John J. Glenn, accused of perjury in connection with the arrest of a woman on a vice charge.
NEW YORK. Wollmar Bostrom, the Swedish Minister, is at the Ritz-Carlton.

New York's dramatic critics, in their comments on Congressman SIROVICH'S indictment of them, ranged from mildly ironic to outspokenly hostile. But in their heart of hearts they must have a kindly feeling for their accuser. His charges convey an enormous compliment.
LONDON, March 3. -- Joseph Stalin is to write a book on "Russia Today," It was learned today.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., March 8. -- Edgar T. Appleby of New York, present holder of the crown, defeated Arie Schaap of Chicago, 300 to 157 in thirty-five innings, in the national amateur 18.2 balkline championship tournament today.

Favorable developments in Franco-German relations, with the possibility of a constructive rapprochement between the two countries, may be looked for after the pending Presidential elections in Germany and the balloting in the French Chamber, according to Dr. Richard von Kuhlmann, former German Foreign Minister, now in this country.
Longacre Press, Inc., third floor in 427-31 West Forty-second Street; Charles M. Clark, third floor in 433-35 West Forty-second Street; Farrell Farrell, brokers.

Refusing to make an immediate ruling on the defense plea that Thomas M. Farley, deposed Sheriff, cannot be prosecuted for his admitted appropriation of interest on funds entrusted to his care, Judge John J. Freschi said yesterday that there seemed to be no unanimity of legal opinion on the Sheriff's powers concerning Interest.
An inspired quintet wearing the colors of Cathedral Boys High trounced the Loughlin High five, 27-17, at the Manhattan College gymnasium last night.

People of all faiths joined yesterday in prayers for the safe return of the Kidnapped baby of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh and from widely separated sources came offers of help in the search.

LONDON, March 4. -- The British police took a hand for the first time today in the investigation concerning the missing Lindberg baby. In three cities inquiries were set a foot in response to an urgent request from the New Jersey police. These inquiries, it is understood, concern a number of Britons who have been residents of the British Isles but now are in the United States.

Ralph Murphy and Lora Baxter, authors at "Black Tower," now running at the Ambassador Theatre, were upheld yesterday by an arbitration decision in their contention that Ben Stein, producer of the mystery play, had violated his agreement with them by substituting during rehearsals a third act different from the one written by the playwrights.

Productions closing after tonight's performances in the Broadway playhouses will be "They Don't Mean Any Harm," at the Charles Hopkins Theatre; "The Bride the Sun Shines On," at the George M. Cohan; George White's "Scandals," at the Apollo, and "The Merry Widow," with which the Civic Light Opera Company will end its long engagement at Erlanger's.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 4 (AP). -- Before a crowd of 4,000, Lord Tennyson's team of English cricketers today made short work of a team representing the County of Cornwall.
Housing properties continued to provide the bulk of realty trading in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 4. -- The Soviet Government has at last given expression to its views on Far Eastern events, and In no uncertain manner. It came in the form of a leading editorial in today's Izvestia, the official mouthpiece of the government, which from the outset of the Japanese operations in Manchuria five months ago had maintained an attitude of extraordinary reserve and caution in its rare editorial comments.

CHICAGO, March 4. -- George B. Everitt, who had been president of Montgomery Ward Co. since June, 1927, resigned today at the annual stockholders' meeting. He was succeeded by Sewell L. Avery, who was made chairman of the board of directors last November.

The market for call loans tightened as a result of settlement day at the Reserve Bank, and after a few Street loans had been made at 2 1/4 the rate rose to 2 1/2, which was the official quotation rate on the Stock Exchange. Federal funds hardened to 2 3/4 @3.

A desperately earned victory for James H. Van Alen and Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. in a closing struggle of two hours and a half enabled New York to gain an equal share of the spoils with Philadelphia yesterday in the national amateur court tennis doubles championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Among the men occasionally mentioned for the Democratic Presidential nomination is Mr. MELVIN A. TRAYLOR of Chicago. Texas claims him as a product of its soil, and a little pamphlet has been issued by his friends in that State referring to him as "The Homespun Candidate."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 4. -- The United States will be urged by the Intercollegiate Student Disarmament Council to act with the League of Nations in the Sino-Japanese conflict. A petition has been drawn up at Yale and sent to President Hoover and Secretary of State Stimson.

The directors of the General Electric Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, placing it on a $1 annual dividend basis, against 40 cents paid quarterly, or $1.60 annually, since January, 1930, when the stock was split on a fourfor-one basis.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Adopting the amendments inserted by the, House, the Senate late this afternoon completed Congressional action Upon the Norbeck-Fish joint resolution to donate 40,000,000 bushels of Federal Farm Board wheat to feed those in need.

Rentner Heads Fashion Guild. Maurice Rentner of the dress firm of the same name has been chosen chairman of the board and treasurer of the Fashion Originators' Guild of America, it was announced yesterday by Jacques Baer, director of the organization.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 4. -- Harvard's varsity hockey team hopes to keep its undefeated record against American college teams intact when it opposes Yale in the second game of their thirty-second annual series in the Boston Garden tomorrow night.

Six members of one family lost their lives and one escaped in a fire of undetermined origin at the International Grenfell Association settlement at Northwest River, Labrador, early Thursday, according to a radio message received at the association's headquarters, 156 Fifth Avenue, yesterday.

The existing structure of the law and the courts of this State was criticized last night by Presiding Justice Edward R. Pinch of the Appellate Division, in an address before the annual dinner of the Bronx County Bar Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The value of Eastern railroad properties proposed to be consolidated into four independent and competitive systems in the plan of the Eastern Trunk Line presidents, was estimated at 59,177,452,979 as of Dec. 31, 1930, in at exhibit submitted today to the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Bureau of Statistics as a final hearing on the plan.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, March 5. -- The Japanese Army of Occupation in control of a wide area about Shanghai was increased today by 10,000 reinforcements. As the men were landed from their transports the battle area was generally quiet, although there were reports of an action at Taitsang, twenty-five miles northwest of Shanghai.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Two bills to modify the stringent fourth-offender law were passed today by the Senate, although the kidnapping of the infant son of Colonel and Mrs. Lindbergh had been used as an argument against them.

GENEVA, March 4. -- The League of Nations Assembly, with Japan's agreement, voted unanimously by roll-call tonight a resolution calling for the unconditional withdrawal of Japanese forces from the Shanghai area.

BRUSSELS, March 4. -- The Belgian newspapers contain numerous criticisms and attacks today on the blue laws enforcing partial prohibition, which are under discussion in Parliament with a view to revision.

In the scheme put forward by M. TARDIEU for the establishment of a preferential tariff league to include the former members of the Hapsburg monarchy and the nations of the Little Entente, not the least interesting feature is that the plan should have the support of Italy along with Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The House Democrats got into "deep water" this afternoon while considering the postoffice and treasury appropriation bill, and before sufficient regulars could be summoned the House had voted, 92 to 74, to eliminate a section to prevent salary raises and automatic longevity promotions of all employes in these departments.

Pressure for election as delegates at large to the Democratic National Convention from New York State has been so great that it has been decided to name twelve men and four women, with one-half vote each, instead of making an equal division between the sexes.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 4. -- The recording of one of the greatest rounds of golf by a woman player in Florida and the defeat of Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., national champion, combined to make the semi-final matches for the Florida East Coast championship here today of unusual interest.

Nearly thirty years ago in a room on an upper floor of Public School No. 1 a young teacher with a Celtic inheritance of imagination and resourcefulness gathered a few "odds and ends" of pupils who did not fit into any regular course of the educational system, for such instruction as she could give them.

HOUSTON, Texas, March 4 (AP). -- W.L. Pearson, indicted in Washington for alleged failure to inform the Internal Revenue Bureau of certain payments to sixteen persons, is a wealthy South Texas road contractor.

VIENNA, March 4. -- In default of a concrete proposal from Britain, France and Italy, the three powers which Andre Tardieu, French Premier, stated in the Paris Chamber of Deputies were in favor of a preferential bloc in Eastern Europe, the Austrian Government is delaying its reply to the formal statement from Germany yesterday that she was prepared to grant tariff concessions to Austria.

TORONTO, March 4. -- Americans are gradually losing their "parochial" viewpoint on world affairs, Professor James T. Shotwell of Columbia University told an audience at Toronto University today in the third of his talks in the Marfleet lectures.

The Hotel Lexington, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, has become the third unit in a hotel chain directed by Ralph Hitz, managing director of the Hotel New Yorker, it was announced yesterday. The National Hotel Management Company, Inc., headed by Mr. Hitz, has been formed for direction of the Lexington and the Book-Cadillac Hotel in Detroit.

The factors determining whether a person is to be classified as head of a family, entitled to the same Federal income tax exemption of $3,500 as a married person, were explained yesterday by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and his wife, the former Anne Morrow, took a dramatic step yesterday to recover their stolen baby, Charles Augustus Jr.

The Coca Cola Company exceeded in 1931 its net income for 1930 and went to a new high record despite a drop In sales, whether measured by dollars or gallons. The net income last year was $14,023,622 after all charges and reserves for taxes. This was equivalent, after class A dividend requirements, to $11.82 a share on 1,000,000 shares of common stock.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, March 6. -- Coupling charges of bad faith and aggression against Japan, Chinese Government leaders last night also definitely charged that fighting had continued for the last thirty hours despite the Japanese command's orders to cease hostilities and, moveover, that eight Japanese transports yesterday landed the last of nearly 35,000 men at Deer Creek, far up the Yangtse River near Liuho Point, twenty-five miles northwest of Shanghai.

MIAMI, Fla., March 4. -- Leading almost from start to finish, Mrs. A. Carfano's Traitor, a 4-year-old son of Runantell and Orageuse, annexed he Jupiter City purse feature at Tropical Park today. Hank Mills, in he saddle, brought his mount home a length in front of Fervid, which beat Silver Lake a length for second.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- In an article prepared for The American Bankers' Association Journal, Secretary Mills of the Treasury Department explained that the work of the Citizens' Reconstruction Organization, of which Colonel Frank Knox of Chicago is head, will be facilitated if persons who desire to invest in the new "baby bonds" are able to obtain the certificates in their own community and without delay.
Among those who will sail today on the Cunarder Aquitania on a thirty-day cruise to the Mediterranean are:

A bill at Albany deserves more attention than it has been getting. It is a rather bold bill, because it would interfere with the business of the bonding companies, which have powerful affiliations. It authorizes the State to dispense with bonds on all public improvements.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The use of foreign-owned ocean liners in cruises to and from United States ports and to "nowhere," was attacked today by American shipping Interests at a hearing before the Senate Commerce Committee on two bills introduced by Senator White of Maine.

LOS ANGELES, March 4. -- An ambitious young man was toiling at first base during two strenuous workouts of the Giants today. Thus did he toil about this time a year ago, with apparently no indication now that he stands a better chance to attain his goal than he did then.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- A recommendation that the seat held by Senator John H. Bankhead, Democrat, of Alabama, be declared vacant was made today by the Republican majority of a subcommittee of the Senate Privileges and Elections Committee.

Navy's undefeated team scored its fourth victory of the season in Intercollegiate Swimming Association competition by turning back Columbia, 42 to 29, last night in the Morningside Heights pool. Captain Lloyd Mustin and his team-mates placed first in five of the eight events.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Cooperation by the United States in the plan of the Assembly of the League of Nations for liquidation of the military situation at Shanghai was assured today. This was announced informally at the State Department after President Hoover and Secretary Stimson had conferred on the resolution adopted at Geneva.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 4. -- Tommy Goodwin of Monroe. N.Y., who started his Florida golfing career here four years ago, won his first local tournament today, routing William H. Hyde of Ridgway. Pa., by 9 up and 8 to play in the thirty-six-hole final of the Palm Beach championship over the course of the Palm Beach Golf Club.

Construction of the proposed midtown vehicular tunnel under the Hudson River to Weehawken and North Bergen will not be started until its bonds can be marketed on a 4 1/4 or 4 1/2 per cent basis, the Port Authority disclosed yesterday in its report for 1931, submitted to the Governors and Legislatures of New York and New Jersey.

In its new and larger setting at the 253th Field Artillery Armory the eleventh annual intercollegiate A.A. A.A. track and field championships, one of the best spectacles of every indoor season, will be unfolded tonight with twenty-five colleges in the race for the team championship that Penn won so easily a year ago.

The United States mails are the backbone of the kidnappers' racket, according to the brief on kidnapping presented by W.B. Weisenburger, president of the St. Louis Chamber of Commerce, to the Senate Judiciary Committee just before the infant son of Colonel Lindbergh was stolen.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Income tax irregularities were attacked for the first time today under a section of the Internal revenue laws which provides that any person or firm paying any person $1,500 or more in any year must file a true and accurate account of the payment with the Commissioner of Internal Revenue in Washington.

Intercollegiate polo, with Princeton's team making its metropolitan debut of the season at Squadron A Armory, and the appearance in the Brooklyn ring at Squadorn C of the Riding Club team which includes Earle A.S. Hopping, the internationalist, are features of tonight's games of indoor polo in the city.

Controller Charles W. Berry's suggestion, for appointment of a ways and means committee to pass on new city expenditures before they reach the Board of Estimate was approved by the board yesterday in a resolution authorizing the Mayor to appoint the committee.
PARIS, March 4. -- France's foreign policies occupied the attention of Premier Andre Tardieu today.

BERLIN, March 4 (AP). -- Former Crown Prince Friedrich Wilhelm, wearing a yellow trench coat, "stopped the show" tonight at a Nationalist campaign meeting at the Sportpalast attended by 15,000 persons.

A day after the Court of Appeals ruled at Albany that State Senator John A. Hastings of Brooklyn could not ignore a subpoena of the Hofstadter legislative committee, the necessary legal steps to force him to appear for questioning were started yesterday by counsel for the investigating body.

Earl Carroll, theatrical producer, sailed yesterday on the French liner Ile de France amid a confusion of legal activity, excited farewells from nearly the entire personnel of his show and shrill playing of his orchestra, which arrived late at the pier and tried to run through the entire repertoire before the gangway was lifted.

Miss Betty Gow, the Scotch girl who was nurse to the baby son of Colonel Lindbergh and Mrs. Lindbergh when the parents were flying in the Orient last Summer and who was the first to discover last Tuesday night that the baby was missing from his bed, "is out as far as any suspicion is concerned," the police declared yesterday when they had finished questioning her.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, March 4. -- The situation in Finland brought about by the uprising of Lapuans (Fascists) became more grave today when the rebels pushed ten miles nearer the capital from Mantsala, their headquarters. Some of the advance guard marched to within a mile of Mariefors.

Stocks fluctuated over a narrow range on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, with little result on either side, while bonds continued to advance with a few outstanding exceptions. The foreign bond market was moderately weaker for the day.

NEWARK, N.J., March 4. -- Representatives of about 150 industrial and trucking concerns operating in New Jersey met at the Motor Truck Club of New Jersey, 343 High Street, this afternoon to organize opposition to bills pending in the State Legislature, which would increase the truck license fees 600 per cent and would impose a mileage tax on trucks for hire.
LOS ANGELES, March 4 (AP). -- Ralph Sheldon, a former Chicago gangster, Louis Frank and Jessie Orsatti were found guilty in the E.L. ("Zeke") Caress kidnapping case tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 4. -- In the interest of economy the New Jersey Methodist Episcopal Conference, with a membership of 75,000 and 290 churches, endorsed today proposals for a merger with the Newark conference, which has 86,000 communicants.
TOKYO, Saturday, March 5 (AP) .-- Baron Takuma Dan, managing director of the vast Mitsui commercial interests, died shortly after noon today from wounds inflicted by an assassin.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., March 4. -- Edgar T. Appleby of New York, defending champion, and Percy N. Collins of Chicago, a six-time titleholder, will meet tomorrow for the 1932 national amateur 18.2 billiard championship.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- J. Edgar Hoover, designated by President Hoover to represent him at Governor Moore's conference on the Lindbergh kidnapping case, is recognized as one of the world's outstanding authorities on scientific crime detection.

Nearly twenty years ago Mr. W. L.R. EMMETT suggested romantically, as it then seemed, that engines could be driven by mercury vapor at high efficiencies. Mercury boils at 677 degrees Fahrenheit and water at 212. Besides, after the mercury had done its work in a turbine the exhaust Still had a temperature of 477 degrees and could therefore be utilized to raise steam in an ordinary plant.

HOPEWELL, N.J., March 4. -- The father and mother of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., who has been missing now more than seventy-two hours, have drawn universal admiration from all who have had occasion to be with them or see them.

The police authorities of several States continued yesterday their hunt for a mysterious Scotty Gow for questioning in the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby, but they ran up against blind trails and clues that flickered out.

LITTLE SILVER, N.J., March 4. -- A sewing table said to have belonged to Martha Washington was rescued last night in a fire which broke out in the 27-room Summer home of Perry B. Strassburger, New York broker, causing damage estimated at $50,000.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 4. -- Meeting at the site of the first intercollegiate football contest between Rutgers and Princeton in 1869, a spirited Rutgers basketball team defeated the Princetonians, 28-26, in the new Rutgers gym tonight.

HOPEWELL, N.J., March 4. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh turned down tonight a proposal which had been advanced by some of his close personal advisers, under which the police army now making its head quarters at the Lindbergh home here would have been dismissed for a period of twelve or twenty-four hours.

Edward W. Browning, operator and president of the Edbro Realty Company, Inc., has purchased the Arcade Building at 21-37 Lenox Avenue and 10-38 St. Nicholas Avenue, it was announced yesterday. The property includes an entire block bounded by Lenox Avenue on the east 201 feet, 111th Street on the south, St. Nicholas Avenue on the west 236 feet and 112th Street on the north 134 feet.

There was little actual change in the underlying conditions la trade and business in the past week, although sentiment continued to improve, according to the weekly commercial reviews. These report also that activity is still for the most part confined to the lighter lines of manufacturing and to the retail lines in merchan dizing.

BERLIN, March 4. -- President von Hindenburg made his first public appearance today in this campaign, which will decide for the world the political stability of Germany, and made it in a fashion calculated to appeal most to the German mentality.

NEW ORLEANS, March 4 (AP). -- E.R. Bradley's B'ar Hunter, 4-year-old son of Black Servant, which has faced the barrier only three times last year, came through with a brilliant victory in the Lone Star Purse at the Pair Grounds today.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 4. -- Perhaps the tumult and shouting on the political battlefield does not reach him here in this quiet Connecticut Valley community. If it does, Calvin Coolidge, thirtieth President of the United States, gives no sign.
