Tonight rounded out the third year since he quitted the White House, a third year of calm and dignified retirement from the political lists.

A plan to merge eleven subsidiary railroads with the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway was announced yesterday by J. E. German, president. A supplementary statement by Mr. German and Charles Hayden, chairman of the board, explained that the purpose of the unification was to provide a broader mortgage to replace the present first and refunding mortgage, which will expire in 1934.

The Attorney General, acting for the Parole Board, filed a brief yesterday with Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, supporting the board's efforts to return Owen Madden and three other ex-convicts to prison for alleged violation of parole, and characterizing Madden as "a racketeer of no little importance," who "has introduced his racketeering methods even into legitimate business."

One of the largest recent industrial deals in Long Island City has been completed for the Muller Paper Goods Company, Inc., which will move within a month to a six-story concrete building on the short block bounded by Skillman. and Forty-third Avenues, Thirty-third and Thirtyfourth Streets.

ROME, March 4 (AP). -- France,and Italy today signed an operating agreement for the regulation of commerce pending the completion of a new treaty, and simultaneously Italy and Austria signed a convention facilitating the transportation of credits and other phases of their commercial relations.

The Chicago district led the New York metropolitan area in construction contracts during the first three weeks of last month, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reports. The Chicago total was $15,779,400, compared to $8,735,500 for New York.

The council of the Actors' Equity Association at a special meeting yesterday afternoon voted a strong endorsement of the bill designed "to clarify the application of the contract-labor provisions of the immigration laws to actors," which has been introduced in Congress by Representative Samuel Dickstein of New York.

When Norman Broad, 22 years old, of 125 West Seventy-seventh Street received an indeterminate term of not more than three years in the penitentiary yesterday in Special Sessions on a charge of passing a fraudulent check, it was revealed that Broad was one of the readiest distributers of worthless checks the authorities had encountered in many years.

Henry Johnson, a deckhand oil the yacht of Thomas W. Lamont, and a friend of Betty Gow, the nurse who tucked the infant son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh into bed the night he was stolen from his parents' home near Hopewell, N.J., was taken into custody last night in West Hartford, Conn.

CHICAGO, March 4. -- A resolution urging all contributors to the Republican party to withhold their financial support unless and until a prohibition repeal plank is adopted by the 1932 convention was adopted here today by the Republican Citizens' Committee Against National Prohibition, headed by Raymond Pitcairn of Philadelphia, at a session attended by 300 delegates from fourteen States.

GENEVA, N.Y., March 4. -- A second period rally allowed Hobart College to end its season with a victory tonight, defeating Hamilton College of Clinton, N.Y., 24 -- 13. The visitors led by 10 -- 8 at the end of the first half, but In the second were held to a single field goal.

TRENTON, N.J., March 4. -- The authorities in charge of the investigation into the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby reported late this afternoon that the police, cooperating all over the country, have questioned -- or otherwise looked up -- some 1,100 persons.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 4. -- The Yale varsity rowing squad of four eights moved into its permanent quarters in the Robert J. Cook Boathouse on the Housatonic River at Derby today and the work of conditioning the Elis for the coming campaign started immediately.

As a result of the progress made by the world's leading copper producers in obtaining an agreement on further curtailment of production, the price of copper for export was advanced 3/8 cent yesterday to 6 1/4 cents a pound, c.i.f., European base ports.
OTTAWA, Ont., March 4 (AP). -- Three stars from the United States each won two matches today in the Canadian squash racquets championship.

The preparations for the campaign of the Block Community Organization of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee received strong impetus yesterday with the announcement by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the new organization, that district headquarters for the "block-aiders" had been opened for a total area of 1,504 city blocks in Manhattan.

WARSAW, March 4. -- A Nationalist motion for a "numerus clausus" for Jews in the universities of Poland was rejected today in the Sejm by an overwhelming majority made up of the Left group and the government bloc.

Alexander R. Stavenitz, one of the more recent of the Guggenheim fellows, is showing paintings and prints at the Morion Gallery. His watercolor style seems to be fairly constant: bright color, impetuous brushwork and a faintly satirical eye.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 4. -- Many dinners and luncheons marked today's social program, Harold S. Vanderbilt entertained with a dinner at his estate near Lantana, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Seligman had twenty-six dinner guests at Sasa Mia. Mrs. Theodore Frelinghuysen was a dinner hostess at Southways.
PARIS, March 4. -- The Harmon trophy for the international aviation champion for 1931 was awarded to General Italo Balbo, the Italian Air Minister, by the International League of Aviators today.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP). -- A decision on independence for the Philippines was brought a step nearer today when the House Insular Committee reported out the Hare bill to establish a republic.

With the stock market fluctuating irregularly and uninterestingly, attention was centred yesterday upon bonds, which extended their gains of the day before in fairly active dealings. United States Government obligations were firm as a rule; some of them were conspicuously strong in the morning.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 4. -- Asserting that Tale is not in a class with Its intercollegiate rivals in basketball, The Yale Daily News today editorially urged giving major insignia for the sport, providing the team with adequate equipment and playing courts and attracting preparatory school players.

With choral splendors unimpaired, an orchestral rhapsody of the sea by Russia's master instrumentalist, and even new and authentic touches of a countryman of the composer in restaging his Slavic folk-legend of poetic imagery, Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Sadko" was welcomed back to the Metropolitan last evening by an audience of musical taste far from today's realism or yesterday's barrelorgan tunes and vocal roulades.
WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The third birthday of the Hoover Administration was noted today by Its friends and its foes.

BILLINGS, Mont., March 4 (AP). -- Plenty Coos, chief of the Crow tribe, who represented the American Indians at the burial of the Unknown Soldier at Arlington Cemetery, died today at his reservation home at Pryor, south of this city. For many months Chief Plenty Coos had been ill, blind and crippled. He was 85 years old.

If any particular incident wag required to explain the moderate decline on the Stock Exchange yesterday, it was the reduction by the General Electric Company of its quarterly dividend payment from 40 to 25 cents. The market community was not reconciled to a lower rate for this company, it appeared.

A Magazine for the Blind. A quarter of a century ago the first number of The Matilda Ziegler Magazine for the Blind was published, to be sent monthly free to every blind person in the United States and Canada who can read.

Bills pending in Congress for the consolidation of the War and Navy Departments were denounced as part of a political "sham battle" by Ernest Lee Jahncke, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, in an address broadcast here last night over a Columbia Broadcasting network from WABC.

President Hoover, Mayor Walker and the municipal heads of large cities throughout the country gave swift assent yesterday to the plan of Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey to coordinate at a conference in Trenton today all available municipal, Federal and private police forces in the nation to work on the Lindbergh case.

The High School of Commerce basketball team gained undisputed possession of second place in the Manhattan division P.S.A.L. race by defeating George Washington High, 17 to 10, yesterday in the Commerce gymnasium. At the half the winners led, 11 to 4.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 4 (AP). -- Provisional President Getulio Vargas received a delegation of the Revolutionary party "Third of October" Club at the Summer palace in Petropolis today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 4. -- With a whirlwind second-half attack, the Harvard varsity quintet handed a strong Williams team a 43-25 defeat in the Harvard Athletic Building tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP). -- The shifting of an army unit from the tropical Philippines to wintry Shanghai has made an unforeseen gap in the army's closely-watched budget.

The fourteenth, annual communion breakfast of the Manhattan, Bronx and Richmond branches of the New York Police Department Holy Name Society will be held in the grand ballroom of the Astor, Sunday Morning, March 13. More than 6,000 members are expected to attend.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Indications of efforts to avoid new taxation for financing the State's unemployment relief program for anotner year were apparent today as Governor Roosevelt renewed his conferences with the Republican legislative leaders. The Executive and Lieutenant Governor Lehman spent some time with Senator Fearon and Speaker McGinnies in discussion of ways and means of raising from $15,000,000 to $20,000,000.

The New York County Lawyers' Association in its seventh report yesterday on the present session of the Legislature voiced its approval of six bills and disapproval of others. The association's action is based on recommendations by its committee on legislation and law reform, of which Manfred W. Ehrich is chairman.
About the last thing one would expect to find in the middle of New York City would be a desert isle -- not one with palm trees and soft breezes, perhaps, but an Island just the same.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4. -- Manager McCarthy today announced the line-ups for the first organized game to be played by the Yankees this year, an intra-camp contest scheduled for Huggins Field tomorrow.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 4. -- Students representing twenty-eight New England colleges and universities opened a model session of the League of Nations at Brown University today, and were welcomed by the faculty as engaging in a game more interesting and significant than intercollegiate debating.

Certain "scientific, expeditions," known by their "build-up and ballyhoo," are held to be "falsely pretentious and insincere" by Dr. Herbert S. Dickey, who is now in South America with a party of "dude explorers" in "My Jungle Book," published by Little, Brown.

Art seems to be entrenching itself in the pharmacopoeia. Henry Patterson, doctor by profession and artist by avocation, prescribes painting for some of his patients -- so one learns at the New York Society of Women Artists' Gallery in the Squibb Building, where Dr. Patterson, along with other artists, is now exhibiting.

LONDON, March 4. -- Viscount St. Davids, brother of Lord Kylsant, former chairman of the Royal Mail Steam Packet group, is now strongly criticizing the reconstruction proposals, it was announced today.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Governor Roosevelt and former Governor Smith, rivals for the Democratic nomination for President, sat down together In the inner sanctum of the Executive's office today and had a long talk.

Columbia, basketball champions of the Eastern Intercollegiate League for the past two seasons, remained in the race for the 1932 title by defeating Dartmouth, 32-17, last night in the Morningside gymnasium before 3,000 persons. The result put the Lions into a tie with Princeton for the league lead and eliminated Dartmouth from the battle for honors.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The Lindbergh kidnapping case was discussed at a meeting of the Cabinet today at which those present agreed with President Hoover that every possible power of the government should, if necessary, be invoked in the effort to rescue the baby and bring its kidnappers to justice.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The Senate, as forecast, brushed aside its customary routine today to rush adoption of a resolution, authorizing a "wide open" investigation of stock exchanges by the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency.

The possibility that the Republic Bolivia can soon resume payment in full on its $62,180,303 of external debt is remote, according to a special report on the republic's finances issued yesterday by the Institute of International Finance through its director.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that the shooting is over, it is only fair for those who thought that they had been hit by my remarks about potential slums on Riverside Drive, at the meeting in the Exhibit of Modern Architecture, to hear the whole story, even if it only relieves their affront as exclusive victims of remarks which were not expressed for their special benefit.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (AP). -- A musicians' strike tonight forced the closing of the musical show "A Little Racketeer," after the patrons were in their seats for the performance. The show, starring Queenie Smith, opened last Monday and was scheduled to run another week.

Many younger members of society attended the annual supper dance and entertainment of the Spinsters last night in the Louis XVI ballroom of the Park Lane. The event had been arranged by the group of eight Spence School graduates representing the four most recently graduated classes of the school.

Advocacy of a peace program, for the United States In dealing with the Sino-Japanese conflict was voted by 1,059 persons out of 1,114 -who answered a questionnaire on the Far Eastern crisis, sent out recently by the commission on international justice and good-will of the Brooklyn Federation of Churches.

MOSCOW, March 4. -- Preparing for a sprint down the homo stretch of the ten-year period it has allotted itself to Outstrip the most advanced capitalistic countries, the Soviet Government is embarked on the complicated work of drafting its second Five-Year Plan.

New offerings of bonds this week reached $39,060.000, the largest total since the final week in January, when $45,518,130 in new issues was marketed. During the corresponding week last year the new offerings amounted to $126,240,044.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The House today, by a vote of 92 to 74, defeated a motion by Representative Lankford of Virginia to increase the 1933 air-mail appropriation from $19,000,000, the amount recommended by President Hoover, to $20,000,000. Advocates of the increase said it was needed for a short Southern extension and for a service from St. Paul to Seattle.

Melvin A. Traylor, president of the First National Bank of Chicago, has begun to share with Newton D. Baker of Cleveland the position of being the leading "dark horse" candidate for the Democratic nomination for President.

Union County, N.J. The Union County (N.J.) Board of Chosen Freeholders announced yesterday it would be in the market on March 15 with a new issue of $2,787,000 of bonds, due 1934 to 1966. Proceeds of this financing is required to retire temporary notes outstanding which were issued to finance street, road and bridge improvements, including $1,900,000 for the construction and equipment of the new court house tower.
The eight teams participating in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden continued to ride closely grouped last night, while a crowd of 8,000 persons watched their efforts.

The Bank of France yesterday took home from this market $12,500,700 of its earmarked gold, bringing the total amount repatriated since Jan. 15 to about $157,500,000. Against this export shipment, imports of $3,379,200 were received and $12,800,700 was released from earmark, with the result that the gold stocks of the counwere increased $3,679,200 net.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I must answer the letter of "E.B." which appeared in THE TIMES, and which refers to me as "your correspondent Mr. Pell, who seems to be more anxious for the future well-being of France than the United States of America."

PASADENA, Cal., March 4. -- On the eve of his sailing for Germany Dr. Albert Einstein held his final press conference last night and good-naturedly answered questions on many subject. Dr. and Mrs. Einstein sailed today on the steamer San Francisco.

Methods of improving prices and increasing the uses of cotton should be of greater concern to the South than the possibility of losing foreign markets, Ernst Ernst conclude after surveying the cotton-growing industry. They express the opinion that although American cotton has met increasing competition abroad from foreign growths, it is actually in little danger of being supplanted as world leader.

PARIS, March 4. -- Jules Ladoumegue, world's record holder for the mile run, who had been expected to carry the French colors in the Olympic games at Los Angeles, today was disqualified for professionalism by the French Athletic Federation.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The main structure of the new tax bill, based on a general manufacturers' sale tax of 2 1/4 per cent, was completed today by the Ways and Means Committee, and every indication was that it would be introduced formally in the House tomorrow afternoon or Monday.

Character and personality are different points of departure for any discussion of an individual's adjustment and behavior, according to Professor Harvey W. Zorbaugh of the New York University School of Education, who said in a speech last night that character had to do with the individual's specialization.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Assuming that there will be no pyramiding of the sales tax -- a very violent assumption -- when goods get into the hands of the retailers, the usual "mark-up" will have to be put on the cost; and the cost being increased by 2 per cent, the consumer will be obliged to pay 3 per cent more for his purchases.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Charles H. Sherrill of New York was nominated today by President Hoover to be Ambassador to Turkey. He will succeed Joseph G. Grew, who has been appointed Ambassador to Japan in place of W. Cameron Forbes, who resigned for personal reasons.
After a reaction of about 15 points from the week's, high levels, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and ended 3 to 7 points higher than on Thursday.

CHICAGO, March 4. -- Traders spent almost as much, time today in the wheat market talking about the probable effect of the plan to donate 40,000,000 bushels of government-owned wheat to the Red Cross for relief purposes as they did in operating in futures.

Mixed price changes were registered in the spot and future markets yesterday, advances and declines being distributed throughout the list. Copper, zinc, rye, cotton and rubber rose in the cash trading, but in futures for silk, coffee, sugar, cocoa and the grains irregularity was noted.
NILES, Ohio, March 4 (AP). -- A heartbroken father and mother begged for some word tonight from the kidnappers of their 12-year-old son.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 4 (AP). -- The directors of the Leipzig- SpringFair, which opens next week, issued a statement from the Minister of Economics today that foreign concerns would be permitted to draw on old credit balances held under the stand-still agreement for purchases at the fair.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP). -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has loaned to the railroads of the country a total of $24,979,850,77 out of $83,973,081,79 drawn from the treasury.
WELLINGTON, N.Z., March 4 (Canadian Press). -- New Zealand and South Africa today began the second test cricket match of the latter's tour. South Africa captured the first game.

CHICAGO, March 4. -- Chicago's Black Hawks regained second place in the American group of the National Hockey League race tonight by routing the New York Americans, 6 to 1, as a crowd of 7,500 looked on.

With malice toward none, except possibly George Jean Nathan and Walter Winchell, Dr. William Sirovich, one of this city's representatives in Congress, came to New York from Washington last night for a brief visit and indicated that he was a very much misunderstood man.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 4. -- Yale defeated the Fordham basketball team, 31 to 22, tonight, largely by a first-half rush that swept 16 points into the basket, while the Ram caged only eight.

The first of those quadrennial oracles of the people's will, the Presidential primaries, opens in New Hampshire on Tuesday. Before Governor SMITH conquered his modest reluctance, Governor ROOSEVELT was the favorite. Now the result is doubtful.

The University of Pennsylvania swimming and water polo teams scored a double victory over City College in a dual intercollegiate swimming association meet last night at the C.C.N.Y. pool, the mermen winning by a 45-26 score and the water polo team prevailing, 50 -- 4.

The statement of the American Corporation as of Dec. 31, 1931, shows total assets of $4,905,777, against 55,373,946 on June 30, 1931, and $5,094,877 on Dec. 31, 1930. This includes $4,811,803 investments at cost, against $4,918,088 and $4,930,725, respectively, and cash and current receivables of $23,561, against $25,952 and $115,612 on the dates mentioned.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The cost of running the New York City government in 1930 was $422,234,010 or $60.64 per capita. This was an increase of 187 per cent per capita over 1917 and 10 per cent more than in 1929, the Census Bureau announced today.

Harvard College will receive the principal of a trust fund consisting of New York State bonds and city corporate stock, appraised at $1,071,000, to be added to the Nelson Robinson Jr. Endowment Fund, according to a transfer tax appraisal of the estate of Nelson Robinson filed yesterday in New York County Surrogates' Court.

Fifty tenements in various parts of the city were searched yesterday by Acting Captain Patrick J. McVeagh and a squad of detectives in running down clues that proved false as the New York police persisted in the Lindbergh kidnapping quest without slackening of effort.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Mitchell will give a dinner tonight at their home, 934 Fifth Avenue.

Declaring that an irresistible force must be created to obtain an equitable distribution of the tax burden and bring a solution of the problems now confronting property owners, the Long Island Real Estate Board has started a campaign to organize taxpayers in every section of the island for mutual protection.

PARIS, March 4. -- The speculative wave which swept the Paris Bourse earlier this week has now spent Itself and trading at today's session was considerably diminished. The buying of French domestic shares fell off as a result of the reduction of the dividend by Comptoir National Descompte.
The police in all parts of the country continued yesterday to receive innumerable communications as to the whereabouts of the missing Lindbergh baby -- and continued to find them virtually worthless.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the discussion which has gone on about the removal of one Tammany district leader from the office of Sheriff and the appointment of another, and in the absorption of our people in their own economic troubles, a very vital matter has been forgotten.

For the Federal Farm Board life is one long series of complications. As if it did not have sufficient troubles of its own, Congress threatens to add to its misfortunes. A resolution adopted by the House, and approved by the Senate in somewhat different form, authorizes the free distribution of 40,000,000 bushels of Government-owned wheat for relief of distress, but makes no provision for repayment.

MOSCOW, March 5. -- It now is apparent that yesterday's editorial in Izvestia on the Far Eastern situation was much more than the newspaper's view, albeit in an official newspaper. It is now clear it had the significance of an act in foreign policy, perhaps the most important such step taken by the Soviet in a long time.

The work of the department of ungraded classes in the public schools of the city was commended yesterday by national leaders In the field of education, sociology and civic activities at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor commemorating the twenty-fifth anniversary of this movement.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Alden R. Ludlow and their debutante daughter. Miss Alicia Ludlow, who had been at the Savoy-Plaza, sailed on the Aquitania for the Mediterranean cruise.

A new program of intramural athletics has now completed Its first session of trial at Columbia University and has been pronounced by the authorities a success. In the first two months nearly 1,200 individuals took an active part in one or more of the sports offered by the intramural department.

WHILE the air transport lines of the United States flew more miles in the last six months of 1931 than in any similar period in their history, the accident record for the period was far worse than the record for the same period in 1930.

The pamphlet report of the American Water Works and Electric Company for 1931 shows gross earnings of subsidiary water companies were $14,027,382, against $14,518,549 in 1930, and net earnings $8,321,911, against $8,383,894. Net income after depreciation and charges amounted to $3,514,877, contrasted with $3,782,002.

BARCELONA, Feb. 24. -- The dissolution of the Jesuit order and the consequent departure of its members from Spain has caused an educational crisis. In the early months of the republic, when the decree of separation of church and State was issued, the government, realizing the crisis that would follow if the Jesuits closed their schools, warned them that they must not abandon their work.

ELINOR MORDAUNT mokes a fine art of traveling and practices it with skill. In her foreword to this new book she stops for a moment to look into her mind and translate from it for the reader's benefit the reasons why she travels, what she gets out of it.
TOPEKA, March 3. -- Political leaders who are charting their courses for the coming campaign might find it worth while to observe some unusual, or hardly-to-be-expected, developments in Kansas.

SHANGHAI, March 6 (AP). -- Edwin S. Cunningham. "United States Consul General, said today that Miss Rose Marlowe, American mission teacher, had been beaten by two Japanese in civilian clothes and that he had filed a formal protest with the Japanese Consulate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am wondering if THE TIMES has also been fearful lest the mildness of our Winter season might not hold out until the end. Here In the country we have received the unseasonable weather and the strange anomalies of the Winter landscape with a delight tempered by misgivings which is really no delight at all.

NEW HAVEN, March 5. -- Defeating Navy, 51 to 20, in the Carnegie Pool today, the Yale swimming team won its fifth meet in a row against Intercollegiate Swimming Association competition, to finish the season undefeated and to gain its eighth league crown in succession and its fifty-ninth consecutive association victory since 1924, when the Elis last were defeated.

Sergeant Albert L. Smith, 37 years old, of the Army Ordnance Department at Camp Dix, N.J., confessed last night that he shot and Killed his wife, Elsie D. Smith, 33, at the Miller Field reservation, in Staten Island, on Jan. 1, because he feared she would have to live at Camp Dix, "a terrible place," the police said.
LONDON, Feb. 27 (NANA). -- A notable sign that the social season is approaching is the fact that the Queen is choosing her gowns for the numerous functions which she will have to attend.

Lack of material has cut the Columbia varsity rowing squad to three crews, but Coach Richard J. Glendon is struggling along with the limited Blue and White squad and all indications point to a good crew.
WEST POINT, N.Y., March 5. -- The Royal Military College of Kingston, Ont., defeated Army at hockey tonight in a fast and interesting game, 7 to 1.

IT should be sufficient to say of this book that it is by the late Edgar Wallace, who died a few weeks ago in California, with no one knows bow many unwritten thrillers in his brain. His stories all have the qualities of suspense and mystery, combined with swift and exciting action, and the book before us is no exception to this rule.

JOHN MACY admits that a sense of dissatisfaction with most books which attempt to deal with American literature from Its beginnings to the present time lured him into the herculean task of assembling the thirty-seven writers who are responsible for "American Writers on American Literature."

LONDON. TO one who has watched the dramatic events of recent months from London, Berlin and Paris in turn, the crisis has appeared in a striking variety of aspects. In each of the three great European capitals it is seen from a different angle: to move from one to another is like looking at a revolving stage where the action is simultaneous while the scenes shift.

HOPEWELL, N.J., March 5. -- Following conferences this afternoon both in Trenton and at the Lindbergh home it was decided to cut down the police forces and send all chiefs back to their own cities and precincts, leaving Colonel Norman Schwarzkopf, commanding the State police, in charge at the home with his troopers and a small body of detectives.

Speaking last night at the eighth annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, 161st Street and the Grand Concourse, Aldermanio President Joseph V. McKee warned that there was a limit to which real estate could be taxed for public improvements.

THE late Edgar Wallace, writer of so many mystery stories, was responsible for a change in the English racing rules. He owned and raced a small stable in England and brought a friendly suit against the stewards of the Jockey Club as a result of which the rules were changed so that nominations and engagements for horses were not made void by the death of the owner.

The itinerary of the Summer European tour to be awarded in the national oratorical contest to the six regional champions who will be the national finalists was announced in Washington last week. The national finals will be held at Washington on May 21; the New York regional finals on May 13 at Town Hall, here.

Artists of the United States are to be represented at the coming eighteenth International Art Exhibition in Venice, according to an announcement by the Grand Central Art Galleries, which are arranging to ship paintings and sculpture tomorrow for a showing of six months in Italy.

AFTER the Revolution that made us a nation the life of American cities was for more than a century and a quarter publicly centred and vividly reflected in the essentially democratic institution called the hotel. The club, an eighteenth-century aristocratic outgrowth of exclusive use by superior persons of the private parlor of the tavern, smacking, therefore, of privilege, had to wait till the 1830s or so for a serious revival.

The site chosen in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, for the replica of Mount Vernon is not unlike the location of the original home of George Washington on the Potomac, according to Charles K. Bryant, supervising architect of the copy of the historic mansion.

Borough President Harvey of Queens yesterday further criticized the Port Authority of New York and said the "bi-State compact of the Port Authority does not prevent the extension of traffic facilities across the East River by the Port Authority."

VIENNA, March 6. -- The French Minister to Vienna, Count Bertrand Clauzel, told Chancellor Buresch today that France had officially brought to the notice of the German Government the results of the discussions which took place in Geneva on Monday between Premier Tardieu and representatives of England and Italy concerning a preferential bloc in Central Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Columbus University's boxing team tonight closed a successful season by disposing of Brooklyn College, 5 1/2 to 1 1/2. Harry Kaplowitz, visiting welter-weight, was the only victor for his team.

Script in lieu of interest on certain external bonds of the Brazilian Government held in Europe and the United States, pursuant to a plan announced by Brazil on Oct. 17, last, will be issued in a few days, according to the bankers who have been active in Brazilian financing.

TOKYO, March 5 (AP). -- The League of Nations' Manchurian investigating commission was informed by War Minister Sadao Araki today that Japan had no intention of invading Russian territory but was prepared to defend Manchuria in the event of Soviet threats.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Thousands of members of trade unions, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, have been asked by William Green, president of the federation, to give every possible aid in bringing to justice the kidnappers of the Lindbergh baby and toward the safe restoration of the child to his parents.

HOPEWELL, N.J., March 5. -- As the hours passed here today and no word of a clue to the whereabouts of the missing Lindbergh baby was received, activity on the farms that surround the flier's home almost ceased as their owners left fields and all but the necessary chores to sit by radios or visit Hopewell to buy newspapers.

MOSCOW, March 5 (AP). -- In line with its policy of maintaining the stability of the ruble by issuing no new currency, the Soviet Government announced today the issuance of a 50,000,000 ruble State loan for 1932.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 5. -- James Dejute Jr., 11 years old, kidnapped son of James Dejute, a wealthy contractor, was found this morning in a house on the Hubbard Road, about a mile outside the city limits. Two men who had him in custody were captured.

THIS book provides a very full and also very colorful account of an episode In Isadora Duncan's life to which she devoted only three pages In her autobiography: the enterprise of her six months' trip to South America in the Summer of 1916. Maurice Dumesnil was her musical director, orchestral conductor and associate manager, and therefore knew all about what happened.

COUNTLESS books have come out of the great war, and it It not likely that any one man has read them all. But it la safe to say that "Way of the Lancer" will stand out In this vast array of volumes. Poland has had few spokesmen and "Way of the Lancer" has Importance as a side-light on larger operations, and, especially as a side-light on that major catastrophe of the war, the Russian collapse.

Mayor Walker is expected to be called as a witness before the Hofstadter legislative committee late in April or early in May and the investigation of his affairs at public hearings, it is understood, will take at least ten days, during much of which time the Mayor himself will occupy the witness stand.

MR. FREEMAN, whose previous voyagings in strange places have spanned such contrasting lands as the Arctic and the islands of the Pacific, has spent a year, most of it in the least known and least accessible parts at the Caribbean region, collecting the adventures and the Impressions which he has crowded into his latest volume.

GERHART HAUPTMANN has come to America as spokesman for the German people at the observance here of the hundredth anniversary of Goethe's death. No one better fitted could have been selected to add a bay to thE brow of Germany's greatest poet, nor could a better messenger of peace and tolerance have come.

THE reader will search the dictionaries in vain for a definition of the title of this latest prose eclogue from the pen of T.P. Powys. But he need read only a few pages before the meaning of the author's coinage becomes clear.

Aroused over the possibility that the city's Ashokan reservoir and its contributing watersheds may past Into the hands of Ulster County for non-payment of back taxes, Alderman Joseph Clark Baldwin sent letters yesterday to Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly and John Dietz, Commissioner of Water Supply, asking them to appear at the Board of Aldermen's meeting on March 8 to explain the reasons for the impending forfeiture.
BERLIN, March 5. -- The Presidential campaign is now in full swing in Germany, and although it has been under way hardly more than a week it has already profoundly stirred the population.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 5. -- The model session of the League of Nations, in which the representatives of twenty-eight New England colleges and universities have sat as national delegations in the manner of Geneva, discussing world problems at Brown University for two days, embodied its conclusions today in a series of resolutions.

PALM BEACH. -- Although few sports tournaments have been planned for this week, there will fee no lack of entertainment, as a multitude of affairs of wide and varying Interest are planned. Each of these scheduled events should be well attended, as the cottage colony appears to be increasing instead of decreasing weekly, Winter residents receiving into their villas guests whose numbers more than balance those who have begun their trek northward.

PANAMA, R.P., Feb. 29. -- President Ricardo Alfaro has called attention to the possibility of American intervention and supervision of Panama's Presidential elections next June, in a warning delivered recently to Dr. Augusto Boyd, Presidential candidate, and Don Antonia Diaz, national chairman of the National Liberal party.

Deals Involving residences and home sites continue to occupy the chief attention of Westchester brokers. Sales of dwellings at Scarsdale and Yonkers and the rental of a number of houses in various parts of the county were announced yesterday.

BUCKHILL FALLS, Pa., March 5. -- A prediction that boards of education of public schools will provide sites for children's camps, which they will manage and which pupils will attend voluntarily, was made to day by Dr. L.B. Sharp of the University of Chicago at the convention of the Camp Directors Association.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

A strong field headed by Miss Marion Lloyd, national champion and member of the 1928 United States Olympic team, will compete Tuesday night at the Fencers Club for the women's metropolitan fencing championship. The competition was inaugurated in 1927, and has been won each year since by Miss Lloyd, who represents the Salle d'Armes Vince.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Despite criticism of its methods by Wickersham Commission experts and others, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has determined to continue without abatement its statistical researches on the prevalence of crime.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 3:

PERHAPS the most notable of the characteristics of the man whom we honor today was the joining in his being of both spiritual and worldly qualities. Spiritually Goethe was almost a hermit; but his worldly being, through its constant struggle for universal knowledge, moved perpetually in ever-widening circles.

THE quality of H.W. Freeman's work needs little introduction. His own particular version of the novel of the soil has remained fairly consistent through his first two books, "Joseph and His Brethren" and "Down in the Valley," and it is essentially unaltered in this one.

IT is an engaging figure that looks out from the frontispiece portrait of this book, youthful, slender, thin faced, large eyed, eager, the kind of man one would expect its author to be, the kind who would plunge with zest Into the experiences it relates.

PARIS. I HAVE already told your readers of the interesting anthologies issued by Editions du Sagittalre. This publishing house, which has already gathered well-chosen extracts from prose writers, from poets and from contemporary French, essayists, offers us this month an "Anthology of French Philosophers."

NO conceivable event, unless it were an invasion of the White House itself, could have so dramatized the crime of kidnapping as did the carrying off. last Tuesday night, of the infant son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh. None could so have focused public attention on a species of felony that is centuries old, yet which has recently showed signs of being organized on an unprecedented scale and with unheard-of extremes of cruelty and audacity.

For the two months ended Feb. 29, approximately 400 litters of purebred dogs had been registered with the American Kennel Club, these figures covering the period since the new rule requiring the registration of all litters went into effect. Some 200 additional litters are awaiting the process of recording and issuing the necessary papers.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., March 5 (AP) -- Eleven alleged alien smugglers, the latest catch of Federal officers in their clean-up of the Niagara frontier, were under arrest here today.

All markets ended the week cheerfully, with the sustained advance in sterling exchange perhaps the most striking movement. Exchange on London, at $3.51 1/2, yesterday reached the highest rate since November, after having in the intervening period touched $3.24 1/2 during the last month of 1931.

Although efforts to solve the mystry of the kidnapping of Colonel Lindbergh's baby seemed yesterday to centre in the questioning at Hartford, Conn., of Henry Johnson, friend of Miss Betty Gow, nurse of the Lindbergh child, clues and tips of problematical validity continued to crop up in a dozen widely separated places.
LONDON, March 5. -- Warm approval of the new banking policy of the United States was expressed today by Sir Josiah Stamp, director of the Bank of England.

When the make-up of the United States Olympic track and field team is announced some months hence the name of Hec Dyer is likely to be included among those who will strive for victory in the 200-meter dash. The California flash, once a crack low hurdler, has started training on the Coast for the tryouts, and it will take super-sprinting to beat him for a place on the squad.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 5 (AP). -- Mrs. Margaret Louise Cleveland Bacon, 93 years old. widow of Norval B. Bacon, Toledo architect, and a sister of Grover Cleveland, twice President of the United States, died today in her home here. She had been in ill health for several months.

The provision of the Federal income tax act allowing a credit of 25 per cent on earned income still is subject to many misinterpretations, usually to the disadvantage of the taxpayer, according to the Bureau of Internal Revenue, although the provision has been included in every revenue act since 1924.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- If the President has been impressed by the agitation in the Republican party for a referendum plank on prohibition he has given no sign of it to his intimates. On the contrary, those who have lately discussed with Mr. Hoover the practical phases of repeal or the restoration of State control by the substitution of a new amendment are convinced that he does not regard the plan as feasible.

PHILADELPHIA. March 5. - A musicians' union strike at the Forrest Theatre, which resulted in the cancellation of last night's performance of "A Little Racketeer" after the audience had been seated, was settled today at a conference between representatives of the union and the Shuberts.

Small lots of municipal and foreign securities were the only additions made last week to the list of bonds called for redemption in March before their maturity dates. The total for the month was increased to $10,509,000, compared with $36,041,000 in February and $86,409,000 in March, 1931, at corresponding dates.

The first test as to whether the candidacy of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for President has been checked by the entrance of Alfred E. Smith into the contest for delegates will come in five primaries and State conventions this month.

Appeals that public pressure be brought to wear in the House on March 14 for and against passage of the Beck-Linthicum resolution, which would amend the Eighteenth Amendment to return liquor control to the States, were made last night by Representatives Fiorello H. LaGuardia, Republican, of New York and Thomas Blanton, Democrat, of Texas.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 5, -- Although disqualified in the 200-yard relay, Rutgers Prep won the Rutgers University interscholastic swimming meet, held in the Ballentine pool today, with a score of 17 points. Manual Training High School was second with 16 and Erasmus Hall third with 15.

Incorporation of the American Council of Foreign Bondholders, Inc., under the laws of New York, to disseminate information regarding economic and financial conditions In foreign countries where American capital is invested, was announced yesterday.

LISBON, Feb. 18. -- Like almost all European countries, Portugal has compulsory military service. Upon reaching the age of 16 years every male citizen is required to present himself for registration and at the age of 20 he is subject to service if entrance requirements are passed and his services are desired by the government.

DETROIT. IT is unlikely that there will be any objection on the part of the automobile industry to the proposed general sales tax of 2 per cent on manufactured products. This general levy will increase the average retail price of passenger vehicles only $11.50, as compared with the average increase of $28.75 under the 5 per cent excise tax originally proposed by the Treasury Department.

LONDON, March 5. -- Declared to be the best-looking crew ever seen on the Thames, the Cambridge University eight arrived at Putney today to prepare for the eighty-fourth contest against Oxford on March 19. The race will be rowed at 10:30 in the morning, the earliest in many years, but a crowd little short of a million is expected to see it.

REPRESENTING a further step in its original program of creating a national organization for the development of aeronautical and radio law and to advance scientific research and investigation in these fields, the American Academy of Air, founded by men connected with New York University School of Law, announced last week that Washington University School of Law at Seattle had become affiliated with it.

That this year offers to department stores an unprecedented selling opportunity in electrical goods is the conclusion of a survey just completed by Dr. Kenneth Dameron, director of the electrical merchandising joint committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

IN the writing of this book Seymour Wemyss Smith disclaimed the purpose and the spirit of the debunker and the iconoclast. Throughout the work he insists that he does not wish even to seem to be trying to detract from the credit and the glory that are the due of George Washington.

PERHAPS the most Carrollian episode concerned with the observance of the centenary of the creator of the Mad Tea Party this year has been one concerning the question of what that fantastic mathematician looked like.

TOKYO, March 5. -- The assassinatiton by a 21-year-old country youth of Baron Takuma Dan has intensified the feeling of terror under which Japanese public men have been living since the slaying of Junnosuke Inouye, leader of the Minseito.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 5. -- Edward Parker Schirmer, 21 years old, a freshman at Rutgers University, was killed instantly today when he was struck by an Atlantic City express train as he was crossing the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks about 100 feet from the campus.

Jewelry in the estate of John Kirk-patrick, official jeweler for Tammany in the old days, includes an interesting Tammany piece, a ruby tiger head brooch with wide-open mouth revealing a large ruby tongue. Two olivines form the eyes and it also has ruby nostrils and 197 diamonds. The jewels will be sold on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries. Inc.

A YEAR ago Pantelelmon Romanov, one of the outstanding Soviet authors, attracted attention in this country by "Three Pairs of Silk Stockings," a novel which received a unanimous welcome. "Without Cherry Blossom" Is a collection of short stories by the same author.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 25. -- An atmosphere of nervousness pervaded the Chamber of Deputies when the political situation was being discussed In the presence of the Cabinet In spite of the fact that the Aprista representatives were reduced to a mere handful, owing to Imprisonment, deportation and the flight of more than twenty of their members, the minority, led by the Decentralists, were stanch In their defense of parliamentary rights.

IN Finland, where recently the Lapuans or farmers, organized as Fascists, marched toward Helsingfors, the capital, and demanded a resignation of Ministers, there has been recurrent trouble since the fall of the Clzardom.

Is the American high school, long largely governed by mandate of the colleges, about to become a self-determining State? In New York, as on many other fronts, to be sure, the tremendous growth and improvement of vocational high schools are automatically freeing an increasingly large proportion of high school students from any lingering entangling alliances with traditional academic requirements imposed from above.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Arthur J. Brown's earnest advocacy of the League of Nations and of American participation, in his letter to THE TIMES, was perhaps unfortunate in the parallels drawn from the history of the American Union. He is correct in saying that "Massachusetts and Virginia were * * * quite as far apart in sympathy as America and Europe today."

FRENCH LICK, Ind., March 5. -- Edgar T. Appleby of New York was dethroned when he lost to Percy N. Collins of Chicago in the twenty-first and final game of the national amateur 18.2 balkline championship tournament today.

FOR the delinquent girl between 15 and 18 who must find her way back to social security as best she can, Inwood House, at 228 West Fifteenth Street, offers a temporary home. Inwood House recently has entered upon its second hundred years of service.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: I find in a French newspaper dated Feb. 2 some statistics which, I think, might be of interest to readers. Some will probably challenge those statements. I cannot endeavor to prove or disprove their accuracy, but they were quoted from an official report prepared for the Committee on Foreign Affairs in Paris by M. Bouilloux-Lafont, a member of the Chamber, and reporter for the War Office.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Mrs. Mary Mooney, 84-year-old mother of Tom Mooney, who is serving a life sentence in the San Quentin Penitentiary, California, as a participant in the Preparedness Day parade bomb explosion at San Francisco in 1917, called at the White House this morning to ask the intervention of the President in bringing about the liberation of her son.

CHICAGO. ODD shapes and showy colors are blossoming along the Chicago lakefront -- outward signs of the huge preparations that are under way to celebrate Chicago's centennial next year in a world's fair.

BERLIN, March 5 (AP). -- Former Crown Prince Friedrich Wilhelm emerged today as a possible candidate for President in the event that none of the candidates now in the field achieves a majority in the first balloting a week from tomorrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES editorial "Prices and Valuation" you comment that it will be interesting to see whether further evidence appears of the reversal of positions of the utilities and the "radicals," as you term their opponents, with respect to the applicability of cost of reproduction and original investment to the valuation of public utilities, as a result of the decline of prices.

Some of the larger financial houses have asked and answered the question: "What appears to be the next step in the Washington Administration's effort to hasten the economic recovery?" The composite guess is that a plan looking to liberalization of the anti-trust law will be offered soon under strong sponsorship.

DETROIT, March 5. -- Lone Eagle of Erlsmoor that well-known champion owned by Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank of New York, was judged the best fox terrier in the show at the seventeenth annual exhibition of the Detroit Kennel Club today. The event, which started yesterday, will end tomorrow when the best in show will be chosen.

OMAHA, March 3. -- Corn belt interest has been drifting around to prohibition again as it inevitably does every so often. An approaching campaign always revives discussion of the question, although it is the last thing, as a rule, which the politicians care to have raised as an issue.

As a result of n wage disagreement with the Federation of Musicians. Milton Aborn announced yesterday that he had abandoned his plans to start a ten-week season of grand opera in English at popular prices on March 28 at the Erlanger Theatre, where his Civic Light Opera Company closed its forty-fourth week last night with a performance of "The Merry Widow."

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- An empty cradle in a house on Sourland Mountain in New Jersey filled the heart and the mind of America last week. The great nation of more than sixscore millions thought of little else. What were the perversions of humanity which could prompt so cruel a plan as the kidnapping of small Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.?

Revival of public works programs in countries of South, and Central America, and consequent reopening of the large markets there for building machinery and supplies, is sought by the American Foreign Credit Underwriters, Inc., in proposals now being laid before Latin-American governments.

A kind of program, rich in interest and in admirable diversity, for which audiences at orchestral concerts in New York wait long and usually in vain, was given by Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

FRANCIS GUMMERE in his study, "The Beginnings of Poetry," pointed again and again to facts that indicated the simultaneous development of music and verse. Many other anthropologists and students of primitive music have reaffirmed Mr. Gummere's conclusions and find that "poetry" is, in its simpler forms, seldom separate from some kind at musical accompaniment.

WE have a system of local government in this State whose general form and structure can be traced back beyond the birth of our nation, back to conditions in rural England before ever a colony existed on North American soil.

The churches of America strove last night to make possible the return of the Lindbergh baby to his parents by issuing an appeal to the kidnappers over the radio to return the child through the medium of any church or church organization.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 5. -- The semi-annual Leipzig Messe, one of the biggest and best-known merchandise fairs in the world and an important agency for promoting Germany's export trade, will open its Spring week tomorrow with 9,000 firms showing goods ranging from electric generators to toys.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- World production of crude petroleum last year totaled 1,370,299,000 barrels, a decrease of nearly 40.000.000 barrels or 2.8 per cent from the 1.410,037,000 barrels produced in 1930, Scott Turner, director of the Bureau of Mines, reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Members of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today mapped preliminary plans for the "wide open" investigation authorized yesterday into Stock Exchange practices, particularly short selling. It was reported that William R. Perkins, an attorney of New York City, who testified at the House inquiry will be the first witness called after a preliminary meeting of the committee on Tuesday.

TORONTO, Ont., March 5. -- The Ontario Mine Prospectors Association came into existence this week when many prospectors, field men and non-technical men met in the King Edward Hotel here to discuss the "professional engineer act of 1932," which is before the Ontario Government.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 5. -- Yale defeated Princeton 11-6, in their varsity fencing contest today, barely capturing the foils, 5-4, breaking even in the saber contest, with two matches each, but sweeping the epee with four straight wins.
Against the flames and battle-smoke of Shanghai recent events have etched with clear significance and in sharp detail the importance of navies in this imperfect world.

SHANGHAI, March 5. -- Another American citizen, this time H.D. Robison, United States Trade Commissioner at Shanghai, has been beaten by armed civilian Japanese officiating as police in an area legally policed by the International Settlement force.

The James Monroe, Washington, Commerce and Seward Park High School swimming teams recorded victories in the Manhattan-Bronx P.S.A.L. tourney for the senior championship in the weekly series of dual meets in the seventy-five-foot pool of George Washington High School yesterday.

Following Instructions from Hartford, Conn., where Henry (Red) Johnson, friend of Miss Betty Gow and periodically employed deckhand on Thomas W. Lamont's yacht Reynard, was interrogated yesterday, New York detectives made a minute search of the premises of the Consolidated Shipbuilding Corporation, Morris Heights, the Bronx.

Frances bavage, who in showing her sculpture at the Women's City Club, 22 Park Avenue, has the invaluable quality of mutability. When she models Abraham Lincoln or Theodore Roosevelt she uses strongly marked planes, a rugous surface that conveys in visible terms the essential quality of the man.
PARIS, March 4. -- Two exhibitions of paintings which have just been opened have aroused social as well as artistic interest.

SENATOR FREDERIC C. WALCOTT of Connecticut, the chairman of the Senate committee which begins this week to investigate short selling on the Stock Exchange, knows bears. As a banker he has traded with them; as a sportsman he has shot them in Alaska.

PARIS, March 4. -- Overshadowing my single event in France this last week has been the realization that in many respects things have taken decided turn for the better. Not in more than a year has the Parisian atmosphere been so optimistic as regards either internal or foreign affairs.

The P.S.A.L. basketball tournament divisional races, which are rapidly nearing a close, will provide several important games for scholastic fans this week. Textile High has already clinched the Manhattan division title, and in the other three divisions the winners may be definitely established before the end of the week.

Supermen on Broadway. Special to By-Products. GENEVA, March 5. -- News of a movement to have the United States Congress declare war on the New York dramatic critics has been received here with great elation. This is not because Geneva welcomes a new threat to the peace of the world, but because it discerns in the circumstances surrounding the new conflict the promise of solving at one stroke all the world's outstanding troubles.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5. -- Young players carried off hitting and fielding honors and a brace of junior pitchers offered the most sparkling mound performances in the first Yankee baseball game of the year, a nine-inning intra-camp contest, played at Huggins Field today.

A mighty burst of inspired riding, less than five minutes before the end, saw Reggie McNamara, the veteran Australian star, and his husky partner, William (Torchy) Peden of Vancouver, steal a lap which gave them the victory in the fifty-second international six-day bicycle race which came to a close in Madison Square Garden last night.

BERLIN, March 5. -- President von Hindenburg threw off his reserve today and in a powerful statement reassured the people of East Prussia, who had been concerned with recent Polish threats. His statement was in a letter addressed to the head of the administration of East Prussia, but it may be regarded as being addressed to Poland.

BERLIN, March 5. -- The price tendency was downward on the Boerse today and what little buying interest existed was concentrated on some of the favorites, notably the electric stocks, which regained some of the ground lost recently. The pessimistic annual report of the Krupp Company did not seem to disturb the Boerse which is concerned more with political conditions.
CHICAGO, March 5 (AP). -- Although the major campaign has not yet begun, the Citizens Reconstruction Organization estimated today that 150,000,000 idle dollars had already been put to work.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- President Hoover was the guest of honor tonight at the tenth annual dinner of the White House Correspondents' Association, at the New Willard Hotel, which was attended by nearly 500 newspaper men. The other guests included Cabinet members, diplomats and many notables.

Sir THOMAS BROWNE said in "Religio Medici" that he could not go to cure the body of his patient but he forgot his profession and called unto GOD for his soul. Somewhat akin to the religion of this famous doctor is Yale University's religion of medicine, the earthly welfare of the soul being of first concern:

MADRID, March 5. -- An army Lieutenant, ten soldiers and six civilians were arrested today in a sudden move to suppress an incipient extremist rising at Jaca, near the Pyrenees, centre of the December revolt against the monarchy.
ALBANY, March 5. -- Amended bills providing for levies on buses and heavy motor trucks will be presented in the Legislature early next week to complete the new tax program.

England has long been on her guard against what many of her sons have called The American Peril. They have dreaded "Americanization" of one kind and another. There was first of all, the fear that the fountain of pure English undefiled would be contaminated by American vulgarisms and slang.

THIS work on Constantinople is large, sumptuous volume. with twenty-three illustrations in color and twenty-two in monotone, drawn by the author himself George Wharton Edwards already has to his credit several books of this type, including his "Paris" and "Rome."

For the second consecutive day, the price of copper advanced yesterday as a result of the improvement in sentiment caused by reports that the world's leading producers had virtually reached an agreement to cut output to 20 per cent of capacity from the present rate of 26 1/2 per cent.
HOPEWELL, N.J., March 5 (AP). -- The kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby has thrown this out-of-the-way hamlet of 1,800 persons into adventure and drama that grow more fantastic as the mystery drags on.

MUNCIE, Ind., March 5. -- George B. Dale, Mayor of Muncie and a militant anti-Ku Klux Klan editor, was arrested today, along with several members of his administration, by Deputy United States Marshals on indictments returned by the Federal grand jury at Indianapolis for alleged violations of liquor laws.

HERE Is another volume to add to the many studies of Shelley, whose life and poetry have undergone several revaluations and interpretations since those years In which, because of the very nature of the times, that poet was exiled from England to write poems which gained little attention from a public for whose instruction they were intended.

Mail orders appeared In the local wholesale markets in heavy volume during the week, as demand expanded for Easter and regular Spring merchandise, according to the report prepared exclusively for THE TIMES by the Independent Merchandising Buieau, Inc.

MINEOLA. L.I., March 5. -- S. Isaac annexed the second registered shoot of the year over the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club at Mineola today. He scored by breaking 99 out of a possible 100 targets. R.H. Helsel finished next with a card of 98.
EXETER, N.H., March 5. -- The Harvard freshman track team triumphed over Exeter today by 74 to 21. Three Exeter records were set.

EKE the soldiers of the G.A. R., the Indian veterans of the border skirmishes and wars of the '60s and '70s are fast becoming, in Black Elk's phrase that is redolent of the spirit of Ecclesiastes. "grass upon the hills."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 5. -- Harvard's fencing team was held to an 8-8 tie by Navy in the Harvard Athletic Building today.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, March 6. -- Despite the fact that both the Japanese and Chinese high commands announced orders for the cessation of hostilities three days ago, fighting continued all Friday night and was still proceeding yesterday.

Sharp disagreement with views now current in retail circles, aimed at improving retail profits through manipulation of merchandise costs or by increasing the percentage of original mark-up, was voiced here yesterday by Kdwin A. Godley, retail consultant for R.D. Leidesdorf Co.

WITHIN the next few weeks residents of New York and vicinity who have spent Winter vacations in Florida and other parts of the South will be motoring home. Others will wish to take trips into Virginia and the Carolinas at this season.

EVOLVING through eons of time, the eyes have become marvelously adapted to natural conditions. They are receiving-sets tuned to respond to electro-magnetic energy of certain wavelengths furnished in great quantities by the sun and map-made sources.

A dead gunman -- or a badly beaten one, at least -- should be found in Queens in the next few hours, according to the theory of Police Lieutenant Michael Abt of the Richmond Hill precinct, made last night after listening to what he characterized as one of the most extravagant tales of crime he had ever heard.

PARIS, March 5. -- Although not scheduled to be put into circulation before the end of this year, 100,000,000 silver 10-franc coins authorized by the law of June 25, 1928, and accordingly ordered by the Bank of France, already have been minted, it was announced today by the French Ministry of Finance.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- O'Kero, nicknamed Snowball because he is as black as the ace of spades, the National Zoo's youngest and only other gorilla besides N'Gi, also has developed bronchial pneumonia.

The second important exhibition of Italian painting to be seen In New York this season is now in progress at the Metropolitan Galleries, in the Heckscher Building, to continue until March 26. The previous one was the baroque show at Durlacher's. The new exhibition includes the canvases lent to the Esposizione d'Arte Italiana, held in Birmingham last year, augmented with other pictures from the gallery's collection.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The official circular by the Treasury Department announcing the "baby bond" issue reads:

RICHMOND, March 3. -- The Legislature of Virginia, supposedly one of the driest and most moral of the States, has been exhibiting well-nigh startling independence at the current session in its attitude toward prohibition. True, the session is rot yet over, and it is possible that the Anti-Saloon League will get the boys back into line before adjournment, but to date the honors are mainly with the modificationists.

WITH the spread of flying activities in Europe as well as the United States, concerted efforts are being made to bring simplicity out of chaos and uniformity out of contradiction in regulating the international aspects of flying and of aircraft.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., March 5. -- A Spring-like day, with Manhass Bay smooth as plate glass under hauling north breeze that fad finally into a nothingless calm. In the dinghy sailors of the Frostb Yacht Club floundering today. The wintry weather defiers were beat by a mild condition rather than chill and all that customarily go with it.

More Thought Needed. I should like to express my disapproval of Representative Collins of Mississippi for his recent remarks regarding poison gas in warfare. Mr. Collins should make a study of the different kinds of torture that can be inflicted by means of modern poison gases.

CAIRO, March 4. -- Is it the fourth pyramid or the eleventh pyramid at Gizeh? This question has been occupying leading Egyptologists for the past fortnight, since Professor Selim Hassan of the Egyptian University identified what hitherto had been considered merely an unfinished mastaba, as a pyramid, the burial place of Queen Khent-Kawes.

HIS explanation of how the human body maintains its stability from youth to age in the face of difficulties of the most diverse nature, despite the fact that it is composed of unstable material, is set forth In the present volume in great detail by the distinguished Harvard physiologist, Dr. Walter B. Cannon.

The airplane is now used on the farm and plantation, and even the cattle and horse range, to sow seed, to protect growing crops, to reforest land, to herd animals, and to save time and labor. On the largest holdings the plane is but another piece of machinery that has become indispensable.

Martin J. Tracey of Fordham University was selected last night over the representatives of thirteen other colleges, universities and normal schools to represent New York State in the national oratorical contest to be held at Washington next month as a feature of the Washington bicentennial celebration.

LONG LAKE, N.Y., March 5 (AP). -- The "wild man of the Adirondacks" is dead in the rugged region he terrorized for several days, but the officers who killed him in a gun battle have been unable to bring the body out of the ice-locked mountains.

An increase of $1,208,341,443 in the quoted value of all shares included in the New York Stock Exchange's trading list is indicated for February in the monthly compilation which the Exchange issued yesterday.
EASTON, Pa., March 5. -- Flashing a strong offense, the Lafayette basketball team closed its season tonight with a 29-22 victory over Lehigh.

GENERALLY speaking, the youth of Germany is in revolt. It wants the right to live, to work, to have families, to share on equal terms with others in the reorganization of Europe and of the world. It has turned against its leaders of the past because they have failed to assure those rights.

IT Is still too early for any physicist to venture a critical opinion on the discovery of the neutron, announced a week ago by Dr. James Chadwick, long an assistant of Lord Rutherford in the famous Cavendish Laboratory of Cambridge, England. The neutron is not so much a particle, as it has been described, as a system.
HAVANA, March 5. -- George Lott of Chicago today advanced to the singles final in the international tennis tournament by defeating J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

Increased supplies and very limited buying caused a drastic rut in the price, of fresh asparagus in the wholesale market at the end of the week, it was said yesterday by George G. Royce, of the New York office of the Stale Department of Agriculture and Markets.

In the first five days of enrolment for this year's Citizens' Military Training Camps 4,600 youths registered at Governors Island, it was announced there yesterday, by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commanding the Second Corps Area. This breaks all records in the history of the camps, General Nolan said.

Since the beginning of broadcasting, no emergency, either public or private, has so completely received the undivided attention of the radio facilities of the nation as has that confronting the family of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and the officials directing the nation-wide search for the kidnapped baby.

BOSTON, March 3. -- Why should the Legislature of Massachusetts meet every year? No other State has a Legislature which remains so long in session. The average session on Beacon Hill is longer than are the average sessions of the lawmaking bodies which meet only in alternate years.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., March 5. -- Every home in Pittsburgh will be visited by policemen on the possibility of uncovering some trace of the Lindbergh baby. Orders for the search, which will start tomorrow morning, were issued here today by James M. Clark, director of the Department of Public Safety.

Varied and odd are the requests for college students that the New York University Employment Bureau handles daily. Practically every position and occupation known to man calls upon the bureau for man power when it feels the need. Because of the economic pressure applied to most students at home, practically every position has at least six or seven applicants.

LONDON. TO the list of London's haunted houses there have been surprising additions. One, already reported upon, la the ancient Mansion House, the official home of the Lord Mayors of London, where blood-curdling sounds, as yet unaccounted for, have been heard after midnight these last few weeks.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 5. -- A grand total of $1,457,000 has been made available for work relief In Westchester County up to the present time, according to an estimate made this week by Wayne D. Heydecker, director of Westchesfer County's Emergency Work Bureau.

BERLIN, March 4. -- No visitor to Germany cognizant of the economic tribulations under which she is struggling in these days of world depression could easily repress a feeling of admiration for the spirit in which her people are meeting their difficulties.

RETAIL trade improved a little during the week but not enough to bring volume muck over the recent level. The beat demand was reported on new lines of women's apparel. Men's wear suffered from the usual reaction that follows a period of intensive promotions.
BERLIN, March 5 (AP). -- Less well known than the French Surete or Scotland Yard, Berlin's criminal Police Department has a record of solving all except eleven slayings here since 1928.

Miss Stella Walsh, world's leading woman sprinter, who is regarded as a certain point-winner for the United States in the coming Olympic games, says she gets more pleasure from basketball than from the aport in which she has gained international fame.

Two offerings of bonds of subsidiaries of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation are expected to be made early this week. The issues are $5,000,000 first and refunding 5 per cent gold bonds, Series B, of the Syracuse Lighting Company, Inc., and $2,000,000 general mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds, Series E, of the Utica Gas and Electric Company.

BETWEEN the clear sky and the golden sands we saw a gray line -- Taudeni! In the midst of this Immense desert It is a Euclidean point, having position but no magnitude -- a city of dreadful hunger, of life just barely nourished by stores of food replenished once a year, and only once a year, when the caravan comes up from Timbuctoo to reap the harvest of salt.

THE contemporary designer is enlarging his field, so that gas boilers and penny weighing machines as well as home furnishings are taking on beauty. In this more practical approach to the things of daily life contemporary decorative design is losing much of its former air of self-consciousness and bizarreness, and the increasing number of patterns in almost every type of household furniture makes easier the achievement of harmonious interiors.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- The public school system of Chicago, as a consequence of the breakdown of the local system of taxation, aggravated by the depression, faces lean and troublous years. Whatever solution may be found for its immediate budgetary problems, none seems likely to save it from the necessity of drastic economies, or the danger of complete collapse.

AFTER mid-April "Old Ironsides," this Winter visiting the Gulf ports, will be at Washington as an important feature of the bicentennial celebration, where she will be "at home" for all the crowds who will flock thither during the coming months.
Princeton University's polo team, in its first metropolitan appearance of the season, upset the favored Pennsylvania Military College team at Squadron A Armory last night, 12 1/2 to 9 1/2.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Exports of American merchandise in January were valued at $149,901,309, $33,676,320 less than in December and $99,696,654 under January, 1931, according to Department of Commerce statistics.

NEW ORLEANS, March 5 (AP). -- In a three-horse race, John Marsch's Prince Atheling, ridden by J. McCoy, today defeated Robert A. Fairbairn's Glastonbury and J. McPherson's Prince Pest in the feature $2,000 added General Beauregard Claiming Stakes at the Pair Grounds.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 5 -- Two Harvard pool records were set in the meet with the University of Pennsylvania swimmers tonight as the Crimson scored a 43-28 victory.

THESE are busy and often hazardous days for the men of America's Asiatic fleet. Ashore in Shanghai, where marines stand guard behind sand-bags and wire entanglements, and in the Whangpoo River, filled with foreign warships, there is work day and night for every one -- from the Admiral to the lowliest rating.

Any character training which results from competition in inter-scholastic or intercollegiate athletics is probably accidental, Professor William L. Hughes of Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday at the final session of the two-day conference on the interpretation of physical education at the NEW York University School of Education auditorium.

ESSEX, Mass., March 5. -- Arthur Dana Story, who designed and built most of the vessels in the Gloucester and Boston fishing fleets, died suddenly here today at his home near the shipyard he founded many years ago.

Rocketing back to the heights once more with a series of breath-taking performances, New York University regained the team championship of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. at the 258th Field Artillery Armory last night, and, as the final stamp to its brilliant achievements, equaled the world's indoor one-mile relay record in the climax event on the program.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP). -- With the turbulent Mississippi still not tightly shackled, although millions of dollars have been spent, the government intends to coax the river giant into wasting his fury on a "battleground" in Louisiana.

Photons, the Principle of Uncertainty, atoms composed of ghostly probabilities, space that is curved, electrons that are now particles and now waves -- what do they mean in our lives? Three good meals a day, a pleasant home, interesting work, a weekly visit to the motion-picture theatre -- these are the realities of life.

Mayor Walker has submitted to the State Water Power and Control Commission an application for approval of plans prepared by the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity for the development of additional subsurface sources of water supply on Long Island to yield to the city an estimated maximum of 109,000,000 gallons of water a day, it was announced yesterday.
