Mrs. Norman Leeds Jr. of Bridgeport will entertain the Service Club at her home on Tuesday.

The experiment of bringing an added force of public opinion to bear on the Sino-Japanese war has been begun at Geneva. The extraordinary session of the Assembly of the League of Nations, called at the instance of China to weigh the Far Eastern situation, has passed, a resolution the effect of which is to call on the Japanese Army to go home.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 5. -- Dr. Charles F. Jenkins, the physicist who is widely known for his experiments in radio photography and who received the medal of the Franklin Institute, tells of a new method of radiovision in the issue of the Yale Scientific Magazine published Monday.

No longer do the dog drivers mush over glistening snow, carrying provisions and news of the outside world to the remote outposts of civilization in far-off Alaska. Airplanes now accomplish these missions, negotiating In an hour what was formerly a week's Journey by dogsled.

New York University will seek the Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt team trophy tomorrow night at the 102d Engineers Armory when the New York County American Legion stages its benefit track meet. The proceeds will go toward the aid of the widows and orphans of those killed in the World War and to disabled veterans and the unemployed.

LONDON, March 4. -- Enemies of the present National Government of Great Britain predict it will go to smash next month when the new budget la presented to Parliament. Friends of the government and even some of its members think there will be a Cabinet reconstruction.

MOSCOW, March 4. -- Soviet determination to reduce imports to a minimum this year -- that is, to economize valuta in order to meet foreign payments -- has brought up somewhat acutely the problem of the employment here of the foreign specialists who are paid in foreign money.

Heavy maturities, coupled with the Six months' Inaction of the market for new bond flotations and the competition for funds by municipalities, States and the government, constitute the principal object of concern among public utility companies for this year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of your correspondents, questioning the year of Washington's birth as expressed in modern chronology, does not find the explanation given to him by Harrison H. Dodge, which he quotes, entirely convincing. Mr. Dodge is perfectly correct, for there is no question that this year is the true bicentennial.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- Strength in the stock market and a cold wave that sent temperatures below zero in Western Nebraska brought today a fair ran of commission-house buying of wheat futures on the Board of Trade here. The surplus in the pit was absorbed at the opening by several houses and no material pressure appeared later.

William A. Cokeley, prominent real estate man, who was the McCooey-Hylan candidate in the Democratic primaries of 1925 for President of the Board of Aldermen, died yesterday at the age of 70 in his home, 3,150 East Tremont Avenue, Bronx, of diabetes, from which he had long been a sufferer.

The amount of receipts and loan authorizations of the Railroad Credit Corporation disclosed to date indicates that this body has gone considerable lengths in making funds available to needy railroads at this time. Funds for the corporation are provided by freight surcharges that went into effect Jan. 4 and these yielded about $4,500,000 in revenue for the month.

Having the game largely in their own hands, and playing much of it well, the Democrats are unwise to make wild, foolish statements about Mr. HOOVER. It is true that these might be considered justifiable reprisals for equally inane adulation from the mouths of some of his subordinates and supporters.

WASHINGTON. March 5. -- Admiral M.M. Taylor, Commander of the Asiatic Fleet, has been directed to join with the British, French and Italian Admirals at Shanghai in reporting to the Assembly of the League of Nations whether hostilities have ceased there between the Chinese and Japanese.

LONDON. DOROTHY SAYERS claims for writers of detective fiction that, as a class, they are the only novelists who have ever really succeeded in making the virtuous characters more interesting than the wicked ones.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- "Young Democrats" from twenty-seven States met here today and organized nationally to work in harmony with their State organizations, but on their own lines and in their own way, for party success this year.
THE extent of crime is and must be a subject of increasing concern to the government and to every well-disposed citizen. This increase is by no means confined to the violation of new criminal laws.

HAVANA -- The Cuban capital enters the final week of the Oriental Park racing meet with the most important race of the season, the Cuban Grand National Handicap, scheduled for March 13, with 510,000 added, at a mile and an an eighth, for 3-year-olds and upward, the closing day.

SHANGHAI. NEW terrain has been opened to aviation by the flight of an airplane belonging to the Eurasia Aviation Corporation, the Cino-German company which plans a direct Shanghai-Berlin air service late this year, from Shanghai to Tihwa, Sinkiang Province.

E.L. CORD, head of Cord and Auburn Motors, the Stinson Aircraft Company and Century Air Lines, has released a statement in connection with his cuts of wages on Century Air Lines in which he brands as false reports that he has hired inexperienced pilots to replace the men who were let out for their wage protest.

LONDON, March 4. -- Early rumblings of the World War are an undercurrent running through the new volume of British official documents dealing with the so-called "Agadir crisis" in 1911 and published here tomorrow.
The same two Philadelphia teams that met in the final of the national crourt tennis doubles championship year ago will play again for the title this morning at 11:30 at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

A strong over-the-counter securities market accompanied the improvement on the exchanges yesterday with increaaed buying orders lifting quotations for nearly all groups. Gains were moderate, being confined for the most part to a point or less, but the movement was broadly distributed.

The annual national A.A.U. women's track and field championship meet will be staged in the Newark Armory on Saturday night. Inasmuch much as entries have not closed, the complete list of competing athletes is not available, but it is certain that at least six of the eight titleholders crowned last year will defend their laurels.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Secretary Hyde struck back today at Senator Robinson, the Democratic leader, who charged on the Senate floor that the Secretary of Agriculture had used his mail-franking privilege.

IN Mrs. Risley's new book she tells the story of wresting a livelihood out of a hundred acres of apple orchard that for years bad been allowed to grow and bear as it would without horticultural attention. She tells this tale in the first person, as

PITTSBURGH, March 3. -- It now seems assured that Pennsylvania will have a spectacular contest between Republican factions over State offices in the coining primary campaign in addition to what excitement may be furnished by the Democrats in their differences over Presidential candidates.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Denial of the request of the New York Transit Commission for a rehearing of issues involved in the rental of the Pennsylvania Terminal in Manhattan by the Long Island Railroad was urged in a brief filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Pennsylvania and Long Island Railroads.

ROME, March 4. -- Probably there is not a business man anywhere the world who can look over the balance sheet of the Italian tobacco monopoly without feelings of envy Its net profits last year were about $130,000,000, representing more the 80 per cent of its total revenue which is considered the highest ratio of profit to revenue which can be shown by any industrial interprise of importance.

NEWARK, N.J., March 5. -- Teams favored in Classes A and B of both the prep and high school divisions of the New Jersey State scholastic basketball tournament continued to show the way in more than twenty-five games contested throughout the State this afternoon and tonight.

Railroad men ending the day's run here on March 17 will have available a new haven of rest and recreation In the midtown district. On that date the ten-story Grand Central Railroad T.M.C.A. building at 224 East Forty-seventh Street will be opened and dedicated to provide an expanded program of social, religious and athletic activities designed to serve about 6,000 workers in the transportation centre.

TRENTON, N.J., March 5 (AP). -- The police gave out information to the press about the Lindbergh baby kidnapping by interviewing one another today in the presence of reporters. Lieutenant Walter J. Coughlin of the State Police met Major Charles Schoeffel between Trenton and Hopewell and questioned him while reporters listened.

BOSTON, March 5. -- The Boston motor yacht Keible and a crew of five men were seized with a $50,000 liquor cargo off Warren Point, R.I., by the Coast Guard early today after a ten-mile chase in which the Keible tried to escape under cover of a smoke screen.

Dr. Herbert Adams Gibbons, author, at a Foreign Policy Association discussion luncheon in the Hotel Astor yesterday, brought an unexpected political angle into a meeting devoted to the question of whether the world's peace machinery is imperiled by the Far Eastern situation.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and his wife, the former Anne Morrow, named two men known and trusted by the New York underworld early today to negotiate for the recovery of their infant son. Their action was announced at the office of Governor A. Harry Moore in Trenton.

IN his first series Professor Mather discussed chiefly foreign artists: in the present volume he is concerned with American. The sixteen essays, most of which have appeared over a period of twenty years in various magazines, deal with the following painters: Gilbert Stuart, S.F.B. Morse, George Inness, Ellhu Vedder. Whistler, George Fuller, Homer D. Martin, Albert Pinkham Ryder, Winslow Homer.

AS a "ghost writer." an author who writes not his own words but those of another in that other's personality, Lowell Thomas brilliantly excels, as his many books of this sort bear witness. This new one strikes a different note a more intimate, philosophic note than any of its predecessors.

VIENNA, March 4. -- Nothing that has been said or done within the confines of Eastern Europe itself this week has been so generally Interesting to its inhabitants as the statement of Premier Tardieu in the French Chamber in connection with the grant of a new loan to Czechoslovakia, that he had appealed in Geneva to the representatives of the Little Entente, Austria and Hungary to unite in a preferential tariff.

WILHELM LANGE - EICHBAUM is a German scientist -- or, perhaps one should say philosopher, since tie collects facts and spins theories about them -- who wrote, the translators of this book tell us, a volume of formidable size on "Genius, insanity and Fame."

Prices were fractionally higher on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday at the end of a session marked by narrow trading. There were no special movements in stocks, although utilities in general did well. For the most part traders took their cue from the action of the Stock Exchange, where a brisk rally took place.

After reaching a high level of 3,965,142 shares in the second week of February, the short interest on the New York Stock Exchange had been reduced to 3,102,876 shares at the end of the month, showing a net decrease of 497,389 shares, as compared with the close of the previous month.

As between the two bitterest adversaries, TROTSKY and STALIN, it will soon be true that each has answered the wish of the other by writing a book. If there were any doubt that the real subject of TROTSKY'S new history of the Russian Revolution is his ancient rival STALIN, it would have been removed by the interview recently issued by the exile of Prinkipo in which he predicts the collapse of the Stalinist regime.

Squadron C's indoor polo team turned back the Riding Club trio for the second time this Winter at Squadron C armory in Brooklyn last night, triumphing by 13 1/2 to 9 after receiving one goal by handicap. This Class B contest was the feature of a three-game program.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Feb. 20. -- Trinidad still occupies the proud position of being the largest producer of crude oil within the British Empire and there was a considerable increase in production during 1931 in spite of the lower prices, the total output being 9,743,503 barrels, compared with 9,418,907 barrels in 1930.

Although the Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. refused to adopt the metric system for its outdoor championship meet at Berkeley, Cal., on July 1 and 2, virtual assurance was given at the convention at the Columbia Club yesterday that future intercollegiate games would be held according to metric measurements.

Harold Samuel, one of the numerous English artists who have found a welcome in New York that seems never to cool, played again yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall. He played, as he always does here, the clavier music of Bach, from which his audience never allows him to stray.

HOPEWELL, N.J., March 5. -- Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh continued yesterday to greet the passing hours, which bore no word of her missing son with a brave, heartening smile which lent strength and endurance to her husband.

Nevertheless, the story is worth repetition and one lays aside the book with a feeling of satisfaction.

"Gee! But it costs to bring up a kid!" exclaimed a junior high school boy in Denver, Col., who, as part of his course on "Problems of Every Day Living" had taken an inventory of his wardrobe and had been astonished to find that his clothes cost his parents more than $100.

PARIS, March 5. -- With an eagerness far exceeding what they feel toward the great world problems such as disarmament and the Far Eastern conflict, the French people are devouring every scrap of news they can find about the search for the Lindbergh baby.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 5. -- The Laetara Medal has been awarded to Dr. Stephen J. Maher of New Haven, Conn., internationally recognized authority on tuberculosis, by the University of Notre Dame, it was announced here today. The medal is awarded annually to an outstanding Catholic layman.

The Kings County Grand Jury would have rendered a greater public service had it heard the testimony of representatives of the Board of Education before drawing up its presentment, handed up to Judge Mc-Laughlin in Brooklyn Friday, criticizing the education body for "laxity in checking school attendance," George H. Chatfield, director of the Bureau of Attendance of the Board of Education, said yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 5. -- The Princeton swimming team took four first and third places and all the second places except one to defeat Rutgers, 45 to 26, at the Ballentine pool tonight. Walter Spence of Rutgers was the only individual swimmer to take two first places.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 5. -- John Raymond Ronan died today of pneumonia at his residence at 304 Summerville Place, Yonkers, in his thirty-seventh year. He was born and educated in Yonkers and was associated with the Westchester Lighting Company for fourteen years.

BOSTON, March 5. -- Barry wood rescued Harvard tonight, scoring a coal from scrimmage in overtime that gave the Crimson varsity team a 1-1 tie with a fighting Yale sextet before 15,000 spectators who filled the Boston Garden. Two overtime periods were played.

HONOLULU, March 5 (AP). -- The trial of Mrs. Granville Fortescue Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and two navy enlisted men charged with second-degree murder of Joseph Kahahawai, accused of an assault on Mrs. Massie, was set today for March 28.

NUREMBERG, Feb. 18. -- At Forchheim, on the Regnitz, eighteen miles to the north of Huremberg, there is a research institute maintained by the German Government exclusively for the study of tobacco. It is directed by Professor Paul Koenig, rated as one of the world's greatest authorities on tobacco in all its aspects, botanical, chemical, economic.

Lawrence, that playboy of the Eastern World, accomplished precisely what this cool soldier accomplished in setting forth into the most forbidding of all deserts, the sandy waste that until now has been blank upon the maps because no European had ever explored it.

ADOLF HITLER was born in Austria in 1889, the son of a customs official. He went to Munich at the age of 20. The war swept him from a precarious existence as a commercial artist into the German Army. For four years he fought, was wounded and severely gassed, and emerged with the Iron Cross, first class, for bravery under fire.

IT is a pity that the first third of the story is so dull, poorly written and cheap in subject material. For, suddenly, with a stirring description of an emergency appendectomy, the novel comes to life; and it moves thereafter surely and convincingly to a brave and honest conclusion.

THE manufacturers' sales tax which has been included by the House Ways and Means Committee in its new revenue measure is in principle one of the oldest taxation devices in the world, though its modern applications date for the most part from the end of the World War.

Response to a questionnaire circulated by the research department of Lawrence Stern Co., Chicago, among investment bankers throughout the country regarding bond market condition shows that 80 per cent of the bankers report definite and substantial improvement in public sentiment.

Although more than 250 women have enlisted as "Block-Aiders" and the number of recruits is growing, more volunteers are invited and it is hoped to have half of the organization, or about 50,000, consist of women, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Charles Cary Rumsey, associate chairman of the Block Community Organization, of which Wilton Lloyd-Smith is chairman.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 5. -- The Manhattan Symphony Orchestra, with Julia Peters, soprano, of Scarsdale as soloist, presented a concert tonight at the Westchester County Centre. White Plains, under the auspices of the social service committee of Grasslands Hospital.
Several industrial properties were included in the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday, in addition to the usual housing transactions.

SOUTHINGTON, Conn., March 5 (AP). -- Marcus Hensey Holcomb, Governor of Connecticut from 1915 to 1921, died at his home this afternoon in his eighty-seventh year. He had been in poor health for several months, due to advancing years.

WHEN Setauko Koizumi died recently at the age of 69 in a Tokyo suburb, the romance of Lafcadio Hearn, writer and educator, was recalled, for she had been his wife, and It was her name that he had adopted when he became a Japanese subject after his marriage to her in 1891.

READING, Pa., Sunday, March 6. -- John Philip Sousa, famous American band conductor and march king of a generation ago, died unexpectedly early this morning in his room in the Abraham Lincoln Hotel from an attack of heart disease.

THE use of airplanes delivering gas attacks will greatly increase the effectiveness of this weapon in warfare, placing even the reserve troops far behind the lines within range of gas attack and ravages, according to Captain John McCoy, Chemical Warfare Service, Fort Sam Houston, Texas.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5. -- The world's champion Cardinals put on an exciting finish today to pull the opening game of the Spring world's series out of the fire and beat the Philadelphia Athletics, 6 to 5, in ten innings.

Municipal and State governments must follow the procedure now being practiced by private business from necessity -- that of slashing expense, throwing out inherited impediments to progress and eliminating waste -- if the costs of these governments, which have increased rapidly in recent years, are to be cut, according to Ford, Bacon Davis, Inc., engineers, who report having made a nation-wide survey.

JANNICE MARLOW, the heroine of this wise and unpretentious study of marital adjustment, finds marriage a difficult but valuable experience. Glynn Marlow, her husband, is an author who accepts his career as all-important, unconsciously sacrificing to it his and his wife's happiness.

Governor Roosevelt's pronouncement in the case of former Sheriff Farley, that a public official must explain his bank deposits if they exceed his salary, was invoked yesterday by the City Affairs Committee against William Kavanagh, Tammany district leader and Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
LONDON, March 5. -- Mrs. Taylor, mother of Betty Gow, the Lindbergh baby's nurse, received a cablegram from her, daughter today, saying: "I'm heartbroken, but cheer up, mother."

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 20. -- Although there is uncertainty regarding the permanency of the present Cabinet selected by President Justo, it is composed of members who have gained distinction either previously in the posts they now occupy or in other fields.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish to point out that H.L. Puxley's article, "Purchasing Power," in THE TIMES reveals a common misunderstanding of the nature of money.

WITH the increase of 1 cent per gallon in the gasoline tax, which went into effect last Tuesday, New York State has joined the ranks of eleven States with an excise of 3 cents per gallon on the fuel consumed by its motorists.

GENEVA, March 4. -- Geneva has spent its week in trying to stop conflict and in seeking a way by which a democratic assembly of fifty-five nations can begin work on the specific problem of reducing every one's armaments.

At its concert last night in Carnegie Hall, the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra repeated Balakircff's symphonic poem "Tamar" and Haydn's symphony in D major from its previous program. The new work was Strauss's "Don Quixote," with Alfred Wallenstein and Rene Pollain as solo 'cellist and violinist.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Horace D. Taft in a letter to THE TIMES inquired about the circumstances surrounding the repudiation of some State bonds -- a matter treated editorially by THE TIMES on Feb. 14.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 5. -- Lawlessness was attributed by John . Pennington, prohibition administrator for the Third District, in a speech here today before the Laymen's Association of the New Jersey Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, to the dishonesty of Federal and State officers who engage in "fixing" and "trading."

City College's varsity basketball team gave one of its most brilliant passing and shooting exhibitions of the entire season last night at the Rockland Palace to defeat Howard University of Washington, D.C., the colored intercollegiate champions, 43 to 26, in a post-season game for charity.

The financial crisis which overtook the world last May and June, after the general economic depression had been in progress more than eighteen months, has been definitely checked in this country, according to the views of leading bankers here, and shows signs of improvement in several directions abroad.

IN common with many other novelists and playwrights of today Vicki Baum brushes aside destiny and bases all on chance. And knowing, as every one does, the large part chance plays in human lives, it must be granted, especially in an age of skepticism, that the prospect of a swift glance at momentarily tangled lives has a suggestion of piquancy.

According to Hector C. Bywater, the naval expert of The Daily Telegraph of London, the United States Navy is experimenting with the largest and most deadly torpedo in the world. At first treating of the subject of torpedoes in general he writes that "not only have the accuracy, range and explosive capacity of the torpedo been improved, but entirely new methods of launching it against ships have also been evolved."

ONE month after the death of Washington a company of gentlemen who had officiated at his funeral formed themselves into an association which they named The Washington Society of Alexandria and dedicated to the perpetuation of his name and fame and ideals.

The proposed manufacturers' sales tax will be a burden on labor, all units of the industrial structure, and on the ultimate consumer, will cause confusion over wholesale quotations, lead to a new form of price cutting and in general retard the free movement of merchandise through distributing channels, according to opinions expressed yesterday in business circles.

THE human body has a temperature about 20 degrees Fahrenheit higher than that of a normally heated room. A hot body always imparts its heat to a celder body. Heat runs downhill like water hence it follows that the human body must be giving up its heat to surrounding colder objects.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- No marked improvement in business activity was shown in most of the American foreign markets covered in the weekly survey of the Commerce Department made public today.

NEW ORLEANS, March 3. -- The first test of one of the most important parts of the new flood-control works along the Mississippi River, the Bonnet Carre spillway above New Orleans, may occur within the month, for a stage of between nine teen and twenty feet has been pre dieted by the Weather Bureau.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5. -- The feature at Tropical Park went to Mrs. A. Carfano for the second day in succession when her James River was first today in the Key West Handicap. Yesterday Mrs. Carfano's Trailor won the feature Jupiter City Handicap.

The Federal Government is a master builder. The general public is more familiar with what it has been doing in Washington, where the erection of the Lincoln Memorial, the work on the Arlington Bridge over the Potomac, the completion of the vast Commerce Department building and the embellishment of the capital generally have given visible form to the dreams of many men and afforded reasons for calling this the Golden Era of Federal construction.

The Morris and Textile teams remained undefeated and Richmond Hill dropped from the unbeaten ranks during the fourth Saturday's competition in the second annual city P.S.A.L. senior high school championship fencing tournament at Washington Irving High School yesterday.

The kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby will take precedence over all other topics in sermons preached in the pulpits of this city today. The Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, will give comment on the case this morning at Christ Church, Riverdale Avenue and 252d Street, the Bronx, where he is to install a new rector.

PANAMA, March 1. -- A difference of $818,938 between the cost to the government of the Puerto Amuelles Railroad and the amount paid the actual builders has been pointed out to the Supreme Court here by Attorney General Aristides Arjona, who charges that the sum represents unwarranted profits as a result of "ingenious administrative procedures."

HAVANA, March 5. -- In the face of what appears to be certain defeat of his attempt to obtain restriction of the present sugar crop to 2,300,000 tons, Thomas L. Chadbourne, originator of the Chadbourne plan for stabilization of the world sugar market and president of the Cuban National Sugar Exporting Corporation, sailed from Havana tonight for New York.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 5. -- Cornell maintained third place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League by decisively defeating Pennsylvania, 32 -- 18, tonight. Cornell took command at the start and staged a spurt at the start of the second half that netted 10 points and clinched the game.

PROFESSOR SLICHTER'S lucid restatement at the most essential features of present-day economic relations is an estimable work, in spite of the fact that most of its contents do not pretend to be original. Its value lies primarily in the sound and temperate views advanced by the author in discussing the various forms which economic activity assumes.

The Princeton wrestling team defeated Columbia, 18 to 16, in the Morningside gymnasium yesterday. Fred Billings, captain-elect of Old Nassau's football team, scored the fall which brought Princeton victory when, in the heavyweight and final bout, he threw Ralph Dudley in thirty-nine seconds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos the announcement that an extensive grasshopper destruction program is to be carried out in some of our "Western States this year by means of poisoned baits spread by airplane, I respectfully ask nine questions:

NOW that the astonishing relics of a long-lost civilization are being unearthed at Monte Alban in Southern Mexico interest in ancient beliefs and customs has received a new stimulus. Probably very few realize, however, in spite of frequent reports in the daily papers, that discoveries hardly less startling are all the time being made, especially by excavators in Western and Central Asia, India, Egypt and the Mediterranean lands.

LOUISVILLE, March 3. -- The United States Bureau of Census figures give Louisville the lowest per capita cost of government and the lowest per capita net funded debt-$84.62 -- of any city in the United States having a population of 300,000 or more.

LONDON, March 4. -- An unprecedented number of cruises by British liners have been arranged for the coming Spring and Summer to help tide the shipping companies over the worst depression In their history.

DALLAS, March 3. -- The martial-law situation in East Texas has become curiously interwoven with the strong Texas pride. Now that the matter has reached the United States Supreme Court the public mind, in the main only casually interested in the legal and economic phases, is keenly interested in the State's rights issue.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 5. -- Leading by 2 up at the end of nine holes in a match which was played through a driving rain, Miss Maureen Orcutt of the White Beeches Club, Haworth, N.J., successfully defended her title in the Florida East Coast golf championship today, defeating Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake of the Old Country Club, Flushing, L.I., by 5 up and 4 to play.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- In a dramatic reversal of views on economy, the House today adopted, 160 to 155, an amendment by Representative La Guardia which restored to the postoffice and treasury appropriation bill salary increases, advances in grades and automatic promotions for employes in these departments.

LOS ANGELES, March 3. -- The California political situation continues complex and filled with contradictions. Los Angeles city and county, pioneer dry territory, is straw-voting four to one for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. Los Angeles, city and county, counted as safely Republican as Philadelphia, has increased its Democratic registration so far this year by 130 per cent, as against a G.O.P. growth of only 40 per cent.
LONDON. I AM the upstart son of a down start," said George Bernard Shaw. The remark was provoked by the report that Shakespeare's "Macbeth" was to have a revival.

WASHINGTON. BY ITS recent action reviving Washington's Order of the Purple Heart, the War Department has made it possible for some grizzled General in the future to address a heroic soldier in these words:

LONDON, March 5. -- All sections of the Stock Exchange closed strong today after a good week. The British Government finds the demand for the war loan was stimulated by the statement by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, that no decision had yet been reached on the question of conversion.

SOME time before next July, if all goes well, New Yorkers will have a new subway to ride in. For the moment it will run only up and down the ridge of Manhattan, from Fulton Street north to Washington Heights. Ultimately other boroughs will share in the benefits of this new rapid-transit facility built by the city.

LEIPZIG, March 5 (AP). -- The Leipzig Fair, barometer of German trade and commerce, is facing a critical situation, but there have been such before -- in 1919, when war industries had to be turned quickly into peace channels; in 1920, when export trade had to be reorganized, and in 1924, after the collapse of the mark.

CHICAGO, March 5 (AP). -- Adele Astaire made her last stage appearance tonight in ''The Band Wagon." After several seasons of success with her brother, Kred, in musical revues. Miss Astaire announced she had given up the theatre for marriage. She will be married next June to Lord Charles Cavendish of London, son of the Duke of Devonshire.

The possibility of college rowing having one more course along which an observation train may take its load of spectators is contained in the sounding and surveying activities of a staff of men along the Schuylkill River at Philadelphia.

Some of the difficulties which would confront advocates of "economic planning" in drafting a blueprint for business are apparent in the problems which face producers of copper and sugar at the present time. Both of these commodities have been the subject of ambitious experiments in "planned" production.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The new non-partisan tax bill, carrying a 2.25 per cent general manufacturers' sales levy as its major feature, was completed by the Ways and Means Committee late today.

DETROIT, March 2. -- The plan of the Common Council to sell the $500,000,000 in property on which taxes amounting to $14,600,000 are delinquent for from eighteen months to more than ten years has caused possibly the greatest sensation which the harassed real estate circles of Detroit have known for some time.

Funds contributed by the seven archdeaconries of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York toward the annual budget for 1931 amounted to $526,116, including an item of $35,348 collected for advance work, according to the Diocesan Bulletin. This represented a drop of only $18,998 from the regular receipts of 1930, the report disclosed.

A NEW series of six-cylinder trucks has been announced by the Indiana Motors Corporation of Marion, Ind., to be sold and serviced through the White company. The trucks will be known as the model 95 series with prices beginning at $1,095.

"THAR she blows and breeches and bellows -- and sperm at that!" Captain Esse Boies probably did not give the historic cry of Mr. Simmons, the finest first mate of the good ship Mozambique, when a whale ran away with his anchor off Green Run, Va., recently, and nearly sent the fishing smack Sea Toy to Davy Jones.

Uniform strength characterized dealings yesterday in bonds on the Stock Exchange. The turnover was large for a Saturday, amounting to $6,552,000. Impressive strength in New York rapid transit issues and new highs for the year in several foreign loans featured trading.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5. -- Peter Peck, Lehigh's 165-pound intercollegiate wrestling champion, was thrown by Kenneth Mann of Penn, but the former team won the annual meet from the Red and Blue at the Palestra today, 26 to 13.

IF any one exists who hasn't, at me time or another, wondered over the chain of events by which some act or omission on the part of one person affects the lives of others whom he or she has never seen, that Individual must be singularly lacking in imagination.

PARIS, March 5. -- The stock market showed firm resistance to further profit-taking during the week's closing session today. Trading on the Bourse, however, was relatively light. The general level of prices was slightly lower, but Rip Tinto Copper and Royal Dutch Oil among the internationals were outstanding exceptions and moved steadily higher.

DUMBARTON HOUSE, in Washington acquired recently by the National Society of the Colonial Dames for conversion into a "museum of domestic life of the early years of the country." is a centre of interest at a time when the eyes of the nation are turned backward by the celebration in connection with the George Washington Bicentennial.

OTTAWA, March 3. -- Economy is the watchword in Canada at the moment, of governments and individuals, and a balanced budget is the objective of every treasury chief. The Federal Government has set an example, and east and west the Provinces are taking drastic steps to bridge the open water which divides receipts and expenditures.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 5. -- Mrs. Dodge Sloane entertained tonight with a dinner at Concha Marina, having as her house guests Mrs. Wesson Seyburn of Detroit, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Goodman Gushing, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Stevens and Charles Black-well, Mrs. Lucius Pond Ordway with her guests, Mrs. William Mitchell and Mrs. John Gaston, and Mr. and Mrs. Henry Carnegie Phipps with Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Phipps.

From near and far yesterday there continued to come suggestions as to how to recover the kidnapped Lindbergh child. Some thought that the police should be eliminated from the case, others advocated calling in lawyers to handle it, still others talked of appeals to the "underworld."

TRENTON, N.J., March 5. -- The abductors of the Lindbergh baby will make every effort to see that it is returned home safely--and soon--in the opinion of the police heads of the country who were gathered here today to discuss the case. The consensus was that the kidnappers would do this in order to relieve themselves "of a constant incumbrance to their freedom of movement and a hopeless drag on their efforts at flight."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Following the S-4 disaster in 1927 I addressed a letter to scientists and naval experts, suggesting a simple preventive device which would also serve as remedial agent. A copy was mailed to THE NEW YORK TIMES and was published in your Sunday edition.

The American people have established a tradition of passing through depressions with their faith in education undiminished. Whether that tradition will be maintained fully this time, we cannot know until after the crisis is over and comparable statictics have been collected, but a look at the past gives ground for hope.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 5. -- Sitting in the stands watching the Robin regulars defeat the yannigans, 6 to 5, in a six-inning game today, President Frank York touched on the case of Babe Herman, the outfielder, who is a holdout, in pointed fashion.

COMMENTARY on Shakespeare has given us an abundance of good literature that does not lack diversity of styles. Professor Knight defines and defends his own approach as "Imaginative interpretation." implying a dissatisfaction with the recent "realistic" criticism that has done good work and perhaps done its best work.

WITHOUT any doubt, "lead and likker" were both overly plentiful In the early days of the Southwest. But not every one who lived there would describe it in terms of such dense alcoholic haze and Incessant rain of bullets as Owen P. White sees dominating its landscape.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Financial and metal experts in New York have been invited to appear before the Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures next week, when causes and effects of the depressed value of silver will be investigated.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3. -- Pennsylvania once more is to rise to the occasion and furnish an entertaining Senatorial combat. Major Gen. Smedley D. Butler's announcement of his candidacy for Senator James J. Davis's seat was music to the ears of those who like their political campaigns well spiced.

WASHINGTON. FEW Presidents in the history of the nation have worked as hard as Herbert Hoover. A Hoover working day is seldom the regulation eight-hour day. More often it is nine or ten and often a twelve-hour day, and on rare occasions it has been a fourteen or fifteen-hour day.

Further improvement in the stock market yesterday wag regarded by Wall Street as a reflection of the uninterrupted advance in bond prices recently. The importance of the revived demand for bonds was emphasized in many quarters outside of the Stock Exchange.

Harry Wolf, defending champion, who was scheduled yesterday to play his first match in the National Squash Tennis Championship in progress at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, did not swing into action, his match with Fred Hart of the Crescent Club being postponed until today.

After questioning Henry Johnson, sailor friend of Betty Gow, the Lindbergh baby's nurse, throughout Friday night and during most of yesterday, State's Attorney Hugh M. Alcorn, at Hartford, decided last night to hold him for further examination. Hartford to visit his brother in the interim.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, March 6 (AP). -- Skirmishes occurred today between the distant lines of the Chinese and Japanese Armies, but foreign military observers said there was no general conflict on this Sunday morning, the first in five weeks without a battle.

VATICAN CITY, March 5. -- A grain of rice, carved With infinite patience to represent a Minute bust of Pope Pius Xl, one of the most extraordinary of many extraordinary gifts, Was made to the Pope today by the Mother Superior of the Franciscan Sisters of Mary, Who have a large number of institutions all over the world.

THE South American distinguishes between the individual North American and his country. Probably in no part of the world will a citizen of the United States receive more genuine hospitality than in South America. On the other hand, while I found less anti-Americanism than I had expected suspicion and distrust of the United States exist practically everywhere though in a lesser degree in some countries and in some classes.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- A report is persistent in Washington that President Hoover, in broadcasting tomorrow night the opening of the "baby bond" campaign, or possibly at some later time, will make it clear to the country that not all the hoarders are plain citizens, but that they include many banks, among them some of the most powerful in the country.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- General business activity remained virtually unchanged throughout the United States in the week ended Feb. 27, tank debits outside New York City being slightly lower than in the preceding week but about 25 per cent under the corresponding period last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions issued today by the Department of Commerce.

BERLIN, March 5. -- The Agricultural Inquiry Institute states that considerable Import of wheat will be necessary in Germany between now and the new harvest. It points out that thus far an abnormally large proportion, of consumers' requirements have been met from home production.
DELHI, India, March 6. --Moslem leaders in India have decided that their community shall "reconsider" its attitude toward the round-table committees owing to the "failure to satisfy Moslem demands."

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 6. -- Mrs. Henry Morgan Tilford gave a dinner in the orange gardens of the Everglades Club tonight in compliment to her daughter, Mrs. Amory L. Haskell, and Mr. Haskell of Red Bank, N.J., who are her house guests.

There is a tendency to ask more and more of the public school. It reflects an increasing faith in the efficacy of education, especially that provided for all the children of the State. Does any civic need or new ideal show itself, the school is sooner or later asked to find a place for it in its already crowded curriculum.

A modern version of the Ten Commandments, reversing the old biblical injunctions to such an extent that fathers and mothers are expected to honor their children, and man is warned not to bow down before machines rather than graven images, was proposed by the Rev. Lon Ray Call in a sermon at the Community Church, Fifth Avenue and Seventysixth Street, yesterday morning.

A National Figure. While It can hardly be said that JOHN PHILIP SOUSA was a great musician, he was a famous conductor and came to be an outstanding national character. His death seems like removing an ancient landmark.

Jay Gould of Philadelphia and New York, national amateur court tennis champion from 1906 until he retired from singles in 1926, added another title yesterday to one of the most remarkable records ever compiled by an amateur in any branch of sport.

LIMA, March 6 (AP). -- President Sanchez Cerro was shot and Slightly wounded today at a church in the Summer resort of Miraflores, near here, by an assailant who shot two other persons, including a bystander, before he was wounded and captured.

LONDON, March 5. -- Sentiment on the London Stock Exchange remains extremely bullish, notwithstanding disappointment of hopes that the bank rate would again be reduced on Thursday. Business this week has been more active than for many months past, and all classes of securities are rising.

LONDON, March 5. -- Sufficient lime has not yet elapsed to form any precise estimate of the tangible effect on trade and Industry of the new tariffs Just imposed by the British Government or of those established earlier. There are, however, definite signs of improvement in domestic trade conditions, especially in those industries which are engaged in manufacturing goods formerly imported from abroad.

ALBANY, March 6. -- Incorporations dropped in New York State in February to a point 321 below the number recorded in January, according to a statement issued yesterday by Secretary of State Flynn. The 2,036 stock companies incorporated last month however, represented a larger number than that recorded for February last year.

OSSINING, N.Y., March 6. -- Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing offered his services today as a go-between in effecting the return of the kidnapped Lindbergh baby. The warden is convinced the kidnapping was not the work of professionals. So, he says, are most of the inmates of Sing Sing, where the case is being followed with interest.

The Inclusion of a 10 per cent theatre admissions tax in the Federal tax bill completed by the Ways and Means Committee of the House in Washington on Saturday was termed an "unjust discrimination" in a telegram sent yesterday to Representative Crisp, acting chairman of the committee, and other political leaders by Dr. Henry Moskowitz, adviser to the League of New York Theatres, and William A. Brady, Broadway producer.

BERLIN, March 5. -- An open conflict on the price rebate question has broken out between the steel syndicate and the manufacturers. The syndicate repudiated the agreement of 1925, under which it had undertaken, to grant price rebates equaling the full difference between the higher home prices and lower world market prices on steel purchased for re-export in manufactured forms.

PITTSBURGH, March 6. -- The movement for stabilization, of the prices of steel products was advanced last week when mills adopted minimum prices on bars, shapes and plates; but, while the new prices are generally quoted, they have had little or no test, buyers being covered for the time being, according to the product.
The New York Americans rallied in the third period to earn a 2-to-2 tie with the Detroit Falcons in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

The Port of New York Authority was notified yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission that lower rail rates between the Middle West and ports on the Gulf and South Atlantic which were proposed by the Southern rail lines and which led the Port Authority to file a formal protest had been suspended and a hearing on the matter would be held on April 18.

Salvy Spitale, who, together with Irving Bitz, was authorized by Colonel and Mrs. Lindbergh at midnight Saturday to act as their go-between In possible negotiations with the kidnappers of their baby, put in an active day yesterday with his movements as thoroughly cloaked as possible.

Albert (Whitey) Michelsen, Millrose A.A. star, defeated a strong field to win the third of the series of long-distance races, which was conducted in a driving rain yesterday under the auspices of the James J. Tappen Post of the American Legion at Silver Lake, Staten Island.

Police Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney issued a terse warning yesterday afternoon to more than 800 members of the Police Department to be alert, responsive, active and ingenious in following any clues, however unpromising, that might lead to the kidnappers of the infant son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh. "Neglect no information and accept every clue," he told them.

LONDON, March 5. -- The Financial News index of 30 industrial shares on the London Stock Exchange, baaed on the average of 100 for 1928, was 63.7 as of March 3. This is the highest since Nov. 25. It compares with 59.5 the previous week, 59.7 a month ago and a low record of 53.1 at the date of suspension of gold payments last September.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At this time may I bring to the attention of your readers a very poignant situation now existing among certain groups of the unemployed? I refer to the hundreds of sensitive souls who have not been able to bring themselves to the point where they could ask the organized charities for assistance.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Opening the "Baby Bond" campaign tonight as a part of the drive against hoarding, President Hoover, speaking over the radio from the White House, called on the American people tonight to mobilize their idle money and put it back to work for the acceleration of business, credit and reemployment.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 6. -- No change in the workout system of the Robins will be made by Manager Max Carey for the present, he announced tonight. A practice game, the third of the training season, will be played tomorrow, but there is no assurance that this will be a daily occurrence.

LONDON, March 6 (Canadian Press). -- American progress interests Prince Lennart, the grandson of the Swedish King, who has given up his royal rights to marry Karin Nissvandt, daughter of a Stockholm broker. Their wedding in London is set for Tuesday.

SHANGHAI, March 6. -- The Loyang Government, which sent few reinforcements to the Nineteenth Route Army while it fought the Japanese for more than thirty days, has sent a curiously-worded telegram to the Nineteenth Army and the Eighty-seventh and Eighty-eighth Divisions.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 5. -- Writs of attachment have been served on W.K. Johnson Co., stock brokers, and the Sons of Italy Industrial Bank of this city for the recovevery of $15,000 damages by the Transamerica Corporation for the alleged fraudulent sale of 900 shares of Transamerica stock.
BERLIN, March 5. -- The gradual recovery in German prices continues. The wholesale index number as of Feb. 24 is 100.1, as against 100 on Feb. 17.

Church congregations throughout the city, irrespective of creed, joined with their pastors yesterday in offering prayers for the immediate and safe return of the kidnapped son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Anne Morrow Lindbergh. In almost every instance the appeals for divine aid were joined with the expressions of sympathy for the parents and admiration for their conduct in their heart-breaking ordeal.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP). -- Of the ninety-six Senators of the United Stales sixty-one are lawyers. Of the 435 members of the House 263 tell, in their autobiographics for the Con- gressional Directory, of being ad- mitted to the bar.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Henry W. Dooley, Democratic National Committeeman from Porto Rico, has suggested in letters to party leaders that the coming national convention in Chicago celebrate the 100th anniversary of the 1832 convention at which Andrew Jackson was renominated.

PEEKSKILL, March 6. -- Division staff officers of the New York National Guard announced today the dates tentatively fixed for field encampments and outdoor training for about 21,000 members of the New York National Guard in five different camps.

Representative Ruth Pratt will ride a prancing white charger up Fifth Avenue in the St. Patrick's Day parade, it was decided last night. The decision came at her own request and from Roderick Kennedy, who has been chairman of the parade for thirty-one years.

The Knights of Columbus were extolled as a force helping to advance the cause of religion at the annual communion breakfast yesterday morning of the New York Council of the order at the Knights of Columbus Hotel.

In reading the news from Germany during this final week of the Presidential campaign there is need to distinguish between HITLER'S own party, the National Socialists, or "Nazis," and the Nationalists under the political leadership of ALFRED HUGENBERG, whose candidate for the Presidency is Lieut. Col. DUESTERBERG.

A national economic advisory council, unofficial in character, to help guide industry to avoid depressions is suggested by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporaion, in "A Basis for Stability," by Samuel Crowther, published today by Little, Brown Co. Mr. Sloan is one of twenty-one leaders in industry, agriculture and finance who collaborated with him in this book.

Despite the much-heralded acclaim of modern authors that they are disciples of frankness and honesty, the most honest biography today is the Bible, Dr. Malcolm MacLeod told his congregation yesterday at the St. Nicholas Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON. March 6. -- After a mild and snowless Winter the nation's capital tonight was in the grasp of a raging blizzard. One of the worst storms that has swept up from the South since the Taft innugural of 1909 hit Washington today and tonight was moving up the Atlantic Coast.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Five hundred Catholics, Jews and Protestants from all sections of the country will open a three-day conference tomorrow on religious prejudices and ways to allay them.

SHANGHAI, Monday, March 7. -- Japan brought in 5,000 more troops today to bolster its long "defense line" northwest of Shanghai, prompting Chinese Government circles to say they feared the invaders might attempt to capture Nanking, China's capital.
To the Editor of The New York Times : Short selling seems right and proper, but some of its accompanying features are iniquitous. For instance:

GENEVA, March 6. -- Despite the handicap that the League of Nations Assembly probably will continue meeting through at least the first part of this week, a serious effort will be made to get the disarmament conference into working shape before its adjournment for Easter.

CONCORD, N.H., March 6. -- New Hampshire will wind up its pre-Presidential primary campaign tomorrow and on Tuesday will settle the question of whether its twelve delegates to the Democratic National Convention will be pledged to Governor Roosevelt or former Governor Smith of New York.

BERLIN, March 5. -- Demand for money at Berlin after the turn of the month was heavier than usual. Month-end credits granted to the provinces returned slowly to Berlin, and cash was in demand for repayment of the Reichsbank's advance on collateral.

A special report of the State commission to investigate prison administration, and construction in the three State correctional institutions for women, made public yesterday by Sam A. Lewisohn, the chairman, recommends no radical changes in the policy of the State in dealing with women offenders.

PARIS, March 5. -- This week's renewal by the Bank of France for three months of its advance to the Reichsbank, with reduction of only 10 per cent, indicates that it is realized in France that Germany cannot at the moment do anything more by way of settlement.
America must get back to God and practice the ideals which it professes, A. Harry Moore, Governor of New Jersey, declared yesterday in an address before the Order of Seville at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, March 5. -- The markets received an undoubted surprise on Thursday when they learned that the Bank of England had decided not to reduce the discount rate. A little reflection, however convinced the City that this attitude of caution was Justified.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 6. -- An upset was recorded at the Agua Caliente race track today in the $5,000 added Agua Callente Derby in which Bahamas led a field of five 3-year-olds that included Cabczo and Joe Florcs, coupled as the Mrs. W.T. Anderson-S.H. Lec entry and strongly favored in the mutuels.
CHICAGO, March 5. -- A better feeling is steadily developing in all lines of manufacturing and wholesale trade hereabout, with retailers doing a fair business considering all returns.

As paradoxical as it might seem a first glance, the standout figure of the eleventh annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships on Saturday was not the winner of an individual race but a man who finished second. He was Frank Nordell, the rangy, longlimbed New York University sophomore who raced a mile in 4:13 and a half-mile in 1:54.2 within the short space of 35 minutes.

Parents who permit their children to grow up without restraint are condemning them to "the shackles of ignorance and the prisons of sin," the Rev. Dr. J.V. Moldenhawer declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street.

It certified copies of the decision of the Court of Appeals, holding that State Senator John A. Hastings cannot ignore a subpoena to appear before the Hofstadter legislative committee, do not arrive this morning, George Trosk, associate counsel to the committee, will ask the court to send copies at once, so that the questioning of Hastings can be begun.

In last week's otherwise colorless economic picture, a few incidents stood out rather strikingly. The gradual but continuous rise in domestic bond prices was one; it obviously reflected the waning of blind terror among American Investors. The very emphatic recovery on the French and English stock exchanges was another; that Indicated subsidence of the similar European panic.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 6. -- "The continued agitation for a boycott against Japan is exceedingly harmful to the interests of the United States and to the cause for peace," declared Professor Edwin Borchard of the Yale Law School in a statement issued here at the request of the Rev. Dr. Fleming James of the Berkeley Divinity School faculty.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one among scores who have, I feel sure, expressed to you the same sentiments, I wish to say that your support of Judge Seabury is in accord with the high tradition of THE TIMES and also in the tradition of Tilden and Cleveland, eminent reformers of their own political party in New York.

PARIS, March 4. -- The increase of 1,244,000,000 francs in the Bank of France gold reserve, during the week covered by Thursday's statement, compared with the reduction of 1,428,000,000 in the bank's foreign balances. The fact that the decrease in foreign exchange reserves considerably exceeds the increase in gold reserve proves that the bank found no market for a certain portion of its sales of foreign exchange.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and his wife waited vainly yesterday in their home on a dismal and stormbeaten hillside near Hopewell, N.J., for their lost baby, Charles Augustus Jr., to be returned to them.
The terms "gross income" and "net income" as used in Federal income tax returns, were explained yesterday by the Bureau of Internal Revenue as "vitally important to the whole subject of income tax."
MUKDEN, Monday, March 7 (AP). -- Henry Pu Yi on his way to Changchun, rested today at Tangkangtze, a hot springs resort sixty-six miles south of Mukden.

Two dance recitals last night wooed a surprisingly large number of the faithful to their doors, in spite of the unpleasant weather, when Elsa Findlay and her group, with Jose Limon as guest artist, appeared at the Recital Theatre, and Belle Didjah offered a program at the Martin Beck.

AMMAN, Syria, March 6 (AP). -- A laconio report reaching here from the northern areas of Tebuk and Theima, in the Hedjaz, contains a threat of revolt in the desert against Ibn Saud, "the Puritan ruler of Arabia."

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The "stop-Rosevelt" faction at the capital felt satisfied today that It would control New England and within two weeks would make great progress there and elsewhere in the country in crystallizing sentiment for a compromise Democratic candidate for President.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6. -- The Athletics unlimbered their heavy artillery along the exhibition baseball front today and scored a victory over the Cardinals, world's champions, 14 to 12, in the second game of the Spring "world's series."

HAVANA, March 8. -- Two persons were injured and several small fishing craft in the harbor damaged by a storm which struck Havana about 1 o'clock this morning, borne on a wind reaching a maximum velocity of sixty-one miles an hour and accompanied by driving rain.
VIENNA, March 6 (AP). -- Hope mingled with skepticism characterized the reaction of Central and Southeastern Europe today to a proposal by Andre Tardieu, Premier of France.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP). -- With the weight of the administration's forces behind them, two investigations are confronting Congress as it enters the closing stretch that leads to the national political conventions.

Sergeant Albert L. Smith of the Ordnance Detachment at Camp Dix, Wrightstown, N.J., who was arrested last Saturday for the murder of his wife, Elsie, a former Russian concert singer, on the government reservation at Miller Field, S.I., New Year's Day will be turned over to the Department of Justice this morning and will be arraigned later in the federal court in Brooklyn on an indictment charging him with murder in the first degree.

With the New Hampshire primary election, the first in the country, to be held on Tuesday, local supporters of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt and former Governor Alfred E. Smith, rivals for the Democratic nomination for President, await the result with knowledge that the outcome may determine the trend of the entire pre-convention campaign.

SHANGHAI, Monday, March 7. -- Five thousand soldiers of the Twentyseventh Brigade, Fourteenth Division, arrived here from Japan this morning and are being disembarked from four ships, two docked at the International Settlement and two at Woosung.

VIENNA, March 5. -- In foreign trade the balance against Austria during January amounted to 72 million schillings, imports being 133 million and exports 61 million. As compared with January, 1931, the total foreign trade was smaller by 26 per cent, but while imports decreased 20 1/2 per cent the decrease in exports was 32 per cent, and the increase in the adverse balance was per cent larger.

MONTREAL, Que., March 6. -- The report of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., for 1931 shows that profit for the year was $5,397,152 after providing for all costs in connection with shut-down newsprint mills, and including $197,205 profit on bonds bought for sinking fund purposes.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., March 6. -- Sweeping over Long Island Sound from the northeast, a gale confronted the members of the Frostbite Yacht Club today as they were about to set sail in their dinghy contests on Manhasset Bay off the Knickerbocker Yacht Club.

PARIS, March 4. -- The interpretation placed by this market on the vigorous advance in European stock exchanges is that the remarkable financial recovery shown by England is now recognized as a powerful factor toward restoring confidence.

LONDON, March 5. -- London banking authorities are clearly desirous of checking further extension of the speculative movement in sterling and sterling securities. They are more or less powerless to restrain foreign buying of British securities, which la now assuming important dimensions; but they are in a position to prevent a too rapid rise of sterling.

The Lindbergh baby kidnapping was denounced at church services and other religious meetings yesterday by the clergy and lay speakers who variously interpreted this latest bold stroke of the underworld as a fore-runner of worse to come, as a break-down of religion, and as a challenge to a government in which evils are bred largely in political corruption.

Five Coast Guardsmen from the Atlantic City base are missing and believed to have been drowned yesterday after they had ventured a life-saving attempt in seething seas tossed up by a gale that wreaked damage all along the Atlantic Coast. The men were the crews of two surfboats, the second of which went out after the first had capsized in its effort to help a fishing sloop in danger.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One reason why there is such a drop in the number of aliens becoming citizens is undoubtedly that which THE TIMES states: that the larger fees now asked are a deterrent, and a substantial reduction would not only be in order but would in every respect be eminently desirable.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I think in your editorial concerning the disappearance of Arcadia you are despairing too soon. Consider the case of Hibbing, Minn.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6. -- Two matches in which the favorites were carried to the thirty-ninth green marked the initial round of play in the International four-ball tournament over the course of the Miami Country Club today.

BERLIN, March 5. -- The industrial outlook in Germany continues unfavorable. In heavy branches the discharge of workmen and curtailment of production predominate. The Institute for Studying Trade Fluctuations predicts that the improvement of employment In seasonal industries will be smaller this coming Spring and Summer than in past years.
Earl Nikkel, star Yale forward, still sets the pace in individual scoring in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race, with the finish of the championship campaign in sight.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., March 6. The Santo Christo soccer team of New Bedford won the Eastern final of the national amateur cup campetition today, defeating the Upper Darby team of Philadelphia by C-1. More than 2,000 fans watched the rivals battle in a rainstorm.
NEW YORK. The Right Hon. Winston Churchill and Miss Diana Churchill will return to the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow and will sail for England Saturday.

THEY held a fish-fry down in Drewton, Ala., and it's Bob Quinn, owner of the Red Sox, who has been left to foot the bill. They were dear fish to him. Ed Morris, the guest of honor, got Into a fight and was fatally stabbed. Ed lost his life and Bob Quinn lost a pitcher for whom he was offered $60,000 a few months ago.

Newtown High School, defending Queens division and city P.S.A.L. champion, has wrasted the lead from Textile High, Manhattan division title winner, in the race for team scoring honors in the current P.S. A.L. tourney.

Americans have never before experienced such an instant and sustained thrill of abhorrence as they have felt continuously for the past four days. Every circumstance of the abduction of the Lindbergh child contributed to a nation-wide sentiment in which sympathy and grief strove with apprehension and dismay.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- A warning to the public not to expect too much from the proposed Federal kidnapping legislation was given today by Attorney General Mitchell.

The beginning of the Presidential primary season in New Hampshire tomorrow may recall to the minds of elderly politicians and reformers the rapid growth and decline of this offspring of the direct primary movement or mania. The first Presidential-preference law was passed in 1910 by Oregon, the home of all radical political thought that isn't sheltered by Wisconsin.

HOPEWELL, N.J., March 6. -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh spent today in enforced inactivity, prevented by the wind-driven snow and rain from taking their now customary strolls about their home. This evening both appeared considerably refreshed and buoyed up by some inner hope.

Difficulties have arisen at Albany in the matter of continuing the State Unemployment Relief Commission. There is no question that its life ought to be prolonged. On that point Governor ROOSEVELT and the Republican legislative leaders are in entire accord.

BERLIN, March 6 (AP). -- The antiFascist "Iron Front" rallied behind President von Hindenburg today for the last week of the pre-election campaign, while over the week-end one person was killed and eleven were wounded in political fights that kept the police on the jump in all parts of the capital.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- "Among more than a million poor and unemployed with whom we have come in direct contact in the past sixteen months, in the Chicago district alone, we find that, under prohibition, the evidence of drink as a factor has been reduced almost to the vanishing point," declares Colonel George H. Davis of the Salvation Army in an interview here with a representative of the American Business Men's Prohibition Foundation.

PARIS, March 4. -- In the Bank of France return of Thursday, covering the position of Feb. 25, the increase of 461,000,000 francs in bills discounted during the week was considered moderate, in view of the approaching month-end maturities. Circulation decreased 609,000,000 and private deposits 453,000,000 francs.

CAIRO, March 6. -- As Winter closes, the archaeological season in Egypt comes to an end. Results of expeditions in various parts of the country reveal more and more wonders of ancient Egyptian civilization.

About 230 teachers of seven Hebrew paroshial schools in Manhatten, Brooklyn and the Bronx will go on strike today in protest against their failure to receive their pay for many weeks, it was announced last night by Rabbi Mayer Kahoanow, president of the organization format by the teachers.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and his wife tonight listened at a telephone in their home at HopeWell, N.J., to a physician in Waukegan, III., describe a plump boy baby with crinkly blonde hair. The infant has been examined in the belief that he might be the missing Lindbergh child.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Drafting clerks worked all day preparing th 60,000-word text of the new tax bill for the printer, and it will be introduced in the House tomorrow by Representative Crisp, acting chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.

The revival of Vincenzo Bellini's "La Sonnambula" will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House, where it has not been since 1916, on Wednesday evening, March 16, it was announced yesterday by General Manager Giulio Gatti-Casazza. Lily Pons, for whom the opera is being revived, will have the title role.

HOPEWELL, N.J., March 6. -- With Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and his wife, the former Anne Morrow, turning to the underworld for assistance in their anguished efforts to recover their kidnapped twentymonth-old son, the army of State troopers and detectives making their headquarters in the Lindbergh home on Sourland Mountain indicated today that they still have hopes of tracking down and punishing the abductors of the child.
The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, headed by Harvey D. Gibson, made public yesterday a report on the work and expenditures of the committee since last October.

TRENTON, N.J., March 6. -- The entrance of Salvatore Spitale and Irving Bitz into the hunt for little Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. was determined upon by Colonel Lindbergh personally without consultation with the New Jersey State police, it was revealed this afternoon by Major Charles A. Schoeffel, Deputy Superintendent of the troopers, who has been in charge at the Hopewell headquarters of the hunt.

Scoring eleven points during the past week against Penn, Harold Kramer of C.C.N.Y. increased his total to 51 tallies and so resumed the lead In the race for scoring honors in the Intercollegiate Swim- ming Association.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- Traders in live stock have found a most interesting situation here in the markets for cattle and hogs, and also in that for dressed beef. Receipts of cattle last week were only 36,100 head, the smallest number, with two exceptions, since last April, and the average price was $6.25 a hundredweight which was 10 cents lower than in the previous week.

In an effort to unify the mural and sculptural details of the eleven buildings that will make up Rockefeller Centre, the builders have named a group of experts to pass upon the extensive artistic features of the development, the Metropolitan Square Corporation announced yesterday.

Henry Johnson, sailor friend of Betty Gow, the Lindbergh baby's nurse, was questioned for six and one-half hours at Police Headquarters in Newark last night, and held for further examination today. With him also was questioned Johanson Junge, a marine surveyor, in whose company Johnson says he spent last Tuesday evening, the evening of the kidnapping.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, March 6. -- The Lapua rebellion definitely ended this morning when the Fascist forces at Mantsala formally laid down their arms and surrendered. Their principal leaders were arrested, including General Marti Wallenius, who was brought to Helsingfors tonight by automobile.

The upper link of the west side express highway will be opened for public use at noon on Wednesday at exercises at which Mayor Walker and Samuel Levy, Borough President of Manhattan, will preside. The occasion will be marked by the presence of 3,000 civic workers and will be preceded by a parade in which army and navy units and city departmental bands will participate.

TORONTO, Ont., March 6 (Canadian Press). -- Improved conditions among secondary industries are reported in the monthly commercial letter issued by the Canadian Bank of Commerce. A recent survey conducted by the bank, covering twentyfive industrial centres, showed rubber goods were making the best showing of six representative lines in this class.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- A "lasting settlement" of reparations at the Lausanne conference in June will depend largely on whether governments concerned "take a long view of their own interests," Dr. Mildred S. Wertheimer asserts in a report on "The Financial Crisis in Germany," issued today by the Foreign Policy Association.

The Hamilton College Choir made its annual appearance at the Guild Theatre yesterday in a recital of choral music of the highest class, which Professor Paul A. Fancher, its conductor, has cultivated in recent years among his students at the classic hilltop campus at Clinton, N.Y.

LONDON, March 5. -- The pace of revenue collection under the new tax schedules is now showing signs of falling off. That, however, was to be expected, in view of the remarkable response made by the public to the appeal that they pay their taxes promptly.
BERLIN, March 6.-- A celebration in honor of the Washington bicentenary was held today in the Reichstag under the patronage of President von Hindenburg.

PARIS, March 4. -- There is no change in the character of domestic trade developments. Receipts of French railways as reported for the seventh week of the year were 208,000,000 francs, a decrease of 53,000,000 compared with the same week in 1931.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Topics of the Times you indicate that English and American language habits are becoming mutually influ enced one by the other at a more or less rapid rate. American-talking films have had a considerable effect on the language of some Englishmen, particularly on that of the youngsters, who are most impressionable and the most avid consumers of our worst specimens of talking-film art.

Recent Investigations by building trades organizations have shown that the "broker," in taking contracts on public building projects and subletting to others, is thwarting unemployment relief, according to Allen E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- At the moment the statistical position gives the bulls cold comfort, although the total world's import needs this season will probably be sufficient to cut the prospective carry-over moderately, taking stocks in all countries.

HOPEWELL, N.J., March 6. -- Five hundred children, wards of the St. Michael's Orphanage here, have been praying daily that the missing Lindbergh baby will be left, like any foundling, on the threshold of their orphanage.

BERLIN, March 5. -- The Reichsbank has delayed decision, on the question of reducing the discount rate, pending definite prolongation of the international $100,000,000 rediscount credit. The prevailing view is that the Reichsbank will immediately cut the rate by fully 1 per cent, placing it at 6 per cent as against the 7 per cent rate which has been maintained since early December.

PARIS, March 4. --News that the English treasury intends to repay, in anticipation, the Franco-American credit maturing in September shows that the English situation has improved much more than had been believed. It is now clearly seen what machinery was used in the establishment of last Autumn's foreign credits, wherein purchases of foreign exchange by the British Government were effected through sales of sterling.

A ruling on whether or not former Sheriff Thomas M. Farley can be legally prosecuted for grand larceny on an indictment based oh his admitted appropriation of interest on funds entrusted to his care will be handed down this morning by Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions when the trial of the former Sheriff, adjourned last Thursday until today, reconvenes.

BERLIN, March 4. -- Early in the week, home and foreign selling of bonds caused sharp reaction In stocks on the Boerse, in which electrical shares particularly suffered. Later, the Handelsbank failure and the disappointing conditions of the prolongation of the Reichsbank's $100,000,000 foreign credit weakened the market.

Interest in the shifting distribution of gold has been intensified by the announcement that the Bank of France's holdings of the metal now exceed the gold reserves of the Federal Reserve System by about $3,400,000.
DUBLIN, March 6. -- The quarrel between Eamonn de Valera and his labor allies is growing so bitter that it threatens the very existence of the as yet unborn Fianna Fail Government.

LONDON, March 5. -- The new spirit of financial cheerfulness now pervading London has resulted In marked revival of business in new securities. This week's offer of u20,000,000 Nyasaland government 4 1/2 per cent stock at 9 1/2 was very largely oversubscribed.

AVALON, Cal., March 6. -- The New York Giants evened the Spring series with the Cubs today but it took them ten innings to do it. The final score was 6 to 3, the Chicagoans collapsing in the extra frame.

TRENTON, N.J., March 6. -- Announcement is made by Miss Elizabeth Robinson Blackwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clayton Blackwell of Greenwood, Ferry Road, Yardley, Pa., of plans for her wedding to Louis Hollenback Twyeffort.

Artigas is showing his ceramics at the Brummer Gallery, 55 East Fifty-seventh Street. The exhibition will continue until April 5. The work is far too beautiful to stand in need of the hyperbolic ecstasy and selectivity contributed as a catalogue foreword by Professor Joseph Pijoan of the University of Chicago.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Howard, senior co-pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, resumed his duties there yesterday morning after an absence of three months because of illness. He preached on the value of human experience as the source of divine revelation as compared to intellectual attempts to discover God.

Charles Evans Hughes Jr., in a discussion of probation and crime prevention yesterday over radio station WOR, said that while it is generally recognized that the contaminating influences of prisons are degrading to the prisoner, "it is also of first importance that administration of probation should not be dominated by the spirit of leniency to the prisoner."
