NEW ORLEANS, La., March 6. -- The cotton market here had a fair volume of business last week and prices were well maintained, despite a somewhat erratic course on the stock market and the uncertain character of foreign political news. Price fluctuations were comparatively narrow, but the closing figures showed slight net gains for the week.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Here ore the texts of the radio speeches delivered tonight in opening the official drive against hoarding:

PARIS, March 6. -- The League Financial Commission, which has been meeting here since Thursday, succeeded today in making great progress in drawing up the frame work of a report it will issue at the end of the week.

HAVANA, March 6. -- George Lott of Chicago, former United States doubles champion, today won the singles final in the international tennis tournament on the courts of the Vedado Tennis Club and received the General Machado silver cup donated by the President.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In remarks at the opening of the Democratic financial campaign in Chicago on Jan. 14, Melvin A. Traylor, not a professional politician, made the following statement, the truth of which is only just now coming to our realization:

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6. -- Satisfied with the general condition of the Yankee squad at this stage of the training season, but uncertain as to the comparative merits of the rival candidates for debatable positions in his regular line-up, Manager Joe McCarthy today prepared to enter the final week of conditioning work for the start of the exhibition game schedule next Saturday.

There will be three openings in the Broadway theatres tonight, "A Night With Barrie." at the Playhouse, with Laurette Taylor as the star; "Money in the Air," at the Ritz Theatre, and a revival of "The Round-Up," at the Majestic. "A Night With Barrie" will present two of his plays, "Alice Sit-by-the-Fire" and "The Old Lady Shows Her Medals."

Despite all that has been done by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, the city, State and other agencies, there are thousands of families in New York that are in acute distress because of unemployment, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the women's division, who appealed to individuals or groups to join the "Adopt-a-Family" movement sponsored by her organization.

One of the greatest tregedies in life is the inability of many persons to translate their experiences into writing, declared Miss Fannie Hurst, the novelist, in an address yesterday afternoon before 600 prisoners at the Welfare Island Workhouse.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, Germany, March 6. -- In this centre of the south German liberalism between fifteen and twenty thousand men an women of all ages -- a crowd" that packed the city's Festhalle to the last square foot -- waited patiently more than seven hours today in order to hear Adolf Hitler utter vehement generalities for thirty-five minutes.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen arrived yesterday a few hours before the storm broke over the New York area, having broken her own crossing record despite one day of heavy, foggy weather. She came within four minutes of the record of the Europa, which holds the laurels of the Atlantic.

The Manhattan Symphony Orchestra under Henry Hadley last night at the Waldorf-Astoria presented Gertrude Bonime as soloist in the Schumann concerto for piano in A minor, and Henrietta Bagger, mezzo-soprano, in the "Gerechter Gott" aria from "Rienzi."

Shooting under adverse weather conditions, C.J. Winninger won the high scvatch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He took the trophy with a card of 79 out of a possible 100 targets. Rain and a high wind made it difficult for the gunners to hit the blue rocks.

TOKYO, Monday, March 7 (AP). -- An official quarter has disclosed that Japan, proposes to retain an army garrison in Shanghai's International Settlement after the withdrawal of tha main expeditionary force. The garrison probably would be one division of troops (in peacetime, 11,000).

LONDON, March 5. -- The public's sales of gold coin and ornaments continue large. The expansion of more than u15,250,000 in the Bank's note circulation, during the week covered by Thursday's statement, was due partly to normal month-end demands for currency, but it was also influenced by the financing of the public sales of gold, most of which were paid for by the Bank in currency notes.

In its report for 1931, which showed that net profits of its consolidated companies after taxes and depreciation amounted to $825,202, against $1,540,202 in the previous year, the Studebaker Corporation announced plans yesterday for a readjustment of its common-share capital and surplus accounts.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A few minutes ago I heard a jazz arrangement of Cadman's beautiful melody "In the Land of the Sky-Blue Waters." It filled me with indignation.

Trailing by 3 -- 1, with only two minutes of play left, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club scored twice in the space of seven seconds to tie the Boston Hockey Club, 3 to 2, before a crowd of 4,000 at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. Russell Blinco tallied both of these and the other Crescent goal as well, the score that produced the deadlock coming in a solo flight from the face-off.

The League of Composers yesterday afternoon presented, modern Pan-American music in the French Institute. Works by Koutzen, Antheil, Allende, Caturla, Chavez, Villa-Lobes, and Ponce were given. Assisting artists were Ruth Breton, Alexandra Barjansky, Rita Sebastian, Marcia Worth, Harrison Potter, Paul Nordoff, and a small orchestral ensemble directed by Bernard Herrmann.

Rudyard Kipling's first new book in six years will be published late in April by Doubleday, Doran, with the title "Limits and Renewals." It will contain ten stories and nineteen poems, none of which, the publishers say, has ever before been published, and this material will fill nearly 400 pages.

VATICAN CITY, March 6. -- Six of the seven ancient bishoprics around Rome governed by Cardinals were understood today likely to be abolished soon by Pope Pius XI in connection with administrative reforms.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An Investigation of short selling on the Stock Exchange cannot possibly result in any other conclusion than that short selling for a decline is not any more wicked than long selling on borrowed money for a rise.

"The time has come when we must love God not only with all our heart but with all our minds," said the Rev. Dr. J. Fort Newton of St. James's Church, Philadelphia, yesterday morning in his sermon, "The Tragedy of a Neutral Life," in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Four-year terms for the Governor, Lieutenant Governor and State Senators, a two-year term for Assembly-men and various changes in procedure, including a so-called "trifurcated session," are urged in a pamphlet issued, by the City Club of New York and sent to every member of the Legislature by Richard S. Childs, its president.

CANTON, China, March 6 (AP) -- The Chinese language, as spoken in the lower Yangtse Valley -- the "Shanghai dialect" -- has invaded Canton with the arrival here of thousands of refugees from Shanghai, but Canton is taking the newcomers of the strange tongue to its bosom.

ST. LOUIS, March 6. -- The Stix eleven, representing the St. Louis Soccer League, defeated the Bricklayers of Chicago by 3 to 2 today in the first of the three-game series to decide the honors in the western division of the National Cup competition.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 6 (AP). -- The two-day match between Lord Tennyson's team of English cricketers and a group of fifteen players representing the County of Cornwall was left drawn Saturday, the teams being unable to conclude two innings In the time allotted to the match.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 6. -- Democratic strife over the control of the California delegation to the party convention at Chicago is keen.

The revenue measure which will be introduced in the House of Representatives today is designed to add $1,096,000,000 to the income of the Federal Government during the fiscal year which begins next July. This is far short of the amount required to balance a budget which now faces a prospective deficit of $1.738,000,000.

BALSAM LAKE, Wis., March 6. -- The bodies of two women, one shot through the head and the other's head crushed, were found early this morning in a burning automobile two miles northwest of Turtle Lake, Polk County, in western Wisconsin. The bodies were burned beyond recognition.

The New York Athletic Club's hockey team won its fifth straight victory and went into a tie for the lead in the Metropolitan Amateur League by defeating the St. Nicholas team at the New York Coliseum yesterday. The score was 5 to 1 and a crowd of 3,000 watched the battle.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 6. -- Because of the Improvement in the bond market, the Mount Vernon Board of Education expects to float a $600,000 twenty-year bond issue within the next few days. The money will be used for the construction of the Washington Junior High School.
BERLIN, March 5. --The net budget of Prussia for 1932-33 fiscal year Is 1,906 million marks, which compares with 2,241 millions in the perceding twelvemonth.

The annual indoor track meet of the New York County of the American Legion will be staged in the 102d Engineers Armory tonight, the proceeds going to the widows and orphans of those killed in the World War, wounded veterans and the unemployed.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The Federal Government's March financing program will take the form of two issues of Treasury certificates, amounting to $900,000,000, Secretary of the Treasury Mills announced tonight.

Ethel Barrymore, whose four-year contract with Lee Shubert will expire at the conclusion of her present road tour in "The School for Scandal," will return to the management of Arthur Hopkins for "an indefinite period" beginning next October, Mr. Hopkins said yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- The wheat market is in a rut and the trade cannot determine what the early trend will be. Were the future clear of attacks on the methods of operating on stock and grain exchanges, the average operator might be disposed to take a decided stand on either side, but the situation is so complex that few men are inclined to make liberal purchases or sales.

HOPEWELL, N.J., March 6. -- Despite the inclement weather, fully one-third of the residents of this town flocked to their respective churches today to offer prayers for the safe return of the baby son of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh.

MOBILE, Ala., March 4. -- Conversion of Ship Island, Miss., into a "national playground" for the American Legion is planned by the Joe Graham Post of the American Legion. Gulfport, Miss., it was revealed by Luther W. Maples, State commander of the American Legion, following the introduction in Congress recently by Congressman Robert S. Hall of Mississippi of a resolution authorizing the War Department to sell the island to the Gulfport post.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- The New York Rangers were beaten by the Chicago Black Hawks tonight in a thrilling overtime National Hockey League battle, 4 to 3. It was the first defeat for New York by Chicago this season. A crowd of 8,000 attended.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read your editorial on "Religion and Politics" and I am writing to congratulate you.
HOLLYWOOD, Cal., March 6 (AP). -- Will Hays and the men who make motion pictures want to know the public's preference, in screen entertainment, and who in the family dictates the choice of programs.

A bridge party in aid of the White Door Settlement will be given on the afternoon of March 15 in the ballroom of the Plaza. The Settlement, which is at 211 Clinton Street, provides an extensive educational and recreational program for children and adults in a crowded district.

Those who expect "to solve the problems of life without God" are "thinking backwards" and are subjects for insane asylums, the Rev. Thomas Kearney of the Congregation of Notre Dame declared yesterday at the opening of the annual actors' mission at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, Forty-ninth Street and Eighth Avenue.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 6. -- Gover nor Roosevelt and Republican legislative leaders will confer early this week on methods of financing the continuance of the State's unemployment relief program.

ALBANY, March 6. -- With only two major problems to consider in the final days of one of the shortest sessions on record, legislative leaders returned to the capital tonight prepared to begin the intense activity necessary to push their way through hundreds of minor measures before adjournment on Friday.

HAVANA, March 6 (AP). -- Lucilla k., bay daughter of Whiskalong-Grief, that races for H.M. Woolf of Kansas City was an easy winner of the Cuban Juvenile Stakes, stellar offering at Oriental Park today. She was ridden by C.E. Allen, and at the finish had a wide advantage over Albert Sabath's Olive Sabath, while O. L. Foster's Larack was third.

LEIPZIG, March 6 (AP). -- The uncertainties of the coming Presidential elections and the world-wide economic debility beclouded the annual Leipzig Fair, which opened today with 15 per cent fewer exhibitors than heretofore.

MOSCOW, March 6. -- The newspaper Pravda today continues the line taken in an editorial in Izvestia two days ago with regard to the Far Eastern situation. It publishes a long article analyzing the rise of Japan as a world power.
BERLIN, March 5. -- The General Electricity Corporation this week passed its dividend. Its report shows a net loss of 19 million marks against a profit of 14 millions in the preceding year.

The entire Metropolitan Opera Company, from the leading stars through the chorus, ballet, stage hands, executive staff and ushers, and including some of the great, comparatively inactive, stars of the days gone by, gave a party, a "surprise" party, at the opera house last night.

BERLIN, March 5. -- The Reichsbank's status has improved further. In the current report, covering the last week in February, not only was the foreign exchange reserve enlarged, but credits and investments increased only 357 million marks, as against an increase of 745 millions in the same week of 1931.

As usual, the annual report of the Port Authority records little progress in some directions and splendid advance in others. Port development goes forward at a snail's pace. Belt lines are still largely in the blueprint and conversation stage. The Jersey City marine terminal project has been postponed.

HAVANA, March 6 (AP). -- Lucilla k., bay daughter of Whiskalong-Grief, that races for H.M. Woolf of Kansas City was an easy winner of the Cuban Juvenile Stakes, stellar offering at Oriental Park today. She was ridden by C.E. Allen, and at the finish had a wide advantage over Albert Sabath's Olive Sabath, while O. L. Foster's Larack was third.

Munds, Winslow Potter, a Stock Exchange firm, entered yesterday the fight of certain stockholders to prevent the acquisition of the Reliance Management Corporation by the Reliance International Corporation, offering conditionally to buy 50,000 shares of Reliance Management stock at $1.50 a share.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP). -- Favorable action on a resolution calling for a Justice Department report on whether the proposed Eastern Railroad consolidation violates the anti-trust law was voted today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Until the last redskin bit the dust that coated "The Round-Up," they shot and talked it out last night at the Majestic, where it proved the happy notion of Carl Reed and A. Wichfeld to restore for a fortnight Edmund Day's torrid old thriller of that year of grace and easy credibility, 1907.

Objecting to certain items in the agricultural appropriation bill, Senator MCKELLAR reviewed sardonically certain achievements of bureaucracy in the Department of Agriculture In 1919 a Massachusetts man found worms in his sweet corn. So Senator LODGE introduced a bill authorizing the appropriation of $10,000 to investigate, and if possible to exterminate the European corn-borer.

A brisk market for United States Government obligations and new high marks for the year by a sizable list of railroad issues featured yesterday's dealings in listed bonds. The market for government loans was stimulated by the announcement of the treasury's financing plans for next Tuesday, and two Issues of the group reached new tops for the year and two others duplicated their previous highs.

CHICAGO, March 7. -- The national drive of the Citizens Reconstruction Organization to put unemployed money to work started today. In 1,607 cities and communities, representatives of the organization opened the campaign. In Chicago, James Keeley, who is assisting Frank Knox, general director, said 82,500 men workers and 70,000 women were making appeals to the public to end hoarding.

Professor John Dewey, president of the League for Independent Political Action, declared last night that unless the Democratic party nominated a man of truly progressive mind in the Presidential contest of this year a third party would surely be in the field.

John Fernnino, a laborer, of Southport, Conn., identified Henry Johnson of Englewood, the friend of Miss Betty Gow, Lindbergh nurse, as the man who picked him up in the Bronx last Wednesday morning at 7:30 o'clock and pave him a ride as far as Bridgeport.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., March 7. -- Dr. Raymond Walters was notified today of his election to the presidency of the University of Cincinnati and will take his new post on Sept. 1.

The trial of Francis X. Mancuso, a former judge of General Sessions, on an indictment charging perjury was started yesterday and eleven jurors were selected before Justice William F. Bleakley in Criminal Term of the Supreme Court. An adjournment was taken until tomorrow to give I. Gainsburg, counsel for Mancuso, time to study the minutes of the extraordinary grand jury which returned the indictment on Feb. 23.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 7. -- A battle between Governor Roosevelt of New York and former Governor Smith at the Pennsylvania preferential primary on April 26 was assured when nominating petitions entering Mr. Smith as a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination were filed here today.

A warning that "it need be no surprise to city officials if taxes are not forthcoming promptly on the May 1 tax bills" was made yesterday by Anton L. Trunk, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, in a statement issued in response to an admission made by President Joseph V. McKee of the Board of Aldermen on Saturday that real estate in this city was overtaxed.
WARSAW, March 7.-- A sweeping change in the Polish unemployment insurance scheme was proposed in a bill that the government submitted to the Sejm today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP). -- Lest it frighten the abductors of the Lindbergh baby and delay his safe return, the Senate Judiciary Committee today withheld action on a measure to make kidnapping across State lines a Federal crime punishable by death.

JOE BROMILOW has a record that is unique in track history. One of the best middle-distance men of his day, he nevertheless acquired a complete collection of second-place medals merely because he had the misfortune to be running against the peerless Mel Sheppard.

PUTNAM, Conn., March 7. -- Thomas Taylor, one of Putnam's few remaining Civil War veterans, who was on the Monitor when she fought her famous battle with the Merrimac, died today at his home here, never having recovered fully from a beating he received when held up by robbers in Worcester, Mass., several months ago.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The joint resolution of Congress under which 40,000,000 bushels of wheat now held by the Farm Board will be distributed among the country's needy reached the White House this morning and was signed by President Hoover late this afternoon following a conference with Attorney General Mitchell.

PARIS, March 7. -- An appeal to wine drinkers, as well as cultivators and exporters all over the world, to unite in an energetic opposition to prohibition and restrictive legislation such as internal taxation and levies of high import duties on wines, was addressed by Premier Tardieu today to delegates from thirty nations assembled in the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs for the opening of the International Wine Congress.

THE president of the National League, John Arnold Heydler, sat In his office yesterday and peered out at the snow that was whipping by the window. He was a trifle gloomy -- and not without reason. This is the vacation period, as a rule. About this time of year he is usually down in Florida slapping a golf ball around some sunny course.

The recovery in sterling exchange, set in motion last week by the announcement that the British Treasury was repaying $150,000,000 of the $200,000,000 banking credit obtained here last August in an attempt to bolster the pound, was pursued yesterday at an accelerated pace.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 7. -- The village of Croton-on-Hudson moved iIn Supreme Court here today for a preference in the eighteen actions brought by taxpayers questioning the legality of the recent annexation of surrounding hamlets.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 7. -- An offensive spurt midway in the first half enabled the Princeton varsity basketball team to assume undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League standing by defeating Dartmouth tonight, 33 to 27.

The pamphlet report of the American Equities Company for 1931 shows that a reserve of $23,180,351 for depreciation in value of investments in and advances to subsidiary companies and to companies in which substantial minority interests are hold was set aside in the year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When an acquaintance asks on a morning of heavy rain, "Isn't this a terrible day?" he of course expects sympathetic agreement. Yet he may be surprised out of his despondency by the counter-query in the excited voice of one just returning from a visit to a menagerie: "But have you seen the vibrissae?"

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7. -- Henry Johnson, Yankee pitcher, now convalescing from an attack of appendicitis, is expected to resume Spring training in about a week, Manager McCarthy said today. His improvement since leaving the hospital has been rapid.

Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman was removed yesterday from the Tammany slate for Congressional district delegates to the Democratic National Convention. It is assumed that Colonel Lehman will attend the convention either as a delegate at large or as alternate at large for Governor Roosevelt, who will be elected delegate at large, but probably will not sit in the convention.

PARIS, March 7. -- The stock market was seriously depressed today and nearly the whole Bourse list declined. In many instances the losses reached substantial proportions, particularly among shares of French banks and domestic corporations. This was traced to some extent to renewed rumors that dividend cuts were in prospect.
LONDON, March 7. -- Viscount Grey of Fallodon declared tonight that Japan had placed herself in the wrong before the whole world by fighting instead of appealing first to the League of Nations.

HONOLULU, March 7. -- The special session of the Hawaiian Legislature reconvened today after a month's recess to take up problems of taxation and school administration and to deal with a message from Governor Judd outlining proposed economies.

A complete slate of Roosevelt candidates for delegates to the Democratic National Convention was filed yesterday in California, which will have its primary election on May 3. This information was received by James A. Farley, Democratic State chairman, in a telegram from James E. Meredith, secretary of the Democratic State Central Committee of California.
Tributes to former Premier Briand of France, gathered by The Associated Press and from other sources, included the following:
WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The text of the Steagall bill introduced in the House today reads:

Eddie Ran, Polish welterweight, scored one of the quickest victories if his career last night when he knocked out Marty Goldman of Brownsville in the first round of what was scheduled as the feature ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., March 7 (AP). -- The South African, cricket team defeated New Zealand today by eight wickets for its second straight victory in the three-game series. The scores were: South Africa, 410 and 150 for two wickets, aggregate 560; New Zealand, 364 and 193, aggregate 557.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The International General Electric Company, the Westinghouse Electric International Company, R.C.A. Communications, Inc., and the National Broadcasting Company were named additional defendants today in the anti-trust suit of the government against the Radio Corporation of America, in a supplemental petition filed by Attorney General Mitchell with the Federal court at Wilmington, Del.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 7. -- With the appearance of Claudia Muzio, soprano of the Chicago Civic Opera Company, tonight at the Everglades Club, the Society of Arts concluded its season's series of concerts. Miss Muzio, who was accompanied by Charles Lurvey, received an ovation.

The State of New Jersey went the legal limit yesterday toward making it easy and safe for the kidnappers of the baby son of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh to restore him to his parents' home near Hopewell, N.J.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP). -- A Congressional effort to lift silver from the mire was begun today with disagreement between two leading bankers as to the value of an international consultation.

CASTLE HARBOUR, Bermuda, March 7.-- The first day's play in the Castle Harbour Cup tourney, which is providing informal international matches between British-Bermuda and United States golfers, ended with the visitors leading by 8 1/2 to 3 1/2.

Since "The Furies," four or five years ago, Lauretta Taylor has been absent from the stage. But, please God, may she never be absent again! As the artful wife in "Alice Sit-By-the-Fire," which was revived at the Playhouse last evening, she does not tamely remind us of what a superb actress she is.

In thinking of the Lindbergh baby, Irvin S. Cobb, author and after-dinner speaker, found it impossible to tell anecdotes and make a humorous speech last night to 600 brokers and traders of the commodity exchanges of New York who assembled at dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria to celebrate the golden jubilee of the Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

Ramsey County, Minn. Award of $500,000 of an issue of $1,000,000 Ramsey County (Minn.) road and bridge bonds. Series L. due on April 1, 1933 to 1952, was made yesterday to a syndicate comprising the Continental Illinois Company, Inc.; the First Wisconsin Company of Milwaukee, the First National Old Colony Corporation, Kelley Richardson Co. of Chicago, and Kalman Co. of St. Paul.

Failure of importers to specify the proper classification under which books imported by Block House, Inc., of this city should have been taxed compelled the United States Customs Court yesterday to uphold the assessment levied by customs officials here.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., March 7. -- Out of conferences with large holders of bonds of the Richfield Oil Company of California information came today that reorganization of that concern might be undertaken by J. Paul Getty, an independent oil operator and now majority stock-holder in the Pacific Western Oil Corporation, if his plan was acceptable to the bondholders.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Horatio. N. Slater is visting her daughter, Mrs. Joseph Kerrigan, in Oyster Bay.

GENEVA, March 7. -- The news of Aristide Briand's death was announced in the Assembly of the League of Nations today by President Paul Hymans and caused in that gathering of fifty nations the most profound sense of personal loss and grief.

John J. Glenn, suspended patrolman formerly attached to the vice squad, was convicted of perjury by a jury in Judge Corrigan's part of General Sessions yesterday afternoon in a case growing out of his arrest of a woman, in June, 1929, on a vice charge.

AMHERST, Mass., March 7. -- Dwight W. Morrow Jr. was elected president of the Amherst College Debating Council today. Richard Glenn Gettell of Berkeley, Cal., was named manager and Robert Leander Davidson, Tulsa, Okla., secretary.

ALBANY, March 7. -- Governor Roosevelt signed today the bill creating a banking board of nine members, headed by the State Superintendents of Banks. Selection of members of the board is expected to be made soon.

CHICAGO, March 7. -- The Chicago, North Shore Milwaukee Railroad Company had a net loss of $746,579 in 1931 after all charges, including interest, according to the annual statement given out today by Britton I. Budd, president. This contrasts with a net income of $597,855 in 1930.

SHANGHAI, March 7. -- If Japan can extricate herself from the mud and muck of the Yangtse delta and the plains around Shanghai she is more than willing to do so, provided the feat can be achieved with honor and with assurances for the security of her people and their investments around Shanghai which shall be of such validity as to satisfy the army that its sacrifice of life was not wastage.

BOMBAY, India, March 7 (AP). -- In protest against the treatment accorded by the government to Mohammedans in the Northwest Frontier Province, executives of the All-India Association announced today that they had dissolved their working committee and named Mufti Kifayat Ullah, president of the organization, as their first dictator.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Member of Bar" is "profoundly concerned about the agitation started at the instances of President Lowell of Harvard, Newton D. Baker and hundreds of other more or less well-known individuals to prejudge the merits of the Japanese question."

In the Sunday night appeals to the hoarders, most loudly sounded was the patriotic note. Emphasis was laid upon the duty of showing today a public spirit like that displayed in the war. Men should now put their hoarded dollars to work for the return of prosperity, just as in 1917 they bought Liberty Bonds and sent their sons to the front.

In a report submitted yesterday to Governor Moore and the New Jersey Legislature, after a survey covering a period of six months, the Port of New York Authority declared that the construction of a bridge across Raritan Bay between Staten Island and Monmouth County, N.J., would not be feasible economically and would result in heavy financial losses to other structures that handle traffic in the port district.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Leaders of the House made quick work today of the formalities necessary for bringing up the new tax bill for consideration Thursday. In view of this speedy action and sensing the temper of the House, Speaker Garner predicted that the bill would be passed by the end of next week.

After occupying the centre of the stage in physics for nearly three hundred years, light, one of the cornerstones in relativity, the speed of which is regarded as one of the only two absolutes to which all else is relative, is beginning to be regarded by modern physicists as playing but a minor role.

TRENTON, N.J., March 7. -- The New Jersey Assembly, meeting in regular session tonight, unanimously adopted a resolution expressing "its deep and heartfelt sympathy" to Colonel and Mrs. Charles A: Lindbergh over the kidnapping of their son, and adding that "we do devoutly offer our prayer for the safe and immediate return of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. to his grief-stricken parents."

The Hotel Pierre, Inc., operator of the Hotel Pierre, which was opened in 1930 on the site of the home of the late Elbridge T. Gerry at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday through Charles Pierre, its president.

Whatever the final estimate of its record, the Legislature is likely to receive credit this year for dispatch of the public business. For so cumbersome a body, loaded with such heavy responsibilities, it has moved swiftly. The present program calls for adjournment before the end of this week -- probably at noon on Friday.

For the second consecutive month the rate of production of steel ingots in this country increased slightly in February, according to the monthly compilation of the American Iron and Steel Institute. The industry's operating rate last month was 27.57 per cent of plant capacity, against 26.54 per cent in January, and 23.58 per cent in December.

LONDON, March 7. -- It has been decided to change the name of the British Atlantic fleet. A movement is afoot to discipline its young sailors by sending them to sea, as in Nelson's day, before the mast under sail.

WEST PALM BEACH. Fla., March 7. -- Tommy Goodwin of Monroe. N. Y., winner of the Palm Beach title last week, was eliminated in a twenty-two-hole match in the first round of the men's county championship over the course of the West Palm Beach Club today, losing to Leon R. Sikes of Palm Beach.

VATICAN CITY, March 7. -- An important reform in the Roman Catholic Church was foreshadowed in an announcement today by the Holy See of its intention to discontinue six of the seven suburbican sees, which have been in existence for almost nineteen centuries and which are reported to have been founded by St. Peter, himself, soon after the seat of Catholicism was transferred to Rome from Antioch.

TRENTON, N.J., March 7. -- One of the most important of the government reorganization bills backed by Governor A. Harry Moore was passed in the Assembly tonight by a vote of 33 to 22, over Republican opposition. The bill, introduced by Majority Leader Brown, calls for the consolidation of a number of commissions into a new Department of Public Works.

ALBANY, March 7.-- With the legislative session entering upon its final week tonight, it was learned that a proposal for a $20,000,000 bond issue to provide the necessary funds for continued unemployment relief under State auspices was receiving serious consideration from the Governor and the Republican leaders of the Legislature.

DUBLIN, March 7. -- Everything is now in readiness for the opening of the new Dail Eireann Wednesday. Eamonn de Valera has completed his task of Cabinet-making and it is believed a minor office will be offered to a member of the independent group.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 7. -- City Manager John F. Donovan presented to the City Council tonight his first local municipal budget, which shows an increase in the tax levy of $474,825 over that of last year and includes salaries of more than $5,000 each for the six department heads he named last week in the face of the growing opposition of the minority in the council and the taxpayers.

Alfred Feldman, 24 years old, a medical student, was doing relief duty late yesterday in the absence of his father, Max, in the latter's seamen's supply store at 421 West Street, when two men entered, held him up with a pistol and took $4 from the cash register.

Evidence that financial Europe is emerging from its exaggerated panic of the past five months has become unmistakable. Not only have prices on the London and Paris Stock Exchanges been rising during the fortnight past, but cables from responsible quarters testify that the buying has changed from mere tentative speculation for the rise to genuine investment purchases and that, in the money market, hoarding of cash has ceased to be an influence.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, March 8 (AP). -- Heavy fighting on a broad scale was reported today to be developing out of skirmishes between the Chinese and Japanese armies along the newly established inland battle line. Both the Japanese and Chinese accused each other of resuming the offensive on the front west and northwest of Shanghai, threatening to precipitate a renewal of general conflict.

James Monroe High School's basketball team clinched the Bronx Division P.S.A.L. championship yesterday when it turned back De Witt Clinton, 20 to 18, in an overtime contest of the Clinton floor. Jack Stelzer's field goal with 35 seconds to play in the extra session broke an 18-all deadlock and gave Monroe its seventh consecutive triumph, assuring it of the title.

New York City's effort to abohsh distress by joint action of all its citizens in a campaign of extraordinary scope and size will begin today with the personal delivery of 2,000,000 circulars calling for leaders in the new "Block-Aid" plan, it was announced yesterday by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the "Block-Aid" organization.

LONDON, March 7 (AP). -- The progress of attempts to communicate with the kidnappers of the Lindbergh baby continued to hold the most prominent place in London newspapers today. Front pages were as thoroughly dedicated to the kidnapping story as they were when it first happened last week.
"All the King's Horses," a three-act drama, was presented last night by the Morningside Heights Players of Columbia University in Earl Hall on the campus. The production will run throughout the week.

After displaying resistance for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased in the last hour in sympathy with the stock market and ended unchanged to 8 points lower than on Saturday. The strongest sterling exchange market in several months brought a further loss in cotton quotations in Liverpool and created active arbitrage trading on both sides of the account.

Hopewell, the township in New Jersey which on the south is bounded by the Delaware but is still known for its lonely farms and primitive wildness, has Revolutionary memories that are treasured by Mercer County. Its signer of the Declaration of Independence, " Honest" JOHN HART, farmer and dauntless patriot, was one of the most respectable figures of his time.

MUKDEN, March 7. -- At 3 o'clock Wednesday afternoon former Emperor Henry Pu-yi will be officially installed as provisional President of the new Manchurian State. All preparations were concluded today with Mr. Pu-yi's approval. Hotels and inns at Mukden and Changchun were crammed with guests. A gala event is planned, with parades, dancing, music, theatricals and other entertainments.

State Senator John A. Hastings, whose legal battle to prevent the Hofstadter legislative committee from calling him as a witness ended in defeat in the Court of Appeals, unexpectedly visited the committee headquarters yesterday morning and announced his willingness to testify.

DEL MONTE, Cal., March 7 (AP). -- Captain C.T.I. (Pat) Roark, British polo player of international fame, seriously injured yesterday, was reported resting easily tonight by his physician, Dr. Mast Wolfson.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Unity of action, now, as in time of war, by Catholics, Jews and Protestants against forces inimical to American institutions was urged by the Right Rev. James Freeman, Bishop of Washington, at today's opening session, of a three-day national conference on "Religious Liberty and Mutual Understanding."

ABOARD U.S.S. AUGUSTA, San Pedro, Cal., March 7. -- The might and majesty of American sea power rolled gently in the ground-swells of the Pacific today, prepared to test its strength for the next two weeks in one of the largest of the navy's annual strategical problems.

A plan of reorganization for the United Milk Products Corporation based on the formation of a new company to acquire the property and assets of the present organization has been approved by the directors and will be voted upon by stock-holders of the company, it was announced yesterday.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 7. -- Mrs. Amelia Wilson Stiles, wife of Mark D. Stiles, president of the Mount Vernon Trust Company and Commissioner of Public Safety, died this afternoon after an illness of several years.

MIAMI, Kla., March 7. -- The defeat of Willie Macfarlane of Tuckahoe, N.Y., and Wiffy Cox of Brooklyn, the defending champions, and the elimination of Walter Hagen of Detroit and Paul Runyan of Little Rock, Ark., one of the outstanding pairs of favorites, marked the quarter finals of match play in the international four-ball tournament over the course of the Miami Country Club today.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 7. -- With a concurrent resolution to ratify sponsored by Senator Pitcher of Jefferson and Assemblyman Sargent of Onondaga already pending, Governer Roosevelt sent a special message to the Legislature tonight urging approval of the so-called "lame-duck" amendment to the Federal Constitution.

Austin H. Montgomery, former convict, who testified for the government during the trial for mail fraud of W. Bernard Vause, former Kings County judge, was arrested again yesterday by Federal authorities, this time on a charge that he and Albert J. Froehlich and Edward W. Baumeister had swindled more than 100 investors of about $50,000.

Another Winter in the life of Egypt is but as "snow upon the "desert's face lasting an hour or "two and gone." Yet it has gathered many shards of antiquity in this brief season of search to tell the world that man has longer known what are called civilized ways than our nearness to savagery sometimes suggests.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 7. -- The Athletics tossed a few more regulars into action today, including the king of the backstops, Mickey Cochrane, and forthwith took the St. Louis Cardinals into camp, 4 to 2, in the third and by far the best played game of the Spring exhibition world's series.

MIAMI, March 7. -- Henry Roseacher's Bacciocco, a gelded son of High Time and Griselda, which won all three of his starts at the first Tropical Park meeting, captured the featured number on the program of the Gables Racing Association today. Hank Mills, leading rider of the meeting, got the 5-year-old home a length before Click, which led Fair Jack by three lengths.
LOS ANGELES, March 7. -- Memphis Bill Terry today engaged in his first workout of the year with the Giants as the McGrawmen returned to Wrigley Field after their two-day excursion to Catalina Island.

PARIS, March 7. -- Aristide Briand, who spent his life striving for peace, died suddenly here of a heart attack at 1:30 this afternoon, just three weeks before he would have reached his seventieth birthday. Although he had been very ill for months, it was thought his health had improved, so that the news of his death stunned France.

TOKYO, March 7. -- The visit to Tokyo of Prince Saionji, last of the elder statesmen, arouses great interest, which is not likely to be satisfied at present because the Prince's secrets are never revealed. Premier Inukai spent an hour with Prince Saionji today and subsequently told newspaper reporters the Prince had come to pay his respects to Emperor Hirohito and was not on a political mission.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The death of Aristide Briand was deeply deplored here today, his distinguished career and services for peace being extolled by President Hoover and Secretary Stimson in messages to officials of the French Government and by Senators and others in public life in statements.

BERLIN, March 7. -- Even if it does not exactly determine "the destiny of the German people," as some ardent partisans tell their followers, next Sunday's German. Presidential election is of fairly grave importance. Yet it has its comic aspects.

A janitor rescued an invalid in a fire yesterday in the Fieldston Boarding School at 22-04 Cornaga Avenue, Far Rockaway. He then re-entered the burning building to help other employes lead ten children to safety.

Moderate weakness on the Stock Exchange yesterday appeared to Wall Street to be nothing more than a casual technical readjustment within the market itself. The unsettlement was not caused by any special news development; it must have resulted from selling by professionals.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Senator Robinson of Arkansas sharged in the Senate today that Senator Hastings had obtained "secret" approval of the latter's draft of a report in the Bankhead-Heflin election contest case from a group of "stand-pat" Republican Senators before presenting it to the Senate.

Aristide Briand, member of twenty-three Cabinets and eleven times Premier in more than three decades of a remarkable political life, was in many respects the outstanding French statesman of his time and one of the greatest of Europeans. Only such men as the late Georges Clemenceau and Jean Jaures, victim of an assassin's bullet at the outbreak of the war, had captured and held the imagination of France and of the world as did Briand.

ALBANY, March 7. -- By unanimous vote, the Assembly tonight passed the bill filed by Joseph T. Higgins, New York Democrat, relieving the State Athletic Commission of supervision over purely amateur sparring, boxing or wrestling contests, even though an admission fee is charged.

ESSEN, Germany, March 7. -- Here in the heart of the Ruhr, in an electoral district where the Communists were the strongest party at the last national election, Chancellor Bruening opened his campaign for President von Hindenburg tonight before an audience that packed the Exposi tion Hall as soon as the doors were opened.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, March 8. -- Japanese airplanes late yesterday brought word that Chinese troops were gradually moving eastward toward the Japanese positions, some proceeding toward Taitsang and some toward Hwangtu, which cities are on the battlefront about fifteen miles westward of Shanghai.

Automobile production increased by about the normal seasonal amount last week, making the adjusted index 36.9 for the week ended March 5, as against 36.5 for the preceding week and 61.1 for the corresponding week last year. Actual output, according to Cram's Automotive Reports, amounted to 35,461 cars and trucks, as against 33.329 in the preceding week and 58,750 in the corresponding weak last year.

GENEVA, March 7. -- The German delegates to the disarmament conference protested today against the listing of their suggestions far down on the agenda, so the "Conference Bureau," composed of the president and vice president, reorganized the schedule.

ALBANY, March 7. -- The Senate passed 116 measures tonight. Fifty-eight of these were claim bills, and among them was the bill of Senator Hastings, Democrat, of Brooklyn, which would give depositors of the Bank of United States the right to sue in the Court of Claims for damages arising from the crash.

"Danse Imperial, Numero Cinque," the fifth in the series of Monday evening dances of The Imperial, was held last night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The series is benefiting the social service bureau of Bellevue Hospital.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 7. Eighty-three pastors were transferred and two changes made in the district superintendencies at the concluding sessions of the annual New Jersey conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church here today.

Judge Freschi, at the resumption of the trial of former Sheriff Thomas F. Farley for retaining interest on money held in escrow pending the outcome of litigation, dismissed yesterday two of three counts in the indictment.

An "apparent discrepancy" in statements made In behalf of Owen Madden in efforts to obtain his release from the custody of the Parole Board was pointed out yesterday in a supplemental brief filed by the Attorney General's office, which is seeking to have Madden and three other ex-convicts returned to Sing Sing.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7. -- The will of Dr. Virgil M. Dow, who was the oldest graduate of Yale University when he died Feb. 19, was filed today in the New Haven Probate Court. It was estimated that his estate will total about $20,000 in value, although it was stated last month, when an application for a conservator was filed by a nephew, that the value would prove to be about $100,000.

DETROIT, March 7. -- Nearly 3,000 of Detroit's unemployed, with Communists in their midst, took part in a riot today at the gates of the Ford Motor Company's plant in Dearborn. Their demonstration culminated in a furious fight in which four men were killed and at least fifty others were injured.
LONDON, March 7. -- The passing of Aristide Briand spread deep and genuine sorrow throughout Britain today.

Prices moved in a narrow range in quiet trading on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, closing with an assortment of gains and losses. Domestic bonds showed a preponderance of gains, while foreign bonds were mixed.

CHICAGO, March 7. -- Offerings of hogs here today were the second smallest for a Monday since last September, and with a good demand and a soaring fresh pork loin market, hogs advanced 5 to 20 cents to a new high since Nov. 19. Light weights showed the most strength, touching $4.70, or 20 cents above Saturday's best figure.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 7. -- Hack Wilson grave concrete evident today that he is on the way to a real come-back. He hit two home runs and one single in three times at bat during the game, which was won by the regulars, 3 to 0.
A Nice Distinction. President HOOVER has signed the bill giving away 40,000,000 bushels of the Farm Board wheat to the destitute. It it had been a grant of money, he could not have approved it.

Reorders Now Gaming Sharply. Reorders picked up sharply in the market here yesterday, both in mail volume and in orders placed by visiting buyers. The gain was held to reflect improved activity in Spring lines of apparel and accessories now being enjoyed by the retail stores.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 7. -- The first year of President Salamanca's administration is receiving favorable comment in the press generally. Bolivia at present is developing in an orderly manner toward a better future.

The only way the people of this country can meet "the most serious financial emergency" that has ever confronted the nation except in time of war is to submit to increased taxation, according to the National Industrial Conference Board, 247 Park Avenue.

The annual report of the American Power and Light Company shows net income of $14,806,767 for 1931, equal after preferred dividends to $2.03 a share earned on 3,013,812 common shares outstanding at the end of the year, comparing with $17,448,738, equal after preferred dividends to $3.20 a share on 2,894,171 common shares earned in 1930.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The world's foremost apostle of peace passed when Aristide Briand died.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter signed "Actuary" printed in THE TIMES contains criticisms of the proposals for dealing with unemployment which were recently presented by me to the New York State Commission on Unemployment, on behalf of the Consumers' League of New York.
LOS ANGELES, March 7. -- Miss Zoe Akins, noted playwright, will be married on Saturday to Captain Hugo Rumbold, British theatrical producer. Today they filed their notice of intention to wed.

Discrimination against Long Island on the part of the Port of New York Authority, as charged by Borough President Harvey of Queens, was termed impossible yesterday by John F. Galvin, chairman. In an explanation of the system of restrictions under which the port body operates.

If the major requisites of light opera be tunefulness and entertainment, the current offering of the New York Opera Comique, which opened for a week at the Heckscher Theatre last night, is doing very well by light opera. Jacques Offenbach's pleasant melodies, sprinkled so generously through "Orpheus in Hades," amply takes care of the one, and the general sprightliness of the production insures the second.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The stock market investigation by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, originally scheduled to begin tomorrow, was postponed today "for three or four days" by Senator Norbeck, chairman of the committee.
Leon Pinetzki, the Polish giant, gained his second triumph in recent weeks over Tiny Roebuck, Indian, in the feature wrestling bout at Madison Square Garden last night before a crowd of 4,000.
ROME, March 7 (AP). -- Italy informed France in a note today that she was somewhat dubious of Premier Andre Tardieus plan for a customs union among the five Danubian States.

John E. Sheehy, Tammany district leader appointed by Governor Roosevelt to succeed Thomas M. Farley as Sheriff of New York County, took the oath of office yesterday, announced that he would make no changes in the personnel of his office except after "a thorough personal investigation," and gave assurance that the interest on funds in his care would be held in a special fund until the courts had decided its disposition.

LOS ANGELES, March 7 (AP). -- Duncan Renaldo, screen actor, pleaded not guilty in Federal court today on three counts alleging he made fraudulent statements in obtaining passports to South Africa, when he went abroad in 1929 to make the film, "Trader Horn."

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Ratification of the treaty drafted by the Conference on Limitation of the Manufacture of Narcotic Drugs at Geneva and signed by the American delegation on July 18, 1931, was urged by the delegation, in a report submitted to the State Department today by John K. Caldwell, chairman.

BRUSSELS, March 7. -- The highest court has rejected the appeal of Whitney Warren, the American architect, against a decision of a lower court prohibiting the erection of a balustrade on the new library of the University of Louvain bearing the inscription, "Furore Teutonico Diruta; Dono Americano Resituta" (Destroyed by German fury; re stored by American generosity).
NEW LONDON, Conn., March 7 (AP). -- A board of inquiry met today to take evidence in the sinking of the schooner Firelight oft Halifax following a collision with the Coast Guard boat Eagle

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The, Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on March 2 shows decreases for the week of $83,000,000 in loans and investments and $70,000,000 in government deposits and an increase of $15,000,000 in time deposits.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- A constitutional amendment empowering Congress "to stabilize prices in time of war" and to eliminate profiteering was recommended in a report by the War Policies Commission, transmitted to Congress today by President Hoover.

CHICAGO, March 7. -- Wheat made a firm start and an easy finish today on the Board of Trade here. Opening trades were around 1/2 cent higher than on Saturday but the bulge was checked on selling on resting orders around 62 cents a bushel for May. and by holders of offers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7. -- Yale has adopted the honor system of scoring points In its fencing matches. The plan was tried Saturday in the Yale-Princeton tournament, and Coach Robert Grasson of the Eli team said tonight that It proved a thorough success.

A German biography of George Washington, written by Walther Reinhardt, German Consul at Seattle, has won the 1932 prize of the Ralph Beaver Strassburger Foundation. Albert Sinstein, Thomas Mann, Jacob Wasserman and Stefan Zweig are among the members of the foundation jury which awarded the prize.

Among the passengers who will sail tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa for Cherbourg, Southampton and Bremen are Charles S. Whitman, former Governor of the State of New York; Mrs. Curtis Bok of Philadelphia; Jack L. Warner of Warner Brothers; Count Carl Moltke, Danish Minister to the United States, and Mady Christians, German film star.
BERLIN, March 7. -- The death of Aristide Briand, it is felt here, deprives the cause of Franco-German rapprochement of its sturdiest official champion on the other side of the Rhine.

The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, opened yesterday an exhibition of "provincial paintings" of the nineteenth century, together with Audubon prints of birds, a group of colored lithographs and a collection of cartoons by Thomas Nast -- all selected from the museum's permanent collection.

Edward G. McLaughlin of the Columbia University Club, third ranking player m the country, had a narrow escape from defeat last night in the national amateur squash tennis championship at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The Democratic leaders of the House took another administration suggestion today when Representative Steagall of Alabama, chairman of the Banking and Currency Committee, introduced a bill to create a fund of $517,000,000 with which to guarantee J deposits in Federal Reserve member banks.

A new issue of $2,000,000 Virginia Public Service Company first mortgage and refunding twenty-year bonds. Series C. will be placed on the market today by a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc.; H.M. Byllesby Co., Inc., and Blyth Co., Inc.

The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, which opened fifty years ago as the first organized coffee futures market in the world, celebrated its golden jubilee last night with a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria attended by 600 business and financial leaders, including the presidents of the various New York commodity and security exchanges and diplomatic and consular representatives of Brazil and Cuba.

Amplifying its preliminary statement issued in the latter part of January, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, in its pamphlet report for 1931, yesterday showed that current assets as of Dec. 31 amounted to $141,873,201, and that current liabilities were $25,563,503.

Events have now demonstrated in a tragic way that something more potent than personal or factional politics was responsible for the recent "sidetracking" of ARISTIDE BRIAND. His absence from the post of Foreign Minister in the late Laval and present Tardieu Cabinets we can now well understand to have been due to more than a premonition, held by himself and his friends, that his end was not far away.

William Duggran, Collector of Internar Revenue for the Second District of New York City, made public yesterday a list of places where revenue agents have been assigned to assist Federal income taxpayers in making out their returns. The Second District has its headquarters at the Custom House, and embraces all of Manhattan south of Twenty-third Street.

John Brazili, who said he was a Prohibition agent attached to the Newark office, was captured last night and held a prisoner at the Fifth Street police station on a charge of robbery following the hold-up of Oscar Bolinsky, a grocer, in his store at 73 East Fourth Street.

HOPEWELL, N.J., March 7. -- The State troopers forming a cordon about the snow-drifted estate of Colonel Charles Lindbergh stood ready tonight to withdraw if that would advance the prime object of their efforts here -- the safe return of Colonel Lindbergh's son, kidnapped last Tuesday night.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7. -- The body of a woman identified late tonight as that of Mrs. Mattie Schaaf, 59, proprietor of a lodging house at 31 South Connecticut Avenue, Atlantic City, was found in a trunk in a Philadelphia rooming house today.

WASHINGTON. March 7 (AP). -- For New York members of the House of Representatives pleaded with President Hoover today for the selection of a new veterans' hospital site within a forty-mile radius of Batavia, N.Y.

Conceding handicaps of up to fifty yards, the New York University relay four scored an easy triumph in the 1,200-meter college and club event that was one of the features of the American Legion benefit track meet at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.

While standard statistical indexes failed to record business improvement in February, "the index of democracy as a factor in the business outlook stands particularly high," says the current review of The American Bankers Association Journal.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP). -- The Southern Pacfic Company today notified the Interstate Commerce Commission that it would accept conditionally terms on which the commission approved the acquisition of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway.

In yesterday's financial markets, the two most interesting movements of last week were carried further. Domestic bonds continued their gradual but deliberate advance; sterling moved up 2 cents further. Going above $3.53, exchange on London made the advance of the past two months more than 18 cents.

ALBANY, March 7. -- A legislative investigation of investment trusts was recommended in a report submitted to the Legislature tonight by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. Reciting the results of an inquiry into the investment trust field, with nearly $4,000,000,000 in total resources, the Attorney General asserted that the disclosures fully warranted action by the Legislature to protect the investing public.

Sposar Poolino, 27 years old, a waiter, of 118 West Third Street, was under arrest last night at the Elizabeth Street station, charged with extortion, and violation of the Sullivan law. Poolino was arrested in Washington Square Park.

LONDON, March 7. -- The stock market was irregular today. Some profit-taking was in evidence and Wall Street advices were not encouraging. The trend of prices on the Paris Bourse was disappointing and further selling orders from the continent were received in the afternoon.

A furious northwest gale that set in Sunday continued yesterday to lash the Atlantic seaboard. Accompanied by driving snow, it paralyzed communications in many sections ashore. It tore down telegraph and telephone lines, blocked highways and isolated towns, leveled trees and houses, delayed trains and caused accidents that took a toll of thirty-one lives.

BERLIN, March 7. -- The Boerse opened extremely quiet today, with distinct nervousness on all sides because of the forthcoming Presidential election. Later the market rallied somewhat following an upswing in mining stocks. The bond market was quiet throughout the day.

A furious northwest gale that set in Sunday continued yesterday to lash the Atlantic seaboard. Accompanied by driving snow, it paralyzed communications in many sections ashore. It tore down telegraph and telephone lines, blocked highways and isolated towns, leveled trees and houses, delayed trains and caused accidents that took a toll of thirty-one lives.

BERLIN, March 7. -- The Boerse opened extremely quiet today, with distinct nervousness on all sides because of the forthcoming Presidential election. Later the market rallied somewhat following an upswing in mining stocks. The bond market was quiet throughout the day.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 7. -- Both the Roosevelt and the Smith forces centred their final appeals tonight in Manchester on the eve of the State primary, the country's first test of the rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Miss Eleanor Holm of the Women's Swimming Association successfully defended her laurels as Metropolitan A.A.U. senior 300-yard medley champion and Walter Medville of the New York A.C. scored a close victory in the 220-yard free-style Junior title test at a water carnival in the 75-foot pool of the West Side Y.M.C.A. last night.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7. -- Sir Thomas Beecham, substituting for Arturo Toscanini as conductor at the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's final concert of the season here tonight in the Academy of Music, was greeted with prolonged and hearty applause.

PARIS, March 8. -- The Greek delegate to the international wine congress, whose sessions here are being attended by representatives of thirty nations, urged the congress today to recommend to wine-producing countries that all join in "a united trade boycott of the United States until the prohibition law is modified to allow the importation and consumption of wine."

CONCORD, N.H., Wednesday, March 9 -- Delegates pledged to the candidacy of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Democratic Presidential nomination carried New Hampshire in yesterday's Presidential preference primary with a sweeping victory over the delegate slate pledged to former Governor Alfred E. Smith, the 1928 nominee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Through renewed efforts of the Treasury Department, a further tax increase is assured to meet the evergrowing deficit of the government. That this tax is essential at this time is evidenced by the concerted effort of both the Republicans and the Democrats.

CHANGCHUN, March 8 (AP). -- President-designate Henry Pu Yi and Mme. Pu Yi have been installed in the new Presidential palace. They made a spectacular entry into their new capital today, passing through streets langely guarded by the alien soldiers of Japan.

CINCINNATI, March 8 -- Dr. R. Lee Bird, president of the staff of the Booth Memorial Hospital and a member of the Covington (Ky.) Health Department, died suddenly of heart disease at his home today. He wass 69.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the articles in your paper of recent date regarding the proposed curtailment of the school building program, I feel that some pertinent facts regarding this condition should be brought to the attention of the taxpayers of the city.

More than nine-tenths of the smoke particles now found in New York City come from relatively small fires in homes, apartment houses and small office buildings, and not from large factories and power plants as is generally supposed.

The gale that set in Sunday continued with but slight abatement yesterday. But the snow accompanying it either ceased to fall entirely or dwindled to mere flurries. The storm left its impress all through the East and took a toll of at least thirty-seven lives.

James A. Farley, chairman of the State Democratic Committee, has been reappointed as a member of the State Athletic Commission for a term of two years and has been re-elected chairman of the Boxing Board, it was learned yesterday. The reappointment of Commissioner William Muldoon was made simultaneously with that of Chairman Farley by Secretary of State Edward Flynn.

ROME, March 8. -- The Hungarian Foreign Minister, Ludwig Walko, had a long meeting with Premier Mussolini today at which Premier Tardieu's plan for economic relief of the Danubian States formed the chief subject of discussion.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 8. -- Admitting that his sole purpose in coming to Greenwich was to threaten his sister, Miss Ethel Armes of Greenwich Lodge, writer and historian, with a loaded revolver, Joseph H. Armes of 178 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty to carrying a concealed weapon in the Greenwich Town Court this morning.

State police and detectives searched twice yesterday the New Jersey State Village for Epileptics at Skillman, N.J., five miles from Princeton, in the hope of discovering the source of the lumber from which the three-section collapsible ladder used by the Lindbergh kidnappers was made.
To the Editer of The New York Times: Governor Pinchot's speech as reported in THE TIMES should not, in my opinion, be allowed to stand unchallenged.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. G. Herbert Walker have returned to the Pierre from their shooting lodge in South Carolina.
ALBANY, March 8 (AP). -- Another "liberal" jurist is to succeed Benjamin N. Cardozo as chief judge of New York's highest tribunal, the State Court of Appeals.

Major Charles A. Schoeffel, Deputy Superintendent of State Police, announced last night in Trenton that "progress" was being made in efforts to recover the kidnapped son of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh.

Recruiting of the army of Two Hundred Thousand in a campaign to fight misery in its last hidden retreats in this city is indeed a " great social enterprise." No one is to be drafted, but every one who is honored by being asked to serve as a " block leader " must feel conscripted both, by this opportunity and by his own desire to be of help to some family in need.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Vail Brokaw entertained tonight with a dinner at the Everglades Club. Their guests were:

Amid the barbaric splendor of Mr. Ziegfeld's familiar stage devices, Bert Lahr appears as a matador in "Hot-Cha!" which was put on at the Ziegfeld last evening. Mr. Lahr is one of the theatre's most comical fellows. As a matador who knows nothing of bull-fighting, Mr. Lahr's dazed belligerence is the heartiest horseplay the current season has given us; and if "Hot-Cha!" is only "warm-cha" in story and melody.

Ottorino Respighi, the distinguished Italian composer who arrived here last Sunday to conduct the premiere of his tryptich for concert, "Mary of Egypt," with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall on March 16, discussed yesterday afternoon various aspects of opera and musical tendencies in Italy.

TRENTON, N.J., March 8. -- Meeting in executive session today to consider nominations, the Republican majority in the Senate adopted a resolution calling upon Governor Moore to make bipartisan judicial appointments.

PEN HALLOWELL of Harvard ran a great mile in the "indoor intercollegiates." His time was 4:12.4 and the runners who have done better than that can be counted on the fingers of one hand. A fine lad, Pen Hallowell, and the Harvard rooters went wild over his achievement. Bill Bingham, head of athletics at Cambridge, was so excited at the finish that he walked around the armory floor biting pieces out of a program.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 8. -- Three Presidential decrees were issued yesterday concerning foreign exchange and banking.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP). -- Although operating revenues of the large railroads of the country decreased more than $1,000,000,000 in 1931, the Class I roads as a whole made more than enough to pay their fixed charges of that year, according to the Interstate Commerce Commission, which today made public summaries of tabulations by its Bureau of Statistics.

CHICAGO, March 8. -- The movement of hogs to market continues light, and with a good demand prices advanced 5 to 20 cents today to a new high since last November, the top showing 75 cents above the recent low. The top was 15 cents higher for the day, at $4.85, while the day's average was up 15 cents, at $4.50.

Sales of automobiles by the General Motors Corporation to consumers in the United States last month totaled 46,855 units, compared with 47,942 in January, 53,588 in December and 68,976 in February, 1931, according to the company's monthly tabulation, issued yesterday.

To assist Federal income taxpayers in making out their returns revenue agents have been assigned to banks, department stores and postoffices in Manhattan, in the Bronx, in Westchester County and throughout Long Island and on Staten Island.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Opposition to New York's ceding the Erie and Oswego Barge Canals to the Federal Government was voiced today in a report of the joint legislative committee on the proposed transfer, headed by Senator William J. Hickey of Buffalo.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., March 8 -- Mrs. Harriet Tiemann, 45, social registerite and widow of Hugh P. Tiemann, who died Jan. 4 from burns received when his bed clothes caught fire from a cigarette, was found shot to death this afternoon in her home in the King Edward apartments.

Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, whose play on the squash racquets court this season, has been adding to the fame she has acquired in lawn tennis and field hockey, won two matches without the loss of a game yesterday as the second annual invitation squash racquets tournament of the Junior League got under way with an entry of sixty-three players.
SHANGHAI. March 8 (AP). -- The big guns of the Woosung forts, targets of the shells from the Japanese warships for weeks, will bark no more against Japan.
WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Books on the Treasury's offering of $900,000,000 in certificates, opened Monday, were closed tonight by Secretary Mills, indicating there had been a large oversubscription.

The reaction of the business world to the new sales tax legislation pending in Congress was "both favorable and unfavorable here yesterday. Comment was withheld by some who had not found an opportunity to read carefully the text of the bill, which, according to Speaker John N. Garner, is likely to be passed by the House of Representatives next week.

The stock market advanced yesterday; its moderate rise was overshadowed by a decided show of strength in the market for home and foreign bonds and by further appreciation of 1/8 to 5/8 point in United States Government securities. But these movements of financial values were quite overshadowed by the rise in sterling, which gained 20 cents in gold value for the day.

Thomas L. Chadbourne, originator of the sugar control plan which bears his name, returned yesterday from Havana, silent on recent developments affecting that plan. Ha was emphatic in his denial, however, that those developments would lead him to resign as head of the National Sugar Export Corporation of Cuba.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 8 (AP). -- The "atomerg," a unit of matter smaller than anything hitherto known, was announced tonight in a new theory of matter by Dr. E.K. Plyler, Associate Professor of Physics of the University of North Carolina.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The arrest in Santiago today of Senor Davila aroused deep interest here. The news has not yet been received by either the State Department or the Chilean Embassy through official channel, however.

KEARNY, N.J., March 8 -- A fraud successfully operated for four years, which victimized at least two large corporations and netted its alleged perpetrators several hundred thousand dollars in merchandise, was disclosed today with the presentation of indictments for conspiracy by the Hudson County grand jury against six men.

Bail of $1,000 each was furnished in General Sessions yesterday when eleven former officials of the defunct World Exchange Bank, Second Avenue and Eleventh Street, pleaded not guilty to an indictment charging they had misappropriated funds of the bank before its closing in March, 1931.

Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. and John D. Rockefeller 3d joined the ranks yesterday of "block-alders" under command of the Block Community Organization, which la organizing an army of 100,000 volunteers throughout the city to seek "adoption" of families suffering under distress of unemployment.

VIENNA, March 8. -- A hint in the Italian reply to the French proposal for a Danubian bloc that it might better be restricted at first to Austria, Hungary and Czechoslovakia seems to have aroused apprehension in Czechoslovakia.

Dr. Louis M. Eilshemius, A.A.P., is having the time of his life. The first instalment of his two-reel show at the Valentine Gallery drew to a triumphant close last Saturday and now the second phase of the cycle is in full swing. The Valentine is thronged and every one, by no mean excepting Valentine Dudensing himself, the gallery's proprietor, is enthusiastic.
GENEVA, March 8. -- Conciliation strongly marked the first real business meeting of the World Disarmament Conference today, when the method of work which will be followed was adopted.

CASTLE HARBOUR, Bermuda, March 8 -- By their victories today, United States golfers defeated a British-Bermuda team in the two-day competition for the Castle Harbour Cup, registering a point of 19 1/2 to 4 1/2 for their opponents.

An analysis of the 1931 passenger traffic carried by seventeen leading transatlantic ship lines made by the Atlantic Conference of Brussels shows a total of 685,248 for the year, a reduction of 317,105 from the 1930 total of 1,002,353. The conference places the North German Lloyd Line at the head of the list in volume of traffic with a total of 117,671 and the Cunard Line second with 105,297.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., March 8 -- For the first time since the Giants opened their training season, John McGraw today was able to put on display all the component parts of the machine which he hopes to drive to a pennant and the world's series next Fall.
The quotations are for three-four months' paper.
BOSTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins, with a play-off berth probably depending on their play this week, were off to a great start tonight by defeating the Detroit Falcons, 2 -- 0.

PARIS, March 8 -- While messages poured in from all over the world and great and humble admirers filed past the bier of Aristide Briand who died yesterday, the French Government paid official homage in both houses of Parliament today to the dead statesman.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 8 (AP). -- Re-election of Charles P. Howard as president of the International Typographical Union by an overwhelming majority is indicated by complete unofficial returns of the primary held last month, international headquarters announced today.

LONDON, March 8 (Canadian Press). -- The army joined the navy today in making cuts in expenditure, with words of warning. Submitting the army estimates to the House of Commons, Captain A. Duff-Cooper, Financial Secretary to the War Office, made it clear they were framed to meet exceptional circumstsances and could not be taken as a standard for the future.

NEWARK. N.J., March 8. -- Vice Chancellor M. L. Berry continued today until final hearing a restraint against seven labor-union locals and a large number of individuals from interfering with work being done by the Rust Engineering Company in Weequahic Park here in connection with the Route 29 construction.

MADRID, March 8. -- Declaring that the United States, Spain and Russia constituted the three chief world experiments, Don Fernando de los Rios, Minister of Education, said today in an address at the American Club that the depression would lead the United States to economic and political reorganization.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., March 8. -- Referring to his interest in the arts. Otto H. Kahn, New York banker, declared in an affidavit filed here today that "these interests have never been with the expectation of personal financial gain, but solely with a view to encouraging artistic merit."

While a cheerful sentiment pervaded the security markets yesterday, the net gains in prices were narrow. The movement on the Stock Exchange was steadily upward most of the day; final prices were higher by about $1.40 on the average, figuring fifty stocks as the basis of computation.

The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company has apportioned $20,692,930 for payment to policy holders as dividends during the current year, comparing with about $19,500,000 paid last year, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 8 -- Columbia tied Princeton for first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race tonight by defeating Yale, 37 to 29, in a game which produced a series of the most brilliant scoring shots of the season in the Yale gymnasium.
The Hofstadter legislative committee will move today In the Supreme Court for an order requiring a Sheriff to bring State Senator John A. Hastings before the committee to testify early next week.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The "stop-Roosevelt" movement has made no headway, James A. Farley. chairman of the New York Democratic State Committee, said today, after conferring here with Senators and members of the House from different sections of the country.

A bridge and backgammon party will be given at the home of Mrs. Ernest Fahnestock, at 954 Fifth Avenue, on the afternoon of March 29 for the benefit of the Ladles' Christian Union. The entire proceeds will bo devoted to the activities of the organization, which was founded in 1858 to provide a homelike shelter for young Protestant business women at a modest rate.
