WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Hope that a national system of guaranteeing bank deposits may be devised, eliminating the unsound features of former efforts in that direction, was expressed by high government officials today, in commenting on the Steagall bill, introduced in the House yesterday, to safeguard the $28,000,000,000 in deposits of member banks of the Federal Reserve System.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Another postponement of the Stock Exchange investigation planned by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, deferring it until next week, became probable today as the Glass banking bill, which has priority over the investigation, neared completion at the hands of a subcommittee.

The Brooklyn Standard-Union has been sold by Paul Block to the publishers of The Brooklyn Daily Times, it was learned authoritatively last night. The public announcement is scheduled to be made today in the two papers. Negotiations for the transfer were concluded late yesterday, to take effect immediately, it was said, and the two papers were to be consolidated beginning probably tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 8 -- Two pilots of the Century Air Lines were killed and three others injured early today when a tri-Lycoming-motored Stinson plane, in which they were practicing night landings, struck a windmill at the edge of the Curtiss-Steinberg Field three miles south of East St. Louis.

In its concert at Carnegie Hall last night the Philadelphia Orchestra, under the direction of Eernardino Molinari, guest conductor, presented Corelli's suite from opus 5, transcribed for strings by Ettore Plnelli, Respighi's theme and variations, Debussy's "La Mer" and Strauss's "Till Eulenspiegel."
BRUSSELS, March 8 (AP) -- King Albert of the Belgians departed for Paris today to pay personal homage to Aristide Briand.
VIENNA, March 8. -- Need for some form of economic relief for Central Europe became more apparent today in Austria and Hungary.

MADRID, March 8 (AP). -- Senor de los Rios predicted today in his speech to the American Club that the United States would be reorganized along Socialistic lines, with gradual nationalization of the major utilities and abolition of industrial trusts.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 8 -- Under a strong ride by Jockey Salvatore Coucci. Liolele scored over Bennett Creech's Portcodine in the seven-furlong fourth race which featured today's program at the Agua Caliente track. Mucker was third. Liolele covered the distance in 1:25.

The Radio-Kelth-Orpheum Corporation, in the first statement of earnings issued since its reorganization last year, reported yesterday for 1931 a net loss of $5,660,770 after "extraordinary charges" of $2,577,834 md dividends of $461,473 paid on preferred stocks of subsidiary companies.

Hearings will be held today by the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund on proposals of Albert Goldman, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, to abandon two ferry lines, that between Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and East Twenty-third Street, Manhattan, and the one between Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, and South Street, Manhattan.

ABOARD U.S.S. AUGUSTA, SAN PEDRO, Cal., March 8 -- Units of the Black fleet under the command of Vice Admiral Arthur L. Willard, flying his flag from the cruiser Augusta, completed fueling and provisioning this morning and are prepared to leave San Pedro Harbor at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Opposition to new taxes proposed in the non-partisan bill introduced yesterday was rampant in the corridors of the Capitol today. Wherever two or more Senators or Representatives met in the cloakrooms, the halls and private offices they talked about the new levies.

Net earnings of the New England Power Association during the first quarter of 1932 will probably show a slight improvement over the first quarter of 1931, Frank D. Comerford, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the association, this despite the fact that industrial conditions in the territory served have been at low ebb throughout the Winter.

The reduction of consumers' electric light and power bills by $20,000,000 a year in New York City was askad yesterday by the City Affairs Committee in a brief filed with the Public Service Commission. The brief asked for immediate revocation of the existing rate schedules, their replacement by an intermediate set of rates to bring about the reductions asked, and a comprehensive rate investigation applicable to all the companies giving service here.

The Newtown High School basketball team, defending City P.S.A.L. titleholder, retained the Queens Division title by routing Richmond Hill, 39 -- 17, yesterday on the latter's court. The triumph was the eighteenth in a row in P.S.A.L. competition, in two seasons for Newtown and the eighth straight of this campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP). -- Grain exports last week from the United States amounted to 1,011,000 bushels against 436,000 bushels the previous week and 499,000 bushels during the corresponding week of last year.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, March 9 (AP). -- Rumors that the Japanese planned to occupy Nantao and other large areas on the southern side of Shanghai, along with reports of a new battle, stirred the Chinese populace into panic, today. Nanking dispatches said the people there also were nervous and a great exodus of the inhabitants was under way because of rumors that Japanese soldiers were marching on Nanking.

Phil Ragozzino of the Parish Club, New Utrecht High School middleweight, outpointed Andy Melia of the Long Island Moose in the 160-pound open class in the semi-finals of the Daily News A.A. Golden Gloves boxing tournament at Mecca Temple last night.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The House, by a vote of 363 to 13, tonight passed the La Guardia anti-injunction bill to curb the powers of Federal judges in labor disputes and prohibit "yellow dog" contracts between industrial concerns and employes whose welfare is not protected in the contracts.

Francesco M. Ferrari, former president of the defunct City Trust Company, owed $1,221,728 when he died on Feb. 1, 1929, according to a transfer tax report filed yesterday in Brooklyn. His gross assets were listed at $49,280. Funeral and administration expenses amounted to $11,510, and other expenses brought the total debt of the estate to $1,259,502.

The pound sterling, which has been gathering strength in the foreign exchange market since the announcement last week of the repayment by the British Treasury of 75 per cent of the New York banking credit of $200,000,000 obtained in August, broke away yesterday for a 20-cent rally, in the widest swing witnessed by the market since that exciting week last September when England suspended the gold standard.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 8 -- A young woman and two children were rescued from a two-alarm fire in the hardware store of Ernest Weiler here this morning shortly after the opening of the business day.

MANCHESTER, England, March 8 (AP) -- An increase of 622,000 bales in world consumption of American cotton in the six months ended in January, 1932, is shown in statistics to be published tomorrow by the International Federation of Master Cotton Spinners and Manufacturers' Associations.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP). -- The Senate today asked the Justice Department to report whether recent railroad consolidations have been in violation of the anti-trust laws and whether the proposed four-system Eastern consolidation would condone violations.

President HOOVER has been invited to the opening of the Port of Albany some time this year. United States engineers have done a great deal of dredging to provide a channel between Hudson and Albany, while the latter city has been constructing terminal facilities, bulkheads, warehouses, freight yards, new roadways and railroad spurs.

Several Chinese expert workmen and at least one Chinese architect will be needed to erect the reproduction of the Jehol lama temple for the Chicago World's Fair next year, it was revealed here yesterday by Dr. Sven Hedin, the Swedish scientist and explorer.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 8 -- A warrant charging murder was sworn out by a member of the Prosecutor's staff today for Louis Fine, 50 years old, accusing him of the slaying of Mrs. Mattie Schaaf, 60 years old, whose body was found in a trunk at Philadelphia yesterday.

HAVANA, Cuba, March 8 (AP) -- Closing strong in the stretch, Eveline F., a 5-year-old mare from S. Gorbet's stable, outclassed a field of platers in the one and one-sixteenth mile feature at Oriental Park today.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 8 -- The modified football rules have received real tests in a series of Spring practice games and at least two Southern experts said they saw little apparent difference in play.

Stock prices advanced generally yesterday on the New York Curb Exchange, few issues failing to respond to the movement. Domestic bonds were also improved throughout the list, while domestic bond prices were mixed.

DUBLIN, March 8 (AP). -- The Sinn Fein, organization of militant Republicans, repudiated Eamonn de Valera, Republican leader, tonight on the eve of his expected election to the Presidency of the Irish Free State.

MOSCOW, March. 8 -- Today was observed as "International Women's Day" throughout the Soviet Union, giving the Moscow press an opportunity to stress the progress made since the revolution in changing the status of women from semi-oriental slaves under the Czarist regime to free and equal citizens of the Bolshevist era.

The pamphlet report of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company for 1931 shows net income amounting to $2,360,209, after expenses, taxes and charges, equal to $1.22 a share earned on 1, 930,065 shares, compared with $2,534.566, or $1.31 a share, in 1930. Total revenues for 1931 were $4,007,738, against $4,258,178 in 1930.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, March 9 -- A force of 400 Japanese early last night attacked Chinese outposts at Lotuchiao, eastward of Taitsang, according to an official report from the front issued by the Shanghai Mayor's office. The fighting was said to be still proceeding, with Japanese cavalry participating in the attack.

BOSTON, March 8. -- The possibility of a compromise between the supporters of Alfred E. Smith and Governor Roosevelt in the Massachusetts contest for delegates seemed remote tonight after a day of many conferences among party leaders, at which trades and concessions were discussed.

The 50 per cent stock interest in the Columbia Broadcasting System heretofore owned by the Paramount-Publix Corporation has been acquired by a group headed by William S. Paley, president of the Radio chain, and including investment banking interests.
NEW ORLEANS, March 8 (AP) -- Bertjohn, E.R. Bradley's most consistent performer over the Winter turf, outclassed a field of rollers in the feature Golden Meadow Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

BERLIN, March 8. -- In anticipation of the Reichsbank lowering the discount rate, the Boerse opening was livelier today, prices advancing. Outside orders did not materialize, however, and the tone became sluggish. Closing quotations generally were slightly lower than on yesterday.

PARIS, March 8. -- French law students went on strike this morning in protest against a bill passed by the Chamber of Deputies reducing the scholastic requirements for applicants for licenses to practice law, but announced tonight that the strike would be terminated tomorrow evening.

LONDON, March 8 -- Despite the nation-wide outcry that it "do something" for Britain's maritime prestige, the government announced today that it could do nothing to help the Cunard Company resume work on its 73,000-ton liner, now lying half completed at Clydebank.

GENEVA, March 8. -- A general discussion ended in the League of Nation Assembly's commission tonight with assurance of a much stronger League warning to Japan than was generally expected when the Assembly began. It certainly will be stronger than Sir John Simon's speech yesterday indicated the British were willing to go.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The Federal Trade Commission, created by the government to regulate business by persuasive rather than punitive methods, faces a breakdown, according to its chairman, William E. Humphrey, if an impending $500,000 slash in appropriations for the next fiscal year goes through.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A $76,000,000 income tax case was brought before the Board of Tax Appeals today by the Transcontinental Oil Company and its chief stockholders, F.B. Parriott of Tulsa and M.L. Benedum of Pittsburgh, oil pioneers of the Southwest, who sought relief from a deficiency in that amount assessed by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Tribute to former Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes of the Supreme Court of the United States wag paid tonight in celebration of his ninety-first birthday anniversary by President Hoover, Cabinet and other high officials and leaders of the bar at home and abroad at the annual banquet of the Federal Bar Association at the Shoreham Hotel.

The year opened inauspiciously for the railroads, according to figures released by the Bureau of Railway Economics yesterday. These showed that 168 Class 1 railroads had net operating incomes of $11,713,000 in January, a drop of 65.9 per cent from the $34,341,000 in January, 1931.

It is not altogether paradox to say that the manner in which Japan has gone about setting up an " independent" Manchuria may help in the long run to affirm the essential unity between Manchuria and China. To select the former infant Emperor from the Dragon Palace at Peiping for the ruler of the new Manchuria is, after all, to emphasize the ancient connection.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Despite the business depression of the last two years, New York State's credit has remained "impregnable." Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, declared in his annual report to the Legislature today.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 8 -- With few close matches, the contenders for the women's Belleair golf championship advanced through the first round of match play, and Miss Bernice Wall of Oshkosh, Wis., last year's runner-up and medalist yesterday, was one of those to triumph on the Belleair No. 1 course today.

CHICAGO, March 8. -- Federal Agents today arrested Colombo Boris, Chicago anarchist, in the belief he as the man who on Dec. 30 mailed even bombs at the Easton (Pa.) postoffice and who also sent bombs to several Italian consuls, vice conils and leading citizens of Italian escent in a number of cities.

CHICAGO, March 8. -- The largest, single movement of relief supplies in the history of the nation started today a few hours after President Hoover had authorized the use of wheat from the Farm Board's bins.

"Stabilizing" Wartime Prices. It is a far cry from the proposal of a constitutional amendment by the Senate Judiciary Committee to adoption by two-thirds of both houses of Congress and ratification by three-fourths of the States.

WARSAW, March 8. -- Political circles here show uneasiness over the French proposal for a union of five Danubian countries -- Austria, Czechoslovakia, Rumania, Hungary and Yugoslavia -- under the auspices of Great Britain, France, Germany and Italy.
BERLIN, March 8 (AP). -- Germany's unemployed on Feb. 29 totaled 6,128,000, an increase of 1,000 in two weeks.

The American people pay more than one billion dollars annually for worthless stocks, and even the colossal slaughter of market values of the last two years has not taught the public caution, Watson Washburn and Edmund S. De Long write in "High and Low Financiers: Some Notorious Swindlers and Their Abuses of Our Modern Stock Selling System," published today by Bobbs Merrill.

DETROIT, March 8 (AP) -- Asserting there was "evidence of criminal syndicalism" in yesterday's fatal rioting at the Ford Motor Company's plant, Prosecutor Harry S. Toy today sought an immediate grand jury investigation into the clash between police and demonstrators in which four persons were killed and more than sixty were injured.

After Thomas M. Farley, former Sheriff, had testified yesterday at his trial on a charge of taking interest on funds held in escrow, Judge Freschl, in General Sessions, took under advisement a motion by defense counsel for the dismissal of the case.

CHICAGO, March 8. -- The Grain Stabilization Corporation has sold about 5,000,000 bushels of cash wheat to mills and others in the last few days, according to a report in the trade today and confirmed later by George S. Milnor, president of the corporation.

MIAMI, Fla., March 8 -- Billy Burke of Greenwich, Conn., national open champion, and Johnny Golden of Noroton, Conn., came through their hardest match of the week when they defeated Nell McIntyre of Indianap olis and Harry Hampton of Chicago in the semi-final round of the international four-ball tournament today.

The Saratoga Association has received a total of 2,385 entries for the twenty-five stakes which closed March 1, according to an announcement yesterday from Victor Schaumburg, racing secretary at both Saratoga and Belmont Park.

ALBANY, March 8. -- Measures embodying proposals of Governor Roosevelt and the Democratic program were slaughtered today in both houses of the Legislature. In the Senate the Republican majority voted down sixteen of these measures, while in the Assembly five of them were killed.

Amazing fellows, these Regional Plan engineers. On Sunday they announce that they are about to set out on an expedition to discover the population centre of New York, and on Tuesday they have it. The spot at which it would be easiest for the 6,930,446 inhabitants of the city (census of 1930) to come together, assuming complete freedom of direct access, is in Calvary Cemetery, Queens.

Miss Marion Lloyd of the Salle d'Armes Vince annexed the women's metropolitan fencing championship for the sixth consecutive year at the Fencers Club last night. She won in a field of fourteen contestants, capturing all four of her preliminary contests and all five of her final-round matches.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of March 6 the following is reported as President Hoover's attitude toward a proposal by Congress for a repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment:
BUCHAREST, March 8. -- At least seven trainmen were burned to death on the Bucharest-Constanza Line today when two petroleum trains were in collision, near the station of Fetesti.

Alderman Joseph Clark Baldwin, representative of the "silk-stocking" Fifteenth District, was assailed by his Democratic colleagues yesterday just before they snowed under his motion to call the Corporation Counsel and the Commissioner of Water Supply before the board to explain why the city's taxes on up-State property were unpaid.

BUDAPEST, March 8. -- A tragedy of the society and film world ended after ten years today when Judge Soltan de Szepessy, divorced husband of the late Lya de Putti, the film star, was found dead in a Budapest hotel with a bullet through the brain.

LONDON, March 8 -- The gold value of the pound sterling shot sensationally upward today from $3.53 1/2 to $3.71 1/2. In French exchange it rose from 90 1/8 francs to 94 3/4, while the Amsterdam rate rose from 8.79 1/2 florins to 9.24, In each case the closing rates were about the highest of the day.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The President made a statement about government economy at the White House this morning which the Democratic leaders in Congress immediately attacked as an "effort to assumie credit in advance" for any reduction in Federal expenditures which the Garner-Byrns committee on economy may be able to effect.

Nathan L. (Nigger Nate) Raymond, the gambler, was freed from the Tombs yesterday under $27,000 bail, pending outcome of his appeal to the Appellate Division from his recent conviction and sentence in General Sessions on a forgery charge growing out of the pledging of two allaged stolen stock certificates with a bank in 1928, on which he obtained a $7,200 loan.

The suit of Miss Mary Ryther of Sayville, L.I., against Harry R. Brevoort for $300,000 for breach of promise was "amicably settled" yesterday during a recess called in the Supreme Court when Mr. Brevoort wept on hearing testimony concerning the funeral of the late Robert Lefferts, his uncle.

Contests against Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, and Herbert N. Straus, organization candidates for delegates to the Republican National Convention from the Twentieth Congressional District, were revealed last night by the filing with the Board of Elections of designating petitions for Simeon D.

The Primavera Ball and a concert will be held tonight at the Plaza under the auspices of the Italian Historical Society in aid of that organization's educational work. The event is under the patronage of Dino Grandi, Italian Foreign Minister; Giacomo de Martino, the Italian Ambassador, and Donna de Martino and Emmanuels Grazzi, Italian. Consul General.

COLOGNE, Germany, Marct 6 (AP). -- Miss Margaret Halstead of Cincinnati, daughter of Albert Halstead, American Consul General at London, made her debut as a prima donna at the Cologne Opera tonight as Juliette in "The Tales of Hoffmann."

LONDON, March 8. -- The rise in the pound provided the outstanding feature of today's stock markets, helping to check profit-taking in British Government funds, which closed firm. Another effect of sterling's advance was a drop in the price of gold to the lowest since November.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- An additional petition has been filed by the government in its anti-trust action against the Radio Corporation and its associates, and the Department of Justice is preparing for a hearing in the case this Spring.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP). -- Contributions to the Republican National Committee in January and February totaled $53,654 and expenditures amounted to 534.666.

TOPEKA, March 8 (AP). -- Election by the Kansas Republican State convention of seven delegates at large, instructed to vote for renomination of President Hoover and Vice President Curtis, completed today the selection of all except two of the twenty-one members of the State's delegation to the party's national convention.

Money market was quiet, but firm. Stock Exchange call loans were held at 2 1/2 per cent all around, on the board and in the counter trading. Federal funds were 2@2 1/4. There was a good supply on offer, but demand was light. Time money market was dull and unchanged in quotation.

The growth of our Negro population, after showing a steadily downward curve for several decades, turned sharply upward after 1920. That is one of the findings, as pointed out by Professor S.J. HOLMES, in the current number of Science, in the preliminary figures for the last census.

A possibility that the kidnappers oF the Lindbergh baby crossed in a green coupe from Perth Amboy, N.J., to Tottenville, S.I., at about 10:45 P.M. on the night the baby was stolen from his crib at Hope-well, N.J., was revealed yesterday by information filed with the Port Authority.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 8 -- Governor Roosevelt issued a proclamation today calling upon Mayors and county officials throughout the State to aid in the "war-against-depression campaign" sponsored by the American Legion. The drive seeks to obtain jobs for 1,000,000 persons now out of work.

MONTREAL, Qua., March 8 (By The Canadian Press) -- Strong upward surge in the value of the pound sterling today featured developments on the foreign exchange market here. British funds, after opening at $3.99. rushed upward to $4.15 and closed at $4.1148, which compared with yesterday's final quotation of $3.9196.

BERLIN, March 8. -- The Reichs -- bank reduced its discount rate from 7 to 6 per cent and its collateral rate from 8 to 7 per cent today. The reduction had long been urged by the business community so that general Interest rates might be further brought down, but was deferred by the Reichsbank until it could be effected without endangering its foreign exchange position.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Governor Roosevelt elevated Associate Judge Cuthbert W. Pound of the Court of Appeals to the chief judgeship of the highest court in the State today. The nomination was immediately confirmed in the Senate by a rising vote.

The sensational advance in stering exchange yesterday stimulated addle business between the New York and Liverpool Cotton Exchanges, breaking foreign quotations arply while prices here closed only to 4 points lower than on Monday. the last week, May contracts in verpool have declined 35 English ints, while the May delivery here s sold 6 points higher than a week o.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 8 -- Francis J. O'Doul, the southpaw pitcher who converted himself into a slugging outfielder, played his first ball game of the training season today, and along with the more famous Hack Wilson was completely eclipsed by the largest rookie in camp.

BOSTON, March 8. -- President A. Lawrence Lowell of Harvard University appeared today at a hearing before the legislative committee on election laws at the State House in favor of the bill to establish a preprimary convention system. He strongly criticized the present system of nominating candidates.

The last of this season's Yorkvilie Dances aiding the maintenance of the Yorkville Community Association's social service activities war given last night in the main bath room of the Ritz-Carlton. Many dinners preceded the entertainment. The guests were received, by several members of the committee headed by Mrs. A. Mansfield Patterson with the assistance of Mrs. J.T. Johnston Mall.

The new petitions filed by the Department of Justice in the government anti-trust suit against the Radio Corporation of America and affiliated companies are considered by students of the case to have increased the difficulties of negotiators who have represented the radio interests and the department in attempts to effect a compromise.

Commuters formerly served by the Whitestone branch line recently abandoned by the Long Island Railroad announced yesterday that they had a definite proposal for the conversion of the line into a rapid transit shuttle under private franchise operation, without capital or maintenance cost to the city.

Detailed schedules showing how the city can rescind authorizations of funds amounting to $196,536,463,36 this year and finish the year with a surplus of $3,000,000 instead of the $43,700,000 deficit predicted by Controller Charles W. Berry were submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday as the departure point for the most drastio economy program ever undertaken by city authorities.

The New York Rangers gained ample revenge for their defeat at the hands of the Chicago sextet in Chicago last Sunday by triumphing over the Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 6,000 persons saw the Rangers launch a high-powered offensive at the start, tear into their rivals spiritedly and emerge with a 6-to-1 victory.

Impressive strength was displayed by virtually all sections of the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Trading was heavy, exceeding $13,500,000, compared with $10,657,700 on Monday. Five of the eleven United States Government bond issues active yesterday made new highs for the year and one duplicated the previous high mark.
WASHINGTON, March 8. -- An initial request of the Red Cross for 5,000,000 bushels of Farm Board wheat to help the needy of the South Dakota drought area was approved today by President Hoover.

In expressing yesterday his wholehearted desire to cooperate with Congress in reducing Federal expenditures, President HOOVER pointed to the difference between postponed outlays and actual reductions. Alluding to the fact that the House had cut under the Executive Budget by about $112,000,000, the President quietly stated that " between $60,"000,000 and $70,000,000 is a deferment "until Congress meets next "December, when they will be compelled "to meet positive obligations "by deficiency bills."
WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Unbelievable intolerance exists in presentday America, Dr. Cyrus Adler declared in a luncheon address at the National Conference of Jews and Christians here today.

American literature stands on a level with the strongest and richest if any literature in the twentieth century, as measured by creative values, Ludwig Lewisohn asserts in a book of criticism called "Expression in America" published today by Harper and Brothers.

MOSCOW, March 8 (AP) -- Soviet Russia seized upon "International Woman's Day" today to issue a call for 1,500,000 more women in industry in 1932 and to point out that more than one-third of all Workers in the Soviet Union are women, who number 6,000,000 in wage-earning activities.

A letter received last Thursday by Mrs. Anne Morrow Lindbergh demanding $50,000 for the safe return of her baby and a letter received in 1929 by Miss Constance Morrow, her youngest sister, demanding $50,000 under threat of kidnapping engaged the attention of detectives yesterday because of their striking similarity.

ST. PETERSBURG. Fla., March 8 -- George Selkirk, rangy outfield recruit from Jersey City, who on Saturday hit the first Yankee homer of the year, definitely established himself as the leading slugger of the squad to date by hammering a single and two doubles in today's 11-to-2 victory of Lou Gehrig's team over Babe Ruth's squad.

PARIS, March 8. -- Although the Bourse sustained further losses today, it showed greater strength than during yesterday's session. The domestic list opened with severe attacks on Generale Electricite, and offers of other French stocks became numerous.

One sees the lawyers and courts of Scotland through a sort of eighteenth-century rosy haze: through SCOTT and STEVENSON and that rogue " BOZZY." The judges must be " hanging " or eccentric; witty, anyway. The stream, of claret is as broad as the Fortn, Faces are flushed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: New York's Negro population is rapidly approaching a desperate crisis. In the closely packed district north of Central Park more Negroes are living than there are people in the whole city of Syracuse.

Two men were under arrest and a third had a bullet wound in the arm after a raid yesterday afternoon on the offices of the Needle Trade Workers' Industrial Union, on the third floor at 131 West Twenty-eighth Street.

MOSCOW, March 8 -- That the attempt on the life of the Counselor of the German Embassy, Dr. Fritz von Twardofsky, last Saturday was really aimed at his chief, Ambassador von Dirksen, is now accepted in well-informed circles here.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 8. -- Declaring that Aristide Briand, French statesman who died yesterday, had taken great pains to organize a "United States of Europe," Winston Churchill, former British Chancellor of the Exchequer, told an audience of 1,500 at the Westchester County Centre tonight, that joint action should be taken by the United States and Great Britain to oppose any dangers which might result from a union of the nations of Europe.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Governor Roosevelt will send a special message to the Legislature tomorrow recommending a bond issue in an amount tentatively fixed at $30,000,000 for unemployment relief. The message, it is believed, will be accompanied by two tentative bills, drafted to embody alternative plans for raising the money.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A vote probably will be taken by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee tomorrow on the proposal for American adherence to the World Court, but the lines are so closely drawn that neither the friends nor opponents of the court are sure of the outcome.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The separate views of the wet minority of the Wave and Means Committee relating to the proposed tax on 2.75 per cent beer were submitted to the House today as follows:
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The separate views of the wet minority of the Wave and Means Committee relating to the proposed tax on 2.75 per cent beer were submitted to the House today as follows:

MIAMI, Fla., March 8 -- O.A. Simmons's Griffin, gelded son of John P. Grier -- Coretta, had a comparatively easy time winning the featured Bocaratone purse at Tropical Park today. Hank Mills, leading jockey of the meeting, rode the winner, scoring his fourteenth victory of the session.

MONTREAL, March 8 -- The New York Americans were practically pushed out of the race for a National Hockey League play-off berth when the Canadiens heat them, 6 -- 1, tonight. The Americans can still win a berth mathematically, but with the defeat they fell six points behind the third-place Maroons in the international group.
The Regional Plan Association announced yesterday that its engineers had located the exact centre of population in New York City.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Loans by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to financial institutions, railroads and agriculture now total $183,800,000, according to information, made available at the White House today. Loans to 255 banks, trust companies, building and loan and other finance bodies aggregate $61,800,000, and of this amoutt the majority went to small country banks.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont arrived on the Majestic and are at the Ritz-Carlton.

TOKYO, March 9. -- The Russo-Japanese situation in the North has been clouded in mystery for some time, but it is asserted in official circles here that when the veil of mystery lifts it will reveal only the Soviet Government's old obsession of the imminence of an attack by capitalist powers.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Brig. Gen. William E. Cole, now in command of the Hawaiian Separata Coast Artillery Brigade at Fort Da Russy, was assigned by the War Department today to command the Second Coast Artillery District in New York City. He will succeed Brig. Gen. Henry J. Hatch, who recently died. General Cole will take up his new duties in October.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The leading article in THE TIMES this morning deserves attentive consideration. Waves of emotion are not uncommon in this country. They come swiftly and disappear as suddenly, leaving little mark on the great society which gives them expression.

PARIS, March 9. -- The French quota system of limiting imports was denounced as a restriction on trade "not consistent with the policy of the International Chamber of Commerce" by Silas Strawn, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, speaking this afternoon before the American Chamber of Commerce in Paris.

De La Salle, Xavier, Chaminade and St. Francis last night triumphed in the opening round of the Metropolitan Catholic High Schools basketball tournament conducted by Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, at its clubhouse in Brooklyn.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 9. -- Edward Rotan of Yale, unlimited-weight wrestling champion, will be unable to defend his title in the Eastern intercollegiate tournament at Syracuse Friday and Saturday because of an injured back.

LONDON, March 9. -- The pound sterling continued to rise sharply at the opening of the foreign exchange market today, but there was a marked reaction in the afternoon, the result of profit-taking. The New York rate was up to $3.77 at one time, but dropped to $3.70 1/4, which was below yesterday's closing figure.

The $149,000 which young Edward Daugherty of Brooklyn won nearly two years ago on a $1 sweepstakes ticket was divided with his father yesterday in a settlement made after a conference with Supreme Court Justice Norton in Brooklyn. It was reported that Dominic Daugherty, the father, who was a doorman in a Brooklyn apartment house when his son a $20-a-week clerk, won the money, is to receive $22,500 and interest.

ALBANY, March 9. -- With a bill already passed in the Senate to set up a new State park commisison to have jurisdiction over existing and proposed parks along the St. Lawrence, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Conservation Commissioner, said today that constitutional amendment would be necessary to insure full powers for the suggested regional board.
VALPARAISO, March 9 (AP). -- Senor Davila was being held incommunicado under a police guard today while authorities conducted an investigation into his political activities.

The section of the west side express highway extending from Fifty-ninth Street to Seventy-second Street and Riverside Drive was formally dedicated to public use yesterday by Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan. After addresses and a parade in which military units and city departments participated, Mr. Levy opened the new traffic artery to the public by cutting a white ribbon stretched across the roadway at Seventy-second Street.

Canvases by Jack Yeats, one of the best known of Irish artists, are being shown in the main painting gallery at Ferargil's until March 14. Here is a romantic artist in the fullest sense, romantic in subject matter, romantic in subjective approach, especially romantic in the fullness of color and the richness of matiere.

"Writing is the only art today that is taken seriously; speaking generally, music, painting and architecture have had their day," Jacob Epstein, American-born artist who is considered by many the greatest living sculptor and by others the "leader of a cult of ugliness," declares in his book, "The Sculptor Speaks," which Doubleday, Doran publishes today.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 7:

Two books designed to present authoritative and up-to-date accounts of the Japanese and Chinese positions in the present controversy in the Far East are announced for publication soon by Macmillan. The first to appear -- it will be published March 14 -- will be "Japan Speaks on the Sino-Japanese Crisis," by K.K. Kawakami, author of several books on Japan.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Moving with speed under the guidance of Representative Mead, chairman of the Postoffice Committee, the House today passed five bills to increase Postoffice Department revenues $11,750,000 annually. Mr. Mead, a Democrat, was the author of one of the bills, and Representative Kelly and Representative Kendall, Republicans, of Pennsylvania, sponsored the other four.

If half the delegates elected in the New Hampshire primaries had been Smith men, there would have been tremendous jubilation among his partisans. If he had even carried the First Congress District they would have made a joyful noise. His strength lay in the cities.

Charging that an unfair protective tariff and other political factors were causes of reduced earnings of the American Sugar Refining Company last year, Earl D. Babst, chairman of the company's board of directors, submitted its annual report yesterday to stockholders.

ALBANY, March 9. -- The capture of the eight delegates to the Democratic National Convention from New Hampshire by Governor Roosevelt in yesterday's primary is viewed by his friends here as a blow at the "stop-Roosevelt" movement from which it may not recover.

As was not unexpected, Tuesday's violent rise in sterling was followed by reaction yesterday; the sight rate declined to $3.63 3/8, as compared with the previous day's high point of $3.73 1/2 and Monday's closing of $3.52 7/8. The other impressive movement of the week, the advance in bond market prices, was not arrested; in some respects, the advances yesterday were even more emphatic.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Silence descended today upon the Democratic group of capital politicians who favor a Presidential candidate other than Governor Roosevelt of New York when they read the returns of the New Hampshire primaries.
PROVIDENCE, March 9. -- Governor Ritchie of Maryland called for budget reform and a lessening of government expenditures in a speech before the Rhode Island Bankers' Association here tonight.

Miss Beatrice Moore of the Montelair A.C., whose severity of stroke and great activity had established her as one of the leading contenders in the invitation squash racquets tournament of the Junior League, met with unlooked-for defeat yesterday as play came down to the quarter-finals on the league courts, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

Columbia started Its Spring outdoor football drill on the wind-swept gridiron at Baker Field yesterday and thirty candidates worked out under the direction of Coach Lou Little. The session lasted about an hour and a half and there was not an idle second, as the men went through their chores for the additional reason of keeping warm.

A sparkling victory by George Fissler of the New York A.C. in the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior 500-yard free style swimming championship featured a water carnival in the 25-yard Winged Foot pool last night.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9. -- Caerleon, a 3-year-old son of Sir Gallahad III and Fairy Wand, making the first start of his career, and made a 2-to-5 choice in a field of twelve maiden 2-year-olds, just galloped to win by ten lengths with Pete Walls doing the riding today in the second race at Tropical Park.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial entitled "Emotion and Action" is deserving of nationwide attention. It is high time that intelligent leadership should cry out against gang rule.

The "lack of sufficient regular family income to insure health and at least a minmum of decency and comfort" is listed first among five major causes of crime and delinquency in 1931 by the year book of the National Probation Association, made public yesterday.

The directors of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., took no action yesterday with respect to the quarterly dividends usually declared at this time on the $7 and $6 preferred stocks, ordinarily payable on April 1. The company has never paid dividends on the common stock and no payments have been made on the second preferred stock for any quarter since the period ended Sept. 30, 1930.
AMIENS, France, March 9 (AP). -- The battlefields of France are slowly yielding the bodies of some of the many thousands of soldiers still marked "missing" on army rolls.
MANILA, March 9 (AP). -- Governor General Roosevelt warned the Filipinos today of two economic dangers which he said were threatening them.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 9. -- Yale's freshman swimming team closed a perfect season today, defeating the Harvard freshmen in the Harvard tank, 44 -- 31. The New Haven cubs won the 200-yard relay to open the meet and, although the score was tied at 15 -- 15 in the first three events, the Yale team was always ahead after that.

NEW HAVEN, March 9. -- Yale and Harvard brought their thirty-second annual hockey series to a close in the New Haven Arena tonight by engaging in a lively 4-4 tie. A crowd of 2,500 persons witnessed the overtime battle, which was the second tie game of the season between the teams.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- President Hoover replied in conciliatory fashion today to the declaration of yesterday by Representative Byrns, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, that the President had not cooperated with the House Economy Committee.

Few contests for delegates to the national conventions of either the Republican or Democratic parties were revealed in the lists available from up-State yesterday. The petitions were filed at the office of the Secretary of State in Albany, with the exception of two Buffalo districts and Rochester.

PARIS, March 9. -- France today restored the embargo on fresh fruit, which the United States Embassy succeeded in getting lifted only a few years ago after it had been applied for ten years. This will mean a loss to the United States of millions of dollars from apples, pears and grape-fruit.

SALEM, N.J., March 9. -- The unprovked slaying today of a Negro woodchopper, which the police declare was inspired by fear of exposure, led to the discovery of the body of a white man in a lonely part of the woods about five miles from here and opened a State-wide search for a hatless man in a red sweater, driving a red coupe, who is wanted here in a double murder mystery.

ALBANY, March 9. -- The Legislature sped today through heavy calendars as Governor Roosevelt and the Republican leaders reached an accord on the two major problems still requiring action. They agreed on a program for financing continued unemployment relief and general lines for measures increasing the tax on buses and heavy motor trucks.

More than 1,500 editors and executives of school publications throughout the country are expected to attend the annual three-day convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association which will begin today at Columbia University, it was announced yesterday by Joseph M. Murphy, director of the convention.

The Standard Union, Brooklyn evening newspaper, published since 1863, was absorbed yesterday by The Brooklyn Daily Times, also an evening newspaper. The sale price was not announced by Paul Block, publisher of The Standard Union, or by Fremont C. Peck, publisher of The Daily Times.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The stock market investigation planned by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee definitely went over until next week because of difficulties encountered today in rewriting the Glass banking bill. This measure has precedence over the investigation.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- Traders on the Board of Trade here were surprised today at a development in the export business in corn, about 120,000 bushels being sold for shipment from Norfolk or Newport News. There bad been intimations of some inquiry, but today's was the first actual export business in volume in many months, and it led to fairly general local and commission house buying of futures.

NEWARK, N.J., March 9. -- Five teams entered the semi-final and final rounds in their respective sections tonight in the New Jersey State interscholastic basketball tournament. In class A, group 2, Rutherford defeated East Rutherford in Newark, 27 to 18, to reach the last round.
William A. Irvin, a 58-year-old steel master, who began his career as a telegraph operator, will succeed James A. Farrell as president of the United States Steel Corporation on April 19.

More than 550 families have been "adopted" through the efforts of the women's division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, of which Mrs. August Belmont is chairman, it was reported yesterday.

PARIS, March 9. -- The apartment on the Avenue Kleber Where Aristide Briand died Monday regained most of its wonted quiet today after two days in which thousands filed past his bier and innumerable floral tributes and messages from the world over poured in.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 9. -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club basketball team for the third year in succession clinched the championship of the Eastern Athletio Club League when it rallied and defeated the Montclair A.C. five, 36 to 31, before a capacity crowd of 500 in the Montclair gymnasium tonight.

VIENNA, March 9. -- Former Chancellor Ignaz Seipel, Austria's leading post-war statesman and as the leader of the Christian Socialist party perhaps the leading influence in determining her policy, broke a silence of almost two years' duration today to give the correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES his opinion of Premier Tardieu's plan for creating a preferential economic bloc in Central Europe.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Do the people of Long Island realize that the sums already authorized by the Legislature this year for the benefit of the ten State park commissions are, to Long Island, $3,694,833, or 73.7 per cent; to all the other State park commissions, $1,321,155, or 26.3 per cent?

ABOARD U.S.S. AUGUSTA, SAN FRANCISCO, March 9. -- Steaming slowly past the San Pedro breakwater into the wide mouth of the Pacific, the airplane carrier Lexington, two destroyers and ten cruisers of the Black Fleet left the adobe bungalows and stucco houses of Los Angeles astern this morning and shaped their course west-by-north for the swells of the open ocean.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 9. -- Figures from the pages of history, folklore, nursery rhymes, songs and ballads assembled tonight in the Orange Gardens and dining hall of the Everglades for the annual costume ball, the most brilliant event of the Winter preceded by a grand march and featured by supper at midnight.

ESSEN, March 9. -- In many parts of Germany your correspondent has studied the rising tide of National Socialism, listened to Nazi speakers, visited the universities, where youth is fired by the Nazi movement, questioned Adolf Hitler and other leaders about Nazi aims and sought vainly to discover the specific economic program of the party, which its leaders say is in process of preparation.

Delaware Hudson. The Delaware Hudson Railroad Corporation reports for the quarter ended on Dec. 31 a net income of $381,136, or 74 cents a share, against $256,810, or 50 cents a share, in the same period a year previous. The statement follows:
The French liner Lafayette is due today from Havre and Plymouth. Among the passengers are:

Trading on the Stock Exchange was slow yesterday, and the heaviness which developed in the afternoon was due more to lethargy than to selling pressure. That, at least, was the Wall Street judgment. The net decline in the composite price average was only about $1; in only a handful of active issues was the loss greater than that.

There are 130,000,000 cases of disabling illness in the United States each year and an equal number of illnesses not producing disability, an average of two illnesses for each member of the population, but the actual distribution is so uneven that a certain number carry a heavy burden of expense while others pay little or nothing at all, it was asserted last night at a special meeting at the New York Academy of Medicine.

LONDON, March 9. -- The probable starting field for the Grand National Steeplechase, which will be run over the historic Aintree course Friday, March 18, was reduced to thirty-nine with the announcement of the final acceptances today.

BOSTON, March 9. -- Proof that Washington was the bravest man of his day because he picked ihs wife's dresses and "Martha liked them" was submitted to the Massachusetts School of Art today by Dr. Albert Bushnell Hart, Professor Emeritus of History at Harvard and historian of the George Washington Bicentennial Commission.
DUBLIN, March 9. - -Eamonn de Valera, New York-born rebel leader of former years, became President of the Irish Free State Executive Council today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 9. -- Hennann Fougner, a widely known Norwegian engineer, who built concrete ships for the government during the World War, died this morning at the New York Medical Centre of ailments resulting from a fall in January.

The cold wave which swept In last Sunday on the heels of a blustering northwest gale tightened its grip on the country yesterday and brought to New York its coldest day of the Winter. The thermometer here reached its minimum, 14 degrees, at 6:30 A.M., while the maximum, recorded at 2:45 P.M., was only 28.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 9. -- Yale swimmers tonight defeated Harvard, 53 to 18, In the final dual meet in the historic Carnegie pool before it is demolished.

LOS ANGELES, March 9. -- Surrounded by an array of some two score young men and a couple who are crowding beyond the 40-year mark, two tall, slender fellows started firing a ball today on Wrigley Field into the big, round mitt of J. Francis Hogan.

Towering apartment houses to replace residences on large suburban estates are proposed by Electus D. Litchfield of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects. Natural advantages thus would be preserved when a city expands, instead of resulting in bare plots for small houses, Mr. Litchfield maintains.

MEXICO CITY, March 9 (AP). -- Coinage of more silver money to relieve a shortage of currency in Mexico and stabilize the exchange situation as the first step in a reconstruction program was said tonight by Finance Minister Alberto J. Pani to have the approval of General Plutarco Elias Calles, president of the Bank of Mexico, and of Pascual Ortiz Rubio, President of Mexico.

Edward Gordon Craig, the son of Ellen Terry, makes one more attack on George Bernard Shaw in his book, "Ellen Terry and Her Secret Self," published today by Dutton. He charges that Shaw betrayed Ellen Terry by publishing their correspondence and pictures, the playwright as a mercenary journalist preying on the sympathies of his friends to advance his own reputation.

The War Department notified the city yesterday that it would not proceed with its $700,000 project for the construction of jetties at the entrance to Long Island's inland waterway at East Rockaway Inlet unless immunity was granted by the city from responsibility for possible damage by erosion.
BERLIN, March 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of March 7 shows the following changes for the week in reichsmarks:

Soviet Russia's six million women workers are said to constitute one-third of all the wage earners in that country. This high ratio of one woman employe to every two men is characteristic of all nations in an early stage of Industrial development.

The foreign exchange market subsided yesterday after the excited run-up in sterling that featured Tuesday's business. The British exchange was erratic, with offerings outweighing demand, in contrast to the one-way movement of the previous day, and the final quotation of $3.69 1/2 was down 1 cent.

The Crescent Athletic - Hamilton Club hockey sextet defeated the New York A.C., 5 to 1, last night at the New York Coliseum and thereby broke the tie for the lead that had existed between the teams in the Metropolitan Amateur Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The cost of running the municipal departments of Yonkers, N.Y., in 1930 was $8,820,210, or $65,09 per capita, the Census Bureau announced today. The corresponding per capita cost in 1929 was $63.83, and in 1917 $24.08.

In debating the policy of his Government before the Chamber of Deputies, Premier TARDIEU made one statement which was received with laughter and applause. His reference was plainly to the coming general election in France. He said:

Easier conditions prevailed in the call loan market with the return, of the Strest rate to 2 1/4 per cent, accommodation at this figure not being available on Tuesday due to scanty offerings. However, the Stock Exchange charge remained at 2 1/2. Federal funds dropped to 1 3/4, from 2, on Tuesday.
NEW ORLEANS, March 9 (AP). -- E.R. Bradley's B'ar Hunter, an extreme outsider in the betting stepped a mile in 1:39 3-5 to win the feature Francisco Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

WARREN, Ohio, March 9 (AP). -- Trial of Dowell Hargraves and John De Marko, charged with kidnapping 11-year-old James De Jute of Niles, was set today for next Monday. The trial had been tentatively scheduled for tomorrow.

Controller Charles W. Berry took the credit for originating vital points In the city's financial retrenchment policy in a statement he issued yesterday expressing his gratification over the Board of Estimate's action in preparing to rescind $196,536,463 in public improvement authorizations.

A review of the relations of non-member States with the League of Nations in 1931 clearly indicates greater readiness to cooperate in its work, even if a disposition to enter the League has not been eager. It is chiefly through the League that non-members (the United States, Russia, Turkey, Brazil, Ecuador and others) have been able to take part in organized international life.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- A report on aid given to improve the real estate situation was requested from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today in a resolution adopted by a subcommittee of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Without discussion and by unanimous consent the House today passed the Cochran bill providing for twenty years' imprisonment or $5,000 fine for using the mails to extort or demand money on threat of harm. The measure is a "companion" to the kidnapping bill now before the House Judiciary Committee, which would legalize the death penalty for transporting a kidnapped person across State lines.

DETROIT, March 9. -- At a conference of county officials today it was decided to hold a grand jury investigation into the cause of rioting at the Ford Motor Company Monday afternoon, when four persons were killed, and fifty, including several policemen, were injured, some seriously.

When Jean Borotra of France begins the defense of his national indoor tennis championship Saturday at the Seventh Regiment Tennis Club, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, he will find the strongest field opposed to him that has competed for the title since 1926.

CALCUTTA, March 9 (AP). -- The dying wish of two Moslem youths who were hanged for murder and the fortitude they displayed in their final hours saved Calcutta today from what police had feared would develop into a bloody riot.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 9. -- A new plan of administrative organization for Massachusetts Institute of Technology was adopted at a meeting of the corporation this afternoon, it was announced by President Karl T. Compton.

GENEVA, March 9. -- When a question was put today in a conversation with Arthur Henderson, president of the disarmament conference, as to when the conference was likely to end, he replied, wearily: "What I would like to know is when It is going to begin."

Tammany influence inspired the refusal of the Board of Education to permit the use of the Erasmus Hall High School auditorium by the Brooklyn Citizens' Committee for a meeting March 19 at which Mayor Russell Wilson of Cincinnati is to speak on the city-manager plan, it was charged yesterday at a protest meeting of the committee at Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn.

It is Stuart Davis's own and unique version of "The American Scene" that one finds currently dramatized at the Downtown Gallery. The subjects dealt with are such old and tried favorities as "Jefferson Market," "Drying Sail," "House and Street" and "Building and Bridge."
The first of the expected reductions in interest paid by local savings banks were announced yesterday when several institutions acted upon the rate of distribution for the quarter ending on March 31.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- Further progress in the national campaign against hoarding was reported today at the offices of the Citizens' Reconstruction Organization set up by President Hoover in an effort to bring out hidden money and put it to work.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted:
LOS ANGELES, March 9 (AP). -- Mary Nolan, film actress, faces the immediate possibility of imprisonment as the result of her conviction today of eight violations of State labor laws.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Ways and Means Committee's unanimous recommendation for passage of the $1,096,000,000 tax bill was laid in report form before the House today and consideration of the measure will begin tomorrow.

Leases of space for business purposes in widely scattered sections of Manhattan were announced yesterday. Some of the contracts reported by real estate brokers and managing agents of buildings were for entire floors.

Total assets of the Provident Loan Society of New York increased $1,000,000 from $31,354,237 to $32,354,237 in 1931, and the society made 530,805 loans, in comparison with 530,905 in the preceding year. The amount of the loans was $36,162,710, against $41,847,770 in 1930.

PARIS, March 9. -- It is becoming more and more evident that the Tardieu Government is undertaking one of the most determined bids for international amity made by any French Government since the last one which Briand headed.
HAVANA, March 9 (AP). -- G.F. Jenkins's Hypoiuxo, a 6-year-old son of High Time, was an easy winner of the six-furlong race, which featured the card at Oriental Park today.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 9. -- Clashes between Smith and Roosevelt supporters today split the Democratic State Convention wide open and resulted in the withdrawal of the Smith group to hold a convention of their own. The result will be two sets of Minnesota delegates to the national convention, one supporting Smith and the other Roosevelt.

The Barge Canal. The Barge Canal is likely to remain the property of New York State for a long time to come. There was a move not long ago to transfer this white elephant to the Federal Government; a modified constitutional amendment actually passed the Legislature.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater New York reiterated its demand yesterday for open and flexible competition among transportation lines on water and rail in a unanimous vote in opposition to two bills recently introduced in the Senate by Senator Hiram Johnson and to the railroad consolidation plan under which the Eastern roads would be combined in four large systems.

HOPEWELL, N.J., March 8. -- From 10 o'clock this morning until well after darkness fell tonight State troopers in uniform and plainclothes and detectives from near-by cities combed the heavily wooded sections of Sourland Mountain in the vicinity of Zion, a small community north-east of Hopewell and about three miles in the same direction from the Lindbergh estate.

Slow but definite improvement in the steel industry is reported by The Iron Age in its weekly review. The operating rate for the country is estimated at 27 per cent of ingot capacity, compared with 26 per cent the week before.

LONDON, March 9. -- Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., a $250,000,000 British concern founded after the World War to rationalize British chemical manufacturing houses and exploit the analine dye and other trade secrets won from Germany, has concluded an agreement of farreaching importance with Continental dye manufacturers, it was learned here tonight.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 9. -- Five persons were injured in a fire early this morning which wrecked a dwelling at 209 North Seventh Avenue. Rescues by police and firemen and the heroism of a mother who dropped her two children from a second-story window to the arms of a neighbor, resulted In the seven occupants of the house escaping death.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, March 9. -- In an elaborate ceremony, said to have been arranged and paid for by Japanese agents, Henry Pu Yi, former boy Emperor of China, was inaugurated at 3 o'clock this afternoon as chingchen (dictator) of Manchoukuo, as the new Manchurian state is to be known.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Department of Commerce was informed today by R.C. Miller, commercial attache at Brussels, that the Belgian Cabinet had approved a proposal for increasing most import duties by 15 per cent of the existing duties, and that the approval of Parliament was expected soon.

Two robbers, who posed as celling inspectors, gained entrance yesterday afternoon to an apartment on the ninth floor of 749 West End Avenue, tied up the Negro maid and escaped with jewelry valued at $1,000 and $100 in cash.

Despite a decrease during February in the number of bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange from 1,595 to 1,592, the market value of the listed issues increased $975,129,481 during the month, according to the Exchange's compilation, issued yesterday.

Decision was reserved yesterday by United States Commissioner Pay in Federal Court in Brooklyn in the case of Edward J. Atwell, secretary to Borough President John A. Lynch and former Sheriff of Richmond County, and a business associate, who are charged with violating the Volstead act.

AMSTERDAM, March 9. -- The management of the A.K.U. factories at Arnhem and Ede. one of the largest European rayon concerns, announces a 20 per cent reduction in production resulting in the dismissal of a great number of workers at both plants.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP). -- Stocks of wheat on farms March 1 were estimated by the Department of Agriculture to have aggregrated 207,323,000 bushels, or 23.1 per cent of the previous crop.

New nigh levels for the year were reached yesterday in prices of many issues representing all sections of the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Nine of the dozen United States Government bonds that were active rose fractionally to fresh tops for 1932, as did more than forty foreign loans and a sizable list, of domestic corporation issues.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Prominent Democrats will participate in a Democratic rally in Washington on Jefferson Day, April 13, the plans for which were announced today by the Democratic National Committee.

Reynolds Forsbrey, 46 years old, the slayer who was released on a commuted sentence from Sing Sing last July by Governor Roosevelt, was sentenced to another life term yesterday by Judge Nott in General Sessions on his conviction last week by a jury for taking part in a holdup.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- An agreement between member lines of the North Atlantic-Spanish Conference and members of the North Atlantic-United Kingdom Freight Conference by which the latter carriers agree to maintain the direct rates, terms and conditions established by the former on shipments from North Atlantic ports to Spain and transshipped at United Kingdom ports was approved today by the hipping Board.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 9. -- The arrest of former Ambassador Carlos Davila, followed by his transfer to Valparaiso under heavy guard, has revived feverish rumors concerning the activities of opposition groups against the government.

IT'S getting a little late in the season, but the recent drop in temperature is sufficient excuse for a little whirl on skates. The Stanley Cup contest is up ahead and this very evening the star-spangled Americans will try to salvage a little something from a sad season by humbling the Rangers on the Garden ice.

LONDON, March 9. -- The orgy of speculation in the British pound reached its climax around 11 A.M. today when the New York rate touched $3.77 and the Paris rate 96 3/8 francs. Purchasers of sterling in the last few days then decided to take profits and at the close the New York rate was steady at $3.69 3/4 and the Paris rate at 94 francs.

Fred H. Bartels, a prison keeper on Hart's Island for forty-nine years, received a gold watch, gold pen and pencil at a farewell ceremony to mark his retirement at the age of 70. The function was held in the office of Richard C. Patterson Jr., Commissioner of Correction.

Sterling Gain Aids Foreign Trade, The sharp advance in pound stepling quotations this week was described as the most encouraging foreign trade development of the last six months by executives of leading importing and exporting houses here yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9. -- Playing through a series of showers Tommy Armour of Detroit, British open champion, and Ed Dudley of Concordville, Pa., won the international four-ball tournament over the course of the Miami Country Club today, defeating Billy Burke, national open titleholder, and Johnny Golden of Noroton, Conn., by 3 and 2.

Cruelty is a fundamental trait of human nature, and the highest expression of our culture is the alleviation of suffering, Dr. E.H. Lewinski-Corwin, director of the Hospital Information and Service Bureau of the United Hospital Fund, declared last night at graduating exercises for the class of 1932 of the School of Nursing of the New York Post Graduate Medical School and Hospital.

All of the required new cash capital that had been sought on behalf of the Federation Bank and Trust Company has been underwritten and the bank will be reopened later in the month, it was announced last night at a meeting of stockholders at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, March 10. -- Japan made the first move to negotiate with China in accordance with the terms of the League Assembly's resolution of March 4. Last evening Sir Miles Lampson, British Minister to China, handed to Quo Tai-chi, Vice Foreign Minister of China, a formal note from Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Minister, saying the Japanese civil and military authorities were ready to open direct negotiations in accordance with the terms of the Geneva resolution.

Stocks on the Curb Exchange inclined toward weakness in the later trading, but there was a strong tone in the bond division. Utility stocks closing lower included Electric Bond and Share issues and Southern California Edison. Cities Service common was off fractionally, but the preferred was firm.

Governor Roosevelt's sweeping victory in New Hampshire's primary on Tuesday provided, in the eyes of his friends here and in other parts of the country, the additional impetus that will carry the Governor's candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination through successfully in the contests that lie ahead.

PRAGUE, March 9. -- Czechoslovakia's distrust of the Danubian Union plan, hinted at yesterday by Premier Udrzal, was made still clearer today at a meeting of the Czech National Socialist party, whose leader is Foreign Minister Eduard Benes.

New Jersey authorities hunting the kidnappers of the infant son of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh broadcast a new appeal yesterday for the "cooperation of our entire lawabiding population" and expressed confidence in the ultimate success of their efforts.

LONDON, March 9 (AP). -- The Board of Trade's returns of Great Britain's foreign trade in February are as follows: Exports of British products, u30,010,000; re-exports, foreign goods u5,450,000; total exports, u35,460,000; imports, u70,100,000; excess of imports, u34,640,000.

TRENTON, N.J., March 9. -- The first of a series of public hearings to be held by the Republican-controlled Senate on bills introduced by the Democratic majority in the Assembly to carry out Governor A. Harry Moore's proposal for reorganization of the State Government was held today by the Committee on Agricultre on the measure creating a new Department of Agriculture.

MONTREAL, Que., March 9 (Canadian Press). -- Both sterling and United States money were slightly firmer here today. Sterling ended the day at $4.1171, compared with $4.1148 yesterday, while United States money at 11% per cent premium compared with 11 1-16 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The form in which the resolution to ratify American adherence to the World Court should be laid before the Senate was so sharply disputed at an executive session of the Foreign Relations Committee today that final action upon the resolution was deferred at least until next week and perhaps for a much longer time.

More equitable distribution of wealth and a policy of self-sufficiency designed to care primarily for the needs of the people of the United States rather than the cultivation of export markets and investment abroad for the benefit of a few are the two lines of economic policy now being rapidly crystallized in the mind of this nation, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, said last night.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP). -- William L. Cooper, Commercial Attache at London, advised the Department of Commerce today that the British Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., had confirmed a report that that company had concluded an agreement with Continental dye manufacturers affecting the European dye market.

UTICA, N.Y., March 9. -- The State Highway Chapter of the Associated General Contractors of America, opening a two-day session here today, went on record as favoring a huge Federal bond issue to carry on public works to relieve unemployment.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Senator Norris today deliberately killed his anti-injunction bill so that a legislative technicality might be overcome. The Senate recently passed the bill by a vote of 75 to 5 and transmitted it to the House. The House last night passed an anti-injunction bill with slightly different provisions, introduced by a Progressive coalition headed by Representative La Guardia and tabled the Morris bill.

GENEVA, March 9. -- The League of Nations Assembly's drafting committee, which is drafting a resolution on the Sino-Japanese conflict, adjourned tonight its secret discussion until tomorrow morning with good prospects of then reaching an agreement.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, March 9. -- An ice-breaker left Helsingfors late tonight to search for 700 fishermen reported to be adrift on pieces of an ice floe somewhere in the eastern part of the Gulf of Finland.

To the Editor of The New York Times: By this time it must be apparent to every one that the various costly experiments at Washington to restore prosperity by artificial means have been pitiable failures. They have all been in the nature of attempts to pull one's self up by means of one's bootstraps.

The extremely rapid rise of sterling exchange on Tuesday elicited all kinds of market comment. At London the judgment expressed was oddly divided between gratification at a sign of returning confidence in England and apprehension lest so sudden an appreciation of the pound sterling, and therefore of British currency, might upset plans already made for home and foreign trade.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 9. -- The value of art objects in the Larchmont home of Daniel O'Connell, New York investment broker, whose property was attached on a Supreme Court order obtained by the Catholic Diocese of Buffalo, was put at $2,672 in an appraisal filed here today.
ATLANTA, March 9 (AP). -- A year's struggle to keep breath in the body of 4-year-old Clarence Hamilton was lost today.

The Niagara Hudson Power System will spend $19,301,000 this year for improvements and extension of facilities, it was announced yesterday. This represents the aggregate of expenditures scheduled by the separate operating companies in the group.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 9 (AP). -- President Hoover made a formal bid for Ohio's delegation of fifty-five to the Chicago convention today when he filed his consent with the Secretary of State for certain delegate candidates and alternates to pledge to him as their first choice for President, in compliance with State law.

While sterling exchange quieted materially yesterday, foreign cotton quotations broke sharply. After holding within a 6-point range, prices on the Cotton Exchange here closed a point lower to 2 points higher than on Tuesday.
BOSTON, March 9 (AP). -- Alfred E. Smith has not changed his attitude regarding nomination at the coming Democratic national convention, an exchange of telegrams with Mayor Curley disclosed tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There has been introduced in the Legislature a bill creating a new family court for the city of New York. A socialized family court, with a more extended Jurisdiction than the present court, which is merely a police court, has long been advocated by the judiciary, the bar and social service agencies.

TOKYO, March 9. -- With the surrender today of Daiji Kurosawa, the third member of the "death band" responsible for the assassinations of Baron Takuma Dan and Junnosuke Inouye, former Finance Minister, police obtained clues which have uncovered the whole sinister background of a murder organization in which educated people have influenced impressionable ignorant youths to kill in the name of patriotism and religion.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- A charge that some banks were hoarding money and that their restrictive credit policies crippled industrial activities was laid before President Hoover today by the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel through its director general, Benjamin Schwartz.

BERUN, March 9 (AP). -- Some uneasiness developed today about the possibility of a forcible uprising on the part of Adolf Hitler's National Socialists in the event that the Presidential election Sunday went against them.
Apartment houses provided the bulk of realty trading in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday. Several business structures and dwellings also changed hands.

The presence of State Senator John A. Hastings before a subcommittee of one, of the Hofstadter Legislative Committee, on the afternoon of March 21 was believed assured yesterday afternoon when Supreme Court Justice Glennon signed an order authorizing the court clerk to issue a writ of attachment for the Senator.

Thomas M. Farley, Tammany leader of the Yorkville section, who was removed by Governor Roosevelt as Sheriff on Feb. 24 was acquitted by order of Judge Freschi in General Sessions yesterday of unlawfully appropriating $118.74 in interest on money rfeld in escrow.

One of the largest residential deals of the year in Westehester County was reported yesterday in the purchase by Joseph Glass, New York lawyer, of Wayside, formerly the Edwin K. Bayer estate, at Mount Kisco. The seller was the Countess Sala of Paris, daughter of the late Julius Kayser.

With swinging clubs, sixty policemen frustrated yesterday afternoon repeated attempts of more than 300 Communists to stage demonstrations in front of the Ford Motor Company Building at Broadway and Fifty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, made a veiled reference to the Hitler campaign in Germany in delivering the closing speech tonight of the National Jewish-Christian Conference Following the Rev. Samuel McCrea Cavert of New York, general secretary of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, who had deprecated anti-Semitic aspects of the Hitler propaganda, Mr. Baker said:

ALBANY, March 9. -- The series of important bills supposedly favored by the Walker Administration and designed to carry out drastic reforms, advised by Leonard Wallstein in the procedure for taking private land by condemnation for public purposes in New York City, struck a snag in the Legislature today as a result of opposition from Republican leaders in upstates counties in the area from which New York City obtains Its water supply.

The Schola Cantorum last night in Carnegie Hall gave Randall Thompson's "Odes to Horace." its first performance in New York, Weber's Villa-Lobos's "Quatour," (American premiere) two Spanish folksongs arranged by Kindler, Bernard Wagenaar's three Chinese songs, with the composer at the piano, and Hugo Herrmann's "Strassesingen" (American premiere).

CAMDEN, N.J., March 9. -- Fourteen men were killed without a chance of escape this morning when a sudden explosion converted the gas-purifying tank in which they were working into a flaming death trap at the South Camden plant of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

ALBANY, March 9. -- In his maiden speech as a member of the Assembly, James J. Wadsworth, son of former United States Senator Wadsworth, opposed a wet measure today which his father, arch foe of the prohibition amendment, endorsed last year.

Better Retail Trade Reported. Improved trade during the last two days has helped sentiment in local retail circles and the belief was expressed that consumer pre-Easter purchasing is now making much-needed headway. Volume for the first half of the month, however, is tending to run around 15 per cent under the corresponding period a year ago, owing to the slow start of Spring purchasing during the first eight days.

Mrs. Chaie Ress, 85 years old, whose wizened figure was familiar to thousands and who for years had offered pencils for sale in all kinds of weather at Broadway and Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn, was found dead yesterday afternoon in her two-room flat on the third floor of a tenement house at 35 Moore Street, in the Williamsburg district.
