A sympathetic audience, with an understanding of the frailty of the flesh, last night heard Mayor Walker explain, and apologize while explaining, just why he doesn't want to ride a white horse at the head of the St. Patrick's Day parade, of which he is grand marshal.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 10 -- A conference among Manager Max Carey and Walter F. Carter of Brooklyn and President Sidney Weil and Manager Dan Howley of the Cincinnati Reds that lasted more than three hours today brought forth only the statement that "there will be nothing to announce tonight."

PARIS, March 10 -- Worried French Importers of American apples were trying to learn today from official sources whether large shipments consigned to them and actually en route would be affected by the sweeping embargo placed on fresh fruit from the United States by the government yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Only Senator King of Utah put into words today a feeling which has spread throughout the ranks of the Democrats in Congress that Alfred E. Smith should withdraw from further contest for delegates in the national convention.

NEW ORLEANS, March 10 (AP) -- Prometheus, a 5-year-old son of Broomstick, which once raced in the Whitney silks, won his second successive race when he outclassed a field of high-grade sprinters at the Fair Grounds today.
LONDON, March 10 -- Mrs. Marshall Field 3d was thrown heavily today while hunting with the Fernie hounds at Kings Norton.

BERLIN, March 10 -- President Paul von Hindenburg, who has never appeared on a political platform and whose voice had been broadcast by radio only twice before, talked to the German voters tonight over the radio from the Presidential palace in preparation for next Sunday's election.

OLIVER WENDELL, HOLMES said that the education of a child should begin with its grandparents. It isn't necessary to go that far back in raising a shotput champion. The rise of Herman Brix to the national championship in shotputting began with the proficiency of an elder brother in that art.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A ruling relative to the deducibility for Federal income tax purposes of s loss sustained by stockholders of a bank which had failed in 1931, issued by the Internal Revenue Bureau today, held that a call on stockholders by the Superintendent of Banks for payment of additional liability imposed upon them by the State law constituted a satisfactory showing of the worthlessness of the bank stock.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Secretary Mills said today that there was a distinctly better feeling on the part of business men generally as a result of the government's reconstruction program.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Great airships sliding through the skies from America to Europe in two and a half days were pictured to the House Interstate Commerce Committee today as a result to be expected if the Grosser bill, which the committee is considering, is passed.

In order to devote his principal efforts to the financial problems of the Middle West Utilities Company and other corporations in which he is interested directly, Samuel Insull is resigning as chairman of some of the numerous intermediary holding companies and operating companies of the Middle West Utilities System.
Teams representing Bayonne, Woodrow Wilson of Weehawken, South Side of Newark and Cranford high schools were among those to advance in the New Jersey State basketball tournament last night.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- An urgent plea came from organized labor today for a huge program of public works to save the country from unemployment and its "serious human consequences."

Zborowski, the famous Paris art firm, has opened a New York branch in the building at 460 Park Avenue. The high spots of the opening show are drawings and paintings by Modigliani, among the latter being a portrait of the elder Zborowski brother; a portrait of Mario, the composer (the last picture Modigliani painted), and a nude that has the lovely line and relaxed grace of Giorgione's sleeping "Venus."

ALBANY, March 10 -- Tammany today cracked the whip over the Democratic delegations in the Senate and Assembly to compel adverse action on a measure providing for a new tax on heavy trucks and buses which Governor Roosevelt had approved and which had been drafted under the supervision of his board of tax commissioners.

Condemnation proceedings have long been subject to serious abuse. Without it the "honest graft" which GEORGE WASHINGTON PLUNKETT preached and others like him have practiced for generations past would never have risen to its present dignity.

The market continued easy, on a minimum of trading. The "outside" rate for call loans was 2 1/4 per cent, but the Stock Exchange quotation remained at 2 1/2. Federal funds were 1 1/2 @ 1 3/4, as on Wednesday. Time money market was dull and unchanged in quotation.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, rated as the largest instalment financing company in the world, reported yesterday that its net profit last year was $8,979,120 after interest, taxes and other charges, equivalent to $17.95 a share on 500,000 shares of stock, which are owned by the General Motors Corporation.

William Campbell, 38 years old, of 93 Prospect Street, Jersey City, a widower and father of nine children, one of the twenty-two ironworkers arrested in connection with the fatal beating of a non-union worker in Jersey City Feb. 27, tried to strangle himself with the belt of his raincoat in his cell in the Jersey City prison on Wednesday, it became known yesterday.
Business and residential properties were about equally divided in the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday.

The Fencers Club team of Lieutenant George C. Calnan, Hugh Alessandroni and Durnell Every successfully defended its national senior foils championship at the Fencers Club last night. Eight teams competed, with the New York A.C. being the runner-up after a thrilling fight.

UTICA, N.Y., March 10 -- A "relief currency" of restricted use was offered here today as a plan to put 8,000,000 idle men to work by Dr. Joseph Jerome Klein, Associate Professor of Taxation in the College of the City of New York, in an address to the State convention of Associated General Contractors of America, which closed a two-day session today.

The directors of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation took no action on the dividend at their meeting yesterday, owing to the low level of business still prevailing throughout the world and the restrictions on exchange in several foreign countries, which affect the transfer of funds.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- On the eve of what promises to be an acceptance by the League of Nations Assembly at Geneva of the broad policy of the United States in the Sino-Japanese controversy, diplomatic Washington is exhibiting more concern over developments in the Far East than it has for some weeks.
LONDON, March 10 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Recent paintings by Nicolai Cikovsky will be on view until March 26 at the Daniel Gallery, 600 Madison Avenue. There is perhaps nothing in the present show that attains in altitude the flight of those beautiful pigeons, seen last year in a group exhibition at this gallery and more recently in the Pennsylvania Academy's salon at Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Supreme Court on Monday will be asked to advance the hearing of the New York reapportionment case to be taken up during the week, when the Minnesota reapportionment case is reached for oral argument.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- J. S. Pyeatt, president of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad, informed the Interstate Commerce Commission today that two New York banks had refused to advance money to build the Dotsero cut-off in Denver and buy control of the Denver Salt Lake Railroad.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 10 -- Thirty-two preliminary and sixteen semi-final matches of the twenty-eighth annual Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association tourney will be conducted at Archbold Gym tomorrow afternoon and evening. The eight final matches will be held Saturday afternoon at 2 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Senator Robinson of Arkansas, Democratic floor leader, criticized the administration tonight as having supplied Congress with budget and revenue estimates which he termed "almost invariably fallacious, if not regulated to meet the desires of the administration."
GENEVA, March 10 (AP) -- The text of the League of Nations Assembly's resolution in three parts for dealing with the Sino-Japanese conflict, as adopted by the drafting committee today, follows:

Nine days had passed last night since Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. was stolen from his home near Hopewell, N.J., and his father's efforts to ransom him seemed to have produced no more tangible results than the police hunt for the kidnappers.

MIAMI, Fla., March 10 -- C.L. King's Panetian won his third consecutive victory at Tropical Park today when he defeated a strong field of sprinters in the feature, the Granada Handicap. The gelded son of Galetian and Pan Maid had a length the better of Martis at the end of the six furlongs, with Don Leon a neck away in third position.

LOS ANGELES, March 10 -- With a long batting and fielding drill in the morning and a seven-inning scrub game in the afternoon, the Giants today concluded their second preliminary training stage and appeared ready for the next, which begins tomorrow with the resumption of hostilities with the Cubs.

Mrs. Catherine Fitzhugh, a plainly dressed middle-aged woman, who the police said, has a penchant for robbing worshipers in fashionable churches, was in the line-up yesterday for the first time in several years. This time Mrs. Fitzhugh, arrested in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church on Wednesday, was accused of having taken $4 from a woman's pocketbook.

Memories of General Sessions Court thirty-seven years ago were awakened yesterday in Judge Allen's part when a faded indictment, accusing Giuseppe Gavorki of feloious assault, was produced in the move of District Attorney Crain to rid the archives of all such documents.

The latest report of the Department of Commerce on American exports suggests an interesting comparison. During the first seven months of the present fiscal year our sales of goods abroad have fallen $1,468,000,000 below the average figure for the last decade.

LONDON, March 10 -- An American has offered to defray the cost of restoring the famous Bow bells of the Church of St. Mary-le-Bow in Cheapside on condition the work is done by the Croydon company that made the bells for the Riverside Church in New York, known as the "Rockefeller Church."

MONTREAL, March 10 (AP) -- The Montreal Maroons improved their chances of clinching a play-off berth in the International division of the National Hockey League tonight when they defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 1.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- While there were signs today of a weakened technical position in the market for hogs, prices at the yards were steady to 10 cents higher than yesterday, the top advancing 10 cents to $5 a hundred-weight, the highest point since Nov. 13.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The new tax bill introduced in the House of Representatives yesterday provides among others for an excise tax on brewer's wort, liquid malt, malt syrup, grape concentrate and evaporated grape juice or so-called grape bricks.

LA PAZ, March 10 -- The controversy between the government and the Central Bank of Bolivia over proposals for inflation, which led to the creation of a new Cabinet yesterday, was explained today in the English-language section of the newspaper La Razon.

More insurance was written by the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company last month than in any other February in the company's history, making the total for the first two months of this year 29 per cent ahead of that of the same period in 1931.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Both houses of the Legislature passed unanimously today three bills paving the way for a $30,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief and continuing machinery for relief purposes. The action is designed to extend State aid through this year and next, should the depression last all of that period.

The three operating districts of the Erie Railroad will be consolidated into two districts effective on next Wednesday, it was announced yesterday. Headquarters of the Eastern district will be in New York. H.J. Bordwell, formerly general manager of the New York district, has been made general manager of the Eastern district, and his jurisdiction has been extended westward to include Buffalo, Hornell and Eastern points.

Mrs. William H. Adams of the Rockaway Hunting Club and Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia reached the final round of the women's invitation squash racquets tournament at the Junior League yesterday and will meet at noon today for the cup on the league courts, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

DENVER, March 10 (AP) -- Three men go on trial next Monday for the kidnapping of Benjamin P. Bower, wealthy bakery executive in January. Instead of the $50,000 ransom money they are alleged to have demanded for Mr. Bower's release they may get a seven-year penitentiary term, the maximum for kidnapping in Colorado.

Life insurance companies can become great stabilizers of business conditions in this country because they do not speculate with their funds, Dr. William B. Bailey, economist of the Travelers Insurance Company, said yesterday at the annual sales congress of the Life Underwriters' Association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial "Emotion and Action" in THE TIMES seems to me of high value in its appeal for "a sterner scrutiny of the society in which we live and a more resolute purpose to correct the conditions out of which such monstrous crimes are produced" and "what is the public share of responsibility."

Among great works of art there are a few which lead us into the same realm of unique enchantment. Their number is small, but they are unmistakable. Coleridge penetrated to this lost and haunted world once only; its half-remembered echoes glamour the stanzas of "Kublah Khan."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The State Department said today it would make no move with reference to the fruit embargo imposed by France before its terms were more clearly defined and Ambassador Edge had reported in detail concerning it.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted and the Reserve note circulation for the syestem as a whole to be at the lowest of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure.

United States Government bonds and the better-rated foreign loans led yesterday's improvement in the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Seven of the eleven active Federal issues reached new peaks for 1932 and many foreign loans touched their best prices of the year.

Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, rejected yesterday the recommendation of Eugene C. Gibney, director of extension activities of the Board of Education, to deny the request of the Brooklyn Citizens Committee for permission to use the Erasmus Hall High School auditorium for a meeting on March 19 at which Mayor Russell Wilson of Cincinnati is to speak on the city-manager plan.
"The Warrior's Husband," a comedy by Julian Thompson, will open tonight at the Morosco Theatre. Colin Keith-Johnston will head the cast.
PARIS, March 10 -- Aristide Briand in death was the object today of two strikingly different manifestations.

Josef Hofmann will interrupt his self-imposed year's sabbatical leave from the public concert platform to appear in Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, April 3, for the benefit of the Musicians' Emergency Aid, it was announced yesterday. He will play two piano concertos and Walter Damrosch will conduct his N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra of ninety men in its first public appearance other than over the air.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 10 -- Anthony Petrillo, 27 years old, of 34 East Devonia Avenue, son of a wealthy contractor here, shot and killed Mrs. Adele Fatrona, 29, of 69 West Devonia Avenue, his brother's sister-in-law; wounded his brother's wife, and then turned the pistol on himself to end his life at 10:30 o'clock tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A bill to amend existing copyright laws by broadening the scope of protection for authors of literary, artistic and scientific works, and specifying other classifications prohibited from copyright protection, was introduced today by Representative William I. Sirovich, chairman of the Committee on Patents.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Representative Sirovich's serious scanning of the wisecracking ways of dramatic critics began today, with a notable cast supporting him, and, whatever the critics may say about it, it was a good show.

Criticism of the report prepared by Budget Director Charles L. Kohler to show prevailing rates of wages in unionized trades was expressed yesterday by representatives of union labor attending a special meeting of the Board of Estimate committee on payment of prevailing rates to city employes.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Commander Alger H. Dresel, on duty at the Naval Air Station at Lakehurst, was ordered today to take command of the airship Akron in April. He will succeed Lieut. Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, who will go to sea on the battleship West Virginia, flagship of the battle force.

Prices on the New York and New Orleans Cotton Exchanges continued yesterday to ignore the violent fluctuations in foreign quotations, and for the third successive day the May delivery ended the session unchanged. Following a break of 20 English points on Wednesday, prices in Liverpool recovered 25 points from the low figures of the week, while there were gains of 73 to 84 points in Alexandria.

Adoption by the Republican National Convention of a "home rule" liquor control plank, virtually iden- tical with the plank proposed by John J. Raskob, Democratic National Chairman, for adoption by the Democratic National Convention, was urged last night in a resolution offered by Frederic R. Coudert Jr. at a meeting of the New York County Republican Committee at Palm Garden.

With volume reduced still further, the stock market presented yesterday a dull and uninteresting picture of a professional interplay. The general list on the Stock Exchange lost a little ground, but there was no acute weakness. The so-called pivotal issues were off a trifle; for fifty stocks the average decline was calculated at about 72 cents.

BERLIN, March 10 (AP) -- Shortly after President von Hindenburg had completed delivering his radio address from his study tonight 20,000 Communists massed in the Sportpalsat at a campaign meeting for Ernst Thaelmann, their candidate for the Presidency.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- A warm political debate developed in the senate today from Democratic attacks on the proposed manufacturers' sales tax. Senators Dill of Washington, McKellar of Tennessee, and Walsh of Montana, were those who objected to the proposal.

Three hold-up men, two carrying pistols, surprised Jack Wallum, assistant treasurer of the Selwyn Theatre, 229 West Forty-second Street, at 6:01 P.M. yesterday as he was alone in his small cage-like box office in the theatre lobby. With record speed they robbed him of about $1,000, the receipts of a matinee of "The Devil Passes," and escaped.
The Evander Childs High School basketball team upset James Monroe High, Bronx P.S.A.L. champion, 30 -- 15, in the Monroe gymnasium yesterday.

PARIS, March 10 -- While the International Wine Congress here was drawing up resolutions today condemning prohibition in the United States, Dr. Ivan Bratt explained to the American Club of Paris the Swedish system of liquor control which bears his name.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Cortlandt Parker, wife of the military attache of the American Embassy in London, is sailing on the American Trader today for her home there.
DAIREN, Manchuria, March 10 -- A new attack was made today upon Hailin by Chinese forces opposing the regime of Hsi Hsia in Kirin, and was speedily repulsed by Japanese army airplanes.
ALBANY, March 10 -- All hope of legislation to segregate thrift accounts in commercial banks appeared at an end tonight as the Legislature prepared to adjourn tomorrow.

In brighter and madder days, a comparison between "income-tax" millionaires in Great Britain and in the United States elicited a faintly superior smile in this country. Whereas in England an income-tax millionaire was a man who paid income tax on approximately a capital of a million, with us it was actually an income of a million.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Fred H. Talcott, 77, retired druggist of Walliston, Mass., and an inveterate fisherman, lost his life at the sport he pursued throughout the year from Canada to Florida.

Elizabeth, N.J. John A. Mitchell, Controller of the city of Elizabeth, N.J., announced yesterday that the city would be in the market on March 21, at 11 A.M., with an issue of $4,493,000 of water bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1934 to 1972, on which the interest rate is to be named by the bidders.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 10 -- The vacancy figures in Westchester homes are not abnormally high and with a return of normal demand for houses there would soon be an actual home shortage, George Howe, chairman of the Westchester County Conference on Home Building and Home Ownership, today told a group of county bankers and building loan officials comprising the finance committee of the conference.

The De La Salle, St. Michael's, Don Bosco and St. Francis basketball teams gained the semi-final round of the Metropolitan Catholic High Schools' tournament conducted by Columbus Council, K. of C., by scoring in last night's games played at the Columbus Council gymnasium, Brooklyn.

The cold wave got an even tighter grip on the country yesterday. Reinforced by a new northwest gale that battered shipping on the Great Lakes and off the Atlantic Coast and by fresh blizzards in snowbound Western New York, it swept on southward, leaving in its wake a trail of blighted fruit and truck crops.

Advocating a world program to end the overproduction of petroleum, J.B. A. Kessler, joint managing director of the Royal Dutch Shell group of companies, proposes that the United States, because of the anti-trust laws of this country, participate in the suggested international cartel as a limited partner.

DUBLIN, March 10 -- The Irish Republican Army flag, forbidden under the regime of William T. Cosgrave, was waved aloft in the streets of Dublin tonight in celebration of the release of twenty political prisoners freed today from Arbour Hill and other prisons.

Winston Churchill, former British Chancellor of the Exchequer, will sail with his daughter, Miss Diana Churchill, on the White Star liner Majestic, which leaves today for Cherbourg and Southampton. Reginald Connellym and James Campbell, English song writers and publishers, also will leave on the Majestic after a month's business visit here.
LONDON, March 10 (AP) -- George Lupino, well-known comedian in his own right and father of Stanley and Barry Lupino, prominent on the contemporary stage, died today at the age of 80.

LONDON, March 10 -- Sir Philip Sassoon, in submitting the air estimates for the fiscal year to Parliament today, pointed out that judgment on the value of airships had been suspended, but that machinery was available at Cardington and overseas for building them if it were found desirable.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- The country's 29,980,000 home owners are urged today to come forth from their cottages, bungalows and mansions and ask for the first time for legislation of their own in the form of the Watson-Luce bill pending in Congress which would establish twelve new banks for the sole purpose of discounting first mortgages on urban domiciles.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Catherine Fitzhugh, charged with grand larceny of a pocketbook in a church, is believed by Washington police officials to be Catherine Fenell, also known here as Catherine Fitzhugh and Catherine Northrupp, who was arrested here on several occasions in 1924 for stealing pocketbooks in churches.

Mrs. Marie Booth Douglas, 75 years old, a former actress, who claimed relationship with the distinguished stage family of Edwin Booth, was found dead yesterday, alone in a cheap apartment in a three-story tenement at 1,133 First Avenue. Her three cats, sole companions of a six-year seclusion, stood vigil beside her body when the police broke down the door.

The ball of the graduates of the Corps des Pages, which is under the patronage of prominent Russians now living in New York, many of whom are former members of the highest court circles of Imperial Russia, will be given tonight in the Louis XV ballroom of the Ambassador.
WARSAW, Poland, March 10 (AP) -- Foreign Minister August Zaleski, who is in Paris for the funeral of Aristide Briand, will inform Premier Tardieu that Poland approves his proposed federation.

Continued strength in the bond market was the most cheerful phase of yesterday's confused financial picture. Stocks fluctuated irregularly without arousing any interest. Sterling extended its decline of the previous day by 7 1/4 cents. Grains and cotton were steady.

MEXICO CITY, March 10 -- The peso showed surprising firmness today, despite expectations in some quarters that panicky selling would follow yesterday's decision to coin additional silver pesos to relieve Mexico's financial stringency.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Billie Dove, actress, had a chat today with President Hoover. She said the conversation had been brief but pleasant; she thought the President "looked well."

OYSTER BAY, L.I., March 10 -- Leo J. Sexton, star shot-putter of the New York A.C., who twice this season bettered the world's record with the sixteen-pound shot, set a new world's record with the twelve-pound shot in a meet at the Oyster Bay High School tonight.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 10 -- The French embargo on fresh fruit from the United States affects a direct export business which has shipped almost 2,000,000 bushels of apples direct to France since last Sept. 1, figures supplied here today by R.G. Phillips, secretary of the International Apple Association, show.

Bail for John Brazill, a Federal prohibition agent, arrested here Monday on a charge of robbery, was raised from $2,500 to $5,000 by Magistrate Dodge in Essex Market Court yesterday at the request of Newark detectives, who said he might be linked with two robberies in their city.

On the petition of three creditors, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson appointed yesterday the Irving Trust Company receiver in bankruptcy for the Lexington Hotel Corporation, operator and owner of the twenty-five-story Hotel Lexington, which was built about two years ago at a cost of about $6,000,000, at Forty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue.

From next week on until it winds up its activities toward the end of May or early in June the Hofstedter Legislative Committee will hold at least three public hearings a week. The investigation will close with an inquiry into the acts of Mayor Walker and his official family, it was revealed yesterday.

A peculiarly appealing opportunity is still open to many who have not given, or given in full measure -- especially to those who have no families of their own -- not only to be of special help at the moment but to win for themselves the lasting gratitude of a family in temporary distress.
PARIS, March 10 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

ABOARD THE U.S.S. AUGUSTA, off San Francisco, March 10 -- The spreading fingers of the sun reached over the green summits of Southern California's coastal islands this morning to find the Black fleet, which is defending the Pacific Coast from the attacks of an imaginary Blue invader, still anchored near the ragged island shore line.

JEFFERSON gets a dinner once a year. HAMILTON runs both parties and the Government of the United States. Yet one loves the Democratic lip-service to the unfollowed saint, even, if "Jeffersonian principles" are strictly confined to resolutions and oratory.

Bryant High School skaters captured two of three city P.S.A.L. senior skating championships decided last night at Iceland. George Burton won the 440-yard crown and Bobby Anstett triumphed in the three-quarter mile event, to score for Bryant. Edward McKavanagh of John Adams High took the senor high 880-yard title.

An attack upon the two pistol-permit bills passed by the Legislature and now awaiting the signature or veto of Governor Roosevelt was made last night by Police Commissioner Mulrooney in an address before a young men's group of the First Presbyterian Church in the Church House, 12 West Twelfth Street.

The New York Americans turned upon their city rivals, the Rangers, for the second time this season and administered a 5 to 1 defeat to the formidable blue-jerseyed aggregation in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Bank clearings throughout the country continue to decline, but there was an increase in this city in the week ended on Wednesday over the preceding week, although the latter period was the first week of the month and included many month-end clearings.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- As a result of the anti-hoarding campaign, millions of dollars are flowing back into the banks and channels of trade, according to reports received at the headquarters of the Citizens' Reconstruction Organization today. Sales of the new treasury savings certificates kept pace with the rapid increase of bank deposits, showing the rapid restoration of confidence in the banking system.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- George W. Leman, assistant secretary of the Irving Trust Company of New York, told the House Coinage Committee investigating silver today that conditions had changed so in the last year there now was a good possibility for success of a meeting of many nations to stabilize monetary exchanges.
PARIS, March 10 -- Trading on the Bourse subsided today and yesterday's recovery was not maintained. At the close the stock list had lost a large proportion of yesterday's gains.

PITTSBURGH, March 10 -- An increase in traffic would be the only permanent cure for railroad ills, but meanwhile the industry could be assisted through being relieved of unproductive expenditures, F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, said tonight at the annual dinner of the Traffic club of Pittsburgh in the William enn Hotel.

Eight hundred and sixty school publications, the product of undergraduate writers, editors and business managers, were graded according to merit in lists made public yesterday by the Columbia Scholastio Press Association, which opened its eighth annual convention at Columbia University.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I note in THE TIMES of this morning a letter from Henry T. Noyes of Rochester with reference to the Long Island park funds.

President HOOVER was assured yesterday by a caller that he is "be"coming politically stronger and "stronger every day." This was not the opinion of a Dr. Coue of politics, but of the Executive Director of the American Institute of Steel Construction.
ROME, March 10 (AP) -- Guglielmo Marconi received today the John Scott award, made by the city of Philadelphia last year, for his invention of the wireless telegraph.

LONDON, March 10 (AP) -- Lord Ruthven, who is Lieutenant Governor of Guernsey, gave his daughter in marriage. She wore a gown of white tulle, which was also the bridal gown of her twin sister, Alison, when she was married three years ago.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted:

ALBANY, March 10 -- A resolution for a proposed constitutional amendment to carry out suggestions of Conservation Commissioner Henry Morgenthau Jr. for a "North County Regional Park Commission" was adopted tonight in the Senate.
BERLIN, March 10 (AP) -- The text of President von Hindenburg's radio address, delivered tonight, follows:

A new all-time low price for sugar at 0.79, which was registered for the May contract, stood out as the most important price change of the day in commodity markets yesterday. Heavy trading accompanied the reaction, carrying the general list 2 to 3 points under Wednesday's finals. Previously 0.80 was the record low. Rubber was also lower, silk and hides being irregular. Elsewhere, prices were generally maintained at Wednesday's levels.

The reduction of the Bank of England rate from 5 per cent to 4 per cent, widely expected though it had been, yesterday put an effective damper on the bullish speculation in sterling. The pound slumped 7 1/4 cents and closed on the bottom at $3.62 1/4.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10 -- Dr. Vannevar Bush, Engineering Dean and newly appointed vice president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, described in an interview today his new "differential analyzer," the "mechanical brain" he has developed for solving problems and calculations impossible for the human brain to compass.

The general decline of shipbuilding in American yards continued during the first two months of the present year, and tonnage under construction on March 1 totaled 261,163 tons, according to the bi-monthly report of the American Bureau of Shipping, issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- N'Gi, a 6-year-old gorilla in whose fight for life all the resources of modern science were enlisted, died early today at the National Zoological Park.

Chain Store Fund, Inc., an investment trust founded in 1929, which at the end of 1930 had total assets of $2,487,493, is being liquidated gradually, Ralph Morgan, president of the company, said yesterday. A liquidating dividend of $11 a share was paid several months ago and other distributions will be made as the company disposes of its investments.

More than half of Pennsylvania's seventy-six delegates to the Democratic National Convention already are assured for Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Warren Van Dyke, president of the Roosevelt-for-President League of that State, declared yesterday at Roosevelt headquarters.

In a drawer crammed with old papers Muriel Hine, English author of "Wild Rye," recently found a long letter written to her in 1895 by Charles L. Dodgson, the mathematician, who wrote as Lewis Carroll and who was an old friend of her father's.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- John Philip Sousa was buried this afternoon in the uniform of a Lieutenant Commander of the Naval Reserve and with full military honors in Congressional Cemetery, only a mile from his birthplace in Southeast Washington.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Even while Representative Crisp was starting the new $1,096,000,000 tax bill on its way in the House today, three of his Democratic colleagues in the Senate were denouncing its basic provision of a sales levy.

Encouraging progress in relieving distress and aiding the unemployed was reported yesterday by two organizations. The women's division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, of which Mrs. August Belmont is chairman, announced that it had raised $174,297.63 so far for the "adoption" of 629 families, while the "war against depression" campaign of the American Legion and associated organizations listed 202,576 jobs found since the drive began on Feb. 15.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 9, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,728,000,000, unchanged from the preceding week and an increase of $784,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

LONDON, March 10 -- Amid scenes of great enthusiasm in Throgmorton Street the directors of the Bank of England today announced a reduction of the Bank rate of 4 per cent from 5 per cent, at which it had stood since Feb. 18.

GENEVA, March 10 -- In that dynamic way in which, both in France and abroad. Premier Tardieu likes to get things started, he has, during the last weeks, launched once more the idea of a Danubian federation.

Morris H. Dixon of Newtown Square, Pa., has been elected a member of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, according to an announcement yesterday from Frank J. Bryan, secretary of the hunts committee of the association.

An advance of $57,000,000 in brokers' loans, the widest rise since the week ended on July 1 last was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The increase carried the total of loans to $552,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the March 4 issue of THE TIMES there appeared a statement by H.S. Cullman, president of the Beekman State Hospital, in which he favored the State specially licensing physicians desiring to do compensation work.

A card party under the auspices of the Hunter College Alumnae committee will be given tomorrow afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the children's work of the Lenox Hill Settlement. The committee takes care of children for the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association and serves a hot lunch to more than 200 of them daily, some of them being served free.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Early settlement of the reparations problem by the European governments directly concerned was advocated as the first essential step toward restoration of confidence and recovery in a statement prepared by the American committee of the International Chamber of Commerce.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 10 -- Miss Bernice Wall of Oshkosh, Wis., last year's runner-up in the women's Belleair golf championship, set the pace for the other quarter-finalists by a wide margin today in winning her match with Mrs. A.B. Harrison of Buffalo, N.Y., 9 and 7.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Charges that the Farm Board has depressed prices and threatens to drive commission merchants out of business were brought to the House Agriculture Committee today by spokesmen for the live stock exchanges.

New York City and the Westchester communities fighting the application of the New York Central Railroad for a 40 per cent increase in commutation rates lost a point yesterday at the joint hearing before the Transit and Public Service Commissions, held in the State Office Building.

An application for the listing of 2,118,959 shares of new $5 par value stock of North American Aviation, Inc., which are to be exchanged, share for share, for the present no par stock, was approved yesterday by the Stock Exchange. Through the reduction in capital represented by the common shares from $12.50 to $5 a share, the capital surplus was increased by $15,892,192.

Miss Jane Baldwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clark Baldwin Jr. of this city and Mount Kisco, N.Y., will be married to Charles Waring Gillespie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Gillespie of South Orange, N.J. and of this city, on March 18 in St. Mark's Church, Mount Kisco.

Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey was the guest of members of the New Jersey State Senate at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore last evening, following a matinee party. The Senate dinner to the Governor has been held annually since it was instituted during the administration of Woodrow Wilson as New Jersey's Governor.

Samuel Hurgon, 50 years old, a peddler, of 61 Montgomery Street was sentenced yesterday to thirty days in the workhouse by Justices Healy, Herbert and Voorhees in Special Sessions for obtaining free food and coal from the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee when he could afford to buy them.
VILLANOVA, Pa., March 10 -- Bucknell, in a second half rally, defeated Villanova at basketball tonight, 28 -- 27. This was the closing game for each team.

The twenty-seventh annual Varsity Show of Columbia University, "How Revolting:" had a successful premiere last night before more than 1,500 undergraduates and their guests in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

ALBANY, March 10 -- "Substantial progress" has been made in negotiations to protect the State's rights in the St. Lawrence development, according to the power authority, which made its first report to Governor Roosevelt and the Legislature today.

NORFOLK, Va., March 10 -- Headquarters of the Norfolk Coast Guard Division was today advised that the auxiliary yawl Nahma, owned by Felix du Pont of Wilmington, Del., of which his son Richard is skipper, had not been reported since Friday, when she was sighted two miles off Charleston.
Several important changes indicative of improvement in the banking situation were disclosed yesterday in the report of the Federal Reserve System for the week ended on Wednesday.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 10 -- Fred Merkle, former star of the Giants, who is residing here, defeated H. Courtney of Stamford, N.Y., by 2 and 1 in the second round of the Volusia championship over the Ormond Beach Golf Club course today.

Max Lipsky, 32 years old, one of three men convicted three weeks ago in the kidnapping of a meat market owner for a $50,000 ransom, was sentenced to a term of from twelve and one-half to twenty years in Sing Sing yesterday by Judge Nott in General Sessions.

"The law," it is said, "has already become air-minded." That is true only with reference to Federal and State statutes and regulations. In an article in March Current History Mr. HOWARD OSTERHOUT says that it is not true of "case law, "which so far lacks the precedents "of our highest courts."
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 10 -- Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d and Joseph E. Widener gave a dinner tonight at their villa for:
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The text of the statement for the American Committee on International Settlements of the International Chamber of Commerce is as follows:

BOSTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks took a long stride toward a National Hockey League play-off berth tonight by coming from behind to cage two third-period goals to upset the Boston Bruins, 3 to 2, in a bruising struggle.

ALBANY, March 10 -- The good faith of State Republicans in their support of the New York City investigation was challenged tonight in the Legislature when the Democrats demanded action on a measure to provide for closer scrutiny of up-State municipalities and were defeated on party lines.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, March 10 -- The Flattop Fuel Company instituted suit in the district court today against Mare Nostrum Soc. Anon. Di Nav., owners of the Italian steamship Comitas, for recovery of $1,033 allegedly due for hunker coal sold to the defendant.

The voice of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, Cardinal Hayes and Walter S. Gifford are typical of the best in American speech, Miss Dagmar Perkins, founder and president of the National Association for American Speech, said last night at a dinner of the Teachers Club of New York in the Hotel Brevoort.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation declined 102,521 tons in February, or to 2,545,629 tons at the end of the month, the lowest in the history of the company. There was a decrease of 87,203 tons in January, which reduced the total of unfinished business to 2,648,150 tons at the end of that month, which also was a new low mark up to that time.

LONDON, March 10 -- The expected reduction in the rate of the Bank of England to 4 per cent was well received in the stock markets today. Most prices were better, although the close was dull after profit-taking. Sterling was cheaper both on New York and Paris following the Bank rate cut.
PESHAWAR, India, March 10 -- Trouble is threatening the northwest frontier from two sources simultaneously.

Robert Edmond Jones is having an exhibition of marquettes at the Bour- geois Gallery, 123 East Fifty-seventh Street, to stay until March 26. In the seventeen years of his professional activity he has desigined the sets for forty-nine dramatic works, "The Wild Duck," "Redemption," "The Jest," "Holiday," "Machinal," "Cross Roads," "See Naples and Die," "The Green Pastures," "Mourning Becomes Electra" and "Night Over Taos" among them.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith charged Mayor Curley of Boston with trickery and trying to put him in a false light before the Democrats of Massachusetts in a telegram sent to Mr. Curley yesterday.

In the foreword to "Search," Lincoln Ellsworth's reminiscences of his many adventures in exploration, published by Brewer, Warren Putnam, Gilbert Grosvenor, the president of the National Geographic Society, has begun with the following paragraph:

To Save Mount Taurus. In the closing hours of the Legislature at Albany the effort to save Mount Taurus, in the Hudson highlands, from the quarryman's drill and preserve it as a State park will fail unless its friends rally and pass the enabling bill.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Marking the heaviest over-subscription to a government issue of securities in many months, the subscriptions to the $900,000,000 offering of treasury certificates to go on the market March 15 amounted to $3,402,725,500, Secretary Mills announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Citing the need of funds with which to complete the electrification of its New York-to-Washington lines, the Pennsylvania Railroad today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve a 3-year $55,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 10 -- Three Americans and one Canadian marched into the semi-final round of the annual Bermuda amateur golf championship at the Riddell's Bay Club today.

GENEVA, March 10 -- The League of Nations Assembly's drafting committee agreed today on the text of a resolution on the Sine-Japanese conflict which is considerably stronger than any of the League's previous lesolutions or declarations on the subject.

SHANGHAI, Friday, March 11 -- China has replied to Japan's proposal for the cessation of hostilities and the withdrawal of Japanese troops and declares she is in complete readiness to accept the terms of the League Assembly's resolutions of March 4 as defined at Geneva by Dr. W.W. Yen, Chinese delegate.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 10 (AP) -- Rationing of gasoline throughout Chile for "strictly necessary" purposes is expected to begin soon under government supervision as an economic measure under regulations for the control of foreign exchange.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 10 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian National Railways have adopted a system for controlling traveling, hotel and other expenses of officials which constitutes a check on these disbursements. Salary cuts and layoffs arranged in the interests of economy will effect a saving of approximately $2,225,000 a year.

No fewer than 1,504 stores, or about 10 per cent of the whole number, are available for rent in the Manhattan area bounded by Fortieth and Ninety-sixth Streets, Sixth Avenue and the East River, the Real Estate Listing Corporation, publisher of the Store Red Book -- Manhattan Vacancies, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- The wheat market continues full of surprises. The bearish construction placed by the trade late yesterday on the government's report of reserves of grain on farms resulted today in little or no pressure on futures on the Board of Trade here, and the trade, likewise, ignored bullish developments abroad.

The proposed series of informal conferences at which the Board of Estimate, Transit Commission, Board of Transportation and representatives of the B.M.T. and Interborough will strive to reach some understanding on the rapid-transit unification problem will get under way next week, it was said yesterday at City Hall.
The fundamental principles of deductions from Federal income tax for depreciation and obsolescense were explained yesterday by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 11 -- At the annual meeting of the Romany Chorus, held this afternoon at Casa Beata, the home of Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne, the following officers were re-elected for the year: Mr. and Mrs. Dobyne, president and secretary; Hugh Dillman, vice president, and Francis A. Shaugnessy, treasurer.

PASADENA, Cal., March 11 Sun bathers are having to expose themselves a third longer to get the healthful results of six or eight years ago, Dr. Edison Pettit, astronomer of Mount Wilson Observatory, said today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial says: "On the whole, the new bill distributes its burdens even-handedly." It seems to me the saving grace of this statement is the phrase "on the whole."

Lydia B. Maier gave a purchase money mortgage for $9.000, due March 1, 1935, at 5 1/2 per cent. to Henry Morgenthau, as trustee of the will of William J. Ehrich, on the southwest corner of First Avenue and Twentieth Street.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 11 -- Credit for genuine economies in the State Government below those suggested by Governor Roosevelt was claimed tonight by the Republican legislative leaders as the session came to a close.

The Port of New York Authority announced reductions of toll charges yesterday on the three bridges between Staten Island and New Jersey, to become effective April 1. These spans are the Bayonne Bridge over the Kill van Kull between Bayonne, N.J., and Port Richmond, S. I.; the Goethals Bridge between Elizabeth, N.J., and Howland Hook, S.I., and the Outerbridge Crossing between Perth Amboy, N.J., and Tottenville. S.I.

BOSTON, March 11 -- A slate of twelve candidates for delegates at large to the Democratic National Convention pledged to Alfred E. Smith for the Presidential nomination was announced today by Chairman Frank J. Donahue of the Democratic State Committee.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Governor Roosevelt today appointed Samuel I. Rosenman, his counsel, as Supreme Court Justice to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Mullan. When the nomination went to the Senate for confirmation, members of both parties joined in unanimous commendation of Mr. Rosenman, and his confirmation was voted at once by a rising ballot.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- President Hoover, prosperity, prohibition and American schools are all "victims of publicity of the wrong kind," delegates to Schoolmen's Week at the University of Pennsylvania were told today by Dr. Clyde R. Miller of Columbia University.

After holding conferences here more than a month, representatives of the world's leading copper companies announced yesterday that they had agreed upon further curtailment of production, and that foreign sales would continue to be made through Copper Exporters, Inc., the cooperative selling organization whose existence had been threatened by dissension over marketing arrangements.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 11 (AP) -- President Hoover was assured of fifty-two of Ohio's fifty-five delegates to the Republican National Convention when the time for entering candidates in the May primaries closed at 6:30 o'clock tonight.

MIAMI, Fla., March 11 -- Half a length was the margin by which Mrs. M. Colford's My Purchase won the Del Prado Purse, feature at Tropical Park today. The son of Purchase and Whim, which was bred by Harry F. Sinclair, had to be put to a hard drive to stave off Jambalaya and Prince Fox, which finished as named, but only a nose apart.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- Miss Elizabeth Swift Ogden, daughter of Mrs. Everett Malcolm Hawley of Chestnut Hill, became the bride of Walter Kelsey Nield of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Nield of East Aurora, N.Y., at a ceremony this afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Hawley.

Ball at $1,000 furnished for Mrs. Vincent Coll, widow of the slain gang leader, when she was convicted on Feb. 26 on a charge of possessing a pistol, was forfeited yesterday in Special Sessions and a warrant for her arrest was issued.

DETROIT, March 11 (AP) -- Five thousand persons packed the Arena Gardens tonight for a meeting avowedly sponsored by Communists and heard speakers demand "the trial and conviction of Henry Ford for countenancing the murder of our comrades."
BALTIMORE, Md., March 11 -- A special dispatch today to The Baltimore Sun from Washington says:

In as fine an exhibition of women's squash racquets as has been seen in New York, Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia defeated Mrs. William H. Adams of the Rockaway Hunting Club, Cedarhurst, yesterday to succeed the latter as the holder of the Junior League challenge bowl.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 11 (AP) -- The defeat of Lord Tennyson's team of English cricketeers was indicated as the second day of the second match against the Colony of Jamaica concluded today.

LONDON, March 11 -- One of the simplest royal weddings, yet one of the most romantic which London has ever known, was that today of Prince Lennart, a grandson of the King of Sweden, to Karin Nissvandt, a daughter of a Stockholm merchant.

Reflecting the shipment of only seventy-seven locomotives last year, the American Locomotive Company and its subsidiaries report for 1931 a net loss of $3,929,384 after depreciation, taxes, reserves for discount on Canadian exchange and other charges.

Frank Shields of New York, member of the Davis Cup team and finalist at Wimbledon in 1931, will be the first of the top ranking favorites to go into action today as play in the national indoor tennis championship gets under way with Jean Eorotra of France defending his title.

Promising to treat all information confidentially, regardless of its source, the New Jersey authorities appealed to the country at large again yesterday for information regarding the whereabouts of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's kidnapped baby.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 11 -- A citizens' protective committee, formed tonight at a meeting of about seventy-five residents here, authorized Hamilton McInnes, former Republican city chairman, to appoint a legal committee to propose court action against the appointments of department heads by John F. Donovan, City Manager, which the committee charges were the result of a political "deal."
BERLIN, March 11 -- Campaign excitement mounted to a high pitch throughout Germany tonight as the Presidential race entered the last lap in a veritable storm of propaganda before Sunday's election.

The cold wave slackened in New York yesterday, but Winter dealt heavy blows to other parts of the country and raged with unabated , fury on the Atlantic. The Rocky Mountain region experienced the coldest weather in two years, while Southern States, threatened with extensive crop damage from the cold, reported snowfalls.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Hoover stated today that the campaign of the Citizens Reconstruction Organization, now active in 2,395 communities, had already achieved positive results in releasing hoarded money. He expressed the hope that every idle dollar would be returned to circulation.

A further advance toward the solution of one of nature's most important secrets, the process by which the coloring substance in plants, known as chlorophyll, utilizes sunlight for the conversion of carbon dioxide into sugar, starch and proteins, thus furnishing food for all living things, was described last night by Professor James B. Conant, chairman of the division of chemistry at Harvard University.

Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to ignore foreign fluctuations and, after holding at a slight advance in most of the session, the list closed at the bottom, 1 to 3 points off.

Testimony that salesmen had been ordered to stop selling supplies to certain laundries in Coney Island was presented yesterday at the public inquiry by State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. into the activities of the laundry industry in Greater New York.

PARIS, March 11 -- Quotations on the Bourse were irregular today, with trading greatly diminished. The approaching German elections and rumors concerning dividends of large French institutions contributed to the hesitancy, but the offerings in many cases were absorbed.

The House Interstate Commerce Committee is considering a bill, approved by Rear Admiral MOFFETT and a group of professional and business men, which, would subsidize transatlantic passenger dirigibles by means of mail contracts. Whatever may be said for or against the proposal, no strong technical reason can now be advanced against the employment of the Zeppelin in regular transatlantic oceanic service.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The "public share of responsibility," quoting your editorial of this date, is, as a mere citizen sees it, just this: We sit under this condition of civic breakdown of law and order and do nothing. You do more than I do, because at least you can speak out in your paper.

PARIS, March 11 -- A resolution urging a united international campaign to show the beneficial qualities of wine in nations with prohibition laws and in countries where it is excluded for religious reasons was voted today by the International Wine Congress, attended by delegates of thirty wine producing or consuming countries, which closed with a dinner here tonight.
TOKYO, March 11 -- All five members of the death band accused in the assassinations of former Finance Minister Inouye and Baron Takuma Dan are now under arrest.

Three productions will be withdrawn from the Broadway playhouses after tonight's performances. They are "The Inside Story," at the National Theatre; "Black Tower," at the Ambassador, and "Marching By," at Chanin's Forty-sixth Street. "Park Avenue, Ltd." will end a brief engagement at the Provincetown Playhouse tonight.

"Fifty Years of French Painting," from Renoir to Modigliani, is current at the Newhouse Gallery through March. The most striking thing about the show is the way in which comparatively mild impressionists like Pissaro, Sisley and Max Jacob stand up beside such masters as Renoir, Redon and Degas.

SHANGHAI, March 11 -- The Chinese and Japanese Government representatives here are now delaying agreement on the cessation of hostilities by quibbling over the exact meaning of the phrases "no conditions" to be exacted by Japan from China and the "complete withdrawal" of Japanese troops.

BUENOS AIRES, March 11 -- Minister of Agriculture de Tomaso has decreed the immediate expenditure of $1,250,000 for the construction at La Plata of a refinery for the preparation of lubricants which will handle 400 tons of crude oil daily. Argentina has been importing 50,000 tons of lubricants a year.

LONDON, March 11 -- Nevilie Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, assured the House of Commons today that the view evidently held by some members that the United States would be forced off the gold standard was entirely mistaken. He also added that the recent financial measures undertaken by the American Government were wisely conceived and might prove beneficial to the whole world.

Delayed four days by going to the rescue of a vessel in distress, the White Star liner Adriatic arrived last night and docked at her West Eighteenth Street pier with less than a day to unload and ship on new cargo, fuel and provisions for her return trip.

MOSCOW, March 11 (AP) -- A Tass (Russian) news agency dispatch from Blagovestchensk today said that the Chinese garrison at Sakhalin, across the Amur River, revolted yesterday when the flag of the new Manchurian State was hoisted. The soldiers killed a number of persons, including two Japanese residents, the dispatch added, and bullets from their rifles fell in Blagovestchensk.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The stock market investigation planned by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today moved further into the indefinite future. A subcommittee of this committee engaged in redrafting the Glass banking bill also was far from completing the bill despite a week of intensive work.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Carley Harriman are expected on the Europa and will be at the Park Lane.

The opera for the special Wagner matinee yesterday in the Metropolitan Opera House was the fabulous "Siegfried." If a devotee of the "Ring" were asked which of its operas he preferred, he might well reply, "The one I am hearing." But "Siegfried" has its special riches and unique enchantment.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Plans of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad to issue $28,142,000 of 4 1/2 per cent gold mortgage bonds as collateral security for $9,000,000 of short-term notes were approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The proceeds of the issue will be used in partial reimbursement of the road for expenditures made in 1931 for various equipment.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. AUGUSTA OFF SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 -- The Black striking force, part of the Black Fleet that is defending the Pacific Coast from "attacks" of an imaginary Blue invader, is far out in the Pacific this evening steaming toward the setting sun.

A ball was given last night in the Louis XV Ballroom of the Ambassador by the Association of the Graduates of the Corps des Pages of the former Emperor of Russia. Under the patronage of many prominent Russians now living in New York, the event attracted many members of society, several of whom formed special committees.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Japanese Consul General at Shanghai has expressed his regret to Edwin S. Cunningham, the American Consul General, for an assault last Saturday upon Arthur R. Robison, American trade commissioner, the State Department announced today.

More than 800 alumni of Princeton University assembled at dinner in the Roosevelt last night to honor Dr. John Grier Hibben, who succeeded Woodrow Wilson as president of the university in 1912 and who is to retire in June, after twenty years' service.
ALBANY, March 11 -- The following table shows the effect of the new truck and bus tax, as passed in the Legislature today:

The better tone in trade and industry that became apparent about a month ago continues, according to the weekly reviews by the mercantile agencies. Among the favorable factors noted are a slight increase in buying by railroads, several manufacturers of boys' clothing working overtime and New England shoe factories operating near capacity.

The New York Chapter of the American Society of Landscape Architects has prepared, at the request of the Municipal Art Society, designs for an approach to the $3,500,000 Roosevelt Memorial Building and Arch which the State is now erecting at Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street, adjoining the American Museum of Natural History, it was disclosed yesterday.

TOKYO, March 11 -- Fresh instructions were sent to Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Minister to China, at Shanghai today which were intended to carry the Shanghai negotiations over the obstacle of China's demand for an immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Japanese troops.

Without giving any evidence of general unsettlement, the bond market tended toward unsteadiness yesterday and this probably accounted for the reactionary character of the share market. Pronounced weakness developed among some of the active stocks, with net losses running as high as 2, 3 and 4 points in spots.

After deliberating for about eight hours, jurors in Judge Morris Koenig's part of General Sessions who heard the trial of Sam Wong, 30 years old, a wealthy Chinese restaurant owner of 202 Mulberry Street, at 12:45 this morning returned a verdict of not guilty of murder.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Senators Kean and Barbour of New Jersey formally notified President Hoover today of their State Republican Committee's endorsing his renomination and simultaneously instructing the delegates to the national convention to strive for a prohibition repeal plank.

CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -- Michigan's track forces, favored to retain the Western Conference indoor championship, swept men into ten qualifying places in preliminary heats at the University of Chicago field house tonight.

Maurice E. Biederman, who was designated as a candidate for Democratic State Committeeman against John H. McCooey, Brooklyn leader, in the Eighteenth Assembly District, filed his declination yesterday with the Board of Elections. Mr. Biederman, whose designating petition had 1,015 signatures, in announcing his retirement from the contest said:
RIVERTON, N.J., March 11 -- Claude J.K. Anderson, portrait painter, reported to the police today that an attempt was made early this morning to kidnap his son, Chilton V. Anderson, 3 years old.

The Legislature had a disagreeable task to perform this year, and on the whole did it well. The State faced an unparalleled shrinkage in revenues, which could only be met by heroic measures of economy and taxation. Just how far retrenchment should go was at issue between the Republicans and Governor ROOSEVELT, but they managed to agree with him on the principal features of his budget and tax program.

With more than two million ballots received and tabulated, the poll on prohibition conducted by the Literary Digest shows the wets still leading the drys by more than three to one. The dry vote continued to gain, however, climbing from 22.61 per cent of the total last week to 23.66 this week.
WASHINGTON. March 11 (AP) -- Gambling and drinking resorts on ships anchored beyond the three-mile limit were the target of a bill passed by the Senate today intended to keep their patrons ashore.

LOS ANGELES, March 11 -- Joan Bennett, 22-year-old film star, and Gene Markey, 36, film writer and son of Colonel and Mrs. Eugene Markey of Chicago, will be married on Wednesday morning at the Town House here in the presence of twelve guests.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Congressional leaders read with interest today the statement by the American committee of the International Chamber of Commerce that settlement of reparations is a a purely European problem.

Stanley High, former editor of The Christian Herald, who recently accepted the pastorate of the First Congregational Church, Stamford, Conn., will speak Monday night at 6 o'clock at a dinner at the Hotel McAlpin, marking the close of the fifty-third year of the Congregational Club of New York and vicinity.

BOSTON, March 11 (AP) -- Two representatives of labor left Boston today for a conference tomorrow in New York with William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor. The Massachusetts men took with them proposals for Federal legislation designed to aid industrial conditions in Massachusetts and establish uniform hours for labor.

The Dance Centre last night presented for the first time a ballet arrangement of Prokofieff's "The Prodigal Son," with scenario and choreography by Gliick-Sandor. Barring an egregious breach of taste in one scene in which the crucifixion is presented allegorically, it is as good as the best of the Dance Centre's repertoire.

On the ground that unrevealed interests behind a recent offer of Munds, Winslow Potter for stock of the company are attempting either to gain control of the Reliance Management Corporation or to make a profit for themselves, Morton H. Fry, president of the company, is urging stockholders not to sell their stock to the brokers.

Mayor Walker, who has complained recently of frequent severe pains above his heart, collapsed during a heart examination at the Rockefeller Institute last Thursday afternoon, it was revealed yesterday when he left his bed to preside over a Board of Estimate meeting at City Hall.

Jefferson High School's quintet gained a deadlock with Tilden in their three-game play-off for the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. championship when it triumphed by 40 -- 23 in the second contest of the series yesterday in the winners' gymnasium before 1,200 spectators.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- If there was any poor workmanship or faulty material used in the construction of the navy's airship Akron it was corrected before the dirigible was completed, according to the report of the House Naval Affairs Committee, which today closed its long investigation into charges of weakness in the ship's structure.

The first goal of an increase in Federal taxes is to bring the national budget into better balance. A second purpose, equally important, should not be overlooked. Action must be taken at this time if the Government is to comply with provisions for reduction of the public debt and thereby keep faith with its creditors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After you ease the reputations of the ostrich and the crocodile, why not do something for poor old King Canute, or Knut? He is much maligned. His case is a fine ironic example of the value of education.

As the aftermath, of the steady run-up of prices in the listed bond market this week, profit-taking yesterday caused an irregular finish, with foreign and domestic averages moderately lower. However, a fairsized list of bonds of virtually all groups made further new highs for the year and closed at or close to the day's best prices.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 11 -- Ocean City High School's basket-ball team won the South Jersey Class B championship by defeating Hammonton High School's quintet tonight, 50 to 18. Ocean City also qualified for semi-finals of the State tourney to be held at Asbury Park next week.

Three new organizations of the seven making application for membership were admitted to the Association of Junior Leagues of America, Inc., it was announced at the closing session of the Spring meeting of the association at the headquarters in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.
MOSCOW, March 11 -- The kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby has been utterly ignored by the Soviet press. This gives a measure of the difference between newspapers in Russia and the United States.

An offer of composition for the firm of Gurnett Co., suspended from the New York Stock Exchange on Jan. 5, was filed in the United States District Court of Massachusetts yesterday, providing for the payment to creditors of 50 cents in cash and 50 cents in notes.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- An attempt by Senator Vandenberg of Michigan to tack onto the Interior Department appropriation bill today a resolution by Senator George of Georgia, giving President Hoover wide authority to abolish or shift government bureaus, failed by two votes when Senator Harrison of Mississippi broke a tie by changing his vote from "aye" to "nay."

President HINDENBURG'S radio address to the German voters may well turn out the decisive factor in tomorrow's election. The moving appeal of the aged soldier-statesman for national unity in a grave hour may bring forth the margin of non-partisan votes needed to give him a straight majority and so obviate the necessity of a second election.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Democratic leaders of the House used every resource today to hold their main lines against continued assaults on the proposed 2.25 per cent manufacturers' sales tax, backbone of the program for balancing the budget in the fiscal year 1933.

CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -- Charles S. Dewey, former financial adviser to the Polish Government and previously Assistant Secretary of the United States Treasury, was today elected chairman of the finance committee of the Colgate-Palm Olive-Peet Company.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Property damage in the Chapei and Northern Shanghai districts, as a result of Sino-Japanese military operations, now totals about $33,400,000, Julean Arnold, American Commercial Attache at Shanghai, today reported to the Department of Commerce.

LOS ANGELES, March 11 -- Mary Nolan. film actress, and Wallace T. Macrery Jr., her husband, were sentenced to serve thirty days in jail each today by Municipal Judge Clement Nye following their conviction for violation of the State wage law.

ALBANY, March 11 -- After a final day of strife, the sharpest of the session, over the measure designed to increase the tax on heavy motor vehicles and permit balancing the budget for the next fiscal year, the Legislature reached final adjournment at 8:07 o'clock tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: BEVERLY HILLS, Cal., March 11 -- In one of my little poems I said the bankers were the first to go on the "dole." The "wrath of the mighty" ascended on me. Even The Wall Street Journal (Wall Street's house organ) editorially said I should confine my jokes to some semblance of truth.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, March 11 -- Hundreds of Finnish fishermen rescued today told pitiful stories of their misadventures on an ice field in the eastern part of the Gulf of Finland, where more than 700 men with about 100 horses had been adrift since Tuesday on large floes detached by a strong wind from the main ice field.

The Great Blizzard. It began at midnight of Sunday, March 11, 1888, and will be celebrated this year by a club, of which ex-Governor SMITH is a member, because he sold newspapers in the severe snowstorm of March 12.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 11 -- The Issue of peace or war in Europe rests largely with France and depends upon the manner in which she chooses to use her military, political and financial hegemony, Henry Morgenthau, former Ambassador to Turkey, declared in an address here tonight before the Institute on Near Eastern Affairs at Brown University.

Salvatore Spitale and Irving Bltz, designated by Colonel Lindbergh to negotiate for the return of his son, were placed on trial yesterday in Federal court, Brooklyn, with thirteen others on an indictment charging conspiracy to violate the prohibition law by landing a cargo of liquor at Gerrittsen Beach last July 26.

The Real Estate Bondholders Committe of Greater New York, of which George E. Roosevelt is chairman, announced yesterday that on the request of S.W. Straus Co. it would act as the committee for reorganization of the Lexington Hotel property, Lexington Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, and for the $3,900,000 of its 6 per cent.

SHANGHAI, March 11 -- The serious problem of clearing up conditions in the ruined parts of Chapei approached a solution today when Mayor Wu Te-chen agreed in principle that the International Settlement take over measures for sanitation in the three Chapei areas which were devastated by shellfire, aerial bombing and incendiary conflagrations.
HAVANA, March 11 (AP) -- Sun Worship, a 6-year-old son of Sun Briar, kept his Winter record clean when he won his third successive race at Oriental Park today.

International Great Northern. The International Great Northern Railway, controlled by the Missouri Pacific, reported a net loss of $214,536 in January after taxes and charges, against a net loss of $183,835 in January, 1931. Current assets were $3,729,526 on Jan. 31, against $4,693,278 a year previously, and current liabilities were $3,293,441, against $2,603,334.

That 860 school papers should be deemed deserving of prizes in a national competition calls attention to a form of journalism that has a distinct place both in the press and in education. These school publications have as great value for the editors and reporters and other contributors as for the little world that each one of them seeks to serve.

Extension of the Block Community Organization drive to enroll at least 12,000 block chairmen and 150,000 wokers, instead of 10,000 block chairmen and 100,000 workers, was announced yesterday by Wiltoti Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the organization, who said the first stage of the campaign had been completed with the acceptance of 135 district, chairmen.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Census Bureau is excluding from its State reports of occupation statistics persons engaged in bootlegging or tending bar, officials disclosed today in connection with publication of a tabulation of the number of workers in New Jersey who were gainfully employed in 1930.

Jobbers Delay Dry Goods Orders. Wholesalers continued to hold back orders in the primary dry goods market during the week, pending an expansion in demand from retail stores for Spring goods, according to reports in jobbing circles yesterday. The extremely cold weather prevailing in many sections of the country was the main retarding factor and retail purchases, particularly in the South, dropped off considerably.

Help for the candidacy of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for President came from an unexpected quarter yesterday when John Biggs Jr., chairman of the Democratic State Committee of Delaware, called on James A. Parley at Roosevelt headquarters and said he believed the six delegates from that State would be for Roosevelt.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 11 -- The defending titleholder, Mrs. Helen B. Stetson of Philadelphia, former national champion, was beaten today by the medalist, Miss Bernice Wall of Oshkosh, Wis., in the women's Belleair championship. In this semifinal round match Miss Wall gained her first triumph over her veteran rival by winning 2 up.

NEWARK, N.J., March 11 -- Chester I. Barnard, State director of emergency relief, declared today, after a conference with Governor Moore on relief administration, that the stopping of road work by the State Highway Commission because of lack of funds would increase the relief problem by depriving 2,000 family heads of Income.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- In the face of a threatened reduction of more than one-fourth of its appropriation for the fiscal year 1933, oficials of the Children's Bureau are trying to decide what projects could least harmfully be abandoned if the proposed limitation on its activities finally is approved by Congress.

Traffic on Broadway in the vicinity of Fiftieth and Fifty-first Streets was tied up for more than a quarter of an hour at theatre closing time last night when a crowd estimated at 10,000 persons was attracted to the scene of a smoky fire in a shore store at 1,638 Broadway, in the building housing the Winter Garden Theatre.

Criticism of certain acts of some of the mortgage companies and loan institutions in Brooklyn in their dealings with builders was voiced at a meeting last Wednesday night of the Associated Builders of Kings County at the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., March 11 -- Chester D. Pugsley, who announced yesterday that the Austrian Government had accepted his offer to finance an institute of international affairs in Vienna, this year, said today that he had received similar acceptances from the governments of Germany and Sweden.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- A New York Chinese and a Bombay Indian today told a House committee trying to find a means of stabilizing silver that one of the best hopes they could see was an international conference to encourage nations to use silver as a reserve.

LONDON March 11 (AP) -- At the wool auction today a good selection of South Americans were sold at full current rates, the Continent securing the bulk of the offerings. There were frequent withdrawals among medium and low-grade greasy crossbreds due to sellers' firm limits.

Revision of Protestant church services so as to place less emphasis on sermons and more on participation by congregations in prayers of confession and forms of religious worship such as responsive readings is expected to come out of the organization of a committee on worship being formed by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, it became known yesterday.
MEMEL, March 11 -- Developments here are driving rapidly to a climax, which, it is feared in German circles, will be the dissolution of the Memel Diet.
Paintings of children and flowers constitute the current exhibition at tha Reinhardt Galleries. 730 Fifth ATenue. Included is work by a score of artists, French and American.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Democratic National Committee today reported to the house clerk it had $140,489 in its treasury Feb. 29, but that its outstanding obligations totaled $786,116.
