Since Governor SMITH went into the real estate and banking business, has there been a gradual petrifaction of that once melting heart? In Washington Senator KING tells him how dear he is and was and ever shall be to Democrats and Progressives.

LONDON, March 11 (AP) -- No sooner had the wedding ceremony of Prince Lennart and Miss Nissvandt ended today than a representative of the Swedish Legation stepped up and handed an envelope to the Prince, and in it was a new passport which certified that he was plain "Mr. Bernadotte."

Preparing for the resumption of public hearings next week, counsel for the Hofstadter legislative committee worked yesterday to clean up several lines of inquiry. Samuel Seabury, counsel for the investigation, who returns today from a vacation in Bermuda, was expected to decide which case shall be taken up first and to fix a date for the first open hearing.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 11 -- Lehigh University's wrestlers, winner of the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association team championship three times in the past four years, gave indications tonight that they would retain the title in the twenty eighth annual meeting, which ends tomorrow in Archbold gymnasium a Syracuse University.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The State Banking Department announced today that it had approved the organization certificate of the Personal Finance Company of Union Square, New York, a personal loan company, which is to continue in business until Dec. 30, 1933.

Construction by the North American Company of new facilitites in 1931 required the expenditure of $42,060,196, more than 80 per cent of which was for electric facilities, while net increase in plant after retirements was $28,636,808, according to the pamphlet report of the system mailed to stockholders yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- lt was clearly indicated today in government quarters that the United States is not disposed to keep any marines in Nicaragua after this year.

SHANGHAI, March 11 -- The United States naval strength here is being gradually reduced. Five destroyers departed today, one up the Yangtse River, three for the Philippines and one for Swatow, to resume normal activities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of a letter from "Constant Reader" in THE TIMES, I append the following, which appeared in Harper's Weekly of Oct. 10, 1857. The letter is copied from one to The Middlebury Register, Middlebury, Vt., in ' its issue of Jan. 28, 1832:

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- The bulk of the $1,000,000 estate of Henry F. Michell, horticulturist and seed merchant, will be shared by his widow and daughters, Mrs. Alien W. Morton of Rodgers Ford, Md., and Mrs. Louis A. Shaw of Boston, under the terms of his will probated today.
Forty-five candidates, including eighteen veterans of last year, reported to Coach Jack Coffey at the first outdoor practice of the Fordham baseball squad yesterday at Fordham Field.

Excepting his one idea of regarding men as the submissive sex, Julian Thompson has very little originality to contribute to his burlesque comedy, "The Warrior's Husband," which was acted at the Morosco. But it is a good enough idea for an evening's fooling among the bouncing Amazons and the stalwart Greeks of legendary days, especially since Romney Brent and Colin Keith-Johnston have the leading parts.
AMHERST, Mass., March 11 -- Taking nine first places, the Amherst track team downed Wesleyan in a Little Three indoor meet today, 74 1/2 to 38 1/2.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a well-defined feeling, no longer limited to any one type of citizen, that the present City Government has led us year after year into extravagant municipal expenditure that must inevitably have most serious consequences.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A demand for the exclusion of all products of Soviet Russia from the United States will be presented to Secretary Mills on Monday by representatives of more than 100 organizations. Senator Oddie, Republican, of Nevada, said today.

PARIS, March 11 -- The International Chamber of Commerce, as it has many times in the past decade, issued a solemn warning today on behalf of the business men of the world that unless armaments and tariffs were reduced and reparations and war debts settled, the world could not hope to get out of the present economic crisis.

Continued weakness in sugar futures, with a new all-time low for May contracts at 0.78, was the most significant development in commodities yesterday. Lower prices wer also recorded in coffee, hides, the grains and cotton, with irregularity in silk and a higher market for rubber. The cash market also showed a mixed trend.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 -- Babe Ruth steered his division of the Yankee forces to a 10-to-2 victory today in the third and deciding game of the intra-club series at Huggins Field, thereby winning the camp championship over Lou Gehrig's team, two games to one.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- The bulk of the $1,000,000 estate of Henry F. Michell, horticulturist and seed merchant, will be shared by his widow and daughters, Mrs. Alien W. Morton of Rodgers Ford, Md., and Mrs. Louis A. Shaw of Boston, under the terms of his will probated today.
Forty-five candidates, including eighteen veterans of last year, reported to Coach Jack Coffey at the first outdoor practice of the Fordham baseball squad yesterday at Fordham Field.

Excepting his one idea of regarding men as the submissive sex, Julian Thompson has very little originality to contribute to his burlesque comedy, "The Warrior's Husband," which was acted at the Morosco. But it is a good enough idea for an evening's fooling among the bouncing Amazons and the stalwart Greeks of legendary days, especially since Romney Brent and Colin Keith-Johnston have the leading parts.
ALBANY, March 11 -- The chief measures passed or rejected in the session of the Legislature closing today follow:

ARUBA, Dutch West Indies, March 11 (AP) -- D.I. Maxwell, president of the Pan-American Employes Association, has cabled Chairman Charles Crisp of the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives at Washington, protesting against the proposed import tax on petroleum products into the United States.

Heaviness on the Stock Exchange yesterday reflected the market's fatigue more than anything else, or so it appeared to Wall Street. The net declines ran from a fraction of a point to 4 points so far as the active issues were concerned. The composite average, based upon fifty stock, showed a net loss of $1.90.

A fighting man of the ring with a deep disdain of a rival's blows, Shristopser (Bat) Battalino, Hartford Italian, who formerly held the world's featherweight title, last night established himself as a contender for welterweight title honors with a smashing ten-round victory over stout-hearted Eddie Ran of Poland before a crowd of 15,000 at Madison Square Garden.

David T. Abercrombie, founder of the sporting goods firm of Abercrombie Fitch and president of the Abercrombie Corporation, left an estate valued at only $10,793 net in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday at the State Tax Commission. The gross estate, before deduction of debts and expenses of $10,624, was valued at $21,417.

Of $61,418,566 of new State and municipal bond and note issues scheduled for award next week through competitive bidding, the bulk will come up on Tuesday, headed by the issue of $35,000,000 State of Louisiana 5 per cent highway bonds.

Several Interesting changes were recorded in the money market. Yield rates on acceptances, thirty to ninety days, inclusive, were shaded 1/8 to 2 5/6@2 1/2 per cent, lowest since early October last, and a drop in time money of 1/4 to 3@3 1/4, with business reported at the lending rate.
Residential properties, including several apartment houses, figured almost exclusively in the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday.

A loss of 3.6 per cent on sales for 1931 is the "probable common or typical experience" of dry goods and specialty stores, according to preliminary figures on 100 stores having an annual sales volume of $500,000 to over $10,000,000 issued yesterday by the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

A.C. Welsh, traffic manager of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, urged that the construction of the proposed freight tunnel between Greenville, N.J., and Brooklyn be undertaken as a means of freeing Brooklyn "from the handicap of delays and irregularity of service," in a report submitted yesterday to Linford S. Stiles, engineer of a joint committee of the Port of New York Authority, Pennsylvania Railroad and the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce.

GENEVA, March 11 -- The Assembly of the League of Nations unanimously adopted yesterday's draft of its three-point resolution for the settlement of the Sino-Japanese dispute tonight after the resolution had been made "stronger and more worldwide" by being extended to cover the Kellogg-Briand peace pact.

It is not hard to understand why the Japanese Government is irritated by the resolution adopted by the Assembly of the League of Nations and speaks of it as proof that Secretary STIMSON is "leading the League by the nose."

The repeal of prohibition is Just the first step in the comprehensive program of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, said Mrs. John S. Sheppard, New York State chairman of the organization, in addressing members of the business and professional women's division of the New York State division at a luncheon yesterday at the Commodore.

Every phase of journalism, from newspaper make-up to editorial writing was considered yesterday by the 1,400 pupils from schools in many States who are attending the eighth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association. Special problems were discussed at a score of meetings of small groups, and leaders in education and newspaper work addressed the youthful delegates at gatherings of the entire group in the McMillin Theatre at the Columbia School of Business.
NEW ORLEANS, March 11 (AP) -- Song Hit, which campaigned successfully over the Florida turf before moving to New Orleans, won the Pearl River Purse over six furlongs at the Fair Grounds today.

BERLIN, March 11 -- The slow decline in prices, despite the small vol ume of trading which baa been characteristic of the Boerse throughout the week, continued today. Since the apathy is due chiefly to political uncertainties, there appears little hope for an early improvement.

New issues of bonds and notes totaling $19,512,000 were placed on the market here this week. Virtually all the issue were taken quickly by investors, several of them being oversubscribed on the day on which they were offered. Last week new financing aggregated $39,960,000, but of this, $25,000,000 was debentures of the Federal Intermediate Credit Banks System.

Following the financial retrenchment policy formally launched on March 4, the Board of Estimate received a report from its chief engineer yesterday showing that small amounts had been allotted to the various boroughs for local improvements out of the $5,000,000 fund set aside for that purpose.

LONDON, March 11 -- Sterling was lower in the foreign exchange market today. The New York rate opened 4 cents cheaper at $3.62, recovered to $3.64 and later dropped to $3.63. Leading Continental currencies also were adverse to London. British Government funds were lower, the 3 1/2 per cent conversion loan at u82 3/8 and the war loan at L101 13-16.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Unqualified approval of the resolution adopted by the Assembly of the League of Nations with reference to the Sino-Japanese crisis was expressed by Secretary Stimson late this afternoon. He stressed the importance of the action and asserted that the United States Government "has been glad to cooperate earnestly in this effort."

Every dollar returned to circulation means from five to ten dollars restored to credit, General James G. Harbord, chairman in New York State for President Hoover's anti-hoarding campaign, declared yesterday in an appeal for support in the drive to check hoarding.

ALBANY, March 11 (AP) -- Governor Roosevelt today convened an extraordinary term of Supreme Court at Cooperstown to try indictments against Thomas J. Mangan, official of the closed State Bank of Binghamton and a member of the State Board of Regents.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, March 12 (AP) -- Chinese cavalry and Japanese troops occupying the front line five miles northwest of Kiating clashed in a brisk skirmish just before midnight last night, General Yoshinorl Shirakawa's headquarters announced this morning.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted:

Miss Lois Lindon Smith, youngest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lindon Smith, was married to John Jay Schieffelin, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin, yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The bride is a granddaughter of the late Major George Haven Putnam, author and dean of American publishers.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- The University of Chicago's new "laboratory of learning" in which a student's aptitude may be measured by machinery, will be dedicated next week in the presence of educators gathered from all parts of the country.

NEWARK, N.J., March 12 -- The Meadowbrook Club of Philadelphia, scoring a total of 21 points, carried off the women's National A.A.U. indoor track and field championship in the Newark Armory tonight. The Newark Women's A.C. was second with 14 points, beating the Medford Girls' Club for the runner-up honors by a half point.

DETROIT. THE fact that total motor car sales so far this year are running behind those for the corresponding period of 1931 is not so disquieting to those In the automotive industry as many might believe. It is ascribed entirely to the absence of a full array of new models in the lowprice class.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Ralph Waldo Emerson warned America that "while we may hope to civilize the Pawnee, to mollify the housebreaker and to reform the drunkard -- with the debauchee of sentiment we can do nothing!" This has a special application in the disposition, to sentimentalize about war -- its glories in wartime and its horrors when peace has come.

ST. PAUL, March 10 -- Many a politician in the history of the West, both before and after Bryan, has risen to greatness on the mortgages of agriculture. Because of the individualistic character of the farming industry, waves of deflation breaking over the land following periods of inflation bring with them particularly violent political movements.

PEIPING, March 12 -- The longsmoldering hatred of the Kuomintang party, fanned by the winds of discontent over the government's failure to assist effectively the Nine-teenth Route army in defending Shanghai, broke into flame here today.
MONTREAL, March 12 (AP) -- A goal in the first period gave the Montreal Canadiens a 1-to-0 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in a fast National Hockey League game toinght.

Long under attack by the parent primarily interested in his child's sleep and outdoor play, home study for young children and adolescents now comes in for hard words from outstanding educators as well. In the forthcoming bulletin of the White House Conference on Child Health and Protection, which deals with home and school cooperation, public and parochial school officials all go on record in favor of home work's curtailment or its entire abolition.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 10 -- Back home for a week-end after his invasion of Winter-bitten North Dakota, Governor Alfalfa Bill Murray forecast victory for his colors over those of Franklin D. Roosevelt in that northern arena on March 15 and outlined plans for a more extensive campaign for delegates to Chicago in June.

G.O. SIMONS, president of Simons-Stewart Company, Inc., announced at a meeting of Chrysler dealers and salesmen held at the Park Central Hotel last Monday that the company's sales in February in the metropolitan district showed an increase of 156 per cent over February, 1931.

IT is not in the daily record of international diplomacy, nor in the reports of the League of Nations, nor in the public announcements of politicians, that the aspect of Europe is really revealed. These are but the distant echoes, the formal and cold summaries, of events that make themselves felt in millions of homes, on thousands of streets, in thousands of villages.

OSSINING, N.Y., March 12 -- The Yonkers High School basketball team gained its second victory in the New York State high school tourney tonight, defeating Arlington High, 36 to 15. Yonkers, the defending titleholders, had an advantage at half time of 17 -- 6.

Ethel Leginska last night conducted the initial concert of the Woman's Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall; the first time, so far as is known, that an orchestra entirely feminine has appeared there under a woman director.

WITH the prohibition question reverberating through the councils of both major political parties as well as through Congress, the attitude of the Democratic candidates on this issue commands increasing interest. Of the eight men prominently mentioned as possible standard-bearers of the Democratic party, no two take exactly the same position on the prohibition question.

A RISE OF THE POUND. GRACEFUL compliments have marked the conferring of recent high judicial appointments by both President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt. The President in appointing Judge Cardozo, former Chief Judge of the New York Court of Appeals, to fill the vacancy in the Supreme Court of the United States created by the resignation of Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes, termed the New York jurist, a Democrat, a worthy successor to Justice Holmes.
The race for championship honors in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League ended last night in a deadlock between Columbia and Princeton.

A review of the reports made by the investigators of the kidnapping on March 1 of the infant son of Colonel Charlea A. Lindbergh fails to reveal a definite clue to the whereabouts of the child or to offer a promise that he will be restored to his parents.

PARIS, March 11 -- One of the consequences of the stretch of five days between the death of Aristide Briand and his burial has been the opportunities it has given for political squabling almost literally over his dead body. All his sincerest friends and admirers here are agreed that his death occurred at a most unfortunate time so far as permitting a just and dignified appraisal of that great statesman's career is concerned.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Senate today confirmed the nominations of Frank Evans of Utah, William F. Schilling, Minnesota, and Sam H. Thompson, Illinois, as Federal Farm Board Commissioners after bitter attacks on the salaries paid to managers of farm cooperative associations.

Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C. retained his hold on the national amateur squash tennis championship by winning the title for the third consecutive year yesterday, vanquishing Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club court in Brooklyn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "A Bygone Institution" rather derides the work of the old-time lyceum that was a benefit to the people of a past generation and especially to poor midWestern audiences. I remember that institution in its dying days, when in a small Pennsylvania town the intellectual people -- and there were a few -- struggled to maintain a lecture course.
CINCINNATI, March 12 -- Frank M. McKee, 40 years old, State aeronautics director, was found dead in bed at his home at Columbus, Ohio, today, a victim of heart disease.
DAIREN, Manchuria, March 12 -- Japan's difficulties in setting up the new Pu Yi Government in Manchuria are thickening rapidly.

LONDON As a result of "arduous researches made by those who fear that the world has been wrong for nearly 200 years," The Daily Express recently announced the belief of "literary archseologists" that Thomas Gray wrote his "Elegy in a Country Churchyard" at Upton-cum-Chalvey and not at Stoke Poges.

AIKEN -- Continuing next week will be the series of annual Spring tournaments at the Palmetto Golf Club play for the Iselin Cup opening on Monday, and for the Phelps Cup for ladies the following day. As the season advances interest in the tournaments is growing daily and should be at its height for these two events and for the Southern Cross tournament, which begins on March 21.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 12 -- Yale's varsity fencing team, which came here with six straight victories, lost to Harvard tonight, 9 to 8. Yale won the freshman competition, also by 9 -- 8.
LONDON, March 12 -- Betty Gow, nursemaid to the Lindbergh baby, told her mother in Glasgow in a letter received today that she felt "numbed and terribly lost without that darling."

Beaumarchals, French dramatist and friend of the American Colonies in their struggle for independence, was perhaps the first man in Europe to utilize modern publicity methods, it was asserted yesterday by Professor Felix Gaiffe of the University of Paris, visiting French professor at Columbia University.

The rapid increase in the number of stockholders in American corporations in the last two years was hailed by the managements of these companies as affording an opportunity to build up a large and loyal group of customers, Colby M. Chester, president of the General Foods Corporation, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is not only helping banks to remain open but will also facilitate the closing of those banks which, finding operations unprofitable, desire to pay depositors in full and voluntarily cease business.

WHEN thinking of your Easter, and that means Spring, wardrobe, think in terms of the silhouette -- for, to be elegant, your lines must be slender. Never has this been truer than in the season that is just getting into the fullnes of its stride.

TORONTO, March 12 -- Sudden death, victory or defeat in overtime for the National Hockey League play-off games was ordered by the N.H.L. governors in session today. It was ordered that overtime periods in the play-offs shall be of twenty minutes' duration, with five minutes' interval allowed to clean the ice.

A collection of Early American furniture, including andirons and firesets, mirrored candle sconces, pewter, lustre-ware of Staffordshire, Liverpool and New England manufacture, early glass, hooked rugs and a variety of silver pieces will be among items auctioned this week at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc. Most of the numbers are from Harry F.R. Dolan of Boston.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Administration leaders in the House decided today that they could find the necessary strength to overcome what has become a very real split in the Democratic ranks over the tax bill.

That people of very moderate circumstances and limited education are as interested in keeping their knowledge up-to-date as those of higher educational background is being demonstrated by the new De Witt Clinton High School's Institute of Adult Education.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A total of 49,940 persons were gainfully employed in Elizabeth, N.J., in 1930. Among them were 38,109 males and 11,831 females of the age of 10 years and over, the workers of both sexes comprising 43.6 per cent of the population and 53 per cent of all persons over 10 years of age.

LONDON, March 13 -- The British scientific world today received further proof of the existence of the neutron, the mysterious ultimate particle which Dr. James Chadwick of Cambridge recently discovered radiating from the metal, beryllium.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Miss Caroline Byron Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon A. Smith of Lake Forest, and George S. Chappell Jr., Yale graduate, whose father was a classmate of Miss Smith's father at New Haven in 1899, eloped today to Aurora and were married by the Rev. W.E. McCormack of the Congregational Church.

Through the $400,000,000 Kreuger Toll Company, which is strictly an investment and financing company, Ivar Kreuger, who committed suicide in Paris yesterday, was personally interested in the development of many types of industries, banking operations and international finance, and was constantly traveling from one country to another to direct the varied enterprises and keep in touch with financial and business conditions.

FRANK WEITENKAMPF in his new book "The Quest of the Print" brings up so many points for the undergraduate llector to consider, so many sugestions for the man of modest -- at the moment increasingly modest-means to follow, so many pitfalls at lie in the path of such collecors, such amazing possibilities for ginners of Judgment, taste and a ndency toward thoroughness, that is quite necessary to own the book one would profit by it.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Five records went tumbling as Indiana, by a slim margin of five-sixths of a point, won the Western Conference indoor track and field championships tonight for the first time in the history of the Big Ten.

Federal prohibition agents raided the Petit Riche restaurant at 112 East Fifty-fifth Street, just west of Park Avenue, early last evening, arrested the manager and twelve other employes, ordered 200 patrons, many of whom were in evening clothes, out of the place and began dismantling the elaborate fixtures of the establishment, which they estimated had cost $50,000.

Public officials and political leaders "walked the plank" last night at the annual dinner of the Inner Circle at the Hotel Astor, when a band of performers, costumed as pirates and buccaneers, produced a seven-act musical show entitled "Treasure Island," under the supervision of Max Mencher, president.

Miscellaneous, THE established taxicab rates in New York City are fifteen cents for the first quarter of a mile, five cents for each additional quarter -- and a final tip of as little or as much as the passenger, enjoying a sense of superiority or suffering in confusion of timidity, la impelled to give.
TOKYO, March 12 -- The general staff is preparing to withdraw threesevenths of the Japanese forces now in and near Shanghai without awaiting the result of negotiations for cessation of hostilities.
PARIS, March 12 -- A number of Americans are visiting Paris before proceeding next week to England to attend the Grand National.

The New York Institute for the Education of the Blind, the oldest school of its kind in the country, will mark its hundreth anniversary this week. The school was founded by Dr. Samuel Akerly and Samuel Wood. Its first director was Dr. John D. Russ and its first student's were three blind orphan boys.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended March 5 were higher than for the previous week but 33 per cent below a year ago, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The German Republic stands at the crossroads. Today the Reich will vote for a new President. On the result depends not only the development of German domestic politics but perhaps the development of European politics for some time to come.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Judge James H. Wilkerson, who sent Al Capone to jail without ball, received praise today from President Hoover. It came as newspapers carried appeals from Capone in his Chicago cell to be released that he might hunt for the kidnappers of the Lindbergh baby.

THE author of this truly monumental work is Professor of Political Science at Heidelberg University. A Baltic German, born in Riga when it was part of the Russian Empire, a graduate of the University of Moscow, an economist in Tsarist Russia, Dr. Eckardt has a unique background for the problems which he approaches.

MOSCOW, March 11 -- One of the strangest paradoxes in this paradoxical country is the way the Saviet authorities, whose fundamental policy is superiority of group effort and collective action over individual initiative, look askance at attempts at organization by foreigners here.

The transfer of fifty of what are believed to be the oldest and what are certainly one of the rarest of railroad bond issues by Wood, Struthers Co. to a financial institution served to recall events in the transportation industry dating back to 1845.

Senior high school swimmers of the Manhattan-Bronx division bettered three of the season's records and tied another at the fifth series of dual meets for the championship of the Public Schools Athletic League in the seventy-five foot pool of George Washington High School yesterday.

EVIDENCE that there existed in Alaska an Indian culture related to that of the Maya Indians in Mexico has been found by Dr. Ales Hrdlicka, curator of physical anthropology of the Smithsonian Institution. For the past few months, Dr. Hrdlicka has been studying intensively the material he uncovered last Summer on Kodiak Island, south of the Alaskan peninsula.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Information that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was ready and willing to make loans on the assets of closed State banks was made known today in a letter written by General Dawes, its president, to Senator Brookhart, which the Senator made public.

WHEN a novel is sincere and well-intentioned; when it is obviously the product of very genuine feeling; when it is written by an author who has, at one time, done pretty good work, one feels exceedingly churlish at being obliged to report upon it unfavorably.

In a letter to N.I. Stone of this city, a director of the National Bureau of Economic Research, former tariff expert of the Department of Commerce and former economist of the United States Tariff Board, Senator Borah declares that he is opposed to the use of an economic boycott against Japan in the present Sino-Japanese conflict.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 12 -- Captain Andrew Hamilton Calhoun, oldest member of the Old Guard of the City of New York, died last night at his home, 25 Park Place, after a long illness. He would have been 89 years old on Wednesday.

A collection of drawings by the sixteenth century Italian artists, Taddeo and Federigo Zuccaro, some of which belonged at one time to such famous British painters as Sir Joshua Reynolds, Sir Thomas Lawrence and Sir Peter Lely, has been brought to America by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach, who acquired the album from Sir Thomas Phillips, Thirlestane House, Cheltenham, England.

CAPE TOWN, Feb. 7 -- Events now shaping themselves in South Africa are bound to have no small effect on the Imperial Conference which will meet in Ottawa this Summer. If matters go on along the same lines as heretofore. South Africa may find herself the "enfant terrible" of the conference, at odds with Great Britain on at least two vital points, namely, empire preference and empire currency.

WHEN the "realistic movement began, some thirty or forty years ago, the word "realism" was synonymous with everything that was unpleasant, drab and unhappy. No doubt this was due to the fact that the pendulum, after the manner of pendulums, had swung too far in its retracing of the arc of romanticism.

The new White Star liner Georgic, which is under construction in Belfast and is scheduled to sail from Liverpool on June 25 on her maiden trip to New York, will be operated in the cruise service of the line after her Summer at sea is completed. She will remain in the transatlantic service during the normally active months of July and August, but in September will go to the West Indies.

SEVERAL hundred thousand American Girl Scouts celebrated yesterday the twentieth anniversary of their organization. A score of years ago eight girls stood in a small house in Savannah, Ga., held up their hands and solemnly swore to obey the Girl Scout laws.

The Blizzard Men of '88, organized survivors of the snowstorm of forty-four years ago, which in tragedies, excitement and far-flung effects was the greatest storm New York has had, assembled at their annual luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday and recounted personal experiences connected with the epochal event.
ALBANY, March 12 -- Only four out of a score of bills affecting New York City and dealt with by the Legislature at the session just ended failed to receive approval by both houses.

Last-minute passage by the State Legislature of measures providing for a one-year extension of the time limit on required alterations to existing residential buildings under the multiple dwelling law brings much-needed temporary relief to many property owners in this city, in the opinion of the Real Estate Board of New York.

Vanitie, Gerard B. Lambert's America's Cup yacht, is to be put overboard at City Island this week and towed to the Herreshoff yard in Bristol, R.I., where the changes are to be made in her for racing against the Weetamoe during the coming Summer and probably with the old defender Resolute as well.

BUENOS AIRES, Inarch 6 -- The establishment of a central bank of issue and the complete severance of such an institution from the commercial business now carried out by the Banco de la Nacion are two changes required by the banking and currency system in Argentina, in the opinion of Dr. Enrique Uriburu, Minister of Finance under the Provisional Government.

NORFOLK, Va., March 10 -- The stiffest fight in the present session of the Virginia Legislature has resulted in the State taking charge of all highway maintenance and construction, thereby increasing the mileage under State control from some 8,000 to four or five times as much, and as a corollary officially recognizing the principle that the State highway system extends inside the corporate limits of cities.

LONDON, March 12 (Canadian Press) -- The question of the composition of Great Britain's delegation to the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa next July has occupied London newspapers all week, with Opposition papers endeavoring to show the Cabinet is in a muddle over the problem.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The State Department has informed Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, in response to an inquiry, that the United States does not intend to recognize the revolutionary government of President Maximillano Martinez in San Salvador because to do so would be contrary to the Central American treaties of 1923.

Heavy importations of carrots from Holland and onions from Chile were reported in the New York market last week by Georgre G. Royce of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets. Unfavorable growing weather in the United States last Fall caused a shortage here in both vegetables.

Thorough reform in the operation and administration of the judiciary, in both high courts and low, was urged by Governor Roosevelt yesterday in an address to about 1,000 members of the New York City Bar Association in its quarters at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The House Expenditures Committee was told today by Secretary Mills that, since President Hoover knows "more about the government than any other living man," he should be allowed broad power to supervise reorganization in the interests of economy.

The application of the revenue bill now before Congress to the public utility industry in all its branches is the subject of unusually close attention by officials of public service companies and their attorneys because of novel features which the measure contains.

A FESTIVAL of contemporary American music, to be devoted to compositions for chamber ensemble, will be held at Yaddo, Saratoga Springs, N.Y., from Friday, April 29, to Wednesday, May 4. Three concerts, for which several hundred invitations will be issued, will be presented on April 30 and May 1.

In sharp contrast to the limited degree of activity in metropolitan real estate last week were the evidences of marked improvement in the demand for suburban properties. There are indications that this increasing interest for homes and building sites in all of the popular suburban centres near New York will continue to be more noticeable as the Spring season advances.

EARLY Spring brings with it prospect of two large dances, the Butterfly and Rainbow Balls, which are among the outstanding post-Easter events of each year and which are given in behalf of philanthropies that have a large patronage from New York society.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., March 11 -- Increased car loadings of the Pennsylvania Railroad, though slight, are encouraging, as small freight movement has heretofore accompanied decline in industry.

ROME, March 11 -- With the signing of the Italo-French commercial modus vivendi coinciding almost exactly with speeches in the French Senate expressing hope that the numerous difficulties that have kept France and Italy apart may be finally smoothed out, and with Premier Tardieu's reply voicing the same sentiment, hopes have been revived that the tension which for years has existed among the neighboring Latin nations may be overcome at last.

Various phases of education will be discussed by more than 4,00O educators of the East at the eighth annual Junior High School Conference next Friday and Saturday, according to an announcement yesterday by Professor Earl R. Gabler, chairman of the conference committee. The conference will be held at New York University under the auspices of it School of Education.
BUTLER, Pa., March 12 -- Eight persons were indicated in the grand jury today as conspirators in a plot to "fix" the Kline-Succop jury panel.

BERLIN, March 3 -- England is the nation of astonishing Olympic surprises and with good reason, too. For the British, sport is still only play, not, as for other nations, hard work or national duty. For them it spells recreation and pleasure, joy especially for the youth.

TODAY. 11:30 A.M. -- Nina Koshetz, soprano and composer, and the Philharmonic-Gymphony Quartet are the guest artits on the Library of Congress musicale over WJZ. The members of the quartet are Joseph Reilich, first violin; David Katz, second violin; Ralph Hersch, violin, and Martin Toicholtz, cello.

Picture Postcards. Doubtless there are hundreds of thousands of persons living who, like myself, bought picture postcards at Chicago World's Fair, 1893. Visiting Europe in 1902, I found a much better grade than could be found in the United States. -- WILLIAM S. ROWELL, Wilkinsburg, Pa.

Three members of the State Senate, George R. Fearon of Syracuse, Republican leader; Samuel H. Hofstadter of Manhattan, Republican, and William Lathrop Love of Brooklyn, Democrat, were commended in a review of the session of the Legislature by R.E. McGahen, secretary of the Citizens Union, made public yesterday.

Land which is merely real estate to the lawyer in office hours may suddenly become landscape when he picks up a paint brush, it appears from the third annual exhibition of the Business Men's Art Club of New York, which will be opened to the public on Tuesday at the Maurel Gallery, 689 Madison Avenue, after a private showing tomorrow.

The action of the Shippers' Conference of Greater New York in opposing the proposed merger of Eastern rail lines into a system of four large groups and recording its opposition to the Johnson bills which would require intercoastal ship lines to file tariffs and limit industrial ship lines to the transportation of their own products was praised by shipping men yesterday as a move to protect opportunities for competition in the port of New York.

THERE is genuine need for improvement in practically all phases of the relations between the two Americas. For convenience, the fields in which the improvement ran propped most hopefully are here grouped under three heads: political, economic and cultural.

LONDON IN a realistic moment, taxes being due, a British duke took his gold and jeweled coronet to a Bond Street jeweler and received therefor in paper pounds the equivalent of $52,200. It is only at coronations that coronets are serviceable.

WASHINGTON DOES America want to go native in the White House, as it did in the days of Andrew Jackson and Abraham Lincoln? Texas thinks it does. With the exception of Calvin Coolidge -- and he succeeded to the Presidency through the death of his chief -- it has been almost a hundred years since the resident of a village became our Chief Executive through direct election.

BOSTON, March 12 -- The first authentic announcement that Governor Roosevelt of New York would wage an open contest against ex-Governor Smith for pledged delegates from Massachusetts to the Democratic National Convention was made today by Mayor James M. Curley of Boston.

ON BOARD THE U.S.S. AUGUSTA, IN THE PACIFIC, March 12 -- The great game of hide-and-seek between two "opposing" forces of the navy continued today with 2,000,000 square miles of shifting Pacific rollers as a playboard, and 140 men-of-war as participants.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 12 -- For the fourth time this season Army's gymnasts totaled more than 50 points in winning a dual meet when they overwhelmed Colgate today by a count of 51 to 3 for their fifth successive victory of the season. Colgate scored its only points on third places in tumbling, rings and rope climb, all tallied by Hall.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 -- While political wiseacres are endeavoring to diagnose the meaning of a surprising increase in Democratic registration, and economic doctors are looking for significance in faint signs of hope in the business situation, the leaders of esthetic thought are encouraged by the response made to the appeal for a popular fund to sustain the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Declaring that unless the voters have an opportunity to express their will before the national conventions of the two major political parties the nominees for the Presidency will be selected by the politicians, Senator La Follette, insurgent Republican of Wisconsin, introduced a bill in the Senate today for a nation-wide referendum on Presidential candidates to be held in all of the States on June 7.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 12 -- Spotting the Harvard poloists a 10-goal handicap, the Yale polo trio today defeated the Crimson, 23 to 15 1/2, in a contest which saw the Blue Riders overcome the early odds against them as the second half began.

TWO events of the last ten days, which have visited sorrow upon the living, appear as tokens of the end of certain phases of American music. One of these was the death, on the 6th of this month, of the gifted and honored "March King" of America, John Philip Sousa.

More than 100 persons will appear before Surrogate James A. Foley tomorrow morning or be represented by counsel in the filing of objections to the probate of the wilt of Ella Wendel, aged spinster, the last of five daughters of John Gottlieb Wendel, founder of the fortune, who lived and died in the old brick house at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street.

IT is, of course, an impeccably phrased document, now excusably faded, which under the date of Feb. 19, 1912, summoned the carriage trade to the pseudo-Georgian doors of Winthrop Ames's new Little Theatre, there to sit before its inaugural presentation, John Galsworthy's comedy, "The Pigeon."

BERLIN, March 11 -- One of the effects of the world economic crisis is that it has sent the more enterprising business men of many nations traveling abroad to see what can be learned from their neighbors that can be adapted to fit their own needs.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., March 32 -- A 19-year-old youth clung to a ledge of broken ice in the Gruendyke mill pond for nearly half an hour this afternoon in an attempt to rescue two boys who had broken through the ice while skating. Attempts to revive the boys were unsuccessful tonight, and their rescuer was reported to be in a critical condition.
BERLIN, March 1 AT the Deutschcs Theater "Vor Sonnenuntergang" ("Before Sunset"), a new play by Gerhart Hauptmann.

PASADENA, Cal., March 12 (AP) -- Literary and motion picture associates waved farewell to Zoe Akins, playwright, and Hugo Rumbold, noted painter and theatrical designer, when they left for an unannounced destination after their marriage here today.

WALTER HUSTON is once more fighting political corruption, in "The Beast of the City," which is at the Roxy. An actors' actor, Mr. Huston knows his business from the cellar up to the attic. He was born in Toronto, spent his boyhood on a Canadian farm and got his start on the stage with a repertory company in Toronto.

THE SQUARE ROOT OF VALENTINE" is a delightful and utterly crazy performance in which Berry Fleming has successfully combined pleasant foolery with amusing satire on Wall Street, on religion, on science and art and love, in fact on all the subjects which men might at any time have been inclined to hold sacred.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Three policeman and a woman and her child were wounded by shots in an anti-Japanese demonstration and rioting by about 1,000 Communists in crowded Michigan Avenue, the pride of Chicago's boulevard system, at noon today.

NEURUPPIN, Germany, March 12 (AP) -- A coachman from an aristocratic estate who was driving along a country road this morning beard moans from a near-by wood. Investigating, he discovered a tragedy involving Mathilde Dischmann, a 12year-old schoolgirl from New York City, and Herbert Huelsen, 16, a Neuruppin youth.

WASHINGTON, D.C. THOSE interested In the continued improvement of traffic management see a danger in the threatened entrance of political into the field of motorvehicle regulation. The particular situation attracting attention right now la that in New Jersey, where advocates of uniform motor-vehicle laws and centralized administration are concerned about what they consider an attack upon an established motor-vehicle department.

INSTALLATION has been started at the Newark Metropolitan Airport of the landing beam, the work of developing which has been going forward for more than five years, with actual flying laboratory experiments at an isolated airport in Maryland not far from Washington for the last twelve months.
WOMEN interested in the charitable projects of the Children's Shelter of Manhattan have taken over the performance at the Palace Theatre on Tuesday night for the benefit of the institution.

To what extent will economy be an issue in the campaign this Fall? So far as the Federal Government is concerned, it is too early to tell. Both sides are doing their best to make capital out of it, President HOOVER calling for reorganization and retrenchment, the Democrats in the House boasting of the way in which they have used the axe on Administration money bills.

NEW ORLEANS, March 12 (AP) -- Spanish Play, which chased Mate home in the Arlington Classic last year, carried the silks of Knebel-kamp and Morris to his third successive victory when he won the feature New Orleans Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.

THERE is a distinct and impressive composite picture of the many-sided activities of aeronautics in the Aircraft Year-book for 1932, published last week by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America. The volume, the fourteenth in this series of year-books, is more comprehensive than ever, containing this year a complete trade directory of the industry in addition to the narrative of its accomplishments in 1931.

IN "1919," John Dos Passos continues his explorations in the modem American and Americanized world which began with "The Forty-second Parallel" and which will continue, one assumes, until the series is rounded off in either a trilogy or a tetralogy.

LONDON. THERE is a paternalism about the British censorship of films which has surprised nobody except those people who had forgotten that the board of which Edward Shortt, formerly Secretary of State for Home Affairs, is president was appointed primarily to protect the interests of the screen industry.
BUFFALO, March 10 -- In the year of a presidential election, incidents of local politics begin to have wider significance than at other times. Several examples have come up recently in Buffalo.

To the Los Angeles Athletic Club, long a power in women's as well men's swimming, has gone the premier event of the women's indoor campaign -- the national championship meet. The A.A.U. awarded the title competition to the Coast club last week, and it will be held in the Olympic Swim Stadium, now under construction, during the last week in April.

THE there dancers who appeared in recitals last Sunday evening all proved to be provocative of considerably more exhaustive comment than could be contained in a brief review, and the occasion to make somewhat fuller observations on their performances is hereby embraced.

CHICAGO. EASILY the most exhilarating show of the season is the exhibition at Increase Robinson's Diana Court Gallery -- portraits of Chicago artists by Chicago artists. Mrs. Robinson's bright idea, sprung in the early days of January, took the fancy immediately of Chicago's artists, radical and conservative, and the exhibition, now flung open, is the result of the most spontaneous ferment Chicago art has known since a decade ago when NoJury was launched.

VATICAN CITY, March 12 -- A number of lawsuits recently brought against several churches in Italy for non-payment of royalties on sacred music by modern composers played during religious ceremonies has induced the Sacred Congregation of the Council to issue a new set of instructions to prevent a repetition of this trouble.

Mail orders provided a steady stream of activity during the week, according to the market report especially prepared for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. There was considerable action in ready-to-wear, partly due to the early advent of Easter, while there was expansion of Spring buying generally, the report noted.

KEEPING an airway beacon, like keeping a lighthouse, can be a very prosaic and monotonous occupation. But romance may touch the beacon keeper, romance of the air, just as heroic moments of the sea touch his brother in the lighthouse.

WITH the Group Theatre assembling on the stage of the Forty-eighth Street Theatre after each performance of "Night Over Taos" to sing "Bromberg for President," it becomes possible and in fact even necessary to illuminate the reasonable progress of J. Edward Bromberg.

The Liverpool Grand National, generally accepted as being the most difficult steeplechase in the world, will be run Friday over the famous Aintree course with the chances of an American victory interesting many on the other side as well as here. Twice American-owned horses have finished first at the end of the grueling 4 miles 856 yards.

With the finest field to gather for the tournament in years, the national indoor tennis championship pot under way at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixtysixth Street, yesterday with Jean Borotra of France in the role of defending titleholder.

FOR the first time in their history some of the charitable organizations of this city are making an appeal to friends outside for funds to alleviate the severe distress now existing among unemployed young women and among children whose parents are without means to provide the barest necessities of life.

THE English, having long since acquired an immutable repu- lation for stern reserve about things that please their hearts most, are able to be loquacious and even lyrical about such matters. And there are few things that come so completely within that category as the aristocratic institutions, known as the Engliah public schools.

THE magnificent voice which in France never stopped pleading for peace, is now mute. The memory of Aristide Briand is receiving the conventional tribute of recognition and eulogy which follows the death of a great man. Passions, rivalries, envy, all the invisible horde of foes which rise up around a leader, have vanished.
On a historic site in the Place de la Concorde, Paris, the new American Government office building is rising as a fit neighbor for the famous old structures that surround it.

The "victory campaign" of the Democratic National Committee to raise $1,500,000 to pay the deficit of the 1928 campaign and provide money for the Presidential campaign has brought in a total of $555,000 in cash and pledges so far, John W. Davis, chairman of the campaign committee announced yesterday.

The proposed sales tax was opposed yesterday afternoon by Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, who addressed the weekly forum of the National Democratic Club on "The Industrial Outlook."

POPULAR government in these difficult days is being assailed with more than usual vehemence for its habit of fiddling while the world is in flames. Yet it is only fair to recall the precise circumstances of the original fiddling incident.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 12 -- Led by Alex Wilson's record-breaking performance in the half-mile run, Notre Dame today won the annual Central Intercollegiate Conference indoor track meet, beating the well-balanced Michigan Normal team, 26 7-10 to 22 6-10.

THE only trouble in iriterviewing Clive Brook, if one may so label that distinct pleasure, is that the carefully considered questions and the lanes into which the discussion might have been led, are quickly forgotten before his engrossing manner of speech and the easy grace of this English gentleman's bearing.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 10 -- InJiana Democrats are maintaining an attitude of watchful waiting while the Presidential situation develops. They have not committed themselves to any of the men prominently mentioned, nor are they likely to do so, out they do want to be in a position, to jump on a bandwagon if one goes by.

Winter relaxed its grip somewhat yesterday and temperatures hers rose slightly. The high winds that had been general throughout the week abated, and ships which had been in distress or missing following persistent gales were reported on their way to port.

BENITO MUSSOLINI, Capo del Governo, recently received a report from the Ministers of Corporations and National Education concerning the decadence of the Italian theatre. Based on the project of Rome's most famous dramatic critic, it set forth the causes of this decadence and pointed out the path toward rehabilitation.

THE broadcasters confess that the Lindbergh kidnapping case has given them some new thoughts on news broadcasting. They rushed to the scene in New Jersey as they have to Roosevelt Field in the past to broadcast, the arrival of a transatlantic airplane.

TORONTO, Out., March 12 -- Canada supplies approximately 90 per cent of the world's stock of nickel, principally from ores in the Sudbury area of Ontario. In December Canadian producers reported an output of 3,530,525 pounds of nickel, according to a statement just issued by the Dominion Government.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The sixth annual archery tournament of Pinehurst is one of the outstanding sports events of the coming week, and the golf at the Pinehurst Country Club will include the annual mixed foursomes of the Silver Foils Club and the annual mixed foursomes of the Tin Whistles Club.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The mystery surrounding the Christmas poem recorded in George Washington's boyhood copybook, now in the Library of Congress, has been solved by the recent discovery of one of the "missing" volumes of the collection that formed the library at Mount Vernon when Washington lived there as a boy with his half-brother, Lawrence.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Representative B. H. Snell of New York, Republican House leader, has been agreed upon by party chiefs as permanent chairman of the national convention. Classified as a dry, he will preside over an assemblage that is expected to become involved in a bitter row over the party's plank on the Eighteenth Amendment.

The New York State Bar Association Bulletin for March reprints an address by Judge CRANE of the Court of Appeals before the New York City bar. It is good to find so eminent an authority declaring that the number of judges in this State "has about reached the limit." The judicial staff is "enormous."
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. John Donaldson of Irvington-on-Hudson entertained with a dinner tonight at their home, followed by a dance.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- George Clyde Hoover, 65 years old, a cousin of the President, died at his home here tonight after a brief illness.

THE new Arts Weekly, successor to The Arts, has made its debut Clothed in the cerulean blue familiar to readers of The Arts, it comprises news and criticism, not only of painting, sculpture and architecture but also of the drama, the cinema, music and books.

SUBSCRIBERS to past entertainments arranged to aid the work of the New York Music Week Association are being asked this year to contribute to a special fund the amount they ordinarily would pay for tickets or boxes for some benefit entertainment.
LONDON, March 12 (AP) -- Arsenal and Newcastle United today won the right to play for the English Football Association Cup in the final game of a competition which began several weeks ago.

For more than a week dispatches from different capitals have hinted that a new federation is being forged in Central Europe. M. TARDIEU is described as the chief proponent of the plan. In some quarters his interest is attributed to a desire to extend the prestige and political influence of his own country.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Adoption by Congress of the Davis radio bill in its present form would require the International Telephone and Telegraph Company either to request the resignation of its foreign directors or to discontinue its radio activities, Frank C. Page, president of the company, today advised the Senate Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.
BERLIN, March 12 -- While the United States is going to church tomorrow, amusing itself or reading Sunday papers, all Germany will be voting in the most crucial election of her whole history.

EXETER, N.H., March 12 -- Taking five firsts, Andover's swimming team turned back Exeter today by 41 to 34 in a meet marked by much record breaking. Four meet standards, one pool mark and one New Engrland interscholastic record fell.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I noted the letter from Scoville Hamlin entitled "Law of Economic Relativity Factor in Business Recovery" in THE TIMES, and take pleasure in informing him that the principles for the sort of stabilization he desires have been laid down.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Growing out of the decision of the United States Supreme Court denying citizenship to Professor Macintosh, an amendment to the naturalization law is now before Congress which reads: "No alien, otherwise qualified in this act, shall be denied citizenship by reason of his refusal on conscientious grounds to promise to bear arms or otherwise participate in war."

TORONTO, March 12 (AP) -- Smashing through a rugged Boston defence for the two goals in the overtime period, the Toronto Maple Leafs took a gruelling National Hockey League game from the Boston Bruins, 5 to 3 tonight. The victory gave the Leafs a clean sweep of the season's home games with the Bruins.

To the Dramatic Editor: As an admirer of Mr. Brooks Atkinson's reviewing of plays may I venture to commiserate him on what I take to have been the usual necessity of catching his edition by wire last Monday night when Shaw's "Too True to Be Good" was having its first performance here?

Consolidation of plant facilities and operations and unification of management in order to reduce waste and out expenses are the major aims of large industrial corporations at the present time, Charles M. Haskins, managing director of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers, told THE TIMES yesterday.

NEWARK, N. J., March 12 -- St. Benedict's Prep of this city, Immaculate Conception of Montclair and Cranford crashed their way to the sectional final of the New Jersey State scholastic basketball tournament by winning games today. All three teams qualified for the State title semi-finals at Asbury Park next Friday and Saturday.
Reports of real estate sales and leases from scattered sections of New Jersey yesterday indicated a good demand for housing properties there.

More than fifty public schools in New York City now have nature rooms, the School Nature League says In reporting the progress of its campaign to have such a room installed in every school in the city. Ten years ago, when the league was founded, existing exhibits were limited to the pollywogs, goldfish and plants that the classroom teacher was interested enough to bring to her room.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., March 10. -- Arkansas is in a clean-up mood. Disregarding such inevitable nuisances as State finances, audit commissions, which litter the State's press, and political rantings, timid office-seekers who know not where to jump, mail-order seed catalogues and missionary society lectures on the Far Eastern situation, the State generally is in the mood of a housewife who reckons to hold Spring house-cleaning, bother or no bother.

BOSTON, March 10 -- No alibi is sufficient to explain completely the Smith debacle in the New Hampshire primaries this week. He was to carry the city of Manchester by a majority big enough to offset the accumulation of Rosevelt majorities in the towns and smaller cities of the State.

PARIS, March 12 -- Aristide Briand, who loved simple things, received today a burial with all the pomp and ritual that France reserves for her greatest citizens. It was inevitable. He himself would have smiled and jested that it should be so and would have accepted it.

OTTAWA, March 10 -- Reports from the liquor commissions which operate in the Provinces of Alberta and Nova Scotia, like that of Quebec, published recently, indicate reduced purchases of alcoholic beverages in 1931 as compared to the previous year and a general trend toward beer and wines.

ST. PAUL, March 10 -- On March 15 St. Paul holds its city primary election. Mayor Bundlie, standing for renomination, is making deflation of government expenses his issue. He demands a reduction of about $600,000 in next year's municipal budget.

SCRANTON, Pa., March 12 (AP) -- A little old lady, half blind and eighty years of age, gave up her life last night in an effort to rescue her four brothers, all over 70 years old, when fire started in their home in the farming district two miles east of Springville, Susquehanna County.

Living conditions of millions of workers and their families throughout the land were denounced yesterday by a group of Socialist organizers who conducted a mass meeting of workers and unemployed at Columbus Circle.

LONDON, March 12 -- The stock markets finished the week dull. British government funds weakened on further profit-taking, the 3 1/2 per cent conversion loan declining to L82 and the war loan to L101 5/8.

Newtown High School of Queens, defending city P.S.A.L. senior high school basketball champion, is the only team which will engage in the interborough semi-finals on Saturday that reached this round in the title competition last season.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- An interesting incident of idle money being returned to circulation is reported from New York, where a bank customer took $300,000 in gold coin and gold certificates from his safe deposit box and deposited them in his savings account.

BETWEEN the covers of a beautifully made book, S.J. Woolf, known for his drawings and accompanying interviews, has gathered together the cream of many years of his labors. Primarily Mr. Woolf is an artist, a master of the pencil and crayon which with well-chosen strokes bring a sitter to life, but a facile writing pen, apparently discovered years after he first began his portrait work, adds interest and charm to his book.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with great interest the address delivered recently by Ivy Lee at Depauw University on the "War Debts Question." Mr. Lee banks on Abraham Lincoln's declaration that "public sentiment is everything."

THE economic depression, with its unemployment, is causing the working women of America to wonder just where they will stand when the wheels of production begin to pick up speed. During the last half century, in which increasing number of women entered the land of adventure called business, they seldom seriously questioned the solidarity of their position.

LIGHTING a motion picture set so that the camera will photograph it and the players effectively is always one of the difficult problems of screen production. Hollywood has painstakingly mastered the secret. Even at this late date many of the European studios are baffled by it.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- The wheat market is marking time. Prices on the Board of Trade here held today within a range of about 1/2 cent, with a small dip early followed by a rally when pit shorts started to even up for the week. The close was at the top at net gains of 1/8 to 3/8 cent.

The business genius of a man who cared little for personal wealth and much for power, as contained in the personality of Ivar Kreuger, the Swedish match king, was discussed last night by Isaac F. Marcosson, the writer and interviewer, who probably known Mr. Kreuger better than most men did in this country.

LONDON, March 12 -- The Light Blue of Cambridge waved triumphant over the Dark Blue of Oxford today for the seventh straight year in track and field, the Cantabs winning the sixty-fourth meet between the rivals, six first places to five. Last year Cambridge won, 8 to 3.

Emil Ganso has outgrown his allegiance to Pascin. The oils included in the Ganso show current at the Weyhe Gallery have the firm outline the strong local color, the carefully constructed composition of the "new realism." Ganso's extraordinary technical facility seems to make a change of style no more difficult for him than a change of clothes for Owen McGivney.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga -- This week's program will include activities in every field of sport, with special events centring around the celebration of St. Patrick's Day. Bridge players will enter the first of the season's tournaments on Tuesday evening, to be played in the card room and sun parlor of the Cloister, with the finals Wednesday evening.

Registrations of thoroughbred dogs with the American Kennel Club for the month of January -- the latest figures that have been compiled -- totaled 3,500. This, in round figures, is identical with the number registered in the corresponding month of 1931.

St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn and St. Michael's of Union City, N.J., yesterday triumphed in the semifinal round of the third annual Catholic metropolitan interscholastic basketball tournament sponsored by the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, Brooklyn.

Politics, economics and social problems in the next three months will be more interesting than ever, but also more complicated. A handy pocket list of fundamental principles and definitions should therefore be of distinct use.

LONDON, March 12 -- Ivar Kreuger's suicide in Paris today caused a sensation, in London comparable to that accompanying the sudden death in 1928 of Alfred Lowenstein, Belgian financier, while flying over the English Channel.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 2 -- The recent revolutions in Salvador and Costa Rica have renewed Interest throughout Central America in a persistent problem. Should the United States continue to prohibit revolutionary governments from holding power?

MELBOURNE, March 10 -- Remarkable speed and resolution in fulfilling election pledges has distinguished the first few weeks in office of the new Federal Ministry led by J.A. Lyons. Its measures have aroused considerable enmity in interested quarters but the vast majority of the people welcome any action whether well or ill advised after the Scullin Ministry's record of compromise and its attempts to tamper with the financial structure.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, March 13 -- The prospects for a formal agreement for the cessation of hostilities and the withdrawal of the major part of the Japanese troops from the Shanghai area were dimmed last night when the Japanese Legation gave out a formal statement virtually refusing to meet the Chinese insistence upon unconditional restoration of the status of "Jan. 28."

SCATTERED across the sprawling swells at the Pacific, somewhere between the tide rips and rocky headlands of the California coast coast the sunswept shores of Hawaii, the might and majesty of American sea power is engaged this week in a far-flung mimic war, the annual test of the country's naval strength.

VIENNA, March 11 -- The casual visitor to Austria might be puzzled to understand why France with its Tardieu plan, Germany with counterproposals for preferential tariffs with Austria, and Italy with a memorandum published on Wednesday declaring the most pressing need in Europe to be the rescue of Austria and Hungary from their plight, are so much concerned about conditions in this little republic.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 12 -- Centralization of extra-mural religious work by students of Princeton Theological Seminary, under the direction of the Department of Christian Education, was announced today at the seminary. The arrangement, which has been worked out as part of the revision of the seminary curriculum now in progress, provides for the supervision of all outside work by the faculty.

BALBOA, in the Canal Zone, and the prostitute quarter of the adjacent city of Panama furnish the background for a tale in which European and Asiatic espionage on the Canal defenses is pitted against the marvelously efficient counter-espionage of the American Navy's Intelligence Department.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 12 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Francis J. Hall, Protestant Episcopal clergyman, author, lecturer and former Professor of Dogmatic Theology at the General Theological Seminary in New York and the Western Seminary in Chicago, died at his home in Baldwinsville, near here, this afternoon.
The new research laboratory at Harvard University has consolidated all of the institution's facilities for the study of physics, according to an announcement yesterday.

The defeat of the Smith forces by the Roosevelt supporters last week in the New Hampshire primaries, the first political skirmish in the Presidential contest, is regarded by leading newspapers of the Democratic South as a blow to the chances of the former Governor.

Three goals by Doug Gubner enabled Poly Prep to score a 3-to-1 victory over Samuel J. Tilden, in a post-season scholastic hockey game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. In another contest, Brooklyn Prep, C. H.S.A.A. champion, was held to a 1-all deadlock by Erasmus Hall.

NEW DELHI, India, March 12 (AP) -- A woman became dictator of the Indian National Congress today with the arrest of Maulana Abdul Kalan Azad, who nominated Mrs. Zutshi, well-known Nationalist, as his successor.

Bonds added to the list of those called for payment in March, before their maturity dates, were few last week, and consisted mainly of small lots of improvement bonds by municipalities. The total for the month, slightly changed from last week, is now $10,513,000, compared with $36,153,000 in February and $87,292,000 in March 1931, at corresponding dates.

Fluctuations of the pound sterling and indications that exchange was assuming a firmer tone held the centre of foreign trade attention here last week. The sudden rise in quotations which carried the pound to $3.70 1/4 on Tuesday from a level of $3.50 obtaining less than a week before, was a source of satisfaction to both exporters and importers.

Dealers in bonds are of the opinion that sentiment can change quicker in the municipal than in any other department of the general bond market. A month ago municipalities whose names were synonymous with high-credit ratings found it next to impossible to borrow on comparatively short-term bonds, even by paying the legal maximum of 6 per cent.
We should reverently watch for the least motions, the least scintillations of thought in this sluggish world; and men should run to and fro on the occasion more than at an earthquake. -- Thoreau.

Establishment of an institute of merchandising research will be an outstanding feature of plans for the coming year of the merchandise managers' group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced here yesterday by Walter Hoving, new chairman of the division.
Eighty prize winners had been determined up to last night among the 357 high schools taking part in the National Oratorical Contest conducted in this region by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

OTTAWA. BEGINNING April 1 the Federal tax on radio receivers in Can- ada is to be $2 instead of $1. The increase is frankly for revenue purposes and has nothing to do with the possible establishment of a national broadcasting service.

OTTORINO RESPIGHI will be the guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra during the coming week. The world premiere of his "Maria Egiziaca" will take place at the special pension fund concert Wednesday night in Carnegie Hall, together with two of his other works for small orchestra, "The Birds" and the "Triptych of Botticelli."

Charles S. Hand resigned yesterday as a member of the Sanitary Commission. In a letter to Mayor Walker he submitted his resignation, "to take effect immediately," declaring that he "cannot longer tolerate the insistent and persistent illegal actions" of the commission's chairman, Dr. William Schroeder Jr.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am grateful for THE TIMES editorial on Federal architecture. I have delighted in the best Federal buildings in Washington, as every one has -- the Capitol, Treasury and others of the older structures. Each has character and Its own distinction.

More than 190,000 persons died of heart disease in New York City during the past twelva years, according to a report made public yesterday by the heart committee of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association. Hardening of the arteries and rheumatic fever are said to cause 85 per cent of heart disease.

Poly Prep's five-year reign as the Athletic Association of Private Schools swimming champion was ended yesterday when Marquand School won the sixth annual A.A. P.S. championship meet held in the McBurney School pool in the West Side Y.M.C.A. building.

DISTRIBUTION of 40,000,000 bushels of the wheat held by the Farm Board to the nation's needy, provided for by the law passed last week, will leave that organization with less than half of the grain acquired during the last three years.

A NEW plant for the purification of the rare gas helium which is used in navy airships is being planned by the U.S. Navy Department. The plant, for which bids will be opened on April 6, will be located at the navy's new airship base at Sunnyvale, Cal.

Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, returned yesterday from Bermuda physically fit and eager to resume public hearings Tuesday after a two-month lapse. Public sessions will be held three, four and five days a week until the investigation of the city is concluded late in May or early in June.

PALM BEACH -- Although the peak of the season, marked by the annual costume ball at the Everglades Club on Wednesday night, has passed and colonists are now in the interval between Winter's strenuous activities and their departures northward, a sufficient number of events is planned to make an interesting program for the ensuing three weeks.

RYE, N.Y., March 12 -- In cold, wet going, with a northwest breeze blowing and drift ice along the shores and on the rocks of Milton Point, the dinghy sailors of the Frostbite Yacht Club carried on today. The iron men were marrow-chilled, snug Arctic outfits proving porous to the chill, but they went through nine races, and among them was Jack Dickerson, one of the six gale-defiers of last Sunday.

THE Cid Campeador thunders again through this break-neck chronicle that would make an excellent scenario for some Douglas Fairbanks -- to whom, by the way, this book is dedicated. Now it is a question whether the great warrior were not better left to the tender mercies of legend -- whether national heroes, like saints and martyrs, should not be seen dimly through the haze of Valhalla to be appreciated.

MOTOR tourists returning from Florida to Hew York will not only have the choice of a number of routes, but will also find much of interest on the way. Georgia and South Carolina both are prolific in this respect and, moreover, the roads now are so good in general as to make it easy to visit the principal places of interest in those States.

PROMINENT members of the French colony here are actively interested in the sixty-first annual ball of the Union Alsacienne, to be held on Saturday in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania for the benefit of the organization's fund for widows and orphans.

AUGUSTA, Ga -- A brilliant array of women golfers, up from the Florida tournaments, competed in the Forest Hills tournament yesterday and will begin the first round of the woman's invitation tournament tomorrow. Helen Hicks, national woman champion and winner here last year, will defend her title with the promise of keen competition from Maureen Orcutt, Canadian champion and former metropolitan champion, Virginia Van Wie.

The spectacular rally in the pound sterling last week brought to the front again the question of the future of the British monetary unit. In recent weeks the steadiness of the pound had lulled discussion of the problem of ultimate stabilization. It was the accepted view of most economists and bankers that a return to the gold standard was out of the question for some time.

RONALD COLMAN stole into Hollywood by the back door last week, coming in from Shanghai with so little warning that Goldwyn's New York office was taken by surprise. He has been away for three months and has had a close-up view of the Sino-Japanese trouble with his friend, Richard Barthelmess.

DETROIT, March 10 -- Last Monday afternoon a mob of 3,000 men inarched down Miller Road and invaded Dearborn, stormed the gates of the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant and demanded jobs. In the rioting which followed four men were killed, nineteen wounded by gunfire, and an unknown number injured more or less severely by stones, bricks and clubs.

The nineteenth annual International Flower Show will open tomorrow for a week's run at the Grand Central Palace. The hours after the opening day will be 10 A.M. to 10:30 P.M., and the show will be the largest ever staged. Heretofore only two or three floors have been required. This year four floors will be used.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Establishment of a regional loan agency at Charlotte, N.C., to be headed by Word H. Wood as chairman, with Torrence E. Hembly as alternate, was announced today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Of the seventeen members appointed to the new agency, ten have been transferred from the Richmond regional committee, previously announced.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Following is the text of Secretary Sana's speech tonight:

Before 500,000 onlookers who will occupy the nine miles of standing room on the Thames for Putney to Mortlake, England, the Cambridge and Oxford eight-oared crews will battle for supremacy for the eighty-fourth time next Saturday morning.
PARIS, March 11 -- Is the hour about to strike for the cause of women's rights in France?
