MILAN, March 1, 1932 OTTORINO RESPIGHI'S setting of "Belkis, Regina di Saba," a choreography in seven scenes, by Claudio Guastalla, now at its tenth performance at La Scala Opera following its highly successful world premiere here, may safely be rated a notable contribution to contemporary Italian ballet literature.

CINCINNATI, March 12 -- Harry E. Taylor, former editor and owner of the Portsmouth (Ohio) Times, one of the most prominent Democrats in Southern Ohio, died in his home there today, after a lingering illness. His age was 58.
PARIS, March 12 -- The Bourse was closed today on account of the funeral of M. Briand.

Completion of the plan by which property owners at Nassau Shores, L.I., will obtain complete control and ownership of the Nassau Shores Country Club from the Harmon National Real Estate Corporation was announced to the owners yesterday by their organization committee appointed for this purpose.

Frank Winner Russum, a construction engineer identified with many large building projects and a member of an old Elizabeth (N.J.) family, died on Friday at his home in the Park Plaza apartments at Larchmont, N.Y. He was 50 years old.

What is the typical American family? Apparently, as good a definition as any would be a household containing at least one relative in addition to the natural group of parents and children. Such at least is a fair inference from a statistical study by Dr. MILDRED PARTEN of Yale, contributed to the symposium on the American family which makes up the March number of the Annals of the Academy of Political and Social Science.

When C. FRANCIS JENKINS claims that he can give us television images 3,600 times brighter than those now attained, communication engineers naturally open their eyes and prick up their ears. Inasmuch as he is a pioneer motion-picture and television inventor, well Known on both sides of the Atlantic, his assertions deserve more than passing consideration.

PARIS, March 12 -- Efforts to create a tariff federation of five Danubian nations made one small step forward today when Sir John Simon, who was here for Aristide Briand's funeral, held a long discussion with Premier Tardieu, after which a vague communique was issued saying that they found themselves in accord.

The police seeking the kidnapped Lindbergh baby admitted yesterday that they had made no appreciable progress in the last twenty-four hours and the eleventh day of the nation-wide search passed with the child still missing from his home near Hopewell, N.J.

OIL filters as standard equipment appeared upon approximately 70 per cent of the cars exhibited at the recent automobile shows here and in other cities of the United States, a substantial increase over the percentage of cars so equipped the year before, and new models offered since show-time have emphasized oil filtration as a special feature, following the completion of tests of the effects of filtration upon cylinder oil.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12 -- In honor of Mrs. Henry R. Rea and Mrs. John Francis Harris, Mayor and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. entertained tonight with a dinner at their residence. Moving pictures and a musical program followed.

The last day of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association convention, held at Columbia University, was marked yesterday by the editing of a convention issue of The Columbia Spectator, the college daily newspaper, by a group of thirty-one delegates, and the awarding of medals to four faculty advisers for outstanding work in the supervision of their school papers.

PITTSBURGH, March 12 -- The Penn State five defeated the Pitt Panthers, 40 to 30, tonight at the Pitt Stadium Pavilion. Fred Brand, State centre, made three field goals at crucial moments for the visitors.

IN a mixed sale at Sotheby's occopying two days, March 21 and 22, there is a book of exceptional interest and beauty, whose fame and value rest almost entirely on external feature. It is the Geneva Bible, 1611, bound with the Common Prayer, 1616, and Psalms, 1624, in a seventeenth century needlework binding of extraordinary delicacy and charm.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 12 -- Harry Baugher of Baltimore, defending champion; Roy Coffin, Philadelphia; Palmer Dixon, New York City, and Don Strachan, Philadelphia, advanced to the semi-final round of the third annual Atlantic Coast squash tennis tournament at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall courts today.

DETROIT, March 12 -- Four caskets containing the bodies of the Communists killed in the riot staged at the gates of the Ford Motor Company last Monday lay side by side in "Workers Hall this forenoon. Perhaps two score persons were in the little hall but on the outside at least 15,000 men, women and children closely watched by 800 patrolmen mounted and afoot, crowded into the narrow streets surrounding the building.

Passage by the State Legislature of a bill increasing taxes on motor trucks by 65 per cent served to direct attention to the issue of motorvehicle regulation which has come to the forefront as a result of the present condition of the railroads. The railroads contend that many of their troubles result from competition which is not regulated or taxed to the same extent as are the railroads.

THE revival of Bellini's "La Sonnambula," with Lily Pens and Gigli-in the leading roles, and the first performance this season of "Gotterdammerung" mark the twentieth week of opera at the Metropolitan.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal OPENLY defying the Hays office and the New York censors, Howard Hughes, youthful millionaire producer, this week announced he is ready for a final showdown on the censorship question and that he would release "Scarface," the picture which outgangsters all previous attempts to chronicle the social and professional killings of the underworld, in spite of all opposition.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 12 -- A definite relationship between the livng forests of Central and South America and those which flourished in Western North America some sixty million years ago has been established as the result of a twomonth scientific expedition through tropical jungles, it was announced here today by Dr. Erling Dorf of the Princeton Department of Geology.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation had total assets of $615,190,021 at the close of 1931, against $604,403,222 the year before, a rise of $10,786,799, according to the annual balance sheet mailed to stockholders yesterday. Plant, property, patents and licenses were carried at $420,818,574, against $394,688,273 at the end of 1930.

REMINISCENT of Continental fencing exhibitions, which are given frequently in European countries to augment the funds of philanthropic organizations, will be the exhibition of prowess in that art of self-defense by members of the American Olympic fencing squad on Friday night at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street, in aid of Sir Wilfred Grenfell's Mission in Labrador.

PARIS. ONE of the most striking points about the new Paris fashions is the tendency to do away with Summer furs; this is, probably more than a mere economical gesture. It expresses the growing conviction that ostentation is not elegance -- it is more likely to be the reverse -- and what but ostentation can justify the sartorial presence of silver foxes during "dog-days"?

ONCE vivid, the local color of the lower East Side has been toned down to neutral tints. Restricted immigration has moderated the pungent personality of the section, depriving it of one character without giving it another. But now come unmistakable indications that a future of new and gilded hues is about to dawn.

IT'S this way," said the Hatter, pouring himself a second cup of tea. "Our farmers produce too much wheat, our factories too many manufactured articles, our machinists too many machines. We're so efficient that we're miserable. Surely you understand that?"

HERE is a book about that long, tremendous and complicated stretch of successive canyons which characterizes the Colorado River for almost a thousand miles of its course, a book whose title hardly suggests its genuine scientific value.

PARIS, March 12 -- Ivar Kreuger, president of the Swedish Match Company and of allied companies, reputed to be one of the world's richest men, was found shot dead in his apartment in Paris today. Beside him were letters announcing that he intended to commit suicide "because of his state of health."

IN the present discussion and difference of opinion as to what the radio audjence prefers in the way of musical selection, the leaders of the Army, Navy and Marine Bands. who receive, thousands of requests from listeners, give much the same report.
MADRID, March 11 -- Leaders of the new Spain have begun a movement with the support of the entire nation to "nail to the post" what they term, the "black legend" -- misconception of Spain abroad.

VIRGINIA'S ratification of the socalled "lame-duck" amendment to the Constitution is the first step in what is generally a longdrawn-out process. In the case of most amendments, at least a year elapses between the time they are proposed and the date on which the last of the needed State Legislatures (three-fourths of the total number in the Union) gives its approval.

Georgre Spitz, New York University sophomore, whose world's record leap of 6 feet 8 1/2 inches stamp him as America's premier high jumper, last night captured his specialty without being seriously extended at the annual indoor athletic meet of the Norwegian Turn Society in the Second Naval Battalion Armory, Brooklyn.

WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART -- Provincial paintings of the nineteenth century (formerly in the collection of Mrs. Juliana R. Force and presented to the museum), together with Audubon prints, colored lithographs and Thomas Nast cartoons, selected from the permanent collection.
NEWARK, N.J., March 12 -- Princeton, Westfield and the Essex troop trios won their first round matches in the New Jersey State championship Class C polo elimination tournament tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., March 12 (AP) Henry Johnson, sailor friend of Miss Betty Gow, nursemaid of the kidnapped Lindbergh baby, was allowed to talk to newspapermen for the first time tonight. Arrested three days after the kidnapping, he has been held at Newark Police Headquarters a week and faces deportation by immigration authorities.
ANDOVER, Mass., March 12 -- Andover won from Exeter, 31 to 30, today in an overtime basketball game. The teams were tied at 27 -- all at the end of the regular time.

So keen a track and field critic as Boyd Comstock believes that Gene Venzke has hardly reached the limit of his speed, despite his astounding feats over the boards this year. The Los Angeles A.C. coach, back on the Coast after an invasion of the East with his athletes, predicts a mile in four minutes flat in the near future by the sensation of the indoor season.
Price changes on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were the narrowest of the week. After holding within a 4-point range, the list ended 1 to 3 points lower than on Friday.

THIS book is a breath of pure fresh air. It tells a simple affecting story that grows larger in the telling, and it brings us to a little world which, strange at first, soon becomes vivid to us, then real, and finally memorable. On every side Mr. Strong was beset by dangers, yet he managed to get past almost all of them.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity, already in new low territory for the present depression, continues downward, although at a slower rate than recently. The preliminary index for the week ended March 5 is 60.7, as against 61.0 for the preceding week and 76.7 for the corresconding week last year.

Mrs. Ida E. Wood, 93 years old, a belle of New York in the '60s and '70s, died yesterday afternoon in her two-room suite at the Herald Square Hotel, to which she had been driven into seclusion a quarter of a century ago by a terror of poverty engendered by the panic of 1907.

HOT SPRINGS, Va -- The Spring program is rapidly taking shape here. The Cascades Club is reopening soon, with a match between the Washington and Lee golf team, captained by Billy Howell, sensation of the national amateur, and the Duke University team on Wednesday, featuring the earlier opening of the course.

THIS volume la an illustration of two great facts: the increasing interest of Americans in foreign affairs, and the tendency in this country to bring the orderly study of history down to the events, not of a generation or a decade ago, but of yesterday.

An unprecedented flood of applications for this Summer's citizens' military training camps is being received at the headquarters of the Second Corps Area at Governors Island, it was said yesterday by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, the commander. Alerady 6,000 volunteers have registered for the various courses of instruction.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- The coming week will find many New Yorkers gathering at the Greenbrier for Palm Sundey and Easter, numbers, as always at this time, coming from the Florida resorts to remain through the Spring.

The Richmond Hill High School rifle team topped sixteen other sextets to win the DuFont Trophy interscholastic shoot with a total of 1,003 points at the General Wingate Athletic Field range yesterday. The meet was the first of a series in competition for the Standard Bearer Trophy, symbolic of the P.S.A.L. Spring championship.

The advance of Spring has increased both the sale and rental demand for small homes in Westchester County and the adjacent territory, according to brokers and developers. Considerable construction work either is in progress or is planned.

TIBERIAS, March 11 -- One of the foremost archaeological discoveries just made in the Holy Land testifies to the life and wanderings of Christ. The most magnificent mosaic floor ever found in this country was uncovered when the memorial church was excavated.

THE many historical exhibitions inspired by the Washington bicentennial are recreating for the entiquarian and the decorator vivid details of everyday Colonial life. Entire rooms have been constructed and furnished with appropriate antiques, and displays of costumes and pictures of old-time scenes aid in the visualization of former days.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 12 (AP) -- Liffy River, black gelding, owned by Ernest L. Woodward, Leroy, N.Y., climaxed a brilliant two-day performance at the twenty-second annual Camden horse show today by capturing the title of champion hunter, the most prized honor of the show.
DETROIT, March 12 (AP) -- New leaders appeared in the American Bowling Congress tourney tonight as a result of the initial showing of out-of-town teams.

MIAMI -- The restraint imposed by economic conditions, which has been maintained throughout this Winter season, will be thrown aside and the lavish display of former years followed at a ball given in aid of charity on a date to be announced soon.

Wall Street gave the share market scant attention yesterday and the total volume of trading on the Stock Exchange approximated only about 600,000 shares. The irregularity of price movements was again interpreted as an indication of speculative uncertainty -- if, indeed, the dull proceedings had any meaning at all.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- An aging admirer of 24-year-old Catherine Varvantuke of Shrewsbury, Mass., shot her to death in a dance hall here today because she spurned his attentions, and then tried to kill himself. The assailant was George Younes, 54, of Worcester, Mass.

Liturgical churches will observe Passion Sunday today with service of music. Sermons will be preachy in many churches on kidnapping o children, with reference to the Lindbergh case. The Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, will resume his official visitations this morning at St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie.

ATLANTA, March 10 -- Atlanta will take part next week in a recall election, brought on by the fight made against Mayor James L. Key by the Atlanta Prohibition and Enforcement League and the Atlanta Federation of Trades, which wants its 3 per cent beer.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 12 -- The Naval Academy swimming team triumphed over Syracuse today, 59 to 12. A water polo match, previously scheduled between the two teams, was canceled.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Total subscriptions to the treasury's offering of certificates, to be dated March 15, amounted to $3,403,225,500 and the allotments $994,146,000, Secreary Mills announced today.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 -- The opening of the annual Yankees-Braves nine-game Florida exhibition, series, scheduled for today, was postponed because of a heavy rain.

ONE thing is sensed immediately as we inspect the "provincial" paintings of the nineteenth century now on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art: That is the immense seriousness of those artists, for the most part anonymous, whose work has at length entered an ambit of posthumous fame.

THE flower garden has turned the corner. In a little while now, within a month, it will overcome its depression and start on the upswing to June and prosperity. The Flower Show says so, and the Flower Show is always right.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article "Our Concerts for Children" grave great joy, and I am grateful that you called attention to the pioneer work of Theodore Thomas and of his successors in this field of art -- Dr. Frank Damrosch, Dr. Walter Damrosch and Ernest Schelling, all of whom have done a work of far-reaching import.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 12 -- Victory in the one-mile relay, the last event, gave Yale's track team a 60-to-53 triumph over Cornell in the drill hall tonight. It was Yale's third victory in the nine meets in the series since 1924.

RUSSIANS do not know what it is to be bored. No play can be so badly acted, no opera so backneyed, no acrobatics so timeworn, no political speech so dull that it fails to arouse their enthusiasm. To them a performance of any kind is a novelty and a privilege.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Business activity remained unchanged, for the most part, in foreign countries reviewed in the current weekly survey of conditions abroad by the Department of Commerce.

Henry Mandel, known as the millionaire builder of skyscrapers, who as president of the Henry Mandel Companies planned and beaded the development of London Terrace in the Old Chelsea section of Manhattan and erected some of the most prosperous and best-known office buildings and apartments in New York, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday.

BERLIN, March 12 (AP) -- Throughout the nation police forces were prepared today for the closest watchfulness over the elections tomorrow. Karl Severing, Prussian Minister of the Interior, issued a decree forbidding all demonstrations tomorrow. Pedestrians have been advised to keep moving tomorrow.

United States Attorney Howard W. Amell, in Brooklyn, yesterday filed with the United States District Court information charging ninety-six physicians with improper use of medicinal whisky prescriptions. Ninety of the physicians live in Brooklyn and six in Queens.

OBSERVERS who have visited the WMAL studios in Washington, D.C., report that the television demonstration of the newly added W2XAP was in every way as good as some of the widely discussed New York try-outs. The images were clear and recognizable.

WESTTOWN, Pa., March 12 -- From a group of bare-floored offices in a weather-beaten converted dwelling a mile from the station and postoffice which give this community its name thousands of letters have gone forth since October enlisting support throughout the country for an unusual "educational movement" within the Republican party.

RICHMOND, March 12 -- Garden lovers from all over the nation will come to Virginia the week of April 25 to see the Colonial gardens of the Old Dominion, which, through special arrangement with their private owners, will be thrown open to the public during this week under the auspices of the Garden Club of Virginia.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Marrh 12 -- At the conclusion of a long day of judging, in which more than 500 dogs came before the experts, the title of best dog in the sixteenth annual show of the Providence County Kennel Club was awarded tonight to the noted Russian wolfhound champion Vigow o' Valley Farm, owned by the Romanoff Kennels of West Nyack, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Important events crowded one another on and off the stage of American public affairs all week long. Not often in the space of seven days have been offered to our citizens so many courses of action, all of which sent or will send their effects into the labor and consciousness of everybody in the country and many in the world outside our boundaries.

NEW HAVEN, March 12 -- Yale's basketball quintet closed its season tonight with a 29-25 victory over Harvard. The Elis had to fight all the way to triumph over their Crimson rivals, who were ahead, 13-11, at half-time and during the early minutes of the closing half held a 19-12 advantage.

With the announcement that nearly 1,600 block chairmen have been enrolled in the Block Community Organization of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, which hopes to enroll chairmen at the rate of 1,000 a day for ten days, added impetus was given to the organization's plans yesterday by Police Commissioner Mulrooney, who issued instructions to all precinct commanders to cooperate to the fullest extent in the drive.

TWO biographies of Thomas Henry Huxley are scheduled for publication on the same date, March 24. "Huxley: Prophet of Science," by Houston Peterson, will be published by Longmans, Green Co., while W. W. Norton Co. will bring out "Huxley," by Clarence Ayres.

THE Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives submitted a tax bill last week designed to raise more than billion dollars in new revenue. This is the first proposal for an increase in Federal taxes since the war.

Figures have been compiled for the American Power Boat Association, ruling body of motor-craft racing, that 4,250 regattas will be held this year under its rules. That would be 250 more than last year. The number of drivers participating is expected to reach 21,000.

CHICAGO THE outer office might be any business manager's anteroom: An alert young woman at a desk, a filing cabinet, a bookcase, a couple of chairs, a table. The wall blackboard with its chalked mathematical equation seemed a bit out of the picture; and yet -- aren't there sometimes blackboards in brokers' offices, too?

A MODEL government speaker, in so far as radio deportment is concerned, is Dr. Julius Klein, Assistant Secretary of Commeroe. Dr. Klein takes the business of broadcasting seriously and is painstaking in preparation for it. He reads his addresses but docs it so skillfully that listeners get the im- pression that he is speaking without notes.

THIS descriptive and interpretative account of what is being done by the Soviet Government for the benefit of women and children is the outcome of two years recently spent in Russia in the study of these activities, the methods used and the results.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 12 (AP) -- Jack Dempsey, former world heavyweight boxing champion, won two more bouts on his exhibition tour tonight by defeating Tim Charles, 197, of Louisville, Ky., and Jack O'Dowd, 205, of Little Rock, Ark., in two two-round bouts.

Many indications point to the belief, in the opinion of Major William Kennelly, that the Spring season will witness a marked revival of suburban realty activity in Bergen County, N.J. One of the contributing factors, he points out, is the Washington Bridge, which has eliminated the river as a barrier to easy accessibility.

To the Dramatic Editor: The hue and cry about dramatic critics is undoubtedly a good thing, because, although the charges against them are obviously grossly exaggerated, where there is smoke there is some fire.
Pennsylvania Military College's polo team came back to the winning column at Squadron A Armory last night with a nicely played victory over a Los Nanduces team, 7 1/2 to 6 1/2.

MIAMI, Fla., March 12 -- James River, 3-year-old gelding by St. James-Star of Danube, which was bred by George D. Widener and now races for Mrs. A. Carfano, won his fourth consecutive victory in the feature John McEntee Bowman Memorial handicap at Tropical Park today.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 12 -- Lehigh's reign as champion of the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association was extended another year today.

METALS to be used in airplane construction are exposed to a salt spray in tests described by J.L. McCloud of the Ford Motor Engineering Laboratory in a paper prepared for the American Chemical Society. These experiments, he explains, are being carried on in an effort to overcome corrosion.

The Property Ownership Corporation with offices in the National City Bank Building at Forty-second Street and Madison Avenue has been formed in accordance with President Hoover's plan for relieving the burden on real estate pending improvement in economic conditions, it was announced here yesterday.

Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey cut a 216-pound cake, became, with Mrs. Moore, an honorary member of the Mozart Society and made a speech at its twenty-third birthday luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Astor, which was attended by 800 persons.

A series of new low record prices in sugar futures was the outstanding feature of trading on the local commodity exchanges last week. Coffee, silver, hides and wool tops also declined on the week, while cocoa continued its upward trend along with rubber futures.

AFTER a series of rumors and threats it turns out that the March lists are no smaller than those immediately preceding them, and on inspection one finds at least one item that should cause excitement. Victor Masterpiece Album M-120 contains five disks carrying the whole of Bach's Church Cantata No. 4 -- "Christ lag in Todesbanden" -- and excerpts from No. 140 -- "Wachet auf, ruft uns die Stimme."

ZBOROWSKI -- This famous Parisian house has recently opened a New York branch at 460 Park Avenue. The inaugural exhibition includes dazzling drawings and three canvases by Modigliani, among them a portrait of Mario (the composer) the last picture Modigliani painted, and a beautiful reclining nude that challenges comparison with Giorgione's sleeping "Venus."

THE state of musical affairs and a variety of other matters, including the original score of "Boris Godunoff," were the subjects touched on in an interview with Albert Coates written by Herbert Hughea in The London Daily Telegraph several weeks ago.

Salvatore Spitale and Irving Bitz, designated by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh to negotiate for the return of his son, were acquitted yesterday in Federal court in Brooklyn of conspiracy to violate the national prohibition law by landing a cargo of illicit liquor at Gerrittsen Beach, Brooklyn, on July 26.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Ten members of the House, most of them drys, said today they would vote to discharge the House Judiciary Committee from further consideration of the Beck-Linthicum "home-rule" liquor resolution when the roll is called Monday, and thus a close vote on the liquor issue was forecast.

JACK BENTLEY, left-handed pitcher for the Giants some years ago, has been appointed manager of the Elmira club. Jack plays the piano, violin, guitar and ukulele and sings bass. There will be harmony on that ball club if nothing else.

AFTER a series of rumors and threats it turns out that the March lists are no smaller than those immediately preceding them, and on inspection one finds at least one item that should cause excitement. Victor Masterpiece Album M-120 contains five disks carrying the whole of Bach's Church Cantata No. 4 -- "Christ lag in Todesbanden" -- and excerpts from No. 140 -- "Wachet auf, ruft uns die Stimme."

ZBOROWSKI -- This famous Parisian house has recently opened a New York branch at 460 Park Avenue. The inaugural exhibition includes dazzling drawings and three canvases by Modigliani, among them a portrait of Mario (the composer) the last picture Modigliani painted, and a beautiful reclining nude that challenges comparison with Giorgione's sleeping "Venus."

THE state of musical affairs and a variety of other matters, including the original score of "Boris Godunoff," were the subjects touched on in an interview with Albert Coates written by Herbert Hughea in The London Daily Telegraph several weeks ago.

Salvatore Spitale and Irving Bitz, designated by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh to negotiate for the return of his son, were acquitted yesterday in Federal court in Brooklyn of conspiracy to violate the national prohibition law by landing a cargo of illicit liquor at Gerrittsen Beach, Brooklyn, on July 26.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Ten members of the House, most of them drys, said today they would vote to discharge the House Judiciary Committee from further consideration of the Beck-Linthicum "home-rule" liquor resolution when the roll is called Monday, and thus a close vote on the liquor issue was forecast.

JACK BENTLEY, left-handed pitcher for the Giants some years ago, has been appointed manager of the Elmira club. Jack plays the piano, violin, guitar and ukulele and sings bass. There will be harmony on that ball club if nothing else.

Under the title of "Treasure Trove," BEN AMES WILLIAMS, in an article in American Forests, casts a spell over Blackbeard Island such as it never had for the seekers of gold supposed to have been buried there in Colonial days by EDWARD TEACH, the most villainous and picturesque of pirates.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To those who knew William J. Guard -- and many of THE TIMES staff knew him, for he was the editor of the rotogravure section of your paper for some time, I remember -- it is unnecessary to speak of the honor and fine fidelity of the man.

EARLY last October the Abbey Theatre Company arrived in New York from Dublin. The players came comparatively unheralded and, after spending a few days in the metropolis, departed as silently as they had arrived.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- The Pennsyivania Railroad Company and the Merchants' Warehouse Company were made defendants in two suits filed in Federal District Court today asking damages of $6,000,000 on the ground the companies had engaged in illegal rebating practices for more than forty years.

FARGO, N.D., March 12 -- The question of whether Governor Roosevelt of New York or Governor Murray of Oklahoma will carry the North Dakota primary Tuesday is contingent upon the extent to which Republican farmers invade the Democratic primary.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- With a sensational spurt in the closing minutes, Princeton defeated Pennsylvania tonight, 27 to 25, in the final scheduled Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game for each team.

BUENA VENTURA, Colombia, March 8 -- Twenty-three members of the Apra (American Popular Revolutionary Alliance) party, of whom twenty were members of the Constituent Congress of Peru, have arrived here, ail having been deported by the government of President Sanchez Cerro for alleged complicity in a revolutionary plot.
HELSINGFORS, Finland, March 12(AP) -- A hundred hardy fishermen, picked off the ice floes on which they had drifted helpless for several days, came back today to spin a real yarn of the North Land.

HELSINGFORS WHEN Runeberg wrote the story of the old canteen woman, Lotta Svard -- "Charlotte Sword" in English -- he could hardly have imagined that today his native Finland would contain 50,000 Lotta Svards organized in a woman's army auxiliary whose like does not exist anywhere else in the world.
The American Museum of Natural History has acquired a large proportion of the famous collection of birds of Baron Walter Rothschild, which has been housed in his private museum at Tring, England.

ANDOVER, Mass., March 12 -- The Andover track team defeated the Dartmouth freshmen in a dual indoor meet today, 58 1/2 to 40 1/2. Three records were created, two by Andover runners and one by Quimby of the visiting aggregation.

Bond prices moved slightly lower on the average on the Stock Exchange yesterday in the two-hour session. Trading, however, was normally active for a Saturday, totaling $5,633,500. Dealings in United States Government bonds were extremely light and final prices for the group were unchanged to 9-32 point lower, with the exception of the Treasury 4 1/4 s, which moved up 5-32 point.

PARIS, March 12 (AP) -- Ivar Kreuger, Swedish "match king," international banker and one of the world's leading industrialists, was found dead in his apartment here today. He left three letters indicating he had committed suicide. They said he was tired of life and of financial difficulties in when he had found himself for some months.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Henry Ware Allen's letter to THE TIMES has been read with interest. He suggests that the restriction of immigration, to this country has made the Statue of Liberty on Bedloe's Island more of a mockery than the gesture of welcome to a free country.

The role of the business depression in arousing interest in vocational education and guidance as a preventive for future economic crises was hailed by speakers at the first annual luncheon of the City College Vocational Guidance Society at the Gramercy Park Hotel yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 29 -- The practical genius of the British people, once again, has come to the fore. The free trade, which to several genera tions was like the truth of the Gos pel, has been laid aside. Protection full-fledged reigns instead. But already steps are being taken to introduce free trade of a different and modern, sort.

THE Bobby Jones series, "How I Play Golf," proved the most popular short subject turned out last year. Now, prompted by numerous requests to theatre ownera by golfers who missed the series or want to see it over again, Vitaphone has decided to reissue the films.

OTTAWA, March 9 -- Perhaps it is a reflection of the critical mood in which men and institutions are surveyed by the public in these days, but the fact is the present session of the Canadian Parliament is remarkable for the importance and variety of subjects under consideration by special committees.

Due fo the services of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company as banker for the Bell System, which includes the company and twenty-four associated telephone companies in the United States, gross expenditures of $391,000,000 for new construction in 1931 were effected without public financing, and contemplated expenditures of $330,000,000 for 1932 will not entail any sales of bonds or stocks to the public.

NO writer of historical fiction has devoted more careful research to the backgrounds of his tales than Stewart Edward White, and none has succeeded in bringing to life from the neglected periods of his country's history more thrilling material of human drama.
I AM speaking directly to you who have withdrawn money from a bank and now hold it in the shape of currency. It is you whose action will count -- no one else.

STOCKHOLM, March 12 -- Legislation was rushed through both houses of the Riksdag late tonight giving the King power to grant moratoria on private payments "when the circumstances warrant." The action followed the suicide of Ivar Kreuger in Paris.

LANCASTER, Pa., March 12 -- Led by the speedy Walter Spence, who besides capturing a first place, performed capably in two relay races, the Rutgers swimming team won the Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association championship tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This morning the country was shocked to find that the French Government has placed an embargo on American fruit. We waver between two emotions -- shall we feel insulted because a product of our sacred soil has been found diseased, and shall we cry blue despair over the insult; or shall we consider this a reprisal for many of our self-righteous national policies?

GENEVA, March 11 -- It is seven weeks since the world disarmament conference began here and there is just one more week to go before the two weeks' adjournment over Easter, There has been so little appearance of accomplishment so far that it is only natural that from almost every country complaints of taxpayerss should have begun to pour in with diatribes against their own and other delegations.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The investigation of the State Government, which Democrats charge was ordered by Republican leaders in Washington in an effort to embarrass Governor Roosevelt during his preconvention campaign for the Presidential nomination, will start early in April.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 12 -- Despite two excellent performancer by Joe Nicholson, Princeton star, the Yala varsity swimming team defeated the Tiger natators in the Brokaw pool today, 43 to 28. It was, the sixtieth successive victory of El swimming teams and the first defeat of the season for the Tigers.

MEMBERS of the Industrial Educational Association for Southern Mountaineers have arranged a bridge party, which will take place on the afternoon of April 5 in the ballroom of the Plaza in aid of the work of the association.

Last week's reduction in the Bank of England's discount rate, from 5 per cent to 4, was one of the now numerous signs of returning financial composure and stability in Europe. Sometimes such changes in European "bank rates" have only remote significance for our own financial situation; but there are reasons for taking a different view on this occasion.

Wall Street friends of Ivar Kreuger warned him repeatedly in the last two or three years that he was shouldering too heavy a responsibility, that he was going at a killing pace. They begged him to slow down.
LONDON, March 11 -- The British people have been watching the Lindbergh case with something more than the fascinated horror of observers 3,000 miles away.

ROME, March 12 -- General Umberto Nobile, commander of the first two airships to fly over the North Pole, is gathering a corps of technical experts in Italy to take to Russia, where he expects to begin construction of a series of dirigibles for the Soviet Government.

Ottorino Respighl's new opera, "La Fiamma," is already entirely formulated: two acts are written and the third will be done this Summer. And now another work is Under way in the composer's fertile imagination, an "original form for the lyric stage, highly experimental in nature."

SANTA ANA, Brazil, March 12 (AP) -- Dispatches from Puerto Alegre said today that leaders of Rio Grande do Sul sent an ultimatum to President Getulio Vargas that unless he accepted a political and economic program of theirs they would no longer support his provisional government.

BRISTOL, Va., March 12 (AP) -- Republicans of the Ninth Virginia District, at a spirited convention today, nominated Roland Chase for Congress and instructed their delegates to the national convention to vote for the renomination of President Hoover and Vice President Curtis.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday through Ashbel Green, its secretary, that securities which have been partly paid for on subscription are to be designated as "part paid securities" and that bonds which have been redeemed on repaid in part are to be designated as "part redeemed bonds."

WASHINGTON, March. 12 -- The kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby is not chargeable in any degree to prohibition, the Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals of the Methodist Episcopal Church declared in a statement today. Prohibitionists, the board says, "resent and denounce as utter falsehood" any assertion that the prohibition law has caused crime, or that prohibitionists are aiding and encouraging crime in supporting the Eighteenth Amendment.

LONDON IF it is difficult for a writer of fiction to hit upon striking titles for his novels, the problem is scarcely less troublesome for authors of volumes of reminiscences. Lady Clodagh Anson seems to have evaded it by using the simple word "Book" (Blackshaw) for her collection of social memories of a previous generation.

Morris High School's undefeated fencing team grained undisputed possession of first place in the current P.S.A.L. championship tourney by defeating Boys High, 5 to 3, while Flushing upset Textile, 5 to 2, in two of the eight tournament matches contested yesterday at the Washington Irving High School.

THE coming of Spring brings the international Flower Show, which for many years has been an annual event in New York in the waning days of Lent. The nineteenth show opens tomorrow and will continue throughout the week at the Grand Central Palace.

FROM figures afterward available, the stores a week ago yesterday did about the best day's business of the year to date in this city. Early reports on yesterday's volume were also cheerful, though actual purchasing fell short of what store attendance might indicate.

AFTER weeks of rumor and experimentation, word comes from Hollywood that Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has at last decided upon the method by which it will bring Eugene O'Neill's nine-act play, "Strange Interlude," to the audible screen.

The note of concern in the National Parks Bulletin about rational expansion of the system is natural, when one considers that at each session of Congress many bills to create new parks are introduced. A suspicion of politics attaches to some of them. Fortunately, the National Park Service, the Interior Department, the National Forest Service and the Agricultural Department are vigilant.

JANE COWL, they say, has been evidencing considerable interest in the Spanish play called "Take Two from One." It is a farce by Gregorio and Maria Martinez Sierra, pleasantly remembered for "The Kingdom of God" and "Cradle Song," among other plays.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 8 -- Conditions have grown neither better nor worse in Colombia, according to an editorial in the Review of the Bank of the Republic, which criticizes mildly the present attitude of foreign bankers toward Latin-American countries as well as the insurmountable tariff barriers erected by many countries.

SNOW avalanches were reported recently in several of their formidable aspects: The town of Silverton, Col., was cut off for weeks by impassable snowdrifts which avalanches piled up; railroads could not break through and food and fuel supplies ran dangerously low.
FREE CITY OF DANZIG, March 12 (AP) -- The Polish Government has served a demand on the Danzig High Commissioner that the Danzig customs administration be handed over to Poland.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Reading the account in THE TIMES of a debate, if it could be dignified by such a word, in the Massachusetts House of Representatives over the question of adopting the veery for that State's official bird, and the final contemptuous disapproval, reminds me of the cropping up now and then of the controversies between bird-lovers as to the merits of their respective pet song-birds.

Outstanding wrestlers, gymnasts and weight lifters in the metropolitan district will compete Wednesday night in Madison Square Garden for metropoltian A.A.U. championships, the events to be contested simultaneously in three rings.

Germany has a curious tendency to make mythical figures of those men who have succeeded by personality and achievement in reaching the subconscious fancy of the broad masses of the people. The picture of Bismarck living in the imagination of the Germans has found complete and typical expression in the colossal figure of the First Chancellor overlooking Hamburg, Germany's proudest seaport.

THE biographer who sets out to write a life of Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes labors under most unusual difficulties. The life itself is of uncommon length as well as of extraordinary achievement. Every year of its conscious duration has been made to count.

HUTNTINGTON, L.I., March 12 -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club held its first big open shoot over its new traps today. It was an inter-club class shoot which brought seventy-five gunners, representing five Long Island clubs, to the firing line.

The New York clubs, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club sextet and the St. Nicholas Hockey Club team advanced to the semi-final round in the New York division of the national A.A.U. hockey championship at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

The balance sheet of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and its subsidiaries, mailed yesterday to stockholders in the pamphlet report for 1931, shows an increase of $15,390,939 in the property account, lifting this item to $609,398,220 and raising the total assets of the company from $719,306,395, reported in the balance sheet adjusted to include $50,000,000 financing a year ago, to $736,893,915 at the end of 1931.

A mild rally reversed the trend of the preceding day in the stock list in yesterday's short session on the New York Curb Exchange, with trading quiet. Domestic and foreign bonds, however, failed to respond and for the most part closed with losses on the day.

BOSTON, March 11 SHAW has done his perfect work. Husbands and wives go amicably to see "Too True to Be Good," return estranged because one finds the play incredibly dull, while the other believes it full of interest and entertainment.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 12 -- Brown and Williams tied for first place in the annual New England intercollegiate association championship swimming meet today, each scoring 31 points. The team from Providence finished on even terms with the Purple by winning the 200-yard relay event, last on the program.

The General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen In the City of New York spent more than $185,000 in 1931, according to its 146th annual report, made public yesterday. Its two major activities were the extension of free, practical, technical education to 3,167 young men gainfully employed in mechanical or allied trades, and the maintenance of a free library of more than 112,000 volumes, open to these students and the public.

BRIARCLIFFE MANOR, N.Y., March 12 -- The first leg of an interclub team shoot between the Campfire Club and the Westchester Country Club was decided over the traps of the former organization today. The conditions called for fifty skeet targets and fifty singles.

THE motion-picture Industry has afforded a continuance of thrills and excitement for at least one explorer between his jaunts in quest of adventure in far corners of the earth. He is Harold McCracken who is to be seen in "Explorers of the World," the current film of exploration in far away lands now showing at the Cameo Theatre.

Prize awards for the year and silver cups for two of the sixty young leaders who had filled "mite boxes" to the tune of more than $4,000 for the Musicians' Emergency Aid made a gala event of the last of the famous "young people's concerts" of the Philharmonic -- Symphony Orchestra yesterday morning in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Voicing the unqualified backing of the administration for the tax bill that is before Congress, Secretary Mills presented to a nation-wide radio audience tonight a review of the government's financial situation. His address was heard over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
NEW YORK. Lord Ilchester of London is arriving this week on the Olympic and will be at the Ritz-Carlton.

Ivar Kreuger, who once sold real estate lots in Illinois after emigrating to this country with less than $100 in his pocket, made himself an almost legendary figure in international affairs as head of the gigantic Swedish holding company of Kreuger Toll and the guiding genius of what has been regarded as perhaps the most powerful interlocking trust in the world.

After a week of numerous interesting movements, yesterday's markets presented a picture of uncertainty, for the most part with moderate reaction. This was as true of sterling exchange as of domestic and foreign bonds. The rate for sight sterling, after recovering 1/2 cent, slipped off 1 1/4, which left the price exactly midway between the previous week's closing and last week's highest.

PROFESSOR ROWAN'S is not just another gossipy or anecdotal book on the migrations of birds, interesting as some of the hundreds of such books by field naturalists or bird lovers undoubtedly are. We have here, and for the first time, a brief discussion of this fascinating problem, based upon all the data obtainable from the provinces of anatomy, biochemistry, biophysics, physiology, plus the contributions of the ornithologist and the naturalist.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 12 -- Miss Bernice Wall of Oshkosh, Wis., succeeded Mrs. Helen B. Stetson of Philadelphia, former national champion, as Belleair golf champion when she defeated Mrs. H.A. Hyde of Hartford, Conn., 8 and 7, in the final round played today in the rain.

In Wall Street little doubt is entertained that had he lived a few hours longer Ivar Kreuger would have been faced with the consequences of a widespread international liquidation movement of remarkable proportions.

MACON, Ga., March 12 -- Helen Topping Miller told 240 members and guests of the Macon Writers' Club at its annual breakfast today that fiction readers are turning from gloomy realism to "romance and roses." She said that novels in the next few years will tell of happy lives.

BOSTON, March 11 SHAW has done his perfect work. Husbands and wives go amicably to see "Too True to Be Good," return estranged because one finds the play incredibly dull, while the other believes it full of interest and entertainment.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 12 -- Brown and Williams tied for first place in the annual New England intercollegiate association championship swimming meet today, each scoring 31 points. The team from Providence finished on even terms with the Purple by winning the 200-yard relay event, last on the program.

The General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen In the City of New York spent more than $185,000 in 1931, according to its 146th annual report, made public yesterday. Its two major activities were the extension of free, practical, technical education to 3,167 young men gainfully employed in mechanical or allied trades, and the maintenance of a free library of more than 112,000 volumes, open to these students and the public.

TRENTON, N.J., March 12 -- Opinion of the Port of New York Authority that construction of a viaduct across Raritan Bay from a point near Keyport to Staten Island would be "economically unsound" is not shared by Senator E. Donald Sterner of Monmouth County.

LONDON RECENT discussions among the powers as well as questions before the World Court have served to remind Europe that the Polish problem with which its statesmen of 150 years ago were familiar if still before the world.

Among the Spring sports, which continue advancing toward their various seasons despite the frigid winds and snows of the past week, is rugby, which several observers of American college sport believe is destined to become a popular activity in this country.

Arturo Toscanini and Bruno Walter will share the duties of conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next season, it was indicated in the advertisements of the society published yesterday with the program of the afternoon's orchestra concert.

ST. PETERSBURG. Fla., March 13 -- The Yankees, with Babe Ruth out of their line-up and not even present as a spectator, staged an eight-run rally in the seventh inning today to open their exhibition game schedule with a victory over the Boston Braves, 11 to 4.

Harold Kramer, City College swimming captain, who sailed last Friday on the Majestic for Palestine, where he will take part in the Jewish Olympics, gained the premier honors in the individual scoring race of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association, which came to an end on Saturday.

After admitting their failure to make any further progress in the search for the kidnapped baby son of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, police officials and others engaged in the hunt conferred yesterday at the aviator's home at Hopewell, N.J., to plan the next phase of their campaign to recover the child.

Fourteen cruises have been scheduled for the ships of the White Star and Red Star Lines during the Spring and Summer, and others are being arranged, the International Mercantile Marine Company announced yesterday. The itineraries in the program thus far prepared will include Bermuda, the St. Lawrence River and Halifax.

MOSCOW, March 13 -- The Soviet authorities apparently are getting worried about foreign immigration, which has begun to assume proportions that few here seemed to expect. The world depression plus reports of no unemployment in Soviet Russia is bringing in a tide of skilled workers from the United States and Europe, mostly with political sympathy for the Soviet regime, but some quite non-political, which rather embarrasses the authorities here.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 13 -- A total eclipse of the sun will be visible from this part of the country on Aug. 31, Professor Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard College Observatory, said, today. On March 7, 1970, another will come, but one will have to journey to Florida to see it.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 13 (AP) -- The British Minister to Venezuela, W.E. O'Reilly, has offered to resign as a result of a dispute with the Venezuelan Foreign Office over the poisoning of his dog. It was understood today the British Government would allow him to do so.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 13 (AP) -- The Prince David struck a reef today and we all had to take to the lifeboats -- to complete a pleasure trip to Bermuda from Boston.
BERLIN, March 13 (AP) -- This most tense election since Germany became a republic went off with comparatively few disorders today, considering the heat to which political passions had been raised.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 13 -- Samuel Kline, 45 years old, was shot and killed early today and two fellow fugitives from the Ulster County jail here were recaptured by a police posse an hour after they had sawed their way out of their cells, slugged a jailer into unconsciousness and escaped.

With haste the characteristic note of our age, our minds are confused by rapid motion, we are restless with the excitement of action and deify change, Dr. Howard Chandler Robbins declared yesterday in a sermon at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

RYE, N.Y., March 13 -- Over its own traps, the Westchester Country Club defeated the representatives of the Campfire Club in a return shoot today. The conditions called for a five-man team race, each gunner to shoot at 100 singles and 50 pairs of doubles.

BERLIN, March 13 -- After a feverish fortnight of campaigning, election day in the capital of the Reich passed with extraordinary quiet today. There was less visible excitement than in the 1930 Reichstag elections and fewer cases of political violence.

Bernardo Olshansky, Russian baritone, last heard here in 1928, re- vealed in his recital in the Town Hall yesterday afternoon a voice of warmth and richness of tone. It is blessed with the roundness and resonance of the true baritone, dark in color and weighty in timbre.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 -- Jewels, ornaments and bronze weapons dating back nearly 4,000 years have been unearthed at Lapithos, on the island of Cyprus, by a University of Pennsylvania museum, it was announced today. News of the find was contained in a message from B.H. Hill, head of the expedition, received by Mrs. Edith H. Dohan, curator of the classical section.

MOSCOW, March 13 -- The American women who boldly undertook the "adoption" of a collective farm at Krilatskoe, a village near Moscow, have won a great and hitherto unexampled victory. They received yesterday a "mandate," or written authorization, with its due seal, signatures and stamps, from the Central Adoption Department to carry on the work in an approved and legitimate manner.

The Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, officiated yesterday at a confirmation ceremony in St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie for the first time in more than eight years.

ALBANY, March 13 -- With provision made by the Legislature for a general investigation of the administrative departments of the State Government, the Republicans are preparing to go into the Gubernatorial campaign this year with economy as their chief issue.

A last-minute demand for tickets today is expected to result in a capacity crowd for the finals of the annual Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament under the auspices of the Daily News A.A. tonight in Madison Square Garden.

LOS ANGELES, March 13 -- John McGraw's grand offensive power went on full display today when a six-run demonstration in the seventh inning completely submerged the Cubs in the fifth game of the exhibition series by a score of 7 to 3.

The President of Germany is elected by the direct vote of all citizens, male and female, over 20 years of age. The law provides that the election must be held either on a Sunday or on a public day of rest. The term of office is seven years.

BOSTON, March 13 Eighty passengers, including many prominent Bostorians, who sailed from Boston yesterday on the Canadian National liner Prince David, were rescued at sea twelve miles out of St. George, Bermuda, today after the vessel had ripped out her bottom on a coral reef.

PARIS, March 13 -- Police investigations today added virtually nothing to what was known yesterday of the suicide of Ivar Kreuger, but the fear of serious stock market conse- quences led Premier Tardieu to summon Count Ehrensvard, the Swedish Ambassador, for a long conference this morning.

ORANGEBURG, S.C., March 13 (AP) -- Dr. Robert Shaw Wilkinson, 67 years old, one of the South's most prominent Negro educators and president of the State Agricultural and Mechanical College, died here today of pneumonia.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Few of the multitudes using Van Cortlandt Park for recreational and other purposes realize that up to and including the Spring and Summer of 1930 the low, swampy area paralleling the Putnam Division of the New York Central was a veritable bird haven.

The resignation on Saturday of Charles S. Hand, one of the three members of the Sanitary Commission, is likely to result in the calling of Mr. Hand for examination by Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative investigating committee, it was reported yesterday.

In one of the most interesting races since the inception of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, Dave Jones, versatile Columbia University guard, captured the individual scoring honors for the regular circuit campaign, which came to an end Saturday night.

PARIS, March 11 -- This week's Bank of France return, showing decrease for the week of 1,432 million francs in foreign credits along with increase of only 678 millions in the gold reserve, proved that, thanks to the firmness of dollar exchange and above all of sterling, the French bank was able to repatriate large amounts without occasioning withdrawals of foreign gold.

Aided by a handicap of one minute, Dan Moffett of the home club won first place in the weekly handicap road race conducted by the St. Anselm's Athletic Club in the Bronx yesterday. The victor's time for the four-and-one-half-mile event was 24:34.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Regarding an article in THE TIMES entitled "Mulrooney Scores Pistol-Permit Bills," may I, as an advocate at the Fake-Hanley bill, which the commissioner condemns, throw a little light on this subject?

GLOBE, Ariz., March 13 (AP) -- The life of Mac (Golney) Seymour, 21-year-old White River Apache, will be demanded in court tomorrow by the government, seeking a forfeit for the slaying of Miss Henrietta Schmerler.

A generous and public-spirited word, coming from an unexpected quarter, was uttered in the House on Saturday by Representative HUDDLESTON of Alabama. Resenting the attempts to make party capital out of the Government shortage, he asserted that it ought to be called neither Republican nor Democratic but just " our deficit."

NEW ORLEANS, March 13 -- The cotton market here last week was only moderately active and price fluctuations were comparatively narrow, developing no definite trend. The extreme range barely reached 50 cents a bale and the net price change was almost nominal.

PARIS, March 13 -- The International Sugar Council will meet again in Paris tomorrow for what is expected to be a supreme effort to reach an agreement among producers on the next crop and export quotas.

NEW LONDON, March 13 -- Fire, starting just after 6 o'clock tonight, swept the seven-story annex of the Hotel Mohican in the heart of New London's business section and threatened near-by buildings for a time.

After a motorists' quarrel, three men cornered four youths and a girl in a restaurant, the Union Luncheonette, at 29 Catherine Street, last night and fired a fusillade of bullets at them. Three of the youths were shot and wounded slightly; the others, and ten diners, escaped injury by hiding behind counters.

Churches in this country are built with an eye toward comfort and repose rather than in the spirit of repentance, the Rev. Dr. Robert Frederick Lau, vice counselor of ecclesiastical relations of the Protestant Episcopal Church, declared yesterday in his sermon at the Church of the Resurrection, 115 East Seventy-fourth Street.

TAMPA, Fla., March 13 -- One of the wildest pitches on record, made by Kershaw Jones, and another erratic heave by young Bobby Reis were not enough aid to the Reds as the Carey crew opened its exhibition series today and the Robins won, 5 to 3.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt is returning today on the Virginia from Panama and will go to Sagamore Hill, her home in Oyster Bay.

An automobile in which four young men and two young women were returning early yesterday morning from a wedding party in Sea Gate, Coney Island, swerved from the road on a sharp turn in East Drive. Prospect Park, Brooklyn, crashed into a tree, turned over and burst into flames.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 13 -- Drinking among Harvard students has reached its lowest level in the past two or three years, according to Dr. Alfred Worcester, the Henry K. Oliver Professor of Hygiene, who supervises the health of the students.

BOSTON, March 13 -- A complete ticket of delegates-at-large and alternates to run in the Republican Presidential primary in the Bay State, all pledged to vote for the renomination of President Hoover, was announced today by Louis K. Liggett, national committeeman.

Registration of aliens is more necessary than ever before, according to Captain John B. Trevor, chairman of the Board of American Coalition of Patriotic Societies, who debated the question of alien registration with Representative Samuel Dickstein of Manhattan in a discussion broadcast by WOR yesterday afternoon.

PESHAWAR, India, March 13 -- The Haji of Turangzai, whom the British blame for the recent frontier unrest, had both his home and his durbar hall at Bagh, near Lakarai, obliterated by aerial bombardment yesterday afternoon.

BUENOS AIRES, March 13 -- Shipments of all grains were larger last week than in the corresponding week in 1931. The market was firm for wheat and corn, and weak for flaxseed. All exports in January and February amounted to 3,027,007 tons, valued at 108,384,021 gold dollars, comparing with 2,848,151 tons, valued at 112,860,827 gold dollars, in January and February, 1931.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- Cold weather over the entire agricultural region that supplies the markets here, particularly early in the week, with temperatures around zero, checked marketing of all live stock. Receipts of hogs were the lightest since September and of sheep and lambs the smallest since August.

LARCHMONT MANOR, N.Y., March 13 -- By returning a card of 98 out of a possible 100 targets, Lynn Hunt annexed the High Scratch Cup at the traps of the Larchmont Yacht Club today. It was the best score in a field of twenty-three gunners. The second scratch prize went to M. J. Tuite who finished with 96.
DETROIT, March 13 -- The Detroit Falcons downed the New York Americans, 1 to 0, tonight in a hard-fought National Hockey League match before 6,500 spectators.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 -- The wind blew a gale, the Babe played golf and the Colonel took a brisk stroll along the beach today. Otherwise all was quiet on the Florida front, with baseball's highest paid performer still a polite holdout and the two principals sparring for time.
STOCKHOLM, March 13 -- The vast Kreuger business will proceed without Ivar Krcuger, but it will hardly take the same course, following its founder's suicide in Paris yesterday.

Delightful weather brought out a field of thirty-six gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The best work was done by T.H. Lawrence, who won the high scratch cup by breaking 95 out of a possible 100 targets.

Members of the Onteora Committee, an organization for the Health Centre and Visiting Nurses of Tannersville, N.Y., will give a bridge and backgammon party on Wednesday afternoon at the St. Regis in behalf of the centre. Tea will be served.

MUKDEN, Monday, March 14 -- new Chinese revolt against Japanese domination in North Manchuria broke out last midnight at Manchouli, just this side of the Soviet-Manchurian frontier on the Chinese Eastern Railway, and the entire Chinese soldiery there began rioting and looting.

SHANGHAI, Monday, March 14 -- The prospects for an early peaceful adjustment of the Sino-Japanese crisis over the Shanghai area became even remoter last night, when the Japanese Legation announced the following communication had been forwarded to the Chinese Government:

Included in the pamphlet report of Radio Corporation of America showing a net income of $768,903 for 1931, equal to $1.95 a share earned on 395,597 A preferred shares, is a consent form through which common and Class A stockholders may assent to a $45,258,200 reduction in capital and surplus proposed by a committee appointed by the directors.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Unlike the average man taking a new job, the latest member of the Supreme Court, Benjamin N. Cardozo, will begin intensive work tomorrow almost immediately after taking the oath.

ON BOARD THE U.S.S. AUGUSTA IN THE PACIFIC, March 13 -- Under leaden skies and heaving to the slow beats of the sea, the navy's Black force rolled on toward Hawaii today, still seeking the powerful Blue battle fleet which left Lahaina Roads several days ago for an imaginary attack on the west coast of the United States.

The Merchants' Association will send to the chairman of the Congressional finance committees this week an outline of a report by the organization's committee on customs service and administration, pointing out that there are serious problems involved in the proposal now before the House to abolish the offices of controllers of customs, surveyors of customs and surveyors of merchandise throughout the country.

Among other items the vaudeville current at the Palace contains a crooners' contest, just as if such a thing mattered very much in these times. Russ Columbo, making what is said to be his first Broadway appearance, sings in a caressing voice into a microphone and displays an agreeable personality, although he is not as yet perfectly at ease before an audience.

Another concert in the series arranged by the Junior League of New York to aid its charitable activities will take place on the night of March 22 at the league's clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. Mme. Lucrezia Bori of the Metropolitan Opera will be the artist.

BERLIN, Monday, March 14 (AP) -- Analysis of the returns from yesterday's election reveals that Adolf Hitler ran behind President von Hindenburg in all districts where the National Socialists were partly or wholly in control, namely, Thuringia, Brunswick and Hesse.

The resumption of play today in the national indoor tennis championship at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, will find a number of the favorites running into opposition qualified to put their mettle to a severe test.

LONDON, March 11 -- Reduction in the Bank of England rate and the sudden and exceedingly violent movement which occurred in sterling are the financial events most discussed at the present moment. On domestic grounds there was every reason for a lower bank rate.

The drama is slipping back into the licentiousness from which it was elevated to a high moral plane by the early Catholic Church, said the Rev. Aloysius J. Hogan, president of Fordham University, at the annual communion breakfast of the Catholic Club held yesterday morning at the clubhouse, 120 Central Park South.

Nearly 6,500 members of the New York Police Department Holy Name Society heard Cardinal Hayes, Mayor Walker, Commissioner Mulrooney and other church and city dignitaries praise the integrity and efficiency of the police yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of the society in the Hotel Astor.

The financial structure of the Kreuger Toll Company, which the late Ivar Kreuger dominated as chairman of the board, is that of a holding company for a group of other investment companies, business corporations and banking institutions, a few of which have engaged in government and other financing both in common with the parent company and individually.

AMSTERDAM, March 11 -- The upward rush of sterling early this week was considered here not only as a speculative movement but as reflecting distinct improvement in the British situation. The British budget is balancing, with a surplus of L15,000,000 expected and with a balanced budget and reduced taxes in prospect for the next fiscal year.

Doris Humphrey brought her season to a brilliant climax in her farewell recital at the Guild Theatre yesterday afternoon by the presentation of two new group dances, the first compositions in this medium which she has offered in more than a year. In these novelties, both of which were distinguished works, and in other numbers Miss Humphrey was at the top of her form as a dancer.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- The rapidity with which the speculative trade takes hold of the grain markets when any striking feature is suddenly developed was illustrated at the middle of last week when it was reported from New York that 120,000 bushels of corn, said to be Virginian, had been sold for export to Great Britain.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 13 -- Award of a Medical School traveling fellowship for 1932-33, an economics thesis prize pward, and thirty-eight scholarships for the second half of the current academic year have been announced by Harvard University.

ALBANY, March 13 (AP) -- Democrats charged tonight that the Republican-controlled Legislature cut from Governor Roosevelt's budget $25,000 he had set aside for experimental work on spinal meningitis and used it to finance the legislative investigation of State departments.

Chairman DELANEY of the Board of Transportation devoted many pages of his recent transit report to an attack on Controller BERRY for advocating fifty-year bonds for subway construction instead of his own pet four-year bonds. The Controller is now out with a sharp rejoinder.

Public sympathy for Colonel and Mrs. Lindbergh in their misfortune was a credit to the American people, but the dickering with gangsters was "public humiliation" and the public hysteria a reversion to the primitive, according to views expressed in sermons in New York churches yesterday.

BERLIN, Monday, March 14 -- In he heaviest and quietest election the German republic has ever known President Paul von Hindenburg failed yesterday by the narrowest margin to obtain the requisite maority over the combined votes of his opponents to insure his re-election in the first ballot as provided by the somewhat cumbersome electoral machinery of the Reich.

The American Scantic Line would spend $1,360,000 in the next ninety days for the reconstruction of four of the eleven ships which it operates between North Atlantic ports and Copenhagen and the Baltic, according to an announcement yesterday by Moore McCormack, general operators, of 5 Broadway.

Extension of probation as a method of crime control was advocated by Charles Evans Hughes Jr., president of the National Probation Association, in an address broadcast yesterday afternoon over WJZ under the auspices of the American Bar Association.

Arthur Garfield Hays and three other members of the city bar association's committee on courts of limited jurisdiction will appear as prosecutors this afternoon before the three justices of the city court designated to hear testimony on the charges that Samuel Seabury filed with the court against its chief clerk, Harry C. Perry, former Tammany district leader.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa will arrive today from Bremen, Southampton and Cherbourg. On board are Ray Long, publisher; and a group of foreign agents of the Ford Motor Company. These are Theodore Tenley, Carl Tittes, Paul Cappel, Emilio Ara, Manual Lay, T.W. Billfors, Erik Siltberg and Ingvo Swenson, coming here to visit the company's plant at Dearborn.
SACRAMENTO, Cal., March 13 (AP) -- Major oil companies of California have launched their campaign to align the State alongside Texas and Oklahoma in the compulsory curtailment of petroleum by law.

The Committee on Economic Sanctions, of which Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, is chairman, yesterday recommended that the United States take the lead in convoking a conference of representatives of the signatories of the Kellogg-Briand antiwar treaty to frame an amendment to the pact.

Charles Fertig, representing the Tappen Post of the American Legion, led home the field in the Manhattan Athletic League's fifteen-mile invitation road race conducted under the auspices of the Good Shepherd A.C. on Riverside Drive yesterday. The winner was clocked at 1:30.43.

LEIPZIG, March 13 -- The Spring fair, which ends today, has brought together buyers and exhibitors from all parts of the world and has reflected accurately the present state of world trade. Thousands of representatives of international business were watching with keen interest all new lines of goods in anticipation of a business revival, but there were few actual business transactions.
The New York Soccer Giants and their local rivals, the Americans, played an exhibition game at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Americans won, 4 to 1.

NEW HAVEN, March 12 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 63.3, which compares with 62.9 a week ago, 63.7 two weeks ago, 63.7 three weeks ago and 63.6 four weeks ago. The present year's highest average to date was 66.3, in the first week of January; last week's average was the lowest.

The New York Rangers piled up a lead of 4 to 1 over the Montreal Maroons last night, but the hard-fighting Canadian contingent, anxious to gain a berth in the forthcoming National Hockey League play-offs, responded grimly and succeeded in tying the blue-shirted sextet in an overtime game at Madison Square Garden.

President HINDENBURG'S great vote yesterday, though apparently a little less than a majority, is a wonderful tribute to Germany's confidence in the purity of his motives and his utter devotion to the well-being of the German people. He is placed far above the suspicion of personal ambition.

LONDON, March 11 -- In the rubber market here plantation grades were firmer today on more inquiry and a reserve of sellers. Smoked sheet spot and March sold at 25-16d to 2 3/8 d a pound, buyers; April-June at 2 3/8 d to 27-16d, buyers; July-September, 2 1/2 d to 29-16d, buyers; October-December, 2 5/8 d to 211-16d, buyers; January-March, 2 3/4 d to 213-16d, buyers; crepe spot, 31-16d, buyers.

Newtown High School, defending city P.S.A.L. basketball champion, has scored 361 points in its nine Queens division games to date and continues to lead all the other P.S. A.L. quintets in scoring. Its closest rival in the scoring race is Textile, Manhattan P.S.A.L. titleholder, which has completed its divisional schedule of ten games with 308 points.

The annual report of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company for 1931 shows a net loss of $3,655,660 after charges, taxes, depreciation and provision for foreign exchange losses, comparing with a net income of $11,881,705 for 1930, equal to $4.46 a share earned on combined 79,974 preferred and 2,586,341 common shares.

According to the London correspondent of Marine Engineering, the Germans will have the first battleship driven by Diesel engines. At Augsburg in Bavaria the Deutschland's engines were recently tested with apparent satisfaction to the builder and the German Navy.

Omnipotence of Press-Agents. The power of publicity in modern life is so unquestioned a fact that one cannot help wondering why its votaries should be citing it in the one case where it so conspicuously will not apply, and that is the change in Mr. HOOVER'S popularity during the last three years.

BERLIN, March 11 -- Except for steel shares, which advanced owing to hopes of orders from Russia and from the government under the unemployment relief scheme, stocks predominantly declined, and for the most part ended the week two to five points below prices of a week ago.

Fify-seven fellowships to scholars and artists of the United States and Latin America have been awarded for 1932-33 by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation, it was announced yesterday by Henry Allen Moe, secretary, on behalf of the trustees of the foundation.
PARIS, March 13 -- An airplane search in the African desert near Dakar for Count and Countess de Sibour has been ordered by the French Government.

Truck loads of plant life from grass to Cymbidium orchids arrived at Grand Central Palace yesterday for the opening today of the nineteenth international flower show. Hammers pounded all day and by nightfall four floors had been converted into a fairyland of banks, beds and gardens of flowers.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The schoolhouse attended by George Washington at the age of thirteen and depicted by him as the center of a surveying problem, is to be reproduced from records recently discovered in the possession of members of the Washington family.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is only too obvious that during periods of national calamity and distress forces that are essential to the maintenance of the most important institution of character-building, the home, are in thousands of cases either perverted or totally lacking.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 13 -- Fire tonight destroyed an unoccupied cottage and damaged an adjoining indoor tennis court on the country estate of Ralph Pulitzer, former publisher of The New York World, at North Hills, four miles from here.

Paul Robeson gave his farewell concert of the season last night in the Town Hall. His entire program was given to the Negro spirituals which he does so incomparably, and upon which any comment at this late date in the season is superfluous. One sometimes rebels at the sophisticated harmonic garments which Burleigh in particular among the arrangers of this music has hung about it.

PARIS, March 13 (AP) -- The District Police Commissioner said today that his inquiry into the suicide of Ivar Kreuger had been discontinued to await the arrival of relatives from Stockholm. All that remained, he said, was an inventory of objects in the flat and a collection of letters and papers there.
