Watson Thompson's goal in 2 minutes and 8 seconds of the sudden-death period that followed two extra periods gave the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club a 3-to-2 victory, over the St. Nicholas Hockey Club before a crowd of 8,000 at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

The Painters and Sculptors Guild, recently organized, is holding its second exhibition in the lounge of the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. The show will continue until March 30. Including paintings, sculpture and sculptors' drawings, the work now on view runs up to about eighty examples.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Miss Kelly's review of the late Seymour W. Smith's work, "John Hanson," whom Mr. Smith terms "our first President," I looked in vain for the names of other men to whom this title of "first President" might be given.

The greatest menace to present-day America is not the racketeer but the Sadducee, the intellectual whose mental culture is devoid of mysticism, the Rev. Dr. Robert Norwood declared yesterday morning in his sermon at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 13 -- Don Strachan, former Princeton University athlete and now representing the Germantown Cricket Club, and Miss Ruth Hall of the Merlon Cricket Club are the 1932 Atlantic Coast squash racquets champions.

Speaking on a practical working faith in, his sermon yesterday at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick suggested three aspects of his own conception of what such faith should be.

ROME, March 13 -- It is hazardous to make forecasts as to what is likely to happen at the expiration of the Hoover moratorium on war debts and reparations July 1, especially at the present moment, when the result of the Presidential election in Germany is still unknown, and another element of great uncertainty represented by the coming general elections in France still exists.

CALDWELL, N.J., March 13 -- The ninety-fifth anniversary of the birth of Grover Cleveland, twenty-second and twenty-fourth President of the United States, wag observed here this afternoon with services in the Caldwell Presbyterian Church under the auspices of the Grover Cleveland Birthplace Association.

Emilio Portes Gil, former Provisional President of Mexico after the assassination of General Obregon and more recently Minister of Mexico to France, arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Augustus, en route to Mexico, again to enter the political life of the nation.

STOCKHOLM, Monday, March 14 (AP) -- The Swedish Parliament, moving quickly after the suicide of Ivar Kreuger, today authorized the government to extend a brief moratorium to business interests, and the privilege was first applied to the "match king's" own concerns.

Immediate abandonment of the four-year bond method of financing new subway construction and the substitution of fifty-year bonds to prevent an unnecessary burden of more than $200,000,000 on the budget and the taxpayers in the next five years are urged by Controller Charles W. Berry in a report to the Board of Estimate, made public yesterday.

H.P. Davison partner in J.P. Morgan Co., will take an active part in the unemployment relief campaign of the Block Community Organization as chairman of the "block-aiders' " speakers' bureau, it was announced yesterday by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the organization.

RYE, N.Y., March 13 -- Three boats were capsized, one was swamped, two went on the rocks and the sail of a seventh was carried away in the dinghy sailing races of the Frostbite Yacht Club held today off the American Yacht Club at the tip of Milton Point.

Friends of James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic State Committee, have suggested him for the Democratic nomination of Lieut. Gov., it was learned yesterday. The suggestion has been made in the expectation that Governor Roosevelt will win the Democratic nomination for President, in which case Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman is virtually certain to be the party nominee for Governor.

Net income of the Western Electric Company, Inc., amounted to $10,816,387 in 1931, equal to $1.80 a share earned on 6,000,000 common shares, compared with $15,624,839, or $2.60 a share, earned on the same number of shares in 1930. Surplus after dividends of $1.75 a share in 1931 was $316,387, comparing with a deficit of $7,625,161 in 1930, when $4 a share was paid.

HAVANA, March 13 -- Lady Broadcast, 6-year-old daughter of Messenger-Conscious, owned by Herbert M. Woolf of Kansas City, won the Cuban Grand National Handicap, closing day feature at Oriental Park today.

In a recent address to the Farmers' Association of Porto Rico Governor BEVERLEY, who has himself been a farmer, declared that "Porto Rican "agriculture will prosper or will be "ruined according to whether or "not it learns diversification of crops "and proper grading and handling "of its products."

Without making any positive prediction as to the probable course of business in the future, the United States Steel Corporation, in its report for 1931, asserts that it is "reasonable to suppose" on the basis of the average demand for steel products in the last ten years that the "requirements of this country for maintenance and current uses alone" should call for a "considerably greater tonnage than was consumed" last year.

A dinner dance will be given on Thursday night in the ballroom of the clubhouse of the American Women's Association, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street. An entertainment will be given during the evening, in which many Broadway stars will take part.

Abandonment of the plan to reorganize the Tri-Utilities system under the agreement dated Sept. 1, 1931, was announced yesterday by the reorganization committee comprising Richard C. Hunt, William Buchsbaum and Medley G.B. Whelpley. It was stated that it had proved impossible to consummate the plan "because of the continued financial depression, further decreases in earnings, insufficient deposits and sales of collateral in enforcement of debts."

LONDON, March 13 -- Next to the question of whether the new British budget is going to show a decrease in the income tax rate, speculation arousing the most interest in national finances is whether the treasury program will be based on the assumption that the Hoover moratorium on war debts and reparations is going to be extended beyond July 1.

The text of the funding operation of the government of the United States of Brazil for its foreign loans on which it has been compelled to suspend payments of interest and sinking fund has been made public here by Dillon, Read Co. and N. M. Rothschild Sons on behalf of the Brazilian Government pursuant to a decree dated March 2.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The outcome of the election in Germany was received with gratification everywhere among officials and Congressional leaders in Washington tonight. Although President von Hindenburg did not obtain a majority, it was believed here that he would be the winner at the run-off election April 10.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., March 13 -- Tribute to the part played by New York troops during the American Revolution was paid at exercises in observance of New York State Sunday at Valley Forge today. Representing Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt and the people of New York, Budget Director Mark Graves was the speaker at the ceremony in the memorial chapel under auspices of the New York State Conference of the Daughters of the American Revolution.
To the Editor of The New YorK Times: Your editorial "A Bureau Cannot Die" irritated me somewhat, for it seems to be written on the basis of partial ignorance of many of the factors involved.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The first record vote in the House since the enactment of prohibition, directly involving the Eighteenth Amendment, is scheduled for tomorrow on the issue of considering the Beck-Linthicum resolution, which proposes submission of a constitutional amendment providing for State liquor control.

In the North Dakota primary tomorrow Mr. HOOVER'S name is not entered, though there is a ticket of delegates who support him. General COXEY of Ohio and former Senator FRANCE of Maryland will represent their divagations from or extensions of the true Republican genius.

The tradition rather generally held in the markets, that nothing of high financial importance will happen in the first eight or ten weeks of a new year, has certainly failed of fulfillment during the fortnight, past. As a matter of fact, however, March has not infrequently been a month of highly important developments, especially at times when, for better or worse, the situation was "on the turn."

Weather conditions served to check expansion of consumer buying of Spring apparel and restricted the volume of reorders placed last week by the stores. Confidence was general that the setback was only temporary and that favorable weather conditions will generate a sharp upswing in buying, particularly in the Easter period directly ahead.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 13 -- Mr. and Mrs. George A. Dobyne were hosts this morning at an informal musicale at Casa Beata. A small group of the Romany Chorus entertained with a program of songs.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 13 (AP) -- Lord Tennyson's team of English cricketers yesterday averted the possibility of an innings defeat in its second and final match against the Colony of Jamaica.

Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, who defeated former Governor Alfred E. Smith in his first test in the East at the New Hampshire primary election last Tuesday, will have his first test of strength in the West tomorrow at the primary election in North Dakota, his opponent there being Governor William H. Murray of Oklahoma.

Mischa Elman, distinguished Rus- sian violinist, whose American career dates from 1908, the same year that brought Gatti-Casazza to the Metropolitan, appeared as guest at the "opera concert" last evening with a half-dozen of Mr. Gatti's singing stars.

Trading will be resumed in American certificates for Kreuger Toll Company participating debentures on the New York Stock Exchange today despite the suicide of Ivar Kreuger in Paris Saturday. Officials of the Exchange did not deem it necessary to call a meeting to consider the question over the week-end, and leading bankers and brokers yesterday expressed the private belief that transactions in the security would be entirely normal from the standpoint of trading rules.

Harlan F. Stone, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, has been appointed to the administrative board of the new Institute of International Affairs of Columbia University, it was announced yesterday. Justice Stone, who will serve three years, was dean of the Columbia Law School from 1910 to 1924, resigning shortly before he was named Attorney General by President Coolidge.

PARIS, March 13 -- Although the communique issued after their conversation yesterday was very restrained, it is understood that the main subject discussed between Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, and Premier Tardieu of France was the position which must be faced when the Hoover moratorium expires.

William Rose Benet, poet, editor and critic, and Miss Lora Baxter, an actress now appearing in "The Animal Kingdom," will be married at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon at the Church of the Transfiguration (the Little Church Around the Corner), 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- Money is being released by bankers and hoarders and the banking situation has been improved throughout the West with indications of further betterment in all lines of trade. Money has been held in savings deposits and otherwise has come into circulation to a liberal extent as a result of drives on the part of the government and bankers.
HONOLULU, March 13 (AP) -- A 17-year-old Chinese girl was assaulted late last night in Honolulu's third attack upon a woman within two weeks.

It is announced by the Federal Council of Churches that a "committee on worship" is to seek greater unity in matters of worship by "non-liturgical communions" of the Protestant churches. This looks toward a greater emphasis upon "responsive" services.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Senator Wagner of New York will introduce in the Senate tomorrow a bill calling for a bond issue of $1,100,000,000 for the actual construction of government projects already authorized and approved by Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Democratic national organization made an open effort tonight to draw together party ranks in the House to support the manufacturers' sales tax, backbone of the non-partisan plan to balance the budget.

"Japanese expansion in Manchuria is far more defensible than American expansion in the Caribbean and in Central America," it is declared in a book published today for which Tsuyoshi Inukai, Prime Minister of Japan, wrote the introduction. K.K. Kawakami, a writer on Japanese policies who is now resident in Washington, wrote the book, titled "Japan Speaks on the Sino-Japanese Crisis," published by Macmillan.

Thirty-two candidates for the New York University football team reported to Howard G. Cann, new head coach, for the opening Spring practice at Ohio Field yesterday. Eighteen veterans were in the group, which is scheduled to engage in daily sessions during the next three weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Personalities prominent in the American scene, ranging from President Hoover to Babe Ruth and including, with impartiality, Mrs. Edward Everett Gann, sister of Vice President Curtis; Mrs. Alice Roosevelt Longworth and Mrs. Mabel Walker Willebrandt, were featured in a series of skits "put on" as part of the afterdinner program of the annual stunt party given tonight at the Willard Hotel by the Women's National Press Club.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Arrests in February for prohibition-law violations in the United States showed an increase of 29 per cent over the previous month. The seizures of automobiles increased 77 per cent and of stills 8 per cent, Commissioner Woodcock reported today.

Repercussions of Ivar Kreuger suicide in Paris Saturday morning were felt in all of the world financial markets yesterday, but most dramatically on the New York Stock Exchange, where 673,800 certificates in Mr. Kreuger's principal enterprise, the Kreuger Toll Company, were sold in great confusion at sharply reduced prices.

Looking for Bargains. An English newspaper reports that an Afghan delegation presented itself at Geneva to take part in the Disarmament Conference. Their appearance rather surprised the officials. Afghanistan, does not belong to the League of Nations, so what were her representatives doing there?

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- Dr. James Hendrie Lloyd, a specialist in mental and nervous diseases, died of pneumonia at his home here today after a brief illness. He was in his eightieth year and had been retired from active practice for some time.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The New York reapportionment case, involving the right of the Legislature to redistrict without submitting the resolution to Governor Roosevelt for approval, was presented to the Supreme Court today with a request that its hearing be expedited.

BERLIN, March 14 -- Paul von Hindenburg's triumph in the contest for the German Presidency should cause lively satisfaction in the United States. The American public and the Americans living in Germany will perceive therein the guarantee for a stable and thoughtful leadership of the country and a firm and dignified representative of the German people.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Vincent Kerens will have to make another try for the $2,000,000 prize which depends upon his convincing a court he has been sober and behaved himself for five years.

TRENTON, N.J., March 14 -- With Dr. John Grier Hibben, president of Princeton University, and Dean G. W. Kirchwey of the Law School of Columbia University leading the attack on the measures and Dr. Frank Moore, former superintendent of Rahway Reformatory defending them, two bills to reorganize the State Department of Institutions and Agencies were the subject of a public hearing today before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Prospects for adoption of the essential features of the new tax bill brightened for house leaders today when debate shifted from the manufacturers' sales tax to the proposed centa-gallon tax on oil imports.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Returns of 1931 Federal incomes will be due in the mails by midnight tomorrow, after which penalties must be paid by taxpayers in addition to the taxes due. The taxes to be received from corporations and individuals will show the largest percentage decline from the preceding year since the World War.

Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, head of the New Jersey police searching for the kidnapped Lindbergh baby, denied yesterday that he knew anything about the activities of underworld emissaries of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and admitted that the men of his command had made no new progress toward finding the missing infant.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- By a vote of 227 to 187, the smallest majority the drys have had in the House of Representatives since the prohibition amendment to the Constitution was adopted, the House today declined to take up the Beck-Linthicum resolution.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Stricter enforcement of the dry laws or modification of them was urged upon President Hoover today by a group representing the hotel and restaurant industries. The delegation, which called upon the President at the White House, promised full support for any recommendation he might make as to a change.

Charges that two Brooklyn politicians were threatened with physical violence if they persisted in opposing the candidacy of Magistrate Sylvester F. Sabbatino for County Judge last year; and that one of them, threatened by the Magistrate himself, also was told he would be indicted for alleged misappropriation of funds and "run out of the country," were contained in an affidavit submitted yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Lewis L. Fawcett in Brooklyn.

For the first time since May 14, 1914, refined sugar was priced generally yesterday at 4 cents a pound, following declines of 10 and then 5 points, or a total of 15 points, from the previously established price of 4.15 cents. On the Pacific Coast refined beet sugar was marked down to 3.90 cents a pound.

Mrs. Ida E. Wood, who as a Southern belle fluttered across New York's social horizon in Civil War days, and whose museum-like rooms in the Herald Square Hotel recently have yielded a hidden fortune, was buried in Calvary Cemetery, Queens, yesterday, while less than a score of persons looked on.

PARIS, March 14 -- Although the International Sugar Council opened its meeting here today, the fact that the Cuban delegate, Luis Marino Peres, reached Paris only late tonight, having come on the Bremen, held the procedure to mere formalities. Tomorrow morning the meeting will start important negotiations, seeking to reach an agreement on sugar production and export quotas.

CLEAR WATER, Fla.. March 14 -- An announcement that must have caused a shock in Glendale, Cal., but which brought great satisfaction to the announcer was made by Manager Max Carey just preceding today's opening game between the Robins and Newark Bears.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14 -- John Maynard Keynes, English economist, will say in an article in the Spring issue of The Yale Review, to be published tomorrow, that it may become necessary for the rest of the world to refrain from buying the exports of such countries as France and the United States which have an unbalanced creditor position, and which insist upon payment in gold of the debts owed them.

Traffic on the State Barge Canal Showed a marked increase in 1931 when nearly all maritime activities decreased here, the Port of New York Authority reports. Emphasizing the need for further development of the canal and the growing importance to New York of the development of inland sources of commerce, the Port Authority reiterates the demand which it has made for a grant of Federal funds to improve the State waterway.

HAMBURG, March 14 -- Two-year-old Frances Quirbach of York, Pa., occupied the spotlight on the American liner City of Baltimore for a brief time tonight as a brace of Hamburg detectives, and several newspapermen sought to convince themselves she was not the Lindbergh baby.

LONDON, March 14 -- Probable starters in the famous Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree on Friday were reduced to thirty-eight today. Remus, which met with a mishap in training last week, is not listed among the likely starters.

BOMBAY, March 14 (AP) -- A woman poet and enemy of the feminist movement today was appointed acting president of the All-India National Congress and thus became the leader of the Mahatma Gandhi's civil disobedience in India. She is Mme. Sarojini Naidu.

Two women and two men, all from Boston and vicinity, were booked at the West Forty-seventh Street police station last night on charges of possessing fraudulent currency. Spurious banknotes in $5, $10 and $20 denominations were found between a spring and matress in their room, the detectives said.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is an exhibition of architecture now in New York at the Museum of Modern Art which should attract any stranger as well as resident of this country. America's contribution to the channels of art today is undoubtedly at its highest point In architecture.

Two hundred and fifty attorneys appeared yesterday in Surrogate's Court to file objections to the probate of the will of Ella Virginia von E. Wendel, aged spinster, who died on March 12, 1931. leaving an estate valued at more than $100,000,000 to charity.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 14 (AP) -- There was nothing in George Eastman'a long and effective career to Indicate a motive for suicide. Dr. Stewart, his physician, said only that he "apparently was in such mental state." He had been ill for several years, tout had recovered to a degree that encouraged his friends, the physician added.

LIMA, Peru, March 14 -- Jose Melgar Marquez went on trial before a court-martial today for an attempt to assassinate President Luis M. Sanchez Cerro a week ago Sunday, while outside the court room the government took steps to eradicate a supposedly widespread communistic revolutionary movement thought to have been linked with the attempt.

PARIS, March 14 -- The French reaction to the German elections as manifested in the press today was one of mild relief combining satisfaction over the prospect of a probable victory for President von Hindenburg on the second ballot with a certain concern over the increase of Nazi strength as exhibited in the popular vote throughout Germany.

STOCKHOLM, March 14 -- Nothing like a panic occurred in Sweden today as a result of Ivar Kreuger's suicide in Paris Saturday. The moratorium with which the government armed itself helped prevent a rush of frightened investors and the public generally followed Premier Ekman's advice to remain cool.

LONDON, March 14 -- London society was chuckling today over a dash to the famous smithy of Gretna Green by a couple in their 'teens and a breakneck automobile and airplane chase by the lad's parents, that thwarted an elopement.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., March 14 James Henry Curtin, 73, of 21 Broadview Avenue, Maplewood, manager of Brooklyn theatres for many years and manager of the London Theatre in the Bowery, New York, many years ago, died today at his home after a long illness.
Eddie Herbst of the Bronx fought a draw with Frank Le Blanco of Brooklyn in the feature six-round bout of the new talent show at the St. Nicholas Arena last night before a crowd of 1,500.

BERLIN, March 14 -- Expressing gratification this morning over the size of his vote in yesterday's election, President Paul von Hindenburg immediately authorized a statement that he would be a candidate in the second balloting on April 10.
The turnover In New Jersey realty reported yesterday was made up largely of bousing properties. Several taxpayers also were conveyed.

Following the resignation last Saturday of Charles S. Hand as Sanitation. Commissioner because of what ha said were the "persistent illegal actions" of Dr. William Schroeder Jr., chairman of the Sanitary Commission, Samuel Seabury declared yesterday that the Department of Sanitation had violated the law in failing to have the words "City of New York" painted on the bodies of the expensive cars used by its officials.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The vote by States in the House today on the motion to take up the BeckLinthicum resolution for resubmission of prohibition shows that the wets prevailed in seventeen of them. The vote was as follows:

LONDON, March 14 -- The death of Ivar Kreuger and its possible effects were the chief topics on the Stock Exchange today. The tragic passing of the Swedish match king was held largely responsible for a drop in sterling, the New York rate opening at $3.60 1/2 but subsequently recovering to $3.62 1/2.
NEW YORK. The Hon. Somerset Arthur Maxwell, son of Lord Farnham of London, is arriving on the Olympic and wilf be at the Ambassador.

Yesterday's markets opened with the course of financial sentiment and financial prices subjected to opposite influences, from two occurrences of which the news had come since last week's markets closed. The suicide of an international capitalist with affiliations as large as those of the Swede, Ivar Kreuger, was bound to have unsettling influence.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Immediate appropriation of $60,000,000 to maintain full employment on Federal waterway improvements was asked of Congress today by President Hoover.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Receipts of hogs here today were in excess of expectations and prices dropped 10 cents generally, although some sales were regarded as 15 to 20 cents lower than the final extremes of last week. Reports from the dressed meat trade were less favorable, which caused smaller butchers to operate with caution.

The ranks of the elect in the national indoor tennis championship stood firm again without a single casualty yesterday, as Jean Borotra of prance set the pace with a victory in love seta over Merritt Cutler at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

The series of technical defects which for two years has impeded the prosecution of City Trust Company defendants culminated in Brooklyn yesterday with the dismissal of conspiracy charges against thirteen former officers, stockholders and depositors of the Atlantic State branch of the defunct bank.

TORONTO, Ont., March 14 -- Cancer research, treatment and preventive education under government control, looking to finding ultimately a cure for the disease, are recommended in a report of the Ontario Cancer Commission made public today.

Unless Mayor Walker acts immediately to appoint the Board of Taxicab Control authorized by the local law which he signed on Jan. 29 no official body empowered to grant new taxicab licenses will be in existence on March 31, when the 19,000 outstanding licenses expire, it was disclosed yesterday.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- Frost and ice, which accompanied Winter's latest march through Dixie, caused heavy crop damage, particularly in Florida.

BERLIN, March 14 -- Despite the bullish effect of the election the Boerse was weak today under the repercussions of Mr. Kreuger's death. Svenska led the decline, which developed into a bear raid on trust shares generally, facilitated by the fact that in anticipation of a strong vote for Hindenburg, the shorts covered on Saturday.

LUCRETIUS imagined that all the objects in nature are constantly giving off films or images, in infinite complexity yet in no Confusion, keeping their forms on their way to the senses. GEORGE EASTMAN, who died yesterday, will be remembered pre-eminently for giving to mankind a means of catching these images in their flight by a film more sensitive than the senses themselves.

By the margin of a single field goal, scored in an overtime period, the St. Michael's High School basketball team of Union City, N.J., last night defeated St. Francis High School of Brooklyn, 21 to 19, in the final of the third annual Metropolitan Catholic High Schools basketball tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Much significance was seen by many leaders in the result of the first test vote on prohibition in the House today. The wet leaders heralded their unexpected strength as indicating a growing desire for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Unlisted stocks eased in quiet trading yesterday. Favorite bank and insurance issues recovered for a time after a weak opening, but receded later to end at net declines. Losses were recorded in First National, Guaranty Trust, Central Hanover, Brooklyn Trust, Commercial National, City, Chemical, Chase, Manufacturers Trust, Bankers, Empire, Manhattan, Public, Irving, Corn and Continental.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 14 (AP) -- The second and final cricket match between Lord Tennyson's team of English cricketers and the colony of Jamaica today resulted in victory for the Jamaicans by four wickets. The colony's team won the first match by an innings and 97 runs.

Columbia and Princeton, tied for the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, will engage in a play-off on the neutral University of Pennsylvania court, the Palestra, on Thursday, it was announced yesterday by Ellwood W. Kemp Jr., secretary-treasurer of the league.

Handshaking, back-patting and the utterance of platitudes by leaders of religious denominations were condemned yesterday morning by Frank A. Horne at a meeting of about 150 Methodist Episcopal ministers of the metropolitan area at Methodist headquarters, 150 Fifth Avenue.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 14 -- Miss Helen Waring of New York today triumphed over a field of golfers from many States to win the championship of the Silver Foils Golf Society with a thirty-six-hole score of 180.

Landlords and renting agents, who in the past have escaped with civil proceedings when their tenants have been found to violate the prohibition law, will be prosecuted criminally in this district if it can be shown that they have rented their property with the knowledge that it was to be used in violating the law, George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, announced yesterday.

BOSTON, March 14 -- Alfred E. Smith, in a letter replying to questions asked by Mrs. Jessie W. Sayre, daughter of Woodrow Wilson, and made public today, stated that a Massachusetts slate of delegates pledged to him would be entirely free to vote for any candidate for the Presidential nomination they chose at the national convention when and if he should be eliminated from consideration.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 14 -- The biggest question mark of the Winter turf is 16 hands, 3 3/4 inches high. He is Phar Lap, Australia's greatest living thoroughbred, which was brought 15,000 miles in an attempt to wrest from American horses the $50,000 first prize in the Agua Caliente Handicap next Sunday.

Dentists who are willing to fill teeth in return for oil paintings and physicians, who agree to accept the same fees for treating ailing artists will be able to begin collecting art within the next few weeks. The same prospect is held out to landlords and merchants by the Society of Independent Artists, who have decided in their show this year to consider other media than hard cash in exchange for their work.

SHANGHAI, March 14 -- A telegram from Loyang addressed to Sun Fo, former Premier, at Shanghai today reveals that the plenary session of the Central Executive Committee at Loyang on March 4 secretly adopted, a resolution calling for "immediate measures for the restoration by means of concrete force of the territorial and political integrity of China."

Awards for Today. Although new State and municipal bonds amounting to more than $50,000,000 are scheduled for award today, the major issue, $35,000,000 State of Louisiana 5 per cent highway bonds due from 1936 to 1957, is not expected to attract bids.

MTAMI, Fla., March 14 -- Jaz Age, trained and owned by J. Parmalee, captured the Orange State Handicap, feature at Tropical Park, today, but considerable interest was centred in the riding of Buddy Ensor, who scored a triple, his first since ha began his come-back as a rider after a long layoff.

The Borden Company reported yesterday a net income for 1931 of $16,088,828, equivalent, after income taxes and provision for profit sharing, to $3.66 a share on. 4,395,281 shares of common stock. In 1930, the net income before provision for profit sharing was $21,681,214, which was equivalent to $4.84 a ahare after profit sharing deductions.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Senator Glass of Virginia said late today that the subcommittee considering his banking bill had virtually completed its work and that it would go to the Banking and Currency Committee tomorrow afternoon.

Notwithstanding the big supply of funds available, Stock Exchange call loans continued at 2 1/2 per cent throughout the day. A little was done in the street market at 2%. Federal funds were offered at 1/2, but there was no demand. Recently this accommodation was as high as 2.

The greatest amateur boxing tournament on the city's calendar to date was held last night in Madison Square Garden before one of the largest crowds ever to witness a boxing show, amateur or professional, indoors.

Coach Richard J. Glendon had the Columbia rowing squad out on the Harlem River yesterday for nearly two hours, but only six miles were covered during the workout. Interruptions were frequent all along the course, as Glendon concentrated his efforts toward improving the racing of the varsity eight.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 14 -- Robert Saltonstall Jr. of Readville, Mass., was today elected to captain the Harvard varsity hockey team for next season.

PARIS. March 14 -- The suicide of Ivar Kreuger, Swedish financier, here last Saturday gave the Paris Bourse today the worst day it has had since the failure of the Kreditanstalt, although the Kreuger Toll interests in France are not very important and the news of the German elections was considered rather favorable.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has agreed to carry the $4,400,000 bank loan, now on a demand basis, for not less than three years for the Federal Water Service Corporation, under a contract signed between the bank and the public utility system yesterday.

Harry C. Perry, chief clerk of the City Court and deposed Tammany district leader, took the witness stand yesterday afternoon before three justices of the court designated to hear testimony in connection with the charges filed against him by Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter committee. He gave what his prosecutors called an "amazing" explanation of the source of part of the $135,000 unexplained bank deposits which formed the basis of the Seabury charges.

Wall Street did not know until after the close of the stock market that George Eastman had committed suicide, although the financial news tickers carried the announcement of his death soon after 2 o'clock. Trading ends on the Stock Exchange at 3 o'clock.
Michael Welch, the famous Smiling Mickey, one of the two pitchers of the Giants of 1888 who brought New York its first National League pennant, has been honored by the Elks with a life membership.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 14 (AP). -- Twenty-five head of show horses of all ages were sold for $5,590, an average of $223.60, as the annual three-day Spring sale of the Kentucky Sales Company opened today.

Political oracles are always as solemn as Roman augurs. Even when they make obvious mistakes, or unwittingly allow one of their predictions or lucid explanations to contradict another, they maintain their admirable poise and self-confidence.

Pressure against the share market yesterday was due largely, in the opinion of Wall Street, to the unsettlement in a small group of stocks in which Ivar Kreuger, who ended his life in Paris on Saturday morning, was interested. The heavy selling of Kreuger Toll depressed not only that stock but also other issues with no kinship whatever.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 14 -- George Eastman, founder and chairman of the board of the Eastman Kodak Company, internationally known philanthropist and inventor, killed himself in his East Avenue home shortly after noon today. He had been in ill health for several years.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, March 15 -- Special honor guards with drawn revolvers and their fingers on the triggers were the first surprising sight that greeted the League of Nations Commission of Investigators upon their arrival in Shanghai last night.

Net income as well as gross revenues and total assets, of the Pacific Gas Electric Corporation continused to grow in 1931, according to the preliminary statement of the company issued yesterday, which shows that total assets passed $700,000,000 for the first time.
CHICAGO, March 14 -- The wheat market In a violent break today went out of the narrow range in which it had fluctuated for nearly a month.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 14 (AP) -- George Eastman gave more than $20,000,000 to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It was largely through his philanthropies that the existing educational plant Was made possible.

The report of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, including subsidiaries for 1931 shows a deficit of $3,255,762 after charges, against a net income of $5,621,536, or $4.03 a share on common stock, in 1930. There was a deficit of $7,513,856 after dividends in 1931, against a deficit of $2,562,531 in 1930.

LOS ANGELES, March 14 -- The Giants went Into the doldrums today and suffered a thrashing at the hands of Rogers Hornsby's Cuba in the sixth game of the current exhibition series. The score was 11 to 5, thereby tying the series at three games apiece.

The culture and material prosperity of civilized nations "have increased by leaps and bounds since inexpensive and abundant printing, now a heritage of common man, replaced hand-written manuscripts that were available only to a few favored individuals," Dr. Calvin W. Rice, secretary of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, declared yesterday.

In order to gauge the political significance of yesterday's roll-call on prohibition in the House of Representatives, one must analyze the vote by parties and sections. The question was whether the House would consider a resolution to resubmit the Eighteenth Amendment to the States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "Debts and Foreign Trade" excellently summarized the outstanding argument for the revision of our foreign financial policy. Despite the undeniable facts pointed out in the editorial, there still remains in this country a large group of intelligent citizens who refuse to sanction in any degree either the reduction of war debts or a downward revision of our present tariff rates.

TORONTO, Ont., March 14 (Canadian Press) -- Total income of $11,055,792 and net profit of $5,094,497 for 1931 are shown by the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., in the annual report just issued. The profit was equivalent to 22 cents a share on the outstanding common stock after allowing $1,933,937 for preferred dividends, compared with $11,770,060, or 67 cents a share, in 1930.

The campaign planned by the Republican State organization to keep economy in government the dominant issue in the coming campaign, in this State at least, was started yesterday by W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman.

Declaring that gangsters and racketeers were terrorizing the millinery industry. Max Zaritsky, president of the Cloth Hat, Cap and Millinery Workers' Union, informed Captain Michael McDermott, head of the industrial squad of the Police Department, yesterday that conditions had reached such a state that the union had formed a volunteer committee of 700 members to eliminate the menace.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES correspondent in Berlin who wrote the piece about Hitler and the Jews must be most naive. He states three dangerous aspects of the situation which, in his opinion, are to be discounted. I quote:

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- There were no "wise-cracking" dramatic critics in the caucus room of the House office building today when the Committee on Patents and fifty or sixty eager spectators, several of them members of Congress, had assembled to "see the show" expected as a result of invitations extended to reviewers by Chairman Sirovich, who has been attacking them.

MAPLEWOOD. N.J., March 14 -- Mrs. M. Casewell Heine, president of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs, told the seventh district conference of the federation here today that mothers and club-women were responsible for the government of the State and that they should spread a knowledge of State affairs.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 -- "Getting wanner, but not hot under the collar," was Colonel Jacob Ruppert's summary of his lengthy conference with Babe Ruth on the subject of the Babe's contract today while the rest of the Yankee players were finishing the practice session.

HONGKONG, March 14.-Attempts by disgruntled politicians and semimutinous military leaders to stir up dissension and promote the founding of a new independent government at Canton apparently have failed despite strong backing given to the secession plan by certain Northern politicians and former Kuomintang party members who are refugees in Hongkong.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- The United States Military Academy led five other colleges in the number of individuals qualified to compete in the intercollegiate boxing championships at Syracuse Friday and Saturday, according to the drawings announced today by Dr. Francis C. Grant.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The quaint, old-fashioned chamber where the United States Supreme Court holds its sessions was crowded to its limits today as Benjamin N. Cardozo, lately Chief Judge of the State Supreme Court of Appeals, took office as an Associate Justice of the highest court of the nation.

Opposition to the proposed manufacturers' sales tax of 2.25 per cent was voiced here yesterday at meetings held by the Merchants Association of New York City, the Associated Dress Industries of America and the United Women's Wear League of America, as well as in telegrams and letters sent to members of Congress, where the proposed tax measure is pending.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on March 9 shows decreases for the week of $218,000 in loans and investments, $33,000,000 in net demand deposits, $72,000,000 in government deposits and $77,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks, and an increase of $14,000,000 in time deposits.

In "Souvenirs, My Life With Maeterlinck," Georgette Leblanc, actress and opera singer, tells of her twenty years' association with the Nobel Prize winner who profoundly affected the literary styles and thought of a quarter-century ago. Their association was abruptly terminated by Maeterlinck's marriage.

The concert given by the Oratorio Society, Albert Stoessel, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, paid observance to the presence of a distinguished visitor in the person of Gustav Hoist, the English composer, whose Two Psalms, for chorus, strings and organ, opened the program.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 14 -- The "outlaw" strike called by some local unions in the anthracite fields of the Lackawanna and Wyoming Valleys was ignored today by most of the 60,000 miners to whom it was addressed, according to officers of the United Mine Workers of America, who are vigorously opposing the strike.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The campaign to give the people a second opportunity to pass on prohibition began immediately after the ratification of the Eighteen Amendment in January, 1919.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Frustrated in efforts to consolidate the War and Navy Departments through action by the House Expenditures Committee, and confronted with objections of Cabinet members to other plans to reduce governmental expenditures, the Democrats today put through the House a resolution extending the life of the Economy Committee and giving it "super" legislative powers.

Mayor WALKER naturally sought to persuade Commissioner HAND to reconsider his resignation from the Sanitary Commission. It puts the Mayor in an awkward position, reminiscent of the days when the late JOSEPH A. WARREN stepped down from the Police Commissionership.

An investigation into the organization and operation of Howard University, a Negro institution in Washington, D.C., was ordered yesterday at a special meeting of the board of trustees of the university held at the Prince George Hotel.

It is humanly certain that President HINDENBUBG will win the runoff election next month. For HITLER it is impossible to foresee more than 14,000,000 votes, representing his own poll on Sunday and that of the Hugenberg Nationalists. For VON HINDENBURG it is impossible to foresee any serious decline from his vote of 18,660,000 votes on Sunday, and he may do better than that.

From the week-end cables, regarding the attitude of financial and official London toward the past week's sterling market, it may be inferred that the plan of "devaluing" the pound sterling is, at least in principle, being considered favorably.
In ' science, George Eastman, unknown to the public, occupied unobtrusively one of the great strategic positions.

The North American Edison Company and subsidiaries report for 1931 a net income of $14,386,361 after taxes, charges, depreciation and preferred dividends of subsidiaries, equal to $39.13 a share earned on 367,660 no par shares of S6 preferred stock, comparing with $17,691,870, or $49.64 a share of 356,350 shares of preferred stock in 1930.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Following is the detailed vote in the House today on the motion to bring up the State-control prohibition amendment. The members art grouped by States, the "ayes" representing the anti-prohibition forces:

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Cotton consumed during February was reported by the Census Bureau today to have totaled 450,018 bales of lint and 52,764 of linters, compared with 435,337 of lint and 50,241 of linters in January, this year, and 433,376 of lint and 53,687 of linters in February, last year.
The second bridge tournament in a series to aid the Vineyard Shore School for Women Workers in Industry will take place this afternoon at the River Club, 435 East Fifty-second Street.

BANG! Bang! And not a single Indian bit the dust. This is a different story. This is the tale of a revolver expert who has never yet hit the target. There are sharpshooters. This fellow must be the world's champion bluntshooter. He can whip out a revolver, fire fifty shots in the course of a festive evening, and not a single friend or foe will fall.

TRENTON, N.J., March 14 -- A measure calling for the repeal of the Hobart act, the State prohibition enforcement law, will be reported out of a Senate committee for a vote next week. Senator Emerson L. Richards, majority leader of the Republican-controlled Senate, announced tonight after a conference of Republican Senators.

Not all the flowers are at the Grand Central Palace flower show. In several art galleries, at the moment, they are blooming their best, as if bent on honoring with the handsomest possible gesture the annual display of real blossoms. The show at the Reinhardt Gallery, which gracefully groups children and flowers, has already been reviewed.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 14 -- The wreck of the Canadian National steamship Prince David yesterday off St. George was attributed today to an unusually strong tide that swept the liner, recently transferred from the Pacific, off its course.

BISMARCK, N.D., March 14 -- Not in many years have North Dakota political forecasters faced such an enigma as that presented by the Democratic Presidential primary this year. So many factors are present that anything may happen.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP). -- An orator to sound the keynote at the Republican National Convention. June 14 will be selected in Chicago, April 9 by the Committee on Arrangements, the committee decided today after preparations had been made for decorations and broadcasting and press arrangements.

Dick Shikat, former champion, defeated Sammy Stein in the feature bout of the championship wrestling elimination series at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night. The end came after more than an hour of wrestling, the time being 1:05:25.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday-3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names.

GENEVA, March 14 -- Determined that whatever else may develop out of this disarmament conference there must be no tampering with what already has been obtained in the matter of arms limitation in the Washington and London agreements, Senator Swanson went to the defense of one of the minor articles of these agreements today in the first outburst of Senatorial oratory that has been heard in the conference.

Recognition by the American courts of evidence based on blood tests in cases of doubtful paternity, murder cases, and in a number of other instances in which evidence is uncertain or unavailable was urged last night at a symposium on "the forensic value of tests for blood grouping" at the New York Academy of Medicine by the Society of Medical Jurisprudence.

All factors combined to make the nineteenth international flower show, which opened yesterday at the Grand Central Palace, the outstanding exhibit of colorful Spring plants and blooms so far conducted by the Horticultural Society of New York and the New York Florists' Club.

Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt has signed certificates which formally enter his name as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President in the primaries of Florida, West Virginia and California, James A. Farley, Democratic State chairman, announced yesterday.
BASLE, March 14 -- Ivar Kreuger's death dominated the talk among the European central bankers assembled today for the monthly meeting of the World Bank board.

PARIS, March 14 -- Necessity for quick action if 500 tons of American apples, valued at several hundred thousand dollars, are to be saved from spoiling on a dock at Havre, was impressed on the Minister of Agriculture tonight by Ambassador Edge.
The participating artists at the season's sixth, concert of the Beethoven Association, last night in the Town Hall, were Margaret Matzenauer, contralto; the Roth Quartet and Frank La Forge, pianist.

One million more New Yorkers will be invited personally to join the "Block-Aiders" today when the official recruiting leaflet of the Block Community Organization is delivered with the morning milk by employes of Borden's Farm Products Company, the Sheffield Farms Company and the New York Milk Conference Board.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Governor Roosevelt will return to his desk at the Capitol tomorrow to be faced with the problem of disposing of 760 bills, so-called thirty-day bills, and the designation of a Supreme Court justice as an associate judge of the Court of Appeals in place of Judge Cuthbert W. Pound, who today assumed the duties of chief justice.

Organization of a symphony orchestra of 200 of the best players among the unemployed musicians of this city has been begun, it wag announced yesterday by Walter Damrosch, chairman of the Musicians' Emergency Aid, and Mrs. Olin Downes, chairman of the orchestra committee.

The performance of "Alice Sit-by-the-Fire" and "The Old Lady Shows Her Medals," the two Barrie plays in which Lauretta Taylor has been, starring at the Playhouse, was called off shortly before the scheduled curtain time last night. Holders of tickets had their money refunded at the box-office.

LONDON, March 14 -- Sir Robert Horne, former president of the Board of Trade and former Chancellor of the Exchequer, predicted tonight that the remonetization of silver would be one of the chief topics to be considered at the next British imperial conference at Ottawa next July.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Commenting on the prohibition repeal vote in the House today, F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League of America, said in part:

A report on the successful operation of a low-rate plan for semi-private patients at the Hospital for Joint Diseases, 1,919 Madison Avenue, whereby doctors are not permitted to charge non-operative adult patients more than $17.50 a week and the hospital charge is only $5 a day for bed, board and nursing, was submitted by Frederick Brown, president of the hospital, to the United Hospital Fund yesterday.

The Skelly Oil Company reported yesterday a net loss of $2,117,110 for 1931, contrasted with a net profit of $1,916,872 for 1930, equivalent, after preferred dividends, to $1.39 a share oh the common stock.

ROCHESTER, Minn., March 14 (AP). -- Former Senator James A. Reed of Missouri today was recovering from an operation performed last Friday. The attending physician said he showed "slight improvement" but that his condition still was critical.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 14 -- A tea and private exhibition of the paintings and sculpture of C. Percival Dietsch was held by Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer this afternoon at Capricho, their villa.

Total liabilities of $19,759,352 and assets of $12,842,213 are listed In schedules of the firm of Pynchon Co., former members of the New York Stock Exchange, who were petitioned into bankruptcy last April.

After an amendment by Senator VANDENBERG as " a procedural contribution" had been discussed and defeated on the ground of its irrelevancy, Senator JAMES HAMILTON LEWIS arose. His look drew audience and attention still as night. Great oaks from little acorns grow.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Of 199,068 gainful workers over 10 years of age in Newark on April 1, 1930, the males numbered 145,851, or 73.3 per bent. The workers were 45 per cent of the population of the city, according to the Census Bureau.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 14 -- A hearing on charges that the town relief officer, Robert Campbell of Hempstead, had insulted a woman who applied for relief was ordered today after Mrs. Alice Perry, a mother of three children, filed a complaint with the Nassau County Board of Supervisors.

The march of Russia toward the Pacific, temporarily blocked by the World War and the revolution, has started again and is "by all odds the most important combined migration of people and culture in the modern world," Owen Lattimore writes in "Manchuria, Cradle of Conflict,' published today by Macmillan.

Giulio Edilberto Borrelli, reputed gambler to whom Hisashi Fujimura, missing Japanese silk merchant, is said to have paid $35,000 before sailing last August on a cruise on the steamship Belgenland from which he never returned, was indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury on a charge of failing to report his income for 1928 and 1930.
Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, once characterized George Eastman as "a literally stupendous factor in the education of the modern world."

DETROIT, March 14 (AP). -- Alexander Graham, New Philadelphia, Ohio, took the lead in the singles division of the American Bowling Congress tourney today with a total of 719. Graham, competing in his third national tourney, rolled games of 227, 276 and 216.

The charge that the Board of Transportation intends to delay operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway "until it is reasonably sure that unification of all lines can be effectuated" was made yesterday by the West Side Association of Commerce in a statement signed by James W. Danahy, managing director.

BUENOS AIRES, March 14 (AP). -- Out of the jungles of Northeastern Paraguay -- "a land of mold and blood" -- has come the story of an American zoologist who is fighting his way to the headwaters of the Parana River under the lash of hunger, heat and venomous insects' stings.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- New policies in education were advocated today before the group attending a series of conferences accompanying the dedication of the new graduate education building of the University of Chicago. President Hutchins will preside tomorrow morning at the closing session.

Robert Ellsworth Johnston, for a generation concert manager for celebrated artists in tours all over the country, died of heart disease yesterday at his home, 440 West End Avenue, after a long illness. He was thought to be much improved in health recently, just as his illness took a sudden turn for the worse.

In sympathy with the weakness in the stock and grain markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke yesterday to the lowest figures in a month and closed at the bottom, 10 to 12 points lower than on Saturday. Despite unfavorable over-Sunday European news, the market held within a narrow range for several hours.

MONTREAL, March 14 (Canadian Press). -- Indications are that the International Division point-makers will excel those of the American section by a considerable margin in the National Hockey League race. Statistics issued tonight from the office of President Frank Calder show leading scorers and play-makers of the international section now well in advance of their sectional rivals.

To the Editor of The new York Times: A letter from Amy G. Bassett is published in THE TIMES which expresses most clearly and emphatically the "do-nothing" policy of our political leaders of today. Like the Psalmist of old, millions of law-abiding Americans are crying out "How long shall the wicked triumph?" and are looking everywhere for relief.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 14 (AP). -- Leon Trotsky, the exiled Communist leader, has received permission to spend three months in Czechoslovakia for his health and will leave here within two weeks.

MONTREAL, March 15. -- Three goals with only forty-eight seconds to play gave Montreal a surprising 4-to-3 victory over the New York Rangers tonight and assured the Maroons of a place in the Stanley Cup play-offs.

Negotiations have been opened for the sale of the Whitestone rail spur by the Long Island Railroad, which abandoned it a month ago, to a private company or individual, Robert N. King, counsel for the United Transit Committee of College Point, Malba, Whitestone and Beechhurst, Inc., told the Board of Estimate yesterday at its weekly meeting in committee of the whole.

HAVANA, March 15. -- Eleven striking cigarette workers were arrested this morning, charged with attempting to set fire to the Aguilitas Cigarette Factory several days ago. The arrests were made at the headquarters of the cigar makers' union, where the police also seized rifles, incendiary material and a quantity of handbills warning the public against the purchase of cigarettes manufactured by the Aguilitas factory.

The following is the stenographic report of the testimony of James A. Higgins, Commissioner of Accounts, before the Hofstadter legislative committee yesterday afternoon: By Mr. Seabury: Q. -- Commissioner, for the record, you hold what office under the government of the city of New York? A. -- The office of Commissioner of Accounts.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 15. -- The Yale freshman relay team, tonight annexed the national junior A.A.U. 400-yard relay title in Carnegie pool in one of three championships, swimming the distance in 3 minutes 46 seconds to defeat a Yale varsity four and the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A.

Most markets came to a virtual halt yesterday. This would ordinarily mean nothing, but it has a possible negative significance under existing circumstances. Probably Wall Street's general opinion, after reading Sunday morning's news, was that the Kreuger suicide would reawaken the financial terrors of last Autumn.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 5 totaled 559,439 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 23,941 cars more than in the preceding week, when loadings were reduced by observance of Washington's Birthday, but 163,776 cars fewer than in the corresponding week in 1931 and 314,277 cars fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

Frank Roseribloom, employed by his father-in-law. George Gillman, as cashier for the clothing firm of Gillman Brothers, 84-90 Fifth Avenue, reported to the police yesterday that he had been "taken for a ride" and thrown out of an automobile in Newtown, Queens, after having been robbed of $24,565.

BOSTON, March 15. -- Headed by Mayor James M. Curley of Boston and James Roosevelt, the Governor's son, a slate of twelve Democratic delegates-at-large pledged to Franklin D. Roosevelt was put in the field today in opposition to the slate pledged to Alfred E. Smith in the April 26 primary.

FARGO, N.D., March 15. -- Slowly accumulating returns in today's Presidential primary showed Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt of New York running ahead of Governor William H. Murray of Oklahoma in their race for the Democratic preference vote.

MILWAUKEE. March 15. -- (AP) -- Daniel W. Hoan. Socialist Mayor, and other incumbents of principal offices in the municipal government appeared virtually assured of renomination on the basis of partial returns from the primary election today.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 15. -- The result of the economic depression, coupled with a desire on the part of the residents to reduce to a minimum all municipal expenditures, resulted here today in some startling upsets in the Nassau County village elections.

HANOVER, N.H., March 15. -- The Dartmouth College Athletic Council today awarded eleven letters for basketball, twelve for swimming and four for boxing. Class numerals were also awarded to the members of the freshman swimming team.

BERLIN, March 15. -- The Boerse was more buoyant today, with an upward movement in prices, and the gains generally were well maintained at the close. Reichsbank shares especially were firm. Svenska at the opening recovered three-eights from yesterday's slump, then sagged, but still closed 23 per cent above yesterday's quotation.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 15. -- Seventeen members of the Yale hockey squad, including Manager H.T. Jones Jr., today were awarded major letters by the Yale Athletic Association board of control.

Jean Borotra of France and Berkeley Bell of New York, winner and runner-up, respectively, in the national indoor tennis championship last year will meet again this afternoon at 3:30 in the quarter-finals of the current title tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Rallying strongly in the last three minutes of play, the Samuel J. Tilden High School basketball team came from behind and defeated the Thomas Jefferson High five, 24 to 22, in the third and final game of a play-off series for the Brooklyn division P.S. A.L. crown yesterday.

Passing of the peak of the quarter's tax demands brought easy conditions to the market for Stock Exchange call loans which were again done at 2 1/4, and Federal funds loaned at 1/2 @ 3/4. However, the board rate continued at 2 1/2. Time money was marked up 1/4 in the offering figure to 3 1/2, and some trades were arranged there.
Production of crude oil in the United States averaged 2,145,600 barrels dally in the week ended on March 12, compared with 2,140,850 barrels a day in the week before, an increase of 4,750 barrels.

Gold to the amount of 512,500,500 was taken out of earmark here by the Bank of France yesterday and shipped to Paris, bringing the total of the transfers of earmarked metal since Jan. 15 to approximately $170,000,000.

In 1930 Dr. LANDSTEINER of the Rockefeller Institute won the Nobel Prize for a discovery which robbed blood transfusion of its uncertainties and made it possible to trace affinities in men and animals. Blood is now classified into four major types. Transfusion can be successful only if the blood of the donor matches that of the recipient.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 15. -- The Bulgarian Government at a late hour tonight had not paid the $320,000 due today as interest on pre-war and post-war State debts.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP). -- Turning to agriculture's problems, President Hoover called in a group of House farm leaders and Secretary Hyde for a conference in the White House proper tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Evidence of the benefit banks have received from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was shown in a telegram made public at the White House today from L.O. Broussard, chairman of the board of the Bank of Abbeyville and Trust Company, at Abbeyville, La.

Trading on the Stock Exchange impressed Wall Street yesterday as being both dull and colorless. The turnover approximated 1,500,000 shares, compared with 2,000,000 shares on the day before. Selling of Krauger Toll was less active than on Monday, and the issue, after fluctuating in a somewhat narrower range, closed unchanged on the day.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 15. -- Yale's basketball and boxing teams today elected leaders for next season Robert D. O'Connell of Cortland, N.Y., centre on the Eli quintet, was named basketball captain. Nicholas Del Genio of Brooklyn was selected to lead the Blue boxers.
CLINTON, Iowa, March 15 (AP). -- An effective police dragnet today blocked escape of four masked bandits with $100,000 they had taken from the City National Bank here.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- President Hoover was assured today by Representative Snell, Republican leader in the House, that the tax bill, including a 2.25 per cent manufacturers' sales levy, would be passed by the House before the end of next week.

BOSTON, March 15. -- Charles L. Edgar, president of the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of this city, informed stockholders at the annual meeting today that it had been decided to issue stock next Summer. He said the company had notes for $70,000,000 coming due next Fall and Winter.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 15. -- At a conference here today of more than 500 dairymen from New York State, Vermont and Pennsylvania, it was decided to consider the whole milk problem thoroughly before forming a new State body. After long discussion it was agreed that such an organization might divide rather than unite the various units involved.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reading the editorials and opinions on the Democratic possibilities, which at this time show Alfred Smith and Governor Roosevelt as the leading candidates, I find that there are a few American newspapers which believe that Smith, by announcing his willingness to run for President, has thrown a monkeywrench into the Democratic machine and that party harmony will be broken.
GENEVA, March 15. -- The Secretariat of the League of Nations published today the Chinese note accepting the Assembly's resolution of March 11.

MIAMI, March 15. -- An upset was provided in the South Miami Beach Purse, feature at Tropical Park today. when Coady, owned and trained by W.C. Weant and next to the outsider in a field of six, won by a head in a rousing finish.

TOKYO, March 15 (AP). -- On the basis of news from Manchuria, Japanese officials predicted today that Soviet Russia soon would recognize officially the new Manchurian State headed by Henry Pu Yi, former boy emperor of China.

James A. Higgins, Commissioner of accounts, testified yesterday before the Hofstadter committee that nearly four years ago to the day, at the conclusion of an exhaustive investigation into the activities of William J. Flynn, then as now Commissioner of Public Works of the Bronx, he urged Borough President Henry Bruckner to demand Flynn's resignation.

LOS ANGELES, March 15. -- Staging a four-run rally in the last half of the ninth inning of the seventh game of the current exhibition series, the Giants defeated the Cubs, 8 to 7, today and took the lead in the series, four games to three.

Eugene Berman is probably a new name to most of us in this country. He is a young Russian artist, born in 1899, who has settled in Paris and whose work is beginning to be talked about. As it happens, his work is being exhibited at the moment in two New York galleries -- a one-man show at the Julien Levy and some drawings in a group show of young Europeans at the John Becker.

CLEVELAND, March 15 (AP). -- Business conditions are better in March than they were in December, January or February, says Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company and nationally known economist.

Mayor Walker appointed and swore into office yesterday four new Justices of the Muncipal Court and a new city Magistrate. Of the Municipal Court Justices, three will serve in Queens and one in Richmond. The new Magistrate will sit in Queens.

Mrs. Henry Rowland Vermilye of Englewood, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Emily de Forest Whitman, to Edward Easton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Easton of Albany, N.Y. Miss Whitman is a great-granddaughter of the late John Taylor Johnston, one of the founders and first president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the late Mrs. Johnston, and also of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. de Forest.

Dr. J.G. William Greeff, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Adam Eberle as medical superintendent of Kings County Hospital to succeed the late Dr. Clamor H. Magna Jr., who committed suicide at Portsmouth, N.H., on last Jan. 27.

LONDON, March 15. -- This certainly is the year of the big games -- the world Olympiad at Los Angeles; the Jewish Olympiad at Tel-Aviv, Palestine; the Bolshevik "Anti-Olympics" in Moscow and the Irish Olympics or Tailteann games in Dublin.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- By casting 227 noes to 187 ayes Monday on the motion to bring up for consideration the Beck-Linthicum resolution, the Seventy-second House declared itself dry. It dashed any hopes the wets may have had for Congressional action this year, since both branches of the national legislature must vote favorably on a question of resubmission.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Legislation to exclude all Soviet products from the United States will be urged by a large group of members of Congress and representatives of industrial and patriotic organizations, it was announced today, following a statement by Secretary Mills that under the present law the Treasury cannot place a general embargo on imports from Russia.

Although prices declined slightly early yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, the market developed resistance around 7 cents for the July delivery and a closing recovery left the list 1 to 5 points higher than on Monday.

Despite the economic stress of the past year the assets of the New York Life Insurance Company increased in 1931 by more than $101,000,000 to a total of $1,890,144,880, and its total income rose $21,944,989, according to the annual report of Thomas B. Buckner, president, to the policyholders of the company.

CHICAGO, March 15. -- Despite small receipts of hogs today and expectations of limited arrivals tomorrow, prices today were 5 to 25 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, light weights showing the most decline. A large carryover from yesterday was a factor in reducing quotations, especially as the shipping demand was abnormally small.

FORT WORTH, Texas, March 15 (AP). -- William R. Edrington, financial backer of Earl Carroll, New York theatrical producer, filed a voluntary petition in bankruptcy in District Court today. His petition shows the bulk of the liabilities are notes which he endorsed for the Earl Carroll Realty Corporation.

Edna Ferber, novelist, and Daniel Frohman were speakers at the graduation exercises of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts which were held yesterday afternoon at the Lyceum Theatre. Forty-one students, among them Miss Helen Bryan of Howison, Va., a granddaughter of the late William Jennings Bryan, received diplomas.

MEXICO CITY, March 15 (Science Service). -- The grandeur and extent of a Mexican Indian city of pre-Conquest days is being revealed by Mexican archaeologists who are unearthing the city of Calixtiahuaca which is translated as "Prairieville." This city, which spread over mountain slopes and valleys, had an area of sixteen square miles, according to latest estimates of the excavators.
PARIS, March 15. -- The entry of fresh fruits from America, recently forbidden by a governmental degree, was authorized today by an order of the Ministry of Agriculture.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 15. -- Mrs. O.S. Hill of Kansas City won the medal in the qualifying round of the annual women's invitation golf tournament at the Augusta Country Club today.

Having completed its twenty-fifth season last Fall, the Handicap Class of yachts on Long Island Sound celebrated last night with a quarter-century dinner and meeting at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.
DETROIT, March 15 (AP). -- The opening squad of booster teams from Detroit failed tonight to land a place among the leaders in the five-man division of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

Four major municipal bond issues totaling $16,740,000 were awarded yesterday to New York banking groups and one of $15,000,000 of an offered amount of $35,000,000 State of Louisiana went to New Orleans bankers. The New York bankers reported at the close of business that advance orders had been received for more than half of the bonds.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 15. -- The estate of Frank W. Savin, New York broker, which was reputed to be many millions, was valued at $1,346,228 in an accounting filed here today by the executors.

WEIMAR, Germany, March 15 (AP). -- Adolf Hitler, Fascist rival of President von Hindenburg for leadership of Germany, appeared as a witness today at an official hearing involving his citizenship and said that he tools the inquiry as a personal insult.

Gerhart Hauptmann, German author, who has been here in connection with the 100th anniversary of the death of Goethe, will sail on the North German Lloyd liner Europa tonight, accompanied by Mrs. Hauptmann and his son, Benvenuto. Others to sail will be Ernest Torrence, motion-picture actor, with Mrs. Torrence; Sir James Dunn, London banker, and Padriac Colum, Irish author, accompanied by Mrs. Colum.

ST. PETERSBURG. Fla., March 15. -- Connie Mack is the dean of the baseball managers. Herb Pennock is the dean of the active ball players. He admits the soft impeachment. Sitting on the porch of the Yankee clubhouse at Huggins Field today, the veteran left-hander recalled his start in the big league just twenty years ago and some of the happenings since that time.

Despite the decline of 497,389 shares in the short interest on the New York Stock Exchange in February, the percentage of "in-and-out" short trading -- or short selling in which the stock is repurchased on the same day that it is sold -- continued to increase last month, according to the Exchange's monthly bulletin, issued yesterday.

The volume of bankers' acceptances declined $41,674,522 to $919,391,880 in February, the smallest amount outstanding since Sept. 30, 1927, and $600,465,604 under the total at the end of February, 1931, according to the American Acceptance Council. The decrease followed moderate reductions in each of the three preceding months.

LONDON, March 15. -- The British branch of the World League Against Alcoholism, the organization that W.E. (Pussyfoot) Johnson founded in 1920, has failed and is amalgamating with the British Temperance Association, says The Daily Express.

CINCINNATI, March 15. -- Lincoln Donaldson, 48, who succeeded his father, the late William Mills Donaldson, as chairman of the board of directors of the Donaldson Lithographing Company, one of the largest concerns of its kind in America, shot himself through the heart at his home, Fort Thomas, Ky., early today.

Some old theatregoers have been writing letters to The London Times about London theatre audiences of fifty years ago. There, as here, audiences were more sentimentally virtuous than their more composed and cynical, better trained or more affected successors.

ALBANY, March 15. -- The bill introduced by Senator Hofstadter of New York and carrying an appropriation of $250,000 for the committee of which he is chairman, now investigating the New York City Government, became law today with the signature of Governor Roosevelt.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 15. -- A combination of great tee shots and irons and an excellent short game placed two New Yorkers -- Tommy Goodwin of Monroe and John B. Ryerson of Cooperstown -- at the head of the qualifying list in the Florida Winter amateur championship today.

Governor Roosevelt will open officially New York City's block community drive for the unemployed this afternoon with a telephone broadcast from Albany to a rally of several hundred block chairmen and workers in the Times Square Studio of the National Broadcasting Company.

GENEVA, March 15. -- The political commission of the disarmament conference, after listening to a long speech by Marjan Szumlakowski, Polish delegate, appointed a committee of twenty-one members today to examine the Polish proposals for moral disarmament.

Sweeping changes were announced yesterday in the official staff of the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, the securities-distributing company controlled by Transamerica Corporation. They include the withdrawal from the organization of nine former officers.

Renewed weakness in sugar, May contract selling down to a new low at 0.75, featured the business in commodity markets yesterday. There was a moderate rally from the lows at the close and sugar prices finished 1 to 2 points higher over Monday. Irregularly lower prices were found in the grains, coffee, silk, rubber and some of the metals, while hides and cocoa turned higher. Other articles were steady.

CHICAGO, March 15. -- Less pessimism than yesterday was shown today in the wheat pit on the Board of Trade. A revival of export demand, with sales estimated at as high as 2,000,000 bushels in all positions, much of which was domestic hard Winter wheat, combined with strength in Liverpool, changed sentiment.

ATLANTA, March 15. -- With the largest vote ever polled in a municipal contest here, Atlanta in a recall election today voted 17,178 to 11,743 to keep in office Mayor James L. Key, who declared the prohibition law a failure, permitted Sunday charity movies, refused to pay a bonus to low bidders on city construction work and approved salary reductions to balance the city budget.

The Theatre Guild and the Shuberts are now making arrangements whereby out-of-town subscription groups of both producing organizations will be combined. Conferences between representatives of the two theatrical firms have been in progress for several months, it was disclosed last night by Warren P. Munsell, business manager of the guild, but the plan as yet has not been officially approved.

The attempt of the defense in the perjury trial of former General Sessions Judge Francis X. Mancuso to attack the State's case, by showing that his alleged perjured testimony in the 1929 City Trust Company inquiry was unsworn, failed yesterday. Louis Granat, the shorthand reporter who took Mr. Mancuso's testimony in 1929, was called as a State witness and declared that Mr. Mancuso had taken the usual oath before testifying.

The combined adherents of pacifism, socialism, communism and atheism "represent less than 1 per cent of the American people" and should not be tolerated, Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the National Civic Federation's executive council, asserted yesterday at a luncheon conference of the League for National Unity, an auxiliary of the federation, at the Lawyers Club.
