Five drivers for New Jersey Bus Lines, Inc., Hackensack-New York interstate passenger line across the George Washington Bridge, will appear in police court at Fort Lee Thursday night on charges of picking up passengers in Fort Lee. An infraction of a borough ordinance is charged because the company has not received permission from the Council to take on Fort Lee passengers.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Frank G. Raichle of Buffalo, law partner of Colonel William J. Donovan, former Assistant Attorney General in the Coolidge Administration, was indicted today by the grand jury of the District of Columbia on four counts of subornation of perjury and obstruction of justice in connection with the defense of G. Bryan Pitts, former head of the F.H. Smth Company.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 15. -- Efforts of Democrats to displace the historic hold of the Republicans on the village governments of Bronxville and Felham Manor were unavailing tonight as the Democratic candidates in both villages were snowed under In elections of record proportions.

The coldest morning of the season apparently cast no chill on the enthusiasm of visitors to the Flower Show yesterday. The brilliant coloring of rhododendrons and azaleas, rainbow-varied tulips and roses, leaped to the eye and warmed the heart.

With a total of almost 900 competitors entered in the various events, Madison Square Garden is to be the scene tonight of an unusual sports carnival in which the leading amateur wrestlers, gymnasts and weight lifters of the district will compete for the metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union championships.
MOSCOW, March 15. -- Let any one who says that revolution has not brought new freedom to the women of Russia consider this story of a wife who sold her husband, and cheap too, for just 100 rubles.

The morale of the woman who cannot have a "permanent" or have her cosmetic needs attended to became a question of first importance yesterday at the opening of the International Beauty Shop Owners convention and exhibition at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Addressing a meeting celebrating the first centenary of the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind in the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, last evening, George W. Wickersham praised the work of the school and its founder.

FREEHOLD, N.J., March 15 (AP). -- More than $2,000,000 in bequests and contributions intended for a State university have been lost to New Jersey, Albert J. Dear Jr., president of the league for a free state university, told the Rotary Club today.

NATCHEZ, Miss., March 15 (AP). -- L. Russell Ellzey, superintendent of Copiah Lincoln Junior College at Wesson, Miss., has won the seat in the House of Representatives made vacant by the death of Representative Percy E. Quinn.

PARIS, March 15. -- The Bourse rallied today from the slump caused by the death of Ivar Kreuger. Financial circles, considering that a relatively small part of the market was directly related to the Kreuger interests and the comparative calm with which the news of Mr. Kreuger's death was received in London and New York, apparently agreed that yesterday's drop of over 10 per cent was excessive and today the trend was steadily upward.

The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company won a verdict yesterday by direction of Justice Genung to a jury in Municipal Court in a suit brought by Mrs. John Rose of 54 Broadwalk, Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn, to collect double indemnity in the death of her son by drowning after his alleged participation in a murder on Sept. 24, 1930.

NEW ORLEANS, March 15 (AP). -- Prince Hotspur, winner of only two races in eighteen starts, came through with a surprise victory in the feature Post Parade Purse over one mile at the Fair Grounds today.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Diligently working behind closed doors for more than three hours, a Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee tonight reached almost complete agreement on the Glass banking reform bill.

LONDON, March 15. -- The stock markets were more confident today. Although business was quiet prices were better in all sections. Swedish Match and Kreuger Toll shares recovered further. Eastman Kodak was marked down sharply on George Eastman's death, but there was practically no selling.

Nearly a fortnight ago, it is now made public, the Nanking Government decided upon immediate measures to restore the political and territorial integrity of China by "concrete force." The phrase may mean force of arms, and official Japanese statements at Shanghai continue to assert that the Nanking Government is preparing to resume hostilities.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Repeal of the consolidation provisions of the transportation act of 1920 was urged today by Mark W. Potter, New York lawyer and former Interstate Commerce Commissioner, before the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 15. -- Tony Cuccinello, slated to be the Robins' regular second baseman, signed his contract in President Frank York's office today and will report to Manager Max Carey here Thursday, the Brooklyn pilot announced just after the start of today's game with the Phillies.
ALBANY, March 15 (AP). -- The Tax Department estimated unofficially today that the State would receive about $2,600,000 as an estate tax on the property of George Eastman.

BERLIN, March 15. -- The appointment of an all-Lithuanian directorate in Memel is resented here as another gross violation of law and international treaty, even more flagrant in view of the contrary assurances recently given by Foreign Minister Zaunius of Lithuania.

Five men who are said to have obtained $750,000 during 1930 and 1931 in what George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, described as the largest bankruptcy racked uncovered here in years, and two merchants who allegedly accepted their services as experts in defrauding creditors, were indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 15. -- For the first time since its organization, members of the Palm Beach Playhouse appeared tonight in Shakespearean drama, giving their first performance of "As You Like It" at the Little Theatre. A capacity audience attended.

Lessons Across Frontiers. It was to be expected that among Germany's neighbors the outcome of Sunday's election should be variously appraised. In France and in Poland the Nationalist elements find the chief significance in HITLER'S large vote.

Stocks moved narrowly on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday and closed with many leading issues unchanged and others with fractional gains. The trading volume was somewhat lower than on Monday. Domestic bonds generally receded, while the more active issues in the foreign bond group were mixed.
LONDON, March 15. -- Henry Ford has decided on Important changes in his "baby car" for the British market, which he exhibited for the first time only three weeks ago.

Mr. and Mrs. Hernand Behn of 903 Park Avenue hava announced the engagement of their younger daughter. Miss Louise Behn, to Irwin A. Powell, son of Mrs. Kimball G. Colby of this city and Southampton, L.I. Miss Behn attended the Sacred Heart Convent in Noroton, Conn., and later studied for a year at the school of Mlle. de Boissier in Paris.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The House wet bloc, stimulated by its gains in strength, is planning to force before the House the Hull-O'Connor bill amending the Volstead act to permit the manufacture and sale of 2.75 per cent beer.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday .3 1/4 to 4 per cent for the best names Monday . . .3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

LIMA, Peru, March 15. -- Jose Arnaldo Melgar Marquez and an alleged accomplice, Juan G. Seoane Corrales, were sentenced by a courtmartial today to die for an attempt to assassinate President Luis M. Sanchez Cerro in a suburban church on Sunday, March 6.

Definite steps now under way, such as the National Credit Corporation and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, would contribute definitely within a short while toward national business recovery, Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, declared last night at a dinner given in his honor by a group of business men at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.

About 500,000 of the 700,000 Federal income taxpayers in New York who were required to make returns this year waited until the last moment yesterday to file them in person or to put them in the mail, according to the estimates of the tax collectors in the four revenue offices covering the city.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14. -- Scoring all their runs in the second inning, the Yankees made it two straight from the Boston Braves by winning the second game of the Sunshine City championship series today. The count was 3 to 2.

SHANGHAI, (Wednesday) March 16 (AP). -- Chinese dispatches from Peiping today said that Chinese volunteers had occupied the town of Lienshan, thirty miles southwest of Chinchow in Manchuria. The dispatches said the occupation was preceded by a military engagement in which 150 Japanese soldiers were killed.

Customs officials announced yesterday that fifteen Customs guards had been summarily dropped from the rolls for incorrect statements on their application blanks when they were admitted to the service.

SHANGHAI, March 15. -- As a direct outgrowth of new and largescale cooperation between the United States and Great Britain in the Far East, China and Japan are ready to enter into negotiations within the next two or three days for the withdrawal of the Japanese troops in the Shanghai area.

James A. Farley, Democratic State chairman and field general of the Roosevelt forces, left last night for Detroit to confer there today with Michigan party leaders about the possibility of getting a delegation from that State instructed to vote for Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for the nomination for President.

PARIS, March 15. -- Music circles here are thoroughly alarmed by the threatened closing of the Paris National Opera on March 31, when the resignation of its director, Jacque Rouche, announced today, becomes effective. The monthly deficit is reported to be more than $80,000, despite the government subsidies.

The continued popular response to opera broadcasting at the Metropolitan Opera House, undertaken first on Christmas afternoon, has led Owen D. Young, on behalf of the radio interests, together with representatives of the opera house owners and operators, to reopen with John D. Rockefeller Jr. the suspended project of an opera house in connection with Radio City at Rockefeller Centre, and consideration of the project is being rapidly advanced.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the political clamor within New York State for reductions in electric rates, reference is made to the following quotation from a recently published edition of "Economics of Public Utilities," by L.R. Nash, printed by the Mc-Graw-Hill Book Company:

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 15. -- The majority of the tickets in Suffolk were uncontested, and the elections held in the villages throughout the county today were for the most part colorless, with the exception of the elections at Southampton, where the three propositions to annex Watermill were overwhelmingly defeated.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15. -- The signing of Babe Ruth, an event of the first magnitude in the realm of professional baseball, is scheduled for tomorrow morning and in the afternoon the Bambino himself very likely will take his place in right field for the Yankees in the third game of their annual exhibition series with the Boston Braves.

LINCOLN, England. March 15. -- The English turfgoer, deprived of his favorite flat racing for four months, is flocking to Lincoln in large numbers for the first big race of the new season, the Lincolnshire Handicap, which will be run over the mile course at Lincoln tomorrow.

The New York Americans staged a rally after trailing by one goal to defeat the world's champion Canadiens of Montreal, 5 to 2, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night before a crowd of 6,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 15. -- Thirty-four athletic insignia were awarded to the members of the varsity and freshman hockey teams of Princeton University, according to the announcement made today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

CHICAGO, March 15. -- The projected world-wide scientific survey to obtain more complete knowledge of the nature and origin of cosmic rays, which long have puzzled physicists, will get under way within the next few weeks under the direction of Dr. Arthur H. Compton, Professor of Physics of the University of Chicago and Nobel Prize winner in 1927.

Repercussions of the recent resignation of Charles S. Hand, Commissioner of the Department of Sanitation, were felt yesterday in the Board of Aldermen, where Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d, the sole Republican member, voiced a futile protest against granting permission for the purchase of $100,000 worth of automotive equipment for the department's use without public bidding.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES printed the report of A.C. Welsh, traffic manager of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, to Linford S. Stiles, engineer of a joint committee of the Port of New York Authority, Pennsylvania Railroad and the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, which is cited as an example of movement of freight by water to Brooklyn.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 15 (AP). -- An attempted criminal attack recently on Miss Barbara Burns, 16, daughter of Bishop Charles Wesley Burns of the Methodist Episcopal Church, today brought a one to fourteen year prison sentence for Victor Perez, 19, a part Hawaiian.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 15. -- Pat Orr Johnson, '34, of Tulsa, Okla., and John Gregory Cornish, '33, of Brookline, Mass., were tonight elected captains of the Harvard varsity Wrestling and squash racquets teams, respectively, for next season.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Members of the House representing more than half the population of the country yesterday voted to give the people a right to express themselves on the question of national prohibition. Many dry members voted to discharge the Judiciary Committee from further consideration of the Beck-Linthicum resolution designed to return control of liquor to the various States.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa arrived yesterday with 770 passengers, a day late due to a delay in leaving Cherbourg and further delay on the Atlantic, where high winds and rough seas held the liner back. The ship docked at her Fifty-eighth Street pier in Brooklyn after considerable difficulty because of the high wind in the harbor.

One of the most constructive pieces of legislation to come out of Albany this year was the Hewitt reclassification bill. Although sharply debated in the closing days of the session, It was the subject of little public comment. Reclassification makes tedious reading for most people, but it is a lively issue for some 35,000 State employes.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. AUGUSTA, via San Francisco, March 15. -- The members of the navy's annual "war," which have been smoldering for the past week while the defending Black Force has been combing the Pacific for the attacking Blue Fleet, flared into fierce flame today when several Black vessels made contact with the "enemy" at Point Moren, 1,000 miles southwest of San Francisco.

The sons of Erin will march up Fifth Avenue tomorrow afternoon in the annual St. Patrick's Day parade, led by Mayor James J. Walker, the grand marshal, mounted not on a prancing white charger but seated comfortably in an automobile. The marchers will assemble at Forty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Arguments on the right of the New York Legislature to reapportion the State without approval of Governor Roosevelt will be heard by the Supreme Court March 24, the court announced this afternoon.

GOSHEN. N.Y., March 15. -- For the first time in over fifty years, control of the Village Board here passed from the Citizens' party to the People's party in the election, today that was one of the most heated this village has ever had and the most bitterly fought of the twelve held throughout Orange County, according to the complete tabulations of returns tonight.
LONDON, March 15. -- Hope was revived today that Colonel P.H. Fawcett, who was lost in the Brazilian jungles with two companions seven years ago, may still be alive.

Elections were held yesterday in 116 villages in the metropolitan area, including fifty in Nassau County, twenty-one in Westchester, seventeen in Suffolk, eleven in Rockland, three in Putnam and fourteen in Orange.

Declaring that work on the $32,000,000 Triborough, Bridge would have to be suspended in three months unless further contracts were let, Edward A. Byrne, chief engineer of the Department of Plant and Structures, urged the Board of Estimate yesterday to modify its economy program in respect to this self-supporting project.

MOSCOW, March 15. -- (AP) -- Examples of flagrant mismanagement and bureaucracy meet with relentless exposure in the Russian press in furtherance of the government's campaign to eliminate those twin obstacles to the Five-Year-Plan.

BERLIN, March 15. -- The German export surplus for February amounted to $20,000,000, not including reparations in kind, thus dropping about $4,000,000, as against the January surplus, which had already led to a widespread conviction that Germany would have serious difficulties in meeting her service charges on foreign debts.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The plans of Postmaster General Brown, for wiping out the annual postal deficit progressed a step today when the Interstate Commerce Commission approved his application for a revision of parcel post rates.

ALBANY, March 15. -- February showed the smallest number of industrial fatalities of any month since July, 1926. Miss Frances Perkins, Industrial Commissioner, revealed today. The total was 108, of which 56 were in the New York district, 17 in the Buffalo district, 12 in Syracuse and 9 in the Rochester district.

NYACK, N.Y., March 15. -- Elections were held in eleven villages of Rockland County today. In Haverstraw, an unusual vote for an off year was polled, returns tonight showed, and Republican gains in that Democratic village were lost, the Democratic candidates defeating their Republican opponents by more than two to one.

The total of new life insurance production in February was 8.6 per cent below that of February, 1931, and the total for the first two months of this year was 1.2 per cent below the same period of last year, according to the monthly report forwarded by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce.

Kites tugged viciously at the ends of long leaders, windows rattled in their sashes and the inhabitants of New York leaned stoutly against the might of a northwest wind yesterday as the proverbial Ides of March passed through with a seasonal gale, while the thermometer registered the coldest March 15 on record at the local Weather Bureau.

HAVANA, March 15. -- Riots broke out late this afternoon at the offices of the newspapers El Pais and Informacion when hundreds of newsboys awaiting the afternoon editicis were informed that the price had been increased a half cent. The police reserves had to be called to restore order.

In the hurly-burly of the debate on the new tax bill now before the House of Representatives there seemed to be for a few days danger that the great purpose of the measure might be forgotten. This is to raise enough added revenue to wipe out the huge Government deficit.

Detectives sought yesterday to find some link between a prisoner's story of a jail-born plot to kidnap the infant son of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh and the actual abduction of the child from their country home near Hopewell, N.J., just two weeks ago last night.

The State of Louisiana failed to receive a bid yesterday for its entire issue of $35,000,000 of 5 per cent highway bonds, due from 1936 to 1957, but did receive a bid for $15,000,000 of the bonds from the Pyramid Securities Company, associate of the Union Indemnity Company of New Orleans.

The cut roses of both private and commercial growers were featured yesterday in the awards at the nineteenth annual flower show, conducted by the Horticultural Society of New York and the New York Florists' Club, which is being held all week at the Grand Central Palace.

Primary control of rates on waterborne commerce, which was definitely placed with the United States Shipping Board as far as transatlantic trade was concerned by a decision of the Supreme Court of the United States, rendered Feb. 15, also has been extended to the Gulf trade.

The philanthropic record of the Bowery Y.M.C.A. was recounted last night by speakers at a dinner celebrating the sixtieth anniversary of the Bowery branch in its historic five-story shelter at 8 East Third Street.

BALTIMORE, March 15. -- The Liberian Government's alleged action in burning the villages of natives who testified that slavery existed in the republic has caused the State Department to send another vigorously worded note to that country, according to a Washington dispatch to The Baltimore Sun.

Emil Jannings is the leading figure in a grim German-language pictorial drama known as "Stuerme der Liedenschaft," which is released in this country as "Tempest." It is a Ufa production with a few subtitles in English for the guidance of those unfamiliar with German.

A witness in a separation action in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday appeared in court with two front teeth missing, bruises on his face and blood spattered over his clothes. He said he was beaten by two men while he was on his way to court.

It has teen said by a distinguished teacher of the sightless that "a "blind man can do everything that "a seeing man can except see." A hundred years ago this would have seemed wildly extravagant. But the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind, founded just a century ago, has done much to bring this miracle to pass.

The Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate approved yesterday, in executive session, the report submitted last week by Charles F. Kerrigan, assistant to Mayor Walker, recommending the revocation of outstanding authorizations involving the expenditure of about $196,000,000.

CHICAGO, March 15. -- One of the greatest programs for combating truck competition in the history of American railways became effective on Western roads today, with slashed rates on mixed freight in carloads taking effect in an area bounded roughly by Chicago, Milwaukee, Green Bay, Lake Superior, Duluth, St. Paul, Minneapolis, Sioux Falls, Sioux City, Omaha, Kansas City and Sock Island.

A record-breaking feat by Miss Eleanor Holm of the Women's Swimming Association and victories in the men's and women's metropolitan A. A.U. junior fancy diving championships from a four-foot springboard by Edward Uniss and Miss Madeline Karson, Dragon Club, marked a water carnival in the 40-yard pool of the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, last night.

ROCHESTER, March 15. -- Tributes to George Eastman flowed into Rochester today from all over the world as the city prepared to pay last honors to its great citizen at the time of his funeral Thursday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Conrad Nagel, motion-picture actor, tonight denied the popular conception of fabulous salaries paid movie actors.

ORANGE, N.J., March 15. -- A convention of about 600 clerical and lay representatives of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Newark assembled here today to elect a Bishop Coadjutor to the Right Rev. Wilson R. Stearly adjourned tonight after ten ballots had failed to give any candidate the two-thirds majority necessary for election.

Simeon J. Beckerman and Dr. Bernard Lazarus, insurgent candidates for delegates to the Republican National Convention from the Twentieth Congressional District, drew first place on the ballot for the primary election on April 5, with Secretary of the Treasury Ogden L. Mills and Herbert N. Straus, organization candidates, getting second place.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- A new shipping conference, to be known as the Brazil-United States Freight Conference, was announced today by the Shipping Board. The lines forming the conference are the Lamport Holt, Munson Steamship Company, Lloyd Brasileiro, International Freighting Corporation, Moore McCormack Company, Prince Line, Ltd., American Republics Line and the Wilhelmsen Line.

WASHINGTON, March. 15. -- The State Department said tonight there was no new or concrete agreement between Washington and London for cooperation in the Far East beyond the understanding, existing for weeks, that the two governments would consult and work together, as far as possible, for peace between China and Japan.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- American bankers who organized foreign bond issues totaling billions of dollars in the United States in the decade following the "World War were charged today by Senator Johnson of California with having betrayed the confidence of the investing public.

NEW ORLEANS, March 16 (AP) -- Lucky Dan, never better than third in five starts since Oct. 12 at Latonia, came through with a half-length victory in the one and one sixteenth mile feature at the Fair Grounds today. It was his fourth start of the Winter season.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 16 -- Mrs. Margaret Nunes, 48 years old, and her only child, a daughter, Marie, 14, were found dead today in their home at 301 New Main Street, where, according to the police, they had been strangled. Alexander Nunes, 44 years old, husband and father of the victims, a mason and builder, was arrested charged with the crime.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Mrs. William Tilton, chairman of the Women's National Committee for Education Against Alcohol, said today that the vote in the House Monday on the proposal to consider modifying the Eighteenth Amendment pressed "enforcement planks in both party platforms."
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Free flour, milled from huge stores of government wheat, soon will be in the homes of more than 150,000 needy families.

Stockholders of the American Cigar Company at their annual meeting in Jersey City on Tuesday approved the plans under which the company will lease some of its assets and sell others to the American Tobacco Company, and will retain investments, notes receivable and cash.

In the figures on population density in the New York metropolitan area, derived from the 1930 census totals by the Regional Plan Association, there is little comfort for the gloomy prophets of the Machine Age-and-Robot school. It is not true that the city of the future is to consist of a few masters practicing unbridled luxury in sky-piercing penthouses and millions of slaves toiling in subterranean dark.

BERLIN, March 16 (AP) -- Silas Strawn of Chicago, president of the International Chamber of Commerce, spent an hour today with Chancellor Heinrich Bruening. He expressed himself as greatly impressed by the Chancellor's personality and grasp of affairs.

LOS ANGELES, March 16 -- By way of establishing a superiority complex over the Cubs, which John. McGraw sincerely hopes will endure for the balance of the year, the Giants wound up their eight-game exhibition series with the Chicagoans today by winning the final engagement, 5 to 4.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 16 (AP) -- Constance Morrow, sister of Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, was announced today as second in the scholastic standing of the freshman class of Smith College. She was a tenth of a point behind Helen P. Boyer of Toledo, Ohio, to whom was awarded the Arthur JEllis Hamm scholarship.

Women are largely responsible for the great increase in divorces in this country since the World War, Dr. Frederick M. Rossiter, author of "The Torch of Life: A Key to Sex Harmony," newly published by the Aventine Corporation here, said yesterday in an interview at the St. Moritz Hotel.

Stocks were unsettled again yesterday, indicating that unpleasant developments of the recent past were still uppermost in the minds of speculators. There was no acute weakness on the Stock Exchange and business was slightly less active than on the day before.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Retention by the Federal, Government of mineral rights on public lands transferred to the States was recommended today by James R. Garfield.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Oswald Garrison Villard will give a dinner Saturday in the roof ballroom of the Pierre for their son, Henry Hilgard Villard. Other guests will come later for supper and dancing.

The twenty-first week of the Metropolitan Opera season next week will be marked by the presentation of two performances of "Parsifal" and the season's second performance of Bellini's "La Sonnanibula." The week will open with "Aida" on Monday evening with Rethberg, Claussen, Merli, Tibbett and Pinza in the cast and Serafin conducting.
The testimony of Louis U. Willard and Commissioner William J. Flynn before the Legislative Committee yesterday follows:
BERLIN, March 16 -- Dr. Hans Luther announced today at the annual meeting of stockholders that the Reichsbank would distribute a 12 per cent dividend the same as last year.

Renewal of a "war" between the millinery industry and the hairdressing business because the tight-fitting hat has been forecast for this season seemed probable yesterday at the International Beauty Shop Owners' convention and exhibition, held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

NORFOLK, Thursday, March 17 (AP) -- The Coast Guard here was notified by the cutter Pulaski of the New York division early this morning that she was off Fenwick Island Light and was proceeding to the aid of the burning ship.

The Transit Commission ordered the Interborough Rapid Transit Company yesterday to purchase additional cars and provide signal equipment, track clearance and extra power facilities to establish better regular and express service on its Queens lines to Flushing, Corona and Astoria.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee today voted to report out the Fish joint resolution to propose an international agreement renouncing the sale or export of arms, munitions or implements of war to any foreign nation.

Prices showed a slight improvement in most of yesterday's session on the Cotton Exchange, but weakness as securities influenced trading in the last hour, and the market closed 3 points lower to 1 point higher than on Tuesday.

Boys of the Malcolm Gordon School, Garrison-on-Hudson, N.Y., will present this afternoon at the Amateur Comedy Club, 150 East Thirty-sixth Street, a Washington pageant and also the one-act play "A Marriage Proposal" by Anton Tchekoff, translated into English Oy Barrett H. Clark.

The Brooklyn Edison Company appropriated $980,719 in 1931 under its employes' profit-sharing plan, compared with $833,096 the year before, $714,219 in 1929, $633,487 in 1928 and $550,864 in 1927, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Last year's mark was a record.

Stock control of the Willys-Overland Company is expected to revert to John N. Willys and asociates on July 1 as a result of voting provisions that vest priority rights in the preferred stock after the omission of four quarterly dividends.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 17 (AP) -- Rengo (Japanese) news dispatches from Changchun today reported that the new Manchurian ship of state, piloted by Henry Puyi, was already tossing in the seas of discord.

FARGO, N.D., March 16 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt has won the North Dakota Democratic Presidential preference contest in Tuesday's primary on the face of returns tabulated by The Associated Press election bureau tonight from more than half of the State's 2,235 precincts.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 16 -- Mrs. Winifred G. McCartney, widow of James J. McCartney, former battalion chief of the New York City Fire Department, was carried to saftey late last night, when a fire swept the upper floors of her home at Livingston and De Kalb Avenues, this city.

NEWARK, N.J., March 16 -- The crack Princeton University polo team defeated Westfield, 7 to 6. in the second round of the New Jersey State Class C polo tournament tonight. By virtue of its well-earned victory the collegians gained the final and will play Essex Troop Saturday night at the Roseville-Avenue Armory for the State championship. The trooners defeated Red Bank last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Glass banking reform bill, which has been revised by a Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee, will be formally introduced tomorrow and immediately afterward referred to the full committee, Senator Glass said this afternoon.

Price trend in commodities was irregular yesterday, but the net result was meaningless, since these fluctuations were small. Sugar, which had dropped to 0.75, for May, on Tuesday, was maintained above that figure, although the general market sold off 1 to 2 points. Cocoa, rubber and hides were lower, but coffee showed improvement. Other articles were steady.

New explanations for parts of more than $69,000 in bank deposits he made in 1929, when his salary as chief clerk of the City Court was $10,000, were placed on record yesterday by Harry C. Perry at the hearing to determine whether he shall be removed from office.

The "Yale, Harvard and Princeton clubs of New York were deadlocked last night after a five-hour tilt in the Princeton Club, 39 East Thirty-ninth Street, in an effort to play off what was intended to be their final match in the interclub contract bridge tournament between the local alumni of Yale, Harvard, Princeton and Columbia.

GENEVA, March 16 -- Ambassador Hugh S. Gibson, acting head of the United States delegation to the disarmament conference, moved today in a full session of the general commission that when the members of the conference return from their Easter vacation on April 11 they should get down to work.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- George S. Milnor, who is regarded as the most important factor in the wheat business in the United States, sailed from New York tonight to investigate the wheat situation abroad and study possible outlets for the domestic surplus of that grain.

MEXICO CITY, March 16 -- A possibility that Mexico will go strongly protectionist as a result of the recent modification in its monetary legislation is seen by financial and economic observers here. This modification allows the Bank of Mexico as a regulatory institution to mint more silver money to an extent which it may consider necessary to alleviate the grave situation caused by shortage of currency aggravated by private hoarding.

BERLIN, March 16 -- Trading on the Boerse was light today, but prices displayed some buoyancy despite the continued influence of Ivar Kreuger's death. The political situation is viewed rather optimistically after the strain of the weeks preceding the Presidential election.
ROME, March 16 (AP) -- An ovation greeted the presentation tonight of the play "Villa Franca," of which Premier Benito Mussolini is co-author.
ALBANY, March 16 -- The approval of thirty-three legislative bills and the veto of thirteen others were announced today by Governor Roosevelt.

WARSAW, March 16 -- Some 50 per cent of the total working population of Poland went on strike today in response to the trade unions' appeal to cease work for the day as a demonstration against the government's attempt to change the existing social insurance system.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16 -- Sharply contested matches, two of which went to five sets, marked the second round of singles in the Southern professional tennis championships on the courts of the Palm Beach Tennis Club today. Paul Heston of Washington defending titleholder, was the only contestant to win in straight sets.

Yesterday's markets were as uninforming as they had been on other recent days. The stock market in general lost ground; but the changes were mostly fractional, and in few cases did the day's decline go beyond 1 or 2 points. The movement of bond prices was more irregular; some domestic securities, especially those which were under pressure earlier in the week, recovered emphatically.

Governor Horton of Tennessee has pledged a State program of retrenchment and rearrangement of the State's system of revenues, in order to provide needed changes in the sinking fund, to New York bankers interested in aiding the State to meet an issue of $9,000,000 short-term highway notes to mature on April 29.

Prints are much in evidence just now in the galleries of New York. At the Art Centre the exhibition, of Fifty Points of the Year has still about a fortnight to run. If does not close until the end of the month. The interesting group of modern prints at Keppel'a, which has been on for some time, remains until April 1.

PARIS, March 16 -- American fruit valued at approximately $100,000 which had been piled on the docks at Havre for several days, is exempted unconditionally from the sweeping embargo established by the French Government a week ago under the terms of the special order signed by Minister of Agriculture Claude Chauveau yesterday and published in today's Journal Officiel.

Search was begun in Queens yesterday by Detectives Devery and Layden for two men who had swindled an unemployed resident of Greenpoint of his savings of $1,996, on which he depended for his subsistence, by a variation of the "rich relative's bequest" story, long familiar to the police.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Charges in Congress and before the Interstate Commerce Commission that the Pennsylvania Railroad had attempted, through stock ownership, to dictate the policies of the New York, New Haven Hartford and other New England railroads were denied today by J.J. Pelley, president of the New Haven line.

WASHINGTON, . March 16.-The right of a Legislature to reapportion Congressional districts -without the. approval of the Governor was argued today before the Supreme Court for the first time in history.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Economy and consolidation were urged as solutions of the railway problem today by Claude R. Porter, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, in a speech to railroad executives and representatnes at the annual convention of the American Railway Engineering Association.

Governor ROOSEVELT properly resents the charge, or the assumption, that ha had shirked his duty either to sign or to veto the bill granting the Hofstadter investigating committee an additional sum of $250,000. It was left on his table as one of the thirty-day bills, and already he has put his name to it.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- Babe Ruth's new contract, the seventh he has signed, as a Yankee player, at the termination of its requirements will have advanced his lifetime total of baseball salaries to close to the $800,000 mark.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., March 16 -- Six persons in one family were killed by illuminating gas early this morning in their home at Clancyville, in New Windsor, a suburb, and four in another family are recovering.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16 -- Mr. and Mrs. Adam G. Thomson entertained tonight with a small dinner at Casa Alexado, their Jungle Road home, having as guests Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Dillman, Mr. and Mrs. Christopher D. Smithers, Mr. and Mrs. George A. McKinlock, Mr. and Mrs. Horace Hutchins Work, Mr. and Mrs. Laurence C. Fuller, Mrs. Willey Lyon Kingsley and Giulio de Claas.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The world is thirsty for something humorous as day after day brings forth distressing news of all kinds, making us wonder if we are not to be classed with the unfortunate Poe depicts, "Whom unmerciful disaster followed fast and followed faster."

The special performance given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the benefit of its pension fund, last night in Carnegie Hall, was distinguished by the presence of the composer Ottorino Respighi, who came from over-seas to conduct the first performance anywhere of his "mystery", "Maria Egiziaca," a tryptich for concert performance in three episodes, the book by Claudio Guastalla.

LOS ANGELES, March 16 (AP) -- Joan Bennett, film actress, and Gene Markey, screen writer, were married in Los Angeles today, thereby creating for a city accustomed to receiving its news of film celebrities weddings from near-by Arizona or Nevada towns a chance to see a real movie marriage.

LINCOLN PARK, England, March 16 -- The Lincolnshire Handicap, first of the classics of the English flat racing season, was run today and went to Jerome Fandor, a lightly weighted outsider, at the long odds of 40 to 1.

WARREN, Ohio, March 16 (AP) -- The maximum penalty of life imprisonment was meted out today to the first of two men tried for the kidnapping just two weeks ago of James Dejute Jr., 11 years old, son of a wealthy Niles contractor.

Two servants who disappeared mysteriously from the New Jersey home of their employers on the day after Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's baby son was kidnapped were the object of a widespread police search yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Proposals which, if adopted, would delay consideration of adherence to the protocol of the World Court by the United States were made today by Senators Pittman and Lewis to the Foreign Relations Committee.

"La Sonnambula," after a sixteen-year repose unbroken even by dreams, to say nothing of sleep-walking, came back to the Metropolitan last night. The work, presented for the first time a year and a century ago in Milan, has appeared from time to time in New York since its premiere here in 1883.

Mr. JAMES L. KEY, Mayor of Atlanta, traveling in France last year and observing the gay sobriety of its inhabitants, took the liberty of saying that prohibition in the United States was a failure. The Dry Extreme Left In his city was shocked almost into spasms.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 16 -- Surrogate George A. Slater traced the "implied revocation" theory in civil law back to the time of Cicero, about 49 B.C., in a ruling today in which he held that Mrs. Mildred Vetter Mosher of Mount Vernon, widow of Frank W. Mosher, Bronx bakery proprietor, should receive one-half instead of one-third of her husband's net estate of about $100,000.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Congress should act at once to permit the importation of commodities under bond pending final disposition of differences between the government and the importer over customs duties, Secretary Mills today informed Chairmen Smoot of the Finance Committee and Crisp of the "Ways and Means Committee.

PARIS, March 16 -- Francois de Saint Phalle, the New York broker, died here today after a brief illness of pneumonia complicated by a cerebral hemorrhage. News of his unexpected death created extreme nervousness in financial circles, already aroused by the Kreuger and Eastman suicides.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The power of Congress to enact retroactive income-tax legislation has heretofore been regarded as well settled as a principle of law. Since the adoption of the Sixteenth Amendment in 1913, every income-tax act has been retroactive in that it has applied to income received or earned prior to the date of the enactment.

The tabling of an application for a jockey's license from Buddy Ensor, at present staging a come-back in Florida, and action against certain half-mile circuits, were major developments at the meeting yesterday of the stewards of the Jockey Club, which governs racing in this State.

Interest in the fate of Colonel FAWCETT, who disappeared in the Matto Grosso jungle in May, 1925, and is now reported to be alive by a jungle trapper, on the authority of British Consul General ABBOTT of Sao Paulo, is naturally acute. Colonel FAWCETT had been an explorer of merit and a brilliant soldier.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A bill seeking to repeal the drastic provisions of the so-called Jones "five and ten" law was introduced in the House today by Representative Britten of Illinois.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. AUGUSTA, in the Pacific, March 16 -- The "Battic of the Pacific" rolled slowly eastward today, with sharp intermittent fighting between the surface men of war and aircraft of the two opposing fleets in the preliminary skirmishes which started Monday, when cruisers of the Black defending fleet found the aircraft-carrier Saratoga, three battleships and lighter units attacking the Blue flect.

The International Utilities Corporation and subsidiary holding companies, including the American Equities Company and subsidiaries, report for 1931 total net income of $1,004,814, exclusive of net losses on sale of investment securities in the amount of $5,439,121, charged to reserves, and before depreciation.

PANAMA CITY, March 16 -- Poltical opinion here differs as to the effect of the withdrawal of Dr. Augusto Boyd, candidate of the National Liberal party, from the race for the Presidency and the reported switching of the support of that party to Francisco Arias Paredes, candidate of the Liberal Reform party.

MIAMI, Fla., March 16 -- J.L. Johnston's 4-year-old chestnut filly, Lady Legs, by Upset-Lady McGee, was piloted to victory by Buddy Ensor in the Biltmore Purse at Tropical Park today. It was the second start of the year for Lady Legs and also her second triumph.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The choice indicated, on the basis of returns to date, by Dakota Democrats of Governor Roosevelt of New York over Governor Murray of Oklahoma, for the Presidential nomination produced today increasing confidence among the New Yorker's supporters here that he would carrry the convention.

The Forty-second Street Property Owners' and Merchants' Association began a campaign to "clean up" that street by sending a delegation yesterday to oppose a license for an amusement centre to include Oriental dancing at 204 West Forty-second Street, just off Times Square.

NEWARK, N.J., March 16 -- A letter to Representative Randolph Perkins of Woodcliff Lakes, N.J., criticizing him for his stand in favor of the Beck-Linthicum resolution, was made public today by the Rev. James K. Shields, superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League of New Jersey, who had sent a letter of the same nature to Representative Charles A. Wolverton of Camden.
MOSCOW, March 16 (AP) -- "Magnetogorsk is producing pig iron."

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 16 -- The thin fellow in the tweed golf suit and light cap, with blue stockings and sweater and tie to match, turned out to be Burt Shotten, manager of the Phillies. He was willing to talk about his team, but only a few words at a time.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 16 -- Mrs. O. S. Hill of Kansas City, whose fine 81 brought her medal honors in the qualifying round yesterday, defeated Mrs. O.B. Keeler of Atlanta, 9 and 7, in the first round of match play today in the women's Augusta golf tournament.

It is significant that FREDERICK J. TURNER was born on a portage -- on the narrow strip which separates the waters that flow into the Great Lakes and toward the Atlantic Ocean from those which find their way through the great "valley of a thousand streams" toward the Mississippi and the Gulf of Mexico.

While the larger exhibits in the main hall continued yesterday to attract thousands of visitors to the nineteenth annual international flower show on the third day of the exhibition in the Grand Central Palace, the competition was confined mainly to the classes displayed on the upper floors of the building.

The line of march of today's St. Patrick's Day parade up Fifth Avenue, with 20,000 persons participating, was made public yesterday by Roderick J. Kennedy, chairman of the parade committee. The parade will start from Forty-fourth Street at 2:30 P.M., led by Mayor Walker, its grand marshal, who with other officials will review it at its disbanding point, 110th Street.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 16 (Canadian Press) -- The House of Representatives and the Senate tonight passed a resolution introduced earlier in the day by Prime Minister Joseph Lyons, attaching certain sources of revenue of the State of New South Wales accruing from State taxes.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- The resistance to pressure shown by the wheat market here today surprised many operators. Strength in Liverpool and Buenos Aires, both of which have been gaining rather steadily on Chicago recently, more than offset the weakness in stocks and the selling by houses with Eastern and Northwestern connections.
"What's It to You?" an intimate revue, "will open tonight at the Provincetown Playhouse.

Tributes to Mrs. Florence Kelley, social worker, who died on Feb. 17, were paid yesterday afternoon at a memorial meeting in the Friends Meeting House, 221 East Fifteenth Street, by Newton D. Baker, Dr. Alice Hamilton. Dr. W.E.B. Du Bois, Harry W. Laidler and Miss Frances Perkins, State Industrial Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- In a seven to four decision today the Interstate Commerce Commission rejected a proposal of the Pullman Company to establish a charge for second occupants of sleeping-car berths. The charge proposed, while excepting children under 12 years of age, was 20 per cent of the lower berth fare.

The directors of the International Match Corporation, controlled by the Kreuger Toll Company through the Swedish Match Company, took no action yesterday on the regular quarterly dividends of $1 a share on the participating preferred and common shares, usually declared at this time.

The Trinity School fencing team won the Athletic Association of Private Schools of New York City championship In the annual title meet yesterday at Trinity School. Trinity defeated Brooklyn Friends, 5-3, in the first round and then vanquished Columbia Grammar, 5-1, in the final.

DUBLIN, March 16 -- A merger of Northern and Southern Ireland was one aim outlined tonight by Eamon de Valera, new President of the Irish Free State Executive Council, in a four-point program for his administration.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 16 -- In an effort to cut down the expenses of the annual junior promenade at Princeton University, Friday and Saturday, undergraduates have been requested specifically to omit purchases of the customary corsage bouquets for their guests.

The last of the "Evenings Abroad" in aid of the Charity Organization Society took place last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis. It was called "A Night in Ireland." There was an entertainment of Irish songs and dances by Marion Bent, Virginia Gode and Pat Rooney.

Approximately 900 athletes performed in Madison Square Garden last night in the three-sports carnival of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union. On the program were wrestling, weightlifting and gymnastics.

Columbia places three men and Yale and Cornell one each on the all-league team picked annually for The Associated Press by Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League coaches, whose selections were announced yesterday.

The second in a series of concerts arranged by the placement committee of the Musicians' Emergency Aid will take place this afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Church. The artists will be Salvatore De Stefano, harpist, and Virginia and Mary Drane, duo violinists.

ST. PETERSBURG, Pla., March 16 -- A single to centre by Lou Gehrig with the bases filled in the eleventh inning enabled the Yankees to win their third straight game from the Boston Braves at Waterfront Park today. The score was 8 to 5.
SHANGHAI, Thursday, March 17 -- General Yoshinori Shirakawa of Japan in a farewell message yesterday to the Japanese troops who will soon sail for home significantly said:...

In an uprising reminiscent of that memorable day at Forest Hills in 1926 when William Tilden. William Johnston and Richard Norris Williams 21 all were engulfed by a French avalanche in the quarterfinals of the turf court championship, a younger generation of American tennis players completely swept France out of the national indoor championships yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

The disastrous effect of noise on the ability of children to think is shown by a report of the Noise. Abatement Commission of an experiment conducted with 200 boys at the Riverdale Country School, Riverdaleon-Hudson, made public yesterday by Frank S. Hackett, the headmaster.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Eastern shipping demand for hogs continues abnormally slow and, while receipts were not large today, the market failed to clean up. Prices were steady to 15 cents lower than yesterday, lightweights leading the decline. Pork loins were quoted at 8 1/2 to 12 cents, or 2 to 4 cents under the high of last week.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Telegrams from forty Governors asserting with, a single exception -- that they knew of no starvation in their States were exhibited in the Senate today by Senator Bingham of Connecticut in opposing the Democratic road construction relief bill.

Monthly figures reflecting changes in Germany's export trade are watched with interest by that country's creditors. The reason is readily understood. Under present conditions an excess of exports over imports constitutes the most important source of income out of which Germany can make payments on her debts.

Action by the New York State Chamber of Commerce to demand that Mayor Walker make a thorough investigation of the Department of Sanitation, and tiring about, if necessary, its complete reorganization, was recommended yesterday by the chamber's committee on health and sanitation.
ALBANY, March 16 -- In connection with the opening of the new Sydney bridge and at the request of the Australian press, Governor Roosevelt today issued the following statement:

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Income-tax receipts so far received by the treasury are running from 40 to 45 per cent behind last year, although there is no way of determining whether this trend will be continued, officials said today.

BERLIN, March 16 -- Another shot has been fired in the political war waged around the complex problem of the reorganization of Southeastern Europe, which more than anything else was responsible for last year's crisis. The German Government, in a statement submitted to the French Ambassador at Berlin, unequivocally rejects Premier Tardieu's plan for a Danubian federation, just as France nearly a year ago opposed an Austro-German customs union.

Fannie Hurst will be the speaker at the Silver Symphony Finale to be held at the Hotel Astor on March 22, Mrs. Frederick T. Steinway, honorary chairman of the committee, announced yesterday. Mme. Ernestine Schumann-Heink and Edward Johnson of the Metropolitan Opera Company will sing, Percy Grainger will play and Mary Fickford will have the leading role in the pageant in which John Erskine, Cyrena Van Gordon and Mrs. Hans Earth will also take part.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 16 -- Going out with a fine 33, four under par, Tommy Goodwin, Monroe (N. Y.) co-medalist, defeated H. C. Neff, Philadelphia, 4 and 3, in the first round of the Florida Winter amateur championship today.

Under the charter the Commissioner of Accounts is required to make "such special examinations of "the accounts and methods of the "departments and offices of the city "and of the counties of New York, "Richmond, Queens, Kings and "Bronx as the Mayor may from "time to time direct, and such other "examinations as the said commissioner may deem for the best interests of the city."

PRINCETON, N.J., March 16 -- Elton E. (Tad) Wieman of Grand Rapids, Mich., has been appointed assistant football coach at Frinceton University, it was announced tonight by Dr. Charles W. Kennedy, chairman of the board of athletic control.

LONDON, March 16 -- The stock markets were firm in early trading today, but were reactionary in the afternoon on fears regarding the Kreuger Toll position, Kreuger Toll shares closing at u1 1/4, against u2 5/8 yesterday. It is feared that some Continental banks may have difficulty in overcoming the trouble.
DUBLIN, March 16 (AP) -- Irish Catholics will celebrate with most solemn, ceremonies tomorrow the 1,500th anniversary of the landing of Saint Patrick on Erin's shores.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- Babe Ruth, baseball's most famous player, holder of the all-time home-run-hitting record and even in the waning years of his active playing career the game's most powerful magnet, today signed a one-year contract with the Yankees at a salary of $75,000.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Senate failure to confirm the promotion of Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson of Chicago to the Circuit Court would be interpreted as "a vote for the triumph of the gangsters," Chicago leaders in the war on crime today warned a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A large group of House Democrats met tonight to lay plans for an attempt to "kill" the 2.25 per cent sales levy from the tax measure, while party leaders were using every available resource to maintain this "essential feature" of their budget balancing program.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Senator Nye, a North Dakota Republican independent, saw in the record Democratic vote there a manifestation of "growing displeasure over the failure of the Republican administration to forward any program looking to the restoration of agriculture."

HUDSON FALLS, N.Y., March 16 -- Lucy Foster Madison, author of novels and articles of historic interest, died tonight at her home here from an apoplectic stroke suffered a few nights ago. She was nearing her 67th birthday.

Edward Comaskey, 60 years old, of 252 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, and Joseph M. Smith, a lawyer, of 2,033 East Twenty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, were adjudged in contempt of court by County Judge Taylor in Brooklyn yesterday. Comaskey was sentenced to thirty days in jail, and sentence of Smith was deferred pending reference of his case to the Brooklyn Bar Association.

Largely as a result of the Ford Motor Company's delay in placing substantial orders for material, operations in the steel industry have not shown recently the improvement that had been expected, according to the weekly review by The Iron Age. This publication says that the delay in the Ford production schedule has "slowed up other automobile manufacturers to such an extent that steel mill schedules have been adversely affected."
COLUMBUS, Ga., March 16 -- President W. Cecil Neill of the Georgia Senate died at his home here today of a sinus infection after a brief illness. He was 51 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The practical impossibility of applying President Hoover's rule banning politics from his office during working hours was strikingly illustrated today. Politics figured directly in two of his conferences and indirectly in a third.

Howell L. Broach, president of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, and officers of Local 3 in this city were directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Glennon to appear tomorrow and show cause why they should not be restrained from "further persecuting" fifteen members of the union.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 16 (AP) -- Three weeks after its management successfully fought to retain control, the $42,000,000 American Republics Corporation of Houston, Texas, went into the hands of receivers today on the application of John Walsh of Washington, a stockholder.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A favorable foreign trade balance of $24,000,000 was attained by the United States last month, when exports were $155,000,000 and imports $131,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today. February exports represented an increase of $5,194,000 over those of January, but imports were $4,533,003 less.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A message received today by Dr. Gilbert Grosvenor, president of the National Geographic Society, from Louis Audoin-Dubreuil, second in command of the Citroen - Haardt Transasiatic Expedition unit on its way from China to French Indo-China, said:

More rapid decentralization than had been expected in the population map of the metropolitan area during a period of ten years, marked by migration from the centre outward to the suburbs and rural communities, is one of the striking changes revealed in the studies of the Regional Plan staff on the trend of population distribution in New York City and the region as indicated by the United States census of 1930.

BOSTON, March 16 (AP) -- Supporters of Franklin D. Roosevelt's candidacy launched their campaign tonight against the forces backing Alfred E. Smith. They seek control of the Massachusetts delegation to the Democratic National Convention.

Nine physicians, eight of Queens and one of Brooklyn, paid fines of $100 each yesterday in United States District Court in Brooklyn after pleading guilty before Judge Robert A. Inch of misuse in medical whisky prescriptions.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Charles S. Barrett, former president of the Farmers' Union, today was accused by Secretary Wilbur of lobbying against the Interior Department Appropriation bill in the Senate "to influence" the War Relief Commission.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 16 (AP) -- President Jose Moncada today declared that the Bryan-Chamorro treaty for construction of a Nicaraguan canal constituted a vital tie between the United States and Nicaragua.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A national conference to discuss ways of safeguarding society against the "crime wave" will be held in Washington probably this Spring. This was announced at the White House this afternoon by J. Weston Allen of Boston, chairman of the National Crime Commission, who discussed the crime problem with President Hoover.

COLON, C.Z., March 16 -- The six members of the crew of the yawl Nahma, rescued 100 miles off Cape Hatteras last week, none the worse for their six stormy days with a disabled engine and tattered sails, arrived here today aboard the United States army transport Republic, which saved them.

International racing with large yachts on a world-wide scale such as never before has been carried on is to be brought about as a result of a decision yesterday afternoon to have the North American Yacht Racing Union, governing body of yachting on this continent, or in this country and Canada, put up a challenge trophy for such competition.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad passed its preferred dividend yesterday for the first time since 1900, and at the same time it was disclosed that the company would apply within about three weeks for a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

The New York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroad were said yesterday to be considering plans for a general acceleration of speeds between here and Chicago which would cut the running time of the two crack trains in this service to eighteen hours.

Appealing from Albany yesterday afternoon over the National Broadcasting Company's network in behalf of the Block Community Organization, Governor Roosevelt urged support of the campaign to "stamp out want."

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- A Philadelphia "metropolitan district" fifty years hence with an estimated population almost double the present 3,520,000 was visualized in a regional plan made public at a dinner tonight by the Regional Planning Federation of the Philadelphia Tri-State District.

A defense of the machine age and an argument showing how mass production may be used to forward artistic ends are presented in "Machine Made Leisure," by Paul T. Frankl, artist and designer, just published by Harper Brothers.

JACKSON, Miss., March 16 (AP) -- An all-day demonstration here against a proposed State retail sales tax of 3 per cent developed this afternoon into a march on the State Capitol, where protesters sought to force their way into Governor Conner's office.

PARIS, March 16 -- The Bourse was irregular today, with a tendency to sudden fluctuations. Numerous rumors were circulated, showing the persistence of the nervousness following Ivar Kreuger's death. A movement toward recovery at the opening was reversed early in the session.

The tabulation of income tax returns proceeded under pressure here yesterday at the four offices of the Internal Revenue Bureau, under instructions from Washington to determine by tonight, if possible, the cash position of the greatest tax area in the country, yielding one-fifth of the national total; so that the treasury might provide estimates for the guidance of Congress in its consideration of new revenue measures.

MOSCOW, March 16 -- The Moscow Grand Opera and the newspaper Communist Youth Pravda today jointly announced a prize contest for a new opera and ballet, libretto and music, to celebrate the fifteenth anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 16 (AP) -- More than a score of persons were overcome by escaping illuminating gas at Nanticoke today, while at least fifty others were made ill by fumes from a broken gas main that followed water pipes into two dozen dwellings.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 16 -- John G. Milburn, member at the time of his death in London, England, on Aug. 11, 1930, of the law firm of Carter, Ledyard Milburn and father of Devereux Milburn, noted polo player, left a gross estate of $1,735,059, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed on his property here today with Surrogate Leone D. Howell.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court reserved decision yesterday on the appeals of Bernard K. Marcus and Saul Singer, officers of the closed Bank of United States, and the latter's son, Herbert Singer, from their convictions in General Sessions last June.

GLOBE, Ariz., March 16 (AP) -- Counsel for the government and for Mac (Golney) Seymour, accused Indian slayer, engaged in a fiery argument today over efforts of the prosecution to establish that the body found near Fort Apache last July was that of Henrietta Schmerler, Columbia University student.
MANISTIQUE, Mich., March 16 -- Shooting of 441,000 pounds of dynamite eight miles from here late today made a big noise, but gave rather a poor imitation of a natural earthquake.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I doubt if many readers have seen the military order which. General Washington issued while his army was stationed at Morristown, N.J., in March, 1780.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 16 -- Nine anthracite collieries that could have worked remained idle today as a result of the insurgent strike, the status of which remained virtually unchanged. One operation which was idle yesterday resumed work, while another mine previously in operation full handed was barely able to operate.
The Rune of St. Patrick. In the famous rune of St. PATRICK, he placed between himself at Tara and the powers of darkness, The sun with its brightness.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The establishment of the new State of Manchuria under Japanese auspices has again directed the attention of State Department officials to the Nine-Power treaty on China of the Washington conference of 1922, and has led to the conclusion that if its signatories, including Japan, should recognize the new State they would be going contrary to stipulations of the treaty.

The bodies of two men who had been strangled by heavy clotheslines were found yesterday on the roof of a six-story tenement house at 124 Thompson Street. They were identified through fingerprints as Gerard Vernotico, 28 years old, of 191 Prince Street and Antonio Lonzo, 33, of 305 East Twenty-eighth Street.

TOKYO, March 16 -- Frustration today by a strong section of the Seiyukai (Government party) of plans for the reconstruction of the Cabinet by appointment of Kisaburo Suzuki, the Minister of Justice, as Home Minister has proved another symptom of the political disunity that is causing a widespread belief in Japan that unless a strong government can restore the prestige of the parliamentary system Japan is on the brink of a military Fascist regrime.

The United States is menaced by a new order of feudalism, more dangerous than that of the Middle Ages, in the form of a "mighty oligarchy" of corporate finance, I. Maurice Wormser, Professor of Law at Fordham University and editor of The New York Law Journal, said in an address before the Business Administration Society at City College.

The Boston Bruin Cubs closed the regular local season of the Canadian-American Hockey League by defeating the Bronx Tigers at the New York Coliseum last night, 4 to 1. A crowd of 2,000 persons saw the game. Twenty penalties were called during the play.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 16 (AP) -- The possibility that Colonel P.H. Fawcett, who disappeared seven years ago into the Brazilian jungles to hunt traces of lost civilizations, is still alive was investigated here today by the British Consul General, Arthur Abbott.

HAMILTON, Ont., March 16 -- For the fourth time this season, George Spitz, crack New York University high jumper, bettered his own accepted world's indoor high-jump record of 6 feet 7 inches in the Hamilton indoor meet tonight.

William J. Flynn, Public Works Commissioner of the Bronx, was so determined "always to keep within the letter of the law," a rule he invariably followed, according to his own testimony, that he sought and succeeded in amending a proposed ordinance so that he could follow his maxim and at the same time make a financial profit, it was indicated by records introduced yesterday by Samuel Seabury at a hearing of the Hofstadter committee.
OTTAWA, Ont., March 16 -- A maximum investment of not more than 25 per cent of its assets in common stocks is the ultimate, not the immediate, objective of the Sun Life Assurance Company.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 16 -- Henry Ward Beer, president of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and former Special Assistant United States Attorney General, in a speech here today before the Kiwanis Club declared that the entire United States "lies stricken a prey to the banker and corporate groups."

"New York has a rhythm all its own," Dr. Gerhart Hauptmann, distinguished German dramatist, said early today as he sailed for home on the North German Lloyd flagship, the Europa, after a three-week visit to the United States. Sighing, he added, "Never have I spent a more intensive period."

To the editor of The New York Times: In considering the probable effect of the proposed sales tax, standard-priced articles in the lower brackets must not be overlooked, particularly goods nationally advertised as selling for 5 or 10 cents. So vital is it to maintain the resale price of these articles to the ultimate consumer at not more than 5 or 10 cents, that the manufacturers would be particularly hard hit.

PHILADELPHIA, Marcli 16 -- Columbia and Princeton will meet at the Pennsylvania Palestra tomorrow night in the play-off for the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League championship. Each team won eight and lost two games in the regulation league season.

The names of 633 students - forty-three of them from New York City and vicinity -- who maintained a high scholastic standing at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology during the first term, which endea in February, were announced yesterday. Students of the first rank included 2.4 per cent of the class of 1935, 2.7 per cent of the second year students.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 16 -- Max Bishop, the last man at bat in the 1931 world series, couldn't puncture the St. Louis defense last October, but he came through today with a booming blow while the bases were full and clinched the final game of the Spring series between the Athletics and Cardinals.

LONDON, March 16 -- David Lloyd George, after eight months of quiescence, resumed active politics today with an appeal to "men of progressive minds of whatever party" to "get together to save Britain from the calamity of Tory protectionism."

TAMPA, Fla., March 16 -- Work was begun here today to convert the huge coliseum on Davis Island, owned by the Stone Webster Company, into a modern motion picture production plant for Beecroft Studios. The coliseum has been leased to the Beecroft concern for a long term of years, and $100,000 will be spent in the installation of four sound stages and equipment for picture-making on a big scale.

Bonds were dull and irregularly lower on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Domestic corporation bonds, especially the rails, bore the brunt of the losses, with German issues the weakest of the foreign group. United States Government bonds drifted irregularly lower in quiet trading, and final prices were 3-32 point higher to 9-32 point lower.

Dr. O.C. Kiep, German Consul General in New York, pleaded for a world reparations policy that would enable Germany to reach a sound financial footing in an address last night before the Foreign Commerce Club at the Hotel Astor. Dr. Kiep was guest of honor, and the meeting was designated "German Night."

The Public Administrator's office is searching through five cases of blueprints, letters and plans left by the late Oscar Hermanson, a recluse, for records of inventions which may prove valuable, it was disclosed yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 16 (AP) -- Governor White of Ohio startled the regional meeting of the Women's Christian. Temperance Union here tonight when he told the exponents of the prohibition laws that they erred when they opposed a referendum on the Eighteenth Amendment.

George Fissler of the New York A.C., Metropolitan A.A.U. title-holder in the 500-yard free-style and 300-yard medley swimming events, easily won the 1,500-meter free-style senior championship of the district, conducted for the first time in the 40-yard pool of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, last night.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 16 -- Former President Hernando Siles, who was overthrown in June, 1930, has been found guilty of two out of eleven charges filed against him in Congress, El Diario reported today.
LONDON, March 16 -- The government announced tonight an ambitious conversion plan for dealing with the outstanding 4 1/2 per cent 1930-1932 treasury bonds, amounting to u116,467,382.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 16 -- The Robins were beaten for the second time today by Al Mamaux's Newark Bears, who bounced hits merrily to all quarters off the deliveries of two of Brooklyn's younger hurlers, John Krider and Van Mungo.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 17 -- Benjamin Fletcher, president of the City Savings Bank, who helped build the ironclad "cheesebox," the Monitor, which engaged the Merrimac in the Civil War, died here early today at his home, 89 Cottage Street. He was 94 years old.
GENEVA, March 17 -- The Nineteen-Power Commission of the League Assembly did two big things today and then recessed subject to convocation at any time by its president, Paul Hymans of Belgium.

Bank clearings at twenty-two leading cities of the country in the last week continued to decline sharply in comparison with last year. Reports received by R. G. Dun Co. show a total of $5,294,721,000 for the week, a decrease of 39.4 per cent from the corresponding week in 1931.

RYE, N.Y., March 17 -- Christine Linkfield, 8 years old, of Huntington, W. Va., was killed, and fourteen persons were injured when a Mayflower bus bound to New York from Boston skidded into a five-ton truck on the icy surface of the Boston Post Road bridge over the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad about 5 o'clock this morning.

The favorable trend shown in the Federal Reserve reports of the last two weeks was carried forward in the report for the week ended on Wednesday issued yesterday. The system continued its purchase of United States Government securities in the week, the statement showed, enabling member banks to reduce further their indebtedness to the Reserve banks.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- For another month, at least, army engineers must carry on waterway improvement projects with a cash balance in the treasury of only $30,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Bitter opposition on the part of both Democrats and Republicans in the Senate to any administration move toward reduction or cancellation of the World War debts owed by Europe to this country was revealed in a fiery debate today which arose over a newspaper article.

MARSEILLES, March 17 -- Stories of how former King Alfonso of Spain had been a delightful cruising companion, declined to seclude himself and associated freely with tourists during the voyage, were related here today when he landed on his return from a Mediterranean cruise.

A request that Magistrate Sylvester F. Sabbatino be compelled to account for the proceeds of tickets sold by him for dinners given by the Michael Laura Club, Inc., was made in affidavits filed in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday by former officials of the club.

Despite the vigilance of the Park Avenue police squad, consisting of seventy-five patrolmen, and patrols of detectives from the East Sixty-seventh Street station, burglars broke into and ransacked two apartments in a fashionable sixteen-story dwelling at 944 Park Avenue between 7 and 11 o'clock last night.

EAST ROCKAWAY, L.I., March 17 -- Anything green seemed to fit in with the general scheme of things this St. Patrick's Day, but not the spurious $10 greenbacks offered in the village stores here by four New Yorkers. The visitors were arrested on charges of possessing counterfeit currency.
The Fordham Centre Committee of the Henry Street Settlement's Visiting Nurse Service will give a bridge party tonight in aid of the service at the settlement's headquarters, 99 Park Avenue.

Controller Berry moved yesterday to accelerate the payment of taxes to the city for the coming year. He announced that he would introduce into the Municipal Assembly today a local law increasing to 6 per cent the discount given to the property owner who pays the second half of the tax, due in November, in May.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 17 -- Referring to Senator Johnson's statements concerning American bankers' "excessive credits" to South American countries. El Diario Ilustrado today editorially supports his contention that bankers are greatly responsible for the unstable condition of Latin America's finance, due fo the freedom with which they have granted credits to the military governments of these countries without protecting American citizens who took up the bonds so liberally offpred in foreign markets.

Despite early weakness in the stock market and new low quotation for rubber and silk, prices on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to display marked resistance. Fluctuations held within narrow limits at a slight advance and when securities rallied in the afternoon covering operations lifted the list, which closed 2 to 5 points higher than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The combined Democratic and Republican leadership of the House brought their "heaviest artillery" into play today in an effort to save the manufacturers' sales tax provision of the tax bill.

TOKYO, March 17 (AP) -- An official source revealed today the gist of a recent discussion between Acting Foreign Commissar Karakhan of Russia and Japanese Ambassador Koki Hirota at Moscow, in which comparisons were drawn between Soviet influences in Outer Mongolia and Japan's status in the new Manchurian Government.

ATLANTA, March 17 -- Bobby Jones sat at his desk on the fourteenth floor of a skyscraper here today, too busy on his thirtieth birthday to talk golf with reporters who wished to interview him on his anniversary. His secretary said he left instructions not to be disturbed and he was occupied in his law office until past lunch time.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Politicians in Washington are so primarily concerned with consideration of what their party and personal attitudes toward prohibition reform shall be this year that the conversion of Governor George White of Ohio to the referendum idea temporarily distracted attention today from the manufacturers' sales tax, the foreign debt debate in the Senate and the country's economic condition.
