MIAMI, Fla., March 17 -- Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Slapstick, 2-year-old daughter of Broomstick and Transit, surprised many at Tropical Park today by taking the Juvenile Handicap, the first race of her career. Ridden by Buddy Hanford, Slapstick reeled off the four furlongs in 0:48 1-5, under 107 pounds, to win by a head from H.C. Hatch's Meany, which annexed the place by five lengths from Frederick Kahn's Ipral.

Demand by the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., for a system of optional piece-work payment as a substitute for the present custom of paying employes by the week, was rejected last night by the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union at a conference in the Hotel New Yorker.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 (AP) -- Diminutive Jules Audy, 18-year-old Canadian rider, was eliminated from the six-day bicycle race today when he suffered a fracture of the skull in being catapulted from his wheel against one of the bunks at the trackside.

HAVANA, March 17 -- Street car service in Havana was partly suspended today as the result of a hastily called strike in protest against the fatal shooting of a conductor yesterday in a fight with a Secret Service operative. The conductor died early this morning.

Those who attended the performance of "Gotterdammerung" given yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House as the sixth of the special Wagner matinees had reason to congratulate themselves, first upon the splendor and the tragic pathos of the incomparable music drama, and secondly upon the prevailingly eloquent and dramatic nature of the performance.

The Hall Johnson Negro choir, which sang last night in Town Hall, again revealed its extraordinary accomplishments. As one listens to Mr. Johnson's chorus one is struck by the degree in which it attains two endsthe setting forth of Negro music in a manner to epitomize the unique contributions of the Negro race to the literature and idiom of music, and the well-nigh perfect mastery of difficult problems in ensemble singing.

GLOBE, Ariz., March 17 (AP) -- The purported confession of Mac (Golney) Seymour, read to the jury trying him for murder, quoted him as saying that he knocked Henrietta Schmerler down with a rock and then stabbed her.

Pre-Easter Volume Lagging. Little improvement has been manifest this week in women's apparel reorders, owing to the poor results retailers are generally experiencing in consumer response to Spring offerings. "With Easter but eight selling days away, the pre-holiday volume being achieved is much below expectations and, unless a sharp pickup is registered, the indications were said to be that the comparison with a year ago will show the sharpest falling off yet experienced.

Divergent versions given by former General Sessions Judge Francis X. Mancuso of the amount of money he paid for stock in the Harlem Bank of Commerce, which later merged into the City Trust Company, were read into the record yesterday by Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd in the trial of Mr. Mancuso for perjury before Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley and a jury in the extraordinary criminal term of the Supreme Court.

Money market was quiet and steady all day. Business was small, and quotations unchanged for every class of accommodation. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 1/2 per cent, with street trades at 2 1/4, and Federal funds at 3/4. While there was a continuance of the demand for acceptances, offerings were light.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Governor Roosevelt today appointed Justice Leonard C. Crouch of the Supreme Court, a Syracuse Democrat, as an associate judge of the Court of Appeals to fill the vacancy left by the elevation of Judge Cuthbert W. Pound to the chief judgeship.
Following is the text of the address yesterday of Eamonn de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Executive Council, as heard in a radio re-broadcast here:
HONOLULU, March 17 -- Nothing could better illustrate the lackadaisical attitude toward crime and criminals in Honolulu, which has led to increased crime, than the recent report of the Prison Board.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- More than $100,000,000 in idle money has been lured out of hoarding since Feb. 10, contributing to the greatly improved condition of the banking structure of the nation. Federal Reserve officials said today. They based this announcement on circulation figures for the week ending yesterday, which showed another decline.
LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- Rich tombs of an unknown line of kings who reigned nearly 5,000 years ago over the biblical city of Ur of the Chaldees, have just been discovered by Dr. Leonard Woolley.

Haardt the Explorer. GEORGES-MARIE HAARDT, who succumbed to pneumonia in Hongkong, broke motor-vehicle records as an explorer of the trackless interiors of continents. On his expeditions he seemed to be attempting the impossible.

Four well-dressed armed youths staged two clothing store hold-ups at busy corners in the Bronx last night, escaping without arousing the suspicions of traffic policemen on duty near each store. First, the four members of the band obtained $1.125 in cash and jewelry at the Crawford Clothes shop at 340 East Fordham Road.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Congress has ample constitutional authority to compel railroads to consolidate in the public interest, but cannot regulate "mere ownership of stock" by individuals or corporations, Herbert Fitzpatrick, vice president and general counsel of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, today told the House Interstate Commerce Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Unofficial reports from Geneva that the American delegation to the general disarmament conference had completed a plan for arms reduction lacked official confirmation here today.

The Lake Placid Hockey Club gained the Eastern Division A.A.U. honors by eliminating the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, 1931 national champions, 6 to 4, at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of more than 6,000 saw the battle.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway provided yesterday an unusually favorable statement of earnings by reporting an increase of about $305,000 in net operating income for February, compared with February, 1931. This result was obtained despite a drop of $1,000,000 in gross revenue for the month.

CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -- Indiana and Illinois led in the national Catholic prep schools basketball championship show today by landing nine of the fourteen survivors in the first engagements for the crown at Loyola University gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- A concerted effort to lift some of the crushing weight of the wheat and cotton surpluses from the domestic markets is being made by the administration and Congressional leaders.

PARIS, March 17 (AP) -- Several shots were exchanged today by the police and 1,200 unemployed men who staged, a demonstration at a building under construction in the suburb of Vitry. Two policemen were injured and six demonstrators were arrested.

BERLIN, March 17 -- The headquarters of Adolf Hitler's National Socialist party throughout Prussia were raided today by the police, acting on orders to smash what Prussian officials declared was a plot to plunge Germany into civil war and seize power by force of arms.

DELHI, India, March 17 -- A complete boycott of the Round Table Conference, with immediate withdrawal from the work of Lord Lothian's franchise committee, has been the main subject discussed at a series of informal conversations among Moslem leaders here during the last few days.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A delegation representing the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers and other organizations in the women's apparel industries went to Washington recently to record our views on the manufacturers' sales tax.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 17 -- Edmund Guggenheim of Roslyn, L.I., extended Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., co-medalist, throughout their second-round contest of the Florida Winter amateur championship over St. Augustine links today, the lead changing hands six times up to the sixteenth green.

Eamon de Valera, newly elected President of the Executive Council of the Irish Free State, discussed the aims of his government yesterday in a St. Patrick's Day message broadcast to the United States and Canada over the WABC network and simultaneously in Ireland over the Free State broadcasting system.
PARIS, March 17 -- Discouragement was general here today over prospects for success of the plan for an economic entente of five Danubian countries, but all hope has not been given up.
INDIANAPOLIS,. March 17 (AP) -- Results of the third annual telegraphic rifle match of the American Legion were announced at national headquarters today.

The usual variety of interpretation will be placed on yesterday's further reduction in the Bank of England's official discount rate; the third within a month. Markets will possibly describe it as another and more determined effort to stop the recovery in sterling exchange.

Bond prices rallied yesterday in late trading on the Stock Exchange in virtually all departments, several issues winning back part of the losses of the days immediately previous. Trading was comparatively quiet except in a few of the railroad issues. United States Government bonds were lightly traded and finished unchanged to 10-32 point higher for the day.
PARIS, March 17 -- After scenes of tumult rivaling those that preceded the fall of the Laval government, the Chamber of Deputies late tonight accepted the Senate's revision of the electoral bill.
In spite of rain more than 20,000 persons were recorded by the management as having visited the international flower show at Grand Central Palace yesterday. The exhibition will close tomorrow night.
MOSCOW, March 17 -- Michael Borodin's new department for the regulation of immigrant workers has now begun to function.

The esthetic and moral codes of Victorian England that have been subject to revolt and ridicule since the turn of this century were imposed more by Prince Albert, consort of Queen Victoria, than by the Queen herself, Hector Bolitho, novelist and biographer, writes in "Albert the Good," a biography, published by Appleton today.

BERLIN, March 17 -- The Boerse opened gloomy today, impressed by New York weakness, but certain Rhineland interests, speculating upon the reorganization of Vereinigte Stahlwerke, bought mining stocks, thereby turning the tide. News of the reduction of the discount rate by the Bank of England stimulated the upward movement, which spread throughout favorite securities.

PRINCETON JUNCTION, N.J., March 17 -- Speeding westward at forty-five miles an hour, the Red Arrow, Detroit flier of the Pennsylvania Railroad, was derailed here at 4:59 o'clock this afternoon. All of the seventy passengers in the train were badly shaken up.

GENEVA, March 17 -- Further extension of the age limit for all classes of war vessels was urged by virtually all the countries in the naval commission of the Disarmament Conference today. This course, it was argued, is essential in the interest of economy, though Senator Swanson raised a warning that economy might be pushed too far and endanger the lives of sailors if the age limit were increased too far.

SUFFOLK, Va., March 17 (AP) -- Exotic music and age-old customs of a nomad race were contrasted with gowns in the latest mode and a waving American flag as a son and daughter of Romany chiefs were united in a "royal" marriage ceremony here today.

A competition for living composers belonging to the nations which have been invited to take part in the games of the world Olympiad will be held in Los Angeles this Summer. Competitors may submit music in the following three classes:

One of those hopeless "intimate revues" that bloom in the Spring, trala, has anticipated the arrival of the vernal season, by four days. Under the name of "What's It To You?", it was presented last night at the Provincetown Playhouse by a willing but misguided band of amateurs, not one of whom displayed the slightest talent for the stage or knowledge of what to do upon it.

BOARD U.S.S. AUGUSTA, in the Pacific, March 16 -- A brisk thirty-mile southwest wind which whipped the spindrift from wave crests and flung spray against the weather side of the Augusta, hampered air operations today as the two opposing forces of the United States Fleet fought it out in midpacific in the navy's annual mimic war.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Governor Roosevelt today approved a bill introduced by Assemblyman Hayes of Albany which, makes it unlawful to inquire into the religious belief or affiliation of any person seeking a position in the public schools of the State.

DETROIT, March 17 (AP) -- The Marksons team of Syracuse went into second place in the American Bowling Congress tournament tonight with a score of 2,870. Four splits near the end of the last game prevented the team from taking the lead in the five-man event.
LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling.

GENEVA, March 17 -- Only small progress has been made by Premier Tardieu of France during his twoday visit here toward advancing his project of economic cooperation among the Danubian States. As has so often happened in the past, his proposal has run counter to so many interests that even his energy seems likely to prove insufficient to carry it through.

As a result of protests against the preferential discounts given to large oil companies, permitting them to buy automobile tires at or below the cost to dealers, several tire manufacturers have rescinded these discounts, F.A. Seiberling, president of the Seiberling Rubber Company, said yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., March 17 (AP) -- St. Patrick's Day brought news to this resort that one of its best known Summer residents, Chauncey Olcott, Irish ballad singer of a generation ago, is seriously ill at Monte Carlo.

Although scattered signs of improved conditions in some fields appeared during February, general business activity for last month declined below the January level, according to the monthly report yesterday of the conference of statisticians in industry, operating under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference Board.

A contest over the estate of Mrs. Ida E. Wood, belle of Civil "War days, who hoarded a fortune estimated at $1,000,000 during the twenty-four years that she lived in seclusion in the Herald Square Hotel, was begun yesterday in the Surrogate's Court by two groups of litigants claiming relationship to Mrs. Wood.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 17 -- Thirty-two college boxers representing six universities, including many a lad with his eye on that reward of rewards -- a possible post on the United States Olympic team -- will clash tomorrow in the first day of the Eastern intercollegiate championships.

Resolutions opposing the proposed manufacturers' sales tax were adopted unanimously yesterday at a meeting of the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York, comprising the largest department stores of the city. The levy also was condemned at a mass meeting of 150 dress manufacturers in the Garment Centre Capitol Club under the auspices of the bueau of trade relations of the Credit Clearing House.

Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, replied to the declaration by Julius V. Burgevin, architect of the Park Board, that he himself would design a tentative plan for Jacob Riis Park in the Rockaways by reiterating yesterday the belief that a nation-wide competition only would provide a suitable plan.
The Toronto Maple Leafs rolled up a big early lead to defeat the New York Rangers, 6 -- 3, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

A conference of unusual secrecy at the home of Charles A. Lindbergh, near Hopewell, N.J., last evening brought to a close a day in which no progress was made and the hunt for the Lindbergh baby, kidnapped sixteen days ago, apparently had dropped to its lowest ebb.

Net income of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation more than covered the annual cash dividend of $6 a share paid on the common stock, according to the annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday. The net was $18,931,511 after depreciation, obsolescence, taxes and renewals, equivalent to $6.74 a share on the 2,401,288 common shares outstanding at the end of the year.
A strongly backed movement to bring about the adoption of a prohibition referendum plank by the Republican National Convention has been started by influential party leaders.

Negotiations are under way for the sale of the Dimon Steamship Company, which was taken over recently by a committee of creditors to avoid the dissolution of its assets, it became known yesterday. Application for the appointment of a receiver in equity will be filed today in the Federal District Court at Newark by two creditors who, it was said, have the support of more than 200 other creditors, individuals and corporations.

Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York, Wimbledon champion, followed the members of the French team out of the national indoor singles yesterday as George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago, runner-up to Ellsworth Vines Jr. at Forest Hills last Summer; Frank Shields of New York, finalist at Wimbledon, and Gregory Mangin of Newark gained the three remaining semi-final brackets at the Seventh, Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Immigration officials of the Labor Department are preparing to deport about 3,000 Chinese who have been forced into the United States from their homes in Mexico by the exclusion act recently enforced in the States of Sonora and Sinaloa.
PARIS, March 17 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

About 34,000 employes of the General Electric Company are holders of General Electric Employes Securities Corporation bonds of a face value of $39,000,000, according to the ninth annual report of the company, issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A check on the use of Federal Reserve facilities for speculation and establishment of a $700,000,000 corporation to liquidate assets of closed banks was proposed in the Glass banking bill, which reached the floor of the Senate today.

LONDON, March 17 -- Eamon de Valera has sent no communication to London on his proposal to withhold the L3,000,000 land annuities paid yearly to Britain and until he does there will be no move from Westminster. If he proposes to refer the question to the World Court, the belief is here that Britain will not consent because Britain did not concur in the registration of the Irish treaty at Geneva.

W.B. Stratton, who represents John N. Willys in his opposition to a proposed reorganization plan for the Fisk Rubber Company, denied yesterday that there had been any intimation of a forced liquidation.
CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -- Secretary Hurley said today he thought the Republican National Convention next June would adopt a "more liberal" stand on the prohibition question.

LINDENHURST, L.I., March 17 -- Patrolman Otto Goercken shot and killed a brown bear with a borrowed rifle in the brush near Forty-fifth Street, just outside of this village, today. The bear was one of two. Dempsey and Tunney, both males Edward of medium size, owned by Edward Sieber of North Wellwood Avenue here.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 17 -- Disposing of property valued at "more than $20,000" in personalty, the will of John Philip Sousa, composer and bandmaster, who died at Reading Pa., on March 6, was filed for probate here today with Surrogate Leone D. Howell.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 17 -- Four children, ranging in age from 8 months to 15 years, were burned to death shortly before midnight tonight in a fire which swept through their home on Crown Point Road, near Mantua Creek, West Deptford, on the outskirts of Paulsborp, N.J.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 17 -- Construction on the Merritt Boulevard, the long awaited motor road to relieve automobile traffic in Southwestern Connecticut from Port Chester, N.Y., past Bridgeport to the Naugatuck River, will begin on April 1, according to announcement today by A. MacDonald, the State Highway Commissioner.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 17 -- The fact that only three of the Philadelphia Athletics' runs were earned may have been comforting to Watson Clark and Waite Hoyt, Brooklyn pitchers, but it didn't change the result of today's game, which the Athletics won, 9 to 7.

VIENNA, March 17 -- The reception of Germany's declaration regarding Premier Tardieu's Denubian economic plan by the States concerned shows little inclination to consider the question purely from an economic standpoint and conforms to the usual political attitude of each.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Following is the text of the Glass banking bill as introduced in the Senate:

The Electrical Workers New Deal Group, comprising members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, in a circular letter to the members of the union, announced yesterday that Price Waterhouse Co., certified public accountants, had been engaged to make an audit of all expenses for the last five years.

The new clubhouse of the New York Chaper, American Red Cross, at 321 Lexington Avenue, was opened with a "housewarming" from 4 to 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The club, which is next door to the chapter house, is designed to serve disabled veterans and men now serving in the army, navy and Marine Corps.
TORONTO, March 17 (AP) -- Ralph Metcalfe of Marquette University twice defeated Eddie Tolan, Detroit sprinter, in the Canadian indoor track and field championships tonight.

The General Motors Corporation has purchased the outstanding 20 per cent minority interest in Adam Opel A.G., automobile manufacturer, in Germany, and now own this property in its entirety, it is revealed in the pamphlet report of the corporation for 1931, issued yesterday by Lammot du Pont, chairman, and Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president.

The Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, rabbi of the Free Synagogue, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street, which he founded, marked his fifty-eighth birthday yesterday. Dr. Wise is president of the Jewish Institute of Religion, a theological seminary at the same address, which he also founded.

The problem of the detention of aliens on Ellis Island is its most serious one and ought eventually to be met by a governmental program of recreational and occupational activities for those held there, Edward Corsi. Commissioner of Immigration on the island, told the Conference on Immigration Policy at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Lexington yesterday.

FARGO, N.D., March 17 -- President Hoover will have at least nine and probably ten of the eleven delegates elected to the Republican National Convention in the North Dakota, Presidential preference primary held Tuesday.

Harry C. Perry, chief clerk of the City Court, whose bank accounts were challenged by Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, lost a skirmish yesterday in the proceedings to determine whether he should be removed.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 17 -- District Attorney Edwards began to investigate today a story of how two young men and two girls in an automobile had killed a pedestrian in Westbury and had disposed of the body as told in a letter, written apparently by one of the girls who had been in the automobile to a girl friend, and found last night by a woman in the wating room of the Lynbrook railroad station.
SAN DIEGO, Cal., March 17 -- The excellently conditioned Giants found San Diego night life a trifle too much for them with the result that they lost to the Hollywood Stars tonight by 2 to 1.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Receipts of hogs today fell below expectations, and with fair buying by shippers and small putchers, prices moved up 5 to 15 cents. Arrivals were the second smallest for Thursday since last July. Fresh pork loins were quoted at unchanged prices.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Police announced tonight that they had broken up a plot to assassinate the heads of the International Union of Operating Engineers in a second outbreak of violence within that organization.

MONTREAL, March 17 -- The Montreal Canadiena trounced the New York Americans, 10 -- 4, in a wide-open National Hockey League game tonight. The Canadiens thereby broke even on the season with the Americans, each, team winning four encounters.

The Long Island Lighting Company reports a net income of $3,633,529 for 1931, equal, after dividend requirements on preferred shares outstanding at the end of the year, to 68 cents a share earned on 3,000,000 common shares, compared with $3,454,770, or 63.5 cents a share in the year before.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Razor Securities Corporation of Brooklyn has received an income and profits tax abatement of $684,014 for the years 1918, 1919, 1924 and 1925, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 16, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was 51,672,000,000, a decrease of $56,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $372,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- A 90 per cent cut in all immigration, Western Hemisphere as well as Old World, was approved today by the House Immigration Committee.

The Canadian Pacific liner Duchess of York arrived yesterday from Bermuda with twenty-three passengers and 147 members of the crew of the liner Prince David of the Canadian National Line, which hit a coral reef off St. George, Bermuda, last Sunday and is believed to be a total loss.

The New York Central Railroad has refused to consent to a further suspension of the 40 per cent commutation fare rise, for which it filed schedules on Dec. 1, 1930, and will put the new rates into effect on April 1, it was announced yesterday "by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission.

The Women's Division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, of which Mrs. August Belmont is chairman, reported yesterday that it had "adopted" 735 families, an increase of 106 in the last week. This is the equivalent of $203,757.55 raised to pay the wages for non-competitive jobs provided for the bread-winners of these families through the Emergency Work Relief Bureau.
NEW YORK. Mrs. George Spencer Eastwick grave a luncheon yesterday in the Oak Room of the St. Regis for Mrs. Amory A. Lawrence, Mrs. Francis M. Whitehouse and Mrs. Alfred Kessler.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- An exchange of messages between Secretary Stimson and Eamon de Valera on the assumption by the latter of the offices of President of the Executive Council and Minister for External Affairs of the Irish Free State was made public today by the State Department.

The new $1,500,000 Railroad Y.M. C.A. at 224 East Forty-third Street was dedicated last night by Dr. John R. Mott, chairman of the world committee of the Y.M.C.A., in the presence of railroad executives and other guests. Dr. Mott characterized the structure as standing in the forefront among the 10,000 Y.M.C.A.'s throughout the world.

Arthur G. Dove's returns are, like those of John Marin and Georgia O'Keeffe, annual. At Mr. Stieglitz's gallery, An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue, Dove's newest work is now being shown --nineteen oils and a series of twenty small framed sketches.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 17 -- An announcement by the West India Oil and Shell Mex companies that the price of gasoline would be raised 25 per cent created such a stir in the early hours this morning that even the Cabinet Ministers and the President of the republic were compelled to take a hand in the matter when nearly a thousand motor buses blocked the principal thoroughfares in a demonstration of protest.

ALBANY, March 17 -- In the two weeks' period ended March 8. 820 certificates of automobile registration and licenses to drive were revoked or suspended. Charles A. Harnott. Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, announced today.

Electric power output rose last week against the usual seasonal downward tendency, and the seasonally adjusted daily average is 218,200,000 kilowatt-hours for the week ended March 12, as against 214,700,000 kilowatt-hours for the preceding week and 237,700,000 kilowatt-hours for the corresponding week last year.

Removal of John Theofel, Queens Democratic leader, from his post as chief clerk of the Queens County Surrogate's Court was asked yesterday by the City Affairs Committee in formal charges against Theofel filed with Surrogate John Hetherington.

NEW ORLEANS, March 17 (AP) -- Justice Logan, ace of the two-year old campaigning at New Orleans, again asserted his claim to the championship when he won the $2,000 added Liam T. MacCosgair Sweepstakes at the Fair Grounds today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 17 -- Harvard University is planning to reproduce artificially the heat and immense pressures comparable to those in the depths of the earth.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 17 -- Nearly 150 guests attended the annual St. Patrick's Day luncheon of the Kobe Sound Yacht Club, at which Colonel and Mrs. Thomas F. Murphy were hosts today at Isle Ri their Hobe Sound estate. For many years Colonel Murphy has been commodore of the club.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- First receipts of income taxes at the treasury justify the estimate of about $1,000,000,000 for the fiscal year ending June 30, according to Secretary Mills.

PARIS, March 17 -- Despite formal protests by the American Chamber of Commerce of Paris and the American Embassy regarding the French Government's alleged discrimination against American manufacturers because of preliminary consultations only with German manufacturers, a new quota limiting severely the importation of machine tools made in the United States was established today by official decree.

The Board of Aldermen recently adopted an ordinance which, in effect, builds an administrative wall around New York. It forbids any one to seek appointment or employment in any division of the City Government who has not been a resident of New York State for five years and a resident of New York City for two years.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Opposition to confirming the nomination of Federal. Judge James H. Wilkerson to be Circuit Court Judge was filed with the Senate Judiciary Committee today by the executives of twenty-one railway labor, organizations.

The charges of criminal contempt of court made last week by County Judge Franklin Taylor in Brooklyn against two officials and a reporter of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle were dismissed by Judge Taylor yesterday.

OSSINING, N.Y., March 17 -- Peter Sardini, 28 years old, of 2,705 Harway Avenue, Brooklyn, who was to have died in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison tonight, received at 8 P.M. a two week's reprieve after telling New York and Kings County prosecutors details of six recent unsolved murders, including an explanation of the mysterious disappearance on Nov. 19, 1928, of Dr. Charles Brancati, wealthy Bronx physician.

The New York Stock Exchange has received application to list deposit receipts for 104,561 shares of common stock and 52,356 shares of preferred stock of the St. Louis South-western Railway, which receipts would represent assenting stock deposited in the proposed merger of the line with the Southern Pacific.

President DE VALERA'S statement of aims and purposes, on the eve of St. Patrick's Day, could not have gone much, further than it did to remove apprehensions aroused by his revolutionary record or his recent campaign utterances. He is firm on the subject of abolishing the oath of fealty to the King, though even here he argues that the treaty does not really make the oath obligatory.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Calvin Coolidge has been, suggested by prominent members of the Republican National Committee for keynote speaker at the national convention.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Seated around a table in Washington, seven men of mature years and considerable experience were discussing the hard times and the best way to overcome the situation. We all agreed that it was not to be expected that the times of 1928 and 1929 would soon return; we also agreed that it would be undesirable.
LONDON, March 17 -- The directors of the Bank of England surprised the financial community today by reducing the bank rate half a point further from 4 to 3 1/2 per cent.
PARIS, March 17 (AP) -- The body of Ivar Kreuger was taken to North Station this afternoon from the apartment where Mr. Kreuger committed suicide on Saturday. It will be sent to Stockholm tonight.

LONDON, March 17 -- The lowering of the bank rate today was welcomed by the Stock Exchange, causing an advance in British Government funds. The war loan rose to L102 1/2 , and 3 1/2 per cent conversion loan to L83 1/2 . Reports of dullness in Wall Street set the tendency for practically the entire industrial list.

To have been beaten by Governor MURRAY in the North Dakota primary might have been fatal to Governor ROOSEVELT'S prospects. To have beaten him is perhaps less of an achievement than his enthusiastic partisans imagine, hopeful of its effects in other States.

Well on its way to a long-distance record for sleeping, a lung fish entered yesterday upon the last half of the fourth year of its existence. The fish is sleeping for the benefit of science, encased in mud in a laboratory of the New York University Medical College.

For two hours yesterday Charles S. Hand, who resigned last Saturday as a member of the Sanitation Commission and made charges against Dr. William Schroeder Jr., chairman of the commission, was questioned yesterday for two hours by Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter Committee.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 17 (AP) -- Conferences in New York City during the next week or so are expected here to result in acceptance by the creditors and bondholders of the Cosach nitrate combine of a plan of reorganization, already approved by the Chilean Government, which was devised here by Medley G.B. Whelpley, the president of Cosach.

Appointment by the Columbia University board of trustees of twenty professors, one associate and one assistant professor to the staff of the New York Post-Graduate Medical School was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary of the university.

LONDON, March 17 -- J.H. Thomas, Secretary of State for the Dominions, won a point in his fight to preserve his Cabinet prestige today when Prime Minister MacDonald mentioned his name first in announcing in the House of Commons the names of those who will compose the British delegation to the Imperial Conference at Ottawa in July.

A bronze plaque is to be placed on the wall of the choir of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, in recognition of the fortieth anniversary of Dr. William C. Carl as organist and director of music of the church. This was announced at a testimonial dinner given by the officers and members of the church for Mr. Carl in celebration of the anniversary at the Hotel Brevoort last night.

Of the thirty birthplaces of the Presidents of the United States, all except two were in the country or in villages or in towns close to rural life. President ROOSEVELT was born in this city, but came to know the frontier as well. When President TAFT was born, hia native city, Cincinnati, was not so large as Albany or Trenton today.

Price losses outnumbered advanced in commodity markets yesterday. Two articles, cash oats and rubber, reached new lows for the year. Tin also weakened. In futures, sugar was irregrular, with May retouching the previous low of 0.75. Coffee, cocoa, hides, rubber and silk all declined. Yesterday's closing wholesale cash prices for commodities in the New York market, unless otherwise noted, were:

Governor Roosevelt's victories over former Governor Alfred E. Smith and Governor William H. Murray of Oklahoma, in Democratic primary contests in New Hampshire and North Dakota, respectively, have demonstrated that he has great strength in the rural sections, the managers of the Roosevelt campaign declared yesterday.

TOKYO, March 17 -- On the eve of the meeting of the new Diet it was generally agreed here today that there would be no change in the government until the brief session, called to pass on credits for operations in Manchuria and Shanghai, had concluded.

MEXICO CITY, March 17 -- So much excitement has been aroused by the campaign for the Congressional elections in the early part of July that two violent deaths already have been reported as a by-product.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A move to reduce all Federal salaries "from the highest to the lowest" by 20 per cent down to 10 per cent to save at least $50,000,000 was started in the House today when the special economy committee authorized a subcommittee to draft legislation to this effect as part of the committee's program to reduce appropriations for 1933 by $100,000,000.

TRENTON, N.J., March 17 -- Greeting them as "Americans having a special responsibility," Governor Moore urged today the members of the New Jersey State Society, Daughters of the American Revolution, to catch the inspiration of this Washington bicentennial year and followeven more closely the heart of 'Washington and his God.

DUBLIN, March 17 -- St. Patrick's Day was celebrated throughout Ireland in glorious weather. As it was the fifteenth centenary of the year of the landig of the Saint in Ireland, there were special ceremonies.
BERLIN, March 17 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement of March 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

PARIS, March 17 -- Opening dull today, the Bourse session continued inactive, with prices tending to decline. With the exception of General Electricite, which issued a favorable annual report today, and gold mining shares, both domestic and international, most stocks lost pround.

The executive committee of the Aviation Corporation elected yesterday LaMotte T. Cohu as president to succeed Frederic Gallup Coburn, who resigned. The resignation of Mr. Coburn and of D.J. Walsh Jr. of Sanderson Porter as directors of, the company were also accepted.

Yachtsmen enthusiastically approved yesterday the decision of the North American Yacht Racing Union to offer a challenge trophy for international competition among 12-meter craft. They praised the plan to make the event open to all nations.

Six thousand striking cap makers and milliners, part of the 15,000 who went on strike yesterday morning, heard speakers in the auditorium and basement of Mecca Temple congratulate them yesterday on their victory over the racketeers in the industry.

Without receiving any impetus from outside, the share market developed rallying tendencies yesterday and made what was considered a satisfactory showing in the late dealing's under extreme difficulties. The volume of trading on the Stock Exchange was about 1,700,000 shares; the composite average showed a net gain on the day of $1.68.

Members of the American Woman's Association gave a dinner, which was followed by dancing and supper, last night at their clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street. An elaborate entertainment was given during the evening. Howard Phillips was master of ceremonies.

LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- David Lloyd George, Liberal leader who became ill before the general election campaign last year and has been convalescing ever since, made his first appearance in the new Parliament this afternoon. He entered unobtrusively from behind the Speaker's chair, but when the House caught sight of him there were general cheers.

Plans for dissolution of the National Bellas Hess Company, reputed to be the third largest mail-order company in the country, will be discussed by stockholders at a special meeting called for April 4. A special committee of the board of directors reached the conclusion recently that "the company cannot continue as a going concern."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 -- By winning today's game, 6 -- 2, their fourth straight victory over the Boston Braves in as many games, the Yankees assured themselves of no worse than a tie in this year's series for the sunshine city championship.

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Hoover's reasons for the proposed promotion of Judge Wilkerson to the Circuit Court, "in recognition of his services in fighting organized crime and gangsters," do no credit to either the President or the judge.

Addressing the housing section of the Welfare Council last night, Carol Aronovici, housing and town-planning expert, decried the efforts to rehabilitate the lower east side as a residential area for the poor.

Who could have imagined that a Republican Administration would set up a loud wail about the bad effects of high tariffs? Of course, it is the tariffs which perfidious foreigners are erecting against our exports. Our own beloved and truly American tariffs are perfect.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, March 17 -- Finland is busy shaping the new alcohol organization, because only about a fortnight remains until the nation is permitted to discard prohibition and freely enjoy liquor.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Prohibition is fast losing caste. It 'will soon be revealed as the enormity it is.

A downpour of rain yesterday caused the annual St. Patrick's Day parade to be postponed until tomorrow afternoon, but did not otherwise interfere with celebrations throughout the city in honor of the saint who landed in Ireland fifteen centuries ago and left his name to be the focus of religion, politics and the sense of being Irish.

AINTREE, England, March 17 -- There were thirteen American-owned horses ready tonight for the attempt to carry the Stars and Stripes to victory in the Grand National Steeplechase, which will be run here tomorrow. The race is worth L9,000.

Gerhart Hauptmann and Sinclair Lewis, two Nobel Prize winners in literature, met for the first time last week at dinner in the home of George Sylvester Viereck, a meeting that Dr. Hauptmann had previously told interviewers was one of his several reasons for coming to America.
PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -- Princeton dethroned Columbia as champion of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League by triumphing in the play-off on the Palestra court tonight, 38 to 35.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Between March 27, 1929, and Dec. 31, 1931, the number of active banks in the Federal Reserve System was reduced by 1,509, while their loans and investments decreased $4,818,000,000 and their deposits $6,053,000,000.

Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck refused yesterday to hold George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, in contempt of court for certain acts performed by him in connection with liquidation proceedings against the Independent Mutual Casualty Company.

GARDEN CITY, N.Y., March 18 -- Further reduction in highway construction plans as a means of reducing taxation and lowering future fiscal deficits was forecast here tonight by Senator Seabury Mastick at a taxpayers' meeting held in the high school under the auspices of the Long Island Real Estate Board.

LONDON, March 18 -- Warning that bitterness would be revived and that the British Government would view with "the gravest concern" any effort in Ireland to abolish the oath of allegiance to Great Britain or to withhold the land annuities was given today by Neville Chamberlain, the Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Representative William I. Sirovich locked horns yesterday with Heywood Broun and Ed Sullivan on the subject of dramatic criticism at the seventh annual luncheon of the Drama Study Club at the Waldorf-Astoria in the presence of an audience that included Daniel Frohman, Jesse Lasky, and a number of other theatrical and motion-picture celebrities.

Fordham Prep dethroned All Hallows Institute as the city's Catholic High Schools Athletic Association swimming champion by winning the annual title competition with 28 points in the New York A.C. pool last night. Brooklyn Prep was second with 20 and third was All Hallows, winner of the crown for the past two years, with 11.

BOSTON, March 18 -- Consolidated net income of the Gillette Safety Razor Company for 1931 amounted to $4,106,728 after all charges and including $3,045,073 of non-recurring items, according to the annual report, issued today. This was equal, after allowing for preference dividends, to $1.23 a share on 1,998,769 shares of common stock.

In reply to questions put to him by The Brooklyn Eagle, William Randolph Hearst, the publisher, explained yesterday the failure of Speaker John N. Garner to vote on the prohibition referendum resolution was perhaps due to his desire not to be classified as a wet or a dry.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- The traveler in Florida, finds ball players all over the landscape and even on the seascape. Out on the end of the Municipal Pier here, of which St. Petersburg is very proud, two fellows in sports clothes were watching some tourists tossing up bread to a wheeling flock of gulls that caught the bits of bread with great dexterity, not to mention voracity.

In the new Japanese Diet, summoned in extra session for the purpose of voting military appropriations for Manchuria and Shanghai, the Inukai Cabinet has a majority of 150 in a body of fewer than 500 members. The session opens just as the first troopships depart from Shanghai, bringing back part of the victorious Japanese Army.

Experiments on animals in which the growth of cancerous tumors was retarded by the removal of the pituitary gland, at the base of the brain, or by the injection of lactic acid or certain dyes are described in three separate reports by cancer investigators in the current issue of The American Journal of Cancer.

CHICAGO, March 18 (AP) -- George Nichols, Buffalo, defeated Davie Maier, Milwaukee, for the National Boxing Association light heavyweight championship tonight in a savage ten-round battle. A crowd of 10,000, including 9,344 who paid admission, saw the bout.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange turned definitely weak yesterday, after having been deadlocked for most of a month, and under active selling movement they broke about $1 a bale. For several hours fluctuations were limited, despite weakness in outside markets and record low prices for sugar.
PUTNEY-ON-THAMES, England, March 18 (Canadian Press) -- The probable boatings for the Cambridge and Oxford crews in tomorrow's race follow:
MOSCOW, March 18 -- The Soviet press gave prominence today to reports that the United States had changed its stand against recognizing Russia.

MOSCOW, March 18 (AP) -- Mo Tehhui, president of the Chinese Eastern Railway, who was "dismissed" by the new Manchurian Government, has offered his resignation to the Chinese Government at Nanking as a result of recent events in Manchuria.

Indicating that the Pennsylvania Railroad is prepared to push electrification of its main line between this city and Washington as fast as circumstances will permit, J.V.B. Duer, electrical engineer of the road, said last night at a meeting of the New York Railroad Club in the Engineering Society Building that ten electric passenger and two freight locomotives designed for the project were already on test.

Leopold Stokowski, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, will direct the Musicians Symphony Orchestra, composed of 200 of the best players among the unemployed musicians of New York, at its first concert, at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 5. Mr. Stokowski will direct Beethoven's Fifth Symphony in the first half of the opening concert of the series of five announced for successive Tuesday evenings.

If it has been good market policy to treat the recent moderate advances and declines as "technical manifestations," then yesterday's moderate downturn on the Stock Exchange had no special significance. Wall Street viewed the backing and filling as a sign of uncertain speculative operations.

Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly will advise the city to relieve the War Department of responsibility for erosion damage that may be caused by the projected jetties at East Rockaway Inlet at the entrance to Long Island's inland waterway, it was disclosed yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 18 -- Miss Dorothy Smith, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Fred B. Smith of 20 Ridgewood Avenue, was married here tonight to John Francis Ryan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Ryan of Larchmont, at the home of her parents.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission closed today its examination of the affairs of the New England Public Service Company, indirect subsidiary of the Middle Western Utilities Company, with testimony regarding the company's constituent holdings.

Fears lest stockholders of the Electrio Bond and Share Company fail to send sufficient proxies to assure the success of the plan to issue one new share for three present common shares brought yesterday widespread selling of the shares and other securities of the company and its affiliates on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges.

SYRACUSE, March 18 -- Science lost its fight with death today when Clarence Hastings, 14-year-old boy from King Ferry, died in the City Hospital after 178 days in an artificial respirator which enabled him to breathe after poliomyelitis paralyzed his lungs.

LONDON, March 18 -- British actors' organizations were awaiting news from Washington regarding action by the House Committee on Immigration on the Dickstein bill involving the possible expulsion of 2,000 British actors from the United States.

The Board of Estimate, at its meeting at City Hall yesterday, indicated that vital public works, such as street repaving and construction of garbage incinerators, would go ahead this year, despite the economy drive.

GLOBE, Ariz., March 18 (AP) -- Mac (Golney) Seymour, young Apache, told a Federal Court jury today that he unintentionally killed Miss Henrietta Schmerler of New York after the girl gave him liquor and attacked him.

Practically every form of religious appeal will be made in the churches of the city throughout Holy Week starting tomorrow, Palm Sunday. Pageantry, cantatas, sermons, prayers, confirmation ceremonies and other exercises will be used in the annual observance of the anniversary of Christ's death on the Cross and His resurrection from the Tomb.

Accessories Lead Week's Trade. Consumer purchases of accessories picked up during the week, despite the lagging tendencies evident in most lines of ready-to-wear, it was reported here yesterday by retail executives. Main floor merchandise did comparatively well, with interest distributed over women's neckwear, handbags, sweaters, skirts, blouses and lingerie.

An estate of $1,355,674 gross, reduced by debts, expenses and commissions to $906,058, was left by Emanuel Van Raalte, retired hosiery manufacturer and founder and former president of the Van Raalte Company, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Postoffice Department expects to proceed against any publication using the malls which carried the news of any part of the distribution of prizes won in sweepstakes. Among the largest and best-known of the sweepstakes is that made on the Grand National Steeplechase, which was run at Aintree, near Liverpool, today.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The new Glass banking reform bill, introduced yesterday in the Senate, was made today the unfinished order of business of the Banking and Currency Committee, which will discuss the measure to the exclusion of all other legislation.

A return to Christian principles in business would aid the current economic situation, according to John Moody of Moody's Investors Service, who yesterday spoke at Fordham University, following a senior class symposium on the principles of social justice taught by the Catholic Church.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 18 -- Commenting editorially on Princeton's basketball victory over Columbia, which gave the Tigers the Eastern Intercollegiate League championship, The Daily Princetonian today expressed the hope that the championship, "taken in conjunction with the hockey team's successful season, may be interpreted as a hopeful indication of a renaissance of Princeton's athletics."

The late Sir CHARLES PARSONS, distinguished as the inventor of the steam turbine, once laid before the British Association for the Advancement of Science a plan to sink a shaft to a depth of twelve miles. The time required? From fifty to eighty-five years.

Although complete figures are not expected to be available for another week, the Treasury Department has made a preliminary estimate of its receipts from the first quarterly payment of income taxes, due last Tuesday. The amount will be in the neighborhood of $185,000,000.

BERLIN, March 18 -- Resistance on the Boerse was considerable today despite the status of Kreuger Toll and the difficulties of a large bank in the Rhineland. Improvement in Wall Street and extraordinary firmness in Western mining shares, especially Kloeckner and Gelsenkirchen, prevented any serious downward movement and gains predominated.

Five men and a woman pleaded guilty yesterday before Commissioner Jacob A. Visel in the Federal Building in Brooklyn to charges of passing counterfeit $10 bills, and were held in $7,500 bail each to await grand jury action. Another man and a woman pleaded not guilty and were held in bail for examination on April 1.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Following the action of the House today on the tax bill, Speaker Garner and Representative Crisp made these statements:

LIVERPOOL, England, March 18 (AP) -- Forbra, a long-legged, brown, 7-year-old gelding unknown to racing fame, today won the ninety-third running of the Grand National, the moral of which is that nobody can buy a ready-made winner for the world's greatest steeplechase classic.

While one condemned slayer was giving testimony before the grand jury yesterday in the murder of a policeman, District Attorney Geoghan in Brooklyn refused to discuss the last-minute confession of Peter Sardini, convicted Brooklyn murderer who won a two weeks' reprieve a short while before he had been scheduled to be put to death Thursday night, by revealing his knowledge of six other murders in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.

A campaign to stem the tide of inferior merchandise, which, it is claimed, is definitely lowering the standard of good taste in America and threatening the existence of important established industries was inaugurated yesterday with the formation of the National Quality Maintenance League at a luncheon meeting at the Empire State Club.

Maurice Hotchner, Special Assistant Corporation Counsel, is under consideration by Mayor Walker for appointment to head the new Board of Taxicab Control, it was disclosed yesterday at City Hall. Mr. Hotchner has repeatedly acted as counsel for commuters in railroad rate proceedings and for consumers in other public utility matters, such as electric light and gas rate cases.

Most of the new issues of bonds aggregating $38,486,000 that were brought out this week were taken quickly by investors, enabling bankers to close the books on the principal syndicate accounts. The total compared with $19,512,000 last week, $39,960,000 the week before and $76,639,000 a year ago.

AIKEN, S.C., March 18 -- The annual sports day was held this afternoon at the Aiken Preparatory School. The winner of the senior championship, equivalent to the school championship, was E.B. McLean Jr. of Washington. Junior champion was Peter Coy of Charles County, Md., and sub-junior champion was Whitney Tower of New York.
WASHINGTON March 18 -- Secretary Stimson expressed to Mr. Forbes today appreciation for his services as Ambassador to Japan. Mr. Forbes will sail for the United States on Tuesday.
BOSTON, March 18 (AP) -- Charlie Retzlaff, Duluth heavyweight, added Jack McCarthy of Boston to his long knockout string tonight in the Boston Garden's feature bout.

A sentence of from three and one-half to seven years in Sing Sing was imposed by Judge Corrigan in General Sessions yesterday on John J. Glenn, a suspended patrolman, who was found guilty recently by a jury of perjury in the Women's Court in connection with a vice charge he made against Mrs. Betty Smith La Paige.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Though thousands of men and women throughout the country are suffering untold privations in a crisis that engulfs the whole world, I nevertheless feel justified in making this plea on behalf of a comparatively small number of unfortunates.

Three young robbers held up two young women, the cashier and bookkeeper, of the Century Hotel, 111 West Forty-sixth Street, and a man employe in the auditor's office on the second floor of the hotel at 11 o'clock yesterday morning and escaped with a payroll of $1,045.

The so-called "Glass banking bill," embodying extensive amendment of the Federal Reserve act, was considered by the Senate Banking Committee last January and referred back to the subcommittee which prepared it. The subcommittee has now again reported the measure, but no important provision which caused criticism last January appears to have been eliminated or essentially modified.

LANGHORNE, Pa., March 18 (AP) -- Nine-year-old Charles Simpson Jr. was killed late today with a 32-calibre pistol which Edward Wall, also 9, found in his father's bureau, but different versions of the tragedy were given by Edward and the brother and sister of Charles, who saw it.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. AUGUSTA IN THE PACIFIC, March 18 -- Seven more destroyers of the Black fleet have been sent to "Davy Jones's locker" by imaginary shells of "enemy" men-of-war, and one of the Blue fleet's battleships, which was badly damaged by a Black torpedo attack last Tuesday night, has either "sunk" or been "abandoned" and is drifting in a half-sinking condition somewhere in the stormy waste of waters to the west.

One of Shakespeare's earliest plays, "Love's Labour's Lost," generally accepted as having been written in 1590, was written fully six years later, about the middle of 1596, according to research by Rupert Taylor, associate professor of English at Clemson College, S.C., just published by the Columbia University Press.
CHICAGO, March 18 (AP) -- Five States, led by Indiana which landed three teams, placed in the quarterfinals of the ninth annual national Catholic prep basketball championship tournament today.

Albert C. Bostwick, owner of Mate, has been granted a license to train horses, it became known yesterday with the announcement by the Jockey Club of the names of 129 trainers and thirty-five jockeys who have been granted licenses. Mr. Bostwick is a member of the Jockey Club, widely known in hunt club circles, and is one of the best of the country's amateur riders.

Mayor WALKER got his "Irish courage" up sufficiently on the evening of St. Patrick's Day to issue a challenge to Judge SEABURY. At least, he sneeringly referred to the fact that thirteen months ago he had been threatened with exposure by the Hofstadter committee, but had not yet been summoned before it as a witness.

Wagner's "Lohengrin" was sung for the fifth time this season at the Metropolitan last evening, when a large audience assembled on word that no further repetition was contemplated in the final month of opera to come. Mme. Ljungberg and Mr. Laubenthal sang the lovers, Mme. Claussen and Mr. Schuetzendorf their opposing conspirators, Mr. Cehanovsky the king's herald and Mr. Tappolet the king.
NEW ORLEANS, March 18 (AP) -- Come On, a 5-year-old son of Sweep On, gained an early lead to win the mile and one-sixteenth feature on an all-claiming card at the Fair Grounds today.
MOUNDSVILLE, W. Va., March 18 (AP) -- With an unconcerned smile on his face, Harry F. Powers, the mountain "Bluebeard" who slew two women and three children, died on the gallows tonight.

Increased interest on the part of the various garden clubs and other affiliated organizations in the nineteenth annual international flower show, which closes tonight at the Grand Central Palace, made it "the most successful exposition in floral history," the directors of the Horticultural Society of New York and the New York Florists' Club, who are sponsors of the exhibits, declared yesterday.

PARIS, March 18 -- Improvement in copper and tin reported from Wall Street was offset on the Bourse today by new sharp declines in Rio Tinto Copper and Royal Dutch Oil, which apparently discouraged trading. The volume of transactions was unusually light, and although the market was fairly firm at the opening most stocks declined steadily thereafter.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Income tax receipts for the month up to Wednesday totaled $100,312,836, or nearly $6,000,000 less than the collections in the corresponding period last year.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Pressing its plans for Federal salary cuts, a House subcommittee today began drafting a bill to reduce the government payroll by at least 575,000,000. The measure is expected to be ready for the full Economy Committee on Monday.

HANOVER, N.H., March 18 -- W. J. Morton of New Rochelle and R.C. Wilkin of Salt Lake City, football stars, were chosen by the senior class today as commencement marshal and class president respectively.

New York City could save money by closing all the city-operated colleges and paying the expenses of their students at privately endowed institutions, Joseph V. McKee, President of the Board of Aldermen, asserted last night in a talk at the twenty-fifth annual dinner of the men's class of the All Souls Universalist Church, Ditmas and Ocean Avenues, Brooklyn.

Yes, those were brave days, the days of Beowulf, son of Egtheow and nephew of Hygelac, king of the Geatas. Random House has just issued a beautiful edition of this precious relic of Old English. It was illustrated by Rockwell Kent, and his lithographs -- few in number, but magnifcent -- are now on exhibition in the gallery of Pynson Printers, on the seventh floor of the Times Annex.

Reserving decision on the petition of fifteen members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, to restrain the officers of the union from "persecuting" then and for an accounting of $7,050,000 income in the last five years, Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck declared yesterday that unions that expelled members for taking their grievances to court were not only "ridiculous" but were "assuming governmental authority which would not be tolerated by the government."

The character of the market showed no change in business or quotation from the sessions of early in the week. Funds are in good supply, but demand continued along small lines. Stock Exchange call loans ruled at 2 1/2 per cent, while street trades went at 2 1/4 and Federal funds at 3/4a 1.
HAMBURG, March 18 (AP) -- The special funeral car which brought the body of Ivar Kreuger from Paris was coupled to the Stockholm Express and left Hamburg tonight for the Swedish capital.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today approved a loan of about $2,250,000 to the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 18 -- Trust funds totaling more than $1,000,000 are left to the widow and son in the will of John C. Juhring, chairman of the board of Francis H. Leggett Co., New York produce merchants, who died in New York on March 9.

A volunteer organization of citizens which could give New York a sound government by eliminating politics from the administration was advocated yesterday by Samuel Seabury, counsel of the Hofstadter legislative committee, at a meeting arranged by the Committee of One Thousand at Town Hall, where he introduced as the principal speaker Mayor Russell Wilson of Cincinnati.
AINTREE, England, March 18 -- After a terrific duel over the last mile, Forbra, a 50-to-1 outsider, won the Grand National Steeplechase today. The purse was u8,000 [about $32,000].
NEW YORK. The Spanish Ambassador and Senora Juan F. de Cardenas are at the Ritz-Carlton.

BERLIN, March 18 -- The lowering of interest charges on German foreign debts and the postponement of amortization payments on the principal are characterized as "inevitable necessities" by the board of the Federation of German Wholesale Trade in a statement issued after a meeting at which the present economic situation was examined.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A coalition of rebellious Democrats and Republicans in a stormy session in he House began today to tear to pieces the carefully planned revenue program of the Ways and Means Committee.

POINT BARROW, Alaska, March 18 (AP) -- Like a ghost rising up out of the ice of the Arctic Ocean, the fur-trading steamship Baychimo, missing for more than three months, was sighted today in floating ice about ten-miles off Point Barrow.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Governor Roosevelt will give a public hearing Thursday on the Cilano and Fake measures, which temper the rigid provisions of the present pistol law.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 18 -- Awards of nine wrestling and eight basket-ball letters were announced by the Cornell Athletic Association today. The baseball, track and tennis schedules for this year were also released.

KIEL, Germany, March 18 -- It is learned that Captain Friedrich Christiansen, commander of the flying boat Do-X will start soon for the United States to fly the huge craft back across the Atlantic; the plane will drop anchor here during the big regatta to be held in June.

Thirty-two communities will seek bids next week on new issues of bonds and notes aggregating $14,219,866, as asainst this week's revised total of $67,505,566. The weekly average of new offerings by States and municipalities for the year to date is $20,817,168.

Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley, sitting in extraordinary term of the Supreme Court, refused yesterday to dismiss the perjury indictment against former General Sessions Judge Francis X. Mancuso, chairman of the board of the defunct City Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The establishment of the new State of Manchuria under Japanese auspices has been attended by disturbing signs of restlessness on the part of Russia and Chinese soldiers in Manchuria, according to authentic reports here today.
The championship aspirations of Berkeley Bell in the national indoor tennis tournament came to an end yesterday in the semi-final round at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

In the first fatal accident in the Holland Vehicular Tunnel since it opened in November, 1927, one man was killed last night and two others, passengers in his car, were injured critically when the automobile crashed into the rear of a truck. New Jersey-bound traffic in the tunnel was tied up for twenty minutes as the Holland Tunnel police cleared away the wreckage and carried the injured to the hospital.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Reports in New York that the Insull utility properties in the East would be sold to the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, the United Gas Improvement Company, and Stone Webster. Inc., were denied here tonight by Samuel Insull. head of the vast utility system bearing his name.

Another witness wanted in connection with the affairs of Mayor "Walker remains unlocated after months of search by process servers for the Hofstadter legislative inquiry it was announced yesterday. He is John McKeon, motion-picture theatre executive, stock market operator and close personal friend of the Mayor.

LOS ANGELES, March 18 -- Mary Nolan and her husband, Wallace T. Macrery, who were convicted on March 9 of failing to pay the wages of employes, filed an appeal in Superior Court today setting forth nine asserted errors of judgment by the lower court and six sections of the State Labor Law that are allegedly unconstitutional.
LONDON, March 18 -- Lord Rutherford, director of Cayendish Laboratary, Cambridge University, discussing the neutron in a lecture before the Royal Institution tonight, said:

Further development of Bergen County realty by former Long Island operators was reported yesterday. The latest arrivals in New Jersey are Joseph A. Cassidy and Roger Sullivan, to whom has been transferred Crystal Lake-Forest Park, a 50-acre Summer colony in the boroughs of Franklin Lake and Oakland.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The labor record of Kenneth Mackintosh of the State of Washington, was criticized and defended today before a Senate judiciary subcommittee considering his nomination for circuit judge.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The refusal of French authorities to postpone the imposition of quota restrictions on imports of American machine tools, which in 1931 were valued at about $2,000,000 was cited in a report to the Department of Commerce today from Fayette W. Allport, American commercial attache at Paris.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 18 (AP) -- Phar Lap, giant Australian 6-year-old thoroughbred, has reached top form for the $50,000 Agua Caliente Handicap Sunday and will go into the race the favorite, although he has never run on a track east of the Pacific.

Fighting Tropical Diseases. The opening of Manson House by the Prince of WALES on St. Patrick's Day reminds us that the work begun by Dr. MANSON and carried on by RONALD Ross and others, including Colonel GORGAS, Dr. WALTER REED and Dr. LAZEAR, has made the tropics everywhere safe for white men in less than forty years of research.

Amplifying its franchise application pending before the Board of Estimate, Bus Transfers, Inc., submitted yesterday a proposal for a comprehensive Manhattan transportation system, linking buses and surface car lines into a network of ninety-four miles, predicated upon a five-cent fare and a two-cent transfer privilege.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 18 -- The Syracuse University boxing team stands in a fair way to garner the Eastern intercollegiate boxing championship as a result of its showing at the Archbold Gymnasium tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The nomination of Fred A. Bradley for a third term of four years as Collector of the Port of Buffalo was referred back to the Finance Committee by the Senate today without a dissenting vote.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Retail food prices declined 32-3 per cent in fifty-one cities during the month ended Feb. 15 and were 17 per cent below those of the corresponding date in 1931, the Labor Department announced today.

The American Tobacco Company reported yesterday net earnings for last year, after depreciation, interest and expenses for management, of $46,189,741, a new high record. This was equivalent, after payment of preferred dividends, to $9.07 a share on the 4,740,905 common and common B shares.
The National Review of London in its March issue makes the following comment on English laws against sweepstakes:

Construction of broad ornamental bridges far above Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets is planned by the Rockefeller interests to link the three blocks of the Rockefeller Centre development, it was revealed yesterday.

Judge Charles P. McClelland handed down yesterday a decision in the United States Customs Court sustaining the protest of the Amtorg Trading Corporation, the trade representative of the Soviet Government, against the levy of more than $1,000,000 in duties under anti-dumping provisions of the tariff law on importations of matches manufactured in the Soviet Union.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 18 -- The Yonkers High School basketball team, defending State Class A high school champion, registered its third consecutive victory in its section of the State scholastic tournament by eliminating Harrison High School. 29 to 17, at the Washington Irving High School gymnasium tonight to gain the Westchester County Class A title.
Henry Johnson, a suitor of Betty Gow, nursemaid to the kidnapped Lindbergh baby, was taken to Hopewell, N.J., last night for a personal interview with Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Fears that the world's wheat market would be demoralized as the result of the outlined plan of the government to start to liquidate its stock of grain accumulated through stabilization operations for several years were the dominating factor today in determining the trend of prices of that grain on the Board of Trade.

Although Gandhi may be seen in history as one of the great men of the world, in the class of Mahomet or St. Paul, his lack of constructive statesmanship made his recent visit to England in several respects a failure and left some observers still in agreement with Winston Churchill's colorful description of him as "the half-naked faquir," Robert Bernays, English journalist, writes in "Naked Faquir," published yesterday by Henry Holt.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 18 (AP) -- Two persons were wounded, several homes were dynamited and working miners and strikers were in conflict today as the strike of insurgent anthracite workers went into its fifth day.

PARIS, March 18 -- When the International Sugar Council adjourned this evening until tomorrow morning two important members admitted that, practically speaking, the Chadbourne sugar plan had collapsed. That does not mean the Chadbourne plan is going to be renounced nor that efforts to reach an agreement will be abandoned, but matters have reached such an impasse between Cuba and Java that the delegates here hold no hope of an accord now.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Secretary Hurley, upon his return from Chicago tonight, denied that he had predicted in an interview there that the Republican party would adopt a liberal plank on prohibition.

The application of creditors of the Dimon Steamship Corporation for the appointment of equity receivers of the company was granted yesterday by Judge Guy L. Fake in the United States District Court at Newark as the first step in clearing the way for the sale of the company and making possible a settlement of claims held by more than 200 individuals and corporations.

Nothing is heard any more in Massachusetts about "stopping ROOSEVELT" or "stopping SMITH." The question is -- and the Boston Anti-Noise Society may have to take it up before long -- can anybody or anything "stop CURLEY"? He howls into all microphones.

Negotiable bonds valued at $51,780, stolen on Feb. 24 in a hold-up in Morris Gottfried's wholesale tobacco shop at 286 East Tenth Street, were recovered yesterday with the arrest of three men at 80 Broadway.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., March 18 -- Long-standing complaints that social activities among the women students of Swarthmore College were limited almost entirely to sorority members has resulted in a decision, announced today, to curtail activities of the organizations for a year and to work out a plan for the participation of all women in campus social affairs.

Representatives of Paper Handlers and Sheet Straighteners Union 1 agreed yesterday to a 7 per cent wage reduction and the reduction of the working week to four days of eight hours each at a conference with the Printers' League Section of the Employing Printers' Association at 461 Eighth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Hoover called into conference at the White House late today executives of thirteen of the nation's greatest railway systems and the chairman and general counsel of the Association of Railway Executives.

BOSTON, March 18 (AP) -- Former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York, in reply to criticism that he was "inviting loss of the State to the Democratic party in November," replied today that he had not insisted that any slate of delegates be pledged to him.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., Saturday, March 19 -- The New Guard, the secret organization which warned it would not permit Premier J.T. Lang to open the $30,000,000 Sidney harbor bridge, carried out its threat today.
LONDON, March 18 -- Three Irish sweepstakes prizes, each worth more than $100,000, went to New Yorkers this afternoon when Forbra, an outsider, won the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree.

Secretary WILBUR, himself a doctor, in his address on Thursday night speculated a little about the future development of medicine and public health in the United States. The Committee on the Costs of Medical Care, of which he is chairman, has been for four years studying the present unsatisfactory conditions of providing and paying for medical service.

BERLIN, March 18 -- In connection with yesterday's raids on National Socialist quarters throughout Prussia. Captain Hermann Goering, Adolf Hitler's right-hand man, called on General Wilhelm Groener, the Federal Minister of Defense and the Interior, today and submitted a formal pledge by the Nazis of strict legality in all their actions.

After seven years without adding even one mystery novel to the everswelling flood, the Viking Press has just brought out "The Tragedy of X: A Drury Lane Mystery," by Barnaby Ross. Drury Lane, no street, is a retired Shakespearian actor with great analytical powers who lives in an Elizabethan castle up the Hudson, where he gives occasional performances of "Hamlet."

Mayor Walker is scheduled to leave the city tonight for a short vacation out of town, it became known at City Hall last night. Friends of the Mayor termed the trip a "week-end," but it was admitted that the stay probably would last at least into the middle of the coming week.

With both stocks and bonds swinging idly up and down, a market element that is avid for excitement after recent incidents found little of interest in yesterday's dull proceedings on the Stock Exchange. The gossip was of such a vague and unsatisfactory character and the actual developments of the day were so colorless that professional Wall Street approached all of the markets hesitantly and without conviction.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., March 18 -- A switch from the glare of arc lights to the glare of another brilliant California sun proved just one more baffling episode for the Giants, who today lost their second straight game to the Hollywood Stars of the Pacific Coast League, 6 to 1.

Dense smoke from a fire in the roofers' supply store of Harry Pietersen in the basement of the four-story tenement at 371 Hudson Street, between King and West Houston Streets, overcame thirteen firemen and drove six families to the street before it was put out last night.

Slight improvement in retail trade is indicated by reports gathered by Bradstreet's. This commercial agency says, upon the basis of reports from fifty-five leading cities, that the continued cold weather has influenced the trend of business more than anything else, but the effect on trade has been somewhat conflicting.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 18 -- Leading the field of 120 players by a stroke, H.G. Picard, Charleston (S.C.) pro, returned 34, 36 -- 70, one under par, for the opening eighteen holes of the Coral Gables-Miami Biltmore $10,000 open tourney over the course of the Miami Biltmore Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, D.C., March 18 -- Behind the screen which veils political manoeuvring from the eye of the voter the leaders in the two major parties are playing a game with the prohibition question. That of the Democrats is reasonably transparent; that of the Republicans much less so.

Rallying from a knockdown in the fifth round, Sammy Fuller, chunky Boston lightweight, knocked out Billy Wallace in the seventh round of a battle scheduled for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night before a crowd of 4,000.

Judge Rosalsky handed down in General Sessions yesterday a decision dismissing an indictment accusing five former officials of the defunct Profesisonal and Business Men's Credit Union, formerly at Second Avenue and Eleventh street, of willfully misapplying funds of the organization last May.

Belief that American prosperity depends upon a Republican President and a Republican Congress has been shattered completely. Governor Alhert C.
