Ritchie of Maryland, candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, declared last night in a radio speech broadcast over the Columbia coast - to - coast network.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- When the House of Representatives revolted today, with Democrats most numerous in the ranks of the rebels, the fears of far-sighted party leaders, who deplored the results of the Congressional elections and by-elections in 1930 and since, came to bitter fruition.

The Board of Estimate voted unanimous approval yesterday of the form of contract for independent operation of the new city subway system, as recently submitted and revised by the Board of Transportation, and authorized that body to advertise for operating proposals.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 18 -- Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Williams entertained tonight with a dinner at their villa, having as their guests Mr. and Mrs. Gurnee Munn, Mr. and Mrs. J. Leonard Replogle, Mr. and Mrs. John C. King, Colonel and Mrs. Barclay H. Warburton, Mr. and Mrs. Rodman Wanamaker, Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Phipps, Miss Louise M. Iselin and Charles A. Munn.

MIAMI, Fla., March 18 -- My Dandy, bearing the colors of the Reichert Brothers, won the Plaza Handicap at Tropical Park today, adding $750 to the total of more than $100,000 he has garnered in six seasons of racing.

SOMERVILLE, Mass., March 18 -- Wnen Forbra, a 50-to-1 shot, galloped home a winner in today's Grand National at Aintree, England, he became responsible for a varied assortment of pleasurable undertakings which will include the burning of a mortage in this city, the halving of a hard-working garage owner's hours of duty and the creation of a substantial donation to the work of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Michigan's radio priest.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- The question of war debts and reparations would be much nearer a solution if it were thought about in a spirit of "business and bard fact" more than in a spirit of "abstract right," Ambassador Claudel of France said in an address tonight at a dinner given in his honor by the French and Franco-American Societies of Chicago.

BOSTON, March 18 (AP) -- Supporters of the Presidential candidacy of Governor Roosevelt drew from the Republican ranks today to complete their list of candidates for delegates and alternates to the Democratic National Convention.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 18 -- The Yankees traveled some sixty miles by motor and ferry to suffer the first defeat of their Florida, exhibition schedule today at the hands of Manager Emmett McCann's swift-stepping Indianapolis team of the American Association.

SHANGHAI, March 18 (AP) -- The armies which fought so bitterly for control of Chapei and Woosung a few weeks ago shivered in the cold of a Chinese Winter while spokesmen for world powers continued seeking to negotiate a formal truce.

The Illinois delegates to the Democratic National Convention not only will not join in any "block-Roose-velt" movement but the majority of the delegation will support the New York Governor for the Democratic, nomination for President after casting a complimentary vote for Senator James Hamilton Lewis, according to Representative Adolph J. Sabath of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Legislation to authorize trade practice agreements and establish special courts to hear matters under the jurisdiction of the Federal Trade Commission was endorsed before a Senate judiciary subcommittee today by S.P. Bush, representing the Ohio Manufacturers' Association, and Norman G. Hough of the National Lime Association.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 18 -- Ray Thompson, the youthful midshipman who holds the intercollegiate record and championship at 50 yards, met with a totally unexpected setback today as the twenty-sixth annual title meet of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association opened in the Naval Academy pool.

Mayor Walker endorsed yesterday the campaign now in preparation by the Block Community Organization when he received leaders of the drive at City Hall and told them the city administration would give its full support to the movement to "stamp out want" in the city.

The annual report of the City Parliament of Community Councils of the city of New York was issued yesterday by Frank P. Beal, executive secretary, to the chairmen and representatives of the seventy-two Community Councils throughout the city.

Minority stockholders of the American Tobacco Company, who have been waging a long battle to stop the payment of bonuses or profit shares to officers of the company, won a point yesterday when Federal Judge Caffey signed a temporary injunction against the extra payment.

A discussion of the engineering problems involved in the erection of the George Washington Bridge and the showing of motion picture films prepared by the Port of New York Authority to illustrate construction methods used on the suspension span featured the March luncheon meeting of the New York Building Congress yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 18 -- With the opening of the championship season three weeks away, Manager Max Carey faces the possibility of shifting his newly arranged infield to cover the absence of Del Bissonette.

HONOLULU, March 18 -- Since the visit to Hawaii of Seth Richardson, Assistant Attorney General, to investigate political and social conditions, it has been possible to determine some of the points of view which must have been presented to him.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 18 -- Nearly 300 couples attended the annual junior promenade of Princeton University tonight, which climaxed the Winter social season here. The dancing, which was started at 10 o'clock, was scheduled to continue until 4 in the morning.

Net income of the National Dairy Products Corporation for 1931 was $22,547,973 after interest, depreciation and all taxes. This was equivalent after payment of preferred dividends to $3.47 a share on 6,263,150 common shares outstanding at the end of the year.

Realty activity in Manhattan yesterday was confined almost entirely to the section below Fourteenth Street. The day's trading consisted largely of leasehold deals. A few transactions in the Bronx and Brooklyn were announced.

Sagging of Electric Bond and Share issues and reflected weakness in the list generally characterized the price trend on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday. Trading in stocks increased substantially in volume. Prices of domestic bonds also declined, while foreign obligations were mixed.

Unless the wholesale cleaners and dyers agree to renew the present agreement by Monday the Cleaning and Dye House Drivers' Union will take steps to paralyze the industry on April 1 by tying up 25,000 retail tailor shops throughout the metropolitan area, it was announced yesterday by Jacob Effrat, business manager of the union.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Asserting that effective railroad consolidation is not possible under present laws, H.B. Heiserman, vice president and general counsel of the Pennsylvania Railroad, today urged Congress to permit the railroads to proceed with their own consolidation plans or to enact broad consolidation legislation depriving State governments of their power to approve such unifications.

Cosmo Hamilton, playwright, and the Rev. Dr. Robert Norwood, rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, were the principal speakers last night at the graduation exercises of the Feagin School of Dramatic Art, 316 West Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Profits of the great packing houses have become so small that their power to dominate the food industry has disappeared, according to statements made before the Supreme Court today by Frank L. Hogan, counsel for Swift Co., Armour Co., Wilson Co. and the Cudahy Company.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, March 19 -- Although Tokyo has announced it will propose amendments to the tentative armistice terms arranged here Monday, Quo Tai-chi, Vice Foreign Minister of China, had not been officially informed of the proposals last night.

Prices of domestic bonds sagged yesterday on the Stock Exchange In the slowest five-hour tracing period in more than six months. Railroad issues, as a group lost considerable ground, while utility and industrial bonds were easier in the order named.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 18 -- South Side of Newark and Trenton High gained the final round in the Class A high school division of the fourteenth annual New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association basketball tournament by triumphing at Convention Hall tonight in semifinal contests.

THE great French exhibition at Burlington House has doubtless been responsible. Indirectly when not directly, for the present flood of books dealing with French art, especially French painting. Though there is no specific reference to the Burlington House show in either Mr. Wilenski's history or Mr. Underwood's, it is likely that their appearance on the market was timed roughly to coincide with the outstanding event in London.

TENNEY FRANK, who is Professor of Latin in Johns Hopkins University, has written with learning and wisdom much about ancient Rome and her people. In this little book there may be found an admirable account of certain phases and developments of Roman civilization.

The decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission as to the price which the New York Central Railroad should pay for acquisition of the Boyne City, Gaylord Alpena Railroad was interpreted yesterday in railroad circles as an indication that the current downward trend in prices of materials, together with the financial condition of the major carriers, might cause minimum considerations to be paid in consolidations of short lines with larger systems.

Latin-American credit and collection conditions have improved since the first of this year, according to the quarterly survey released yesterday by the foreign department of the National Association of Credit Men. Credit gains are reported from twelve countries, William S. Swingle, director of the foreign department points out.

BERLIN, March 19. -- A sweeping reconstruction scheme for the two leading German shipping lines, the Hamburg-American and the North German Lloyd, which have successfully weathered the storms of past years but as a result of the rapid decline in world trade in recent months have threatened to succumb, was announced today.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Latham Clarke of the Park Lane are at the Hotel Claridge. Atlantic City. They will return to New York before Easter.

Declaring that many of the traditional functions of the home have been delegated to various external agencies, including the school, Mrs. Sidonie Matsner Gruenberg, director of the Child Study Association of America, warned teachers yesterday against assuming that family life is static, and urged them to strike a balance between extreme points of view in training children for a new age.

Two men entered the branch haberdashery of Joseph Hilton Sons, on the southwest corner of Thirty-sixth Street and Broadway, shortly after 9 o'clock last night, drew pistols and herded more than two score customers and clerks into the basement.

LONDON. March 19. -- David Lloyd George has written a book entitled "The Truth About Reparations and War Debts" which will be published here on Monday by Heinemann, and in the United States by Doubleday, Doran Co. as soon as the copies can be run off the press.

REVIVAL, of portraiture Some one used this expression the other day with apparent confidence in its significance. But when has there been a decline in the art of perpetuating our physical aspect? Ebb and flow, certainly, but never any danger of dying out of the world's art.

BRICKS and blocks of wood, how inert they seem! Dead matter. But not to the physicist. He reduces them in imagination to molecules, atoms, electrons, all engaged in a mad dance. Electrons dance in atoms, atoms dance in molecules, and molecules dance in space.

FEBRUARY shipments of Chrysler, Dodge, De Soto and Plymouth cars to dealers were 36 per cent in excess of January shipments, according to B. E. Hutchinson, vice president and treasurer of the Chrysler Corporation. During the first two months of this year shipments were 101 per cent of the same period of 1931, it is said.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., March 19. -- Representatives of the Bayville Aquatic Club won the interclub five-man team shoot over the traps of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today. Bayville compiled a total of 447 out of a possible 500 targets. The Nassau Trapshooting Club finished second with 403, and the home organization next with 375.

THE annual bridge party and tea for the benefit of the Children's Health Service maintained by the New York Diet Kitchen Association will be held on the afternoon of April 5 in the small ballroom of the Plaza. The entertainment already has aroused much interest and many tables have been taken.

DR. LAURENCE M. GOULD, who was second in command of the Byrd Antarctic expedition and who figured as one of the six explorers in the motion picture, "Explorers of the World," expects to leave early this week for the Carlsbad Caverns, in New Mexico, at the head of a camera expedition which will plunge into the tantalizing depths of these subterranean catacombs in search of a motion picture.

One hundred years ago next Tuesday Johann Wolfgang van Goethe called for "more light" -- and died. The centenary of this greatest of German poets is being observed all over the civilized world. A peculiar flavor is given to these observances by the fact that Goethe, one of the great literary figures of all time, has an important place in the modern world.

AMID the plans for transatlantic airplane lines, to use either the northern islands and Canada or the Bermuda-Azores route involving longer water jumps but more clement weather conditions, which are publicly discussed from time to time, studies involving a chain of man-made islands for landing fields have been prosecuted vigorously by E. R. Armstrong, inventor of the seadrome, and his associates.

The world's amateur championship at 18.2 balkline billiards will start Wednesday night at 8:30 o'clock at the New York Elks Club, 108 West Forty-third Street, with a field of nine in competition. The entries consist of seven foreign players headed by Albert Poenssen of Germany, who will be the defending titleholder, and two American contestants.

BOSTON, March 19. -- Colonel John F. Osborn, retired, of the Massachusetts National Guard, died today at the Soldiers' Home Hospital in Chelsea after a brief illness. Colonel Osborn, a graduate of Harvard, had been active in the National Guard and the United States Army from 1897 until placed on the retired list with the rank of Colonel in 1927.

BOSTON, March 19. Led by Miss Lisa Lindstrom, member of the 1928 American Olympic team, the New York University Women's Swimming team defeated the Posse Nissen School, 30 to 18, in the university club pool today.

LONDON. BRITAIN'S Houses of Parliament are undergoing repairs which, it is estimated, will cost nearly $5,000.000. Incidentally they are having the first "bath" they have had since they were rebuilt in 184O-47 after having been almost totally destroyed by fire in 1834.

WE have just visited El Dorado, and explored its recesses for clues to the legend that has haunted the world for centuries, and to the people of the fabled land -- a race that disappeared abruptly after the arrival of the Spaniards four hundred years ago.

Miss Audrey Peppe, brilliant little skater who, at 14 years of age, represented the United States in the recent Olympic Winter games at Lake Placid as a member of the figureskating team, and Robin Lee, 12-year-old holder of the boys' State championship of Minnesota, held the centre of the stage yesterday afternoon as the national junior figure skating championships got under way at the Ice Club at Madison Square Garden.

AIKEN. -- The biggest event of the coming week in Aiken will be the annual Southern Cross tournament at the Palmetto Golf Club. The Southern Cross Cup is the most coveted of all the trophies annually played for at the club, and the tournament for it is the only one of the annual series there that is not by handicap play.

Playing inspired polo, the Pennsylvaina Military College learn turned back the Optimists at the Squadron A Armory last night. 18 to 9. The collegians were granted a handicap of 9 goals, so that they really held the Optimists even on the flat and scored an impressive victory wih the aid of their handicap.

DETROIT. GREAT things are expected by automobile industry executives from the combination of Spring and the new Ford. The latter is counted upon to awaken a nationwide interest in automobiles generally and the whole industry is preparing to take advantage of it.

DURING the Victorian era the melodrama of history was a duel to the death between two saints. "Chinese" Gordon, absorbed in his Bible, and the Mahdi Mohammed Ahmed, reciting his Koran, fought for the lordship over the Soudan.

THE latest chapter in the history of Manchuria is in large part a chapter in the history of the soya bean. Like Jack, who climbed to the clouds on the stalk of the bean he had planted, the Japanese-sponsored Henry Puyi may be said to have risen to the dictatorship of the new Manchurian State, Manchoukuo, by virtue of a magical legume.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 19 (AP). -- Spring racing dates for Lexington and Latonia were awarded and a reduction in the daily purse average for Kentucky tracks was approved at a meeting today of the newly-appointed State Racing Commission.

THIS book contains history treated as a novel. The author follows the public records and permits himself no liberties with doctored events. Professor Sidney B. Fay reminds the reader in a foreword that much of the material used in the book has been obtained from official documents.

IN an effort to present "the best testimony available to the economic state of the nation," Mr. Crowther has assembled the views of twenty-one American business men. The list includes Myron C. Taylor of the United States Steel Corporation.
Mayor Walker left the city at 5:50 yesterday afternoon for a short vacation in Hot Springs, Va., where he expects to arrive this morning.

LONDON, March 19. -- Canadian boy marksmen won the King's trophy for miniature rifle shooting, competed for by 33,000 boys in all parts of the empire, it was announced today by the National Rifle Association.

Calls issued last week for bonds to be redeemed this month before their maturity dates provided for retirements in part of foreign issues and miscellaneous improvement loans of several municipalities. The month's total is now $11,110,000, compared with $36,170,000 in February, and $88,563,000 in March, 1931, at corresponding dates.

LISBON, March 2. -- Speaking for the government, the Minister of the Interior revealed recently at a meeting of civil governors of the various cities that it is the intention of the military dictatorship to create a new Constitution for the republic which will provide for election of the President by a direct vote of the people.

IN an effort to assist radio listener in paining as much as possible from lectures on the air, the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education points out that nearly every one can improve his ability to remember by putting into practice certain psychological laws of learning.

MODERN man boasts that he lives by science and reason and has put behind him superstition and magic. Whether this is true or an idle boast, science and reason are now the ideal and superstition and magic are set down as ugly words, carrying with them slanderous implications.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- The wheat market felt today the full effect of the announcement that the Federal Farm Board planned to sell abroad its holdings of grain, and while the latest version of the proposed sale was somewhat different from that given to the trade, yesterday it had relatively little effect in checking the liquidation and demoralization that prevailed.

THIRTY-FOUR years ago last month, while the cry, "Remember the Maine," echoed through the country, a dynamic, aggressive Assistant Secretary of the Navy sent this cablegram to Admiral Dewey at Hongkong: "In the event of declaration of war Spain, your duty will be to see that the Spanish Squadron does not leave the Asiatic coast, and then offensive operations in Philippines."

There will be lull for the next two weeks in the various P.S.A.L. tournaments now in progress, because of the Easter vacation period, which will start in the city's public school ranks on Thursday and continue until Monday, April 4.

THERE are enough able orchestral musicians out of work in this city to form at least four fine symphony orchestras, declared Sandor Harmati last week after holding auditions for the selection of the 200 men who will make up the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra.

BERLIN. THIS is a week for the stars. All the pictures that have come out within the last few days have been built around well-established screen personalities: Conrad Veidt, Lilian Harvey, Curt Bois and Gustav Froehlich.

VANCOUVER, B. C., March 17. -- Almost due west of Stewart which nestles among the mountains at the end of the appendix-like Portland Canal that separates Alaska from British Columbia lies the valley of the Ingenika. Immediately south is the country drained by the Omineca.

Supporters of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Democratic Presidential nomination have determined definitely to oppose the selection of Jouett Shouse, national executive chairman, as temporary chairman of the national convention, it was learned yesterday.

Except for a marked recovery in all Electric Bond and Share issues, trading in stocks on the New York Curb Exchange in yesterday's short session was uneventful. There were some rallies in recent weak spots in the domestic bond list, while foreign obligations were mixed at the close.
LONDON, March 19. -- For the ninth year in succession the Cambridge University crew flashed to victory on the Thames today, Oxford finishing five lengths behind.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 19. -- The Army gymnastic team defeated M.I.T., 30 to 24, and Springfield College defeated M.I.T., 28 to 26, in a double header at the Walker Memorial Gymnasium today.

MODERN ideas in child training are definitely influencing furnishings for children's rooms. Emphasis is placed on decorative design that will appeal to youngsters rather than to their parents, and the age and interests of children are considered in choosing their furnishings and accessories.

AT any rate as this department views it, one of the most significant achievements in the career of Ivar Kreuger, who committed suicide March 12, was the beautiful building in Stockholm that houses the Swedish Match Company's head office.

Even the most insensitive to the drift of public opinion must be aware of a great change in the national attitude toward prohibition. There is a new mentality about it. This is really more important than the recent accumulscion of significant events. They have merely reflected and reinforced the general impression.

CHICAGO, March 17. -- Despite the fact that Chicago in recent months has had more than its fair share of bank, failures -- some of them scandalous -- and that a circuit court judge, as candidate for State's Attorney on the Republican ticket, has been daily assailing bankers in a demagogic campaign, this city has a banker who is being talked about as a possible nominee of the Democratic party for the office of President.

An exhibition of Egyptian, Greek and Roman antiques, including glass, bronzes, faience, rare jewelry and other objects collected by Azeez Khayat of Palestine, Egypt and New York, will open today and continue for the next two weeks at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., where the items will be sold during that period.
The Council of the American Library Association. 520 North Michigan Avenue. Chicago, Ill., has adopted the following timely resolution:

LONDON, March 19. -- British Government funds today continued their remarkable progress of the past few days, but other sections of the Stock Exchange were dull on fears or further liquidation from the Continent.

It is hardly an exaggeration to say that the attention of most turf followers throughout the world will be turned toward Agua Caliente in Mexico today when the famous Australian champion Phar Lap will race a mile and a quarter in a strange land and under alien conditions against keep competition for the $50,000 prize of the Agua Caliente Handicap.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The thirtieth United North and South open golf championship tournament will be the outstanding event next week of Pinehurst's program. Others will be a race meeting of the Pinehurst Matinee Club, three games between teams of the Sand Hills Polo Club, an archery tournament, a trapshoot, a women's rifle competition, and golf tournaments of the Tin Whistles and Silver Foils societies.

Three weeks have passed since President Hoover on Feb. 27 signed the Glass-Steagall bill liberalizing the discount and note-issue provisions of the Federal Reserve act, a measure which had been rushed through Congress, but none of the privileges bestowed by the law upon the central banking system and its members has been exercised yet.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I hear a great many writers talking about the interview of Mr. Orr in THE TIMES and all say the same thing. It was interesting but it was also true. He gave the picture viewpoint all right, all right.

A full meeting of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, charged with the expenditure of $20,000,000 in State and local funds for unemployment relief during the Winter, has been called in Albany for Tuesday. It was reported yesterday that the resignation of Jesse Isidor Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., as chairman of the relief administration, would be handed to the Governor then.

CHATTANOOGA, March 17. -- Efforts of the Tennessee Legislature to pass on to automobile owners the burden of wiping out the enormous deficit have developed into a boomerang which has floated back around the necks of the officials and bids fair to increase instead of eliminate the pressure.

BOSTON, March 17. -- This is the open, season for town meetings in New England, that annual demonstration of pure democracy which is one of the most treasured institutions of the land of the Pilgrims and the Puritans. From the far northern hills of Vermont and New Hampshire to the sandy reaches of Cape Cod and the suave stretches along the Sound, the towns these recent weeks have been busy with their affairs of State.

To the Dramatic Editor: I have observed that the allegations of Representative Sirovich anent the destructive attitude of the New York dramatic critics are at best rather hazy. As a lawyer, I believe that the member of Congress knows that in making out a case the complaint must be very specific: nothing must be left to the imagination.

IN the British scientific weekly Nature Dr. James Chadwick tells us more about his discovery of the neutron. Rays of neutrons are emitted not only by beryllium when It is bombarded by alpha particles (helium nuclei) from polonium, a radioactive element, but also by hydrogen, helium, lithium, carbon, air and argon.

NEW ROCHKLLF, N.Y., March 19. -- As the result of threats by the Chamber of Commerce, the newly organized Citizens' Protective Association and the Citizens New Charter League to bring legal action against the city budget for 1932 should it have been adopted as proposed without there first having been published a comparative budget table, the new City Administration has decided to hold a second public hearing on the budget on March 28.
WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Unable to check the revolt in both parties against the tax bill, leaders summarily adjourned the House early this afternoon to prevent further emasculation of the measure.

CHICAGO, March 19 (AP). -- Vice President Fred Uhlman of the Chicago Board of Trade said today regarding announcement from Washington that the Farm Board was trying to arrange credits for wheat sales:

OTTAWA, Ont., March 19 (Canadian Press). -- The Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today that a more confident attitude regarding the future of business was in evidence during the latter part of February, owing to financial developments. These included an increase of $8,200,000 in notice deposits on Jan. 33.

ABAULEROS DE LA CAPA ia a, new society in Spain that seeks to get men to wear capes as of old. Romantic in intent, recalling ceremonious times, it is not a movement that would have been expected to develop among the severities and utilitarianisms of the young republic.

CONSTRUCTIVE action and energy are needed to meet the situation which confronts music and musicians today in this country and over the whole world. To consider the purely human and therefore fundamentally important issue first is to realize that musicians by the thousands and tens of thousands are now without employment and in dire need.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. AUGUSTA IN THE PACIFIC, March 19. -- The United States fleet with its 140 ships was headed for San Pedro and San Diego Harbors tonight. The navy's annual war game, one of the longest and most extensive battle problems ever held, ended last night in a thick fog off San Francisco.

PARIS, March 19. -- Despite the check which the plan for a Danubian tariff union received from Germany. Premier Tardieu has decided to ask for a meeting in Geneva on April 15 of the representatives of Great Britain, Germany, France and Italy to consider means to bring the preferential bloc into existence.

Cautious selling was continued on the Stock Exchange yesterday, but there was no acute weakness in any part of the list. The total turnover was only about 800,000 shares; the composite averages showed a net loss of 46 cents. It might even be said that the day's movement ushered out an extremely dull week of trading, relieved only by the spectacular reaction, on Monday resulting from the Kreuger suicide.

TORONTO, Ont., March 19. -- Mineral production in Ontario in 1931 made a total of 595,272,332, a decline of 518.369,136 from the output in 1930 and the lowest total since 1927, according to the preliminary report of the Provincial Department of Mines. Metallic production, at $"2,950,799, was off $10,405,566, or 12.3 per cent, in value from the preceding year, the decline being traceable to lower output of nickel, copper and silver.

BARCELONA, March 6. -- How deeply the Syndicalist-Anarchistic doctrine that the worker is the master of property has taken root among the working classes of Spain, has been strikingly, if somewhat pathetically, illustrated here recently. The Syndicalists, who are identical with Anarchists, have been busy for fifteen years trying to implant this doctrine in Spain.

THOUSANDS of men and women apply to the key stations of the radio networks for the position of announcer. Few are chosen. In fact, a simple test eliminated 750 applicants at WABC before they saw much of the microphone. Only six new announcers were selected by the Columbia System from 1,000 applicants in 1931.

PARIS, March 18. -- These are days of jumpy nerves for France, politically and financially speaking. The reaction to everything important happening these days is quite the reverse of the recent calm, showing how ragged are the nerves and how critical the times.

LONE COWBOY" and some of the other writings of Will James, the author-artist-cowboy, will be brought to the screen by Paramount as the result of a contract signed with Mr. James last week. "Lone Cowboy" will be produced first. A newcomer to films, Randolph Scott, will have the leading role.

LOC HOLTZ'S VAUDEVILLE-REVUE -- Tomorrow afternoon at the Hollywood Theatre. For the second edition of his popular-priced jollifications. Dr. Holtz unfurls a banner bearing the names of Harry Richman, Mitzi Mayfair and Hal Le Roy (to pick only three from the latest "Follies"), along with those of Irving Aaronson and his Commanders, Lyda Roberts, Norman Frescott, Gloria Grafton, Benny Baker, Larry Adler, Sammy Fain and "Ben Eernie's Sepia Nephews."

Evidence is abundant that the situation in Europe is about due to enter on a period of large improvement. These signs come from the three great countries upon whose action Old World progress, both economic and political, depends. Great Britain, France and Germany, all three, appear ready to make a real effort toward the accommodation of interests the continued conflict of which would make recovery impossible.

The Princeton rugby team opened its season successfully yesterday by defeating the French Sporting Club, 5 to 4, at the Gas Companies Field, Astoria. in a fast and interesting game in which the excellent kicking of both sides was the outstanding feature.

PALM BEACH. -- With the arrival of Holy Week, activities in the colony are having their usual lull and the many remaining for March are anticipating a temporary release from busy days. No sports tournaments and only a few social affairs are planned, with dates for the remaining cultural events to complete the Winter set ahead for next week.

Another new unit of the fleet which the United Fruit Company plans to build for its combined passenger and freight traffic will arrive in New York today to be made ready for her maiden trip. The liner Chiriqui is on the way from the yard of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company to Pier 3, North River, where she will be tied up until Thursday.

Is the use of "poison" gas in war effective, and should it be condemned as inhuman? The debate goes on. Representative COLLINS of Mississippi, who advocates reduction of the military services, said recently in Congress that chemical warfare has more in its favor than any other weapon, and that "by the "exploitation of mustard gas it would "be possible to immobilize an army."

The steel plant construction program of the Soviet Five-Year Plan is only slightly behind schedule, according to Authur L. Collette of Long Beach, Cal., and Herbert C. McAdams of Mehane, N.C., American engineers who returned last Wednesday from Russia where they supervised the construction of some of these plants.

COREY FRICK, hired by a detective agency to guard Danforth, the crooked financier, remarked that it was a fine night for a murder, and so it was. Frick might have added that the place was as appropriate as the time, which would have been equally true.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is unfortunate that the Baptist ministers' conference of Philadelphia recently made a pronouncement on economic conditions at a time when our President and the best minds in the nation are making herculean efforts to bring hack prosperity and save our country from ruin.

"A voice is singing 'The Palms,'" Joanna said; "I'm going to find" -- Before I could answer, she went And after her, down the stairway, I, too, sped, For the halls of the old apartment house were rent,

The champion is pounded by his powerful and aggressive young challenger and finally is dropped by a crushing right to the jaw. He gets up, rallies momentarily, but sinks to the canvas again under the impact of his opponent's fist.

MANAGUA, March 3. -- Since the destruction of Managua by the earthquake of March 31, 1931, great efforts have been made to get the city back to normal, but owing to scarcity of government and private funds not a great deal has been accomplished in the matter of the actual reconstruction of the city itself.

BANGOR, Me., March 19. -- A great wave of economy is sweeping over rural Maine this month. Town meetings are held in March because in this month the farmers have plenty of time to sit around and argue. The economy is compulsory, for taxes are hard to collect and it is not safe for any town to arrange to spend money that it is not likely to get.

The Board of Transportation yesterday set April 26 as the time limit for the filing of proposals for Independent operation of the new city subway system under the form of contract approved by the Board of Estimate on Friday. The contract form will be extensively advertised during the next thirty days.

THERE was a day when actors and producers would have nothing to do with radio. some one sounded a warning that broadcasting, which carried entertainment direct to the home, was a menace to the theatre. It would keep people at the fireside.

William Devereaux, James Madison High School's fencing captain, triumphed in the annual interscholastic foils competition, which was staged under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America at the Fencers Club yesterday. The 17-year-old foilsman captured the gold medal in a field of thirty-four competitors.

LA PAZ, March 19. -- According to figures just issued by the National Statistical Bureau, the foreign debt of Bolivia previous to the fixing of the new exchange rates totaled $61,724,000, which at 2.90 bolivianos to the dollar amounts to 178,999,600 bolivianos, to which must be added u152,925 in connection with obligations with the South American Mining Company, making an additional 2,038,955 bolivianos.

IN an effort to bring about the location and marking of routes through New York City, the New York Automobile Club has surveyed and designated certain streets and avenues as direct lines of travel for motorists driving into and out of the metropolis.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Senator Borah was asked to intercede with Attorney General Mitchell to obtain protection for citizens of Chicago from threatened control of the primary election there by the gangster element, in a telegram received today from Richard Prendergast of the University Club, Chicago.

Portugal Cleans House. In a recent broadcast THE NEW YORK TIMES was quoted as stating that the late John Philip Sousa was of Spanish origin. John Philip Sousa's grandfather was born in Portugal, and was exiled from that country during the revolution in 1822.

CLEVELAND, March 19 (AP). -- St. Louis has made the greatest advance of all cities investigated in improving atmospheric conditions by the elimination of smoke and dust, engineers attending an air conditioning conference here were told today by Howard C. Murphy of Louisville.

LIKE a swift breath of fresh wind out of the north from which it comes is the Scandinavian novel. "Two Living and One Dead." by Sigurd Christiansen, a Norwegian author now for the first time brought to the attention of English readers.

This is Mr. LLOYD GEORGE'S forty-second year in the House of Commons. What would it be without him? The present mighty batch of young Conservatives In it will be indebted to him. for a sound training in all parliamentary arts. What other foeman worthy of his steel can Mr. WINSTON CHURCHILL find? The old Liberal chief has lost most of his tribe.

THE NEW TORK TIMES weekly index of business activity shows a slight decline for the week ended March 12 and again makes a new low. The rate of decline, however, continues to be slow, as has been the case for the last few weeks. The preliminary index is 60.1, as against 60.4 for the preceding week and 77.5 for the corresponding week last year.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The number of contested wills of Mrs. Mildred McLean Dewey, widow of Admiral George Dewey, the hero of Manila Bay, filed in the District Supreme Court was increased to five yesterday when a will dated August 8. 1916, executed before the Admiral's death, was presented.

ST. PAUL, March 19 (AP). -- Minnesota Republicans refused today to modify the party's attitude on prohibition, defeating a proposed plank calling for a national referendum. The convention, however, did not readopt its previous position endorsing the Eighteenth Amendment and urging enforcement through the Federal Government, but instead approved a proposal of the platform committee which admittedly could be construed as neither "wet nor intensively dry."

TOKYO, March 19. -- Ejiro Miyoshi, a former Diet member, has been detained by police in connection with a political and industrial scandal centring around tax evasions by the Meiji Sugar Company on a colossal scale and subsequent blackmailing of the company by persons who knew of them.

The war-against-depression campaign of the American Legion and associated organizations reported yesterday that 275,593 persons had been taken out of the ranks of the jobless since the drive started on Feb. 15. The other organizations engaged in the task of finding 1,000,000 jobs are the American Federation of Labor, the Legion Auxiliary and the Association of National Advertisers.

AFTER weathering two years of "sturm und drang" The Colophon emerges as fresh, colorful and immaculate as always. This happy collaboration of writers, artists and printers has come to be regarded as the bright spot on the collector's horizon, and its appearances are looked forward to by subscribers with the alert consciousness of a child awaiting the arrival of his Christmas package.

The Bronx Hockey Club overwhelmed the New York Athletic Club at the New York Coliseum last night, winning the fastest-scoring game of the Metropolitan Amateur League season by a score of 11 to 3. The going was rough, and thirteen minor penalties and one major were imposed by the referee.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 19. -- Paul Heston of Washington defended his singles title successfully against James Kenny of Palm Beach on the courts of the Palm Beach Tennis Club today, then went on to win, with George Agutter of Forest Hills, L.I., the doubles for the Southern professional title, defeating Ed Faulkner, of Boca Raton, Fla., and Robert Murray of Forest Hills, L.I.

TAMPA, Fla., March 19.-- A ninth-inning outbreak of Yankee batting today after eight torpid innings did not last long enough to retrieve the battle the Cincinnati Reds scoring a 4-to-3 victory at Plant Field.
NORFOLK, Va., March 19 (AP). -- The little schooner Granville R. Bacon, unreported since she left Charleston, S. C., Feb. 26, with a cargo of lumber for New York, was reported safe today.

The anticipated speeding up of business at retail, which would be timely considering the early Easter, has failed to materialize, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The budget may be balanced when a tax bill is finally put through Congress. But the bill itself is sadly out of balance, since a combination of Democrats and Progressive Republicans, aided by a smaller number of regular Republicans, smashed its symmetry Friday with the axe of amendment.

SOUTH PORCUPINE, Ont., March 19. -- After three nights and two days of isolation, facing bitterly cold weather and occasional snowstorms, without food, seven men who started by air from Oshawa to Timmins on Wednesday were found today near the wreckage of their plane by one of the half dozen searching aviators who have been pressing the hunt since yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 19 (AP). -- Richard Prendergast has long been active in Chicago politics, but he has not held a major office.

CHICAGO, March 18. -- The new Graduate Education Building of the University of "Chicago, just opened, is in many respects unique, according to Dr. Charles H. Judd, dean of the School of Education. Erected with part of a grant of $1,500,000 given by the General Education Board for the scientific study of educational problems, it makes available for the work an unusually complete and carefully organized array of facilities.

CHICAGO, March 18. THE bottom has dropped out of theatrical affairs in this vicinity with a dull, Lenten thud, and Congressman Sirovich's prophecies of doom seem on the verge of fulfillment. To illustrate:

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 19 (AP). -- General Candido Rondon, for many years an authority on the vast jungle land of Inner Brazil, was asked by British officials today to help them verify the story of a trapper that Colonel P. H. Fawcett is alive after having been missing for seven years.

LONDON, March 19. -- On the eve of the momentous Moslem conference at Lahore which may result in a Moslem boycott of the round-table conference, the British Government today reaffirmed its intention to settle the communal problem by itself, if necessary.
CHICAGO, March 19. -- Poetry: A Magazine of Verse is faced with suspension with the publication Monday of its April number.

A bust of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, the centennial of whose death on March 22,1832, is being observed throughout the world, stood on the stage at Carnegie Hall last night while distinguished American and European scholars paid tribute to the "greatest of German poets" before a capacity audience.

The economic importance of a college education is going to decrease in the future, for the number of college graduates is increasing faster than the demand for them, Dr. Harvey N Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, declared yesterday at the eighth annual luncheon of science teachers and research investigators of the metropolitan district.

AN exhibition of the eight student industries conducted at Berea College, the institution in Kentucky that educates mountain boys and girls and trains them in handicraft, will be held at the Roosevelt for a fortnight, beginning tomorrow. Woodcraft, wrought iron work, dairy and bakery products, hand-weaving, sewing, homespuns, printing, toys, knickknacks and a variety of other articles will be on view, all the work of the students.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- Major bank failures in the Middle West have been halted, according to figures released today. Support of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the citizens' reconstruction campaign are credited with bringing this about.

LONDON. THE production of a new book by H. G. Wells could not be other than a major event of the literary year. "The Work, Wealth and Happiness of Mankind," now appearing in England some weeks after its publication in the United States, has accordingly occasioned many columns of press notices.
The Kabalan Company, Inc., sold yesterday the twenty-seven-family apartment house at 11-15 Gardner Avenue, Jersey City, assessed at $95,000, to Nalabak Realty Company, Inc., of Wood-Ridge.

CHICAGO, March 18. -- The contribution of the Chicago Board of Education to the Century of Progress Exposition, to be held next year, will be a building designed to show the latest developments in school organization and lay-out. That it will represent the latest has been assured by the Chicago architects in submitting their original designs to twenty-nine leading American school building planners and architects, many of whom made suggestions that will be incorporated.

IN recent years the fashion parade on the Boardwalk at Atlantic City on Easter Sunday has attracted thousands of visitors. The proximity of this resort to both Philadelphia and New York draws large number of visitors from these two cities, a considerable percentage of whom travel to Atlantic City by motor car.

The campaign to get out 50,000,000 votes in the forthcoming Presidential election as part of the Washington Bicentennial is being conducted on a non-partisan basis by the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce, according to Harlan Stuart Miller, chairman of the committee in charge of the drive.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 19. -- Churning the pale blue waters of the Naval Academy pool into white-flecked foam, Walter Spence of Rutgers romped off with two titles as the twenty-sixth annual championship meet of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association came to a close today.

To the Dramatic Editor: It has been noticed by this theatregoer, and by many of his friends, that, theatres housing worth-while productions which are not in the "smash-hit" class are doing a good orchestra business, and the balcony trade simply "isn't."

A PROGRAM of Russian opera sponsored by the Russian Opera Foundation, of which Walter Leighton Clark is president, will be given at the Mecca Temple the week of March 28. "Le Coq d'Or," "Boris Godunoff," and "Kovanchina" will be presented.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended March 12 were less than those of the preceding week and were 26 per cent under those of the corresponding week last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

HAVANA. -- With the continued arrival each week of excursion vessels bringing hundreds of Spring vacationists to Havana, and the arrival of many special delegations, activities in tourist centres of the Cuban capital have in no way abated.

The swimming teams of George Washington and Evander Childs High Schools continued to share first place in the tournament for the senior high school championship of the Public School Athletic League. Manhattan-Bronx division, by winning their engagements in the former's T-foot pool yesterday.

THE broadcasters have developed a radio-weather almanac. When they consider a transatlantic program they first consult the oracle to determine how atmospheric conditions are likely to be on that day. It is the engineers of the National Broadcasting Company, who after several years of observations have correlated all the weather data into a broadcaster's guide.
THE happiest faces of grown-ups seen in London are the faces of the country parsons, their wives and their gardeners, who come up every year to the Chelsea Flower Show.

VIENNA, March 17. -- Nowhere outside of Germany are the results of the German Presidential election more immediately interesting and significant than in Eastern Europe where 11,000,000 Germans live. One reason for this interest lies in the steady growth of Hitlerism, or the nationalistic Fascist movement, roughly corresponding to it, from Germany's southern borders right down to the Aegean Sea.

The annual alumni dance of Webb Institute of Naval Architecture was held last night at the institute under the auspices of the student body. It brought out a large attendance of graduates. The ballroom and halls were decorated with Spring flowers in shades of brown, orange and apricot.

A PLAN cailling for credits amounting to 30,000,000 francs has been forwarded by the French Minister of Public Instruction, Mario Rouston, to the Administration of Fine Arts. This sum, if passed, will be used for the relief of many branches of the arts in France, both in Paris and the provinces.

ANNAPOLIS. Md.. March 19. -- Losing three of four saber matches, the Columbia University fencers were dafcated by Navy tonight, 9 to 8. The visitors started strongly, enpturing five of the nine foil bouts and breaking even with the epee.

An unequivocal stand for unemployment insurance that will function without government subsidies was taken yesterday by Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland in an address at the National Democratic Club, Thirty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue.

MEN and women whose names have appeared in newspaper headlines in various parts of the world constantly are arriving in Hollywood to join the large group of former stars of the stage and screen who earn a living as atmosphere or extra players in motion pictures.

THERE is real poetry to be found in the little voulme, "Middle Earth" by Gamel Woolsey. And by that is meant that on nearly every page, in nearly every one of the twoscore pieces, will be felt the presence of that poetic sensibility, lacking which, lines metrically placed formmerely verse.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 19. -- Eleven thoroughbreds, on edge for the $50,000 Agua Calionte Handicap tomorrow, were named through the entry box at $500 each today and the drawing for post positions was made.

AT his last appearance here with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra Ottorino Respighi will this afternoon conduct in the Brooklyn Academy of Music compositions of his own that have not appeared on his previous programs here. These are "The Matins of Santa Chiara," the "Belfagor" overture and the "Roman Festivals."

A discussion based on the general topic, "America's Responsibility in World Affairs" will be held on 'Wednesday at the American Woman's Association clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street. It is expected that 25,000 women, members of seven major organizations, will be represented at the two sessions of the World Affairs Institute.

One touch of reality in a school project is enough not only to make pupils and teacher kin, but to set the pupils agog and keep enthusiasm at fever pitch from beginning to end, according to the experience of the Hibernia School of Hibernia, N.J. The village, it was discovered by the young principal, Thomas F. Baliman, had no written history.
HERE is the list of shows, gimcracks and novelties which have served notice of their intention to come to town Easter week, which would be the week beyond this:

Flemington High School, on Friday evening, won the Hunterdon County (N. J.) finals in the National Oratorical Contest being sponsored in the local region by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The event was the first of the district championships to be held in the 1932 competition and signalized the opening of the interscholastic elimination round.

LONDON, March 17. -- Since the appeal of Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw in September, it is estimated that the number of Britons traveling abroad has declined by 80 per cent. The "Winter in Britain" movement is largely patriotically inspired, while the decline of the pound's exchange value has made it an economic virtue.

To the Editor of The New York Times : I am a farmer living and working out in the great open spaces, away from the sophistication of the enlightened centres of population, so naturally there are a number of things I don't know and can't quite figure out.

NINE feature sound films are scheduled to go into production at the Paramount Hollywood studios during the next fortnight, inaugurating the company's Spring production program and putting the studios on a full capacity basis.

MANAGUA, March 9. -- An idea of the difficulties and dangers encountered by American officers serving with the Nicaraguan National Guard is given in a report submitted today by Second Lieutenant C. H. Clark of the United States Marines, attached to the Nicaraguan forces of an engagement between his men and bandits near El Sauce, in the northern part of the country.

KAISER and Chancellor" left a bed taste in the mouth of the Imperial exile at Doom House. The author has admitted it; the exile has proclaimed its. He told the author that he was not sufficiently obsequious -- "you are not servile."

To the Editor of The New York Times: In these days of disarmament problems, it may be interesting to review the history of the relationship between Canada and the United States since 1870, during which time questions vitally concerning the welfare of both countries were placed before boards of arbitration, and decisions which both countries accepted were reached.

When Judge Alien in General Sessions yesterday accepted $2,500 bail for Clifford A. Braider, who for ten years had been secretary of the Twenty-third Street branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, it became known that on the previous day Braider had been arrested in his room, at 237 East Twentieth Street, on three indictments accusing him of small thefts from the branch.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with a great deal of Interest the comments by two correspondents relative to my letter advocating opera in English in this country and giving more employment to American artists. The replies you have thus far published lead me to the conclusion that neither of the two gentlemen grasped the point of my contentions.
PITTSBURGH, March 19. -- All "work relief" in Pittsburgh will be halted Wednesday unless new funds are found to continue the program, the Allegheny Emergency Association announced today.

A national system of intermediate credit housing banks to aid in financing low-priced homes has just been proposed to members of Congress by Dwight L. Hoopingarner, an executive of the American Construction Council. The system would be patterned after the present Federal intermediate credit banking system for agricultural purposes.

MOSCOW, March 18. -- "The Union of Socialist Soviet Republics saws wood and looks at the world with discrimination not untinged with bewilderment" -- this is a fair a summary of the Soviet situation today.

PALM BEACH, Fla.. March 19. -- More than 200 persons witnessed the annual boxing bout by children of members of the Sea Spray Beach. Club this morning, staged on a platform built on the sand. William A. Kohler athletic director, was in charge.
THEY have come, been seen, have conquered, New York likes the Paris imports. On every side one hears the comment: "Clothes have not been as attractive in years'"

The Eastern Utilities Associates and constituent companies report for 1931 a consolidated net income of $791,383 after taxes, charges, depreciation, subsidiary preferred dividends and minority interest, equal after common dividends of $1,370,815 to $1 a share earned on 789,543 convertible shares.

AT the Sunday afternoon concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra throughout the season of 1930-31 Mr. Olin Downes, music critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, gave a series of radio talks about the musical compositions making up the programs.

Mark Eisner, newly elected chairman of the Board of Higher Education, announced yesterday the names of members of a committee he has appointed to study possible economies in the operation of City College, Hunter College and Brooklyn College, the three institutions governed by the board.

A surprising feature of the women's national indoor track and field championships, more or less overlooked in the rush of events, was the showing of Miss Pearl M. Young, a novice, in the special non-title competition.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- A proposal to use $125,000,000 in marketing surplus American wheat abroad, the sum to be obtained through an additional appropriation by Congress to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was disclosed today by Secretary Hdye, Who stated that the administration favored the plan.

IN the recent tragedy of Ivar Kreuger another powerful force disappeared from the world of international finance. The dramatic exit of the "Swedish Match King" is the latest among financial fatalities of the turbulent post-war era. In that era of sudden crises and swift changes of economic currents hardly a year passed without the dramatic decline of a formidable financial power.

Four Iowa bank robbers were captured and sentenced to life imprisonment within, eight hours after the perpetration, of the crime, and the loot of more than $100,000 was recovered. Yet somehow one cannot help feeling that under present circumstances a bank robber renders a public service by proving there is something in the banks to be carried off.

LET us approach the traffic problem not as a tinker or garage mechanic, nor childishly try to tear the city down to get the green country in and set the city up in it again on its old site -- feudal towers a little further apart, Vested interests, once invested, cannot be divested except by agreement.

Maurice Hotchner, attorney, of Beechhurst, Flushing, was appointed chairman of the Board of Taxicab Control yesterday by Mayor Walker, who announced at the same time the appointment of Daniel L. Reardon of the United States Trucking Company and Colonel George W. Mixter of Day Zimmermann, engineers, as members of the board.

NEW YORK CITY has much to learn from other cities, both in the United States and in Europe, with regard to the disposal of its solid wastes. It has, moreover, a distinct necessity not only to accumulate that knowledge but in put it into practice in the shortest possible time.

THIS is an extremely amusing collection of examples of sentimenlalism in literature. The editor bag searched diligently for those passages, in prose or poetry, in which the greater writers betray themselves, and he has found most of his victims guilty.

CORAL, GABLES, Fla., March 19. -- A triple deadlock by sharpshooting professionals who tied with totals of 143 for their 36-hole play over the difficult Miami Biltmore course marked the halfway goal today in the $10,000 Coral Gables-Miami Biltmore open golf tournament.

A CHARITABLE organization which is making a special appeal for help to carry on extra relief work is the Girls' Service League. The league is seeking to raise $100,000 as an emergency tide-over fund with which it may be able to maintain its workshop and shelter for young unemployed girls at 138 East Nineteenth Street.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga. -- Spring will be ushered in at Sea Island with an unusually brilliant calendar of sports and social activities. As part of the Spring festival, the gardens adjacent to the Cloister will be converted into a tea garden on Tuesday afternoon for a showing of mid-season and early Summer fashions.
The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, by its lease last week of space in the Empire State Building, makes the sixth insurance organization having offices there.

Federal Judge Bondy appointed equity receivers yesterday for F. W. Grand 5-10-25 Cent Stores, Inc., operators of a chain of 115 stores in ninety cities, and for Isaac Silver Brothers Company, Inc., an affiliate, which operates forty-nine stores in seventeen States.

The work of the world disarmament conference in Geneva, which has taken an Easter recess, was summarized by Senator Claude A. Swanson of Virginia, one of the United States delegates, in a radio address which was heard in this country over a coast-to-coast network of the National Broadcasting Company.

The necessity for proper inventory control is the outstanding lesson that has been impressed upon manufacturing companies during the last several years, C. H. Crocker, controller of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation, told THE TIMES yesterday.

To the Dramatic Editor: There is a certain miscarriage of justice in the theatre today that has long been a bane of existence among the general bulk of playgoers. In sum, it is this: When the majority of theatre patrons go to a box-office of ticket broker in quest of seats far some particular show they are informed that such-and-such a row is the best that is left.

PARIS, March 19. -- The meeting of the International Sugar Council here went from bad to worse today but most of the members are remaining over the week-end to see whether they cannot avoid a total breakdown of the Chadbourne agreement, which now seems likely.

A familiar name to the followers of polo in this city, the Pennsylvania Military College of Chester, Pa., now is putting the finishing touches to its preliminary season. It next heads for the intercollegiate division of the national indoor polo championships which, in all probability, will open the various branches of title competition when the nationals start in this city the week after next.

Shares of the Electric Bond and Share Company recovered yesterday on the New York Curb Exchange, the present common stock rising 5/8 point to end at 6 7/8, and the new common stock, traded in on a when-issued basis, rallying 2 points to end at 21.

SPRIGHTLY and dynamic creature though she was Peggy Eaton, around whom in her younger days gyrated a disrupted Cabinet, an angry President and a political world set by the ears, never in her life did anything more startling and dramatic than she has done now, after fifty years in her grave, in sending out this passionate cry of protest against the aspersions which blackened her name.

JERUSALEM, March 18. -- An acute situation is arising in Palestine which is further complicating the ever-difficult Arab-Jewish problem. Arab agitation, which until recently was confined to talk and to the press, now has taken on a far more serious aspect.

DURING the remaining days of Lent much time is being devoted to preparations for post Easter festivities. One set for April 8 will be the annual Butterfly Ball, under the auspices of the Junior Auxiliary of the House of Rest, which will aid that institution's work in caring for patients afflicted with pulmonary tuberculosis.
DALLAS, March 19. -- Retail trade has shown a marked increase as severely cold weather gives way to Spring-like days.
In an exhibition soccer match at Commercial Field, Brooklyn, yesterday, the Hakoah All-Stars defeated the Hakoah Athletic Club, 6 to 3. The All-Stars gained an early lead and led 3 to 0 at half time.

When the Japanese troops stormed Muken in the early morning of Sept. 19 last, they attacked something more than the ancient capital of the Manchus. The edifice of international peace which had been built up on the ruins of the World War was shaken by the impact of the blow almost as much as the Chinese Republic.

BEDFORD, Mass., March 19. -- Gordon Lindberg enabled Tufts College to retain the New England intercollegiate varsity wrestling championship when he defeated Donald Matheson of Springfield in the final of the unlimited class by a fall in a little over two minutes at the new Tufts College gymnasium tonight.

All the old graduate's suspicions that his alma mater is being changed nowadays beyond recognition find abundant confirmation in the first comprehensive survey of recent transformations in the colleges, just issued by the National Society for the Study of Education.

SHANGHAI, March 19. -- Monday is likely to witness the consummation of the formal armistice agreement between Quo Tai-chi, Vice Foreign Minister of China, and Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Minister to China, if the Chinese and Japanese Governments approve the preliminary agreement reached this evening after two meetings which took four hours and a half.

The Intense competition prevailing in retailing is causing marked expansion of the "exclusive selection" type of buying by stores, according to a well-known merchandising authority here. He remarked yesterday that this trend parallels the development of "selective distribution" in the manufacturing field whereby producers aim to confine their output to wholesalers in non-competitive territories.

EVERY silhouette depends, or should depend, on a firm foundation. This year, when Dame Fashion insists on a flat diaphragm, you must give your best attention to your corseting. (The "word suggests stays, and nothing in the world is further removed from style than whalebones!) See to it that your girdle or corselette is long enough and high enough.

Railroad earnings for February reported yesterday failed to follow the lead set by the Chesapeake Ohio lines, which reported increased net income for the period. Both the Kansas City Southern and the New York. Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) reported decreased net returns for February.

The Brooklyn Central Branch romped off with the national Y. M. C. A. indoor track and field crown last night at the Second Naval Battalion Armory in Brooklyn. By tallving a total of 63 points the Hanson Place athletes returned to the championship heights which they occupied in 1928.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Income tax collections for the first seventeen days of March amounted to $124,581,907, a reduction of $70,363,930 from the corresponding period of last year. From July 1, 1931, through March 17, 1932, the receipts were $782,703,249, a reduction of $583,763.612 from collections in the corresponding period of the fiscal year 1931.

Neil R. Sullivan and Roy R. Coffin, Germantown Country Club representatives who won the annual invitation tournament for the Arthur H. Lockett trophy a year ago, are still formidable factors in the competition as a result of the victory they scored yesterday as play opened at the University Club.

Stockholders of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation have been notified that at the annual meeting on April 12 they will be asked to act on the proposal to change the shares and captal stock of the company so that the number of shares will be reduced from 45,000,000 to 15,000,000 and the amount of its capital stock will be reduced from $450,000,000 to $225,000,000, divided into 15,000,000 shares of $15 par value each.
MADRID, March 19. -- Eleven years after the assassination of Premier Eduardo Dato the police believed today that they had captured one of his assassins.

HONOLULU, March 19. -- There is no race antagonism in Hawaii as it is known on the mainland, and very little race prejudice. One has only to go to dances at some of the hotels to learn that. White men and women, and others who are apparently white but have many mixtures of blood in them, are seen dancing with dusky Hawaiians and with those of obvious Oriental ancestry.

LACOS, Africa. CENTURIES before white men ever had learned to send code messages, whether by flaxes, cables or wireless, the natives of Central Africa had already invented a system by which they could send messages over great distances with speed and accuracy.

BERLIN. THE great official addresses commemorating the Goethe centenary are being delivered by Gerhart Hauptmann in America and by Thomas Mann and Hauptmann in Germany. Goethe's native city, Frankfort, however, has turned to a remarkable personality who, while not one of our authorities on Goethe, has through the universality of his work come closer to Goethe's ideal of humanity than perhaps any of the other speakers.

To the Editor of The New York Times : Henry W. Jessup, in a letter to THE TIMES, advocates the cancellation of interest on Great Britain's debt to us for a period of ten years. This interest with its accruals over the period, of course, would nearly be equivalent to remitting one-half of the principal.

CROWN POINT, Ind., March 19 (AP). -- Vice President Charles Curtis told a county Republican rally here tonight that better times were returning and could not fail to arrive because the citizens of America were working, planning and cooperating.

SAN BERNARDINO, Cal., March 19. -- Fog brought death to five passengers in a Los Angeles-bound airplane twenty-two miles east of here tonight as the pilot, apparently confused, dropped his ship into a hightension power line.

Efrem Zimbalist gave his last recital of the season before an over-flowing audience in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. He was ably accompanied by Theodore Saidenberg in some fresh works, far from the conventional repertoire, and suggestive of Spring.

MIAMI, Fla., March 19. -- Prince Tokaion, a son of Prince Pal, which sired Mate, set a new track record in the featured Miami University Handcap today at Tropical Park, where the Southern Florida racing season came to an end.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 19. -- By a great come-baclc, Isaac Lincoln Merrill Jr. of Camden, Me., 21-year-old sophomore at the University of Florida, defeated Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N. Y., one up at the thirty-sixth green to capture the Florida Winter amateur golf championship at the St. Augustine Links today.

BERLIN, March 19 (AP) -- The certain withdrawal of the Nationalist Steel Helmet candidate, Colonel Theodcr Duesterberg, from the Presidential run-off election April 10 was indicated tonight when the Nationalist party announced that it would, not participate in the second contest for the Presidency.

Comparing the financial plight of the government at the present time to that of any larsre industrial organization, W. Clement Moore, economist and tax expert, asserted yesterday that the government should adopt business methods and common sense in attempting to balance the budget.

To The Editor of The New York Times: In his informing article upon Peggy Shippen published in THE TIMES Magazine, E. Irwine Haines leaves the reader with, a false impression of the breakfast scene at which Benedict Arnold received his information about the capture of Major Andre ("John Anderson").

RALEIGH, N. C., March 17. -- North Carolina delegates to the National Democratic Convention at Chicago on June 27 will not be chosen until June 16, the State Executive Committee having deferred the State convention until then in order that the convention might meet in a spirit of harmony considered impossible of attainment prior to the Democratic primary on June 4.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Wholesale prices throughout the United States declined 1 1/2 per cent during February from the preceding month and were 13% per cent below the average for February, 1931, the Labor Department announced today.

VATICAN CITY, March 18. -- The Pope is expected to hold a consistory for the creation of new Cardinals some time in the near future, since death recently robbed the sacred college of several of its members, leaving its ranks sorely depleted. The Cardinals at present number only fifty-five, while the permissible maximum is seventy.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- If reports reaching the President of economic recovery in the nation were a plentiful these days as the account brought to him of his political convalescence. Mr. Hoover would be on of the happiest men in the United States tonight.

Racing dates of the New York Yacht Club for the coming Summer, including the itinerary of the cruise in August, will be announced on Thursday night at a meeting in the clubhouse in West Forty-fourth Street. A week later, on March 31, the delegates of the clubs in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound will gather at the Yale Club on Vanderbilt Avenue and settle upon the dates for the weekly Sound regattas.

FOR thirty-nine years Carlton Bailey Hurst served bis country as its consular representative successively in various foreign parts. When he retired last Summer, his publishers tell us, "he was the premier Consul General of the United States by seniority, with a record seldom attained by any member of the foreign service."

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 19. -- Charles R. Harrison of London, England, bounced his little Non-Sequitur XI outboard motor boat into second place in each of two heats today for the Colonel E. H. R. Green trophy, high prize of the Biscayne Bay regatta, and took a commanding lead in the three-heat competition with 722 points.

A STONE was lifted, a cave three or four feet deep stood open, with a little door and descending steps; beyong --!" What lay beyond that little door all the world knows today. For scientists have told, in many important volumes, the story of King Tut-ankh-Amen and his eighteenth-dynasty family connections.

The Irish societies, whose parade was stopped by rain last Thursday, marched three miles up Fifth Avenue from Forty-fourth Street yesterday afternoon in honor of St. Patrick, with Mayor Walker as grand marshal apparently enjoying every foot of it.

GIULIO GATTI-CASAZZA says that opera, on the radio has pleased him so far. He calls it "an experiment still going on." As director of the Metropolitan Opera Company, he has been studying the many letters received from listeners in all parts of the country, expressing appreciation of the Metropolitan broadcasts which have been on the air since Christmas day.

The automobile Industry in this country is "largely overbuilt" since its plants have an annual capacity of 9,000,000 cars, while the present output is 2,000,000 cars, A.K. Erskine, president of the Studebaker Corporation, said yesterday in a letter sent to stockholders outlining the reasons for the proposed reduction in the stated value of common stock of the company which will provide a surplus for the writing down of its plant facilities, good-will and other items.

Values for commodities were again shaken in yesterday's trading. A fresh all-time low being established in sugar. May contract, selling off to 0.71, while cash wheat, corn, oats and flour sagged to new lows for the year following the unsettlement in the futures market. Silk was another to register a new low. Elsewhere, hides, rubber, coffee and cocoa reacted. Metals and dairy products were steady.

CHICAGO, March 19 (AP). -- Two of Chicago's greatest prep rivals, St. Mel and St. Patrick, displayed surprising strength tonight to enter the finals of the ninth annual national Catholic schools basketball championship tournament.

BOSTON, March 19 (AP). -- The Boston Bruin Cubs took possession of second place in the Canadian-American Hockey League tonight by defeating the Bronx Tigers, 2 -- 1, in the last home game of the regular season.

ALTHOUGH a second election on April 10 is legally necessary to give President von Hindenburg a second term in office, the fundamental lessons of the German election last week art clear. "The Old Gentleman" has won his greatest victory and the German people have conclusively proved what has been, for a long time, uncertain-that the forces working for order among them are stronger than the forces making for disorder.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, March 16. -- A political event that had been looked forward to with a great deal of apprehension has occurred and joy has displaced fear. The Unionist party has passed into history and the Liberal party has taken its place. This burial and birth, accomplished at a single convention and by one group, ended in a love feast when a battle had been expected.

In all lands and at all times education has been distributed unequally. * * * With the aid of the Commonwealth Fund the Institute of Educational Research of Teachers College has followed the educational careers of 785 boys, constituting a representative sample of eighth-grade pupils in New York City in November, 1922.

THERE is a tyranny of the printed word which imposes upon the author of controversial matter the obligation to be accurate. Statements that appear in print have a way of gaining currency and their frequent repetition assures their general acceptance.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 19. -- Confronted for more than a year by a monetary situation becoming worse as time went on, the Government of Chile was forced today to admit that the progressive withdrawal of gold reserves from the Central Bank and unstable exchange rates had brought the country to a position where its currency is no longer freely convertible.

TIME STOOD STILL," the story of a German civilian interned in a British camp during the great war, inevitably recalls the two books by another German, up to the present perhaps the greatest indictment against war.

Palm Sunday services today will include the usual processions in the liturgical churches. Music composed on themes of the Easter Season and Holy Week will be used in all churches. Palms will be blessed in Roman Catholic and some Protestant Episcopal churches.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 19. -- Five persons were injured here today when a large motor truck, carrying five and one-half tons of paper, crashed into a one-man trolley car on Warburton Avenue. The accident occurred six days after the anniversary of a similar crash last year, in which one person was killed and twenty-eight were injured, when a trolley car plunged down Park Avenue Hill.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The special economy subcommittee drafting a bill to reduce all Federal salaries to save from $50,000,000 to $100,000,000 annually today considered raising the maximum cut to 25 per cent for the higher officials, but was unable to agree whether to reduce the salaries which are below $2,500.

Morris High School's fencing team went down to its first defeat in the current P. S. A. L. championship tourney in bowing to George Washington High, defending champion, 5 to 2, in one of the eight tournament matches contested yesterday at the Washington Irving High School gymnasium.
