ALBANY, March 19. -- Although a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, Governor Roosevelt may attend the national convention in Chicago as head of his State's delegation, a position to which he is entitled as titular and de facto State leader.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 39. -- Hill House High School of this city successfully defended its title of State inttercholastic swimming champion by capturing' the annual meet in Cainegie pool today with 46 points. Crosby High School of Waterbury was second with 15.

Victory in the one-mile relay, the final event, gave the 107th Infantry the team laurels in the annual Military Athletic League championship trark and field meet, at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.

SEVERAL, pictures are to be built around the fighting in Shanghai, but Columbia has a new angle. "War Correspondent," it is called, and it will deal with the lighter side of the conflict. Jack Holt will be precipitated among the warring factions in the role of a news gatherer with no sense of the fitness of things.

One hundred and eight day students of the New York University School of Commerce. Accounts and Finance have won places on the honor roll, it was announced yesterday by Professor Gerald E. SeBoyar, chairman of the committee on scholastic standing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Albert Eushnell Hart, Professor Emeritus of History at Harvard and historian of the George Washington Bicentennial Commission, states in THE TIMES that Washington "was the most voluminous writer of his day and the most effective writer of his time."

OMAHA, March 17. -- Protest against high taxes grows in volume and vehemence throughout the corn belt. It is the one subject of public concern on which there is virtual agreement and sustained interest. Prohibition, farm relief, the tariff, the causes of the depression remain moot questions, but nobody denies that taxes are too high.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19.-- Slightly more than three weeks in advance of the start of the major league baseball pennant races, the prospects are that the Philadelphia Athletics will be better situated to win again than their world's series conquerors, the St. Louis Cardinals.

LONDON, March 3. A "SERIES of articles on the condition of England fifty years ago has been appearing in The Times. The article on the theatre was written by Sir Arthur Pinero, who, recalling the charm and dignity of actors of the past, has provoked a brisk correspondence on the contrasted manners of old actors and new.

"MUSEUM" and "mausoleum" were once almost synonyms. Dead animals in glass cases; dead people in stone tombs. If the museum's collections were dead it was because the collector bad his reasons for mounting and arranging butterflies, sea-shells.

The debt of Great Britain's unemployment fund to the British Exchequer at the end of October. 1931, totaled $525,000,000, in addition to which special transitional benefits cost the government $107,000,000 in the year ended March 31, 1931, according to a monograph prepared by a special commission of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which spent several months in Europe studying unemployment insurance and has just published its findings.

An attempt to break into the nursery of a sleeping baby in the exact manner used by the kidnappers of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. was made early yesterday morning at the home of J. Seward Johnson, wealthy vice president of Johnson Johnson, manufacturers of surgical supplies, at New Brunswick, N. J.
WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Business conditions improved little or not at all in most countries reviewed in the weekly survey of foreign markets by the Department of Commerce.

Methods of increasing this country's overseas trade will be the subject of consideration at two meetings scheduled for this week by organizations interested in the subject. The World Trade League tomorrow night will hold a dinner at the Hotel Astor to urge adoption of a reciprocal tariff policy by this country, and on Tuesday the Export Managers' Club of New York, Inc., will hold its annual "get-together" meeting of export executives at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Mr. and Mrs. Oswald Garrison Villard gave a dinner for a large company last night in the roof ballroom of the Pierie to celebrate the twenty-first birthday of their son, Henry Hilgard Villard, who is a senior at Yale university. Additional guests came in later for supper and dancing.

"ENCHANTED WOODS" will be warmly welcomed by all who appreciated the individual flavor and charm of Henry Baerlein's earlier books. Most of these have had to do with journeyings through parts of the world little known to the ordinary wayfarer, more especially those countries, liberated by the war, which were formerly part of t he Austro-Hungarian empire.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 19. -- Cornell University has conferred 206 degrees with the conclusion of the first term.

LETTERS help the broadcasters to visualize their audience, to learn their habits, to partially count thern find to know what they like to hear. Human nature is said to be the same the country over, but while an artist is entertaining at the microphone on Manhattan Island he often wonders if listeners in New England.

Being excerpts from an address delivered, last Tuesday afternoon by Edna Ferber at the Lyceum Theatre, inhere she and Daniel Frohman were speakers at the graduation exercises of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., March 19. -- Dinghy sailors of the Frostbite Yacht Club spent the last official day of Winter going through seven contests today under canvas on Manhasset Bay off the Knicker-bocker Yacht Club. There were five events among the 11-footers of the international class and two among the 14-foot type.

LONDON. IT will be just, six months tomorrow (March 21) since Great Britain went off the gold standard. In the half-year period between Sept. 21, the day of the autumnal equinox of 1931, and the vernal equinox of 1932 the country's economic and financial recovery has been one of the most amazing transformations in her history.

THE fortnight just ended has compassed two of the most important victories yet to be scored try the contemporary dance movement in its campaign for recognition on an equal basis with the other arts. In the last hours of its' recent session the State Legislature passed an amendment to the Sunday law whereby concert dancing is specifically exempted from its restrictive provisions.

THE list of Fellowships recently awarded by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation for this year is an extremely interesting one and one which testifies to the broadmindedness and catholicity of interest of the trustees and the founders.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 19. -- Battling more than two hours and for ten innings without reaching a decision today, the Robins and Phils finally called it a day and retired to their dressing rooms. Each club scored five runs.

PARIS, March 19. -- The trend was slightly lower on the Bourse today, hut the week's closing session was generally satisfactory. The volume of transactions was small. The opening was weak, yesterday's heavy market in Wall Street being blamed for the wave of selling orders which depressed principally Rio Tinto, Royal Dutch.

THE tax collector used to corner the taxpayer once a year and then let him go care-free until another year had rolled around. Times have changed and continue to change, and the taxpayer looks forward to years not far away when every month may be a tax month.

The investigation into the kidnapping of the infant son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh took a new turn last night, when investigators reported that a city gang of criminals had agents in the quiet countryside near the aviator's country home, just outside of Hopewell, N. J.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reply to the letter of the Rev. W. N. P. Dailey, which appeared in THE TIMES, it is not at all surprising that Elias Boudinot of New Jersey was known as "President of the United States in Congress Assembled." Boudinot, however, was the second of the seven Presidents who served under our first Constitution, the Articles of Confederation.

A PROMINENT French lawyer and a former president of the American Bar Association were dining in New York. "But is it really true." the American asked, as be pushed the cigars over to his guest, "that in France you consider an accused person guilty until he can prove himself innocent? That seems to us a frightfully medieval brand of justice."

Spring begins officially at 2:54 o'clock this afternoon. If the weather man is correct in his forecast, however, it will be only officially, for colder temperatures are promised, and possibly rain or snow.

A resolution urging the United States Senate to appoint a committee, as proposed by Senator Edward P. Costigan of Colorado, to investigate conditions among the miners of Harlan and Bell Counties, Ky., was adopted yesterday at a meeting under the auspices of the International Juridical Association at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.
TOKYO, Sunday. March 20. -- Already having organized itself for business and elected its presiding officers, the Imperial Diet was formally opened by Emperor Hlrohito at 11 o'clock this morning.

Colonel GREENE'S latest report as State Superintendent of Public Works contains some striking statistics about the New York State Barge Canal. It is evidently not quite such, a white elephant as it has been painted. Traffic on the canal has trebled in the past ten years, rising from 1,270,407 tons in 1921 to 3,722,012 in 1931.

The County Trust Company of New York, of which Alfred E. Smith is chairman of the board, has been accused in a suit in Supreme Court of advancing large sums of money to the Democratic National Committee during the Presidential campaign of 1928 in violation of a law which prohibits corporations not organized for political purposes from using their funds for political ends.

After active selling yesterday had carried prices on the Cotton Exchange near the low levels of last month, the market recovered sharply and the list closed unchanged to 2 points lower than on Friday. Overnight selling orders had a depressing effect early, but operators covered before the close in advance of tomorrow's final report of the Census Bureau on the season's cotton ginning.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 19. -- Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, who never swung a golf club until she was past 30, today defeated Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., 2 and 1, for the honors in the second annual Augusta women's invitation tournament.

ONE of the outstanding events of early May will be the Charity Carnival of 1932, to be held in Madison Square Garden on the night of May 3. Preparations already are well under way for this entertainment, which will be known this year as "Adventure."

PARIS, March 10. -- Many Americans visited Versailles last Monday to attend a ceremony that made the well-known American scholar, historian and novelist Warrington Dawson an honorary citizen of Versailles. Bestowal of the honor was made in Mr. Dawson's Versailles apartment, where he was for many years bedridden.

MANILA, March 19. -- Before leaving tonight for Baguio for three months Manuel Quezon called, a general press conference and discussed the present Philippine situation. He said he believed independence bills were likely to pass both the House of Representatives and the Senate soon and he anticipated little difficulty in reaching a compromise basis between the two providing for Philippine independence in ten to fifteen years.
LONDON, March 19. -- The British and Dutch Governments have met with complete failure after a five-month attempt to restrict or otherwise regulate the output of rubber.

ISTANBUL, March 11. -- Turkey this week found herself compelled to ask various armament and public works contractors to agree to a delay in the payment of treasury bonds falling due this year until 1936.

PERHAPS it is to become the Springtime custom of Boston's E. E. Clive to act in this town. At all events he appeared here last April in "The Bellamy Trial" and now he is preparing a new piece wherein he will be starred. "Shanghai Marriage" is its title, and it is said to be the first work for the theatre of an Englishman, R. R. Harris.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., March 19. -- Captain of Kilsyth, a white, black, tan and ticked Knglish setter, owned and handled by Gerald M. Livingston of Huntington and New York, tonight was awarded the chief trophy in the fifth annual field trial of the North Shore Game Protective Association, which came to a conclusion as night was falling and the moon riding high.

THE March number of Parnassus, the College Art Association monthly, contains in addition to the usual departments and critical articles, the complete program for the twenty-first annual meeting of the associatior.

THE heroine of the story is a 14-year-old Kentucky mountain girl. The book begins on the day when Sairy Ann. in the face of her family's disapproval and in spite of her brother's active interference, starts off with determination to attend the school taught by the new "fotched-on" teacher from the level country beyond the mountains.

All commodities on exchanges here declined last week, because either of the general fall in securities or the unfavorable technical developments within the various lines themselves. Sugar, coffee, cocoa, rubber, hides, silver and wool tops all gave way under selling pressure.

SCRANTON, Pa., March 19. -- More than 100 insurgent anthracite mine workers were arrested today as augmented forces of State, county and municipal police sought to maintain order in the troubled strike areas of Lackawanna and Luzerne Counties.

The centre of population of New York City might with more justice have been placed at Queensboro Plaza, one of the most active commercial areas in the metropolis, points out D.E. McAvoy, president of the Queensboro Plaza Association, instead of in a graveyard, as was done by the City Regional Plan.

WHAT constitutes right of way and when is it wiser not to exercise this privilege? Are good roads unsafe, as some lay philosophers avouch? What immediate benefits do improved highways bring not only to the motorist but to the community as a whole? Are trucks harder on the pavement than passenger cars? How does the airplane assist the automobile?

BERLIN, March 18. -- The day this is published there will begin in Germany a fortnight's truce, extending over Eastertide, wherein all political activities will be suspended. The government has decreed it partly to give the police a well-earned respite after the exciting days of the recent campaign and partly in response to popular desire, and the government is in a position to enforce it.

Concordia de Melikoff, Russian pianist and refugee, who worked her way to this country and resumed with help of friends here a musical career interrupted by a motor accident abroad, gave a recital in Steinway Hall yesterday afternoon.

I AM requested by THE NEW YORK TIMES to present an analysis of the recent vote in the House of Representatives on the wet motion to discharge the Judiciary Committee, from further consideration of the proposal to submit a constitutional amendment changing the Eighteenth Amendment so as to remit the question of prohibition to State control.

Though April has not yet come with its "shoures soote" to pierce "the droghte of March" to the root, one can go on such a pilgrimage as that to which the Chaucerian WILLIAM ALLAN NEILSON, President of Smith College, invites one over the "Roads to Knowledge." His company are fewer than half the nine-and-twenty who made their way in fellowship to Canterbury with, full devout courage.

Los Nanduces Seniors triumphed over the Riding Club, 14 1/2 to 6, in the feature polo frame at the 105th Field Artillery Armory last night. Other victors were the trio representing Los Nanduces Juniors and Squadron A.

The Lincoln Forty-second Street Corporation, owner of the fifty-three-story Lincoln Building, one of the outstanding office skyscrapers of the Grand Central zone, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in United States District Court listing liabilities of $25,021,130 and assets of $31,405.

There are 188,576 security holders of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, giving the company the largest number of security holders of any gas and electric utility in the United States, according to the Associated Magazine.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, March 19. -- The new Manchurian Government formally notified Loyang and Nanking today of complete severance of relations with China and also notified the League of Nations that China no longer represented Manchuria in the League.

UNDER the auspices of the Ladies' Auxiliary of St. Vincent's Hospital a dinner dance will be given on March 30 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The guests will be seated at small tables, placed around the ballroom, where an elaborate entertainment, featuring many Broadway stars, will take place at midnight.

DETROIT, March 19 (AP). -- The Greenvilles, leaders of Divyer's Major League in New York City, took the lead in the team division of the American Bowling Congress tourney tonight with a total of 2,929.

HOPEWELL. THE advance of aviation in general use has been fully exemplified in the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby. It was a Tuesday night when the child was taken away. Before light Wednesday morning airplanes at Roosevelt, Mitchel and Floyd Bennett Fields and Glenn Curtiss Airport at North Beach had been chartered and made ready for flights anywhere in the country on a moment's notice.
HOUSTON, March 19 (AP). -- Government price-fixing for wheat and cotton grown and consumed in the United States was advocated tonight by William G. McAdoo to accelerate economic recovery.
WASHINGTON. WHAT next in the fight against prohibition?"

THE demand made last week by a group of members of Congress for an embargo on all products of the Soviet Union directs attention to the large decrease that has taken place in Soviet-American trade in the last year. Commerce between the two nations grew from a total of $5,998,000 in 1923 to twenty-three times as much, $138,785,000, in 1930, but last year this figure dropped 16 per cent, to a total turnover of $116,800.000.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Permits for buildings estimated to cost $40,836,173 were issued last month by 355 cities of 25,000 population or more throughout the country, according to reports received today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department.

AMONG the headliners of a week is Silas H. Strawn of Chicago, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, who is now in Europe, speaking with a freedom that he would not enjoy if he were a government official instead of representative of 800,000 American business men.

The Painters' and Sculptors' Gallery, at 22 East Eleventh Street. which thus far has maintained an admirable flexibility in its choice of artists, is showing for the first time in America a group of paintings by Mme. de Corini, who has exhibited at the Paris Salon, the Artistes-Francis, the Beaux-Arts, the Salon d'Automne and the Independants.

PARIS, March 4. IN addition to several pieces in which well-known authors have hardly added to their reputations, the past fortnight has given us three plays of real interest-two by promising new writers and the third by Paul Raynal.
WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Republicans in Washington today received a statement from William D. Guthrie of New York City, who has a plan to restore liquor control to the States.

The raids of the Prussian police on Hitlerite headquarters last Thursday failed to find favor in the eyes of General WILHELM GROENER, Minister of Defense and of the Interior in the Bruening Cabinet. This is not because General GROENER can be suspected of an excess of sympathy for HITLER.

JOHN BECKER GALLERY -- "Six Young Europeans." The artists here presented art united only by the elusive and chameleon quality known as "modernism." Francis Gruber, an Aisatian painter living in Paris, who has studied with Dufresne and Friesz, is probably the best of the group.

A number of dog fanciers from the metropolitan district will make another excursion into New England this coming week-end in quest of championship points. This time their objective is the third annual show of the Manchester Kennel Club, which is to be held in the State Armory at Manchester, N. H., on Saturday.

FLESH IS HEIR" Is a first novel whose omissions are eloquent. Like so many novels by youthful writers, it is patterned loosely on the autobiography. It commences with life in prep school, continues on through a first job.

TRENTON, N. J., March 19 (UP). -- Orange defeated Trenton for the Metropolitan Y. M. C. A. swimming championship. 39 3O tonight. The only other entrant, Jersey City, was third with 14 points.

A solution to the problem of war reparations and a method by which that troublesome question could be removed from the realm of international politics and put in the hands of the world's business men was seen by Dr. Max Winkler, economist and Professor of Social Science at the College of the City of New York, through formation of an international finance and trading corporation funded with reparations bonds.

TO the Editor of The New York Times: I read and reread with a great deal of interest in Topics of The Times about Tristan da Cunha's teeth. According to report, out of 156 inhabitants examined by two dentists, 131 were found to have perfect sets of teeth.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Legalization, of 4 per cent beer as a revenue measure and a stimulant of agricultural and business was recommended by a subcommittee today in a report to the Manufactures Committee of the Senate.

The position of the foreign debts of the government of El Salvador presents several anomalies, according to a staement issued yesterday by the Latin American Bondholders Association. The country's external debt, it is explained, although technically in default, is still backed by customs revenues which are ample to lake care of the loan contracts.

CHICAGO, March 39. -- President Hoover is asked to withdraw as a candidate for re-election in an open letter pent to him by the 37th Ward Progresive Republican organization, of which Henry W. Plaff is president.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 19. -- A St. Patrick's dance was held here tonight at the Larchmont Shore Club. The hosts included:

THE Opera Comique in Paris is busy organizing a season of Russian opera and music which is scheduled to last two months. The Russian season will commence in May. Many of the performances will be given with Feodor Chaliapin, and there will be several ballets under the direction of Bronislava Nijinska, sister of the former dancer, Nijinsky.

PORTLAND, Ore., March. 17. -- To assist the general program of Governor Julius L. Meier in reducing cost of government the Oregon State Board of Higher Education has approved a drastic reorganization of the higher education system, to become effective when the Fall term opens.

PARIS, March 18. -- Prince Nicholas of Rumania admires sincerely the courage of Prince Lennart of Sweden, who has just emulated him by renouncing his dynastic succession rights and marrying a commoner.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 19. -- The winning of two New Jersey women's athletic titles, the achieving of a new State record and the distinction of equaling another State mark were the accomplishments of Miss Effy Oord of the Newark Turnverein, who monopolized the spotlight tonight at the New Jersey State indoor track and field championships for women and men in the Armory.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP). -- American wheat farmers, hoping for a return to the world's export markets, are cheered by the dwindling of Russia's exports of the grain.

ALTHOUGH the title of this volume might lead one to suspect that the contents would prove of interest chiefly to booksellers themselves., one has the "delightful surprise of finding a genuine human document hidden among the rambling and ill-assorted comments on the various types of literature and the various types of purchasers of literature.

STILL, light-headed with the success of Eugenic hats, fashion has decided to "go period" again. But it is a very different period, and it is being put forward in a very different manner. The word which emerged from the Paris openings is Directoire.

RICHMOND, March 10. -- Governor John Garland Pollard's veto of the bill providing for the conversion of the Fredericksburg State Teachers' College into a State liberal arts college for women coordinate with the University of Virginia, has served to prolong the lengthy controversy over the matter of higher education for women in the Old Dominion.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19. -- Trapshooters of the New York Athletic Club defeated the Perm A. C., 483 to 478, over the Quaker City Gun Club traps today in the first of a series of three intercity matches between teams of the two organizations.

The ownership of the principal public utility companies in Greater New York has shown few changes in the last twelve months other than large increases in the total number of shareholders, but there has been, in several instances, a strengthening in the holdings of management interests.

Robert H. Lucas, executive director of the Republican National Committee, advised the members of the Queens County Young Republican Congress, meeting last night at Public School 89, Britton Avenue, Elmhurst, that they "can accomplish the same results" as the youthful Republican leaders who formed an organization in 1916 to "wipe out the Democratic gang that controlled Louisville for many years" and which was "just as ruthless as your Tammany Hall."

WITH a general cessation of large private dances during Lent, plans are now being made for several entertainments that have marked each Spring season for years and have had a generous support from New York society.

The Supreme Court has appointed Leon Leighton and Raymond J. Scully receivers of the Hotel Gotham on the southwest corner of Fifty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue in foreclosure proceedings brought by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company against the Two West Fifty-fifty Street Corporation of which M. Gignoux is president and Frederick F. Bowen is vice president, it was announced yesterday.
THE biennial convention of music teachers and supervisors will take place in Cleveland April 3 to 8, when the Music Supervisors' National Conference will hold its silver jubilee.

THERE is a limitless sea between the Maurice Chevalier whose new picture, "One Hour With You," is to be presented simultaneously at two Broadway theatres -- the Rialto and Rivoli-Wednesday night and the Maurice Chevailer who returned to his native France in 1913, a poilu in a faded horizon-blue uniform, from a prison camp in Germany.

SHANGHAI. BEFORE Japanese troops brought a new aspect to the situation here the Chinese National Aviation Corporation had blazed the trail for the new Chungking airline. The flight began in Shanghai at the Lungwha Airdrome with Captain Ernest Allison, chief pilot, in charge of the expedition.

The nineteenth annual international flower show, which closed last night at the Grand Central Palace, set a new record in the history of the exhibition when it was announced by the management that the estimated attendance for the week had surpassed that of last year.

MONTREAL, March 19 (AP0. -- The Montreal Canadians virtually clinched first place in the International Division of the National Hockey League tonight by scoring two goals in an overtime period to defeat the Maroons, 6 to 4, in the final intracity struggle of the regular season.

WINCHESTER, Va., March 19. -- James B. Russell, dean of Winchester bankers and one of the pioneers in the development of public utilities in this locality, died at his home here today in his ninety-first year. He succumbed to a severe cold, contracted on his way home early this week from a visit in Hot Springs, Va.

PUTNEY-ON-THAMES, England, March 19 (AP). -- "We did our best, but we could not pull it off." said C. M. Johnston. Oxford president, who rowed in the Dark Blue boat today. "It was a remarkably hard race and the going was splendid. Cambridge has a great crew."

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 19. -- A nose finish in which John J. Robinson's Kentucky Derby candidate Lucky Tom was the winner thrilled thousands at the Fair Grounds today at the end of the eleventh running of the Louisiana Derby, worth $10,000 in added money.

The enterprising Long Island Golf Association, headed by W. Neal Fulkerson Jr., has taken time by the forelock to get the jump on most other associations in the country and announced its full schedule of events for the coming season. The opening tourney is less than two months away, the tournament season being ushered in by a one-day event to being played at the Brookville Club on May 17.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was perhaps natural that the newspapers of this country, where the late Edgar Speyer was less well known than in England, should have dwelt, in their notices of his death, upon the most spectacular incident of his career -- the struggle with the British Government which culminated in the revocation of his certificate of naturalization in 1921.

THE present writer recalls the time when he first heard a capstan chanty. He was in the roadstead of Bridgetown. Barbados, and a short distance away lay an English brig that was getting up anchor, the crew aided by a gang from the shore that made a business of such assistance for vessels carrying few hands.

ALBANY, March 19. -- As Governor Roosevelt is preparing to take up final consideration of the Republican measure providing for a thorough-going re-classification of the civil service employes in administrative departments, it was learned that the Republican leaders of the Legislature will meet here in about a week or ten days to begin their prospective survey of these same departments.

Herman C. Satz, jewelry dealer, reported to the police yesterday morning that he had been held up a few minutes previously in his nineteenth-floor office in the Empire Trust Building, 580 Fifth Avenue and 3 West Forty-seventh Street. Mr. Satz said the robbers snatched from his pocket an envelope containing set and unset diamonds and emeralds valued at $22,293 and escaped from the building without being observed by any one else.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19. -- The Great Shires, having looked over half a dozen teams in training, says that the Yankees have the best assortment of young players he ever saw in a training zone.

BUENOS AIRES, March 19. -- The Cabinet will meet on Monday to consider the modification of the rediscount law. It is proposed to rediscount government bonds worth 150,000,000 pesos ($37,500,000) at the Conversion Office and issue paper currency against them.

MOSCOW, March 19 (AP). -- The crime of sabotage, which has been gaining increased attention from Soviet authorities of late, brought sentences of death to eight persons today in four criminal cases in various sections of the country.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 19. -- The annual "one hundredth night" show, named because there are 100 nights before graduation time in June, was given this afternoon and repeated tonight to capacity crowds in the U. S. Military Academy's gymnasium. Several thousand persons witnessed the show, a two-act musical comedy entitled "The Merry Wives of West Point," and written by Cadets Donald L. Hardy, '32, and James McCormack, '32.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The report of a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on manufactures on the proposal to amend the Volstead, act to legalize the manufacture of 4 per cent beer, submitted today by Senator Metcalf, was as follows:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 19. -- By scoring three victories in the final round and placing two men in the runner-up positions, the Syracuse University boxing team captured the ninth annual championship tournament of the Eastern Intercollegiate Boxing Association tonight.

PASADENA, Cal., March 19. -- Upon picturesque field that lies alongside he imposing structure of the Rose Bowl, the Giants' offensive power, dormant for a couple of days, reapeared with startling force today to overthrow the Los Angeles Angels by a score of 9 to 0.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 19. -- The greatest hope for curbing crime lies in education, in early training, in right living and in the restoration of the Golden Rule, George W. Wickersham, chairman of President Hoover's Law Enforcement Commission, told the Harvard Teachers' Association at its annual meeting today.

In yesterday's week-end markets, stock and bond values came almost to a halt. In stocks the day's changes were for the most part trifling fractions; home railway bonds again presented scattered but not important signs of weakness, and foreign bonds moved in a manner quite purposeless.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. POLITICS. prohibition and a smattering of adventure engaged the production eye this week. Three studios announced they already have political stories on the lira and two others indicated they are looking for political yarns.

WHILE going through part of the material selected for consideration this week, a letter singnlarly apropos to our preoccupation arrived from an Idaho town the name of which, it must be confessed, was new to us Being so typical of a certain portion of the mall addressed to this department.

The banking and brokerage accounts of the three members of the city's Board of Water Supply have been subpoenaed by Samuel Seabury in connection with the Hofstadter committee's investigation of the award to Patrick J. McGovern, contractor, four years ago, .of a $43,000,000 contract for the building of the new water tunnel from the Yonkers line to Brooklyn.
PARIS, March 17. -- Gray gains in style importance as the season advances. Many smart wedding guest 5 are ordering pearly gray flamisol ensembles trimmed with blue or silver fox.

THE returning Joseph Santley renounced Klieg for footlights last Monday night in Newark, where he bowed into the theatre again as the producer of "Life Begins," Mary McDougal Axelson's new play, first known as "Birth." Joanna Roos, Edward Pawley and Glenda Farrell are among those prominent in the proceedings, which -- take it on the word of Elizabeth Perkins of The Newark Star-Eagle -- are as obstetrical as you might guess.

LONDON, March 8 -- Our expedition has just returned from re-excavating the royal tomb of Queen Nefertiti, Tut-ankh-Amen's mother, and has obtained new and tragic evidence of the family quarrels which resulted in placing the boy Pharaoh on Egypt's throne.

Perfume made from aromatic woods was a toilet accessory of the well-dressed woman 4,000 years ago, it would seem from the annual report of the Metropolitan Museum's Egyptian expedition for the season 1930-31, which has just been published.

With eleven days remaining in which New York Stock Exchange firms must obtain written authorization from customers for the lending of their shares to the short interest, as provided in the recent ruling of the Exchange, approximately 50 per cent of the margin traders of brokerage firms have assented to the lending of their stocks, it was indicated yesterday in a survey of leading brokerage houses.

SYDNEY, Feb. 16. -- Government in business is to be investigated hero by an independent commission for the first time since the Commonwealth was formed. Since 1914, it has been revealed, government invasion of the railway field in Australia has cost the country a total of $326,000,000 in losses.

LOS ANGELES, March 17. -- The business upswing in Southern California, previously observed in this correspondence, continues to manifest itself, not, of course, in any sensational degree, but with a mild persistency that is heartening. Buying is still hand-to-mouth, but as stocks reach bottom, replacements are being made with renewed assurance.
Two Squndron C teams won their way into the national indoor pole championships at the Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, last night.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Agreement has been reached between the government and the railroads on a formula coordinating "programs and policies" to produce increased employment and insure stability in the financial structure of the country.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., March 19. -- C.L. Smith led a field of twelve gunners at the traps of the Country Club Beach today. He took the high scratch cup by breaking 43 out of a possible 50 targets. The high handicap cup was annexed by F.L. Tompkins Jr.

Reverting to form, the Jamaica High School rifle team romped off with the Peters Trophy interscholastic rifle shoot with a grand total of 998 points to lead the seventeen combinations performing at the General Wingate Athletic Field rifle range yesterday.

PARIS. March, 5, 1932. EXTRAORDINARY as it appears, Paris has only recently heard Strauss's "Elektra," though the director of the Opera ordered its costumes and settings from the painter R. Poit fifteen years ago.

The failure of the American cvilization to withstand the bad influence of its devotion to the ideal of material gain was the subject of the sermon preached by Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in the Riverside Baptist Church yesterday.

With the national indoor tennis championship written into the records and all the honors in the possession of American players, Jean Borotra and his compatriots from France will seek better fortune this week in the international team match between France and the United States which will start at 7:45 this evening at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

While retail trade throughout the country was again hampered during the week by unfavorable weather, stores, in an effort to keep their stocks balanced, placed a fairly substantial volume of small orders in the local markets. Some trend developed to higher price merchandise, particularly ready-to-wear, and special requests for such goods were numerous.

BELFAST, March 20 (AP). -- Authorities of Northern Ireland watched an increasingly serious situation in the Irish Free State, where Eamon de Valera, President of the Council, is intent upon further severance of the ties to Great Britain, with anxiety and alarm today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 20. -- Mayor and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. entertained with a dinner at Casa del Pastor this evening. Among the guests were:

In aid of Irvington House, a convalescent home for cardiac children, a musical entertainment, followed by a dance, will be given on the night of April 17 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The proceeds will be used in the maintenance and equipment of Irvington House in Irvington-on-Hudson, which is sponsored by the Hearst committee of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.

When WILLARD bought the piece of property at the corner of River Avenue and McClellan Street in the Bronx, intending to build a public garage there, he took a big chance. Both streets were zoned for business. Under the zoning laws, public garages are normally excluded from business districts, along with blacksmith shops, crematories and fertilizer plants, which might tend to restrict neighborhood business development.

It looks like a rather light week in the local galleries, as regards new shows, though exhibitions that continue swell the roster and the complete list provides much of interest for the gallery visitor.

MONTREAL, Que., March 20. -- The Montreal stock brokerage house of McDougall Cowans will reopen for business tomorrow morning, the remaining formalities in connection with the firm's reinstatement on the Montreal Stock Exchange having been completed yesterday morning.

The Panama Mail liner Santa Rosa, the first of four snips which the Grace Steamship Company plans to build for its intercoastal subsidiary at a total cost of about $19,000,000, will be launched Thursday morning at the yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company at Kearny, N.J.

DUBLIN, March 20 (AP). -- Eamon de Valera, new President of the Irish Free State Council, today disclaimed for his people any responsibility if, as Great Britain has warned him, disorders arise out of his intention to withhold allegiance and land annuities from Britain.

BERLIN, Md., March 20. -- Weak from hunger and exposure, Charles W. Brown, 31 years old, of this city, who had been the object of an intensive search since his disappearance last Tuesday night, was found today manacled with chains to a tree in Holly Grove swamp, six miles from here.

A marked increase in the number of children entering charitable homes in recent years because their parents have separated or there has been "a breakdown of family morale" was noted in the annual report of Samuel Strasbourger, president of the board of trustees at the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, made last night at a meeting of the board in the home at 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

NEW DELHI, March 20. -- A profound sensation was caused here by yesterday's communique from London, indicating the readiness of the British Government to impose upon India a settlement of her communal issues.

Among the thirty subjects that are being shown this week at the Trans-Lux News-Reel Theatre are pictures taken during the stormy weather on the Atlantic, location scenes of the Lindbergh baby kidnapping, Communist rioting in Chicago, fighting in China, Japanese and German elections, a talk by Clarence Darrow, Grand National trials in England, the latest in Easter hats and Easter eggs, wrestling and football practice.

Any one sent swaggering from a concert of John Goss and the London Singers by the roars of "What Shall We Do With a Drunken Sailor?" is in no mood for sober criticism anent nuance and phrasing, especially when a dozen other merry folk tunes are humming through his head.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 20. -- In a spectacular race that saw six drivers disqualified for beating the starter's gun, William Crawford Jr. of New York and Miami won the Colonel E.H.R. Green Trophy and the unlimited outboard motorboat championship of America today.

FASSAIC, N.J., March 20. -- Preceded by the muffled sounds of a double explosion, a fire that started in the basement of a furniture store wiped, out two buildings on Main Avenue in the centre of the city here today, threatened the Municipal Building and halted trains on the Erie Railroad for more than an hour.

The observance of Palm Sunday, said Dr. Minot Simons, minister of the All Souls' Unitarian Church, meeting temporarily in 166 East Seventy-third Street, in his sermon yesterday, is the commemoration of a triumph of spirit that should be applied by the people of all nations to the current problems of the world.

The second edition of Lou Holtz's vaudeville revue will begin an engagement at the Hollywood Theatre this afternoon. Harry Richman will be costarred with Mr. Holtz in the company, other members of which will include Irving Aaronson and His Commanders, Lyda Roberti, Hal Le Roy, Mitzi Mayfair and Gloria Grafton.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Democratic leaders of the House will hold a "council of war" tomorrow in an effort to regain some control over their unruly ranks and develop strategy for saving the essential features of the tax bill.
ROME, March 20 (AP). -- Christ's triumphantal entry into Jerusalem was commemorated here today with the picturesque Palm Sunday ceremonies traditional in this chief city of the Catholic world.
Aeronautical hopes up in Harlem have blossomed again with the first touch of Spring.
AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 20. -- When Phar Lap came home in front in the Agua Caliente Handicap today, lightning struck the time-honored American theory of training thoroughbreds.

The Lake Placid sextet defeated the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 3 to 2, before a crowd of 6,000 in Madison Square Garden yesterday in the final game of the total-goal series for the national A.A.U. hockey championship, but failed by a large margin to make up the deficit of its 9-2 setback on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Representative Charles R. Crisp of Georgia, acting chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, was urged tonight by some friends of Governor Roosevelt for the permanent chairmanship of the Democratic National Convention on the ground that his prominence in the party and ability as a parliamentarian entitled him to that honor.

In the news dealing with the progress of the Soviet Government's industrialization plans the name Magnitogorsk is likely to figure as prominently during the current year as the Stalingrad tractor works did two years ago and the Nizhni-Novgorod automobile works more recently.

PARIS, March 19. -- The Bank of France continues to recall its foreign balances, but just now at a slower rate. It is evident to all experienced financial observers that the bank does not like to have such sales almost entirely compensated by import of gold. London, however, persists in exporting all gold arriving from India and sold by private individuals in England.

Proud as Brian Boru at Clontarf, the McGlone rode down Fifth Avenue at high noon yesterday, with his teeth clamped hard on the rubber stem of his clay dudheen, and a sneer on his face for the shiny machines that hemmed him in at the curb.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20. -- The Yankees' attack, bolstered by the return of Earl Combs and Bill Dickey to the line-up, came to life suddenly today with devastating consequences for the Boston Braves who were buried under an 18-to-5 score.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I thank you for your editorial of recent date on the report of the Interstate Commission on Unemployment Insurance?

The world today is not asking what is God's will but what is the expedient thing to do in the immediate crisis, the Rev. Dr. Caleb R. Stetson, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

ROME, March 19. -- The prolongation of trade depression was attributed in this market mostly to incapacity, on the part of the governing classes of the principal countries, to find and accept an international solution of the present trade difficulties.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. AUGUSTA, SAN PEDRO, Cal., March 20. -- Steaming into port from a heavy seaway kicked up by forty-five knot northerly winds, scores of ships of the navy fleet anchored in San Pedro and San Diego Harbors today, their stacks and strakes caked with salt rind and their decks wet with flying scud.

LONDON, March 18. -- Although the London markets were suprised at this week's further reduction in the bank rate to 3 1/2 per cent, coming as it did so soon after the cut from 6 to 5 and from 5 to 4, the bank's action is considered justified upon many grounds.

The Welfare Council Coordinating Committee on Unemployment issued an appeal to employers yesterday not to take advantage of present conditions by imposing longer hours of labor, but to preserve the ordinary hours and hire additional employes, even if only for temporary work. The appeal of the council said:

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 20. -- Hitting long, crisp irons into the wind for an outgoing 33 in his afternoon round, Gene Sarazen of Great Neck, L.I., held his lead in the final thirty-six holes of the $10,000 Coral Gables-Miami Biltmore open golf championship today and won by a stroke, carding 75, 69 for a total of 287 over the course of the Miami Biltmore Country Club.

Cornelius, the saturnine Bengal tiger who inhabits the lion house at the Central Zoo and carries his eighteen years with a certain dignity and affability, will have something to tell his friends about this evening. For at 2 o'clock this afternoon he will undergo an operation on an ingrown claw on his left forepaw.

SAN BERNARDINO, Cal., March 20 (AP). -- The death of another passenger today increased to seven the toll of lives lost last night in the crash of an American Airways passenger plane near Calimesa, Cal.
Manhattan College's Spring athletic program, comprising seventy engagements for seven Jasper teams, was announced yesterday.

Investment building, which ordinarily would be moving along at a favorable pace at the present time, is being retarded by four factors, according to opinions expressed by builders to Allen E. Beals, writer in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with particular interest the latest stories published in THE TIMES concerning the fate of Colonel Fawcett, also your editorial comments on the subject in yesterday's TIMES. If these accounts should prove to have some foundation of truth I would be glad to organize an expedition to bring the lost explorer back to civilization.

The pamphlet report of the European Electric Corporation, Ltd., of Canada, headed by Count Giuseppe Volpi di Misurata, shows a net income of $1,355,124 after interest, income taxes, expenses and loss in foreign exchange, before $509,612 loss on securities sold.
LONDON, March 20. -- A cleaning of the war debts slate is thought in some quarters to be appreciably nearer as a result of David Lloyd George's definite support for that policy in his new book.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 20 (AP). -- With Iowa's twenty-five delegates to the Republican National Convention "tucked away" for President Hoover, interest in the party's State convention here Tuesday was expected today to centre around the field opposing Senator Smith W. Brookhart.

Some of the patriots in the House who are so eager, not for the collection of productive taxes, but for the forms of taxation which seem to them most likely to collect votes, have been prattling about " Jeffersonian principles." This vague and hollow formula is never dearer to Democrats than when they are transgressing those principles.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP). -- Sweeping charges of fraud and irregularities throughout North Carolina in the 1930 Senatorial election are made in a petition filed with the Senate Elections Committee for George M. Pritchard of Asheville, contesting the election of Senator Josiah W. Bailey, Democrat.

BOSTON, March 20. -- James A. Farley of New York, who is directing Governor Roosevelt's campaign for the Presidential nomination, was in town for a short time today, having come from Portland, Me. There he met sixty Democrats, representing thirteen counties, and after his conference was enthusiastic as to the prospects of his chief in that State.

MEXICO CITY, March 20. -- An international express train speeding from Laredo to Mexico City was wrecked by bandits early this morning, two of the train crew being Killed in the smash. One of the bandits was fatally shot by the train's military escort.
LONDON, March 20. -- The Prince of Wales and Marshall Field 3d of Chicago figured in week-end hunting mishaps.

Spring weather was just around the corner, the Boy Scouts of the nature-study troop of the Kips Bay Boys' Club agreed yesterday. With notebooks, field glasses and hammers they patrolled in Palisades Interstate Park and found thirty-four signs indicative of the oncoming of mild weather.

BERLIN, March 18. -- Hitler's defeat at the Presidential elections served partly to counteract any shock of confidence which was caused by the Kreuger incident. On the whole, financial circles consider the German outlook improved by the political results.

Mary Pickford told 600 inmates of the Welfare Island Workhouse the inside story of Hollywood yesterday and surprised them which early-to-bed, early-to-rise tales of the stars. But featuring the program were the questions with which the prisoners besieged her as for once they found themselves in a familiar field.

MOSCOW, March 20. -- There is no change in the Soviet policy regarding Japan and the Far Eastern conflict, but an unmistakable change in tone and attitude. Likewise, there is no change in the Soviet policy regarding the United States, but an unmistakable change in tone and attitude.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 20. -- Out of the ninth annual Eastern Intercollegiate Boxing Association championships, bringing together the finest college boxers in the East, have come at least four youngsters who must be considered when the eliminations get under way for the United States Olympic squad.

SHANGHAI, Monday, March 21 (AP). -- Negotiators for peace in the Shanghai area were widely reported today to be deadlocked over withdrawal of Japanese forces from Hongkew, one provision of a three-point basis of discussions.

CHICAGO, March 20 (AP). -- Paul Thompson blazed a shot past his brother Cecil tonight to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 1-to-0 triumph over Boston and enabled them to clinch second place in the American division of the National Hockey League.
ST. LOUIS, March 20. -- Flashing an air-tight defense, the Six team of St. Louis today defeated the Bricklayers of Chicago, 1 to 0, to win the Western soccer championship series, two games to one.

Arturo Toscanini will return from Italy to America to conduct a single concert, one for the benefit of New York's unemployed musicians, according to an announcement made yesterday by Clarence H. Mackay, chairman of the board of directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Declaring that a vote for resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment would really be a move for repeal, the Anti-Saloon League, through F. Scott McBride, its general superintendent, stated that it would oppose members of Congress who stand for resubmission.

Announcements that the various organizations in the cleaning and dyeing industry would not tolerate racketeering in the industry and were cooperating in the drive to end the menace were made yesterday.

It is a large, fast and generally ambitious entertainment which is newly installed at the Palace, where the billing gleams with such various names as those of Paul Whiteman, Al Trahan, Jay C. Flippen, Nell Kelly, Russ Columbo (held over for a second week), and, together again after all these years, Weber and Fields.

MADRID, March 20 (AP). -- Catholics throughout Spain attended the customary Palm Sunday services in the churches today, while the country generally prepared to observe the first Holy Week of the new republic without official government participation.

DETROIT, March 20 (AP). -- Toronto's Maple Leaf's scored a 3-to-2 victory over the Detroit Falcons before a crowd of 9,000 tonight in a wild National Hockey League match that was decided four minutes before the close of the final period.
CHICAGO, March 20. -- What few changes have occurred recently in trade and in manufacturing and labor conditions, in this district are regarded as improvements.

HAVANA, March 20. -- Radio fans throughout Cuba were startled at 12:25 P.M. today when they heard the voice of a new announcer who said that a political upheaval was at hand and that Havana and the entire island would within a few hours be in grave danger, as communistic elements were prepared to deal a decisive blow at the present government.

Prayers for Marshal Ferdinand Foch, generalissimo of the allied armies in the World War, were said at the Palm Sunday high mass yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street, at the request of Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, the rector.
DETROIT, March 20 (AP). -- Broggers Recreation of Grand Rapids, Mich., took the lead in the team division of the American Bowling Congress late tonight with a 2,956 total.

It is good news that Mayor WALKER intends to veto the ordinance recently passed by the Board of Aldermen requiring all city employes to be residents of the city of New York. The text of the ordinance as published in The City Record reveals that it is even worse than the earlier published extracts would indicate.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There are so many erroneous conclusions in the letter of Henry "Ware Allen on "Immigration Restriction" published in THE TIMES that I feel compelled to answer it.

Paul De Bruyn, German marathon champion and New York County cross-country titleholder, added another victory to his long string yesterday in winning the twenty-five-mile run held at Silver Lake, Staten Island, by the Metropolitan A.A.U., under the auspices of the James J. Tappen Post of the American Legion.

The tournament committee of the Indoor Polo Association of America has announced the dates of play for the national championships and an important change in the method of handling the most important of the tournaments, the open.

The United Aircraft and Transport Corporation, rated as the largest unit in the aviation industry, reported yesterday a net income for 1931 of $2,907,548, equivalent after preferred dividends to $1.04 a share on the average number of shares outstanding during the year.

A bridge party under the auspices of the Service Club of St. Thomas Church will be given on the afternoon of March 30 in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis to aid the Church Mission of Help, which maintains many philanthropic organizations.

The comedy by Louis Verneuil which the Teatro d'Arte presented at the Little Theatre last evening was first seen here in an adaptation made by Gladys Unger, just eleven years ago, at the Bijou Theatre. It was then called "The Love Habit." The Italian translation is more faithful to the French original, and fully as insinuating as the latter.
PITTSBURGH, March 20. -- Feit-coated steel, a new material, was announced tonight by the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research.

NORFOLK, Va., March 20 (AP). -- Ernest C. Gunther, who disappeared from the liner Conte Biancamano at Phaleron, Greece, on March 10, is well known here in business circles. He recently retired from active work after having spent many years in retailing farm tools and machinery.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Short sales of stock are an almost unmitigated evil, and if Congress can devise means to limit or perhaps eliminate the practice altogether, it will have taken a long step forward in preventing such disaster as almost overwhelmed that portion of the public which endeavors to save and invest some portion of its income and for a time threatened to overturn our entire financial system last December.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., March 20, -- Recovery of business is unlikely "until such a time as agriculture is put on a cost plus profit basis," Dean C.L. Goodling of the National Farm School' here told forty-one members of the graduating class and more than 1,500 visitors at the thirty-second annual commencement exercises today.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 20. -- The cotton market here developed only a moderate activity last week. It was influenced in some measure by the slowing down in the spot demand. This was regarded as merely temporary and was attributed to the rather disappointing character of the demand for goods in the domestic textile markets, which slowed the demand for raw cotton from domestic mills.

PITTSBURGH, March 20. -- Steel demand did not increase last week, but it had no definite loss. Steel ingot production for the week was estimated at about 26 per cent of capacity, against and average rate of 27.57 per cent for February. Pittsburgh showed no change for the week, Chicago was up a couple of points and some intermediate districts were down.

Seventeen sailing dinghies of the Frostbite Yacht Club engaged in twenty-one contests, classed in eleven races, off the Harlem Yacht Club at City Island yesterday, and with a brisk northwest breeze encountered an afternoon full of thrills.

The Niagara Hudson Power Corporation in 1931 was again the largest seller of electric energy in the world, with a total of 5,159,069,101 kilowatt-hours, compared with 6,153,430,568 gold in 1930, a decline of 16.2 per cent. Gas sales of the system totaled 8,397,812,100 cubic feet in 1931, against 8,608,061,000 in 1930, a drop of 2.4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Secretary Stimson is watching the Sino-Japanese controversy with close attention, although the situation has become less spectacular since the Chinese retreat from Shanghai and, accordingly, has been marked by a lessening of public interest in this country.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 20 (AP). -- The body of Ivar Kreuger, international financier, who killed himself in Paris two weeks ago, arrived here today and funeral services will be held Tuesday afternoon. Only the family, a few business friends and newspaper reporters will attend the final rites for the man who built a vast fortune out of a small match company.

The New York Rangers retained the city hockey championship by defeating the Americans at Madison Square Garden last night, 4 to 2. Clashing in the final local battle of the regular National Hockey League campaign, the teams waged an interesting contest, to the satisfaction of a crowd of 10,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Senator Burton K. Wheler, Democrat, Montana, predicted upon his return from a trip to the West today that if the contest in the national election was between President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt the latter would carry the Northwestern States, heretofore traditionally Republican.

Professor WILLIAM MCDOUGALL of Duke University has devoted more than forty years to " the sciences of life," as distinguished from the physical sciences. In a recent statement he has indicated (while " still pre-senile ") concisely the lines of evidence and reflection along which he has been led from agnosticism to religion.

A tribute to Goethe as both a practical man and a dreamer was voiced yesterday in services commemorating the one hundredth anniversary of the death of the German poet on March 22, 1832, by Dr. Gustav F. Beck, director of Labor Temple, at the Community Church, Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is quite generally assumed that, to rid ourselves of the embarrassment arising from the presence of the Eighteenth Amendment in the Constitution, the consent of three-fourths of the States must be obtained as well as a two-thirds majority in each house of Congress.
NEW YORK. Lord Trent of Nottingham, England, will arrive tomorrow on the Mauretania and will be at the St. Regis.

SHANGHAI, Monday, March 21. -- It was intimated here last night that Japan might waive her oral insistence upon a round-table conference with the Chinese subsequent to the signing of an armistice, another conference on which will be held today.

Developments in the cotton textile industry during the next few months should continue an important step in the reconstruction of basic industries, George A. Sloan, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, declared in a statement issued today. Mr. Sloan saw in the liquidation of inventories and the reduction of operation schedules constructive influences which would justify price improvement, adding that the "return of reasonable profit rests squarely with mill executives and their selling agents."

The Phelps Dodge Corporation shows in its annual report that dividends of $2,117,042 were paid in 1931 from other than "earnings or profits accumulated since Feb. 28, 1913," and these, with a net loss of $5,057,376 after depreciation and depletion for the year, with other deductions, reduced surplus from $62,580,621 on Dec. 31, 1930, to $55,391,823 on Dec. 31, 1931.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 20. -- Centring their assault upon Dazzy Vance in the third inning, the world's champion Cardinals today scored six runs in that frame on two home runs, three singles and a pass, and defeated the Robins, 9 to 8, before a crowd of 1,500.

Public hearings on the merits of the tentative $474,500,000 unification plan will not get under way before the Transit Commission on April 4, as recently scheduled, but will be further deferred to enable the commission, the Board of Estimate and the B.M.T. and Interborough to conduct informal negotiations, it was disclosed yesterday.

If prophecies that Western civilization in general and American civilization in particular are doomed are to be proved false, contemporary leadership must soon find the way toward a New Renaissance, a New Reformation, and a New Industrial Revolution.

The drift of events last week seemed to cause frequent putting of the question whether the financial situation has improved, or has actualally grown worse, or has not changed at all. On this occasion the question is easily answered. That part of the economic picture which is made up purely of developments in trade and industry cannot be said to have improved.

BERLIN, March 18. -- Some nervousness prevailed in financial circles this week owing to the Kreuger suicide. It caused unpleasant reminiscences of the Creditanstalt bank collapse of 1931. Kreuger's financial and industrial processes had never been thoroughly approved in Germany, although, while his program was meeting with success, his system evoked little criticism.

LONDON, March 18. -- In the rubber market here today plantation grades were quiet but steady. Smoked sheet spot and March sold at 2 3-16d a pound sellers, April-June at 2 1/8d to 2 3-16d value, July-September at 2 1/4d to 2 5-16d sellers, October-December at 2 3/8d to 2 7-16d sellers, January-March at 2 9-16d sellers, crepe spot at 3d value.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh spent the third Sunday since their infant son, Charles Augustus Jr., was kidnapped waiting vainly yesterday for news of the baby's whereabouts, in their home near Hopewell, N.J.

LOS ANGELES, March 20. -- Returning to Wrigley Field after a series of adventures in San Diego and Pasadena, the Giants opened a nine-game exhibition series with the Tigers today and were at once pleased to note that they are not the Tigers of old.

State Senator John A. Hastings, who for three months waged a futile legal battle to prevent his examination by the Hofstadter committee, will appear "voluntarily" this afternoon before Vice Chairman Hamilton F. Potter, sitting as a sub-committee of one, for questioning under oath by Samuel Seabury, the committee's counsel.

To the Editor of The New York Times: E.C. Simmons, replying to H.L. Puxley's article, writes, in a letter to THE TIMES, "Money does not create credit but money is created along with other forms of credit."

J.H. Wantling was both high scratch and high handicap gunner at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He took the scratch trophy with a card of 97 out of a possible 100 targets. As he could not win both cups, the handicap prize went to E.S.S. Carroll, who had a card of 96 -- 0 -- 96.

CHICAGO, March 20. -- The present demoralization of the grain trade throughout the world is the worst that traders of this generation can recall. Even during the World War, they say, there was nothing that compared with it. Then supplies were short and transportation facilities were inadequate.

Writing of one of the minor battles of the Peninsular War in Spain, the historian NAPIER said: "There " disorder triumphed over discipline, " and inexperienced men defeated " practiced generals." That would not be a bad description of the proceedings in the House of Representatives on Friday and Saturday.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The candidate for the Presidency who is rated highest as the ally of the public against the "power trust" in a survey made by the National Popular Government League is Governor Roosevelt. President Hoover, Newton D. Baker, Alfred E. Smith, Governor Ritchie and Speaker Garner are put below par so far as power company regulation is concerned.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 20. -- Governor George White, in a public statement late today, threatened to invoke martial law in the Hocking Valley bituminous coal district, composed of Athens, Hocking, Perry, and Vinto Counties, to put an end to violence in the strike of 7,000 miners which has been in progress since Feb. 1.

CHICAGO, March 20. -- A better situation has developed in the live stock markets here in the face of liberal supplies, suggesting an improved consumptive demand for beef, pork and mutton. Prices to consumers are lower than they were a year ago, and this has attracted attention.

SCRANTON, Pa., March 20. -- Augmented by patrols of State troopers, deputy sheriffs and local police, the authorities prepared today to deal with the swiftly mounting crisis in the anthracite collieries of this region induced by an insurgent strike of union miners, who are demanding "equalization" of work.

At her recital in the Town Hall yesterday afternoon Rachel Morton, soprano, presented a program beginning with Bach's "Komm, susser Tod," and including Handel's aria of Elisa from "Tolomeo," the aria "Abscheulicher! wo eilst du hin?" from Beethoven's "Fidelio," and groups of German, French and English songs.

Formal offering will be made today of an issue of $2,000,000 city of Louisville (Ky.) 4 1/2 per cent sewer bonds, due on Feb. 1, 1969, by the N.W. Harris Company, Inc. The bonds will be priced at 101.81, to yield about 4.40 per cent. The city reports an assessed valuation for 1931 of $431,452,345 and total debt, including this issue, of $36,020,300 and net debt of $29,249,532.

Robin Lee, just turned 12 years of age, yesterday was crowned national junior men's figure skating champion. The lithe boy from Minneapolis defeated five other aspirants, every one of whom was twice his age at least, in a most spectacular climax to the titular events, staged under the auspices of the New York Skating Club at the Ice Club.

Richard Thomas, who was competing unattached, annexed first place in the fifteen-mile scratch race conducted by the Manhattan Athletic League on Riverside Drive yesterday. The victor's time for the event, which was staged under the auspices of the Good Shepherd Athletic Club, was 1:31:58.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The total expenditure by the government for the care and relief of war veterans, including those of the Civil and Spanish Wars, will reach or pass $16,000,000,000 before the end of the fiscal year 1932-33, according to the forecast of the Veterans' Administration.

SAN RAFAEL, Cal., March 20 (AP). -- Looking back over a career that started in a machine shop in Scotland, Captain Robert Dollar celebrated his eighty-eighth birthday today and pronounced the world "a fine place if you want to work."

Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the New York City Bicentennial Commission, announced yesterday the appointment of the executive officers, borough chairmen and directors of its activities. Mr. Whalen expressed, pleasure at what he said was the interest and cooperation being shown by patriotic and fraternal societies and by civic and business organizations.

A brave display of gardenias, silk hats, old-fashioned nosegays on trim tailored suits, with here and there a glimpse of warm-colored frocks peeping from under protecting fur coats, were the main features of the Palm Sunday parades in Park and Fifth Avenues yesterday.

R.C. Sherriff, whose play "Journey's End" is now being produced by fifty different companies in twenty different languages, is expected to arrive here from England aboard the Bremen on Wednesday. His new novel, "The Fortnight in September," has just been published by Stokes and, only two weeks old, is in its third printing.

MIAMI, Fla., March 20 (AP). -- The Princeton University expedition that sailed tropic seas for two months in search of the cause of earthquakes returned to Miami yesterday with much scientific data and reports of a new ocean deep near Grand Cayman Island.

"Big business" has "absolutely nothing" to fear from Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt as President, William H. Woodin, president of the American Car and Foundry Company chairman of the board of the American Locomotive Company and director of the Federal Reserve Bank, declared yesterday in a statement made public by the Roosevelt headquarters.

The primary consideration in the treatment of criminals today is the lasting benefit of society, not vengeance upon the criminal, Sam A. Lewisohn, chairman of the New York State Commission to Investigate Prison Administration and Construction, said yesterday afternoon in an address on "Twentieth Century Prison Policy," broadcast over Station WOR in one of the forum periods arranged by S. Theodore Granik.

Neil R. Sullivan and Roy R. Coffin of the Germantown Cricket Club retained possession of the Arthur H. Lockett Trophy for another year by winning the annual invitation squash racquets competition concluded yesterday at the University Club's courts.

Many aliens in New York City are being exploited by racketeers and crooked lawyers, according to Edward Corsi, Commissioner of Immigration at Ellis Island, who spoke yesterday at the twenty-third annual meeting of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society of America in the Hotel Astor.

New York's Museum of Science of Industry. Following the example of the Deutsches Museum of Munich, the Museum of Science and Industry of New York permits its visitors to push buttons and pull levers and thus see for themselves what makes the wheels of industrial machines go round.

The people who greeted Christ with waving palms on Sunday and crucified Him on the following Friday were made the symbol of present-day religious indifference by the Rev. Charles E. Jefferson, honorary minister of the Broadway Tabernacle, in a sermon yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

A call to Catholics to unite against the enemies of their faith in America was issued by speakers yesterday morning at the thirty-fifth annual communion breakfast of the New Amsterdam Council of the Knights of Columbus at the Hotel Astor.

BAYARD, Fla., March 21. -- The six-furlong track record was broken twice today as the ten-day meeting of the Florida Jockey Club got under way at St. Johns Park. Jaz Age, owned and trained by John Parmalee, lowered the record the second time in the St. John's Handicap, the feature, when he was timed in 1:13 2-5.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 21 (AP). -- Political leaders from all parts of Brazil were called upon today to heal the breach between the military regime of Getulio Vargas and the political forces of the Southern State of Rio Grande do Sul. The de facto President himself was engaged in long conferences with the Governor of Rio Grande, General Flores da Cunha, but the results of their dission were carefully guarded.

For the second of his vaudevillerevue experiments Lou Holts has assembled a lengthy till which jumped along agreeably and informally last night in its second performance at the Hollywood Theatre. It displayed, not unnaturally, a number of the faults inevitably arising; from its hurried preparation -- there was too much show and it could have been better paced and routined -- but these were relatively minor matters which playing is certain to correct.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The American people are faced with an emergency more serious than war, Louis D. Erandeis, associate justice of the Supreme Court, asserted today in the course of a dissenting' opinion in a case before the court.

The suggestion for the formation of a World Court of Audit and Bankruptcy, to get nations on a business basis by checking up their budgets, is made again in "Europe and Our Money" by Dr. Lothrop Stoddard, published today by Macmillan. As Dr. Stoddard outlines the plan, the proposed tribunal would place States found to be insolvent in temporary receivership.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21. -- Jack Moran knocked out Gus Hoffman in the first round in the heavyweight class to give Philadelphia a 4-3 victory over New York amateurs before a crowd of 3,000 at the Arena tonight.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21. -- Making their initial 1932 contact with the Boston Braves today, the Robins ran afoul of shut-out pitching by young Bob Brown, a rookie from the Binghamton club, and Ben Cantwell, now a veteran Brave. The Robins got three singles and made two errors.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 21. -- The new Franklin Simon Co. store, located at the intersection of West Putnam Avenue, the Boston Post Road and Dearfield Drive, Greenwich, was formally opened this morning.

Hector O. Hamilton, young New York architect, who won a share in the first prize with his design for the projected Palace of the Soviets in Moscow, announced yesterday that he would sail for Russia in a month at the invitation of the Soviet Government to aid in the construction of the building.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 21. -- Reports that Soviet soldiers had shot down rebellious peasants in the Ukraine, among them women defending their churches against wreckers, came today from Rumanian villages on the Ukrainian frontier.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 (AP). -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company announced today that it "has been regretfully compelled to call upon its pensioned employes to share in the efforts which have been instituted over the entire railroad to decrease expenses."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read the paragraph on today's editorial page about taxicab rates in Cleveland. Just before returning from that city on a business matter I read in the papers that there is before the City Council in Cleveland a recommendation for a minimum rate on taxicabs.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Representative Royal C. Johnson of South Dakota, ranking Republican on the Committee on World War Veterans' Legislation, today told President Hoover that there was now less chance for the enactment of legislation for full payment of adjusted compensation certificates to World War veterans.

Sitting in one's easy chair and reading of wave-tossed ocean liners late in docking or of cloud wrack and fog that have confused some daring flier seeking to link the continents by air, one thinks of the mid-Atlantic as a place of turbulence and storm.

After fighting off a man and a young woman who tried to restrain him, T. Langland Thompson, 60-year-old attorney, of Elberon, N.J., hurled himself from a ninth-floor window of the New York Central Building, 230 Park Avenue, shortly after noon yesterday.

NEW YORK. Mrs. H. Clinton Backus of 825 Fifth Avenue has gone to the Mayflower, Washington, for a brief stay. The Countess Cowley and her daughter, Lady Patricia Wellesley, are expected today on the Mauretania.

MOSCOW, March 21 (AP). -- A reiteration by the Japanese Government that massing of Japanese troops on the Korean border did not threaten Soviet territory and that Japan stood ready to suppress Russian "White Guard" activities in Manchuria if they threatened the Soviet frontiers was made public today by the Foreign Office here.

Two youthful bandits attempted to hold up a restaurant at 88-26 Myrtle Avenue, Woodhaven, Queens, about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, but after a pistol battle with a policeman, off duty and in civilian clothes, who was in the place when they entered, they fled empty-handed.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 21. -- The appointment of Earl Martineau, back-field coach at Purdue University, as an assistant football coach at Princeton University, was announced tonight by Dr. Charles W. Kennedy, chairman of the board of athletic control.

BERLIN, Md., March 21. -- Warrants charging assault and kidnapping were sworn out tonight against Robert Alien, Chief of Police of Ocean City, Md., and George K. Jarvis, a cattle dealer and business man of Berlin.

TRENTON, N.J., March 21. -- After a vote of confidence had been, given by his Republican colleagues, Senator Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic County withdrew tonight his resignation as majority leader and as chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

An abandoned farm near the Sourland Mountain estate of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh near Hopewell, N.J., yielded a possible new clue yesterday to the kidnappers of his infant son, who has been missing for the past twenty days.
