WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The importance of the Pacific to the United States was stressed by Dr. Stanley K. Hornbeck, chief of the Far Eastern division of the State Department, at today's opening meeting of the Institute of Far Eastern Affairs at the American University.

The peak of activity in American shipyards, resulting from new construction contracts awarded under the terms of the merchant marine act of 1928 will be attained during the present year, according to H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders.

Francis X. Mancuso, former Judge of General Sessions and chairman of the board of the defunct City Trust Company, was acquitted of perjury by a jury before Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley at 1:15 o'clock this morning. The jury's verdict, which came after almost nine hours' deliberation, was greeted with cheers which rang through the courtroom until attendants silenced the demonstration.

LONDON, March 21 (AP). -- What are believed to be letters to the Egyptian Pharaoh from cities of Palestine imploring military aid to help stem the invasion of the Israelites of the exodus have been found near Tel el Amarna, Egypt, according to a statement today by Sir Charles Marston, noted biblical archaeologist.

NICE, France, March 21 (AP). -- Prince Nicolas of Rumania said here today that he was going back home to resume his old place in the court of his brother, King Carol, from which he has been a virtual exile for love.

It is the happy privilege of the German people in the twentieth century to have their supreme national poet stand so close to them in time, so intimately a part of their recent yesterday. There must be many Germans now living whose fathers were contemporaries of GOETHE, who may have seen him and talked with him, who were at the very least under the influence which he shed on the national life and thought.

At the fifth concert of the Town Hall endowment series, Rosa Ponselle last night presented a varied program before a capacity audience with an overflow upon the stage. She gave two operatic arias, "O divina Afrodite" from Romano Romani's "Fedra," wherein the composer accompanied, and "Bel raggio lusinghier" from Rossini's "Semiramide"; a group of French and Italian songs including Veracini's "Pastoral" and Widor's "Contemplation"; a group in English and a group of German lieder.

Mail Orders Show Good Increase. Mail and telegraph orders received yesterday by resident buyers, here showed a substantial increase over previous weeks, but the volume continued below expectations for a period so close to Easter. The bulk of the requests were for children's apparel and ready-to-wear.

Jose Iturbi, distinguished pianist, will contribute his services as soloist on April 19 at the third concert of the series to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House by the Musicians Symphony Orchestra of 200 unemployed musicians, it was announced yesterday by the orchestra committee. Sir Thomas Beecham will conduct this concert.

Southern beaten biscuit, hooked rugs, homespun woolens, hearth brooms, copies of authentic pieces from Mount Vernon and Monticello and many other hand-made products of the student industries of Berea College in the Kentucky Appalachians were placed on display at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday under the patronage of prominent New York women.
DETROIT, March 21 (AP). -- New Jersey bowlers scored in the American Bowling Congress minor events today, four berths among the leaders being taken by the Eastern entrants.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 21 (AP). -- The British Consul at Sao Paulo, Arthur Abbott, and Consul General Charles Goodwin here are increasingly impressed with the story of Stephan Rattin, a Swiss trapper, that he saw the British explorer, Colonel P.H. Fawcett, last October 500 miles west of Dead Horse Camp, the last outpost of civilization in Brazil.

Short covering sent the principal public utility clocks higher yesterday on the New York Curb Exchange, some other active issues also advancing on a moderate amount of trading. The Curb's bond market was erratic, recoveries appearing in some issues as others lost ground slightly.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, March 22. -- Formal acceptance of the armistice terms of the governments of China and Japan was announced late yesterday afternoon following a meeting of Quo Tai-chi, Vice Foreign Minister of China, and Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Minister to China, in the presence of American, British, French and Italian diplomatic representatives.

The death of Edward C. Plummer, vice chairman of the United States Shipping Board, caused speculation yesterday in shipping circles concerning his successor. Mr. Plummer's term of six years had about five years to run. His service as legal adviser on many phases of marine law added to his value as a member of the board and his successor, it is believed, will be sought among men with similar background.

The "vilification" of men in high public office was denounced by Supreme Court Justice Cotillo yesterday in a decision granting a reargument on an injunction previously granted by him against the author and publishers of "The Strange Career of Mr. Hoover -- Under Two Flags."

Bond prices showed rallying tendencies on the Stock Exchange yesterday, though the improvement was by no means general. United States Government bonds displayed even strength as did the better rated foreign loans, and the more active issues of the domestic railroad group made sizable recoveries following the sharp declines of last week.
HAVANA, March 21. -- Cuba plans to increase the silver in circulation by $3,566,829.20, which will be minted immediately under a decree signed by President Machado today.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- Missouri's reapportionment controversy was presented to the Supreme Court today with a request that it be heard with the New York case growing out of a similar question.

Myron Melyn stopped arranging a display in the window of his jewelry store in the Bronx yesterday to open the door far a man and a girl who had been watching him interestedly. A few minutes later Melyn was in a back room, his hands bound with wire, and the couple and another man had fled with jewelry valued at $20,000.

Choked and beaten, with pistol butts by two hold-up men who entered his haberdashery at 667 Eighth Avenue at 9 o'clock last night, Samuel Robbins nevertheless managed to get to the door and by his shouting caused the arrest of one.

GLOBE, Ariz., March 21 (AP). -- Federal Court jury decided tonight that Mac (Golney) Seymour, Apache Indian, range rider, should be imprisoned for life for the murder of Henrietta Schmerler, Columbia University co-ed.

CONCORD, N.H., March 21. -- The employment of trained social workers at the expense of the State, to be lent first to counties and then to cities and towns for investigation and case treatment, was authorized by Governor Winant and the executive council this afternoon at a special session considering unemployment.

The application of the Minneapolis Gas Light Company for permission to issue 25,000 participating units yielding an annual income of $5 each in exchange for about $2,500,000 preferred stock of the American Commonwealths Power Corporation has been approved by the Minnesota Securities Commission with one minor reservation.

Medical science played its part yesterday for the third time in the life of Old Dick, who also allows himself to be addressed as Cornelius. The 19-year-old Bengal tiger of the Central Park Zoo took the entire procedure without concern until the iodine was applied.
SAN PEDRO, Cal., March 21. -- The results of the recent war game between units of the United States fleet have shown, in the opinion of naval officers, the necessity for new naval construction.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 21. -- City Controller John A. Mitchell received today three bids for the city's $4,493,000 issue of forty-year municipal water bonds. They will be considered at a special meeting of the City Council tomorrow night before being awarded.

On exhibition in New York is the handiwork of students in a college which takes its name from the little town of Berea in the mountains of Kentucky and in turn from the city in Macedonia, whose inhabitants were "more noble" in that "they "received the word with all readiness "of mind."

Gene Tunney, who retired as heavy-weight boxing champion of the world, was among almost a thousand persons who saw the Manhattan College boxing team defeat the Brooklyn College boxers, 4 1/2 to 2 1/2, last night in the Manhattan College gymnasium. Tunney later presented the trophies in the Manhattan College Intramural Championship tournament, which recently was established by John F. (Chick) Meehan, director of physical education.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, March 22. -- New complications concerning the establishment of the independent Manchurian State are now facing officials of the Chinese Government with the news from Changchun that Mo Teh-hui has been appointed by Manchoukuo as its diplomatic representative to Russia.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- President Hoover called on the nation today to join in honoring the memory of Dr. Robert Koch, the German physician, and scientist, the fiftieth anniversary of whose discovery of the tuberculosis germ will be celebrated throughout the world Thursday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 21. -- More than 1,500 persons heard Robert Goldsand, Viennese pianist, in the final concert of the Rutgers Winter series at the gymnasium tonight. Howard D. McKinney, Professor of Music at Rutgers and director of the series, announced next year's program.

PROVIDENCE, March 21 (AP). -- Characterizing the action of the Coast Guard in firing 470 machine gun bullets at the rum-runner Eaglet as "a rather sad commentary on the administration of law in this country." Judge Ira Lloyd Letts of the United States District Court denounced the practice today in charging a jury which heard smuggling conspiracy evidence against seven members of the crew.

Local color in the form of jazz band and pioneer ballad will be lent to an Easter Sunday night concert planned at the Metropolitan Opera House next Sunday, when the company will extend its program to include numbers of unusual character and 100 per cent Americanism.

Dick Shikat of Philadelphia, former world's champion, threw Leon Pinetzki of Poland in the feature wrestling bout at Madison Square Garden last night with a double headlock in 34:58 of what was scheduled as a finish match. A crowd of 8,000 attended.

In their not particularly emphatic movement of yesterday, the market for securities seemed to be influenced by Mr. Hoover's statement of Saturday on the railway obligations. His reminder that impending debt maturities are "of smaller dimensions than has been generally believed," and that not more than $300,000,000 or $400,000,000 would be needed to cover the coming year's deficiency in charges and maturing indebtedness, conveyed no new information to people in touch with the railway position.

Debate in the Senate on the renomination of Mr. FRED A. BRADLEY as Collector of Customs at Buffalo brought out some curious information on double or multiple personalities. Mr. COUZENS, Mr. GEORGE and Mr. WATSON, the subcommittee of the Committee on Finance, to which the nomination was referred, found that it was incongruous for Mr. BRADLEY to be chairman, of the Erie County Republican Committee as well as Collector.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- The 1931 cotton crop amounted to 16,595,780 running bales, or 17,060,772 equivalent 500-pound bales, the Census Bureau reported today in announcing final ginning figures for the season. The 1930 crop was 13,755,518 running bales, or 13,931,597 equivalent 500-pound bales, and the 1929 crop 14,547,791 running bales, or 14,824,861 equivalent 500-pound bales.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 21. -- Mrs. Sara Fownes Wadsworth of Pittsburgh, with the score of 82, led the Class A golfers today in the second annual Pine Cone women's golf tournament being played this year at the Pinehurst Country Club instead of at Pine Needles.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 21. -- The British Consulate and Brazilian officials both deny knowledge of any expedition seeking or being organized to seek Colonel P.H. Fawcett, the British explorer who vanished in the Brazilian jungles seven years ago.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 21. -- The first meeting ever to be held in the United States by the International Astronomical Union is announced by the Harvard College Observatory for the week beginning Sept. 2 and ending Sept. 9. The only public lecture of the session will be given by Sir Arthur Stanley Eddington, distinguished European astronomer, on the subject, "The Expanding Universe."

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- A response to the speech of warning against the program of Eamon de Valera which Neville Chamberlain, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, made last week at Birmingham, was issued here today by the Kevin Barry Council of the American Association for the Recognition of the Irish Republic.

MOSCOW, March 21. -- The final year of the first Five Year Plan has begun well. Preliminary figures for the first quarter produced yesterday at a meeting of the State Planning Commission show a startling advance over the same period last year.

Spiritual and material benefits will come from the city's celebrations of the George Washington Bicentennial, more than 500 club women were told yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel Commodore called by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the city of New York commission for the observance.

Jesse Isidor Straus, whose contemplated resignation as chairman of the State Emergency Relief Administration was reported two days ago, wound up his affairs yesterday at the offices of the commission at 124 East Twenty-eighth Street and prepared to step out of the position he has filled since last October.

Mme. Frances Alda, who retired from the grand opera stage in December. 1929. after an association of twenty-two years with the Metropolitan, is announced to begin a limited tour of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum vaudeville circuit on April 9 in Cleveland.

Two major developments were reported yesterday in the Hofstadter legislative investigation of New York City. They were the refusal of State Senator John A. Hastings to answer questions before a subcommittee and the discovery that a $49,598.14 income tax lien had been filed against the property of Russell T. Sherwood, missing accountant of Mayor Walker.

Expansion will be continued by the W.T. Grant Company this year, leases for thirty-four new stores in sixteen States having been signed, and fifty-four stores were opened in 1931, according to the annual report made public yesterday for the year ended Jan. 31.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 21. -- Tornadoes late today and tonigh struck in four Southern States, killing ninety-five persons, injuring scores, rendering hundreds homeles and causing undetermined property damage.

BERLIN, March 21. -- Prices generally were maintained at today's session of the Boerse, but the turnover declined considerably, due to the approaching Easter holiday, which for the Boerse will begin on Thursday. There was some interest for Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd as a result of the comprehensive reconstruction plan announced on Saturday.

TOKYO, March 21 (AP). -- A nonpartisan "national" government, similar to the Cabinet of Prime Minister MacDonald in Great Britain, was seen today as the likeliest way out of difficulties threatening the administration of Premier Ki Inukai.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on March 16, shows increases for the week of $331,000,000 in investments, of which $312,000,000 was in government securities, of $394,000,000 in government deposits and of $22,000,000 in net demand deposits, and decreases of $48,000,000 in loans, $27,000,000 in time deposits and $69,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve banks.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 21. -- In place of the present two-thirds rule, a new rule providing for a majority vote to nominate the Democratic candidate for the Presidency was urged today by Homer S. Cummings, former national chairman, a supporter of Governor Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, March 21. -- Montgomery Ward Co.'s new organization setup, which has been worked out since the advent of Sewell L. Avery as chairman of the board, will be put into effect soon. It is designed to provide sufficient autonomy for the retail and mail-order divisions, which have differing problems, to enable each to operate with maximum smoothness and efficiency in its own field.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The House Ways and Means Committee today amended the sales tax project to exempt farm implements, wearing apparel, all foods, medical supplies and many miscellaneous items. This action, taken as a concession to opponents of the tax, wiped out $144,000,000 of estimated revenue.

TAMPA, Fla., March 21. -- Sitting in the lobby of the rambling Tampa Bay Hotel Harry Heilmann was telling of old times with the Detroit Tigers, of Hughey Jennings, Ty Cobb and Rob Roy Fothergill. There were some great hitters on the old Tiger teams and Handsome Harry was one of the best of them. Four times in his clouting career he led the American League in hitting.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 21 (AP). -- Wilbur B. Foshay, whose promotions grew from a few thousand dollars to control of enterprises he valued at more than $50,000,000 in twelve years, lost a court fight today to avoid being held criminally responsible for their collapse in 1929.

The International Paper and Power Company has almost completed the segregation of the paper and public utility branches of its business through the sale to the International Hydro-Electric System, for $31,700,000, of most of the water-power properties in the United States owned or controlled by the International Paper Company.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Tuesday, March 22 (AP). -- Japanese military authorities today reported insurgent uprising over a wide area in Eastern Kirin Province, which adjoins Soviet Russia on the east. More than 160 men were killed in a battle at Nahu, on the southern end of Lake Birten.

CHICAGO, March 21. -- With reiteration of reports from Washington that the Federal Farm Board's grain would not be dumped on the market, sufficient local and commission-house buying developed today on the Board of Trade here to advance prices rather sharply, although the day's news generally was regarded by many traders as rather bearish, especially in relation to the new crop.

The finest gifts of that remarkable artist, Jose Iturbi, were displayed when he gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Iturbi played eighteenth century music with a sense of proportion and wonderful polyphonic flow which were only the vehicles of its romantic spirit.

ATLANTA, March 21. -- William Nelson Taft of Philadelphia, editor of The Retail Ledger, predicted here today that credit conditions in 1932 would be "distinctly better." He spoke before the Southern Conference of the National Retail Credit Men's Association.
Former Assemblyman Robert K. Story Jr. was acquitted by a jury before County Judge McLaughlin in Brooklyn yesterday of a charge made on the complaint of a 16-year-old Brooklyn girl.
CHICAGO, March 21 (AP). -- The devotees of sun tan may wear next to nothing on the beach at Rogers Park on the North Shore next Summer -- but they may not bask in nothing at all.

LOS ANGELES, March 21. -- Exploiting, for sake of variety, the college football theory that a team can't be beaten that won't be beaten, the Giants chose today to remain in sublime ignorance of the fact that the Tigers were giving them quite a battle, and while this may have been a bit trying upon the nerves of John McGraw, it eventually brought about the desired result.

Final figures of the Census Bureau on cotton ginning showed yesterday that in its annual report in December the Crop Reporting Board had estimated the second largest crop on record to within 143,000 bales of the actual harvest, and prices on the Cotton Exchange held within a 10-point range of fluctuations.

"And then suddenly," as Mr. Winlock puts it, climaxing a description of the gorgeousness that must have attended processions of Amun in the days of Hat-shepsut of Egypt, who reigned about fifteen centuries B.C., "suddenly we realize the sham of it all.

City College's major Spring sports teams will engage in a total of thirty-six contests during the coming season, according to the schedules released yesterday. The baseball team will face twenty-one opponents, the lacrosse team nine and the track team will engage in four dual meets and two championship events.

Jack (Kid) Berg, English boxer, came back to New York rings last night with his perpetual -- motion style of punching and his tireless energy on the attack and carried off the decision over Buster Brown, chunky Baltimore welterweight, in the ten-round feature at the St. Nicholas Arena.

SHANGHAI, March 21 (AP). -- Chinese and Japanese negotiators reached a basis for peace today after long parleys here, while the League of Nations investigators viewed the scars of recent battle between the two forces.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- A test of strength between the Senate wets and drys is being arranged for the near future by Senator Tydings of Maryland, matching the roll-call in the House on the Beck-Linthicum resolution last week. Mr. Tydings is circulating a petition among his colleagues and expects by tomorrow to have gathered signatures sufficient to warrant an open show of wet sentiment in the Senate.

ALBANY, March 21. -- Governor Roosevelt in a veto message today rebuked promoters of legislation which would deprive the State Park Council of revenues from the parking of automobiles belonging to visitors in the State system. Under the present plan moneys from this course are paid into a revolving fund which is used from year to year for upkeep.

Van, Wyck Brooks, whose "The Life of Emerson" is the Literary Guild choice for April, writes that his book is largely an "imputed autobiography" of Emerson with the subject speaking largely for himself in phrases that were often his own, and that have been, in every case, carefully verified either from his own writings or the writings of contemporaries.

Details of "Tiger Room" financing during the final period of the drive to elect Alfred E. Smith President in 1923 are scheduled to have an airing in open court next month, it was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court when a motion was filed in the $50,000 suit instituted by the County Trust Company against Timothy J. Mara.

Supporters of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt expect him to make a material gain in the race for the Democratic nomination for President during the next two weeks. During this period, five States, Georgia, Maine, Iowa, Missouri and Arizona, will elect delegates to the national convention at primaries or State conventions, with the selection in the case of Arizona to be made by the State committee.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 21. -- John Sanford and his daughter, Miss Sarah Jane Sanford, entertained with a large dinner tonight at Villa Marina.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- Seeking wider opportunity for the physical and mental development of children, President Hoover today issued a proclamation setting aside May 1 as Child Health Day. It read:

The second day of Spring brought to New York freezing weather yesterday and a snowfall that measured slightly under half an inch. By a strange freak, the day's two extremes of temperature occurred within an hour in the morning. At 8:48 the thermometer registered 33, its highest during the day.

LONDON, March 21. -- Trading dwindled in the Stock Exchange today and even British Government funds, which were buoyant all last week, reacted slightly. The international issues were marked down as a result of Saturday's dullness in Wall Street.

Seven balkline stars arrived from Europe yesterday on the Ile de France ready for action in the world's amateur 18.2 tournament, which will start tomorrow night at the New York Elks Club, at 208 West Forty-third Street. They were greeted by a delegation of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players, which is sponsoring the championship.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An idea industriously propagated of late and accepted as axiomatic by people in general is that "reduced wages mean reduced purchasing power." It is only one of the economic revealments that have been handed out to the public gratuitously, but it is an immensely popular one.
LONDON, March 21. -- Princess Elizabeth's "wonder cottage," presented by the people of Wales, was destroyed by fire today while a motor truck was bringing it to London for exhibition.

MUKDEN, March 21. -- The new Manchoukuo Government announces that formal recognition was accorded to it by France and Italy on March 18, by Japan on March 19, by Estonia on March 20, and that favorable replies from other countries were expected soon.

SCRANTON, Pa., March 21. -- The insurgent element of the United Mine Workers of America, whose unauthorized strike entered its second week, today, suffered a setback when some of the collieries deserted last week were again manned by loyal union workers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am taking the liberty of replying to the letter of 9-year-old Marcia Singer of Far Rockaway, who wrote to THE TIMES a few days ago asking what depression means and whether you can feel it if it does not hurt you.

ATHENS, Ohio, March 21 (AP). -- A strict watch was maintained tonight by State and local authorities in the Hocking Valley coal mine field, where about 7,000 miners are on strike, after two National Guard Captains were stoned during the day.
WASHINGTON, March 21. -- A House committee failed today after six hours' energetic discussion to agree on a bill reducing Federal salaries as a means of economy.
WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Income taxes continued to reach the treasury through March 18, in accordance with advance estimates of Secretary Mills.

TOKYO, March 21. -- Despite the fact that Ambassador W. Cameron Forbes has had to conduct his office at a time when there has been great strain on the relations between Japan and the United States, he is leaving for home tomorrow amid manifestations of friendship from all ranks.

A WEEK ago Saturday Columbia and Cornell were in the throes of a desperate battle on the court of the Morningside Heights gymnasium. Players of both teams fought with unusual intensity. This was reflected in the unrepressed excitement of the spectators.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES dispatch "Democratic Wets Win Leading Dry," I find the following amazing statement: "It is accepted in Washington that he [President Hoover] agrees with a bit of political advice on the subject, relayed to him from Calvin Coolidge.

Directors of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, meeting last night at 305 Washington Street, instructed A.J. Gonnoud, national councilor to the annual meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce to be held in San Francisco, May 17 to 20, to ask the national chamber to carry to Congress the request that 2.75 per cent beer be legalized.

Medley G.B. Whelpley, president of the Nitrate Corporation of Chile, who returned yesterday from a conference with the Chilean Government regarding the status of the corporation and the basis for future operations in view of the overproduction in the nitrogen industry throughout the world, announced that his conferences had been both "illuminating and satisfactory."

The adjusted index of automobile, production shows a further decline to 33.5 for the week ended March 19 from 34.8 for the preceding week and 60.2 for the corresponding week last year. Actual output, according to Cram's Automotive Reports, was 34,135 units, as against 34.587 for the preceding week and 61,457 for the corresponding week last year.

LOS ANGELES, March 21 (AP). -- Dr. Arthur H. Compton, Nobel Prize winner and physicist at the University of Chicago, arrived here today, ready to establish stations in the far corners of the earth in a hope he may "trap" the cosmic ray.

Through a decision of the Appellate Division, allowing the former Cohoes Light and Power Corporation only $82,500 on its $1,500,000 damage claim against the city in connection with up-State water-supply development, the city has saved $1,417,500, Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly said yesterday.

LONDON, March 21. -- The British rubber industry was relieved rather than disappointed at the failure of the Anglo-Dutch negotiations for restriction of output. Although rubber shares fell heavily at the start of trading today, they steadied later and prevailing sentiment was that the industry now knows where it stands.

MADRID, March 21. -- Plans for a big-scale Communist revolution early in April on a united front in Spain were uncovered by the government with the arrest on Saturday of Ramon Casanellas, who is said to have murdered Premier Eduardo Dato in 1921 and fled to Russia.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The Supreme Court today held unconstitutional that part of the revenue law of 1926 which provides that transfers of property within two years before death shall arbitrarily be held to have been made "in contemplation of death."

A chapter of the Memoirs of the late GUSTAV STRESEMANN was published in the Revue de Paris of March 1. It caused something of a sensation at the French capital, because it comprised an account of STRESEMANN'S negotiations with HERRIOT at London and elsewhere.

LONDON, March 21. -- A movement is afoot in England to hold a great exhibition of American art at Burlington House comparable to the brilliant displays of French, Italian and Dutch art of recent Winters.

Potatoes and tomatoes, it appears, are not the only commodities notably cheaper this year. The range and quality of "attractive objects costing not more than 25 cents," which the Art Alliance of America is presenting at the Art Centre indicate that persons anxious to follow Eddie Cantor's well-known advice could fit up an apartment with a few pieces of soft-pine furniture and a pocketful of nickels, dimes and quarters.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Responding to pressure from many quarters, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today decided to hold public hearings on the Glass banking reform bill. They probably will begin Wednesday morning.

Four matches were completed in the third round of the Class C championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association last night on the courts of the Downtown Athletic Club. H.F. Baker of the Princeton Club, J.H. Manning, a clubmate, and two Harvard Club players, W. T. Emmett and L.H. Rouillion, reached the fourth round as the result of the play.

Stocks moved nervously and within narrow range yesterday, reflecting the continued uncertainty of speculative professionals as to the probable course of the market. Trading on the Stock Exchange involved fewer than 900,000 shares. Early weakness was due largely to the reported possibility of a disagreement over the tax legislation in Congress.

Contradicting recent reports from the Pacific Coast, it was learned on good authority last night that Mrs. Helen Wills Moody of San Francisco, women's national tennis champion, is planning to return to Europe this year in quest of the French and English championships.
ST. LOUIS, March 21 (AP). -- Dr. Carol Skinner Cole left Lambert-St. Louis Field at 8:40 o'clock last night, explaining she was hastening to the bedside of her daughter, Mrs. William T. Bingham.

The Senate had a delightful time last Thursday characteristically wasting two hours in discussing what is not. A newspaper report had it that Ambassador MELLON's first duty on reaching London will be to open negotiations for a revision of the British war debts settlement.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Confidence that "in time the sympathy of the Western powers will turn gradually in favor of Japan" in considering the Far Eastern crisis wag expressed by Kenkichi Yoshizawa, the Japanese Foreign Minister, in an address tonight (tomorrow Tokyo time) before the special session of the Diet in Japan, made public here by the Japanese Ambassador.

The annual observance by members of Jewish congregations of Purim, the Feast of Lots, was begun yesterday at sundown and will continue today. About 1,000 persons attended a play entitled "Esther," given last night by the Association Players at the Young Men's Hebrew Association building, Ninety-second Street and Lexington Avenue.

Reversing the result of their meeting in this series a year ago, Jean Borotra. French Davis Cup veteran, defeated Frank Shields of New York last night to earn an even division of the spoils for his country in the opening session of the Franco-American team match at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.
The "Block-Aid" organization of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee entered its final week of recruiting yesterday with the announcement that 4,338 block chairmen had now been enrolled.

LONDON, March 21 (AP). -- New facts on the Oldoway Man, whose skeleton was found in Tanganyika, East Africa, in 1913, have been discovered by an expedition now exploring there, A.T. Hopwood of the London Museum of Natural History announces.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21. -- Such interest has been displayed in coming court hearings on the audit of the closed Bankers Trust Company's accounts that Judge Thomas D. Finletter today requisitioned the Municipal Convention Hall.

If dispatches from Chicago may be trusted, the Federal Farm Board has the best of reasons for moving to dispose of its surplus stocks of wheat. The present holdings of the board, added to those in private hands, are now so large that some action must be taken to reduce them if storage room is to be found for the new crop when it comes on the market in another ninety days.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- Big salaries paid by Farm Board subsidiaries were defended today by C.E. Huff, president of the Farmers' National Grain Corporation, with an assertion that results counted more than cost of operation.

Garret Hixson Wilson, superintendent of the Hudson, Harlem and Putnam divisions of the New York Central Railroad, died suddenly last night of heart disease at his home, 25 Overlook Street, Mount Vernon, in his sixty-sixth year.

PARIS, March 21. -- Opening heavy today, the Bourse was affected by weakness which developed rapidly in several leading international stocks. Rio Tinto, Royal Dutch and Canadian Pacific declined sharply and Kreuger Toll obligations, following advices from Stockholm, dropped from 39 to 30.

Lord Inverforth, English shipping man and the new head of the Lipton Tea Company, will arrive today on the Cunard liner Mauretania. Sir Ashley Sparks, resident director of the Cunard Line in the United States, is also on the Mauretania. Others on board are:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 21. -- The old homestead known as the Miller House in North White Plains, which for many years has been glorified by the phrase "Washington's headquarters," was never used by the General on his frequent visits to Westchester County during the Revolutionary War, according to an article in the current issue of The Westchester Historical Society Bulletin by William S. Hadaway, its president.

The French liner Ile de France docked yesterday with one passenger who was not on board when the ship left Havre. He was Pierre Vanlaer, member of a wealthy French family, and an amateur aviator, who had been rescued from the English Channel.

Gar Wood, holder of the world's speed-boat record of 111.712 miles an hour, made at Miami, Fla., last month, is building a new boat to defend the international Harmsworth Trophy at Detroit next September.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Six changes in the operations of leading radio manufacturers controlling most of the radio patents, as the result of negotiations by the Department of Justice, were reported to the Senate Judiciary Committee today by Attorney General Mitchell.
CHICAGO, March 21. -- An offer of help to Chicago's 14,000 school teachers, who have received only two and a half months pay in almost a year, came from New York City school teachers today.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- The battle within a battle as foreign correspondents at Shanghai sought to get their "war" news back home was described today by Charles Stephenson Smith, of the Washington Bureau of the Associated Press, before the Institute of Far Eastern Affairs.

Allan Jardine, unattached, won the decision from Edward Robinson, also unattached, in the 135-pound class final of the amateur boxing tournament at the New York A.C. last night. Jardine defeated William Iacavene in the semi-finals and Robinson advanced by stopping John Francis in the second round.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 21. -- Lou Gehrig and Frank Crosetti joined the Yankee home-run-hitting set today as the McCarthy athletes scored their first triumph of the year outside of St. Petersburg.

OVER the Party Wall. The non-partisan spirit frequently displayed by the present Congress has led many to exclaim how good it is to see brethren dwelling together in unity. Last week the effect of brotherly love between Democrats and Republicans took a practical turn.

BOSTON, March 21. -- Mayor Curley today opened Governor Roosevelt's Massachusetts campaign for a pledged delegation to the Democratic National Convention with an address in which he denounced Alfred E. Smith as having divided the party. At the same time Mayor Curley eliminated himself from the Gubernatorial race.

The annual report of the American Gas and Electric Company for 1931 shows net income of $16,671,135, after charges, taxes, depreciation, subsidiary preferred dividends and minority interests, equal after preferred dividends to $3.57 a share earned on 4,064,997 common shares, against $19,238,012, or $4.37 a share, on 3,907,812 common shares in 1930.

Changes in the list of securities considered legal for investment by savings banks in this State were announced yesterday by the State Banking Department. Bonds of four municipalities were added to the list and those of five were dropped. One railroad bond issue and nine public utility issues were added to the list.

ROME, March 21. -- The fourth arrest in Vatican City in the more than three years' existence of that tiny State was made today when papal gendarmes found a man committing irreverent acts in front of the statue of St. Peter in St. Peter's basilica.

Arthur S. Vernay, explorer and big game hunter, returned on the French liner Ile de France yesterday and told of his successful expedition to Perak in the Federated Malay States, where he bagged a one-horned rhinoceros, or sondaicus, after searching for the rare animal since 1926.

A group of women active in the management of the Community of St. Johnland, in Kings Park, L.I., has taken over part of the seating capacity of Madison Square Garden for the performance of Ringling Brothers' and Barnum Bailey's Circus on the afternoon of April 15 to raise funds for the community, which provides homes and a chapel for needy men, women and children, also a school for the children.

Religious pedigrees acquired by denominational affiliations of long standing are of no value unless in addition to the badge of church membership there be plainly discernible in the lives of the members the identifying marks of Christlike sacrifice. Gipsy Smith, the evangelist, told more than 1.800 persons yesterday noon at the opening meeting of the eleventh annual Holy Week services in the Palace Theatre.
AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 21. -- Phar Lap dozed behind stoutly barred stable doors today, resting after his astonishing victory yesterday in the $50,000 added Agua Caliente Handicap.

The World Trade League of the United States, organized here last month to conduct a series of nonpartisan mass meetings throughout the country advocating a "bargaining" or reciprocal tariff instead at a tariff continually rising, held its first dinner mass meeting at the Hotel Astor last night.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, March 21 (AP) -- The fog-laden Ohio River Valley tonight obscured the fate of a woman physician who ventured on a stormy midnight plane ride to hurry to the bedside of her ill daughter after the wreckage of the plane and the pilot's body were discovered near here.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 (AP). -- Edward M. Biddle, a Philadelphia attorney, repeated today that he was not alarmed over the request of his wife for an airplane or dogsled to take her out of Katishna, Alaska, where she is snowbound.

Within half an hour after they had carried out two small hold-ups, three youthful gunmen were captured last night by detectives and after prolonged questioning confessed, the police said, that they had perpetrated fifteen robberies on the lower east side in the last month, in which they had realized about $8,000.

The Transit Commission announced yesterday the cancellation of the public hearing set for April 4 on its tentative $474,500,000 unification plan. Chairman William G. Fullen said that the date of the next hearing would be made public at least ten days in advance.

NEW YORK. Marchese and Marchesa Niccolo Antinori arrived yesterday on the Saturnia and are at the Weylin. The Marchesa is the former Signoreta Carlotta della Gherardesca, a granddaughter of the late Henry A.C. Taylor.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Senator Barkley of Kentucky tonight declared himself in favor of the nomination of Governor Roosevelt of New York for President in declining an offer of friends in Kentucky to have that State's delegates instructed to work for his own nomination.

Silas H. Strawn, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce and also of the International Chamter of Commerce, will arrive today on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. He has been visiting foreign divisions of the organization.

Fewer Buyers Due to Holiday. Due to the early Easter season the number of buyers registered in the market for the past week showed a decrease as compared with the figures for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The movement to oppose the nomination of President Hoover, first fostered by some insurgent Republicans, has been revived, although Senators Johnson and Norris refused to lead it and recently declined to give their support to Governor Pinchot.

The Southern California Edison Company, Ltd., in 1931 had to meet severe contraction of industrial and commercial activities of large consumers, subnormal water conditions, lower rate schedules voluntarily adopted by the company and adjustment of organization personnel due to the completion of large and extended construction work, such as the Big Creek hydroelectric project, John B. Miller, chairman of the board, says in his annual report, the thirtyfirst to be issued under his administration.

READING, Pa., March 22 -- Each scoring nineteen out of twenty fliers, Martin McVoy Jr. of the New York Athletic Club, Allen A. Frantz of Myerstown, Pa., and Samuel T. kurtz, former Middle States amateur champion, divided the high-gun honors today in the Cedar Top preliminary handicap, the opening event of the Cedar Top Gun Club's three-day amateur flyer trapshooting tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- William G.McAdoo today advocated Federal legislation guaranteeing wheat and cotton farmers a minimum price for their products. He made this suggestion in a formal statement on the economic situation.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The Red Cross spread its relief wings in six States today to succor living victims of last night's tornadoes. Officials said their relief machine was functioning in Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee, Kentucky, South Carolina and Ohio.

Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter committee, struck back yesterday at the renewed defiance of Senator John A. Hastings and laid the ground-work for another court battle to jail the legislator. Mr. Seabury announced that on Monday he would move before the full committee to have Senator Hastings cited for contempt for refusing to testify before a subcommittee of one.

While George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, carrying on his campaign to rout hangers-on from the corridors of the Federal Building, forwarded to the State Superintendent of Insurance yesterday the names of four bondsmen accused of charging exhorbitant rates for writing bail, the eight judges of the United States District Court issued orders yesterday supporting the Federal Attorney's program.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- By way of a fitting start for his twenty-first season of major league pitching, Herb Pennock twirled five no-hit innings today in the course of the Yankees' 2-0 victory over the Boston Braves.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Twenty-four Senators today signed a petition circulated by Senator Tydings of Maryland asking for an opportunity to vote on the question of repeal or modification of the Eighteenth Amendment. Thirteen were Republicans and eleven were Democrats.

LWOW, Poland, March 22 (AP) -- Emilian Czechowski, chief of the Polish political police, was slain today by persons believed by the police to be terrorists from the Ukraine, and several persons were arrested.

GENEVA, March 22 -- China, in a note dated March 19, reported to the League of Nations that its Far East inquiry commission was considering prolonging its stay at Shanghai to participate in the peace negotiations and protested that would delay accomplishment of its "principal" duty, the examination of the Manchuria question.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- The smallest arrivals for a Tuesday since March, 1929, and a fairly active shipping demand today lifted prices of hogs 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight from yesterday's levels. Heavyweights, which led the decline yesterday, showed the most strength.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a great admirer and constant reader of your paper and rarely find cause to disagree with any of your editorial views.

LONDON, March 22 -- A bill legalizing lotteries in Great Britain for raising money for charitable, scientific and artistic purposes after the manner of the Irish Hospitals Sweepstakes passed on its first reading in the House of Commons today by a vote of 176 to 123.

WINNIPEG, Man., March 22 (Canadian Press) -- Walter Lindrum world's English billiard champion, today shattered the Canadian record with a break of 1,349 in 1 hour and 20 seconds of play against Tommy Newman, former English champion, in the second day of their exhibition match.

BOSTON, March 22 -- Posing as the uncle of Mary Di Batista, 15 years old, to have her excused from classes in the Continuation School on Common Street. Charles Russo, 32, of Newark, N.J., abducted the girl today, according to police of the East Boston Station.

The familiar tale of the immigrant boy who made good, retold in terms of social criticism, sprinkled with satirical thrusts, in the autogiography of Louis Adamic, called "Laughing in the Jungle," was published yesterday by Harper Brothers.
PARIS, March 22 -- In an analysis of the French budget situation presented to the Senate today Senator Abel Gardey disclosed a situation which he regarded as far from satisfactory.

LONDON, March 22 -- The stock market was stronger today, but price movements were only fractional. Profit-taking caused slight declines in British Government funds. Cables and Wireless was outstanding among the industrials, the 5 1/2 per cent preference stock rallying to 48 1/2 per cent of par, then declining to 48 per cent.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Liquidation of lines of long wheat by houses with Eastern connections, some selling credited to foreign accounts and a bearish construction placed on official statements from Washington regarding contemplated sales of the Federal Farm Board's wheat carried prices off today as much as 3 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish to a new low mark on the current downturn on the Board of Trade here.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Arthur J.W. Hilly, Corporation Counsel for New York City, today urged renewal of the license of WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station, and opposed renewal for Station WMCA, New York. In a brief filed with the Radio Commission he also opposed changes in the frequency assignment of Station WPCH, New York.

PARIS, March 22 -- After a week of strenuous effort which, until yesterday, seemed certain to fail, the International Sugar Council disbanded today with a new plan of regulation for world sugar production and export quotas. The terms have not been divulged as yet, pending settlement of certain minor points with Cuba, but it is hoped that complete agreement will be reached by tomorrow.

With only a taste of Spring in midafternoon yesterday, drying sidewalks wetted by the morning's rain which had been preceded by a freezing mist, the metropolitan area found, the weather continuing to belie the season last night when the temperature had fallen in five hours from 58 degrees to 38 at 8 o'clock.

LONDON, March 22 -- George Lansbury, leader of the Labor Opposition in the House of Commons, precipitated another debate tonight on British foreign policy by asking Sir John Simon. Foreign Secretary, for a statement concerning the Far Eastern situation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 22 (AP) -- The De Facto President of Brazil, Getulio Vargas, tonight agreed to sign a decree fixing dates for general elections to restore constitutional government to the country. No dates were mentioned, but it was understood that the decree would satisfy a demand from the State of Rio Grande do Sul for prompt termination of President Vargas's military rule.

The proposed tariff on crude oil and some of its products imported by this country would result in "little, if any," additional revenue, but it would have disastrous effects on the American-owned Mexican oil industry and would cause the oil bunkering business on the Atlantic seaboard to be diverted to European ports, according to Jose Miguel Be- jarano, secretary of the Mexican Chamber of Commerce of the United States, with headquarters at 74 Trinity Place.

State of West Virginia. The State of West Virginia has set March 28 as the date for opening bids on its issue of $2,000,000 of highway bonds, due $80,000 annually from 1933 to 1957. The issue will be sold as not exceeding 4 1/2 s.

The arrival of Spring has brought an expanded construction schedule on the first buildings in Rockefeller Centre, and 1,600 workmen now are employed on the site of the midtown office and amusement project, the largest number of men yet placed on the job, a survery yesterday showed.

Sir Ashley Sparks, director of the Cunard Line in the United States and Canada, returned from a visit to England yesterday on the Cunard liner Mauretania and expressed the belief that England was definitely on the "up-grade." He advised Americans who had "lost their optimism" to visit England.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In connection with the discussions of an official embargo on trade with Japan, in view of the violations by Japanese military forces of the Kellogg-Briand pact and other international agreements to keep the peace, and of the "consumers' boycott" of Japanese goods which has been started, it seems to me that the following considerations should be borne in mind.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The peril that lies in the recent legislation passed by Congress for the rehabilitation of American industry is the acceptance by a vastly increasing number of Americans of the erroneous theory that the government is all-powerful and the only source from which can be drawn the capital and aid that will bring back prosperity.

PARIS, March 22 -- Despite Ambassador Frederic M. Sackett's denials that his visit to Paris had any political significance at all, it is being still treated in the French press as having some mysterious motive behind it. There were at least a dozen leading articles in the Paris newspapers today heavy with suggestion as to what the United States Ambassador to Berlin has brought to Paris or come seeking.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- House foes of the 2.25 per cent sales tax wrote into the revenue bill today a provision to increase the present estate taxes to a degree designed to yield, eventually, $500,000,000 annually in new revenue.

Reduction of governmental expenditures, national, State and local, is a prerequisite to sound business recovery, Calvin Coolidge declared yesterday in an article on "Debts and Taxes" published in the current issue of The Saturday Evening Post.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the admission to dealings on a when-issued basis of $8,700,000 New York Steam Corporation first mortgage gold bonds, 5 per cent series, due in 1956. The bonds at the same time were removed from unlisted trading privilege on the Curb Exchange.

On the first day of the recent legislative session, Assemblyman LEWIS of Oswego introduced three bills amending the conservation law. One of them changed the open season for cottontail rabbits in Oswego and explicitly authorized the use of ferrets in hunting them.

WEIMAR, Germany, March 22 -- This little Thuringian capital -- the cradle of the Republican Constitution of the new Germany and one of the strongholds of German fascism -- presented itself again today as "the town of the muses" as notables in the world of letters, science and politics paid tribute to the genius of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, who died here 100 years ago.

The National Credit Corporation, organized last October at the instance of President Hoover to make loans to needy banks on assets which are not eligible for rediscount by the Federal Reserve Banks, has notified banks which subscribed to its notes that on next Monday 15 per cent of the notes outstanding will be paid off.

BOSTON, March 22 -- The Roosevelt slate of delegates to the Democratic National Convention, to be voted on at the Presidential primary on April 26, was filed today with the Secretary of State by Mayor J. M. Curley.

TRENTON, N.J., March 22 -- Lacking one of the eleven, votes required for passage, Senator Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic County, floor leader of the Republican majority, failed today to move the Assemblybill for repeal of the State prohibition enforcement act.

Efforts of the Kreuger Toll Company management to adjust to the deflation in business and in security prices were disclosed by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in a statement showing the collateral behind the 5 per cent debentures of the company maturing in 1959.

DESSAU, Germany, March 22 -- The Junkers concern, including the Research Institute, Junkers Co., the Junkers Airplane Works and the Junkers Motor Company today announced the suspension of payments to creditors. To avoid bankruptcy and to protect the interests of all creditors, application has been filed for a legal settlement with them.

TOKYO, March 22 -- Declaring that a "desirable consummation" of the Manchurian problem was of more importance to Japan than even the Russo-Japanese War had been, Lieut. Gen. Sadao Araki, the Minister of War, told the Diet today that even larger forces should be stationed there if possible.

PARIS, March 22 -- An automatic radio, immensely simplifying the process of sending messages, was demonstrated here today by its inventor, Jacques Detruiseux, before representatives of the Ministries of War, Posts and Telegraphs, Merchant Marine and Public Works.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 -- The Tigers unexpectedly upset everything today by giving the Giants a jolly thrashing, 11 to 2. Among other things, they upset John McGraw by swatting two of his pitchers for eighteen hits. They also cut the Giants' lead in the exhibition series right in half, the McGrawmen's margin now being only two games to one.

Following a mass meeting at the steps of the Columbia University library at 1 o'clock this afternoon, upward of 200 Students from Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Columbia, City College, Hunter College, New York University and Smith College will depart by bus and automobile for Kentucky to make an impartial survey of conditions in Harlan and Bell counties, where the coal miners are on strike.

John C. Judge, Brooklyn lawyer, delivered last night the keynote speech, in the Kings County Roose-velt-for-President campaign, which he has been appointed to lead. Mr. Judge spoke on "Franklin Roosevelt, the Man," at a meeting of the Flatbush Division of the Young Folks Democratic League in the Flatbush Club, Ocean Avenue and Avenue K, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Having recently passed its preferred dividend for the first time since 1900, the Baltimore Ohio Railroad today followed the action of its competitor, the Pennsylvania, in applying to the Interstate Commerce Commission for approval of a three-year loan of $55,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Sixteen players from New York, Philadelphia, Tuxedo and Boston will start play today in the United States amateur court tennis singles championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

The tornado which caused death and destruction in Alabama on Monday afternoon and blasted a course over the boundaries of other States was one of the worst ever generated in the Mississippi Valley. The conditions producing such storms are warm, humid air in conflict with cooler layers above them, in lowpressure areas.

PESHAWAR, India, March, 22 -- With the coming of Spring the young Indian border tribesmen's fancy always turns to thoughts of war. It is a period of acute anxiety for the Government of India and a grueling one for the British Royal Air Force.

LONDON, March 22 -- A new wave of hopefulness was manifest in ship- ping circles tonight that work would soon be resumed on the 73,000-ton Cunard liner half-built on the Clydeside ways. Several members of Parliament intend to goad the government into action now that Germany has guaranteed a huge loan to aid her shipping, and the Cunard directors are again approaching London banks for a loan.

MUNICH, March 22 -- New York might have been a Bavarian town had the British not occupied New Amsterdam at the decisive moment and forcibly made the Dutch settlement an English colony, ancient documents incidentally discovered in the Munich archives disclose.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 22 -- Defeating the House of David team today, 19 to 3, the Robins enjoyed a lot of batting and base-running practice which was rather useful, since they had previously gone through five games without a victory.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Veterans' bonus advocates in the House insisted today that Congress will approve at this Session full payment of the World War adjusted compensation certificates. The view was expressed by two Democratic Representatives, Patman of Texas, and Connery of Massachusetts, who criticized the statement made yesterday by Representative Johnson, Republican, of South Dakota, that he had told President Hoover sentiment against payment of the bonus was increasing.

A 21-year-old girl stood on the pier of the Cunard Line at the foot of West Fourteenth Street yesterday morning peering across the rainswept Hudson to the decks of the liner Mauretania. On the ship, Louis Rousseau, French tenor, stood watching the pier.

MANILA, March 22 -- Governor General Roosevelt began his first provincial inspection trip today, motoring from Manila to Cabanatuan, the capital of Nueva Ecija Province. He was greeted with the warmest hospitality and enthusiasm.

Another drop of 1/4 in time money to 2 3/4 @3 per cent, with 90 days' lending at 3, and a cut of 1/8 in yield on acceptances, all dates, represented the highlights of the business in the money market. Maturity money is now quoted at the lowest since last November, and acceptances unmatched since last October.

In an open letter to Senator Borah yesterday Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt wrote that her forty years of experience as a suffrage leader had led her to fear that proposed membership of the United States in the World Court is now "being gently hitched along toward the shelf that has received so many good causes when a Presidential election approaches."

That section of the revenue act of 1926 which, provides that a transfer of property made within two years of a decedent's death shall be held to have been made in contemplation of death, and shall be included in the decedent's gross estate and made subject to the death transfer tax, was declared invalid by the Supreme Court on Monday.
DETROIT, March 22 (AP) -- The leaders remained unchanged in the thirty-second annual American Bowling Congress tourney today as several bowlers missed excellent chances of overtaking the leaders.

The stockholders of the Electric Bond and Share Company approved by a large majority yesterday the plan to issue one new common share for each three common shares now outstanding, to give the new stock a par value of $5 a share, against no par value for present shares, and to transfer from capital to surplus an amount of approximately $123,000,000.

The Hans Lange String Quartet, consisting, besides Hans Lange, of Arthur Schuller, Zoltan Kurthy and Percy Such, gave a concert in Steinway Hall last night, with Frank Sheridan, pianist, as assisting artist The ensemble gave Zoltan Kodaly's quartet No. 2, Schubert's posthumous "Quartett-Satz," and Ernest Bloch's quintet for piano and strings.

The Musicians Emergency Aid, with estimated proceeds from Josef Hoffmann's concert on April 3 included, will be within $10,000 of the goal of $300,000 set by the committee, Walter Damrosch, its chairman, announced yesterday in the Astor Hotel at the close of the Silver Symphony Finale in which opera, concert and motion-picture stars, writers and club women took part.

So far as the stock market was concerned, Wall Street might have taken a day off yesterday. Transactions on the Stock Exchange involved slightly more than 1,000,000 shares and the drift of prices was so slow and uninteresting as to excite virtually no comment.

In the face of strength in United States Government bonds and rallying tendencies in domestic corporation issues, foreign loans, notably German issues, were weaker yesterday in the bond market of the New York Stock Exchange. Bonds of the Kreuger Toll group continued lower.

DAIREN, Manchuria, March 22 -- Demolition of a motor railway car on the South Manchuria Railway by a mine that also destroyed a section of track, and a clash between insurgents and Japanese troops near Lake Chingpo in which the former suffered twenty-eight casualties and the latter large losses added today to the gravity of the widespread, rising in Kirin Province against the Japanese and the new Manchoukuo Government.

BERLIN, March 22 -- German industry, taken as a whole, no longer yields a profit, and if this situation lasts a little longer there must be a collapse, Dr. Hermann Buecher, director of the Allgemeine Elektrizitaetsgesellschaft, the second largest electrical manufacturer in Germany, declared at a stockholders' meeting today.

WASHINGTON, March. 22 -- Per- sistent reports that the Farm Board contemplates "dumping" its stabilization wheat holdings and that George S. Milnor, general manager of the Farmers National Grain Corporation, had gone to Europe for that purpose, were again denied by James C. Stone, chairman of the Farm Board, and C.E. Huff, president of the Grain Corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I believe it was Edmond A. Walsh in his authoritative work. "The Last Stand," who said: "Mr. Walter Duranty, whose dispatches to THE NEW YORK TIMES may be safely accepted as aceurate interpretation of the Soviet point of view."
A former member of Detroit's notorious "purple gang" was being sought here last night by police in the kidnapping of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's infant son just three weeks ago.

A few days ago the 1932 list of Guggenheim fellowships was announced, and it is very interesting to have now on exhibition work by one of the 1931 fellows, Joseph Pollet, whose show at the Downtown Gallery opened yesterday. Here we may see what a fellowship did for one artist.

PARIS, March 22 -- After opening Somewhat firmer today the Bourse Experienced new attacks on leading stocks and prices fell steadily throughout the session. Selling began on Royal Dutch and Citroen, soon extending to others, but trading during the latter part of the session practically was suspended.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 22 (AP) -- The Boston Cubs clinched second place in the Canadian-American League tonight when they defeated the league-leading Rhode Island Reds, 6 to 4, in a hotly contested overtime game.

Surprised by detectives of the Safe and Loft Squad in the midst of the hold-up early last evening of a fur shop at 343 Amsterdam Avenue, the leader of three youthful thugs had the audacity to try to convince the detectives that he was the proprietor of the establishment.

"Merry-Go-Round," a play by George Sklar and Albert Maltz, is scheduled to open at the Provincetown Playhouse on April 19 or 20, under the management of Shepard Traube, Walter Hart and Michael Blankforth. In a cast numbering twenty-nine players will be Ian Maclaren, Elisha Cook Jr., Viola Frayne, Sayre Crawley, Walter Fenner, Ruth Thomas and Gregory Robins.

Retirement of Mr. JESSE ISIDOR STRAUS as Chairman of the State Emergency Relief Administration was not unexpected. He took up last October the exacting duties of that position with the distinct understanding that he could not serve out a full year.

A sharp gain in retail failures featured business defaults for the week ended March 17, according to Bradstreet's. The retail embarrassments numbered 415, as against 367 in the previous week. The manufacturing and commercial service groups were the only ones to register a decline.

A jury in Supreme Court yesterday awarded a verdict of $40,000 to Mrs. Mabel Manton in her $100,000 suit for alienation of affections against Marjorie Rambeau, actress. The jury, sitting in the case before Justice Phoenix Ingraham, deliberated less than a half-hour.

Fresh declines were encountered in the commodity markets yesterday, new lows for the year being recorded in cash corn, oats, flour and silk. In futures, the grains, cotton, sugar, cocoa, rubber, silk, hides and coffee declined. Dairy products and some of the metals were steady.

The Metropolitan Jockey Club, which conducts racing at Jamaica, announced yesterday through its president, Edward P. Kilroe, the schedule of stake events for the opening of the metropolitan season, which shows that stake values will be maintained.

Dr. Edward C. Stempel, pastor of the Moravian Church, of New Dorp, S.I., and civic worker, died yesterday in the Staten Island Hospital at New Brighton of pneumonia, after an illness of six days. He was 51 years old.

The world's amateur 18.2 balkline billiard championship will start tonight at the New York Elks Club at 108 West Forty-third Street, with Albert Poensgen of Germany defending his laurels against eight other players. The entries comprise one of the strongest fields ever assembled for a world's tournament.

BOSTON, March 22 (AP) -- Before the time for filing withdrawals expires it is expected that some changes, chiefly in the Democratic slates, will be made. The last day for filing vacancies caused through withdrawals is next Tuesday, at which time the then-standing tickets will go into the primaries, April 26.

PARIS, March 22 -- Further governmental help to the French Line was refused today by the Chamber of Deputies Finance Commission when it rejected, after considerable discussion, a government bill for a second guaranteed loan of 68,000,000 francs, or $2,700,000, to enable the company to continue its building program, at least to the extent of finishing ships already laid down.

The clergyman who would have Easter week symbols banished forgets that the Christian church "planted the seeds of the new faith on the old stock of paganism." It consecrated whatever it touched and made secular things in everyday life holy vessels of its spirit.

Stockholders of the Reliance International Corporation upheld its officers and directors in approving all changes recommended, at the annual meeting held in Trenton yesterday, thereby ending the first stage of the fight for control of the Reliance Management Corporation which has been going on for more than a month.

The Social Science Research Council, 230 Park Avenue, which, with the financial support of several of the country's largest private foundations, has financed world-wide researches into social and economic problems, announced yesterday that it had made a special grant of $25,000 to enable Dr. Charles A. Beard, historian, to undertake a study of the topic "National Interest."

Flexible tariff provisions authorizing the President to write new language into the 1930 tariff law were held unconstitutional in a unanimous decision handed down here yesterday by the Second Division of the "United States Customs Court.

BAYARD, Fla., March 22 -- Although four of the seven favorites won at St. John's Park today, great interest developed in long shots since some unusual prices were returned. In the sixth race H.A. Coulson's Dr. Syntax was the winner at $5.60 for $2, but the second horse, Clare Bea, returned $98.60 for place, and $236.30 to show.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Heated personalities were injected into the discussions at the Institute for Far Eastern Affairs at American University today when Frederick Moore of this city, formerly foreign councilor to the Japanese Foreign Ministry, and Judge Paul M. Linebarger, legal adviser to the National Government of China, also of this city, indulged in acrimonious discussion.

The opening of "We Are No Longer Children" announced for April 4 at the Booth Theatre, has been advanced to Thursday evening of next week, March 31. June Walker and Geoffrey Kerr will head the cast of the play, an adaptation from the French, which is being directed by William A. Brady Jr. and Leslie Howard, the former of whom is the producer.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 22 -- Stockholders of the Packard Electric Company of Warren, Ohio, manufacturer of automobile cables, will vote on April 6 on a plan to sell their company to the General Motors Corporation, its largest customer. Terms tentatively approved by the majority of the Warren Company's directors are the exchange of one share of General Motors common stock for three shares of Packard Electric.

SAN PEDRO, Cal., March 22 -- "Every naval officer of experience believes the battleship is the fundamental strength of the navy. Everything else is auxiliary to it," Admiral Frank R. Schofield, Commander-in-Chief of the United States fleet, said today in commenting on the results of the recent war game between the Black and Blue forces off the California coast.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Dr. Harold W. Thompson, a member of the faculty of the State College for Teachers, was notified today of his election to membership in the Royal Society of Edinburgh. The honor was bestowed in recognition of research work in Scottish literature.

The Union Pacific System reported yesterday an increase in net operating income for February despite a decrease in gross. The Norfolk Western reported decreases in gross and net. Returns for January brought down to net income by other railroads showed continued declines.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Senate for the second time sent a general appropriation bill back to the Appropriations Committee to be cut arbitrarily 10 per cent under the total voted by the House, when it today voted, 50 to 29, to recommit the "four-department" appropriation bill.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 22 -- Mayor Walker of New York City has decided to extend his visit in Hot Springs until some time next week, he said this evening following another quiet day in the Homestead Hotel where he is taking a rest cure.

A program of interior renovation which will alter the appearance of the United States liner Leviathan in most of her important aspects is under way at the Hoboken pier, where she is laid up awaiting departure for Boston on April 17 for drydocking prior to her return to the transatlantic service on April 26.

The directors of the Fox Film Corporation yesterday elected Sidney R. Kent, formerly vice president of the Paramount Publix Corporation, as vice president in charge of operations of the Fox company. Leonard A. Woolams, formerly vice president of the Transamerica Corporation, was elected a vice president of the motion picture company to supervise its West Coast finances.

COLUMBIA, Mo., March 22 (AP) -- Three engineering students were shot, and one of them seriously wounded, tonight as the outgrowth of the "kidnapping." Saturday of Miss Mary Butterfield of Kansas City, who had been chosen as St. Pat's Queen for the Engineering School's annual dance.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, March 23 -- A last-minute refusal by General Chiang Kwang-nai, Chinese commander at Shanghai, to attend the meeting designed to conclude the armistice with Japan, again defeated attempts to achieve an official cessation of hostilities.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- For the fourth time in two weeks a notice saying "No Press Conference Today" was displayed on the White House Bulletin Board today.

In observation of the one hundredth anniversary of the death of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, a memorial assembly of students at Barnard College was held yesterday, at which Mme. Ernestine Schumann-Heink sang and spoke; a message was read from Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, who is now in Georgia, and a short address was delivered by Dr. Wilhelm Braun, head of the German department at Barnard.

In so far as could be judged from surface appearances, the swing in several markets yesterday was occasioned by aggressive professional transactions. This was almost certainly true of the wheat market, from which the stock market for a time appeared to take its cue.

BOSTON, March 22 -- The New York Americans and the Boston Bruins, tail-enders in the National Hockey League, tonight closed their seasons in a high-scoring game before a crowd of 15,000. Neither team was willing to use aggressive defensive gestures, and the Americans won by 8 to 6.

The attitude of the Brooklyn Museum toward art students was termed "archaic and prejudiced" yesterday by Miss Kav Hardy, executive director of the New York School of Design at 625 Madison Avenue. Miss Hardy's criticism was evoked by the refusal of Herbert B. Tschudy, curator of art at the museum to permit students of the School of Design to make complete copies of paintings by John Singer Sargent and Winslow Homer.

The Latex Fiber Industries, Inc., has been formed by the United States Rubber Company and the J.P. Lewis Company interests of Beaver Falls, N.Y., manufacturers of paper board products, it was announced yesterday.

The United States took the lead in the international tennis match with France last night when George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago and John Van Ryn of Philadelphia, Davis Cup combination, defeated Jean Borotra and Antoine Gentien in the doubles engagement at the Seventh Regiment Armory, 15-13, 6-4, 4-6, 6-4.

SCRANTON, Pa., March 22 -- The first jail sentences in the unauthorized strike of insurgent members of the United Mine Workers were imposed today on eleven picketers. They were arrested in Jessup this morning by State troopers and deputy sheriffs and sent to jail for ten days for stoning miners returning to work.

MONTREAL, March 22 -- The Canadiens handed the Toronto Maple Leafs a 4-2 defeat tonight and captured first place in the National Hockey League's international section for the second year in succession.

Selling pressure developed yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and carried quotations to the lowest figures of the last two months, causing final losses of 13 to 15 points. Besides weakness in outside markets, sentiment was influenced by a breakdown in labor negotiations in Lancashire and by warm weather throughout the cotton belt, theremometers registering 70 degrees in Georgia yesterday morning.

LAHORE, March 22 -- The All-India Moslem conference, speaking for the mass of India's 70,000,000 Mohammedans, tonight decided it was no longer possible to continue to cooperate with the round table conference or its committees.

Backers of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for President said yesterday that the developments of the last few days had confirmed their conviction that he would start in the national convention with the support of a majority of the delegates and be nominated on an early ballot.

LONDON, March 22 -- Henry J. Haskell, editor of The Kansas City Star, now in London, who is a friend of President Hoover, has written a letter to The London Times, in which he says that after the American elections Washington may agree with London on some revision of the British debt settlement with the United States to meet the temporarily impaired capacity of this country to pay.

At Shanghai the fundamental terms of peace have been agreed upon. Japanese troops are being shipped home. The armed forces of the other Powers are released from emergency duty. The League of Nations commission of inquiry is conducting its investigation on the spot.

Choking clouds of heavy, yellowish smoke poured from a three-story scrap rubber loft at 152-154 Lincoln Avenue, the Bronx, from 1 P.M. Until after dark yesterday, while more than one hundred firemen struggled to control the blaze. Thirty-two of them were cut by fragments of glass or overcome by the acrid fumes, which seethed and billowed inside the building and hung over an area of several blocks.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- There were to be observed today geographical and other divisions among the House Democrats as they voted on the amendments to the tax bill, which suggested to some observers that the consideration of this measure by Congress is a rehearsal of the party's national convention.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 22 -- Five Southern States tonight counted a total of 275 persons killed, more than 2,500 others injured or made homeless, and viewed unestimated property damage caused by a series of tornadoes that struck numerous communities last night and early today.

Sing Sing sentences were imposed yesterday by Judge Collins in General Sessions on two men, believed to be members of a gang which, in the last two years, had obtained more than $500,000 in jewelry in hold-ups in homes in the midtown section.

The Mexican Government has purchased 2,000,000 ounces of silver for delivery next month from a group of American producers and has taken an option for the purchase of an additional 2,000,000 ounces a month at the average price prevailing during the months in question up to a total of 23,000,000 ounces, it was announced yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- Bill McKechnie, manager of the Braves, has been watching his hired men from the left field bleachers in these games in the Grapefruit League. He sits out there with Judge Emil Fuchs, owner of the club, and transmits signals and dispatches to the trenches via Hank Gowdy, coach at third base.

Yesterday the acting chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the House, Mr. CRISP, said to the correspondents that the way in which the revenue bill had thus far been dealt with by the House of Representatives has been "very harmful to the country."
