PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 22 -- In the first clear statement of policy by any representative of the five Danubian States concerned, Dr. Eduard Benes, the Foreign Minister, told the foreign affairs committee of Parliament today that Czechoslovakia was willing to negotiate with her neighbors for realization of Premier Tardieu's plan for a preferential tariff bloc provided it was confined to the economic field.
BAD SAAROW, Germany, March 22 -- Max Schmeling, world's heavyweight champion, says he feels in tiptop shape to defend his title against Jack Sharkey in the Yankee Stadium, New York, June 16.

NEWARK, N.J., March 22 -- Brig. Gen. Winfield S. Price, in command of the Forty-fourth Division, New Jersey National Guard, in the absence of Major Gen. Quincy A. Gillmore, relieved from duty today Colonel Edward Phillips, commanding officer of the 113th Infantry Regiment, and Major Charles S. Tate, regimental plans and training officer, and directed the Judge Advocate of the division to prepare charges against them, on which they will stand trial by court-martial.

Surrogate James A. Foley announced yesterday to a court room that was crowded with lawyers representing 1,622 claimants to the $100,000,000 estate of Ella V. von E. Wendel that on April 10 he would hold a hearing to determine whether his court or a Westchester tribunal had jurisdiction over the settlement of the estate.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Governor Roosevelt today approved the bill increasing by 65 per cent the license tax on buses and heavy motor trucks, a measure which encountered bitter opposition in the late legislative session.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Senator Bratton, Democrat, of New Mexico, called upon President Hoover today to define the administration's attitude on the prohibition question.

Crude oil production in the United States averaged 2,157,200 barrels a day in the week ended on last Saturday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This compares with 2,145,600 barrels daily in the week before, indicating an increase of 11,600 barrels.

Sir William Howe's indifference to fighting and his too great fondness for warm baths, mulled wines and ten-day holidays in critical periods, were major forces in determining the outcome of the War of the Revolution, Bellamy Partridge, novelist and biographer, writes in "Sir Billy Howe," published today by Longmans, Green.

Ignace Jan Paderewski has contributed $6,000 toward the educational work of the PhilharmonicSymphony Society of New York, Mrs. Melbert B. Gary Jr., secretary of the committee on ensemble, musical training and scholarships announced yesterday.

The pamphlet report of the General Electric Company for 1931 shows a net profit available for dividends amounting to $40,956,996, equivalent, after dividends on the special stock, to $1.33 a share on 28.845.927 no-par common shares, compared with $57,490.915. or $1.90 a share, in 1930.

LIMURU, Kenya, Feb. 20 -- Discoveries made by the East African archaeological expedition at Oldoway, Tanganyika, in November, 1931, make it almost beyond question that the skeleton of a human being found by Professor Hans Reck in 1913 is the oldest known authentic skeleton of homo sapiens.

A campaign for the erection of "wage earners' " apartments in New York City at a rental of approximately $7.50 a month a room was started last night at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, when social service workers and experts attended the first meeting of the new Public Housing Conference.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The picture of a dignified Senator making a speech with a lapel microphone attached to his coat was painted when the Senate Rules Committee this afternoon discussed the Dill and Howell proposals to broadcast the Senate proceedings.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 22 -- Six thousand employes of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company have asked the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Manchester Gas Company to reduce rates.

LONDON, March 22 -- The Jockey Club, its stewards, The London Times and Weatherby's, publisher of The Racing Calendar, today won their appeal against judgment for $80,000 damages awarded last December to Charles Chapman, race horse trainer, who charged the defendants with libel.

An estate of $7,129,621 gross and $6,310,730 net was left in the United States by Marshall Owen Roberts, who lived at 15 Grosvenor Square, London, and died on July 3, 1931, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday at the State Tax Commission.

CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -- Detectives spoiled a double wedding planned for Easter Sunday with the arrest of six robber suspects in an early morning hotel raid today, wounding one of the prospective bridegrooms.

Magistrate Casey in the Coney Island Court yesterday, at an adjourned hearing, dismissed charges of felonious assault against three members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, brought by Michael Clohessy, an electrician employed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
AIKEN, S.C., March 22 (AP) -- Entries from the Carolinas won a large share of the honors in the final events of the Aiken field trials today at the game preserve of Miss Claudia L. Phelps.
SHANGHAI, March 22 (AP) -- Famine and pestilence in the form of smallpox, which menaced foreigners, were sweeping over the crowded camps of warfare's refugees in China today.

Southern California Edison. Formal offering of an additional issue of $10,000,000 Southern California Edison Company, Ltd., refunding mortgage bonds, 5 per cent series, dun in 1954, will he made today by a syndicate headed by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and including E. H. Rolling Sons, Inc., and the N. W. Harris Company, Inc.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 22 -- A thrift party was held tonight in the Orange Gardens of the Everglades Club, concluding the series of large entertainments for the season there. Regular teas, luncheons and dinner dances, however, will continue until the club is closed on April 1.

Not the Napoleonic Touch. Long before the war the traditional German discipline and respect for law used to be humorously summed up in the warning that no revolution in Germany must ever be expected unless by the permission of the police.

Like ease painting and the other arts, contemporary stage design is marked by an increasing reverence for the essential fact. The real-filet-mignon realism of Belasco, the jittery angles and interpenetrating planes of the expressionists, the fourth-dimensional ladders of the constructivists have all given way to a mode more in keeping with the modern temper.

Four more players reached the fourth round of the metropolitan Class C squash racquets championship at the Downtown Athletic Club as the result of matches in the third round of the tournament on the club's courts yesterday.

The twenty-second week of the Metropolitan Opera season will include the first performance this year of "Andrea Chenier" on Wednesday evening, with Mmes. Rethberg, Bourskaya and Dalossy, Messrs Gigli, De Luca, Ludiker, Bada, Windheim, Cehanovsky, Picco, Gabor, Malatesta and Ananian, and Mr. Bellezza conducting.

J.P. Morgan joined yesterday the campaign of the Block Community Organization, whose objective it will be to finance emergency work for 20,000 unemployed family heads during the Spring by contributions to be sought from residents of more than 16,000 blocks throughout the city.

LONDON, March 22 -- The de Valera Government of Ireland served notice on Great Britain today that in accordance with its election pledges it intended to remove the oath of allegiance from the Constitution.

DUBLIN, March 23. -- I already have stated the attitude and policy of my government in relation to the oath of allegiance to the British Crown, but I am glad to have this further opportunity of restating our position to the American people.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., March 23 -- Mrs. O.S. Hill, Kansas City, toured the wind-swept Southern Pines Country Club course in eighty-one strokes today to take a two-stroke lead in the battle for the woman's mid-South championship.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 23 -- Employes of the three major anthracite operations who voted Sunday afternoon to join the insurgent strike to "equalize" work, returned to their jobs today, while another large operation whose miners had ignored the strike ordered for ten days was added to the list of idle collieries.
Paolino Gerli of E. Gerli Co., Inc., was elected president of the Silk Association of America at the annual meeting yesterday of the board of managers in the organization's headquarters here.

MONTREAL, March 23. -- The New York Rangers arrived today from Detroit confident of starting with a victory tomorrow night in the first game of the National Hockey League playoff series with the Montreal Canadiens.

The Russian Opera Foundation's production of "Boris Godunoff" will include the opera's final scene dealing with the populace and the new Czar Dmitri, instead of closing the performance with the death of Boris, as was done in their performance last Spring.

The British Government's position in India will really not be made harder, in the final event, if the Moslem leaders carry out their threat and resort to "direct action" on the Gandhi model. Two anti-British movements will then tend to neutralize each other.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent editorial in THE TIMES on why Mr. Hoover does not end prohibition is significant. More than any individual, Mr. Hoover is in a position to take an authoritative step on a question that is literally burning up a nation.

Members of the faculties at Hunter, Brooklyn and City Colleges will begin their Easter vacation without receiving the monthly salary checks that ordinarily would be paid today, it was revealed yesterday. For the first time in many years instructors in the three city institutions will not receive their checks from the Controller on the last teaching day of the month, but will wait for payment until March 31, the last calendar day.

The fiftieth anniversary of the announcement of the discovery of the tubercle bacillus by ROBERT KOCH calls attention anew to the great German bacteriologist and to the diseases whose causative microbes he was the first to detect.

PINEVILLE, Ky., March 23 (AP) -- Warning that no communistic activities and no incendiary speeches will be tolerated during the visit of students to the Southeastern Kentucky coal fields was issued by city and county officials here today.
ATLANTA, March 23 -- Governor Roosevelt of New York swept Georgia in an overwhelming victory in the Presidential preferential primary today.

LOS ANGELES, March 23. -- Concluding the first section of their exhibition string with the Tigers, the Giants decided today to make a lasting impression on the foe and so made off with the fourth encounter by a score of 6 to 1.

MEXICO CITY, March 23. -- Henry R. Hall, long a resident here, and the most prominent American lawyer in the capital, dropped dead of heart disease this morning as he was leaving the British Hospital after visiting a sick friend.

WASHINGTON, March 23. - An application of the Mississippi Shipping Company for a loan not to exceed $201,128 to be applied to the reconditioning of the steamships Casey and Clavarack, operating between New Orleans, other Gulf ports and South America, was approved by the Shipping Board today.

Following the arrest here in the last several months of a dozen passers of counterfeit notes, Alan G. Straight, head of the United States Secret Service, issued a warning yesterday, saying that counterfeit $10 banknotes of the Federal Reserve had been successfully passed in this district.

BERLIN, March 23. -- The downward movement on the Boerse continued today, with average losses of 1 per cent. The turnover was even smaller than that of yesterday. Securities which are close to the city of Berlin were offered by holders abroad, resulting in a slump in the Berlin Transit loan, which carried the market lower.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP). -- The idea that the universe is "exploding," with space constantly increasing in size, is regarded as receiving added support from new studies of Dr. Albert Einstein and Dr. Willem De Sitter of Holland, just announced through the National Academy of Sciences.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 23 -- Rain, wind and three Brooklyn errors deprived the Robins of a chance for their third major league victory today and the Flatbush flock and their guests, the Reds, retired from the field at the end of five and a half innings with the score deadlocked at 3-3.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a speech before the Queens County Young Republican Congress THE TIMES quoted Robert H. Lucas as saying that "in their [the Democrats'] appeal to the unrest of the country -- to those of our citizens who are in distress, to their passions and prejudices, to the wildest of fevered imagination in this time of depression -- the Democratic campaign promises to exceed even the demagogue."

A million years ago -- possibly two million -- a tall, powerful, long-headed, long-faced, long-nosed man was ceremoniously buried in the Oldoway district of what was formerly German East Africa. There Dr. HANS RECK found him in 1913, completely fossilized, his arms folded, his thighs flexed, under ten feet of ancient soil.

The East River, it seems, is the dividing line between that section of the city where paintings by John Singer Sargent and Winslow Homer may be copied in full and the region where they may be copied only in part.

The necessity for coherent action by the great powers of the world if the present economic and political crises are to be resolved or even prevented from developing into vast disasters was stressed by several speakers yesterday afternoon and evening before the World Affairs Institute at the clubhouse of the American Women's Association, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Stocks were mixed in price trend in quiet trading yesterday on the New York Curb Exchange. A majority of the more active domestic bonds closed lower, while foreign bonds, although showing some losses, were steadier than on Tuesday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23. -- Ed Cunningham, the secretary of the Boston Braves, pointed to a tall, bronzed man watching the ball game at Waterfront Park here and said:

A pledge of support to the Washington bicentennial celebration, here by the advertising profession in New York City was made yesterday by Gilbert T. Hodges, president of the Advertising Federation of America and chairman of the advertising and publicity committee of the city's bicentennial commission.

LONDON, March 23. -- Sir Herbert Samuel, leader of the Liberal group in the British National Government, issued a statement tonight to members of his political party throughout the country explaining why his colleagues intended to remain in the Cabinet.

Miss Joan McSheehy of the Women's Swimming Association, who has proved a bright Olympic prospect of late, achieved the outstanding feat at the March water carnival for members of the organization in the 75-foot home pool last night by winning the 100-yard back stroke handicap in the sparkling time of 1:14 2-5.

PARIS, March 23. -- The Bourse turned toward recovery today, although trading did not increase greatly. The improvement, centring mostly in domestic stocks, followed a rise in Banque de Paris shares. The copper agreement strengthened Rio Tinto, which had been seriously affected by the recent restriction conferences.

Exactly reversing the result of last year's series, the United States defeated France, 3 to 2, in the inter-national indoor team match which ended at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night and took possession of the new bowl offered by the Seventh Regiment Tennis Club.

Jersey City, N.J. A new issue of $5,500,000 Jersey City (N.J.) 6 per cent tax-revenue bonds, due on Aug. 1, 1935, will be placed on the market today by a syndicate comprising the National City Company, the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, the Trust Company of New Jersey, the Hudson County National Bank, the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company and the First National Bank of Jersey City.

LONDON, March 23 -- The British Cabinet devoted itself today to the Irish situation and at the close of the deliberations sent its reply to President Eamon de Valera's declaration that he was going to abolish the oath of allegiance of members of the Free State Dail to the British Crown.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Commenting today on Professor Leakey's report, Dr. Alex Hrdlika, curator of the Smithsonian Institution and internationally known anthropologist, said that he had not read the entire report but that he knew the conditions, and that it was extremely doubtful that the authenticity of the Oldoway skeleton as that of the oldest man had been established.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 23. -- The limitations of time and space were challenged today by scientists speaking at the formal dedication of the new astrophotographic building at Harvard University Observatory, erected to house the 400,000 stellar photographs, forming the largest and most valuable collection in the world.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 23 -- Awarding of forty silver trophies to winners of the fishing contest which opened on Dec. 15 and closed on March 15, was a special feature of the annual dinner dance given tonight by the new Sailfish Club at the clubhouse on North Lake trail.

CHICAGO, March 23. -- Shorts rescued the wheat market today, despite bearish influences, and brought about a rally of 1 1/2 to 2 3/8 cents from the early low marks, with the finish at about the top at net gains of 3/8 to 3/8 cent.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. J. Reginald Newton gave a dinner last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis for Lord Trent, who arrived recently from England.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (AP). -- The annual report for 1931 of the Pennroad Corporation, an affiliate of the Pennsylvania Railroad, which will be submitted tomorrow at the annual meeting of stockholders in Wilmington, Del., shows that net income for the year and credited to earned surplus was $4,495,046, an increase of $26,281 from 1930.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 23. -- William Lewis Smith, cashier of the Welfare Federation of the Oranges and Maplewood, died today at his home, 94 Harrison Street. He was 80.

According to Representative PATMAN of Texas, ",the ex-service men are yelling" for immediate full payment of the adjusted service certificates. that mature in 1945. Mr. PATMAN himself has been yelling for it for some time. So has Senator BROOKHART.

The United Gas Corporation reports for 1931 a net income of $8,270,298, after charges, taxes, underlying interest and dividends, minority interests and depreciation, equal to 7.36 cents a share earned on 7,817,144 common shares after preferred dividends.

R.C. Sherriff, the Englishman who wrote the war play "Journey's End" and whose book "Fortnight in September" has just teen published, arrived yesterday on the North German Lioyd liner Bremen to try his hand at Hollywood, a new experience to which he looks forward eagerly.

Three men, who were alleged to have been trapped by the police alien squad about a year ago in a plot through which natives of South American countries obtained bogus certificates as natives of Porto Rico, thus enabling them to pose as United States citizens in obtaining jobs, were placed on trial before Judge Corrigan in General Sessions yesterday on a forgery indictment.

BUCHAREST, March 23. -- Serious student rioting occurred last night and all today in the neighborhood of the university, caused by the dissatisfaction of the students with certain bills before Parliament that they regard as affecting their rights. Both the students and the police employed gas bombs.

EASTON, Pa., March 23 -- Two Princeton students on their way to their homes for the Easter vacation were killed on the Easton-Freemansburg highway, six miles west of this city, late this afternoon in a head-on automobile crash. Three other students traveling with them were injured and are in hospitals.

Two centenarians living at the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged, Howard and Dumont Avenues, died within three hours of each other "yesterday morning. Hyman Rothschild, 105-year-old patriarch of the institution, suffered a heart attack at 5 A.M., dying an hour later.

Dinghy sailing, given an impetus by the Frostbite Yacht Club's Winter activities and which has spread so rapidly, was drawn into an organization on this continent last night when the by-laws of the North American Dinghy Association were adopted at a meeting at 145 West Forty-fourth Street.

L.H. Rouillion, C.P. Anderson Jr. and G.D. Mattison of the Harvard Club and H.F. Baker of the Princeton Club gained the semi-final round of the metropolitan Class C squash racquets championship at the Downtown Athletic Club following yesterday's matches.

A deadlock accompanied by threats from some employers to sever contractual relations with the union and introduce the open shop developed yesterday in the negotiations between representatives of the Printers' League Section of the New York Employing Printers' Association and Typographical Union No. 6 when the employers offered their proposal for a wage reduction.

A player who won the amateur championship in lawn tennis thirty-four years ago and another who was playing his first match in a national court tennis singles tournament contributed the most interesting opposition to the favorites yesterday in the opening round of the championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club, 370 Park Avenue.

LONDON, March 23 -- England's opera-lovers will have their Wagner season at Covent Garden this Spring alter all Such a storm of protest was aroused when the usual international opera, season was canceled last month that the Covent Garden Opera Syndicate announced today a reversal of its decision.

While various real estate organizations announced yesterday that they were considering the possibility of a tax strike as a relief to property owners, city tax officials declared that the proposal would not get beyond the rumor stage and pointed to increased tax receipts this year over last year to bear out their contention.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "De Valera in Office," in its reference to Ulster, is misleading to readers who are not acquainted with Irish history and English political methods.

The pamphlet report of the Municipal Service Company for 1931 shows a net income of $1,926,336 after depreciation, taxes, charges, underlying dividends and minority interest, equal after preferred dividends to $2.56 a share earned on 622,657 shares of common stock, compared with $2,079,275, or $3.34 a share earned on 621,450 common shares the year before.

Looking rather pale and drawn, Jack Dempsey, former world's heavyweight champion, paid a flying visit to this city yesterday, departing within a few hours of his arrival after transacting some private business matters with his local attorneys.

Forty New York college students -- twenty-eight men and twelve women -- left the city by bus and private cars yesterday afternoon for the coal strike districts of Kentucky to "investigate the existing social and economic conditions" and to distribute several truckloads of food and clothing to the striking miners of Harlan and Bell Counties.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 23. -- The Atlantic County Board of Freeholders met here today to dispose of 6 per cent tax revenue bonds for $1,650,000 at private sales. Lacking an offer, however, it took a recess until tomorrow, when it hopes to receive a bid from outside banking interests.

LONDON, March 23. -- British Government funds were fairly steady today, but persistent Continental selling depressed other departments of the Stock Exchange. Irish loans remained firm despite the intense interest in the new Anglo-Irish controversy.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The manufactured output of 1,052 establishments in the Rochester industrial area, in Monroe County, N.Y., had a 1929 value of $420,610,921, the Census Bureau announced today.

A black, leather-bound book, of the type that can be locked with a key, made its appearance yesterday as a principal bit of documentary evidence in favor of Harry C. Perry, chief clerk of City Court, in removal proceedings based on large bank deposits uncovered by Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee.

Some commodities evidenced a stiffening tendency yesterday, following several days of irregularly lower prices. The grains, dairy products, coffee, rubber and silk all recovered, while sugar futures were steady. Lead, spot, was weak and at a new low for the year, cotton also pointing lower. Other articles were firm.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A most pathetic case -- typical of the domestic tragedies that come to light day by day in our great city -- recently came to our notice when our attention was directed by neighbors to the misfortunes of a little family of husband and wife and two beautiful but sickly children.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 23 -- The five Southern States swept by a tornado Monday night were struggling today to combat the suffering and need in the wake of the storm. Under the leadership of the American Red Cross and the American Legion, relief efforts were directed, toward caring for the thousands left injured and homeless.

Hesitancy in the course of trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday was again attributed to the Congressional dispute over the Federal tax program. While the financial community has no doubt that revenues and expenditures will eventually be balanced approximately, there are some outcroppings of uneasiness here and there.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Postmaster General Brown told the House Postoffice Committee today that he favored a "monopoly" in the operation, of the air mail because it would result in more efficient and less costly service to the government. He also expressed the belief that interstate air mail regulation would have to be turned over to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

In its major items, at least, the program offered by Sir Thomas Beecham and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall was a refreshing departure from the lists of compositions offered us at the greater number of the Philharmonic - Symphony concerts of the season.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23. -- Effective pitching by Ed Brandt and Fred Frankhouse restrained the Yankee bats today and the Boston Braves managed to beat the Yanks, 2 to 1, after losing the first six games of the dual series.

BAYARD, Fla., March 23. -- The nird triumph in succession was ained today by Red Face, 6-year-old gelding by Ballot -- Frances Star, hich recently was bought by Joseph dwards, when he raced home an easy victor in the Hotel Mayflower urse at St. Johns Park.

VIENNA. March 23. -- Austria, Hungary and Yugoslavia today followed the example set yesterday by Foreign Minister Edouard Benes of Czechoslovakia by making the first official declarations of policy on the Tardieu plan for a Central European preferential block.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 23. -- The squad of forty-five men competing for positions on the Princeton baseball team will remain here during the Easter vacation period for practice, it was announced today by Coach Harry Hooper, who is starting his second season as Princeton's mentor.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Bernard M. Baruch advocated an international silver stabilization conference in an address today before the House Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures. At the same time the committee revealed that it had asked by letter bankers and government officials of this and seven foreign countries to state their attitude toward such a conference.

After scribbling a farewell note in which she wrote "please let them think it was an accident," and removing her hat and jacket, Miss Lauri Anderson, 23 years old, of 115 East Eighty-sixth Street attempted suicide early today by jumping from the bathroom window of an apartment on the fifth floor of 51 East Ninetieth Street.

DURHAM, N.C., March 23 (AP) -- The home of Mrs. John. A. Buchanon, daughter of C.W. Toms, vice president of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, has been under heavy police guard because of death and kidnapping threats, police revealed today after ten days of secrecy.

Final settlement of the claims against the city by sixty-six banking institutions for refunds of bank taxes collected illegally between 1923 and 1926 was accomplished yesterday when Controller Charles W. Berry distributed to the banks certificates amounting to $14,141,560.98.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that public work has all but stopped and it is essential to the very life of the city that self-supporting and productive work be expedited, it is most unfortunate that the plans of the City Administration to build on Forsyth-Chrystie Streets should again be delayed, and at the mercy of careless legislation.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 23. -- Lehigh today awarded a major L to Harry W. Walker of West Chester, Pa., breast stroke star, for his excellent performances in the pool during the past season.

The most recent arrival at the Bronx Zoo was making its first hazardous attempt yesterday to walk. It has no name, like its 2-year-old brother, but it is a three-day-old giraffe and the centre of interest at the Zoo.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- A spirit of courage and confidence is arising throughout the country as a result of thousands being put back to work, President Hoover was told today by Mark T. McKee of Detroit. The latter is directing a campaign to put jobless to work, under the joint sponsorship of the American Legion, the American Federation of Labor and allied organizations.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- A proposal of the Southern Pacific Lines to reduce its rail-water rates drastically on traffic between California points and New York and Baltimore to recover traffic lost to the Panama Canal Lines was rejected today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

A drop in the quotation for Federal funds to 1/4 @ 1/2 per cent from a recent charge of 1 featured business in the money market. This was the lowest rate for this accommodation in months and offered a striking illustration of the underlying ease of the market.

MONTREAL, Que., March 23 -- The report of the Canadian Fairbanks Morse Company, Ltd., for 1931 shows operating profit at $39,749, compared to $395,300 in 1930. Addition of $39,812 miscellaneous income brought the total income to $79,561. Earnings of $16,601 are shown after all charges but before dividends.

Long Service in America. Americans are seldom accused of being too modest. Yet it appears that in these columns a few days ago the palm for long and faithful service was too readily granted to members of an English firm.

J. Henry Esser, counsel for the Westchester Commuters' Association, told the Public Service and Transit Commissions yesterday that he would ask for a State court injunction to prevent the putting into effect on April 1 of a 40 per cent increase in commutation rates by the New York Central Railroad.

WEIMAR, Germany, March 23 (AP) -- Scholars of eight nations began this afternoon a two-day cycle of addresses on the universality of the genius of Goethe and commemorating the hundredth anniversary of his death.
AMHERST, Mass.. March 23. -- The Amherst student council today approved awards of Winter sports insignia.

The Travers and the Alabama, outstanding races for 3-year-olds at Sar atoga, have respectively sixty-nine and forty-two thoroughbreds remaining eligible for this year's tests, according to an announcement yesterday by Victor Schaumburg, racing secretary at Saratoga.
Following is the text of the radio address delivered last night by J.P. Morgan in behalf of the campaign of the Block Community Organization over a national hook-up from Station WJZ:

TOKYO, Thursday, March 24. -- Reports that the fall of the Cabinet had been averted by a compromise within the ranks of the Seiyukai (Government party) on a plan for reorganization of the Cabinet were carried by the Rengo (Japanese) News Agency this morning.

J.P. Morgan, speaking over a nation-wide radio hook-up last night, appealed to the people of the city to rally to the support of the campaign of the Block Community Organization, which will begin Monday with the objective of collecting additional funds for relief of the unemployed and discovering those suffering want in silence.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Al Capone will not be taken to Leavenworth penitentiary to begin serving his eleven-year sentence for income tax fraud for at least six weeks. The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today denied to the gangster a rehearing of his appeal, but granted a stay of mandate for the penitentiary trip, pending appeal to the Supreme Court.

Skippers and crews planning to sail in the Bayside Yacht Club's annual Block Island race this year, as well as past performers, gathered at a dinner last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania. The contest, started eleven years ago, is for auxiliaries, on a handicap basis.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES published an interesting letter from George P. Le Brun opposing the Hanley-Fake pistol bill. He calls attention to an error on the part of T.R. Mullen, who in an earlier letter attributed the uniform firearms act, upon which the Hanley-Fake bill is based, to the National Crime Commission.

DUBLIN, March 23. -- J. H, Thomas's unequivocal statement in the House of Commons this afternoon was received in Dublin with some concern. It is realized generally that President de Valera has precipitated a political crisis at a moment when the Irish Free State needs freedom from all distractions.

Indications in the steel trade point to a "seasonal rise of some proportions," probably starting in April, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age. "Based on definite business that seems to be just around the corner," this publication says "steel companies expect that the turn will come within the next two weeks."

The final "Dutch Treat" report luncheon of the Women's Division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, of which Mrs. August Belmont is chairman, will be held in the Plaza Hotel today. Final results of the adopt-a-family campaign, which the division has been conducting since the first of the year, will be announced at the luncheon.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Harry J. Haas, president of the American Bankers' Association, and Allan M. Pope, president of the Investment Bankers' Association, emphatically told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today that the Glass banking reform bill is deflationary in character and that it would be a mistake to enact it at this time.

Three nineteenth century French artists -- Cezanne, Gauguin and Redon -- constitute the present attraction at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street. This triune galaxy will hold the boards there until April 15.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Nominating committees appointed by G.J. Stewart Baker, president of the New York State Bankers Association, have selected nominees for election to the newly authorized banking board to act as an advisory "cabinet" to Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, in two of the four groups into which banks of the State are divided for purposes of the election.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, March 24. -- Once more a definite hour has been set for an armistice conference to end the Sino-Japanese hostilities but there is no guarantee that the representatives will meet at 10 o'clock this morning, as scheduled.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Governor Roosevelt expressed great satisfaction on receiving a report tonight from the Georgia preferential primary, giving the following result:

The prevalence of illness among school children in February, causing an increased number of absences, will cost the school system about $270,000, the loss representing financial aid which comes to the city from the State on the basis of attendance records, according to an estimate made yesterday by George H. Chatfield, director of the bureau of attendance.

On the eve of the fiftieth anniversary of the discovery of the tubercle bacillus by Dr. Robert Koch, famous German bacteriologist, which will be celebrated today throughout the world, the Health Department announced yesterday a continuation of the decline in deaths from tuberculosis in this city.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Stock market traders, buying and selling on their own account, are not entitled, to classification as dealers in securities and cannot take losses for Federal income tax purposes except through disposal of their holdings, according to a ruling today by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 23 (AP) -- The last golf stake of the Winter -- the $5,650 North and South open tournament -- today beckoned the homeward-bound professional brigade for the start tomorrow of the seventy-two-hole medal test.

Officials investigating the kidnapping of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's baby son concentrated yesterday on the search for Harry Fleischer, former Detroit gangster, and efforts to identify the criminals through the ladder they left behind when they fled with the child.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Secretary Stimson's letter on the World Court protocol read as follows:

GENEVA, March 23. -- The financial committee of the League of Nations, in a report which is expected to be completed tomorrow, recommends financial aid for Austria, Greece and Bulgaria, it was learned today, and an extension of the Hungarian moratorium.

ROME, March 23. -- An optimistic forecast of the return of prosperity was made today by Premier Mussolini at the conclusion of the celebration, of the thirteenth anniversary of the founding of Fascismo. Addressing a large crowd that gathered in the Piazza Venezia, he assured them the worst of the crisis was over.

An exhibition captioned "Railroads and Gardens," which title somehow lacks the inevitability of ham and eggs and Mutt and Jeff, is current at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries until April 2. The artist is A. Sheldon Pennoyer and the exhibition numbers forty-four canvases.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- On the eve of the House vote on the sales tax, the administration finds itself in the unusual position of hoping, though it is Republican and this is Presidential election year, that the Democrats will rally to save their own party from the political consequences, as well as to save the country from the economic consequences the defeat of the levy would bring.

NORWICH, Conn., March 23. (AP). The man who introduced Connie Mack to major league baseball died today. He was Charles F. Daniels, 83, believed the last survivor of the original staff of National League umpires. Injuries and exposure suffered when he fell on a country road during a snowstorm Monday caused his death.

Albert Poensgen of Berlin, Germany, defending champion, and Francis S. Appleby of New York, former United States titleholder, were winners in the opening matches of the world's amateur 18.2 balkline billiard championship, which opened at the Elks Club last night.

LONDON, March 23. -- It was six months ago last Monday that Great Britain abandoned the gold standard, but the question of returning to it has not yet become a live issue either in politics or finance. Neither has the time arrived, in the opinion of the government, for stabilizing the pound based on gold or some other standard.

The Metropolitan Opera Company, which has been subsidized for generations by the most prominent families of New York as the social backbone of the Winter season, officially announced yesterday that "reduced receipts due to the prevailing financial depression have practically wiped out its capital of $550,000 and most of its reserve, leaving it with insufficient funds to assure another season."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today the application of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to lend $2,500.000 to the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad and $800,000 to the Kentucky Indiana Terminal Railroad.

ALBANY, March 23. -- Governor Roosevelt today approved two bills affecting Dutchess, his home county, one abolishing fees in the Sheriff's office and substituting salaries, and the other abolishing the office of Coroner.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Norris bill forbidding the issuance of injunctions by Federal courts against strikers without evidence of danger or injury to the interests against which a strike is directed and providing for jury trials where persons are cited for violation of in junctions was signed by President Hoover this afternoon.

Silas H. Strawn, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and chairman of the American Committee of the International Chamber, returned from Europe yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.

Christopher (Bat) Battalino, former world's featherweight champion, will make an attempt in the ring at Madison Square Garden tonight to stop the onward rush of Billy Petrolle of Fargo, N.D. The bout is scheduled for twelve rounds, at 140 pounds, and it is expected that a near-capacity crowd of close to 20,000 will attend.

Frank W. Hart, Professor of Education at the University of California, and Morse A. Cartwright, director of the American Association for Adult Education, New York, have been appointed visiting Professors of Education at Columbia University.

WARSAW, March 23. -- "Danzig is the port of Poland and is permanently connected with the Polish Republic," Dr. Casimir Pappee, the new Polish High Commissioner of Danzig, declared in a statement to the press on taking office today.

John J. Raskob, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, denied explicitly yesterday the charge by Timothy J. Mara and Patrick F. Kenny that there had been fraud in the financing of the Presidential campaign of Alfred E. Smith in 1928.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., March 23 -- Ann Hardmg, motion picture star, and her husband, Harry Bannister, actor, announced in a joint statement today their intention to be divorced because, they said, Mr. Bannister is becoming known as "Ann Harding's husband."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 23 (AP) -- A new field was added today to the districts where bituminous coal miners are on strike in Ohio.

Most of the Washington correspondents think that the Democrats have during the past week seriously impaired their chances in the Presidential election. One special writer bluntly states that they have "kicked away" their great opportunity for success this year.

The purposeless drift of values in financial markets, which has grown familiar during the present week, continued yesterday. On the whole, the trend was downward, but with much irregularity and with the day's changes generally unimportant.
The Texas Corporation reported Yesterday a net loss for 1931 of $9,354,478 after all deductions. This contrasted with a net profit of $15,073,303, or $1.53 a share in 1930.

The railroads have withstood remarkably well the competing forms of transportation that have been developed in the last ten years and they require only normal traffic to restore their prosperity, W.W. Colpitts of the engineering firm of Coverdale Colpitts said last night at a dinner of the Security Owners' Association in the Roosevelt Hotel.

The name of John J. Meyer, former member of the Examining Board of Plumbers, which is soon to be the subject of a public hearing before the Hofstadter committee, was added yesterday to the committee's long list of missing witnesses, headed by Russell T. Sherwood, Mayor Walker's financial agent.

The liquor-possesion charge against Edward J. Atwell, secretary to Borough President John A. Lynch and former Sheriff of Richmond County, was dismissed yesterday in United States District Court by Commissioner Edward E. Fay. The Commissioner upheld Mr. Atwell in his contention that any liquor sold at the drug store partly owned by him at 1,916 Richmond Terrace, Port Richmond, was dispensed without his knowledge.

The first call for deposits of bonds by any of the foreign, bondholders' committees which have been organized thus far was made yesterday in connection with the announcement of the formation of a committee to protect the interests of holders of dollar bonds of the Republic of El Salvador which are outstanding here in the amount of $13,804,430.

Ralph Pulitzer, former owner of The New York World; Maria Jeritza of the Metropolitan Opera Company, Robert Goldsand, Viennese pianist, and Alexander Legge, president of the International Harvester Company, will be among the passengers sailing for Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The fate of the sales tax, mainstay of the revenue bill, will probably be decided by nightfall tomorrow.

German bonds led the rally yesterday in foreign loans, which showed better strength as a group than did domestic corporation issues, which finished irregularly lower. United States Government bonds closed 8-32 higher to 4-32 point lower, being featured by new high marks for the year in three issues, the Liberty 3 1/2s, the first Liberty 4s and the first Liberty 4 1/4s.

PARIS, March 23. -- Ambassador Sackett returned to Germany today from his two-day visit to Paris, taking with him, it is believed, only a confirmed impression that this vicious circle of debts and reparations which weighs so heavily on the life of every country, is more tightly locked than ever.

Scenes of the World War caught by cameras, showing men in flight from shells and others overtaken by them, sharpshooters who were outshot, civilians dead of starvation and the faces of men in reconstruction hospitals are presented in "The Horror of It," prepared by Frederick A. Barber and published by Brewer, Warren and Putnam.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today received from Secretary Stimson a letter accepting its reservations to ratification of the World Court protocol, but declined to consider the letter until Mr. Stimson appears personally before the committee.
ATLANTA, March 23 (AP). -- Major John S. Cohen, Georgia national committeeman, tonight wired the New York Governor congratulations as follows:...
CHATTANOOGA, Term., March 23 -- Tennessee's work of rehabilitation and aid to sufferers in the tornado of Monday night was well under way today.

Reflecting a drop in passenger traffic to the lowest level in about ten years, Pullman, Inc., holding company for Pullman transportation and manufacturing organizations, reported yesterday a net income of $2,378,632, or 61 cents a capital share, in 1931, against $16,943,081, or $4.37 a share in 1930.

Voting trust certificates for 144,642 common shares of the Columbia Pictures Corporation, previously traded on the New York Curb Exchange, will now be traded on the New York Stock Exchange as a result of favorable action by that exchange on the company's request for listing.

News that a grant of $25,OO0 has been made by the Social Science Research Council for a study, under the direction of Professor CHARLES A. BEARD, to define the term "national interest" may suggest to some only a theoretical quest. But if such a study could make clear the things that are or should be of national interest, it should be most helpful practically.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Secretary Stimson has informed Nicaragua that if the Presidential and Congressional elections scheduled for this Fall are altered to provide for election of a Constituent Assembly to revise the Constitution, the United States will not supervise the elections.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 23 -- General Candido Rondon, noted Brazilian explorer, in an interview with your correspondent today reiterated his disbelief in the statement of Stephan Rattin, a Swiss trapper, who recently returned from Matto Grosso and reported that while traveling in the interior last October he had seen and spoken to Colonel P.H. Fawcett, the British explorer who vanished in the Jungles seven years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today set April 12 as the effective date of its order authorizing the Southern Pacific Railroad to acquire control of the St. Louis Southwestern. It notified the railroads, however, that it would make no modification of the final consolidation plan of 1929 as required for the acquisition until certain minority stockholdings had been deposited with the applicant.

United States Senators James Hamilton Lewis of Illinois and Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky will be the principal speakers at the annual Jefferson Day dinner of the National Democratic Club at the Commodore Hotel on April 2, according to William H. Hickin, its president.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Seventy-five Democratic "messengers of goodwill" from Connecticut came here today to tell Governor Roosevelt that their State's sixteen delegates to the national convention would support him for the Presidential nomination.
AIn the confusing circumstances of the peace negotiations between China and Japan at Shanghai, these factors stand out clearly:

ALBANY, N.Y., March 24. -- Governor Roosevelt will veto the bill sponsored by the New York City Administration, which would give the city authorities the right to mortgage the fee of excess lands obtained through condemnation and lease them to private corporations for housing purposes.

Militarist sentiment at Tokyo is now reported to be concerned with plans for large-scale colonization of Manchuria. Next Summer the annual convention of the Japan Reservists' Association is to meet at Mukden, so that the delegates, representing' a body of nearly two million veterans, may study the problem on the spot.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24. -- Sergeant Gabby Street (late of the First Battalion, Gas and Flame, A.E.F.) has been troubled greatly by hold-out problems in the Spring training of the world's champion Cardinals, but he thinks everything will turn out all right in the end. The old Sergeant, puffing on his pipe, is a confirmed optimist.

VIENNA, March 24. -- The recommendation for a new loan for Austria by the League of Nations finance commission yesterday came when a moratorium for Austria State obligations was being strongly urged. Even with the extension of the present loan there was little hope of the country being able to meet her foreign obligations after the end of May.
DETROIT, March 24 (AP). -- A drive for business such as the automobile industry has not seen in years is expected in trade circles to get under way early next month.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To my knowledge the first decision involving the constitutionality of any part of the new Article 10-C of the tax law by Chapter 710 of the laws of 1930 was handed down by Surrogate Foley on March 16. Article 10-C substituted an estate tax for the old transfer tax in the State of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- A Senate vote on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was assured today when Senator Norris, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, promised Senator Tydings of Maryland that the committee would report one of the pending repeal resolutions.

CASTLE HARBOUR, Bermuda, March 24. -- A gala dance in the grill tonight ushered in a brilliant round of social and sports activities of the Easter week-end which will be a climax to the first season of the new Castle Harbour Hotel. Among those present were:
SCHENECTADY, March 24. -- Sixty-seven undergraduates at Union College, 8 per cent of the total enrolment, have won scholarships for the current year, Dean Edward Ellery announces.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Williams entertained tonight with a buffet dinner followed by a treasure hunt and supper, at their residence.

The New York Central Railroad agreed yesterday, after a conference with Milo R, Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, and Transit Commissioner Leon G. Godley, to modify the 40 per cent increase in its commutation rates that it had intended to put into effect on April 1.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation, rated as the third largest copper company in this country, announced yesterday that because of unfavorable conditions in the copper market it would curtail production of the metal. The reduction is expected to be in line with the recent agreement of the world's copper producers to curtail to 20 per cent of capacity, compared with the previous rate of 26 1/2 per cent of capacity.

"What History Teaches." In the course of the Senate debate on cutting down all government expenses by 10 per cent, Senator LOGAN of Kentucky expressed a discouraging view, based on his study of historical precedents.

MEXICO CITY. March 24 (AP). -- Word was received here today that all gambling quarters in the State of Chihuahua, among them the Casina Turista in Juarez, across the border from El Paso, Texas, would be closed as the result of a recent visit by General Juan Jose Rios, Secretary of the Interior.

NORWICH, N.Y., March 24 (AP). -- Fire preceded by what was described by Al C. Brookins, Fire Chief, as a bomb explosion, early today destroyed the two-story Distesano block and the Smalley Theatre adjoining it, in Main Street, a block from the centre of the city.

Billy Petrolle. the "Fargo Express." did to Bat Battalino of Hartford, who formerly held the world's feather-weight title, what no other fighter had been able to do when he knocked him out in the twelfth and last round of a sizzling battle in Madison Square Garden last night.

Meditations on the suffering of Christ on the cross will be held today at all Christian churches. The seven sayings of Jesus Christ from the cross will be used as topics at three-hour services this afternoon. They will be found also in cantatas, oratorios and pageants given at services tonight.

The first twelve railroads to report for February showed net operating income of $4,695,000, against $5,688,000 in February, 1931, a drop of 17.4 per cent, and compared with $10,942,000 in February, 1930, a fall of 57 per cent. Net was $3,216,000 in January, against $7,718,000 in January, 1931, a decrease of 58.3 per cent.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24. -- A momentous and long-awaited entry was made in the year's Yankee chronicles today at Waterfront Park when Babe Ruth sent a long liner soaring over the canvas barrier marking the far boundary of right field.

LONDON, March 24. -- King George, accompanied by Queen Mary, went to Westminster Abbey today, where in a service of most impressive symbolism he gave sixty-seven pence to each of sixty-seven old men and sixty-seven old women.

A misdemeanor indictment, charging the International Broadcasting Company, which operates Station WOV, and its general manager, John Iraci, with violating the State insurance law in 1930 by broadcasting an advertisement for the Union Mutual Life Company of Iowa, which has no license from this State, was handed up to Judge Alien in General Sessions yesterday by the grand jury.

Before a public stirred as it has not been in a quarter-century by an admitted crisis in New York's proudest institution of opera, the Metropolitan last night continued its round of subscription performances with a packed house and a star whose conquest of this public has done most to redeem the lethargy of two seasons of financial depression.

Building standards proposed by the Regional Plan of New York and Its Environs to give more light and air were described and discussed last night at a meeting of the Metropolitan Section, American Society of Civil Engineers, at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirtyninth Street.
ALBANY, March 24. -- Governor Roosevelt announced his approval today of four of the seven condemnation bills sponsored by the New York City Administration at the recent session of the Legislature.

A rise in monetary gold stocks, a more than seasonal reduction in money in circulation and continued open-market purchases of government securities were shown in the weekly report of the Federal Reserve System, published yesterday, indicating a continuance of the favorable trend of recent weeks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From 1914 to and including 1920 I was chairman of the Finance Committee of the Senate of the State of New York. During that time I with the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the Assembly drew and passed the appropriation bills, so I know whereof I speak.

"Dole Brothers," a play translated from the German of Richard Duschinsky, will be presented tonight and tomorrow night by the Workers' Theatre in the Debs Auditorium of the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

For the third successive year Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C., amateur champion, heads the ranking list of the National Squash Tennis Association, given out last night at the annual meeting and dinner of the organization at the Columbia University Club.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Caustic but jocular criticism of the prophetic ability of Senator Watson, Republican floor leader, by Senator Harrison, today marked the opening of a fight for passage of a Democratic tariff bill in the Senate.

Declines marked the more active leaders yesterday on the New York Curb Exchange. American Gas and Electric, Cities Service, Electric Bond and Share, Glen Alden Coal, Standard Oil of Indiana, St. Regis Paper, Middle West Utilities and American Superpower showed moderate losses.

Substantial advances in petroleum prices were announced yesterday, the most important applying to mid-continental crude oil, which will be increased 15 cents a barrel, effective on April 1. This advance is the first since Nov. 2 of last year, and it establishes a maximum of $1 a barrel, the objective of various movements in the large oil fields.

Demands for further city economies. Including the placing of the subways on an increased, "self-sustaining" fare, were made yesterday by property owners' organizations following conferences between Controller Charles W. Berry and members of the Manhattan and Brooklyn Real Estate Boards on the taxation of real estate.

MONTREAL. March 24 (Canadian Press). -- "I have nothing: more to say; I expressed my opinions before Frank Calder, president of the National Hockey League, said today when questioned in regard to the challenge.

SHANGHAI, Friday, March 25. -- While the Sino-Japanese armistice conferences were reaching an impasse in Shanghai yesterday, China's Central Government made its first admitted move to frustrate a rapidly developing independence movement at Canton, which threatens again to plunge this country into a disastrous civil war.

Stanley Mortimer, noted polo player and huntsman of the '80s and '90s; lawyer, art collector and former artist, died yesterday of heart disease aggravated by influenza at his home, 4 East Seventy-fifth Street. Mr. Mortimer, who was 79 years old, was once one of Long Island's most noted sportsmen, known as a fearless and expert rider.

HAVANA, March 24. -- Cuba's present sugar crop will be restricted to 2,700,000 long tons, plus whatever amount the mills may have exceeded their respective quotas under this figure on March 30, when the restriction becomes effective, according to a resolution passed this afternoon by the Sugar Institute after almost two days of continuous sessions.

With fair and generally vernal weather indicated for the week-end, the annual transfer of a good part of New York's population to resorts for the Easter holidays began yesterday and was expected to reach the peak tonight and early tomorrow.

Driven into a rage during a domestic quarrel, Anthony Puleo, 61 years old, shot and killed his wife, Antoinette, 46, and their son, Louis, 27, in the kitchen of their home at 102-10 103d Avenue, Ozone Park, Queens, early last evening, according to his confession made to the police a few hours after the shooting.

The classified statement yesterday by the Department of Commerce on the origin and destination of gold imported or exported in February shows that of the $37,644,428 gold imports for the month $19,441,108 came from Japan and $8,416,773 from Canada.

The many corrective measures taken lay business and the constructive and helpful legislation enacted by Congress and the administration are bound to have a powerful recuperative effect on industry, according to the annual letter sent to stockholders with the pamphlet report of the American Rolling Mill Company by George M. Verity, chairman, and Charles R. Hook, president.

Musical conditions having proved "too uncertain" to warrant further expenditure of time and effort on an independent orchestral venture, Dr. Henry Hadley announced last night that he had sent a letter of resignation to the executive committee and active managers of the Manhattan. Symphony orchestra, which the American composer has served as its conductor for the last three years.
New York has lost a one-time conspicuous figure of its skyline.

BUCHAREST, March 24. -- Violent anti-Semitic student demonstrations at Jassy today followed yesterday's student disorders in Bucharest, against which Jassy students belonging to Professor Cuza's anti-Semitic Iron Guard protested. A State Attorney and many policemen and students were seriously injured.

BERLIN, March 24. -- The Boerse opened with prices irregular on the last day before the Easter holiday, but the market rallied during the day and closed generally firm. Favorable reports on the financial status of the city of Berlin led to the quick recovery of the Berlin transit loan and public utilities, which were pressed on the market yesterday.

An application for the listing of 14,311,432 shares of stock of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, formed through the merger of the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation, the Prairie Pipe Line Company and the Prairie Oil and Gas Company, has been received by the New Tork Stock Exchange and will be acted upon by the committee on stock list of the Exchange at its next meeting.
For the first time in the history of the Metropolitan Golf Association a committee has been appointed to investigate and consider actions which may be classed as violations of the amateur rule.
WASHINGTON, March 24. -- A large reduction in money hoarding and rapid slowing down of bank failures in recent weeks were shown in figures made public today by Secretary Mills.

LIVERPOOL, March 24 (AP). -- Liverpool's cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 363,000 bales, against 840,000 a week ago, 851,000 two weeks ago, 851,000 three weeks ago and 1,153,000 a year ago; of which American 429,000 bales, against 408,000 a week ago, 412,000 two weeks ago, 416,000 three weeks ago and 551,000 a year ago.

A circumstantial story that the baby son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh is on a yacht somewhere in Chesapeake Bay near Norfolk, Va., in the hands of kidnappers who are willing to turn him over to representatives of Colonel Lindbergh immediately was laid before the Colonel and New Jersey State police on Wednesday night, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The right of the New York and Missouri Legislatures to proceed with Congressional reapportionment without the approval of the Governors was argued this afternoon before the Supreme Court, which already has a Minnesota case of a similar nature under consideration.

TULSA, Okla., March 24 (AP). -- Increased retail gasoline prices were predicted freely today, as additional companies followed the example of the Continental Oil Company, which last night increased crude oil quotations to the dollar mark.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- With a view to speeding up action on applications for loans, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation called upon the Treasury Department today for an additional $100,000,000 in capital stock of the $500,000,000 authorized. This will make the total paid to the corporation $350,000,000.

An announcement of the New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday, which revealed the identities of members who had sold their seats in the Exchange in the last week at prices ranging from $117,000 to $132,000, showed that two of the seven floor partners of M.J. Meehan Co. had made arrangements for the sale of the seats.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 24. -- Nine chimpanzees on the roof of the Sterling Hall of Medicine at Yale University are proving most willing students, according to a doctor in the laboratories of comparative psychobiology.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Manufactured products valued at $1,157,751,878 comprised the 1929 contribution of the Buffalo industrial area to the industrial output of the nation, the Census Bureau announced today. The number of manufacturing establishments was 1,923, employing 115,212 wage-earners with a combined payroll of $171,674,331, and 20,327 officers and employes with salaries totaling $52,859,806.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP). -- Farmers' intentions as to planting 1932 crops, based on returns as of March 1, were reported by the Department of Agriculture today to show an acreage of corn 2.2 per cent more than the 104,970,000 acres harvested last year; of durum wheat, 34.8 per cent more than the 2,869,000 acres last year, and of other Spring wheat, 53.3 per cent more than the 11,071,000 acres last year.

James H. Van Alen of New York, one of the players most favored to win the national amateur court tennis championship, found himself in jeopardy of defeat yesterday at the hands of an opponent whose tournament experience has been confined to half a dozen matches.

Florence Wayne Foreman, former film actress, and the widow of Winfield Amos Foreman, founder of Foreman Clark, clothiers, who died Feb. 11 at his home, 480 Park Avenue, leaving his large fortune to two adopted children and some relatives and friends and cutting off his widow with a trust fund of $50,000, served notice yesterday on John Kiloran, Chief of the Probate Division of the Surrogate's Court, that she would contest the will.

LONDON, March 24 (AP). -- Great Britain intends to proceed without deviation with her program for India, Sir Samuel Hoare told the House of Commons today, and will not be deflected from it "by threats or force or sudden alarms."

NEW ORLEANS, March 24 (AP). -- A gasoline style show will be put on by the American Chemical Society at its meeting beginning here Monday. Instead of plain, old-fashioned gasoline, the proper scientific term today is "gasolines," some for hot weather, others for cold, gasolines for heavy engines and for high-speed motors.

The American Palestine Campaign, which seeks to raise $2,500,000 throughout the United States for the maintenance of Jewish reconstruction activities in the Holy Land, was opened last night at a meeting in the Town Hall. The plea that nothing be permitted to interfere with the continuance of the work was made by both Zionists and non-Zionists.

The decline in bank clearings in twenty-two leading cities of the country continued for the week ended on Wednesday, when the total was $4,869,144,000, or 39.5 per cent below that of the corresponding period last year, according to R.G. Dun Co.

After a period of ten days in which there were no openings, some of us found ourselves brooding last evening. On the stage of the Forrest Theatre a disturbance entitled "A Few Wild Oats" kept the curtain up until about 10:30. It was the work of Arthur Hoerl, who, according to the press agent, "is, indeed, a versatile chap."
PARIS, March 24. -- The British reply to the French memorandum proposing a Danubian federation, according to Pertinax in the Echo de Paris, today constitutes a check for France's proposition.

LONDON, March 24. -- The House of Commons adjourned this afternoon for the eleven-day Easter recess in a state of somewhat anxious curiosity as to what President Eamon de Valera's next move is going to be in the Irish situation. But there was a calm assurance in the Cabinet and in Parliament that nothing tragic could happen in the immediate future and that nothing of the sort was likely at any time.

Miss Laura Smith of Toronto, who adopted the stage name Lauri Anderson when she came to New York eight years ago, died in Mount Sinai Hospital at 6:30 A. M. yesterday, several hours after she had jumped from the apartment of Philip S. P. Randolph Jr. on the filth floor of 51 East Ninetieth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Passage by Congress of the Rayburn bill to bring holding companies under Federal control would have an injurious effect on the value of railroad securities, restrict the number of persons in a position to buy them and deprive present holders of such securities of the opportunity to sell, Fred N. Oliver, general counsel for the Security Owners' Association, told the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 24. Five intercollegiate regattas have been scheduled for this Naval Academy oarsmen this Spring, including the Poughkeepsie regatta, besides probable participation in the Olympic tryouts, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The sales tax, which was the leading feature and main revenue producer of the pending revenue bill, was stricken from the measure today in the House by a vote of 223 to 153.
DETROIT, March 24 (AP). -- Thaddeus Kirk and Ray Hartnagel of St. Louis gained a tie for fifth place in the two-man event of the American Bowling Congress tournament today with a 1,255 score.
MIAMI, Fla., March 24 (AP). -- Anne Booker, famous diving star, whose back was broken in a high dive at Vienna last October, died in a hospital here today.

The Real Estate Board is well advised in cautioning its members against joining in any tax strike. The time has come for action, but not for resort to that doubtful weapon. At the present stage it would only injure the property owner who wielded it.

Further conferences between officials of the State of Tennessee and of New York banks which have handled most of the State's bonds in the past are expected to take place next month preliminary to the $9,000,000 of new long-term financing the State must do to meet its highway notes that will mature on April 29.

CHICAGO, March 24. -- Grain traders today construed the government report on farmers' intentions to plant Spring crops as bearish on Spring wheat, corn and oats. The possible increase of almost 7,000,000 acres of all Spring wheat was viewed as a desperate effort by Northwestern producers to recoup losses sustained last year when drought and heat forced down the yield to the smallest to the acre ever known in that section.

TOKYO, March 24. -- Declaring that no civilized nation could tolerate a "blood brotherhood" vowed to political assassinations, Giichi Matsumura, in the House of Peers, accused authorities today of having condoned the activities of the band whose members killed Junnosuke Inouye, former Finance Minister, and Baron Takuma Dan, the noted financier.

KEARNY, N.J., March 24. -- A message from President Hoover expressing optimism concerning the development of an American merchant marine was read by Postmaster General Walter F. Brown today at the launching of the new $5,000,000 Panama Mail liner Santa Rosa, first of four sister ships to be built at the yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company in Kearny.

MONTREAL, March 24. -- The Canadiens of Montreal went into the lead over the New York Rangers in the first-place play-off for the National Hockey League championship by defeating the speedy blue-jerseyed aggregation from the United States tonight.

By the tumultuous vote of the House of Representatives yesterday, the proposed sales tax was destroyed. But other things were also destroyed. Party leadership and party responsibility fell in the general ruin. This was true of both parties.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 24. -- Today's scheduled game with the Philadelphia Athletics at Fort Meyers was prevented by rain, but the day in the Robins' camp was not devoid of interest, for the reason that considerable talk was heard centring on a reported pending deal between Brooklyn and the world's champion St. Louis Cardinals.

Improvement in the grains, cotton, rubber, hides, silk, cocoa and a generally firm undertone in other articles, featured trading in commodity markets yesterday. The only exception to the upturn was a drop in sugar, the March contract selling down to a new low at 0.69.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 24. -- This city's fiscal officers were making plans today to feel out the New York bond market, in the hope of selling an issue of $2,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The proposed real estate tax strike, while a method hardly appealing to conservative citizens, may be the only way for such afflicted taxpayers to secure adequate consideration from the local authorities, either by a revision of the budget through a special session of the Legislature or other appropriate action.

Veterans of the Fourth Division, A.E.F., who fought with him in shell craters, barbed wire entanglements and under barrages at the Aisne-Marne, Vesle sector, Toul sector, St. Mihiel and Meuse-Argonne are rallying at the eleventh hour to save William M. Frazer of Rahway, N.J., from the electric chair.

The proposal to amend the by-laws of the New York Cocoa Exchange to extend trading hours to 3 P.M. each day instead of closing at 2:45 has been approved by the board of managers. The Exchange will close at noon tomorrow as usual. The new trading hours become effective on April 1.

WARSAW, March 24. -- The 23-year-old blind Hungarian pianist, Inre Ungar, and the Russian emigrant of Paris, Alexander Uninzky, 24, were winners of the two first prizes of $561 and $336 respectively at the second international Chopin competition organized, by the Warsaw Chopin Acad- emy of Music.

LONDON, March 24 (Canadian Press). -- George Robert Harris, fourth Baron Harris of Seringapatam and Mysore and of Belmont, Kent, goes down in the records of cricket as a great batsman and a brilliant field in his younger days. Until his death he was a respected authority on the game.

Two men were held at Ellis Island yesterday while immigration officials wondered whether to turn them free in the United States or seek to deport them. The two gave their names as Leon Grinbaum, 23 years old, and Leon Alterman, 24. They were discovered early yesterday morning as the Holland-America liner Statendam steamed seaward.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- A Senate investigation into charges of fraudulent financing of the Smith Presidential campaign through the County Trust Company of New York is under discussion by Senate Republican leaders.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date and the note circulation to be at the lowest. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure.

The reorganization, plan for the Inland Gas Corporation has been deferred because of the decrease in earnings of the company and of the Kentucky Fuel Gas Corporation, according to the committee representing holders of Inland Gas first mortgage 6 1/2 per cent bonds, due in 1938, and Kentucky Fuel Gas first mortgage 6 1/2 per cent bonds, due in 1942.

At the Grand Central Galleries, in a hushed atmosphere of velvet, cunningly subdued light and, at intervals, music extremely well played by the gallery's mechanical pipe organ, American old masters are on view -- nearly seventy canvases. It is true that none of these painters antedates the nineteenth century, while a few of them are still active in our midst.

Mrs. Nan Walker Burke, sister of Mayor Walker, was served yesterday with a subpoena to appear before the Hofstadter legislative committee for questioning at a private hearing, she said last night at her home, 13-96 Beach Twenty-eighth Street, in Far Rockaway.
With a sharp rise in sterling exchange and less weakness in foreign commodity markets yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied and closed 1 to 4 points higher than on Wednesday.

ALBANY, Maich 24. -- Law enforcement officials, appearing before Governor Roosevelt today, were divided on the merits of the two bills which would modify the drastic pistol law enacted at the special session of the Legislature last Fall.

Re-establishment of the unemployment insurance fund and limitation of the number of contractors who may produce garments for one jobber were among the demands presented by the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union to the Merchants' Ladies' Garment Association, the jobbers group, at a conference last night at the Hotel New Yorker.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. George M. Gales gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino for Lord Trent of Nottingham, England. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Woolley, Mr. and Mrs. George Armsby, Miss Helene Gales and Seaton Gales.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 24 (AP). -- Government agencies and private citizens joined hands with the Red Cross today in the task of rehabilitating the areas slashed by Monday night's tornadoes, the death list from which was placed tonight at 359.
PARIS. March 24 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

Asserting that a manufacturers' sales tax of 2 1/2 per cent would have worked no undue hardship on the consumer or upon the poor man, Dr. Joseph J. Klein, income tax expert, 19 West Forty-fourth Street, predicted yesterday that the defeat of the measure by the House of Representatives would eventually result in the imposition of a 5 to 10 per cent tax on selected commodities such as automobiles, and radios.

Indecision in the security markets yesterday was again ascribed to the news from Washington bearing on the tax legislation. For the time being the financial community is absorbed -- to the exclusion of almost everything else -- in the fiscal problems of the Federal Government.

MOSCOW, March 24 (AP). -- Robert P. Lament Jr., wearing the "ten-gallon" hat of the American plainsman, reached Moscow today to talk with Joseph Stalin about running Russia's cattle industry. The Soviet Government invited the son of the American Secretary of Commerce to look over the ground for himself, and he came from his 15,000-acre ranch in Colorado.

A contest for deposits of bonds of the Republic of El Salvador by two rival committees was begun yesterday, when F.J. Lisman, head of the former firm of F.J. Lisman Co., which was active in distributing the bonds, said the committee he headed would call for deposits from bondholders on Monday. He expressed regret that another committee had been formed.

Operations of the Hahn Department Stores, Inc., for the year ended on Jan. 31, resulted in a net loss of $309,027 after depreciation, amortization and interest. This contrasts with a set profit in the preceding fiscal year of $2,515,844, equivalent after preferred dividend re- quirements to 71 cents a share on 1,357,489 common shares.

Freight to be moved in the Atlantic States in the second quarter of the year will require 626,141 cars, compared with 694,362 in the same period last year, a decrease of 9.8 per cent, according to estimates submitted yesterday at a meeting of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board in the Robert Treat Hotel in Newark.

Trading will be suspended to a large extent in the financial and commodity markets today on account of Good Friday. The banks will be open and therefore dealings will take place in foreign exchange. However, business generally will be sharply curtailed in all centres.
