The money market was quiet, with the same undertone of ease that has prevailed from the outset of the week. Federal funds were again done at 1/4, with the final at 1/2; Street trades were arranged at 2, but the official rate on the board for day loans continued at 2 1/2 per cent.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 24. -- At the end of the first thirty-six holes over the difficult No. 2 course of the Pinehurst links, half of the journey in the North and South Open championship, Craig Wood of Deal, N.J., held the lead with a total of 138.
No transactions were recorded yesterday on the Real Estate Securities Exchange. The mart will be closed today (Good Friday) but will be open for business tomorrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial based on Judge Crane's address to the Bar Association was an excellent service. It is the more regrettable, therefore, that you should have omitted mention of what was, I am sure, to many readers of Judge Crane's paper, its most striking feature -- that portion in which he came out flat-footedly for the abolition of the defendant's immunity from self-incrimination.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Those who propose remedies for ills in the banking structure should remember that "the patient is only now starting to recover and that a major operation in the present state of financial health may result in a relapse or even death," Robert O. Lord, president of the Guardian Detroit Union Group, Inc., told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today in discussing the Glass banking bill.

William Gibbs McAdoo, candidate for the Democratic nomination for President in 1920 and 1924, declared yesterday that he favored the nomination of Speaker John N. Garner for President because he knew him well and believed he would make the best President.

BOSTON, March 24. -- The enormous world-wide burden of taxation, rapidly growing since the war, was not only one of the causes of the depres- | sion, but was also one of the difficulties confronting the world in the restoration of normal activity, Myron L. Taylor, chairman of the finance committee of the United States Steel Corporation, said today in a discus- sion of the present economic situa- tion before the Boston Chamber of Commerce.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 24. -- Holding that a fair and impartial trial was accorded seven of eight Negroes in the Scottsboro assault upon two white girls, the State Supreme Court by 6 to 1 today affirmed the verdict of the lower court and set May 13 as the date for their execution.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 23, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,596,000,000, a decrease of $76,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $716,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 24. -- Kentuckians are awaiting the arrival of 100 or more college students, expected in the coal regions tomorrow, with a promise to "file them along with other exhibits in the Harlan and Pineville jails if ihey don't watch their step."

Three paintings were withdrawn from the sale held last night by the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., when the authenticity committee of the American Art Dealers' Association decided that they were not as described. The paintings were represented as the works of Ralph Blakelock and Albert P. Ryder.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 24. -- A bill to terminate the artificial maintenance of the foreign exchange rate and permit the Chilean peso to seek its own level has been submitted to Congress by Finance Minister Luis Izquierdo.

Bad times have added to the work of the Legal Aid Society, as appears from its report for 1931. Its cases rose to 40,000 from 33,000 in 1930. The increase was entirely on the civil side. Of the complaints as to which advice was sought and given 16,000 were in regard to wages.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 24. -- Mayor James J. Walker suffered a setback today following too strenuous exercise yesterday and was confined to a deck chair on the sun terrace all morning and afternoon. The Mayor developed a Charley horse in his shoulder as a result of the short baseball session yesterday with a group of young people in the Homestead and was treated by a masseur twice during the day.

Suit has been brought in Supreme Court by Burns Brothers, retail coal dealers, against eight of its former officers and directors for an accounting and restoration of money, assets and properties of the company allegedly lost, misappropriated or diverted in a conspiracy to defraud Burns Brothers, it was disclosed yesterday.
A decrease of $3,002,500 in earmarked gold and receipt of $999,300 gold from Canada were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank, making a total net gain of $4,001,800. There were no exports.

Prizes totalling $2,500 were awarded yesterday by the jury of awards at the 107th annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design, which will be opened to the public on Sunday in the galleries of American Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The directors of the Metropolitan Opera Company expect to take about two weeks to determine the consequences of their announcement, made on Wednesday, that the opera producing company has "insufficient funds to assure another season."

Foreign loans proved again the strongest spot in yesterday's listed bond market. Domestic corporation loans were weaker and United States Government long-term issues finished irregularly lower. The rally in German Government bonds was further extended.

It is impossible not to feel sympathy with, the merchants who, wishing to redeem Union Square, have petitioned Commissioner MULROONEY to discontinue the privilege of holding public meeting there. The square has belied its name, standing more often for disunion than for union.

Montague Street, one of the oldest and best known thoroughfares in Brooklyn, is technically unknown to the city of New York. It may be very much a public street to 2,600,000 inhabitants of Brooklyn, but to the city officially it is just a private right-of-way.

With victories over former Governor Alfred E. Smith in New Hampshire and Minnesota, over Governor William H. Murray of Oklahoma in North Dakota, and over Speaker John N. Garner, by proxy, in Georgia, the backers of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for President prepared yesterday to meet an entirely different kind of a test in the State conventions in Maine and Iowa next Tuesday.

MARLAND, Okla., March 24. -- While the auctioneer's hammer resounded outside, Colonel Zack Miller, ranchman and former circus owner, resorted to the forceful rule of the West today in defending his 101 Ranch homestead, "the White House," a small part of a once large Western domain that disintegrated beneath a series of financial difficulties.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP). -- The tools of the college professor's trade were the theme today of hot words and drastic action in Representative Sirovich's copyrights committee.

SANTA MONICA, Cal., March 24 (AP). -- Traveling under a guard because of a fear that kidnappers might attempt to seize one of her children, Mrs. Harold Gatty, wife of the roundthe-world flier, left here last night by train for Washington.

Journeying in tow up the Sound to Greenwich, Conn., the members of the Frostbite Yacht Club will have their dinghy racing this week-end under the auspices of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. It will be the furthest east they have been with the exception of Stamford.

Easter flowers may be had in profusion to decorate milady's ensemble, brighten the home and beautify churches and graves, according to leading florists questioned yesterday, and in general prices are considerably lower than they were last year. Some florists described prices as "pre-war," but many denied this The demand, which will reach its height tomorrow, was described as Hltely to be better than last year.

CHICAGO, March 24. -- Four officials and directors of the MissouriKansas Pipe Line Company and Frank P. Parish Co. were charged in an indictment returned by the Federal grand jury today with using the mails in a $35,000,000 stock fraud.

Francis S. Appleby, former champion of the United States, forced his way into a triple tie with two foreign cue experts, Gustave Van Belle of Belgium and Albert Corty of France, by winning his second consecutive victory in the world's amateur 18.2 balkline billiard championship at the Elks Club last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 24. -- The defeat of the sales tax in the House after the close of the Eastern stock exchanges today had an immediate and depressing effect on the local stock market and prices on both the San Francisco and Los Angeles Stock and Curb Exchanges declined from fractions to as much as a point and a half in some of the "competitive" issues.

A truly amazing feature of the current show at the G.R.D. Studio is the presence of two paintings, by different artists, of two "Brick Kilns." The concurrence of two nudes, two still-lifes or two abstractions in the same exhibition is surely no cause for alarm, but the coincidence of two drawings dealing with the manufacture of the great American missile seems to have some profound sociological significance.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., March 21. -- Mrs. O.S. Hill, the Western champion, today added the women's mid-South championship to her Rolfing laurels by shooting a 78, one over women's par, on the final eighteen holes.
LONDON, March 24 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

A 59 per cent response instead of the usual 20 per cent is indicated as the probable ratio with, which NewYorkers will answer the appeal of the "block-aiders," according to Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the Block Community Organization, who reported yesterday that a series of careful trial solicitations had shown the probable effectiveness of the campaign beginning next week.

LONDON, March 24. -- Sterling jumped to $3.69 1/2 today on renewed buying from the Continent, carrying British Government funds upward with it. Some brokers reported resumption of foreign buying of the funding loan, which is tax free. This issue rose 1/4 to u97 1/2.

ROME, March 24 (AP). -- Wine and water were poured on the central altar stone of St. Peter's today in the closing ceremonies of Holy Thursday, the anniversary of Christ's institution of the eucharist.

CHICAGO, March 24. -- Prices of hogs slumped 10 to 35 cents today as the result of a sharp increase in receipts, many stormbound hogs being included in the arrivals. Shipping demand was relatively slow, and packers were able to make liberal purchases at 25 to 35 cents decline.

February Retail Collections Drop. A decline in February collections on retail charge accounts of 1.58 per cent, according to the index based on the figures of twenty local stores, was reported yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. The decrease compares with a drop of 3.46 per cent in January and of 1.23 per cent in December.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note the article on Poland in THE NEW YORK TIMES, over the initials "H.C." It was accompanied by a map, the caption of which read "The Area in Light Shading Is the Old Russian Poland; Areas in Heavy Shading Show Territories Acquired After the World War."

Personal qualities rather than technical proficiency make for success in the modern business world, in the opinion of Professor Atlee L. Percy of the College of Business Administration, Boston "University, who delivered his annual address as president of the Eastern Commercial Teachers' Association yesterday at the convention of the organization in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
RENO, Nev., March 24. -- Mrs. Alice Delafield Dean Livingston filed suit here today for a divorce from Robert R. Livingston, to whom she was married in New York on Feb. 23, 1922.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note the article on Poland in THE NEW YORK TIMES, over the initials "H.C." It was accompanied by a map, the caption of which read "The Area in Light Shading Is the Old Russian Poland; Areas in Heavy Shading Show Territories Acquired After the World War."

Personal qualities rather than technical proficiency make for success in the modern business world, in the opinion of Professor Atlee L. Percy of the College of Business Administration, Boston "University, who delivered his annual address as president of the Eastern Commercial Teachers' Association yesterday at the convention of the organization in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Despite defeat by the House today of the sales tax, Representative Rainey, the Democratic floor leader, in a radio address tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System, declared the fight to balance the budget had been won.

PARIS, March 24. -- On the eve of the four-day Easter closing the Bourse was quiet today, with the volume of transactions greatly reduced. At the opening the market was steady, but as the session progressed the tendency, due to dullness, turned toward declines.

"WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The homes of Mrs. Alice Roosevelt Longworth, widow of former Speaker Longworth of the House, and of Sir Willmott Lewis, Washington correspondent of The London Times, are under police guard as the result of threatening letters to them demanding money.

Declaring that while Typographical Union No. 6 would negotiate with the employers in the job printing shops on "matters of mutual Interest" it would in no circumstances consent to a reduction of the present scale of wages, Austin Hewson, president of the union, insisted yesterday that the present contract, which expires in September, was a beneficial one.

WILKES BARRE, Pa., March 24. -- Insurgents made grains in the district below Wilkes-Barre today in their efforts to close every anthracite mine to bring about equalization of work and end wage cutting. In the upper end of Wyoming Valley, in Lackawanna and in the lower coal field the situation was unchanged, most of the miners remaining at their posts.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- When the House of Representatives today struck the manufacturers' sales levy from the Ways and Means Committee's tax bill, the whole of Congress, for the first time in years, passed out of the control of either of the two major political parties.

PARIS, March 24. -- Every country's budget difficulties can be solved, former Ambassador Henry Berenger declared in the Senate today, only by concerted international action on debts and reparations. There is hardly a country in the world, he reminded the Senate, which does not have a budget deficit.

SHANGHAI, March 24. -- The Chinese Government agreed today to go in for kidnapping in a big way as a desperate move to save the life of a captive American. The step was taken when the friends of Charles Baker, a Yangtse River boat captain of Pasadena, Cal., found themselves unable to free him.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Charges that Al Capone's power is so great that he offered to police Chicago in exchange for immunity in controlling labor unions and the beer, liquor and gambling rings were made to a Senate subcommittee today in a letter from Frank J. Loesch, president of the Chicago Crime Commission and a member of the Wickersham Commission.

DAIREN, South Manchuria, March 24. -- The inhabitants of Harbin believe that the expected Russo-Japanese clash is likely to result from today's order of the Chinese president of the jointly owned Chinese Eastern Railway to the police to prevent more locomotive and freight cars from being taken across the frontier into Siberia.

It must be that the spirit -- the "cocky" spirit -- which Mr. SILAS STRAWN found pervasive in England is in no slight degree due to the stirring appeal of the Prince of WALES to the courage and faith of the youth of Britain. In a recent address he brought his threefold message to a climax by saying

DAIREN, South Manchuria, March 24. -- The inhabitants of Harbin believe that the expected Russo-Japanese clash is likely to result from today's order of the Chinese president of the jointly owned Chinese Eastern Railway to the police to prevent more locomotive and freight cars from being taken across the frontier into Siberia.

It must be that the spirit -- the "cocky" spirit -- which Mr. SILAS STRAWN found pervasive in England is in no slight degree due to the stirring appeal of the Prince of WALES to the courage and faith of the youth of Britain. In a recent address he brought his threefold message to a climax by saying

Passenger revenue of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad declined 32.37 per cent in 1931 because of the depression and motor vehicle competition, M.H. Cahill, president, says in his annual report. New forms of competition adversely affected freight revenue.

Nearly one hundred performances of Wagner's "Parsifal" have been given by the Metropolitan Opera Company since Conned first produced the festival play in this city in 1903, and all but twenty-five of these were given, in New York and on tour, under the direction of Mr. Gatti-Casazza.

MANHASSET, L.I., March 25 -- The Tar Baby, which put out from Manhasset a week ago for a seal hunt at Falkner and Goose Islands, in Long Island Sound, slid wearily into its dock here today without a seal on board.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 25 -- Jockey C. Smith performed an outstanding feat today by bringing home five winners at the Agua Caliente race track. The prices on his mounts ranged from $24.20, which Bonaire returned for $2 to take the seventh race, to $3, paid by Captain Gilbert in the fifth.

BOMBAY, March 25 (AP) -- Meher Baba the parsee seer whose followers call him the "god-man," left today for the United States to make the Americans realize the "infinite state" which he has enjoyed since he first saw the divine light many years ago.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 25 -- Mrs. Anna Hill, a widow who spurned a bribe, was responsible here early today for the seizure by the police of champagne, whisky, brandy, gin and other liquors valued at upward of $250,000 from a seagoing steam lighter, and the arrest of forty-six men.

To the Editor of The New York Times: National taxation should be equitable, but such has ever proved an iridescent dream. Generally speaking, taxation is blurred by imperfect visualization and realization of facts and is consequently misconceived.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Mr. and Mrs. John Crerar of Chicago today announced the marriage last Saturday of their daughter, Mrs. Catherine Hatton Koehn, to John Reginald Dane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Linwood Dane of Bedford Hills, N.Y.
LOS ANGELES, March 25 -- Finishing with a grand flourish, the Giants concluded their stay in Los Angeles today by again downing the Pirates to score a clean sweep of the twogame series.

Promises that the Lindbergh baby would be restored to its parents soon were repeated yesterday in Norfolk, Va., but they found no echo in Hopewell, N.J., where Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh waited ready to consider any new proposals laid down by the kidnappers.

Under the constant threat of being casually picked off and killed by the guns of blockading Spanish warships. Larry Rue, flying European correspondent for The Chicago Tribune, crossed the Straits of Gibraltar, insinuated himself into Abd-el-Krim's camp and confidence in the midst of the Riff war and came back to civilization as an unofficial ambassador with, peace terms and colorful newspaper stories of battles.

PARIS, March 25 -- In a statement issued by the American Chamber of Commerce here today it is declared that the increased tariff rates just published by the French Government for rubber boots and shoes destroys the most-favored-nation treatment hitherto accorded to the United States on these articles.

ESCRAGNOLLES, France, March 25 -- I fooled them when I made that 500-foot drop to the earth in my plane yesterday, purposely wrecking it to prove the practicability of the shock absorbing device I have invented for airplanes. Everybody thought I would be killed. I wasn't even scratched.

BELFAST, March 25 -- In anticipation that Eamon de Valera's Government will base its case on the retention by Northern Ireland of its land annuities, H.M. Pollock, Minister of Finance, issued an explanation of the position today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- No significant improvement in world trade or finance can take place until some settlement is reached among European nations on the reparations question, Silas Strawn, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, told its board of directors today.

MONTREAL, March 25 -- Elated over their success against the New York Rangers in the opening game of the first-place play-off for the National Hockey League championship, the Canadians of Montreal, holders of the Stanley Cup and the world title that it symbolizes, are eagerly awaiting the second game of the series, which will be played here tomorrow night.

The word "maund" was used by Elizabethan writers as a name for a basket. One describes a little "maund" made of osiers small, which served "to do full many a thing withal." Another fills it with roses "to strew the way," and SHAKESPEARE pictures a "maid full pale" drawing a thousand favors from a "maund of amber, crystal and of beaded jet."
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Defeat of a House bill that would grant 181,000,000 acres of public lands to States for park purposes was urged today by Governor Pinchot in an open letter.
NEWKIRK, Okla., March 25 (AP) -- Colonel Zack Miller responded today to the law for his trigger-finger defiance of a receiver's auction sale of the equipment of the 101 Ranch.
Many outdoor union church services will mark Easter Sunday tomorrow. Some of these will be followed by communion services. Many groups also will meet at breakfasts.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Opposing passage of the Glass banking reform bill at this time as deflationary and unwise, Percy H. Johnston, president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, New York, told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today he did not "think any superpower should be set up in Washington to dictate to a bank's board of directors" what business they should do.

The body of a man identified as Charles Anderson, 30 years old, of 481 Jackson Avenue, Long Island City, believed by the police to have been "taken for a ride" and killed by criminals who mistook him for some one else, was found yesterday morning in a driveway between 79 and 83 Midwood Street, Flatbush, a neighborhood which includes the homes of District Attorney Geoghan, Supreme Court Justice Dodd and other prominent citizens.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Petitions signed toy 2,500,000 ex-service men asking immediate payment of the remaining $2,000,000,000 on their adjusted service certificates will be presented by the Veterans of Foreign Wars to Speaker Garner within two weeks.

Music festivals will form the greater part of the services of worship tomorrow in all churches. Cantatas, oratorios, organ recitals and specially prepared liturgical compositions will be heard. Many of the non-liturgical churches will borrow some of the liturgical works and adapt them for their own use.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 26 -- Warning that Japan would secede from the League of Nations and deny its authority to intervene in the Orient if the League's commission now in China continued to display ignorance of Far Eastern conditions and showed determination to interfere in Far Eastern affairs was given today by Lieut. Gen. Sadao Araki, the Minister of War.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Decoding offices to combat criminal groups using "outlaw" radio stations to facilitate the smuggling of liquor, aliens and narcotics, have been set up by the Radio Division of the Department of Commerce.

The source of a series of mysterious wireless messages sent out in code to ships on Rum Row from various points on the Rockaway peninsula-signals which have baffled Coast Guard ships and investigators of the Federal Radio Commission for the last two months-was traced yesterday to a portable radio set mounted in an automobile.

Three cue experts from the European Continent, Albert Poensgen of Germany, the defending champion; Albert Corty of France and Gustave Van Belle of Belgium, last night went into a tie for first place in the world's amateur 18.2 balkline billiard championship at the Elks Club at the end of the third day's play.

By means of an upset victory scored by their captain, Cadet Charles Murray, over John F. Potter of Yale, Army swordsmen early this morning captured the famous Iron Man Trophy, emblematic of the foils title, in the thirty-ninth annual championship tournament of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association at the Hotel Commodore.
The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds now offered by dealers:

DAIREN, South Manchuria, March 25 -- The areas along the Chinese Eastern Railway and the South Manchuria Railway lines between Mukden and Antung are alive with insurgents, mutinous former Manchurian troops and bandits, all highly aroused against the Japanese and Koreans.

ASHLAND, Pa., March 25 -- Calling upon Governor Pinchot to remove State police detailed to keep order in District 9 of the United Mine Workers since the calling of the outlaw strike for "equalization" of a working time, the Shenandoah Mine Board, representing 10,000 miners, voted today to join the insurgents in a walkout tomorrow.

John J. Raskob's "lack of knowledge of politics" was responsible for the spending of $5,000,000 for Alfred E. Smith's Presidential campaign in 1928, Timothy J. Mara charged in a statement issued yesterday. Mr. Mara, a sports promoter, and Patrick F. Kenny, Yonkers contractor, are being sued by the County Trust Company on notes given by them for contributions to the Smith campaign.

William J. Flynn, Bronx Public Works Commissioner, who was accused at a hearing before the Hofstadter legislative committee last week of ruining a Bronx business man and of driving the latter's wife to suicide, took steps yesterday to start a counter-investigation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 25 -- Miss Ruth Nichols, aviatrix, announced today that the Westchester Airport Association probably would have a definite announcement to make within a week concerning plans for the construction of a WestChester County airport.

More than thirty civic and business organizations brought the question of increased subway fares definitely to the forefront of the city's financial situation yesterday when they adopted resolutions favoring an increased fare and salary cuts for all city employes and officials earning more than $1,200 a year.
The first offer to help the Metropolitan Opera through another season came last night from Giulio GattiCasazza, who for twenty-four years has managed the production of opera there.

A fusillade of shots from a waiting automobile just as after-theatre parties of fashionably dressed persons were arriving at Connie's Inn, well-known Harlem night club at Seventh Avenue and 131st Street, shortly after midnight this morning, fatally wounded a Negro woman, slightly injured a white man who was passing by and sent scores of persons scattering in terror.

SCHENECTADY, March 25 -- Mrs. Izetta Jewel Miller, who as a delegate from West Virginia to the Democratic National Convention in 1924 seconded the nomination of John W. Davis for President, was threatened today with a jail sentence it she attempted to conduct a scheduled hearing on charges affecting a member of the Municipal Welfare Bureau, of which she is director.

HONOLULU, March 25 (AP) -- Circuit Judge Charles S. Davis today tentatively set the trial of Mrs. Granville Fortescue and three others, charged with lynching Joseph Kahahawai, accused attacker of her daughter, Mrs. Thomas H. Massie, for April 4.

The message of Good Friday, commemorating the crucifixion of Christ upon the Cross at Calvary, was brought to many thousands of persons in this city yesterday, not only through their attendance at church services, but through various other means of communication extending beyond church walls.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 20 -- Double honors were captured today by Perry E. Moore of Morristown, N.J., in the running of the first two stakes at the ninth annual field trial of the Brcokhaven Game Protective Association on the association's grounds at East Manorville.

Easter Sunday promises to be cloudy and colder, the Weather Bureau announced last night, warning the host of those who plan to observe the holiday in the customary manner by appearing in the fashion parade in new Spring finery that showers were possible tomorrow morning.

MEXICO CITY, March 25 -- The ruins of an ancient city have been discovered in mountains near the small village of Tacupa, in the State of Guerrero, according to Guillermo Magana, brother of Divisional General Gildardo Magana.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A call has "been issued to the committee on arrangements for the Democratic National Convention to meet at the Congress Hotel in Chicago April 4. The personnel of the committee will be announced in a day or two, but some of its members are already known.

Rum-runners off New York are so desperate that they have resorted to a novel way of sending liquor ashore, it was indicated yesterday when Coast Guard found twenty-five kegs of whisky malt extract floating in toward Rockaway Point. Deputy Surveyor John H. McGill, in charge of the customs enforcement division, valued the seizure at $12,500.

DETROIT, March 25 -- Detroit will not default on its bonds, but the city will seek to refund $31,000,000 of its obligations due this year, Mayor Frank Murphy said today. The city proposes to replace these bonds with low-interest-bearing securities to cover the indebtedness.

The likelihood that former Governor Alfred K. Smith would go to Massachusetts to speak in the primary campaign on behalf of candidates for delegates to the Democratic National Convention pledged to him seemed ended yesterday when Governor Joseph P. Ely called on Mr. Smith but obtained no assurance that he would go to Massachusetts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the fact that many citizens of Pennsylvania are starving, as reported by Governor Pinchot, it may be interesting to note the elaborate technique employed by that Commonwealth for squandering taxpayers' money.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES reported the recent signing by Governor. Roosevelt of the act amending the civil rights law in a particular of great importance. By this act State officials, and indeed all interested parties, are forbidden to inquire or examine into the religious beliefs of candidates for the positions of teachers in the public schools.

William C. Wright of Philadelphia, national amateur court tennis champion, will defend his title at 2 o'clock today against the same player who met him in the concluding round of the 1931 tournament at Boston.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 25 -- The first musical comedy to be heard in the Westchester County Centre is "The Chocolate Soldier," which the New York Opera Comique is presenting in performances tomorrow afternoon and night. The company will be under the general direction of Kendall K. Mussey.

With the polo at Squadron A in Manhattan tonight devoted entirely to the last rounds of national championship eliminations and final tune-up games scheduled at Squadron C in Brooklyn, the tournament committee of the Indoor Polo Association of America has announced a postponement of the opening of the nationals from next Tuesday night to next Saturday, when the first night's play at Squadron A will be featured by two open championship games.

Loans on the Bonus A World War veteran whose application for a loan on his adjusted service certificate was refused on the ground that the certificates have no loan value until they are two years old writes as follows:

DUBLIN, March 25 -- Little imitatation Easter lilies made of muslin, which were sold all over Dublin today and worn in hundreds of buttonholes, may bring trouble to Ireland before this week-end is over.

Twenty-five charitable and public institutions receive more than $200,000 under the will of Mrs. Mary M. Mitchell, widow of John Ames Mitchell, artist, editor, author and founder of the humorous magazine Life, who died at her home, 41 East Sixty-seventh Street, on Feb. 22.

MIDDLESBORO, Ky., March 25 -- A group of Eastern college students who wanted to investigate the labor controversy in the Kentucky coal fields were hustled out of town tonight after an investigation by County Attorney Walter B. Smith.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 25 -- The Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland, a financing and trading corporation controlled by the Schoelkopf interests of this city, and which holds stocks and bonds acquired at a cost of more than $123,000,000, plans a readjustment of its capital structure in order to "correct capital impairment," it was announced today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 25 -- State Democratic leaders were formulating plans today to push the Cross-for-Vice-President movement after Governor Cross yesterday informed a group of Democrats of, his willingness to run. Town Chairman David J. McCoy of this city, today explained that the purpose of the conference was to ascertain the Governor's desires and said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just read a letter of my friend Frederic A. Delano which appeared in a recent issue of THE TIMES, and wish we could oftener see in the public prints expressions of like tenor.

The business depression resulted from avarice as much as from poor business planning, according to Henry G. Russell, teacher in the Bulkeley High School, Hartford, Conn., who sent a paper on "The Business Cycle" to the economics section of the convention of the Eastern Commercial Teachers Association yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Match 25 -- The Washington police believe they have developed excellent clues toward identifying the person or persons who wrote threatening letters to Mrs. Alice Roosevelt Longworth, widow of the former Speaker of the House, and Sir Wilmott Lewis, correspondent of The London Times, although no arrests are imminent.

PARIS, March 25 -- Premier Tardieu told the French Senate today that he hoped to reach an agreement with Great Britain on his plan for an economic union of the five Danubian nations and on Britain's proposal for a conference of Britain, France, Italy and Germany before the Danubian countries meet.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 25 (AP) -- The gravity of the South's tornado aftermath became more apparent today as field workers for relief forces discovered additional dead, injured and homeless.

To propose raising revenue out or a tax on non-existent beer might seem rational to a House of Representatives which bad voted higher taxes on incomes that are no more and on estates which, have vanished. But it was really for other reasons that the proposal was brought up yesterday, first to legalize beer with an alcoholic content of 2.75 and then to tax it.

The National Academy of Design, one of the oldest art organizations in the country and considered a stronghold of conservatism, departed from its traditional paths last night by electing to associate membership an artist of the modern school, Edward Hopper.

TRENTON, N.J., March 25 -- For the first time in more than a year an upturn in industrial conditions was reported throughout New Jersey for the month ended Feb. 15, Colonel Charles R. Blunt, State Labor Commissioner, announced today. On a State-wide basis the gain in employment in major industries was 1.5 per cent.

For a statesman whose goal is a non-partisan government. Senator NORRIS is a remarkably good hater. President HOOVER and the whole Administration are particular objects of his dislike. But this should be regarded as impersonal, characteristic and Norrisian.

Mrs. C.G. Keck has bought from Mrs. Mollie B. Kilpatrick a seven-room English-type house at 52-25 Douglaston Parkway, Douglaston, on a plot 60 by 116 feet. The seller took in part payment a house at 67-101 Exeter Street, Forest Hills. Hosinger Bode, Inc., arranged the deal.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 25 -- One of the few still existing coaches that, back in the gay '90s were a feature of the coaching parades in Newport is now on the market. It belonged originally to late August Belmont and passed from him to his son, Perry Belmont, who has sold it with a quantity of other personal effects to a second-hand dealer.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Ambassador Mellon paid a short visit to the House Foreign Affairs Committee this morning to receive felicitations of the members. He addressed the committee in executive session for about fifteen minutes.

In a recent Senate discussion of Europe's indebtedness to the United States, Senator SMOOT revived the question of American loans to France, "I will repeat to the Senate," he said, "that there was paid to France more in dollars and cents after the Armistice was signed than had been advanced to her before."
A new corporation has been formed under the laws of New York to take over the Art Centre and its seven constituent societies at 65 East Fiftysixth Street, it was announced yesterday.

Speaking of the recent war games in the Pacific, Admiral SCHOFIELD, commander of the United States fleet, said that "every naval officer of experience believes that the battleship is the fundamental strength of the navy and that everything else is auxiliary to it."

The Public Education Association has advised the public school authorities that it will be unable for financial reasons to continue its support of the experimental program in "progressive" education in Public School 41, at 26 Greenwich Avenue, after the present term.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Willys R. Peck, American Consul General at Nanking, has advised Americans who left that city during the SinoJapanese crisis at Shanghai that they may return with some assurance of safety. He informed the State Department today that he had issued the following statement to the American residents of Nanking and to the press:

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 -- Using the new Pocock shell which recently arrived from Seattle, the University of Pennsylvania varsity crew won the opening practice race of the season over the Henley course today on the Schuylkill River. Morning, and afternoon workouts were held.
The Block Community Organization was speeded up yesterday in preparation for the opening of active solicitation by the great army of block-aiders on Monday.

Miss Katharine McMahon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John J. McMahon of 148 West Eighty-eighth Street, will be married to Alfred J. Talley Jr., son of former Judge and Mrs. Alfred J. Talley of 1,172 Park Avenue, Easter Monday morning in the Church of St. Gregory the Great, West Ninetieth Street.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 25 -- The Valparaiso Automobile Association and other organizations are urging the government to import gasoline in navy tankers in order to combat a 25 per cent increase in brice contemplated by foreign oil companies operating here.

The usual early Spring demand for homes, though in diminished volume, was apparent in the suburban realty deals reported yesterday. Remodeling and new construction is under way in some cases to provide for the exodus from city quarters to more open residential sections.
SCHENECTADY -- N.Y., March 25 (AP) -- Economic conditions have caused the return of old-time communal farming methods to at least one up-State New York village.
ROME, March 25 (AP) -- All Italy observed today the commemoration of the death of Christ with traditional Good Friday ceremonies, processions, prayer and periods of silence.

BUFFALO, March 25 (AP) -- Crouched behind a closed refreshment stand ton the river road which skirts the banks of the Niagara River just north of Buffalo, a 16-year-old high school student fought a gun battle with police and Federal officers today and died with a bullet in his heart.

Next week's schedule of new State and municipal bond and note issues lists forty-seven loans totaling $12,933,188. The revised total for this week was $17,119,866 and the weekly average for the year to date is $20,509,078. Only three of next week's issues call for amounts of $1,000,000 or more.

CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) --Three years' observation of normal men in the University of Illinois Research Laboratories here has led medical scientists to conclude that men whose bodies undergo constant change are the energetic, enterprising and forceful leaders in business.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An article in THE TIMES on various proposals looking toward reduction of salaries of Federal Government employes states that Representative La Guardia, who has opposed any salary reductions, received a letter from Anthony J. Grasso, president of the Italo-American Association, saying that "this was no time to uphold high pay for government workers."

To Defer Post-Easter Clearances. Eight retail trade groups, chiefly in cities of the Middle West, have cooperatively agreed to defer after-Easter clearances to the week of April 10 or 17, according to communications received by the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Federal budget must be balanced, declared President Hoover in a statement this afternoon on the financial situation of the government. Unless this was accomplished, he said, the measures adopted to restore public confidence would not be complete and the depression, would be "prolonged indefinitely."

RYE, N.Y., March 25 -- The Mamaroneck High School sextet, Westchester High School Hockey League champion, defeated Lynbrook High of Long Island, 8 to 1, in a non-league game today at Playland Casino for its eighth triumph in eleven games. Ken Mink was high scorer with three goals.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 25 (AP) -- Applications for a rehearing of appeals to the Alabama Supreme Court were filed today in behalf of seven Negroes sentenced to death at Scottsboro a year ago for attacks on two white girls.

CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Six regional managers were apointed today by Montgomery Ward Co. to make effective the company's plan for decentralization of managerial control while effecting closer cooperation between mail-order and retail-store branches and a greater flexibility in management.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 25 -- Stanford University's challengers from the Pacific Coast assumed the lead in the preliminaries of the national collegiate swimming meet tonight by qualifying eight men for tomorrow night's finals.

Business will return to a normal basis in Wall Street this morning after having been suspended for Good Friday. The security markets, which were closed yesterday, will reopen, and the banks, which operated in many cases with limited staffs, will have their regular quotas of employes at work today.

For its first production the Workers' Theatre has, by a natural application of logic, chosen a play about unemployment, "Dole Brothers," which was acted by amateur players at the Rand School last evening. It has been adapted from the German of Richard Duschinsky, a young German actor whose "Gallery Gods" was tried out in the neighborhood of New York last Autumn.

MOSCOW, March 25 -- Albert Kahn left Moscow tonight, unable to renew his contract to teach the Russians industrial and architectural designing, which legally terminated March 1 but had been held open in the hope that a renewal might be effected upon mutually satisfactory terms.

MOSCOW, March 25 -- "A little cloud no bigger than a man's hand on the eastern horizon, but full of ominous possibilities," was the way one of the ablest foreign diplomats in Berlin characterized the Memel situation a month ago to this correspondent.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Silas Strawn's report to the Chamber of Commerce on the financial situation in Europe is as follows:

Charges that the Securities-Allied Corporation lost $6,000,000 through exchange of bonds of Empire State, Inc., for stock of the Manufacturers Trust Company were made in a stockholder's suit against the corporation, disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday, when Justice Peter Schmuck upheld a motion by the plaintiff for examination of an officer of the corporation before trial.

One man who sang at his work last Thursday must have been Baron VON BORN, Minister of the Interior in the Finnish Cabinet. On that day he signed an order suppressing all activities of the Lapuan or Fascist organizations. Among the first demands put forward by the leaders of the abortive Fascist coup d'etat at the end of February was the removal of Baron VON BORN from his post.

WILSIINGTON, Del., March 25 (AP) -- The Wampun Oil Corporation of New York today filed in Chancery Court here a bill for an accounting for specific performance and other relief against the Lago Petroleum Corporation and the Venezuela Syndicate, Inc., both of New York.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S decision to veto the Dunnigan bill, giving the city an unrestricted right to mortgage the fee of property acquired through condemnation proceedings, is sound. The public hearing in the executive chamber brought out arguments in favor of the bill which fell of their own weight.

A discovery of importance concerning the ductless glands, and results of other research which tend to upset commonly accepted theories on the process of hearing, were announced at yesterday's meetings of the forty-eighth session of the American Association of Anatomists.

PARIS, March 25 -- If the disarmament conference has been slow in getting started it is because the SinoJapanese conflict has had a way of interrupting, Premier Tardieu told the French Senate today in a defense of his foreign policies.
"Harlan Miners Speak," published today by Harcourt Brace Co., is the record of visits to the Kentucky coal fields by committees under the direction of Theodore Dreiser and Waldo Frank.

PARIS, March 25 (AP) -- The government was understood tonight to have in mind a suggestion that the French motion-picture industry produce more films as a means of lightening the tax burden of exhibitors, who have complained of excessive taxation.

The version, in the not-too-distant future, of Emerson's "hitch your wagon to a star" will be "hitch your rocket to a star," according to Dr. H.H. Sheldon, Professor of Physics, New York University, who described seven hypothetical methods of controlling the direction of pilotless rockets inside and outside the earth's atmosphere, in a lecture last night before the American Interplanetary Society at the American Museum of Natural History.

Practically all security and commodity exchanges were closed for the Good Friday holiday, and most of the European exchanges similarly suspended business. Since this was not a legal holiday in the United States, the money markets were open; but the only interest was in foreign exchange.

New public financing this week aggregated $32,056,000, consisting of $20,000,000 of public utility bonds and $12,056,000 of municipal issues, compared with $38,486,000 last week and with $142,999,000 in the corresponding week last year. In addition, $5,000,000 of new municipal bonds will be placed on the market formally on Monday, although advance orders for these issues are being received by the bankers this week.

ORANGE, N.J., March 25 -- John Currier, 60 years old, of 322 Charlton Avenue, South Orange, died today in the Orange Memorial Hospital of injuries suffered in an automobile accident in West Orange last night. Mr. Currier was riding with Lawrence Woodbury of 112 Evergreen Place, East Orange, when their car was in collision with a truck driven by Salvatore Daniello, 18, of 693 Nassau Street, Orange.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 25 -- Johnny Golden, Wee Burn professional, came through in the last round of the North and South open today to score a 71 and tie Craig Wood, the New Jersey pro, at 286, one of the lowest scores that has ever been made in the seventy-two-hole event. The leaders will play off in an eighteen-hole test tomorrow morning for the title.

STOCKHOLM, March 25 -- The committee of six men appointed to investigate the position of the Kreuger Toll Company issued today an interim report declaring that the company needs a prolonged moratorium.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, March 26 -- While the Sino-Japanese armistice negotiations almost reached the point of rupture yesterday afternoon, a large part of the Cantonese faction of the Kuomintang party of China took steps to force the Loyang Government to fight the Japanese.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 25 -- Facing the almost perfect pitching of Sylvester Johnson and Big Jim Lindsey today, the Robins lost to the St. Louis Cardinals, 7 to 1.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 25 -- Oklahoma A. and M. and Iowa State College showed tthe way in the National Collegiate wrestling championship tournament tonight, each placing three grapplers in the semi-finals.

BAYARD, Fla., March 25 -- Make Speed, a gelded son of Whiskalong from Oronge, owned and trained by Oscar Chaney, captured the Bayard Purse, feature at St. Johns Park today, by the narrow margin of a nose. The winner was timed in 1:15 1-5 for the six furlongs, staving off Infinitive in one of the most thrilling finishes seen at the meeting.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 25 -- Three weeks after his wife had died from a bullet wound in her apartment at the Greystone Hotel in New York City, Gerald Sturgis Greenlief, former manager of the Mirasol Hotel in Santa Barbara, Cal., ended his life today by taking poison in this city, where they spent their honeymoon twelve years ago.

The Treasury Department's monthly report of the general stocks of all kinds of money in the United States as of March 1 shows the following principal changes during February. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted, gold released from earmark is added:
CLEVELAND, March 25 -- Reports of a merger of independent shipping interests, a project which was planned in 1929 but failed, have been revived here.

Indications that the Easter volume of retail business failed to reach expectations are found, in reports received from fifty-five leading cities by Bradstreet's, which states that, although part of this may be charged to inclement weather, much of it is simply because the public is not buying.

Conflict in the French Chamber of Deputies about an appropriation of $2,000,000 to finance the construction of the new French superliner known as the T-6, will not impede work on the ship, according to Jean Tillier, manager of the French Line in the United States and Canada.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25 -- The off-day in the Yankee exhibition schedule today was a day off for only two members of the training squad, namely, Babe Ruth and Rufus Meadows. The others put in a full two-hour session of intensive batting and fielding practice at Huggins Field under the most satisfactory weather conditions that have prevailed for more than a week.

WELLESLEY, Mass., March 25 -- After telling his chauffeur to wait outside, Bernard Arthur Behrend, 56 internationally noted engineer and electrical inventor, entered his home at 110 Cliff Road, Wellesley Hills, today and committed suicide by shooting himself through the heart.
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Discussing Secretary Hyde's criticism. Peter B. Carey, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, said today:
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A proposal to legalize 2.75 per cent beer as a basis for new taxes was defeated in the House today by a vote of 216 to 132.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Organized labor went to work today to defeat the movement for reduction by Congress of salaries of Federal employes. Forty-eight representatives of workers throughout the country started a door-to-door canvass in the House Office Building and Capitol under the direction of Edward R. McGrady, legislative agent of the American Federation of Labor.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 25 (AP) -- Police and firemen told the Mayor, Charles S. Owen, today that they had voluntarily agreed to take reductions in their salaries.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 25 -- One of the largest social events of the season was the tea with which Mrs. Charles Curry Chase and her daughters, Mrs. Maurice Fatio, Mrs. Roy Brodhead Meredith and Mrs. George Stevenson Fenton entertained at Mrs. Chase's Via Del Mar villa today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Sixteen States and the District of Columbia had no bank failures in February, as contrasted with eleven States without any suspensions in January, the Federal Reserve Board reports today. The States free from bank failures were Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, Rhode Island, Connecticut, New Jersey, North Dakota, Delaware, South Carolina, Alabama, Mississippi, Arkansas, Montana, Wyoming, New Mexico and Arizona.

PATERSON, N.J., March 25 -- County officials refused to reveal the results of an autopsy performed today upon the body of Peter Wagenaar, which was exhumed from the Lodi Cemetery near Garfield on an order signed yesterday by Common Pleas Justice William Seuffert in Hackensack.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 25 -- Three men were in custody and under indictment today on charges of first degree murder in connection with the fatal shooting Saturday night of William H. Ryder, 66 years old, Yorktown cider mill owner. The arrests were made and the indictments obtained through the tracing of prints left in the mud by automobile tires by Sergeant Charles La Forge of Troop K, New York State Police.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Minturn Pinchot and her niece, Miss Leslie Scott of London, will come to Mayfair House today to remain until sailing for England April 6.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 25 -- A statement issued jointly by Mrs. William X. Weed, Regent of the White Plains Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, and Mrs. Elizabeth G.H. Coles of Mamaroneck, criticizes the Westchester County Historical Society and its president, William S. Hadaway of New Rochelle for "discrediting" the authenticity of the Miller house in North White Plains as the headquarters of General Washington during the Revolution.

War at Long Range. When Hans Chlumberg's "Miracle at Verdun" was produced by the Guild last season, some dramatic reviewer remarked, apropos of the fact that the play was written some ten years after the end of the war, that a similar "time lapse," or lag, usually occurs between a great social catastrophe and its adequate celebration in the arts.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 25 -- Jersey City won easily from North Carolina State College today, 14 to 5, by virtue of heavy and timely hitting. Except in the pitching department, the collegians played a better game than the score indicates.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Canada and the United States are approaching the point in their negotiations on the St. Lawrence Waterway where they expect soon to begin drafting a treaty. So far the negotiations have been oral and designed to reach agreement on fundamental points.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- President Hoover's statement on the subject of government financing read as follows:

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 25 -- Cornelius McGillicuddy, better known as Connie Mack, is starting on his forty-ninth season in organized baseball. The tall, thin manager of the Athletics, in that thin, gentle voice of his, was talking things over today.

LONDON, March 25 (AP) -- Representatives of the British railways and bus and truck lines met today at the Transport Ministry to discuss problems arising from the growing competition among their services.

War at Long Range. When Hans Chlumberg's "Miracle at Verdun" was produced by the Guild last season, some dramatic reviewer remarked, apropos of the fact that the play was written some ten years after the end of the war, that a similar "time lapse," or lag, usually occurs between a great social catastrophe and its adequate celebration in the arts.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 25 -- Jersey City won easily from North Carolina State College today, 14 to 5, by virtue of heavy and timely hitting. Except in the pitching department, the collegians played a better game than the score indicates.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- President Hoover's statement on the subject of government financing read as follows:

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 25 -- Cornelius McGillicuddy, better known as Connie Mack, is starting on his forty-ninth season in organized baseball. The tall, thin manager of the Athletics, in that thin, gentle voice of his, was talking things over today.

Citing as vital elements in the retail situation the need of emphasis on wanted merchandise of reliable quality and efforts to revive consumer confidence in values and trices. P.A. O'Connell, head of the E.T. Slattery Company, Boston, and president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, expressed the view that April should yield a large and profitable business for the stores.

Mayor Walker will return to City Hall tomorrow prepared to defend the five-cent fare, the short-term subway bond policy and the 1932 budget against the massed attack of real estate boards and various business and civic organizations.

The listed bond market was subjected yesterday to strong pressure in the brief trading period following the holiday on Friday. Final prices showed rather severe losses in most groups. Trading was heavier than usual for a Saturday. United States Government bonds were actively sold, reflecting, in the opinion of many, the seriousness of the unbalanced budget as set forth by President Hoover's appeal.

The International Business Machines Corporation and Remington-Rand, Inc., which are said to have combined gross receipts of $10,000,000 a year through the rental of tabulating and statistical machines an through the sale of cards which are used in tabulating, were named defendants yesterday in an anti-trust suit begun by the Federal Govern ment, one of their largest customers.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- Chicago Ford dealers will get their first glimpse of the new Ford V-8 and Four here on Tuesday night, and photographers will view them on Wednesday, and the public announcement, with extensive advertising in the newspapers of the country is expected on Thursday.

SOME practical rules for handling wild animals in filming exterior location scenes were outlined the other day by W.S. Van Dyke, whose directorial assignments of the past few seasons have ranged from Tahiti and "The Pagan" to Africa and "Trader Horn," and to Western Mexico and "Tarzan, the Ape Man," which is now at the Capitol.

JERUSALEM, Sunday, March 27 (AP). -- Christians of Jerusalem, their number augmented by thousands of pilgrims from abroad, commemorated Easter Sunday with moving and colorful ceremony. The city was peculiarly alive from long before dawn in observance of the event, which coincides with the Jewish Passover and an important Moslem feast.

The case for pressing of Federal construction work, financed by an issue of long-term bonds, was summed up yesterday by United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, its chief advocate, in an address before the forum of the National Democratic Club, 233 Madison Avenue, and broadcast by WOR and WABC.

Walter Spence of Rutgers and Ray Thompson of Navy gained two places each on the all-league team picked annually for The Associated Press by coaches of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association. The selections were announced yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Post-Lenten festivities in this resort begin tomorrow with a full program of events for both sports devotees and those less inclined to the out-of-doors. The South Atlantic contract bridge tournament and the Georgia State tournament will take place at the Bon Air-Vanderbilt, beginning tomorrow.

PARIS, March 25. -- The Concours Hippique, or Paris Horse Show, has just opened, and will continue until April 12, with a highly diversified program, and it will offer nearly 800,000 francs in prizes. Half of this sum is given by the government and the other half by the Paris Municipal Council and by the principal racing and breeding organizations.

Construction methods which have heretofore been limited to the waterfront have been utilized by the contractors who are building the new union inland freight terminal for the Port of New York Authority in the block bounded by Eighth and Ninth Avenues and West Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- A concerted demand for Congressional action on legislation to aid the farmer was made by John A. Simpson, president of the Farmers' Union; Senator Frazier, Republican, of North Dakota, and Senators Thomas of Oklahoma and Wheeler of Montana, Democrats, this afternoon over a nationwide network of the National Broadcasting Company.

ITHACA. N.Y., March 26. -- Cornell's track team concluded its indoor track season by defeating the University of Michigan, 49 1/2 to 45 1/2 in a close meet tonight. Two meet records were shattered, each, team getting one.

FORTY-SIX screen writers, several of them well-known authors and playwrights, have been engaged by Carl Laemmle Jr. for next year's Universal program. In no instance, however, have they been employed to develop original screen stories.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 26. -- Enrolment figures of both parties for Nassau County, made public today, show a decided increase over the enrolment of last year. The increase was attributed to the Presidential elections.

VALLEY STREAM. L.I., March 26. -- The Bronx Lacrosse Club triumphed over the New York Lacrosse Club twelve, 5 to 2, in a game played at the Curtiss-Wright Airport today. Sam Aronosky, outside home, and Sam Roth, first attack, starred on the attack for the victors, each tallying a pair of goals, while Smith, third attack, accounted for the winner's other tally.

ALBANY, March 26. -- A revival of the old battle over the executive budget and the consolidation of State departments is predicted by observers here as a result of the prospective legislative investigation of the State Administration, scheduled to begin next week.

A SERIES of studies in severe black and white, sketched in part upon, legal foolscap and part upon newsprint -- such is perhaps the best way of describing this up-to-now biography of Samuel Seabury, who bas attacked Tammany Hall in three successive investigations.

THE NEW YORK TIMES Weekly Business Index shows a further slight rise. The preliminary figure for the week ended March 19 is 61.3, as against 61.0 (revised) for the week ended March 12 and 60.4 for the week ended March 5. The increase was caused by gains in the adjusted indices of freight-car loadings and electric-power production, which slightly offset declines in the adjusted indices of steel-mill activity, automobile production and carded cotton, cloth production.

Of the 203 municipalities in Hudson and Essex, Middlesex, Union, Morris, Bergen and Passaic counties of North Jersey, 122 will have decreases in their tax rates this year, seventy-nine will have increased and two will have the same rates as last year.

All along the Pacific Coast owners of six and eight meter racing yachts are preparing for the Olympics in August. There will be the Western and notional eliminations for them preparatory to the internationals.

English and French period furniture, tapestries, Oriental rugs, silver and porcelains from the estates of Dr. Reginald H. Sayre and Samuel Adams Clark of New York, together with property of Mrs. W.H. Bougherty and others, will be sold Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

RECENT announcements of the forthcoming Charity Carnival of 1932 have brought, it is reorted, an unprecedented response from members of society, many of whom already have requested that the same boxes and seats to which they subscribed in previous years be reserved for them again.

MIAMI -- Like the fourth, annual all-American air meet, which in early January featured the opening of Miami's Winter season, so the principal events arranged for the Spring season will continue to emphasize the growing mutual interests of Miami and the principal cities of South America.

Jack (Kid) Berg's qualifications -- or lack of them -- as a lightweight championship contender are to be determined Friday night in the ring at Madison Square Garden, where the dynamic English lad is to oppose rugged Sammy Fuller of Boston in the main bout of ten rounds.

SOME 600 feet beneath the point where Steinway Avenue in Queens runs into the East River, at the foot of what is known as shaft 9A, drillers are now putting the finishing touches to their three years' task of excavating the nineteen shafts and twenty miles of city tunnel No. 2, the $43,000,000 water conduit being built by the Board of Water Supply.

The budget method of dispensing family relief should be adopted by all agencies, both public and private, even in such an emergency as the present, when funds are insufficient to meet all needs, according to Mrs. Louise Kraus Addiss, consultant in home economics of the New York Charity Organization Society.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 26. -- Chilean police are investigating the shipment by truck of a large consignment of ammunition from Valparaiso, presumably destined for Santiago.

WHILE business marks time in the third year of an international depression, the nations of the world are rapidly involving themselves in a system of tariffs and trade controls for which there is no parallel in their experience.
WASHINGTON, March, 26. -- Some Improvement in a few of our foreign markets was reported in the weekly survey of business conditions abroad made public today by the Department of Commerce.

TOPEKA, March 23. -- With farm prices at the lowest point they have touched in modern times, and fault-finding flourishing as never before, the wisdom and unselfishness of farm organization leaders who desert their posts as such to seek the best-paying political plums are being challenged throughout the agricultural sections of the country.

RICHMOND, March 24. -- The recent session of the Virginia Legislature devoted a good deal of time to a question over which it had no jurisdiction, namely whether Professor D.S. Muzzey's "History of the American People" is a proper book to be used in the public schools of the Old Dominion.

WHEN Uncle Sam leans over to scrape the bottom of his tax barrel he is following the example of every country in the civilized world, all of which have faced deficits and all of which have taxed their citizens heavily.

ELKINS, W. Va., March 24. -- If the number of Democrats seeking the Gubernatorial nomination in West Virginia be any criterion, then that party may entertain reasonable hope for success, for there are no fewer than six entrants, a larger number than at any time in the history of the State.

TOKYO, March 26 (AP). -- Emperor Hirohito granted permission today for a second withdrawal of Japanese troops from Shanghai, and General Shirakawa, commander there, was instructed to send the units back to Japan.

THE review of "Food and Drink," by Louis Untermayer, that should do this little collection justice would have to be as graceful as the verses the book contains, dance with a Puckish wit, and scud from cadence to cadence on slippered feet.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A foreign dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES declares that the Nineteen-Power Commission of the League of Nations * * * then recessed, subject to convocation. "Recessed," for "adjourned" seems to be new in the creation of a verb from a noun without change of form, "a poor method," as a critic recently declared.

HERE is a detailed and authentic history of one very Important activity In American participation in the World War. Colonel Wilgus, who writes it, was Director of Military Railways and Deputy Director General of Transportation in the A.E.F. and a member of the military Railway Commission to England and France.

A REGULAR IRREGULAR. REPRESENTATIVE F.H. LA GUARDIA has dropped bombs on Austrians and monkey wrenches in Congress. His bombing days are over, but judging from recent La Guardia activities in Congress the monkey-wrench industry should be ready to pay some extra dividends.

THE president of Smith College brings inspiring evangel to those many men and women who would like to keep abreast of at least the main currents of intellectual progress but are bewildered by the swiftness of their onward rush and the multiplied variety of their contents.

OF the many South Americans who have made conspicuous careers in motion pictures. Lupe Velez of Mexico is one of the most successful. The very titles of the pictures in which she has starred -- "Hell Harbor." "Tiger Rosey," "The Storm," "Lady of the Pavements" -- indicate her tempestuous temperament.
PARIS, March 26. -- Premier Tardieu announced today that he would accept Prime Minister MacDonald's invitation to attend a conference on Danubian problems.

The fundamental Marxian tenet that capitalism is only a transitory introduction to communism, because it forces labor into an increasingly unbearable position, is denied by Thomas N. Carver, Professor of Political Economy in Harvard University, in an article entitled "Capitalism Survives" in the April issue of Current History.

One of the schools that pioneered in dropping the old formalities of classroom drills, marks and grades and in substituting emphasis on "the moral development of the child through sincere, unselfconscious experiences" has now had twenty-five years of trial.

THIS week the division of industrial and engineering chemistry of the American Chemical Society is to discuss in New Orleans the chemical engineering processes of the oil Industry. Behind such forbidding technical titles as "Fracionation of Straight Run Pennsylvania Gasoline."

THE Theremin Electronic Symphony Orchestra will have its first performance on Friday evening, April 1, at Carnegie Hall, under the direction of Albert Stoessel, as part of a concert devoted to some already well-known and other entirely new electronic musical instruments of Leon Theremin.

MONTREAL, Sunday, March 27. -- The New York Rangers conquered the Montreal Canadiens, 4 to 3, and tied the first-place National Hockey League play-off at one victory each in a game that ended at 12:40 o'clock this morning. Bun Cook's goal on a pass from Bill Cook in 19:32 of a third extra period decided a grueling battle.

Heavy charges against surplus to adjust the plant and equipment account and to convert foreign, assets into dollars were made by the Union Carbide and Carbon Company in 1931, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Net income for the year was $18,029,522 after taxes, depreciation, interest, subsidiary dividends, depletion and other charges.

Twenty teams will compete in the annual city P.S.A.L. senior high school championship handball tournament, according to the schedule of matches issued by John J. McHugh, inspector of athletics of the P.S.A. L., who is in charge of the tourney. For the first time, the teams will be divided into four groups, instead of two as was the case last year.

The thirty-eighth annual session of the New York University Summer School will start on July 7 and will continue for six weeks through Aug. 17, it was announced yesterday by Milton E. Loomis, assistant dean or the School of Education and director of the Summer School.

Available relief funds are entirely inadequate to meet the emergency caused by unemployment and "every good citizen" should support the campaign of the Block Community Organization which begins tomorrow, declared William Hodson, executive director of the Welfare Council, who announced yesterday that a study just completed indicated that more than 80 per cent of the 700,000 applications for various forms of relief handled through the Social Service Bureau in the last year resulted from, unemployment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Lord Justice Darling over twenty years ago remarked to me that his brethren of the King's bench objected only to criticism from the bar and public which had the blast of the east wind and that the wisest judge welcomed suggestions which came with the mildness of the south wind.
THE distinguished modern German composer Ernst Toch will make his first New York appearance at the League of Composers' concert next Sunday afternoon at the French Institute.

Plans for a recapitalization of the Middle West Utilities Company which may entail the sale of some of the properties owned and a diminution in the amounts received by the company from its subsidiaries were reveled yesterday in the annual report, issued simultaneously with the passing of the preferred and common dividends.

Mrs. William H. Good of 880 St. Marks Avenue, Brooklyn, chairman of all women's activities of the city's George Washington Bicentennial Commission in the five boroughs, said yesterday that a meeting of Manhattan women, with Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson serving temporarily as chairman, would be held early in April.

Members of the junior and senior championship basketball teams of the Catholic Youths' Organization of Chicago are scheduled to arrive in the city tomorrow for their intercity games with the St. Nicholas of Tolentine junior and senior quintets of the Bronx, to be played at the 102d Engineer Armory on Wednesday night.

Exeteres baseball team will play a sixteen-game schedule this Spring, starting on April 16 against the Huntington School nine at Exeter. N.H. Six of the contests will be with college freshman nines, those of Harvard, Holy Cross, Yale, Tufts, Brown and Boston College.

HERE is a single day in the life of a drab middle-aged woman -- an uneventful day composed chiefly of trivialities and petty worries and small, accustomed pleasures. Emily Akbarjian, wearing a shapeless black felt hat and a long, old-fashioned black coat, leaves her bungalow on Long Island to spend a day in New York.

THE MASTER'S GOLDEN YEARS" continues the story of the life of Christ begun by John Oxenham in his earlier novel. "The Hidden Years." "The Splendour of the Dawn," published two years ago, dealt with the years immediately following the Crucifixion and the persecutions under Nero.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- A distinct probability that Congress may not be able to complete necessary legislative work in time to adjourn before the Chicago National Conventions occupied the attention of Senate leaders today while that body marked time during a three-day Easter recess.

Figures reported by the Department of Commerce show that during January and February American foreign trade reached the lowest level recorded for the first two months of any year since 1910. This was in part the consequence of reduced purchasing power abroad. It was also the result of the tariff war in which the chief trading nations have recently engaged and of the break-down of the machinery of international credit.

AIKEN, S.C. -- Aiken -- the Winter colonists and the townspeople as well -- will commemorate half a oentory of local polo, and on Satarday, the day of the celebration, the prevailing styles in Aiken will be of the vintage of 1882. In the Spring of that year polo was first introduced in Aiken by the late Captain Clarence S. Wallace of New York.

The first play-off match or the year in Madison Square Garden is scheduled for tonight with the Rangers meeting the champion Canadiens of Montreal. A capacity crowd is expected to be on hand to see the battle between the teams which finished on top in their respective groups in the National Hockey League.

An interesting commentary on women's goll is revealed in the handicap list which has just been completed by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association. Glancing over the roster of 322 names and comparing it with the 1931 list, one finds that in general the handicaps are slightly lower than they were a year ago.

Two of the six city P.S.A.L. senior high school team champions which have been, called upon this year to defend their 1931 titles have done so successfully, and three others are making strong bids to retain their laurels in competitions which have not been completed.

PLANS are proceeding well for the fashion show and tea that will aid Everybody's Thrift Shop on the afternoon of April 5 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The final details will be decided on tomorrow afternoon when Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell, who heads the entertainment committee, and Mrs. James Duane Pell will have a tea at the hotel for those in charge of the benefit.

Economic depression makes a frontal attack on the standard of living, Frances Perkins, New York State Industrial Commissioner, said last night in an address over a National Broadcasting Company network under the auspices of the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education.

TIN PAN ALLEY, which in the old days was considered generally as part of the lunatic fringe of the professions, has become respectable Indeed, it has gone even higher than that, for it is now grouped with Big Business as well.

GRETNA GREEN'S fame as a place where clandestine marriages may be performed at a moment's notice persists Respite that its once easy marriage laws were made more severe many years ago. At least this is indicated by a recent report from London.

Easter even though the weather may not corporate to its fullest extent marks the active beginning of the Spring sport seasons at the colleges of the East. Baseball has been played in one or two places and after a few day' hiatus for the Easter vacations, will begin in earnest with two or three games a week.

WINTER departs sullenly, halting on the northern horizon, looking back with a scowl, aa a bandit does who thinks he might have extorted more tribute from his victim. The chill of his late presence remains In the air and the soil.

IF there is one thought which floes not spontaneously occur to the visitor who explores what is going on in the aging architectural monument in Washington where the State Department conducts its business, it is that of the traditional American policy of "isolation."

CLATTERING over stony fields, or laboring through swamps and thickets, with their guns sputtering incessant streams of shells at imaginary enemies, students are in training in the United States Army's only tank school, at Fort George Meade, Maryland.

FOURTEEN impartial, non-partisan broadcasts on "Civic Education by Radio," sponsored by the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education, will begin at 8 P.M. on April 5 over the WJZ network with Dr. John H. Finley making the introductory address.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The Irish Free State Legation declared today that its government was not repudiating obligations in its stand against paying land annuities to Great Britain. A large part of the American press, the legation said, had misunderstood the position of the Irish Free State Government.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga. -- Young people on vacation from Eastern schools are temporarily dominating sports and entertainment features at Sea Island, crowding the days with a variety of activities and filling the evenings with dances and dinner parties.
The national court tennis singles championship, like the doubles title, remains in the keeping of Philadelphia for another year.

PANAMA, R.P., March 22. -- Although Costa Rica's recent revolt failed to overthrow the present government, it has left the country with a political situation so complicated that it will stir unrest for months to come, even if it does not cause another uprising.
