The approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission of a transaction whereby the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will assume one-half of an $11,700,000 bank loan of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, falling due on April 1, was hailed as a constructive move in Wall Street yesterday.

IN announcing the concert next Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall, in which Josef Hofmann will play with the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra conducted by Walter Damrosch for the benefit of the Musicians' Emergency Aid. Mr. Damrosch recalled the fact that, he had been present at the memorable occasion in the Metropolitan Opera House nearly forty-five years ago when the 10-year-old prodigy of the piano revealed his artistry to the astonished and rapturous public of New York.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 26. -- University of Michigan's well-balanced swimming team retained its national collegiate championship tonight by taking a first place in the medley relay, last event on the program. Michigan earned 34 points. Stanford was second with 31.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 26. -- A buffet dinner and dance was given by Miss Lillian Feitner and Quentin F. Feitner Jr. tonight at the patio of Casa Invierno. Mr. and Mrs. Feitner also invited friends. The guests were members of the school and college set.

A baseball game with Columbia and a lacrosse match with Princeton on Saturday will mark the opening of the Spring sports season at New York University. The diamond duel will take place at Baker Field and the lacrosse meeting at Princeton.

What of the higher life in Chicago today as compared with conditions soon after the armistice? Offhand one would say that the decade after 1920 was one of intellectual decline. The writers who flourished in Chicago at the beginning of the period apparently all migrated to New York, and their places have been taken by the gangsters and the racketeers.

MR. MACCALL describes his present work as a "first attempt to give the public a coherent and comprehensive story of the origin and evolution of the Irish nation." That so warranted a need baa not hitherto been met he attributes to the "almost insurmountable difficulties" that have beset the study of Ireland's past.

LAKE WOOD, N.J., March 26. -- The covering and a gas cell of the navy's airship Akron were damaged in its second accident during a heavy gale two weeks ago, while it was in the hangar at Lakehurst undergoing repairs, it became known today. Captain Harry Shoemaker, Commandant of the Naval Air Station, said that the damage would not delay the completion of repairs in time for a trial flight on April 21.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- An assertion that President Hoover "at a most threatening juncture in the fiscal affairs of the government" was seeking to inject partison bias into the public consideration of tax legislation was made tonight in a radio address by Jouett Shouse, chairman of the executive committee of the Democratic National Committee.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 26. -- A desire to point out the perils and tragedies of West Rock resulted fatally this morning for John W. Patterson Jr., 15, son of the superintendent of the Seamless Rubber Company.
LONDON, March 26. -- Sir Horace Plunkett, Irish reformer and leader of the cooperative movement, died today at his home in Weybridge, Surrey, England, at the age of 77.

PANAMA, R.P., March 21. -- Communists of Russian type are not numerous in Latin America, but the number of radicals and discontented laborers, faced with unemployment and pitifully low wages, who are willing to follow Communist leaders and agitators, has grown considerably as a result of the economic distress and the political upheavals of the past year.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The capital's celebration of Easter will open with the sunrise service of the Grand Commandery of the Knights Templar of the District of Columbia in the Arlington Ampitheatre, attended by President and Mrs. Hoover.

CHICAGO. ATER functioning for twenty rather uneventful years, the Chicago Society of Etchers has faded out of the picture, so far as the show-seeking public is concerned, and its functions have been taken over by the Art Institute of Chicago, which on Thursday, March 24.
EASTER in the theme of broadcasting today. Four sunrise services will begin this day which will bring the sound of St. Peter's chimes and sacred music from the Eternal City.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Sports activities at Pinehurst this week will be of exceptional interest, with, the women's North and South golf championship, the horse show of the Pinehurst Jockey Club, a race meeting of the Pinehurst Matinee Club and three polo games heading the list of attractions for the large number of vacationists now at the resort.

TWO pictures with parallel themes, one a German production, the other from the studios of Warner Brothers, will be on exhibition here this week. The German film, described as a musical drama, is scheduled for its first presentation at the Europa Theatre next Tuesday.

GENEVA, March 25. -- Some unsuspected achievements of the League Assembly during its "first phase," as its debonair and doughty president, Paul Hymans of Belgium, called its recent meeting, are coming out, now that the session can be viewed at a distance of a few days.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 26 (AP). -- The advantage of Summer sunshine through the dark days of Winter has been the privilege of half the children in the Cornell Nursery School.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 26. -- The dinghy sailors of the Frostbite Yacht Club today held their second Spring session, after their Wintry carrying on, at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. They went through five races, three of which were won by Bill Swan and the others by Corny Shields.

LONDON. March 26 (Canadian Press). -- Final services will be held tomorrow at St. Andrew's Church, Wells Street, in Us day one of the west end's most celebrated churches. The days of its chief glory were during the long rectorship of Rev. Benjamin Webb, one of the leaders of what was known as the Tractarian Movement, which had such a momentous effect upon thought and practice in the Anglican Church In the nineteenth century.

ANDREA CHENIER" this week wlll bring the Metropolitan opera productions for Gatti's twenty-fourth season up to the remarkable figure of forty-eight different titles. It is within one of the record forty-nine given four years ago and a like number two years earlier, when an extra "Samson" was added outside the home stage.

NORTH CAROLINA offers many attractions for an early Spring motor trip. Good, paved highways crisscross the State in all directions, while the scenery in the western portion is equal to anything east of the Rocky Mountains.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 (AP). -- Two armed bandits held up "The Lark," a Southern Pacific passenger train, just outside the railway yards here tonight, forced the passengers riding in the lounge car to give up money and jewelry and then leaped from the train.

The Argentine Government has about concluded arrangements with Brown Brothers, Harriman Co. whereby the $13,000,000 of 6 per cent notes held by the bankers, which will mature on April 1, will be taken care of. It is understood that Argentina will pay off a small part of the issue and that the balance will be extended to 1933.
IT seems that Apollo, as well as Pallas Athene, Castor and Pollux and other robust deities presiding over the efforts of athletes, is to be invited to the Olympic Games in Los Angeles this Summer.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 25 (AP). -- Negotiations are under way for the purchase of the Karle Lithographic Company by the Stecher Lithographic Company, both with headquarters here and branches in many parts of the United Stales. Both concerns make colored folding boxes, seed bags and labels for canned goods.

UNBRIDLED COMPETITION. By Justice BRANDEIS In a Dissenting Opinion Before the Supreme Court of the United States. THE people of the United States are now confronted with an emergency more serious than war. * * * Some people believe that the existing conditions threaten even the stability of the capitalistic system.

WILDWOOD, N.J., March 25. -- Clarence Fisher, a local bank clerk and the defending champion, gained the semi-final round of the ninth annual Eastern States tournament at the Wildwood Golf Clnb today. Fisher triumphed after a close match with the medalist, W.H. Goeckler, 1 up.

VIENNA, March 12. -- The eagerness of even the poorest of the Viennese to acquire knowledge, regardless of whether it can be of use to them, was well illustrated last night when several hundred unemployed waited patiently for more than an hour to receive a lesson in English for which they were called upon to pay a small fee.

WASHINGTON. March 26. -- A representative exhibition of the work of American artists was opened today at the National Gallery of Art in the National Museum as a feature of the George Washington Bicentennial. It will continue until Thanksgiving Day.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP). -- The Justice Department today answered a request for protection of college students studying mining conditions in Kentucky with the statement that that was a matter to be handled by the States.

THE relations of rival trading nations with South America were broken into, if not entirely suspended, by the World War, and since the armistice there has been the keenest competition to recover lost ground. The economic depression has been a blight on efforts to restore business with the nations of South America, for they also have had their industrial and credit problems.

A UNIQUE private library in Westchester County, begun as a hobby a few years ago, is now being transformed into a legacy for future writers of history. And since the collection is eventually to become part of the library of the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, it is also in the nature of a legacy for future makers of naval history as well.

READING, Pa., March 26. -- Scoring fifteen straight flyers each, despite the difficult shooting due to a heavy downpour, five gunners divided the honors in the Eastertide, feature of today's flyer shoot of the Strausstown Gue Club, which brought five consecutive days of wine shooting in this vicinity to a close.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 26. -- The slogan in the Sunshine City is "Sports for All" and the program runs from setting-up exercises on the beach at dawn to the hurdle event in the dog races close to the witching hour of midnight, which is very late for St. Petersburg. This is a town that delights Joey Sewell of the Yankees, who has been brought up to believe that sundown is bedtime.
Two Squadron A teams qualified for the national indoor polo championships in games at their own armory last night.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 26. -- Myron Taylor Hall, the new home of the Cornell Law School, will be dedicated on Oct. 15 by Chief Judge Pound of the State Court of Appeals, it was announced today by President Livingston Farrand.

MISS HULL'S new book is quiet and controlled, always hovering on the verge of violent action and never quite falling in. It reproduces by great artistry the very lifelike quality of constantly arousing in us the expectation of some exciting event, and then bringing forth nothing but the most commonplace of everyday experiences.

Two mysterious callers who said they were on a mission connected "with the return of the baby" spent two hours early yesterday morning with Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh in his home on Sourland Mountain near Hopewell, N. J., and then drove away, saying that they would return.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, C.Z., March 22. -- Canal Zone Democrats Will send six delegates to the Democratic National Convention at Chicago, and there is at present a possibility that twelve may go, although only six can finally be recognized. Although the local Democrats cannot vote in the national elections they run true to form and stage a good fight in the ejection of delegates.

DISTINCTION is an Important requirement in wall hangings today. Rare and, beautiful examples of fabric mural decoration were found in all important interiors from Gothic times until the late eighteenth century.
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Herman E. Wills, for more than fifty years an outstanding figure in the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, died of pneumonia at his home here this morning.

MOSCOW, March 25. -- They say abroad that there is no freedom of speech in the Soviet Union, but those who say it have-not traveled in the street cars of Moscow. At that they don't miss much; because these street cars are never overclean, and they are always over-crowded, and frequently are subject to long and unexplained halts.

NEW PHILADELPHIA, Ohio, March 26 (AP). -- Several shots were fired at the Wolford Coal Company mine near Newport tonight as a crowd estimated, by Sheriff Harry C. Smith at 1,000 milled about the mine.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 26. -- Willard E. Blain failed today in his second attempt to fly like a bird and narrowly escaped drowning. He crashed first in October when he tried to take off with a truck pulling him.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The first of a series of dinner dances at the New Casino Terrace Restaurant will be held on Monday, inaugurating the gay Spring season in Virginia Hot Springs. Tea dances have been among the outstanding affairs of the past week in the colony and will be continued throughout the season.

BRIDGE and backgammon parties, in combination with dancing and other entertainment, have been arranged for the near future, several of them coming this week. Many tables have been taken for the bridge tournament which will be held on Tuesday afternoon in the roof garden of the Waldorf-Astoria in aid of Stony Wold Sanatorium.

More than 1,000 chemists from all parts of the country are expected to attend the eighty-third meeting of the American Chemical Society which opens in New Orleans tomorrow and will continue for five days.

Lawrence Johnstone, Staten Island's oldest resident, will celebrate his hundredth birthday today with his family in the little house at 382 Fingerboard Road, Fort Wadsworth, where he has lived for a quarter of a century.

PENN YAN, N.Y., March 26 (AP). -- Milton L. Rapalee, former sheriff of Tales County, was arrested today by Constable Gordon Simpson, whom ha had discharged as a deputy sheriff, on charges of burglary and grind larceny.

AMONG the world's serious musicians radio broadcasting seems to be gaining approval as an adequate carrier of sound. For my part I am not yet sure that this condition of adequacy has been attained. I do not suggest abolishing radio, as some apprehend, however undeveloped I may consider it for musical purposes.
CHICAGO, March 26 (AP). -- An unemployed switchman's liking for auctions has brought him a small fortune and considerable worry.

A FEW months ago the young Korean author, Younghill Kang, published his autobiography, "The Grass Roof." The most affecting passage in the book was that in which Mr. Kang, who lived through the episode, described the Japanese Invasion and later the annexation of Korea.

IF the problems of financing the trip and of sufficient rehearsals with a British orchestra can be solved in time, London opera lovers will have a chance to enjoy six performances in the Savoy Theatre by the Austrian. State Opera Company in May this year.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Negotiations between Canada and the United States for a treaty to govern the development of the St. Lawrence waterway were brought a step nearer conclusion today when Major W.D. Herridge, the Canadian Minister, arrived from Ottawa and conferred with officials of the State Department.

Decrying the influence of "petty supergovernments" as selfish groups interested only in their own welfare, Henry Morgenthau, former Ambassador to Turkey, in an address before the Eastern Commercial Teachers Association, in convention yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, urged an expansion from provincialism to nationalism in the teaching of the youth of the country.

THOUGH the South's recent tornado disaster was by no means of unprecedented magnitude, most years do not yield a storm or group of storms of this character so destructive of human life, and there have been years in which the aggregate death toll of tornadoes throughout the country was much smaller than it was in this single visitation.

MR. SAMUEL'S discussion of the plight and problem of the Jewish people is not quite so sensational as the description on the jacket would make it appear. It is not so much "a merciless expose of a cowardly leadership, a commercialized rabbinate and a servile press" as it is a frank and fearless discussion of a very definite point of view.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 26. -- The colors of Mrs. T.H. Somerville of Montpelier, Va., waved on high in the third running of the Carolina Cup race today. In the three-mile event over timber. Troublemaker, which had been the favorite since he was entered, triumphed after being hard pushed by Mrs. T.H. Symington's aged bay gelding Primero.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Easter Sunday sees a large colony here, many of whom have come up from the far South resorts, and the coming week will see the activity customary at White Sulphur at this time. A concert will be given tomorrow night at the Greenbrier by the University of Virginia Glee Club, to be followed by a dance.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- A new coalition of high tariff Democrats and administration Republicans Seized control of the tax bill this afternoon and succeeded in writing into it a duty of 10 cents a hundred pounds on coal and coke imports before the movement could be stopped.

ARTHUR HAMMERSTEIN stole quietly into town the other day from Palm Beach, where he spent several months recuperating from a series of operations, not from show business. Since his arrival fee has been catching up on his theatregoing and before long he intends to be back in the managerial harness.

LAS VEGAS, Nov., March 26 (AP). -- A three-year search for the slayer of Mrs. Virginia Patty of Los Angeles led today to tentative identification of the body of a Hoover Dim laborer who committed suicide Wednesday as that of William L. Tallman. missing radio operator.

THE rumors that the British Broadcasting Company may broadcast all the concerts of the Royal Philharmonic Society next season have been greeted with approval by the London press. There also have been suggestions that the London Symphony Orchestra be brought into the general scheme.

ROME, March 25. -- Easter Sunday usually marks the culminating point of the Rome season, which runs from the end of November to the middle of April. This year, however, though the weather promises to live up to its much-advertised traditions, things are taking on a quiet aspect.
NEW YORK, Henry Theodore Leggett gave a luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria for his cousin, the Hon. Drogo Montagu of London, whose wife 13 the former Miss Tanis Guinness.
To the Editor of The New York Times: As one who knew and loved Billy Guard, permit me to thank you for the splendid tribute you paid him in THE TIMES of last Sunday.

IN Soviet Russia the workmen and the boss are comrades. The workmen may talk back to the boss But if comrade-boss talks back to comrade-worker there may be difficulties. This proletarian principle is carried to an extent that seems incredible to us.

AFTER a silence of three years. Mrs. McClure now publishes a novel which In several respects shows decided Improvement upon her preceding work. From this story she has eliminated her former tendency to the floridly artificial and to the building up of main situations too high-pitched In dramatic tension for credibility.

ROME, March 26 (AP). -- Thousands will congregate in the immense basilica of St. Peter's at Vatican City tomorrow for Easter mass. Cardinal Pacelli, arch priest of the basilica, will conduct the ceremonies, which will centralize the Roman Catholic world's expression of joy for the resurrection of Christ.

Cardinal Hayes, a sexton and four Roman Catholic institutions were benefited by the will of Mgr. Edward McKenna, which was filed for probate yesterday in Bronx Surrogate's Court. Mgr. McKenna died on Dec. 12 last, in his eighty-eighth year, after having served sixty-three years in the priesthood.

A smashing victory by New York A.C. swimmers in the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior 400-yard free style relay championship featured the water carnival in the 75-foot pool of the Brookly Central Y.M.C.A. last night. John Wicklum of the Dragon Club won the junior 150-yard back stroke title test.

IN the chapel of Warden Lewis K. Lawes's Big House more than 2,000 men in gray, prisoners doing sentences ranging from one year to natural life, vigorously applauded the cast of "Counsellor-at-Law" at the conclusion of its performance at Sing Sing Prison on Sunday, March 13.

PINEVILLE, Ky., March 26 (AP). -- County Attorney Smith, when informed tonight that Gabriel Cairitt, a British subject, alleged he was struck by an officer last night in the ejection of students, said, "When the British Embassy complains to me I will reply."

MART MIMS Is the State Community Worker for Louisiana, and in this book she and her collaborator give graphic and inspiring accounts of the success which has attended her efforts in that State. For some five years she has been carrying on this constructive work; more than three hundred organized communities have passed under her molding and revitalizing hands.

John F. Potter of Yale broke a thirty-nine-year-old precedent last night when he captured his third successive individual foils title as the annual championship tournament o the Intercollegiate Fencing Association game to a close at the Hotel Commodore.

KKOXVILLE. Tenn., March 26 (AP). -- An appeal to faculty members and student bodies throughout the nation for support in their fight to get into the strife-torn Kentucky coal fields for sociological research was prepared here today by leaders of the college students ejected from the mins area.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP). -- Thirty-one of the votes cast for bringing the Beck-Linthicum anti-prohibition resolution before the House were termed "not wet" today by the Methodist Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals.

Joseph A. Broderick, State Banking Superintendent, will have to stand trial in New York City on the misdemeanor charge of neglect of duty in the Bank of United States case, Supreme Court Justice John Ford ruled yesterday in denying the motion of Mr. Broderick's attorneys for a change of venue on the ground that their client could not have a fair and impartial trial in the city.

LEIPZIG, March 26 (AP). -- The suit of Adolf Hitler against Karl Severing, Prussian Minister of the Interior, growing out of recent raids on meeting places of Hitler's National Socialist party, was settled out of court today.
TONAWANDA, N.Y., March 26 (AP). -- Edward Briggs, whose wife and two children disappeared last night, said tonight he was convinced they had plunged to their death over Niagara Falls.
PARIS, March 24. -- Spectator sports clothes show signs of returning to town mode. Worth's smartest clients are ordering this type, preferring fresh colors to black and white.

NEW features have been combined with several dances of the Spring which are now in preparation in the interests of various philanthropic enterprises. One of the popular events of each post-Lenten season, is the Rainbow Ball, which is to be held April 16 in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

Last week's overturn in the House of Representatives will doubtless be seized upon to point many a moral. Especially will those who have already been shaking their heads gloomily over the break-down of parliamentary institutions in modern democracies find new reason in it to despair of the Republic.

THE annual National Air Show scheduled for next Saturday at the municipal hangar on Detroit's great airport is well on the way of becoming a fixture in that city. Whether air shows are held elsewhere or not, Detroit and its board of trade, its manufacturers and its bankers insist that Detroit have its own show.

A dinner in honor of Cass Gilbert, noted architect, designer of the Woolworth Building, and president of the National Academy of Design, was given last night by the Salmagundi Club at its house, 47 Fifth Avenue.

Manual Training High School's lacrosse team, winner of the Colonel Robert M. Thompson Trophy, emblematic of the city P.S.A.L. championship, eighteen times since the award was placed in competition in 1910, has started preparations for the coming campaign.

JUDGING by the demands made upon the modern radio announcer, that unfortunate individual must, indeed, be a perambulating encyclopedia or the ancient curator of the Boston Athenaeum, for whom the entire subject of belleslettres as become the sine qua non of the intelligent citizen.

EAST MANORVILLE, L.I., March 26. -- Redgate Jock, a white and blue licked English setter dog, owned and handled by George Terrell of Bellport, L.I., was the outstanding contestant in the feature event of the annual field trials of the Brook-haven Game Protective Association, which were concluded today on the association's grounds.

DETROTT, March 26 (AP). Formation of a new organization to handle all sales activities of the General Motors Corporation in the medium-priced field was announced today by R.H. Grant, vice president of the corporation. He will direct the organization, which will be known as the Buick-Olds-Pontiac Company.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 26. -- J.F. Reed, president of the Minnesota Taxpayers' Association, asserts in a statement that his reports show the town meetings held in Minnesota on March 8 cut township expenditures a total of about $1,500,000.

Negotiations have been resumed looking to the acquisition by the United States Steel Corporation of the A.O. Smith Corporation, a $40,000,000 enterprise. It is believed the transaction will be completed soon.

SPECIAL performances of Russian opera by Russians will be an important feature of the music of the week. The performing company, now known as the Russian Opera Foundation, Walter Leighton Clark, president, indicated what it could and what it might accomplish when it mounted Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff" and "Khovantchina" last Winter in Mecca Temple under the artistic direction of Max Panteleieff.

HAVANA, March 26. -- A resolution of the Cuban Sugar Institute, the official-body under which the Chadbourne plan operates, fixing the present Cuban sugar crop at 2,700,000 tons, was signed by President Machado and sent to the Official Gazette of publication today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 24. -- Two thousand miles of main line added to the rail systems that feed this port and supply outlets for the traffic originating in San Francisco's industrial district. That was a pleasant item in the news of the week.

LONDON, March 25. -- The coolness with which the British public received Eamon de Valera's challenge to the oath of allegiance this week is an indication of the profound change which is coming over the conception of British Commonwealth relationships in this country.

THE very latest thing for the bride's attendants is to dress them, like the bride, in white. In some of the most fashionable of the early wedding parties the only color will be introduced in the hats, the trimmings on the dresses of the attendants, their shoes and bouquets.

In a statement pointing to the steadily mounting cost of government, the National Industrial Conference Board declared yesterday that the business as well as the political world should consider the future fiscal policy of tie nation.
WASHINGTON. UNCLE SAM'S payroll, whose relation to the Federal deficit is now the subject of lively debate in Congress, amounted last year to $1,341,670,431.

AS in its previous issues, the American Year Book for 1931 intimately interlocks with previous volumes, since it carries on the story they have told, and forms the immediate background for those that will follow it. That is, the series, as it goes on from year to year, provides a continuous and comprehensive history of the United States in contemporary terms.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 26. -- C.E. Hyde broke fifty straight targets at the Mineola traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. It was the best scratch score in a field of thirteen.

Optimistic but not overconfident, George H. Vreeland, head coach of this year's women's United States Olympic track and field team, writes that he expects America's representatives to turn in a creditable performance in the international games at Los Angeles.

IT Is taken for granted that in the slow, deliberate years of the Catholic Church Father Damien, the savior of the lepers, will be canonized and take his place in the saints' calendar. It was so assumed when, in 1889, his martyred body was laid in the sand of Molokai.

Several hours after a shooting affray near Connie's Inn, 131st Street and Seventh Avenue, in which a Negro woman bystander was killed and a white passer-by was wounded early yesterday morning, the police arrested Gerald Conroy, 30-year-old former convict, in his apartment at 270 Sherman Avenue, where John Dempsey, another ex-convict, was binding a wound in Conroy's leg.

Cheryl Crawford, director of the Group Theatre, denied yesterday that Hollywood was killing the legitimate theatre. On the contrary, she held that the theatre was killing itself. She expressed that and other views in an address at a luncheon of the League for Industrial Democracy at the Hotel Woodstock, 127 West Forty-third Street.

The Eastern racing season of 1932 will open on Friday, when the thoroughbreds which have been running at Southern tracks during the Winter months will begin competition at Bowie, the course of the Southern Maryland Agricultural Association, midway between Baltimore and Washington, where more than 1,000 horses are now stabled.

Pageants festivals of music, organ recitals and dramatic representations or lessons taught by episodes from Good Friday until the resurrection of Christ will be given in Christian churches of all faiths today. The Crusade Union Boy Singers of America will sing the entire music service at the Cornell Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church tonight The sacrament of the Lord's Supper will be administered in many churches.

AIME BERTHOD, the French Under Secretary for Fine Arts, recently approved of plans submitted by Henri Verne. Director of National Museums, calling for the expansion of the Louvre at an estimated cost of $1,200,000.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- President Hoover today endorsed plans to increase the total vote at the national elections in November, saying in a formal statement that every encouragement should be given to the project of the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce for bringing out a maximum number of voters.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP). -- Mechanical improvements have created in the grain exchanges a price barometer so accurate that fair dealing virtually is forced upon dealers throughout the country, Siebel C. Harris said today.

SEATTLE, Wash., March 26. -- Stricken by a heart attack in his sleep, William Clyde (Jack) Lyon, 47 years old, widely known newspaper man and Watchtower correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died early today at his home here. Mr. Lyon is survived by his widow, Mrs. Mabel A. Lyon; a daughter, by a former marriage, Mrs. Mary Jones of Bennettsville, S.C.; three grandchildren and his mother, Mrs. Laura F. Lyon of Greensboro, N.C.

WE are all familiar with the tremendous advances that have been made in preventive medicine. Thus, small-pox has been practically wiped out by vaccination. Typhoid lever has been practically eliminated, not only by better supervision of our water and food supplies, but through vaccination with anti-typhoid vaccine.

The search since Wednesday for John Alien Baker, former trustee of Lynbrook, L.I., and president of a ship supplies company at 35 Water Street, Manhattan, ended yesterday when it became known he, had committed suicide by taking poison in his room at the Empire Hotel, Broadway at Sixty-third Street.

WHEN it was first proposed to broadcast the Metropolitan Opera it was suggested that the majority of opera lovers were in the New York area and that it would be a waste of radio facilities, wave lengths, time and power to send the performances across the land to Main Street.

WILKES-BARRE, March 26. -- The Pennsylvania Civil Liberties Union made public today the results of a survey of conditions in the anthracite field, holding illegal the ruling by which Sheriff Luther Kniffen of Luzerne County declared a state of disorder and empowered his deputies and State troopers to break up all gatherings to prevent rioting in the insurgent strike.

JOHN BUCHAN is to be thanked for the many things that he has written himself, but like Bran the Blessed he has whispered words into the ears of others that have increased our debt to him. It was he who urged Mrs. FRANCES WOLCOTT to write her memoirs, which have just appeared with the title "Heritage of Years."

THIS big book is filled to the brim with what Mr. Shaw now writes about what he really wrote about the war. He has here reprinted much of what he published originally in various periodicals, generously interspersing these war-time documents with his present reactions toward them.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 26 (AP). -- The South, in spite of its romantic past and future possibilities, is described as "in a sorry plight" by Edwin R. Embree, president of the Julius Rosenwald Fund.

LONDON, March 26. -- Scarabs found this season in recently excavated Jericho tombs prove conclusively that the city was destroyed by Joshua about 1400 B.C., while Amen-hotep III was reigning in Egypt, Sir Charles Marston, who has been financing various expeditions to the ancient city, announced today.

BOSTON, March 25. WRITE in New York as you like about the waning season. Here in Boston it is waxing according to Spring precedent. Fortunate town, with, usually, a long, cold Spring, reaching through May and beyond, with a theatre public slow to move countryward, with a most essential part of it -- the school and college contingent -- ready and waiting.

To the Art Editor: CHANCHING to turn the pages of L'Art Vivant, I recently came across a Parisian reference to an American artist which set me to thinking. It was the French critic Gauthier who wrote: "We would like to see Belmont's efforts with all their delightful capriciousness in the mural decorations of a large auditorium."

PRINCETON, N.J., March 26. -- An ancestral form, more than 10,000,000 years old, of the African aardvark, an ant-eater, was discovered in Wyoming by the Scott Fund Expedition, of which Dr. Glenn L. Jepsen of the department of geology of Princeton University was the leader, according to an announcement made here today by Dr. Jepsen.

PALM BEACH. -- Many colonists are foregoing this year their customary visits in the Georgia, Carolina or Virginia resorts on the way North and spending the additional time here. Paralleling these tardy departures is the postponement of the closing of several hotels and clubs.

NEW DELHI, India. March 26 (AP). -- Hope for peace between the government and the Indian Nationalists was suddenly revived today when It was learned that Mrs. Sarojini Naidu, president of the All-India National Congress, had a long conversation with the Viceroy, the Earl of Willingdon.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 26. -- Mayor Eugene H. Lehman received wide support during the last week in his effort to let the taxpayers frame a taxpayers' budget. About forty persons attended a committee meeting on Wednesday night and proceeded to reduce the Mayor's budget by $85,971.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., March 26. -- The annual village election to be held here on Tuesday, April 12, will provide a new village president, two trustees and a commissioner of finance. The voters also will pass on the tentative 1932 budget which provides for a 10-point reduction in the tax rate.

The removal of Sheriff James A. McQuade of Brooklyn, former Register of Kings County, whose bank deposits in seven years exceeded his salary by about $400,000, was asked yesterday by the City Affairs Committee in a communication sent to Governor Roosevelt.

Springing from a desire to get wider distribution, to maintain resale prices and in some instances to obtain higher wholesale quotations, consignment selling by manufacturers in some fields is being adopted more widely, according to a canvass of opinion yesterday in various branches of industry.

DETROIT. APRIL 9 now la assumed to be the date of the new Ford's debut. It Is known that 200 of the new models, and others running back to 1908, are going to participate In a parade which will be the high light of Dearborn's civic party set for that date.

KOENIGSBERG, East Prussia, March 26. -- The possibility of an armed invasion of East Prussia by one of Germany's neighbors was openly discussed in the Koenigsberger Allgemeine Zeitung today by General Wilhelm Groener, Minister of Defense and the Interior, who reassured the populace of this frontier province that Germany's army and navy were prepared to protect them, thereby sounding a sharp warning against any such plans.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 26 Yale and a strong alumni lacrosse team met on a muddy field today the undergraduates opening their season with a 4-to-3 victory. The alumni had eight former all-American players, including Coach Reggie Root, in their line-up.

A special committee of the Twentythird Street Association appointed to study Controller Berry's plan for a 6 per cent deduction on May 1 for payment of taxes ordinarily due on Nov. 1 recommends that the association oppose the plan, it was announced yesterday.

Donald C. Vaughan of the Garden City Casino won the second annual men's singles invitation tournament of the New York Badminton Club by defeating Mills Baker of the Great Neck Badminton Club, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 8, in the final yesterday at the 212th Anti-Aircraft Armory, after both had triumphed in hard-fought, three-game matches in the semi-final round.

OTTAWA, March 24. -- Parliament, having been in session seven weeks, is taking a brief Easter recess and the time is opportune to survey what has been accomplished and what remains to be done in the second half, because early prorogation is demanded by the assembling in July of the Imperial Economic Conference and the necessity of adequate arrangements by the government of Canada.

DALLAS, March 24. -- The signs are plain enough for even those who run along the political highways to read that the Texas democracy will be split wide open this year over prohibition. Just as in 1928, the drys are out to rule or ruin. But this year they have a harder fight.

AND now, what of Japan? Since Sept. 18 we have been reading much about events in Manchuria and Shanghai, but what has been happening in Japan? What have been the reactions of the Japanese people to the incidents in China and to the almost universally unfavorable criticism of their country?

IT has been the custom for many years for women active in the management of the Community of St. Johnland in King's Park, L.I., to raise funds for it by taking over a section of the seating capacity of Madison Square Garden for one of the performances of the circus.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 24. -- High school basketball isn't a sport in Indiana; it is a mania which has transcended all other community ventures. Nothing has tended to weave Hoosierdom so closely as has the annual competition in which one school team out of 800 is crowned champion of the State.

IT will not be at all surprising if ultimately we learn that Herber E. Winlock has some unpublished novels -- even detective stories -- and perhaps a parcel of poems, in the drawer of his desk at the Metropolitan. For an archaeologist, he is surprisingly romantic; amazingly alive to poetic, dramatic and human values.

THE picture of a very small man with a very large head, clad in a flaming red coat starred with glittering buttons, his cheeks flushed with strong punch, his small white hands not too decorous in their gestures toward the laughing woman seated nearest him.

PARIS, March 26. -- The French fliers, Lucien Bossoutrot and Aime Rossi, established a new world's distance record for flying over a closed circuit when they landed this morning at Oran, Algeria, according to telegraphic advices received here tonight.

SHANGHAI, March 26. -- The Sino-Japanese armistice conference was again almost wrecked this morning when Quo Tai-chi, China's "Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, proposed eliminating from the preliminary agreement the phrase "pending later arrangements," regarding the stipulation that the Chinese army remain in its present positions.

IN his present little book of verse, "Trial Balance." John V.A, Weaver assumes to turn his glance inward, and thus place himself, one knows not with how much fullness, beside the Rousseaus and the Laurence Stemea.

HAPPILY, Mr Lewisohn's book appears at a time when literary criticism needs integration and a new birth of influence. It is well for us now to be reminded of old truths and to have them newly applied. That is what Mr. Lewisohn, in this study of American literature from its beginnings to the present, has done.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 26. -- Johnny Golden, the Jolly Noroton, Conn., professional, whose ability to win play-offs brought him the world's richest golf prize at Agua Caliente last year, today won the North and South open title in an extra eighteenhole match with Craig Wood of Deal, N.J.

Thirty-seven papers dealing with technical problems of anatomy and related fields were read yesterday at the concluding meetings of the forty-eighth session of the American Association of Anatomists. The three-day conference was held at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University at the Medical Centre, 168th Street and Broadway.

DETROIT, March 26 (AP). -- Jimmy Smith, famous veteran bowler of Chicago, and Mike Mauser of Youngstown, Ohio, former American Bowling Congress champions, were high scorers in the doubles event today with an even 1,200, but they failed to land among the leaders.

Six firemen, endangered by a sudden back-draft as they arrived at a fire amid 400 bales of lintin on Pier 45, owned by the New York Dock Company, at the foot of Conover Street in the Erie Basin section of Brooklyn, escaped serious injury by leaping to safety last night, but the engine caught fire and was destroyed along with the lintin and the greater part of the pier.

HEADLINES actually lives up to the description on its Jacket; it does read like the veracious account of a gallant woman's struggle to save her husband from the electric chair. The book in remarkable, not as a novel but as the record of an unusual love story.
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP). -- Another dream of the late Julius Rosenwald, who searched for new worlds to serve rather than to conquer, is rapidly being transformed into actuality.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 26 -- A dance was held tonight at the Bronxville Field Club in honor of students home for the Easter holidays. Mrs. Russell McCandless was in charge.

ONE of the many entertainments for philanthropic purposes planned for Easter week will be the supper dance to be given on Saturday in the Regency Room of the Carlyle in aid of the West Side Hospital. It will be under the auspices of the Junior Auxiliary of that organization, with Miss Eleanor Hirsch in charge of arrangements, and Miss Rosalie Rahte, treasurer.

CALDWELL, N.J., March 26. -- Robert Stevens, 15-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Stevens of 7 Bond Place, West Caldwell, committed suicide yesterday, leaving $3, the only money he possessed, to his parents with a request that they buy Easter presents with it, it developed today.

To the Art Editor: THE most illuminating comment on the subject of "The American Renaissance" seems to me to have been enunciated by yourself in a recent article devoted to the decoration of Rockefeller Centre. The men you Indicate as the logical candidates for such responsible and important commissions are beyond doubt the most outstanding and capable painters that we possess today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the proclaimed determination of the new Irish President to take certain steps in the direction of separation between Ireland and Great Britain and the empire, may I say that I think in so doing he would be committing an unfortunate error?

ELIZA ORNE WHITE is an artist in the sure and effective use she makes of her chosen material. New England at its best and finest permeates bar books whether she writes of life today or a hundred year ago.
To the Editor at The New York Times: My sole object in writing this article is to be helpful in the anomalous condition we seem to be passing through at the present time.
DETROIT, March 26. -- Gar Wood, Detroit speedboat wizard, is now officially the world's power-boat champion.

Not long ago the door of the Human Engineering Laboratory at stevens Institute of Technology at Hoboken opened to admit a department store executive seeking answers to his vocational problems. It was not the question of the bewildered young college graduate -- "What shall I do next?"

The principal feature of trading on the local commodity exchanges in the week, which for most of them ended on Thursday, was a rally in the price of sugar after several weeks of steady decline. Coffee and raw silk futures also ended at gains for the week, while cocoa, hides, silver and wool tops closed lower.

OAKLAND, Cal., March 26. -- Advancing on San Francisco by a Slightly circuitous route, the Giants Stopped here today to open a two days' exhibition against the Oakland Oaks and were giving a really gorgeous demonstration of their skill before a gathering of about 5,000 when several untoward incidents well night ruined the entire performance.

Had DIOGENES turned his lantern on New York last week he would have found the honest man he has been hunting for. This unknown soldier of civic virtue sent $300 in currency to the Treasury in Washington in an envelope which could be identified only as having been postmarked in this city.

WITH the sun westering Into our eyes we climbed the most gorgeous, twin-hilled, serpentine, scenic-railway of a bridge in existence and, at its far side, slid down quietly into the somnolent afternoon peace of Meeting Street, Charleston.

Liquidation by general management investment trusts has played a much smaller part in the general market decline than has generally been supposed, according to Frazier Jelke Co., who have completed a survey of 162 trusts which shows that these companies owned 10,487,855 shares of stock at the end of 1931, against 11,583,959 at the end of 1930.

TORONTO, Ont., March 26. -- Expectation in Ontario government and mining circles is growing that the Province in 1932 may well be able to show as large an increase in the output of gold as was shown in 1931 over the total in 1930. The total of $35,886,558 in 1930 was increased to $43,117.688, a gain of more than $7,200,000.

ST. PETERSBURG. Fla., March 26. -- Babe Ruth touched a new high for the year today -- two home runs, three other titanic drives over the right-field fence which happened to be on the wrong side of the foul line, and eight catches of flies hit into his territory, two of which required nimble stepping to get.

LONDON. OUR present-day reviewing has been suddenly and simultaneously assailed by spokesmen of both authors and publishers. Writing in The English Review, Douglas Goldring says there has probably never been a time when authors were not more or less dissatisfied with the state of literary criticism, but the present is the first he can remember during the twenty-five years of his professional life when the reading public was more dissatisfied even than the authors.

IN our era of crowded communities and small apartments we should be inclined to smile at the practice of saving all household records -- grocery and doctor bills, tax and rent receipts -- with no intention of ultimately throwing them away.

In a report submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate the Board of Transportation Indicated that the city, by refusing to grant the application of the Westchester Electric Railroad Company for a bus franchise in the Bronx from Dyre Avenue to the Mount Vernon line, would be exerting pressure to compel the company to establish a 5-cent fare in Mount Vernon, where a 10-cent rate is now in force with the community's approval.

The dollar volume of real estate mortgages recorded in the chief cities of the country during February dropped to the lowest point for any month in recent years, according to the monthly survey of Nelson Hunt Co. of Chicago, specialists in real estate financing.
In his recent presidential address before the Physical Society of London EDDINGTON remarked:

To the Editor of The New fork Times: The interest of chemical producers in toxic gases for warfare can be understood, but when such a campaigner for peace as Representative. Ross Collins of Mississippi comes out for poison gas as an approved weapon, it is time to ask him upon what facts he bases his opinion.

THE late Eddie Foy used to sing, in melancholy accents, a ditty in which he proclaimed himself to be "the ghost of a troupe that was stranded in Peoria." As a result that shy municipality practically sprang into a comic significance akin to that enjoyed by such cultural centres as Kokomo, Kalamazoo and Ypsilanti. It was an unofficial "joke town."
MADRID, March. 26. -- The terms of a new Spanish-Italian, commercial treaty will be published in the Official Gazette within several days, it was learned definitely today.

BOSTON, March 24. -- On Tuesday and Wednesday of the coming week the Democrats of Maine, always hopeful, although seldom successful, will assemble in Portland for a two days' powwow. On Thursday, the last day of the month, the Republicans of the State will assemble for a convention of a single day.

THE centre of interest in the dance shifts this week to Philadelphia, where the Philadelphia Grand Opera Company will bring to production for the first time on Thursday evening a modern Mexican ballet entitled "H.P.," with music by Carlos Chavez, designs by Diego Rivera and scenario by Frances Flynn Paine.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended March 19 were slightly higher than in the preceding week, but lower than a year ago, according to the weekly review of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

More than 1,100 of the 1,700 employes of the Federal Water Service Corporation have become part owners of the largest single block of shares of the company as a result of the plan sponsored by Christopher T. Chenery, president of the company, and worked out in negotiations with bankers over a period of two months.

Mr. CHARLES A. JONAS, Republican National Committeeman for North Carolina, was nominated by Mr. HOOVER to be United States Attorney-for the Western District of that State in February. The Senate did not act on the nomination before March. 4, and Mr. HOOVER gave him an interim appointment.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 26. -- The batting power of the Robins appeared suddenly today, after a mysterious disappearance of several days, and displayed itself in the sixth, seventh and eighth innings, with the highly satisfactory result that Brooklyn won its third victory of the exhibition season against major league opposition, defeating the Braves, 10 to 8.

TO understand these short stories by Sean O'Faolain, three of which are of an unmitigated excellence, one must know something of the turmoil out of which they were born. They are all stories of the Irish rebellion, marked and shaped by the rude matrix of a land in temporary chaos.

Eryant Park is to be graded and entirely re-landscaped as a setting for the reproduction of old Federal Hall which is being erected there in connection with the Washington Bicentennial Celebration, according to an announcement yesterday by Joseph H. Freedlander, architect of the model building and chairman of the plan and scope committee of the city bicentennial committee.

THE language problem at the Geneva disarmament conference has been solved with the aid of a recently installed device which enables delegates to hear translations of speeches at the same time that they are being delivered. As soon as the speaker begins his address, experts translate his words into as many as five different languages, on any one of which each of the delegates may listen in.
CHICAGO, March 26 (AP). -- Musicians of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra today received notices of discharge.
DETROIT, March 26. -- Henry Martyn Leland, pioneer automobile and airplane motor manufacturer, died at 6 A.M. today in Grace Hospital after a month's illness. He was 89 years old.

With every important European currency advancing vigorously against the dollar, it was made plain yesterday that, no matter how confident Wall Street may be that Congress ultimately will produce a tax bill that will balance the budget, actual doubts are entertained abroad.

Factors expected to exert a strengthening influence on general business failed to stimulate activity this month, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents points out in its current report. The buying looked for from railroads has not developed it was explained, while the national campaign against hoarding is without marked effect up to this time.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee, headed by Senator Borah, which is considering the opposition to the appointment by President Hoover of Judge James H. Wilkerson of Chicago to the Circuit Court of Appeals, made it clear today that it would not investigate "any personal or political feuds which seem to obtain in Chicago."

PIRATE gold exists mainly in legend and in fiction, but some genuine treasure turned up recently when a poor Bahama fisherman led the police to a cache on the shore of New Providence Island. Here he had found five bars of gold bullion worth about $60,000 which had been buried beneath a wild plum tree among rocks bearing a sign of Freemasonry.
METROPOLITAN MUREUM -- Newly arranged Egyptian rooms opened last Monday (permanent exhibition). See comment on this page. Also reviewed March 22.

The Yonkers High School basketball team and the East Islip five advanced to the semi-finals in the New York State basketball championship tournament as the result of games played last night in the Manhattan College gymnasium. Yonkers, which won the championship last year, defeated Amityville High, 39 to 24, while East Islip overcame Ardsley, 26 to 22.

Various divisions of the ready-to-wear markets showed, a spurt in activity during the week, with better merchandise for immediate selling in most demand, according to the report, prepared exclusively for THE TIMES, of the Independent Merchandising Bureau, Inc. While coat activity slackened somewhat, dresses, suits and sportswear moved in large volume, the report stated.

Three weeks overdue on a ten-day run up the coast from Charleston, S. C., and with a considerable list to starboard, the three-masted schooner Granville R. Bacon moved into New York harbor early yesterday morning under a tattered main-sail and makeshift jib.

Assistance of the United States Building and Loan League to enable bankers throughout the country to place proper values on real estate is recommended by George A. Martin, president of the Railroad Cooperative Building and Loan Association, the largest institution in the league, to William E. Best, president of the group.
SANTANDER, Spain, March 26 (AP). -- Marquis de Valdecilla, a long-time friend of former King Alfonso and one of the wealthy men of Spain, died today in the village of Valdecilla after a long illness.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 26. -- J. Henry Esser, former Corporation Counsel of Mount Vernon, counsel for the Westchester County commuters in their fight against New York Central Railroad commutation rate increases, declared today that when the commuters got through fighting the railroad's temporary 25 per cent rate increase, effective for five months beginning April 1, they then would have to contest the 40 per cent permanent increase.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- Wheat was liquidated from the start today on the Board of Trade here, the prospective increase of 7,000,000 acres in the Spring wheat area for this year's harvesting leading to general selling, which found support lacking. Bearish ammunition was not lacking, as the stock market was weak and the trade was impressed also with the action of the House in voting down the proposed tax on beer affecting the coarse grains.

OTTAWA, March 24. -- Completion of plans for the establishment of a town of 5,000 people to be called Moosonee, on the southern shore of James Bay where the Hudson Bay Company trading post of Moose Harbor has stood for some scores of years, gives special interest to a report on the possibilities of that region which has been made by officials of the Ontario and Quebec Governments.

A SIDE from the story, which has greater possibilities than the producers have realized, "Hotel Continental," the film Which was at the Roxy, has quite a number of ingenious turns and twists and here and there some bright dialogue.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- More than 200 Communists and 100 police officers battled before the Japanese Embassy at 2,514 Massachusetts Avenue early this afternoon when the Communists staged a demonstration in denunciation of "Japanese imperialism" in Manchuria after they had been refused a permit to parade.

SCHENE. ADY, N.Y., March 26 (AP). -- A demand for a public apology by Harry E. Blodgett, an attorney, for his remarks to a Supreme Court justice yesterday concerning the official acts of Mrs. Izetta Jewel Millor, head of Schenectady's Welfare Buncan, was delivered to Blodgett today by Professor Hugh Miller, husband of the welfare commissioner.

THIS is a dangerous book to put before the general public. The average reader not familiar with the background of the Russian revolutionary movement may be misled by the undocumented and purely legendary pages that fill the first half of this biography of the "legendary Georgian" written by the mysterious Essad-Bey.

FOR years past, the Japanese publicists have taken great pains to convince the world that the control or possession of Manchuria is vital to the existence of Japan. They have appealed on sentimental or historical grounds; they have elaborated its economic necessity, and they have argued on military necessity.

A LUNCHEON in honor of mural painters has been arranged by the Membership Extension Committee of the Art Centre. It will be given next Saturday at 12:30. Hildreth Melere and Eugene Savage will speak on "Architecture from the Mural Painter's Point of View" and James Helium Smith and Eric Gugler will speak on "Mural Painting from the Architect's Point of View."

The Sino-Japanese situation presents a picture of a contest of Oriental and Occidental diplomacy. On the one hand there is Japan trying to convince the Western powers that things are not what they may seem to be. On the other hand there is China trying to profit by the ingerence of Occidental diplomacy, while, at the same time, her diplomats and Generals are working their own plans on the side.

WAGNER'S firmest friend, perhaps the only one with whom he never had a serious break and who remained attached to him for thirty-six years, was Dr. Anton Pusinelli of Dresden. They met in 1842, soon after Wagner took up the post of conductor at the Dresden opera, and were friends till Pusinelli's death in 1878.

With all securities of the Kreuger Toll group toppling yesterday to new low records on the New York Stock Exchange, further reports were heard with respect to the fruitless attempts of Ivar Kreuger in the weeks preceding his suicide to bolster the market prices of securities and to obtain funds necessary for the furthering of his enterprises.

IN the land of El Dorado we visited the Kagaba and Goajiro Indians to find out what light they could shed on the Tairona Indians, who disappeared mysteriously some 400 years ago after barring the Spaniards' way into their legendary land of gold.

BERLIN, March 12, 1932. DIE BUERGSCHAFT" ("The Pledge"), Kurt Weill's new three act opera which the Stadtische Oper produced in altogether exemplary fashion on March 10, is what the Germans call a "Tendenzstuck."

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- John N. Garner, Speaker of the House of Representatives, was bluntly told by some of his most important chairmen today that his course next week toward the tax bill would either complete the chaos in the House or make it a responsible legislative body once more.

Mrs. Annie M. Cassidy Sadlier, widow of William H. Sadlier, died on Friday at her Winter home in Lakewood, N.J., at the age of 80. She had been president of the textbook publishing firm of William H. Sadlier. Inc., since her husband's death in 1877.

Stocks and bonds were generally weak on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday as the volume of trading increased almost to the total reached on last Thursday, the last preceding full day of trading. Foreign bonds were quiet.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 26 (AP). -- George Taylor Plowman etcher and author, died at his home here today. He was 62 years old.

WILKES -- BARRE, Pa., March 26. -- The second week of the outlaw mine strike to bring about equalization of work in the anthracite fields ended violently here today when eight miners were injured and twelve automobiles smashed in an outbreak at Exeter, a suburb.

PORTLAND, Me., March 26 (AP). -- Maine conventions of both Democratic and Republican, parties here next week will start in earnest the campaigns of five men in each party for the two Gubernatorial nominations.
An onslaught of foreign selling, based on the failure of Congress to agree upon tax legislation for balancing the budget, precipitated yesterday the worst break in the dollar since last Autumn.

HERE comes the bride!" It is her season. Easter gives the signal that rings up the curtain on Spring weddings. And pretty affairs they are going to be, judging from the displays of brides' and bridesmaids' gowns that nave been in preparation for the past weeks.

MEMEL, March 10. -- Were it not for the fact that an internally disturbed and preternaturally touchy neighboring power has recently got somewhat excited about it, the quarrel here over Memel's autonomy and its "Germanism" would resemble in many ways a small-town feud. For the Memel Territory, as it is officially called, is not very big.

TEMPLE bells of pagodas seemed louder than passing street cars as Sven Hedin sat in his hotel room speaking of the tragic mystery of the East while I, with portfolio propped against a modernistic chair, drew his picture. Rain beat a mocking tattoo against the windows as a successor to Marco Polo recited his struggle against thirst in the desert of Takla Makan.
TOKYO, March 26. -- Talk of Japan's quitting the League of Nations must now be taken seriously.
The Columbia rowing squad will take up quarters tomorrow in the Manor House at Baker Field, an annual indication that the opening of the Lion's campaign is near.

The outcome of instruction in beginning reading is of utmost educational and personal significance. It is of educational importance for the reason that the typical curriculum, utilizes reading as a basal tool in most subjects, and hence those who fail in reading are incapable of advancing in other subjects.

NEGOTIATIONS now in progress between Japan and China for the withdrawal of Japanese troops from Shanghai should bring to an end the "war" in which these two governments have been engaged since Sept. 18. To millions of people in every country the fighting between these two great nations has come as a profound shock.
CHICAGO, March 26 (AP). -- The fertile wits of gangland may not be earning much money these days, what with Alphonse Capone in jail, but they go right on making language.

PARIS, March 25. -- His friends who were with him during his last days have been recounting several of Aristide Briand's sayings during those short weeks between the time he was compelled to resign the office he loved and his death. During that time, they say, no one ever heard him utter the slightest complaint against the treatment he had received at the hands of his countrymen.

VIENNA, March 24. -- With the declarations of policy by the Czechoslovak, Hungarian and Yugoslav Foreign Ministers yesterday, the Tardieu plan for a Central European preferential bloc began to assume an actuality it hitherto had lacked as regards the five Danubian countries most immediately concerned.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Automobile production in the United States in February declined to 117,413 units, according to figures issued by the Department of Commerce. This was 1,931 below the January mark.

CALENDAR reform is one of a the subjects with which the League of Nations concerns itself, and calendar reform, is possible only if the date of Easter is stabilized. Hence the Council of the League has sent out a circular letter asking for an expression of opinion on the advisability of having movable festivals fall on fixed dates.

EUGENE GOOSSENS, who has just been announced as one of the conductors for the concerts to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House by the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra, stated that the plan for giving work to 200 unemployed instrumentalists was an admirable one and should receive the fullest public support.

LONDON. TIME and taxes have impoverished the aristocracy so seriously that its future has become a question. Its disintegration seems to be part of a great silent revolution which is working itself out all over England.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 26 (AP). -- Congress will meet again as a legislative body on Monday after eighteen months of de facto government in which were held only two brief sessions to ratify elections. It will turn immediately to financial problems.
OTTAWA, Ont., March 26 (Canadian Press). -- The present value of the Canadian dollar in New York is causing no anxiety fn Parliamentary circles.

Louis E. Stoddard, chairman of the United Slates Polo Association, discussing the game with enthusiasts in California not long ago revealed that he does not expect Great Britain to challenge for the Westchester Cup next year. He looks for another series for the championship of the Americas between Argentina and the United States to replace the Westchester Cup competition.

While the big feature in the real estate world last week was centred in the efforts being made by leading realty and civic organizations to work out a proper economic program for the city to follow directed toward relief of the steadily mounting tax burden, there were, on the actual trading side, evidences of steadily increasing interest in good suburban properties.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The State Department today asserted that Liberia must end slavery and improve sanitary conditions before the United States will extend recognition, but denied the United States Government would engage in an active effort to oust President Edwin Barclay.

Through New York? MAYBE it will again, be necessary at this time next year to remark upon the waste and confusion caused by the absence of markers Indicating motor routes through New York City -- but maybe not.
LONDON, March 26. -- Sterling shot up again today in consequence of heavy Continental buying. Starting at 53.71 1/4 the rate jumped quickly to $3.76 1/2, finally reacting slightly to $3.75 3/4.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- President Hoover has had no part, directly or indirectly, in the movement to pigeon-hole the Glass banking bill, it was stated at the White House today on behalf of the President because of reports in some newspapers that he had intervened to bring about the postponement of action on the bill.

HOW President Hindenburg of Germany spends his day is indicated by bits of letters, conversations and anecdotes lately gathered from his associates. Altogether these new items of memorabilia sharpen the already familiar outlines of the character of this imposing leader, now known by his people after his labors in war and peace as the "Alte Herr."

THE name of Allan Ramsay brings to mind many pleasant anecdotes and legends of this once popular Scots poet. No one who has heard it likes to forget the tradition that the Edinburgh housewives of the eighteenth century would send their children out to buy his latest piece to be read over their dish of tea.

DECORATION of many kinds but especially of walls, has been growing apace -- so rapidly, indeed, that the anuated expression "by leaps and minds" might have been created to the present situation. And the present situation is compounded of any side issues which now and then rust themselves into the main Issue.

GREAT cities are the natural playground at great personalities. New York has been very fortunate in that for a full century and a half its social, its intellectual and its public life have been marked by an exceptionally striking aeries of personalities Each one of these men made marked impression upon hta conteoaporaries and each one of them played a large part in the life of the years through which he lived.

SANTA FE, N.M., March 26 (AP). -- A resolution to instruct the New Mexico delegation to the Republican National Convention for President Hoover was defeated by the Resolutions Committee of the New Mexico Republican State Convention tonight by a vote, of twenty-four to three.

To the Art Editor: AS you seem to be an enthusiastic exponent of the present interest in mural painting, may draw your attention to an exhibition of work by the Mural Atelier of the Beaux Arts Institute of Design, which has been running now for two years (the class, not the exhibition) and which is conducted on very novel lines.

The first twenty-five railroads to report for February had net operating incomes of $8,474,000 in the month, against 512,614,000 in February. 1931, a drop of 32.8 per cent, and against $23.997,000 in February, 1930. a fall of 64.6 per cent.

The demand for free service at Beekman. Street Hospital has doubled in some departments and trebled in others in the five-year period from 1926 to 1931, according to figures made public yesterday by the management of that institution. The number of outpatient cases cared for increased from 29,756 in 1926 to 40,608 in 1931.

Clarence H. Mackay, head of the Postal Telegraph Company, is suffering from a slight concussion of the brain at his residence, 3 East Seventy-fifth Street, where he has been confined since March 8 with a severe attack of intestinal influenza, it was learned last night from Dr. Foster Kennedy, the noted brain specialist.

BAYARD, Fla. March. -- J.I. John on a Chatford, several times second but never a winner during a specious Florida campaign, broke bis lossing stock by capturing the Chalrs Pumison Memorial Handicap, feauter at St. John's Park today.

EASTER trade suddenly bounded forward midway in the week and the stores reported brisk sales in both apparel and accessories. The latter had been fairly active in recent weeks but garment volume had lagged. A slight trend toward better quality goods was also distinguished. Children's wear business has been good and is expected to increase over the holiday vacation period.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 26 (AP). -- Foreign oil companies are preparing for any eventualities, should the government give its final approval of the petroleum monopoly bill in Congress, which would exclude private business from Chile and put the oil and gasoline business in the hands of the State.

KANSAS CITY, March 26. -- An English landlord has cased the burden of 260 tenant farmers on the 45,000-acre Scully estate in Bates County, Southwest Missouri -- they were advised this week that all rents would be reduced an average of 50 cents an acre.
RENO, Nev., March 26. -- Mrs. Helen Lownes Spellman of New York obtained a divorce here today from Howard Hilton Spellman. Cruelty was alleged.

PARIS. EASTER once past, the Paris season gets under way with surprising rapidity. The Ritz and other social centres attract the smartest affairs in international society; there every night one has occasion to judge the effect of the new formal evening fashions as they are and should be worp.

Chief Judge Cuthbert W. Pound of the Court of Appeals will preside at the regional finals of the National Oratorical Contest at Town Hall May 13, when eight speakers, representing an initial participation of 357 schools, will compete for the regional championship.

LONDON, March 8. SINCE he gave "Journey's End" to the theatre at a time when others were rejecting it because there was no woman in the cast, Maurice Browne has proved himself to be a manager with courage to make what many have considered rash experiments and to back his own opinion.

Taxing Public Officials. Because I have had eight years of public office, I have a vivid impression of a fertile source of federal income tax. I am referring to the fact that State county and municipal officials in the United States are exempt from payment of income tax.

WITH siren screaming, an open-bodied truck dashes down a Berlin street at night. A searchlight is mounted behind the driver's seat and behind, in the body of the truck, sit four rows of men in blue uniforms.

Something has certainly happened to the National Academy of Design since its last exhibition, in November. The 107th annual show, which will be opened to the public today, is by all odds the best acadetny performance this reviewer has seen. The "difference" must have struck all those who attended the traditional "varnishing day" reception yesterday afternoon in the gaileries of the American Fine Arts Building.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The pocketbook appeal is keeping House galleries crowded these days with citizens eager to grasp at any crumb of the tax debate. One touch of taxes has made the whole nation kin.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On all sides one hears the question, What is America coming to? It is a question that concerns us all, it fills the minds of thoughtful men with foreboding, convinced our civilization, or what remains of it, is being submitted to a strain it is not equipped to hear.

WHO likes to sup on horrors can have his fill of gruesome tales in this book. For it is written by a man who has rather specialized in that grim category of letters and has to his credit half a dozen or more volumes brim full of awesome tales of murder and ghosts, and mysteries and hair-raising terrors of many kinds.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. RKO-RADIO and Paramount took the centre of the cinema stage this week with production activities or announcements that were gratifying to stockholders as well as Hollywood's unemployed.

THE recent discovery of a Viking cache of gems on the Swedish island of Gothland, in the Baltic Sea, directs attention to other relics dug up during the present century that appear to trace the activities of these sea wanderers of a thousand years ago.

LONDON. SYNCHRONIZED pictures of European Inspiration and production are having in London just now a noteworthy value. It is not by their quantity but by their quality that they have attracted public attention.
In the face of lowering skies and a bare possibility of rain the residents of New York and its environs prepared yesterday to celebrate Easter Sunday in the manner to which they are accustomed.

THE age-old conflict between force and law has entered into a new phase in our generation. The human elements that determine power are exactly as they always have been, variable, emotional and easily swayed by self-interest cloaked in specious phrases.

PALM SPRINGS, Cal., March 26 (AP) -- Said by his physician to have experienced a "reaction" in the illness that brought, him here, Samuel Untermyer, noted attorney, left suddenly tonight for his home in New York.

Harold Parsons scored the decisive goal which gave the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club trio a 10-to-9 victory over Los Nanduces in a Class B exhibition match at the Squadron C Armory is Brooklyn last night.
CHICAGO, March 26 (AP). -- With one alleged confidence man in custody, police tonight sought other victims of the confidence game of "smuggled diamonds."

Bernon S. Prentice, chairman of the United States Davis Cup Committee, will also head the selection committee which will chooze the team to represent this country in the 1932 matches for the international tennis trophy.

SINGE 1883, at least -- which was the year our present New York society was born with the Vanderbilt ball and the beginning of the Metropolitan Opera -- the fashion parade along Fifth Avenue of an Easter Sunday has been assumed to be an annual fixture In the local calendar of gala events.
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Leo P. Hogan of East Orange, N.J., Vice Consul at Buenos Aires, has been assigned as Vice Consul at Montevidio.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES article "Why Latin Is Useful to Moderns" contains the following statement: "It has teen estimated that there are more words in the English language today that owe their existence to the Latin tongue than any other language with the possible exception of Anglo-Saxon."

TO one who was harrowed distantly in Europe by despairing cries from American shores about theatrical hard times and who listened sympathetically to variations on the same theme in numerous Continental cities it was refreshing to visit Prague, recently and to be told that so far as the Czechoslovak capital is concerned "theatre crisis" is quite literally a foreign phrase.

FEW periods in the world's history have been as rich in splendid personalities as the Victorian. Its close marked the coming of a great change, the beginning of an era of skepticism so profound, so all-pervading, that the skepticism of the Victorians seems by comparison the deepest faith.

THE parenthesis of Rumanian music served to reveal to auditors of the season at the Augusteo in Rome this Winter another symphonic school of recent formation in the process of seeking, though not actually evolving, an indiciduality of its own.

MADRID, March 26. -- Mgr. Tito Crespi, auditor of the nunciature, stated today that "the crowds attending Holy Week services everywhere and the absence of disturbances have been a great source of satisfaction." Mgr. Crespi is in charge of the Vatican's affairs in Spain during the absence of the Papal Nuncio, Mgr. Tedeschini, who is worn out by his arduous labors and is resting for two weeks at the Monastery of Sagrada Familia in Hortaleza.
