WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Deploring what was termed the failure of scholars and the public to understand the Oriental viewpoint, particularly during the Sino-Japanese crisis, the American Gouncil of Learned Societies tonight announced a six weeks seminar on Far Eastern studies this Summer in connection with the Harvard Summer School.

Sterling performances were achieved by Clarence (Buster) Crabbe and Curtis Cummings of the Los Angeles A.C. swimming team, here to face the New York A.C. squad tomorrow in a dual meet, at a water carnival in the 75-foot pool of the Downtown A.C. yesterday.

Interest on yesterday's brief weekend market was divided between the irregular decline on the Stock Exchange, presumably in response to the Congressional tangle over the Federal budget, and the renewed and somewhat violent advance in sterling. The fact that other foreign exchange rates also moved against New York led to the inference that the situation at Washington was reflected in that market also.

Three historic portraits and several other treasured art objects relating to the early history of the Methodist Episcopal Church in this country and abroad have been acquired recently by the Old John Street Methodist Church, "the Mother Church of American Methodism."

BERLIN, March 12. WHATEVER just complaints therE may be against this most theatrically untheatrical of seasons, Ladislaus Fodor has no reason to kick. Three of his plays have been produced in Berlin within the last four months, and I understand a fourth is in the offing.

INVARIABLY at this season the missionary spirit rises within us and the temptation to buttonhole representatives of the various companies to tell them something about their business becomes particularly strong. For, despite the fact that the Metropolitan Opera Company's Good Friday matinee "Parsifal" is an established occasion, it seems that the annual announcement regularly comes as a surprise to many, and habitually a portion of the backwash reaches this department.

THE publishing house of Jonathan Cape Harrison Smith, Inc., announces that it is changing its name to Jonathan Cape Robert Ballou. Inc., with Jonathan Cape as president. Robert Ballou as vice president and general manager and Charles A. Ackerman as secretary.

HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- As the annual yachting week in Bermuda -- the third week in April -- draws near the promise of a fine series of races grows brighter. There will be two classes, an international series between the Bermuda and American six-meter yachts and a team series in which four Bermuda one - design yachts will compete against four Long Island inter-clubs.

MILWAUKEE, March 26. -- A movement to put the city of Milwaukee in the banking business was Started today. Sponsors of the plan envision thrifty citizens carrying their savings to the City Hall, giving their pennies and dollars to a municipal teller and having their deposits noted in a city bank book.

A SING SING graduate named Casey was a tough man in San Francisco. He organized the hoodlums into a formidable gang, established political control of the city by degrees, amassed a fortune by judicious graft and turned his hand to a bit of murder when it pleased him.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, March 27 (AP). -- Japanese Army authorities have tempered their "minimum" armistice demands, it was learned today, reviving hope for a successful outcome of the truce negotiations which have been dragging along here for many days.

Sponsors of the plan envision thrifty citizens carrying their savings to the City Hall, giving their pennies and dollars to a municipal teller and having their deposits noted in a city bank book.

A SING SING graduate named Casey was a tough man in San Francisco. He organized the hoodlums into a formidable gang, established political control of the city by degrees, amassed a fortune by judicious graft and turned his hand to a bit of murder when it pleased him.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., March 27 -- Gloucester is alive with industry today and employment for 1,000 men is in prospect as half a hundred schooners complete their preparations for the Spring mackerel fishing, which bids fair to be the best in years this season.

While the resurrection is difficult to comprehend, it is more difficult to overlook, the Rev. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Madison Avenue Methodist Church, declared yesterday morning. He was the chief speaker at the Easter dawn services held under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches in front of the library of Columbia University.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Traders here find the world's grain markets uncertain, and they attribute this condition to government officials who have made many statements which, they say, are so conflicting that speculators and grain handlers do not know which way to turn.

Samuel Seabury made thirteen recommendations for reform, in the Magistrates' Courts as a result of the investigation he conducted by order of the Appellate Division. A summary of the reforms advocated follows:...

PINEVILLE, Ky., March 27 (AP) -- Four more Eastern students reported last night as missing, two of them women, were escorted from Pineville today after being lectured by County Attorney Smith. The students were Mrs. Eleanor Curtis Henderson of Columbia University, Miss Margaret Bailey of New York University, Willard Spence of the Union Theological Seminary of New York and Herbert Ellis of Harvard.

HORACE PLUNKET was a great Irish, prophet without honor in his own country. At least, he was without adequate and deserved honor. The chief reason for this was that he stood apart from the fierce political contests in Ireland. His main work lay "above the melee."

PEIPING, March 27 -- Following prolonged concentration of political attention upon the Manchurian and Shanghai affairs, interest again is swinging toward the perennial internal situation of China as a result of General Feng Yu-hsiang's trip to Northern Shantung.

ROME, March 27 (AP) -- America was told tonight by Cardinal Cerretti, proprietor or several religious organizations there, that the United States is "called by Providence" to play the chief part in a return to world prosperity.

The strongest amateur boxing team ever to represent New York in an intercity tournament will enter the ring in Madison Square Garden tonight primed for the attempt to repulse the invasion of a dangerous Chicago squad in the fifth annual intercity Golden Gloves competition under the direction of the Daily News A.A.A crowd of 20,000 is expected to jam the Garden for the occasion.

The performance of "Riddle Me This." on the night of April 4 at the John Golden Theatre has been taken over in the interests of the philanthropic work of the Catholic Centre for the Blind. The proceeds will be devoted to the Centre at 221 East Seventy-ninth Street, which provides a shelter for young blind girls, most of whom are employed at the Lighthouse, a workshop for the blind.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Nobody much except the veteran himself was ever interested in seeing the veteran receive any bonus at all, to say nothing as to how much and when paid.

BOSTON, Mass., March 27 -- Cardinal O'Connell, foe of crooners and jazz on the air, was the innocent victim today of a mistake in a Rome broadcasting station, whereby he unintentionally introduced a dance program to a huge audience of radio listeners all over the country.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 27 -- A total of 526 students of Princeton University received high scholastic honors during the first term of the current academic year according to the annual list of scholastic rankings announced here today. The senior class received the largest number of high honor awards, 178.

It is not all the time a state of war between science and the rooted habits of mankind. With surprising and gratifying frequency scientific research comes to the defense of common behavior. The spirit of free inquiry is not always slaying ancient superstitions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Leaping to a conclusion, this column March 14 seems to demand a gospel of verification of the genuine howler reported from London, where the hasty youth in the fourth form, wrote: "Leap year is called a bisexual year because women are obliged to propose to men on the extra day in February."

A demand for greater unity among Zionist fund-raising bodies was expressed by the New York Zionist Region yesterday in a resolution unanimously adopted at the fourth annual convention of the organization at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Problems of administration were discussed for the greater part of the seven-hour session, which concluded with Carl Sherman, former Attorney General, succeeding Louis Lipsky, former head of the Zionist Organization of America, as regional chairman.

The fact that there were thousands in churches yesterday who had not attended a service for a year and would not again until next Easter, was not the fault of the people but the fault of the churches, the Rev. Dr. Allen Knight Chalmers declared yesterday morning in his sermon before 2,500 at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.

HANKOW, March 27 -- The long conflict for control of Hupeh Province ends with the "home rule" faction in complete ascendancy with seven portfolios, while only one Nan-king man is included in the government. He received the Finance Ministry, an undesirable position, since the province faces a huge deficit.

A more optimistic outlook toward prospects in the building trades in the near future was expressed by millwork manufacturers from fifteen Eastern seaboard and adjacent States following their discussions at a convention in this city last week, according to Alien E. Beala in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

The plight of millions of Jews in Europe is desperate, and their fate depends on continued financial aid from Jews in this country, according to speakers yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Council of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

DETROIT, March 27 -- The Montreal Maroons and the Detroit Falcons fought a 1-1 tie tonight in the first game of their third-place National Hockey League playoff. A crowd of 12,216 spectators saw the grueling match.

J.H. Wantling and S.B. Masten tied for the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. Each finished the regular shoot with a score of 97 out of a possible 100 targets. The shoot-off was taken by Wantling, 24-23.
The tide of Easter vacationists that began pouring out of the city early last week reached its ebb yesterday afternoon. By nightfall, countless thousands of New Yorkers were hurrying back home.
NEW ORLEANS, March 27 (AP) -- A new "lingering" anesthetic, which continues to kill pain after an operation but has no habit-forming power, was reported to the American Chemical Society tonight.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Monday, March 28 (AP) -- About 3,000 Chinese irregulars under General Tsinghai, who recently rebelled against the new Manchurian State, were reported today to be within two miles of Nungan, thirty-five miles north of this city.

"Irene," opening tonight at the Shubert Theatre, Newark, as the first of a series of revivals by Milton Aborn's Civic Musical Comedy Company, will be seen at the Majestic Theatre, Boston, for two weeks, beginning next Monday, and at the Forrest or Chestnut Theatre.

BOSTON, March 27 -- Eddie Farrell, coach of the Harvard track team, today advocated the selection of America's leading athletes for places on the Olympic team without requiring them to go through the tryouts.

The annual bridge party in aid of the New York Diet Kitchen Association will take place on the afternoon of April 5 in the small ballroom of the Plaza. A feature will be a fashion show. Later in the afternoon tea will be served.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, March 27 -- The first shipment of fresh-caught halibut to the Middle States left here tonight. It is expected to open up a new market and help relieve congestion in Boston and New York.

SHANGHAI, March 27 -- Now that the League of Nations's inquiry commission has left Shanghai for Nan-king and as the Sino -- Japanese armistice negotiators are not meeting on Sunday, today has been largely devoted by Chinese leaders and foreign diplomatic observers to surveying China's internal condition.
TAMPA, Fla., March 27 -- The Robins closed their exhibition season in the Florida training region today by losing to the Cincinnati Reds, 7 to 6, before a gathering of 2,150.

A new contact has been made with the kidnappers of the infant son of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh and negotiations for the child's return are in the "semi-final" stage, John H. Curtis, wealthy Norfolk boat builder, said yesterday upon his return from a mysterious overnight journey.

The question whether Easter's observance was of any use to "our topsy-turvy civilization" was raised by the Rev. Dr. George Maychin Stockdale in his Easter sermon yesterday at St. James's Methodist Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and 126th Street. He had this to say:

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Legislation to enforce the laws against kidnapping and other crimes through cooperation of the States will be pressed in the House after the tax bill is out of the way. A bill to accomplish this was introduced by Representative Hatton W. Sumners, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, a few days after the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby.
LONDON, March 27 -- The first successful flight in history with a wingless flying machine has been made by Juan de la Cierva, inventor of the autogiro, according to The Sunday Express.

A protest against any further delay in reporting the World Court protocols to the floor of the Senate has been sent to Chairman Borah and the other Republican members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee by the National Committee of Republican Women, for the World Court, it was announced yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, March 24 -- Quite aside from the maintenance of gold payments on the existing basis by France and the United States, continuance of gold payments in such countries as Holland and Switzerland is now considered assured. There is still more or less talk of something unexpected possibly happening, such as a new diversion of capital or an outbreak of distrust.
NEW YORK. Sir Josiah and Lady Stamp of London are arriving on the Majestic and will be at the Barclay.

CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -- Samuel Insull said in a statement issued to- night that 1932 financing for three big utility operating companies that serve Chicago and vicinity would put no strain upon any of the companies. The corporations are the Commonwealth Edison Company, the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois.
NANKING, March 27 (AP) -- China's capital turned out today in holiday fashion to welcome the League of Nations commission sent to inquire into the dispute between China and Japan.

More than 4,000 persons, including several hundred standees, attended Easter services at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday morning, when the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of Nev York, occupied the pulpit.

DETROIT, Mich., March 27 -- A change in policy, which will place increased emphasis upon the question of world peace, national legislation and vocational guidance, forms the nucleus of discussion for the fortieth anniversary convention of the National Council of Jewish Women which opened its five-day session here tonight at the Temple Beth El.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Banking conditions continued to improve the first three weeks of March, following substantial gains in February, but the volume of industrial production and factory employment failed to reflect this progress, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its monthly review of the business and financial situation.

Many reservations have been made for the dinner dance which will be given by members of the Almoners tonight in the ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital. There will be an entertainment later in the evening. Among those who will take part are the Misses Jane Degnon.

MOSCOW, Marcb 27 -- The Central Committee of the Communist party issued an edict today prohibiting the "enforced socialization of cattle," which it declared had occurred in a number of regions, "thus infringing in the most brutal manner the repeated instructions of the Central Committee."

The drive of the Block Community Organization to "stamp out want" in the city, described as "the greatest peace time organization ever assembled," will begin this morning in the more than 6,000 blocks of the city already organized.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 27 -- Mr. and Mrs. Gurnee Munn entertained today with a luncheon at Louwana, preceded by a swimming contest in their pool in which their children. Miss Fernanda and Gurnee Jr., and Miss Lillian and Quentin F. Feitner Jr., Betty and John Ordway and Alice Wyeth and Charles A. Munn Jr. participated.

ROME, March, 27 -- More precious objects have come to light in the "house of Menander" at Pompeii where unusually valuable treasures were found eighteen months ago. Three gold rings, one silver ring and two gold bracelets have been found on three skeletons that were in a position that indicated the persons had been fleeing from, the volcanic catastrophe of 79 A.D.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Pathfinder, a national weekly published here, announced tonight that President Hoover had received 115,042 ballots in a straw vote which it has taken in an effort to determine the sentiment as to all Presidential candidates.

Circuses must have elephants; the show is built around them, and since the days of Heckaliah, Bailey's "Old Bet," who made something of a habit of falling into ditches and refusing to come out until she had several drinks of whisky, no big tent show in America has been without them, Earl Chapin May writes in "The Circus -- From Rome to Ringling."

Despite a wan sun and chilly winds, which forced most of the participants to don heavy coats over their new costumes, many thousands of New Yorkers staged their annual parade along Fifth Avenue and its adjacent thoroughfares after the Easter church services yesterday morning.

John McCormack, noted tenor, will contribute his services as soloist at the second concert, that on April 12, in the series of five Tuesday evening performances to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House by the Musicians Symphony Orchestra, composed of unemployed instrumentalists.

The present financial difficulties of the Metropolitan Opera are, of course, but part of the troubles in which the whole country finds itself. One of the most luxurious of entertainments could not, in the nature of things, expect to be exempt from the universal stringency.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The spectacle of many exhausted and ill members of the hard-working House still carrying on has caused Dr. George W. Calver, attending Capitol physician, to issue a warning to slow down to avoid danger.

One of the largest Easter congregations in the history of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, filled every available pew, chair or other place to sit within the church yesterday morning. It was estimated that more than 2,000 persons attended the 11 o'clock communion service and hundreds were turned away.

WILDWOOD, N.J., March 27 -- Clarence (Spike) Fisher, local golfer, successfully defended his Eastern States golf championship, today, with a 2-up victory over Tom Wootton, Country Club of Atlantic City, in the final round at the Wildwood Club.

BERLIN, March 26 -- Business circles showed in the past week some signs of nervousness, the causes for which were partly political and part- ly economic. As against the certain- ty of Hindenburg's re-election on April 10, there was much talk of increased activity in the revolutionary wing of the Hitlerite party.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 (AP) -- Sterling young athletes were limber- ing up. The start of the quarter-mile wag five minutes off. A telephone at the side of the field jangled. The call was for Ben Eastman of Stanford University, competing against the Los Angeles Athletic Club Saturday.

A decrease of 36,375,314, or 8.63 per cent, in the number of commuters and other passengers entering and leaving the city by railroad and ferry in 1931 is shown in the annual report of the Suburban Transit Engineering Board, made public yesterday by the Port Authority.

With thirteen recommendations for reform, including such sweeping ones as consolidation of three inferior courts and removal from the Mayor of the power to appoint judges, Samuel Seabury yesterday made a final report of more than 70,000 words an the magistrates' courts investigation which was authorized by the Appellate Division at the instance of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Easter week generally offers thronged art calendar, and this year it promises to be more lively than usual. The first of the outstanding events became current yesterday, with the public opening of the National Academy's 107th annual exhibition in the American Fine Arts Building.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- President and Mrs. Hoover braved a light rainfall to attend the special sunrise service today in the amphitheatre of Arlington National Cemetery under the auspices of the Knights Templar of the District of Columbia.

Supporters of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt and former Governor Alfred E. Smith will clash on Tuesday, when Democratic State conventions to elect delegates to the national convention will be held in Iowa and Maine, and the Roosevelt adherents will attempt to get instructions for their candidate.

GENEVA, March 27 -- The reports from Tokyo that the Japanese Government is planning to withdraw from the League of Nations if it deals with Manchuria, under Article 15 of the Covenant leave League officials unperturbed. They doubt these reports, even if officially inspired, will be confirmed by action for the same three reasons that made the same officials take lightly Tokyo's previous threats of withdrawal.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 27 (AP) -- The two groups of Eastern college students, excluded from the Southeastern Kentucky coal mining area, left here today for Nashville, Tenn., and Frankfort, Ky., to protest to the Governors of Tennessee and Kentucky against the alleged treatment they received from the authorities of both States.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 27 -- True to tradition, the Boardwalk Easter parade overcame the handicaps of showers and depression and presented all the color, Spring styles and crowds of its predecessors.

A strong protest against the position on "mixed marriages" of the Catholic Church, which holds that children of the marriage of a Catholic and non-Catholic must be reared in the Catholic faith, was made public yesterday by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, which represents the majority of the Protestant communions.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick discussed "The Temporal and the Eternal" in his Easter Sunday sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street. He declared that "petty and merely egoistic conceptions of immortality are incredible to the intelligent."

Singing the "old favorite" songs that were new When America was a young nation and when pioneers intoned in quaint melodies their hopes and achievements in a Western wilderness, the American stars of the Metropolitan aroused a rainy Sunday night house at the opera concert last evening to unwonted enthusiasm, mingled with sighs of nostalgia for the good old times of long ago.

How To Balance a Budget. Germany faces many difficulties which do not trouble the United States. Her gold reserve is low, her middle class impoverished, her central government burdened with an expensive system of benefits for unemployment.

A department of harbor cleaning, administered by New York and New Jersey, is proposed by Captain WHITE, U.S.N. But there is the Tri-State Treaty Commission to be considered. Captain WHITE, who is Supervisor of New York Harbor, has among his duties that of employing eight patrol boats to watch for and report pollution of the harbor waters by ships.

Philip J. Wickser, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, announced yesterday the expansion of the work of the administration through the formation of a State-wide advisory council, organized at a meeting in this city, at which Mrs. August Belmont presided.

Efforts by Samuel Seabury to cause State Senator John A. Hastings of Brooklyn to be punished for contempt of the Hofstadter legislative committee are to begin today when the committee reassembles for public hearings.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Legislative and Cabinet circles have been so engrossed with the fate of the tax bill in Congress that it is just beginning to dawn upon them that, for the second time in his administration, President Hoover has disregarded the judicial barrier between the government and the Interstate Commerce Commission.

A match which fell from his fingers as he was attempting to light a cigar last Saturday afternoon cost the life of Dr. Stephen Smith Burt, 81-year-old Professor Emeritus of Medicine and Physical Diagnosis at the PostGraduate Medical School and Hospital.

Until the threats of unsound tax legislation and possible drastic revision of the Federal Reserve act are stopped there is certain to be further hesitation in economic rerovery, says the current Guaranty Survey, published by the Guaranty Trust Company.

PITTSBURGH, March 27 -- Production of steel ingots last week was between 24 and 25 per cent of capacity, representing a loss of between 1 and 2 points from early March. Decreases in demand, though small individually, were widespread. Pittsburgh's output was off a couple of points, while Chicago's showed no change.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Contending that speeding up work on public buildings will help restore prosperity, Senator Wagner, Democrat, of New York, announced today that he will offer an amendment to the treasury and postoffice appropriation bill tomorrow authorizing an appropriation of $21,275,000 for the erection of 106 Federal buildings in New York State.

The evolution of Fascist economic practice and theory in Italy from 1926 until 1930 is analyzed by Shepard B. Clough, instructor in history at Columbia University and coauthor of "Making Fascists," in the new quarterly issue of the Harvard Business Review, to be published April 1 by the McGraw-Hill Book Company for the Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration.

The Irish Rugby Club defeated the New York Rugby Club, 3-0, yesterday at Knab's Park, Whitestone, L.I., in the opening game of the season for both teams, the only score of the game coming shortly after the middle of the second half on a 30-yard penalty kick by Taylor, Irish right wing.
The New York Rangers went into the lead in the first place play-off for the National Hockey League championship by defeating the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If by their fruits you shall know them, then our method of dealing with the criminal is the worst by far to be found in the world today. But to hear Mr. Lewisohn talk of the "modern idea" in treating the criminal and the twentieth century prison policy one would almost think that we have made some advance.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Donald Henderson, a Columbia University instructor and president of the National College Committee of the National Students League, sought in Washington today intercession by Congressmen for the Eastern students barred from surveying Kentucky coal mining conditions.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- The Soviet army organ, The Red Star prints on its front page today an editorial entitled "War in the Far East and Japanese-American Contradictions" which contains several interesting points.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., March 27 (AP) -- A band, breaking the silence of old Salem in the hour before dawn with chorales, proclaimed the resurrection today.
The styles of the Bowery paraded with the fashions of the well-to-do in the Easter parade yesterday.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 27 -- Sylvio Coucci of New York City, who led the riders in the long meeting at the Agua Caliente track which began last Thanksgiving and ended today, and two other jockeys scored doubles on the final day of the racing.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Steers obtainable at the low prices of last week were, of fair to good quality. Prices ranged from $5 to $6.25 a hundredweight. No choice steers or yearlings were on the market at the close. Steers of quality were 25 cents off, while the general run were virtually unchanged for the week.
GREENWICH, Conn., March 27. -- Clad in strikingly original Easter costumes, the dinghy sailors of the Frostbite Yacht Club engaged today in their second-day regatta at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

Net income of the Philadelphia Electric Company for 1931 amounted to $21,978,224 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal, after $993,033 subsidiary-company dividends, to $20,985,191, or $76.52 a share on 274,263 shares of $5-dividend preferred stock outstanding at the end of the year, compared with $21,541,278 in 1930, equal, after subsidiary dividends of $1,004,929, to $20,537,349, or $164.22 a share earned on 125,058 preferred shares the year before.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 27 -- Less than a week after more than 300 persons were killed in Alabama by a series of tornadoes, at least nine persons lost their lives and fifty were injured this afternoon when the State was again swept by tornadoes and high winds.

Leaders in the world's amateur 18.2 balkline billiard championship in progress at the New York Elks Club will face a stern schedule today which gives promise of breaking the four-cornered deadlock for first place.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 27 -- A fanfare borrowed from Hollywood and Broadway and the attendance of prominent persons are scheduled as features of the opening tomorrow night at the Montclair Theatre of the first of a series of plays to be presented by William Faversham.

LONDON, March 25 -- In the rubber market plantation grades were quiet on the eve of the Easter holidays, but prices remained steady. Smoked sheet spot and April-May sold at 2d a pound, buyers, July-September at 2 1-16d to 2 1/8d sellers, October-December at 2 3-16d to 2 1/4d sellers.

Announcement of the complete schedule for the indoor polo championships, which start at Squadron A Armory in Manhattan and Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn Saturday night, has been made by the tournament committee of the Indoor Polo Association of America.

Improvement projects on the waterways of the New York district which are being carried out by the army engineers at an estimated cost of $5,812,875 for the fiscal year will continue without alteration, despite the failure of the House Appropriations Committee to grant President Hoover's request for an allotment of $63,000,000, as recommended by the Budget Bureau.
LONDON, March 27 -- A serious view of the budgetary situation in the United States is being taken here, where memories of last Summer's financial emergency are still all too vivid.

Holders of Olympic, national and intercollegiate championships will clash in the New York A.C. pool tonight when the combined Log Angeles A.C. -- Hollywood A.C. squad engages the Winged Foot natators in a dual meet preparatory to the national indoor championships at Yale University on March 30 and 31 and April 1 and 2.

The Boston Football Club disposed of Hakoah by the decisive score of 5 to 0 in an American Soccer League game at Commercial Field in Brooklyn yesterday. The Bostonians were leading at half-time by 2-0.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- President Hoover has again been asked to define his position on modification of the Volstead act to permit the manufacture and sale of beer. The latest demand, contained in a letter written to him by Mrs. Lorraine C. Brower of Brooklyn, vice president of the Congressional District Modification League, was made public tonight by Senator Bulkley, wet Democrat, of Ohio.

John Brennan, who was competing unattached, established a new course record as he turned in the fastest time for the St. Anselm's Athletics Club handicap road race in the Bronx yesterday. Starting from scratch. Brennan pounded over the six-mile course in 29:46 to shatter the mark of 32:22 made by John Sullivan, Good Shepherd Athletic Club star, last week.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- Wilfred Knothe's single to left, which, almost carried Lary along with it into the outfield, broke a tie score in the ninth inning today, driving home two runs and winning for the Boston Braves the farewell game of the series with the Yankees, 3 to 1.

LOS ANGELES, March 27 -- William Lindley, director of salvage operations, arrived here today to perfect plans for raising the steamer Islander, which sank off Juneau. Alaska, Aug. 14, 1901, with $3,000,000 in gold aboard. He exhibited many articles already recovered by salvagers working from a diving bell specially designed for the job.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Daisy, a 6-year-old great-granddaughter of Mark Hanna, and only child of Elizabeth Hanna Davidson and Richard Porter Davidson, is the third child in the national capital to be made the subject of threats within a few days.

At the hearing in Albany last week on the pistol bills, Governor ROOSEVELT asked one of the champions of the new legislation if he thought it derogatory to be fingerprinted. "Yes, I certainly do," was the reply," and there are thousands "of other citizens who feel the "same way."
CHICAGO, March 27 -- The Chicago Black Hawks downed the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in the opening match of the second-place National Hockey League play-off, 1 to 0, before 15,000 persons.

Usually we try to dignify the theatre by employing such refined terms as "play" or "drama." But everything about "Happy Landing," which was produced at the Forty-sixth Street Saturday evening, stamps it unmistakably as a show. From the routine bathroom joke, which is the big punch line of the first act, to the routine happy ending it is a jerry-built show, flimsily designed and hastily put together to catch the trade.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES prints an address delivered by Myron D. Taylor of New York, before the Boston Chamber of Commerce, in the course of which Mr. Taylor touches on the tariff, extolling its benefits and virtues, adding: "There must be no 'tinkering' with, it, because any change would destroy our economic safeguards."

Representatives of the banking groups which supplied the city with $251,000,000 in cash and credit resources in the financial stringency of last January will confer soon with Mayor Walker regarding action to create new sources of municipal income by placing certain city activities upon a totally or partly self-supporting basis, it was reported yesterday.
Following are the recommendations for the reform of the Magistrates' Courts made by Samuel Seabury in his final report on the investigation ordered by the Appellate Division:
OAKLAND, Cal., March 27 -- Combining skill with a remarkable display of endurance, the Giants put in a long day of baseball today to capture two games from the Oakland Oaks.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Women of the country began organizing a movement today to demand that the Republican and Democratic parties, at their national conventions at Chicago in June, adopt "definite programs for the protection of the people against the war system and its financial burdens."

NEW ORLEANS, March 27 -- Trading in cotton here last week was spasmodically active. The general trend of prices was rather downward and the close of the week showed net declines of approximately 51.25 a bale. Several influences combined to cause prices to ease, the principal ones being the downward trend of prices of securities and of wheat.

A full program of entertainment Was broadcast last night from a Baltimore Ohio Railroad, train speeding from Washington to New York. The innovation in broadcasting experiment was relayed from a shortwave broadcast over Station WABC and a Columbia network between 9 and 9:30 o'clock.

The pamphlet report of Best Co. for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, 1932, shows net sales of $13,822,324, a decline of $1,275,411, or 8.4 per cent, compared with the previous year. This is the first drop in sales experienced since 1922, Philip Le Boutillier, president, reports.

LONDON, March 24 -- Absence of any further reduction in the Bank of England rate this week accorded with general anticipations of the London money market, but it is not taken to imply any change in policy. Little doubt is entertained in banking circles that the downward movement of the bank rate will continue.

Early in January two prominent Republicans were talking politics. One of them asked: "How can we "possibly re-elect President HOOVER "this year?" The reply of the other was: "We can't, not our party, but the Democrats will do it for us." At Washington they seem to be doing it to the best of their ability.

Perhaps the position of the mo- ment, in the markets and in the general field of industry, may best be described as one of lassitude and apathy. It is one of the rather numerous phases through which the "depression period" has passed since 1929; each of those phases, as is usual in such episodes, having a distinctive character of its own.

Andy Varipapa of New York in- creased his lead over Ray Schultz of Buffalo in their sixty-game bowling match for a $2,000 purse by winning the second block of ten games rolled at Dwyer's Broadway Alleys last night, 2,294 to 1,972. Varipapa now is ahead by 562 pins, having a total of 4.485 to 3,923 for Schultz.

DUBLIN, March 27 -- Two thousand men of the Irish Republican Army paraded through crowded Dublin streets today, sixteen years after the Easter week rebellion laid the centre of the city in ruins. There was no disturbance here or in any other part of the country.

BERLIN, March 27 -- An faster calm, deepened by the fortnight's political truce decreed by the government and the traditional Teutonic responsiveness to the arrival of Spring, has stilled for the moment the turbulent surface of German domestic politics.

PARIS March 25 -- This week's Bank of France return indicates that recall of foreign balances by France is slackening, but it would not be safe to conclude from this that the bank has ceased liquidation of the foreign exchange holdings acquired by it since 1927.

Real estate transactions announced over the week-end consisted largely of residential leases. Houes were taken under lease for occupancy in Westchester, New Jersey and on Long Island. A business lease was also reported from New Jersey.

John McCormack, who will sail away to Ireland early in April, not to return for a year, gave his fourth and final New York recital last night in Carnegie Hall. The old McCormack enthusiasts filled every corner of house and stage. The faithful accompanist, Edwin Schneider, was at the piano.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- Two blocks east and one block north of the tall, glistening water tower at the Yankee ball park here in St. Petersburg is a modest subtropical cottage. That's where Miller Huggins lived.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Reports compiled by the American Federation of Labor show that "March has not brought the usual Spring gain in employment." This led William Green, president of the federation, to issue a warning today that "now is the crucial time in the organisation of relief."

The customary last-minute rush for Easter merchandise marked trading in the wholesale markets here last week. Demand for coats and suits, in both trimmed and untrimmed styles, was an outstanding feature of the call for women's apparel. Orders for suits were so numerous that resident buyers predicted they will continue active for several weeks.

PARIS, March 27 -- Whether Premier Andre Tardieu will go to London this week has not yet been settied. It would be too much to say there has been a hitch. But perhaps there has been a misunderstanding, and there certainly has been misrepresentation in certain press agency reports of the desires and intentions of the British Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The stock market apparently will be the next major target for the rebellious House group which last week struck the 2.25 per cent sales tax from the budget-balancing revenue bill.

DETROIT, March 27 -- Frank Benkovic and Charley Daw of Milwaukee went on a strike rampage at the American Bowling Congress tourney today, taking the lead in the doubles event with a mighty total of 1,358. The score topped the 1.290 score of John Fehr and Jess Pritchett, Indianapolis, who had taken the lead on an earlier squad, by sixty-eight pins.

NEW HAVEN, March 26 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 63.1, which compares with 63.1 a week ago, 63.3 two weeks ago, 62.9 three weeks ago and 63.7 four weeks ago. The present year's highest average to date was 66.3, in the first week of January; the average of three weeks ago was the lowest.

ST. LOUIS, March 27 -- Jimmy Burke's fleet Stix eleven battled the clever Whaler aggregation of New Bedford, Mass., to a 3-3 deadlock today at Sportsman's Park. Two extra periods of fifteen minutes each were played.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A wide range of political opinion and social standing will be represented at the annual meeting of the Women's National Organization for National Prohibition Reform in this city next month.

Mount Vernon, N.Y. Formal offering will be made today of $1,137,000 city of Mount Vernon (N.Y.) 4 2/4 per cent school bonds, due on April 1, 1933 to 1952, at prices to yield 4.50 per cent. The offering will be made by the Guaranty Company of New York and Estabrook Co., who have received advance orders for the bulk of the issue.

Modern man has lost all conception of the meaning of eternity because he keeps his eye too much on the clock and is more interested in citizenship in this world than in the kingdom of heaven, declared the Rev. Dr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America in the annual Easter message yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Indecision in Washington with respect to the national tax problem was again blamed yesterday for the moderate weakness on the Stock Exchange and for the discouragement in market circles. There was a fairsized rally in the last hour which canceled some of the early losses, but the combinations of price averages showed a slight net decline on the day.

CHANGCHUN, Tuesday, March 29 (AP) -- Reports from Nungan today said that 7,000 Chlneae insurgents were on the verge of capturing the town, and a Japanese infantry detachment was sent from Mukden to aid Japanese troops already in the field.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The number of veterans' adjusted service certificates pledged for loans and carried by the Veterans Bureau on Feb. 29, 1932, was 2,477,012. The amount of outstanding loans on the certificates on that date was $1,247,785,108.

MOSCOW, March 28 -- The Soviet Union will launch, one of its latest trimotored airplanes tomorrow in a test flight to the new Socialist city of Igarka within the Arctic Circle. The flight will be In the nature of a trail-blazing expedition to map a route for regular air communication which will be started between Moscow and Igarka next Winter.

Speaker GARNER is said to be ready to answer the despairing cry for help which, has come to him from the disorganized Democrats in the House, He has already reaffirmed his conviction that the budget must be balanced, and that new taxes must be enacted to produce the needed revenue.

MOSCOW, March 28 -- The Kremlin evidently attaches great importance to yesterday's edict forbidding "socialization" of peasant live stock, as all newspapers here have vigorous front-page editorials on the subject today.
MONTREAL, March 28 (Canadian Press) -- To Harvey Jackson, leftwing player of the Toronto Maple Leafs, went the scoring honors of the 1931-32 season of the National Hockey League.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, March 28 -- James A. Mollison, 26-year-old "flying Scot," swooped down in the darkness on Milnerton Beach here at 8:35 tonight, having clipped nearly fifteen hours off the record for the flight from Britain to Cape Town.

All responsible civic and business organizations interested in the question of easing the tax burdens upon real estate would have a chance to present their proposals or suggestions to the entire Board of Estimate at a public hearing on the afternoon of April 11, Mayor Walker announced yesterday at an open conference with committees representing the Real Estate Board of New York, the Brooklyn Real Estate Board and about thirty business and civic groups.

BAYARD, Fla., March 28 -- Home Work, which lost and then won by a nose in two races at Tropical Park, scored by the same narrow margin in the event which had the place of honor at St. Johns Park today.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- Net earnings of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana and its subsidiary interests for 1931 are estimated by Edward G. Zubert, president of the company, on preliminary calculations, at $17,500,000, equal to $1.04 a share on the 16,911,410 shares outstanding on Dec. 31 last.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 28 -- Miss Margaret Blake of Lenox, Mass., 1929 champion, narrowly averted defeat in her opening match as the women's national indoor tennis championship began today on the Longwood covered courts.
"Border-land." a play by Crane Wilbur, will be presented tonight at the Biltmore Theatre. In the cast will be Howard Lang, Lester Vail, Catherine Doucet, Lenita Lane and Fuller Melllsh.

PARIS, March 28 -- Whether or not Dino Grandi, Italian Foreign Minister, and Chancellor Bruening of Germany go this week-end to London to discuss proposals for a Danubian confederation, Premier Tardieu of France intends to go for what he believes to be a necessary conversation with Prime Minister MacDonald and Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary.

NEW ORLEANS, March 28 -- Tung oil production, which revolutionized the manufacture of varnishes twenty-five years ago, may become a Gulf Coast region iridustry, ranking with sugar cane, cotton and corn, it was announced today at the opening session of the eighty-third national meeting of the American Chemical Society.

Snow, sleet, rain and high winds swept over the North Atlantic States yesterday, causing widespread suffering and property damage from Ohio to Maine. At least twelve lives were taken by the storm, which was decribed by some Weather Bureau observers as the worst to occur at this season in many years.
The readiness of the Board of Estimate to take early action to grant bus franchises in Manhattan and Queens, perhaps by Friday, is set out in an affidavit signed by Mayor Walker yesterday.

Net profits of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation in 1931 amounted to $200,646, leaving no balance for common stock. In the year before the company reported the equivalent of 60 cents a common share.

The good old days when Bohemia was Bohemia and artists wore long hair and flowing ties is revived for a week at the Art Students' League, where the rejuvenated Society of Fakirs is holding a show. One finds bright red automobiles, 1909 model, careening through posters with what one is tempted to interpret as alcoholic abandon; while every second picture in the show celebrates, in one way or another, the teaming stein.

Operations of Patino Mines and Enterprises Consolidated in 1931 resulted in a net loss to surplus of L87,305 after depreciation, depletion and other charges, comparing with a net loss of L158,004 in 1930.

LESLIE M. SHAW was a characteristic product of the Nineties. He was one of the fortunately numerous Westerners of that period who had political aspirations, but who were honest enough and shrewd enough to see that the unsound-money craze, which appeared at the moment to be sweeping irresistibly over the Middle West, was sure eventually to lose its hold.

Developments in other markets during the three-day holiday caused yesterday the heaviest selling in several months on the Cotton Exchange and prices broke more than 35 points. Weakness last week and less activity in dry goods quarters than had been expected for the Easter trade reduced the tendency to buy and the list closed at net losses of 26 to 31 points.

The Rev. H. Dobson Peacock of Norfolk, Va., flew through a storm yesterday to visit Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh at Hopewell, N.J. He spent half an hour trying to convince the aviator that he was in touch with the actual kidnappers of the missing Charles Augustus Jr., but left, declining to say whether he had been successful. bergh," he replied, his teeth chattering with the cold. "All I can say is that we are optimistic."

More than 300 women attending the twelfth annual meeting of the New York State Home Economics Association, which opened yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt, were told by Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the women's division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 28 -- Peter A.B. Widener 3d and Ella Widener, children of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d, entertained today with a party at the home of their grandfather, Joseph E. Widener.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- While securities of the Middle West Utilities Company showed various reactions here today to the proposal for a financial reorganization as contained in the company's annual report, LaSalle Street heard rumors from New York over brokerage wires that plans were being made for a merger of that company with the Insull Utility Investment Trust and Corporation Securities.

MADRID, March 28 -- The burning of a monastery by Communists at Antequera, in the province of Malaga, and the killing of one and wounding of several members of a mob were reported to the Cortes today and made the subject of questions to the government and a Socialist attack on the Catholic Church.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- Light hogs of shipping quality were in active demand early today and 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight higher than on Saturday, but other kinds were steady to 10 cents higher early and closed weak and barely steady. While today's top was up 20 cents at $4.60, the average was only 5 cents higher at $4.20.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Alleged pressure put upon the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve a loan of $12,800,000 to the Missouri Pacific Railroad by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation aroused a Senatorial debate today which indicated the possibility of an investigation into the corporation's loans to railroads.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for 1931 shows a net income of $5,974,499 after taxes, depreciation and charges, equal to $5.71 a share earned on 1,045,280 shares of stock, against $9,247,032, or $9.03 a share on 1,023,811 shares earned in 1930.

After six weeks of preparation, the Block-Aid campaign to "stamp out want" began yesterday morning in more than 7,000 city blocks. Although the amount of stamps sold was not ascertained, it was said the demand was enormous, actually totaling $5,519,600.

Some advocates of the plan for immediate redemption of veterans' service certificates urge its adoption as a measure of economy. Representative PATMAN argues that it would "save the Government annual pay"ment of more than $112,000,000 "until 1945."

Anything from a vacuum cleaner to a cottage on the Hudson will meet the needs of members of the Society of Independent Artists it seemed yesterday when they started bringing in canvases for their annual show in Grand Central Palace.

HAVANA, March 28 -- In contradiction to press dispatches from New York that Java had rejected the sugar crop figure of 2,700,000 tons fixed by Cuba, the Heraldo de Cuba, the government organ, stated today that the demands of Cuba had been accepted with but slight modifications, which are easily surmountable.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 28 -- Guests at the demonstration of the semagraph here today included the following:

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 28 (AP) -- Automatic typesetting -- the operation of a linotype direct from copy without human effort -- was demonstrated here today before a small group of publishers and newspaper executives.

DAIREN, March 28 -- Manchurian insurgents tonight penetrated within thirty-five miles northwest of Changchun, Manchoukuo's new capital, and menaced the walled city of Nungan The insurgents number more than 3,000, and it is reported the Nungan garrison of 1,500 Kirin troops has mutinied and is Joining them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The extensive account of propaganda agencies and efforts for communism cited by William H. Grady as operating in this country looks terrifying to those who are afraid of Communist activity. Nevertheless, a little examination of the situation as stated in his letter will show that the situation is very decidedly not alarming.

Another Wise Veto. Again Governor ROOSEVELT has exercised his veto power with, discretion. The pistol bills introduced at this session of the Legislature had the support of numerous well-meaning persons, but nevertheless came in for wide criticism on the ground that they tended to break down essential safeguards in the war on crime.

Upon tie evidence in Judge SEABURY'S report it is unnecessary to dwell. It has already sunk into the public mind. His recommendation that the Magistrates', Special Sessions and Children's Courts be combined in a Court of Special Sessions in one building, has long been advocated by Chief Magistrate CORRIGAN and has been approved by the Bar Association.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Serious interference with recovery would be caused by the passage of the Glass banking bill, Leonard P. Ayres. vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, testified today before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

ST. LOUIS, March 28 (AP) -- The Slate Democratic convention tonight instructed Missouri's delegates to the rational convention to use all "honorable means within their power" to obtain the nomination of former Senator James A. Reed as the Democratic candidate for President.

Admiral Sir William Reginald Hall, head of the British Naval Intelligence during the war, who has been here on a brief visit after a vacation in the West Indies, sailed for England last night on the Cunard liner Mauretania. He left England in February and came to New York a week ago to make hurried visits to friends in New York, Washington and Philadelphia.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- Reaffirming his stand that the United States should enter the League of Nations, but that the question of adherence should no be made a partisan issue in the coming campaign. Newton D. Baker of Cleveland, mentioned for the Democratic Presidential nomination, addressed the Democratic Women's Luncheon Club here today and later conferred for an hour and a half with leaders of the "Stop-Roosevelt" movement in Pennsylvania.

BOSTON, March 28 (AP) -- Milwaukee's claim to fame as the highest ranking American city in point of financial rating has been challenged by the Boston Finance Commission which asserts that Boston enjoys a far superior position in municipal debts and taxation.

TOKYO, March 28 -- Having received reports from General Uyeda on the peace negotiations at Shanghai, military authorities here seem to expect a breakdown. They are reported to be discussing with General Shirakawa the number of troops to be returned to Shanghai in the event of a rupture.

Forty-three of the fifty-one seniors at the New York Law School, 215 West Twenty-third Street, believe that the Seabury investigation should be continued to cover completely the entire city government, according to the results of a questionnaire sponsored by the Student Council made public yesterday.

ROME, March 28 -- Another series of 1,000,000,000 lire or about $52,000000,000 at par, of nine-year treasury bonds will be issued for public subscription from April 7 to April 24 to redeem 915,000,000 lire of treasury bonds maturing next Nov. 15.

Net loss of the F. W. Grand 5-10-25-Cent Stores, Inc., an operating subsidiary of the F. W. Grand-Silver Stores, Inc., was $1,206,133 in 1931, after interest on bonds of subsidiaries, depreciation, amortization and other charges. There was a charge of $944,744 against surplus for write-off on leaseholds and one of $237,407 for write-down on 11,272 shares of parent company stock owned.

NEW YORK. The last for this season of the colony dances for future debutantes will be held tonight in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The committee is under the direction of Mrs. Gordon Auchincloss and includes Mrs. De Lancey Kane Jay, Mrs. Stephen C. Clark, Mrs. Robert S. Brewster, Mrs. Philip Livermore, Mrs. Beverley Bogert, Mrs. George S. Brewster and Mrs. Robert Low Bacon Jr.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Efforts to create a confederation of Danubian States among Czechoslovakia, Austria, Hungary, Rumania and Yugoslavia are being watched with close interest here, not only because of the relief that would be given to the economic distress of Central and Eastern Europe but also because of the contribution a better political atmosphere would make to the progress of the disarmament conference at Geneva.

BOSTON, March 28 (AP) -- Governor Roosevelt cannot understand why Alfred E. Smith is not among his supporters in his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, his son, James, told several Roosevelt meetings here tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., March 28 -- Severe criticism of "the oppression and exploit ion of labor by so-called labor leaders," which was declared to be "a thousandfold worse than capitalism, which labor unions were formed to resist," was contained in a decision today of Vice Chancellor M.A. Berry in upholding the refusal of four members of the Iron Workers Union to work under the "permit" and "card-index" system of their organization.

In an address last night denouncing governmental extravagance, Silas H. Strawn, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, declared that the costs of government must nevertheless be met, and that the public must submit to enough taxation to balance the budget if the country is to be saved from financial and economic disaster.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 28 -- An estate estimated at more than $6,000,000 is disposed of in the will of Robert H. McCurdy, former general manager of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New, York, who died on March 18 at his home here. The will, probated today in the office of the Morris County surrogate, contains specific bequests totaling more than $1,500,000 to institutions, relatives, friends and employes.
To the Editor of The New York Times. If we must have this prohibition repeal clamor let us at least have fair play and the facts.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 28 -- Five women and one man held in Bell and Harlan County (Ky.) jails since Jan. 4 on charges of criminal syndicalism were released today on bonds of $5,000 each, which their attorneys, W.J. Stone and J.H. Taylor, signed.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 28 -- The status of all athletic coaches at Syracuse University will be changed to faculty membership rating as full-time teachers or professors, Chancellor Charles W. Flint announced tonight before 1,000 persons at the annual block "S" dinner.

NEWARK, N.J., March 28 -- Four equity receivers were appointed today by Federal Judge Fake here for the Botany Consolidated Mills, Inc., of Passaic, holding company for the Botany Worsted Mills of that city. The court acted on a bill of complaint filed by William A. Summer.

Representative J.J. McSWAIN of South Carolina, chairman of the Military Affairs Committee, would like to see the enlisted force of the army of higher quality in intelligence and general capacity. To quote him, he "would have it so that promo"tions to Second Lieutenant should "be distributed among West Point "graduates, enlisted men, honor "graduates from select military "schools and from the National "Guard."

The President's Medal of the National Academy of Design was awarded posthumously yesterday to Samuel Finley Breese Morse, inventor of the telegraph and distinguished American painter, at impressive ceremonies at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in a room the walls of which were covered with a collection of the artist-inventor's bestknown paintings.

William J. Flynn, Public Works Commissioner of the Bronx, was cited for contempt yesterday by the Hofstadter legislative committee, and proceedings to punish him were started in the Supreme Court, after he had refused to answer questions.
DETROIT, March 28 -- Edsel B. Ford, president of the Ford Motor Car Company, stated tonight that the new Ford V-8 will be shown to the public in 200 cities Thursday morning.

Transatlantic steamship lines are considering the reduction of passenger rates, effective in April or May. A meeting of the principals of the Transatlantic Passenger Conference is scheduled for tomorrow in London and a final decision is expected then. Reductions have been considered recently at meetings of subcommittees of the conference.
DETROIT, March 28 (AP) -- Standings in the doubles and singles competition in the American Bowling Congress tournament were shifted today by Chicago and Cleveland bowlers.

NEW DELHI, India, March 28 -- Amid brilliant pageantry, the Viceroy, the Earl of Willingdon, today opened the eleventh annual session of the Chamber of Princes, which will decide whether to bring the native Indian States with their 125,000,000 subjects into the proposed allIndia federation.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 (AP) -- An alleged plot to abduct or assassinate Archbishop Francisco Orozoco y Jimenez of Mexico at a Catholic mission here where he was a guest caused the prelate to move to more secure quarters under guard today.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Speaker Garner announced today that he would take the floor tomorrow to urge passage of the remodeled tax bill by the House.

HAVANA, March 28 -- Two local officials of the New York firm of Frederick H. Knocke, film distributers, were arrested today in connection with a $123,000 fire on March 1, which destroyed the company's warehouse here and cost the lives of two children trapped on the roof of an adjoining building.

TRENTON, N.J., March 28 -- After defeating a bill providing for the repeal of the State prohibition enforcement law, known as the Hobart act, the Senate tonight passed two bills providing for State referenda on the prohibition laws at the next election.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Rain, sleet and a biting northwest wind failed to deter the annual egg rolling on the White House grounds today. The official count showed 11,240 arrivals during the day, compared with 30,000 last year and 48,000 in 1930.

New York State plans to come to Wall Street soon for a short-term loan of upward of $50,000,000, of which $25,000,000 is expected to be in the form of notes maturing in about one year and the balance in the nature of a revolving fund which will be drawn on as the money is needed, according to information in banking circles here yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, March 28 -- Congress met in special session today and, with a quorum in both houses for the first time in two years, reduced the budget 24,864,952 pesos ($6,216,236) below the estimate of the Provisional Government. The total revenue from tax collections is put at $757,736,238 and from a bond sale at 61,871,920 pesos, the two sums being equivalent to $204,902,000.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- Fluctuations in wheat on the Board of Trade today were wide enough to suit all classes of traders, prices covering a range of about 1 1/2 cents a bushel. May touched the high and low figures twice. An early break was followed by a rally, another sinking spell around noon and a fresh upturn toward the last.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was with a good deal of amazement and indignation that I have read the letter which was published in THE TIMES from David R. Coker, concerning the salaries of postoffice employes.

TIGHINA, Bessarabia, March 28 -- More than 1,000 Moldavians -- men, women and children -- are declared to have been shot down by Russian frontier guards while trying to escape across the frozen Dniester River into Rumania in the past three months.

Charles Winninger, it is announced by the Chamberlain Brown office, will head the cast of a revival of "The Music Master" at the Riviera Theatre for a week's engagement, beginning next Monday. Mr. Winninger will be seen in the role made famous by David Warfield in the late David Belasco's production of the Charles Klein play in 1904.

The strongest team ever to represent New York thrilled one of indoor boxing's greatest crowds with a smashing triumph over Chicago's squad in the fifth annual intercity Golden Gloves tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.

The County Trust Company of New York lost a point yesterday in its legal fight to collect $50,000 on a promissory note from Timothy J. Mara, sports promoter, when Supreme Court Justice John Ford ruled that Orie K. Kelly, president of the bank, must submit to examination before trial and must answer questions as to Mr. Mara's defense to the suit.

Opening his drive here for the Republican nomination for Governor with an address at the Twenty-third District Republican Club at 19 Bennett Avenue, last night, Joseph A. McGinnies, speaker of the Assembly, pledged his support to maintenance of the five-cent fare.

NANKING, March 28 (AP) -- Protection of China's territorial and administrative integrity must be a condition of any settlement of the SinoJapanese conflict, Lord Lytton, chairman of the League of Nations inquiry commission, told a group of Chinese officials at a luncheon today.

With the outcome of the meet hinging on the final race of the program, the 300-yard medley relay, New York Athletic Club swimmers not only triumphed to turn back the vaunted Los Angeles A.C. and Hollywood A.C. combined forces, 33 to 27, but also set a new world's record for the distance before an overflow crowd of 1,500 persons in the Winged Foot Natatorium last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 -- Football weather that produced a football score prevailed today as the Giants took the measure of the San Francisco Seals. The final score was 22 to 12, and if the Seal outfielders tonight are not in the same superb condition as the Giants it cannot be laid to the fault of the New Yorkers, who battered four pitchers for a total of twenty-six hits.

What was described as an important advance in the treatment of pernicious anemia was announced yesterday in the development of a solution by Dr. William P. Murphy of the Harvard Medical School faculty and a member of the staff of the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston, where the treatment has been applied successfully.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 28 (AP) -- Commodore V. Mason Well of the Florida Outboard Motor Association announced today that be had been appointed to investigate charges that nine American drivers lured C.H. Harrison of England across the starting line ahead of the signal in the Biscayne Bay regatta at Miami last week.

BARTOW. Fla., March 28 (AP). -- Two companies of National Guardsmen armed with rifles and machine guns stood guard today over the Polk County Jail, where three men and a woman are held for the slaying of two Lakeland policemen last night.

Gustave Van Belle of Belgium went into the lead in the world's amateur 18.2 balkline billiard championship yesterday when he defeated the former American champion, Francis S. Appleby of New York, 400 to 141, at the Elks Club.
A further sharp fall in the dollar occurred yesterday as European selling, based on the delay of Congress in framing a tax measure to balance the budget, poured into this market from foreign sources.

Blanche Ring returned to the New York stage last night in "Intimate Relations," billed as a comedy, which was presented at the Ambassador Theatre. That brief statement of incontrovertible facts comprises just about all the news of the drama from Forty-ninth Street this morning, for the play was an infirm trifle, well meaning but ineffectual in its efforts to amuse.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Governor Roosevelt today vetoed two bills which would have amended the socalled pistol law, enacted at the extraordinary session of the Legislature last year at the request of New York City authorities to aid their fight on gangsters.

The range of trading on the New York Curb Exchange broadened yesterday. Prices in the stock list were mixed. Several leading issues rallied to show gains late in the day. Domestic and foreign bonds, however, were generally lower.

New York City s new House of Detention for Women, at Sixth Avenue and Tenth Street, built at a cost of nearly $2,000,000, will be opened for inspection this afternoon from 4 to 6 o'clock by Richard C. Patterson Jr., Commissioner of Correction.

Thirty members of the junior and senior championship basketball squads of the Catholic Youths Organization of Chicago arrived yesterday for their intercity contests with the St. Nicholas of Tolentine junior and senior fives of the Bronx.

Photographers upset the birthday plans of King Leo, the Metro-Gold-wyn-Mayer Numidian lion, yesterday as he was being lionized on the toy floor of Gimbel Brothers. Not that Leo had developed a temperament in his movie career, but he had spent many of his eighteen years under the bulging eyes of cameras and hardly could see his birthday as another workday.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, again pressed the issue of economy in the State Government when he addressed the School of Politics of the Women's National Republican Club yesterday. He predicted that, in view of the economic stress, the people would "change the present situation."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28 -- Despite a seven-run drive in the fourth inning by the Indianapolis Indians, the Yankees swung mightier bats today and evened the Spring series with Manager Emmett McCann's crew by winning, 12 to 8.

The pamphlet report of the Central and South West Utilities Company for 1931 shows a net income of $4,304,447 after charges, taxes and depreciation, equal after dividends on prior lien and preferred stocks to 76 cents a share on 3,258,906 common shares, including scrip, against $5,922,373, or $1.34 a share earned on 3,047,813 common shares and scrip, in 1930.

Although in general accord on most of the minor items, the members of the bench and bar expressed divergent opinions yesterday on the major reforms recommended by Samuel Seabury in his final report on the magistrates' courts investigation.

Dexter Fellows, who has been served faithfully these many years by the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, came to town again yesterday. Twirling the ivory-topped cane that he wrested from Swallowo three years back, he appeared at the office of THE NEW YORK TIMES with two announcements.

J.L. GAKVIN, the editor of The (London) Observer, assumes to give answer from England's walls to the deepening question of every thoughtful lover of Britain: "Watchman, what of the night?" His heartening cry is that morning is here. The first streaks of dawn came in the transformation under the National Government beginning last Autumn -- a transformation not only real but magical.

The New York Central and the Baltimore Ohio joined yesterday the list of some twenty railroads which increased their net operating incomes in February, compared with February, 1931, by drastic cuts in expenditures. The Pennsylvania held its reduction in net operating income for February to $68,000.

The British Treasury notified participating banks yesterday that it would pay off the $30,000,000 of bills maturing today, composing part of the outstanding 25 per cent of the $200,000,000 credit extended last August by a syndicate of 110 banks headed by J.P. Morgan Co. Similar repayment is expected to be made of the remaining $20,000,000 of British Treasury bills, due on April 5, but in both cases the credit line will be kept open.

The New York Rangers, content with their lead of one game over the Canadiens of Montreal, will strive to capture the championship of the National Hockey League when the first place play-off is resumed at Madison Square Garden tonight. The game will be the fourth of the series, which will be decided on a three-out-of-five basis.

BOMBAY, March 28 (AP) -- Prospects for an immediate peace between the Indian Nationalists and the British Government receded today when Mrs. Sarojini Naidu, head of the All-India National Congress, said her peace overtures with the Viceroy had been unsuccessful.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., March 28 -- A merger of the Pacific Investing Corporation, and the Southern Bond and Share Corporation under the corporate name Pacific Southern Investors, Inc., has been approved by directors of the two investment trusts, subject to ratification of stockholders, Henry S. McKee, president of Pacific Investing, has announced to stockholders.

Walter G. Jones, a building contractor and former Republican alderman in Yonkers, was the principal State witness yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Roland C. Bastress, formerly chief inspector of the Building Department, and John I. Cahalan, a construction superintendent, on a charge that they accepted a $1,500 bribe on July 27, 1927, for Bastress's approval of plans for a penthouse that Jones built atop 280 Madison Avenue.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 28 (AP) -- A 1-to-1 tie resulted tonight in the first game of the preliminary play-off series between the Rhode Island Reds and the Bronx Tigers, the first and fourth place teams in the Canadian-American Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The old dreadnought Utah, will go into commission Friday under Commander Randall Jacobs as a radio-controlled target. The ves 1 was demilitarized under the provisions of the London naval treaty and was reconditioned for her new service at the Norfolk Navy Yard.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Further decreases in the volume of money in circulation during the past few days brought the total return flow to the Federal Reserve Banks and the treasury to $201,000,000 between Feb. 6 and March 26, Secretary Mills announced today.
SHANGHAI, Tuesday, March 29 -- Prospects for successfully concluding the Sino-Japanese armistice conferences are the gloomiest they have been since the negotiations began.

While oil producers generally were reluctant yesterday to discuss the proposed import tax of 1 cent a gallon on crude petroleum, gasoline, gas oil and fuel oil, it was agreed that such a duty would have a far-reaching effect on the oil industry:

Twenty-eight recent canvases by Ernest Lawson have just gone on view at the Ferargil Gallery. Mr. Lawson long ago succeeded in turning French impressionism into a technique strongly his own, and without any radical departures, he reveals, season after season, an ability to turn with enthusiasm from problem to problem.

At a special meeting of the Actors' Equity Association yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor, a committee of six was chosen to meet with three members of the Equity council for the purpose of nominating the regular ticket of candidates for election to the council at the annual meeting to be held late in May.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Making extensive use of the veto at his Hyde Park home over the week-end, Governor Roosevelt disapproved fortyfive legislative measures. He signed forty-nine others, mostly of a local nature, it was announced at the Executive Chamber.

To rid New York City of Tammany domination and American politics of its sinister symbolism will require the awakening of public opinion to the importance of city government to general well-being, declares Norman Thomas in his book "As I See It," published today by the Macmillan Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Through, the efforts of an organized minority, smug in virtue, an unnatural law has been forced upon the people of the United States. During the futile efforts of its enforcement has crept a criminal society of such magnitude that the world is stunned by its power and recent daring.

The listed bond market lost further ground yesterday in selling to the accompaniment of large trading. United States Government bonds especially were heavily sold, the turnover in the group amounting to $5,157,500, the most since Jan. 12. Prices for government issues were down 3-32 to 1 14-32 points, except the Liberty 3 1/2 s, which held unchanged, and the Treasury 4 1/4 s, which moved up 6-32 point.

Mrs. Lesley Josephine Pearson, widow of Commander Frederick Pearson of the United States Navy and daughter of the late Dr. James C. Ayer, manufacturer of Ayer's sarsaparilla, left an estate of $16,766,053 gross and $16,484,528 net when she died on May 16, 1928, it was shown in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday at the State Tax Commission.

HIGH BRIDGE, N.J., March 28 -- I Percival Chrystie, chairman of the board of the Taylor-Wharton Iron and Steel Company here, one of the oldest corporations in this country, was found dead from a shot-gun wound this morning behind the power house of the steel plant, a short distance from his home.

Marie Powers, contralto, presented a program of songs last night in the Town Hall that included Rossi's lovely "Ah! rendimi" aria, four songs of Wolf, Liszt's "Die Lorelei," Grieg's "Swan," Brahms's "Von ewiger Liebe," and an English and French group.
Testimony yesterday at the public hearing of the Hofstadter legislative committee before which Commissioner William J. Flynn was a witness in part, follows:

The Russian Opera Foundation opened its second season of Russian opera in this city last night in Mecca Temple, with a performance of Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Coq d'Or," sung in Russian, and heard and seen for the first time here in the composer's original version.

Unfavorable grain conditions and prospects in Soviet Russia are reflected in the news from a number of sources. The London wheat market assumes that Russia is out of the export business for the rest of the season. Berlin publishes detailed figures on the Spring sowing, which make it clear why very little Russian wheat may be expected in foreign ports.

The final supper dance of the Imperial, a dancing club organized in the interest of the Social Service Bureau of Bellevue Hospital, was held last night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. A carnival motif was carried out and the dance was called the Closing Imperial Carnival.

State of Minnesota. The State of Minnesota will issue soon a formal call for sealed bids on a new issue of $10,000,000 4 1/2 per cent highway and rural credit bonds, due in twenty years, according to present plans. Julius A. Schmahl, State Treasurer, has been conferring with bankers here in the last few days.
The varsity and freshman crews of Columbia took up their residence in the Manor House at Baker Field yesterday, inaugurating the official training season for the Blue and White.
Chick Devlin, 160 1/2, San Francisco, won the decision from Larry Marinucci, 154 1/2, Brooklyn, in ten hard rounds of close in-fighting in the main bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

Periodically the Montross Gallery puts on a group show of work by contemporary Americans. The present attraction involves the participation of fourteen artists. They represent an extremely varied approach. As a matter of fact, there isn't the slightest aspect of a "school" in these Montross groups.
