Practically all of yesterday's markets were under the influence of the confusion at Washington; but it affected them in different ways, and they gave no evidence that all were moving in line with expectations that the program for balancing national expenditure would go to pieces.

The New York Rangers captured the championship of the National Hockey League last night by defeating the courageous Canadians of Montreal in the fourth game of the first-place play-off at Madison Square Garden.

TORONTO, March 29 -- Unleashing an attack of blinding speed, the Toronto Maple Leafs gained a 6-to-1 victory over Chicago tonight in the final game of the second-place playoff and will meet the Montreal Maroons, third-place winners, in the next play-off series.

Myron C Taylor, a lawyer turned industrialist, assumed yesterday the full executive direction of the United States Steel Corporation following his election as chairman of the board to succeed J.P. Morgan, the banker.

BERLIN, March 29 -- The Boerse reopened after the four-day Easter recess still under the influence of the holiday doldrums, with trading listless and prices sagging under slight oferings. Bonds were dull and irregular.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 29 -- The Yale University Athletic Association Board of Control tonight announced the awarding of 150 athletic insignia in basketball, fencing, swimming, indoor polo, squash racquets and wrestling. Henry T. Snowden, '34, of Sewickly, Pa., received the only major "Y" for winning the unlimited class championship in the recent intercollegiate wrestling meet at Syracuse.

A rally in dollar exchange, based on profit-taking by European traders who had made speculative sales on Saturday and Monday and on indications from Washington that Congress was making renewed efforts to balance the budget, set in yesterday, virtually wiping out the gains made by leading European exchanges on the first day of the week.

As a result of $1,036,776 losses realized on sales of securities, the Newmont Mining Corporation shows a net loss of $206,709 after expenses, taxes and interest in 1931. This contrasts with a net profit of $2,332,769, equivalent to $4.38 a share on 531,646 capital shares, in the preceding year.

NEWARK, N.J., March 29 -- Following the appointment in Federal court here yesterday of four equity receivers for the Botany Consolidated Mills, Inc., holding company for Botany Worsted Mills of Passaic, an involuntary petition in bankruptcy was filed in Federal court today against the Botany Consolidated Mills by three ceditors with claims totaling $676.
PARIS, March 29 -- Commenting on the reports that Japan may retire from membership in the League of Nations and on the declarations of the Japanese Minister of War the Temps says:

Young lawyers with some experience, instead of wasting their time seeking jobs during the depression, should set up offices of their own, it was declared yesterday by Edward Gluck, secretary of the Law Clerkship Committee of the Alumni Association of the Columbia University Law School.

Albert Poensgen, defending champion, went into the lead in the world's amateur 18.2 balkline billiard championship at the Elks Club last night when he defeated the Belgian star, Gustave Van Belle, 400 to 206, in a long drawn-out game in which neither played up to his best form.

MONTREAL, March 29 -- The Montreal Maroons gained the second round of the National Hockey League play-off elimination series by blanking the Detroit Falcons, 2 -- 0, in a close game tonight, winning the third place series on total goals, 3 -- 1.
ROME, March 29 (AP) -- Premier Mussolini thinks there is an all too lans lack initiative, so he is going to publish a book about their great deeds.

DETROIT, March 29 (AP) -- Robert Irish and Irvin Kelly of Albany, N.Y., went into sixth place in the two-man event of the American Bowling Congress tournament today when they posted a score of 1,268 on games of 418, 431 and 419.

CHICAGO, March. 29 -- President Hoover was endorsed for the renomination at a meeting here today of nearly 200 members of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, representing five Central States. The women gathered to make plans to elect dry delegates to the national conventions and to place dry planks in the pltaforms of both parties meeting here in June.

A Printing Millenium In a hundred newspaper composing rooms a hundred linotypes simultaneously setting type without fingers and in response to the impulses transmitted from a central office as a photoelectric cell scans a piece of copy prepared on a special typewriter -- such is the prospect held out by the demonstration that Mr. BUFORD L. GREEN gave in Charlotte, N.C.

MEXICO CITY, March 29 -- Roberto Hernandez Alexander, whose picaresque adventures and misadventures have diverted the Mexican public for months and won for him the sobriquet of the "Mexican Raffles," has been recaptured after two daring escapes, according to dispatches from Torreon, in the State of Coahuila.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- A description of "a dull night" aboard a "floating gambling palace" three miles out in the Pacific off San Pedro, Cal., was given today to a House committee considering a bill to restrict the activities of such resorts.

Losses predominated among the more active stocks at the close of trading yesterday on the New York Curb Exchange, but the list was not without gains. Domestic bonds rallied briskly from recent declines, while foreign bonds displayed a firmer tendency and closed with gains and losses about evenly divided.

Crane Wilbur, who is an able actor, has put a play together out of the oddments and impedimenta of the theatre, "Border-land," which was acted at the Biltmore last evening. To some extent, as the Yankees say, it is a play about spiritualism with the lights turned low at strategic moments and the vocal tones adjusted to eerie.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William Warner Hoppin will give a dinner at the Pierre tomorrow night to celebrate the thirtieth anniversary of their marriage.

Virgean England Estes, who gave a debut recital yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall, presented Bach's Toccata in G minor, a group of Brahms, Chopin's sonata in B minor and a final group comprising two Scriabin etudes and Albeniz's "Triana."

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Refusal of signatories of the World Court protocol to accept the American Fifth Reservation, which requires this country's consent before an opinion touching its interests can be rendered, would end the question of American adherence "probably permanently," according to Senator Pittman of the Foreign Relations Committee.
The city's new $2,000,000 House of Detention for Women at Sixth Avenue and Tenth Street was formally opened for inspection yesterday afternoon by Richard C. Patterson Jr., Commissioner of Correction.

The emergency that gave rise to bus operations inaugurated in the days when HYLAN was Mayor has become a perennial. The public, and also the courts, apparently, seem to have grown accustomed to one stay after another of the judicial process which would bring it to an end.

LONDON, March 29 -- A dispatch from Paris attributing to Premier Tardieu announcements that he is coming to London during the next week-end for a conference with Prime Minister MacDonald on the Danubian situation does not conform precisely with London's understanding of the matter.

Rollin C. Bastress, former chief inspector in the Manhattan Building Department, testified yesterday before Judge Koenig in General Sessions, where he and John I. Cahalan, construction superintendent, are on trial on a charge that in August, 1927, they accepted a $1,500 bribe from a builder for Bastress's approval of plans for a penthouse on the building at 280 Madison Avenue.

The twenty-mile city water tunnel built to bring Catskill water into the city from Hillview Reservoir north of Van Cortlandt Park will be holed through at noon today with the firing of a final blast in the shaft at Bronxwood Avenue and 233d Street.

Details of the principal items included as "investments in subsidiary" companies in the annual statement of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company were issued in Chicago yesterday on behalf of Samuel Insull, chairman of the board. The total was $46,789,556.

Motor vehicle operation, both independent of and in connection with train service, was increased by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in 1931, according to the annual report issued yesterday by J.J. Pelley, president, and E.G. Buckland, chairman.

NEW ORLEANS, March 29 -- Buildings, bridges and other structural work built with common cane sugar as one of the construction, ingredieats, which will last longer and be far stronger than those in existence today, were visualized by scientists of the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research who addressed the American Chemical Society on the second day of its meeting here.

PARIS, March 29 -- After the four-day holiday the Bourse had a listless session today. Absence of trading was chiefly responsible for the losses, which were traced to some extent to the Stockholm committee's report on Kreuger Toll, issued since the Bourse closed for the holiday.

PORTLAND, Me., March 29 (AP) -- The prohibition question was brought forcefully before Maine Democrats today as they assembled for the State convention which will name twelve delegates, probably favorable to Governor Roosevelt, to the national convention.

Declaring that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh "seemed much impressed," with the information he took to the flier's home at Hopewell, N.J., the Rev. H. Dobson Peacock said yesterday in Norfolk, Va., that he had been authorized to continue negotiations for the recovery of the kidnapped Lindbergh baby.

Firemen rescued three women and sixteen children from the second floor of a ten-family tenement at 143 St. Ann's Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon after a fire started in a coal bin in the basement and enveloped the five-story building in dense smoke which cut off their escape.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Senator Borah is quoted as saying: "I wonder if we have built up a bureaucracy that is master of both the Executive and the Congress, and whether in this time of distress it is going to refuse to share with the taxpayers the burden they are carrying."

CHICAGO, March 29 -- With a denunciation of the "disease of over-taxation," business leaders of the Middle West today joined in a protest against "excessive" appropriations by Congress and "Federal waste and extravagance."

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 29 -- Miss Dorrance Chase of Dorchester scored the first upset of the women's national indoor tennis championship, being played at the Longwood covered courts, when she eliminated Miss Edith Sigourney of Southboro, Mass., 1928 champion, who is seeded fourth, in the feature match of today's play.

PATERSON, N.J., March 29 -- The scheduled stage appearance of Mrs. Jack Diamond at a Paterson burlesque theatre drew today the protest of clergymen who called upon the police to prevent the public appearance of a woman "whose only stage value is the fact that her husband was slain in a gang feud."

WHITE PLAINS, March 29 -- Major Louis Livingston Seaman, a retired surgeon of the United States Army, who traveled around the world in 1886 to study epidemic diseases and whose colorful career is legend in army medical ranks, left his residuary estate to Cornell University for experimentation to determine the best foods for the American soldier, according to his will filed here today.

Women voters were urged to disregard all political issues except prohibition and to support only candidates pledged to work for repeal in addresses yesterday by Mrs. Emily Price Post and Mrs. John S. Sheppard of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform at a luncheon in the Commodore of the business and professional women's group of the organization.

A.C. and G.H. Bostwick, two of the best known amateur riders in the country, with the latter the leading amateur for several seasons, have had their applications for certificates as amateur riders favorably acted upon by the stewards of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, Frank J. Bryan, secretary of the hunts committee of the association, announced yesterday.

More than 50,000 New Yorkers have responded already to the block-aid appeal for subscriptions to "stamp out want," it was announced yesterday at the close of the second day of active solicitation in the city-wide canvass. The stamps, from 10 cents to $1 each, are being sold to those who will pledge contributions for twenty weeks.

From the new models about to be put on display the automobile industry should profit. Potential purchasers of low-priced cars had adopted a waiting attitude, with the result that production has declined at a season of the year when normally it is expanding.

Supporters of Governor Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for President took steps yesterday to bring about the selection of Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky for temporary chairman of the Democratic National Convention by canvassing the members of the committee of arrangements, which will meet in Chicago next Monday to make a tentative selection.
AUSTIN, Texas, March 29 -- While friends of John N. Garner throughout the country are working earnestly to advance his Presidential chances, all is not rosy politically in his home State.

Although United States Government bonds rallied mildly on the Stock Exchange yesterday, domestic corporation and foreign loans dipped again. THE NEW YORK TIMES average of forty domestic issues touched 64.61, compared with the low mark for the year to date, 64.54, touched on Feb. 10.

Captain Yoshinori Nagoya, Japanese Army Air Service reserve pilot, was killed instantly yesterday at Floyd Bennett Field, at the start of a test flight in his new Bellanca monoplane, the Hochi Hinomaru. He had planned to make a non-stop flight across the Pacific.

All the lights were on last night in the Restaurant L'Aiglon, Inc., at 13 East Fifty-fifth Street. They bathed the rich red paneled walls, upstairs and down, and shone thinly on the white tablecloths. The whole place wore the solemn air of a chateau swiftly abandoned before a bombardment.

One of the best things about the change suddenly wrought in the temper of the House of Representatives is that it was due to the use of old-fashioned American means. During the gloomy interval of uncertainty, there was more or less talk of a resort to high-handed methods.

Refusing to enjoin the erection of a Jewish house of worship and school in a residential section of Great Neck, L.I., Supreme Court Justice Steinbrink in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that the meaning of the term "church" properly includes a school, gymnasium and social rooms when they are made an integral part of the religious edifice.
LONDON, March 29 -- All steamship lines in the North Atlantic service have agreed to cut passenger rates approximately 20 per cent beginning early in April, it became known tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- President and Mrs. Hoover entertained at dinner tonight in honor of General John J. Pershing, his sister, Miss Mae Pershing, and his son, Warren. At the dinner was a distinguished company including the Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. Mills, the Secretary of War and Mrs. Hurley, and General and Mrs. Charles G. Dawes.

HOUSTON, Texas, March 29 -- Ellsworth Vines Jr., national singles champion, was eliminated today by Martin Buxby, University of Texas star, in the second round of the annual Houston invitation tennis tournament. The score was 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The eleven amendments by which special excise taxes on manufactures, estimated to raise $158,500,000 in revenue, were voted by the Souse today, read as follows:

The importance of self-discipline and independent thinking in present-day education was emphasized yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in an address to the members of the Wells College Alumnae Association at a luncheon in Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 29 -- Francis T. Hunter, former Davis Cup tennis player and publisher of The White Plains Daily Press, broke his right leg above the knee and suffered lacerations of the head and left hand in an automobile accident on North Avenue here early this morning.

An exhibition of French prints (fifteenth century to the twentieth) from the private collection of George W. and Harriet B. Davison opens to the public today at the Museum of French Art. The private viewing for members of the French Institute was yesterday.

While carrying two children, from the second floor of a smoke-filled tenement at 38 Clay Street, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, endangered by a three-alarm fire in the New Kay Lumber Company's yard at 34-36 Clay Street, adjoining, Patrolman Lawrence Webster of the Meserole Avenue station was overcome early today.

Attributing the troubles of the railroads largely to uncontrolled and unregulated competition, of commercial trucks, buses and waterways, General W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, told the Economic club at its 100th dinner at the Hotel Astor, last night, that regulation of these competitive agencies is essential to the prosperity of the railroads and the restoration of the country's commercial equilibrium.

The responsibility of management for the regular operation of industry and for the continuation of employment has come to be recognized generally since the onset of the depression, speakers declared last night at a dinner of the American Statistical Association in London Terrace.

LONDON, March 29 -- Strength in sterling, which closed at $3.78, continued to stimulate British Government funds today. Otherwise the stock markets were characterized by a keen demand for new British debenture issues and weakness in international stocks.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 29 -- Miss Maureen Orcutt, Englewood (N.J.) star, played at top form today to beat Miss Anjeanette Hunter of Pittsburgh, 9 and 7, and serve notice that she is bent on retaining the North and South championship, which she won last year.

TRENTON, N.J., March 29 -- Municipal indebtedness should not become an obligation of the State, Governor Moore was told today by the committee of bankers recently appointed by him to suggest ways of providing local financial relief.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Vigorous condemnation of several features of the Glass banking bill was expressed this afternoon by the Federal Reserve Board and the board's advisory council, both of which characterized the measure as tending to contract credit and seriously interfere with business recovery.

WARSAW, March 29 -- The provi- sional trade agreement concluded be- tween Poland and Germany Saturday was described in a semi-official statement today merely as a mutual promise to change the "trading principles" now in force between the two countries and not as a formal written convention.

The Kreuger Toll Company, holding company of the interests of Ivar Kreuger, Swedish capitalist, who committed suicide recently in Paris, has declared itself unable to pay $137,479 due as commissions for the last quarterly period to its American agents.

MARK ROTH, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs of the Yankee Ball Club, was seated under a palm tree in St. Petersburg, Fla., one day last week. The rotund secretary looked up from the newspaper he had been scanning and said:

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Apprised of growing support in the House for passage of the pending bill providing full payment to World War veterans on their adjusted compensation certificates, President Hoover today warned advocates of the measure that by adding about $2,000,000,000 to the burden of the Treasury it would "undo every effort that is being made to reduce government expenditures and balance the budget" and would "irretrievably undermine" the credit of the government.

ALBANY, March 29 -- Although city and county offices are not affected by the Hewett civil service reclassification bill, Tammany Hall sent some prominent representatives to the Capitol today to oppose the measure at a public hearing before the Governor.
NORFOLK, Va., March 29 -- Sketches of the three Norfolk residents who are seeking to bring about the return of the Lindbergh baby follow:

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 29 -- The move to tie up the mines of the anthracite field in an effort to bring about equalization of work appeared near collapse today when operations were resumed in seven collieries, leaving only five idle in this region. In the lower field it was reported that all scheduled mines were operating.
The national epee team championship was won last night by the Fencers Club. Nine organizations were represented in the tournament held at the Twenty-third Street Y.M.C.A.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The speech of Speaker Garner in the House today was as follows:

ALBANY, March 29 -- An increase, effective April 1, of 25 per cent in commutation rates, and 20 per cent on school, family and round-trip tickets, on the New York Central Railroad in Westchester County was authorized today by the Public Service Commission.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 29 -- At the annual meeting of the Middle West Utilities Company here today Benjamin Mahler of New York charged the officers with mismanagement and cited that the corporation had invested huge sums in New England paper and textile mills, which were outside the utility field.

TRENTON, N.J., March 29 -- After referring to the judiciary committee a request of Governor Moore that he be permitted to withdraw the nomination for another term of Judge Arthur Gorman Gallagher of the Ocean County Common Pleas Court, the Senate adjourned for a week late today.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 29 -- The Robins today not only dropped the ball game to Indianapolis, 11 to 7, but lost temporarily the services of one at their leading offensive units, Frank (Lefty) O'Doul, left fielder.

Louis C. Widrig, treasurer of the Cincinnati National League Baseball Club, died at the Hotel Commodore yesterday of pneumonia, which developed during his convalescence from burns received in a fire in his hotel room last January. He had come to New York to attend the annual dinner of the Baseball Writers' Association.

On the eve of another application by the city to the Appellate Division, Brooklyn, for further stay of the injunction barring emergency bus operation in Manhattan and Queens, important changes in the proposed bus franchise contracts awaiting action by the Board of Estimate were urged yesterday by Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee.

The five countries in Central Europe which figure in the plans for a Danubian tariff union contain a population of sixty-five millions. It is not necessary to argue the benefit to the cause of stability in a distracted continent if a single economic unit of this size were set up in place of five separate and warring tariff areas.

A resolution providing that in the future all contributions made by the New York Telephone Company and its subsidiaries shall be deducted from the surplus and not, as heretofore, charged to operating expenses was introduced yesterday at the company's annual meeting by Paul Blanshard, a stockholder, who also is executive director of the City Affairs Committee.

The annual report of the Federal Water Service Corporation for 1931, giving effect to the recent developments placing control of the company in the hands of officers and other employes, shows consolidated net income of $1,937,461 for the year after charges, taxes and depreciation.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Government loans which serve to increase the farmer's surpluses and keep down his prices today drew the fire of Secretary Hyde.

Buyers' Registrations Increased. Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed an increase over the figures for the previous week and for the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
Net premium income of the General Exchange Insurance Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, in 1931 was $11,942,325, comparing with $9,753,824 in 1930.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, March 29. -- Overwhelmed in a sudden attack by Chinese irregulars today, 100 Japanese and Manchurian soldiers were killed or captured in trying to defend six motor trucks in which they had been speeding to the relief of besieged Nungan, thirty-three miles north of Changchun, the new Manchurian capital.

PARIS, March 29 -- The proposal to send a group of French war veterans to the United States this Summer to return the visit of the American Legion to France in 1927 is receiving considerable criticism in and out of Parliament.
BERLIN, March 29 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of March 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

The original manuscripts of Washington Irving's works relating to the Moorish conquest of Spain, together with the library of an Ohio collector and rare sporting books and prints consigned by various owners and estates, brought a total of $27,325.50 at an unrestricted auction sale last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 29 (AP) -- Four telegrams were received today at the office of Governor Laffoon protesting the ejection of college students from the Southeastern Kentucky coal fields. They were from the Cornell Liberal Club and Sage Philosophy Club, the John Reed Club of the University of North Carolina, the University of California Social Problems Club and the Liberal Student Society, Ann Arbor, Mich.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 29 -- Charges of an extensive and well-laid Communist plot for a revolution in Chile early this month are disclosed by the publication Ultimas Noticias in purported copies of secret communications from the Communist International at Moscow to the Communist centre of Latin-American operations at Montevideo.

LONDON, March 29 -- C.J. Mill, financial editor of The Times of London, commenting on today's movements of foreign exchange, holds that the fall of the dollar has been checked without -- so the market reports -- any official buying of the Bank of England.

PARIS, March 29 (AP) -- Filippo Turati, former Socialist Deputy in the Italian Parliament and leader of the political Italian emigres in Paris, died here last night of pneumonia. He was 74 years old. He had resided here since he was exiled five years ago.

BAYARD, Fla., March 29 -- Under the feather of 100 pounds, C.A. Grande's Morvich filly, Morden, won the Atlantic Coast Line purse, feature at St. Johns Park today. Running in front from the start of the five and one-half furlongs with Donald Meade up, Morden beat Everytime by a length.

Frank Lloyd Wright, architect, whose sixty-two years of life have been a long fight for the preservation of his "freedom" and "individuality," publishes his autobiography today. Persecution by those who could not understand him, he declares, caused most of his difficulties, and he could never have been left in peace unless he had remained obscure or had been, a "nonentity."

DAVENPORT, Iowa, March 29 (AP) -- The State Democratic convention today adopted a resolution brought in by the resolutions committee, pledging the national delegation to "use all honorable means to bring about the nomination of the New Yorker for President." It also instructed the delegates to vote as a unit on all questions.

The Spring migration of the seal herds from the south to the Pribilofs has begun, so Seattle reports. They are wards of the United States Government, Coast, Guard cutters convoying them to the breeding places. Canadian ships cooperate until Alaska is reached.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 -- Though a strong early attack, featuring homers by Combs and Saltzgaver and triples by Lary and Crosetti, put the Tanks seven-up on the visiting Cincinnati Reds, the score became tied later on and the Yanks had to win today's battle all over again.

In December, 1930, the prize of The Popular Science Monthly for current achievement in science of greatest benefit to the public was awarded jointly to Dr. GEORGE H. WHIPPLE and Dr. GEORGE R. MINOT. Their discovery was the value of liver in the treatment of pernicious anemia.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 29 -- Governor Wilbur L. Cross stirred the Democrats of Connecticut today by an appeal for harmony in the State to be achieved by dividing its votes at the Democratic National Convention equally between Franklin D. Roosevelt and Alfred E. Smith.

An order asking imprisonment for William J. Flynn, Bronx Public Works Commissioner who refused to answer questions before the Hofstadter legislative committee, was drawn by counsel for the committee yesterday afternoon and sent out for service upon Flynn's attorney.

SHANGHAI, March 29 -- Though the Chinese and Japanese armistice negotiators agreed on minor points at their conference this morning, prospects for settlement of the fundamentals continued to be gloomy.

An injunction wag granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Dore restraining Tiffany Productions, Inc., motion picture producers, from using the name "Tiffany" or any similar name or names as part of its corporate designation.

DETROIT, March 29 -- Mayor Frank Murphy, commenting today on the Detroit financial problems, said that although the city is faced with the prospect of refunding operations, to take up expected tax delinquencies of $18,000,000 in the 1932 fiscal year, Detroit has "never repudiated an obligation nor defaulted upon a debt -- and I do not believe it ever will."

BOSTON, March 29 -- A party of men and women motorists was rescued from seven-foot snowdrifts today near Pinkham Notch, in the heart of the White Mountains, while two Massachusetts men are believed to have been marooned on top of Mount Washington by yesterday's blizzard.

MANILA, March 29 -- Princess Tarhata, niece of the Sultan of Sulu, who has wielded extraordinary power in the Southern islands since her uncle's elevation to the Philippine Senate, has petitioned the British Government to transfer to Philippine jurisdiction certain large important islands of the South Seas, claiming previous documentary agreements with the Sultan to this effect.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 29 -- Mrs. George A. McKinlock was reelected president of the Garden Club of Palm Beach at the annual meeting today after a luncheon with which Mrs. Christopher D. Smithers entertained club members at Pelican Point, her Gulf Stream residence.

The International Nickel Company completed last year its $50,000,000 modernization program, which was started in 1924, without recourse to borrowing, Robert C. Stanley, president of the company, said yesterday in his annual message to stockholders.

Except that Federal funds were quoted at 1/4, compared with 1/2 on Monday, and unequalled since 1/8 was quoted last Summer, there was little else of interest in the day's money market. Stock Exchange call loans, maturity funds and business money were all unchanged in quotation.

Knights of Columbus throughout the United States and its possessions and Canada celebrated yesterday the golden anniversary of the founding of their order. New York's observance of the anniversary was featured by a radio address by Supreme Knight Martin H. Carmody from Station WEAF and broadcast over a nation-wide hook-up by the National Broadcasting System.

HIGH BRIDGE, N.J., March 29 -- The First National Bank of High Bridge, of which Percy Chrystie, who was found dead near his home here yesterday, was president, did not open for business today. Two notices were posted at the doors, one of which said that H.E. Stewart, national bank examiner, had assumed charge of the institution.

Metropolitan Transit District. Faced with the necessity of refunding on April 14 notes for $23,500,000, the Metropolitan Transit District of Massachusetts is expected to delay its plans until the Legislature of the Commonwealth has passed on the bill which would alter the name of the district and amend the laws governing the issuance of its securities, according to word received in municipal banking circles here yesterday.

With Mr. Stokowski confining his ministrations to the Philadelphia Opera for tomorrow night's premiere in that city of a ballet by Chavez, Fritz Reiner conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra in Carnegie Hall last night. It was the orchestra's ninth visit of the season to this city -- one more remains -- and it was Mr.Reiner's third with this orchestra.

NEW DELHI, India, March 29 -- Despite doubts and misgiving's among its members, there was little doubt today that the Chamber of Princes, now meeting here, would adopt a resolution pledging general support to the proposed all-India federation.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Ways and Means Committee's substitute plan for the defeated sales tax is in detail as follows:

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, March 29 (AP) -- Chinese irregulars, calling themselves the "anti-Japanese Army for the salvation of the country," were believed to have taken the town of Nungan, only thirty-five miles from here, today in a victorious march on Changchun.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, March 29 -- In their stormiest session in years, Iowa Democrats in convention today instructed their delegates to cast the State's twenty-six votes at the National Convention for Franklin D. Roosevelt for President, passed resolutions attacking the Republic tariff and the Farm Board, and favored submitting repeal or modification of the Eighteenth Amendment to State constitutional conventions.
HOLLYWOOD, March 29 (AP) -- Greta Nissen and Weldon Heyburn, both of the films, will fly to Tia Juana, Mexico, tomorrow to be married, they said tonight.

How the schools are training children to aid their parents in the present period of distress was discussed yesterday at closing sessions of the annual conference of the New York State Home Economics Association at the Hotel Roosevelt.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, March 29 -- The Colonial Council for the municipality of St. Thomas and St. John was thrown into an upheaval today as a result of the introduction of a long tax ordinance by Acting Governor Boyd Brown as a means of raising additional revenues to balance the budget, which has a deficit of $16,000.

MEXICO CITY, March 29 -- Another archaeological treasure has been unearthed in Mexico, following the wonderful find at Monte Alban, in the State of Oaxaca, and the discovery later of the ancient city of Tacupa in the State of Guerrero.
WINTER PARK, Fla., March 29 -- A new chapel and a new theatre, built simultaneously and connected by cloisters enclosing a chapel garden, were dedicated at Rolling College today.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Evidence that wealthy citizens of the ancient city of Seleucia dodged taxes more than 2,000 years ago was revealed today before 100 archaeologists attending the annual meeting of the American Oriental Institute at the University of Chicago.

The United States Lines yesterday prepared announcements to its agents throughout the country of reductions, averaging 20 per cent, in rates for the transatlantic liners Leviathan, President Harding and President Roosevelt. The statement will be forwarded today.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange was unusually active yesterday, and after frequent fluctuations over a range of nearly $1 a bale, the list closed 5 to 9 points lower than on Monday. The decline of more than a cent a pound in less than a month attracted professional short covering, while trade demand increased as July approached 6 1/4 cents.

General HANCOCK'S famous description of the tariff as a local issue was verified again in the House of Representatives Friday. The provision in the revenue bill for a tariff of a cent a gallon on imported gasoline, gas oil, fuel and crude petroleum was retained by a vote of nearly 2 to 1.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Buying of wheat futures today on the Board of Trade here was marked by a snap that had been absent for some time, and, while the market had a dip of around 7/8 cent, the close was at the top, with net gains of 3/8 to 7/8 cent.

The Washington National Bank of New York will be placed in voluntary liquidation in accordance with a resolution adopted by stockholders at a meeting held yesterday at the bank's offices, 385 Fifth Avenue. In view of the difficulties created by existing business conditions, a statement issued by the bank said it was considered advisable to liquidate the affairs of the bank rather than to continue to operate an unprofitable venture.

PORTLAND, Me., March 29 -- The sentiment of 1,000 delegates gathered here for the Democratic State Convention augurs an uninstructed delegation, with the majority favoring Governor Roosevelt. Roosevelt adherents worked all today to crystallize a support that would result in sending an instructed delegation to Chicago.

A sharp decline in retail failures to 375, as compared with 415 in the previous week, featured business defaults for the week ended March 24. according to Bradstreet's. Increases were registered in all of the other trade groups, particularly in the manufacturing classification, in which failures were 78, against 62 in the week before.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I congratulate you on your article dealing with my compatriot and namesake, the late Sir Horace Plunkett?

MINNEAPOLIS, March. 29 (AP) -- The biggest bank robbery in Minnesota's history today brought $50,000 in cash and about $150,000 in securities to seven robbers who enforced their commands with sub-machine guns, shotguns and pistols.

The "Theatre in Art" exhibition opened with an invitation showing yesterday at the Sidney Ross Gallery, 22 East Fifty-fifth Street. From today until April 17, the public will have an opportunity to see this absorbingly interesting group of pictures, all dealing with one aspect or another of the great amusement world.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The House of Representatives, which has been in revolt more than ten days against the non-partisan tax plan of the Ways and Means Committee, responded to a personal appeal from Speaker Garner today and buckled down soberly to the task of balancing the Federal budget.

Two girl sophomores from the University of Maine took the affirmative last night in the Casa Italiana at Amsterdam Avenue and 117th Street in a debate with two men undergraduates of Columbia University on the subject, "Resolved, that women should pay half the expenses of a date during the current depression."

The response of the stock market to yesterday's ending of chaos in the House at Washington was feeble on the whole; but United States bonds recovered most of their loss of the day before, and the foreign exchanges also reversed their movement of the preceding day.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The story of the trial and conviction of Al Capone, sentenced to eleven years in prison for income tax evasion, was told to a Senate judiciary subcommittee today by George E.Q. Johnson, United States District Attorney of Chicago.

Sharp declines yesterday in all securities of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Postal Telegraph and Cable Companies, coupled with news of a break in L.M. Ericsson Telephone stock in Stockholm, brought rumors of a selling of Kreuger Toll holdings in International Telephone and Telegraph which proved to be unfounded.

Partly as a step toward deciding the old controversy as to the effect of book prices on sales, Houghton Mifflin Company is offering a slight price range in the five murder mystery stories it will bring out this Spring. The books originally were listed at $2 but the publishers have marked down the two shorter ones to $1.75.

A two-cent "sales tax" on all rapid transit rides, to be collected by the companies and turned intact into the city treasury, is suggested by Professor Lindsay Rogers of Columbia University, in a memorandum filed with Mayor Walker yesterday, as a feasible method of relieving the drain upon the city budget and easing the tax burden upon real estate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from William Seaver Woods, editor of The Literary Digest, referring to my statement on that magazine's prohibition poll has just come to my attention. As always, Mr. Woods is generous in his personal reference and courteous in his statement.

Reports from Washington indicating that the Congressional insurgents were becoming more tractable in their consideration of the national tax problem helped to rally Wall Street's drooping spirits yesterday. There was a slow advance on the Stock Exchange in dull, colorless trading, the averages showing net gains of trifling size.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES account of the debate before the Drama Study Club a paragraph reads:

The stockholders of the Middle West Utilities Company, representing more than 75 per cent of its voting strength, approved yesterday in Wilmington, Del., an amendment to the certificate of incorporation modifying the pre-emptive rights of common stockholders.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- When Columbia, Yale and Pennsylvania row in the annual Blackwell Cup regatta May 7, the new Schuylkill River course above Flat Rock Dam will be used for the first time. This announcement was made today by Chairman C. Louis Borie 3d, of the Red and Blue rowing committee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from William Seaver Woods, editor of The Literary Digest, referring to my statement on that magazine's prohibition poll has just come to my attention. As always, Mr. Woods is generous in his personal reference and courteous in his statement.

Reports from Washington indicating that the Congressional insurgents were becoming more tractable in their consideration of the national tax problem helped to rally Wall Street's drooping spirits yesterday. There was a slow advance on the Stock Exchange in dull, colorless trading, the averages showing net gains of trifling size.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES account of the debate before the Drama Study Club a paragraph reads:

The stockholders of the Middle West Utilities Company, representing more than 75 per cent of its voting strength, approved yesterday in Wilmington, Del., an amendment to the certificate of incorporation modifying the pre-emptive rights of common stockholders.

Brown Brothers, Harriman Co. announced yesterday the conclusion of negotiations with the Argentine Government for taking care of the $10,000,000 of notes of the republic due here on April 1 and a like amount due on July 1. In addition $5,000,000 of notes of the government are held by American firms doing business in Buenos Aires.

The Russian Opera Foundation, which began its season Monday night with an indifferent presentation of Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Coq d'Or," followed this yesterday evening in Mecca Temple with an eloquent and highly effective performance of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff."
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- New reports in European capitals that the United States was likely to go off the gold standard are regarded here as propaganda against the dollar.

PARIS, March 29 -- Out of the discussion as to how the problem of Central Europe should be tackled there has risen in France a feeling of uneasiness regarding the possibility of an impending change in the foreign policy of Great Britain.

TEL-AVIV, Palestine, March 29 -- American Jews were prominent in the opening contests when the first Jewish Olympic Games, known as the Maccabiad, were formally inaugurated today. Ideal weather prevailed.

Crude oil production in the United States averaged 2,163,050 barrels daily last week, or 5,850 above the average of 2,157,200 barrels in the preceding week. The figures represent the weekly estimates of the American Petroleum Institute. Production east of California averaged 1,670,950 barrels compared with 1,649,200, an increase of 21,700.

Many aspects of ancient and modern art will be discussed at the twenty-first annual meeting of the College Art Association, which will open a three-day program at 9:30 o'clock this morning at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hnll, held an informal press conference here today. Stopping in Washington on his return from Florida, he insisted there was no political significance in his visit. He was just dropping in on "a lot of old friends," political as well as personal, he said.

LONDON. March 30. -- The stock market brightened today, partly because of encouraging news from Washington that the United States budget would be balanced. British Government funds declined slightly on profit-taking, but the international stocks recovered from the past few days' weakness.
College baseball in the metropolitan district got under way yesterday when Columbia defeated City College, 4 to 3, in a ten-inning combat at Lewisohn Stadium.

Thomas Carlyle is regarded as perhaps the greatest and bitterest critic of the steam engine who has put pen to paper. Writing in 1843, he painted a terrifying picture of the smoke-stained and fume-withered nineteenth century in contrast with the clear, simple and sunny twelfth.

There was probably never a serious expectation that the Glass bill's amendments to the Federal Reserve law would pass Congress it the form proposed. If there had been a chance of such action, it is apparently ended by the judgment on the bill submitted to the Senate committee by the Reserve Board and the Reserve System's advisory council.
ALBANY, March 30. -- Following is Governor Roosevelt's letter to Dr. John Haynes Holmes and Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, conveying his refusal to oust Sheriff McQuade:

Miss Harriet Russell of 3,706 Dyre Avenue, the Bronx, former teacher at exclusive girls' schools of the East, whose police record dates back to her expulsion from Wellesley College in 1909, was arrested again yesterday at her home on a charge of having forged the name of Mrs. Sarah Maitland, society woman, of Lawrence, L.I., to three checks drawn on the Peninsula National Bank of Cedarhurst.

H.H. Broach, president of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers of Washington, D.C., and the chief officers of Local 3, of which Frank Wilson is president, were enjoined temporarily yesterday from "further persecuting" fifteen members of the local union In an order signed by Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck.
Sales and leases announced yesterday indicated a mild demand for housing properties in Manhattan. Investors bought multifamily buildings, several of which were in Harlem.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 30. -- Clarence (Buster) Crabbe of the Los Angeles A.C. performed brilliantly as the national senior A.A.U. swimming championships opened in Carnegie Pool at Yale today, shattering his own American record of 20:06 1/2 for the 1,500-meter swim with a mark of 19:45 3-5 to capture the event from a field of eleven other starters.

BAYARD, Fla., March 30. -- Genial Host and Bo Ballot accounted for doubles at St. Johns Park today for Owner William Duffy, Trainer Willie Shea and Jockey V. Arthur. Genial Host, a 9-year-old son of Granite and Kathryn Kruter, captured the featured Chamber of Commerce purse, while Bo Ballot was first in the sixth race.

Albert Poensgen of Germany, who is defending his crown as world's amateur champion at 18.2 balkline billiards in the tournament at the Elks Club, hurdled one of his two remaining obstacles yesterday when he defeated Francis S. Appleby, former American champion, 400 to 328, to keep his lead in the title play.

Vladimir Horowitz, pianist; Nathan Milstein, violinist, and Gregory Piatigorsky, 'cellist, last night united their talents for the benefit of the unemployed musicians in their first public chamber music concert which took place -- after a twenty-five-minute delay -- in Carnegie Hall before a capacity house.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 30. -- Spurred to action under the inspiring influence of a bristling pep talk by John J. McGraw, the Giants turned on the Mission Club today and won a game more in keeping with the style of baseball to which the venerable New York pilot is accustomed.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 30 (AP). -- Little Jeff, entered by the Thorndale Stable of Mrs. L.B. Smith and Mrs. Langdon Thorne of New York, was adjudged the champion hunter today, in the second and final day of the annual Pinehurst horse show.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 30. -- Major and Mrs. Elisha Dyer Hubbard entertained with a large dinner tonight at their villa. They will depart on April 12 for Lone Tree Farm near Middletown, Conn.

ALBANY, March 30. -- Governor Roosevelt today "peremptorily denied" a demand for the removal of Sheriff James A. McQuade, Kings County, on charges submitted to him on March 25 by the City Affairs Committee of New York.

LONDON, March 30 (AP). -- Confidence in the American financial situation was expressed today by one of the highest financial authorities in Great Britain, who would not permit his name to be used. He said it was inconceivable that the dollar should go off the gold standard.

The new house of detention for women, at Sixth Avenue and Tenth Street, formally opened for inspection this week, is the latest word in prison construction. The fact that it is a skyscraper is not so significant as the character of the building itself, together with the imagination and scrupulous care for details that went into its planning.

HOUSTON, Texas, March 30. -- George Lott of Chicago, seeded No. 2, was eliminated today from the second annual Houston invitation tennis tournament by Karl Kamrath of Texas University, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5.

"Although the underlying motive of the program launched by the General Motors Corporation in connection with the national exhibit of its products is to increase sales, the plan was conceived and has been developed as a direct and aggressive attack upon existing psychology," said Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the corporation, in an interview here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- More than 3,000,000 of the foreign-born white population of the United States, or 23 per cent, gave English or Celtic as their mother tongue in the Federal census, while more than 2,000,000, or 16 per cent, returned German and more than 1,000,000 one or another of the Scandinavian tongues.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Studies in the preparation of a bill for the establishment of a unified system of banking under national supervision, as suggested to the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency by Eugene Meyer, Governor of the Federal Reserve Board, will start at once.

PARIS, March 30, -- News of Speaker Garner's victory in Washington on the tax bill strengthened the dollar today. The dollar's rise from 25.37 to 25.43 1/2 was accompanied by a drop in sterling which had improved yesterday.
NEW YORK. The Marchese and Marchesa Nicolo Antinori gave a luncheon yesterday at the Pierre for their cousin, Miss Symphorosa Bristed.

PANAMA CITY, March 30. -- The Doctrinal Liberals have been accused of an attempt to assassinate Antonio Anguizola, a Chiarista leader in the Province of Chiriqui, last night, according to El Diario tonight.

MOSCOW, March 30. -- A gigantic new reservoir of military strength for national defense will be created here if plans for reorganization of Osoaviakhim, the Soviet air league, outlined by the army newspaper the Red Star, are successfully carried out.

Neither on the stock market nor on the bond market was there any sign of particular initiative yesterday, to reflect the brighter political horizon. The general trend was better, but in stocks the recovery, although general, was relatively slight, and in bonds the familiar conflict of movement was presented.

TORONTO, March 30 (Canadian Press). -- Ice, jammed into the "bottlenecks" of the St. Glair and St. Mary's Rivers, is holding up what might have been the earliest start of navigation for many years on the Great Lakes. "With the official opening set for April 15, ice at Sault Ste.
DETROIT, Mich., March 30. -- When the price list was given out Henry Ford said:
JOHANNESBURG, March 30. -- The great De Beers mines at Kimberley will be closed tomorrow, as forecast last month, and with this the main diamond industry of South Africa will come to a standstill.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents on the common stock and the regular quarterly dividend of 87 1/2 cents on the preferred stock, both payable on April 30 to stock of record of April 11.

In a letter sent to stockholders of the International Business Machines Corporation, Thomas J. Watson, president, replied yesterday to the anti-trust suit brought against the company by the Department of Justice last Saturday. Mr. Watson denied that the company's cross licensing agreements were made for the purpose of eliminating competition.

John H. Curtis, Norfolk shipbuilder, who is seeking to recover the Lindbergh baby, revealed yesterday that the mysterious week-end flight on which he is supposed to have made contact with an agent of the kidnappers took him to the Philadelphia Navy Yard.

In the present discontents Progressive thought and speech are even more than usually rich and helpful. Governor PINCHOT, the tengallon hat bestowed upon him by former Governor PAT NEFF of Texas still vainly held out for Federal alms, appeared as sponsor by the side of General SMEDLEY D. BUTLER, beginning his campaign for the Republican nomination for Senator.

The "Five and Ten" Law. The Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives has voted to kill a proposal to repeal the Jones law. This is the drastic prohibition measure which provides maximum penalties of five years' imprisonment and $10,000 fine for violation of the Volstead act.

The Russian Opera Foundation, which, last season introduced Moussorgaky's "Khovantchina" to the New York public, repeated that opera as the third performance of its present season last night in Mecca Temple.

Giulio Gatti-Casazza marked up a forty-eighth title in his New York season's repertory by restating Giordano's "Andrea Chenier" before a large subscription audience at the opera last night. This total of varied and arduous productions was itself extraordinary, though it lacked one of equaling Mr. Gatti's top record when forty-nine works were sung a few seasons ago.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- An increase in the first-class postage rate from 2 to 3 cents led a list of twelve tax items voted by the House today in its effort to balance the budget in the fiscal year 1933. The rise would go into effect thirty days after enactment of the tax bill and terminate July 1, 1934.

"We Are No Longer Children," adapted by Ilka Chase and William B. Murray from the French of Leopold Marchand, will be presented at the Booth Theatre tonight by William A. Brady Jr. Geoffrey Kerr and June Walker will head the cast.

The Board of Transportation plans to ask the Board of Estimate within the next week or two for a substantial appropriation for municipal operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway line, it was disclosed yesterday. Plans for an operating force have been virtually completed and an estimate of operating costs, on the tentative assumption that revenue traffic will begin on July 1, is nearing completion.

Guy Pene du Bois, whose exhibition of paintings and drawings is current at the Kraushaar Gallery until April 19, has mastered his craft. Yes, it is pretty safe to call him a master and to add that there isn't a better artist working hereabout today. His draftsmanship, to put it coldly, commands instant and unlimited respect.

Professor LINDSAY ROGERS of Columbia has long been a student of subway finance; he is the author of several monographs which have been helpful to an understanding of that highly intricate subject. His ingenious scheme to tax the subway rider two cents, instead of raising the fare by that amount, has much to commend it to a community unwilling to face the realities more directly.

Opposition to the proposed Federal taxes on motor vehicle products was expressed yesterday by officials of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, who declared that if the measure was passed by the House the fight would be carried to the Senate.

Floyd B. Odium, president of the Atlas Utilities Corporation, was elected yesterday a director of both the Reliance International Corporation and the Reliance Management Corporation. This action was interpreted in the financial community as marking a harmonious conclusion of the proloneed difficulties the directors of the two Reliance companies have encountered since it was announced that International had acquired control of Reliance Management, substantially reversing their former relations.

Trading in stocks and bonds on the Curb Exchange was confined chiefly yesterday to public utilities. The volume of sales was small and price movements were irregular. German issues held most attention in the foreign bond group.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 30. -- Two rum-running boats heavily laden with liquor were seized close to the Rhode Island shore by Coast Guard patrol ships last night and brought to Base 4 headquarters at State Pier here early today.

A further rally in United States Government securities and irregularly lower prices on domestic corporation issues and foreign loans characterized dealing's in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Although the decline in domestic corporation bonds was far less severe than it has been on many days recently, THE NEW YORK TIMES average of forty domestic issues touched a new low for the year, breaking through the previous low level, established on Feb. 10.

MADISON, Wis., March 30 (AP). -- The University of Wisconsin's three-month, quest for a head football coach ended today when Dr. Clarence Spears, coach at the University of Oregon, accepted a year's contract.

With the championship of the National Hockey League in their possession, by virtue of their first-place play-off victory over the Canadiens of Montreal, the New York Hangers are confidently awaiting the call to battle for the Stanley Cup, the symbol of the hockey championship of the world.

Around a throbbing theme Annie Nathan Meyer has written an unfortunately inept play in "Black Souls," which stopped at the Provincetown Playhouse last night and looked into the matter of the color line and kindred dark subjects. Its ineptness was the more unfortunate because Mrs. Meyer, setting her play in the heart of the conflict, had obviously been at pains to inscribe an honest record and to ask a number of significant questions.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 30. -- Despite an early lead, the Naval Academy baseball team lost its opening game of the season today to Vermont, 9 to 8.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- A proposal of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad to put its stock holdings in the Western Maryland Railroad in trust with the Chase National Bank of New York, was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The commission in January, 1930, found the Baltimore Ohio's possession of control of the Western Maryland to be in violation of the Clayton act, and ordered it to divest.
ALBANY, March 30. -- Working to dispose of all the thirty-day bills this week. Governor Roosevelt announced today that he had signed forty-three measures and vetoed forty-six.

PARIS, March 30. -- Representatives of American business in France today played their last and most important card in trying to save their country's exports from the French quota system, which they say threatens virtually to kill American trade with France.

TIJUANA, Mexico, March 30 (AP). -- Greta Nissen and Weldon Heyburn, film players, flew here from Hollywood and were married late today in a civil ceremony read by Judge Riccardo Gibert of the Mexican Civil Court, in the bridal suite at a hotel.

The debts that statesmanship and diplomacy owe to the fundamental principles of advertising were discussed by Dr. Richard A. von Kuhlmann, former German Foreign Minister, at a luncheon of the Advertising Club in his honor yesterday. He laid the degree of success which Hitler's movement has attained in Germany to the Nazi leader's appreciation of the importance of the human voice as the best advertising medium.

Changes in the capital structure of the Kelly-Springfield Tire Company were proposed yesterday by William H. Lalley, president, in a plan submitted to the stockholders. A committee has been working on the plan several months. The primary purpose is to eliminate a deficit of $9,676,761 and patent and good will items of $7,254,021.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Crop reports are rapidly becoming a dominating influence in shaping the trend of the wheat market on the Board of Trade here. Numerous official and private returns from Western Kansas and Nebraska were received today suggesting that heavy losses would result from dust storms that have prevailed for several days.

Returns to date indicate that the net operating income of all railroads was nearly double in February what it was in January, although gross revenues decreased about 2.8 per cent. The returns indicate that net operating income in February was about $22,100,000 against $11,713,613 in January, an increase of 89.8 per cent, $27,264,469 in February, 1931, a decline of 18.9 per cent, and $59,580,894 in February, 1930, a drop of 62.9 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The first cheerful news to American farmers in a long time was provided in an announcement by the Department of Agriculture today that the general level of farm prices had shown an upward trend for the first time in nine months.

ALBANY, March 30 -- The New York Telephone Company today was directed by the Public Service Commission to eliminate all its gifts to charity from operating expenses and charge them against corporate surplus.

The bribery case against Rollin C. Bastress, former chief inspector of the Manhattan Building Bureau, and John I. Cahalan, a construction superintendent, will go to the jury today. They are accused of accepting $1,500 in 1927 from a builder for Bastress's official approval of revised plans for a penthouse atop 280 Madison Avenue.

A penitentiary term of not more than three years was imposed by Judge Levine in General Sessions yesterday on Maurice Lewnosky, 34 years old, of 1,369 Rosedale Avenue, the Bronx, for defrauding the allmony fund of the Manhattan Family Court of $7,200 about two years ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To New Yorkers Colonel William A. Starrett, who died yesterday, is doubtless chiefly known as tha man who put up the Empire State Building and many other great hives of human beings in this particular spot of the Western World.

New York State borrowed $50,000,000 in Wall Street yesterday through the sale of an issue of notes, dated April 1, 1932, and due on Jan. 15, 1933, at the record low rate on a State or municipal loan of this magnitude in the current market of 3 1/2 per cent.

SHANGHAI, March 30. -- Eugene Chen, three times Foreign Minister of China, said today that a report was circulating in inner Chinese political circles to the effect that Chiang Kai-shek, head of the Nationalist Government, would permit Japan to validate her position in Manchuria.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Importers of Soviet Russian anthracite asked the treasury today in a hearing before Assistant Secretary Lowman not to place restrictions on importation of this product.

Mr. NEWTON D. BAKER has just proposed to amend the Constitution of the United States so that treaties would be ratified by a majority of both houses of Congress instead of requiring two-thirds of the Senate. It is hard at this time to greet with delight any man bearing another amendment in his hands, yet it must be said that Mr. BAKER has at least the justification of impatience with the ways of the Senate.

DUBLIN, March 30. -- Dispatching of the Free State's reply to the British Government was delayed today by an unexpected Cabinet hitch. It was learned that the draft prepared by President de Valera had not been approved in its entirety, and a special meeting of the Executive Council will be necessary tomorrow.

WARSAW, March 30 (AP). -- Government by Presidential decree was inaugurated, for Poland today in a conference between President Moscicki and all the nation's Premiers since Marshal Pilsudski came into power.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 30. -- Semi-final brackets in the women's national indoor tennis championship were gained by two non-seeded players as the result of today's fourth-round matches at the Longwood covered courts.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Howard M. Sims, agent of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today practical elimination of bank failures in Northern Illinois and Indiana, all of Iowa and Southern Wisconsin has been the effect of activities of the corporation's advisory committee for the area.

RYE, N.Y., March 30. -- Mamaroneck High won the first championship of the Westchester High School Hockey League by defeating the Scarsdale High, 5 to 1, at Playland today. The superiority of the Mamaroneck players was manifest from the start, excelling as they did in stick-work and team-work.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, March 30. -- Six persons were killed and forty were severely injured when an apartment house was destroyed by a fire caused by a film explosion in the offices of the Star Film Company late last night.

The United States is still suffering from a case of "nerves" and the rest of the world is "looking earnestly" for a revival of confidence here, according to Sir Josiah Stamp, British economist and head of the London, Midland Scottish Railways, who arrived yesterday on the White Star liner Majestic.

Louis Taubman, 29 years old, who was known to the underworld as "The Dove" and used the name Louis Tobin when arrested recently in St. Petersburg, Fla., pleaded guilty before Judge Corrigan in General Sessions yesterday to an indictment accusing him of willfully disobeying a subpoena issued for him more than a year ago for questioning before Samuel Seabury as referee in the Appellate Division investigation of the magistrates' courts.
PITTSBURGH, March 30 (AP). -- There will be no pay cuts for the arbiters of college football games under the jurisdiction of the Eastern Intercollegiate Association next season.

Although the number of transactions over the company's counters was the largest in its history, Gimbel Brothers, Inc., showed a net operating loss, after depreciation and interest, of $1,763,253 in the year ended on Jan. 31. This contrasted with a net profit of $145,607, or 84 cents a share on 173,000 shares of preferred stock, in the preceding fiscal year.

NEW ORLEANS, March 30. -- Science generally and the chemical industry In particular is working as never before to lift business out of the depression, said Dr. E.B. Weidlein, director of the Mellon Institute for Industrial Research, tonight at the closing session of the American Chemical Society meeting here.

With the last preliminary completed through the enforced default of the Manhattan Polo Club to Los Nanduces in Class B last night, the tournament committee of the Indoor Polo Association of America has announced the opening contests and points of play for the start of the national championships on Saturday night.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Appointment of a receiver for Thaull Utility 1nvestments Inc., and dissolution of the trust is asked in a bill filed today in the Cook County Circuit Court on behalf of Mrs. Helen Samuels of Chicago owner of four of the cornpany's $1.000 debenture notcs.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Government officials and representatives of organized labor from all parts of the country attended the funeral service held here today for Charles P. Ford, president of the International Executive Council of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

American sports, led by football, baseball and boxing, figure to contribute close to $10,000,000 toward balancing the 1932 national, budget, under the provisions of the bill adopted by the House yesterday for a 10 per cent tax on all athletic admissions over 46 cents.

Mayor Walker let it be known yesterday that he stood ready to appear before the Hofstadter legislative committee to give its counsel, Samuel Seabury, full opportunity to question aim regarding the affairs of the City Administration, but that he would refuse to be questioned by Mr. Seabury in private.

Although, the New York Stock Exchange's new rule requiring brokers to obtain a "separate authorization" from each customer for the lending of stock to the short interest will not become effective until tomorrow, withdrawals of stocks from the Exchange's loan crowd yesterday by brokers anticipating the imposition of the rule resulted in a sharp increase in the lending rates on stocks.

With the exception of one scene all the action of "Bloodstream," which was acted at the Times Square last evening, takes place in the bottom of of a coal mine. It is a vivid setting for a phantasmagoria of horror. In his scene designs Jo Mielziner has given it visually a sense of monstrous, shadowy terror and of ghoulish imprisonment that presses in from all sides.

MONTREAL, March 30. -- The Maroons are accorded an even chance of defeating the Maple Leafs in the play-off opening here tomorrow night. The optimism of local followers is based on the Maroons' showing against the Detroit Falcons last night.

Low Sheet Prices Reported. The slackening in demand for sheets and pillow cases, although more or less seasonal, has again Drought forth a certain amount of trading on the cheaper goods and some low prices have been heard in the market recently.

Lloyd Byrn, 48 years old, cashier of the Brooklyn Savings Bank, Pierrepont and Clinton Streets, where he started his career twenty-eight years ago as a messenger, was held in $20,000 bail yesterday on a grand larceny charge after State bank examiners had disclosed a shortage of $30,608.

Towed down from City Island early yesterday morning, the American team of four Interclub class racing yachts which will compete in Bermuda in a five-race series with the Bermuda one-design craft starting on Monday, were hoisted on the deck of the liner Monarch of Bermuda, which sailed yesterday afternoon.

There was a greater stability about the price trend in commodities yesterday, the recent heaviness being succeeded by general improvement. The grains, cotton, sugar, coffee, cocoa, silk registering good-size gains, while rubber and hides were firm. Steadiness prevailed in other staples.

The new tax plan proposed in Congress is designed to raise $990,000,000 in additional revenue. The deficit now indicated for next year is $1,738,000,000. Between these figures there is a gap of $748,000,000. How can it be said that the budget will be "balanced"?

Negotiations have been completed between the Rockefeller interests and a group of leaders in French commercial and art circles for the erection in Rockefeller Centre of a building to be known as La Maison Frangaise, the Metropolitan Square Corporation announced yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30. -- The Florida baseball schedule of the Yankees closed today with a game against the House of David team of Benton Harbor, Mich. The contest proved to be one of the snappiest and best played games in which the Yanks have appeared so far this year, the major leaguers winning, 2-0.

CAIRO, March 30. -- The ruins of a Roman city have been unearthed in the Libyan Desert, fifty miles northwest of El-Bahariya Oasis, by Dr. Herman Junker, head of the German Oriental Institute at Cairo. Dr. Junker believes the city served as a base for a military garrison during the time of the Romans, the soldiers being stationed there to protect the western frontier.

The establishment of a department of art in the Federal Government was urged last night by John Sloan, president of the Society of Independent Artists and president of he Art Students' League, in an address at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 30. -- Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City and Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., favorites to meet in the final, easily won their second-round matches to gain the semi-finals in the women's North and South golf tournament today.

TORONTO, Ont., March 31 (Canadian PressX --The Toronto Mail and Empire says today that it has learned from an official source that plans for mergers among important Canadian newsprint manufacturing companies are near completion.

CHANGCHUN, March 30 (AP). -- Japanese military forces and the provincial troops of Governor Hsi Hsia continue their efforts to put down the revolt in Western Kirin Province, which has threatened Changchun itself.

STEVENS POINT, Wis., March. 30 (AP). -- Mme. Ernestine Schumann-Heink, opera and concert singer, is in a hospital here, suffering from bronchitis and laryngitis. Fearing pneumonia might develop, physicians ordered complete rest and quiet.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Among the tourists now visiting Washington to look at Congress and the cherry blossoms is Godfrey G. Gloom, an old-fashioned Jeffersonian Democrat from Amity, Ind., who was encountered this afternoon by a reporter outside the House of Representatives gallery.

DUBLIN, March 30. -- President Eamon de Valera and his new Irish Free State Cabinet, after having prepared a reply to the British Government's declaration that the oath of allegiance and the land annuities were integral parts of the agreement between Great Britain and Ireland, commenced a revision of the entire reply today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a patriotic American, Congressman La Guardia gives me a pain. I know of no man in public life who is more antagonistic to the spirit upon which this country was founded and developed. If his ideas prevail, there will be no longer an incentive for hard work and intelligent enterprise.

Championship teams of the Catholic youths' organization of Chicago conquered their New York City rivals, the St. Nicholas of Tolentine juniors and seniors of the Fordham Juvenile League, in intercity basketball games at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.

William C. Harrison of Scarsdale, N.Y., vice president of the Oxweld Acetylene Company and Eastern manager of the Linde Air Products, subsidiaries of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, died yesterday afternoon in the Presbyterian Hospital after a three months' illness of blood infection that seven physicians failed to arrest.

LONDON, March 30 (AP). -- One of the British expeditions which will investigate polar mysteries in Canada during the second international polar year will concentrate on a theory that the aurora borealis is caused by rays from the sun which have been stopped by the so-called "heaviside layer."

The Lewis Carroll exhibition prepared by Columbia University in honor of the 100th anniversary of the author's birth, and said to be the most complete showing of his works ever arranged, will be opened this afternoon for a private showing in Avery Library, Columbia University, from 2 to 6 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars, through National Commander Darold D. Decoe, today invited President Hoover to appoint a personal representative to debate the question whether or not the bonus amounting to $2,500,000,000 should be immediately paid to ex-service men, 1,000,000 of whom are reported by the veterans' association to be in destitute condition.
NEW DELHI, March 30. -- India's princes have reaffirmed their support of the all-India federation, which they were among the first to give in principle at the London round table conference.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The Shipping Board approved three conference agreements today as follows:

VIENNA, March 30. -- Jan Kubelik, celebrated violinist, brought his financial difficulties into bankruptcy court today, placing his liabilities at $125,000 and offering to pay his creditors 35 per cent.

LONDON, March 30. -- The London Times in an editorial tomorrow will take a much more optimistic view of the United States Government finances than has been suggested by its own news despatches from Washington in the last few days. After reviewing the recent Congress situation and the defeat of the sales tax measure, the paper will say:

The weak voices of the phonographs of 1918 and 1925 vied unsuccessfully yesterday with the ponderous tones generated from a tiny record twelve inches in diameter, recorded electrically in 1932 from one of New York's huge theatre organs and played before 1,000 luncheon guests in the ballroom of the Hotel Astor in a demonstration designed to show the progress made in the past decade in sound recording and reproduction by electrical means.
PORTLAND, Me., March 30. -- Maine's delegation of twelve to the Democratic National Convention will go instructed to vote for Governor Roosevelt under the unit rule.

The money market was lifeless. While offerings of Stock Exchange funds were in good volume, virtually little was taken at the quoted figure of 2% per cent, but in the Street trading at 2 about $500,000 was placed. Federal funds were 1/4@1/2. Time money ruled 2 3/4@3 per cent, business being small.

HAVANA, March 30. -- At midnight, tonight all the Cuban sugar mills that have ground or exceeded their quotas stipulated by the Presidential decree promulgated Saturday will cease grinding, it being optional with those mills that have not completed their allotments to continue until their quotas have been fully made up.

BERLIN, March 30.-With the announcement of Premier Tardieu of France that he will not stay in London for the conference on the Danube question, the impression here is that this four-power meeting, which is greatly welcomed in German political circles as a British counter-move against the alleged desire of France to exclude Germany from the organization of the Danube nations, has lost much of its significance.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The following amendments to the tax bill, which were estimated to produce $293,500,000 in additional revenue for the fiscal year 1933. were adopted by the House today:
LIMA, Peru, March 30. -- Congress returned to its task of rewriting the Constitution today, while the government called for plans and specifications for 4,000 new public schools.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Government operation of many railroads, as a result of the loan policies of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was predicted today by Senator Couzens in a Senate speech. The alternative will be large losses to the corporation, he said.

Presiding Justice Edward Lazansky of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn signed an order yesterday setting Monday for a hearing on the city's application for an extension until July 1 of the stay which would expire tomorrow and under which emergency bus operation in Manhattan and Queens is protected from a Supreme Court injunction issued nearly two years ago.

The alternative of "getting out of the Western Pacific and turning our commercial Interests over to Japan" or "taking a militant stand to prepare for the inevitable conflict" must be faced by the United States in the Far East, Admiral Henry A. Wiley, former commander of the fleet, declared yesterday in an address before members of the Young Men's Board of Trade at a luncheon in the Hotel New Yorker.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 30. -- The legislative committee named to consider economies in the State Government met here today to organize and map out the line of its investigation and, after naming Senator Charles J. Hewitt. Republican, of Locke, as chairman, decided to begin work at Albany April 13.
