WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Although Governor Ropsevelt tonight has pledges of votes representing something less than one-sixth of the two-thirds (770) which he will require to be nominated for the Presidency, influential Democratic leaders here, with few exceptions, have concluded that he will be named on an early ballot.

The Elliott five rolled a 2,221 total to feature the bowling yesterday in the eleventh annual tournament for the women's bowling championship of Greater New York on Thum's Alleys. The score enabled the Elliott team to take first place in the standing.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- An investigation of what Senator Glass called a "night school," at which bankers "were coached in organized propaganda" against his banking bill, will be undertaken by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, the Virginia Senator announced this afternoon.

LONDON, March 30. -- When Premier Tardieu of France meets Prime Minister MacDonald and Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, at luncheon here Monday it is probable the wide range of the conversation will include the question of the Lausanne reparations conference in June, disarmament and possibly the long-delayed settlement of the naval dispute between France and Italy.

THE wicked Canadiens have ceased from troubling and the weary Rangers are at rest temporarily. One more frozen river to cross and the Stanley Cup will be back in town. That's the program if the Rangers can put it on ice.

The new Ford eight-cylinder automobile will go on public display in New York and throughout the country this morning, and the prices announced for it last night keep it definitely in the lowest price field. The majority of the models are only from $10 to $25 higher in price than the corresponding models in the now retired Model A four-cylinder line.

Without exhibiting any enthusiasm, Wall Street seemed more cheerful yesterday and the stock market made some progress toward recovery. Trading was of limited volume, but prices worked higher in a plodding fashion. Since the weakness of the recent past had been ascribed to the tax tangle in Washington, it followed logically that the rallying tendencies should be traced to the brighter prospect of an early agreement in the House on the revenue measure.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 30. -- Cornelius E. Hourigan, 45 years old, of 318 East Eighty-fifth Street, New York, captain of a coal barge, was burned to death at his post in the Hudson River off this village today while the crew of tugboat W.N. Bavier of Roundout, N.Y., extinguished a fire which threatened the barge.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am riled by that editorial "Again the War Debts" in today's issue. The editorial writer says -- and not for the first time -- that we didn't reduce the debts, because the "reduced debts," plus interest for sixty-two years, is more than twice the original obligation.

PARIS, March 30. -- The French Line opposes further reductions in transatlantic passenger fares which are being urged by the United States Lines at the North Atlantic conference subcommittee meeting now going on in Brussels, it was revealed in shipping circles here today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At the outset of what would seem to be developing into a very interesting campaign for tax relief in New York, two groups have already set themselves up with conflicting ideas. One group, led by real estate boards whose membership is largely made up of real estate brokers, advocates moderation and deprecates the tax strike suggested by the other group, composed largely of actual property owners.

Weird conceptions of life, still and active, from angels to speakeasies, in oil, water-colors, pen and ink, embroidiery, plaster, bronze and shoe polish were hung on the walls and grouped in various rooms on the fourth floor of Grand Central Palace yesterday in preparation for the annual show of the Society of Independent Artists.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 30 (AP). -- The Rhode Island Reds earned the right to face the Boston Bruin Cubs in the final aeries for the Canadian-American Hockey League championship when they downed the Bronx Tigers, 4 to 1, before 4,000 tonight.

Asserting that he had never seen or heard an estimate of the number of speakeasies in New York City which was within 20,000 of the correct figure, Police Commissioner Mulrooney declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Bond Club of New York at the Bankers Club that the actual number would surprise most persons.

Miss Audrey Watts, a debutante of this season, gave a tea yesterday at the Plaza for some of those interested in the Floating University, which is to leave next Autumn on a world cruise. Miss Watts appointed her committee for the entertainment of prospective students prior to their departure.

PRAGUE, March 30. -- The critical condition of Czechoslovakia's industry has caused a strike of 30,000 of the country's 83,000 coal miners, following a decision of the mine owners to dismiss 12,000 men. Clashes of strikers and police in which shots were fired and a number on both sides wounded were followed by stormy debates in Parliament tonight.

LONDON, March 30. -- One of the world's coolest stowaways is returning to the United States this week after having seen the sights of London from the inside of a prison to the outside of Buckingham Palace.

Leases of space for business purposes in buildings in widely scatered sections of Manhattan were announced yesterday. The Uddeholm Company of America, representative in this country of Uddeholm A-B, iron and steel works of Sweden, leased space in 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

Rapid progress was made yesterday in the campaign to "stamp out want" as the Block-Aid organization work expanded and the number of contributions increased to 72,400. Gifts of 10 cents to $1 a week for twenty weeks are being solicited in behalf of thousands of families who are in need due to unemployment.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange was active yesterday and following the decline of more than a cent a pound in the last month, the market steadied under increased trade and speculative buying. Resistance that had developed on Tuesday, when the July approached 614 cents, encouraged short covering, and the list closed at the top at gains of 19 to 22 points.

The cradle of contract bridge was rocked by sixteen hands yesterday, most of them trick hands. They were printed on a neat white folder captioned "World Bridge Olympic Hands -- For Game Captains Only," and presented, to the reader the layout of the hands which will confront 50,000 -- maybe 75,000 -- bridge players in the four corners of the earth at exactly 8:01 P.M. tomorrow.

Touching a switch on a platform 725 feet below the street level, shortly after noon yesterday in the presence of more than 100 city officials, Mayor Walker set off a charge of dynamite that blasted through the remaining twenty feet of rock 4,000 feet away at the northern end of the new twenty-mile city water tunnel No. 2, completing the "holing through" from end to end.
Member lines of the Transatlantic Steamship Conference announced yesterday new rate schedules which brought travel costs down to prewar levels.

BERLIN, March 30 (AP). -- Through a vast system of public works, more than three-fourths of which will be revenue-producing. Germany hopes, with the seasonal demand for labor this Spring, to put a large part of her 6,200,000 unemployed back to work.

BAGDAD, March 30. -- Colonel James de Reynier, Swiss president of the League o Nations commission to delimit the frontier between Syria and Iraq, was killed with two others yesterday when a single-engined Farman plane belonging to the French Air Orient Line crashed in a sandstorm on a flight from Damascus to Bagdad.

LONDON, March 30. -- Herbert Morrison, one of the most responsible Ministers in the recent Laborite Government, gave a clear hint to the Irish Labor party tonight as to what line to take regarding President de Valera's policy of repudiation of the oath of allegiance.

The last week but one of the Metropolitan Opera Company's twenty-four week season will begin next Monday evening with "Tannhauser" with Mmes. Rethberg and Manski and Messrs. Melchior, Tibbett and Tappolet, with Mr. Bodanzky conducting.

Under the auspices of the Junior Auxiliary of the West Side Hospital a supper dance will be given tomorrow in the Regency Rooms of the Carlyle for the benefit of the hospital. During the supper hour there will be an entertainment by many stars from current Broadway attractions.
TOKYO, March 31. -- No funds being available, the Seiyukai (Government party) five-year plan for industrial expansion does not figure in the draft budget which the Cabinet will approve tomorrow.
High winds and rough water kept the Columbia crews close to shore yesterday on the Harlem River and Coach Richard J. Glendon limited the daily session to a light six-mile workout.

The past month has brought favor- able developments in the banking situation, but the general course of business has been disappointing in view of the hopes raised by the financial improvement, says the National City Bank in its current monthly bulletin.

ALBANY, March 31. -- In a proclamation setting aside the week from tomorrow to April 7 as "Conservation Week" Governor Roosevelt declared today that rapid strides were made in the State during the last year in "conserving and extending the natural resources of our State."

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 31. -- Under the most adverse conditions the Mount Holly Field Dog Club today started its fourth annual Spring trials. One stake was completed and a start made on another. The trials will run through Sunday.

The reduction of passenger rates to North Atlantic ports, which was announced on Wednesday by the United States Lines and member lines of the Transatlantic Passenger Conference, will probably be extended to the Mediterranean ports.

PARIS, March 31. -- The improvement in Wall Street yesterday influenced the French market favorably and trading was considerably more active. Sterling rose above 96 and was not followed by a slump in the dollar as had been the case in recent days.

Office space in the downtown financial and insurance districts is being taken in large volume, according to announcements of leases made by brokers and renting agents yesterday. Houses dealing in investment securities, Stock Exchange brokers and insurance underwriters signed contracts for quarters in several buildings in lower Manhattan.

PARIS, March 31. -- May 1 has been fixed, it was officially announced today, for the French general election. The second ballot will be taken May 8 in cases where no clear majority is obtained by any candidate.

Violation of union rules by submanufacturers, the piecework system in some shops and the unlimited number of contractors in the cloak industry were to blame for the crisis in the industry, according to Benjamin Schlesinger, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, last night in presenting the union's demands to the American Cloak and Suit Manufacturers' Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

With the only strong hope for the return of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's baby still resting apparently in the efforts being made by the three Norfolk negotiators, the centre of the mystery veered yesterday to Philadelphia as reports came that the baby was a captive in or near that city.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The United States is expected to emphasize reduction and limitation of offensive weapons of warfare at the resumption of the Geneva General Disarmament Conference as a result of conferences held with officials this week by Norman H. Davis, a delegate to the conference.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP). -- To save America's natural resources from waste and depletion, Secretary Wilbur today urged legislation to permit producers to control production by agreement among themselves under Federal supervision.

GENEVA, March 31. -- Two notes which W.W. Yen, Chinese delegate, handed to the Secretariat of the League of Nations and one which came today from neutrals indicate that the nineteen-power commission is going to have its hands full when it resumes its session in mid-April.

PICHER, Okla., March 31. -- The frantic, all-day efforts of almost 100 miners resulted in the rescue tonight of 3-year-old Gerald Collins, who had been imprisoned since morning twenty feet down in a small drillhole at the Mary Ann Lead and Zinc Mine near Picher.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The following amendments to the tax bill, which were estimated to produce $143,500,000 in additional revenue for the fiscal year 1933, were adopted by the House today:

Speyer Co. announced yesterday that they were prepared to pay today the April 1 coupons on city of Berlin 6 1/2 per cent bonds of 1925, the city of Frankfort-on-Main 7 per cent bonds, and on Berlin Electric Elevated and Underground Railways Company first mortgage 6 1/2s.

Gold released from earmarked holdings last month, which more than offset the net loss through actual shipments out of New York, reached the largest total since June, 1931. The net decrease in earmarked gold was $58,421,300, against net export shipments of $29,786,700 from New York.

With the House of Representatives committed to a stock sales tax that brokers decried as confiscatory, the share market broke sharply yesterday in spite of an unprecedented squeeze of an overextended short interest.

GULFPORT, Miss., March 31. -- The Robins today defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 10 to 3, in eight innings, the contest being curtailed so that the Orioles could catch a train to fill another engagement tomorrow.

The Walton team turned in the outstanding performance thus far in the eleventh annual tournament for the women's bowling championship of Greater New York by rolling a 2,455 total on Thum's Alleys yesterday, the third day of the tourney. The score sent the Walton five into first place in the standing.

Since a real artist never paints exactly or exhaustively what is there, since he must always build a picture, with its myriad implications of color harmony, linear and spatial rhythm, perspective, "out of his own head," there can remain no reasonable doubt that Henri Matisse is a designer of hats and gowns, as well as an artist in the realm of palette and brush.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Agitation for enactment of a World War veterans' bonus bill at this session of Congress is continuing to gain in strength. Privately, administration leaders admit that if the $2,000,000,000 bill for full payment of adjusted service compensation certificates were voted upon in the House tomorrow it would pass.

Mr. CURRY is too modest to have such an intention, but the interview he was good enough to give at Washington showed him in the mood, now of philosophic ataraxy, now of enlightened altruism. He doesn't think New York "wants to hog things in 1932."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was interested in THE TIMES editorial commenting on the effort to have government buildings in different parts of the country supervised by local architects. Although I know nothing about the science of architecture or the practice of the profession of the architect, I have observed in a closely allied science, bridge-building, the folly of bringing an expert out from the East to superintend a local job.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Acqui- sition by Pennsylvania Railroad in- terests of additional stock of the New York, New Haven Hartford brought their holdings to 29 per cent of the common stock outstanding, ac- cording to the annual report of the New Haven for 1931, filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

BAYARD, Fla., March. 31. -- Donny Johnny, the 4-year-old gelding by Cherokee -- Sunshine which races for H.A. Coulson, today captured the Jacksonville Chamber of Commerce Purse, closing-day feature at St. Johns Park. The program also con- cluded the Florida racing season which got under way last December.

LONDON, March 31. -- A third daughter of Mrs. Kate Merrick, London's night club "queen," will be married into the peerage. She is Miss Nancy Merrick, whose engagement to the Hon. Charles Fitzroy, Lord Southampton's son and heir, was celebrated early yesterday morning in the Forty-three Club here.
BALTIMORE, Md., March 31. -- The 1932 Eastern racing season will open tomorrow at Bowie, the course of the Southern Maryland and Agricul- tural Association, midway between this city and Washington.

MOSCOW, March 31. -- Mme. Joseph Stalin, wife of the virtual Dictator of Soviet Russia, has been cited publicly for "cutting" classes in the institute here, where she is studying to become an expert in artificial silk manufacturing and for delinquency in returning library books.

Banks and insurance companies, which on the whole had maintained dividend rates through the reaction in business, fell into line last month with the prevalent trend to conserve funds by curtailing payments to shareholders. This change, with additional sharp contractions by industrial corporations, accounted for decline of nearly $60,000,000 in payments to stockholders in March, compared with a year ago.

The city is rapidly approaching another rapid transit crisis. With the new Eighth Avenue subway practically ready for operation, there is a growing and natural demand that it be opened at the earliest possible date, so as to afford relief for the present congestion on the other west side line.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- Wheat traders paid little attention today to the general run of news of the crop on the Board of Trade except for a brief period early, when the highest prices were made. A change in sentiment to the most pessimistic feeling in some time dropped prices about a cent from the top, and caused net losses of 1/2 to 7/8 cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was impressed with the statement of George Garner in THE NEW YORK TIMES that "the rejection of the manufacturers' sales-tax provision by the House in Congress is a natural and logical incident resulting from the transformation of the United States from a republic into a democracy."

Foreign exchanges again turned upward against the dollar yesterday, with sterling and the franc in the lead. The movement was accomplished in a highly erratic session, which appeared to be governed chiefly by speculative impulses, according to exchange dealers.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 31. -- Knute Rockne's spirit marched on in double quick time at Notre Dame today, the first anniversary of his tragic death in an airplane crash.

Net loss of the Aviation Corporation for 1931, after all charges but exclusive of $2,002,663 loss on sales of securities, was $1,183,006. This compares with a net loss of $4,718,080, including $14,479 profit on sales of securities, in the preceding year.
ALBANY, March 31. -- Governor Roosevelt today approved thirty-three bills carrying appropriations of about $1,000,000. He signed a total of fifty-six measures and vetoed sixteen.

Prices turned lower in yesterday's trading in commodities. The grains, cotton, hides, rubber, silk and cocoa in the contract markets sagging, while in spot trading butter and rubber established new lows for the year. Coffee and sugar showed slight improvement.

Cardinal Hayes, Governor Roosevelt and former Governor Smith will open the Catholic Charities' annual appeal for funds at a luncheon of 2,000 business leaders, social workers and volunteer canvassers at the Hotel Astor April 9. The actual solicitation of funds, by more than 25,000 volunteer workers, will begin in the 369 parishes of the Archdiocese of New York on April 17 and continue until April 25.

Woman's invasion of the gainful occupations may have moved forward a trifle faster in New Jersey than in the country at large in the decade after 1920, but not enough to signify. The census of that year recorded 23.9 per cent of all females over 10 years of age as engaged in remunerative work.

PARIS, March 31 (AP). -- Gaudy red, white and blue calico streamers, announcing the establishment of a new "permanence," or headquarters, for such and such a candidate for the Chamber of Deputies, have begun to make their appearance in Paris and the provinces, most frequently over cafes.

With as fine an exhibition of cue wizardry as has ever been witnessed in an amateur championship, Edmond Soussa, dark-haired Egyptian star, administered a decisive defeat to the defending champion, Albert Poensgen of Germany, at the Elks' Club last night, winning by the score of 400 to 101 in the final match of the world's amateur 18.2 balkline tournament.

TOKYO, March 31 (AP). -- The War Office published an official report today from Harbin which told of a concentration of 30,000 Soviet Russian troops at Vladivostok and said the number had been increased steadily since last January by the arrival of reinforcements from Europe.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31. -- Concluding its season, the Everglades Club was the scene of a large dinner dance in the Orange Gardens tonight. Features were a program of songs by the sixty members of the Romany Chorus and the awarding of cups to winners of the duplicate contract tournament, played every Saturday for eleven weeks.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 31. -- The eight days homeward-bound tour of the Yankees began today in the same fashion as did their Florida exhibition schedule, that is, with a postponement.

Peter Anselmo gave to Delfino Gardino a mortgage for $2,100 to be paid off $200 quarterly at 6 per cent, on 157 and 159 West Forty-ninth Street, subject to a first mortgage for $140,140 held by the Greenwich Savings Bank, a second for $30,000 and to a third for $40,000.

Appropriations of $9,162,722, including $5,139,485 for Negroes and $3,647,621 for whites, were made by the General Education Board in the fiscal year ended on June 30, 1931, according to the report of that institution for 1930-31 made public yesterday at its offices, 61 Broadway.

Agents of Andrew McCampbell, prohibition administrator, paved the way for the seizure of fixtures valued at $75,000, confiscated more than 100 bottles of alleged liquor, and arrested thirteen persons yesterday in raids on four mid-town restaurants and drinking resorts.

LOS ANGELES, March 31. -- Some idea of the magnitude of the Olympic Games next Summer is afforded by statistics released today by the organizing committee. During the sixteen days the international spectacle is in progress, from July 30 to Aug. 14, there will be 135 distinct programs in fourteen branches of sports.

A proposed order, calling for the reinstatement of fifteen members of Local 3 of the International Brother- hood of Electrical Workers, in pursuance of an order signed by Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck, was served yesterday on Frank P. Walsh, who was substituted as counsel for the union.

The Guerrero-Mendoza company of Spanish actors will begin its engagement at the New Yorker Theatre tonight with a performance of "Pluma en el Viento," a play by Joaquin Dicenta. "The Decoy," a melodrama by Harrison King, will have its premiere tonight at the Royale Theatre.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the veteran Hoosier Democrat, was found by a reporter this afternoon, peering through a window on Pennsylvania Avenue at the new Ford.
Several sales and leases of housing properties in Manhattan were announced by brokers yesterday. Details of other transactions were shown in contracts filed at the Register's office.

AIKEN, S.C., March 31. -- Pom Ray, a gray mare owned by Mrs. Seymour H. Knox of Buffalo and ridden by Miss Polly Potter of New York, this afternoon took the blue ribbon for open jumping in the first class of the annual Aiken Horse Show in the Hitchcock Woods.

Eben MacBurney Byers, wealthy iron manufacturer of Pittsburgh and New York and internationally known sportsman, died of radium poisoning at the Doctors' Hospital at 7:30 A.M. yesterday at the age of 51. Dr. Raymond B. Miles, Assistant Medical Examiner, began an investigation last night into the circumstances of his death and will perform an autopsy today.

Arrangements were made yester- day for the sale of a membership in the New York Stock Exchange at $101,000, an increase of $1,000 from the previous sale, which was made at the lowest price in more than seven years.

The decline in the volume of bonds called for redemption before their maturity dates, which set in after the first of the year following an upturn in the last six months of 1931, continued in March, when the total was the smallest in more than five years.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 31. -- Bettering his former world's record of 3:383-5, Clarence (Buster) Crabbe, of the Los Angeles A.C., tonight won signal honors in the finals of the national senior A.A.U. championships in Carnegie Pool, capturing the 300 yard medley swim in 3:362-5, two and one-fifth seconds better than the mark made by him at Chicago a year ago.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 30, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1599,000,000, an increase of $3,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $680,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

A slight stir in the acceptance mar- ket caused by one dealer cutting the yield 1/8 on all maturities, but which was not followed by other dealers and therefore unofficial, represented the only development of interest in the day's money market. Elsewhere, business was quiet and rates for every class of accommodation unchanged from the preceding day.

The 1931 income of the Long Island State Park Commission from the recreational facilities that it' operates was $691,449.09, an increase of $265,240.77, or 60 per cent, over its income in 1930 from the same sources, according to the annual report of the commission, which was made public yesterday.

To Back Quality Campaign. Every facility of the National Retail Dry Goods Association will be placed behind the quality campaign launched by P.A. O'Connell, head of the E.T. Slattery Company, Boston, and president of the association, it was stated yesterday by Channing E. Switzer, managing director, in announcing the work program of the organization for the coming year.

An agreement designed to stamp out racketeering in the cleaning and dyeing industry will be signed at 11 o'clock this morning in the office of former Municipal Court Justice Jacob Panken, 225 Broadway.

To the Editor The New York Times: Every right-thinking citizen should support the constructive proposals for the reform of the magistrates' courts so admirably outlined in the report of Judge Seabury. The limitations imposed upon the scope of the report prevented the consideration of certain important aspects of our judicial system which cannot be separated into isolated divisions.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31. -- Dis- playing a mastery of the vagaries of night baseball, hitherto carefully con- cealed, the Giants trounced the San Francisco Seals in a frost-bitten bat- tle under arc lights and before a crowd of 3,000 tonight by 10 to 2.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Lawyers are accustomed to receiving circulars from trust companies pointing out the great advantages to be gained by their clients from appointing the particular trust company executor or trustee under wills or deeds of trust.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Secretary Hurley, who some months ago was mentioned as a possibility for the Republican nomination for Vice President, today vetoed efforts of some of his friends to name him as national committeeman from Oklahoma.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 31. -- Mrs. George W. Wightman and Miss Sarah Palfrey of Brookline, favorites and defending champions, today gained the final in the women's national indoor tennis doubles championship on the Long-wood covered courts and tomorrow will oppose Miss Marjorie Morrill of Dedham, Mass., and Mrs. John A. Van Ryn of Philadelphia.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 31. -- St. Benedict's Preparatory School of Newark, N.J., tonight fought its way into the semi-finals of the Eastern States basketball tournament by defeating Hun Prep School of Princeton, N.J., 22 to 13.

Borough activity for block aid gathered momentum yesterday throughout the city end increased results in organization and in the sale of stamps were re-ported. Pledges of from 10 cents to $1 a week for twenty weeks are being sought to assist those of the needy unemployed who have not been aided by public or private agencies.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, March 31 (AP). -- The insurgent Chinese forces under General Li Hai-tsing, which have been threatening this new Manchurian capital for several days, today were pressing on a few miles south of Nungan, thirty-five miles north of this city.

VIENNA, March 31. -- Chancellor Buresch for Austria and Finance Minister Argetoianu for Rumania supported today the view already expressed by Germany, Italy, Britain and Czechoslovakia, but not by France, that unity of opinion among the four great European powers should be obtained before the five Danubian States began negotiation for a pereferential bloc.

Rollin C. Bastress, 58 years old, of 88-82 146th Street, Jamaica, Queens, a graduate engineer and former chief inspector of the Manhattan Building Bureau, and John I. Cahalan, 54 years old, of 323 West Eighty-second Street, a building construction superintendent, were found guilty in Judge Koenig's part of General Sessions yesterday of accepting a $1,500 gratuity from a builder in return for Bastress's approval of plans for a penthouse in July, 1927.

A traffic signal system, having as its object the protection of pedestrian crossings and cutting down speeding by means of a progressive timing plan, will go into effect in Central Park at 10 A.M. today. Police Commissioner Mulrooney and Park Commissioner Herrick will be among a group of officials present at the opening of the new system.

LONDON, March 31. -- The stock markets were irregular today largely because of renewed liquidation from the Continent. The trouble appeared to centre in Brussels, where the failure of a small speculator yesterday was followed by several small failures today.

ST. LOUIS, March 31. -- Former President Coolidge has written Lewis B. Tebbetts, St. Louis insurance man, assuring him that no personal offense was intended by his radio speech on insurance last October. With the letter, according to J. Porter Henry Mr. Tebbetts's attorney, came a $2,500 check of Everett Sanders, Coolidge'a attorney and his secretary while he was President.

BUCHAREST, March 31. -- A mixed Russo-Rumanian commission formed to inquire into the shooting of Russion refugees who have attempted to cross the River Dniester during the last three months will assemble at Kishineff, April 12.

Clairville J. Gartlan of South Orange resold to Mary E. Feldman a three-story brick store building covering a plot 25 by 112 feet at 371 Central Avenue, southwest corner of Charles Street, Jersey City, subject to two mortgages totaling $85,000. The seller purchased the property from the Robert Company, Inc., last Jan. 18.

BERLIN, March 31. -- The Boerse continued weak today. Several leading securities lost as much as 3 to 4 per cent owing to realization sales. The turnover remained small. North German Lloyd and Hamburg-American were weak, following their price movements in New York.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Advocates of abolition of the Federal Farm Board as a major economy in Congress' effort to balance the budget revived the movement today in the face of considerable opposition among both parties in House and Senate.

It is proof of the vitality of the merchant marine even in these times that competition to win the blue ribbon of the Atlantic from the North German Lloyd's new liners is not to be given up. Having obtained a government loan, the French Line hopes to complete "the largest and "fastest electrically driven passen"ger ship in the world" by the Spring of 1934.

To the Editor of The New York Times: World conditions are now such that national unity is the greatest asset a nation can have. It is the surest road to world understanding and international amity, and legislation that arraigns class against class is the last thing that should be in the minds of legislators.
LONDON, March 31 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31. -- Gains of almost 3 points were recorded in some of the Wall Street stocks on the local market today after the New York Stock Exchange had closed. The principal advances were in American Telephone and United States Steel, although Southern California Edison common and Southern Pacific made good showings.

Fear of a stringency in the stock loan market was uppermost in the minds of professional speculators yes- terday, but when it became appar- ent that an ample supply of stock would be available the selling was renewed so aggressively in spots that the entire Stock Exchange list was depressed.

Through Ambassador EDGE the American Chamber of Commerce in Paris has urged President HOOVER to protest against the new French "quota" system. Some forty lines of American exports to France have been entirely stopped or drastically cut by it.

HOUSTON, Texas, March 31. -- J. Gilbert Hall, South Orange, N.J.; Junior Coen, Kansas City, and Lester Stoeffen, California, the three remaining favorites in the annual Houston invitation tennis tournament, cleared their hurdles to the quarter-final singles play today.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- One of the most elaborate reports ever prepared by the Department of Justice has been written by Assistant Attorney General S.W. Richardson on conditions of lawlessness in the Hawaiian Islands. It was prepared in response to a Senate resolution.

For the second time in eleven months Police Commissioner Mulrooney ordered a shake-up yesterday of plain-clothes men engaged in running down vice, liquor law violations and gambling. Under the order, effective at 8 A.M. today, 154 men working in the sixteen inspection districts into which the city is divided will be shifted about so that all will have new tours of duty.

PARIS, March 31. -- Emphasizing that the French Line is only meeting the challenge of its American competitors under protest, officials of the company announced here today 20 per cent reductions in the first and the tourist class passenger fares and a 10 per cent cut in the third-class rates, effective immediately.

Testimony given yesterday by William J. Flynn, Bronx Public Works Commissioner, after he had purged himself of contempt by answering formal questions to which he had refused to respond at an earlier hearing, follows in part:

Increased commutation rates go into effect today on the Harlem, Hudson and Putnam divisions of the New York Central Railroad. The increases are 25 per cent on the regular monthly tickets, and 20 per cent on family and excursion tickets.

BOSTON, March 31. -- Mrs. R.C. Norwood, wife of the second assistant keeper of Boston Light, faced childbirth alone, save for the aid of her nervous husband, in their galelashed island home three miles at sea tonight after Coast Guardsmen fought a brave but futile battle with a wild March storm to take a doctor to her side.

The history of court tennis in America, hitherto reckoned as starting with 1876, goes back more than 200 years beyond that date, according to information disclosed by Malcolm D. Whitman of New York, national lawn tennis champion in 1898, 1899 and 1900, and a member of the first United States Davis Cup team.

HELSINGFORS, March 31. -- Marked interest which the Finnish press and general opinion are taking in preparations for the new drinking system, beginning on April 5, brought a public protest by the aged Archbishop Ingman today.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- If the business world is concerned lest Congress remain in session throughout the Summer, it may be interested in an informal poll taken today among experienced members of the two houses and of the press gallery as to that probability.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Even with the sharp increases made in the income-tax rates by the House, the lot of the American taxpayer of moderate means will be a happy one as compared with that of the citizen of Great Britain.

Encouraged by their success in getting instructed delegations in Iowa and Maine, the managers of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt's campaign for the Democratic nomination for President moved yesterday to bring about the election of Roosevelt delegates at conventions and primaries during April.

MONTREAL, March 31. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and Montreal Maroons remain on even terms in their struggle for the right to meet the New York Rangers in the Stanley Cup series. The Maroons held the Maple Leafs to a 1-1 tie tonight and play their rivals again at Toronto on Saturday.

The weekly Federal Reserve report, covering the position of the Reserve System as of Wednesday, published yesterday, disclosed a continuation of the favorable trend pursued since the close of February. Open-market buy- ing of United States Government securities lifted the System's holdings $36,620,000 to $871,618,000, the largest amount ever reported.
PARIS, March 31 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

ALBANY, March 31. -- Although apparently somewhat shaken by the interview given in an impressive setting at Washington yesterday by the Tammany leader, John F. Curry, Governor Roosevelt does not read a threat to his own candidacy for the Democratic nomination into the statements which the usually reticent chleftain of Tammapy Hall made to newspaper correspondents present at his special invitation.

BRUSSELS, March 31. -- The International North Atlantic Steamship Conference, concluding a two-day meeting at Brussels today, adopted an agreement to cut rates 20 per cent for first and second class passengers and 10 per cent for tourist and third class.

Replying to the contention of attorneys for Owen Madden that the former convict was conditionally discharged by the State Parole Board in March, 1929, the Attorney General filed in Supreme Court yesterday affidavits denying that such a discharge had been given and declaring that records of the board showed that the discharge was not given at the time Madden says it was.

The city administration, to which the request for an appropriation for municipal operation of the Eighth Avenue subway is to be made shortly by the Board of Transportation, indicated definitely yesterday that to it, municipal operation is, and always will be, a last resort.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Students from about forty Eastern colleges who recently tried to investigate conditions in the Kentucky coal fields, described their experiences today to Senators Copeland, Costigan and Logan. The Senators met informally to receive the students' protest that their Constitutional rights had been flouted by their ejection from Kentucky, and to hear their demand that the Costigan-Cutting resolution for an investigation be adopted by the Senate.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Unanimous agreement to investigate the "night school" at which Senator Glass asserted bankers were coached as witnesses against his banking bill was reached today by the subcommittee of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

Leopold Marchand and his American adapters have written one of those fine-grained plays that one dislikes to condemn as tepid, "We Are No Longer Children," which was affectionately acted at the Booth last evening. Strictly speaking, it is Jean in quest of his youth, to draw the inevitable Leonard Merrick comparison.

General Sessions Judge Freschi, acting on the recommendation of William M.K. Olcutt, Special Assistant District Attorney, dismissed yesterday the $2,500 bail on which former Sheriff Charles W. Culkin had been at liberty under two indictments charging that, as Sheriff, he had misappropriated about $1,000 in interest money which he had held in escrow.

LONDON, March 31. -- The British Government's 1931-32 fiscal year, which had been divided roughly into six months of desperate anxiety followed by six months of increasing hopes, ends tonight at midnight. The hopes were justified because the budget balanced.

DUBLIN, March 31 (Canadian Press). -- President de Valera and his Republican Government continued tonight consideration of their reply to Great Britain's note warning that abrogation of the oath of allegiance to the crown and withholding of land annuities would be considered breaches of the Anglo-Irish treaty.

George W. Sweeney, president of the Bowman Biltmore Hotels Corporation, issued a statement yesterday to holders of the corporation's first mortgage leasehold 7 per cent bonds, due on March 1, 1934; the 7 per cent sinking fund notes due on Dec. 15, 1934, and the 6 per cent notes (extended) due on July 1, 1933, outlining; a plan of readjustment.

DETROIT, March 31. -- W.S. Knudsen, president and general manager of the Chevrolet Motor Car Company, announced today drastic cuts ranging up to $55 in the prices of all fourteen Chevrolet passenger models, making the base price $445.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31. -- A distinguished aggregation of artists under the auspices of the Philadel phia Grand Opera Company conspired to bring to performance for the first time on any stage tonight a Mexican "ballet-symphony" bearing the cryptic title of "H.P."

Ninety-six college girls who are studying sociology at fourteen Eastern institutions began yesterday a three-day inspection tour of social agencies here. Their visit is under the auspices of the Association of Volunteers in Social Service, which conducts these trips annually to help young women students decide whether they will want to go into social work after they graduate.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Passage of the tax bill in the House before adjournment tomorrow seemed tonight to be assured. The last rates were voted upon today and the measure stood to raise $999,000,000 for the fiscal year 1933.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S letter in reply to Dr. HOLMES and Rabbi WISE first took a shot at these critics and petitioners. At least a part of the charge which he fired in their direction went home. The case which he made out in the matter of the clerk of the Surrogate's Court in Queens was especially strong.

One of the dramatic clashes between factions of the Hofstadter legislative inquiry which have been absert for some time developed late yesterday afternoon when the committee, after a day devoted to the affairs of William J. Flynn, Bronx Public Works Commissioner, attempted to carry out its announced plan to cite State Senator John A. Hastings of Brooklyn for contempt.

Not All the Salesman. Dr. VON KUBHLMANN, in his speech before the Advertising Club, drew a parallel between the art of winning votes and the art of selling goods, both activities being essentially an exercise in mass persuasion.

PARIS, March 31. -- The progress of the Geneva disarmament conference's efforts during fifty-eight days to reduce the equipment for war that mankind has been building up and improving during the last 25,000 years was reported to the American Club of Paris at its weekly luncheon today by William Hard, Washington journalist and organizer of radio broadcast programs.

Except for slightly easier rates in time obligations, interest charges for money in March remained the same as in the previous month. Available funds were more than sufficient to take care of the demand, which changed little.

JERUSALEM, March 31. -- Radical changes in the political situation in Palestine are expected in May, when it is understood that Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, the High Commissioner, will announce the British Government's decision to create the legislative assembly for Palestine proposed in the Churchill White Paper of 1922 and the Passfield White Paper of 1930.

NEW ORLEANS, March 31. -- Medicine droppers with openings the size of a hair, dishes and crucibles the size of a thimble, and at times small magnifying lenses, used in a system of qualitative microanalysis, were described in a paper presented today at the closing meeting here of the American Chemical Society.

For the mediocrity, music is not a profession but a starvation, declared Josef Hofmann yesterday in discussing the causes, effects and cures of the depression. One remedy, he suggested, lay with the schools, in restricting professional students to those of the greatest promise.

In their annual statement, issued yesterday, Burns Brothers and subsidiaries reported that, as a result of financial readjustments and drastic economies, the company's operating position had been substantially improved in 1931. The balance sheet shows current assets of $9,122,716, against current liabilities off $3,632,474, leaving net working capital of $5,490,242.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Senate ratified today, without debate, the international convention for regulating manufacture and distribution of narcotics, adopted last year at Geneva by delegates from fortyfour countries. It also ratified six reservations recommended by the delegates from the United States, none of which, it is said, weakens the force of the treaty.

Another slight increase in the dry vote in The Literary Digest prohibition poll in revealed in the seventh balloting by States, announced yesterday, although the wet forces continued to lead by almost three to one.

Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, the former Miss Gwladys Hopkins, is to enter racing and will have her own colors up this year, it was learned at the offices of the Jockey Club yesterday. According to pres- ent plans the steeplechasers which last year became an important part of the Whitney string, will bear the colors of Mrs. Whitney this Spring.

"Thanks to the Christian brother-hood-of-man poison," this country is going the way of China toward national suicide, Walter B. Pitkin, Professor or Journalism at Columbia University, and holder of a degree of Bachelor of Divinity from Hartford Theological Seminary, writes in "A Short Introduction to the History of Human Stupidity," published today by Simon and Schuster.

BERLIN, March 31. -- Reports from New York to the effect that financial circles there were becoming restive under recurring rumors that the German Government or the private debtors bracketed under the standstill agreement concluded last January were contemplating the declaration of a general moratorium have provoked both surprise and chagrin here in competent banking and industrial circles, which promptly denied today that such a step was under consideration.

Following closely upon the action of the Metropolitan Golf Association, the Westchester County Golf Association has also appointed a committee to sift questions of amateur standing among golfers in its own section.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Elimination of "competition" between Federal and State employment services was advocated by Miss Frances Perkins, New York Industrial Commissioner, today before the Senate Commerce Committee.

UNION, N.J., March 31. -- Herman Kramm was arrested by United States marshals and the local police at his home, 1,008 Coolidge Avenue, here today, as the man for whom another is serving a six months' sentence in Hudson County Jail for illegal manufacture and possession of liquor.

The first public demonstration of the use of ultra-violet rays in the detection of fraudulent works of art was given yesterday morning by James J. Rorimer, assistant curator in the department of decorative arts at the Metropolitan Museum, before members of the College Art Association at their twenty-first annual meeting.

The question whether the State of Tennessee will receive a bid on Monday for its issue of $9,000,000 of bonds under the present terms of sale, which stipulate that the issue shall mature serially on Jan. 1, 1936 to 1940, or whether the bankers will submit a plan calling for other maturities will be settled at conferences today and tomorrow at which six of the largest municipal bond houses in Wall Street will be represented.

Maxwell Stewart Simpson, who was born in the industrial city of Elizabeth, N.J., has developed into what appears to be one of the few genuinely and spontaneously mystical painters in America. His Work is currently on view at the Dudensing Gallery.

MOSCOW, March 31. -- A threefold increase in the pay of Soviet workers who are members of the Communist party is under consideration by the party's political bureau as wages go up 11.5 to 18 per cent tomorrow in the light and heavy industries.

A southbound Fifth Avenue bus, with just one passenger aboard, skidded on the wet paving near Twenty-sixth Street about 10 o'clock last night, knocked a taxicab into collision with another, mounted the sidewalk and buried its nose in the huge display window of the Dennison Manufacturing Company, at 220 Fifth Avenue.

Delegates of member clubs of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound met last night at the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, and adopted the organization's racing schedule for this year. These dates are the ones of the regattas that count on the season's championships in the various classes.

PARIS, March 31. -- The French Government today gave renewed evidence of its intention not only to continue but to intensify its policy of restricting importations by quotas. Today's Journal Officiel published a large number of decrees, decisions and notices to importers renewing and giving import quotas from April 1 to June 30.

The fiftieth annual report of the United Gas Improvement Company shows for 1931 consolidated net in- some of $37,722,774 after deprecia- tion, charges, taxes, subsidiary inter- est and dividends and minority in- terest, equal, after preferred divi- dends, to $1.46 a share on 23,254,424 common shares, compared with $38,- 415,912, or $1.54 a share on the same number of shares, earned in 1930.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Collier Trophy, the highest award in American aviation, was today presented by President Hoover to the Packard Motor Car Company in recognition of that company's work in the development of the Diesel aircraft engine.

A mild difference stirred the New York annual conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, in session at the Park Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church at Eighty-sixth Street, yesterday when Dr. B.C. Warren of Cold Springs, N.Y., was challenged to conclude his semi-centennial sermon at the end of an hour.

PARIS, March 31. -- The position of the European debtor countries with regard to the United States at the expiration of the Hoover moratorium will occupy chief attention, it is believed, during the visit this weekend of Premier Andre Tardieu, Finance Minister P.E. Flandin and their experts to London.

The virtuoso feature of the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was the performance of the Tchaikovsky violin. concerto by Mishel Piastro, the concertmaster. Brilliant, at all events, from the standpoint of a soloist's deed of derring-do and a rapturously applauding audience.
NEW YORK. Lord and Lady Brougham and Vaux, who arrived on the Majestic, are at the Ambassador.

Louis S. Gimbel, vice president of Gimbel Brothers from 1910 to 1923, left an estate estimated yesterday in the transfer tax appraisal at 1,516,147 gross and $1,231,520 net, after deduction of debts and expenses. Mr. Gimbel left $30,000 to charities and $5,500 to employes, the rest of the estate going to the widow, Mrs. Julia M. Gimbel, of 555 Park Avenue, and two sons.

Mrs. Harold Van Buskirk of the Fencers Club led a group of six women who qualified for the national foils championship following the preliminaries at the Fencers Club last night. The others who qualified were Mrs. Leon M. Schoonmaker and Miss Lena Gilbert of the home club, the Misses Muriel Guggolz and Dorothy Locke of Salle d'Armes Vince and Miss Amy von Hansa, who competed unattached.

The total bank clearings at twenty-two leading cities of the country for the week ended on Wednesday night, as reported to R.G. Dun Co., was $4,055,546,000, a decline of 52.4 per cent from the corresponding week last year.

The first public exhibition of the new Ford V-8 yesterday brought a steady stream of visitors to the company's headquarters here at Broadway and Fifty-fourth Street. So large were the crowds, despite the weather that many had difficulty at times in getting close to the models on display.

Gagged, bound and with her arms tied behind her back, a small, frail woman over 60 years of age was found dead in her bed late yesterday afternoon in a tenement at 535 West Fifty-ninth Street. She apparently had been killed by some one who believed she had money hidden in her dingy two-room flat.

The sixteen hands which will be held tonight by about 40,000 persons in the World Bridge Olympic, sponsored by Ely Culbertson and his National Bridge Association, yesterday became the subject of statements, replies and counter replies and the worry of private detectives.

DUBLIN, March 31. -- The more moderate Ministers of Eamon de Valera's Executive Council have forced the President to modify the terms of his reply to the British Government on the oath of allegiance and the land annuities.

Vacancies in the two city educational boards were filled yesterday by Mayor Walker with the appointment of Rabbi Louis D. Gross as a member of the Board of Higher Education and Dr. Philip A. Brennan of Brooklyn as a member of the Board of Education.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 31. -- Army's football staff, which will assist Major Ralph I. Sasse, head coach, in developing this year's team, was announced today by Major P.B. Fleming. As in the past all coaches will be graduates of the Military Academy and former players on the Army team.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 31. -- About 2,000 skilled workers on Long Island would be thrown out of employment unless they disobeyed union edicts to accept their employers' scale of wages, it was announced today by John D. Cosgrove, chairman of the board of managers of the Building Trades Employers' Association at his office in Glen Cove.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP). -- A prediction that a brain abscess resulting from radium would prove fatal to Eben M. Byers was made last September by Dr. Joseph M. Steiner, New York specialist, before the Federal Trade Commission.

SHANGHAI, March 31 (AP). -- Illfeeling between Chinese and Japanese civilians, stirred by an attack of Chinese ruffians on a Japanese man in the heart of the International Settlement, threatened further trouble for the peace negotiations here today just as they made definite progress.

LONDON, March 31. -- Between now and the imperial conference in Ottawa in July, Great Britain will not enter into any trading negotiations whatever with any foreign countries that would prevent her going to Ottawa with an absolutely free hand to deal with the dominions.

BOSTON, March 31. -- Charles F. Hurley, State Treasurer, announced tonight that the new issue of $2,705,500 Massachusetts bonds had been awarded to a syndicate of bankers headed by R.L. Day Co. and including Estabrook Co., the First National-Old Colony Corporation, the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and Jackson Curtis.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass, March 31. -- The dean's list of honor students in Harvard College, for all four classes, was announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 . -- Preliminary studies in the proposed investigation of Stock Exchanges by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee will be started early next week, Senator Norbeck, chairman, announced today.

CLEVELAND, March 31 (AP). -- Pilot Forrest Malick gambled his life against the weather and lost today. Flying the night mail from New York to Cleveland, he fell to death in a farmer's field near Bedford, a Cleveland suburb, early today, when he ran into a blinding fog and rain and snow.
AT one minute after midnight, the president being in the chair, the meeting of the April First So- ciety was called to order.

MONTREAL, March 31. -- President Frank Caider of the National Hockey League today solved the problem of play-off dates for the final Stanley Cup series by bringing Boston into the picture as one of the home ports of the New York Rangers.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Congress makes more fuss about raising $4,000,000,000 than England does, and England has one-third the population which has less per capita wealth.

ALBANY, March 31. -- The State Education Department announced today that it intended to continue its survey of the efficiency of New York City's schools, but upon a "decidedly reduced scale," because of the refusal of the Legislature to appropriate $50,000 to defray the cost of the investigation.

Hundreds of hungry children, some alone and others leading younger brothers and sisters through a drizzling rain, wandered into public schools throughout the city yesterday to receive the warm food prepared for them by teachers who have sacrificed their Easter holiday to carry on the work of the School Relief Fund.

BUENOS AIRES, March 31. -- Brazilian millers are beginning to import Argentine wheat at the rate of 60,000 tons a month, with a considerable increase expected soon, at the termination of the agreement between Brazil and the United States for the exchange of coffee and wheat.
Transactions on the New York Stock Exchange for March amounted to 33,060,518 shares, compared with 31,718,556 shares in February and with 65,493,639 shares in March, 1931.

A program to balance the Federal budget for 1933 by meeting one-third of the estimated deficit of $1,350,000,000 through additional taxes, onethird through a tax on beer, and onethird by the issuance of bonds for proposed permanent construction work, was suggested last night by former Governor Alfred E. Smith in an address broadcast over Station WEAF and the National Broadcasting Company's network.

Andrew W. Mellon, the United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James's, will sail for England on the Majestic of the White Star Line this afternoon. Others, bound for Cherbourg and Southampton, are:

A proposal to reduce the stated value of the capital stock of the Fox Film Corporation from $90,780,000 to $12,628,300, involving a change in the A and B shares of the company from no par value to a par value of $5, was outlined in a letter to stockholders sent out yesterday by Edward R. Tinker, president, in connection with the issuance of the corporation's annual report.

New bond financing in March was more than double the amount offered to the public in February. However, it was short of January's total by a small margin and less than 25 per cent of the marketings in March, 1931.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Senator Robinson announced today that he was not a candidate for President, thereby making probable the selection of an uninstructed delegation from Arkansas favorable to Governor Roosevelt.

The operations of the Railroad Credit Corporation, through which revenues derived from the freight surcharges that went into effect on Jan. 4 are pooled and lent to needy railroads, were roundly condemned by L.F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Company, in the annual report of the company issued yesterday.

The entire chorus of 104 singers of the Metropolitan Opera Company met yesterday as union members of the Grand Opera Choral Alliance to consider the declaration of the Metropolitan directors a week ago that they had "insufficient funds to assure another season," together with the subsequent appeal of Giulio Gatti-Casazza, as impresario, urging all members of the opera company to "work for a compensation in relation to changed conditions."

In view of theatrical conditions the Players will not present a play revival on Broadway for a week's engagement late in the Spring as has been the annual custom for the last ten years. At the club it was said yesterday that the suspension of the revivals was for this year only and that they would be resumed at the end of next season.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Mrs. Hoover attended this afternoon the society circus given annually in the drill hall at Fort Myer, Va., for the benefit of local charities by members of the younger set, including the season's debutantes and others skilled in horsemanship.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Opposition was reiterated today by the Interstate Commerce Commission against loans by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to railroads to pay off obligations to private banks. Coincidentally, Senator Couzens of Michigan introduced in the Senate a bill which would strip the Reconstruction Corporation of all authority over loans to railroads and rest it solely in the commission.

The new Eighth Avenue subway should be turned over to some competent operator other than the B.M.T. or Interborough under an agreement more equitable than the "impossible" contract now being advertised by the Board of Transportation, according to a statement issued yesterday by Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel for the Transit Commission.

Forty-two municipal bond issues, aggregating $22,239,223, will come up next week for award to investment banking houses, compared with this week's total of $17,209,739 and with the weekly average for the year to date of $20,255,283. This week's total does not take into account the issue of $50,000,000 3 2/4 per cent notes, due on Jan. 15, 1933, which the State of New York allotted.
HOUSTON, Texas, April 1 (AP). -- Wilmer Allison of Austin tonight was the lone seeded player remaining in the singles of the Houston invitation tennis tournament.
KANE, Pa., April 1. -- Dr. Evan O'Neill Kane, who drew nation-wide attention by performing two operations on himself, died in the Summit Hospital here early today of pneumonia. He was 71 years old.

The fact that foreign exchange moved against New York during the two days in which the House was deadlocked, and reversed that attitude when obstructive legislators yielded, was not of itself surprising. Variations in foreign exchange rates are influenced by the flow of international capital into or out of a given country, and they will for that reason usually reflect the shifting of financial confidence as promptly as does the stock market.

NEW DELHI, April 1. -- The Hindu members of the Indian Legislative Assembly today drafted a number of violently worded resolutions protesting against the recent decision of the All-India Moslem Conference at Lahore. It is feared here these resolutions will arouse the Moslem temper to a fresh pitch of excitement and will immensely increase the British Government's difficulties in imposing a communal settlement.

The City College lacrosse team upset Western Maryland yesterday, 4 to 1, in a fast contest at the Lewesohn Stadium. Wilie Rosenthal, playing at the out home position, was outstanding in the Lavender's victory. He tallied three goals and also excelled on the defense, especially during a spirited second-half bid by the losers.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 1. -- About 500 carpenters in Nassau County were out of work today as the result of a deadlock between the union and the Building Trades Employers' Association over a proposed wage cut of about 33 per cent. A temporary compromise agreement until Monday was reached in Suffolk County on the union's contention that a ninety-day notice was necessary before new wage scales could be put into effect.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reply to the letter of Sylvia Loines Dalton, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, may I draw attention to the fact that even if only 86,000 men were employed in the manufacture of liquor in 1914, this figure probably means that some 60,000 to 70,000 more men were employed than are at present in the beer business?

Spirits of the Democratic leaders in the House were a good deal ruffled yesterday by changes in the estimated yield of certain luxury taxes, made by Treasury experts. Their latest figures were considerably below those they bad earlier given to the Ways and Means Committee.

The Independents are all set and ready for the public influx, which begins today. Last night the sixteenth annual exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists had its private opening at the Grand Central Palace -- by card only, but plenty of cards.

William J. Flynn, Bronx Public Works Commissioner, who received yesterday his chance to discredit Louis H. Willard, who accused Flynn of ruining him and driving Mrs. "Willard to suicide, left the stand with his testimony refuted by official records and rejected by the Hofstadter committee.

Stocks extended their decline yesterday, but only moderately. The market did not exhibit the uneasiness over the stock-tax proposals that might have been expected in view of the clamor raised in Wall Street; yet there was evidence enough of genuine concern in the large community whose interests are touched directly by the Stock Exchange.

A general reduction of 20 per cent on third-class passenger fares on eastbound and round-trip crossings and a 10 per cent reduction on westbound crossings probably will be effected by all steamship lines operating in the North Atlantic trade. Following announcement of the Cunard and Anchor Lines on Thursday that this schedule would be followed on their ships, the United States Lines and the Hamburg-American Line announced similar schedules yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- A tariff bill containing radical modifications of the House Democratic tariff measure was passed in the Senate late today by means of a Democratic-Progressive coalition. The vote was 42 to 30.

Unable to meet the demand from foreign and domestic sources, and with their own portfolios reduced to the vanishing point, bill dealers yesterday slashed open-market discounts one-quarter of 1 per cent, carrying acceptance rates to 2 1/8 per cent on shorter paper, the lowest yields since last October.

As the news from Washington that the House of Representatives had voted to make dividends subject to the normal income tax sent many stocks to new low levels for the current movement yesterday, Wall Street brokerage firms and their connections sent hundreds of telegrams to Senators and Representatives protesting that the proposed stock transfer tax of one-quarter of 1 per cent would be confiscatory and destructive.
MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., April 1. -- New Jersey captured the bulk of the honors today in the second day's running of the fourth annual field trials of the Mount Holly Field Dog Club.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- When the House passed the tax bill today, the Ways and Means Committee estimated that $1,262,900,000 additional revenue had been assured for the 1933 budget, or $21,900,000 above the $1,241,000,000 estimated to be needed. The treasury calculated the total yield of the new revenue program at $1,152,900,000, or $88,100,000 short of the goal.

The fourth International Antiques Exposition opened at Grand Central Palace last night with a large attendance. The visitors found two floors given over to paneled rooms of various periods, old murals and tapestries, early Americans, as well as rugs and jewelry from the Orient.
WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The surtax rates on individual incomes finally agreed upon by the House today after rejection of the Swing amendment and the lowering of exemptions to $6,000 are as follows:

Complete estimates by Shippers' Regional Advisory Boards indicate that carload shipments of twenty-nine leading commodities in April, May and June will be about 5,082,198 cars, or 13 per cent below the loadings in the corresponding period last year. The boards have a membership of more than 16,000 persons representative of all sections and all industries, including agriculture.
WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Dr. Joseph V. Fuller, historian and chief of the Research Section of the State Department, died at Garfield Hospital today of pneumonia. He was 41 years old.

The winners in the National Bicentennial George Washington Poetry contest, sponsored by the National Life Conservation Society, were announced yesterday in Wanamaker's auditorium at the annual conservation week program conducted under the joint auspices of the State and City Federations of Women's Clubs.

A general cut of 1/8 in yield on acceptances, all dates, featured an otherwise quiet market. For comparison. present discounts about match those in effect during the first ten days in October, 1931. No great change in conditions accompanied the decline, since the market was adjusting itself to the new schedules.

Election of a new Chamber in France has been set for May 1, with a second ballot a week later in constituencies where no candidate has secured a majority. To some extent the outcome may be determined by what happens in the preceding three weeks in Germany.

The 237th New York yearly meeting of the Religious Society of Friends will be held for six days, beginning at 10 o'clock this morning at the Meeting House, 221 East Fifteenth Street, and closing with the morning session Thursday. A report will be read Tuesday night by a member of the American Friends Service Committee appointed by President Hoover to investigate conditions in the coal fields.

A national educational plan for correct speech was urged yesterday by Professor George Philip Krapp of Columbia University at the opening of the twenty-third annual convention of the Eastern Public Speaking Conference in the Casa Italiana, Amsterdam Avenue and 117th Street.

While preparations for today's Army Day parade, which commemorates the fifteenth anniversary of the entrance of the United States into the World War, were being completed, a vigorous protest against holding similar parades on Fifth Avenue in, the future was lodged with officials in charge of the demonstration by Captain William J. Pedrick, president of the Fifth Avenue Association, on behalf of his organization.

Irregular price changes were found in the trading in commodities yesterday. While the grains were lower, cotton turned up. In other sections sugar, cocoa, hides were weak, while coffee was higher. In the spot markets new lows were registered in lard, tin and rubber.
The reply of the City Affairs Committee to the statement of Governor Roosevelt when he rejected, the charges against Sheriff McQuade follows:
WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The tax bill was passed in the House today by a vote of 327 to 64, and was being prepared tonight to be sent to the Senate.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 1. -- Opening its baseball season today, the Lehigh University nine bowed to the University of Vermont team, 9 to 7.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, April 1. -- Liquor is flowing fast into Finland. All ships arriving at Finnish ports in the last week have been landing bulky wet cargoes in anticipation of the country's going off the dry standard next Tuesday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 1. -- The Arkansas delegation to the Democratic convention will go uninstructed, but the State's eighteen votes will be cast for Governor Roosevelt. The delegation was selected here today by the State Central Committee and is made up of Roosevelt supporters.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 1. -- The Yankees were cordially treated today in the first game of their schedule. The largest crowd they have seen this year, about 2,500, was in attendance.

The United States once led all the nations in the whale fishery. Moby Dick is still something more than a character in fiction; he is one of the symbols of the American tradition. Recently the Norwegians have taken an increasingly active part, especially in the Antarctic.

Deals in housing properties on the upper west side featured trading in Manhattan yesterday. Activity was quiet on the first day of the month, with brokers reporting a few scattering transactions. Thursday's brisk activity in business leasing was not maintained.

BERLIN, April 1. -- The Federation of German Industry went on record today against the adoption of a quota system for imports, at a meeting that had been looked forward to with considerable anxiety in many quarters.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 1. -- Harvard's varsity lacrosse team opened its season today by turning back the M.I.T. twelve, 9 to 0.

William Colgate of 5 East Eighty-second Street, son of the late George and Jane Cauldwell Colgate, who died at his home on March 7 in his ninety-second year, left more than $1,000,000 to twenty-one religious, charitable and public institutions and more than $1,500,000 in personal bequests, according to his will, filed for probate in the Surrogate's Court yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 1 (Canadian Press). -- The Commonwealth Government of Australia today made payments in London of u900,000 and in New York of u200,000 due as interest on bonds of the State of New South Wales, which defaulted previous payments Feb. 1.

The National Credit Corporation, the so-called bankers' pool organized last October at the instance of President Hoover to make loans to needy banks on assets ineligible for rediscount at the Federal Reserve Banks, announced yesterday the second redemption of part of its outstanding gold notes.

L.R. Powell Jr. and E.W. Smith, receivers for the Seaboard Air Line Railway, asked yesterday for the deposit of equipment trust certificates under the plan of exchange for receivers' certificates approved by the District Court for Eastern Virginia on Feb. 15.

During recent years New York has been favored by visits from several Spanish-speaking theatrical companies. Included among them was the very competent group of players from Buenos Aires. Then there was the Sierra troupe, which made so fine an impression upon audiences here by acting of a sort not common on the exuberant and tempestuous Spanish stage.

Values of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange reached a new low level for the bear market at the end of March, following a steady decline after the first week, when an upward movement ended. The early advance was halted at a level where resistance had been encountered in the two previous months.

BROOKLINE, Mass., April 1. -- Miss Marjorie Sachs of Cambridge, Mass., gained the final round in defense of her women's national indoor tennis championship at the Long-wood covered courts today by defeating Miss Mianne Palfrey of Brookline, Mass., 1930 champion, 4 -- 6, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 1.

A reduction of about $180,000,000 in the indebtedness at Federal Reserve Banks of member banks outside of New York was the most important development in the banking situation last month, says the April 1 monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

AIKEN, S.C., April 1. -- To Morning Mist, a chestnut gelding belonging to Thomas Hitchcock of Westbury, L.I., went the blue ribbon for the championship as the best hunter in the sixteenth annual Aiken Horse Show, as the last class was completed late this afternoon.

The person or the nation not prepared to make sacrifices for art is spiritually, if not economically, in a precarious condition. Professor George J. Cox of Teachers College, Columbia University, told members of the College Art Association yesterday in an address at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
With three games in Manhattan and three in Brooklyn, the national indoor polo championships get under way tonight. Play in the title competition will close on April 19.

BOWIE, Md., April 1. -- Jaz Age, owned and trained by John Parmalee, won the feature $5,000 added Inaugural Handicap as the Eastern racing season began at Bowie today, but a great share of the honors fell to Trainer Elmer Trueman who sent out the first three winners.
JACKSON, Miss., April 1 (AP). -- The cotton, tobacco and potato belt of the South has reopened thirty-one banks this year and has begun its Spring plowing with renewed faith in the soil.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 1. -- Shorter hymns, the predominance of old traditional Church tunes from every nation and sect and changes in text position are the outstanding features of the new Presbyterian hymnal which virtually was completed by the Content Committee of the Presbyterian Church which closed a five-day session here today.

PARIS, April 1. -- An ancient parchment-hued tunic, said to have been worn by Mohammed more than 1,300 years ago, will be brought to the United States this Summer by a group of Moslem converts seeking to spread Mohammedanism throughout the Western world.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 1. -- Breaklng the world's record for the second time today, the New York Athletic Club tonight retained its national senior A.A.U. championship in the 400-yard relay with a brilliant performance that brought the mark down to 3 minutes, 31 4-5 seconds.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 1. -- Mrs. Henry Ellsworth Bemis entertained more than fifty guests this afternoon at the final tea dance at The Breakers. Those present were:

PARIS, April 1. -- Activity was greatly diminished at today's session of the Bourse, influenced partly by the fall in metal prices and by unfavorable reports from foreign markets. Offers found practically no response and the whole list was affected.

TORONTO, April 1. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and the Montreal Maroons will meet tomorrow night at the Maple Leaf Gardens in the second and deciding game of the series between the second and third place play-off victors. The winning team will advance to the Stanley Cup series to engage the Rangers in the final struggle for the world's hockey championship.

The Harvard rugby team will open its season this afternoon when it meets the strong New York Rugby Club fifteen at the Polo Grounds in the first game ever played between the two organizations. The game will start at 3 o'clock, with a preliminary encounter between the two reserve teams listed for 1 o'clock.

Eight members of what George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, described as the busiest and most vicious ring of wholesale narcotic distributers in the New York area were arraigned yesterday in Federal Court following their arrest on Thursday in four secretly engineered raids made by a special squad of narcotic agents.

NEW YORK. The final Knickerbocker Assembly for this season will be held tonight in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The dances, which are arranged annually for debutantes of former years, are under the direction of Mrs. Frederick W. Longfellow and her committee, including Mrs. F. Kingsbury Curtis, Mrs. James Gore King, Mrs. Thatcher Magoun Brown, Mrs. I.N. Phelps Stokes, Mrs. Adrian V.S. Lambert. Mrs. Lyman Delano and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin.

The attempt of racketeers to chisel $2,500,000 a year from the cleaning and dyeing industry of New York has been scotched, Abraham Panken declared yesterday after signatures had been appended to an agreement creating a conference board designed to minimize disputes among the various factors in the industry.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 1. -- Bequests totaling more than $800,000, including five amounting to $73,000 to the five churches of Rockaway, are provided in the will of George W. Stickle, Morristown banker, filed for probate today in the Surrogate's office here.

Heavy engineering contracts in the United States for the week just ended total $17,400,000, which compares with $17,211,000, the average weekly valuation for March, according to Engineering News-Record. The average weekly total for the same month in 1931 was $61,836,000.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., April 1. -- Mrs. Loretta Alretus Bernard, retired actress and noted beauty of the '90s, died yesterday of pneumonia at the Englewood Hospital after a brief illness. Mrs. Bernard, whose stage name was Loretta Alretus, was a great-aunt of Bebe Daniels, screen star.
