Means of meeting the demands which the current depression has made on child life were discussed yesterday at the opening session in Brooklyn of the twelfth annual Eastern Regional Conference of the Child Welfare League of America.

The arrival of Spring has giver stimulus to retail trade and hence to manufacturing in some of the lighter lines, but industry generally is continuing quiet, according to the weekly reviews of business.

The Rev. Dr. Benjamin Clark Warren of the Coldspring Methodist Episcopal Church, Coldspring, N.Y., a minister for more than fifty-three years, suggested in an address last night to the delegates to the New York annual conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church that the authority of the Bishops be so circumscribed as to prevent its abuse in the exercise of the appointing power.

LONDON, April 1. -- Little business was done on the Stock Exchange today and prices declined all along the line. British Government funds weakened in the afternoon despite the statement by the Chancellor of the Exchequer showing that the budget had been balanced.

The march or Sammy Fuller, Boston's ring warrior, toward a world's lightweight championship battle, was halted temporarily last night by stout-hearted Jack (Kid) Berg, England's perpetual motion machine.

John Haynes Holmes and Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, representing the City Affairs Committee, struck back at Governor Roosevelt last night for his rebuke to them in refusing to remove Sheriff James A. McQuade of Kings County or to use his influence to have John Theofel, Democratic leader of Queens, ousted as Surrogate's Clerk.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S veto of Assemblyman MOFFAT'S bill directing that no primary election be held in districts in which all the nominations are uncontested, and permitting the County Committee in such cases to designate the candidates, is a triumph for principle.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 1 (AP) -- Yonkers and Johnson City tonight won their way into tomorrow night's class A final of the New York State Interscholastic basketball championship. Yonkers defeated Gloversville, 29 to 24, and Johnson City downed Lackawana, 19 to 18, in two fast semi-final games.

To the Editor of The Now York Times: Judge Seabury's recommendation in his recent report that a public defender system be inaugurated to represent accused poor persons in the lower criminal courts is a significant step in the right direction, although it falls short of the true solution of the problem.

Federal and local agencies, as well as medical authorities in various parts of the country, were stirred to action yesterday as a result of the death of Eben M. Byers, wealthy Pittsburgh steel manufacturer and sportsman, who died here Wednesday at the Doctors' Hospital from causes attributed to radium poisoning resulting from the drinking of water containing radium in solution.

Lily Pons and Beniamino Gigli sang the season's fourth "Rigoletto" at the opera yesterday afternoon, the special matinee being a benefit for Willoughby House Settlement. A well-filled house turned in a profit of upward of $2,000 at the Metropolitan, in addition to contributions made directly to the settlement.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- President Hoover today expressed the hope that Congress would legislate the Shipping Board out of existence and, in the interest of efficiency and economy, authorize the coordination of all Federal shipping agencies into a single bureau. He voiced this wish in announcing that he had no present intention of naming a successor to the late Commissioner E. C. Plummer.

Vanitie, Gerard B. Lambert's America's Cup yacht, will have the tallest mast ever stepped in a sailing vessel, either racing craft or merchantman, when she appears for competition against the Weetamoe the coming Summer. Figures on her new rig were disclosed yesterday.

The first average of commodity prices, published yesterday by Dun's Review, makes the decline in the index number during March eight-tenths of 1 per cent. Since the beginning of the year the decline has been 1 3/4 per cent, but as compared with Oct. 1 of last year the average has advanced 1 3/8 per cent.

GENEVA, April 1. -- The League of Nations Financial Committee in the report of its recent Paris session given out here tonight fairly breathes alarm over the situation of the world in general, and in particular that of Austria, Greece, Bulgaria and Hungary, with which it specifically deals.

An army of about 53,000 Block-Aiders and block chairmen was at work yesterday seeking help for nearly 10,000 of the 20,000 needy families on the lists of the Block Community Organization, it was announced by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman.
Nervous price fluctuations over a range of 15 points occurred on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and gains of 5 to 9 points were shown at the close.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read your editorial "A Democratic S O S" with equanimity at the knowledge concealed in its facetious phrases. You have been advising the Governor ever since Judge Seabury has been unearthing graft, but apparently he does not think that you are sound in your reasoning, and he is firm in the stand of following the line of least resistance.

MONTREAL, Que, April 1. -- According to information from an official source a majority of all classes of securities of the Asbestos Corporation has been deposited in acceptance of the plan of reorganization proposed for the company. The original term of deposit expired today, but an extension to April 15 has been arranged in order to provide for the receipt of securities coming from a distance.

Sirens wailed and bus riders and pedestrians screamed and shouted in Fifth Avenue at Forty-seventh Street yesterday as two-score policemen rounded up two hold-up men and a woman who had shot a jeweler and slugged his wife in Room 2110 of the Empire Trust Building.

ALBANY, April 1.- Three measures which will prepare the way for extension of emergency unemployment relief under State auspices until Nov. 15, and probably beyond that date, received the approval of Governor Roosevelt today.

Representatives of one of the strongest syndicates ever formed to bid on the bonds of a State other than New York met yesterday in the offices of the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation to consider the lending of $9,000,000 to the State of Tennessee.

PARIS, April 1. -- A great international industrial combination ceased to exist today when the countries belonging to the European Steel Cartel allowed the day to go by without renewing their agreement.
NAPLES, April 1. -- Inhabitants of Villa Santo Stefano, midway between Naples and Rome, saw their town disappearing today into the ancient Roman caves over which it is built, and fled for safety.

Mayor Walker took steps yesterday that promise a speedy rehabilitation of the long dormant project for a model multiple-dwelling development on the Chrystie-Forsyth Streets area, where the city many months ago acquired and razed seven blocks of old-law tenements in a street-widening improvement.

TOKYO, April 1. -- The Japanese War Office agreed today not to occupy the Woosung forts or the village of Kiangwan at Shanghai. Fresh instructions accordingly were sent by the general staff to General Tashiro, military attache at Shanghai which are expected to enable the peace conference to reach an agreement regarding the proposed new Japanese line.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- With the movement for the $2,000,000,000 World War bonus apparently gaining strength every day, a program for hearings before the House Ways and Means Committee is now being worked out.

LONDON, April 1. -- Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw, Lord Privy Seal in the present coalition government of Great Britain, availed himself to the uttermost today of the liberty granted to free-trade members of the Cabinet to oppose the government protectionist policy without resigning.

Major Charles H. Schoeffel, second in command of New Jersey State Police, is on his way to England on a mission connected with the search for the kidnapped Lindbergh baby, it was announced officially yesterday as the investigation of the crime entered its second month.

After the flurry of excitement on the day before which resulted from the adoption by the House of a greatly increased tax on stock sales, the market on the Stock Exchange became more orderly yesterday and, of course, less interesting. The proceedings were dull, although business was a trifle more active.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 1. -- Miss Maureen Orcutt, the Englewood (N.J.) star, who won the North and South women's championship last year, and Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City will meet tomorrow for the 1932 crown.

Albert Poensgen, German billiard star, grained the world's amateur 18.2 balkline billiard championship for the second successive year by defeating Gustave Van Belle, his Belgian rival, in their play-off at the Elks Club last night.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 1. -- Members of the New Haven Junior League, assisted by Yale students, staged tonight the annual junior league revue for the benefit of charity in the Shubert Theatre. Twenty scenes in two acts comprised the program which was featured by songs, dances, and comedy skits.

LONDON, April 1. -- Prime Minister MacDonald had an audience with the King at Windsor Castle today, where it is believed he explained the present policy of the government on the Danubian situation, which is to be discussed in London next week by representatives of Great Britain, France, Germany and Italy.

Plans for a reorganization of General Theatres Equipment, Inc., are expected to be announced on Monday, little more than a month after receivers were appointed for the company by the Chancery Court of Delaware on Feb. 29. Interest was defaulted yesterday on $30,000,000 of 6 per cent convertible debentures, due in 1940.

State and municipal issues monopolized the new offerings of bonds this week. Seventeen of this classification totaling $18,012,222 were placed on the market. It was the first week since mid-February that no new public utility or other corporation financing was done.

CHICAGO, April 1. -- Bullish news fell flat today as a market influence on the Board of Trade here. A small buying movement carried prices up fractionally early, but when the private crop reports were given out showing a prospective yield of 500,000,000 bushels, compared with 787,000,000 harvested last year and a 1924-28 average of 551,000,000 bushels, the market failed to respond.

HONOLULU, April 1. -- The trial of Mrs. Granville Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, her son-in-law, and two naval enlisted men, E.J. Lord and Albert O. Jones, for the murder of Joseph Kahahawai, Hawaiian, probably will open Monday as already arranged, unless Clarence Darrow asks for an adjournment of a few days because of some unforseen obstacle.
WASHINGTON, April 1. -- March income tax collections amounted to about $195,000,000, a decline of $140,000,000 from March, 1931, according to figures available at the treasury today.

Architects have taken steps to help those out of employment and at the same time to advance the general interests of their profession through researches and competitions. Over 2,000 of the estimated 4,000 out of work have registered with the committee, the large majority of them with dependents.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Political consequences to men and parties of the passage by the House today of the tax bill which balances the Federal budget were carefully weighed in Washington after the weary Representatives completed their labors. A digest of views expressed publicly and privately by those who have been in the thick of the fight, and by those who have occupied the role of experienced onlookers, seemed to lead to these conclusions:
TEL-AVIV, Palestine, April 1 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- A crowd of 25,000 watched with emotion the conclusion of the first Jewish Olympics held in Palestine yesterday.

Reed Harris, Columbia University senior and editor of the Columbia Spectator, who aroused members of the football team and alumni of the university last Fall with published charges that the sport was a "semiprofessional racket," announced last night that he had been expelled from the university yesterday through the action of Dean Herbert E. Hawkes and members of the Committee on Instructions.

Defending his regime against the charge that lack of administration was responsible for "what's wrong with the undergraduates of Princeton," Dr. John Grier Hibben, retiring president of the university, declared last night that the only discipline that was worth while was "self-discipline."

The Japanese Room of the St. Regis was the scene last night of the annual dinner dance of the North Carolina Society of New York, Many members of the organization and their guests composed the dinner parties at the tables.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Loans authorized by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation between Feb. 2 and March 31 amounted to $238,739,939.06, of which $192,346,308.01 has been actually advanced and $7,471,894.36 repaid, leaving $184,874,413.65 now outstanding, the corporation announced today in its first quarterly report to Congress.

New Park Lights. The new traffic lights in Central Park ought to mean a great improvement. From the day when it was decided to make through motor arteries of the old East and West drives it has been evident that a better form of control was required.

Open discord arose in the Board of Estimate meeting yesterday over the city's retrenchment program, with Joseph V. McKee, President of the Board of Aldermen, labeling the board's resolution rescinding about $213,000,000 in public improvements as "only a bookkeeping gesture," and the Mayor presenting it as evidence of the economy program on which he said the granting of another $100,000,000 loan by the bankers within two weeks depended.

MANILA, P.I., April 1. -- Philippine Democrats in convention here today elected an uninstructed delegation of six and adopted a resolution strongly condemning present bills under consideration in Congress to grant independence to the islands.

IN the Autumn of 1886 there came a knock on the door of the room of a freshman at Yale. The freshman opened the door and beheld a lordly sophomore. "Freshman," said the soph briskly, "your name Sherrill?"

SHANGHAI, April 1. -- While the Sino-Japanese armistice conferees are working late tonight in preparation for what is expected to be the final struggle to reach an agreement tomorrow, events of the gravest moment are proceeding in other parts of China.

MOSCOW, April 1. -- Robert P. Lamont Jr. seems to have arrived in Russia at the right moment to advise the Russians about stock breeding, as there was published today a stern edict, signed by Josef Stalin, Premier Molotoff and Commissar of Agriculture Yakovleff, denouncing the mismanagement of State cattle, sheep, pig and poultry farms and ordering the dismissal of ninety-four managers and criminal proceedings against thirty-five others.

Captain Harry Wright Rogers, pioneer flier, operator and airplane designer, died in Flushing Hospital yesterday after a crash in Bowery Bay, adjoining Glenn Curtiss Airport at North Beach, Queens. Edward Ortega, a mechanic, who was flying with Rogers, received a broken collarbone and possible internal injuries.

BUDAPEST, April 1. -- Riotous scenes were enacted in the Hungarian Parliament today when it became known government expenditures had exceeded the budget by $7,500,000 for the first half of the current fiscal year. In an attempt to avoid a deficit the civil service personnel had been reduced to a minimum, the heating of schools had been abandoned and the transfer of payments on foreign debts stopped.

The New York Telephone Company threw its corporate strength against a tradition yesterday with sad results. The April fool victims kept begging for Mr. Fish at the Aquarium, Mr. Hale at the Weather Bureau, Mr. Lyons at the Zoo and Mr. Payne of Bellevue Hospital.

BUDAPEST, April 1. -- Riotous scenes were enacted in the Hungarian Parliament today when it became known government expenditures had exceeded the budget by $7,500,000 for the first half of the current fiscal year. In an attempt to avoid a deficit the civil service personnel had been reduced to a minimum, the heating of schools had been abandoned and the transfer of payments on foreign debts stopped.

The New York Telephone Company threw its corporate strength against a tradition yesterday with sad results. The April fool victims kept begging for Mr. Fish at the Aquarium, Mr. Hale at the Weather Bureau, Mr. Lyons at the Zoo and Mr. Payne of Bellevue Hospital.

ALBANY, April 1. -- After a talk over the telephone today with his chief political lieutenant, James A. Farley, chairman of the State Committee, who had just returned to New York City from the West, Governor Roosevelt announced this evening that he had accepted an invitation from the Democratic organization in Minnesota to deliver a Jefferson Day address at St. Paul, April 18.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1. -- This may have been All Fools' Day, but decidedly the Giants were not in a mood for fooling, as behind another brilliant pitching effort by the serious-minded young Harold Schumacher they shut out the San Francisco Mission club by a score of 4 to 0.

Statistics on management expenses of large buildings compiled by Norbert Brown, show that of seventeen New York City structures operation expenditures averaged 59.3 cents per square foot of rentable area. Fixed charges, such as insurance, taxes, and depreciation, averaged 28 cents.

WASHINGTON, Pa., April 2 -- Washington and Jefferson College, oldest in America west of the Allegheny Mountains, inaugurated Dr. Ralph Cooper Hutchison as its new president this afternoon. He is the ninth to hold the position since Jefferson College, Canonsburg, and Washington College, of this place, were consolidated in 1865.

IN his "Human Values and Verities," of 1928, Dr. Taylor spoke of "nearing the close" of his "long education" and his "yearning for synthesis" of the forms of knowledge and attainment set forth in his six previously published books.

PARIS, April 2 -- Hoarders of French banknotes here and abroad have withdrawn from circulation about 20,000,000,000 francs [about $800,000,000] in bills of large denominations, Stephane Lauzanne, editor of Le Matin, estimates from statistics issued by the Bank of France.

PARIS, April 2 -- The resolution adopted Wednesday by the American Chamber of Commerce here appealing to President Hoover for relief against the import quota system imposed by the French Government was presented to Ambassador Edge today.

BERKELEY, Cal., April 2 -- Southern California's Trojans sent California's Bears down to an overwhelming 102 1-3-to-28 2-3 defeat today in a track and field meet that lost much of its glamour through the last-minute withdrawal of Frank Wykoff, Trojan sprint ace, from the 220-yard dash.

THE dramatization of labor troubles in Harlan and Bel Counties in Kentucky has spread an impression that those few square miles of hills sun up the national soft-coal problem. In point of numbers involved this is far from accurate.

Holdings of Arthur Curtiss James in the Great Northern Railway, listed under the Curtiss Southwestern Company, did not change in 1931, according to the list of the twenty largest stockholders of the road. The list as of Dec. 31 follows:

The Optimists came through against Yale last night in the opening game of the national open polo championship by a score of 10 to 7 1/2, but only after four of the hardest, most bitterly fought periods the indoor game has seen this season.

INDIA is a land of glamour and contrast -- a land of color and of cruelty, of abundance and of extreme poverty, of magnificence and of misery, of sunshine and of damp, enervating heat. She is a land of teeming millions speaking in scores of languages and practicing many sharply divergent religions.

EDWARD HENRY GORDON CRAIG (Christianly named when he was quite grown up for big father and Henry Irving jointly -- with the Gordon thrown in for his godmother, a lady with a title) -- Edward Henry Gordon Craig, son of Ellen Terry, has written another book mainly about himself.

THOSE who make it a practice to celebrate centenaries of great national events with learn with chagrin what an opportunity escaped them last year. For a popular error, supported no doubt by the author's faulty memory, has fixed the date of composition of the famous hymn "America" in the year 1832.

The city P.S.A.L. senior high School basketball championship will be at stake in the season's second meeting between Textile of Manhattan and James Monroe of the Bronx at the 102d Engineers Armory on Saturday afternoon, when the curtain will be lowered on the 1931-32 scholastic campaign.

BOWIE, Md., April 2 -- Air Pilot, second last year in the Breeders' Futurity at Churchill Downs and an eligible for the Kentucky Derby, to be contested there on May 7, made an impressive 3-year-old debut today when he captured the feature Capitol Purse from eight other smart 3-year-olds.

WASHINGTON THE Democrats are supposed control the House of Representatives. In the Senate the Republicans officially prevail. For some years Republican responsibility for the actions of the Senate has been a fiction.

VIENNA, March 10, 1932 THE Vienna State Opera is negotiating with Maria Olszewska for her reappearance on its boards. On the conclusion recently of her engagement at the Chicago Opera she met Director Clemens Krauss of the Vienna State Opera, who urged her to return to the Vienna company.
LONDON, April 2 -- Distrust in the dollar last week was exaggerated and not justified by facts, in the opinion of Sir Walter Layton's Weekly Economist.

The Holland-America Line announced reductions in fares yesterday to conform with the sweeping reductions announced in all classes of other lines last week. The new rates become effective with the sailing of the Veendam for Europe April 13.

LONDON, April 1 -- Great Britain's policy for the economic rehabilitation of the Danubian States, which is the outstanding European question for the immediate future, is exactly the same in principle as that which she hopes to see adopted at the British Empire conference in Ottawa next July.

A NEEDLEWOMAN of more than average skill employed in one of New York's exclusive dress shops lost her job a few months ago because the volume of business had decreased. Jobless, she faced the problem of supporting her two children and an invalid sister.

The New York Rugby Club defeated the Harvard fifteen by 11 -- 7 at the Polo Grounds yesterday in the opening game of the season for the Crimson. In a preliminary game the New York seconds were victorious over the Harvard seconds, 5 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The four years' war waged by Federal authorities on Chicago gangs, culminating in 1931 with the sentencing of Al Capone to eleven years in a Federal penitentiary, was described in detail for the first time today through the publication of testimony given by George E.Q. Johnson.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, April 2 (AP). -- Japanese infantry, fighting a fierce battle against Chinese insurgent forces at Nungan, thirty-five miles north of here, smashed through the insurgent lines this afternoon and occupied the town, turning back a serious threat against the new government of Henry Pu Yi.

DOES, any one ever express a fear of what the talkies may do to the circus? Do astute observers of the American scene ever discourse on the way the motor car, the moving pictures, prohibition and a jazz-crazed civilization are dealing knockout blows to the world under the big top?

MANY thousands of years ago a primitive man, squatting in the dust, traced with his finger for the benefit of his younger and less experienced fellows the path by which the deer went down through the forest at night to drink at the moonlit water-hole.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., April 2 -- Believing that he has established the actual movements of Colonel P.H. Fawcett, British explorer, some forty miles further in Central Brazil than any other living white man, Vincenzo Petrullo, research associate in anthropology of the University of Pennsylvania Museum, today disclosed information which, in his opinion, leaves little doubt that Colonel Fawcett died of starvation and thirst.

The week-end markets yesterday were confused and did not move in unison. Stocks declined and recovered; home bonds were pretty generally weak; wheat prices rose 3 cents. Apparently the stock market was endeavoring to express its conviction as to how badly it would be hurt if the tax on stock transactions were to be enacted.

Competition in the city P.S.A.L. swimming, fencing and rifle tournaments will be resumed on Saturday morninig, when contests in the tourneys, halted because of the Easter vacation recess, will be held for the first time since March 19.

To the Art Editor: YOUR discussion of murals for Radio City is most welcome. If the average insipid American work were all that one had to choose from, an endorsement of a pro-American program would be impossible.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 2 -- Enrolled voters of Westchester County will register their approval of their parties' delegates and alternates to the Democratic and Republican National Conventions in the State-wide primary on Tuesday. There are no contests for delegates or alternates in Westchester.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 2 -- Miss Lorna Whittelsey of Greenwich, Conn., continued her streak of dinghy sailing victories by capturing four of six contests held today by the Frostbite Yacht Club off the Knickerbocker Yacht Club's landing on Manhasset Bay.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Secretary Stimson will leave next week for his long-expected visit to the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva. He will go for the announced purpose of considering means to facilitate the work of the conference but under circumstances which in political and diplomatic opinion here almost inevitably will lead to important discussions of political and financial problems of Europe with Premiers and Foreign Ministers.

GENEVA, April 1 -- Neither in the League nor in the World Bank do financial circles here appear to have been frightened by the way the House of Representatives in Washington has been dealing with the task of balancing the United States budget as much as some of those in London and Paris and other capitals where national or material interests have a way of influencing printed judgments.

JUAN DE LA CIERVA, like so many successful inventors and research workers, has gone back to fundamentals in his work of developing the autogiro or windmill plane. The first autogiro flew successfully without wings. Stability was maintained by supporting the vanes on an articulated shaft, instead of the one in use now, which is rigid in its position perpendicular to the fuselage and the path of flight.

That a French Huguenot should have been the earliest American ancestor of GEORGE WASHINGTON and should also have been the "original patentee for Yorktown, Virginia," presents a poetic coincidence in truth that takes on the aspect of destiny. The inscription which records these facts marks the Site of the home of NICHOLAS MARTIAU the adventurous Huguenot who was born in France 1591 came to Virginia 1620 and died in Yorktown 1657.

FOR Douglas Dumbrille -- and you might as well learn now as later that he is the one-handed cigarette maker, Panama Joe, in "Child of Manhattan" -- life has always been full of big decisions, the first of which tracked him down in Hamilton, Ont., and fairly put him on the spot.

HIS name is Carl Laemmle Jr. and he is filled with the elation of a very young man in a fascinating job. As overlord of the production activities of Universal Pictures Corporation he made recently one of his annual pilgrimages to New York in search of stories for next season.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 3. -- The Japanese War Office has obtained the Emperor's sanction to send a new ' military expedition into Manchuria. The additional force, of unannounced strength, will cross the Korean border into the Chientao district and engage the Chinese troops Under General Wang Teh-lin.

DETERMINED to make good the failure, owing to bad luck with the weather, of Seiji Yoshihara's attempt to fly the Pacific last Summer, the Hochi, newspaper of Tokyo, is now sponsoring two attempts, which will he made in 1932 with all that forethought and careful organization can do to achieve success.

EVER since the appearance of "Pudd'nhead Wilson," Mark Twain's famous story of the mixed babies, fingerprints seem to be associated in the public mind exclusively with crime. In that story, the rustic jury laughed at the bright young lawyer who had been experimenting with the then newfangled notion of fingerprints, only to be thoroughly discomfited when he proved by this strange medium that the babies actually had been mixed.

ONE of the artistic needs of the Metropolitan Opera Company, recognized for seasons past, has been new ideas and energy nstage direction. This situation was met for the performances of 1931-32 by the engagement of the two new stage directors, Alessandro Sanine and Hanns Niedecken-Gebhard.

A WIDENING interest in antiques for actual use as well as for collectors' items is graphically shown at the Antiques Exposition now at the Grand Central Palace. Some connoisseurs, of course, specialize in only one type of ancient craft-work, such as Chelsea porcelains or pewter, but the broader interest of the majority of antique lovers leads them to collect many types of furnishings.

A 50 per cent increase in the number of homes using gas for hezting was noted in 1931 in The tomorrow served by the Consolidated GES Company of New York and its afffciated companies. The area includes Manhattan, Bronx, "Westchester and portions of Queens.

WHEN the Russian Communist party carried out its successful revolution in October, 1917, it had only 40,000 members in all Russia. The Communist party in Germany today has on its rolls more than six times that number -- 245,000.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 2 -- Complimenting Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Howes, Mayor and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. entertained tonight with a dinner at Casa del Pastor. Others present were:

LIKE most men who have made a large splash in the world's affairs, Henry Ford has been regarded as a man of mystery. With possibly a billion dollars at his disposal he has seemed a million times more mysterious than a citizen with only a thousand dollars.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- White House members today rested bodies weary and nerves frazzled from tax bill labors in their third Saturday recess of the entire session, Dr. George W. Calver, the House physician, installed a miniature hospital in the Capitol.
CHERBOURG, March 12 -- The first deep-water dock, 640 meters long, which is included in the port improvement and extension work now under construction at the port of Cherbourg, has been opened.

PAST generations will remember a romantic (oh, so romantic!) drama based on the short but thrilling career of Robert Emmet. They will also remember poems and declamatory prose-pieces concerned with the illfated insurrection of 1803.
GRAND CENTRAL PALACE -- Annual exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists opened with a private view Friday evening and to the public Saturday. Reviewd yesterday. It remains until April 26.

DETROIT A GREAT change has taken place in Detroit. The automobile industry has begun to move at a feverish pace reminiscent of those climactic days of 1929. There is a widespread conviction that the industry finally has done the thing that every one has been waiting for, as heralded in pronouncements by two of the leading figures in the industry.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- The Phillies started in their customary Spring series style by beating the Athletics, American League champions, in the first game of the city series at Shibe Park today, 8 to 4.

BERLIN, April 2 -- The Boerse opened weak today and rallied later, stocks advancing generally after making early losses. Business, which was quiet at first, improved quickly, the demand for leading securities being relatively large. The upward movement was the result of the especially favorable status of the Reichsbank, which brings a reduction of the discount rate into the range of early possibilities.

OSSINING, N.Y., April 2 -- Without reducing the quantity or quality of ration, the cost of feeding Sing Sing's prison population has just been cut 10 per cent, Warden Lewis E. Lawes announced today. The State formerly spent an average of 26 cents daily for food and drink for each of the 2,475 inmates.

BERLIN, March 31 -- Prophets of the occult are enjoying a bull market in Germany these days, and the sancturns of clairvoyants and star gazers are increasingly being sought out by perplexed people who believe the solutions of their mundane worries must surely be locked up in the zodiac.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 31. -- Wet sentiment in North Carolina, which is now more aggressive than at any time since the adoption of State prohibition in 1908, is finding a rallying point in the candidacy of Robert H. Reynolds for the United States Senate with the result that the opposition to Senator Cameron Morrison is being taken much more seriously than it was a month ago, although the latter is still expected to win.

Germany will choose a President next Sunday; in November the United States win choose an occupant for its White House. These events have focused attention not only on the notable "White Houses" of the two continents and their symbolism but on the men who live in them and hold the executive power.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., April 2 -- Mont Pleasant High School of Schenectady, N.Y., won the final of the Eastern States interscholastic basketball tournament tonight, defeating St. Benedict's Prep of Newark, N.J., 37 to 26.

"Block-Aid Sunday" will be observed in many churches today where clergymen will preach on the meaning of the movement to "stamp out want" for the 20,000 families which are not receiving aid from public or private welfare organizations.

RICHMOND, Va., April 2 (AP) -- The Governors of the nation, meeting here here April 24-28, will take this year's annual conference "on the fly." Throughout the five days they will be traveling almost continually, visiting historic shrines.

Both advocates and opponents of price maintenance are awaiting with a great deal of interest the decision of the Federal Trade Commission on the Armand Company case, which has been in the process of litigation nearly ten years and on which final arguments were made before the commission last week.

IN "Search" Lincoln Ellsworth has drawn with broad and colorful strokes a picture of his quest for an elusive goal.In each chapter is recorded a series of adventures, some of which can never be repeated.

OMAHA, March 31. -- With Iowa's twenty-six delegates added to the Roosevelt string, the friends of the New York Governor anticipate another easy victory in the Nebraska primary on April 12. His opponents for this State's popular preference will be Speaker Garner and Governor Murray of Oklahoma.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., April 2 -- A mahogany lowboy with silver mounts, which once belonged to George Washington, is to become the property of the Mount Vernon Ladies Association of the Union, according to a decree just handed down by Judge Arthur M. Robinson of the Probate Court.

WASHINGTON THAT there should have been disappointment in some quarters over the failure of the House of Representatives to retain the sales tax provision of the new revenue bill was inevitable. This springs, more or less, from the almost universal desire on the part of business men, both large and small, to see Federal expenditures come within the limits of Federal income.

THE abuses that have been disclosed do not strike at people of wealth and power. They oppress those who are poor and helpless, under circumstances where the oppressor enjoys practical immunity. A court in which these practices could have obtained, or in which they may obtain again, is not a court of justice.

Members of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform will meet in Washington on April 12 and 13 for their third annual conference. Officials said yesterday that the convention would act on the determination of members "either to take prohibition out of the 1932 campaign completely by securing repeal planks in both platforms, or failing that, to make it the paramount issue."

With the question, "Is the Gulf Stream coming closer?" PHILIP E. CHURCH of Clark University begins an article in the April Geographical Review. That temperatures in the Gulf Stream and bordering waters have a moderating effect upon climate in countries whose shores it approaches has long been known.

WHAT with Ernst Lubitsch's unfaltering direction and Maurice Chevalier's engaging portrayal, "One Hour With You," a picture which has the distinction of being on exhibition simultaneously at both the Rivoli and Rialto, is a most enjoyable offering, wherein the imaginative German director indulges his characteristic flair for risque incidents and smart patter.

Although Governor Roosevelt and former Governor Smith are rival aspirants for the Democratic nomination for President, their supporters will clash in only one district in the New York State primary election on Tuesday. The one contest for delegates to the Democratic National Convention in this State is in the Forty-first Congressional District, In Buffalo.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Some foreign markets for American products are reported slightly more optimistic in the current weekly survey of business abroad made by the Department of Commerce.

Dexter Fellows, who has been the advance guard of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus these many years, had another announcement yesterday. Tuesday night will see the circus almost intact in Madison Square Garden. Only the mysterious "Man From India" will be missing.
BOSTON, April 2 (AP) -- The Providence Reds overcame the Boston Cubs with a display of speed tonight to win the opening game of the Canadian-American Hockey League's championship series, 4 to 2.

FOR this volume Miss Addams has collected ten memorial addresses which she has delivered at various times during her long residence in Chicago. Five of these are for women and four for men who were identified in various ways with the earlier efforts at Hull House, and the tenth is for a child.

Students of Columbia University rallied yesterday to the defense of Heed Harris, editor-in-chief of The Columbia Spectator, who was expelled on Friday, and the American Civil Liberties Union offered to fight his expulsion in court if investigation showed a basis for legal action.

Creation of an agency charged With the task of cleaning the city's harbor of driftwood dangerous to river traffic and navigation was urged in an interview yesterday by Captain R. Drace White, U.S.N., supervisor of New York Harbor. The agency envisaged by Captain White would do for the harbor what the Street Cleaning Department does for the streets of New York.

The ninety-six college girls, students of sociology at fourteen Eastern Institutions who came to New York to see "theory in practice," under the auspices of the Association of Volunteers in Social Service, ended their three-day inspection tour of social agencies yesterday.

BANOS, Ecuador, March 19 (By mail via Guayaquil). -- We are about to plunge into what is known as the Dark Oriente, with its snakes, its jaguars and its tribes of treacherous Jivero Indians, those dangerous people who think nothing of decapitating even the most intrepid explore and shrinking his head to a souvenir -- in books.
FORT ERIE, Ont., April 2 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bisons jumped into the lead in the International Hockey League's round robin play-off series tonight by handing the Windsor Bulldogs a 3-to-1 defeat.

ANNA STEN, the Russian actress who supported Emil Jannings in "Tempest" and who appeared also in the German version of "The Brothers Karamazov," has been engaged by Samuel Goldwyn for United Artists. Miss Sten was born in Kiev of a Russian father and a Swedish mother.

OF all American classics Emerson most certainly grows with time and reveals new riches to new men. Within a few months we have had fine chapters about him in books by Henry S. Canby and Ludwig Lewisohn, an essay by Henry Hazlitt, the lectures by Bliss Perry.

ATLANTA, April 1. -- Indictments charging attempt to incite to insurrection for which it is possible to mete out the death penalty on conviction, against six alleged Communists were dismissed today in Fulton Superior Court by an order of Judge Edgar E. Pomeroy, who upheld a demurrer on the ground that the indictments did not set out enough specific alleged acts of violation.

IT was not so many years ago that with the passing of Winter radio engineers abandoned attempts to stage transatlantic broadcasts. But not so in 1932. They have made much headway with the oversea technique. Unseen forces that lurked over the ocean to stop the performances have been conquered.

MOSCOW, April 2. -- Joseph Stalin today sent The Associated Press correspondent a letter in which he gave assurances that he was in good health, and expressed ironical regret over the necessity of disappointing those who wished to see him otherwise.

HELSINGFORS, April 2 -- Finland's expectations of a return of liquor next Tuesday apparently are to be disappointed. A serious dispute has arisen at the last moment between the government alcohol monopoly and the nation's restaurant proprietors over the prices the latter are to be permitted to charge for drinks.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- At the end of the ninth month of the fiscal year the government on Thursday showed an increase of $451,000,000 in expenditures for the fiscal year to that date and a decrease of $836,000,000 in receipts as compared with 1931.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index is back to its previous low point of 60.4. Only the adjusted index of automobile production showed an advance, and, although the declines in three of the other components were not severe, freight car loadings show a relapse from the upward movement of the two preceding weeks, which was caused largely by the increased demand for coal for heating purposes.
With the exception of coffee, all contracts for commodity futures on local Exchanges lost ground last week. Sugar, cocoa, rubber, hides and wool tops felt the pressure of the adverse trend.

Butter. Receipts. 5,692 Packages. With no buying support and some pressure to sell, prices sagged off about 1/2c on nearly all grades of fresh butter. Limited business at the decline and tone unsettled.

A COMPLETE new line of 1932 trucks and commercial vehicles has been announced by the Willys-Overland Company. The line comprises three groups -- model C-113, 1/2 ton, with wheelbase of 113 inches; model C-131, 1 1/2 ton, with 131-inch wheelbase, and model C-157, 1 1/2 ton, with 151-inch wheelbase.

PARIS, April 2 -- Tomorrow evening the Prime Ministers of France and Great Britain will sit down together in London to discuss the situation in Europe and what must be done to prevent a complete collapse over large areas with disastrous results for all.

THE redesigned Plymouth is out today. Varied in appearance, the new car is presented in nine body styles with horsepower increased to 65. The wheelbase has been lengthened from 109 to 112 inches in eight of the models, the other -- the seven-passenger sedan -- having a wheelbase of 121 inches.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 2 -- Princeton opened its baseball season today by defeating the University of Vermont, 6 to 5. Eight errors marred the play as both teams weakened in the late innings.

YOUNG matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons are taking an active interest in the arrangements for the tea and fashion show in aid of Everybody's Thrift Shop, which will take place on Tuesday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

Magistrate Michael A. Ford, at the close of a summons proceeding in the Tombs court yesterday, held four midtown news-stand owners in $500 bail each for trial in Special Sessions on charges of violating Section 1141 of the penal law in the sale early in the year of alleged obscene magazines and other publications.

WHEN the Butterfly Ball is held on Friday night at the Ritz-Carlton it will mark the culmination of weeks of effort on the part of younger members of society who each year give much of their time and interest in arranging this dance for the benefit of the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge near Yonkers.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 2 -- The Giants' intensive training manoeuvres advanced to that stage today where they found themselves called upon to prepare for an April series in Boston and climatic conditions here at once lent themselves to the idea.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP). -- Legislation to permit a State to tax national banks on the same basis as other business and financial institutions was urged before a Senate committee today by California State officials and opposed by a representative of the California Bankers' Association.

EL PASO, Texas, April 2 (AP) -- Straight-shooting riders pushed man-hunt on both sides of the Mexican border tonight for three bandits who killed seven members of the family of Melqulades Espinosa, a Berino (N.M.) dairyman, in a robbery attempt last night.

TODAY. 11:30 A.M. -- Tom McLaughlin, youthful baritone, the newest recruit to Major Bowes's "family" circle, faces a microphone for this WEAF song recital. Starting his vocal career at the age of 14, when he broadcast over KFI, Los Angeles, he was then known as the world's youngest baritone.

Sounding a note of confidence in victory next Fall, Democrats of the country assembled in force for the annual Jefferson Day dinner of the National Democratic Club at the Commodore last night and heard Senator Robert J. Bulkley of Ohio demand inclusion of a prohibition referendum plank in the national platform of the party.

LONDON, April 2 -- Edward Marjoribanks, a brilliant young Member of Parliament and the author of the best seller. "The Life of Sir Edward Marshall-Hall," shot himself last night at the home of his stepfather, Viscount Hailsham, Secretary of State for War. The body was discovered lying on the floor of the billiard room with a gun beside it.

HOLLTWOOD, Cal. THE cinema rarely does things half way. From the squeaky days of the audibles when music was forced into each production, with or without reason, pictures overnight would not permit even the lilting warble of birds because "the public was off the song stuff."

NANKING, April 2. -- General Chiang Kai-sheh, Chinese leader, said today that Manchuria was still part of China and that China would resist with arms any further attacks of the Japanese, although she was not preparing for war.

BUDAPEST, March 17 -- The famous racing stable in Kisgyalla belonging to Count Christopher Festetics has fallen victim to the prevailing economic crisis in an extraordinary way. The valuable horses, after first being condemned to slaughter and the butcher's shop, were finally rescued for a new life on peasant farms through the system of barter which is becoming general in the Hungarian countryside.

PARIS, April 2 (Canadian Press) -- The Radical Socialists under the leadership of former Premier Edouard Herriot are entering the French general election campaign in the confident belief that they will make a net gain of about thirty seats la the polling on May 1 and May 8.

BRUSSELS, March 19 -- Whitney Warren would be greatly surprised if he could see his Louvain University Library today. During the period of construction he was reproached for having created something much too big -- with putting up another university, as the university balls are not very imposing and Louvain, like Oxford and Cambridge, is a university in itself, there being lecture halls and schools, throughout the inner part of the town.

With Wall Street angrily resisting the proposed increase in the Federal tax on stock sales, the continued selling on the Stock Exchange yesterday was generally regarded as an expression of the prevailing dissatisfaction. The market averages fell at one time to the lowest level thus far this year, which also means the lowest for the entire "bear movement."

HERE is an authoritative book on Japan, based on study of her political, economic, religious, philosophical and literary background. Mr. Sansom describes how Japan grew to be what she is today, tracing her cultural history from prehistoric origins to the decline of feudalism and the opening of door's to the West in the best short work ever written on the subject by a Western scholar.

BOSTON, April 2 -- Seven adventurers and explorers, starting from Boston on July 1, will plunge into the dense Brazilian wilderness this Summer with the prime object of hunting Colonel P.H. Fawcett, lost explorer.

McKinley's Favorite Hymn. A correspondent asks for President McKinley's favorite hymn. It was sung at his funeral in Canton, Ohio -- "Lead, Kindly Light." His last spoken words when he died at Buffalo were: "Nearer, My God; to Thee." I was in the church during, his funeral, the president of the McKinley Memorial Association that placed his last used words in bronze and tablet on the heroic statue to perpetuate his memory.

Mr. Curry Misunderstood. A striking instance of words twisted out of their obvious meaning is Mr. Curry of Tammany's remark while chatting with the reporters In Washington. Said Mr. Curry, brief and economical, the way Tammany always is:

LONDON, April 2 -- Gilt-edge securities reacted sharply in a depressing day on the Stock Exchange. International shares likewise were weak as a result of Wall Street's declines yesterday and none of the leadlng issues except Brazilian Traction recovered its losses before the close.

STOCKHOLM, March 21 -- Rarely has this beautiful Swedish capital presented such an air of determined poise as during these days of crisis succeeding the tragic death of Ivar Kreuger, Swedish match king and one of the world's foremost International financiers.
DETROIT, April 2 (AP) -- Two changes occurred among the American Bowling Congress tournament leaders, as a result of today's bombardment of the pins.

THE new Ford V-8 went on display last Thursday at the Ford Motor Company's building, 1,710 Broadway, and at central points throughout the country. While the new models were not available for exhibit at dealers' showrooms, it is hoped to have them in these places within the week.

THIS book by the able Berlin correspondent of The New York Evening Post embodies the series of articles published recently by Mr. Knickerbocker in that journal after a two months trip through Germany in "the midst of 'its hardest Winter in a century' and in the first period of 'the Hitler era.' "

The public domain of the United States still includes about 180,000,000 acres of unappropriated lands in Nevada, Utah, California and other Western States. Secretary WILBUR has always been in favor of turning these public lands, with certain reservations, over to the individual States in which they are situated.

Whenever two boxers clash in the ring there is always a winner. A draw result is an impossibility. That is the opinion of Abe Roth of Los Angeles, regarded by fight followers on the Coast as one of the outstanding referees in the game.

PARIS, April 2 -- The Bourse was irregular during most of today's session, but at the close the greater part of the market was firm, with the exception of the international stocks. French industrials and banks strengthened. The volume of trading was light as is usual on Saturdays.

PARIS. A YEAR ago M. Georges Duhamel's "Scenes de la vie future" created a stir in both America and France. Many of its readers believed then that M. Dubamel was accusing American civilization of destroying the classical Occidental civilization to which it was traditionally attached.

OF all the States in the Union none has more wealth of historic traditions than Virginia. Wherever the motorist may wander he will find monuments, ancient buildings, battlefields and other landmarks reminiscent both of Revolution and the Civil War.

VILLA SANTO STEFANO, Italy, April 2 (AP) -- Engineers drilled the surface of the earth in many places today in an effort to determine whether the remainder of this little city would sink into the labyrinth of old tunnels dug by the Romans 2,000 years ago.

MOSCOW, March 31 -- Moscow today is the strangest oasis of energy and hope in the desert of world depression. Always in sharp contrast with other capitals it is in sharper contrast today than ever. And inside Moscow there is yet a stranger oasis in a yet sharper contrast -- the foreign diplomatic corps.

LONDON, March 14. JAMES BRIDIE, whose play, "The Anatomist," proved him to have a natural gift for storytelling on the stage, has followed it with "Tobias and the Angel," a much more serious challenge as a work of art.

IN her suite aboard ship, just before she sailed last week, La Argentina expressed, an opinion on the dance as she has found it in America, which, coming from, her, is of no little significance. In offering congratulations to Martha Graham on the receipt of the first Guggenheim Fellowship ever to be given to a dancer she added her enthusiasm for the purpose to which the fellowship was to be put.

MORE than two years ago Lieutenant James H. Doolittle, United States Army Air Corps, working with the Guggenheim Fund for the Promoion of Aeronautics, demonstrated the possibility of bringing an airplane safely down on a landing field in dense fog.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP). -- Public support for Congress in its determination to balance the budget by increased taxes and government economy was asked tonight by Senator Smoot in a radio address.
Parnassus, it seems, Is taking hints from politics.

SIR THOMAS BEECHAM will conduct infrequently heard works of Elgar, Bax and Lalo with the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra this week, as well as compositions he directed during his previous visit to this country, including Delius's intermezzo "The Walk to Paradise Garden," from his opera "A Village Romeo and Juliet," and Berlioz's "Chasse Royal et Orage."

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad cut its operating expenses 20.5 per cent in 1931, compared with 1930, to meet reduced revenue, H.A. Scandrett, president, said in his annual report. He pointed out that the company's operating revenues decreased 21.8 per cent in 1931, compared with a decrease of 24.2 per cent for all Northwestern railroads and with 21.7 per cent for all Western railroads.

ROME, March 21, 1932. THE Italian version of "Sadko," recently mounted at the Royal Opera in Rome, was an undistinguished one, taken as a whole. It was a repetition from last year, with the same cast, in which only Adelaide Saraceni as the Princess merits mention with praise.

The Scriptural record is that CAIN, son of ADAM, went out from the presence of the Lord and built a City which he named after his own son ENOCH. One may have wondered where the inhabitants came from, but now it is well established that cities were in existence back of the period when, according to USHER, the creation of man occurred.

Increased supplies of green peas resulted last week in lower prices and a weaker market, according to George G. Royce, acting director of the New York office of the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets, in his weekly review of local wholesale markets.

THE mills of the gods grind slowly -- but it begins to look as if, after so many, many years, they are about to reach a grist labeled "Justice to Thomas Paine." It is almost a century and a quarter since Paine died, old, ill. poor, the victim of neglect and venomous misrepresentation and defamation.

Greater powers for salaried trade association executives, longer terms for elected officials and more emphasis on fundamental objectives were urged here last week as ways of improving the effectiveness of the organized business movement in this country.

RAILING serenely along, a bit ahead of schedule, as has become something of a habit with Dr. Hugo Eckener, the old Graf Zeppelin is back at Friedrichshafen once more after the first of her season's round trips to Brazil. She made the return journey in eighty-four and one-half hours.
MAPLEWOOD. N.J., April 2 -- Charles R. Tyson, 48 years old, builder and business man, died suddenly of heart disease today at his home here.

NEWARK, N.J., April 2 -- Dr. Grace Murray, 84 years old, one of the first women physicians admitted to practice in New York City, arrived here by plane this afternoon after an all-night flight from the West Coast. She had boarded the plane yesterday at San Francisco, a few hours after arriving on the steamer on which she had left Honolulu last Saturday.

Activities aimed at specific, constructive assistance In the solutio of current problems of merchandising management, expense control, advertising and personnel feature the work program just adopted by the National Retail Dry Goods Association for the coming year, it was announced yesterday by Channing E. Sweltzer, managing director of the association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Reports of two bills for Philippine independence, favorably recommended by the Senate and House committees, are interesting to me, who served ten years in the Philippine Government as assistant chief and as chief of the Philippine Constabulary.

ATHENS, Ohio, March 25 -- Six years of experience in using a commercial newspaper as a laboratory for training university students to meet the demands of the editorial department of a newspaper have so convinced authorities of Ohio University at Athens, Ohio, of the practicability of such a program that this semester the cooperative arrangement has been expanded to include business phases.
CLEVELAND, April 2 -- Loron A. Taylor, commercial artist and former cartoonist, committed suicide today. He shot himself twice, once under the heart and a second time in the head.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 2 -- With Curtze winning the all-round championship, taking two first places, Navy's gymnastic team captured the intercollegiate title for the fifth successive year today.

OWING to the increased demands made upon them in the past Winter, many of the charitable organizations, especially those whose main object is the welfare of young people, have found it necessary to arrange Spring entertainments to gain funds with which to carry on their work.

TOKYO, April 2 (AP). -- A new military expedition of unannounced strength was ordered by the government today to assist the two Japanese divisions that are attempting to stamp out rebellion against the recently constituted Manchurian Government of Henry Pu Yi.

Members of five Winter sports teams at Dean Academy, Franklin, Mass., have received fifty-three letters in recognition of their athletic activities. Thirteen were honored in swimming and as many in hockey, ten in basketball, nine in indoor track and eight in wrestling.

Although public education in the United States is considered a function exclusively of the State and local governments, the Federal Government disbursed more than $63,500,000 for various educational projects throughout the country during the fiscal year ended last June.

In ordinary circumstances Wall Street would have worked up a fine enthusiasm when the House of Reprepresentatives buried its rancorous differences and passed a revenue measure calculated to balance the Federal budget. There was, however, no celebration of the legislative achievement and for this there were two reasons.

The upturn in the grains featured trading in commodity markets yesterday, the improvement ranging from slightly less than one cent to close to three cents. In other sections the trend was lower, cotton, rubber, sugar, hides and silk reacting, cocoa alone developing higher prices. Butter was at a new low for the year.

LONDON. THE BOOK SOCIETY has made its position clearer by a statement issued in reply to recent hostile criticism in the press. It is a private "limited liability company," which sells books and service to its 10,000 members, of whom one half live overseas and one half of the remainder in rural areas not served by bookstores.

BUENOS AIRES, April 2 (AP) -- Buenos Aires police were under orders today to break up a meeting of the Radical followers of former President Hipolito Irigoyen, who set up their own Senate in Matanzas yesterday, claiming they were rightfully elected in provincial elections a year ago.

FINDING a community that has no need of doctors, dentists or dietitians, the president of the Dental Society and the surgeon lieutenant of the Royal Naval Hospital of Cape Colony acknowledge themselves nonplussed.

THE first of a series of five Tuesday evening concerts by the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra for the benefit of unemployed musicians will take place Tuesday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House. Another benefit cocert for the Musicians' Emergency Aid will take place this evening at Carnegie Hall.

BROOKLINE, Mass., April 2 -- Miss Marjorie Morrill of Dedham, Mass., played the role of conqueror to perfection on the Longwood covered courts, Chestnut Hill, today, as she scored a clean sweep in the three national indoor tennis championship finals.

THE PERFECT SECRETARY. ALL must be well with the League of Nations, for Sir Eric Drummond, its Secretary General, was able to leave last week upon a vacation; and when Sir Eric takes a vacation it is news. He has a harder job than the Recording Angel.

SOME piquant artistic liaisons have marked the week just concluded. Movie critics found themselves unexpectedly in the Louvre, watching re-enacted, in romantle and absorbing fashion, the sensational theft of Leonardo's "Mona Lisa" (concerning all this Hordaunt Hall is writing on another page today).
BERLIN, April 2 (AP) -- The Reichsbank statement as of March 31 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

The listed bond market continued lower yesterday, with domestic corporation issues, notably the rails, sharply off again, and United States Government bonds and foreign loans irregularly down. Few railroad issues closed at gains and many active liens of the group lost 1 to 9 points, establishing new bottom marks for the year.

ONE of the principal effects of the war upon English poets was that, in their revolt from human nature in its terrifying contemporary aspects, they came to seek out once more the old familiar world of poetry: they returned to the subject of Nature, to the simple pastoral theme, to picturing peasant life, as it indicated a remoteness from complexity and from the violence of thought.
FOR decades the attire of American men has been classed as little more than a modest and utilitarian covering. But this Spring it is coming out, one hears, as nothing less than a gloom dispeller.

By an old George M. Cohan custom, as certain as the Spring, that actor-manager-playwright made gestures toward next season by going to Philadelphia last week at the head of his "Confidential Service" troupe. While the rumor is that Walter Huston will take over the Cohan role on Broadway in the Fall, Philadelphia appears to have taken to the player as well as his play, both to be seen at the Broad Street Theatre.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31. -- More seriously than at any previous time since the pre-campaig tallo began, Newton D. Baker was discussed by Pennsylvania Democratic leaders this week as a Presidential possibility. Accidental though the fixing of the date may have been, Mr. Baker's visit here last Monday to address the Democratic Women's Luncheon Club came at such a time as to react favorably in behalf of any unexpressed Presidential aspirations he may entertain.

Sixty-nine Brown University athletes, among them several from the metropolitan district, were awarded insignia at a meeting of the athletic council. Not since 1928 has the number of awards been as great as this year. In 1928 seventy-seven insignia were given to the members of the institution's sports squads.

GUAYAQUIL, March 28 -- The national pride of Ecuador has been aroused by the fact that one of the country's most famous products, jinijapa hats, as known as "Panamas" and are not associated with the nation whose craftsmen have made the mthe world's best-known Summer headgear.

FOR ten years England and Ireland have let bygones be bygones and lived in a somewhat uninteresting amity. Today, the uncertain billows of St. George's Channel, so distressing to the nerves of politicians, are again heaving and rolling with their traditional emotions.

AN American who sings leading roles with the Metropolitan Opera Company has, of course, many things in his favor. There is a special place for him in the public eye and heart, because real native talent is so rare. A management, grateful for any opportunity to prove its interest in our artists and our art, is willing, even anxious, to provide him with every chance to progress.

This coming Saturday will be a highly interesting day for members of the college sport world who are interested in racing shells and the water. On that day the annual curtain raising which the crews of Washington and California do for the intercollegiate rowing season takes place with their three-mile race.
Etiquptte Authority, at a Luncheon of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.

NEW ORLEANS, April 2 -- Van Mungo, 20-year-old rookie, and John Picus Quinn, veteran of thirty years of baseball wars, today collaborated in winning a game from the Cleveland Indians, 7 to 5. Both were aided considerably by eleven Robin hits, including a rousing pair of triples by Joe Stripp and Ike Boone.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Henry Brocksmith of Indiana University, the mid-West's premier middle distance runner, turned in a 4:14.1 mile tonight to head the list of individual performers in the first annual Armour Tech relays in the University of Chicago Field House.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The semi-centennial of the discovery of the tubercle bacillus, now the subject of almost universal interest, recalls the marvelous strides in bacteriological technic made since Koch, in 1881, introduced his plate method for isolation of the various types of bacteria, a procedure which cannot be too strongly emphasized, probably ranking in importance with the discovery of the causative agent of tuberculosis.

ANY schoolboy is sure that George Washington was born on Feb. 22, 1732, but his biographers are less certain. The Washington family Bible gives the date, somewhat ambiguously, as "ye 11th day of February 1731/2." Which year was it, 1731 or 1732?

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 2 (AP) -- Miss Laura J. Wylie. 76 years old, Professor Emeritus of English at Vassar College, died here today after a short illness. She was born at Milton, Pa., was graduated from Vassar in 1877 and received a Ph. D. from Yale in 1894.

Co-eds once again this Summer will take their places alongside their campus brothers in seeking to demonstrate America's athletic supremacy in the Tenth Olympic Games at Los Angeles. Throughout the country women athletes are preparing for the international contests, and among the outstanding candidates are several who are college students.

DETROIT, April 2 -- In a setting of a towering, modernistic forest, the National Aircraft Show of 1932 opened in the largest hangar in the world at the Detroit City Airport today. The show, the second consecutive one to be held here under the auspices of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, Inc., with the cooperation of the Aircraft Bureau of the Detroit Board of Commerce, will last through next Sunday.

REALIZATION of the importance of our tourist traffic socially, economically and politically has penetrated into wider circles, and an ever-increasing appreciation of its economic value is particularly evident in States and countries with an unfevorable balance of trade or where the main resources consist of marvels of nature, climate and scenery, which might attract visitors from abroad.

IN 1883 William T. Stoll, of Ohio birth and Boston legal education, was doing his best to practice law in Spokane, Wash., then a frontier village of 800 inhabitants. His 25 years and his six feet plus of height and 200 pounds of bone and muscle gave him the essentials of youth and strength for making good on the frontier.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., April 2 -- The Ardsley Racquet and Swimming Club was the scene of a large subscription dance tonight. The sponsoring committee included Mrs. Edwin Balmer, Mrs. Paul K. Randall, Mrs. D. Theodore Kelly, Mrs. Jerome Monks and Mrs. J. Wood Rutter.

A score of 2,455 made last Thursday by the Walton five enabled it to capture the team prize in the eleventh annual tournament for the women's bowling championship of Greater New York. A total of thirty-one teams competed.

BUFFALO, March 31. -- If local public feeling on the subject of taxation is typical of the thought of American communities generally, those theorists and politicians who imagine that taxpayers have became a negligible part of the voting population are due for a rude awakening.

Plans for meeting the maturity of $20,727,750 first and consolidated mortgage 4-per cent bonas of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company, known as the Cotton Belt, due on June 1, possibly involving cash payments in combination with an exchange for another bond issue, are under contemplation, it was said yesterday.

Competing In their home pool last night, contenders for the Brooklyn Central T.M.C.A. were outstanding at the first championships of the newly organized Metropolitan Y.M. C.A. Swimming League. No team title was at stake, but the Central boys ran up the highest tally of 29 points.

Seven younger school champions of Queens will compete on Friday in the first borough finals for the New York City junior high schools entered in the National Oratorical Contest, which is conducted in the New YorkNew Jersey area by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

TORONTO, April 2 -- Hurdling the last obstacle in their path to the Stanley Cup series, the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight defeated the Montreal Maroons, 3 to 2, to capture the two-game total-goal series between the second and third place play-off winners by 4 to 3.

MADRID, April 1 -- The noncommissioned officers of the Spanish Foreign Legion in Morocco "are merciless, shameless and immune to punishment." charged Captain Macartney, who, with fifty-seven other Englishmen, was retrieved from the Legion in 1921 by the British Foreign Office after an investigation by the Ambassador in Madrid.

SEATTLE, March 31. -- Governor Roland H. Hartley's announcement last week that he would be a candidate for a third term as Gavernor of Washington recalls a statement made after his first election in 1924. Some were inclined at the time to take it as more or less of a joke or at least as an utterance made in the exuberance of a freshly-won victory.

With a seven-run outburst in the ninth inning Columbia wrested a free-scoring baseball game from City College at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, 10 to 7. With this last-ditch rally the Lions more than counter-acted a five-run cluster that had given the Lavender an apparently secure lead in the seventh session.

MANDAN, N.D., April 2 -- Independent electoral tickets in States where the party organization or public feeling, or both, may be opposed to the nominees of the two major party conventions are the objective of a plan being discussed with important Republicans and Democrats by Judge J.M. Hanley of Mandan.

RADICALLY as Dr. Cronin's new novel differs in plot and episode from "Hatter's Castle," so indelibly does this author impress his personality on his work that one will recognize the same hand behind both. Nor is this all, for in one particular is there similarity.

ROME, March 18 -- The International Educational Cinematographic Institute at Rome, an organ of the League of Nations, has undertaken a series of inquiries with the object of discovering the educational value of theatrical and didactic films and their effects on the minds of children and adolescents.
CONCERTS of exceptional attractiveness in the month before us will be results of conditions of unemployment among musicians!

THERE has never been a time when women have not liked knitted goods. There has never been a time when these fabrics were as smart as now. Like woolens, they are being developed in interesting weaves, and like all fabrics they are trying to look like something else.

SOVIET Russia continues to follow its declared policy of severely punishing those whose actions delay the progress of its industrial program or who otherwise do injury to the social scheme. Soviet justice recently meted out death sentences to eight found guilty of sabotage, bringing the total number of those condemned to death for this crime to twenty since the first of the year.

CHICAGO, April 1 THE stage drought was broken, as the chickens of Spring began to chip their way out of the Easter eggs, by two musical shows, offered under Shubert auspices - "Everybody's Welcome" and "The Blue Mask."

Having put their house in order, the British are now turning their attention to foreign affairs. During the period of Socialist dominance, when the evangelistically inclined MacDonald was in full control, the influence abroad of Great Britain waned considerably and notably on the Continent.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- Dr. Max Leopold Margolis, widely known Hebrew scholar. Professor of Biblical Philology at Dropsie College, died of a cerebral hemorrhage this afternoon at his home in Oak Lane. He was 65 years old.

Definite clues that have withstood preliminary investigation are still being followed by the police investigators seeking the kidnapped infant son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, it was disclosed last night by Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the New Jersey State Police.

Appeals in behalf of block-aid subcriptions will be made from several pulpits today. Young people from the metropolitan area will attend a rally in the Calvary Baptist Church in the afternoon. The Rev. James M. Gillis will give a lecture tonight at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, at Fifty-ninth Street and Columbus Avenue.

Within three weeks outdoor Spring sports in the schoolboy ranks will be in full swing, competitions for the various Spring championships will be under way, and, according to the schedules, there will be virtually no cessation of scholastic athletic activities until late in June.

Radio broadcasting is a recognised social force whose measure is still to be accurately gauged. The broader aspects of this new force were dealt with in an article in last Sunday's Times Magazine. In the following article, the second of a series of three, the vast radio audience, its tastes and its reactions, are discussed.

AN event of early May which already has gained the interest and cooperation of many members of society is the annual Toe H dinner dance and entertainment to be held on the night of May 2 on board the liner Berengaria at its pier here.

FOUR new pictures, in addition to "Shopworn," will be shown at the Paramount Theatre during the month of April. These are "The Misleading Lady," based on the stage hit of the same name and featuring Claudette Colbert, Edmund Lowe and Stuart Erwin; "This Is the Night," with Lily Damita and Charles Ruggles; "Sky Bride," with Richard Arlen, Jack Oakie and Virginia Bruce, and "Sinners in the Sun," with Carole Lombard and Chester Morris.
THE symposium of ideas regarding the motion picture Indus try, as conducted under the heading "Motion Picture National Preference Roll," has brought to the fore certain expressions of admiration.

GENEVA, April 2 -- The news that Secretary of State Stimson will leave next week for Geneva is considered here the first genuinely good news received in a long time. All League officials to whom this correspondent telephoned the news, regardless of nationality, were surprised and delighted.

NEW ORLEANS, March 31. -- A long and strenuous effort to enlist private funds in amount sufficient to meet the condition preceded the decision of the Commission Council of New Orleans to seek a $750,000 bond issue for the unemployed. For fourteen months some of the most able men in New Orleans worked at this task, but they found it impossible to make the income of the welfare committee approximate the urgent demands upon it.

I AM now opposed to a sales tax; but, gentlemen, if I find it impossible to balance this budget and restore the confidence of the world and our own people in our government, I would levy any tax, sales or any other kind, in order to do that.

MEXICO CITY, April 2 (AP). -- Mexico will hold her primary election tomorrow for the purpose of choosing candidates for State and Congressional offices. Until 6 A.M. Monday the entire nation, will be controlled by the army.

On the eve of a new horse show season there is a considerable amount of optimism among the show-promoting associations and among the exhibitors as well. On the other hand, there are those who prefer to wait upon early events -- the entries received at the first big shows and the sales and prices received at the important auctions during the early part of this month -- before making predictions.

Three New York A.C. teams triumphed in the interclub test with Penn A.C. gunners, scoring in the second and last leg of the competition at the Travers Island traps yesterday. The Winged Foot shooters also triumphed in the first leg, contested recently in Philadelphia.

WILLIAM HARRIS JR. it may be who will stage "The Green Pack," Edgar Wallace's last play, in New York. The London production of "The Green Pack," with Sir Gerald du Maurler in it, opened just a day or so before Mr. Wallace's death in Hollywood.

TRING, England. FOR weeks past the work of packing and shipping the Rothschild bird collection has been going on in Lord Rothschild's private zoological museum at the edge of this old village in the Chiltern Hills.

A supplemental agreement similar to that arranged with four other printers' unions in the book and job industry has been requested of Mailers' Union No. 6 by the New York Employing Printers' Association, it was announced yesterday.

DALLAS, Texas, April 2. -- One candidate for Congress in Texas is thoroughly wet, so wet on the prohibition issue that he went into court and had his name changed so that one of his initials was made to stand for the word wet.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, in telegrams sent yesterday to friends in Minnesota and Wisconsin, denied published reports that he would withdraw as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President before the national convention.

A lull developed in wholesale market activities last week, with very few buyers being in the market and mail orders light, according to the special market report prepared for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Many buyers, however, are expected this week for special sale merchandise, particularly coats and dresses, the report says.

ONE of the first acts of Andre Tardieu as Premier of France was to propose the idea of a federation of the Danubian States. This plan, which has been for many years the object of ardent hopes and bitter antagonisms, becomes especially interesting now because it comes for the first time as a concrete proposal.
CHICAGO, April 2 (AP). -- Two dozen Democratic leaders will meet in Chicago on Monday to arrange for the national convention.
