HARTFORD, Conn., April 2 -- Governor Cross and Mayor Rankin formally opened the annual flower and garden show this afternoon in the State armory. The show will close next Sunday.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., April 2 -- From a field that included some of the greatest field trial dogs in the United States, three were chosen by the Judges today as the prize winners in the open all-age stake, the most important event of the fourth annual Spring field trial meeting of the Mount Holly Gun Dog Club.

Of all New York's major industries, education has thus far perhaps suffered least from the effects of the depression. Vast new hordes of adolescents have knocked at the high school doors and been admitted. With jobs secure, teachers have been possibly the one large class of wage earners who have not only had their rate of pay maintained but even automatically advanced according to schedules laid out in rosier times.

LONDON IT is rare that a prophet and social reformer has for his rostrum the King's Bench Division of the High Court of England and for his mantle the scarlet and ermine of his Majesty's Judges; but such is the privilege of Sir Henry McCardie.
Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange were less nervous yesterday than on Friday, and prices, after holding within the narrowest range of the week, ended with losses of 4 to 8 points on the day.

OTTAWA, March 30. -- A Dominionwide empire trade inquiry has been launched by the executive committee of the Canadian Chamber of Commerce, and as the initial step a comprehensive questionnaire has been sent to local Board of Trade and Chamber of Commerce members of the national organization.

THE search for the fossil bones of our ancestors goes on with unabated zeal and with a surprising degree of success. Discoveries are being made in all parts of the world. Nevertheless, it is not the fossil-hunters who are now occupying the centre of the prehistoric stage.
NO woman minds a rainy day if she can look smart, and today there is no excuse for not looking one's best in the most drenching downpour. Rainyday togs have actually acquired chic.

The lengthy study of the Glass banking bill submitted to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee last week by the Federal Reserve Board attracted attention in Wall Street less for its criticisms of the proposed bill than for its suggestions for new and previously unconsidered changes in the banking law.

Preliminary work has been started on the Merritt Highway, the new motor road linking Trumbull, Conn., and Port Chester, N.Y., and intended to relieve automobile congestion in Southwestern Connecticut. In the opinion of really interests in the Greenwich and Stamford sections, which will be served by the boulevard, it will be of benefit to real estate and will open up new districts for development at the edge of those two residential centres.

BROADCASTERS and the radio industry expect that the second quarter of 1932 will be more active than the first quarter, which got off to a slow start compared with other years. Curtailed activity among the sponsors brought fewer voices of distinction to the microphone and less frequent appearances.
PHILADELPHIA, April 2. -- After an absence of eleven years, Tobias J. Burke, shell-shocked World War veteran, was reunited with his family today, but he still cannot remember who he is.

CANNES, France, April 2 -- Baron Maurice de Rothschild was seriously injured here today when he was run down by an automobile. He was knocked unconscious, one arm was broken and he is believed to have internal injuries. His physicians are awaiting the results of an X-ray examination before making a statement.

As Hamlet puts it, "When sorrows come, they come not single spies, but in battalions." The House Committee on Interstate Commerce at Washington at the moment is conducting hearings on a Senate bill to subject railroad holding companies, like operating roads, to regulation by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

BERLIN. ELLY BEINHORN, acclaimed by Berlin newspapers as the Amy Johnston of Germany, is attempting to fly around the world and may soon appear in the United States. Though she has flown only three yeans, this 24-year-old fraulein has piloted a plane over three continents, has twice been forced down far from cities, and has encountered many celebrities in the course of her adventure.

Tusitala. the last American squarerigged ship in active service, has juSt returned to New York, her home port, after voyage of 98 days from Honolulu, by way of the Panama Canal. Life aboard this sturdy vejtsel, now nearly fifty years old and manned, chiefly by American youngsters, is described in the following article by her captain, a seaman of the deep-water school.

While opposition to the proposed increase in the Federal tax on stock sales continued to gather momentum, the stock market sank yesterday to the lowest levels touched in the last ten years. The decline was of moderate scope, but it was sufficient to carry the industrial, railway and combined price averages into new low ground.

A Former 'Depression' Recalled. Statisticians of an optimistic temper are wont to condone the current bad times by recalling worse ones from which the world has successfully recovered. It is not often, however, that we are vouchsafed a chance to see these now lengendary "depressions" in the flesh.

MISCELLANEOUS flying operations continue to hold the unenviable position as champion in the accident division of aviation. Colonel Clarence M. Young, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aeronautics, made public last week the figures for the last six months of 1931 in this particular division of aviation, which includes all civil flying except that on scheduled air lines.

ST. LOUIS, March 31. -- Missouri Democrats met in State convention here this week and after Boss Tom Pendergast had ridden roughshod over all opposition and elected his slate of delegates to the Nalional Convention, four outstanding results were to be noted.

B.A. ROLFE, the rotund maestro of fast-tempo music, who has been vacationing in Hawaii these many weeks, returns to the microphone on Thursday. Mr. Rolfe and his troubadours face WJZ's microphone for broadcasts on Thursday and Friday nights at 8:30 o'clock.

The State of Tennessee, which, like other ambitious States, has embarked on a comprehensive highway construction program since wartime, has provided a gasoline tax and motor vehicle tax which is calculated not only to provide for service on the highway debt but is estimated to yield a substantial surplus.

ARTHUR BAGLEY celebrates his eighth anniversary on the air this week as director of an invisible gym class, which he believes is one of the largest in the world. His alarm clock rings at 5:30 A.M. He has never been late for a broadcast, despite the fact that he has been on the WEAF network for more than 2,000 hours.

HENRY HADLEY will make his last appearance as conductor of the Manhattan Symphony Orchestra at its concert tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria. This concert closes the organization's present season. Its manager has announced that It expects to continue next year.

DETROIT, Mich., April 2. -- Walter P. Chryeler's new series of Plymouth, motor cars was introduced today by the Plymouth Motors Corporation Division of Chrysler Corporation on a nation-wide scale. They include nine body types on two wheel-base lengths, ranging in price from $495 to $785.

TORONTO, Ont., April 1. -- The progress made in bringing new mines to production and in searching out other ore-bearing properties will be revealed at the annual meeting of the Canadian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy which will be held in Montreal on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday of next week.

A $1,000 mortgage certificate was sold yesterday on the Real Estate Securities Exchange. The spread between bid and asked bond prices was narrowed in numerous instances, the greater revision being downward.
An excellent entry has been received for the twenty-fourth annual specialty show of the French Bulldog Club of America, which will be held in the Winter Garden of the Hotel McAlpin next Saturday.
A three-family house at 67 Saratoga Avenue, Yonkers, was sold by Mrs. A. Schmidgal to a Mr. Knight through Raymond R. Best, broker, who later resold the property to M. Scheitsol.

THIS is one more book of memoirs of the old regime, of revolution and of flight from Russia, written in the form of autobiography, by a woman who stood high in the social hierarchy of the Czardom and who, in the years of the upheaval, saw and experienced a great deal.

CERTAINLY a photograph can be a work of art -- if we accept the definition of art as the presentation of a subject in a manner that wakes up our esthetic sense. And why not accept that definition with its implication of sensitive selection and fearless elimination?

THE man in the street is at least 95 per cent wrong when he asserts that the Gulf Stream -- that old familiar scapegoat for weather anomalies -- is to blame for the extraordinary mildness, of the past Winter in the Eastern United States.

While city, State and Federal authorities continued to investigate the possible danger of radium waters and to warn the public against their indiscriminate use, Dr. Harrison S. Martland, radium expert and chief medical examiner of Essex County, N.J., disclosed yesterday that he had been called into consultation, on a second radium-water case at the same time that he was called in on the case of Eben M. Byers.

THIS history of the United States from the close of the Civil War to the growth of agitation for "planning" that came in the wake of the 1929 stock market collapse is put forth in the garb of a textbook, but it should not be allowed to suffer with the general public on that account.

A SMALL rift in the cloud of gloom surrounding the situation of opera in Chicago which may lead to a clearing of the skies is indicated by Edward Moore in The Chicago Tribune, with the total of guarantees for the Civic Opera Company's half million goal reaching $316,450.

N.Y.U.'s baseball team showed to advantage as it defeated the alumni, 8 to 4, in an exhibition game at Ohio Field yesterday. Seven errors by the graduates contributed to their downfall. Five twirlers saw action, three being employed by the losers, who presented one of the strongest graduate teams to oppose the undergraduates in many seasons.

LOS ANGELE5, April 1. TWO events that would be of major importance on any Rialto claimed the attention of the local playgoers on two successive evenings of the week just past. First, on Sunday night, there was Al Jolson and his "Wonder Bar," and second, on Monday, Grace George in her well-nigh perennial vehicle, "The First Mrs. Fraser."

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- Eddie King, a freshman at Columbia University, tonight retained the Middle States A. A. U. 175-pound wrestling championship in the tournament conducted at the First German Club.

DR. DICKEY knows the vast jungles of South America as very few other men do. With the exception of only thirty months, he has spent all of the last thirty-one years in South America, serving for a quarter of a century as surgeon-physician in mines, on railways and on sugar and rubber estates in various parts of tropical America.

WILKESBARRE, Pa., April 2 -- Thomas Maloney, president of Stanton Local Union leader among the insurgent anthra miners, was discharged by the Glen Alden Coal Company today when he reported for duty after the "outlaw" strike which it is estimrted, cost hard-coal producers more than $5,000,000 in the past three weeks.

The entry of the United States into the World War fifteen years ago this month was commemorated in New York yesterday afternoon with, a parade of 18,000 persons, who ranged from trim grim regular army units to Girl Scouts, and who tramped steadily up Fifth Avenue for two hours.

NEW YORK was recently startled and not a little amused by the discovery made by engineers for the Regional Plan Association, after a study of the 1930 census of the city, that the centre of population of this energetic metropolis was located among the quiet tombstones of Calvary Cemetery, between Long Island City and Maspeth, Queens.

On the opening day of its annual exhibition in Grand Central Palace, the Society of Independent Artists was stirred yesterday by the possibility that this year's show had established something of a record.

PARIS, April 2 -- After having jogged along quietly for some years, that old question of whether and how much France and England are really united in friendship and in common policy has suddenly become an absorbing subject of conversation and press comment in Paris.

PARIS. THE term "spectator sports," particularly when it is applied to Summer clothes, has been so broadened as to embrace practically all outdoor and many indoor daytime costumes, and quite a few evenings gowns also fit into this category.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 2 -- Though Babe Ruth drove home five runs, hitting his first homer of the homeward exhibition tour and his fourth of the year, the Yankees lost to the Memphis Chicks today, 7 to 6.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For the edification of W. F. McSparran, who cannot figure out how the six-hour day would benefit the farmers, may It be suggested that at least his grasp of the causes of the present economic dilemma might be strengthened had he more time in which to ponder the problem.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- President Hoover will remain in Washington if Congress takes a recess over the national conventions and continues its session into the late Summer. It was also stated in informed circles today that he was considering the advisability of staying here and conducting his campaign for re-election from the East rather than from his home in Palo Alto.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 2 (AP) -- Preliminary efforts to stage a regional arms conference in South America have virtually fallen through, it is stated on authority here, and a new plea for a meeting to limit navies may be issued by Chile if no action by the Latin American delegates in taken at Geneva.

The American artist will receive preferential treatment in the selection of those who are to paint murals for Rockefeller Centre, Wallace Harrison of Corbett, Harrison MacMurray, one of the architectural firms engaged in the enterprise, said yesterday at a luncheon at the Art Centre, 65 East Fifty-sixth Street.

WITHIN the past twenty-five years the United States has had the phonograph and the radio. Whatever else they have done, these two mediums of sound transmission have influenced a musical development which cannot be matched by any other country or at any other time in the world's history.
James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, resigned yesterday as treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, a post he had held since 1924.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So long as certain of the clergy and various other persons who hold the same views feel it their duty to malign the rich, and as many people have the privilege of freeing their minds in "Letters to the Editor," let me free mine in support of the rich.

The city's newest official agency, the recently named Board of Taxicab Control, is under Investigation by the Hofstadter legislative committee, it was revealed yesterday. Whether it will be made the subject of a future hearing has not been determined.

MEXICO CITY, April 2 -- Archaeologists who are clearing the ruins of Monte Alban, where an Indian treasure tomb was recently found, have come upon what appears to be a secret passageway in the ancient city.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 2 -- A crack trio of swimmers wearing the winged foot symbol of the New York Athletic Club posted a new world's mark, its second of the day, to win the 300-yard medley relay race tonight in the national senior A.A.U. championships.

An all-day conference on the subject, "Philanthropy Must Answer the Challenge," involving the question whether privately maintained philanthropies will be able to survive the present depression which has only emphasized the demand for their services, will be held by the Women's Division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies at the Hotel Commodore on Tuesday.

Unqualified disapproval of Samuel Seabury's recommendation that the Appellate Division instead of the Mayor appoint the judges of the new court he would set up to replace the magistrates' courts and the Court of Special Sessions was expressed yesterday by the directors of the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended March 26 were lower than in the preceding week as well as the corresponding week of last year according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., April 2 -- At the end of the current academic year Dr. Henry Franklin Cutler will retire from the principalship of the Mount Hermon School for Boys, near here, after forty-two years in the post.

BELGRADE, March 31 -- Yugoslavia, which a few days ago established a virtual transfer of the moratorium to the payment of its private foreign debts and which has sought to improve its financial situation further by lopping $35,000,000 from its budget, is facing a State political crisis even more serious and threatening than its economic troubles.

GENEVA, April 2 -- After a week's investigation the police of Berne estimate about 2,000,000 Swiss francs ($400,000) is involved in an alleged international swindle in connection with which Baron Lemheny, Hungarian, and his German nephew, Gerard Duerssen, have been, detained.

MR. RUKEYSER is an American engineer who served in Russia as adviser to the Asbestos Trust of the Soviet Government at two periods during 1929 and 1930. In simple and realistic fashion he has written an account of his Russian experience from the time he first crossed the Polish border until his last contract expired.

THE announcement in Mexico City that President Pascual Ortiz Rubio had appointed a commission to proceed with the construction of Mexico's National Theatre, suspended since the fall of the regime of Porfirlo Diaz in 1910, revives public interest in a fabulous theatre and one of the world's most perplexing engineering problems.

CLEVELAND, April 2. -- Charging that wealthy citizens controlled, the Government of the United States for selfish interests. Governor Pinchot of Pennsylvania today directly accused former Secretary Mellon of having caused the depression.

Three speakers at yesterday's discussion luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association at the Hotel Astor, whose topic was "Can We Have National Planning Without a Revolution?" differed widely in their views on how national planning was to be achieved, but all agreed that it was necessary.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 2 -- In its opening game of the season the Army lacrosse team defeated Western Maryland, 11 to 0, today. The visitors were unable to penetratae the cadets' defense and the Western Maryland goalie was almost constantly under fire.

LONDON, April 2 (AP) -- After a notice had been filed at the registry office today of the Intended marriage of Bernard Mannes Baruch Jr., son of Bernard M. Baruch, American financier, to Miss Winifred Beatrice Mann, an announcement was made at Miss Mann's home that there would be no wedding.

The 1932 bronze medal of the John Burroughs Memorial Association was awarded yesterday afternoon to Frederick S. Dellenbaugh, historian and explorer, at a meeting of the association at the American Museum of Natural History to observe the anniversary of the naturalist's birth.

THE annual book drive of the American Merchant Marine Library Association. 67 Wall Street, will be held in the metropolitan area from April 4 to April 9. Mrs. Samuel Adams Clark of 655 Park Avenue is chairman of the book drive.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 2 -- New Rochelle High School defeated the Princeton University freshman baseball team, 12 to 3, today. Ryan, in the box for the victors, fanned ten and allowed only four hits.

LONDON, March 23 -- So after ten years of peace we are in for trouble again with Ireland. Mr. De Valera has seen to that Having taken power in Dublin, he has made haste to announce that the oath of fidelity to King George is to be abolished.

The seventh performance this season of "Aida" was given yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House under the direction of Tullio Serafin before an audience highly responsive to the performance of conductor and cast, which included Arthur Anderson, Carmela Ponselle Elisabeth Rethberg, Francesco Merli Ezio Pinza and Armando Borgioli.

A STUDY of the customs of the head-hunters of the Ecuador jungle -- the Jivaro Indian tribesmen, who deal sudden death to animals with mysterious poisons on their arrow tips and preserve the heads of their human victims as souvenirs -- is being conducted by Matthew W. Stirling, chief of the Bureau of Ethnology of the Smithsonian Institution.

THE Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games at Los Angeles has figured it out that it will cost approximately 52 per day per man to board and lodge the visiting athletes in the model village out there. It seems reasonable enough, with the famous California climate thrown in free of charge.
THAT perfect family man. Philip II of Spain, four times married and the father of eight royal children, appears in this book as the stepchild Nature dowered with everything but genius.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Governor Roosevelt will offer his cooperation to the Republican leaders in the Legislature when they gather here on April 13 to begin their prospective investigation into the conduct of the State administrative departments during the decade of Democratic rule at the Capitol.

SOME improvement was reported for the week In retail trade, though the day-to-day result were rather spotty. Several of the stores here on Wednesday equaled their figures for the same day last year. Dress accessories and apparel attracted the best demand.
A different approach to the problem of store advertising is vitally needed, according to Dorothy Swenson, advertising manager of Abraham Straus, Brooklyn.

PITTSBURGH, April 2 -- Riding at the head of an army of Jobless workers, Father James R. Cox, pastor of St. Patrick's Church, will assemble his forces in St. Louis for a national convention of the unemployed on Aug. 17.

IT would appear that those who select the subject matter for recording -- whether it be for educational, historical or, most important, entertainment purposes -- are barely aware of the formidable list of the progeny of the prolific Johann Sebastian Bach.
WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the veteran Jeffersonian Democrat, was found by a reporter this afternoon pensively descending the steps of the Capitol.
BERLIN. A GLANCE at the flood of Goethe books published this year convinces us of the impossibility of making a complete critical appraisal of these works, which vary so greatly in volume and merit.

SHANGHAI, April 2 (AP). -- Chinese and Japanese peace negotiators were "in somewhat closer agreement," It was announced after today's conference at the British Consulate, but their opposing attitudes on the main issue of troop withdrawals remained unreconciled.

Charles A. Stone, chairman of the board of Stone Webster, Inc., says it is the duty of a corporation to keep its stockholders as closely as possible in touch not only with the financial aspects of the enterprise but with its background and ideals, in a statement accompanying an illustrated book to be issued tomorrow to stockholders and others interested in the company and its growth.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 2 -- Sinking putts of more than twenty feet to win the seventeenth and eighteenth holes, Miss Maureen Orcutt, Englewood (N.J.) star, overcame the 1-up lead of Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City today and captured the North and South championship.

Following representations by the Fifth Avenue Association, patrolmen having posts along that thoroughfare, as well as members of the mendicancy and borough headquarters squads, have been directed to be more active in driving peddlers from that part of the city, it was said yesterday by William J. Pedrick, the association's president.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 2 -- Gnat, a big bay gelding owned by Peter Drever of Mount Kisco, provided one of the outstanding exhibitions at the Saxon Woods Club's Spring horse show today In the class for jumpers over hurdles four feet high, taking the blue ribbon after a jump-off.

ELISSA LANDI, who acts the principal role in "Devil's Lottery" at the Roxy Theatre, is a Venetian, but was brought up in England. Her mother is the Countess Zenardi-Landi. Before taking to the stage and screen seriously she wrote two novels. "Neilson" and "The Helmers."

DUBLIN, April 2 -- While the Free State's Executive Council was still wrestling today with the terms of the Irish reply to Britain on the proposed abolition of the oath to the King and retention of the land annuities, President de Valera denied there had been any serious split among his Ministers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Canada public sentiment as it concerns the United States is socially and politically friendly. It is also sympathetic with American ideals of citizenship and progress. Canadians are likewise patient and tolerant when an American newspaper or citizen gives expression to thoughts that are critical of foreign nations, customs and policies.

THE "tri-pack" photographic film for making pictures in natural color, which was recently put on the market by a firm in Binghamton, N.Y., is a development of a process which was first used some years ago without much success. The improvements contained in the present product are said to overcome the faults of the earlier more complex films which were made according to the same general theory.

The immediate full payment of World War veterans' adjusted service certificates would "go further toward establishing an early economic equilibrium and actually balancing the budget" than any one measure that has yet been proposed, Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma, sponsor of the bill now before Congress, said yesterday when he arrived here to confer with bankers and economists on the bill.

Walter Lindrum of Australia, world's champion at English billiards, will return to action in New York this week, engaging in a special match with Tom Newman, former holder of the title in England. Twelve blocks are scheduled for the visiting e stars, who have been on a tour through Canada and the Middle West.

ONE thinks a little or Benvenuto Collini. if only because of certain contrasts, as one reads this self-told story of the life and an of Frank Lloyd Wright. In both cases the artist is passionate, combative. impatient of control, completely single-minded in his art.

The cuts in running time between New York and Chicago to be made by the New York Central and the Pennsylvania line on April 24 involve changes in passenger train operation which could well be described as revolutionary, according to L.W. Landman, general passenger traffic manager of the New York Central.

The special features yesterday at the fourth International Antiques Exposition being held at the Grand Central Palace were lectures in the afternoon and evening by Wallace Nutting on "The Earliest American Furniture, 1620-1710," and by Marion Micholl Rawson, whose subject was "The Crane and Its Cronies."

WHAT we know about muscles and fatigue we owe largely to Professor A.V. Hill. His views were amplified, at last week's meeting of the American Chemical Society, by Dr. R. Adams Dutcher of Pennsylvania State College.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- Terrorism, violence and intimidation in the race for ward committeeman in the Twenty-fifth Ward brought before the Senate last week in a letter from Frank J. Loesch, president of the Chicago Crime Commission, flared into the open today with the murder of Nicholas Testa, Republican precinct captain and campaigner for the nomination of James Savage for Republican ward committeeman.

FOR about three years W.C. Stevens, who is connected with the engineering research laboratory of an East Pittsburgh electrical manufacturing company, has been working on the theory that electricity can be used in hotbeds. After much experimenting he reports that the problem has been solved.

In a certain hunting and fishing club of the days of darkness there was a ritual call, which, begun by one member, had to be repeated and followed in action by all: "What do we do before we eat? Drink." Now the wicked tell us that all the good food is in the speakeasies; and to keep gracile, millions deny themselves all but the fewest necessaries.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 2 -- The permanency of the reign of Phillip N. Krug as leader of the Nassau County Democratic party will be decided here next Tuesday when the enrolled Democrats elect their State committeemen. It is the first time in many years that any opposition has been registered to the choice of the leader.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- The primary election to be held in Illinois on April 12 includes nominations running the gamut from Presidential preference to ward committeeman. In Cook County the ballot, always of blanket proportions on such occasions, will be bigger than ever.

ADHERENTS of both airship and heavier-than-air are watching with interest an hope the progress of two bills now before Congress designed to stimulate, through government aid the creation of passenger airship lines between the United States an Europe and between this country and the Far East.

AMOS 'N' ANDY have broadcast 820 episodes. That is quite a record on the radio. Even the diversified orchestral offerings must be changed from time to time to inject "new blood" into the ether veins, else the program goes stale and fewer listen.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., April 2 -- Mrs. Orna Brandt, 37 years old, and her three sons, Vernon, 9; George, 7, and Joseph, 3, were burned to death early this morning when fire of undetermined origin destroyed their home, a two-story frame building, at Bergen and Hallock Avenues here.

Dick Shikat, former holder of the world's wrestling championship, will face Earl McCready in the feature match to a finish in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. McCready, formerly a student at Oklahoma A. and M. College, gained prominence in intercollegiate wrestling during his undergraduate years and has had fair success among the professionals.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont, who have been at the Ritz-Carlton since returning from Europe, will leave for Washington Tuesday.

LONDON, April 2 -- On the eve of the arrival of Premier Tardieu of France for discussions of Danubian problems Stanley Baldwin, Lord President of the Council, delivered a speech in Worcester setting forth the British policy toward Central Europe.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- The net estate of Dr. Richard A.F. Penrose Jr. available for distribution is $8,909,457, according to the first and final account of the executors, filed with the Register of Wills here today.

WHAT may be called a new era in the commercial education of the Negro is getting under wav, according to Albon D. Holsey, secretary of the National Colored Merchants Association. The familiar type of Negro education is giving way to something more, practical.

STUDENTS of folk-music -- not those who merely glance through pages in a search for a few pretty tunes and stories about them, but serious students of this rich and marvelous phase of the musical art, will welcome the remarkable collection of Hungarian folk-music by Bela Bartok, the literary material translated by M.D. Calvocoressi, now published in English by the Oxford Press.
Real estate owners and brokers found encouragement in market developement during the week.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 2 -- G.C. Schwalb led a field of thirty-seven gunners in the second registered shoot of the year over the Mineola traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. He took the high scratch cup by breaking 96 out of a possible 100 targets.

"In the world there is nothing great "but man. In man there is nothing "great but mind." If it be true that as a man thinketh, so is he, much the same may be said of a whole people. There is always in the mental attitude of a nation something which rises above, and may actually control or modify, material conditions.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- A House vote Monday on the Hare bill for Philippine independence appeared assured today, when Speaker Garner said that he would recognize Representative Hare to move for a suspension of the House rules as soon as formal business was out of the way.

To the Editor of The New York Times: June 15 will mark the celebration in the English-speaking world of the signing of Magna Charta some seven centuries since. This act was followed eighty years later by the establishment of responsible government by Simon do Montford and King Edward I.

WASHINGTON THE Federal Government is ready to start work on the biggest irrigation canal in the world, destined to bring water to the lowest, dryest and most tropical spot in continental United States, and to convert desert sands into farming areas that, because of their peculiar geography, are different from any other.

On the petition of William H. Browning, president of Browning, King Co., manufacturers and retailers of men's and boys' clothing, Federal Judge William Bondy appointed yesterday receivers in equity for the company, which operates retail stores in twenty-four cities.

LORNA REA, who in her earlier novels. "Six Mrs. Greenes" and "Rachel Moon," showed her power of dealing with the subtleties involved in human relationships, tells in "The Happy Prisoner" a story which, for all its lightness and charm, is far-reaching in its implications.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 2 -- L. D. Ward won a leg on the President's Cup over the traps of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today. He took the shoot by returning a card of 40-9-49.

BOSTON. March 31. -- Maasachusetts has established its own reserve banking system. Boston has the Federal Reserve Bank for the First, or New England, District, and the State itself now has in operation two central banking institutions designed to give for the mutual savings banks of the Commonwealth and for the cooperative banks, respectively, a service similar to that assigned to the central banks in the Federal Reserve System.
LONDON, April 2 -- Sidney and Beatrice Webb -- officially known as Lord and Lady Pasafield -- are going to spend eight weeks in Russia this Summer studying the cooperative movement there.

Mayor Walker officially opened the General Motors exhibition yesterday at the Hotel Astor -- one of fifty-five exhibits of the corporation's products held simultaneously in as many points throughout the country in an aggressive campaign to stimulate business.

The purchase of the Century Air Lines, Inc., and the Century Pacific Lines, Ltd., independent air lines operated in the Middle West and along the Pacific Coast by E.L. Cord, airplane and automobile manufacturer, was announced yesterday by W.A. Harriman, chairman of the board of directors of the Aviation Corporation.
WASHINGTON, April 2. -- President Hoover today assumed an active part in an effort to expedite through the Senate the billion-dollar tax bill which was passed yesterday by the House.

BOOKS have been written in ever increasing numbers about listening to music, that difficult occupation for babbling infancy, unwilling childhood, indifferent adolescence. They lure, they persuade, they beguile by all the artifices of the newer education to induce first pity, then endurance, then embrace.

IT is not to be expected that George Bernard Shaw, the promsing playwright whose latest work, "Too True to-Be Good," will be presented by the Theatre Guild tomorrow night, will wait up for Tuesday's, newspapers to read the verdict of the dramatic critics.

FOR seven years, so they tell us, the editors of The Viking Press have been searching for "a novel of detection so completely satisfactory that it would rival the best that is being written today." The result of this search is "The Tragedy of X," the first detective story ever published by this house.

WHILE the motion pictures quite obviously have provided the drama with serious competition and, in fact, since the advent of talking films have changed the entire complexion of the legitimate theatre, they have, as every one on Broadway knows, helped producer and playwright by providing them with a market, frequently at a handsome price, for what in the commercial world would be called a by-product.

TRENTON, N.J., April 2 -- An order by Vice Chancellor John O. Blgelow, filed here today, appointed Stuart A. Young, Newark lawyer, custodial receiver for the Durant Motor Car Company of New Jersey, with headquarters at Elizabeth, and directed the company to show cause in Newark on April 12 why the receiver should not be continued.

An unusual achievement in reducing the number of behavior cases that bring children into courts has been made by the guidance clinics operated for the last two years in a North Tarrytown school by the Educational Adjustment Bureau, a project of the Westchester County Children's Association.
WEYHE GALLERY -- Drawings and lithographs by Daumier, Opened March 28, closes April 9, reviewed in news columns today.

Art work by Mexican children under 15 is now on exhibition at Teachers College, Columbia University. The exhibit was brought from Mexico City by Senor Juan L. Olaguibel, Chief of Art Instruction for the Mexican Government. In classroom and open air schools these beginners are wielding a vigorous brush in the Mexican tradition -- some similar work recently won second prize in an exhibit at Geneva.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Once more we note a rising vote of thanks to Messrs. Rockefeller, Harkness, Juilliard and the Metropolitan Museum, whose generosity made possible the recent symphony concerts conducted on the highest plane of musicianship at the museum.

WARSAW, April 1 -- As soon as the Sejm's budgetary session closed, a few days before Easter, important changes were announced in the Cabinet. Three Ministers, those of Agriculture, of Agrarian Reforms and of Public Works, resigned. Communications Minister Alfons Kuehn took the agencies of Public Works, while those of Agrarian Reforms and of Agriculture were merged with Professor Ludkiewicz, chairman of the State Landbank, as Minister.

Three calls for foreign bond issues which are to be redeemed in future months prior to maturity were issued last week. Additions to the list of those to be paid this month were few, consisting mostly of odd lots of municipal loans. The total for April is now $13,416,000, compared with $10,319,000 in March, and $60,879,000 in April, 1931, at correspondhig periods.

AIKEN, S.C., April 2 -- Fifty years of polo in Aiken was colorfully an gayly celebrated here this afternoon with a grand parade. Old victorias, landaus, surreys and other vehicles were brought out for the occasion. The occupants were arrayed in costumes of half a century ago.

American furniture of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, with a large group of the finer work of Duncan Phyfe and notable examples of Hepplewhite, Sheraton and Chippendale, collected by the late Louis Guerineau Myers, treasurer of the Rockefeller Foundation, is now on view at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., and will be sold there Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 2 -- Yonkers High School's quintet won its third State interscholastic title by vanquishing Johnson City in the Class A final tonight, 17 to 15, in an overtime struggle. Two foul shots in the extra session won for Yonkers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 2 -- Yale opened its baseball season today with an 8-to-3 victory over the Springfield College nine. Cold weather kept the attendance down to a few hundred, but the contest, the first for both teams, gave the coaches a chance to measure their strength.

Speaking before the annual New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in the Park. Avenue Methodist Church yesterday, Dr. Clarence True Wilson, general secretary of the Methodist Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals, asserted that he would not be opposed to a referendum on prohibition every ten years.
MILWAUKEE, April 2 (AP). -- Wisconsin voters, seemingly aroused as never before in a similar campaign, will elect on Tuesday delegates to the Republican and Democratic National Conventions.

At a meeting of copper fabricators and consumers, in the Hotel Biltmore on Friday. Louis S. Cates, president of the Phelps-Dodge Corporation, said that without a duty on copper, mines in the United States would be unable to operate at more than 27 per cent of capacity, even in normal times.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Stalling in basketball was stalled today. The National Association of Basketball Coaches, after a three -- day discussion of ways of speeding up the game, adopted a drastic rule whereby any team in possession of the ball in the back court must cross the centre of the playing floor toward its target within ten seconds.

Log Nanduces, defending national indoor open polo champions, scored impressively in their first game of the round robin for the title by stopping the Riding Club, 12 1/2 to 3, at the Squadron C. Armory, Brooklyn, last night.

WESTERN civilization, thereby meaning particularly American civilization, seems to President Frank of the University of Wisconsin to be in a pretty bad way. It is economically disordered, of course, but that is only one of its troubles.

VANCOUVER, B.C., April 2 (AP) -- Captain Samuel Robinson, dean of the shipmasters of the transpacific sea lanes, quit the sea today on the arrival of the Empress of Japan from the Orient, ending a career that started forty-eight years ago. He is 62 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Consideration of legislation for cash payment of the soldiers' bonus will begin April 11 in the Ways and Means Committee.

IT is known, from authentic records, that Jews helped equip Columbus and that several Jews were members of his expedition. For centuries before him there had been Jewish travelers, navigators, scholars, scientists, cosmographers, cartographers of distinction, notwithstanding the sorry lot of the Jew in Europe.

BERLIN, April 2 -- Precisely at noon tomorrow the Easter political truce will be over and one minute later the gigantic machinery of political propaganda that was constructed for the first ballot in the Presidential election, and has grown since, will be set in motion to prepare for the second ballot on April 10.

PHIILADELPHIA, April 2. -- A year ago all of the ordinarily gainfully employed workers within the Philadelphia city limits who were totally unemployed represented a lost buying power of $5,405,400 a week. This has now increased to $7,275,000 weeky, according to an analysis of unemployment surveys by the Department of Industrial Research of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

GEORGE O'BRIEN, good-natured hero of the Zane Grey films, popped into New York the other day with Ricardo Cortez and popped out again. He is now back at the Fox studio, where David Howard has everything in readiness to direct him in "The Killer," adapted from the novel by Stewart Edward White.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The eyes of the nation were fixed with concern on the House of Representatives. this week as last. But last week the concern was for the government this week the individual citizen was worrying about himself.

The City College junior varsity nine turned back Abraham Lincoln High-School, 3 to 0, at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. Murray Poss and Phil Davis held the high school combination hitless and shut them out. Poss worked five innings and Davis was on the mound for two.

PARIS, April 1 -- Paris, like other big European cities, has lost many of its quaint customs in the last quarter century, but there is one picturesque ceremony connected with Easter that still endures and draws thousands of French people of distinguished families, though it is little known to foreign visitors.

New educational problems and theories will be discussed by more than 2,000 administrative officers, faculty members and students from 100 teacher-training institutions in New England and Middle Atlantic States at the seventh annual conference of professional schools for teachers, which will open on Thursday for a three-day session in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

GEORGE A. HASTINGS, extension director of the White House conference on Child Health and Protection, in an address on Saturday in Detroit put a question which might seem purely academic or fanciful. Specifically, he asked whether one would choose to be born in Detroit if one were about to come into the world and could decide where.

BERLIN, April 3 (AP). -- Election fireworks and disorders began in Germany today almost on the stroke of noon, when President von Hindenburg's decree enforcing a political truce for the Easter period expired.

The business of the church is to make the world aware of God, the Rev. Dr. Wallace MacMullen declared yesterday in dedicating the new edifice of the Metropolitan Methodist Episcopal Temple, Thirteenth Street and Seventh Avenue. Services were held in the basement of the church, as the auditorium is not yet completed.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 3. -- Because Babe Ruth hit a homer yesterday and because the Memphis Chicks at the same time defeated the NewYork Yankees, the fans of this city and the surrounding countryside massed into Russwood Park today to the number of 9,127, a crowd more than three times as large as any that had watched a Yankee game this year.

The list of thirty-five players who will comprise the New York University baseball squad this season was announced by Coach William V. McCarthy yesterday. This was the first cut of the campaign and will be the last, the Violet mentor said. Until yesterday forty-eight were on the roster.

Less than $28,000,000 is all that Germany will be called upon to pay during the next three months on account of German bonds held in the United States, it is estimated. This sum includes interest on all government, State, municipal and corporate securities held here, as well as sinking fund payments on them.

The New York Charity Organization Society had a total of 14,965 resident families under its care in 1931, an increase of 67 per cent over the previous year, according to the annual report made public yesterday. A little less than half of this number, or 6,452, required intensive, longtime help and guidance.

Drug-Store Sales to Prisoners. Because a drug store is located near a jail it does not follow that its sales must be confined, even though its patrons are. The American Druggist reports that a Los Angeles store, almost in the shadow of the municipal jail, does a flourishing business with the inmates.

The voice of Pope Pius XI was heard in America yesterday as he spoke in the ceremonies prior to ultimate beatification and possible canonization of Mother Alexia Leclerc. The address was broadcast by networks of the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting Company.

MANHASSET, L.I., April 3. -- Bishop Ernest M. Stires of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island dedicated the new Christ Church parish house here this afternoon at ceremonies attended by more than 300 persons in the auditorium in the Payne Whitney Memorial Wing of the building.

Miss Eleanor Holm of the Women's Swimming Association shattered the world's record for the 100-yard backstroke in the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior title test at a water carnival in the 75-foot W.S.A. pool yesterday.

The tradition concerning a concert given for the benefit of an individual or an organization or for some other helpful purpose is that criticism be adjourned for the occasion. The professional reviewer, if he attends a concert of this kind, turns reporter rather than analyst or stays away.

BERLIN, April 3. -- The Easter political truce banning campaigning expired at noon today, and on the stroke of the clock the party batteries reopened fire with a vehemence intensified by a fortnight's enforced silence and the fact that the final balloting for the Presidency is only one week off.

SANFORD, Fla., April 3. -- Nine outboard drivers were cleared today by the Florida Outboard Motor Boat Association of charges that they banded together to lure Charles H. Harrison, English pilot, across the starting line ahead of the signal and caused him to be disqualified in the race for the Colonel Green Trophy at Miami Beach, March 20.

William T. Tilden 2d, who was ranked at the top of the amateurs for ten years, heads the first ranking of the professional players to be made in this country, as issued today by the Professional Lawn Tennia Association of the United States.

PARIS, April 1. -- The fall in dollar exchange at the beginning of the present week, and the rise of European exchange rates in New York, were unquestionably due to speculation, chiefly on the British market. The comment was made here this week that, since the currency troubles began in Europe last Summer, all speculators have considered themselves economists.

When EMERSON felt particularly low in mind about his country and his fellow-countrymen he found himself looking out, about the year 1845, upon a scene which, as VAN WYCK BROOKS reports, was remarkably like the American scene outspread before the eyes of the contemporary depressed observer:

Patrolman Andrew Murphy, 32 years old, was injured fatally, and Patrolman Harry Hauser, 25, critically hurt yesterday morning when the automobile in which they were riding crashed into an elevated railway pillar and overturned at Southern Boulevard and 173d Street, the Bronx.

A campaign of education in the methods of shipping and handling imports of less-than-carload freight was undertaken yesterday by the Port of New York Authority preparatory to the opening of its first union inland freight terminal, which is scheduled in October.

The Stanley Cup series for the hockey championship of the world will start tomorrow night when the New York Rangers, holders of the National League title, oppose the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden. The series will be decided on the basis of best three out of five games, and promises to provide spirited action.

Awards in the eleventh annual poster contest conducted in the elementary public schools and Roman Catholic schools by the humane education department of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals were announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 3. -- The movement of wheat from farms to primary markets is small at present, but supplies on farms are liberal and might come out freely if there was an advance of 5 to 10 cents a bushel in price. Closing quotations on the Board of Trade here yesterday were the highest of the week.

BERLIN, April 3. -- With German official and political anticipations converging on the Lausanne conference, the news that Secretary of State Stimson will go to Geneva soon has whetted curiosity as to the scope of his itinerary and whether his official agenda, will be confined strictly pursuing the progress of the disarmament proceedings.

LONDON, April 2. -- In the rubber market plantation grades were dull and prices slightly easier, at the end of the week. Smoked-sheet spot sold at 1 7/8d. a pound value, April at 1 7/8d. sellers, May at 1 7/8d. buyers, July-September 2d. value, October-December 2 3/15d. to 2 1/41d. buyers, January-March 2 1/4d. sellers, crepe spot 2 7/8 to 2 3/4d. buyers.

Secretary WILBUR has endorsed a Senate bill proposing to amend one of the present anti-trust laws. This measure (S. 2626) is now before the Judiciary Committee for consideration. It would empower the Federal Trade Commission to sanction "trade conference agreements," provided they did not "unreasonably restrain trade or tend to create a monopoly."

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP). -- Manchuria'a guerrilla warfare has reached a point not more than 100 miles from Vladivostok, and foreign military observers are speculating as to whether Soviet Russia will remain complacent.
The fifteenth season of free concerts by the Goldman Band, under the direction of Edwin Franko Goldman, will be presented to the public this Summer, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, April 3. -- On nearly every election billboard in France there is being posted these days the portrait of Raymond Poincare, the man who saved France six short years ago from complete financial disaster and built up her resources so strongly that, better almost than any other country, she has been able to weather the storm of the last two years of depression.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To one who looks down on the Bowery from a train on the elevated these days the whole aspect of that big, grim street is better than it was last year. No longer those enormous crowds of ragged, shivering men and boys; and toward the end of the afternoon no great breadlines forming except the one at the Holy Name.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The volume in which first appeared the motto "E Pluribus Unum," adopted in 1782, perhaps at the suggestion of George Washington, for the Great Seal of the United States, has been discovered after years of search by Henry Woodhouse of New York, and acquired for his collection of Washingtoniana from descendants of the family of Betty "Washington Lewis, only sister of the first President.

A call for renewal of social idealism in the United States to defeat communism was sounded yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

The campaign of the Block Comnunity Organization will enter upon its second week today in the hope of having more than 10,000 blocks in the city fully organized by the end of the week. The 55,000 Block-Alders already in the field will be called upon to make their first financial reports tonight.

HONOLULU, April 3 (AP). -- Clarence Darrow, veteran Chicago criminal attorney, tomorrow will begin a court struggle to acquit Mrs. Granville Fortescue, society woman, of the murder of a young Hawaiian. Court sessions will be shortened because of Mr. Darrow's health.

PRAGUE, April 3. -- Statement of Czech National-Socialist speakers in Parliament two days ago that 15,000 children are threatened with starvation in Ruthenia do not exaggerate the famine conditions prevailing in that far eastern province of Czechoslovakia, according to assertions today by a Ruthenian Deputy, Ivan Kurtjak.

DUBLIN, April 3 (Canadian Press). -- The Free State Government of Eamon de Valera tonight was said to contemplate no severance of the link between this country and the British Commonwealth of Nations as a result of its proposals to abolish the oath of allegiance to the crown and to withhold payment of land annuities from the British Treasury.

The Social Problems Club of Columbia University, in cooperation with the National Students' League, will hold a mass meeting at noon today on the steps of the university library as part of its fight for the reinstatement of Reed Harris, former editor-in-chief of the Columbia Spectator who was expelled last Friday.

ASH MOUNTAIN, Sequoia National Park, Cal., April 3 (AP). -- The body of Lieutenant Edward D. Hoffman, army aviator missing since Feb. 1, when his plane was dashed to pieces against a Sierra peak, was found today where he had perished in deep snow.

CHICAGO, April 3. -- A "crop scare" is on in the Southwest, and unless rain comes within a short time the prospects of the wheat trade will be materially changed, since Kansas, Oklahoma and the Texas Panhandle will have a shorter crop than last year.

Many bridge parties in aid of various philanthropies have been organized for this Week. One will be given this afternoon in the Japanese Room of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Leake and Watts Orphan House of this city and Yonkers, under the patronage of its educational auxiliary.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3. -- Closing more than six weeks of intensive training on the Pacific Coast with a grand flourish, the Giants flattened both of San Francisco's baseball entries in the same arena today before an aggregate crowd of about 5,000.

Dame Partington is back. She has multiplied herself into the National Prohibition Board of Strategy, which is the collective voice of thirty-nine Dry agencies. The board emits a solemn warning. It prohibits both parties from declaring for referendum or repeal.

Formal offering will be made today of the issue of $2,765,000 Commonwealth of Massachusetts 4 1/4., 4 and 3 1/2 per cent bonds, consisting1 of $2,000,000 metropolitan water bonds, due from Jan. 1, 1933 to 1962; $500,000 metropolitan sewerage bonds, due from Sept. 1, 1932 to 1951, and $265,000 Cambridge subway bonds, due from May 1, 1933 to 1981, at prices to yield 3.75 to 4 per cent.

MOSCOW, April 3 (AP). -- The wheels of the $119,000,000 automobile plant at Nizhni-Novgorod -- Soviet Russia's challenge to Detroit -- have ground to a jolting stop barely three months after they began to hum. This was admitted today by the powerful executive committee of the Communist party in a proclamation demanding drastic reforms in leadership so that production may be resumed By April 15.

Members of the Mural Painting Atelier are showing mural designs and projects at the Beaux Arts Institute of Design, 304 East Forty-fourth Street. The exhibition opened with a private view yesterday afternoon. Beginning today, the public may visit the gallery through April 9.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Roosevelt has vetoed the Lord-Miller bill, passed unanimously by both the Senate and Assembly, which would require applicants for chauffeurs' licenses after June 1 to be American citizens or to have declared intentions of becoming such.

VIENNA, April 1. -- The adverse trade balance of Austria improved somewhat in February; a change attributed chiefly to the milder handling of government regulations regarding foreign money, and particularly to the partial restoration of the right to export against payment in schillings.

CHICAGO, April 3. -- Unsatisfactory conditions prevailed last week in the live-stock market here. Choice steers sold here at $8.15 a hundredweight, the lowest price since last May. Supplies were smaller, with the run at Chicago 36,600 head, a decrease of 2,000 for the week but an increase of 4,000 over that total last year.

The group managing the campaign of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for President have become convinced as the result of a series of victories last week that his nomination at the Democratic National Convention is virtually assured and that he has in sight not only a majority of the 1,154 delegates but the two-thirds necessary to nominate.

Dry opposition to Governor Roosevelt as the Democratic Presidential nominee would be lessened if he ran on a platform calling for a referendum on prohibition and offering a definite alternative program, Dr. Clarence True Wilson, general secretary of the Methodist Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals, said last night.

The 300 men and officers of Squadron A of the 101st Cavalry, under the command of Major Nathaniel H. Egleston, and 100 veterans marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon to the Church of the Heavenly Rest, at Ninetieth Street, where memorial services were conducted.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Some Republican leaders, convinced that President Hoover will be re-elected if the party appeals to the conservative East in its platform declarations, hold that it will fare best if the Democrats are forced into the attitude of espousing a radical program objectionable to the East.

If the city's budget requirements call for any increased charge for rides upon subway and elevated lines the "sales tax" of two cents a ride, recently suggested by Professor Lindsay Rogers of Columbia University, is the only form in which such a charge should be tolerated, according to a statement issued yesterday by Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel for the Transit Commission.

BERLIN, April 2. -- Financial Berlin believes that no confident inference can be based on the slight increase of the Reichsbank's reserve reported for the two last weeks of March. A similar increase occurred in the corresponding week of February, but the decrease in reserves was subsequently resumed.

LONDON, April 1. -- The new and spectacular rise of sterling exchange this week was regarded with mingled feelings on the London financial market. In the main, an appreciation of sterling which was in any sense due to deterioration of economic conditions abroad is not considered a matter for congratulation but for regret, and this week's movement of sterling seemed to be so regarded here.

Buying activity in the wholesale markets here last week fell much below expectations. Small fill-in orders were placed, but the general disposition of retailers was to delay reordering until weather conditions were conducive to moving stocks on hand. Few post-Easter sales were held, but the slowness at retail was held to indicate that such promotional steps may have to be undertaken shortly.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., April 3. -- With the running of the amateur allage and the shooting dog stakes the fourth annual Held trials of the Mount Holly Gun Dog Club came to a successful conclusion today. The final events were run under the best conditions Eastern field-trial enthusiasts have encountered this Spring, warm April sunshine bringing out a record gallery.

BUENOS AIRES, April 3. -- Shipments of all grains continued greater than in 1931. Prices are all weaker. The Minister of Agriculture publishes export surpluses as at date as follows: Wheat, 84,785,844 bushels; corn, 297,766,247 bushels; flaxseed, 53,456,920 bushels.

E.E. Clive will present the late Edgar Wallace's mystery melodrama, "The Ringer," on Broadway on April 18, at a house not yet selected. With Mr. Clive in the cast, the play will be revived tonight in Boston, where it was first seen in the Spring of 1929.

NEW ORLEANS, April 3. -- Trading in cotton contracts had periods of extreme activity last week and on the whole a large business was done. Prices were on the down grade virtually all week, rallies being shortlived. The extreme range was nearly 49 points and the net decline for the week was 37 to 41 points, or approximately $2 a bale.

The first balance sheet to be issued by the Railroad Credit Corporation shows total assets were $18,609,378 on March 31. The corporation was organized to distribute loans to weak railroads from funds derived from the freight surcharges that became effective on Jan. 4.

WASHINGTON. April 3. -- Secretary Stimson will not participate in any formal discussion of reparations or other intergovernmental debts on his visit to the League of Nations Disarmament Conference at Geneva, State Department officials said tonight.

LONDON, April 3. -- Passing all barriers like a will-o'-the-wisp, Major Charles H. Schoeffel of the New Jersey police is believed to have entered England tonight to follow clues in Birmingham and Glasgow which LONDON, April 3 the United States police think may throw some light on the Lindbergh kidnapping.

As inordinately difficult as is the task of making the American Olympic team, the Olympic Committee yesterday announced a set of standards for each event that will prevent hundreds of athletes from even reaching the semi-final tryouts. As a result of this move, made in collaboration with Head Coach Lawson Robertson, the semi-finals will have a smaller but much better group of contestants than at any time in the past.
NEW YORK. Sir Hugh Cunliffe Owen, Bart., of London is at the Ritz-Carlton.

As part of a plan by which rentals would be postponed for two years, holders of the $11,000,000 of 7 per cent bonds of the Hotel WaldorfAstoria Corporation have been asked to accept income bonds in lieu of their present holdings.

Nine prominent Democrats, among them aspirants for the nomination for President, joined yesterday in a prediction of party victory at the November election, in a "victory-gram" sent by mail to 100,000 Democrats urging them to contribute to the national committee's $1,500,000 victory fund.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Although 35,000,000, or seven-ninths of the total child population of the country, were found to be "reasonably normal" and 1,500,000 were reported "specially gifted," about 5,630,000 are handicapped to an extent requiring special attention and education, the report of the White House Conference on Child Health and Protection disclosed today.

The Federal revenue bill was described as an "irresponsible action of moral and mental defectives of the House of Misrepresentations" by the Rev. Dr. E. Russell Bourne in his sermon yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Resurrection, Seventy-fourth Street east of Park Avenue.

The fourth League of Composers' concert of the season, given yesterday afternoon in the French Institute, presented a string quartet by N. Berezowsky, four pieces for clarinet and piano by Alban Berg, Donald Tweedy's sonata for 'cello and piano; a sonata and "Caprigetti" by Ernst Toch, with this distinguished German modernist at the piano, and, last but by no means least, Randall Thompson's "Americana" for mixed chorus and piano.

BAYONNE, N.J., April 3 -- John Lawry, 5 years old, was killed this afternoon when a Broadway bus ran him down in the street between his home and a candy store operated by his stepfather on the other side of the avenue.
BOSTON, April 3. -- Twenty-eight worn officers and seamen reached Quincy today in the collier William C. Atwater of Fall River after a terrific night struggle with gales off Cape Cod.

This is conservation week. Governor ROOSEVELT issued a proclamation about it last Friday and will speak on the subject over the radio tonight. Conservation has a new significance for all the inhabitants of New York State this year, because it marks inauguration of the great reforestation program advocated by the Governor and endorsed by the people last Fall.

Paul De Bruyn of the GermanAmerican A. C., German marathon champion, won the eighteen-mile run conducted by the Metropolitan A. A. U. under the auspices of the James J. Tappen Post of the American Legion at Silver Lake, Staten Island, yesterday.

The Italian liner Roma is due today from Mediterranean ports. On board are Prince and Princess Carlo de Murat. Count and Countess Bonacossi, Dr. Willis Neally, John Knight, first vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, and Mrs. Knight.

BERLIN, April 3 (AP). -- The action against Nurmi, one of the greatest runners of all time and Finland's chief hope in the marathon at the 1932 Olympics in Los Angeles, bars him from participation in international athletics pending the result of the inquiry into his amateur status by the Finnish association.

Detective Francis Murray of the Manhattan Homicide Squad, driving through Queens with his wife yesterday afternoon, spotted a man whom the police have been seeking for a Fifth Avenue jewelry store robbery, homicide, and violation of parole. Murray tried to arrest him, but friends interfered.
NEW ORLEANS, April 3. -- Emmet Toppino, Loyola's great sprinter, equaled the world's record of 0:10.4 for the 100 meters, official Olymic sprint, in the Loyola Carnival of Sports today.

BLACKWOOD, N.J., April 4. -- An explosion of gasoline fumes in the basement of a bungalow here today hurled two women through a window, shattered every other window in the house and started a fire which burned the owner about the hands and face.

Brigantine Shoals, N.J., the graveyard of ships, accounted for three more lives when the barge Salem in tow of the tugboat Nassau sank there Saturday night and three men tried to escape to shore in a lifeboat. The lifeboat, awash and empty, was sighted fifteen miles southeast of Brigantine, by a Coast Guard airplane piloted by Gunner C.T. Thium of Cape May yesterday and hope was abandoned for the lives of the crew.

Henry R. Linville, president of the Teachers' Union, made public yesterday a letter sent by him to Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, attacking alleged coercion in the campaign to collect $400,000 a month from public school teachers for school and home relief.

ALWAYS in good humor, Lawson Robertaon has devised a comfortable and convenient try-out system for ambitious Olympic candidates. Every man his own judge, or a tryout in each backyard. Coach Robbie has set the standards for the various events. The candidate can have a proud father or a friendly uncle hold the watch on him or put the tape on his marks.

A committee to study the problem of wider diffusion of the Jews of the United States into the various economic spheres was appointed yesterday by the executive committee of the American Jewish Congress, at a meeting in the Jewish Club, 23 West Seventy-third Street.

CHICAGO, April 3. -- Donald Loftus, a daring bank bandit who operated alone, calmly confessed his crimes to detectives today. He told of robbing twelve banks in two years and leaving a trail of wives and women on whom he lavished loot of almost $100,000.

DETROIT, April 3. -- Prospective pilots of tender years swarmed upon the National Aircraft Show at the City Airport here today and fairly stole what was officially "Famous Pilots' Day" right away from the experts.

Soviet oil interests are willing to participate in an international conference which would undertake to bring about an understanding on various ills which beset the industry, according to a cablegram from Chairman Riabovol of the export division of the Russian oil syndicate to Russell Palmer, publisher of World Petroleum.

NEW ORLEANS, La., April 3. -- Wesley Ferrell, ace of the Cleveland staff, pitched good ball today to give the Indians the second and final game with the Robins, 3 to 2, to even the series. A crowd of 5,000, attracted by the prospect of a duel between Ferrell and Dazzy Vance, witnessed the contest.

The financial condition of Louis H. Willard, Bronx business man, who testified that he had been ruined as a result of the actions of William J. Flynn, Bronx Public Works Commissioner, is to be gone into today at a private examination by counsel for the Hofstadter legislative committee in preparation for a further attack which Flynn has indicated be will make on Willard's testimony.

The annual report of the Police Department of this city, published today, is a document which will repay a great deal of study and analysis. Commissioner MULROONEY himself discusses the facts and figures presented with intelligence, and with a manifest desire to interest the public in the details of police administration and discipline.

Mrs. Anne Henshaw took the lead last night in the singles event of the women's Greater New York bowling championship tournament. The singles and doubles competitions opened yesterday at Thum's Alleys. Mrs. Henshaw totaled 606 pins, thirty-eight in excess of the score of her nearest rival, Mrs. Jeanette Nolte.

MOSCOW, April 3. -- Production has been held up at the huge new Nizhni-Novgorod automobile plant and two of Joseph Stalin's closest associates in the Political Bureau of the Communist party, L.M. Kaganovich and Commissar of Heavy Industry Ordjonikidze, were sent there to find the reasons.

George La Torre of the GreekAmerican A. C., Otto Essig and Edward Walsack, both unattached, were the winners yesterday in three races held by the Manhattan Athletic League from the Greek-American A. C. clubhouse. La Torre captured the handicap 12 1/2-mile walk, Essig the 13-mile run and Walsack the handicap 4 1/2-mile run.

The use of economic boycotts to give force to the Kellogg-Briand pact outlawing war was advocated yesterday by three outstanding international authorities in addresses broadcast from station WOR in a symposium arranged by S. Theodore Granik, New York attorney.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Edwin C. Dinviddie, secretary of the Prohibition Strategy Board, said in a statement tonight that the returns of the Literary Digest poll on prohibition did not indicate the actual sentiment in the country.

A mysterious week-end trip by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, whose infant son has been held by kidnappers for more than a month, was revealed early today when the noted aviator drove up to the gate of his estate near Hopewell, N.J., behind the wheel of his automobile.

Clad in pajamas, slippers and a nurse's sweater, Edward Crygalis, 26 years old, whose address was listed as 1,887 Willoughly Avenue, Brooklyn, a prisoner in the men's surgical ward of the Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn, escaped from his police guard last night.

Neither dictatorship nor a monarchist restoration can help Germany rise from her present position of a defeated country to the level of a free and prosperous nation, declares Baron Richard von Kuhlmann. former German Minister of Foreign Affairs, in his book, "Thoughts on Germany," published, today by the Macmillan Company.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 3. -- Mrs. Neil Graham Finch entertained with a dinner at the Homestead this evening, later attending the concert in the Great Hall with members of her party.

The national financial measures now being taken in the United States have a vital bearing on the hope of the entire world for the return of prosperity, said Sir James Arthur Salter, director of the Economic and Finance Section of the League of Nations, in a broadcast from London yesterday through the WABC-Columbia network.

LONDON, April 1. -- The week's early movement of sterling at New York was occasioned by heavy liquidation of French and dollar balances, and this arose directly from the controversy at Washington over the methods by which the American budget was to be balanced.

A home run by Marty McManus with two on base in the third inning enabled the Boston Red Sox to register a 5-to-2 victory over Jersey City at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday. It was the first home game for the International Leaguers under their new manager, Hans Lobert, and a welcoming crowd of 6,000 turned out.

BERLIN, April 2. -- For the moment the influence of German politics on the financial situation at Berlin has fallen into the background. Financial circles now seem to consider that developments in the Krouger affair will determine the course of international business in the next few months more than any other factor.

The New York String Quartet gave one of the most satisfactory chamber music concerts of the season last night in the Town Hall, both from the viewpoint of program and performance. The program began with Smetana's quartet in E minor "From My Life."

Martha Graham has never danced more brilliantly here than she did in her season's farewell at the Guild Theatre yesterday afternoon. In a taxing program, during which she was on the stage the entire time, she maintained a height of inspiration which even to an artist of her calibre is not an everyday occurrence.

HONOLULU, April 3. -- The eyes of the nation -- of the world -- are focused on the opening here tomorrow of the trial of Mrs. Granville Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas Massie, her son-in-law, and two navy enlisted men. Albert O. Jones and E.J. Lord, for the murder of Joseph Kahahawei.

LONDON, April 3. -- Premier Andre Tardieu of France came here today and conferred with Prime Minister MacDonald preliminary to the fourpower conference which is to be held here Wednesday on the proposed Danube economic union. The two will hold a longer conference tomorrow.

The price trap for basic construction commodities has been brought considerably nearer by a shrinkage in the stocks held at common brick kilns, according to Alien E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports. Common brick is generally considered a safe indicator of forthcoming small building construction and alteration work, but inventories show a Spring shrinkage to 118,000,000 on hand as against a normal of two times that amount.

BASLE, Switzerland, April 3. -- Officials of the Bank for International Settlements are following the London conversations of the great powers, beginning with the Franco-British talks tonight, with special interest, but with little expectation that any concrete advance will be made either on the Danubian project or the reparations question.

Murders, manslaughters and robberies increased last year, but so did the efficiency of the Police Department in bringing the guilty to justice, Commissioner Mulrooney said yesterday in his annual report to Mayor Walker. The report, which dealt extensively with the work of the Crime Prevention Bureau, called special attention to a problem that has caused increasing concern in recent years -- the extreme youth of the majority of offenders.
The "know-it-all" attitude of the present generation was condemned by the Rev. John M. Quinn yesterday in his sermon at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "The Danube Union" misinterprets the aims and motives of such a union. Such a union could never be "the reconstitution, for economic purposes, of the Hapsburg monarchy," because, economically, all Slavs and Rumanians have been ruthlessly exploited by the Germans and Hungarians of the Hapsburg empire.

In the course of a sufficiently varied and entertaining bill, the Palace this week frequently breaks out in song. The singers range from Nanette Guilford, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, to the Yacht Club Boys, a quartet from the night clubs, and the selections are as varied as their interpreters.

Pan American Airways, operators of the international mail passenger and freight line to South America and the West Indies has joined Transamerican Air Lines of Cleveland and Detroit in developing an Arctic air transport route between the United States and Europe.

WARSAW, April 3. -- The Polish press is giving serious consideration to the danger of repudiation, of the Franco-Polish treaty of alliance in the event of a Left victory in the approaching French elections.

The executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York will urge the immediate modification or repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment to permit control of alcoholic beverages by the States, in a report to be presented at a meeting of the chamber Thursday.

Public officials "who play Judas for private gain while in office" are doing the Catholic Church more harm than "the religious bigotry of a half century ago," the Rev. Dr. Edward Lodge Curran, dean of Cathedral College, Brooklyn, declared in an address to the councils of the Twelfth District of the Knights of Columbus at their fiftieth anniversary celebration yesterday morning at the Hotel Astor.
Housing properties in Manhattan and outlying communities, figured prominently in real estate transactions announced over the week-end.

ROME, April 3. -- Premier Mussolini made the first public speech in German of his career today when, as part of the celebration of the Goethe centenary, he inaugurated an institute of German studies, situated in tha magnificent villa on the Janiculum Hill donated to the city of Rome by Mrs. Henrietta Tower Wurts, widow of George W. Wurts, once secretary of the United States Embassy here.

Announcement that Mr. STIMSON is about to sail for Geneva will quicken hopes for at least a moderate success of the Disarmament Conference.
