If it were, as has been pessimistically asserted, at a complete deadlock, it is not to be supposed that the Secretary of State would expose himself to a rebuff.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 3. -- Spread-eagling over perfectly good Springtime water, an energetic northwest wind more than filled the sails of the Frostbite Yacht Club's dinghies today and turned placid sailing into roller-coasting at sea.

ST. LOUIS, April 3. -- The machinelike passing of the New Bedford (Mass.) Whalers enabled them to defeat the Stix Club of St. Louis today, 5 to 2, and win the Dewar Trophy, emblematic of the championship of the United States Football Association.

On the whole, the mutiny of the House majority over budget-balancing ended happily, but not until the exchange market had given a spell of uneasiness. Probably Washington was more frightened than Wall Street, but that was doubtless for the best.
DETROIT, April 3 (AP). -- In another day of upsets several changes occurred among the leaders as a result of today's activity in the thirty-second annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress.

Four decorative metal and enamel plaques, reported to be the largest ever planned for exterior ornamentation of buildings, will adorn the facades of the two theatres in Rockefelier Centre, the Metropolitan Square Corporation announced yesterday.

The Paramount-Publix Corporation reported yesterday a net profit for the year ended Dec. 26, 1931, of $6,345,488, equivalent to $2.02 a share. This compares with a net profit for the preceding year of $18,381,178, equivalent to $6.15 a share on the average number of shares outstanding.

AMESBURY, Mass., April 3. -- Miss Margery Y. Jewell, aged 67, assistant treasurer of a Boston realty company, shot and killed her mother, Mrs. Mariannie F. Jewell, aged 88, in bed this morning and then turned the weapon, a revolver that had been her brother's, on herself, dying instantly from a bullet in her brain.

Spring, which optimists the land over have been hailing as "just around the corner" since those falsely smiling days in January, made an unmistakable bow to New York and its environs yesterday with a warm sun. Thousands flocked to parks and open spaces, highways and beaches.

ALBANY, April 3. -- Governor Roosevelt has approved a bill under which persons sent to State prisons or penitentiaries after July 1 will be able to earn compensation of seven and one-half days each month off their minimum, sentence, for good behavior-instead of five, as at present.

NEW HAVEN, April 2. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 62.9, which compares with 63.1 a week ago, 63.1 two weeks ago, 63.3 three weeks ago and 62.9 four weeks ago. The present year's highest average to date was 66.3 in the first week of January; this week's average, which was also reached four weeks, ago, was the lowest.

LIMA, Peru, April 3. -- From statements in the Peruvian Congress it would appear that the government, under the recently approved defense Of the realm act, is disposing of Communist agitators of the Aprist party by sending them to a tropical Siberia on the far side of the Andes, where the unexplored jungle of the Amazon sweens across the Peruvian border into Bolivia and Brazil and across South America to the Atlantic.

LARCHMONT MANOR, N.Y., April 3. -- H.M. Atwood won the trapshooting championship of the Larchmont Yacht Club today, breaking 193 out of a possible 200 targets. In the first round he had 24, 23, 24 and 22, for a total of 93. In his second he ran 100 straight.

The Pennsylvania Railroad increased its holdings of New York,? New Haven Hartford Railroad common stock from 265,025 shares in 1930 to 319,925 shares in 1931, it is shown in the report for 1931 of the trunk line. Apparently, however, the Pennsylvania pledged for loans or made other disposition of its controlling holdings in the Wabash and Lehigh Valley, because the status of these securities is not disclosed in the report.

PESHAWAR, India, April 3. -- The Northwest Frontier is now approaching a crisis in the yearly danger season, which will be a time of trial for the settlement negotiated with the Afridi tribesmen last October. The period until the end of May will give the transborder tribesmen an opportunity to show their practical disapproval of the government's action against the All-India National Congress and the Red Shirt organizations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Two recent articles in THE TIMES, one by Mr. Wickersham and one by Russell Owen, struck the two sore spots in our social life that stand out above all others. Both result from our absurd ideas on education.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- President Hoover will send a message to Congress early this week, probably tomorrow, according to Republican leaders, suggesting that department budgets be reduced by $300,000,000 for the fiscal year 1933.

MEXICO CITY, April 3 (AP). -- Troops kept Mexico's primary elections fairly peaceful today as voters gathered in the streets and plazas to choose candidates for Congressional and State elections in July, but two persons were reported killed and fifty-two injured in disorders.

After trailing for nearly an hour, the Harvard University rugby team rallied to defeat the French Sporting Club yesterday, by the score of 10 to 4. The game was played on the athletic field of the Consolidated Gas Company in Astoria, and was attended by an enthusiastic crowd.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Under parliamentary strategy seldom resorted to in the House, Democratic leaders are planning to pass within an hour tomorrow the Hare bill providing for independence of the Philippine Islands within eight years and then send it to the Senate, where it is generally agreed that it will not be accepted in its present form.

The New York Opera Comique announced yesterday that it would present its productions next season at a theatre in the Broadway district instead of the Heckscher Theatre, as in the last four seasons. The announcement answers the question whether the company, which has had to conduct a special campaign to raise funds to complete this season, will continue in existence.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., April 3. -- A cooperative, profit-sharing enterprise in film production, to be known as The Screen Guild, has been organized by M.C. Levee, formerly executive manager for the ParamountPublix studios and since last Fall president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

The oldest public utility holding company in the United States, which is the United Gas Improvement Company of Pniladelphia, will complete its fiftieth year of existence on June 1 with a capitalization which advanced from $832,736 at the time of its foundation to $347,861,795 at the end of 1931.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., April 3. -- A cooperative, profit-sharing enterprise in film production, to be known as The Screen Guild, has been organized by M.C. Levee, formerly executive manager for the ParamountPublix studios and since last Fall president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

Plans for financing for the Federal Intermediate Credit Banks system for April were announced yesterday by Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent. Offering will be made today of a new issue of $25,000,000 4 1/4 per cent collateral-trust debentures, dated April 15 and due in three, four and five months.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 4. -- The Robins played ten innings with the Minneapolis Millers today, and were rewarded only with a lot of exercise. The game ended in a tie, 2 to 2. It was called to allow the Robins to catch a train.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 4. -- After a full day replete with high class and extremely interesting work in the field, a large gallery of lovers of the bird dog gathered about the headquarters of the English Setter Club of America late today to await the announcement of the winners of the members' derby stake, first event of the program of the twenty-seventh annual field trials of the organization.

After a sharp debate which brought charges of "pussyfooting Americanism" from ministers who had served overseas during the war, the eighty-fourth annual New York East conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church adopted a resolution at its closing session at the Central Methodist Church.

Addressing the Repulican Organization Club of the Ninth Assembly District at the Hotel Monterey, Broadway and Ninety-fourth Street, last night, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared that he would go to the Republican National Convention uncommitted to President Hoover or any other candidate.

TRENTON, N.J., April 4. -- By a vote of 18 to 0 the Senate rejected tonight Governor Moore's renomination of Justice Arthur Gorman Gallagher for a second term on the Ocean County Common Pleas Court bench. Ignoring the Governor's request last week for permission to withdraw the nomination, the Senate made it impossible for Justice Gallagher to receive an ad interim appointment after the Legislature adjourns.

TRENTON, N.J., April 4. -- A reduction of salaries for all State employes was rejected today by the Joint Appropriations Committee of the Legislature after Senator Dryden Kuser, Republican, Somerset County, had moved it on the ground of economy.
TOKYO, April 4. -- The Foreign Office states definitely that Japan will not resume hostilities at Shanghai even if the present conference fails, unless the Chinese attack.

Despite weakness in the stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward yesterday and closed with net gains of 15 to 18 points. In the recent decline of more than a cent a pound liquidation of long accounts had reduced the floating supply of contracts, and short-covering disclosed few selling orders.

Opposing the plan of the Bowman-Biltmore Hotels Corporation regarding payment of its funded debt, which was made public last week, Frank Meyers, who declares himself to be a holder of first mortgage lease-hold 7 per cent bonds of the corporation, due on March 1, 1934, sent in a letter yesterday to other bondholders asking them to refrain from depositing their holdings with the bondholders' committee that has been organized.

TRENTON, N.J., April 4. -- With the consent of Federal Judge John Boyd Avis, who made a public statement explaining his action, Theodore M. Brandle, North Jersey labor leader, and his business partner, Joseph F. Hurley, a former Assemblyman, pleaded guilty in the United States district court here today to having defrauded the government of income taxes.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, choice of the supporters of Governor Roosevelt for the Presidential nomination, was picked today for temporary chairman of the Democratic National Convention, which will convene here June 28.

HELSINGFORS, April 4. -- On the eve of Finland's twelve years' experiment in compulsory prohibition, the Finnish capital is both quiet and sober. The general public seems entirely satisfied and in the same frame of mind that it was last December when, at the national plebiscite, it overwhelmingly decided to go off the dry standard.

The protective committee for first and refunding mortgage bonds of the Worcester Consolidated Street Railway Company has adopted a plan of reorganization under which a new operating company would e formed to handle the facilities of the present operating company would be formed management would be provided through a holding company, since the original trustees would be appointed by the committee for ten years.

The new $10,000,000 liner Manhattan, which is being built at Camden, N.J., for the United States Lines, will enter the transatlantic service in September or October instead of June as originally planned. The ship has been altered in some details at the direction of the group who took over the obligation to complete the Manhattan and a sister ship when they bought the United States Lines from Paul W. Chapman early last year.

The Central Park Casino, which on April 1 was five months in arrears in the payment of a monthly rental of $700 to the Park Department, shortly after Sidney J. Solomon, the Casino proprietor, was asked to produce his books for examination in the city inquiry, paid three months of the back rent on Saturday.

BERLIN, April 4. -- The campaign for the run-off balloting next Sunday for the Presidency of the Reich got under way with a rush in all parts of Germany today, Chancellor Heinrich Brucning opening the second campaign for Field Marshal von Hindenburg's re-election with an impressive speech at Karlsruhe, which was broadcast throughout South Germany.
Sale of 35,000 in mortgage participation certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company was reported on the New York Real Estate Securities Exchange yesterday.

WITH the final whirl for the Stanley Cup starting this evening at Madison Square Garden, it was deemed advisable to seek out Lester Patrick and query him about free skating and poke-checking. The big, broad-shouldered, gray-haired manager of the Rangers knows all about hockey in general and play-offs in particulars. As a player, a manager or a player-manager, he has been in so many Stanley Cup finals that he has lost count.

Prime Minister MACDONALD lets it be known that his conversations with M. TARDIEU have indicated progress toward a solution of the Danubian problem. This is reassuring. One's first impression cannot help being that greater progress would have been recorded if the two Premiers had not found it necessary also to discuss reparations, disarmament and Franco-Italian naval rivalry.

The president and the board of directors of the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association held the second in a series of receptions yesterday afternoon at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street, for the honorary officers of the organization.

AIKEN, S.C., April 4. -- The ponies of Seymour H. Knox of Buffalo took a share of the honors in the annual Aiken Polo Pony Show, held this morning. His Baby Grand, a brown mare, won the championship for best pony. Several others took blue, red and yellow ribbons.

The Whitney Museum of American Art has installed, in four of its galleries, an exhibition comprising Part II of the permanent collection -- paintings, water-colors and print that were not included in the initial showing. This exhibition opened privately yesterday afternoon, and will be on public view from today through April 27.

COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., April 4. -- Police Chief Harry Hayes and the twenty-one members of his force had their first day off since Christmas today, following the action of Mayor Joseph H. Van Meter in suspending every member of the Police Department this morning.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, April 5. -- With sixty out of Shanghai's seventy-two delegates and the entire North China delegation refusing to attend the National Emergency Conference to open at Lioyang Thursday, the revolt against the dictatorship of the Koumintang party is in full swing.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 4. -- Arthur W. Stanley, president and treasurer of the J.O. Draper Company, soap manufacturers, died at his home here today after an illness of six months. He was in his eighty-fifth year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In B. Frank Dake's comments in your columns on the shortcomings of democracies, he quotes George Garner as saying: "Nor is it pessimism which evokes a reminder that no democratic regime in all history ever has survived."
PITTSBURGH, April 4. -- A young Professor of Chemistry at the University of Pittsburgh announced casually tonight:

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Extreme laxity in law enforcement in the Hawaiian Islands has given rise to a feeling of personal unsafely among a substantial portion of the citizens, and the unusual conditions of race, society and industry in the territory make a continuance of this laxity fraught with "much social and political danger," Seth W. Richardson, Assistant Attorney General, stated in a report to the Senate this afternoon.

Hamilton M. Wright, New York advertising and publicity man, returned on the Cunard liner Aquitania yesterday after spending six months in North Burma hunting big game, principally tigers. Mr. Wright said that he was an honest hunter and had returned with nothing in the bag except a couple of stuffed jungle fowl which he shot one day while seeking tigers.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP). -- The public domain of 180,000,000 acres was thrown open to oil prospectors today on condition that if petroleum is found any pool discovered must be operated as a single unit.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, April 4. -- Finnish, athletic authorities were aroused today over the suspension of Paavo Nurmi, Finland's great runner, by the council of the Amateur Athletic Federation, meeting in Berlin, on charges of irregular expense accounts.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- Charges that Alphonse Capone was using his alleged power in Chicago politics in an effort to elect in the coming primary a majority of ward committeemen friendly toward obtaining a Federal pardon for him became today a leading issue in the campaign.

The Wabash Railways' holdings of common stock of the Lehigh Valley Railroad were 132,803 shares on Dec. 31, 1931, against 241,629 shares a year previously, according to the list of the twenty largest Lehigh Valley stockholders. Holdings ascribed to the Pennsylvania Railroad remained unchanged at 365,039 shares.

The possibility of substituting electric light for paint, paper or other wall covering in the interior decoration of homes was held out yesterday by Major H.S. Bennion, engineering director of the National Electric Light Association, who addressed the first sessions of a three-day home service conference at the Electrical Institute of the Electrical Association of New York, Inc., at Grand Central Palace.

Pressing demand for all possible economies has made it necessary for the Home Relief Bureau of the Department of Public Welfare to curtail by 10 per cent the amount of financial relief afforded to 125,000 families and will also make it necessary to close about fifty of the seventy-five precinct relief stations this month, it was reported yesterday.

Red tops and yellow coats will be worn this Spring by fire plugs in the theatrical district west of Eighth Avenue. Commissioner Mulrooney issued the fashion note yesterday after an hour's conference with Fire Department officials worried by motorists' indifference to the regulation against parking near fire hydrants.

NEWARK, N.J., April 4. -- The Newark Bears defeated the House of David, 7 to 2, today. Bobbie Barrett returned to third base for his first game since his sinus attack two weeks ago in Lakeland, and celebrated by smashing the first home run of 1932 here, a blow into the leftfield bleachers.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 4. -- Long Island builders declared an "open shop" today and about 500 carpenters were called off their jobs by union delegates, it was admitted today by P. Joergensen, Huntington contractor, a member of the board of governors of the Building Trades Employers' Association.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, whose infant son was kidnapped more than a month ago, slipped away from his home, near Hopewell, N.J., yesterday, and a little later flew away from the Newark Airport on his second mysterious journey since Saturday, searching, apparently, for a yacht off the Massachusetts coast.

High honors, including those for a soldier, will be paid tomorrow at his funeral to Major William F. Deegan, Tenement House Commissioner, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Receptions to Distinguished Guests and former State Commander of the American Legion, who died on Sunday at the age of 49, after an appendicitis operation performed a week ago.

HELSINGFORS, April 4 -- The enthusiasm of the Finnish people was growing on the eve of the great "drink day" tomorrow, marking the end of twelve years of prohibition. Contrary to expectations, all the new liquor shops in the capital are ready to open tomorrow.

Although the State of Tennessee had, as a matter of record, scheduled for award yesterday an issue of $9,000,000 of bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1936 to 1940, the proceeds of which it wants to refund a like amount of highway notes maturing on April 29, the sale was not consummated.
DULUTH, Minn., April 4 (AP). -- Four men on their way to Detroit to compete in the National Aircraft Show were killed this morning in an airplane crash twenty-five miles north of Duluth.

Identification of the basic chemical constituent of the coloring matter in bacteria as a member of the same group of compounds which are the building blocks in the green coloring substance of plants (chlorophyll) and in the red coloring matter in the blood (hemoglobin), has been made by Dr. Calvin B. Coulter of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, it was disclosed yesterday.

Imitating Lord Balfour. When ARTHUR BALFOUR was Prime Minister he used languidly to explain that he "never read the newspapers." It was more than once remarked by his political opponents that it would have been better for him if he had read them.
LONDON, April 4. -- George Bernard Shaw's tongue was as sharp as ever when he landed today, bronzed and vigorous, from his South African trip and breezily discussed the Irish situation.

Sacramento, Cal. The Sacramento (Cal.) High School District failed to receive any bids yesterday on its issue of $1,146,000 of bonds, due on July 1, 1933 to 1955, according to private advices received here. These bonds were originally offered on Dec. 28, 1931, and attracted no bids then.

JUST as the last world's championship baseball series brought Pepper Martin to the notice of every follower of this country's national pastime, so did the play-off for the National Hockey League championship, recently won by the New York Rangers, bring Ott Heller directly and forcibly to the attention of the hockey enthusiasts of this city.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The House today passed the Hare bill to grant complete independence to the Philippine Islands, effective eight years after inauguration of a Philippine Government. The vote was 306 to 47. The measure now goes to the Senate, where it is virtually certain to be modified to set the independence date at least fifteen years distant.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 5 (AP). -- A dispatch to the Rengo News Agency from Harbin, Manchuria, said today that Japanese troops had entered Fangchen [about 100 miles east of Harbin] after a fierce battle in which Chinese rebels against the new Manchurian regime were routed.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The Japanese Government is shipping 7,000,000 yen (about $2,310,000) of gold to the United States today, according to a cable message received by the Department of Commerce from Commercial Attache B.A. Butts at Tokyo.

HONOLULU, April 4. -- Six jurors were tentatively chosen on this the first day of the trial of Mrs. Granville Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, her son-in-law, and two navy enlisted men for the killing of Joseph Kahahawai.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice THE TIMES account of Commissioner Mulrooney's speech in which he appears to confuse boot leggers and speakeasy proprietors with other criminals. Does he not realize what a service these people are performing for the country in helping us to get rid of the prohibition law by nullifying it?

Rollin C. Bastress, former chief inspector in the Manhattan Bureau of Buildings, who is awaiting sentence next Monday with John I. Cahalan for accepting a $1,500 gratuity from a contractor for Bastress's approval of building plans, was questioned for an hour and a half yesterday on suspected general corruption in the bureau under the administration of Charles Brady, the former superintendent.
BOSTON, April 4. -- The field of 70 that started in quest of the eight National Junior A.A.U. boxing championships in the arena tonight was reduced to 16 after seven hours of thrilling fighting.

Strength in the grains and cotton, and moderately higher prices for coffee, sugar, rubber and silk, featured trading in the commodity markets yesterday. The improvement in these staples more than offset the softness in tin. Provisions were firm.

The week opened yesterday with the course of the markets more irregular and confused than usual; in fact, with uniformity of movement completely lacking. In stocks, the day's variations of price were unimportant, but in home bonds, especially the railway issues, declines of considerable scope occurred.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 4. -- The Australian Government today issued the text of a note it has sent direct to the de Valera government of Ireland urging it not to take any action which would weaken the Free State's ties with the British Empire.

Pledges of cooperation in solving the problems of the taxicab industry in this city were exchanged yesterday by Maurice Hotchner, chairman of the recently organized Board of Taxicab Control, and leaders of the industry at a luncheon in honor of Mr. Hotchner at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, April 4. -- Premier Andre Tardieu left London for Paris tonight after five hours and a half of official discussion with Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald on the Danubian question and fully twice as much of informal talk at two dinners and one luncheon.

John Howland of the New York A.C. scored an upset victory in the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior 220-yard free style championship, and John Wicklum of the Dragon Club won the 300-yard medley title test of the district for juniors at a water carnival in the 75-foot pool of the West Side Y.M.C.A. last night.
Manhattan College successfully inaugurated its 1932 baseball campaign by routing the Vermont University nine, 17 to 1, before a crowd of 1,000 at Jasper Field yesterday.

Members of the League of New York Theatres and representatives of theatrical labor unions met yesterday afternoon at the Astor to continue the fight against the 10 per cent amusement levy contained in the Federal tax bill, which was passed in the House of Representatives last week and which will come before the Senate shortly.

In contrast to the lively bidding, pungent wit and general festivity of other years, the annual auction of city concessions yesterday by the Department of Plant and Structures presented a glum picture of depression times in which dejected bidders offered small amounts for the privileges that formerly brought good revenue.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The Senate stock market Investigation, which was to have been started this week, was again pushed into the indefinite future today when Chairman Norbeck of the Banking and Currency Committee said that Bending business before the committee made an immediate investigation impossible.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- If the wets will agree on a substitute for prohibition, the dry forces will be willing to meet the issue, Dr. Clarence True Wilson, general secretary of the Methodist Board of Temperance, Prohibition, Public Morals, said when he was asked by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
DETROIT, April 4 (AP) . -- Chicago bowlers created two changes among the American Bowling Congress tournament leaders today.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 4. -- The Casino lawn was the setting for a number of tennis parties this afternoon. Colonel and Mrs. J.W. Cleveland entertained with a tennis tea. Mrs. Frederick Steinway, Mrs. Robert Mallory, Mrs. Richard Nott Dyer, Mrs. Philip W. Lennen, Mrs. Paul C. Downing and Mr. and Mrs. W.E. Massey Jr. were others entertaining informally.

PARIS, April 4. -- The price trend was upward on the Bourse today. Bank shares, Rio Tinto Copper and Royal Dutch Oil all showed surprising strength. Except the metal group, which continued weak, almost the entire list was firm. The Bourse's strong technical position at present is attributed to the abundance of available unemployed capital here.

The living costs of wage-earners in the United States declined 17 per cent during the two-year period ending December, 1931, according to the eight annual report of the National Industrial Conference Board, made public yesterday.

The Texas Corporation announced yesterday that it had advanced prices of crude oil 10 to 15 cents a barrel throughout its territory in the Southwest, meeting recent advances of 15 cents a barrel made by competitors in the midcontinent and Texas fields and extending the higher prices to the Gulf Coast field, Louisiana and Arkansas.

Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, chairman of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, asked Dr. Clarence True Wilson yesterday whether he would instruct "the lobbyists" of the Methodist Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals to work for resubmission to the people of the Eighteenth Amendment.

NEWARK, N.J., April 4. -- Following a report by Haskins Sells, auditors, that a shortage of $28,250 had been found in the real estate account of the North Jersey District Water Supply Commission, in connection with the Wanaque Reservoir Construction, the commission adopted a resolution today suspending Henry G. Hershfield of Pompton Lakes, its real estate representative; Maurice McLaughlin, head of the auditing department, and James F. Martin, bookkeeper.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., April 4. -- Mrs. Raymond B. Fosdick, wife of the internationally known lawyer, war worker and peace advocate, shot her two children dead and ended her own life in the family home here early this morning. She had been mentally deranged for ten years.

DETROIT, April 4. -- Two erstwhile chiefs in the Army Air Service, Major Gen. James K. Fechet, retired, and former Brig. Gen. William Mitchell, flew here today to attend the national aircraft show in the huge hangar at the city airport and to address meetings in connection with the exhibition tomorrow.

Has anybody got any money? If he has, can you pry it out of him with a crowbar for such luxuries as payments to discharge old debts of political managers, and something over for their successors to start out with? As a committee for the relief of the Democratic National Committee, nine distinguished Democrats who have felt or feel the hopes and pangs of candidacy have had mailed to 100,000 Democrats a "touching" request.

An increase in bill offerings, but not enough of a supply to meet the demand by dealers, and some buying by the Federal Reserve Bank for foreign account, represented the only development of interest in the day's money market. In other sections Stock Exchange day loans, maturity money and commercial paper were all quiet and unchanged in quotation.

Declaring that Owen Madden, ex-convict called by the State a "beer racketeer of no little importance," had been arrested "on flimsy and highly technical grounds" and that no "substantial charges" had been made against him, Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy discharged Madden from custody yesterday and sustained the writ of habeas corpus under which he had been free in $10,000 bail since the middle of February.

Stephen P. Nash of Jackson, Fuller, Nash Brophy, attorneys for the late Joseph Pulitzer and of the former New York World, filed an accounting of the residuary estate yesterday in the Surrogate's Court. The accounting was made necessary by the birth of a new grandchild, Susan Pulitzer, daughter of Ralph Pulitzer of 450 Park Avenue, who was born Jan. 29, making the seventeenth grandchild of the elder Pulitzer.

An increase of $8,439,301 in borrowings by member firms of the New York Stock Exchange in March is disclosed in the monthly compilation made public yesterday by the Exchange. The loan account stood at $533,103,059 on March 31, compared with $524,663,758 on Feb. 29.

General EDWARD S. GODFREY of the old army died in a quiet little village in New Jersey on Friday at the ripe age of 88. He was a typical West Pointer of the old school, proud of his profession, and having certain standards of behavior that are rather uncommon in this age of advancement by the use of political influence.

HONOLULU, April 4 (AP). -- Comment varying from cautious remarks from Legislative quarters to caustic newspaper criticism was Honolulu's greeting to the report of Assistant Attorney General Seth W. Richardson, submitted to Congress today, which charges extreme laxity in law enforcement here.

LA PAZ, April 4. -- In reply to reports of war preparations by Bolivia in the Chaco region the Foreign Office sent out today a circular cablegram to Bolivian legations and consulates throughout the world denying that there was any Bolivian military activity in the Chaco except the annual routine relief of the frontier guards.

The charge that the B.M.T. and Interborough, through their banking connections, seized upon the city's recent financial difficulties in the floating of substantial loans as a pretext for reviving the higher fare issue was made yesterday by Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel for the Transit Commission.

ROCHESTER, April 4. -- George Eastman, in a codicil to his will signed and witnessed a few hours before he killed himself March 14, left the bulk of his $20,000,000 estate to the University of Rochester. It was revealed when the will was offered for probate today that Mr. Eastman laughed and joked with the witnesses to the codicil and that his suicide followed soon after their departure.

Five of the twelve jurors who will determine whether or not Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, neglected his duty in not closing the Bank of United States before he did were selected yesterday at the opening of the superintendent's second trial before Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- Sensational reports of damage to grain crops are being received in increased numbers on the Board of Trade here, with evidence of a marked widening in the area in the West and Southwest affected by the recent freezing weather or the drought.

Net income of the United Light and Power Company for 1931 was $7,819,382 after taxes, charges, depreciation, subsidiary dividends and minority interest, equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.21 a share on 3,473,919 average number of common shares outstanding during the year, against $10,462,450, or $2.01 a share on 3,424,193 average number of common shares, in 1930.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., April 4. -- Forest fires raged in this section of Suffolk County today, and according to Chief Fire Ranger Clarence E. Dare more than 300 men have been fighting flames at Miller's Place, Bohemia and Melville. Mr. Dare reported tonight that all fires were under control, but not until after a large amount of timber had been destroyed.

Adoption of a new educational policy, calling for higher standards of admission and training, was announced yesterday by the Columbia University School of Journalism. The changes, sanctioned both by the university council and the university trustees, will take effect on July 1, when the school will have completed twenty years of academic service.

Professor HOCKING in his new book, "The Spirit of World Politics," holds that it is today "controlled more profoundly by the incidents of inequality or supposed "inequality than by any other circumstance." He has gone to the so-called" backward" peoples, in their A B C degrees of backwardness, in the Near East and Northern Africa.
PHILADELPHIA, April 4. -- The Athletics turned the tables on the Phillies by the exact score of their Saturday defeat and evened the city series at one game apiece today with an 8-to-4 triumph.

Forty-five members of the Fordham football squad reported for the initial Spring practice session of the 1932 season at Fordham Field yesterday. The men engaged in a light workout which lasted about two hours.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The bill fixing a definite time for Philippine independence may progress no further at this session, but its overwhelming passage by the House today may change the foreign policies of many countries. This belief was expressed tonight by some important administration officials who interpret the House action as an international calamity.

Borough President Henry Bruckner of the Bronx is to be examined on his bank accounts before the Hofstadter legislative committee, as well as on his relations with William J. Flynn, Bronx Public Works Commissioner, it was announced yesterday as assistant counsel to the inquiry prepared for the resumption of public hearings tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP). -- Strong administration opposition marked the opening of hearings today before a Senate committee on the Shipstead bill to issue $500,000,000 of bonds for river and harbor improvements.

With stocks again exploring depths that had not been reached previously in any phase of the bear market, Wall Street was in a cheerless frame of mind yesterday. The day's news was not of such a character as to give the financial community any concern, but the market resumed its slow decline.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 4. -- Forbes K. Wilson of York Harbor, Me., stalwart linksman who last year was a star on Yale's golf team and who twice has held the Maine State title, led the field today for the first half of the thirty-six-hole qualifying round of the thirty-second annual North and South amateur golf championship.
Paulino Uzcudun, Basque heavyweight, knocked out Jack Gagnon of Boston last night in the seventh round of the scheduled ten-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Creation of a joint Congressional and executive board to work out reductions of more than $200,000,000 in Federal expenditures was recommended to Congress today by President Hoover as the essential remaining step toward balancing the budget.
The Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association has completed plans for another golfing year, which begins in tournament fashion in one month.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The veteran who left the service as able-bodied as when he entered it has no least claim upon his country for any bonus whatsoever. Such a demand is unsportsmanlike, and smacks so strongly of political blackmail that every sensible, honest legislator should scorn to entertain such a preposterous claim.

Protests against the proposed local law requiring city employes to live in New York City were sent to Mayor Walker and the Board of Aldermen yesterday by the Teachers' Union, of which Dr. Henry R. Linville is president.

Only $130,816,000 of new public financing, exclusive of domestic and Canadian municipal loans, was done in the first three months of 1932, according to figures announced yesterday by Otto P. Schwarzschild, president of the National Statistical Service, Inc.

From the several hundred books published in the last six months, the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee, headed by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, has prepared a "white list" of about 100 titles which are recommended for Catholic readers.

A general strike of Columbia students was called yesterday for tomorrow by the sympathizers of Reed Harris, expelled editor of The Spectator. The idea is that pickets will patrol the buildings while the professors lecture to empty halls.

BERLIN, April 4. -- All foreign unfunded long-term credits, as well as foreign short-term credits not included in the standstill agreement, will henceforth be treated, as far as repayment of principal is concerned, like the standstill credits, which means according to Clause 10 of the standstill agreement.

For the House of Representatives to pass almost without debate a bill to grant independence to the Philippines after eight years seems at best a very inconsiderate way of legislating on an important question. The vote was overwhelmingly in favor of the measure.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 4. -- Despite a weak batting attack last year and the loss of key men in even this light assault, Yale faces the start of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League season on its home diamond Wednesday confident of making a fight for the championship.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 4. -- The Naval Academy varsity crews had their first racing today, a series of sprints on the Severn. Having started conditioning a month later than usual, and meeting with adverse weather conditions almost daily, the squad, according to Coach Charles (Buck) Walsh, is far behind in practice and sadly in need of instruction.
Steps were taken last night to form junior block-aid auxiliary to cooperate with the Block Community Organization, whose canvass and stamp sale is now in its second week.

RICHMOND, Va., April 4 (AP). -- Rival groups of delegates to the natrict committeemen were named at a gathering of Third District Republicans here today at which it was indicated the fight between the "Old Guard" and the so-called progressive faction would be carried to the Chicago convention for settlement.

Exchange memberships depreciated sharply again yesterday simultaneously with a further fall in the stock market and the receipt of reports from Washington indicating an apparently serious determination on the part of Congressional leaders to retain the increased stock sales tax in the pending revenue bill.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The establishment of a department of art in the Federal Government was urged by John Sloan, president of the Society of Independent Artists and president of the Art Students' League, in a recent address at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
NEW YORK. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt will leave for Washington tomorrow. After a few days there, Mrs. Vanderbilt will go to Hot Springs, Va.

BELGRADE, April 4. -- After governing Yugoslavia three years, two and a half as head of the dictatorship and the last half year as chief of a pseudo Parliamentary regime. General Pera Zivkovitch, "Napoleon of the Balkans." handed his resignation to King Alexander this morning and was succeeded by Vorgislas Marinkovitch, who had been Foreign Minister of his government.

A reshuffling of the direct and indirect holdings of O.P. and M.J. Van Sweringen in their railroad system was disclosed yesterday in reports of the Alleghany Corporation, the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad, or Nickel Plate.
THE BAT. comic opera in three acts and four scenes by Johann Strauss. English book and lyrics by Lawrence Langner and Robert A Simon. Presented by the New York Opera Comique at the Heckscher Theatre.

Ordinarily this is not a time of year when city officials pay much attention to financial matters. Appropriations are out of the way. The Controller has finished his annual calculations. The Aldermen have fixed the tax rate. Next comes the tax collector, whose job the meek citizens of this metropolis, accustomed to pay what they are told to pay without grumbling, have made something of a sinecure.

Issay Dobrowen, conductor of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra, will be a conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next season with Arturo Toscanini and Bruno Walter, it was revealed yesterday when the board of directors announced next season's plans.
MOSCOW, April 4. -- The trial of Judas Stern for the shooting last month of Dr. Fritz von Twardowski, the Counselor of the German Embassy, opened today like a chapter from a book of Dostoievski.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- Prices of hogs were unsettled today, opening strong only to weaken later and close 10 to 25 cents lower than on Saturday. Packers were good buyers at the lower figures. Shipping demand was rather limited. The top was steady at $4.55 a hundredweight, while the day's average was 10 cents lower than on Saturday at $4.15.

Several taxes contained in the bill passed by the House of Representatives are opposed in a report of the Committee on Taxation of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York. The report will come before the chamber at its meeting on Thursday.

The creation of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation probably has done more toward restoring confidence to bank depositors and the bankers themselves than any other action undertaken so far, according to Howard W. Smith, trust officer of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, who addressed the financial advertising group of the Advertising Club at a luncheon at the organization's clubhouse yesterday.

The Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard University will present its eighty-sixth annual show, the musical comedy "Pudding on the Ritz," at Mecca Temple on Friday evening. There will be only one performance here. The production is a burlesque of undergraduate life at Cambridge.

TRENTON, N.J., April 4. -- Spokesmen for New York State and Connecticut appeared today before the Senate Judiciary Committee to urge passage of the bill providing for New Jersey's participation in the proposed tri-State compact for control of pollution of water.
Rowing was introduced formally at another New York college yesterday when five boatloads of Manhattan College oarsmen took to the Harlem River in the crews' first outdoor workout.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I observe that we are again to have a national clean-up week -- a very beneficial and desirable movement to encourage cleanliness and tidiness, and avoid waste, disease and conflagration.

BOWIE, Md., April 4. -- A. Pelleteri's Marlene, a daughter of St. Germans from Afternoon, won the Attractive Purse, feature at Bowie today. In addition to saddling Marlene Pelleteri sent out H.C. Murnan's Sister Zoe to win the nightcap. Jockey J. Smith rode both winners.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Back from the United States, I am very glad to find out that we Swiss may perhaps contribute something to relieve the unemployment situation in your country. We have a great many small and prosperous country communities, with a management of culture and small industries of their own, in which people are happy and do not feel much of the depression.

TOO TRUE TO BE GOOD, a "new play" in three acts, by George Bernard Shaw. Settings and costumes designed by Jonel Jorgulesco; staged by Leslie Banks under the supervision of Theresa Helburn and Philip Moeller; produced by the Theatre Guild. At the Guild Theatre.
WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The text of President Hoover's message sent to Congress today calling for a national program of economy follows:

PHILADELPHIA, April 4. -- Three pool records were shattered as the combined swimming team of the Los Angeles and Hollywood Athletic Clubs, swimming under the name of the latter club, defeated the Penn A.C. in the latter's tank tonight, 44 to 20, before a capacity crowd.

The New York Rangers are slight favorites at 6 to 5 to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden tonight in the first game of the Stanley Cup final, the world's series of hockey. A capacity crowd of 16,000 is expected

Dick Shikat of Philadelphia, former world's champion, and Earl McCready of Canada wrestled more than an hour in the feature bout of a program at Madison Square Garden last night without reaching a decision.

MIAMI, April 4. -- Wherever Columbus first landed in the new world it could not have been Watling's Island, or San Salvador (in the Bahaman group), as is generally believed, Dr. David Fairchield, plant explorer, said today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Y.W.C.A. of the city of New York has been forced by present conditions to inaugurate a temporary relief program to help the young women who come to its branches discouraged, without a job, often penniless and ill.

ALBANY, April 4. -- Governor Roosevelt this evening formally opened "conservation week" with a brief radio address, broadcast over Station WGY, in which he urged defeat at the polls at the general election this year of the proposed constitutional amendment which would open the forest preserves to the establishment of popular amusement resorts conducted on a commercial scale.
WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Secretary Stimson's letter to Senator Bingham of Connecticut on Philippine independence read:

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Following is the official summary of the report on crime and law enforcement conditions in Hawaii as prepared by Assistant Attorney General Richardson and submitted to the Senate:

Additional State-chartered banking institutions yesterday issued statements of their condition as of the close of business on March 28 in response to the call of the State Superintendent of Banks. The reports indicated a high degree of liquidity in all cases. The principal items shown were:

PRINCETON, N.J., April 4. -- Marking the first time in its gridiron history that a non-alumni coaching system has been employed, Princeton began Spring football practice today with Head Coach H.O. (Fritz) Crisler, formerly of Minnesota, confronted with the task of bringing the Tigers back into their traditional rating among the leaders of college elevens.

In his message yesterday the President urged both houses of Congress to delegate representatives who, "together with representatives of the Executive," would be authorized to frame" a complete national "program of economy and to recommend the legislation necessary to make it possible and effective" at the present session.

Mayor Walker's application to the Appellate Division in Brooklyn for an extension until July 1 of the stay under the protection of which "emergency bus" operation has continued for about two years, despite a Supreme Court injunction, was described as "amazing temerity" yesterday in the argument on the petition.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The shutdown of the Soviet's $119,000,000 automobile plant at Nizhni-Novgorod until there can be "absolute obedience to the will of one man -- namely the Soviet manager" -- convinced a number of Senators today that the government of the U. S. S. R. was fast abandoning the original Communist doctrine of diversified direction of industry.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Exports in February were valued at $153,924,528, or $4,023,119 more than in January, but $70,421,044 less than in February, 1931, according to Department of Commerce figures issued today.

The quadrennial Spring primary election to choose delegates to the national conventions of the Democratic, Republican and Socialist parties and to elect members of the State committees of these parties will be held in New York State today. In New York City the polls will be open from 3 P.M. to 9 P.M.

The annual report of the National Electric Power Company for 1931 shows that the operating revenue of subsidiaries was $67,512,892, compared with $62,996,177 the year before. Net operating income after expenses, taxes and depreciation was $26,184,826, compared with $22,777,168 in 1930, and net after rent for lease of lines and plants was $25,823,684, compared with $22,355,732.
MOSCOW, April 4. -- The first practical wheat sowing from an airplane has been carried out successfully on a State farm in Central Asia.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 4. -- The Yankees' homeward-bound march along the exhibition trail occasioned another notable gathering of fans today, a crowd of 6,500 collecting at Parkway Field and running a variable gamut of fan emotions as the Yanks defeated the local American Association team, 9 to 6.
NEWARK, N.J., April 5. -- The Newark Bears easily defeated the Youngstown club of the Middle Atlantic League before a slim and chilled gathering today, winning, 13 to 0. The Bears made fifteen hits.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 5. -- The Philadelphia Athletics bunched three hits to score two runs in the sixth inning and then repulsed a last inning Princeton rally to defeat the Tiger varsity team, 3 to 2, on the university field today before a crowd of 3,000.

Buyers' Registrations Gained. An increase in the number of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES For the week 770 buyers were listed as against 627 in the previous week and 588 in the same period last year.

The Federal grand jury in Brooklyn banded to Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the United States District Court yesterday eight indictments charging ten persons with bribing members of the Coast Guard service on the south shore of Long Island to permit the landing of contraband liquor and with conspiracy to smuggle liquor into this country.

As a preliminary to what is expected to be one of the widest drives against liquor and beer New York has known in years, sixty prohibition agents, acting on secret orders from Amos W. W. Woodcock, Director of Prohibition, started out yesterday to make a thorough survey of the speakeasy situation, listing all known places where alcoholic drinks are sold.

H. Ellsworth Vines Jr. of Pasadena, the national tennis champion; Frank Shields of New York, third in the ranking; John Van Ryn of Philadelphia, fourth in the list, and Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, rated ninth, will constitute the United States Davis Cup team for the opening tie in the North American zone with Canada, to be played at the Chevy Chase Club, Maryland, April 28, 29 and 30.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 5. -- Mrs. Fay Ingalls, M.F.H. of the Bath County hunt, led a large field of riders on a drag this afternoon. The hunt met at The Yard and from there the course led in a wide circle, swinging back toward the Homestead for the kill on a rise immediately in front of the hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- When details of the acrimonious debate and the day-long deadlock in the committee of arrangements for the national convention at Chicago yesterday reached Democrats here privately today, they realized that only by forceful generalship had a serious party split been averted.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 5. -- Declaring that "the President is obviously playing politics," Representative Crisp, acting chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, who is resting here, declared today that nevertheless Congress should support the efforts toward economy which the Chief Executive outlined in statements yesterday and today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At this time, when it seems necessary to tax everything and everybody, cannot Congress find some way to make those in the liquor business bear their equitable share of the burden?

PARIS, April 5. -- This world famous "City of Light" was not illuminated as brilliantly as usual tonight. Along the boulevards, up in Montmartre and over in Montparnasse the customary blaze of electricity was reduced at least 50 per cent if not more.

Six men qualified last night at the New York A. C. for the semi-final round of the national foils championship which will be decided April 25 at the New York A. C. The first and second rounds were contested last night.
BERLIN, April 5. -- The German Government is going ahead with its financing plans on the theory that there will be no more reparations payments.

BERLIN. April 5 (AP). -- A committee of the Boerse announced tonight that when the exchange is reopened on April 12 for unrestricted trading twenty-four securities no longer will be listed, including St. Louis San Fransclsco general lien, and ManiSouthwestern mortgage, St. Louistoba Consolidated Railway bonds.

ALBANY, April 5. -- A new health program for the State which has for its goal the saving of 50,000 lives yearly is outlined in a final report by the State Health Commission, headed by Dr. Livingston Farrand, president of Cornell University. The report was made public by Governor Roosevelt today.

The Atlantic Transport liners Minnewaska and Minnetonka, operating between New York and London as first-class liners, have been re-designated tourist-class snips and transferred to the Red Star Line service between New York, British ports, Cherbourg and Antwerp, effective May 13.

New York had its sad parody of a circus parade last night when the Messrs. Ringling and Barnum and Bailey moved their elephants into Madison Square Garden. There were no calliopes to play waltz salutes to the beer gardens of Yorkville and no performers dancing in spangles.
Action of outside markets had a depressing influence on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the setback left prices 10 to 16 points lower for the day.

It will be a pity if the differences between the President and Congress in the matter of reducing Federal expenditures should blind the country to the facts. Mr. HOOVER recalls the many times, even before he became President, when he has explained the only way in which economies can be effected.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., April 5. -- Following a turbulent day in which an infuriated mob of 10,000 persons besieged and wrecked the Newfoundland legislative building and completely demoralized the police and other civil forces, Sir Richard Squires, Prime Minister of Britain's oldest colony, was beaten and trampled on this evening until he promised to resign.

Twenty-four hours after he had wrestled Earl McCready of Canada to a no-decision finish in Madison Square Garden Dick Shikat of Philadelphia, former world's heavyweight champion, tackled Sammy Stein of Newark at the New York Coliseum last night, and this match also was a draw.

None of the Austrian banks is expected to pay dividends for 1931, usually declared at about this time of year, according to advices received here by Carl Marks Co., who say that, although their correspondent mentions conservation of assets as the reason, it is understood that the difficulties of the Austrian Credit-anstalt have had an important part in the decisions not to make payments.

An honor list made public yesterday by Police Commissioner Mulrooney cited 194 members of the department for meritorious acts of service. Bravery, heroism and death in line of duty speak from the cold lines of the roll of departmental recognition.

DETROIT, April 5 (AP). -- Robert T. Walker, assistant to William B. Mayo, chief engineer of the Ford Motor Company, and a factor in building up the company's airplane division, resigned today. He had been associated with the company for eighteen years.

A notice of appeal from the decision of Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy freeing Owen (Owney) Madden, ex-convict, and three other former Sing Sing inmates from the custody of the State Parole Board will be filed with the Appellate Division today or tomorrow by John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General.

An Admirable Crichton passed with WILHELM OSTWALD. Not content with the position that he won as a founder of physical chemistry -- a science which treats chemical reactions as exchanges of energy -- he ranged over the whole field of human knowledge.
HONOLULU, April 5. -- Out of preliminary chaos the Massie-Forescue murder trial emerged today with certain definite trends which aroused much interest and speculation.

How a forger's guilt has been made to shine out in darkness since the ultra-violet ray has been enlisted in the detection of this form of crime was described yesterday by Samuel G. Hibben, lighting specialist of the Westinghouse Lamp Company at Bloomfield, N.J.

FARGO, N.D., April 5. -- Fargo's call to its nearly 29,000 citizens to rout depressed business conditions, sounded a week ago today with every siren in the city screaming, resulted today in pledges totaling $606,792.02. a per capita promise in excess of $21.

HELSINGFORS, April 5. -- Finland went wet today, temperately and with order prevailing. The change of standards was accomplished in a businesslike manner during the daylight hours, nightfall giving the transition more of a gala aspect.

Talking to people who saw ROSE COGHLAN, one hears of her voice. The Barrymore voice is the one admired and imitated among young actresses and hopelessly stage-struck girls today. ROSE COGHLAN'S voice is mentioned, taken for granted, never described but always figuring in accounts of her acting, her home life, her bankruptcies and her "return engagements."

Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, announced yesterday the membership of the administrative committees for each of the city's three institutions of higher learning -- the City College, Hunter College and Brooklyn College.

The first of the five concerts to be given on Tuesday evenings by an orchestra of 200 unemployed musicians, with distinguished conductors and soloists who donate their services -- concerts made possible by the cooperation of the Musicians' Emergency Aid and the Musical Union, Local 802, of this city -- took place last night in the Metropolitan Opera House before a packed auditorium and a warmly appreciative audience.

Reports that negotiations looking to the merger of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company were being resumed could not be confirmed officially here last night. It was said in informed circles, however, that a revival of the plan was expected, whether or not discussions are now taking place.

Within two weeks, it was learned yesterday, the backers of the socalled Untermyer plan for liquidation of the assets of the defunct Bank of United States with eventual full payment to depositors expect to be able to report that the $8,000,000 necessary to assure the working out of the proposal has been raised.

DUBLIN, April 5. -- A flat refusal to pay next June's instalment of land annuities is believed to form a part of the de Valera's Government's reply to the British Government, which left Dublin by special messenger today.

CINCINNATI, April 5. -- Sam Byrd's homer with two on base in the seventh inning was a helpful factor in the Yankees 9-to-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today. Since the two teams broke even in their two Florida contests, today's result gave the Yanks the series honors, two games to one.

The balance sheet of the Chicago Great Western Railroad for Dec. 31, last, shows that the company included among its investments 104,500 shares of Kansas City Southern Railway common stock acquired from the Alleghany Corporation. The stock is pledged as collateral for notes of $3,175,200.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 5. -- Phar Lap, the sleek-coated, reddish-brown gelding brought to this country from Australia last January in the expectation of becoming the greatest money winner of all time, died of colic today on the Ed Perry Ranch at Menlo Park, near Palo Alto.

James W. Gibboney, 54 years old, who disappeared last Friday from his home at 12 Sutton Place, was found dead from illuminating gas in a furnished room at 126 East Thirty-first Street on Monday, but his identity was not established until last night, when his widow made the identification at the Bellevue morgue.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, April 5. -- The summit of Mount McKinley, North America's highest peak, is the goal which is drawing four men in dog sleds from McKinley National Park across the Kantisha region to the mountain's base, from where they will begin the first ascent attempted since 1913.

An air of optimism, as inexplicable as the events of the last few days, characterized yesterday's search for the kidnapped son of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh. The aviator, who spent most of the afternoon helping volunteers beat out a brush fire that menaced his home on Sourland Mountain, seemed almost cheerful, and an attitude of expectancy pervaded the near-by village of Hopewell.

NEWARK, N.J., April 5 (AP). -- Bishop James Cannon Jr. of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, warned both political parties tonight that the inclusion of wet planks in their Presidential platforms would arouse dry opposition. Addressing the Newark Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, he called upon President Hoover, as the probable Republican nominee, to demand that his party reject proposals for a wet declaration.

The National Orchestral Association gave the seventh concert of its season yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Leon Barzin conducted Beethoven's First Symphony and his piano concerto No. 3 in C minor, with Myra Hess as the soloist, and Rimsky - Korsakoff's "Scheherazade."

A return to the 1/4 rate for Federal funds, which had occurred on several occasions recently, was the only distinguishing mark of an otherwise quiet day. While the cheapness in this charge again demonstrated the underlying ease of the market, it was specifically ascribed to the heavy over condition of the banks at the Reserve institution due to the repayment of the British credit.

A tea and fashion, show in aid of Everybody's Thrift Shop took place yesterday afternoon in the main ball-room of the Ritz-Carlton. Young matrons and debutantes acted as manikins in the fashion show, which was a feature of the entertainment. Among them were:

GLASGOW, April 5. -- Twice today, at the request of Scotland Yard, two Glasgow detectives visited the house on Nithsdale Street occupied by Mrs. John Taylor, mother of Betty Gow, the Lindbergh baby's nurse, and her family. Their call this morning was the first since the police visited the house early in the kidnapping investigation when it was reported from Hopewell that Betty Gow had been questioned and absolved of any suspicion in the crime.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 5. -- Plans for a merger of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation are being renewed and it is expected here that the consolidation will be effected this time without opposition. The sheet and tube company's auditing department is working days and night developing data pertinent to the negotiations.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The text of President Hoover's statement on governmental economy, issued today, read:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wonder if Congress realizes that as soon as the so-called soldiers' bonus is paid in full the American Legion is automatically released from its promise not to press for general pension legislation? Such a promise was made by the officials of the Legion before the bonus bill was enacted.

The weakness in railroad bonds in the last few days spread yesterday to public utility and industrial bonds on the Stock Exchange. Foreign loans were irregularly lower in quiet trading, while United States Government obligations held firm. Although several railroad issues touched new lows for the year, the list of these was not so great as on Monday.
LONDON, April 5 (AP). -- A daughter was born tonight to Gloria Swanson, American moving picture actress.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 5. -- The American team gained the lead today in the series between Long Island Sound inter-club class craft and the Bermuda one-design yachts for the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club Trophy by taking the first four places in the opening race, with Drake Sparkman's Poppy, sailed by Briggs Cunningham, with Mrs. Cunningham in the crew, first across the line.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., April 5. -- While Governor Harry G. Leslie threatened to call out State troops to quell mine disorders in Sullivan County and in any other fields where trouble occurs, the Indiana Coal Operators' Association issued an official ultimatum to the striking miners tonight.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- The financial future of the Middle West Utilities Company, an Insull holding concern, rested in the balance today as bankers and officials met to discuss plans for a reorganization.

The Port of New York Authority lent its support to the proposal to create foreign trade zones in New York and urged that Congress enact legislation to authorize them in a bulletin issued yesterday. The zones would provide space for the landing of foreign merchandise for storage, cleaning, repacking and other treatment preparatory to re-export or transshipment to foreign countries.

Lending rates quoted in the stock loan market of the New York Stock Exchange declined again yesterday, as the stringency caused by the new restrictions on loans of stock to the short interest was relieved by new ending offers. The easier trend was shown in the fact that only thirtyone issues were quoted at premiums, against forty-two on Monday.

Successfully meeting a last-period charge which was electrifying in its dash and viciousness, the Toronto Maple Leafs gained the edge on the New York Rangers by defeating the blue-jerseyed skaters in the opening game of the Stanley Cup series at Madison Square Garden last night, 6 to 4.

The trial of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, on a charge of neglect of duty for failing to close the Bank of United States sooner than he did moved forward sluggishly yesterday, the entire day being devoted to the selection of five additional jurors, bringing the total number picked in two days to ten.
Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt won a victory over former Governor Alfred E. Smith in the only contest of general interest in the New York State primary election yesterday.

Operations of the Timken Roller Bearing Company in 1931 resulted in a net profit of $2,571,241 after depreciation, idle plant expenses, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equivalent to $1.06 a share on the 2,411,638 capital shares. It compares with a net profit of $7,524,122, equivalent to $3.12 a share on 2,411,842 shares, in the preceding year.

ALBANY, April 5. -- Governor Roosevelt today put an end to the long controversy over the so-called fourth-offender life-penalty law when he signed a bill introduced by Assemblyman Robinson providing a minimum penalty of fifteen years' imprisonment for fourth offenders.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- President Hoover has received word that the American Legion "stands solidly behind him" on his fight against pending legislation for immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus.

PARIS, April 5. -- With the exception of rentes, which remained steady, the Bourse was dull today and most of the stock list showed looses. The international stocks especially were weak, notably Rio Tinto Copper. No reaction from Premier Tardicu's conversations in London was visible.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., April 5. -- Fifteen brace in the members' All-Age Stake of the annual field trial of the English Setter Club of America were run off today, out of a total of twenty-two brace and one bye dog in the more important of the two closed events on the week's program.

STOCKHOLM, April 5. -- "Gross misrepresentation" in the last published balance sheet of Kreuger Toll was charged tonight in an accountants' report issued by a committee which is investigating the late Ivar Kreuger's companies.

MACON, Ga., April 5. -- A seventhinning comedy of errors that gave the Hartford Senators four runs on one hit and all but took the game away from the Robins today was followed by an accident in the ninth inning, when Roy Humphries, 19-year-old rookie outfielder for Hartford, broke his leg sliding into second base.

LOS ANGELES, April 5 (AP). -- Fourteen world-wide sports-governing federations have agreed on a final program for the tenth Olympic Games, to be held in Los Angeles July 30 to Aug. 14. Their completed work represents two years of study.

BOSTON, April 5. -- The trustees of the Metropolitan Transit District have asked for tenders on Friday on an issue of $23,125,000 of securities, the proceeds from which will be used in retiring the $23,500,000 of 2 3/4 per cent notes due next week. The plan, while stipulating a minimum price of par for the loan, allows bidders an option of two set-ups.

BASLE, Switzerland, April 5. -- Following is the balance statement of the Bank for International Settlements, giving its condition as of March 31, 1932, as made public here today. Figures are in Swiss gold francs at par, 19.3 cents:

Dr. Joseph Colt Bloodgood, Professor of Surgical Pathology at Johns Hopkins University and president of the American Association of Cancer Research, was guest of honor last night at a dinner given in the New York Athletic Club by the editorial board of The American Journal of Cancer.

A decrease of 9,050 barrels in the daily average gross crude oil production of the United States in the week ended on Saturday is indicated by the estimates of the American Petroleum Institute issued yesterday. The daily production fell to 2,154,000 barrels from 2,163,050 barrels in the preceding week.
An Ancient but Dwindling Institution. Nine years ago the Abyssinian Government reinforced a long-standing ban on the slave trade by making the offense punishable by death.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation was the target for two attacks today, once when Senator Wheeler said in the Senate it had been of no value to the farmers and again when Senator Capper in a radio speech declared the nation had been "betrayed by powerful interests working through" the corporation.

Sir Thomas Beecham will be unable to conduct the last week of the present season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and Hans Lange will take his place in directing the concerts of Thursday evening, Friday afternoon, Saturday evening and Sunday afternoon, April 21-24, at Carnegie Hall, it was announced yesterday by the management.

BOWIE, Md., April 5. -- Three Kentucky Derby eligibles trailed William Ziegler Jr.'s Phantom Legion to the finish line in the Ona Munson Trophy, feature at Bowie today. The gelded son of Our General and Phantom Fairy just lasted to win by a nose from Regula Baddun, a sprinter which few expected to show the tenacity he exhibited today.

A very apparent increase in the effort to market obscene books manifested itself during the past year, according to the fifty-eighth annual report of the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice, issued yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The tax schedule on sales of stock as passed by the House of Representatives provides a high rate on sales or transfers amounting to one-quarter of 1 per cent of the sale price, but the schedule provides in addition a minimum tax-rate of 4 cents a share.

An indeterminate term of not more than three years in the penitentiary was imposed yesterday by Judge Corrigan in General Sessions on Louis Taubman, ex-convict and former police informer in vice cases, who was known to the underworld as "The Dove."

The compensation of George W. Hill as president of the American Tobacco Company was more than $1,000,000 for 1931, it is disclosed in papers filed by the company in the United States District Court in reply to a stockholders' suit brought by Richard Reid Rogers, who recently obtained a temporary injunction barring further bonus payments to officers of the company.

A dispute between heirs of the late Mrs. Frank W. Woolworth, widow of the five-and-ten-cent store capitalist, and the New York State Tax Commission over $30,000 in transfer taxes was won yesterday by the Tax Commission. The Appellate Division in Brooklyn reversed an order of Surrogate Howell of Nassau County which fixed the tax on the Woolworth estate at $2,175,684 instead of the $2,206,518 claimed by the State.

PARIS, April 5. -- Until tomorrow evening when Premier Andre Tardieu makes his first campaign speech at a dinner for 2,000 persons here no definite indications will be given as to what use he intends to make of his reception in London or of what influence that conversation will have on his policy.

Renewed declines in public utility stocks on the Curb Exchange yesterday resulted in many new low records for the depression in the group, with the volume of trading only moderate. Electric Bond and Share, American Gas and Electric, American Superpower, Associated Gas and Electric, Utilities Power and Light, Commonwealth Edison, Standard Power and Light, United Gas, United Light and Power and other common and preferred stocks ended the day with losses.

Army Day, the fifteenth anniversary of the entry of the United States into the World War, will be celebrated today by military, veteran, patriotic, civic and religious groups throughout the city. There will be no special observance other than a half holiday at the military posts in the metropolitan area as the parade commemorating the day was held on Fifth Avenue last Saturday.

An appeal for nation-wide aid in saving historic monuments in the United States from destruction was made yesterday by the American Institute of Architects. Robert D. Kohn, president of the institute, asserted in a statement that the immediate danger spot was Charleston, S.C., where priceless eighteenth-century landmarks were threatened.

On the program of "Angels Don't Kiss," which appeared at the Belmont last evening, you read that R.B. Lackey has written a "sophisticated comedy drama." On the the stage you see another Spring product of playwright's vertigo. What amazes you, if you are still a spectator of folly, is the inescapable fact that some one thinks this maudlin and humorless jumble is worth the trouble of rehearsing and producing.

Yale University's polo team, with a great last-half rush that netted fourteen goals, defeated Los Nanduces as the Class A division of the national polo championships opened at the Squadron A Armory last night, 20 to 7 1/2.

The report on conditions in Hawaii made by Assistant Attorney General RICHARDSON does not seem to have pleased the people of the islands. They are fairly well satisfied with their present form of government. Senator BINGHAM praises the report, and bills are being introduced to carry out its recommendations.

The Art-in-Trades Club, which William Sloane Coffin founded twenty-six years ago, gave a dinner last night in its clubhouse, 34 East Thirty-eighth Street, in celebration of his recent election to the presidency of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

The Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate, in executive session yesterday, reached a virtual agreement to approve recommendations submitted by Chairman John H. Delaney of the Board of Transportation, amending the pending bus franchise contracts for Queens to meet objections recently voiced by Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee and Controller Charles W. Berry.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 5. -- Seton Hall College opened its season with a victory over Vermont University today, 10 -- 4. Nippy Joyce, young southpaw, went the full distance, striking out ten, besides getting a triple and scoring two runs.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5. -- Sir Victor Sassoon, British banker, on his arrival here yesterday aboard the Dollar liner President Coolidge from Shanghai, disclosed that he was arrested and assessed $150 in Honolulu a week ago as a liquor smuggler.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 5. -- The unexpected defeat of Miss Bea Gottlieb of New York by Mrs. Ashby Taylor of Atlanta featured first-round match play in the Sedgefield Country Club's dogwood golf tournament today.

Thomas W. Lament, partner in J. P. Morgan Co., will sail tonight for Europe on the Cunarder Aquitania, accompanied by Mrs. Lamont. Others aboard will include the Earl of Ilchester, Baroness Bachofers von Eckt, Sir Geoffrey R.S. Byass, Charles Bancroft, Miss J. Bancroft, Mrs. August Belmont, Mr. and Mrs. John M. Cabot, Mrs. M. Pinchot, Mr. and Mrs. R.W. Milbank, Mrs. Elliot Wadsworth, Mrs. H.V. Ravenscroft, Mrs. C.E. Haines and Dr. C.F. White.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 6 (Wednesday). -- In the only contest for election to the Democratic and Republican State Committees in the five Assembly Districts of Westchester County, which occurred in the Second District, incomplete returns last midnight indicated that Mrs. Caroline O'Day of Rye had been redesignated as Democratic State Committeewoman.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5. -- Pennsylvania opened its fifty-seventh baseball season by losing to Villanova College on Franklin Field today, 4 to 3. This was also the opening game for the Villanovans and marked their first victory over the Red and Blue in more than a dozen years.

TOKYO, April 5. -- A curious secret chapter in the history of Japan's Manchuria policy has been disclosed for the first time by Fusanosuke Kuhara, who was Minister of Communications at the time of the events that he describes in the Tokyo magazine Bungei Shinju (Literature All Year Round).
