The women's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies raised a total of $635,615.75 in 1931 from women contributors, nearly $87,000 more than the total raised in 1930, and about $120,000 in excess of the sum contributed by women in 1929, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Sidney C. Borg.

BERLIN, April 5. -- The proscription of Adolf Hitler's "brown army," comprising half a million storm troops, within the next forty-eight hours is foreshadowed as a result of documents seized in police raids on National Socialist centres throughout Prussia March 17 and made public today by Carl Severing, the Socialist Prussian Minister of the Interior.

In humorous vein, former Governor Alfred E. Smith, made his maiden speech last night as a member of the Washington Square Association, at its annual dinner at the Hotel Brevoort, and kept his audience in merry mood with a series of anecdotes of the east side and the west side.
NEW YORK, Mr. and Mrs. William Adams Kissam gave a dinner last night at their home, 9 East Seventy-sixth Street, for Bishop and Mrs. Ernest M. Stires.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 5. -- A Decrease of nearly $7,000,000 in net earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company from 1930 was shown in the annual report for 1931, made today. Profits of the company and its wholly owned subsidiaries were reported at $13,408,785, against $20,353,788 in 1930.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S foreword to the report of the New York State Health Commission -- an unofficial body of fourteen appointed by him two years ago under the chairmanship of President LIVINGSTON FARRAND of Cornell -- speaks of the health of the people as the State's "paramount concern."

Who would have expected to find in the committee on arrangements of the Democratic National Committee a school for the making of subtle distinctions? In the order of excellence and power, who is greater, the temporary or the permanent chairman of the national convention? The former "keynotes."

LONDON, April 5. -- The good feeling with which the British Ministers had said good-bye to Premier Andre Tardieu last night upon his departure was dampened today by dispatches from Paris to the effect that the French were boasting that their Premier had completely won over Prime Minister MacDonald and got an agreement from him to advocate the French program for the fourpower Danubian conference which is to begin here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- President Hoover renewed today, in the face of Congressional criticism, his proposal for a joint legislative-executive board to work out government savings of more than $200,000,000 needed to supplement the billion-dollar tax bill in balancing the budget during the fiscal year 1933.

George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, has been asked to appear for private examination before the Hofstadter legislative committee, it was announced yesterday, and is scheduled to be questioned tomorrow by associate counsel.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, April 5. -- Unable to win a Walker Cup series in six attempts with its old guard, the Royal and Ancient Club of St. Andrews today named a youthful and little-known array to go to the United States this Summer in pursuit of the elusive international golfing trophy.

BOSTON, April 5. -- John Kilcullen Jr. of New York, a Yale University football player, outpointed Joe Uzdavinis of Northwestern University to gain the heavyweight title in the National A.A.A. junior championship finals tonight at the Arena.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I am trying to leave the United States to make a trip to my native land -- England.

Further weakness on the Stock Exchange yesterday was ascribed again to the prevailing pessimism and uncertainty. Among brokers and professional traders the impression is that the proposed increase in the Federal tax on stock sales is mainly responsible for the recent sustained decline.

LONDON, April 5. -- The stock markets again were strong today, stimulated by news of the biggest drop in British unemployment in many months. British Government funds were in keen demand and all the leading issues advanced.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The Lehigh Valley Railroad today applied for a loan of $1,500,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. It asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to use as collateral any part of $15,400,000 of the road's general consolidated 4 1/2 and 5 per cent mortgage bonds, maturing in 2003.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Secretary Stimson is going to Geneva to help promote the success of the general disarmament conference and will not engage in any debt discussions or negotiations, President Hoover announced today.

Mrs. Emma Denninger tied Mrs. Anne Henshaw for the singles title with a three-game total of 606 on the last day of the women's Greater New York championship bowling tournament on Thum's alleys yesterday. There will be roll-off for the first prize between Mrs. Denninger and Mrs. Henshaw tomorrow at 5:30 P.M.

TRENTON, N.J., April 5. -- Republican opposition to the program of Governor Moore and the Democratic Assembly for reorganization of the State Government on a Cabinet basis was brought to a crisis today with the suggestion that the program be postponed and that attention be turned to unemployment problems.

There are two sides to the picture of the Long Island State parks in 1932. One is bright. Reviewing the work of 1931, the commission headed by ROBERT MOSES is able to report steady progress in the extension and development of the parks and parkways which are the splendid product of its labors.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- No constitutional obstacle hinders legislation to bring the banks of the country into a national system under Federal supervision, according to Federal Reserve Board experts, who studied that point in connection with recommendations to be made to Congress.

Supporters of former Governor Smith for the Democratic nomination for President professed to see a distinct victory in the action of the committee of arrangements for the national convention in voting to "commend" Jouett Shouse, national executive chairman, for permanent chairman of the convention.

In most respects yesterday's markets repeated the trend of the day before. Stocks moved irregularly lower, with most of the day's losses small, but fairly numerous declines of 3 points or more. The market for railway bonds again declined; the movement being as usual indiscriminate.

JOLIET, Ill., April 5 (AP). -- Thirty-five years in prison and "tired of being shut up," Lyman Hall set fire to the chapel of the State penitentiary today and then gave the alarm because he saw no chance of escape.

Thirty-one persons have given $142 to the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, in response to an appeal for funds to buy insulin, pay rent and purchase food for a family of four described by Marucs C. Hankinson, president of the association, in a letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on March 24.
DAIREN, Manchuria, April 5. -- More than 3,000 irregulars opposing the Manchoukuo Government have been killed in battle at Nungan, which the Japanese and Manchoukuo forces have just recaptured.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A copy of "Word Study" has just reached me in which it is stated that I condemn the use of "intrigue" as a noun. There is a mistake somewhere; surely not mine. Of course, it is the use of "intrigue" as a verb that I object to.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 5. -- Dick Wilson of Southern Pines, N.C., former Georgetown University links star, and Chandler Harper of Virginia Beach, Va., 1930 champion of his home State, today tied for the medalist honors in the thirty-second annual North and South amateur golf championship.

BERLIN, April 5. -- The German Steel Works Association announced today a contract with the Russian Government for the delivery of 300,000 tons of rolling-mill products within three months after the specifications have been forwarded by the Russians.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- Traders who were looking for a straightaway advance in wheat on the Board of Trade were disappointed today. Crop reports were as sensational as yesterday, with forecasts that the abandoned acreage in Kansas would exceed normal, while in Nebraska the loss is expected to be the heaviest since 1917, according to official reports.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, after an interview with a student delegation yesterday afternoon, refused the demands of the delegation for the reinstatement of Reed Harris, expelled editor-in-chief of the Columbia Spectator.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 5. -- Only twenty-three American Legion posts out of 10,400 have "kicked over" on bonus legislation and all the other posts as posts "are standing squarely behind" the mandate of their national convention on such legislation, so far as the national headquarters is informed, Henry L. Stevens, National Commander, declared here today.

Trade associations have successfully met the severe test imposed upon the organized business movement by the major economic crisis of the last three years, according to a statement by Robert P. Lamont, Secretary of Commerce, which was read to members of the American Trade Association Executives at a dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The imminent curtailment of the work of the Home Relief Bureau in New York City places greater responsibility on the Block-Aiders to do their utmost to provide relief for as many families as possible, Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the Block Community Organization declared yesterday on learning of the danger that many of the home relief bureaus would be closed this month.
HELSINGFORS, April 5. -- Under gray clouds and a dismal snowfall, Finland became officially wet again today. Nearly thirteen years of prohibition became a melancholy memory.

The Federal grand jury in Brooklyn handed up yesterdey indictments naming four persons in irregularities in bail bonding. The bills charge the defendants with forging the names of Supreme Court Justices Mitchell May and Selah B. Strong and with substituting false defendants in bonds signed by Justices May and Strong and Justice James J. Mclnerney of the Court of Special Sessions.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway put its common stock on a $4 annual basis yesterday for the first time since 1905, the board declaring a dividend of $1 a share, compared with $1.50 declared in January.

If you have not yet visited the small exhibition of modern German water-colors at Marie Sterner's International Gallery, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street, "stand not upon the order of your going," but lose no time, for the pictures will be there only until the end of this week.

MEXICO CITY, April 5. -- The ancient Toltec pyramid of Cholulo in the State of Puebla, a tremendous structure of adobe brick and earth, is built over and around still older structures, a Mexican Government archaeologist has just discovered. Exploratory tunnels now being driven into it have already revealed stone stairways and walls of stone, with mural paintings inside them.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- Batting the rookie pitchers, Cain and Bowman, opportunely in the early innings, the Phillies defeated the Athletics at Shibe Park today, 5 to 3, and assumed a 2 to 1 lead in the city championship series.
NEWARK, N.J., April 6 -- A rally of two runs in the ninth inning enabled the Red Sox to tie the Newark Bears, 8-8, today, and then Boston went on to win the game in the eleventh, 10 to 8.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The elimination of the ten-day limit on the issuance of prescriptions for medicinal liquor was endorsed today by Dr. James M. Doran, Commissioner of Industrial Alcohol, and Amos W.W. Woodcock, Director of Prohibition could retain their regulatory power to control the use of medicinal liquor.

The New York United Hotels, Inc., operator of the Hotel Roosevelt, is "abundantly solvent," although, like other hotels, it has difficulty during the economic depression in making its current income meet its overhead charges, Frederick W. Rockwell, president of the company, declared yesterday in an affidavit filed in Supreme Court, asking dismissal of the suit for a receivership brought by Samuel M. Bomzon, a bondholder.

BOSTON, April 6 -- The New York Rangers and the Toronto Maple Leafs arrived early this evening for their second game of the Stanley Cup hockey series which is to be played at the Boston Garden tomorrow night.

TOKYO, April 6 (AP) -- The far-flung campaign of the Japanese Army in Manchuria to eradicate armed opposition to the new federated State Government of Manchoukuo continued active today on at least two fronts, according to dispatches to the Hengo (Japanese) news agency.

Laurette Taylor's engagement in the Barrie revivals at the Playhouse will not be resumed, William A. Brady, the producer, announced yesterday. He declared the run had "abruptly ended" when Miss Taylor's inability to appear resulted in the cancellation of Tuesday night's performance.

Adverse criticisms of the afterschool athletic centres in the public elementary and junior high schools are made in a report issued yesterday by the United Parents' Associations of Greater New York Schools. The report, covering a survey made of the centres, also recommends that 100 additional centres be established and that more attention be directed toward small children.

Under the hospitable and flexible primary system of Wisconsin and the long shadow of Lafollettism the Democrats are apt to be submerged. Thus, at the special Senatorial election in 1925 the Democratic candidate got less than 11,000 votes. In 1926 the Democratic candidate for Governor got 13 per cent of the total vote.

The resignation of Frederick Toppin as vice president of the Roosevelt International Mercantile Marine Company was announced yesterday. Mr. Toppin will retire after nearly fifty years in business and will return to his home in Northern England.

BUDAPEST, April 6 -- Although no trouble developed today during the newspaperless day resulting from the general strike of printers that was called after the government's suppression of the Socialist party's organ Nepszava, the situation is extremely critical.

BOWIE, Md., April 6 -- The On Watch mare. On Tap, which bears the colors of Al Jolson, made a successful return to the races when she led practically from start to finish of the Martha Washington Purse, feature today, to win easily.
MACON, Ga., April 6 -- The Robins played their final game with the Hartford farm club today and won, 10 to 4, in a contest limited to seven innings.

Fifteen dissenting members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers won a complete victory yesterday in their temporary injunction action against officers of the union when Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck signed an order restraining the officers from interfering with their rights as union members and ordering the officers to restore to the suing members their membership cards and to rescind fines of $300 each levied against them.

The only new consideration confronting markets yesterday was the formal admission that the books of the Kreuger companies had been kept in deceptive shape and had grossly misstated the condition of the enterprises. This had been pretty generally suspected from the circumstances which surrounded and followed the suicide of the chief promoter; probably the announcement caused no surprise.

LA PAZ, April 6 -- The Foreign Office issued a new communique declaring untrue reports emanating from Argentina that Bolivia was mobilizing military forces in the Chaco for an attack on Paraguay. The communique was telegraphed to all Bolivian Legations abroad.
These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area.

PARIS, April 6 -- Premier Andre Tardieu, in his opening speech of the French electoral campaign tonight, vigorously espoused the foreign policy of firmness and conciliation as developed by Aristide Briand, Raymond Poincare, Pierre Laval and himself.

LONDON, April 6 -- The four-power conference of Great Britain, France, Germany and Italy, summoned by Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald to consider what can be done to rescue the Danubian States from economic disaster, began its discussions in London this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Because of increased cracking, the percentage yield of gasoline in the United States rose in February to 46 per cent, the highest ever recorded, the Bureau of Mines said today in a survey covering petroleum and its products. As a result the daily average output of motor fuel rose from 1,082,000 barrels in January to 1,095,000 barrels in February.

Notices of a special meeting of stockholders of the Federal Water Service Corporation to be held on April 20 were mailed last night with proxies to all stockholders. The purpose is to elect a new board of directors, according to Christopher T. Chenery, president of the company, whose letter says in part:

Progress in meeting the competition of motor trucks and prospects for repeal of the recapture of earnings clause in the transportation act are discussed by W.B. Storey, president of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, in his report for 1931. The report notes that, because of low traffic volume, the road has ordered no new equipment for this year.
SHANGHAI, Thursday, April 7 -- The news of Han Fu-chu's desertion and denunciation was like a bomb-shell to central government leaders in Shanghai this morning.

LONDON, April 6 -- Belief that the reduction in Atlantic passenger fares last week came a "year too late" and would involve the shipping companies in further losses was expressed today by Sir Percy Bates, chairman of the Cunard Line board of directors at a meeting of stockholders.

Owen D. Young, chairman of the General Electric Company, is making a close study of the conditions affecting the Middle West Utilities Company at the invitation of Samuel Insull, chairman of the holding company. Mr. Insull held consultations with Mr. Young in New York City on several days last week following the annual meeting of Middle West Utilities stockholders in Wilmington, Del., on March 29.

Even the House revenue bill was framed largely on the theory that the taxes it proposed would be temporary. Some of them, were distinctly labeled " good for only one year." They were designed mainly to cover the unprecedented deficit, and to help the country through the time of depression.

Columbia's Alma Mater sat last night gazing dreamily down the library steps. Around her were bits of paper, chunks of broken glass and pieces of what bad once been decorative black crepe. But the warriors had gone for the night, called away by the cool of evening.

A maximum fluctuation of 541,761 shares in the size of the short interest in March is disclosed in figures issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The compilation does not include the "in and out" short trading, details of which are customarily furnished later in the month.

PARIS, April 6 -- Affected by unfavorable reports from foreign martets, trading was light on the Bourse today. News from Wall Street was regarded sis discouraging, while the report of the committee in Stockholm on Kreuger Toll made an unsatisfactory impression.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Massie-Fortescue murder trial in Honolulu is certain again to "embroil the people of the Territory in most unpleasant consequences," Assistant Attorney General Seth W. Richardson said in his report on law enforcement in Hawaii, which was made public today by the Senate Insular Affairs Committee.

The mortgage for $65,000 held on the six-story tenement at 233-7 East Eighty-fourth Street by Mark W. Maclay and Frederick Johnson, as trustees, from the Kal-Mar Realty Corporation, Harry Markel, president, has been extended to April 4, 1937, at 6 per cent, $500 to be paid off semi-annually.

The name of Mary Pickford, now synonymous with stardom in motion pictures, may be known a few years hence as that of a sculptress as well is an actress. She is about to essay the difficulties of sculpture, not with my desire to rival the fame of professionals but to achieve this form of expression for her own pleasure.

Anti-depression " drives " and relief campaigns are in harmony with the traditional American way. In New York it is block-aid, among other things. The Rochester (N.Y.) " idea" is to have a community pledge itself to spend usefully a per capita amount for the purpose of stimulating trade.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., April 6 -- While war veterans were assisting the police in trying to restore order and in preventing raids on liquor stores by remnants of the mob that wrecked the Newfoundland Colonial Legislative Building and attacked Premier Sir Richard Squires last night, the Prime Minister returned to his office in the ruined building today, apparently determined to ignore the demands that he quit.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

HONOLULU, April 6 (AP) -- Racial cross-currents flowed through the jury box here today as opposing counsel sought to divert them to their own advantage in choosing a jury to try Mrs. Granville Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, her son-in-law, and two navy enlisted men, accused of the murder of Joseph Kahahawai.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- An international silver conference was termed probable within a year today by Representative Somers of New York chairman of the House Coinage Committee.

The market value of all shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $3,084,162,977 during March, to $24,501,826,280 as of April 1, which was the lowest point since the Exchange began to compile these figures on Jan. 1, 1925. On March 1, the market value was $27,585,989,257.

ERIE, Pa., April 6 -- Setting new tank records in three events, the Los Angeles A.C. defeated the Erie Y.M.C.A. swimmers tonight, 44 to 18. It marked the first defeat at home since the Erie team was organized in 1917.

BUENOS AIRES, April 6 -- Predicting that 1932 will witness the inauguration of Argentina's economic and financial independence. Dr. Alejandro Bunge, president of the Conversion Office, in an address to the National Academy of Economic Science, of which he is president, said that, confronted with evidence of its inability to cirry on public works and cover deficits with foreign loans, the nation is hastening to balance its budget and create internal credit.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 6 -- The Cascades Club was a popular rendezvous for the colonists today, with many parties on the terrace at tea time, concluding an interesting afternoon for those who followed the matches between the Washington and Lee University golf team and the William and Mary team.
LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- David Lloyd George was reported tonight to have decided on his virtual retirement from the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Navy League today urged construction of a navy to meet the provisions of the London treaty of 1930. It characterized as "dishonest" assertions that the country could not afford to spend $18,000,000 for new ships in the next fiscal year, in view of the fact that "about 90 per cent" of this would go to labor.

The British Commonwealth of Nations, as a substitute name for the British Empire, is usage still largely confined to scholars and orators, though it appears in official documents. Even the specialist does not rind that the new designation comes trippingly from the tongue.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP). -- Acting under orders from the Senate, expressed in a resolution sponsored by Senator McKellar of Tennessee, the Senate Appropriations Committee today reduced the total of the Interior Department measure from $57,000,000 to $45,000,000 and reported it out for action.

Weakness in outside markets caused a further decline yesterday in prices on the Cotton Exchange, and quotations worked back to the low levels of last week, ending 10 to 13 points lower than on Tuesday.

Although in past years the first invitation, golf tourney of the year has been staged at the Lido Country Club, Long Beach, L.I., the metropolitan district's season will be inaugurated next month with the Garden City Golf Club classic, one of the historic events on the schedule.

Only music students having the highest talent should be encouraged to enter music as a profession at this time, in the opinion of Ernest Hutcheson, dean of the Juilliard School of Music. His view concarred with that expressed last week Dy Josef Hofmann of the Curtis Institute, thus establishing the agreement of two of the leading music Echools of the East upon this matter.

Vincent Mummiani, 21 years old of 423 East 114th Street, whose conviction on a first-degree murder charge in General Sessions last year in the shooting of Dominick Buoncore in a Harlem restaurant was set aside recently by the Court of Appeals, took the witness stand yesterday at his second trial before Judge Freschi in General Sessions.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 -- Mrs., Helen Wills Moody announced tonight she would sail from New York April 27 for Europe to participate in three major tennis tournaments.

Pig iron production, as computed by The Iron Age, in March fell to the lowest point since August, 1921, the daily rate of 31,201 gross tons having been only a little above the minimum of the 1921 depression, which was 27,889 tons daily in July of that year.

Jack Sherry of Ohio threw Al Mercier of Montreal in the feature finish wrestling exhibition at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 3,000 saw Sherry toss his rival in 25 minutes and 38 seconds with an airplane spin and body slam. Sherry weighed 220 pounds and Mercier 215.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 6 -- Poison may have been the instrument which brought death yesterday to the Australian "wonder horse," Phar Lap, but if so it undoubtedly was an accident.
LONDON, April 6 -- The great un known desert of Southern Arabia has been crossed a second time -- this time by H.St. John Philby, the British explorer and Arabic scholar.
NEW YORK. Lady Lister-Kaye, who has been for the Winter at the Ambassador, will sail Saturday on the Empress of Britain.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., April 6 -- Pal's Pal, a white and orange setter dog, owned and handled by Eastman Jacobus of Montclair, today was declared the winner of the Bob White Trophy, presented by E. B. Chase of Radnor, Pa., the most coveted prize in the members' events of the annual field trials of the English Setter Club of America.
KENT, Conn., April 6 -- Another rowing season opened today on the Housatonio as a fine looking Kent School eight turned back the Harvard varsity 150-pounders.

PHAR LAP, so the story goes, means Lightning in some Javanese dialect. About six years ago Harry Telford was a stable foreman on the Australia turf. He was a trainer, too, when he could get horses to train. Like every other trainer, Harry dreamed of some day coming across a colt that would bring him fame and fortune, a great colt that would win famous victories and set records that would astonish the world.
To the Editor of The New York Times : In the recent death of Walter L. MacCorkle our community lost one of its most useful citizens.
Former Governor Smith paid a visit yesterday to the lower east side tenement district that was home to him in his youth and early political career.

Although it was slightly less than in the preceding year, the net income of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company in the year ended on Feb. 27 exceeded that of 1929. It was 529,792,975 after all charges, which was equivafent, after preferred dividends, to $13.40 a share on 2.086,748 common shares.

The departmental trial of James McKnight, suspended school inspector, charged with accepting bribes from furniture repair contractors, was interrupted yesterday by a witness who challenged the defense attorney to physical combat.

Paul D. Cravath was elected president of the newly organized Metropolitan Opera Association at an informal luncheon meeting on Tuesday, it became known last night. The other officers named are Edward Ziegler, secretary, and Frank Garlichs, treasurer.

OTTAWA, April 6 (AP) -- Projects Increasing revenue from taxation by $55,000,000 and decreasing appropriations by $25,400,000 were introduced in the Canadian Parliament today as the means of balancing a 1932-33 budget estimated at $369,900,000.

American government was described as having drifted from its foundations as an institution for the protection of "life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness" into a morass of paternalism, bureaucracy and promotion of special interests, with paralyzing taxation as the consequence, in a radio address last night by Clinton L. Bardo, president of the New York Shipbuilding Company and of the New Jersey Taxpayers' Association.

Because of the State law which makes an executor responsible for all debts incurred while carrying on a business under a will, John J. Pulleyn, the banker, who has been an executor of the estate of Michael Berardini, Italian banker, since 1925, was forced yesterday, as a result of financial reverses in the affairs of that estate, to file a petition in bankruptcy.

Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the New York Bicentennial Commission, was named defendant yesterday in a $200,000 action for libel filed with the Kings County Clerk by attorneys for Samuel Swett, treasurer and executive director of the National Washington Portal Committee, of 113 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.

MILWAUKEE, April 6 -- With their, dream of a solid La Follette delegation from Wisconsin shattered, the managers of the Progressive State machine groped tonight in the debris of Tuesday's Republican delegate election, striving to save a majority of the State's delegation of twentyseven.

Monuments in Charleston. South Carolina, like other States, feels the slackening of business. Perhaps she has felt a longer, steadier decline as fewer ships, with smaller cargoes, have steamed away from Charleston In the past few years.

Military comrades, civic and political associates, friends and admirers joined yesterday to honor Major William F. Deegan, Tenement House Commissioner, in a funeral service Which rarely, if ever, has been equaled in the city for its solemn splendor and color.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Speaker of the House and Mrs. John N. Garner were the honor guests tonight at a reception given by the Congressional Club. It was the third and last reception held this season by the club, which entertains annually in honor of the President, the Vice President and the Speaker.

Elmira, N.Y. Graham, Parsons Co. will offer today a new issue of $147,000 city of Elmira (N.Y.) 4.70 per cent street and funding bonds, due on April 1, 1933 to 1941. The offering prices will range from 4.40 to 4.65 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- A petition seeking an injunction against price-fixing and curtailment of production activities by fifteen makers of corn syrup, corn starch and corn sugar was filed today in Chicago, the Department of Justice announced tonight.

The campaign of the Forty-second Street Property Owners' Association against the burlesque shows on that street will be continued. It was announced yesterday by Edward W. Forest, secretary of the association, despite the dismissal of the last of the cases against the theatre owners and managers yesterday morning in West Side Court.

Sir Arthur Salter, who retired recently after eleven years as director of the Economic Section of the League of Nations, analyzes the economic and political processes that resulted in the depression and recommends first-aid measures for turning back the depression tide in "Recovery: The Second Effort," published today by Century.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- A final decree, enjoining twenty-one of the largest moving picture companies in the country from continuing in an alleged monopoly of the film industry, was signed this afternoon by Judge Charles E. Woodward of the Federal District Court.

Discontinuance of "all attempts" by representatives of the American Legion "to coerce Congress" and of the "Washington Lobby" was demanded in a telegram sent to Henry L. Stevens Jr., National Commander, by Willard Straight Post of New York.

ALBANY, April 6 (AP) -- Governor Roosevelt, stepping into the Owney Madden case tonight, announced that he "must respectfully disagree" with the action of Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy in freeing the ex-convict and alleged racketeer. The Executive warned that if the action of the justice were upheld by the higher courts it would mean the destruction of the State's Parole Board.

The $200,000 slander suit brought by Dr. Joseph C. Regan against his former superior, Health Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne, went to trial yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Byrne and a jury in Brooklyn, with a bitter exchange of charges by both physicians.

A plan is being considered for the redemption on June 1 of $20,727,750 of St. Louis Southwestern Railway first and consolidated 4 per cent bonds, partly with cash and partly with bonds bearing a higher rate of interest, William M. Greve, chairman of the executive committee, said yesterday.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of the American Tobacco Company, held yesterday in Jersey City, a latter was read from George W. Hill, president, which said that despite the decline in public consumption of cigarettes since the middle of last year, the company was continuing to increase its percentage of the total cigarette business and its sales of manufactured tobacco.

GENOA, Italy, April 6 -- Guglielmo Marconi has developed a completely successful ultra short-wave radio telephone, capable of both receiving and sending, according to witnesses who attended a test conducted by him today.

BERLIN, April 6 -- The National Socialist documents seized by the Prussian police in raids March 17 constituted the topic of the day today, the publication of part of the evidence yesterday eliciting a rather divergent response in the German press.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 6 (AP)) -- Roland L. Redmond, a lawyer, of New York City, was elected today a director of the Louisville Nashville Railroad to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Henry Walter of New York. The action was taken at the annual meeting of stockholders here.

A death rate for Manhattan out of proportion to its percentage of the city's population, as well as an excessively high tuberculosis toll was shown in the report of a three-year survey submitted, yesterday by Godias J. Drolet, statistician of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association at a special meeting of the committee of that organization and other health workers at 386 Fourth Avenue.

SYDNEY, N.S. W., April 6 (Canadian Press) -- The maximum penalty of a fine of u5 was imposed by Magistrate Laidlaw today on Major De Groot, formerly of the Royal Hussars, for maliciously damaging the ceremonial ribbon and threatening a police officer at the formal opening of the great Sydney Harbor bridge March 19.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 6 -- Army opened its baseball season today with, a one-sided victory over the Connecticut Aggies, 18 to 2. The cadets pounded three Aggie pitchers, unleashing a four-run attack at the outset and registering safe hits in every frame thereafter.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- An agreement for a Pacific Coast conference of ship lines engaged in carrying lumber and lumber products between Pacific Coast ports of the United States and British Columbia was approved by the Shipping Board today.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- A charge in the House that policies of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation were dictated by J.P. Morgan brought the reply today that the huge government money agency has improved conditions.

A total of fifty-seven thoroughbreds remain eligible for the Belmont Stakes, the most historic test for 3-year-olds run in this country, according to an announcement yesterday by Victor Schaumburg, racing secretary at Belmont Park, where the stake will be renewed on June 9.

Acting upon application of a committee representing bondholders whose bonds are secured by mortgages on the building, Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan has appointed Philip J. Curry of 116 Nassau Street receiver for the Roerich Museum, Inc., at 103d Street and Riverside Drive, it became known yesterday.

ALBANY, April 6 -- Governor Roosevelt has vetoed the Hewitt bill providing for a temporary additional contribution to the State retirement fund by employes, instead of the contribution the State has made for ten years additional to its regular 3 percent.

PEIPING, April 6 -- General Han Fu-chu, Governor of Shantung Province, today assumed an attitude of open rebellion toward the Nanking-Loyang Government, and his move is believed to be the signal for an immediate outbreak of civil war in cooperation with Generals Feng Yuhsiang and Yen Hsi-shan and Cantonese leaders.

Contributions of $115,379.09 were obtained in Manhattan during the first week of the Block-Aid campaign, it was announced last night by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the Block Community Organization, who said the result was extremely encouraging, especially in view of the fact that the organization work had not been completed at the time the collections were made.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- According to Robert W. Woolley, former member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, the pledge of the Roosevelt forces to support Senator A.W. Barkley of Kentucky for temporary chairman of the Democratic National Convention followed, and did not precede, the announcement by Mr. Barkley that he favored the nomination of Governor Roosevelt for the Presidency.

As a part of a program to revitalize the rubber industry in the United States and to cure the ills arising from the depression, plans are being discussed to concentrate coordinating power in the hands of one man. This industry, one of the most important in the country, has encountered unusual difficulties in the last two years.

In slightly over two months' time Billy Burke, professional at the Round Hill club in Connecticut, will be called upon to defend the national open golf championship he won at Inverness last Summer following his seventy-two-hole play-off with George von Elm, "business-man" golfer.

Possibility of a fight on the selection of Jouett Shouse as permanent chairman of the Democratic National Convention loomed yesterday as the forces supporting Governor Roosevelt hailed his victory over former Governor Smith in the Wisconsin primary elections and his indication of strength in the New York State primary as reflected in his victory In Buffalo.
BAGDAD, Iraq, April 6 (AP) -- Kurdish snipers shot and wounded Brig. Gen. Henry Rowan-Robinson, the Inspector General of the Iraq Army, today.

William F. Kenny, wealthy contractor, friend of former Governor Alfred E. Smith, and owner of the "Tiger Room" celebrated in the annals of Tammany Hall, became a witness before the Hofstadter Legislative inquiry yesterday. He was questioned in private for an hour and a half by Samuel Seabury, the committee's counsel.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 6 -- Behind the brilliant pitching of Johnny Broaca, Yale opened the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League season auspiciously today by turning back Columbia, 10 to 4.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 6 -- Robert Kohler, who was convicted recently of manslaughter in connection with the deaths of Patrolmen Milton Verity and Alvin Borgwardt in an automobile accident, will have a new trial on April 18 as the result of the discovery of an eyewitness to the accident, District Attorney Edwards announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- From 1917 until the end of the present fiscal year the government will have spent about $23,517,000,000 more than it collected from taxes and other ordinary sources of revenue. The figure includes the deficit of $2,500,000,000 anticipated on June 30.

TRENTON, N.J., April 6 -- An investigation of labor conditions in textile mills at Paterson, was requested today by Senate President A. Crozer Reeves of Mercer County, following the presentation of a petition to the Legislature yesterday by a delegation of mill workers.

LONDON, April 6 -- British bankers and others interested in the Kreuger companies took swift action today as a result of the accountants' report published in Stockholm. A meeting was hurriedly convened by Higginson Co., N.M. Rothschild Sons and the Hambros Bank and attended by representatives of the Stock Exchange and insurance and trust companies.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 6 (AP) -- President Hoover was praised tonight by Senator Hiram Bingham, keynote speaker at the Republican State Convention, as the first Chief Executive to try to restore normal economic conditions in times of stress.

LONDON, April 6 (Canadian Press) -- A run of remarkable successes in new first-class loan issues on the London money market was broken today by the result of New Zealand's issue of u5.000,000 in 5 per cent bonds issued at 98 1/2. The underwriters will take back about half of the amount. Four-fifths of the new loan was earmarked for funding treasury bills.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- President Hoover was invited by the House Economy Committee today to send to it his specific recommendations for department economies, or to send a representative to present his ideas.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- A resolution designed to "put teeth" in Secretary Stimson's doctrine of non-recognition of treaties which are in violation of the Kellogg pact was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Capper.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 6 -- Sixty hours of continuous traveling across more than one-third of the continent proved too much for ever the hardened Giants, with the result that when they resumed hostilities in the fifth game with the Tigers today they felt they were still seeing a lot of scenery whirl by their eyes while a lot of base hits actually whistled by their ears to give Detroit a 5-to-1 victory.

John H. Curtis, who left Norfolk, Va., on Saturday for a secret rendezvous with an agent of the criminals who stole the infant son of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, returned home yesterday with word that the baby is safe and well.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 6 -- The defeat of Chandler Harper of Virginia Beach, Va., co-medalist, by Milton Pierpont Warner of Pine Orchard, Conn., member of the Yale golf team, by 2 and 1, was one of the features of the opening round of match play today in the North and South amateur golf tournament.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 6 (Canadian Press) -- The Australian High Court today decided by a majority judgment of 4 to 2 that the Commonwealth Government's new "financial agreement enforcement act" is valid legislation.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Senator Hayden, Democrat, of Arizona, today introduced an amendment to the revenue bill calling for a levy of 5 cents a pound on copper Imports. He announced that Senators Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, and Wheeler, Democrat, of Montana, joined him in submitting the measure.

President HOOVER, by way of superabundant political caution, states that Secretary STIMSON while in Europe will enter into no negotiations whatever about the war debts. However, as Mr. STIMSON is to meet the leading European statesmen, it is hardly possible that they will not at least mention the biggest financial question which they have to study.

Many dinner parties will be given in advance of the opening performance of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey's Circus tomorrow night at the Madison Square Garden which has been taken over for the benefit of the Emergency Fund of the Henry.

Delay in the placing of substantial automobile and railroad tonnage is again blamed, in the midweek steel reviews, for continuance of slack conditions in the steel industry. In spite of this tact, however, the prevailing attitude is one of hopefulness.

Headquarters for the newly established Bureau of Child Guidance of the Board of Education was officially opened yesterday at 228 East Fifty-seventh Street, marking the completion of organization work connected with the bureau, which was created upon the recommendation of Dr. George J. Ryan, President of the Board of Education.

James Bliss Gray, Yale graduate, formerly instructor at Yale-in-China and son of Professor John Henry Gray, prominent economist of the American University, Washington, committed suicide by shooting himself in the heart Tuesday night or early yesterday, the police reported last night.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 6 -- In a seven-inning game called because of darkness, Manhattan College of New York defeated the Lehigh nine today, 13 to 3. The visitors collected fourteen hits, two of which were home runs slammed out by Leonard and Elake, and a three-base blow collected by Hassett.
MANILA, April 6 -- Ironical treatment of Japan's reported offer to enter into a treaty to guarantee the independence of the Philippines was given today in The Manila Bulletin.

The attitude of various army chaplains toward peace, war and the national defense was revealed by speakers at the opening sessions yesterday of the seventh annual convention of the Chaplains' Association of the Army of the United States, at the Hotel Taft.

CLEVELAND, April 6 (AP) -- Three young high school musicians, all of them members of the National High School Orchestra, today were announced winners of the music discrimination contest sponsored by the National Broadcasting Company and the National Music Supervisors Conforcnce.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Samuel Insull, chairman of the board of directors of the Middle West Utilities Company, left Chicago today for New York. Meanwhile, La Salle Street awaited developments in the reorganization. So far as could be learned here, no definite plan has yet been presented to the bankers by Mr. Insull.

The final week of the Metropolitan Opera's twenty-four-week, season will begin next Monday evening with a performance of "Lakme," with Lily Pons, Gladys Swarthout and Messrs. Jagel, DeLuca and Rothier, and with Mr. Hasselmans conducting.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The capital, led by President Hoover, paid tribute today to Americans who took part in the World War as 30,000 men in uniform paraded on Pennsylvania Avenue to mark the fifteenth anniversary of this country's declaration of war on Germany.

Harry F. Sinclair was elected yesterday chairman of the executive committee of the newly formed Consolidated Oil Corporation. This company resulted from the merger of the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation, the Prairie Oil Gas Company and the Prairie Pipe Line Company.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Next Jan. 2 has been fixed for handing over complete control of the Nicaraguan National Guard to Nicaraguan command. A State Department announcement today indicated that after that date plans would be followed to withdraw all American forces from Nicaraguan soil.

TOKYO, April 6 -- The Japanese Foreign Office is sending instructions to Mamoru Shigemitsu, Minister to China, tonight for tomorrow's conference in Shanghai. It is stated, however, that these cannot alter materially the position adopted.

Pressure against domestic corporation bonds continued unabated on the Stock Exchange yesterday, and a sizable list of foreign loans, representing all shades of credit rating, lost considerable ground in moderately active dealings. United States Government bonds, however, stood out in contrast with the rest of the market, advancing 2-32 to 13-32 point for the day in brisk trading.

Except that Federal funds were again offered at 1/4, as on Tuesday, but without takers, there were no other developments of importance in the day's money market. Business was light, and quotations for Stock Exchange call loans, maturity money, commercial paper and acceptances remained unchanged.

George M. Prisco, 28 years old, who did not know until seven weeks ago he had been indicted last Summer with his father and a brother in the misappropriation of about $188,000 from the Prisco State Bank in Mulberry Street, founded by his father, died Tuesday night of tuberculosis at Saranac Lake, N.Y.

At the Newhouse Galleries, recently removed to handsome and spacious quarters at 578 Madison Avenue, one finds this week a group of contemporary Americans. It is a good show -- and doubly an "event," in view of the fact that with the Newhouse Galleries we have always associated old masters.

ALBANY, April 6 -- Governor Roosevelt will speak on national politics for ten minutes tomorrow night on a nation-wide radio hook-up over a Naional Broadcasting Company network. He will speak during the Lucky Strike program between 10 and 11 P.M.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is remarkable to see how methods which are used in everyday life are condemned in international affairs, methods which represent common sense and the true way of dealing among men.

Although the news that the commander of the American Legion was supporting President Hoover in his opposition to bonus legislation had a heartening effect on financial sentiment, the stock market again extended its decline yesterday. The losses were narrower than on the day before, but they were wide enough to carry the price averages into new low ground.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 6 -- The Rutgers baseball team defeated the University of Vermont, 5 to 4, in a thirteen-inning game today at Nellson Field. Gotthardt's sacrifice fly brought in Burke to give the Scarlet a hard-earned victory.

National Coffee Council, said in an interview today that out of 24,000,000 bags of coffee on hand at the time of the 1930 revolution, 4,000,000 bags had been destroyed. He asserted that the destruction would continue at the rate of 1,000,000 bags a month until the council had liquidated its accumulation of the lower grades.

C.F. Zittel, owner of Zit's Weekly and former lessee of the Central Park Casino, threatened yesterday to sue the city for recovery of $12,000 he paid in water rents during his occupancy, if the law department decides that Sidney Solomon, present lessee, need not pay a water bill of $4,304.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Modification of the House tax bill to cause less drain upon the working capital of the nation was advocated today by Secretary Mills of the Treasury in testimony before the Senate Finance Committee as it opened hearings on the measure.
Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES. WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Secretary Mills's statement on the revenue bill, made before the Senate Finance Committee today, read:
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Federal land banks announced today that the treasury had almost doubled the paid-in capital stock of the twelve Jand banks by subscribing $63,243,740 to their stock.

GENEVA, April 6 -- Norman H. Davis is the man the League of Nations financial committee had in mind when in its recent report it recommended that the Council at its special meeting on April 12 appoint some big man as a sort of envoy extraordinary of the League to all the Danubian States to help them stave off disaster by uniting on customs and other questions.

HONOLULU, April 6 -- Nothing expresses the polyglot community of Hawaii better than the groups now moving through the jury box preparatory to the trial of Mrs. Granville Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, her son-in-law, and two navy enlisted men for the murder of Joseph Kahahawai.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 6 -- A theory that may link the language of the ancient Mayan Indians of Central America with the tongues of Asia has just been developed here by Dr. Herman Walde-Waldegg of the Colombian National Library after long and arduous study.

The program given by Sir Thomas Beecham and the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall began with the ballet suite, "The Gods Go A-Begging," a set of short pieces arranged by Sir Thomas from little-known music by Handel.

Justice Mitchell May, in order to simplify the problems of a jury that for two and a half days had been listening to a complicated brokerage commission action in Part I of the Supreme Court, Queens, yesterday afternoon dictated, with the consent of attorneys, a series of questions to be answered "yes" or "no" before reaching the final question, the amount to which the plantiff was entitled.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S approval of the Robinson bill will help to substitute common sense and orderly process for the somewhat hysterical ruthlessness of the Baumes law making life imprisonment mandatory in all fourth-offense felonies, regardless of their nature.

Charles Stern of 611 West 180th Street, the Bronx, one of seven defendants charged with counterfeiting, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Federal court in Brooklyn to printing 8,000 false $5 notes and preparing paper to be made into 200,000 more.

The three-day convention of the New York Federation of Music Clubs will begin today at noon at the Hotel Victoria with a discussion of practical methods for meeting presentflay problems faced by music teachers, young artists and communities.

The contract for operation of the Eighth Avenue subway, now being advertised by the Board of Transportation, "is totally inadequate and not calculated as a practical matter to arouse interest on the part of prospective bidders," it was charged yesterday by R.E. McGahen, secretary of the Citizens Union.

Controller Charles W. Berry issued a statement yesterday asserting that the modifications made by the Board of Estimate in the contracts for bus operation in Queens "are still unsatisfactory and fail to entirely correct some of the conditions complained of."

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Federal Farm Board was under fire in the House again today, with assertions that high-salaried grain and cotton officials are "racketeers," and with demands by three members for abolition of the board.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 6 -- Cured of a bad case of colic by a pint of whisky, Zoobu, 350-pound infant elephant in the animal incubators at the steel pier here, fell and broke his leg today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 6 -- Though the Yankees hit three home runs today, and overcame a six-run lead held by the local American Association club, in the end they had to capitulate to the slugging of Manager Emmett McCann's hustling Indians, losing, 12 to 11, on Jonah Goldman's single with the bases filled in the ninth.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Improvement of the Hudson River to provide a channel forty feet deep at mean low water for the full width of the river from Fifty-ninth Street, New York, to Upper New York Bay, was recommended to Congress today by Secretary Hurley upon the advice of Major Gen. Lytle Brown, Chief of Army Engineers.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 6 -- Matching the strides of Columbia in a climb up from the baseball depths, Princeton now finds itself in a position to make a real fight for the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

Members of the faculty of Long Island University announced yesterday that the faculty, as a whole, would demand the resignation of Dean George R. Hardie today unless he characterized the drastic reductions in salaries as "forced" instead of "voluntary."

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- To most Democratic leaders here the victories of Governor Roosevelt in the primaries in Wisconsin and Erie County, N.Y, yesterday merely strengthened the conclusion they reached after his successes in Maine and North Dakota that his nomination for President in a certainty.

Detectives and police reserves had to be called yesterday to clear the corridors around Judge Corrigan's part of General Sessions of about 300 men and women who had appeared as volunteer witnesses for the grandlarceny trial of Nicholas C. Partos, head of a bankrupt drug store chain and several realty corporations, and Ellia A. Laskey, his accountant.

A series of clashes between Max D. Steuer, special prosecutor, and Martin Conboy, defense counsel, featured yesterday's session of the trial of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, who is charged with neglect of duty for not closing the Bank of United States sooner than he did.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Representative Simmons of Nebraska said today that President Hoover had agreed to request Secretary Hyde to look into the sugar beet situation in Montana, Wyoming, Nebraska and Colorado, where a higher contract from the Great Western Sugar Company is sought by farmers.
PARIS, April 6 -- The French Academy finally today fulfilled one of the objects for which it was created in 1634 when it published a grammar as a companion piece to the famous Academy dictionary.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Southeastern Kentucky is trying to meet the problem of caring for its stricken people and resents the implication that its inhabitants are viewing with complacency their suffering and want. The attitude of Theodore Dreiser, Waldo Frank and others has been to assume that the State is apathetic about the matter, and this explains the general resentment of their actions and those of other writers and so-called liberals.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 7 (AP) -- The Rhode Island Reds, leaders in the Canadian-American League when the regular season was ended, tonight won the 1932 championship when a thrown stick 15 seconds before the game ended gave them a 3-to-2 victory in the final game of the series with the Boston Cubs.

BANBURY, England, April 7 (AP) -- William Henry John North, eleventh Baron in the family line, which was created in 1554, succeeded to the title at the death of his mother, Baroness North, in 1884. He was born on Oct. 5, 1836.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 7 -- The Temple varsity baseball team pounded five Princeton pitchers for sixteen hits, easily defeating the Tigers on University Field today, 19 to 3. Len Gudd went the route for Temple, allowing ten scattered hits.

Yesterday's markets seemingly indicated slackening of pace in the decline which has prevailed this week, but there was no distinct recovery. In the stock market an early irregular decline was turned into recovery before the close, which left net losses for the day generally insignificant, with some advances.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 -- An arsenic spraying solution used to rid fruit orchards of pests was eliminated today as a possible cause for the untimely death of Phar Lap, Australian "wonder horse," on Tuesday. Oak trees only were found by Department of Agriculture experts on the Ed Perry ranch where the great gelding died, and oak trees here are not subject to pests requiring a poisonous spraying.

With reports from 1,625 blocktreasurers still to be heard from, the partial report of the Block-Aiders' efforts in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx showed contributions of $133,524,89 for the first week, it was announced yesterday by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the Block Community Organization.

TOKYO, Friday, April 8 -- Count Yasuya Uchida, president of the South Manchuria Railway, has telegraphed his resignation from Manchuria because of the dismissal of an associate, and the incident seems likely to cause a storm that may cause the government to fall.

Yale and West Point reached the final round of the intercollegiate branch of the national indoor polo championships at Squadron A Armory last night. West Point stopped Harvard, 11 to 4, and Yale, with a great display of polo, overhauled a hard-playing Pennsylvania Military College team, which had taken seven goals on handicap, and won, 15 to 9.

SHANGHAI, Friday, April 8 (AP) -- While the Sino-Japanese peace negotiations simmered in deadlock today, there appeared two threats of civil war against the Nanking Government -- one from the Communists in the West, and the other from a group of war lords in the North.

VLADIVOSTOK, April 7 (AP) -- Valuable paintings, porcelains, sculpture and books sent here for exhibition in an art museum projected by the Far Eastern Province are lying in the street, exposed to snow and wind, because the museum has not yet been built and there is no place in which to store them.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- All work on the electrification of the Pennsylvania Railroad between New York and Washington will be halted unless the railroad obtains a loan of $55,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, S.J. County, vice president of the Pennsylvania, stated in a letter to Eugene Meyer, chairman of the corporation board, made public today.

A lack of uniformity in the methods of admitting students to American colleges was held to be one of the weaknesses of the present educational system by Dr. Carl A. Jessen in a report yesterday afternoon before the annual Interstate Conference for the Discussion of Common Problems of Teacher Education, held at Teachers College.

A handsome gold loving cup, presented to the late Sir Thomas Lipton in 1899 by American friends of the famous yachtsmen following his first unsuccessful attempt to lift the America's Cup, became the property of the New York Yacht Club yesterday.

The annual pastoral letter of Cardinal Hayes will be read at all masses Sunday in the churches of the 369 parishes in the Archdiocese of New York. It precedes by a week the annual appeal of the Catholic Charities, which will be made this year from April 17, when the actual collection will begin, to April 25.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 -- The Talbot act, passed by the anti-Pinchot forces at the special session of the Legislature, appropriating $10,000,000 for direct relief of Pennsylvania's unemployed, was declared constitutional by a 4-to-3 vote of the State Supreme Court today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President and Mrs. Hoover entertained at dinner tonight for Admiral and Mrs. William S. Sims of Boston and Newport, who are guests at the White House for a few days, inviting to meet them a company headed by the Secretary of the Navy and Mrs. Adams.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 7 (AP) -- A bill to increase the borrowing power of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, but which limits all secured obligations to one-Half of the company's capital investment, was submitted today by the railway committee of the House of Commons.

Continued softness in Federal funds, which were taken in moderate amount at 1/8, lowest ever recorded and unmatched since the period of easy money last Summer, wag the single feature of the day in money. The call loan rate on the Stock Exchange remained at 2 1/2, and Street money traded at 2.

BOSTON, April 7 -- Dr. Elisha Shephard Boland, a physician who had practiced for almost forty-six years in South Boston, died yesterday at his home in Dorchester, after an illness of two years. He was born at Fort Hope, Ont., and was in his eightieth year.

TRENTON, N.J., April 7 -- The legislative committee of the State League of Municipalities criticized today a statement made last week by the bankers' committee appointed by Governor Moore to lay plans for financial relief to municipalities. The statement contained "some indisputable generalizations," said the league committee, but "not very much help of a constructive nature," temporary or permanent.

The issues brought up in the suits by the County Trust Company against Patrick F. Kenny, Yonkers contractor, and Timothy J. Mara, sports promoter, to collect $70,000 from them on promissory notes, will have to be decided at a trial, Supreme Court Justice Irwin Untermyer ruled yesterday in denying motions by the bank for summary judgment against the two men without trial.

The James Monroe High School baseball team opened its season by defeating Stuyvesant High, 5 to 2, yesterday at James Monroe Field. The winners scored four runs in the third inning to clinch the victory.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I saw in THE NEW YORK TIMES Richard Aldrich's cheering account of the Damrosch-Schelling long-continued children's concerts. Fine! Out here, with a high-class symptony orchestra and surprising music in the schools, people have not forgotten the pioneer work in New York by Dr. Henry Fleck of Hunter College.

HERTFORD, Conn., April 7 -- Connecticut's nineteen Republican delegates were chosen in a brief routine session of the party's State convention today, after which the new State committee re-elected J. Henry Rora-back State Chairman. Following its custom, the convention gave no instructions to the delegation.

Members of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York gave a dinner dance last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. Spring flowers in pink and white, the colors of the society, were used as table decorations. After dinner younger members of the society enacted a scene recalling the life of the Pilgrims.
ST. JOHN'S, N.Y., April 7 (AP) -- Sir John Middleton, Governor of Newfoundland declared today a Royal Commission would be appointed to inauire into "certain occurrences at the Colonial Building."

Jobbers' Dry Goods Orders Gain. Orders placed by wholesalers in the local dry goods markets during the week showed a slight improvement over last week, according to reports in jobbing circles yesterday. Most of the purchases were confined to fill-in goods, no expansion of Spring comitments on a large scale having developed yet.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 7 -- Bermuda yachtsmen, triumphed today, after losing two consecutive team races to Long Island Sound skippers, in the third contest of the series for the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club Trophy. The margin of the Bermudians' triumph was 20 1/4 to 16, the victorious team taking first, third, fourth and eighth places.

PARIS, April 7 -- Attacks on the American dollar, which have been occurring sporadically in recent months, reached a climax today in the publication in the Parisian newspaper L'Ordre of a false report that the National City Bank of New York had suspended payments.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A poem by Theodore Roosevelt, Governor General of the Philippines, appears in the current issue of The Carillon, a quarterly magazine of poetry.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Peter Goelet, son of Robert Goelet, New York banker, today applied to the Federal Radio Commission for a construction permit for a new broadcasting station to be erected at the Goelet estate at Chester, Orange County, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended April 6, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,600,000,000, an increase of $1,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $598,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure. The following tables show for various items the highest and lowest points reached thus far in 1932 and in a series of years past.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company yesterday bought from the city twelve unimproved blocks of property in the vicinity of Newtown Creek for $251,012.50 as part of an expansion plan started in 1928. The city received an option to rebuy the land at the same price within five years after the first thirty years have elapsed.
Louis Wiley, business manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was the guest of honor last night at the annual dinner of the Steuben County Society of New York at the Hotel Commodore.

BERLIN, April 7 (AP) -- The Zwoelfuhr Blatt today quotes Bo Ekelund, secretary of the International Amateur Federation, as saying that if the Finnish Association "doesn't care to handle the Paavo Nurmi matter we (I.A.A.F.) have an opportunity of handling it again."

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 7 -- The Cabinet resigned today after a run had started on the Central Bank of Chile that alarmed the capital, and tonight Congress was expecting from President Juan Esteban Montero a proclamation of a state of siege (martial law) and a request for special powers to deal with the situation.

Boxing and wrestling appear to be rather popular just now in the galleries of New York. The outstanding demonstration in this line is the exhibition at Knoedler's, which is devoted altogether to boxing. But one picks up threads elsewhere too, all of them leading straight to bouts and rounds and referees.

The circus tonight puts on its motley and tinsel and opens the new season at Madison Square Garden. There will be no formalities. No celebrity will blow the first whistle, a trick that was adopted from baseball for a time, but abandoned, and the whole thing will spin into the usual performance without fanfare.

The Editor of The New York Times: One of your Topics of the Times this morning deplored the reluctance of Bailout and Baldwin to own to reading the newspapers. It would seem that our American Congressmen too are ashamed to read public opinion as expressed in the press.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 7 -- The Rogers Memorial Library of Southampton, receives the undivided onehalf interest of Edward H. Foster of that village in a parcel of land at Foster's Island, near here, in the will filed for probate today of Mr. Foster, who died March 19.

Dr. Joseph C. Regan admitted on the witness stand in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday several of the charges made by Health Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne concerning Dr. Regan's management of the Kingston Avenue Hospital for Contagious Diseases in Brooklyn before his removal in 1927.

There was little visible change yesterday in Wall Street's attitude toward the stock market. Trading on the Stock Exchange involved about 1,800,000 shares. Many representative issues went into new low ground, but rallied later. Final quotations were only a trifle lower, on the average, than at the close of the day before.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Secretary Stimson conferred with Senator Borah, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, at the State Department this noon about the Secretary's visit to Geneva and outlined its purposes with special reference to the prospects for achievements by the General Disarmanent Conference.

Encouraged by the election of twenty-five out of twenty-six Roosevelt delegates at the Wisconsin primary, five more than had been counted upon, the managers of Governor Roosevelt's compaign for the Democratic nomination for President prepared yesterday to put him further in the lead by obtaining the eighty delegates from, Nebraska, Kentucky and Michigan, which will be elected next week.
Arbitration in the Movies. Machinery for setling disputes between employer and employe in the movies is the subject of a proud report submitted by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

BOWIE, Md., April 7 (AP) -- Mate, chief rival of Twenty Grand for the 3-year-old turf championship last year, will start his 4-year-old campaign for stake honors in the $15,000 added Dixie Handicap at Pimlico on May 7.

BOSTON, April 7 (AP) -- A gale that blew so hard whales were flung against the ship made most of the animal cargo of the Hagen seasick during a voyage that ended here today. Captain Paul Winhorse docked the Hamburg-American steamer, three and a half days late, after a stormy passage from Germany.

Governor PINCHOT'S candidate for Senator from Pennsylvania, General SMEDLEY D. BUTLER, not content with cannonading the Wets, has turned his angry guns upon the Senate. Remembering his vocal sanitation of Philadelphia, he promises to repeat his triumphs in "another place."

Lowest quotations in several months were registered on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, when steady selling pressure caused a 10-point decline, which carried October to 6.35 cents a pound, the lowest price reached since trading in the 1932 crop started last Fall.

Willard Straight Post of the American Legion may face disciplinary action for sending a telegram to Henry L. Stevens Jr., national commander, calling for a cessation of attempts by Legion representative "to coerce Congress," Maurice Stember, adjutant of the New York State organization, said yesterday.

Controller Charles W. Berry, who has been at odds with Mayor Walker over the city's financial policies for some time, yesterday cast his lot definitely with the realty interests and civic associations who have been demanding drastic city economies and a moratorium on the Delaney short-term bond policy for the financing of subway construction work.

Two wild pitches by Hal Pivnick, relief pitcher, which enabled Ed Gainen, pinch runner, to score from second base in the ninth inning, gave City College an 8-to-7 victory over the Brooklyn College nine yesterday at the Lewisohn Stadium.

Resolutions pledging support to this country's system of national defense and assailing attacks on it by secular or religious groups were adopted at the closing session yesterday morning of the seventh annual convention of the Chaplains' Association of the Army of the United States at the Hotal Taft.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 7 -- James McHutchison of New York was elected president today of the Society of American Florists and Ornamental Horticulturists at the final session of the annual convention.

ALBANY, April 7 -- While Republicans were preparing to start next week on their investigation of the State's administrative departments, with a view to effecting economies in years to come, Governor Roosevelt today called his department heads together at a "cabinet meeting," which resolved itself into a discussion of ways and means of bringing about savings in the next fiscal year.

The bulk of realty trading in Manhattan yesterday again was confined largely to leases of housing properties. Details of other long-term contracts were shown in papers recorded at the Register's Office. Two of the recorded contracts concerned hotels on the west side.

The first four volumes of "Narratives of the Trans-Mississippi Frontier" have been published and four more are announced for publication next Fall. The series, composed of reprints of first hand accounts of the epic of the opening of America west of the Mississippi, is being brought out by the Princeton University Press and will contain twenty-five or thirty volumes.

The United Gas Improvement Company, the Philadelphia Electric Company and the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey have rejoined the National Electric Light Association, it was announced yesterday by Bernard W. Weadock, new executive director of the organization.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 7 -- Samuel Dewey Byrd, the outstanding star developed by the Yankees' Spring training trip, hit his third homer in three successive games today but the rest of the team failed to generate any offensive at all, so the exhibition tour closed with a 5-to-4 defeat at the hands of the Columbus American Association club.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 7 (AP) -- Reversing the stand it took in 1928, Wisconsin apparently will send a delegation controlled by the Conservatives of the party to the Republican National Convention. Four years ago the La Follette Progressive faction dominated.

LONDON, April 7 -- Many of the belongings of Princess Mary, the daughter of King George, went begging today when they were offered for auction at Chesterfield House, the former London home of the Princess and her husband, the Earl of Harewood.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 7 -- Captain Frank M. Hawks, the speed flier, is in the City Hospital here painfully injured as a result of a crash at the Worcester Airport today when, unable to lift his plane from a soggy field, he ripped through a hedge, struck a large stone and overturned.

PITTSBURGH, April 7 (AP) -- Net income of $4,885,124 after interest, depreciation, depletion and taxes is reported for 1931 by Lone Star Gas Corporation and subsidiaries. This is equal after dividends on the preferred stocks of subsidiaries and parent company to 75 cents a share on the 5,451,043 shares of common stock outstanding at the end of the year.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Outside interest in the wheat market has failed to broaden to the extent expected by the trade despite the sensational crop reports regarding Winter-sown grain. Prices on the Board of Trade here today held within a range of 1 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel, fluctuating erratically.

George R. Hardie was still dean of Long Island University last night. His dispute with the faculty remained unsettled, but that body had not made good its threat to demand his resignation unless he characterized the recent salary cuts as "forced" Instead of "voluntary."

An application for a receiver to take over the assets of the National Bellas Hess Company, Inc., which is ranked as the third largest mail-order house in the country, was made to Justice Dodd of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday by a group of preferred stockholders.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien denied yesterday the application of Arthur Garfield Hays, attorney for Rosa Dew Stansbury and other contestants of the will of Miss Ella V. von E. Wendel, aged spinster, who bequeathed most of her fortune estimated at more than $60,000,000 to divinity schools and other institutions, to remove the temporary administrators of the estate on the ground that the testator, according to her will.

P.V.G. Mitchell, vice president of the Roosevelt International Mercantile Marine Company, defended the recent action of the United States Lines in reducing its transatlantic passenger rates by 20 per cent, or more and forcing all of the lines operating in the North Atlantic to follow suit, in a statement issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson of Chicago denied that he disregarded an agreement with prosecuting officials when he permitted Alphonse Capone to withdraw a plea of guilty last Summer, in a letter received today by Senator Borah.

The report of the Federal Reserve System as of Wednesday, published yesterday, revealed continued purchases of United States Government securities, but a check, due to the influence of first-of-the-month demands, to the decline in memberbank borrowings and in money in circulation.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The value for rate-making purposes of the carriers embraced in the Southern Railway System, as of dates ranging from June 30, 1916, to 1918, was placed by the Interstate Commerce Commission today at $475,188,476, including $6,608,064 for working capital.

Further upward revision of crude oil and gasoline prices in Louisiana and Arkansas to conform to recent advances in other areas was announced yesterday. The Magnolia Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New York, advanced crude oil 15 cents a barrel.

HONOLULU, April 7 -- The hearing of the evidence in the trial of Mrs. Granville Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and two navy enlisted men for the killing of Joseph Kahahawai, a native, will begin on Monday morning. The jury that will hear the case was completed unexpectedly just before noon today and an adjournment was taken until next week.

Prizes amounting to more than $1,000 were awarded yesterday in the sixteenth annual textile design competition of the Art Alliance of America, 65 East Fifty-sixth Street. This year's competition, which was extended to include wallpaper, decorative paper, playing cards, linoleum, rug, carpet and oilcloth designs, brought forth the largest number of entries ever received.

FREDERICTON, N.B., April 7 (Canadian Press) -- A unique auction of international interest to anglers was held in the Assembly Chamber of the New Brunswick Parliamentary Building today, when thirty-five stretches of trout and salmon waters were leased to the highest bidders for ten-year periods.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Retroastive repeal of the recapture clause of the transportation act of 1920 was voted by the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today, and if Congress acts favorably on the recommendation $361,465,815 of excess profits earned by the railroads since 1920 will be saved by them.
