BOWIE, Md., April 7 -- B'ar Hunter, 4-year-old son of Black Servant and Bit of White, owned by E.R. Bradley, captured the feature Mayor H. W. Jackson Purse today at Bowie. Racing well within himself the entire mile and a sixteenth, B'ar Hunter won by four lengths from Wotan, which led Frumper by two lengths.

BERLIN, April 7 -- With only two lays of the Presidential campaign remaining, the organization backing President von Hindenburg and Adolf Hitler's machine -- as well as the Communists, who are sniping impartially at both -- are working under forced steam.

The movement inaugurated by the Metropolitan Golf Association a short time ago to tighten the amateur rules seems to be spreading like wildfire. A short time after President Stacey Bender of the M.G.A. announced the appointment of a "status and conduct" committee to ferret out violations of the amateur rule the Westchester County Golf Association followed suit.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Leaders of both parties in the Senate were using every influence today to head off attempts to turn the billion-dollar tax bill into a tariff measure.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A personal appeal for the passage of bonus legislation will be made by Brig. Gen. Smedley D. Butler, retired, before the Ways and Means Committee.

In a letter to the Board of Estimate, made public yesterday, the City Club urges the defeat of the bill introduced in the Municipal Assembly by Mayor Walker to authorize the city to mortgage the fee of land taken under excess condemnation for housing purposes.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor, gave the first of its final pair of New York concerts of the present season last night in Carnegie Hall. The event testified again to the surpassing tonal beauty and technical finish of this orchestra, and to Mr. Kousseyitzky's special and significant qualities as interpreter.

Four New York A.C. fencers, Leo Nunes, Pieter Mijer, Curtis C. Shears and Lieutenant Frederick C. Weber, were among the eight favorites who survived the qualifying rounds of the national epee championship tournament at the New York A.C. last night.

Mrs. Helen Far, 66 years old, of Bridgeport, Conn., appeared as the State's first witness yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Nicholas C. Partos. formerly head of twenty-two corporations, including a drug store chain, for the alleged theft of $612 from the woman and her husband in the sale of stock in one of his corporations in 1928 through misrepresentation.

Mrs. Eleanor Beauchamp, 22 years old, who was exonerated recently on a charge, of shooting her husband, George Beauchamp, an unemployed restaurant manager, was shot in the left side by him yesterday morning in a crowded subway kiosk at 104th Street and Broadway, following an attempt by him to effect a reconciliation.
NEWARK, N.J., April 7 -- Timely hitting by Johnnie Neun, Andy Cohen and Dixie Walker featured a 7-to-6 victory scored by Newark over the Boston Red Sox in the final of a six-game series today.

Any attempt to maintain the status quo among the nations is foredoomed to failure, in the opinion of Dr. Richard von Kuehlmann, former German Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, who spoke yesterday at a luncheon of the Greater New York branch of the League of Nations Association in the Hotel Woodstock.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Charges that the "little fellow" was entirely beyond the range of vision of the Hoover Administration at Washington in its effort to rebuild the nation economically and lift the country out of its present period of depression were made by Governor Roosevelt in a radio address delivered tonight from the Executive Mansion.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Regulations pertaining to ship manifests were amended by Secretary Mills today to withdraw from ship owners and masters the privilege of preventing publication of the information on import manifests.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., April 7 -- Swarthmore College opened its baseball season today by conquering Lehigh University, 12 to 7. The Garnet batters pounded out fourteen hits, while Schembs and Stetson were limiting Lehigh to eight.

NORFOLK, Va., April 7 -- Gayly assailing the offering of Henry Grampp, former batting practice pitcher for the Cubs, and the underhand deliveries of Herb Brett for seventeen hits, including two home runs by Hack Wilson, the Robins closed their exhibition tour today by defeating the Norfolk Tars, 13 to 4, before about 2,000 persons.
An increase in bank clearings in the last week over the final week in March was somewhat larger than seasonal, although the total was still below that of the corresponding week last year.

MOSCOW, April 7 -- Former Governor Percival P. Baxter of Maine and Henry Clay Wright of Bath, Me., have just completed a 7,000-mile trip of thirty-four days' duration through the Soviet Union under the auspices of the Soviet tourist bureau.

Belief in the permanence and importance of political parties in the United States is the keynote in "American Parties and Politics," by Harold R. Bruce, published today by Henry Holt Co. Mr. Bruce is Professor of Political Science at Dartmouth College.

LONDON, April 7 -- The Stock Exchange continued weak today, still influenced by the report on Kreuger Toll and discouraging news from Wall Street. The 5 per cent war loan advanced further on strong buying, but other British Government funds were heavy on profit taking.

A vigorous rally in United States Government bonds which carried four issues into new high ground for the year featured dealings yesterday in the listed bond market. Domestic corporation bonds continued weak and foreign loans were irregularly lower.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 7 -- Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt arrived today from New York for her usual Spring visit. She will be joined later by Brig. Gen. Vanderbilt.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Hoover today accepted the invitation of the House Economy Committee to cooperate with it in reducing Federal expenditures. He requested the entire committee to meet with him at the White House at 11 o'clock Saturday morning.

The question whether William J. Flynn, Bronx Public Works Commissioner, promised to use his influence in the Board of Estimate to further his attack upon Louis H. Willard was raised yesterday before the Hofstadter legislative committee as the committee resumed public hearings.

A good time having been had by all who took part in the spirited manifestations on Columbia campus, it is in order not to let the affair assume apocalyptic dimensions. No great issues are involved in the expulsion of an undergraduate editor, who has hitherto enjoyed full freedom of expression, on the charge of deliberate slander.
CICERO, Ill., April 7 (AP) -- This village of 66,000 on the western fringe of Chicago, once a headquarters for Capone hoodlums and scene of many bloody gang episodes, is out to redeem its reputation.

About 200 delegates attended the opening of the eighth State convention of the New York federation of Music Clubs at the Hotel Victoria yesterday. The delegates voted to form a committee consisting of two members from each of the 222 clubs in the organization to work out a legislative program to obtain further school credits for work in music.

The United States continued to hold the highest homicide record among the civilized nations of the world in 1931, according to a survey By Dr. Frederick Hoffman, statistician, appearing in an article in The Spectator, an insurance periodical.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Increased importations of foreign goods by the United States since Great Britain and other countries went off the gold standard were cited today by Senator Reed in urging the Senate to adopt his resolution for a tariff commission investigation of the effect of depreciated foreign currencies on American trade.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, April 7 -- Former President Leonidas Plaza Gutierrez, who was deposed in 1925 by a revolt led by Major Ildefonso Mendoza and junior army officers, returned to Ecuador today for the first time since then to find that his arrival precipitated another revolt.

The birthday of Dr. WILLIAM H. WELCH has special significance this year, since it is the fiftieth anniversary of the announcement of the discovery by KOCH of the tubercle bacillus and its artificial cultivation, which in turn marked the beginning of the public health movement with which Dr. WELCH has been associated as a leader in America and in the world at large.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, April 7 -- Secret orders broadcast in a daily radio program from a Russian town to spies of the Ogpu (Soviet secret police) in Finland were revealed as pare of a conspiracy that resulted in the sentencing today of eleven Finnish Communists, including two women, to penal servitude for treasonable activities.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Unemployment of additional thousands and curtailment and disruption of the government service even to closing twelve embassies and legations were predicted by Cabinet officers in resisting attempts at further reductions in their departments.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 7 -- First of the open events on the program of the twenty-seventh annual field trials of the English Setter Club of America, the junior all-age stake, was completed today after the running of nine brace in the first series and three more in the second.

On the eve of the arrival of Max Schmeling, world's heavyweight boxing champion, from Germany, his manager, Joe Jacobs, announced yesterday that plans had been completed for the Teuton's preliminary exhibition tour and for the training quarters where he will prepare for the defense of his title against Jack Sharkey on June 16 at the Yankee Stadium.

Two southbound Ninth Avenue elevated trains collided at 5 o'clock last night in the station at Ninety-ninth Street and Columbus Avenue, eighty feet above the street. Two passengers in the first train were slightly injured and several were thrown from their seats.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- From the man who officially notified Alfred E. Smith in 1928 of his nomination for President by the Democratic National Convention, Senator Key Pittman of Nevada, came this recommendation today to the friends of Mr. Smith, based on the continued defeats of the ex-Governor of New York by Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt in the Presidential primaries:

TRENTON, N.J., April 7 -- A measure, passed by the Legislature this week, giving Circuit Court judges the power to decide whether recall of a City Commissioner should be put to a municipal vote, was signed today by Governor Moore.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 7 -- John McGraw celebrated his fifty-ninth birthday today and in order to commemorate the event in a proper and fitting manner the Giants defeated the Tigers, 5-4, in the sixth game of the current series.
The number of women in Holland pledged to support world disarmament has reached about one-third the population of that country, according to Miss Cornelia M. van Asch van Wyck of Utrecht, Holland.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- In preparing estimates for revenues during the 1933 fiscal year, Secretary Mills included $254,740,000 due from foreign powers on war debts. This may not be received.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The recommendations of Assistant Attorney General Seth W. Richardson for improvement of law enforcement in the Hawaiian Islands would deprive the Hawaiians of some of their most important elements of self-government, Governor Lawrence M. Judd of the Territory said today in a telegram to Secretary Wilbur.

An appeal against "discrimination against women on civil service lists" was made to the members of the Municipal Civil Service Commission yesterday morning by Dr. Anna W. Hochfelder, president of the New York Chapter of the American Alliance of Civil Service Women.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., April 7 -- Plans to extend Pan-American Airways' schedule this Summer between Boston, Bangor and Halifax to include Newfoundland were revealed here today in a talk before the St. John's Rotary Club by Alan Francis Winslow, representative of the airways system.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Supporters of Governor Roosevelt of New York said today that he would not be one of the speakers at the Jefferson Day dinner here Wednesday in which ex-Governor Smith, Newton D. Baker and others are scheduled to participate.

Mrs. Reginald Clarke left her apartment at 1 Christopher Street to buy a newspaper about 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. When she returned she found a large crowd assembled out in front around the body of a man. He had committed suicide just a few minutes before by leaping from a seventh-floor window.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 7 (AP) -- A serious run on the Central Bank of Chile culminated today in the resignation of the Cabinet of President Montero, followed by a defeat of his administration, in the Chamber of Deputies on the method of solving the nation's monetary troubles.

Counsel at the trial of Joseph A. Brodericky State Superintendent of Banks, conferred after the close of yesterday's court session with a view to admitting a mass of documentary and routine evidence by stipulation to shorten the trial by at least a month.

BUDAPEST, April 7 -- While Budapest's second newspaperless day passed without very serious incidents, despite frequent collisions between strikers and the police, which resulted in 400 arrests, one man was killed in an outlying village and a few persons were wounded.

PASADENA, Cal., April 7 (AP) -- Astronomers at Mount Wilson observatory and others in this country and Europe are keeping a close watch on "Delporte's object," an asteroid or comet discovered recently by an astronomer at the University of Brussels.

Secretary of State Stimson and Norman H. Davis will sail tonight on the French liner Ile de France to attend the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva. Mr. Stimson will be accompanied by Mrs. Stimson; Allen T. Klotz, his special assistant in the State Department; Captain Eugene Regnier, his military aide, and Alien W. Dulles of New York, who has been appointed legal adviser to the American delegation.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 7 -- Award of fourteen Sheldon Traveling Fellowships, having a total value of $18,800, was announced. Twelve graduate students will spend the next academic year in travel and study abroad, while two students, one in economics and one in law, will study abroad this Summer.
PITTSBURGH, April 7 -- Two convicts were slain and another believed fatally wounded in a stabbing affray in the yard of Western Penitentiary today.

Production, of steel ingots was smaller by 48,717 tons in March than in February, and dally output decreased 6,129 tons, according to the monthly figures of the American Iron and Steel Institute, issued yesterday.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, the Western, champion, and Miss Margaret Maddox of Atlanta, the Georgia champion, vanquished their respective opponents by decisive scores today in the semi-final round of the annual Dogwood golf tournament, and tomorrow they play for the title, which Mrs. Hill won last year.

The identities of seven members of the New York Stock Exchange who sold their seats last week at prices ranging from $101,000 down to $83,000, the latter being the lowest price since 1924, were disclosed yesterday by the Exchange. With one exception they are partners in firms which had more than one representative on the floor of the Exchange, so that their firms will not be deprived of membership in the Exchange.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 7 -- Grand opera at the Zoological Gardens, a feature of the musical life of Cincinnati for the last sixteen years, will be abandoned this year. In announcing the decision the trustees of the Cincinnati Zoological Park Association said:

The student factions at Columbia University, still recuperating from the effects of Wednesday's strike, will clash again today, it was feared, over the expulsion of Reed Harris, editor of The Spectator.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 -- The Phillies won the city baseball championship for the third straight year by beating the Athletics, 3 to 2, in ten innings today at Shibe Park before 2,500 fans. This was the third victory in four games this Spring, with the fifth and final contest to be staged Saturday.

The Senate Committee on Agriculture is considering a bill which would compel the Federal Farm Board to impound its stocks of surplus wheat until July 1, 1933. The author of this measure, Senator GORE, believes that its adoption would raise the price of the coming crop.

With fewer than half a dozen voices opposing a reverberating chorus of "ayes" among 311 members yesterday, the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York formally pronounced prohibition a "failure."

DETROIT, April 7 -- Detroit's City Council was notified in writing today of the united refusal of New York, Chicago and Detroit banks to lend the city more money or to renew the present loans unless the promise is kept to balance the city's budget.

The New York Central Railroad increased its interest in the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad to 10.7 per cent in 1931, it is shown by the list of the twenty largest stockholders in the latter company. Under the four-party consolidation plan for the East, the Lackawanna would be merged with the New York Central system.

MUNICH, Germany, April 7 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler's National Socialists and the authority of the Bavarian State came into direct conflict today when Ernst Roehm, commander of the Nazi storm troops, announced that he would mobilize his battalions for the Presidential run-off election Sunday and the Bavarian Government decreed that no such mobilization might be held.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Seven hundred Republican women, including wives of high officials, national committeewomen and party leaders, reaffirmed their allegiance to President Hoover at a luncheon held today in honor of Mrs. Hoover by the League of Republican Women of the District of Columbia.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Willis H. Booth will give a reception at 1,010 Fifth Avenue for Sir Josiah and Lady Stamp the afternoon of April 14.

PARIS, April 7 -- Heavy offerings of French bank shares and international stocks resulted today in an agitated session of the Bourse, which closed almost uniformly at the day's lowest prices. Yesterday's weakness in Wall Street, exaggerated reports concerning the United States monetary situation, the slump in Kreuger Toll holdings and uncertainty over the Danubian conference all contributed to the confusion.
ROCHESTER, April 7 (AP) -- Gene Tunney knows today that at least one baby has been named for him It's a girl -- Gene Haley.

Predicting that municipal financing would undergo an evolution similar to that which took place in corporation financing twenty to thirty years ago, Fred Lavis, Mayor of the village of Scarsdale, N.Y., consulting engineer and former president of the International Railways of Central America, said yesterday that in the future buyers of municipal bonds would demand and receive just as complete information regarding a community's financial position as do buyers of corporation bonds.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A chivalrous incident of the Spanish-American War was recalled today when Senorita Carmela Eulate sent word to the State Department through Claude I. Dawson, Consul General at Barcelona, of the death of her father, Vice Admiral Eulate Fery, commander of the cruiser Vizcaya in the Battle of Santiago.

The 10 per cent wage deduction that took effect on Feb. 1, together with drastic cuts in other disbursements, made it possible for the Eastern railroads to report an increase of 4.98 per cent in net operating income for February compared with February, 1931, it is shown in figures issued yesterday by the Bureau of Railway Economics.

BERLIN, April 7 -- Trading was light on the Boerse today, at one time almost at a complete standstill. Reports concerning Kreuger Toll and rumors of difficulties in a big concern in Amsterdam caused considerable nervousness and the general level of prices declined 1 to 2 per cent.

BOSTON, April 7 -- After trailing by two goals early in the second period, the Toronto Maple Leafs rallied sensationally to overwhelm the New York Rangers in the second game of the Stanley Cup championship series in the Boston Garden tonight.

When George Washington's inaugural journey from New Jersey to Manhattan is re-enacted on April 30 in connection with the local bicentennial celebration, the modern Washington will be landed on the tip of Manhattan Island in a rowboat manned by thirteen sailors assisted by a "kicker," according to Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the New York Bicentennial Commission.

Gold exports to France on the basis of the position of franc exchange will be resumed today after a lapse of nearly two months when at least $7,000,000 gold will be sent abroad on the Olympic and the Ile de France, sailing this evening.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Abner J. Stillwell, vice president of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, and Edward E. Brown, executive vice president of the First Naional Bank, left for New York this afternoon to confer there with Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company, and Samuel Insull.

Doubt that the studies of ancient Central American languages now being made by Dr. Herman Walde-Waldlegg in Bogota, Colombia, as told in a dispatch yesterday, would prove a connection between the ancient Mayan culture and the cultures of Asia was expressed yesterday by Dr. Herbert J. Spinden, curator of ethnology of the Brooklyn Museum and an authority on Mexican and Central American cultures.

YONKERS, April 7 -- G.R. Jackson, president of the Miners' and Merchants' Bank of Nome, Alaska, who was host at Nome to Colonel and Mrs. Lindbergh on their flight to the Orient last Summer, is visiting his brother, Robert W. Jackson, at his home, 293 North Broadway, here.

Some day when the budget is balanced and a Democrat is elected President something will have to be done about keeping our better playwrights out of Hollywood. Here is Gilbert Emery, one-time author of "Tarnish," and as gentlemanly an actor as ever lounged across the footlights, now writing as debilitating a piece as this impudent month has afforded, "Housewarmjng," which was acted to two or three hilts at the Charles Hopkins last evening.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Urging amendment of the Volstead act to permit physicians to prescribe malt liquors, Dr. Warren Coleman of New York told a Senate committee today that "beer contains almost as much energy value as the best milk."

PINEHURST, N.C., April 7 -- Favorites, including the aggregation of golfers from Yale, found the going hard today in the second round of, the annual North and South amateur tournament. Three of the quartet representing Old Eli were eliminated, along with Dick Wilson of Southern Pines, the medalist.

At the close of yesterday's session of the General Sessions trial of Vincent Mummiani, 21 years old, on a first-degree murder charge in the shooting of Dominick Buoncore, in September, 1930, in an East Harlem restaurant. Judge Freschl reserved until today decision on a motion to admit as evidence a confession the defendant admitted he signed on his arrest five months after the killing.

Hundreds of earnest students of child psychology are at work on the problems which with growing complexity confront parents today. These researchers make an honest effort to be scientific. They do not accept parental opinions until several thousand from homes of varying levels are available.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 7 -- Seventy-four boxers from all sections of the country are awaiting the start of the first National Collegiate A.A. boxing tournament, which will be held here tomorrow and Saturday.

The object in one of the hands of the figure of the Infant Jesus in the carved wood statue of the Madonna and Child, dedicated last Sunday at the Little Church Around the Corner, in Twenty-ninth Street near fifth Avenue, is a piece of bread, symbolical of the Last Supper, it was revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The State Department will consider carefully the protest of the Paris branch of the National City Bank of New York against a false report published in Paris today that the bank had suspended payments. The department, however, withheld judgment pending receipt of the protest and a report from the American Embassy in Paris.

If one of the Founding Fathers -- say MADISON -- could come back to watch what is going on in Washington today, one thing would overcome him with special wonder. It is the complete breaking down of the wall which the framers of the Constitution thought they had set up between the Executive and Legislative departments of the Government.

While the efforts of three Norfolk men to recover the kidnapped Lindbergh baby have been unsuccessful thus far, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh has asked them again to keep on trying. Rear Admiral Guy H. Burrage, their spokesman, said yesterday in answer to questions.

Sensational journalism is the keynote of "Scandal For Sale," the picture which reached the Mayfair last evening. It is an adaptation of Emile Gauvreau's story, "Hot News," which in turn was evidently inspired by the tragic attempt of a tabloid editor to fly the ocean.

LONDON, April 7 -- The fall in Royal Dutch and Shell Transport oil shares as a Result at Continental selling is held here to be due to the publication of reports speculating on what profits if any these and other oil companies are making by the sale of gasoline, at current rates.

Armand Tokatyan, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera Company, appeared in his only New York recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. His program began with the aria, "Una furtiva lagrima," which was followed by a group of three in Italian by Handel, Donaudy and Cimara.

HONOLULU, April 8 (AP). -- A swift conclusion of the trial of Mrs. Granville Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas A. Massie and two navy enlisted men, accused of the murder of Joseph Kahahawai, was in prospect tonight as the result of hopes and plans of both prosecution and defense.

Mrs. Mabel Drury, daughter of the late Commodore Elbridge T. Gerry, lawyer and philanthropist and founder of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, and sister of former United States Senator Peter Goelet Gerry of Rhode Island, left an estate valued in the New York State transfer tax appraisal, filed yesterday, at $7,598,246 gross and $6,998,284 net.

In the leading article in this week's Publishers' Weekly a poet utters the complaints and defines the encouragements to be found in a materialistic world by its unthanked songsters. Mr. ISIDOR SCHNEIDER does not protest against hard times for poets in a financial sense.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., April 8. -- Premier J.T. Lang of New South Wales today defied the Commonwealth Government by padlocking the three floors of the income tax office at Sydney where the assessment records are kept. He hoped thus to block the seizure by the Federal authorities of State income tax payments to cover defaults in payments on the State's foreign debt.

Charges that the development of sound pictures has "mechanized the theatre, the drama, the opera and even the art of music itself," were voiced last night by Fred Birnbach, assistant to Joseph N. Weber, president of the American Federation of Musicians, who spoke at a dinner given in conjunction with the eighth biennial convention of the New York State Federation of Music Clubs.

Men's wear Sales Again Slow. After a somewhat favorable start on Monday, retail sales of men's clothing and furnishings slowed down during the rest of the week and the total volume was again disappointing. Some action was reported on low-price suits featured by the chains and department stores, but the higher brackets failed to attract interest.

Peace had returned to the Columbia campus yesterday. Speech had been so free as to be anti-climactic, and those who had expected and hoped for a riot went away to take examinations. The case of Reed Harris, expelled editor of The Spectator, seemed to have been rested by both the people and the defendant.

PARIS, April 8. -- The French Government stepped in today in an effort to suppress mischievous attacks on the dollar, seizing all copies of Marthe Hanau's weekly financial journal Forces, which had been one of the leaders in the campaign against the financial standing of the United States.

President Hoover joined with the Calvert Associates last night in reaffirming the principle of religious freedom and tolerance in a letter addressed to that organization and read at a meeting held under its auspices in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in commemoration of the 298th anniversary of the founding of Maryland and the establishment of the principle of religious liberty in America.

Because of a shrinkage in its income, the American Museum of Natural History will run at only threequarter speed this year, President Henry Fairfield Osborn announces in the sixty-third annual report of the trustees, made public today.

The annual Butterfly Ball, one of the largest dances of the Spring season, was held last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton in aid of the House of Rest at Sprain, Ridge, near Yonkers. Many dinners preceded the ball.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 8. -- Defendant companies in the long-standing "radio trust case," brought by the Federal Government against the Radio Corporation of America and associates, filed an answer today before Judge John P. Nields in Federal District Court here.

The Earl Carroll "Vanities" will end its engagement at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre after tonight's performance. Other closings tonight will be "Angels Don't Kiss," at the Belmont Theatre, and "Black Souls," at the Provincetown Playhouse.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 8 (AP). -- Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, the Western champion, defeated Miss Margaret Maddox of Atlanta, the Georgia champion, 7 and 5, today to win the Sedgefield Country Club's Dogwood golf tournament for the second successive year.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Spurred by reports of bear raids in Wall Street this week, the drop in the market values of securities and reputed efforts abroad, especially in France, to drive down the dollar, the Banking and Currency Committee of the Senate at an emergency session this afternoon decided to start Monday an investigation of the New York stock market.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The State Department, it was said today, has no reason to believe that the French Government was responsible for yesterday's report in a Paris newspaper that the National City Bank of New York had suspended payments and regarded the story as so manifestly absurd that it would die a natural death.

For the fourth successive year, the big chestnut gelding Juan, owned by Robert A. Granniss, president of the Indoor Polo Association, yesterday captured the championship rosette at the national indoor polo pony show at the Riding Club.

The Pius X Ciaoir of Liturgical Music of the College of the Sacred Heart, singing plain chant and compositions by Palestrina, De Lassus, and other composers of early centuries, made its first public appearance in New York last night in Town Hall.

The profit of the Standard Oil Company of California for 1931, after allowance for depreciation, depletion and amortization and reserves for Federal income tax, amounted to $14,559,593, or $1.11 a share on the average stock outstanding, compared with a net profit of $37,675,300, or $2.93 a share, in 1930, according to the annual report to shareholders, issued last night.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 8 (AP). -- An indefinite period of martial law was decreed by President Montero today as he sought to complete his coup of yesterday by which he retained control of the government despite a Cabinet crisis and a run on the National Bank.

VILLA SANTO STEFANO, Italy, April 8. -- The complete abandonment of this 2,000-year-old town of 2,400 inhabitants, midway between Rome and Naples, was ordered by Premier Mussolini today following the collapse of its central district last week into the ancient caverns with which it is undermined.

Formal announcement of the acquisition by the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company of the banking business and assets of the Liberty National Bank and Trust Company was made yesterday. The majority of the shareholders of the absorbed institution agreed recently to exchange their stock for that of the Harriman in the ratio of 180 for one.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP). -- The Lake Shore Athletic Club's relay team tonight broke the world's record for 400 yards in a dual meet with the Los Angeles Stars, swimming the distance in 3:32:2. The old record, established recently by the New York Athletic Club, was 3:34.9.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Lafayette College's nine defeated Georgetown today, 5 to 4, after quelling a Georgetown uprising that netted three runs in the ninth inning. Substitute pitcher Davis fanned Larry Sullivan, pinch-hitter, for the final out with the tying and winning runs on base.

TULSA, Okla., April 8 (AP). -- "Dollar oil" in the mid-continent area appeared threatened today as Standard of Indiana, Standard of New Jersey, Gulf Oil and their subsidiaries continued the old scale of 61 to 85 cents a barrel and showed no disposition to meet the recent advance instituted by several other concerns.

Joseph T. Mulligan, 56 years old, real estate expert of 475 West 141st Street, who, up to September, 1930, was one of the heads of the Bureau of Real Estate in Controller Berry's office, was arrested yesterday afternoon an on indictment growing out of the investigation by Leonard M. Walistein, as a special Assistant Corporation Counsel of the acquisition of land by the city.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- President Hoover made it plain to the members of his Cabinet today that they must be prepared to take further drastic reductions in their budget estimates for the fiscal year 1933. With the exception of Secretary Stimson, who is on his way to the disarmament conference at Geneva, all members were present.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8. -- Poison spray blown into the paddock where Phar Lap was quartered and fed to him on grass pulled by his trainer probably killed the Australian, wonder horse, officials of the United States Bureau of Food and Drugs said tonight.

LONDON, April 8. -- The passing of dividends for 1931 by the Ford European companies was a policy recommended by Henry Ford himself rather than a result of necessity, Sir Percival Perry, chairman of the British company, told shareholders today.

Charles A. Levine, who flew across the Atlantic as a passenger in the airplane piloted by Clarence Chamberlin, ran into a series of legal complications yesterday when he appeared in the Tombs Court to face a charge of grand larceny growing out of the allegation that on Aug. 30, 1930, he posted $22,000 worth of stolen stock with the Manufacturers Trust Company as part collateral for a loan of $25,000.

ROME, April 8 (AP). -- Italy filed a long memorandum at the offices of the disarmament conference it Geneva today, outlining a sweeping program for confining the wars of the future to sharply limited armament.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES'S stand on parks in general, and Long Island parks in partticular, has always been commendable. Your editorial "Long Island Parks" is no less commendable, and in addition throws much desirable light on the present status of public improvements.

The largest liquor and ship seizure in the port of New York in the last five years was made yesterday by customs agent under John H. McGill, Deputy Surveyor in charge of the enforcement squad, when the collier Maurice Tracy and more than 5,000 cases of alleged liquors were taken, in charge at a coal dock in Astoria, Queens.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Belmont are at the Pierre.

In a letter sent to stockholders of the Paramount Publix Corporation, Adolph Zukor, president, has proposed a plan through which 648,000 shares of stock would be set aside for the principal executives, under an option exercisable up to Dec. 31, 1935, at prices ranging from $15 to $32 a share.

BERLIN, April 8. -- Boerse opened comparatively firm today, but lost all its early strength. The influence of various rumors demonstrated the general nervousness. The decline affected leading securities, which, are the only stocks that may be regarded as reflecting fairly accurately the trend in Germany.

Financial panics of the first magnitude have often brought to light gross breaches of trust by men in positions of financial responsibility. Sometimes (notably after the panic of 1884) these discoveries have had to do with outright embezzlement or misappropriation.

After reaching the lowest figures recorded this season for the 1932 crop, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered sharply in the last hour yesterday and closed unchanged to 4 points higher on the day.

The circus came to town last night to the tune of a vast calliope's song of Spring. Clowns danced under the lights of the Garden, where normally there are wrestlers and mere battles of the century. Animals Jumped through hoops, whips cracked and aerialists dived from their perches high above the crowds.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP). -- Two of America's foremost ship owners -- P.A.S. Franklin and Edgar F. Luckenbach -- told the Senate Commerce Committee today that if legislation to stabilize rates in the intercoastal trade was not enacted some of the lines would be forced out of business.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The value of freight transported by Class I railways in 1930 was $62,090,176,000, as compared with $68,261,054,000 in 1928, according to a survey made public today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. Studies of this character are made every two years.

Four representatives of the New York Athletic Club -- Leo Nunes, Nicholas Muray, Bela de Napy and Irwin F. Acel -- were among the eight fencing stars to qualify for the semi-final round of the national saber championship in the competition at the Winged Foot clubhouse last night.

Joseph Cohen, 49 years old, a member of the wholesale poultry firm of Joseph Cohen Brother at 20 Tenth Avenue, was wounded fatally last night by three unidentified gunmen at his home at 240 Westminster Road in the Prospect Park South section of Brooklyn.

BERLIN, April 8. -- The failure of the Danubian conference provoked little surprise in the Wilhelmstrasse, where the incompatibility of the French and German proposals was evident before the conference met.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- A Winter wheat crop of 458,000,000 bushels was indicated by conditions on April 1, the Department of Agriculture reported today. This is 42 per cent below the very large crop of 787,000,000 bushels harvested in 1931 and 17 per cent less than the average of 551,000,000 bushels produced during the five-year period, 1924-28.

Using notes she had written overnight to refresh her memory, Mrs. Hen Tar, 66 years old, of Bridgeport, Conn., continued her testimony yesterday at the General Sessions trial of Nicholas C. Partos, former head of twenty-two drugstore and realty corporations, and his accountant, Ellis A. Laskey, on a charge they defrauded her out of $612 in 1930 by falsely representing the value of stock they sold her in two of the corporations.

First among companies of its size to protest in an open statement against governmental extravagance, E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., through its president, Lammot du Pont, appealed yesterday to "stockholders, employes and friends" of this company to bring pressure to bear upon Senators and Representatives in Washington to curtail expenditures by the Federal establishment.

The House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce has favorably reported a bill to repeal the "recapture" clause of the transportation act of 1920. This requires the railways to turn into a revolving loan fund for the assistance of weaker roads one-half of their net operating income in excess of 6 per cent on the value of their property.

TORONTO, April 8. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and New York Rangers, Stanley Cup finalists, arrived in Toronto today and rested tonight in preparation for the third contest of their three-of-five-game series for the historic trophy and the world's hockey championship.

With more than 4,000,000 votes tabulated in the eighth report of The Literary Digest prohibition poll, announced yesterday, those favoring repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment continued to hold a lead of almost three to one over advocates of continuance of current conditions.

BOONEVILLE, Mo., April 8. -- With his chest pierced several times by bullets, Leo Meistrell, 42, investment banker, was found in the vault of his business office here today after an all-night search by police for Meistrell and his partner, William W. Kingsbury, 55.
LONDON, April 8. -- Andrew W. Mellon stepped shyly onto English soil today to begin his duties as Ambassador in a land where, as he said later, "next to my own country I feel most at home."

Governor Roosevelt, as president of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, appealed yesterday, in a radio address at the tenth annual meeting of the foundation in the City Club, for support of the Scout movement as a constructive means of combatting crime, and added a plea in behalf of "all character building and social service agencies during this difficult period."

Money market was quiet and featureless. Business remained upon a small scale and at no variation from the quotations which have been in effect for some time. Money was in good supply against Stock Exchange call loans but demand was light. Quotation held at 2 1/2 per cent on the board, with 24 prevailing in the street trading.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial comment on Governor Roosevelt's discourteous letter to Dr. Holmes and Rabbi Wise is extremely tantalizing. Many of us are not in accord with the views and activities of Dr. Holmes and Rabbi Wise, but they are practically alone on the firing line, using heavy artillery under the greatest difficulties, to mow down the corruptions and indecencies of Tammany and its allies.

BERLIN, April 8. -- The Iron Front held a wind-up rally today in the Lustgarten to the tune of "For Hindenburg Down With Hitler!" From the solid human mass filling the huge square rose Social Democratic standards and labor union banners, but above, dominating them and most conspicuous, floated the flags of the Reich.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8. -- A record registration of Democrats for the California Presidential primary May 3 and a loss of about 14 per cent for the Republicans were revealed today in a tabulation by The Associated Press.
BUDAPEST, April 8. -- Hungarian opinion as indicated in tonight's papers is not greatly disturbed over the failure of the Danubian conference.

Universities and colleges must train people to take a constructive part in the political, economic and social life of the United States, a group of distinguished educators agreed yesterday at a luncheon in honor of Dr. Alexander G. Ruthven, president of the University of Mlchjgan, given at the Bankers Club by Henry Woliman, lawyer and graduate of the university.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. George M.L. La Branche Jr. entertained this evening at dinner in The Homestead for Mr. and Mrs. Melville P. Dickinson and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wood Johnson.

FROM time to time boxing promoters have advertised their shows at what they were pleased to call "popular prices," a designation evidently used in a Pickwickian sense. But at last there is a boxing show at a really popular price. Admission is free.

Most of the great roasters of art poetry and sculpture have "toiled in vain" as far as Americans are concerned, Lorado Taft, sculptor, declared in a message read last night at a dinner of the Eastern States Association of Professional Schools for Teachers at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

In Wall Street it was asserted that yesterday's renewal of aggressive selling on the Stock Exchange resulted largely from the impairment of margins and possibly of investment accounts. This explanation of the market's further weakness was offered by brokers who contended that speculative short selling was drying up and who professed to see little evidence of voluntary liquidation.

Seven pounds of heroin and 128 pounds of morphine hidden in a shipment of five cases of toys on the liner Ile de France at Pier 57, North River, were seized yesterday by Federal agents. Joseph Frankel, head of a toy importing concern, was held in $5,000 bail in connection with the seizure.

The loss of traffic of the Southern Railway in 1931 might be attributed 70 per cent to the depression and 30 per cent to competition from new transit agencies, according to the report for 1931 of Fairfax Harrison, president. Ton-mileage of the road decreased 15.6 per cent in 1931 from the total in 1930, wIth a consequent reduction of 15.6 per cent in freight revenue.

Recognition of a new science, psychobiology, the principal aim of which is to understand and describe man as we understand and describe any object of natural history, without cutting out man's essential nature, as behaviorism does, was urged last night by Dr. Adolf Meyer, Professor of Psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University and director of the Henry Phipps Psychiatric Clinic at Baltimore, in a lecture at the New York Academy of Medicine.

Such sorry consolation as may be retrieved out of Dr FREDERICK HOFFMAN'S annual presentation of homicide statistics in the United States consists in the fact that a dismal situation has not been growing perceptibly worse. In 1924 we had attained a rate of 10.9 murders for every 100,000 of the population in the cities, and that is the rate which Dr. HOFFMAN finds for the years 1930 and 1931.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 8. -- After one of the most notable competitions in the history of the English Setter Club of America, the Free-For-All Stake ended today with a victory for the white and liver pointer dog The Coming Storm, owned by Udo M. Fleischmann of New York and handled by Sam Yount.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, in a tentative report today, fixed $6,402,679 as the amount due from the Elgin, Joliet Eastern Railway Company under the recapture provision of the Interstate Commerce act from 1920 to 1926, inclusive, but eliminated as a deduction from operating expenses in ascertaining new railway income, $209,588 in bonuses to officers and employes.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Opponents of the Farm Board in the House failed in a Three-hour fight today to abolish the board and turn over its affairs to the Department of Agriculture for liquidation. The resolution of Representative Vinson of Georgia was rejected by a vote of 152 to 23.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 8. -- More than 3,500 Westchester residents heard their operatic favorites, Lily Fons end Lawrence Tibbett, at the County Centre tonight in the Metropolitan Opera Company's performance of "The Tales of Hoffmann."

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- An Outlet abroad for large quantities of surplus wheat before the new crop comes on the market in July is sought by the Farm Board in negotiations it has opened with Germany and Greece.
For the third successive year, the champion St. Louis Cardinals and Philadelphia Athletics have the backing of the majority of experts to win. the major league baseball pennant races.

HARTFOKD, Conn., April 8. -- At the final day's judging in the National Flower Show, which will remain open until Sunday night, the following awards for roses and snapdragons were made today for groups of fifty:

The semi-final round Davis Cup tie in the North American zone between Mexico and the winner of the match between Canada and the United States will be played at the New Orleans Country Club May 13, 14 and 15.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Democrats are going to have a dry keynoter and a wet chairman, carrying water on one shoulder and rum on the other. To present appearance the platform will be written in the same spirit, so that neither wets nor drys will have any reason to vote against the Democratic ticket.

PARIS, April 8. -- In Paris the breakdown of the Four-Power Conference in London on Danubian economic relief is attributed to Germany's unwillingness to consider European problems apart from her own national interests interpreted in the narrowest sense.

NEWARK, N.J., April 8. -- A light rainfall in the seventh inning ended the game between the Boston Braves and the Newark Bears today. When Umpire Gus Getz halted hostilities the teams were tied with one run each, the Bears deadlocking the score in the final stanza, on Barrett's walk and singles by Hill and Zitzmann.

TOKYO, April 8. -- The Cabinet's view on the application of Article XV of the League Covenant, which would bring the League into the Manchurian dispute, has now been communicated to the principal powers.

Borough President Henry Bruckner of the Bronx, called as a witness before the Hofstadter legislative committee, testified yesterday that he and his son had two safe-deposit boxes which they had visited 185 times in the last five years, and in which they habitually kept up to $50,000 in cash.
CHICAGO, April 8. -- The Chicago taxpayers' "strike" received a setback today when the Illinois Supreme Court upheld the validity of the 1929 assessment rolls of Cook County.

Not at Another's Expense. When the number of British unemployed shrinks by nearly 150,000 the explanation is obvious to those in sympathy with recent innovations. Abandonment of the gold standard has stimulated trade and industry by putting England in a more favorable position to compete with other producing nations.

In the first official protest filed by a New York Exchange against the proposed increase in the Federal stock transfer tax to a quarter of 1 per cent of the sales prices, Howard C. Sykes, president of the Curb Exchange, declared yesterday that through the approval of the impost by the House of Representatives "the recuperative power and hope of the country had been given another blow."

Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of State, sailed last night on the French liner Ile de France to take a leading part in the disarmament conversations in Geneva. Before departing he issued a statement expressing confidence that there is in prospect agreement upon "a number of useful measures designed to limit the chances of war."
Georges Barrere, William Kroll, Alfred Wallenstein and Gaston M. Dethier are announced in a benefit for the United Parents Association on Saturday, April 30, in the home of Adolph Lewisohn.

The thirty-ninth day since Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh's baby was stolen from their home near Hopewell, N.J., passed, yesterday with no indication that a solution of the kidnapping mystery was near.

Senator PITTMAN has had the usual luck of the too candid friend. His affectionate dissuasive advice has caused Governor SMITH to publish certain correspondence. To remove the doubts of some of his friends he declares that he "wiil ac"cept the Democratic nomination "for President."

CHICAGO, April 8. -- Uneasiness caused by the continued recession in the stock market, the general financial conditions and developments in Washington led to a reversal in operations today by local professional dealers, who recently had been active on the buying side of wheat on the Board of Trade.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 8. -- In the absence of detailed information from New York regarding the nitrate conferences between United States, British and Chilean delegates there, brought together by Medley G. B. Whelpley, president of the nitrate corporation of Chile, deep interest has been aroused here by an article in a Valparaiso weekly on the subject.
MANILA, April 8 (AP). -- Salary cuts of from 2 to 10 per cent for all employes of the Philippine Government were ordered today in an executive decree issued by Governor General Theodore Roosevelt.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, April 8. -- With all of Ecuador's naval craft in the hands of revolutionists, the government ordered the port here closed to all traffic today to prevent the revolutionists getting provisions or additional arms.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 8. -- The city of Cambridge today demanded court prosecution and financial redress for injuries to five firemen and damaged and stolen equipment resulting from rioting on the quadrangle of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

New State and municipal bond issues formally scheduled for award next week aggregate only $5,906,685, compared with $45,589,223 for this week. However, two issues totaling $32,125,000 which were to have been awarded this week are expected to be awarded on Monday.

Governor ROOSEVELT began his radio address on Thursday evening with a disclaimer of partisan motives. Yet he presently found himself accusing the Hoover Adminis tration of being able to "think In "terms only of the top of the so"cial and economic structure."

LONDON, April 8. -- The conference of British, French, German and Italian Government delegates which has been in session here the last three days trying to agree on a plan for economic rescue of the Danubian States of Austria, Hungary, Rumania, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia adjourned today without having achieved any economic results whatever and without any plan for resuming discussions.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- An attack by H.E. Miles, chairman of the Fair Tariff League, upon the refusal of the Tariff Commission to specify whether an increase or decrease should be made in the duty on fresh pineapples has been placed in the Congressional Record by Senator Walsh of Montana with a request that his flemocratic colleagues from Florida.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 8. -- Taking advantage of a light, sixmile breeze, which was better suited to their rig than to the invading craft, the Bermuda skippers won the fourth race of their team match with the Long Island Sound Inter-club Class yachtsmen today to even the series at two victories each.

The manner in which he intends to deal with the 1,622 individuals who claim relationship to Miss Ella V. von E. Wendel, who died on March 13, 1931, leaving an estate of $100,000,000, was announced yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley.

Max Carey's Robins and Joe McCarthy's Yankees opened their annual local exhibition series at Ebbets Field yesterday and, while 10,000 chilled but enthusiastic fans looked on, the Babe Ruth brigade defeated the Flatbush troupe, 3 to 1.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 8. -- Nineteen colleges qualified athletes for the final Olympic boxing tryouts as a result of their showing today in the National Collegiate A.A. championship tournament in the Penn State gymnasium.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 8. -- Martial law went into effect with Congressional approval today for sixty days, prominent critics of the Montero Administration were ordered not to leave their homes, the new Cabinet took office and President Juan Esteban Montero appealed to the people to help tide over the stringent crisis which has developed out of the depression.

LONDON, April 8. -- A tariff of 33 1-3 per cent on Iron and steel is expected to be recommended to the government for immediate imposition by the advisory committee that is reviewing the operation of the new import duties act.

ALBANY, April 8. -- Governor Roosevelt vetoed tonight the Hewitt civil service reclassification bill because be believed it would confer "extraordinary and autocratic powers" upon a proposed director of the reclassification of about 13,000 of the State's 31,000 employes.

NEWARK, N.J., April 8. -- The Laymen's Association of the Newark Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church urged the conference today to cut the salaries of district superintendents or authorize the Bishop to reduce the number of districts, or to take both these steps as means of economy.

LONDON, April 8. -- The stock markets were depressed today, although the tone improved slightly in the afternoon. The pessimism was increased by the failure of the Danubian conference and by estimates that British investors had lost between u15,000,000 and u20,000,000 in the Kreuger Toll difficulties.

PURCHASE, N.Y., April 8. -- Bend Down Sister, a 9-month-old white and liver pointer, was the bright star of the opening day's events of the fifth annual field trials of the Southern New York Field Trial Association, staged on the Clark estate near here today.

Although President Hoover is understood to favor the renomination of Vice President Curtis, friends of the President have started a movement for the nomination of Senator Peter Norbeck of South Dakota for second place on the Republican national ticket, it was learned here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The fight to ward off any consideration of tariff duties in the tax bill was taken to the floor of the Senate today by Senator Tydings.

GUAYAQUIL, April 8 (AP). -- Strong detachments of troops left Guayaquil tonight for the fort at Punta Piedra with orders to launch an attack at dawn to dislodge the naval mutineers who have seized the fortress and Ecuador's two-ship navy.
Plans for a $4,500,000 building in Rockefeller Centre to house opera were filed yesterday with the Manhattan Bureau of Buildings.

Four separate committees under independent chairmen are being organized to protect the interests of holders of Kreuger Toll and International Match securities issued in the American market, it was announced last night by Lee, Higginson Co. The issues covered by the committees are Kreuger Toll American certificates, representing participating debentures; Kreuger Toll 5 per cent secured debentures, International Match preferred stock and International Match 5 per cent debentures.

Stockholders of the Collins Aikman Corporation, manufacturers of pile fabrics, will be asked to reduce at the annual meeting on May 7 the capitalization of their company by retiring 26,833 common shares held in the treasury and reducing the capital represented by the remaining common stock to $5,650,000.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor announces that the index number of wholesale prices for the week ended April 2 stands at 65.9, as compared with 66.2 for the week ended March 26.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We agree with your editorial "The Philippine Bill" that the bill was not "forced upon an unwilling House by a parliamentary manoeuvre," and that "the action was non-partisan and also emphatic."

BELMONT, N.Y., April 8 (AP). -- Judson L. Howden, 78 years old, Allegany County newspaper publisher and editor, died today at his home in Fillmore, several miles north of here. He founded The Northern Allegany Observer, a weekly paper, in 1888 and served as editor until his death.

DETROIT, April 8. -- The Giants and the Tigers brought their show in from the Wild West today and encountered frigid weather supplemented by a biting blast off the lake, and while some 2,000 hardy enthusiasts were present when hostilities commenced, only a mere handful remained to cheer feebly as the Tigers staged a stirring rally in the last of the ninth.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Some remarkable fluctuations in currency circulation in the past twelve months, involving a maximum increase in October of $293.OO0.O00 and a maximum decrease in March of $144,000,000, were revealed in treasury figures today.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Senator Dickinson of Iowa probably will be selected by the committee on arrangements of the Republican National Committee as the keynote speaker for the national convention. Senate leaders believe Senator Dickinson fits into the situation facing the party, and that his speech would be received with good grace by the farm and wheat belt States.

Samuel Insull, Owen D. Young and their assistants continued yesterday their review of the problems of the Middle West Utilities Company. Mr. Insull, questioned as to the progress accomplished, said he did not expect to make any statement until after he had returned to Chicago, where a committee of Chicago and New Tork bankers is meeting.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8. -- In one of the greatest pitching duels seen on Franklin Field in years Pennsylvania today defeated Harvard, 2 to 0, when Don Kellett of Brooklyn hit a home run with Dick Dennison on base in the first inning.

The ultra-violet ray, either from sunshine or from proper artificial sources, has a real therapeutic value in the treatment of tuberculosis of the skin and glands, and is an important contributing factor in the treatment of, tuberculosis of the intestines, of bones and joints, and of the larynx, it wasn said yesterday by Dr. Edgar Mayer in a lecture at the Academy of Medicine.

BOWIE, Md., April 8. -- Felix Spatola's Wise Count, which gave much promise last Spring as a 2-year-old, was the winner of the third race today in what was his 3-year-old debut. The gelded son of Wise Counsellor and Grace Troxler was sent to the post by Elmer Trueman.

Policemen who have been cooperating with the block-aid campaign by special order of Police Commissioner Mulrooney enrolled nearly 100 blockaiders yesterday, bringing the number of active workers in all boroughs to 69,000.

An offer to acquire stock of the Atlantic Securities Corporation through an exchange of stock has been made by the Atlas Utilities Corporation. Atlantic Securities had net assets, valuing securities at market, of approximately $2,500,000 on March 31.
UNIONTOWN, Pa., April 8 (AP) -- Governor Roosevelt's attack on the Hoover Administration's economic policies drew a sharp reply tonight from Secretary of War Patrick J. Hurley.

Renewed weakness in sugar and heaviness in the grains and cotton among the major staples featured trading in commodity markets yesterday. The May contract in sugar established a new all-time low of 0.61, with the remainder of the contracts off 3 to 5 points. Cotton also broke badly but recovered at the close. Rubber, hides and cocoa were weak, but silk turned up 2 to 3 points. Tin was at a new low.

The Rev. Dr. Leland Foster Wood professor of Christian Sociology in Colgate-Rochester Divinity School, has accepted a call to become secretary of the committee on marriage and the home of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America. He will assume his new duties at the close of the academic year at Rochester.
VIENNA, April 8. -- The break-down of the Danubian conference was not unexpected in Vienna, but it had a depressing effect.

The report of the twenty largest stockholders of the New York Central as of Dec. 31 shows that, while the holdings of the late George F. Baker were apparently distributed among nominees for the Baker interests, the shares held by these and other interests in control of the road increased slightly in 1931.

The "victory campaign" of the Democratic National Committee was $36,690 nearer its $1,500,000 goal yesterday as the result of a check for that amount being presented to John W. Davis, national chairman of the campaign, by Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland.

The Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard University presented its eighty-sixth annual show last night at the Mecca Templee before an enthusiastic and appreciative audience numbering clos eto 3,000 persons. Calling it "Pudding on the Ritz" a name which appeared to have little or no connection with the "plot," the young men of Harvard presented a musical show in the modern manner, complete from chorus to specialty artists.

ROME, Saturday, April 9. -- The Grand Council of Fascism came out flatly in favor of renunciation of reparations and cancellation of war debts in a resolution adopted at a session presided over by Premier Mussolini, which lasted until early this morning.

The President of the English National Union of Teachers, in his address at the recent annual conference, urged all "educationists" to become "crusaders," determined to regain the ground they have lost in the reduction of expenditure for the schools "without regard to consequences." He further proposed a "campaign of conquest," so that coming generations shall not pay in loss of educational facilities and opportunities for the blunders and the failures of the immediate past.

LONDON, April 8. -- Prime Minister Hertzog of South Africa, who only a few years ago advocated South African secession from the British Empire, has now told Eamon de Valera, president of the Executive Council of the Irish Free State, that the benefits of belonging to the "British league of nations" far outweigh the benefits of separation.

A stock market that has been growing steadily weaker for more than a week was subjected yesterday to further selling pressure in circumstances that served to intensify the mood of discouragement in Wall Street. Measured by points, the decine on the Stock Exchange was of only moderate scope -- running from 1 to 3 points among the more prominent issues -- but gauged on the basis of percentages the fall was quite sharp.

As his second General Sessions trial on a first-degree murder indictment in the shooting of a man in an East Harlem restaurant in 1930 was nearing a close yesterday, Vincent Mummiani, 21 years old, of 423 West 114th Street, unexpectedly entered a guilty plea to second-degree murder.

Heavy buying of United States Government bonds, which forced prices up to 1 1/2 points and established now high marks for the year in each of the eleven issues active, yesterday overshadowed the further acute weakness in domestic corporation bonds and the generally weak market for foreign loans.

PARIS, April 8. -- The dollar improved today, reaching 25.34 francs after falling below the gold transfer point yesterday, following false reports regarding the National City Bank of New York. These rumors were admitted to be false by the French press and evoked an apology from the newspaper which published them.
MACON, Ga., April 8. -- Dr. Dice Robins Anderson, Methodist layman, was inducted today as president of Wesleyan College. one of the oldest chartered woman's colleges in the world.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Democrats who are supporting Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Presidential nomination generally refrained from comment tonight on the telegrams and letters sent to Connecticut, Pennsylvania and California by Alfred E. Smith, vigorously reasserting his active candidacy.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- More than 1,200 war veterans marched to the steps of the Capitol today in a demonstration accompanying the presentation of petitions to Congress for passage of a $2,600,000,000 bonus bill.

A long-smoldering conflict of personalities developed recently into clashes in the board of control of the Art Students League and brought about the resignation from the board of two well-known artists, John Sloan, president, and Jonas Lie, N.A., it was disclosed yesterday.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 8. -- The conviction of a Plainfield theatre manager for operating a moving picture theatre on Sundays was set aside today in a decision filed by County Judge Alfred A. Stein in Common Pleas Court on an appeal from a fine of $25 imposed by Police Judge William G. De Meza of Plainfield.

A slight seasonal increase in business activity characterized the opening week of the second quarter, according to the reviews by the mercantile agencies. Warmer weather stimulated buying in some lines, although general industrial conditions showed little improvement, even in the steel industry.

Arnold Blanch has recently been added to the roster of the Rehn Gallery, where his first one-man show under the new auspices is now being held. However, he is by no means making his exhibition debut, for he has, within the last few seasons, created a definite place for himself in the art world.

Lack of sufficient vocational training facilities has caused many instances of retardation, truancy and delinquency among children forced to remain in academic classrooms when their interests were centred on industrial subjects, according to the forthcoming annual report of Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, excerpts from which were made available yesterday. He says:

Declaring that he would accept the Democratic nomination for President and welcomed the support of his friends, former Governor Alfred E. Smith stigmatized yesterday as untrue "propaganda" that he was a "stalking horse" for any other candidate, meaning Governor Roosevelt, and denounced as un-American and undemocratic the alleged tactics of Roosevelt supporters in California in asserting that he could not be elected President because he was a Catholic.

Public utilities were criticized yesterday for "Irrational consolidation, over-capitalization and uncontrolled service charges" by speakers at the Round Table Conference on Regulation in which nearly 100 members of State and Federal utility regulating commissions and leaders in various fields of regulation are taking part.
LONDON, April 8. -- I am amazed by the way the Prince of Wales has improved his game of golf. I have just had the honor and pleasure of being his guest at Fort Belvedere, and his golfing companion.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- Work on the billion-dollar revenue bill was at a standstill today with both Senate and its Finance Committee on week-end recess, but a coalition to force tariffs into the bill was developing.

ROME, April 8. -- Three years ago Parliament abolished all entrance fees to government museums, art galleries and archaeological excavations. It believed it would thereby on the one hand increase the number of tourists visiting Italy and on the other do a considerable service for the culture of the Italians by stimulating their interest in the treasures of art and beauty which are one of the greatest boasts of this country.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 9. -- Brown was defeated, 7 to 4, today by the Boston Lacrosse Club in the opening game of the season. Stafford was outstanding in Brown's play, while Sullivan was prominent for Boston.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Cal., April 9. -- On the same oval where he shattered all existing quarter-mile running records two weeks ago, Ben Eastman, of Stanford today ran a half mile in 1 minute 51.3 seconds to clip three-tenths of a second from the world's standard established in London in 1926 by the German, Dr. Otto Peltzer.

Even the wanderlust in this scientific age is being turned to educational account. Less and less nowadays are student parties setting sail for Europe with the all-inclusive idea of "seeing the world" or making the Grand Tour a la Baedeker. Traveling with a purpose is the modern fashion.

Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt and former Governor Alfred E. Smith, rival candidates for the Democratic nomination for President, exchanged compliments yesterday and referred to each other as "Frank" and "My old friend Al" when they addressed a luncheon at the Hotel Astor opening the Catholic Charities' thirteenth annual appeal for funds.

MOSCOW, April 9. -- The Soviet Government will try to avert great discomforts for the people of Moscow in Winter and large costs to itself by preventing heavy snowfalls in this city. If its plan succeeds the clouds will be emptied before they reach this vicinity.

SOUTH HAJDL.EY, Mass., April 9. -- New opportunities for balancing collegiate budgets will be extended to some Mount Holyoke students next Fall when two of the smaller college houses, Byron Smith and Hitchcock, now used as sophomore houses, will be run on a cooperative basis.
There have, however, been important accomplishments in these two decades, of which the following are examples:

BARCELONA, March 19. -- An active and growing nucleus of a Catalan Sinn Fein movement, the leaders of which insist that if ever the region is to win its liberty it must win it by force, has been discovered here. Strangely, this movement has been born since the proclamation of the republic and the establishment of the provisional Catalan Government known as the Generalitat, with Colonel Francisco Macia as President.
A demand for small housing properties in New Jersey was indicated in deals announced yesterday.

While accountants for the Hofstadter legislative committee were analyzing figures dealing with the finances of Henry Bruckner, Borough President of the Bronx, who testified Friday that he deposited $455,000 in various banks in the last five years, Samuel Seabury, counsel to the committee, and his assistants began to prepare yesterday for the next public hearing, scheduled for Wednesday.

DETROIT. FOR all the confusing rapidity with which they have occurred, recent price changes on motor cars have followed a clear-cut rule. This is the general sentiment in Detroit and the logic of it is apparent. The explanation is offered that where prices have been cut, the reduction has been based upon the hope for increased sales in the most keenly competitive Battle the industry has ever known.
NO visitor to the National Aircraft Show of 1932 who had seen exhibitions of other years could fail to be impressed by signs of progress.

THE belief that the last word in magnificence had been uttered for the season at the Lothian sale in January is now shattered by a blast from Sotheby's. In a preliminary notice contained in a seven-page leaflet they unfold the plot of an auction that promises to match in brilliance anything in its field that has been witnessed in this generation.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the Hospital for Joint Diseases, at Madison Avenue and 123d Street, will be celebrated at a dinner at the Plaza next Saturday evening, it was announced yesterday by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, of which it is one of the ninety-one affiliated institutions.

The present line-up of members of the Board of Estimate indicates that enough votes favor the granting of the Queens bus franchises to the Jamaica Central Railways Company and the North Shore Bus Company to insure voting of the franchises at as early a date as the mechanics of holding hearings and advertising the contracts will permit.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 9. -- Governor and Lady Cubitt today entertained naval, military and government officials, prominent Bermudian residents and American visitors at a garden party at Government House on the occasion of the Governor's birthday.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- Sugar cane waste has been turned by the Department of Agriculture into a new source of rayon, a silky dress material.

A deal of prelusive effort having been expended and completed to perfect a young man's technique in the art of batting, throwing and catching a leather-covered sphere a degree or two better than if he had no preliminary training in the matter whatever, the sixteen clubs comprising the two major leagues of professional baseball are about to embark upon another championship season.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation declined 73,216 tons to 2,472,413 tons at the end of March, it was announced yesterday. It was the twelfth consecutive contraction and brought the corporation's bookings to a new low mark. February's decrease of 102,521 tons placed the backlog at 2,545,629 tons.

THERE was a day when radio was delightes to have the opportunity to broadcast the United States Army, Navy and Marine bands, also the Summer concerts by the Goldman Band. These high-class musical aggregations filled in many an hour on the air in the days when the program director were greatly relieved to find such a fine group of musicians to fill in the evening hours.

Chairman, The Daily Princetonian. From an editorial point of view, it seems to me that a student editor has three main duties -- to encourage what he honestly considers the most rational attitude toward general questions of current importance; to offer sane evaluations of concrete issues which arise, and to suggest vigorously original changes which he feels will better the existing situation.

A campaign to raise $175,000 to be used for maintaining Summer and week-end camps and to increase the enrolment of Boy Scouts in the city to at least 50,000, was announced yesterday by Frederic Kernochan, Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions and chairman of the committee on ways, means and endowment of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York.

AT the age of 80, a lively lads who has enjoyed all her eight decades, and Is still enjoying herself as heartily as she did seventy years ago, tells all about It She has been everywhere and seen everything -- and everybody; all sorts and conditions of men, the somebodies and the nobodies.

BALTIMORE, April 9. -- Johns Hopkins opened its track season with a 65-to-61 victory over Swarthmore today on a muddy and rain-soaked field. Neu clinched the meet for Johns Hopkins by winning the broad jump with a leap of 20 feet 6 inches.

BERLIN, April 9. -- The re-election of Paul von Hindenburg in tomorrow's run-off balloting for the Presidency of the Reich is viewed as a foregone conclusion tonight, the most optimistic predictions by his backers conceding the veteran Field Marshal a lead of anywhere from 8,000,000 to 10,000,000 votes over Adolf Hitler, the National Socialist candidate.

Comparatively little is known In this country about Finnish art, so that the exhibition that opened yesterday at the Roerich Museum is certain to perform a real service. Although examples both of painting and of sculpture are included, interest centres in the craft work shown: the rugs, tapestries, draperies, curtains, bed covers, table linen, , about which Walter Rendell Storey will write in next Sunday's Magazine Section of THE TIMES.

The international survey of the Young Men's and Young Women's Christian Associations, begun several years ago to "determine priority among projects for which financial resources might be sought," presents, among other conclusions in its recently published report, the suggestion that it might not be desirable to amalgamate the Y.M.C.A. and Y.W.C.A. abroad.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Senator Smoot, chairman of the Finance Committee which is considering the $1,000,000,000 tax bill, assured the nation today that a revenue measure least oppressive to business and the country generally would be speedily enacted and the budget balanced to counteract hostile foreign movements against American investments.

Technological unemployment has had its greatest effect upon women because of the mechanization of the home, Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, declared yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Barnard College Club of New York at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue.

AMHERST, Mass., April 9. -- Stanley King of Boston was elected the eleventh president of Amherst College today by the board of trustees. The new president, who is 49, is the son of Henry A. King, a graduate of Amherst in 1873, and is a former judge of the Massachusetts Superior Court.

BERLIN. WITH a new year of aeronautic development ahead the German airplane industry shows special interest in the solution of the problem of transocean flying. The two leading airplane manufacturers have concentrated their research staffs on this job and a third independent airplane designer of pre-war fame.
Fifty-six matches are listed in the New York and New Jersey Cricket Association's annual championship competition, opening May 14 and ending Sept. 10, according to the schedule announced yesterday.

BERLIN, April 8. -- Carrier pigeons and military dogs have not been overlooked in the mobilization plans of Adolf Hitler's "Brown Army," if the documentary evidence uncovered when the police recently raided Nazi centres throughout Prussia is to be trusted.
