THE final week of the current Metropolitan Opera season begins tomorrow evening with a performance of "Lakme," and closes on Saturday with "Sadko," and will also include a special matinee of "The Tales of Hoffmann" on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, April 9. -- Wheat opened today with a rush of buying on the Board of Trade here as a result of the trade's belief that the government estimate on the Winter crop, issued late yesterday, was sensationally bullish. With little pressure and despite numerous sharp dips, prices advanced finally to 60 cents a bushel for the July, showing 3 1/2 cents above yesterday's close.

MEXICO CITY, April 7. -- Mexico will invest 100,000,000 pesos during the next three years in road construction, according to an official statement. The money will probably come from foreign sources and the plan is likely to bring about a great improvement In the local economic situation by giving work to thousands of laborers.

A VAULT that contains three-quarters of a million gallons of wine has been shown to several of London's distinguished visitors of late. Known as the Crescent Vault. It is one of the wonders of the London docks.

HARRISON, N.Y., April 9. -- The Board of Water Commissioners of District 2 issued orders last night to Fire Chief Robert Olson of Harrison to ignore fire calls to the exclusive Purchase section of the township where some of the largest estates in Westchester are situated.

Many friends of the late Archdeacon Stuck will be interested in the announcement in THE TIMES that Messrs. Lindley and Strom are now engaged in an endeavor to duplicate the achievement of Archdeacon Stuck and his party in the ascent of the south, peak of Mount McKinley.

A belated rally by the New York University baseball team enabled it to tie Columbia, 1 to 1, at Ohio Field in an abbreviated battle yesterday. The contest went seven innings by agreement and no effort was made to prolong the contest because of the adverse weather conditions.
In a game marked at times by furious action, the Harvard and Stevens Institute of Technology lacrosse teams played an overtime 2-2 tie on the Stevens field, at Castle Point, Hoboken, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Fewer unfavorable developments have been reported fn the foreign mercantile credit situation in the last few weeks than in any similar period in two years, according to cable and radio dispatches to the Department of Commerce.

Dr. P.A. Wickmann of Brussels announced yesterday that he intends to call on Mayor Walker this week and extend to him on behalf of the International Union of Cities and Local Authorities an invitation to send an official representative to the International Congress of that organization, which will begin in London on May 23.

DODGE CITY, Kan., April 7. -- The X quantity in the political equation in Kansas is this -- What will the farmer do with his ballot if he has to sell his half-crop of wheat this year for less than 30 cents a bushel?

DETROIT, April 9. -- Sweeping majestically on to the moment when they will be called upon to unfold their gifted talents before a home crowd, the Giants bowled over the Tigers once more today just to keep their hand in the game of bowling over opponents.

IN "Men in Darkness" James Hanley bade the reader look over the edge of the abyss and plumb the depths to which the human soul can plunge in degradation and despair. And in his present offering, a short novel called "Boy," he invites to a second look.

WASHINGTON. THE House of Representatives is less dignified than the House of Commons, even in these days of obstreperous Labor members. It is less excitable than the Chamber of Deputies. It is less brutal than the Reichstag.

BERLIN, April 9. -- An unsuccessful attempt on the life of Dr. Hans Luther, president of the Reichsbank and former Chancellor, was made tonight. A young man fired at him with a revolver at close range as he was standing on the platform of the Potsdamer station beside a train that was to take him to Basle, Switzerland, for a meeting of the Bank for International Settlements.

Fifty-two ship companies operating under the flags of fourteen nations are supporting the United States Public Health Service in its efforts in New York to prevent the spread of disease by eliminating breeding spots for rats on their ships, according to Surgeon General Hugh S. Cumming.

Study of the plans for the $4,500,000 opera house to be erected in Rockefeller Centre indicates that in the new quarters an organized effort will be made to popularize opera and to attract a larger patronage from the public generally.
MILWAUKEE, April 9 (AP). -- For the first time in twenty-eight years a Wisconsin delegation to the Republican National Convention will be dominated by the Conservative faction of the party.

WASHINGTON. UNDER the provisions of the tax bill which recently left the House of Representatives for the Senate, the American public -- assuming that the bill goes through -- will become accustomed to another postage stamp.

Discussions between Samuel Insull, chairman for the Middle West Utilities Company, and Owen D. Young, chairman of the General Electric Company, of plans for a reorganization of the Insull utility system occupied the centre of the financial stage during the greater part of last week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES article by Mr. Callender on the subject of the Memel controversy was very much, appreciated by me and undoubtedly by many other readers. I should like to mention a few facts of clarifying nature.

THE Paris Opera has been saved by the offer of its 800 artists and employes to accept reductions in their salaries and wages and by economies in other directions, it is reported by The London Daily Telegraph.

Assuming that Wall Street correctly judged yesterday's stock market, the modest advance resulted largely from a bear covering movement, inspired by uneasiness over what the proposed Congressional inquiry into short selling may disclose. Brokers who, presumably, were speaking for their speculative customers professed to have no concern over the impending investigation, but at the same time they ascribed the slight rally to a small-scale retreat by timid "shorts."

MINNEAPOLIS, April 7. -- The Farmer-Labor party of Minnesota, unique during its ten-year career as a political group with no national affiliation, is on the verge of taking part in the coming Presidential campaign. Firmly convinced that Franklin D. Roosevelt is a "progressive," as that word is understood by them, they are disposed to go Democratic this Fall.

THE Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation announces the names of the five young musicians who are the successful candidates in the Foundation's eighth annual series of competitive auditions, each of whom has been awarded a New York debut recital during next season.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Possible because there is a general feeling that the Senate will make the House tax more equable, the attention of the country seemed to stray from the capital this week and take note of happenings elsewhere. For months this Interest has been concentrated on Washington.

BOSTON. April 9. -- The Braves beat the Red Sox. 2 to 1. in the first game of their annual city series today, several thousand fans having the courage to sit out in the bitter cold for nearly two hours. The National Leaguers got five hits off MacFayden, Durham and Moore, and the American Leaguers six off Betts and Frankhouse.

The mighty Sysonby, whose skeleton stands in the Museum of Natural History here, has been recalled by turf veterans as a result of the announced plan to preserve the remains of Phar Lap through taxidermy. Both thoroughbreds were cut down at the height of their careers.

EBEN M. BYERS having died because he regularly drank water overcharged with radium, we shall probably hear less of the virtues of bottled mineral waters and of thermal springs. The truth is that many natural mineral waters are slightly radioactive and that they owe what virtue they may have to their radium content.

GENEVA, April 9. -- The contrast between Secretary Stimson's previous visits to Europe in the past two years and the present one brings into high relief how the stress of economic and political difficulties has been forcing the United States to seek American salvation more and more through the League she once forced on the world and then shunned herself.

IN his excellent new book Karl Tschuppik deals mostly with General Ludendorff's military activities and with his dictatorship in the most crucial period of the world conflict. The author gives a balanced and fair account of the doings of a Highly controversial figure of contemporary history.

EDGAR WALLACE soon may be having a posthumous Spring season on Broadway. As the daily papers have recorded, Mr. Clive, having found "Shanghai Marriage" decidedly not to his liking, has cast it aside in favor of "The Ringer," now trying out in Boston.

The open-air Americanization meeting to be held at noon on April 23 in connection with the Union Square centennial celebration will be opened by Mayor Walker and former Governor Alfred E. Smith will speak, it was announced yesterday by A.M. Plyer, chairman of the committee on arrangements.

The college newspaper is primarily the product of a group of students who enjoy collecting and editing news about the college and in selling this product to any one who cares to buy it. This work is not done out of a desire to be of service to the college; it constitutes merely one of a number of extra-curricular recreational activities.

Tom Newman, England, defeated Walter Lindrum, Australia, world's champion, last night in the final session of their English billiards exhibition at Lawler Brothers' Manhattan Academy, 905 to 563, and won the match. Newman's aggregate score for twelve sessions, spread over a week, was 9,849, including 3,000 on handicap, against 9,786 for Lindrum, a difference of 63 points.

THERE will be a special performance of "The Tales of Hoffmann." with Mme. Lucrezia Bori, Mme. Lily Pons and Mme. Grace Moore in the cast, on Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Catholic Writers Guild.
CLEVELAND. April 9. -- Business In this section continues spotty and does not reveal any particular trend.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- The allowance for the veterans' expenses was approved just after an appeal for definite assurances that more than twice this sum would not be voted for the soldiers' bonus.

JOSHUA'S BUGLER. ABOUT the walls of Jericho there was once a convention of Israelites. Like many a political gathering since, it was peculiarly susceptible to promises; and if there is anything of which a politician has more than his share, it is promises.

THE customers are saying it now. In the latter part of last year, when the first 1932 model automobiles appeared, it began to be evident that the manufactures had ordered their army of motor-car products to advance. When the ranks and ranks of new models marched into the automobile show in January the evidence became indisputable.

Early in 1780, when the army had to live from hand to mouth on restricted rations, "a good many days at a time "without meat and other days without "bread," WASHINGTON wrote to one of his Generals that affairs were in so deplorable a condition "as to fill the mind with most anxious and alarming fears."

LOS ANGELES, April 9 (AP). -- William Koenig and his family were without support today because his sister, Mae Murray, the film actress, and the County Welfare Department cannot agree who should contribute funds.

Fred Cauchois annexed high scratch honors at the Travers Island trap of the New York A.C. yesterday by breaking 96 out of a possible 106 targets. J.M. Schirmer defeated N.E. Sprague in a shoot-off for the High Handicap Cup.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- Chairman White of the Chaco negotiations today asked Bolivian and Paraguayan delegates to meet with him, as the neutral representative, Monday.

Secretary of State Stimson sailed Friday for Geneva to help the Armaments Conference. He went on a French liner, which may be taken either as a reflection on the state, of our merchant marine or as an evidence of the broadening of our foreign policy, for generally our statesmen go abroad on American ships.

The achievements of various trade associations during 1931 in combating unfair practices and in improving conditions in their industries were disclosed during the week in the annual competition of the American Trade Association Executives, which was won by the American Paint and Varnish Manufacturers' Association, of which George V. Horgan is manager.

Encouragement of invention has been so potent a factor in the industrial development of the United States that dedication of the new Patent Office tomorrow must be regarded as an event of major importance. While only a small percentage of the 1,850,000 patents thus far issued are of outstanding technical merit, the eagerness and optimism with which over 100,000 Americans file applications for patents every year prove clearly that invention can be stimulated by legislation.

RADIO retailers have three hopes in which they foresec increased business activity. They hope that manufacturers in designing new sets for the 1932-33 season will concentrate on the console cabinet machines and not the midget outfits as they have in the past year.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, April 9 (Canadian Press). -- Important compromises in regard to language and citizenship and extended Parliamentary powers were reached today between the Union of South Africa and the Protectorate of Southwest Africa, administered by the union under a mandate, following discussions between Prime Minister J.B. Hertzog and an official deputation from Southwest Africa.

THIS book is a report made by members or the Dreiser committee that went down into the striking coal fields in Kentucky at the close of last year, and includes also the details of the hearing held in Washington on Feb. 14 of this year, at which time Waldo Frank and his committee gave testimony of their experiences while conducting an independent investigation.

Among the baseball veterans from last year who are again available for this season at the Riverdale Country School are the Armstrong brothers, Frank and John, who form one of the very few brother batteries in metropolitan scholastic baseball circles.

BUDAPEST, April 8. -- The suppression by the government for an indefinite period of the Social Democratic party's official organ Nepszava, the party's reply by a general strike of the printers, and the ensuing conflict mark the entry of the struggle for democracy in Hungary into its decisive stage.

The second annual Pan American Day will he observed next Thursday in many parts of this country and in Latin America, it was announced yesterday by The Pan American Society, Inc., 67 Broad Street. It was on April 14, 1890, that the resolution creating the International Bureau of American Republics, now the Pan American Union, was adopted, and the American governments have set April 14 as the day for official observance.

Insisting that under the established schedule of expenditures, State governmental costs had been cut to the bone, Governor Roosevelt said last night at a dinner of the Young Democratic Club at the Astor that a 10 to 20 per cent further slash would be possible if extreme economy were to be fixed as a definite policy.

One of the season's records was shattered and two equaled at the seventh series of Manhattan-Bronx dual meets for the senior high school swimming championships of the Public Schools Athletic League in the 75-foot pool of George Washington High, School yesterday.
There were two matters of special note yesterday at the circus. One had to do with the elephants and the other was the condition of Buck Baker, clown.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 9 (AP). -- The Alabama Supreme Court today denied rehearings to seven youthful Negroes under death sentences for attacking two white girls near Scottsboro, and their hopes were narrowed down to two possible avenues -- intervention by Governor Miller or an appeal to the United States Supreme Court.

Endorsement of the proposal for the founding of an institute of merchandising research, as made recently by Walter Hoving, executive vice president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., is expressed by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, in the latest issue of the Bulletin of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
CHICAGO, April 9 (AP). -- Once their happy bunting grounds, Illinois is rapidly becoming the scourge of bank robbers.

THE losses of the London Symphony Orchestra and its plans for the future were discused in The London Telegraph on March 19 by the secretary of the orchestra, Arthur Maney. The letter is worth republishing in full, Mr Maney wrote:

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- A tentative agreement which would reduce Federal expenditures in the fiscal year 1933 between $160,000,000 and $210,000,000 was reached at a White House conference today by President Hoover and the House Economy Committee.

THE House of Representatives has passed the Hare bill granting independence to the Philippines in eight years by an overwhelming majority. It is reasonable to think that the Senate will adopt the Hawes bill calling for independence in fifteen years.

SHANGHAI, March 17. -- Lord Lytton's blunt warning to the Chinese to the effect that "it is not possible for any nation to cultivate hatred and hostility toward other countries and then expect the League of Nations to step in and save it from the consequences of that attitude" has made a deep impression upon the Chinese leaders here and has driven the Kuomintang extremists into the sulks.

The Princeton rughy team won its second game of the season yesterday, defeating the New York Rugby Club fifteen, 12-0, at Innisfail Park. In a preliminary contest the Princeton reserves were also triumphant, over-coming the New York Rugby Club reserves, 6-0.

IF you want a book to while away a train train journey, something that can be satisfactorily read between glances out of the windows and guesses about your fellow-passengers, something whose continuity will not be too disastrously interrupted by Jolts and stops, and something that can be left behind without too much heartbreak at the end of the journey, then "This Giving in Marriage" may suit your purposes exactly.

A sedan automobile plunged over the brink of the Palisades at Alpine, N.J., late yesterday afternoon, carrying a mother, her daughter and a granddaughter to their death. The car and its passengers fell a distance estimated at 160 feet before the fall was broken, and two of the bodies, with the completely wrecked machine, continued all the way to the bottom, approximately 275 feet.

TAXATION experts in "Washington have differed sharply in their estimates of revenue to be derived from new imposts. When the House passed the tax bill on April 1, the Ways and Means Committee estimated that $1,262,900,000 additional revenue had been as sured for 1933, or $21,900,000 above the sum needed.

The examination, of John J. Raskob, chairman' of the Democratic National Committee and director of the County Trust Company, in the bank's suits against Timothy J. Mara and Patrick F. Kenny to collect on $70,000 promissory notes, was stayed yesterday in an order signed by Justice John V. McAvoy of the Appellate Division.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 7. -- "What we need is not a bread line but a friend line." Miss Dorothy C. Enderis, director of the Public School Extension Department, gave these words to Milwaukee and something real has happened. A rickety old factory building, near the City Hall and in the banking district, has been turned into a clubhouse for the unemployed.

OLD Mother Earth releases from her inscrutable depths a cataclysm which here provides the basis for a tremendous, truly hair-raising thriller. The story-an impressive feat of sustained imagination -- has an extraordinary capacity for conjuring terrific violence in nature and man's heroic struggles to survive the impact of elemental forces which seem blindly bent upon his destruction.

PARIS, March 26. -- The problem of how to re-establish stability and prosperity in Central Europe has become acute. Without entering into details. It may be said hat the deplorable financial and economic situation of the countries that formerly formed the Austro-Hungarian Empire, with Poland and Bulgaria added, is one of the essential causes of the disturbed situation in Europe.
NEW HAVEN, April 9. -- A Yale scientific expedition led by Professor Hellmut de Terra, research associate in geology, has just arrived at New Delhi, India, according to advices received today.

EXHIBITIONS of the work Honore Daumier, painting drawings, lithographs, wood engravings, portraits in clay, recur year after year, in one gallery or another, throughout Europe and America, to celebrate one phase or several phases of this extensive work, amounting in all to between 5,000 and 6,000 examples.
SEATTLE. April 9. -- The boatings of the three crews in the California-Washington regatta follow:

Marie Edelle, soprano, brought to Steinway Hall last night a recital of songs drawn discriminatingly from German lieder, modern French and Spanish schools and the pre-revolutionary Russians. "Amalie," "Liebeslauschen" and the "Didone" aria from "Metastasio" were followed by Brahms's "Ach, wende diesen Blick," "Ich muss hinaus," "Schwermut" and "Botschaft."

ALBANY, April 9. -- Governor Roosevelt signed today the bill providing for a recodification of the century-old town law, although he commented that it "falls far short of the reorganization, the simplification and the lessening of the cost of the town and county government for which I have striven for the last four years."

Comparisons of the earnings and disbursements of the four Eastern trunk lines in 1931 show that these carriers made substantial reductions in expenditures to compensate for declines in revenues. It was thought the percentage declines in expenditures for 1931 compared with 1930 were the more abrupt for the reason that in 1930 the railroads made an effort to continue disbursements at as near normal levels as possible in order to maintain business activity.

LONDON, March 20. THERE has been this week but one play for me to see. If it proves to be a failure, as I am afraid it must, it will have been nevertheless an uncommonly interesting one, for it poses half a dozen of the questions that most vex the critical playgoer.

Although railroad executives declined to comment publicly on the report of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee favoring legislation to repeal the recapture of earnings clause of the transportation act they pointed out yesterday that this repeal was urged by the Association of Railway Executives, representing about 95 per cent of the railroads.

NEWARK, N.J., April 9 (AP). -- Disbursement of $27,244,111 in mortgage loans in the first three months of 1932 was announced today by the Prudential Insurance Company of America. Of 4,855 individual loans, 3,146 were on dwellings and 150 on apartment houses.

MIAMI, April 8. -- Not nearly so bad as the pessimists predicted and not half so good as professional optimists foretold, Florida's Winter season has now been inventoried and found to be about 70 per cent of normal in the number of tourists.
LET us either tax for revenue or let's go to the other extreme and confiscate these large holdings and invest them in semi-public enterprises.

Gifts to Columbia University amounting to $36,643.41 were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler. The Carnage Corporation, which gave $15.000 for the support of the Institute of International Affairs, was the largest contributor.

FAIRLY good gains were reported in retail trade during the week, and business, in some instances, exceeded pre-holiday volume. Weather was counted the best influence on the side of rising sales, since the general situation remained much the same and security prices sagged.
DETROIT, Mich., April 9. -- It was announced officially today that William G. Woolfolk had been elected president and a director of the Detroit City Gas Company to succeed R.B. Brown of Milwaukee.

THE producers have come considerably closer to the brand of comedy suitable to Edna May Oliver in "Ladies of the Jury" a film version of the play of the same name in which the late Mrs. Fiske appeared more than two years ago -- than they did in her previous venture, "Fanny Foley Herself."

IN a "disclaimer" which prefaces their work, the authors tell us that "this is a very unlearned book." thereby disarming the critical reader. The engineer familiar with the history of his profession wishes they had been Just a little learned.
WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Little improvement in economic conditions in markets for American commodities abroad was reported in the weekly survey made public today by the Department of Commerce.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 9. -- Charles Mower, veteran designer, with Miss Lorna Whittelsey as crew, easily captured all three races in the regatta of the Frostbite Yacht Club held off the Larchmont Yacht Club today. Racing his own dinghy, the Snowbird, Mower won by wide margin in each event.

LONDON, April 9. -- Andrew W. Mellon, the new United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James's, accompanied by Sir John Simon, the British Foreign Secretary, motored this morning to Windsor Castle, where the Ambassador presented his credentials to King George.

IN his annual report, published last week, Police Commissioner Mulrooney dealt with the work of the Crime Prevention Bureau and asserted that there is "a growing appreciation of the need for reaching offenders early and a realization that if the major offense is to be prevented the roots of juvenile delinquency must be eradicated."

An inlaid and decorated mahogany and satinwood pianoforte, made by John Geib Son, New York, 1805, was bought yesterday by James W. Loewy for $3,350 at the third and closing session of the sale of American furniture of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, collected by the late Louis Guerineau Myers at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

THE recent realization of the originating and creative part that the Near and Middle East has played in human history is one of the most significant cultural facts of our day, recalling the Renaissance discovery of classical civilizations.

The threat to the success of the design-protection movement in the silk trade, occasioned by the withdrawal of some printers from the agreement to print only registered designs, found retailers rallying to the support of the movement during the week.

Since college papers are the most powerful, and in most cases, the chief mediums through which undergraduate opinion can be expressed, their duties and responsibilities are of great importance. To interpret correctly the position and importance of a college paper it is first necessary to examine the structure of the college administration.

Led by United States Government bonds, which continued strong, the listed bond market showed rallying tendencies yesterday. Numerous domestic corporation bonds and foreign loans recovered a point or two of the previous day's losses, although many established further new lows for the year, particularly in the home group.

WHEN the League of Nations was organized in 1919 Sir Arthur Salter became director of its Economic Section. He served for eleven years in this position, sharing at first band in most of the attempts made to unravel the economic consequences of the peace by international action, whether through the Reparation Commission, the Supreme Economic Council, the "pleasure resort" conferences at Spa and Genoa, or the meetings of the League itself.

March, usually the peak month, for factory employment, showed a decrease of 1 per cent in employment and of less than 1 per cent in payrolls, according to Miss Frances Perkins, State Industrial Commissioner, who said this was the largest February-to-March decline ever recorded for New York State factories.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 9. -- Paul Edward Gardner won the high scratch cup at the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. He took the shoot by returning a card of 47. T. Bedell had a full card of 50 targets to capture the handicap honor.

PARIS, March. 21 BEFORE you read these, lines, you will have received the latest news from the front, and you will know where things stand in the theatre war in Paris. The managers certainly have a strong case.

JOHN BARRYMORE and Dolores Del Rio will appear in the main parts in a RKO-Radio picture, so far unnamed, according to an announcement by David O. Selznick. Mr. Barrymore is at present busy with "State's Attorney," while Miss Del Rio is working in "The Bird of Paradise."
CHICAGO, April 9 (AP). -- Will Harridge, American League president, today made the following statement on the 1932 season:

ONE way to avoid augmenting the grave situation that has risen from the unemployment of hundreds of musicians is to limit qualitatively the number of students trying to enter music as a professional career, said Ernest Hutcheson, dean of the Juilliard School of Music, in a recent discussion of this problem.

THE decision of the New York Central Lines and the Pennsylvania Railroad to cut the time of the Twentieth Century Limited and the Broadway Limited from twenty hours to eighteen hours not only shows that our railroads can speed up their service, presumably with safety, but also raises the question of ultimate railroad speed in passenger service.

A young oak was planted yesterday afternoon on, the grounds of the American Museum of Natural History in memory of the late Mrs. James Robert McKee by the members of the New York Bird and Tree Club under whose auspices she j headed and completed the planting of nearly 20,000 fruit trees in the Chateau-Thierry sector of France several years ago.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 9. -- With Ed Schwab leading the attack with four goals, the Princeton varsity lacrosse team defeated the Lehigh twelve today, 15 to 1. Wildman scored the only Lehigh goal in the second half.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- A collection of twenty-four etchings by Philip Harris Giddens of New York City is attracting the interest and favorable comment of visitors to the exhibition which was opened last Tuesday night at the Sears-Roebuck Art Galleries in Connecticut Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The present generation has seen popular interest In scientific discovery grow as never before. Outstanding among the scientific influences upon modern thought have been the evolutionary hypothesis, the conditioned reflex, or, as it is better termed, the conditional response, and psychoanalysis.
WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Some industries may look to youth for leadership, but in the United States Senate, "the greatest deliberative body in the world," they still like their leaders seasoned.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- A prophetic pre-view of the Republican and Democratic National Conventions in June was given by the Gridiron Club tonight at its annual Spring dinner, in the course of which the virtues and foibles of the nation's leaders were cast into high relief in a review of the contemporary scene.

BOSTON, April 8. A the New England mother said of her household, the Boston theatres are "all comings and goings." The goings have included "If Booth Had Missed." which vanished after nine performances and the setting of a new record at the Shubert for scanty audiences.

With stocks rallying moderately as uneasy speculators covered their short commitments, the New York Stock Exchange proceeded yesterday with feverish haste to assemble the vast amount of statistical evidence which Richard Whitney, its president, has been directed to produce at the opening tomorrow in Washington of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee's market investigation.
HOLLYWOOD, Cal. GOOD stories and good writers first; then good directors, good artists and proper assembly and you have good pictures."

WILMINGTON, Del., April 9. -- Mismanagement of the affairs of the International Match Corporation and associated companies by Ivar Kreuger, Swedish capitalist who committed suicide recently, is alleged in a bill of complaint filed in Chancery Court here today asking for appointment of a receiver for the corporation.

OUT of the jungle by way of Hollywood -- that is, by easy stages -- came Noel Coward ten days ago with, as the public prints were quick to say, a newly completed comedy: the one in which, under Max Gordon's non-musical aegis, Mr. Coward and Lynn Fontanne and Alfred Lunt will join their friendly hands and bright talents next January, first in New York and then in London.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 9. -- The Crystal Room Assembly in the Homes stead this evening marked another colorful event in the calendar of the Spring colony and was preceded by as number of formal dinner parties.

MANY millions of Americans are listening in. They often hear "The Star-Spangled Banner" and wonder if they should stand until the loud-speaker completes the selection, no matter whether at dinner, visiting with friends or playing bridge.

PARIS, April 8. -- The election campaign that has begun in France promises to be full of interest, for it will be full of fight. When the French electors were called on four years ago to decide who should represent them they could scarcely distinguish among the parties which were seeking their suffrage.

Within the next few days tennis officials will put Into effect plans for the Wightman Cup matches that are to be played at Wimbledon June 10 and 11. The task will be somewhat simpler than it was a year ago when the United States played host, for the chief work will centre about the naming of a team.

AFTER twenty years of more or less quiet In the realm of city government, tales of graft, corruption and Inefficiency again reach us; and, inevitably, these are followed by proposals for reform, public discussions, oratory, resolutions, commissions, reform associations and the subsequent processes of remedial treatment.

The Democratic State Committee will meet Friday at Albany to elect delegates at large and alternates at large to the Democratic National Convention and to choose new officers of the committee. The call for the meeting was issued yesterday by James A. Farley, State Chairman and manager of Governor Roosevelt's campaign for the Democratic nomination for President.

It is a far cry from the days when individual athletic clubs sent over teams that formed America's representation in the Olympic Games to the present system when the rigors of even the semi-final tryouts are so great that scores of stars will be unable to hurdle the barrier of a preliminary trial.

Copyright, 1932. by N.A.N.A., Inc. CHICAGO, April 9. -- Both the Agricultural marketing act and the Farm Board since their enactment have been the targets of outrageous misrepresentation. Some of the misrepresentation has been mere partisan politics, but most of it comes from sheer self-interest.

DO our militant feminists realize how momentous a victory for their sex has been won on the nineteenth floor of the new Waldorf-Astoria, where women cooks have been admitted to the culinary staff of the hotel?

THE free concerts of the Goldman Band under Edwin Franko Goldman will begin June 13 and continue ten weeks, the last concert being scheduled for Aug. 18. The Central Park concerts will take place, as formerly, on the Mall on Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Sunday evenings; those at the New York University campus, University Heights, on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday evenings.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 9. -- City College of New York offered little resistance to the powerful Johns Hopkins lacrosse team and went down to a 14-to-1 defeat today. A steady and chilling rain converted the field into a quagmire and made the going under foot extremely hazardous.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, April 5. -- Juan B. Huyke, former Commissioner of Education, has recently written a most interesting criticism of American administration in Porto Rico in his column of comment in El Mundo, in which he expresses the opinion that the administration of Theodore Roosevelt was "disastrous to American ideals in Porto Rico."

IT is from external rather than internal evidence that the production of the Mexican ballet "H.P." by the Philadelphia Grand Opera Company on the last day of March must be adjudged an important event. There is copious evidence of this character.

The mortgage for $290,000 held by Spear Securities Corporation from the 791 Park Avenue Corporation, Joseph Polstein, president, on the fourteen-story apartment building on the southeast corner of ParK Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street, has been extended to March 11, 1934, at 6 per cent, and will be amortized $5,000 quarterly, this being subordinate to a first mortgage for $1,045,000 on the property.

LONDON, April 9 (AP). -- The Sunday Express said tonight it under-stood a delegation of Yugoslav Deputies, led by a former Cabinet Minister, was coming to London to offer the throne of Yugoslavia to Prince Arthur of Connaught, nephew of King George.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 9 (AP). -- Kentucky swung into the Roosevelt column today. Its Democratic county conventions in ninety-six of the 120 counties voted for Roosevelt -- supporting delegates to the State convention to be held here on Tuesday.

Rules similar to those governing the Harms worth Trophy contests are being drawn up by J.W. Shillan in London for an international outboard motor boat race, according to an announcement by Charles F. Chapman of New York, chairman of the National Outboard Racing Commission.
BALTIMORE, April 9. -- William H. Brown, member of one of the oldest Maryland families, died today at his home here. His age was 78.

OTTAWA, April 6. -- The Imperial Conference to be held at Ottawa in July is now a subject of intermittent discussion, flavored with the spices of controversy, in the Canadian press. It la also being freely discussed in political and business circles.

MR STRONG'S title seems chosen for these particular times, in which there is so much written that is not common sense about poetry. His book is, indeed, an attempt to restore poetry to its position of importance "among all activities of mind and body."

DOMINANT among the impressions of the National Aircraft Show of 1932, closing at Detroit tonight, is that of courage. It is the confident courage of a young industry undaunted by its experience of inflation and mushroom growth followed by two lean years of general slack business in which only the continual forging ahead of air transport has sounded a note of real encouragement.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh revealed last night that he had paid $50,000 to the criminals who kidnapped his infant son but that they had failed to return the child as they had promised.

FROM time to time during the past eighteen months budgets of news relating to the recording activities going forward in Russia have reached this department. Studios and factories found a place in the general industrial plan, and ambitious schedules for large-scale production were prepared.

APRIL 15 marks the twentieth anniversary of the greatest sea disaster of modern times, the sinking of the liner Titanic off the Grand Banks of Newfoundland. Her passengers and crew numbered 2,340; of these only 705 were rescued by the liner Carpathia, while 1,635 went down with the ship.

WHAT should be done with the public domain? That question is uppermost in the minds of both Public Lands Committees of Congress at the present time. Chairmen Nye and Evans of the respective Senate and House Public Lands Committees, upon request, have introduced duplicate bills carrying out the recommendations of the President's committee on the conservation and administration of the public domain.

THE management of the Carlton Hotel in Amsterdam has proposed a prize competition for a popular composition, according to a cable dispatch received recently from that city. The piece should be a waltz or similar light number for small orchestra, to last from four to eight minutes.

PRAISE THE LORD!" tells the story of the Crima family, emigrants from the Middle West to Los Angeles, destroyed by a religious emotionalism springing from a temple conducted by a clever woman evangelist. The temple and Sister Teressa, the evangelist, are obviously drawn from life, and the members of the Crims family are convincing specimens of their class, though they are but dimly outlined as individuals.

THERE was no radio in those days, nor even a telegraph wire, yet it seems certain that the historic shot fired at Lexington actually was heard around the world. Not at the instant of firing, of course. Then it took time for notices of revolutions and declarations of Independence to reach the ears for which they were intended.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- With a warm handclasp President Hoover rejoiced today with two veterans of the "60s -- one blue, one gray -- in the well-healed scars of the Civil War.

To Yale and the Lawrenceville School went the first of the 1932 national indoor polo championships at Squadron A Armory last night. Yale overcame a ten-goal handicap to defeat Army in the intercollegiate final, 16 1/2 to 13, successfully defending its title, and Lawrenceville defeated Hun School, 7 1/2 to 6, for the interscholastic championship.

LONDON, March 21, 1932. SIBELIUS'S music is growing in favor with the London public. In the course pf a few weeks we have had performances of three of his symphonies by British conductors in touch with public opinion.

In more comfortable times there was a romantic fashion of calling the United States Government an immense "business corporation." To it and its branches was to be given a "business administration." The phrase, seriously meant and a thousand times repeated, was profoundly satiric on view of the practice.

A festival of Greek games, staged in the manner of ancient Hellas, will take place next Sunday afternoon, April 16, in the gymnasium of Barnard Hall, Barnard College, it was announced yesterday. Three hundred and twenty girls, chosen from the freshman and sophomore classes, will take part in the games, which will consist of competitions in song, lyric, dance and athletic skill.

To the Dramatic Editor: If you were to examine the newspaper files of the first week of April, 1922, you would find this: As regards economic conditions, things were very bad; in fact, we were in the midst of a depression (one of the cyclic depressions economists have familiarized us with lately).

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- A Republican member of Congress, Representative Maas of Minnesota, charged today that the national inland waterway program, on which he said President Hoover "sold himself to the electorate of the mid-West in 1928, seems to have been junked by him."

To the Radio Editor of The New York Times: Using a two-tube receiver made in 1929, equipped with two UX-199 dry cell tubes, I have succeeded in hearing and confirming broadcast band stations located on the far sides of the Atlantic and Pacific. In addition, I have heard island stations of both oceans, the countries of South America, and all surrounding countries of North America.
Already one of the fastest of all games, basketball will be speeded still further as a result of action taken by the joint basketball committee at its annual meeting at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.

VATICAN CITY, April 9 (AP). -- A check for $1,100,000, representing contributions of American Catholics, was presented to Pope Pius XI this morning by Mgr. William Quinn of New York, director of the Organization for the Propagation of the Faith.

RADIO listeners in tune with WEAT's network will be given a birdseye view of the transcontinental air mail routes tonight at 11:30 o'clock. Pilots of three planes will carry announcers and short-wave apparatus with them when they take off from the Cleveland airport.

CHICAGO, April 9. -- Dr. A.E. Budde, 48 years old, physician and surgeon, of North Chicago, was kidnapped from his home early this morning. Lake County officials reported that his wife received a letter from him this afternoon in his own handwriting, assuring her that he would "be home late tonight or tomorrow" and adding:

ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 8. -- Four years of litigation that won for Rochester the right to flood historic Honeoye Valley in order to assure a sixty-year water supply, may have gone for naught if a taxpayers' protest that has split the community into two even camps delays the project unduly.

W. Schmonses has sold a brick dwelling at 133 Senator Street, between Colonial Road and Ridge Boulevard, through the Bulkley Horton Company, which also leased the four-story brick building at 473-75 Clermont Avenue, between Fulton Street and Atlantic Avenue, to the Dart Moving Company.

CHICAGO April 8. -- One of the problems over which educators have puzzled, but which has not been met satisfactorily, is that of the precocious student in the university. Sometimes four and five years younger than the average student and frequently smaller in stature, the gifted boy or girl has been something of a misfit in university life.
WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Important representatives of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt will attend the Jefferson Day dinner in Washington on the night of April 13 in the capacity of watchful observers.

LONDON. A LITTLE workshop in London is one of the most vigilantly guarded places in the metropolis at present. It is watched day and night by special policemen, for it holds one of the world's most priceless treasures.

AS preparations for the charity carnival of 1932 enter the final weeks, much effort is being directed toward the proper casting for the elaborate pageant, "Adventure," which is to feature the event. The carnival is to be held on the night of May 3 in Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Judson Health Centre.

SAN FRANCISCO. April 8. -- Application of the chain-store idea to higher education in California was the subject of an investigation by a commission of seven eminent educators which has been holding a series of hearings here and in Sacramento under the direction of Dr. Henry A. Suzzallo of the Carnegie Foundation.

The dangers of monopoly in industry were discussed by economists yesterday at a meeting of the League for Industrial Democracy in addresses on the subject, "Concentration in American Industry: What Are Its Implications?"
PARIS, April 9. -- The French press carried on today with even more bitterness the attacks on Germany for "wrecking" the attempt In London to reach an agreement on aiding five Danubian States.

LONG BEACH, L.I., April 9. -- Miss Margaret Decker of the Women's Swimming Association annexed the national A.A.U. junior 500-yard free style championship today in the pool of the Sea Breeze Beach Club, showing the way to Miss Evelyn Fogler, a club-mate, in the final of an exciting race.

The football teams of Columbia and Manhattan gave a demonstration of the new rules yesterday at Baker Field before more than 200 college and high school athletic officials. All of the changes that were brought about at the rules committee's meeting last Winter were put into practice, with most of the interest being centred on the kick-off.

IN his latest book John Owen, the author of "The Shepherd an the Child," has produced a really beautiful piece of work. He has combined and contrasted, with a terrifying clarity and calm, the beauty which the human soul is able to perceive in nature and the horrors which are revealed when it gaze is turned in upon itself.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The executive board of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union voted today in favor of resisting "with every means and resource at the command of the union" an alleged attempt by employers in the coat and suit industry in New York City to introduce piece-work in place of week-work.

A local clearing house for exchange on import and export orders was suggested last week by economists consulted by the American Manufacturers' Export Association's committee studying the "aid to export" provisions of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation law.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9. -- Rutgers won a sensational extra-period lacrosse match from Perm on Museumf Field today, 8 fo 7. Metzger tallied the winning goal for the Scarlet, making the second victory over Penn in two years.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 9. -- Under a bill approved today by Governor Roosevelt, the State Athletic Commission no longer will have jurisdiction over bona fide amateur boxing, sparring and wrestling bouts, even though an admission is charged.
To the Editor of The New YorK Times: I was much interested in a news dispatch entitled "Churches Rap Marital Edict" which appeared in THE TIMES.

FIVE methods are generally followed in applying irrigation water in farms and ranches of the West, according to a booklet recently issued by the Bureau of Reclamation. The scheme to be followed depends principally upon the topography, the character of the surface soil and subsoil, the kind of crop to be irrigated and the quantity of water to be used.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 9. -- William Steiner of New York City finished first in the initial running of the Governor's Marathon from Schenectady to Albany today. Steiner ran the fifteen miles in 1 hour, 24 minutes and 7 seconds to defeat Charles Porter of Brooklyn by about a yard.

LONDON, April 8. -- In the next few days a quiet and retiring old gentleman from Washington will discover how difficult it is to be an American Ambassador and lead the life of a private citizen at the same time. For the British people are simply bursting to honor him and their hospitality is going to put his shyness to a supreme test.

Problems confronting the furniture trade will be discussed here Tuesday when more than 200 furniture producers of the Eastern States attend a sectional meeting called by the National Association of Furniture Manufacturers at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The practice of guaranteeing prices to buyers, an innovation at the January furniture trade shows, will be one of the principal topics of the gathering.

SHANGHAI, March 17. -- The reshuffling of China's immense domestic loans and the part, which the country's leading bankers have played in rearranging interest and sinking fund terms indicate that the banking group will hereafter be more of a power than ever before, and may be able successfully to quell the ever-present readiness of the leaders to indulge in civil warfare.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, April 9. -- Government forces under Colonel Astudillos captured Fort Punta Piedras this morning in a surprise attack after a forced march through the inundated marshes.

One of the finest examples of Japanese brocade in the Occident, from the standpoint of both design and technique, has been acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in a group of Japanese No costumes just placed on exhibition in the room of recent accessions.

Charging that Governor Roosevelt's recent radio attack on the Reconstruction Finance Corporation might have the effect of discouraging the small home owner, and declaring that as a member of the Democratic party he was embarrassed when the Governor "departed so far from the facts," George V. McLaughlin, former State Banking Commissioner, addressed a letter to the Governor pointing out what he contends are the facts regarding the operations of the board.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Business in the week ended April 2 showed a further slight retrogression, although the intensive sales campaigns inaugurated in the automobile field are expected to be strengthening influences in the weeks ahead, according to the weekly survey by the Department of Commerce.

DETROIT, April 8. -- Michigan's Legislature has met in special session at the call of Governor Wilber N. Brucker, who has asked it to help solve the problem of county and municipal finances. It has studied this question for two weeks without making much progress, for it is being pulled this way and hauled that way by conflicting interests.

The number of orders received from out-of-town stores last week was comparatively gratifying, the total appearing to have exceeded that for the Easter business, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.
