WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Cooperation by the United States, Great Britain, India and Mexico would be sufficient to stabilize "silver to gold at any ratio which the parties concerned regarded as reasonable," in the opinion of Robert S. Horna, former British Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Leopold S. Amery, a member of Parliament.

A considerably more cheerful aspect was presented In the week-end markets yesterday. Stocks reversed their downward movement, bonds steadied perceptibly, and wheat rose with some emphasis. Retreat of speculators for the decline no doubt accounted for much of this; in fact, Wall Street professed to be convinced that the day's abrupt recovery in stocks was occasioned by the announcement that Congressional investigation of the methods of current Stock Exchange speculation was to begin at once.

GRETA GARBO, one of the five stars in the screen version of Vicki Baum's "Grand Hotel," which opens at the Astor Theatre Tuesday evening, was once salesgirl in a Stockholm department store. Her name was Greta Gustaffon and she was 14 when her father died.

SPERLI THE CLOCKMAKER lived in the Black Forest and made cuckoo clocks for a living, clocks that not only told the hour but played little tunes into which it seemed as though the clockmaker managed to put all the forest sounds that he knew and loved.

TORONTO, April 9. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs brought the Stanley Cup back to this city after a lapse of ten years by defeating the New York Rangers tonight by the score of 6 to 4. The game was the third of the cup series, which decides the hockey championship of the world, and was the third straight triumph for the speedy local sextet.

A dawn on April 14 last year the usual donkeys trotted into Madrid with fresh beans and live chickens. Short men in hip boots gave the Calle Alcala its morning bath, and nuns. In thick blue and starched white, paced around the garden or a new brick convent, their rosaries swinging a heavy cross against their knees at every step.
WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The Senate stock market investigation starting Monday has the approval of President Hoover, Senator Walcott stated today.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 9. -- The James Madison High School baseball team defeated the Princeton freshmen today, 9 to 4. Terjesen, school-boy third basemen, led the hitters with four hits, Including a home run and a triple. Bernstein went the route for the visitors.

ERNEST NEWMAN, writing in The London Sunday Times of recent date, begins with a remark which applies to musical conditions in other countries as well as England. He remarks that music there is in "one of its periodical messes."

BOSTON, April 7. -- A few days ago the Massachusetts Senate adopted, 19 to 9, an order requiring the opinions of the justices of the Supreme Judicial Court on three questions of law pertaining to the examination of candidates for admission to the bar. The significance of these questions will best be understood in the light of a recital of the facts which induced this action.

Until "spectator of all ages" realize that they are part of every athletic contest they witness, and that they, too, are just as much bound by the code of sportsmanship as the actual players, the progress necessary to decent conduct of competitive sports will not be made, Prank S. Hackett, headmaster of the Riverdale Country Day School, declared yesterday at the spectator sportsmanship luncheon in the Janet Drew Restaurant, 1 University Place.

The first instalment of the Stats income tax is due on Friday. Because of the increase in rates, payment in three instalments is permitted this year for the first time. Fifty per cent of the tax is due on or before April 15, another 25 per cent on or before July 15, and the remaining 25 per cent on or before Oct. 15.

THE long-smoldering controversy over the "soldiers' bonus" will flare this week in Washington, when the Ways and Means Committee of the House takes up the proposal for immediate redemption of veterans' adjusted service certificates.

THERE have been many accounts of the mountaineers of the Appalachian Range, some published within recent months: but there have been few chronicles of the Ozarks, that more or less isolated group that extends its tentacles into the three States of Arkansas, Missouri and Oklahoma.
WINDSOR, Ont., April 9 (AP). -- The Windsor Bulldogs outskated the London Tecumsehs tonight, 4 to 1, end went into the lead in the International Hockey League's championship playoff series.

MANHASSET, L.I., April 9. -- Scores of carpenters, painters, interior decorators, landscape artists, gardeners, masons and tile-setters are preparing the new Munsey Park Golf Club and the eighteen-hole course and tennis courts for opening on Memorial Day.

Announcement has been made, by the executive committee of the academic council in charge of the awards, of the prize winners in the seventh annual Intercollegiate Current Events Contest sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES in twenty of the leading educational institutions of the country.

THE Atlantic novel prize of $10,000, offered jointly by the Atlantic Monthly Press and Little. Brown Co., has been awarded to Ann Bridge for her novel, "Peking Picnic." which will be published in September by Little, Brown Co. in Boston and by Chatto Windus in London.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 9. -- Lehigh's track and field team experienced little difficulty in defeating Dickinson in the opening dual meet of the season today, 90 1/2 to 35 1/2.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., April 9. -- The lacrosse team of Swarthmore College, which won the Middle Atlantic States championship last year by beating New York University in the final game of the season, handed the Violets a 9-1 setback today.

LONDON, April 9 (AP). -- Everton virtually clinched first place in the first division of the English Football League today by defeating Leicester City, 1 to 0, to take a 5-point lead over the second-place team.

A wide variety of topics will be taken up in city pulpits today "Clergymen will discuss what remedy Christianity has for virtually every human problem. Special emphasis will be placed on crime and the solution of economic problems. The chapel choir of West Point Military Academy will sing jointly with the choir of St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, at the morning service.

In sympathy with a sharp upturn in wheat yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved 12 to 15 points in the most active trading in several days. There was heavy short covering both here and abroad. After having reached on Friday the lowest figures in several months, the list gained more than a quarter cent at one time and July ended the week at 6.31 cents a pound, unchanged from the previous Saturday.

JUDGING from the large number of boxes and seats which have been secured for the performance of Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey's Circus on Friday afternoon at Madison Square Garden in aid of the Society of St. Johnland, the funds of the organization will be greatly augmented.

Liszt's "Faust" symphony, preceded by Beethoven's "Egmont" overture, made the program of the last New York concert of this season by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, and also served, with Beethoven's overture, as a musical observation of the Goethe commemoration.

A possibility that the experiment in "progressive education" at Public School 41 in Greenwich Village, affectionately called the "Little Red School House," may be continued, was seen yesterday in efforts by a group of parents to evolve some plan by which the work may be carried on after June when the financial support which has been given for the past four years will cease.

Textile High School of Manhattan won the city P. S. A. L. senior high school basketball championship for the first time by conquering James Monroe High of the Bronx, 23 to 17, before 3,000 yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory as the curtain was lowered on the scholastic court campaign.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 9. -- Facing a knockout before the pounding fists of Joe Moran of Syracuse. Dennis Flynn, crack middleweight from Loyola of the South, called on his ring generalship to bring him a victory tonight.

TULSA, Okla., April 9 (AP). -- Officers of the Gypsy-Gulf Oil Companies announced this afternoon that they would post a 15-cent price advance for crude oil, meeting the increase of the Standard of Indiana, effective at 7 A.M. on Monday. The' top price will be $1 a barrel.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 9 (AP). -- The National Collegiate Athletio Association's Olympic committee announced tonight a squad of thirty-four college boxers, from which list about twenty will be chosen to represent the association in the Olympic tryouts at San Francisco, July 20, 21 and 23.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 9. -- With a strong offensive during the closing minutes the Mount Washington Club lacrosse team defeated the Naval Academy this afternoon in the latter's first tilt of the season, 5 to 4. The game was played in a driving rain.

INTERESTTNG touches of elegance from many periods of the past are being added to interiors to create a luxurious background for present day activities. This trend is seen, for example, in the amplitude of curtain material. In a revival of the use of hand-painted wall papers, and In examples of furniture of the courts of Louis XV and Louis XVI, where suavity of line and accents of carving give even a footstool a distinguished appearance.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., April 9. -- Robin Hood and his merry bowmen, King Richard of the Lion Heart, his evil brother, Prince John; fair Marion, the outlaw's love; Friar Tuck and the others of their gay company will reappear from the shadowy past on the Bryn Mawr College campus on May 6 and 7.

THE Disarmament Conference, which began its deliberations on Feb. 2 to the sound of gunfire in the Far East, meets again tomorrow after a three-week recess over the Easter holiday. The world is charged with expectancy over the outcome; for, though the guns have ceased firing, temporarily at least, it is still 1932 in the third year of a devastating depression.

Cruise ships are using liquor to attract passengers in allegedly unfair competition with the American hotel trade, the current issue of The Allertonian charges, in an editorial discussion of Winter vacations at sea. The magazine is published by the operators of the Allerton club residences.

The rugby influence in the sports of American colleges is making itself felt in the West. From the Eastern seaboard the game has reached the Middle West, teams having been formed at Iowa and Chicago universities. This brings the total of colleges playing the game on a more or less formal footing to eight.

IN its exhibition of historical costumes, recently opened to the public, the Museum of the City of New York has invented a technique which involves imagination and humor. The clothes of former days are arranged so that one can tell how they looked in their prime.

The Jamaica High School riflemen, P.S.A.L. champions three years carried off the Winchester Trophy with 1,063 points yesterday, topping the eighteen teams competing at the General Wingate Athletic Field rifle range. The competition was the third of a series of four to determine the Spring P.S.A.L. championship sextet.

HAVANA, April 5. -- Cuba claims complete jurisdiction over coastal waters within a twelve-mile limit, according to a recent decision by the Audiencia Court of Havana in a suit brought by the Empresa Naviera de Cuba, S.A., against Walter Runciman Co., Ltd., of England, in the matter of the collision of the steamship Hallmoor and the Cuban vessel Antolina del Collado on Oct. 15, 1930, which resulted in the sinking of the latter vessel.

Leasing and readjustments of leasehold holdings as shown by the many records of that nature being filed dally la the Registers office held a feature position last week in the generally quiet realty situation.

DALLAS, Texas, April 9 (AP). -- "Ultra-dry" Texas Democrats, credited with carrying Texas for Hoover in 1928, today failed in the first round of an effort to prohibit the State Executive Committee from requiring voters in precinct conventions to give a loyalty pledge.
MEXICO CITY, April 9 -- A decree issued last night made important modifications in the regulations governing the importation of parts and materials for the construction of automobiles.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 9. -- A party plank declaring that a rising tide of sentiment demanding the repeal of the prohibition laws called for a radical change in strategy of all organizations favoring enforcement of prohibition, was adopted unanimously today at the convention of the National Prohibition party of New Jersey held in the First Presbyterian Church here.

A major portion of the interest in the city's public school athletic activities will be shifted to outdoor, sports this week.Three P.S.A.L. senior high school outdoor championship tournaments are scheduled to open -- the annual baseball, lacrosse and handball competitions.

FASHION, like a boxer, is making its real hit this season above the waistline. Two moods are deftly interwoven to bring about the Interesting silhouette that characterizes the Spring mode-the classicism of the Empire and the romanticism of the mid-Victorian era.

IN "Bright Skin" Mrs. Peterkin has made an attempt to repeat the episodic pattern of "Black April," though on a diminished scale, and the book will suffer, perhaps unjustly, from the inevitable comparison with the earlier work. Yet for all the similarity of pattern, there is a difference in intention between the two books.

The round table conference on regulation of public utilities ended Its two-day session at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday afternoon with a split over the report of its policy committee, which declared that utility regulation had failed to protect the investor in utility securities, failed to obtain rate reductions for the consumer, and to safeguard the credit of the utility companies themselves.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- At the close of the White House conference today of House members with the President and his aides on the subject of national economy, this statement was issued: As a result...

THERE is a rumor in Washington that President Hoover has been indulging in secret practice for the ceremony of throwing out the first hall to open the major league season tomorrow in Clark Griffith's ball park. A wild throw by President Hoover would be hailed by Democrats as another administration error in these depressing times.

STUDENTS of the Neighborhood Playhouse Studios will give a special performance of "The Nursery Maid of Heaven," with Miss Georgia Graham in the leading role, tonight at the Little Theatre for friends of the organization. After the performance there will be a reception at the headquarters of the studios at 441 Madison Avenue.

WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART -- Exhibition of paintings, water-colors and prints comprising Part II of the museum's permanent collection. Opened last Tuesday and remaining through April 27. Reviewed April 5 and on this page.

COUNTERFEIT coins whose value increases with the disclosure of the fraud perpetrated are not common in the banking world. Recently, however, such a case came to light in London. Among a parcel of coins bought as gold was a clever imitation of a sovereign of 1863.
With the Paumonok Handicap as the feature, the metropolitan racing Season will open Saturday at Jamaica with every expectation of a successful meeting.
WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Carl D. Meinhardt of Brockport, N.Y., Consul at Tsinan, has been assigned as Consul at Shanghai.

Members of the "Harris" party at Columbia University claimed a victory yesterday afternoon when a statement, signed by two members of the faculty, announced that an impartial investigation of conditions in the John Jay dining room would be made by a committee of faculty members and students.

THE part played by the Indian during the Colonial period of American history has never been studied adequately. His influence upon the development of the English Colonies and the effect of the impact of European civilization, upon him have been surmised, but await thorough examination.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 9. -- The thwarted revolutionary movement which attempted to overthrow the existing civil administration is believed to have died out. The feeling of ominous tension throughout the country has been relieved as a result of the prompt establishment of a state of siege for two months.

TOKYO, March 26 (Canadian Press by Mail). -- Banks in Japan are feeling more than ever the strain of the continued industrial and commercial depression. This is shown in the large reductions in deposits and loans of leading banking institutions, while many smaller ones have gone to the wall, especially in Central Japan in and around the big city of Nagoya.

THE familiar formula of Western fiction is largely evident in this new Kyne novel, but there are a few departures from the standardized which save the action from being too readily foreseen and lend a modest freshness to the Story's slightly threadbare materials.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 9. -- Playing a calm, methodical game that totally belied his lack of tournament experience, Milton Pierpont Warner of Pine Orchard, Conn., defeated John B. Ryerson of Cooperstown, N.Y., 5 and 3 today, to capture the thirty-second annual North and South amateur golf tournament.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, April 9. -- The first four days of Finland's new liquor regime have been uneventful. Drunkenness has not increased, though the liquor sales figures have grown daily. The highest turnover was reached yesterday in Helsingfors, totaling the equivalent of $11,000.

THE tinted art of ballyhoo baa completed a cycle. It started out long ago, with bands, flaring posters and those regiments of happy characters who stood outside the stores and grabbed at the passing crowds. It was personal and individualistic.
BUDAPEST, March 23. -- Kosarik, Hungary's celebrated hangman, died suddenly two days ago of influenza contracted while hanging the bandit Tichy three weeks ago.

SHANGHAI, March 16. -- Now that the League of Nations commission named for the thankless task of inquiring into the basic causes of Japan's seizure of Manchuria has been for two days in China, the magnitude of the task ahead is dawning fully upon the members.

Champion Charmeuse d'Amourette owned by the Amourette Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. P.A. Halsey of Plainfield, N.J., and shown in the ring by Mrs. Halsey, was crowned queen of the twenty-fourth annual specialty show of the French Bulldog Club of America yesterday at the Hotel McAlpin.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 9. -- William D. MacQuesten, civic leader and a personal friend of the late Thomas A. Edison, died this morning at his home, 349 Garden Avenue, after a long illness. He was 72 years, old. Mr. MacQuesten had been in poor health since he left the office of Mayor In December, 1927.

DAIREN, March 8. -- Well-organized bands of Chinese bandits still continue to roam the fields of Manchuria, leaving destruction as they go, and engendering Constant fear in the souls of the inhabitants. They strike without warning, murdering those that resist, and depart with such valuables as they obtain for their camps miles away.

The Fifth Avenue Association, in a resolution made public yesterday, called on the city administration and Mayor Walker, to formulate at once a definite program for economy. The president of the association, Captain William J. Pedrick, in a statement accompanying the resolution, declared that the formulation of the program was the duty of the administration and not of the civic associations which have been clamoring for the economies they believe can be effected.

A bulletin published by the Department of Commerce lists each week the tariff changes reported by its agents in foreign countries. The latest report shows no let-up in the race to erect new barriers to trade. The Union of South Africa has imposed a general surtax of 7 1/2 per cent ad valorem on all imports except goods used predominantly by agricultural producers.
The second game of the pre-season series between the Yankees and the Robins, scheduled for yesterday, was postponed because of wet grounds.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial, "Thin Leaders and Fat," THE TIMES refers to the Investigation of the metabolism of two different types of men made by the University of Illinois.

INVOLVED though it is in searching for new friends and friendly dollars, the Group Theatre -- which is serious about its work -- paused recently in the midst of preparations for next season to put five sharp questions to several persons known to have the interests of the drama close to their representative hearts.
Three teams gained the finals of the National Indoor Polo championships at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 9. -- Despite a pitching corps of better-than-average ability, the Cornell baseball team, because of its weakness at bat, faces a battle to avoid a repetition of the cellar finish in the Eastern Inter-collegiate League made by the big Red nine a year ago.

THEATRICAL performances are holding their own as a means of raising funds for philanthropic purposes. When the curtain is raised tonight on. "The Wives of Henry VIII," starring Cornelia Otis Skinner, at the Selwyn Theatre, there will he an audience made up of prominent men and women interested in St. Mary's Hospital for Children, the beneficiary of the net proceeds.

THE Supreme Court of the United States has been attacked many times In its 150 years existence, but seldom as violently as Mr. Boudln here attacks it. Putting on his lawyer's robes and seizing' the documents of the historian, he comes before the tribunal of the American people to seek the abolition of the Judicial power -- the power of the Supreme Court to declare unconstitutional acts of Congress and of State Legislatures.
MOSCOW, April 8. -- Something new in the field of industry has appeared this week in the Soviet Union-new and with infinite possibilities.

DALLAS, Texas, April 9 (AP). -- Two Federal prohibition agents were charged with murder today for the killing of Marion McGlothlin, 50-year-old proprietor of a crossroads gasoline station and grocery.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 9. -- The cash distribution of $3 a share voted yesterday by the directors of the Peerless Motor Car Corporation will be made from capital surplus. It will be payable on April 25 to stock of record of April 20. Based on the 326.739 shares shown in the annual report for the year ended on Sept. 30. 1931, it will aggregate $980,217.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP). -- The Standard Oil Company of Indiana met today the advance in crude oil prices recently made by other companies and raised the price 15 cents. making it $1 a barrel in Kansas. Oklahoma, North and North-Central Texas, effective Monday.

Advertised items bringing volume response in local stores during the week were imported scatter rugs retailing at around $1.90, imported neckties aggressively promoted in five price lines from 55 cents to $1.98, boudoir lamps with colored or plain glass or gold-plated bases, complete with tailored georgette lace or ribbon-trimmed shades; inexpensive furtrimmed coats and anniversary sale goods, according to analyses by shoppers of the Meyer Both Retail Reporting Bureau.

SAN REMO. IF there ever was an earthly paradise, it might well have been at San Remo in March. But If there ever was a sure and patentable method of turning a paradise Into something very different, that method must have been the institution of a literary prize.

DETROIT, April 7. -- Another curious chapter has been written in the political history of Hamtramck, one of the two cities completely surrounded by Detroit, and inhabited princioally by people of Polish extraction. Peter C. Jezewski this week was elected mayor for the third time.

WHEN this department approaches the annual task of pronouncing a benediction upon the Theatre Guild season it is generally in a benevolent mood. After fourteen seasons of struggle and success, blunders and achievements the Theatre Guild still occupies the foremost position in the American theatre.
THIS is the second biography of the Prince Consort that, within a year of depression, has been offered by an interested author to an interested public.
PHILADELPHIA, April 9. -- The Athletics handed the last game of the city series to the Phillies, 3 -- 2, when the winning run was walked over the plate at Baker Bowl today.

Stephen N. Bobo, chairman of the board of the Interstate Properties Corporation, announces that title has been taken to the 3,000 acres of land on the Atlantic Coast where Ocean and Burlington Counties meet in New Jersey, which the company contracted to purchase early in February.
Two 16-year-old youths stood in the glare of the line-up at Police Head-quarters yesterday morning and admitted automobile thefts and hold-ups.

ALBANY, April 9. -- All but two of thirteen bills sponsored by the Walker Administration and left behind for the Governor by the Legislature when it adjourned sine die have been approved by the Chief Executive during the thirty-day bill period.

A broader view of America's economic, legal, social and cultural affairs is to be supplied the future student at the School of Journalism at Columbia University under the new program just outlined by Dean Carl W. Ackerman in a letter to President Butler.

MR. GAMBS'S book is concerned with the history of the Industrial Workers of the World from 1917 to the present time. He thinks that the story of the first half of its life, from its organization in 1905 to 1917, has been told with such completeness, thoroughness and authority by Paul P. Brissenden in his "The I.W.W." that it does not need to be re-done at present.

The Morris and George Washington High School fencing teams were upset yesterday at the Washington Irving High gymnasium as competition in the second annual city P.S. A.L. senior high title tourney was resumed following a three-week halt because of the Easter vacation.
AMHERST, Mass., April 9 (AP). -- Lloyd Jordan, assistant football coach at Colgate University, today was appointed head football mentor at Amherst College.

PURCHASE, N.Y., April 9. -- Running over a course that was deep in mud and dotted with pools of water, High Island Treve, a Belton blue English setter, today captured the close-cover stake, the premier event of the second day of the fifth annual trials of the Southern New York Field Trial Association.

A collection of Chinese porcelains, paintings on silk, Jade carvings and enamels, formed by Ton-Ying, now on view at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., will e sold there next Friday afternoon and evening and on Saturday afternoon.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.T., April 9 (AP). -- Seven ballots were required before the Troy Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church today selected its six delegates to the general conference of the denomination at Atlantic City next month. The balloting began yesterday and four ballots were taken, today.

A greater autonomy for the college fraternity was urged last night by Dr. Henry Noble McCracken, president of Vassar College, at the dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria closing the ninety-ninth annual convention of the Psi Upsilon fraternity. Dr. McCracken said the fraternity made of the college student a well-rounded man and was a necessary supplement to scholastic life.

TODAY. 12:30 P.M. -- Sir James Jeans, eminent British scientist, discusses "The Present Position in Science" when he faces a microphone in London for an international broadcast to be distributed by WABC's network. Jeans was formerly Professor of Applied Mathematics at Princeton and research associate at Mount Wilson Observatory for several years.

AN interesting new development in the program of the Art Alliance takes the form of two practical study tours for designers, craftsmen and typographers in collaboration with the Open Road, which, like the Art Alliance, is a non-profit service organization.

THE opening of the new Patent Office in Washington is an event of major significance, for the patent system has been a potent force in the evolution of the United States from a wilderness to the most powerful industrial State that the world has ever seen.
One man was killed and three others seriously wounded yesterday afternoon in an attempted hold-up of a small bookmaking and lottery establishment in a tenement house at 54 Elizabeth Street.

LONDON. SPEAKING at a recent book-sellers' dinner. Prince George remarked that the length of many novels and biographies presented a difficulty to those who were obliged to fit their reading into a crowded life.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 9. -- Municipal budgets and tax rates fell in Westchester County this Spring as village and city officials found an aroused public opinion ready to contest any excessive expenditures.
NEW YORK. The Italian Ambassador, Giacomo de Martino, is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

RICHMOND, Va., April 9. -- After duelling with the even-money favorite, Primero, over the first six jumps, Racketeer II, sporting the colors of Mrs. T.H. Somerville of Montpelier, Va., went to the fore at the seventh and held the lead over the balance of the distance to win the Deep Run Hunt Cup, feature of the hunts meeting today at Curies Neck.

New bonds called last week for redemption in April consisted principally of small lots of municipal issues. Other calls Included partial retirements of bonds of one foreign industrial company and of mortgage loans. The total for the month is now $13,529,000, compared with $10,509,000 in March and $88,409,000 in April, 1931.

ESSAD BEY'S new book is like nothing so much as a fantastic Arabian Night's Dream literally spotted with the ghastliest and most gruesome nightmares imaginable. But it bears every appearance of being the simply written, unadorned, personal narrative of actual, first-hand experiences and observations that it pretends to be.

IRVING FINEMAN, who turned from the pursuit of civil engineering' to win a prize with his first novel. "This Pure Young Man," has here written a second book. By almost any standard, "Lovers Must Learn" Is workman-like production.
THE people of Europe are hysterical, but not half so hysterical as the people of this country."
To the Editor of The New York Times: I was amused at THE TIMES article that appeared on March 27 relative to the campaign under way to get out the vote this coming Presidential election.
PARIS, April 8. -- Experts who are training teams for the Los Angeles Olympics might be surprised if they examined the diet of riders in the international six-day bicycle race in progress in Paris.
GENEVA, April 9. -- Four big League of Nations meetings will resume or begin here next week, with disarmament and Central European finances as the probable centres of interest at the start.

Classical music played by a toy symphony" orchestra, competition in piano movements for eight hands by 10-year-old children, and songs by a junior church choir of fifty voices featured the closing session yesterday of the State convention of the New York State Federation of Music Clubs at the Hotel Victoria, at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

WITH the approach of pleasant weather shipboard card parties are becoming popular as a means of augmenting the funds of charitable organizations. A group of women interested in the work of the Society for the Relief of the Destitute Children of Seamen has -- appropriately enough -- arranged a bridge and backgammon party to take place on board the Conte Grande at Pier 95 at the foot of West Fifty-fifth Street on Wednesday afternoon.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 9. -- Army's lacrosse team continued its winning streak today by defeating Lafayette, 11 to 0. The game was played in a drenching rain and the slippery footing handicapped both teams.

The evening session riflemen from Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn pained a second leg on the trophy offered by St. John's College in its annual metropolitan competition yesterday, repeating their victory of last year. Six other teams competed In the event at the 106th Regiment Armory.

Opposition to the reorganization plan for the Mount Hope Bridge Company of Rhode Island, which went into receivership in June, 1931, was voiced yesterday by Harry P. Schaub, investment banker, of Newark, representing minority holders of the first mortgage 6 1/2 per cent bonds outstanding in the amount of $2,800,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Sunday, March 20, you print a letter by Mr. W. Wilson dealing with the questions of opera in English and the employment of American singers in the opera houses of the United States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I appreciate deeply the kind words of Dr. Daniel A. Poling in his letter on our Literary Digest prohibition poll, published in THE TIMES, endorsing its honesty and squareness, and making some criticisms. He displays breadth of mind and soul and his criticisms are welcome.

The steady pressure upon money rates exercised in the last six weeks by Federal Reserve purchases of United States Government securities in the open market at the rate of about $25,000,000 a week found further expression yesterday in a general reduction of one-quarter of 1 per cent in discount rates on bankers' acceptances.
BERLIN, April 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of April 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

JERUSALEM, April 8. -- Ever since the 1929 riots in the Holy Land which were the climax of the Arab-Jewish animosity that has been brewing here through the last decade the most insignificant incidents, such as in any other part of the world would pass off unnoticed, has become political issues likely to lead to the most serious consequences, creating an atmosphere of the highest tension.

PARIS, April 9. -- As a result of what is considered to be governmental pressure, the press of Paris was noticeably lacking today in attacks on American financial stability. Although the dollar again was weak, closing below the gold export point, it is understood that the speculative manipulations which forced it down on Thursday have been temporarily withdrawn.

Asserting that the New York Stock Exchange "should have been under governmental regulation and supervision ever since it was organized," Samuel Untermyer, who conducted the Pujo money trust investigation in 1912, yesterday placed responsibility for what he termed the Exchange's iniquities "squarely at the doors of Congress."

Arrangements were made yesterday for the sale of a New York Stock Exchange membership at $80,000, a decrease of $1,000 from the preceding sale and the lowest price since 1924. During the last ten days the price of memberships has declined $37,000.

LONDON, April 9. -- Authorities of Scotland Yard, It was learned tonight, have grown apprehensive over the personal safety of Major Charles H. Schoeffel, who, having completed his preliminary inquiries into the antecedents of persons mentioned in the Lindbergh case, is rumored here to be awaiting the arrival of an envoy of the kidnappers in England.

THOSE attending the mural luncheon at the Art Centre a week ago yesterday were indeed gratified to hear Wallace Harrison, the architect, announce that American artists will enjoy preference when it comes to giving out contracts for the walls of Rockefeller Centre.

PARIS. ACTIVE sports clothes are necessarily less affected by the vagaries of the mode than other costumes; they must qualify from the practical standpoint, as well as from (or even more than) that of chic, so they constitute, as it were, a mode unto themselves.

PARIS, April 8. -- Paris expects to have a brisk Spring season socially. The Longchamps races opened last Sunday with a tremendous attendance, including visitors from across the Channel; the Opera has Just received a new lease of life and the horse show is drawing enthusiasts.

LAST Tuesday Finland lifted the lid that had been clamped on the sale of liquor in that country for the last thirteen years. On Monday the strongest brew that could be legally obtained in Finland was 2.25 per cent beer; twenty-four hours later the government itself was selling the public as much of even the strongest liquors as it wanted.

MANY persons living in New York City and owning automobiles are not aware of the number and variety of places they can reach within an afternoon's or a day's drive. Yet it is a fact that the region around New York abounds in spots well worth visiting for their recreational, scenic or historic value.

FORMAL organization of Communist activities in Latin America as part of Moscow's world-wide revolutionary program began shortly after the failure of the 1922 effort to disrupt Europe had convinced the authorities at the Kremlin that the fight would be a long one which must be carried to all parts of the world.

Forecasts on the chances of their teams in this year's pennant races were made yesterday for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the managers of the three local clubs. The statements of John McGraw of the Giants, Joe McCarthy of the Yankees and Max Carcy of the Robins fol'ow:

BOW BELLS will be enabled to resume ringing through the generosity of Gordon Selfridge, the American merchant of London. His repair fund for these bells of St. Mary-le-Bow in Cheapside amounts to about $25,000. Only by living within sound of them could one claim to be Cockney.

ARDEN GALLERIES -- Paintings by Princess Nina Chavchavadze who with equal grace immortalizes the sleek silver and White pied a terres of "us moderns" and the Louis Quinze or Heppelwhite salons of the more conservatively minded.

Large scale operations to provide low-cost housing should receive careful study at this time, since it is the one field which has not been overbuilt, according to Clarence S. Stein, former chairman of the New York State Commission of Housing and Regional Planning, who made public yesterday the program of an attempt to be made next Wednesday to focus attention on such projects.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- Representative La Guardia in asserting in the House today that threats had been made by brokers to create a panic if the Senate initiated its investigation, put into the record letters he said were mailed by brokers and financial institutions to their clients giving them instructions on the kind of letters to write their Senators on the tax bill.

LOURENCO MARQUES, March 3. -- Bootlegging has become a flourishing Industry in Portuguese East Africa. It is bootlegging not of liquor, but of currency, yet real bootlegging nevertheless. It is forbidden by law, on pain of fine and imprisonment, yet it attracts the best class of people.
The rise in prices of United States Government obligations last week is expected to smooth the way for the heavy borrowing the Treasury must do before June 30.

THE current engagement of the Guerrero-Mendoza company at the New Yorker Theatre has been eagerly awaited not only by the Spanish colony but also by the Increasingly large portion of the American public which recognizes the contribution which the art of Spain has to offer.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The American thesis on disarmament will be elaborated by Hugh S. Gibson, acting chairman of the American delegation, before the general disarmament conference at Geneva early next week upon its reconvening after the Easter holiday.

MADRID, March 25. -- It is unpleasant to sit in a dentist's chair. That is when Spain has been sitting during the first year of the Second Spanish Republic. Politically and socially Spain wag hopelessly antiquated and any reform in a country ruled by a small but omnipotent plutocracy must result in economic disturbance.

BALZAC GALLERIES -- Paintings by Margaret Brisbine, William Waltemath and Count aetano Bentivoglio. Miss Brisbine is by far the most interesting, if not the best known, of these three. Her painting combines clarity of color and strength of form with unusual success.
PITTSBURGH, April 9 (AP). -- For Julius Spindler, life is over at 65, and the silver flute he played against the background of Damrosch and Sousa bands has been put away.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- The Senate Appropriations Committee unanimously agreed today upon details of the 10 per cent cut in the appropriation for the State, Justice, Commerce and Labor Departments, including a million dollar reduction in the fund for prohibition enforcement.

LONDON, April 9. -- British iron and steel shares advanced sharply on the Stock Exchange today in anticipation of early imposition of a heavy duty. Railway shares also improved in the hope of larger freight receipts.

AFTER writing more than twenty books, Elizabeth Jordan is still content to deal lightly with her subject-matter, whatever its nature may be. In this, her latest, novel, she presents a problem of marital adjustment without attempting any interpretation of the conditions which cause it.

Massachusetts Agricultural Experiment Station. OUR grandmothers were right. They grew good plants in tin cans, sometimes punching holes in the bottoms of the cans for drainage. A window in a stuffy kitchen or a chilly living room was their greenhouse.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The American thesis on disarmament will be elaborated by Hugh S. Gibson, acting chairman of the American delegation, before the general disarmament conference at Geneva early next week upon its reconvening after the Easter holiday.

MADRID, March 25. -- It is unpleasant to sit in a dentist's chair. That is when Spain has been sitting during the first year of the Second Spanish Republic. Politically and socially Spain wag hopelessly antiquated and any reform in a country ruled by a small but omnipotent plutocracy must result in economic disturbance.

BALZAC GALLERIES -- Paintings by Margaret Brisbine, William Waltemath and Count aetano Bentivoglio. Miss Brisbine is by far the most interesting, if not the best known, of these three. Her painting combines clarity of color and strength of form with unusual success.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The Senate elections committee referred the Heflin-Bankhead contest back to a subcommittee today to determine whether further evidence should be taken.
The management division of the Real Estate Board of New York has just completed a vacancy survey of the financial district of Manhattan.

A POINT raised a few days ago in the review of the Whitney Museum's present exhibition would seem to deserve reiteration and expansion here. This concerns the museum's laudable effort to represent artists, not as static an isolated elements in an assemblag of pictures but as living and growing entities whose outlook is constantly changing.

BOWIE, Md., April 9. -- The Sagamore Stable's Kentucky Derby eligible Towee, a son of Harpenden and Blue Grass Belle, today dashed through a driving rainstorm and deep footing to victory in the James Rowe Memorial Handicap. Despite the inclement weather a crowd of 15,000 persons, including Vice President Curtis, saw the contest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the Washington bicentennial celebration approaches it is fitting for the people to reflect that Washington believed in government by the people. This is evident from the fact that in his farewell speech he addressed the people as "my friends and fellow-citizens"; he did not address Congress nor public officials.

PARIS, April 9. -- The prestige of the League of Nations never hid the realities from Aristide Briand, with whom I was so long and so closely associated that, now he is gone, I can tell with fidelity what was in nil mind and in his heart.
WASHINGTON, April 9. -- An allowance of nearly $1,000,000,000 for the Veterans' Administration was granted today by the House, which passed the independent offices appropriation bill.
NEW YORK. The Earl and Countess of Berkeley, who have been in California, are expected today at the Ritz-Carlton.

ALBANY, April 10 -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., head of the Department of Conservation, has made public a list of new laws making changes in the statutes affecting fish and game, approved by Governor Roosevelt. In all the Governor approved sixteen such measures from the recent session and vetoed fifteen.

PARIS, April 8. -- The sterling market seems to have been calmed by the intervention of the Bank of England, at the close of last week. This appears to have arrested the previously rapid rise of sterling and it was easier to keep the pound in equilibrium.

Continuing his attack on "governmental extravagance," Lammot du Pont, president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., sent a letter yesterday to Senator Daniel O. Hastings of Delaware, in which he took issue with the latter's assertion that it would not be expedient to make any substantial reduction in government expenditures.

PARIS, April 10. -- Cheers for President von Hindenburg, who led the invading German Army against which France's soldiers fought desperately only fourteen years ago, were emitted again tonight by Parisian crowds as they read the election bulletins posted by the newspaper Le Matin on the boulevards.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Roosevelt's charge in his speech delivered last night, that the administration is not doing anything for the farmer or for the small banks and loan companies, exposes him to the danger of being classified with the "shallow thinkers" for whom he expresses his scorn.
The Fismar Garage, Inc., has surrendered to the landlord, the Mablin Holding Corporation, its lease of the garage and equipment at 157 and 159 West Eighteenth Street.

Knowledge of a definite move by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to ease the mortgage money situation in New York has kindled hope among the building trades of an early start toward a revival of construction activity in this vicinity, writes Allen E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

Opposition to two bills introduced by Senator Johnson of California, designed to give to the Shipping Board the power to regulate and control rates on intercoastal shipping, was expressed in a brief filed yesterday with Senator Johnson by William H. Chandler, acting for the Shippers' Conference of Greater New York and the National Industrial Traffic League and at the request of the Boston Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- One of the largest gatherings of Democrats in years will be held here this week for the Jefferson Day dinner and exercises at the National Cathedral in honor of President Wilson on Wednesday. Issues of the Presidential campaign will be discussed and, with the exception of Governor Roosevelt of New York, most of the leaders of the party will take part in the ceremonies.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Appearing as a witness tomorrow as the Senate Banking and Currency Committee begins its inquiry into the New York stock market, Richard Whitney, president of the Stock Exchange, will discuss the recent decline in security prices.

BERLIN, April 8. -- The stock market was weak throughout the past week and the volume of turnover reached a new low point. It was in fact remarked that the Boerse can hardly be called a real stock exchange any longer, and that it hardly performs its function as a barometer of business.

ALBANY, April 10 -- In three months of this year 6,628 stock companies were chartered by Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, an increase of eighty-three over the corresponding period of last year. In March 155 fewer companies were formed than a year ago, but the month's total ran ahead of February by 199.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 10 -- Hardy skippers of Long Island Sound craft spent a tempestuous day in the Frostbite Rpgatta held today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Starting in the morning and lasting until well into the afternoon, the pilots of the small boats flirted with frigid submersion in the face of a strong northeast wind and mixture of rain and sleet.

ALBANY, April 10. -- Few New York State municipalities maintain central purchasing agencies, with the result that most cities and villages are paying widely varying prices for purchases of identical materials, according to a report made public today by the New York State Conference of Mayors and Other Municipal Officials.
GENEVA, April 10. -- There will be Eome plain, forceful speaking during the next few days at the world disarmament conference, which reopens here tomorrow. Every one agrees that it must be so.

PARIS, April 10. -- French newspapers in their weekly financial summaries today devote much space to refuting American charges that they are waging a campaign against the dollar. The accusations are seen here as an attempt to hide what is called the serious situation of American finances.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Department store sales decreased 20 per cent in March and also dropped 20 per cent in the first three months of 1932, as compared with similar periods in 1931, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

"Pollyanna" optimism will no longer serve to carry us through the depression, Dr. Ralph. W. Sockman, pastor of the Madison Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, at Sixtieth Street, told his congregation yesterday morning.

BERLIN, April 10. -- The attempt on the life of Dr. Hans Luther last night when the president of the Reichsbank was slightly wounded by a bullet has turned out to be something of a sensation as Dr. Max Roosen, who was apparently the instigator of the attack, has been found to be an extremely well-educated economist, 60 years old, who is well known among financial writers.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Associate Justice Cardozo is expected to render his first opinion as a member of the United States Supreme Court when it reconvenes tomorrow to announce decisions in a number of important cases. Thirty-two have been argued and await decision.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A mustering of forces against soldiers' bonus legislation was assured today by Acting Chairman Crisp of the Ways and Means Committee.

New Kochelle, N.Y. Formal offering will be made today of the new issue of $2,007,000 City of New Rochelle (N.Y.) 5 1/4 per cent bonds, due on April 1, 1934 to 1967, by a syndicate comprising the Bankers Trust Company, the National City Company, the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and the Guaranty Company of New York.

Saving comes doubly hard after a long period of extravagance. The English spendthrift whom his creditors ordered to retrench complainea that he could not possibly discharge his French chef and kitchen staff, "because, as he said, " a man must have a bit to eat, you know."

At the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony orchestra given yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, Sir Thomas Beecham conducted Smetana's overture to "The Bartered Bride," Arnold Bax's symphonic poem "The Gardea of Fand," Tchaikovsky's serenade for string orchestra, Handel's concerto grosso in E minor for string orchestra, Delius's intermezzo "The Walk to Paradise Garden" from his opera "A Village Romeo and Juliet," and the overture and redding procession from Rimski-Korsakoff's "Le Coq d'Or."

CHICAGO, April 9. -- Lowering of security prices and uncertainty of the Winter wheat crop, with an enormous reduction from last year's bumper production, combined with irregularity in prices of grain and cotton tend to make more or less uneasiness in business lines hereabout.

Hopes of an increase in specifications from automobile manufacturers buoyed sentiment last week in the steel industry, according to the magazine Steel. The steel industry's operating rate declined one point last week to 22 per cent of capacity, the publication says. It continues:
HAVANA, April 10. -- Kid Chocolate, flashy Cuban boxer, retained his somewhat synthetic junior lightweight championship today by outpointing Dave Abad of Panama in a fifteen-round bout.

Revision of courses of study in the public schools in response to changing social and economic conditions will be continued, Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, declares in an instalment of his forthcoming annual report dealing with new courses in health education, phonetics and music.

Reports drifting into the New York State Conservation Department offices indicate that the trout streams of the upper part of the State are still high and that here and there vestiges of snow remain. In the Adirondack and Catskill regions the waters are still muddy, but the expected warm weather within the next two weeks should be cheering to the anglers.

Installed as a member of the Loyal Order of Moose yesterday at ceremonies held at Palm Garden, 306 West Fifty-second Street, Governor Roosevelt was hailed by 3,000 members of New York Lodge 15 as "our next President."

TORONTO, April 10 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, the youngest team in major professional hockey, are the new holders of the Stanley Cup. Punch-packed reserve power shot the Leafs last night to the pro game's pinnacle with a 6-to-4 triumph over the New York Rangers in the third match of the best-of-five series.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh revealed last night that the criminals who stole his infant son from his home in Hopewell, N.J., provided for their subsequent identification in the original ransom note they left in the empty nursery.

The establishment of boys' and girls' clubs at police actions or public schools as part of a crime prevention program was recommended yesterday by Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing in an address before the congregation of the Frees Synagogue in Carnegie Hall.

Rain and wind handicapped a small field of gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York A C. yesterday, comparatively low scores prevailing as a result. J.H. Wantling broke 92 out of a possible 100 targets to annex the High Scratch Cup. F.J. Ryan, who had a card of 82 -- 13 -- 95, captured the handicap honors.

The formal opening of the new Allen Street Boulevard on Monday, April 18, will be celebrated by a program of speeches and a parade down the widened thoroughfare in which many city officials and representatives of civic bodies will participate.

PARIS, April 8. -- Dollar exchange monopolized attention on the Paris market this week, but the great strength of the franc in terms of dollars was directly due to the unfounded rumors concerning American banks, which, although circulated originally with precise details, were immediately contradicted.

Just as mankind has in the past discarded the use of herrings, carved bones and dog teeth as bases for commodity exchange and standards of value, so gold and silver may before long be abandoned and a system of pure "managed money" replace them, Donald B. Woodward and Marc A. Rose write in "A Primer of Money," published today by Whittlesey House.
WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Baseball starts a new season tomorrow and will occupy an important place in the nation's activities for the next six months.

The committees representing holders of the general and the improvement bonds of the City of "West Palm Beach, Fla., outstanding in the amount of approximately $17,000,000, have announced that the various requirements precedent to making effective the refunding plan adopted by the city and the two committees as of Jan. 1, 1932, are being "satisfactorily carried forward to completion."

CHICAGO, April 10 -- While more than 2,200 candidates for Republican and Democratic nominations in Tuesday's Illinois State-wide primaries were preparing for the final day of the campaign, the national aspects of the contest loomed larger tonight as the time for balloting approaches.

"Not scolding, but in a cry for help," the Rev. Dr. Robert Norwood, rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at Fiftieth Street, told his congregation from the pulpit yesterday that his duties make it impossible for him "always to be ringing doorbells."

LONG BEACH, L.I., April 10 -- Nine gunners reported for the shoot of the Lido Country Club today. The best work was done by Dr. N.E. Sprague, who had a card of 43 -- 4 -- 47. Wind and rain made the shooting conditions difficult.
Real estate transactions announced over the week-end included sales and leases of houses in the suburbs. Deals on Long Island featured activity.
BERLIN, April 10 (AP). -- Adolf Hitler fell short of reaching the 15,000,000 votes he had claimed in the run-off election for the German Presidency today.

After hearing sermons for two years by the Rev. Elden H. Mills, a Quaker minister, the congregation of the First Presbyterian Church, Seminole Avenue and Gown Street, Forest Hills, Queens, had decided to extend a call to him to become their pastor, it became known yesterday.

Communication by voice between three pilots of air mail planes flying over the transcontinental route and the dispatcher at the municipal airport at Newark, N.J., and a running conversation among announcers and the pilots and a colleague at the field were picked up last night and broadcast for the first time over a National Broadcasting Company network.

A plea that philanthropy and education be maintained at maximum efficiency despite the economic crisis, "for upon them the very worth-whileness of life and civilization depends," was made yesterday by Dr. Abraham Flexner, director of the Institute for Advanced Study, addressing the annual meeting of the trustees of Montefiore Hospital for Chronic Diseases.

The Block Community Organization enters upon the third week of its unemployment relief campaign this morning with 10,508 blocks in the five boroughs organized, it was announced yesterday by Wilton LloydSmith, chairman. An army of 61,000 Block-Aiders will be in the field.

The annual report of the Hydro-Electric Securities Corporation of Montreal for 1931 shows net income of $2,968,465, equal after preferred dividends to $1.33 a share on the common stock, comparing with $7,426,292, or $4.25 a share, in 1930. Total ordinary income, including $1.830,752 dividends and interest received in cash, was $3,019,931, comparing with $2,599,420 and $4,272,876, respectively, the year before.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 10. -- Colonel and Mrs. Arthur Kelly Evans entertained for luncheon today at Malvern Hall in honor of Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt. Others in the party were Miss Mary Wheat, Miss Jessie Graham and the Rev. Ambrose H. Beavin.

If a future historian were seeking the most succinct contemporary review of the affairs of the world in 1931, he could find it in President BUTLER'S introduction to his report as Director of the Division of Intercourse and Education of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

Frank Butter of the German-American A.C. won the six-and-three-eighths-mile handicap walk conducted yesterday by the Manhattan Athletic League from the clubhouse of the Paulist A.C. The event was the final in the league's series of three handicap walks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The animosity of Mr. Untermyer toward the B.M.T. and the Interborough Rapid Transit Companies is so apparent in all the statements ha has recently made in THE TIMES that his deductions must be taken with a grain of salt.

BERLIN, April 10 -- President Paul von Hindenburg won the run-off election for the Presidency of Germany with an absolute majority today, defeating Adolf Hitler, his National Socialist rival, by almost 6,000,000 votes.

The tariff doctrines of those who make goods and those who sell them were vigorously debated by radio during the forum hour of Station WOR at 3 P.M. yesterday. H.L. Derby, one of the leaders of the chemical industry of the United States, argued that the rates should be even higher and that Congress should revise the tariff upward again, in opposition to Philip Le Boutillier, president of Best Co.

Improved activity in stores during the week was reflected in a better can for merchandise in the local wholesale markets. In addition to a larger number of out-of-town buyer arriving here, both mail and telegraphic orders for Spring goods showed an increase over the previous week.

A decision on the selection of a site for the Max Schmeling-Jack Sharkey world's heavyweight championship bout, Signed by the Madison Square Garden Corporation for June 16, must be forthcoming not later than Saturday, if complications are to be avoided in connection with the proposed title struggle.

The city's rapid transit lines carried 92,100,000 fewer passengers in 1931 than in 1930, a decline of 4 1/2 per cent, the report of the Transit Commission for the calendar year of 1931 showed yesterday. Traffic on trolley cars fell off an additional 50,028,865 fares.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, April 10 -- A close working arrangement between the White Star Line and the United States Lines is expected to emerge before Summer, with the Leviathan, Majestic and Olympic joining in a weekly transatlantic service.

LONDON, April 8. -- While professing that it was neither surprised nor disappointed that the Bank of England made no reduction in its rate on Thursday, the London money market became appreciably firmer immediately after the Bank had announced its decision.

Mura Dehn made her New York debut in a dance recital at the Guild Theatre last night, while a few blocks south at the Cort Theatre Paul Haakon was giving his first dance concert since his return from a European tour in Pavlova's company.

Resolutions calling for a religious union of Jews in this country and pledging support in efforts to rehabilitate Palestine as a national homeland were adopted yesterday at a convention of the New Jersey Branch of the United Synagogue of America at the Jewish Community Centre in Jersey City.

PARIS, April 10 (AP) -- Jules Jusserand in a transatlantic broadcast today pleaded for less sarcasm and more brotherly love between France and the United States. He spoke in the International Radio Forum formed by Ira Nelson Morris last week as a non-commercial organization to "stimulate intelligent public thinking on a wide range of problems in both continents."

Members of the Junior Federation of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies have arranged a dance for the night of April 30 in the Italian Garden of the Ambassador in behalf of the work of the organization. An entertainment will be given by several Broadway stars from current theatrical attractions.

The kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby inspired yesterday a suggestion for revival of the old English proclamation of outlawiy, following the issuance of which the persons declared beyond the pale of the law may be summarily lulled by any citizen if they refuse to surrender.
PARIS, April 10 -- For two successive weeks the official figures of the French Ministry of Labor have showed a decrease in unemployment, which had been steadily rising for nearly a year.

DETROIT, April 10 (AP). -- Two changes were recorded among the ten leaders in the minor events of the American Bowling Congress tournament today. Tom Corken and Art Hein, Chicago, gained sixth place in the two-man event when they rolled 1.298 on games of 429, 447 and 422.
To the Editor of The New York Times: What underlies this calamitous world depression? Fear! Banish fear and confidence will flourish again. Why this fear? It is thought of war.

Senator TIDINGS'S resolution to strike from the revenue bill the tariff rates stuck into it by the House ought to pass. The duties on oil and coal should never have been imposed. Tariff revision once begun is hard to stop. Tariff revision from a protectionist point of view is a dangerous thing for Democrats to venture on.

The most important tennis tournament to be held at Pinehurst will begin, today when the American Davis Cup team for 1932 and a host of other ranking and college stars will start out in the annual North and South championship on the clay courts of the Pinehurst Country Club.

The circus yesterday pulsated with excitement. Tight-rope walkers danced as they went about their work, and elephants did dutiful little clogs through the basement of the Garden. The sword-swallower early in the afternoon was forced home with a bad case of nervous indigestion, and most of the contortionists went on benders.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, April 10. -- Finnish athletic authorities took a long step forward today in their effort to clear Paavo Nurmi of charges of professionalism and lead to his reinstatement by the International Amateur Athletic Federation.

BASLE, April 10 -- No relief beyond the renewal of the existing credits to Central European countries after the breakdown of the four-power Danubian conference can be expected from the Bank for International Settlements, it was learned, as the directors gathered here tonight for their regular meeting tomorrow.

The city manager plan of municipal government was examined in detail yesterday afternoon in a debate on the feasibility of the plan when applied to large cities. Walter J. Millard, field secretary of the Committee of One Thousand, which arranged the discussion, argued that the city manager form of government was admirably adapted to large communities.

Two hundred and fifty members of the Jewish. "Writers' Club of America and their guests attended a "jubilee banquet" last night at the Hotel Astor to celebrate the semi-centennial of the beginning of Jewish immigration from Eastern Europe to the United States.

NEW ORLEANS, April 8. -- The cotton market ruled nervous and erratic last week, with trading rather narrower than of late. The market was dominated mainly by uncertainty regarding the final outcome of the tax and economy measures before Congress and the resulting unfavorable effects on the stock market.

The reasons Governor ROOSEVELT gives for his veto of the Hewitt reclassification bill may tie dismissed as unsubstantial. No piece of legislation is perfect, and it may be that in some minor and unimportant respects this measure could be improved upon.

DETROIT, April 10 (AP) -- Buffalo won the International Hockey League championship tonight when Referees Jerry Goodman and Mike Rodden declared the game between the Buffalo Bisons and Detroit Olympics forfeited near the end of the third period as a wild protest by fans prevented completion of the match.
Dwindling Rapid Transit. The latest report of the Transit Commission, covering the calendar year1931, reveals much the same traffic trend as was in evidence six months before.

As a matter of Presidential courtesy, the Senators are being given a head start on their American League rivals, the Tankees and Athletics. This is to allow President Hoover to have the field to himself in the matter of throwing out the first ball to start the big league season. Weather report for Washington, D.C. Rain today, if the Democrats can arrange it.

A letter sent to Senator Key Pittman of Nevada by Philip C. Jessup, secretary of the National World Court Committee, disputing the accuracy of a statement made by Senator Pittman and printed in the Congressional Record on April 4, was made public yesterday at the headquarters of the organization, at 18 East Forty-first Street.

PURCHASE, N.Y., April 10 -- Nepken Lady, the 5-year-old lernon-and-white pointer owned by Dr. Wallace F. Vail of Greenwich, Conn., today captured the fifth running of the All-Age Stake of the Southern New York Field Trial Association, defeating thirty-five of the highest calibre setters and pointers in a grim battle over the treacherous course laid out on the Clark estate near here.

George H. Ceiger, a radio operator, pleaded not guilty yesterday when arraigned in the Sunday Federal Court in Brooklyn charged with conspiracy to violate the National Radio laws by the operation of an unregistered radio station and with conspiracy to violate the tariff act.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A Slight but encouraging upward trend in employment, Indicating that a number of factories have reopened and that others running on part time are getting back to normal, is reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Many tables have been taken for a card party in aid of the Mary Fisher Home, which will take place tomorrow afternoon In the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. The home, which is in Tenafly, N.J., offers a shelter for needy authors, teachers, artists and others in professions.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Consolidation of all Federal activities in connection with transportation into one department under a Cabinet officer to be known as Secretary of Transport has been recommended to the Chamber of Commerce of the United States by the advisory board of the National League of Commission Merchants.

BOSTON, April 10. -- The Boston Red Sox tied their Spring series with the Boston Braves today by beating the National Leaguers, 4 to 1, in the city series. The game was played in very cold weather, but 5,000 attended and saw an airtight fielding game, neither side making a misplay, but very little hitting.

The saving of civilization from the chaos it now faces is paralyzed by man's inability to outgrow in thousands of years his superstitions and fears, the relics of barbaric and pagan ancestors, declared the Rev. Dr. Caleb R. Stetson in his sermon yesterday morning at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street.

BERLIN, April 8. -- The question whether the Reichsbank will manage to preserve a sufficient amount of gold during the coming months, while meeting the requirements of its foreign debt service, continued this week to hold the centre of discussion in financial circles.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, will be the major issue in the national election campaigns of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, according to Mrs. Charles H. Sabin of New York, national chairman, who arrived today with the vanguard of delegates to the organization's annual conference opening here on Tuesday.

This afternoon Mayor WALKER holds his widely heralded public hearing on retrenchment. Some of those who would like to see it bear fruit are frankly pessimistic. Looking back over the record of the years since the war, they can find little in the way of economy but idle gestures.

A complaint against the "apparent disregard" of certain magistrates for written instructions issued last Summer by Chief Magistrate James E. McDonald calling for the enforcement of the city ordinance barring peddlers and other vendors from certain restricted thoroughfares, was voiced yesterday by the Forty-second Street Property Owners and Merchants Association, Inc.

President HINDENBURG'S re-election yesterday was foregone, which explains the total vote, considerably smaller than had been predicted but is full of happy augury. No event in modern German public life has equaled its importance, not only for the German people but for the outside world.

The timorousness, inconsiderateness and incompetence of governments "so varied and so marked as to stagger imagination" are held responsible for the continuance of the world crisis and the disaster threatening all nations, in a report for 1931 of the Division of Intercourse and Education of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, submitted by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, director of the division, and made public yesterday.

TOLEDO, April 10 (AP). -- The doubles team of F. McNeely and J. Pritchett of Indianapolis toppled 1.267 pins to take first place in the Elks National Bowling tournament tonight. One other change was made in this division, B. Montgomery and P. Haseltine. Aubnrn, N.Y., hitting 1,245 for fifth place.

Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, is scheduled to question witnesses in private today and tomorrow on matters the nature of which has not been revealed, but which are understood to mark a new turn in that phase of the city-wide inquiry directed gainst Mayor Walker.

The modem attitude toward the sex relationship has now divorced the Catholic world completely from the non-Catholic, the Rev. Harold Purcell, Catholic editor, declared yesterday in an address before the New York Postoffice Holy Name Society, at the society's tenth annual communion breakfast at the Hotel Astor.

Ten free band concerts will be inaugurated next month in Central and Prospect Parks, giving temporary employment to unemployed musicians. These concerts, in pairs, have been arranged by the Musicians' Emergency Aid and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Reduction in armaments was urged at a youth mass meeting here today at which the young people of America spoke for themselves in favor of peaceful cooperation in place of war. A message was read from Secretary Stimson, who said that progress in disarmament "is one clear contribution to a better world."

Various men and women whose past performances give them frankly veteran ranking occupy most of the important places this week at vaudeville's own Palace Theatre, where some old-fashioned showmanship has apparently restored the policy of a new entertainment every seven days, beginning on Saturday afternoon.

The Eastern Association of College Basketball Coaches was formed yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania at a meeting of coaches from virtually every section of the Eastern States and Ed Kelleher of Fordham was elected president of the new organization.
LONDON, April 10 -- Two buried capitals of ancient kingdoms have been rediscovered by Hr St. John Philby, British Arabic scholar, on his crossing of the great unknown desert of Southern Arabia.

Collapse of the city's unemployment relief work, affecting nearly 600,000 of the 828,000 persona now receiving aid from public or private agencies unless an additional $20,000,000 Is provided for the period from June to November, was predicted by Frank J. Taylor, Commissioner of Public Welfare, in a letter to Mayor Walker made public yesterday.

ENNIS, County Clare, Ireland, April 10. -- Eamon de Valera told an audience of 6,000 at an open air meeting here today that Ireland's "national honor" was at stake in the issue with Great Britain over the Parliamentary oath of allegiance to the King and the land annuities which his government has refused to pay.

"The Truth About Blayds," A.A. Milne's play, will be revived tonight at the Belasco Theatre with Pauline Lord as the star and O.P. Heggie in his original role. "Take My Tip," a comedy by Nat N. Dorfman, will be presented at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre with Donald Meek and Helen Lowell in the leading parts.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Weather and crop reports and the security market are being watched more closely than ever on the Board of Trade here as they are regarded as the dominating factors in the grain trade; especially in wheat, not only for the present, but also for the distant future.

On the rain-soaked, wind-swept quarter-mile track at Macombs Dam Park yesterday Eino Pentti, former Detroit runner, who is now the Queens County two and five mile champion as well as cross-country titleholder, raced to victory in a 5,000-meter run conducted by the Metropolitan A.A.U.

Rain yesterday caused the second postponement in as many days of a scheduled game between the Yankees and the Brooklyn Robins, leaving the honors for the pre-eeason series in possession of the Yankees, on the strength of their Friday victory at Ebbets Field in the only game played of the three that were scheduled.

Copernicus, Newton, Darwin and Einstein, and the discoveries of electricity and of the expanding universe were described yesterday by Sir James Jeans, British astro-physicist. as the six outstanding landmarks of science during the last 6,000 years, in a radio talk on "the present position in science" broadcast from London over the WABC-Columbia network.

GENEVA, April 10. -- It became probable today that the League of Nations Council, which meets in special session on Tuesday to consider the Financial Committee's report, would content itself with naming a committee to study the Danube situation further and report back at the regular session of the Council in May.

The deception practiced upon Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh in connecion with the futile payment of $50,000 ransom for his kidnapped son vas denounced from pulpits in New fork City yesterday. Preachers called the trickery almost worse than the Original crime and declared that the Kidnapping outrage should arouse the nation to a determination to eradicate the evil state of affairs that Bade it possible.

DETROIT, April 10. -- One of the longest training trips ever undertaken by the New York Giants, both as to time and distance, concluded today as it had begun almost eight weeks ago, in a drizzling rain that washed out the final exhibition game with the Tigers.

ST. LOUIS, April 10. -- Winning their first city championship series from the Browns since the World War, the Cardinals defeated their rivals, the Browns, 6 to 2, today for their second straight victory. The Cardinals won yesterday, 5 to 2.

Charles E. Adams, president of the Air Reduction Company, Inc., and James H. Perkins, president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, have consented to serve as chairmen of two committees formed for the protection of International Match Corporation security holders, it was announced yesterday by Lee, Higginson Co.

Steamship officials of the Atlantic passenger lines said yesterday that the new rulings regarding reduction of fares, which were put into force so hurriedly that mistakes were made, would be straightened out at the meeting of the North Atlantic Passenger Conference to be held in London Thursday.

PARIS, April 10 -- While Andre Tardieu was opening his electoral campaign in his constituency with a speech at Belfort today, Deputy Leon Blum, chief of the French Socialist party, was delivering to his own constituency in Narbonne a vigorous denunciation of the Premier's policies and administration.

RESERVE HAT RUH, a German film comedy, with Claere Rommer, Lucie Englisch, Senta Soeneland. Paul Hoerberger and Fritz Kajnpers; directed by Max Obal; an A.A.F.A. production. At the Seventy-eighth Street Tobis Kino.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The budget balancing program recommended by President Hoover will be placed before the House Economy Committee tomorrow in detail by Colonel J. Clawson Roop, Director of the Budget, as Congress enters upon the session's most serious consideration of economic questions.

BOSTON, April 10 -- Dudley Field Malone proposes that the Democratic party nominate Owen D. Young for President, Speaker Garner for Vice President and pledge itself to create, in the event of victory, a coalition Cabinet which would include both Democrats and Republicans.
Morton R. Cross, president of the Cross Brown Co., one of the largest real estate and management organizations in tha country, has become a director of the United Realty Brokers, Inc.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 10 (AP) -- The victory of the Bermuda fleet marked the first time in the history of the series that the craft have won in their home waters. The Bermuda boats found light winds to their liking to capture the series.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Congressional leaders are confronted by a large mass of legislation which must be disposed of with somewhat more than usual speed if Congress is to adjourn in time for the political conventions in June.

The Rev. Dr. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street, asserted in his morning sermon yesterday that the Christian religion was not a "prudential religion" at all but a "reckless religion."
