A lesson in reading, applied by LEE EMERSON BASSETT of Stanford University to college students, but useful to any one resolved on getting the most from literature, is the leading article in The Quarterly Journal of Speech for April. Many intelligent and rapid readers will agree with the faculty members opposed to courses in oral interpretation, that they are a waste of time.

Establishment of a system through which applications for mortgage loans would be handled by the appraisal committee of the Long Island Real Estate Board, Inc., in conjunction with a contact committee representing a group of Brooklyn savings banks, has been recommended by the special mortgage committee of the board.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -- Four prominent Democrats, who oppose the Roosevelt-for-President League in seeking election as delegates at large to the Democratic National Convention, denied today that they were against any Presidential candidate thus far mentioned, but explained why they desired that Pennsylvania's delegates be sent to the convention "unshackled and unpledged."

Threatened by political corruption and economic stress the fate of the country "hangs on the strength of the national conscience," said the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, yesterday in his sermon to the congregation of All Souls Unitarian Church, meeting temporarily in the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Leading scientists and inventors of the United States and other countries will participate tomorrow In a celebration marking the removal of the Patent Office from the home it has occupied for ninety-two years.

BIG STONE GAP, Va., April 10 (AP) -- Bearing welts across their backs which, they charged, were inflicted by sticks in the hands of Harlan County "vigilantes," five students and instructors from Commonwealth College, Mena, Ark., reached Virginia safely today after being ejected from Kentucky.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The "propaganda statistics" of Stephen G. Rich deserve a little further consideration.

No doubt, last week's persistent decline on the Stock Exchange had many causes. Absence of the traditional Springtime "seasonal recovery" in trade, the fact that the country's steel production in March showed by last week's report a decrease of 7 per cent from that of January, whereas even in 1930 and 1931 there had been an increase of 17 to 26 per cent, was at least partly accountable for the market's action.

TORONTO, Ont., April 9. -- "No man familiar with gold mining in Canada, can be other than optimistic concerning its future. We have stable government. Our mining regulations are on the whole reasonable and generally acceptable to those in concerning its future.

FRENCH LICK. Ind., April 10 (AP) -- Best out of a field of 136. Chick Evans, veteran amateur of Chicago. today won the first mid-West amateur championship on the difficult hill course with scores of 73, 68, 75 for a total of 216.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 10. -- Five persons were killed and twelve others were injured, three of them seriously, in a mysterious explosion early today which wrecked a threestory brick apartment block on Ferry Street in the congested heart of this city's "Little Syria."

The demand of the nation today is for less partisanship and more common sense in dealing with the present emergency, Governor George White of Ohio told the Ohio Society at a dinner meeting last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Governmental expenditures, he said, must come down; confiscatory taxes are not the remedy, but the budget must be balanced by paring the costs of government.

Retail Gain Aids Market Activity. Mail orders reaching this market yesterday were heavy, the volume running ahead of last week in view of improved retail trade during the last few days. Buying interest centred on untrimmed coats, jacket dresses, millinery, mesh hosiery, underwear and varied dress accessories.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S radio address last week continues to excite wonder and to provoke questions. How did he propose to "restore pur"chasing power to the farming half "of the country ?" Criticizing other plans, he produced none of his own. But on one point he exposed himself to instant refutation.

THE Giants haven't won a pennant since 1924. This may be John McGraw's year to climb back to the top with his boys. A seventh-inning stretch is a convention in baseball, but a seven-year stretch without a pennant is a long, sad period in the life of the Little Napoleon of the diamond.

Governor franklin D. Roosevelt visited yesterday for the first time this year the rooms of the Democratic State Committee at 331 Madison Avenue, where the campaign for his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President has its headquarters.

The Department of Hospitals was charged last night at the New York Academy of Medicine with, "robbing" physicians employed in municipal hospitals and dispensaries of their rightful fees, particularly in socalled compensation cases, by taking advantage of an antiquated law enacted several years before the workmen's compensation act was passed, under which physicians employed at municipal hospitals are forbidden to receive fees in such cases.

OSSINING, N.Y., April 11 -- After twenty-two years of freedom Walter Bannigan, 47 years old, walked into Sing Sing prison today and surrendered himself to-finish serving twelve years of a sentence of fourteen years and four months. He explained that he had "got religion," and said:

Despite a substantial increase in the number of transactions, the combined sales and net profits of R.H. Macy Co. and its three affiliated stores for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 30, showed declines. The number of transactions increased from 53,856,355 to 60,981,264, or 13.23 per cent, while the combined sales decreased from $147,769,497 to $144,611,817, or 2.14 per cent.

BOWIE, Md., April 11 -- Chestnut Oak, the son of Apprehension and Bantry Pass, made his 6-year-old debut in the feature George Washington Bicentennial Trophy Purse at Bowie today and won by the narrow margin of a nose. Avalon was second, four lengths before Soupcon, while Blimp and Pigeon Hole completed the field in the order named.

Mr. H. ST. JOHN PHILBY, who is reported to have discovered in a "hairpin-shaped" traverse of the Ruba-el-Khali the sites of two ancient cities, Magan and Ubar, was already an Arabian explorer of note. BERTRAM THOMAS struck for the interior of the unknown southern desert, crossing from Dhofar on the central coast to Dohar on the Persian Gulf, a distance of 900 miles.
Overcast skies, rain and heavy seas for the most part dampened the enthusiasm of those who ventured forth over the week-end, especially on Sunday, to fish in the waters around Long Island.
DETROIT, April 11 -- Charley Daw and Frank Benkovic of Milwaukee are the 1932 doubles champions of the American Bowling Congress.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 11 -- An official communique concerning Prince Nicolas's flying visit to Rumania, issued today, says that he has "requested" a year's leave on account of Ill health, which forces him to rest abroad."

All preliminaries having been completed, the National League clubs will start today in their fifty-seventh annual pennant derby, while six clubs of the American League will begin their thirty-second campaign. The American League's formal opening was staged in Washington yesterday with the Senators meeting the Red Sox.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Benjamin N. Cardozo, the newly appointed associate justice of the Supreme Court, today handed down his first opinion since he became a member of the court. The opinion was a dissent in the case of Fierce Coombes, petitioner, against Milton E. Getz, which reached the Supreme Court on a writ of certiorari from the California Supreme Court.

Five hundred impoverished artists of the Greenwich Village and Washington Square sections who are too proud to accept charity have asked Park Commissioner Walter R. Herrick for permission to set up an openair market for art works around Washington Square Park.

Withdrawal of passenger ships from the transatlantic trade as a means of reducing operating expenses will be discussed when representatives of the ship lines in the North Atlantic passenger conference meet in London on Thursday. During the past week the matter has been placed before the various lines.
Germany's Republican Succession. Because of President HINDENBURG'S age, the thought was bound to occur that before very long the office of Reichsprasident might have to be filled again.

The final concert of the season by the Beethoven Association, last night in Town Hall, was of special interest and musical value. The burden of the performances was borne by a small string orchestra of players from the Juilliard Graduate School, reinforced when the situation called for it by the Barrere Ensemble of Wind Instruments.

GENEVA, April 11. -- To help dispel fear of invasion and thus promote a greater feeling of national and individual security throughout the world, Hugh Gibson, in the name of the United States delegation and the United States Government, proposed this afternoon to the disarmament conference total abolition of weapons of peculiarly aggressive value -- tanks, heavy mobile guns and gases.

Students rose on chairs and their voices rose higher and higher for two hours last night at a turbulent mass meeting of the Art Students League, held in the exhibition gallery of their school at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, to protest against the resignation of John Sloan as their president.
ALBANY, April 11 -- Commenting on the Supreme Court's upholding the Democratic contention on the reapportionment resolution, Governor Roosevelt said today:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 11 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors authorized today the sale of $12,002,000 in long-term bonds to take up issues of certificates of indebtedness which fall due on June 5. The resolution authorizing the Controller to advertise the sale fixed a maximum rate of 6 per cent interest on highway bonds and of 5 per cent for all other issues.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to comment briefly upon, the article of S.O. Levinson, titled "War Debts and Reparations," which you published.

While Richard Whitney was testifying on short selling before a Senate committee in Washington yesterday, the nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange recommended his re-election to the presidency of that institution. If elected, as in all probability he will be, he will begin his third term In May.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 11.-- All four of Yale's varsity crews resumed practice on the Housatonic today after a week-end rest, their only let-up of the present Spring vacation. Only one workout was held.

LA PAZ, April 11 -- The Argentine Government is attempting to bring about a renewal of diplomatic relations between Bolivia and Paraguay, it was learned here today. Relations were broken off last July because the Bolivian Government regarded as unfriendly a statement given out in Washington by Charge d' Affaires

BOSTON, Mass., April 11 -- Thomas P. Beal, president of the Second National Bank, was elected today president of the Boston Clearing House Association, and Alfred L. Ripley, president of the Merchants National Bank, retired after Having served for nine years.
CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- Fair skies and good crowds promised to send the thirty-first American Association flag race off to a fine start on the Eastern fronts tomorrow.
William P. Kenneally, leader of the old Twelfth Assembly District, was elected last evening chairman of the Tammany Executive Committee, to succeed the late Peter J. Dooling.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, speaking last night at a men's dinner marking the thirty-first anniversary of the pastorate of the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman at the Central Congregational Church in Brooklyn, discussed the world economic situation and warned that the time had passed when one man or one nation could be an entity to itself.

The transaction whereby Kreuger Toll arranged in June, last, to sell to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation a large interest in the L.M. Ericsson Telephone Company was rescinded by mutual consent when Ivar Kreuger made his last visit to the United States, it was revealed yesterday.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was hailed last night as the next President of the United States at a dinner meeting of about 100 members of the Association of Collection Agencies at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

LONDON, April 11 -- The stock markets recovered their cheerfulness today, partly as a result of von Hindenburg's election and partly as a reflection of Saturday's strength in Wall Street. British Government funds improved.

BUENOS AIRES, April 11 (AP) -- Towns in Mendoza Province asked the Ministry of Interior tonight to rush drums of oxygen for the treatment of cases of asphyxiation from volcanic gas poured forth by erupting craters in the Andes.

FLORENCE, Italy, April 11 -- Premier Mussolini as a playwright has the same forceful views and power of expression that have contributed so greatly to His political success. His dynamic personality injects itself into his dramas as strongly as it does into his other fields of activity, says his collaborator, Giovacchino Forzano, director of the Scala Opera.

First editions of famous authors from the library of Frank Irving Fletcher of this city will go on exhibition today at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., prior to the three-day sale beginning on April 19.

The Women's Auxiliary of the West Side Hospital will hold a card party this afternoon at the home of Mrs. Walter E. Rahte, 876 Park Avenue. The proceeds will be used in providing free care and treatment for needy patients. Mrs. Schuyler Knox, Mrs. Thomas Clark, Mrs. J. Louis Schaeffer, Mrs. Ralph Moolten and Mrs. R. de Mille Brown have arranged the benefit.

BERLIN, April 11 -- With German fascism's second attempt within a month to gain control of the Reich Government successfully repulsed in yesterday's re-election of President von Hindenburg by a decisive majority, the activities of all party camps today turned swiftly to preparations for the election of a Prussian Diet on April 24.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- Notice from Senator Tydings of Maryland that lie would not press for action today on his resolution directing the Senate Finance Committee to strike out import levies from the revenue bill precipitated a brief debate over copper.

A picture of the days when Rudyard Kipling, "the dark young man from India," was the great literacy figure of the English-speaking world, is given in an item that Arnold Bennett wrote in his journal on Oct. 22, 1898. "This is my idea of fame," Bennett wrote.

TRENTON, N.J., April 11 -- The United Public Service Company, with offices at 15 Exchange Place, Jersey City, has been ordered by John J. Fallen, Vice Chancellor, to show cause before him on next Monday why a receiver should not be apuointed to take over and conserve the assets of the company. The order, which was granted on Friday, was filed in the Chancery Court Clerk's office here today.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The sale of the first series of "baby bonds" which the treasury announced on March 6, in connection with the administration's nation-wide drive to bring hoarded money back into circulation, will be ended on Wednesday, Secretary Mills said this evening.

CANBERRA, April 11 -- The Commonwealth Government issued a new proclamation tonight, attaching all betting and receipts at race courses and entertainment taxes in New South Wales and also the revenues of the State railways and tramways to meet the default of Premier Long's Government.

PARIS, April 11 -- After reflecting overnight on the results of yesterday's German elections France has decided that, after all, there is precious little to cause satisfaction. Today's French press is far more concerned over Adolf Hitler's gains than it is reassured by President von Hindenburg's re-election.

In so far as yesterday's action of the stock and bond markets was response to the hearing at Washington on the "bonus bill," it served merely to indicate speculative "Wall Street's state of mind. It is now a considerable time since that part of the financial community has been able to frame any view of the general situation except such as a timid and imaginative reader or the tabloid newspapers might have entertained.

Pursuing his plan to bring the affairs of Mayor Walker before an early public hearing, Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, left his offices yesterday to conduct what was understood to be the first of a series of secret examinations of witnesses.

A celebration marking the eighty-fifth anniversary of the birth of Joseph Pulitzer, founder of the Columbia University School of Journalism was held yesterday afternoon at the school by members of the faculty and the entire student body.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, testifying today before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, flatly denied that bear raids take place on the Stock Exchange.

The Boston Metropolitan District, successor to the Metropolitan District of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, by virtue of a bill signed by Governor Ely on Saturday, is expected to sell tomorrow its issue of $23,125,000 of bonds to a syndicate headed by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, the Guaranty Company of New York, the National City Company, the Bankers Trust Company, and the First National Old Colony Corporation.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The nation's gratitude to the Red Cross for ministering to the victims of drought, storm and unemployment in time of need was expressed today by President Hoover.

A $1,000 mortgage certificate comprised yesterday's turnover on the Real Estate Securities Exchange. The price trend in bond quotations was mixed, the asked price being revised upward in numerous instance, while in other cases the bid was lowered.

ST. LOUIS, April 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Marie Warmbier of Chicago set two new records tonight and took the lead in the singles and all-events of the Women's International Bowling Congress tournament. She had a score of 658 to establish a new mark for the singles and a total of 1,807 to shatter the all-events record.
The North German Lloyd liner Bremen arrived yesterday from Europe, completing the first half of her fiftieth round trip in the Atlantic service.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Robert Burton, born in England, Feb. 8, 1576, published the "Anatomy of Melancholy" in 1621, yet the following extracts from that work accurately describe conditions of vital interest today:

ALBANY, April 11 -- A distinct stabilization trend is visible in American Israel, Rabbi Louis I. Newman of the Congregation Rodeph Sholom, New York City, declared at the opening meeting tonight of the State Federation of Temple Sisterhoods' three-day convention.

NEWARK, N.J., April 11 -- An exhibit of theatre arts was opened at the Newark Art Club, 59 Lincoln Park, tonight, with a private showing for members and artists. The display, which includes scenery designed by Norman Bel Geddes and Rollo Peters, will be open to the public daily until May 1.

Newton D. Baker and George W. Wickersham both oppose adoption of the Pittman resolution, which will be voted on by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee tomorrow. The resolution proposes to defer further consideration of the World Court protocols until the President has again asked the signatory States whether each of them understands the Root formula according to the interpretation placed on it by Secretary of State Stimson.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The United States Supreme Court today ruled illegal the resolution under which the New York Legislature, dominated by Republicans, voted in 1931 a Congressional reapportionment. Drawn as a resolution, the measure debarred Governor Roosevelt from passing on the legislation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A year ago there appeared a statement from Herr Fred Groissmayr that brought not a little comment on the part of meteorologists in the United States. In effect, Herr Groissmayr asserted that if the Winter temperatures of "Winnipeg, Man., fall materially below the average, the following Spring will be late in the Eastern United States.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Opponents of soldier bonus legislation became more hopeful today that such measures would not be enacted at this session of Congress when Senator Robinson, Democratic floor leader, and Representative Rainey, the Democratic House leader, came out emphatically against immediate cash payment.

HAVANA, April 11 (AP) -- The government denied today reports brought up in this United States Senate that three students awaiting military trial on April 14 on charges of having violated Cuba's "explosives law" in a plot to assassinate President Gerardo Machado had not been permitted to see counsel.

ALBANY, April 11 -- Voters who have been in the service of the army or navy or who have changed from one election district to another in the same county may enroll any time between now and Aug. 21, according to the political calendar which has just been issued by Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State.

The Presbytery of New York, meeting yesterday in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, voted down five amendments suggested by the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church. One proposal was to license probationers to preach the gospel.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Baseball put on one of its finest shows -- an extra-inning pitchers' battle -- to usher in the 1932 major league season today before the nation's Chief Executive and First Lady. A crowd of nearly 18,000 attended.

Loans of stock by both the Tri-Continental Corporation, an investment trust listed on the New York Stock Exchange, and its affiliate. Selected Industries, Inc., increased in the first quarter of the year. These are virtually the only trusts that have let It be known generally that they lend stocks from their portfolios as a means of increasing their revenue.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 11 -- Sir Josiah Stamp, English financier, economist and industrialist, in a lecture here tonight voiced the belief that 50 or 60 per cent of the economic unrest of the world would be remedied when the universal demand for gold reached such a low ebb that the price level would rise and allow a wage increase.

In the presence of Mayor Walker and other city officials ground was broken yesterday for a new $500,000 outdoor sports arena to be known as Madison Square Garden Bowl. It will be built on an eighteen-acre plot in Queens, and work was immediately begun to prepare the structure for the Schmeling-Sharkey fight on June 16.

Acceptance of the terms on which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation would extend a loan of $18,000,000 to the St. Louis Southwestern Railway (Cotton Belt) will depend on action by the Southern Pacific Company, which probably will be determined on Thursday.

Social agencies have been "put or the spot" through the short-sighted cutting of community budgets in all parts of the nation, Weaver Pangburn, director of publicity of the National Recreation Association, declared yesterday at the biennial convention of executives of the Camp Fire Girls of America at the Barbizon-Plaza.

GENEVA, April 11 -- The informal get-together meetings of the principal political leaders of the League of Nations Council, which it was assumed would be held here during the corning week, are much in doubt tonight. For one reason or another their comings and goings are now so arranged that some of them, upon whom most depends, will not be here at the same time.

It was said that when VIVIANI was in America, though he spoke in French everybody understood him; that when President WILSON a little later spoke only in English in France everybody there understood him, and that when Marshal JOFFRE was here everybody understood him though he did not speak at all.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 11-- Scoring 38 on the outgoing nine and returning in the same figures for a 76, H. H. (Tex) Newton of New York captured the medal today in. the qualifying round of the annual Mason and Dixon golf tournament, leading the field by a single stroke.

Copyright, 1932 by N.A.N.A., Inc. The policy of Paul von Hindenburg, the aged President of the German Republic, has been approved by an overwhelming majority of the German people. The increase of 700,000 votes in the second round of the election over what he polled on March 13 is remarkable.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- The business of the Utility Securities Company, stock-distributing organization of the Insull utility system, is to be closed out and a new company will be formed to carry on its security-selling activities. Capital for the new company, which will bear the same corporate title, will be furnished by the Insull operating companies, Commonwealth Edison, Peoples Gas and Public Service of Northern Illinois.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Bullish sentiment was strong today in the wheat pit on the Board of Trade. At no time did futures dip below Saturday's finish, and persistent purchases by houses with Eastern connections, combined with general buying toward the last, swept prices steadily upward to close at the top at net gains of 3 1/4 to 3 1/2 cents and at the best prices registered since March 10.

TULSA, Okla., April 11 (AP). -- The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey made the $1 a barrel top for midcontinent crude oil unanimous among the major concerns today. The 15-cent a barrel increase previously adopted by other companies was made effective by the Carter Oil Company, subsidiary of the New Jersey company.

Columbia's freshman oarsmen yesterday received the most strenuous workout they have experienced this season as they directed efforts toward reaching peak form for their race with Kent School at Kent, Conn., Saturday.
The season's final Coffee Dance took place last night in the Assembly Room of the Cosmopolitan Club. Many of the subscribers entertained with dinners and took their guests to the club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one of thousands deprived of a musical background during my school days, I am surprised, in fact shocked, to read the statement made by Dr. Russell Carter, supervisor of music of the State Education Department at a convention of the New York Federation of Music Clubs held to devise means of obtaining school credits for work in music.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The new borne of the Patent Office, a unit of the $17,500,000 Commerce Department building, was dedicated today in the presence of numerous inventors, patent law attorneys and friends of the bureau.

The year 1931 was one of the most tiring in the history of the Illinois Central Railroad, L.A. Downs, president, said in his annual report, made public yesterday. Mr. Downs cited general conditions and competition from other forms of transportation as adversely affecting the line.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius has returned from Bermuda to 960 Fifth Avenue and shortly will go to her home in Locust Valley.

PESHAWAR, April 11 -- "The first 5,000 Red Shirts," operating in the Northwest Frontier Province, picketed the polling booths at Charsadda and Mardan with such violence and effect today that at Charsadda this evening only one vote had been recorded.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- The Yankees were camped tonight ready for the opening battle of their pennant campaign tomorrow, which, weather permitting, will pit them against Connie Mack's Athletics, the league champions and the team which it is popularly agreed the Yankees, or any other American League company, will have to beat to gain the coveted pennant.

Controller Charles W. Berry wrote to Mayor Walker and Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor yesterday denouncing the latter's statement that the Controller had refused to cooperate with unemployment relief agencies as a "malicious" and "incredibly contemptible" falsehood.

BASLE, April 11 -- Despite the world economic difficulties the Bank for International Settlements remains a paying institution. At the regular meeting here today the bank's directors were informed that at the close of its second fiscal year the bank would be in a position to announce next month at the annual assembly the distribution of about 4,000,000 Swiss francs (about $776,000) as dividends from the profits of this year's business.

While the president of the Stock Exchange was testifying in Washington yesterday on the subject of short selling, the market continued to absorb liquidation. Brokers reported small-scale speculation for the Fall and this information was apparently confirmed by the circumstance of a comparatively limited demand for stocks in the "loan crowd" after the close.

Fifty-two persons indicted for conspiracy to violate the national prohibition law by bringing in cargoes of liquor on the oil tankers Raritan Sun and Blue Sunoco of the Sun Oil Company, without the knowledge of the owners of the vessels, pleaded guilty yesterday in the United States District Court in Brooklyn before Judge Grover M. Moscowitz.

Unless the block-aid effort brings in a sizable amount of additional funds, the work of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee from May to October will have to be materially curtailed, Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the committee, said in a statement yesterday after publication of "Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor's letter to Mayor Walker concerning the possible collapse of the city's unemployment relief program.

HONOLULU, April 11 -- Three witnesses for the prosecution today outlined the entire circumstantial case against Mrs. Granville Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, her son-in-law, and the two navy enlisted men, A.G. Jones and E.J. Lord, who are on trial for the murder of Joseph Kahahawai, a Hawaiian athlete.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The text of the speech delivered today, by Hugh Gibson, acting chairman of the American delegation to the general disarmament conference at Geneva, before the general commission of the conference, was made public today by the State Department as follows:
PINEHURST, N.C., April 11 -- Mrs. Sidney Willcox entertained with a large dinner dance at the Finehurst Country Club tonight in honor of Mrs. Robert Gould Shaw of Boston, Among the guests were:

The National Public Service Corporation reports for 1931 net income of $3,703,948 after taxes, charges and depreciation, including $600,000 profit on sale of properties, equal, after preferred dividends, to $2.18 a share on 1,122,695 combined shares of A and E common stocks outstanding on Dec. 31, 1931.

DUBLIN, April 11 -- The straightforward and unambiguous terms of J.H. Thomas's replies and Eamon de Valera's notes, both of which were published here this afternoon, are expected to clear the air. While the communications leave no doubt regarding the gravity of the situation, the friendly tone of the British dispatches and their freedom from any kind of threat are welcomed.

During the last year the trend of motion pictures "has been away from sordidness and toward romance and clean comedy," Will H. Hays says in his tenth annual report as head of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America. The increasing number of pictures "that are raising the standard of public entertainment" is also increasing the ''potential" audience, he thinks.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Responding to an urgent appeal from President Hoover, Democratic members of the Senate agreed on a campaign tonight to put the tax bill through Congress at the earliest posaible date.

MEXICO CITY, April 11 -- A passenger train bound from Laredo, Texas, to Mexico City was derailed late last night at the station of Obregon, about 200 miles north of Mexico City. The accident was laid to criminals.

SANTA ANA, Cal., April 11 (AP) -- Dr. Besaica Raiche, 58 years old, reputed to be the first woman who ever flew an airplane, died yesterday at her home in Balboa, a beach resort near here. She was found in her bed by her daughter Catherine. Death apparently was caused by heart disease.

Dates of events for Westchester golfers have been announced by John A. Maher, president of the West-Chester County Golf Association, with the season opening tournament scheduled to be played at the WestChester Hills Golf Club on May 18. This will be the first of ten one-day tournaments which have been arranged.

TRENTON, N.J., April 11 -- Land sharks, whose activities were checked in a concerted campaign several years ago, are again active in New Jersey, George S. Burgess, secretary of the State chamber of commerce, declared today in issuing a warning to residents to be on the alert for this type of promoter.

The change in the bill rates last Saturday had relatively little effect on the day's business in acceptances, there being practically no change in the volume, notwithstanding that the demand was good. On the Stock Exchange call loans continued at 2 1/2 per cent, Street trades at 2 and Federal funds traded 1/8@1/4.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 11 -- The Princeton varsity eight outclassed the junior varsity boat in a mile-anda-half race over the Lake Carnegie course today as the Tiger oarsmen opened their final week of training for the first race of the Spring with the Navy here Saturday.

Predicating his arguments on the theory that the general trend of the white race is toward extinction, as is shown by the declining birth rate in various countries, A.M. Carr-Saunders, Professor of Social Science at the Liverpool University, predicts eventual universal limitation of the family.

A large exhibition of sculpture by Carl Milles has been installed at the Brooklyn Museum, to remain until May 15. This constitutes the local public's first opportunity to see a really representative group of work by the famous Swedish sculptor, whom many critics consider the foremost plastic artist of our time.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that Spencer Kellogg Sons, Inc., of Buffalo was prohibited from limiting its liabilities growing out of the sinking of its motor launch Linseed King in the Hudson River Dec. 20, 1926.

LONDON, April 11 -- The notes recently exchanged between the governments of Great Britain and the Irish Free State concerning the oath of allegiance and the land annuities dispute were given to the House of Commons today after J.H. Thomas, Minister for Dominions, had reiterated his former statement that the British Government was going to stand absolutely by the Anglo-Irish treaty agreements.

BERNARDS VILLE, N.J., April 11 -- Under the most discouraging conditions, the annual trials of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club were started today at Basking Ridge, about half way between this town and Morristown.

The New York Board of Trade will meet tomorrow at 12:15 P.M. at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue, to take action on several reports by its committees, favoring legislation for re-sale price maintenance, regulation of intercoastal commerce by the Shipping Board and a further broadening of the income tax base by a reduction in exemptions.

A petition asking for reconsideration of the Players' recent decision not to present their customary annual revival this June is now being circulated among members of the club, and probably will be placed before the board of the Players late this month, it was learned yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 11 -- A committee headed by John D. Rockefeller Jr. recommended to the Board of Supervisors today that the 200-acre county park at Woodlands Lake in the town of Greenburg be named the V. Everit Macy Park in, memory of the president of the West-Chester County Park Commission.

LONDON, April 11 (AP) -- An appeal to all "sportsmen and patriots" to help raise a fund of u20,000 ($80,000) to send the British Olympic team to the Los Angeles games was made today by Sir Harold Bowden at a dinner of the British Olympic Association.

John Kilcullcn of the New York A.C., national junior heavyweight champion, knocked out Donald Lloyd, unattached, in the second round of a special bout at the amateur tournament staged at the New York A.C. last night. It was the first time that a Winged Foot boxer had been permitted to compete at the home club.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The House Economy Committee today sought right of way for legislation reducing by 11 per cent all Federal salaries over $1,000 a year. At the same time the Senate Appropriations Committee announced the program agreed on Saturday for reducing the State, Justice, Commerce and Labor appropriations bills $12,423,353.21 under the amount passed by the House, with a $1,119,500 cut for the Prohibition Bureau.
MONROVIA, Cal., April 11 -- These international outboard motor-boat races are a family affair for the Turnbulls -- in fact, something like a picnic.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 11 -- Charles J. Tiensch 2d, '33, of Newark was elected captain of the Princeton varsity gym team for the coming season today. Charles B. Brick, '33, of Crosswicks, N.J., was named manager of the team.

The system of producing opera in this country must be modified in the light of new conditions and put on a cooperative basis, declared John McCormack in an interview yesterday. The tenor, who will make his final appearance of the season as soloist tonight with the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra at the Metropolitan Opera House, added that he did not consider opera "dead," as some critics of opera have asserted.

Fritz Kley, German heavyweight wrestler, who is unbeaten since his arrival in the United States, added Tiny Roebuck, Choctaw Indian, to his list of victims in the feature match last night at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The copper mining industry of the United States is in extreme distress and billions of dollars invested in copper and dependent activities are threatened with total loss, President Hoover was informed today by the Governors of the twelve States in which the copper mining industry is centred.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 11 -- For 400 miles along the Andes an unknown number of towering volcanoes roared into activity today, frightening tens of thousands of Chileans from their homes.

ST. LOUIS, April 11 -- Charles (Chick) Hafey, 1931 batting champion of the National League and regular left fielder for the St. Louis Cardinals in their four championship years, was traded today to the Cincinnati Reds for Benny Frey, a right-handed pitcher, and Harvey Hendrick, utility player.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The government today moved to a higher court with its attempt to convict Bishop James Cannon Jr. and Miss Ada L. Burroughs of Richmond, Va., of violation of the Federal corrupt practices act.

SHANGHAI, April 11 -- The prospects for the resumption or the eventual success of the Sino-Japanese armistice negotiations were dimmed today when the Chinese delegates sent word they had received no instructions from Nanking or Loyang and that they could not attend the meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- Attorney General Mitchell defended in the Supreme Court today the action of President Hoover in signing a bill after the final adjournment of the Congress which had passed it.

Robert Burns, the "heaven-taught plowman," and Scotland's greatest poet, had "an affectionate and reckless nature," but he was neither a spendthrift nor a habitual drunkard, Professor Franklin Bliss Snyder of Northwestern University writes in "The Life of Robert Burns," published today by Macmillan.

The annual report of the New York Water Service Corporation for 1931 shows net income of $752,480 after depreciation, taxes, charges and minority interest, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $1.83 a share on 26,015 common shares, against $708,664, or $1.75 a share, earned in 1930.

The team that will carry the hopes of Brooklyn fandom in the National League race will show its wares in its opening championship campaign game today at Ebbets Field when it comes to grips with the Boston Braves.

Several factors doubtless enter into the break-down of labor discipline to which the Soviet authorities attribute the serious delays in their industrial program. Workingmen who have been taught that they are the masters in a proletarian State will show a natural tendency to scrutinize and discuss orders from above.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 11 (AP) -- The central cordillera of the Andes snapped into terrifying activity today and set its volcanoes to belching fire and ashes in a darkening mantle over panic-stricken cities.

Benny Leonard advanced a bit further in his come-back campaign by defeating Buster Brown of Baltimore at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The bout, scheduled for ten rounds, was witnessed by a crowd of 4,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The reported plight of three Cuban students held for trial in Cuba in a bombing plot was brought before the Senate today by Senator Borah, with the assertion that, if true, it was not a matter to which the United States could be indifferent.

The fifteenth season of symphonic concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium of City College will be given by the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra this Summer, Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of the Stadium Concerts, announced yesterday.

Thanks to the work of the Gibson committee, supported by the unremitting efforts of the private welfare organizations and supplemented by liberal appropriations from city funds, the work of unemployment relief has gone steadily forward. Hundreds of thousands of men and women have managed to survive the misery of another Winter without regular work.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that prohibition agents have no right to hunt for evidence after making an arrest if they do not carry a search warrant. The court held that agents who searched for and seized papers in Room 604 at 1,547 Broadway, on Jan. 12, 1931, violated the constitutional rights of Daniel M. Lefkowitz and Pauline Paris.

Taking umbrage at a charge of "misplaced leniency" made against him by the Forty-second Street Property Owners and Merchants Association, Inc., Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein, sitting in Jefferson Market Court yesterday, used eight peddling cases as the basis for a retort.

WTLMINGTON, Del., April 11 -- A teletype alarm was flashed through the States of Delaware, Pennsylvania and New Jersey tonight urging all police to be on the lookout for a blue Buick roadster with yellow wire wheels and bearing Delaware license plates 24-302, in which Charles Chickeringr, 16 years old, described as "son of the president of the du Pont Company," had been kidnapped from his home in Wilmington, Del.

The will of Major William F. Deegan, Tenement House Commissioner, who died on April 3, was filed for probate yesterday in the Bronx Surrogate's Court. The beneficiaries of the estate, which was recorded as amounting to less than $10,000 personal, with no real property, are Evelyn H. Wagner, secretary to Mayor Walker; William S. Deegan, his son, and James Madison Blackwell, a friend.

Directors of the American Petroleum Institute urged yesterday the imperative need of a balanced Federal budget and indicated their readiness to accept, with industry generally, a manufacturers' sales tax. At the same time they expressed determined opposition to special excise levies directed against lubricating oils and oils transported through pipe lines.

The Bond Club of New York will hold its twelfth annual field day on Friday, May 20, at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, it was announced yesterday by G. Munro Hubbard, president of the club. William H. Long Jr. of Doremus Co. has been named chairman of the executive committee.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 11-- Andrew F. O'Rourke of 120 West Grand Street, for thirty-seven years a member of the engineering staff of the Elizabeth Consolidated Gas Company, died yesterday at the Alexian Brothers Hospital after a long illness. He was born in Newcastle-onTyne, England, sixty-six years ago and was ^ resident of this city a half century.

LOS ANGELES, April 11 -- At dawn today the United States fleet started steaming out of Los Angeles Harbor to set the stage for "force-firing" practice, in which 104 surface vessels and nearly 300 aircraft will simulate a modern naval battle with a "phantom enemy."

Warning against excessive public spending and against inflation schemes by which Congress and the country seek to "pull themselves up by the bootstraps," Representative Frederick M. Davenport, prospective candidate for the Republican nomination for Senator, demanded a curb on expenditures, in talks before the Twenty-second and Twenty-third District Republican Clubs on Washington Heights last night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Reading over the articles on the "Two Americas," by Dr. Stephen P. Duggan, which have appeared in THE TIMES, it appears to me that Dr. Duggan seems to imply that the South American people were used very badly by the North American bankers who were guilty in forcing several billion good American dollars upon their reluctant governments.

Directors of the American Petroleum Institute urged yesterday the imperative need of a balanced Federal budget and indicated their readiness to accept, with industry generally, a manufacturers' sales tax. At the same time they expressed determined opposition to special excise levies directed against lubricating oils and oils transported through pipe lines.

The Bond Club of New York will hold its twelfth annual field day on Friday, May 20, at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, it was announced yesterday by G. Munro Hubbard, president of the club. William H. Long Jr. of Doremus Co. has been named chairman of the executive committee.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 11-- Andrew F. O'Rourke of 120 West Grand Street, for thirty-seven years a member of the engineering staff of the Elizabeth Consolidated Gas Company, died yesterday at the Alexian Brothers Hospital after a long illness. He was born in Newcastle-onTyne, England, sixty-six years ago and was ^ resident of this city a half century.

LOS ANGELES, April 11 -- At dawn today the United States fleet started steaming out of Los Angeles Harbor to set the stage for "force-firing" practice, in which 104 surface vessels and nearly 300 aircraft will simulate a modern naval battle with a "phantom enemy."

Failure of the Four-Power conference at London to agree upon a relief plan for the Danubian States has inevitably produced an exchange of recriminations. Paris loses no time in citing additional proof that Germany is really opposed to European recovery.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh has received no word from the kidnappers of his baby since he paid the $50,000 ransom they demanded, but one of the $20 bills with which the payment was made was recognized yesterday by a sharp-eyed Connecticut shopkeeper.

The response of the public to the Metropolitan Opera crisis has beer warmer and more spontaneous than expected. The desire on the part of operagoers to have their opera here continue has prompted a large number of them to come forward without solicitation to offer to the management expressions as well as more concrete evidence of encouragement and support.

Crime is cumulative. To violation of parole, violation of treaty, violation of the Volstead act succeeds a darker deed. English idiom has been violated. From rocky Ithaca a distinguished Latinist, far-seen in English also, points an urbane but accusing finger:

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is too early to be able to say what will be the outcome of the Disarmament Conference, but it is pleasing: to realize how closely the British delegation is working with that from the United States. There certainly is a very earnest desire on the part of every one to make the conference a success.
PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- Vincent Reed of Sigma Theta scored two knockouts in the Arena tonight to win the 126-pound title in the Middle Atlantic States A.A.U. amateur boxing tournament.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee approved by a vote of 3 to 2 this afternoon the nomination of Judge James H. Wilkerson to be a judge of the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals.

Mrs. Margaret V. Kieley, widow of Timothy J. Kieley, engineer and inventor, left an estate of $3,115,543 gross and $2,872,224 net, of which $110,000 goes to four Catholic religious and charitable institutions, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12.-- President Hoover is confident that the $2,400,000,000 bonus bill is no longer a "menace" to the nation's financial stability. This confidence is based upon assurances of Republican and Democratic leaders that the measure would be defeated, probably in the Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- The American League season opened with a high degree of auspiciousness for the Yankees today, featuring five home runs of their own making and a 12-to-6 victory over Connie Mack's three-time pennant-winning Athletics.

While the calliope was blaring out the first movement of a new circus season yesterday a headliner of the old days lay critically ill at Bellevue. He was William O'Dale, who thirty-five years ago rode with the best of them. Seventy-three years old now, and only recently retired from an active circus life of more than half a century, he was taken to the hospital with pneumonia.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Steagall bill providing for a $500,000,000 "bank deposit guarantee fund" was favorably reported today by the House Banking and Currency Com. ttee. The bill sets up a board to administer the fund, and. according to Mr. Steagall, provides for initial resources of $1,000,000,000 through provision for a $500,000,000 loan to the board from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in addition to the fund it creates.

LONDON, April 12 -- The Fox Film Corporation and the United American Investing Corporation of New York issued a writ here today to recover P4,000,000 (about $15,200,000 at the present rate of exchange) that the Fox company contributed toward financing and investing in shares of the Gaumont British Picture Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- The World Court protocol does not prevent submission to the court of requests for advisory opinions affecting American interests nor the rendering of such opinions by the court, Senator Pittman said tonight in a letter to Philip C. Jessup, secretary of the National World Court Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Speedy repeal of the prohibition amendment was predicted tonight by Representative Florence Kahn of California and Howard Lee McBain, Professor of Law at Columbia University, at a banquet of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. will arrive from New York this week.

Two scientific processes, one the manufacture of diamonds "larger | than ever before produced artificially" and the other the production of artificial wool from jute, were announced yesterday afternoon by Professor Ralph H. McKee of the Department of Chemical Engineering, Columbia University.

PARIS, April 12.-- George S. Milnor, president of the Grain Stabilization Corporation, will sail for the United States next Tuesday without concluding any contracts with European governments for purchase of the Farm Board's surplus wheat, he said today when he returned to Paris from a visit to several European capitals.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice on the streets that there are a lot of taxicabs operating at the rate of 5 cents for each one-fifth mile instead of on the quarter-mile basis. This is particularly true in front of hotels like the Biltmore and Commodora and Grand Central Station.

Charles M. Schwab, famed for his optimism, said yesterday to stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation at their annual meeting that although never in his twenty-seven years in the corporation had the outlook been so depressing or as unpromising as this year, he continued to be optimistic regarding the future both of the country and the company.

Every time a budget is balanced incomes are cut and business hesitates because it is afraid to go ahead until the government stabilizes taxes, according to views expressed by peakers yesterday at the fifth annual conference on public affairs held by the New York City League of Women Voters at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 12 (AP). -- The people in the 400-mile strip of South America which has been darkened for two days by a heavy rain of volcanic ash breathed easier today as the sun peeked feebly from the clouds.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 12 (AP) -- Alan Smith, University of North Carolina golfer, the medalist, won his first-round match in the annual Dogwood tournament today by shooting par golf to defeat Bennie Goodes, Burlington, N.C., 4 and 3.

MOSCOW, April 12. -- The Ninth Congress of Soviet Labor Federations, which opens this week, will be an event of the greatest importance. Since the last congress, three years ago, the labor federations' membership has increased from 11,000,000 to approximately 17,000,000.

DETROIT, April 12 (AP). -- Snowballs instead of baseballs were tossed about Navin Field today as the Detroit Tigers and Cleveland Indians called off the scheduled American League opener because of snow and cold weather.

At its regular started meeting held last night the Bar Association of the City of New York approved a resolution calling for the appointment of judges of the Court of Appeals and justices of the Supreme Court by the Governor, with the consent and advice of the State Senate, instead of the present method of election.

CHICAGO, April 12. -- Kidnapping, slugging and shooting, in which one man was probably fatally wounded, marked the polling in Chicago today as Republicans and Democrats, voted in the State-wide primaries, to name delegates to the national conventions and to pick their November tickets, headed by nominees for Governor.

TRENTON, N.J., April 12. -- Three forms of legislation for the improvement of employment conditions in silk mills in Paterson were suggested today by State Labor Commissioner Charles R. Blunt, following his investigation of a protest made to the Legislature last week by a delegation of silk workers.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Republican members of the Senate Finance Committee joined with the Democrats today in a bi-partisan move to bring the billion-dollar tax bill to the floor for action at the earliest possible date.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Stocks and bonds have shrunk $6,000,000,000 in the last two weeks in a decline described today by Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, as being "as drastic as at any other time."

Joseph H. Zweeres, bank examiner, testified yesterday at the trial of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, that although, at the suggestion of a superior, he had rewritten a report on an examination of the Bank of United States, made in the Summer of 1929, he had never conferred with Mr. Broderick on the subject.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 12. -- Thougn the men's singles field of seventy players in the fourteenth annual North and South tennis championship completed almost a full three rounds on the courts of the Pinehurst Country Club today after yesterday's postponement, not an upset was recorded so far as national ranking and sectional stars were concerned.

When Richard Maibaum's "The Tree," which was acted at the Park Lane last evening, is a drama of lynching it is blunt and sinewy theatre. When it becomes a study in Christian remorse it is muddled. After two acts that go briskly to the point of a lynching in a rural district north of the Mason-Dixon line "The Tree" gets completely out of hand.

Dr. Robert D. Leigh, president of Bennington College, Bennington, Vt., which will open in September with eighty young women students, announced yestenday at a luncheon at the Cosmopolitan Club, 133 East Fortieth Street, the names of the men and women who have been appointed to the faculty of the new institution.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 12 (AP). -- Slamming out four runs in a ninthinning rally, the Cincinnati Reds today defeated the Chicago Cubs, 5 to 4, in the opening game of the season, before 25,000.

Although there were indications of further liquidation on the Stock Exchange yesterday, the selling, it seemed to Wall Street, was more easily absorbed and the market gave a better account of itself. Brokers reported "good buying" on a scale down in many stocks.
WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Federal prohibition agents were unusually active in New York City during March, having made 861 cases, in which the arrests were about twice that number.

To the Editor of The NEW YORK TIMES: In these days when pessimism Is carried beyond all reason it seems to me that one contributory cause for this state of mind has not been mentioned. Never before in my many years of experience in investment matters have I known of so many individuals who have placed available funds in "short-term governments."

Predicting that "despite the activities of some politicians in Washington" this country will not go off the gold basis. Silas H. Strawn, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said yesterday to members of the Bond Club of New York that if the United States failed to balance its budget foreign investments in this country would virtually fly away.

Five experienced executives of established welfare agencies, representing the Coordinating Committee of the Welfare Council, declared in a statement yesterday that Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor's request for an appropriation, of $20,000,000 for unemployment relief for the next six months was "a conservative request," although unprecedented.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Prohibition modificationists in the House started a petition today for a record vote on the O'Connor-Hull "beer bill," designed as a revenue measure, and obtained eighty of the 145 signatures required for a vote on discharging the Ways and Means Committee from further consideration of the proposal.

A report on the progressive encroachment by government on the domain of private business was made yesterday to the committee on commerce of the American Bar Association at the first meeting of a three-day session at the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.
MADRID, April 12 (AP). -- Premier Manuel Azana, for the first time in bis career, bowed tonight toward the public of Madrid as a playwright.

The stockholders of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation approved yesterday a reduction in the common stock to one-third of the number of shares outstanding, corresponding changes in the warrants and a change in the authorized capital from 45,000,000 shares of $10 par common stock and 5,150,000 shares of no-par preferred stock to 20,000,000 shares of $15 par common stock and 1,500,000 shares of no-par preferred stock.
The James Madison High School baseball team, defending All-Brooklyn champion, lost to Erasmus Hall, 10 to 4, yesterday at Erasmus Field as play in Class B of the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. got under way.

The National League's 1932 championship campaign got under way in New York yesterday to a somewhat surprising start with the Giants, rated almost universally as powerful pennant contenders, practically left at the post. For, to the consternation of a gathering of 25,000 shivering enthusiasts, including Mayor Walker, the McGrawmen went turmbling down to a humiliating defeat at the Polo Grounds before the Phillies by a score of 13 to 5.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Important topics involving the public and private business situation were under discussion today by governors of the Federal Reserve banks, who are in the capital for a series of conferences with high officials.

An increase of 72,500 barrels in the daily average gross crude oil production of the United States in the week ended last Saturday was announced yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. The increase, which was the largest reported in several weeks, was believed to have been caused mainly by the stimulus received from the recent increases in midcontinent prices of crude oil.

A paradoxical faith in the stability of the business world, based on the belief that realization of the seriousness of present economic ills should bring recovery, was expressed yesterday by Bruce Barton, author and journalist, at a luncheon of the New York Financial Advertisers in the Downtown Athletio Club.

MOSCOW, April 12. -- "I'm sorry, but I have no time now for political interviews -- I've got 250,000,000 acres to get planted," said Joseph Stalin, Russia's dictator, with a smile in response to a question by James Abbe, a news photographer whose work has frequently appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Despite the absence of their leading candidate for the Presidential nomination, Democrats arriving tonight for the Jefferson Day activities tomorrow predicted that the events would be important, interesting and effective in aiding the chances of the party in the national elections.
LINCOLN, Neb., April 12 (AP). -- This was primary day in Nebraska, with a three-way Democratic Presidential preference race.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP). -- Cottonseed crushed in the eight-month period, Aug. 1 to March 31, was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 4,589,877 tons, compared with 4,407,445 tons the same period a year ago, and cottonseed on hand at mills March 31 was 704,327 tons, compared with 210,159 tons a year ago.

Till this year it has been the invariable practice to create Congress districts by laws passed in compliance with the State Constitution. The New York Legislature by concurrent resolution not submitted to the Governor, the Missouri and Minnesota Legislatures by bills vetoed by the Governor and not passed over his veto, adopted a new method.

Plainclothes Patrolman James A. Ward, while making an investigation last night at 534 Broadway, Brooklyn, was accosted by two well-dressed young women who asked him if he could take them in his automobile to "Broadway and Flushing Avenue."

Commissioners of the Boston Metropolitan District are expected to consummate a deal today for the sale of a new issue of $24,000,000 of bonds to the banking group organized to purchase the issue in order that notes of the district that will mature tomorrow in approximately a like amount may be met.
Colonel Alexander F. Powell, author and world traveler, and Mrs. Powell are sailing today for Europe on the President Harding of the United States Lines. Others on the passenger list are:

Gold in the amount of $8,430,000 was exported to Europe yesterday. $8,295,000 going to France and $135,000 to Holland. The shipments raised to $19,341,900 the effiux, which began last Friday, and all but $145,000 has gone to France.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, April 12. -- The recapture of the navy and the quelling of the naval revolt were not received with rejoicing here. On the contrary. General Astudillo, the leader of the victorious government forces, and Minister of Public Works Aviles on arriving from Punta Piedras at 11:30 today were hissed upon landing by a crowd which had to be dispersed by a saber charge of mounted police, bruising a few.

The second of the Tuesday evening concerts in the Metropolitan Open House given by and for the hitherto unemployed members of the Musicians Symphony Orchestra took place last night, when the soloist was John McCormack, and the conductor Sandor Harmati.
PARIS, April 12. -- It is no exaggeration to say that France has not one good word for the arms limitation plan offered at Geneva yesterday by the United States.
"Foreign Affairs," with Dorothy Gish, Osgood Perkins and Henry Hull heading the cast, will open tonight at the Avon Theatre.

A plan for a Pre-Bar Association as a training school for prospective lawyers was put into effect at New York University yesterday following its unanimous approval by the undergraduate body of the university's Law School. The movement, described as "unique in the history of American law education," was voted upon at a meeting in the office of Frank H. Sommer, dean of the Law School.

The Reading Company commenced door-to-door trucking in 1931 between Philadelphia and New York, a distance of 107 miles, and between Harrisburg and New York, a distance of 184 miles, according to its report for that year issued yesterday. The report is" signed by Agnew T. Dice, president of the road at the time of his recent death.

Millionaires Not Wanted. General SMEDLEY BUTLER, who recently announced his purpose to "clean up" the Senate, now proposes to clean up the Cabinet. In it, he declared yesterday, there are far too many millionaires.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 12. -- Colonel William Mitchell Smart, United States Army Medical Corps, retired, died at his home here today. He had been on the retired list since 1922 and had been in ill health during that period. His age was 52.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange showed a pain yesterday more disposition to advance in sympathy with the wheat market than to follow the course in securities. After fluctuating in a range of about 15 points, quotations ended at gains of 1 to 3 points on the day.

Dr. John F. Condon said last night that he was still in contact with the kidnappers of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's infant son and he hinted that he had at least a suspicion regarding their identity.

Amos W.W. Woodcock, Prohibition Director, who came here yesterday from Washington to confer with his special agents on enforcement work, announced at the Federal Building, following a talk with George Z. Medalie, "United States Attorney, that sixty agents had completed their work of taking a census of speakeasies here in just five days.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12. -- Greeted enthusiastically by 400 Democrats during a brief stop at North Philadelphia Station today, former Governor Smith of New York said he was not engaged personally in rounding up delegates for the national convention, but, as he had stated previously, he would gladly assume the burdens of another campaign if the convention made him the nominee.

PARIS, April 12 -- The Bourse had a depressing session today, with scarcely any activity. The market opened much weaker under the influence of Adolf Hitler's gains in the German election, French hostility to Hugh Gibson's armament suggestions at Geneva and unfavorable reports of the market in Wall Street yesterday.

ORLANDO, Fla., April 12 (AP). -- Failure in the country's tax crisis was charged to Democratic leadership in Congress by Ernest Lee Jahncke, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, in an address at the Florida Republican convention today.

The creation of a governing or stabilization council, composed of two delegates from each division of the wool industry, was unanimously approved yesterday at a meeting of representatives from various branches of the trade at the Hotel Commodore. It was decided that the members be named and the group meet not later than the first week in May, at which time a chairman will be elected by the council.
Yesterday 30,000 Flatbush fans sat in the bunting-draped stands of Ebbets Field to watch the revamped Robins open their championship season with the Boston Braves and were disappointed.

WASHINGTON. April 12. -- Senator W. Warren Barbour, Republican, and Representative Percy H. Stewart, Democrat, announced their candidacies today for Senator from New Jersey to fill out the term of the late Senator Dwight W. Morrow. Each, it is expected, will be unopposed in his own party.

TOWSON, Md., April 12 (AP) -- Iodine Pet, owned by C.E. Jacobus of Montclair, N.J., today won the allage stake, second day event of the Spring trials of the Oriole Amateur Field Dog Association. As in the puppy stages run yesterday, Maryland dogs were crowded out of the winning column by dogs from the outside.

Morgan, Turner Co., nominee for Corporate Trust Shares and other interests, continue to be the largest stockholder in the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, according to the company's report to the Interstate Commerce Commission. The firm's common stock holdings increased from 28,552 in 1930 to 41,175 shares in 1931.

Such improvement as occurred in the stock and bond markets yesterday was of a negative character. The selling was less aggressive than on the preceding day and the losses were small, as a rule. There was, however, unmistakable evidence of further release of securities from "long" accounts.

The importance of pre-school training for children was stressed yesterday by educators at the annual conference of the Association of Day Nurseries at the Hotel Pierre. About 300 representatives of the forty-four units of the organization attended.

The sale of the United States Lines to a group consisting of the International Mercantile Marine Company, R. Stanley Dollar and Kenneth D. Dawson, as voted last Fall by the directors of the lines, will be discussed today before a House committee in "Washington and eventually will be taken to court by a committee of stockholders if Congress fails to take action to protect the stockholders' interests, it was announced yesterday.

Although streams are still high in New Jersey and present indications are that conditions will be none too favorable for the opening day of the trout season in the State on Friday, Chief Warden Stratton of the State commission held out some hope yesterday that anglers might be able to find some improvement for any Sunday sorties they might be planning.
TRENTON, N.J., April 12. -Issuance of $18,000,000 in highway construction bonds and $3,000,000 in institutional construction bonds was authorized today by the Sinking Fund Commission.

American monopoly of film entertainment, boasted by Hollywood and conceded by the rest of the world, may receive a jolt at the Ottawa Imperial Conference in July. The intention to put British films into the cinema houses of New Zealand, Australia, South Africa and Canada is firm and unconcealed.

CHICAGO, April 12. -- Wheat traders were impressed again today with the unfavorable comments on the Kansas and Nebraska crops, and, while heavy profit-taking at times caused sharp setbacks, the market rallied quickly on new buying and prices advanced to new high marks on the present movement.

GENEVA, April 12 -- Like an oratorical tank crushing everything in its path and shooting out arguments like machine-gun bullets. Premier Andre Tardieu of France made war on the proposal advanced by Ambassador Hugh S. Gibson yesterday that the disarmament conference should begin by outlawing some few aggressive weapons, now that all countries had outlawed aggressive war.

HONOLULU, April 12 (AP). -- Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, one of the four on trial here for the slaying of Joseph Kahahawai, asked the Associated Press tonight to transmit the following message to his mother, Mrs. W.S. Massie of Winchester, Ky.

Stockholders of the Erie Railroad at their annual meeting here yesterday elected Robert E. Woodruff, vice president, a director to succeed L.F. Loree, who resigned some months ago. Mr. Loree is president of the Delaware Hudson Company. The stockholders re-elected to the board Stephen Birch, George F. Brownell and Robert W. Pomeroy, whose terms expired.

ROME, April 12 (AP). -- Premier Mussolini today received Hugh S. Robertson and Douglas Gibbs, representatives of the Rockefeller Institute, which is building a public health centre here. They gave him a letter from John D. Rockefeller Jr., inviting Italy to place a permanent display of its art, manufactures and commerce in the new Rockefeller centre, under construction in New York.

Many tables have been reserved for the bridge and backgammon party in aid of the Society for the Relief of the Destitute Children of Seamen which will take place this afternoon on board the Conte Grande at Pier 95, West Fifty-fifth Street. Later in the afternoon there will be a musical entertainment and tea.
FORT EDWARD, N.Y., April 12. John H. Morse, hotel owner and for thirty years president of the Washington County Hotel Association, died today after a brief illness. He was 79 years old.

The Palace of the Soviets, about to be erected in Moscow as the Capitol of the new Russia, will be seven Fifth Avenue blocks long and three such blocks wide, it was revealed yesterday by Hector O. Hamilton, 27-year-old architect, of East Orange, N.J., who won first prize in the world-wide competition for which famous architects from many parts of the world submitted designs.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP). -- While the House was debating today the proposal to reduce the salaries of Federal employes President Green of the Federation of Labor issued a statement protesting against such action as a step presaging a breakdown in the American standard of living.

Controller Berry began on Monday negotiations with the bankers for the sale of about $10,000,000 of city contractual obligations, it was disclosed yesterday. The loan will be the first of several, all of which will be in similar or smaller amounts, which probably will be arranged during the rest of the year.

LONDON, April 12. -- The United States proposal at Geneva for the abolition of tanks, heavy mobile guns and poison gas with which Great Britain is substantially in agreement was hailed here as something tangible and concrete which might provide a starting point.

Continued strength in the contract grains, with, the advance in wheat ranging from 1 to 1 1/2 cents per bushel, and steadiness in cotton featured business in the commodity markets yesterday. Coffee, rubber, cocoa, hides and silk also responded with firm undertone. The only offsetting factor was the break in sugar to a new all-time low of 0.59 cents for May contracts. Other staples were steady.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 12. -- The defeat of R.A. Stranahan, Toledo, provided the only upset today in the first round of the Mason and Dixon golf tournament. Stranahan lost to Roof GUson of Jackson, Mich., 4 and 2.

Electric lamps, automatic dial telephones, the transatlantic telephone, vacuum tubes to transmit and receive broadcast music, rayon, synthetic dyes, drug's and flavors by the thousand, fats from cotton-seed oil, synthetic ammonia from gases -- industrial research has given us these and more.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday 3 8/4 to 4 per cent for the best names Monday ...3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the beet names The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 12 (AP). -- Support for Governor Roosevelt of New York and the starting of a boom for Senator Alben W. Barkley for Vice President marked the open for Vice President marked the Democratic State Convention here today.

Despite the depression stock racketeers are unloading worthless securities on a gullible public, State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. declared yesterday as he made public a report on the activities of the Bureau of Securities for the three-month period ended March 31.

Officials of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation now in Stockholm are watching the denouement of the tangle resulting from the rescinding of the deal whereby an interest in the Ericsson Telephone Company was to have been acquired and from the failure of Kreuger Toll to repay the advance of $11,000,000 made under the terms of that transaction.

The $200,000 slander suit brought by Dr. Joseph C. Regan against Health Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Byrne in Brooklyn. The court held that statements made by Dr. Wynne concerning Dr. Regan's fitness to head the Kingston Avenue Hospital for Contagious Diseases in Brooklyn were not made with malicious intent.

Election of Merlin H. Aylesworth, president of the National Broadcasting Company, as president of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation is expected to be announced after the directors' meeting late this afternoon. He would succeed Hiram S. Brown, who, although not expected to have an official capacity, will retain his position on the directorate, it is believed.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 12. -- Choppy water on Lake Carnegie hampered the Princeton varsity crews in their workouts today. The junior varsity boat defeated the varsity shell in the first of two quarter-mile sprints, but the varsity had the advantage in the second.

Squadron C won the national class B indoor polo championship in its own armory in Brooklyn last night when it overcame a stubborn fight by the First Cleveland Cavalry to triumph, 13 1/2 to 7 1/2. There was no handicap.

BOWIE, Md., April 12 -- Under a strong ride by Jockey Alfred Robertson, Howard Bruce's Acautaw scored his second straight triumph by outlasting Cattail in a drive through the homestretch to annex by the margin of a head the sixth running of the feature $2,500 added Bowie Kindergarten Stakes at the Bowie track today.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., April 12 -- The two leading stakes of the annual field trials of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club -- the Open All-Age and the Junior All-Age were completed today. In the former New England dogs carried away the major honors, first and second places going to Dr. W.F. Vail of Greenwich, Conn., with his pointer dogs, Nepken Carolina Bill and Rosedale Jack respectively.

Bringing the greeting of President Hoover to a "prosperity mass meeting" held at Carnegie Hall last night under the sponsorship of the National Washington Portal Committee, Representative Scott Leavitt of Montana asserted that recent remedial legislation enacted by Congress already had begun to clear the economic skies.

THERE should have been more shouting in the suburbs and dancing in the streets over the recent track performances of Big Ben Eastman, the Stanford speedy stepper. His feat of cracking Ted Meredith's great record for the quarter by a full second was phenomenal.
NEW YORK. Dwight F. Davis, former Secretary of War and former Governor of the Philippines, and his daughter, Miss Alice B. Davis, returned from Europe on the Bremen and are at the Madison.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover was the honor guest today of the Congressional Club at the Spring breakfast given annually in honor of the wife of the President. The club is made up of the wives and daughters of present and past members of the Senate and House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Continued importation of Cuban refined sugar at the present rate of increase will "utterly wipe out the domestic cane and beet sugar industries of the United States in just nine years," representatives of domestic sugar refiners told the Tariff Commission today.

CHICAGO, April 12. -- Hogs were quoted today as unevenly 5 to 25 cents a hundred pounds lower than yesterday, lightweights showing the most loss. The prices were only 15 cents above the lowest figures since 1900. The top was off 10 cents at 54.25, while the day's average was 10 cents lower than, yesterday, at $3.90.

The spreading relaxation of bank credit, induced by the open-market operations of the Federal Reserve System, resulted yesterday in another reduction of one-fourth of 1 per cent in the discount on bankers' acceptances, the third cut thus far this month, carrying the yield on ninety-day bills down to 1 3/8 per cent, a net decline of 1 1/8 per cent since the last week in February.

James J.
