McCormick, Deputy City Clerk, in charge of the Marriage License Bureau, who was indicted last January for accepting tips from bridegrooms, was indicted again yesterday this time by the Federal grand jury, on the charge of tax evasion and failure to report a taxable income of $222,388.97 he received from 1926 to 1930, inclusive.

Knives flashed, fists flew and a serious riot between Socialists and Communists was narrowly averted last night at the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street, when a disturbance occurred at a meeting called by the Socialist party and the Emergency Committee for Strikers' Relief to protest the alleged denial of civil liberties to striking coal miners in West Virginia and Kentucky.

BUENOS AIRES, April 12. -- Exports from Argentina in the first quarter of 1932 totaled 4,839,000 tons, against 4,012,000 tons during the same period last year, an increase of 20 per cent. The combined value of such exports is estimated at $102,890,000 at the current rate of exchange, against $96,350,000 in the same period last year, or a 5.7 per cent increase in value.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP). -- Louis A. Bauer, known internationally for his work on terrestial magnetism, was killed tonight in a fall from a window of his sixth floor apartment.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 12. -- Ingenious robbers stole the clockworks and the 155-pound clapper of the bell in Memorial Hall and managed somehow to lower it 115 feet to the ground.

A cut of 1/4 in yield on acceptances, all dates, made late in the afternoon, was the most significant development of the day in the money market. It was the third cut of the month, for a gross reduction of 5/8, from the end of March, and lowest since last October.

The American Council of Learned Societies has announced research and fellowship awards totaling $60,000 for advancement of research in the humanities. These grants cover study in subjects as widely separated as the ancient Hittite and the dialect of South Carolina Negroes.
PARIS, April 12 -- Captain Rene Lacoste, who already is mapping his campaign for defense of the Davis Cup, will replace Jean Borotra with young Marcel Bernard -- if the Basque veteran really retires.

Leo Nunes of the New York A.C. defending champion, gained the final round in the metropolitan championship saber tournament at the Salle d'Armes Vince last night. Three other members of the Winged Foot club were among the eight fencers who qualified.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Why can we no longer do the obvious thing? Have we lost the logical process?

The advance in crude oil prices to $1 a barrel in the Southwest became virtually unanimous among the major companies yesterday when the Shell Petroleum Corporation, a subsidiary of the Shell Union Oil Corporation, announced that it would meet the figures posted by other leading producers.

The annual bridge in aid of the National Navy Club Canteen took place yesterday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The proceeds will be used in the maintenance of the canteen, which was established in 1917 for men of the navy and Marine Corps and which, is a part of the National Navy Club.

CHICAGO, April 12 (AP). -- Two newcomers, the veteran Sam Jones and Carey Selph, started the White Sox off to a good beginning in the American League race today, as Chicago scored a 9-to-2 victory over the St. Louis Browns before a half frozen gathering of 18,000 spectators.

PARIS, April 12. -- Edouard Harriot, the man who is widely expected to be the next Premier of France. opened the electoral campaign for the Radical-Socialist party tonight in a keynote speech delivered to a vast throng of followers in Lyons. With Premier Tardieu's permission the speech was broadcast not only in France but to the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Seven representative citizens who can contribute expert opinions as to the problems faced by American holders of defaulted foreign government bonds, in several instances holders of such bonds themselves, have been invited by the State Department to a conference Friday to consider the advisability of organizing a bond-holders' protective association.

Superiority of the offer of the Nevins Bus Company for the Queens bus franchises was urged on the Board of Estimate, sitting in Committee of the Whole, yesterday by N. Taylor Phillips, counsel to the Nevins company. Thus far the preference of the majority of the board has been for the Jamaica Central Railways Company and the North Shore Bus Company.

GENEVA, April 12 -- The Council of the League of Nations met today in a public session under the presidency of Premier Tardieu of France specially called to consider the League financial committee's report on the urgent need of helping Austria, Greece, Bulgaria and Hungary.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Indications that the Democratic proposal to reduce Federal salaries is objectionable to the administration and that President Hoover's "staggered furlough" plan will be substituted were seen today when the President again invited the House Economy Committee to the White House, setting tomorrow afternoon for the meeting.

LYNN, Mass., April 12. -- Captain Frederick C. Melville of Lynn, who commanded the bark City of New York, flagship of the Byrd Antarctic Expedition, in a talk before a Kiwanis club here this afternoon said he had read that Admiral Byrd had realized $5000,000 from the venture and added:

A $20,000,000,000 building program to rehabilitate city slums and modernize existing buildings and obsolete plants was urged yesterday by Francis Lee Stuart, prominent engineer, as the quickest and surest way of restoring prosperity. The plan has the endorsement of the American Engineering Council, of whose public affairs committee Mr. Stuart is a member.

LONDON, April 12. -- Two Hems in today's news add materially to the satisfaction of British protectionists in the recently enacted tariff law. One is a dispatch from Washington to the effect that Congress is contemplating a surtax on all imports from countries with depreciated currencies.

There was no march on City Hall last Monday. The real estate boards and their allies did not desire, at this stage of the proceeding's, the kind of mass demonstration which took place at Philadelphia recently. They sought rather a conference with Mayor WALKER and his associates to ascertain what the city officials had to offer in the way of an economy program.

Credit problems confronting furniture manufacturers selling in this district will be handled by a committee representing all production branches of the industry, members of the National Association of Furniture Manufacturers, Inc., decided at the mid-Atlantic meeting held at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

Parents, whose occupations range from that of janitor to doctors of medicine and literature, voted last night to make every effort to save from the depression the "Little Red School House." The school is an experimental enterprise in "progressive" or "realistic" education conducted at Public School 41, 26 Greenwich Street.

LONDON. April 12 (Canadian Press) -- A trading loss of u646,605 ($2,457,099 at yesterday's rate) for last year, including provision for its liability in the losses of subsidiary companies, was reported today by Hudson's Bay Company.

Russia is undoubtedly the greatest market today for American goods, but Europe, using American credit in some instances, is developing the field before us, Thomas D. Campbell, Montana mass production farmer, writes in his book. "Russia: Market or Menace?"

Annoyed at what he termed the unwarranted arrest of fifty-two men in a loft building suspected of housing a racing bookmaker's headquarters. Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein in Jefferson Market Court yesterday criticized the police and ordered copies of the papers in the case sent to Chief Magistrate James E. McDonald.

Although the crop outlook in the Northern Pacific Railway's territory is grood, there is no change in the trend of the company's earnings. Charles Donnelly, president, said at the annual meeting yesterday. While figures for March were not yet available, they probably would not show results much different from those of the first two months of this year.

Against the plan submitted by Ambassador GIBSON at the Disarmament Conference it cannot be alleged that it is selfishly American. He proposed the abolition of weapons now favoring the aggressor in a surprise attack by an army. These are tanks, mobile heavy artillery and poisonous gas.

Miss Elsie Thorenz of the German-American A.A. and Miss Elizabeth Harrison of the Women's S.A. were the winners of Metropolitan A.A. U. championships at a water carnival in the seventy-five-foot London Terrace pool last night. Only scratch events were on the card.

BERLIN, April 12. -- Hugh S. Gibson's proposals at Geneva are acclaimed in Berlin political circles as going into one of the most important elements in disarmament in a positive and concrete way, in welcome contrast to the theoretical discussions dominant earlier in the conference, and as offering leverage for practical accomplishment.

Continuing his secret inquiry into the activities of Mayor "Walker, Samuel Seabury left his offices at the headquarters of the Hofstadter legislative committee yesterday and for the second time in two days questioned witnesses whose names were not revealed.

Selection of three members of the Columbia University faculty and three students as a committee to investigate conditions in the university dining halls, which were criticized by Reed Harris, expelled editor of The Columbia Spectator, was announced yesterday by Professor James C. Egbert, chairman of the commons committee of Columbia.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Democratic party is in a state of lethargy, explainable only by the desire for so-called harmony. Since when did harmony become a prerequisite to the successful conduct of a national political campaign? Was Cleveland a harmonizer?

HONOLULU, April 12. -- With the prosecution in the trial of Mrs. Granville Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, her son-in-law, and two navy enlisted men, E.J. Lord and A. G. Jones, for the killing of Joseph Kahahawai, a native athlete, nearly at an end, every one is speculating on what method will be adopted by the defense.

Observers in London agree that the new British budget will propose a substantial increase in the 10 per cent tariff recently imposed on many imports. This will be done partly for the purpose of raising additional revenue. But it is frankly admitted that England, having abandoned, at least temporarily, her traditional policy of free trade, will attempt to use the tariff to "bargain" her way into an advantageous commerce between nations.

The Macbeth Gallery is celebrating its fortieth anniversary this week with an exhibition appropriately called "Forty Years of American Art." It was in April of the year 1892 that William Macbeth opened his gallery in this city, the first gallery, a note in the catalogue reminds us, that devoted itself exclusively to work by native artists.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., April 12. -- Losing the village presidency by a margin of less than 100 votes, the Democrats gained control of the Village Board today for the first time in four years. Two Democratic trustees were elected by small majorities, giving the Democrats four of the six votes in the Village Board.

Standing in the front cockpit of the big coaching launch as she follows crews up the gray Hudson toward Yonkers and swaying with the motion like a man on the deck of an ocean vessel, Richard J. Glendon keeps peering at the sky and the horizon.

LONDON, April 12 -- British Government funds continued strong today, but other sections of the Stock Exchange were uncertain. German bonds weakened owing to nervousness over the coming Prussian elections, while Argentine railway shares were adversely affected by news of the volcanic eruptions in South America.

BERLIN, April 12. -- In an extra session of the Prussian Diet today the Socialist-Centrist-Democratic coalition that governs Prussia put through by the scantiest majority an amendment to the Diet's by-laws prescribing that an absolute majority be required for the election of the Premier.

TOKYO, April 12 -- In deciding to nullify Manchoukuo's refusal to admit Dr. Wellington Koo with the League of Nations commission of inquiry headed by Lord Lytton. officials said today the Japanese Government recognized that it was at present responsible for preservation of order in Manchuria.

SHANGHAI, April 12. -- The alleged puppet government in Chapei has collapsed after a few days of existence, sixty Japanese soldiers raiding its headquarters, evicting the occupants and closing the place.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- An immediate meeting of the American Legion, the American Federation of Labor, the Association of National Advertisers and the American Legion Auxiliary, which are engaged in a united drive against unemployment, is recommended in a letter sent to these organizations by J. Cheever Cowdin, vice president of Blair Co. of New York and famous as a polo player.

ST. LOUIS, April 12 (AP). -- Championship strides were taken today by the St. Louis Cardinals as they decisively downed the Pittsburgh Pirates by 10 to 2 at Sportsman's Park in the opening game of the season. The 1931 National League pennant won by the Cards was raised with ceremony just before the game, which attracted 5,937 paying customers.
BUENOS AIRES, April 12. -- The rain of ashes from Andean volcanoes ceased today almost as abruptly as it began Sunday.

SHANGHAI, April 12. -- The alleged puppet government in Chapei has collapsed after a few days of existence, sixty Japanese soldiers raiding its headquarters, evicting the occupants and closing the place.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Outside Virginia the suggestion made at the Jefferson Day dinner tonight by ex-Governor Harry F. Byrd of that State of a popular referendum on the Eighteenth Amendment may not cause a sensation, but to Virginians and others familiar with the attitude on the subject of Bishop James Cannon Jr. and his former influence in Virginia it was a major political event.

The railroads of the country are considering a proposal to have the Railway Express Agency, which they own, undertake door-to-door delivery and thus offset competition by independent motor trucks. It was emphasized, however, in statements made yesterday, that the project had not gone beyond the stage of preliminary discussion and that the number of managements involved made it difficult at this time to predict the outcome.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Immediate creation of a special committee to investigate 1932 campaign expenditures was urged today in the Senate by Senator Robinson, Republican of Indiana, who gave as one of his reasons reports that $50,000 had been sent into Nebraska to carry yesterday's primary for Governor Roosevelt.

Since the time of Andrea del Sarto, and probably long before, artists blessed with beautiful wives and handsome children have found inspiration in the family circle for everything from, classical mythologies to Old Testament scenes. Rubens, Vigee le Brun and, in our own time, John Costigan and George de Forest Brush stand out as painters who had not to look beyond their own foyer for their models.

LONDON, April 13 -- Lord Revelstoke, reviewing the causes and cure of economic troubles, depicted the "world writhing in a purgatory of its own making" in an address at today's annual meeting of the United Kingdom Provident Institution. He said There was ground for cautious optimism in Britain and then turned his consideration to conditions abroad.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A celebration unique in the history of the United States Foreign Service is to be held April 30 at the consulate at Gibraltar, when Richard L. Sprague, the consul, will hold a reception to mark the one hundredth anniversary of the first appointment of one of his family to that post.

FRANKFORT - ON - MAIN, Germany, April 13 -- Replying to the demand of the trade unions at an extra convention that the government raise 2,000,000,000 marks [about $475,000,000] to create jobs for 1,000,000 workmen for one year, Adam Stegerwald, Minister of Labor, declared today that the government must look after the stability of the currency, balance public budgets and provide industries with sufficient credits to maintain production before any such scheme could be considered.

Within the formula of "no disarmament without security," to which all French political parties subscribe, there exist differences of emphasis which make it unsafe to speak of the "French position" as something completely defined and rigid.

ALBANY, April 13 -- Beginning tomorrow, filling stations in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania will display colored posters warning motorists against violation of traffic regulations which are responsible for loss of life, injury and heavy property damage.

More than one hundred persons, representing forty-two Long Island municipalities, water districts, county governments, water companies and civic organizations, appeared before the New York State Water Power and Control Commission at a public hearing yesterday morning in the Surrogate's court room, 161-10 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, to oppose the application of the City of New York for permission to develop additional subsurface sources of water supply on Long Island.

After seven years' study of the operation of the anti-trust laws, the commerce committee of the American Bar Association submitted the eighth revised draft of an amendment for discussion here yesterday at an all-day hearing in the New York State Chamber of Commerce Building.
ALBANY, April 13 -- The Democratic State committee will meet here on Friday to effect organization after the primaries.

Before Joseph H. Zweeres, bank examiner, rewrote the report of his August, 1929, examination of the Bank of United States so as to remove from it criticism of the actions and ability of high officials of the bank, he had been officially informed that the bankers objected to his strictures and were afraid that if they were not altered the report, when sent to the Federal Reserve Bank, would harm their institution.

A merger of the Western Union Telegraph Company and the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, under the control of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, became an imminent possibility yesterday, when Newcomb Carlton, president of the Western Union, told stockholders at their annual meeting that they must be prepared for a change when business revived.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Following are the total amounts due each year to the United States in principal and interest payments from the foreign debtor countries, whose obligations have been funded, over a twenty-year period beginning with 1933:

BERLIN, April 13 -- President von Hindenburg, in an emergency decree based upon Article XLVIII of the Federal Constitution, today dissolved the National Socialist storm detachments and guard units constituting Adolf Hitler's "Brown Army." Their numerical strength had been given at Herr Hitler's headquarters as 500,000, or more than two-thirds of the peacetime strength of the German Army before the war.

Concerted international action by responsible governments for the removal of trade and tariff barriers, the stabilization of prices and normalization of the world's monetary system, as against what were characterized as the present Micawber-like policies of politicians, was urged by economists yesterday at the morning session of the Academy of Political Science in the Hotel Astor, at which Professor E.R.A. Seligman of Columbia University presided.

PARIS, April 13 -- The Paris Bourse was unexpectedly buoyant today and a substantial recovery took place, affecting nearly the whole list. The improved situation in the Chicago wheat market and rises in other commodities started the activity, which soon extended to other sections.

Reporting on the results of 1931 operations, the Anaconda Copper Mining Company shows a net loss of $3,151,726 after all charges for depreciation, obsolescence, interest and discount on bonds. This contrasts with a net profit of $18,782,968 in 1930.

GENEVA, April 13 -- Ambassador Hugh S. Gibson's speech on Monday and Premier Andre Tardieu's reply yesterday have given form and substance to the disarmament conference that is meeting here. They have offered a choice between two methods and two objectives.

NEW YORK. The Misses Barbara and Tatiana Litchfield are returning tomorrow from Camden, S.C., where they passed the Winter, to Cantitoe Farm, Katonah, N.Y., where they will be joined on Monday by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Sands Litchfield, who are returning by motor.

Miss Margaret Keyes, who will complete thirty years as a contralto soloist at the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, at Fifty-sixth Street, will resign on April 30. Miss Keys explained her resignation as fulfilling a desire to round out thirty years at the Tabernacle.

DETROIT, April 13 (AP) -- Cleveland and Detroit played a torrid eleven-inning game in frigid weather today, Cleveland winning, 6 to 5, before 12,000 spectators, the smallest American League opening-day crowd here in fifteen years.

The first official census of speakeasies in New York City has been completed by Federal agents, but Commissioner WOODCOCK declines to say how many his investigators found. To do so, he believes, would merely start a controversy.

Lucrezia Bori and Michael Bohnen were among the stars of the Metropolitan taking a season's leave in two operas sung yesterday, the Spanish soprano as the Antonia of Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffmann" in the afternoon and the German basso as Wotan in Wagner's "Siegfried" last night.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- More than 700 Presbyterians from sixteen States, including Attorney General Mitchell, members of Congress and others in official circles, joined tonight in paying tribute to the pioneers of their faith at a dinner in connection with the Washington bicentennial celebration.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., April 13 -- A conference of members of the civic conference committee of the North Bergen Taxpayers' Association, with Mayor Julius Reich in the City Hall, ended abruptly today when the Mayor struck August P. Gunther, a member of the committee.

Raymond L. Wise, attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union and legal adviser of Reed Harris, expelled Columbia editor, announced yesterday that legal action against Columbia University would be delayed until today. Mr. Wise said that after conferring with John Godfrey Saxe, attorney for Columbia, he had agreed to postpone action for a day.

The elimination of "political debts" and the reciprocal lowering of tariff barriers throughout the world were suggested yesterday by Dr. Ernest Patterson, Professor of Economics at the University of Pennsylvania, as two ways of "slightly relieving" the economic pressure on the United States occasioned by its sudden change in status from a debtor to a creditor nation.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 13 -- The Senate passed a bill today authorizing divorce in Bolivia and then recessed.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senator Pittman's resolution regarding the World Court, asking the President to ascertain how foreign nations construe the court's jurisdiction over advisory opinions affecting American interests, was defeated by 11 to 8 in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

John A. Mobley, general counsel for the Southern Division of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and Texas counsel for the Freeport Sulphur Company, fell or jumped to his death yesterday from the window of his room on the ninth floor of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Early revision of reparations and war debts on a basis of compromise and mutual sacrifice by all nations concerned was advocated as essential to world recovery by speakers yesterday before the meeting of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor.

PARIS, April 13 -- Speaking at a Rotary Club luncheon here today, Charles G. Loeb, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in France, cited figures to show that under the now existing conditions France derives more benefit than the United States from Franco-American trade.
BURT SHOTTON, the tourist club leader from Philadelphia whose merry men made John J, McGraw miserable on opening day at the Polo Grounds, was persuaded to say a few words about baseball yesterday.

Lack of international cooperation and national political prejudice are responsible for the world's woes and rehabilitation can come only by recognition by all nations, including the United States, of their interdependence, Sir Josiah Stamp, British financier and reparations expert, told the Academy of Political Science at its dinner in the Hotel Astor last night.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 13 (AP) -- Tourists, most of them from the United States, spent $250,776,000 in Canada in 1931, the Bureau of Statistics estimates. The total was a decrease of $29,000,000 from the 1930 estimate.

PRAGUE, April 13 -- Three strikers were killed and more than 100 miners, soldiers and gendarmes more or less seriously injured today in clashes between 15,000 demonstrators and the authorities in four different parts of the North Bohemia coal mining region, where 30,000 men have been on strike for the last fortnight.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Samuel Untermyer probably will direct the stock market inquiry by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee when it is resumed next week.

PORTLAND, Me., April 13 -- A youth who said he was John Snyder, 20, of San Francisco, after he was arrested here Friday, charged with the murder of Policeman Honore Dutremble of Biddeford, was identified today as Lawrence Noll by his mother, Mrs. Mary Noll of 251 West Sixty-eighth Street, New York City.

Led by Charlie Toner, pitcher, the Evander Childs High School baseball team repulsed the New York University freshmen, 9 to 3, on Ohio Field yesterday. Toner turned the Violet cubs, making their first start of the season, back with three scattered hits and struck out eight.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- With the notable exception of Governor Roosevelt, all the leading Democratic aspirants for the Presidential nomination were present today to participate in the party celebrations in memory of Jefferson and Wilson, to exchange views regarding the trends in the country and to weigh the outcome of approaching primaries.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Sentiment in the wheat pit on the Board of Trade veered somewhat to the bear side today. Aside from the development of an area of low barometer in Texas, the news was as bullish regarding the coming crop as heretofore, with a further lowering in estimates by some Southwestern interests.

Except for the absence of one player, the same team that wrested the Wightman Cup from the English last year will represent the United States in the tenth of these annual international women's tennis matches, to he held June 10 and 11 at Wimbledon.

BOWIE, Md., April 13 -- Almost a year to the day from the time he made his 3-year-old debut, Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Equipoise, leading juvenile money winner of 1930, flashed his most brilliant form today in his first start as a 4-year-old, when he won the Au Revoir Handicap in time that set a new five-furlong track record.

A plan to have the Reconstruction Finance Corporation restore railroad credit by advancing money to railroads with which to buy their own bonds at a discount in the open market will be placed before the authorities in Washington today by Ambrose W. Benkert and, Rudolf H. Weber.

MEXICO CITY, April 13 -- The Huasteca, Aguila, Transcontinental and Sinclair oil companies have exported from Tampico to the United States more than 2,000,000 barrels of petroleum in the last few days, according to press dispatches.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 13 -- The per pupil cost of education in the twenty-five school districts of Westchester County is highest in Rye and the lowest in Port Chester, according to figures from the State Department of Education received in Westchester today.

BOSTON, April 13 (AP) -- A home run by Heinie Manush with two on base in the ninth gave Washington a 7 to 6 victory over Boston in the local American League opening today, before a crowd of 5,000. It was Manush who connected for a double in the tenth inning at Washington Monday to give the Senators a 1-0 triumph over the Red Sox in the opening game of the season.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Frank appeals for inflation of the currency were made by witnesses favoring immediate payment of veterans' adjusted compensation certificates before the House Ways and Means Committee today.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Hoover, in a third conference with the House Economy Committee today, insisted that Congress adopt his pay-reduction plan of a five-day week in "principle," that per diem workers be put on a five-day-week basis, that annual employes each take a one-month vacation without pay and that allowances for rural mail carriers for vehicle maintenance be eliminated.

MONTREAL, Que., April 13 -- The St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., and constituent companies, reported today, covering, for 1931, operating profit of $1,171,738, against $2,759,876 in 1930 working capital at the end of the years was $5,913,380, against $5,980,419.

The Seaglade of the St. Regis was the setting last night for an English garden fete, the third in a series of weekly entertainments to aid the work of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association. The room was decorated with large garden umbrellas and tall urns of variegated Spring flowers. Lanterns were hung over the dance floor as well as clusters of balloons.
LIMA, Peru, April 13 -- Francisco Lanatta resigned this morning as Premier and Minister of Finance, climaxing weeks of rumors of disagreements between him and other members of the Cabinet.

Spokesmen for the boys's work section of the Welfare Council, comprising forty organizations carrying an work among boys, reported yesterday to the Welfare Council's coordinating committee that the institutions were in a critical financial condition and would have to curtail their activities unless early assistance was made available.

One member of the crew was drowned and six customs guards injured yesterday morning when the Coast Guard cutter Manhattan was hit amidships on the port side by the bow of the inbound Panama Railroad freighter Guayaquil in the upper bay between the Barge Office and the Statue of Liberty.

ST. LOUIS, April 13 (AP) -- Intensive hitting that produced five runs in the ninth inning enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to triumph over Pittsburgh, 9 to 8, today, after the Pirates had been ahead all the way.

HONOLULU, April 13 -- When the court opens in the morning in the trial of Mrs. Granville Fortescue, her son-in-law. Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, and two navy enlisted men, E.J. Lord and A.G. Jones, for the killing of Joseph Kahahawai, a native athlete, it is probable that the prosecution's last witness will be the dead man's mother.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of the Republic Steel Corporation, held yesterday in Jersey City, Tom F. Girdler, president, said the steel business at present was the worst that it had been in the thirty years that he had been connected with the industry.

BERLIN, April 13 (AP) -- Scores of National Socialist headquarters were closed and a number of Hitlerites arrested today as hundreds of policemen searched for and seized forbidden uniforms and other materials.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Because of the quality of its programs and the educational work it is carrying on, WNYC, the municipal station of the city of New York, "should get everything that it wants," Edward P. Joyce Jr. argued today before the Radio Commission is the time-allotment controversy with Station WMCA.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 13 -- An exhibition swimming meet between the Rutgers varsity and the alumni was won by the varsity, 37 to 32, in the official opening of the new Rutgers pool before a crowd of 1,500 tonight. Proceeds were used for the benefit of the Rutgers Olympic fund.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- An agreement between the American Hampton Roads Line and the Cunard Steamship Company to avoid overlapping and duplication of sailings from North Atlantic ports, except New York, to London, was approved today by the Shipping Board.

LONDON, April 13 -- Viscount Craigavon, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, arrived in London unexpectedly today to obtain assurance that the British Government was not using Ulster as a "pawn" in its controversy with Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Executive Council.

LOS ANGELES, April 13 (AP) -- Ben Lyon, screen player, was sued for $35,000 damages today by Cedric La Mar, 18, film studio clerk, who alleged Mr. Lyon beat him in a dispute. The suit grew out of a clash when Mr. Lyon became incensed because La Mar had kept the actor's wife.

PANAMA CITY, April 13 -- Political unrest here is seen as a danger by El Tiempo, which fears serious consequences unless remedial action is taken soon, adding that the country's liberty and independence are being put to a test in the present electoral campaign.

VIENNA, April 13 -- A scheme for the economic relief of Central Europe as an alternative to Andre Tardieu's plan has been proposed, it is understood, by the Austrian Government to the European great powers with the approval of Germany. It was tentatively outlined by Baron Franckenstein, Austrian Minister to London, while the four-power conference was still in progress and will be revived when Central European problems are again discussed at Geneva.

PARIS, April 13 -- A decision today by the Cour de Cassation, the Freach Supreme Court, secures to the French State possession of the Chateau of Chambord and its famous hunting domain of the Bourbon Kings in Touraine.

A further improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange early in yesterday's trading carried July contracts $2 a bale above recent low figures and within a point of the best quotations made last week. The recovery attracted May liquidation in advance of the first notice day, April 26 and an increase in the supply of contracts wiped out the gain, leaving the list unchanged to 2 points lower than on Tuesday.

BUENOS AIRES, April 13 (AP) -- Men familiar with the Brazilian interior toyed today with the idea that the white man whom a Swiss trapper said he saw there and believed to be Colonel P.H. Fawcett, missing British explorer, might have been Ambrose Bierce, American writer and adventurer, who vanished in Mexico in 1914.

Offers of free gallery and wall space were received yesterday by the committee of forty artists acting in behalf of 500 impecunious artists of Greenwich Village who are too poor to hang their canvases in galleries, after the announcement by Park Commissioner Walter R. Herrick that it would be against the law under the City Charter to permit an art fair in the streets around Washington Square in the European manner.
After trailing for the greater part of the game, the Pratt Institute nine braced to defeat City College yesterday, on the former's diamond in Brooklyn, 5 to 4.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 13 -- One upset was recorded today in the Mason and Dixon golf tournament when John E. Hines of Garden City, L.I., defeated David N. Tallman of Minneapolis, 2 and 1, to reach the semi-finals.

Self-instructed, prodigiously industrious in the twelfth of each day which the delicacy of his health permitted him to labor, GAMALIEL BRADFORD became one of the most respected and liked of American literary figures. He failed as a novelist, a poet, a playwright.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 13 -- A disabled World War veteran who died here ten days ago without knowing his real name was identified today by the Veterans' Bureau at Washington through his fingerprints. Instead of going to an unmarked grave in Potter's Field, Sergeant Charles W. Vernoy, mechanic in the Air Corps, will be buried on Saturday at Beverley with full military honors by the American Legion.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A bold policy to broaden credit facilities and check the decline in prices has been embarked upon by the Federal Reserve system, the decision having been reached that the time is ripe for the system to throw its vast resources into a counter movement against the business depression.

SHANGHAI, April 13 -- Letters from Sinyan, Honan, report that emissaries have visited the Rev. Bert Nelson, the American missionary, who has been held captive in the stronghold of Chinese Communists since October, 1930.

A trio of young hold-up men was surprised by detectives last night holding up the dairy of Murray Steinlicht at 753 Fifth Street, four blocks from the Fifth Street police station. Two of the trio were shot through the body and taken to Bellevue Hospital in dying condition.

In its application for the listing of certificates of deposit for about $30,000,000 of its 6 per cent convertible debentures, which was approved yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange, the General Theatres Equipment, Inc., revealed that its net loss last year was $993,703.

A survey of special interest to holders of municipal bonds on the subject "How American Cities Are Retrenching in Time of Depression" was announced yesterday by the National Municipal League. The survey, which has been made by Harry H. Freeman of the Buffalo Municipal Research, summarizes the principal economies reported by twentyfive of the country's largest cities.

Amos W.W. Woodcock, prohibition director, before returning to Washington last night announced at prohibition headquarters that the recent census of speakeasies taken by sixty picked men in five days had revealed that the problem of enforcement here was much simpler than he had believed it to be a week ago.

Plans through which the property accounts of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company and its subsidiaries may be written off by approximately $32,100,000 will be submitted to stockholders at the annual meeting on May 5. The proposal is to restate the book value of the no par common stock at $10 instead of $15.68 a share, creating a capital surplus of $34,069,543 from which to effect the write-off.
NEWARK, N.J., April 13 -- The Newark Bears opened their season in midwinter weather today, defeating Toronto in a ten-inning battle, 6 to 5. A crowd of 13,000 saw the game.

TOKYO, April 13 -- The Japanese Government is informed that Mr. Yoshida, Japanese assessor with the League investigating commission, is trying to arrange a modus vivendi with the Manchoukuo Government to enable the commission to carry out its duties in Manchuria.

The International Match Corporation, controlled by the Swedish Match Company, an affiliate of Kreuger Toll, which was controlled by Ivar Kreuger, Swedish capitalist who committed suicide last month in Paris, passed yesterday into the hands of the Irving Trust Company as equity receiver.

Scotch whisky, 780 cases of champagne, artificial teeth and other unclaimed and abandoned goods from ports throughout the world will be offered for sale today at a public auction in the United States Customs Department seizure room at the Army Supply Base, Fifty-eighth Street and First Avenue, Brooklyn.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., April 13 -- Heckled by several persons in an audience of 2,500 here today, Major Gen. Smedley D. Butler, candidate for the Republican, nomination for United States Senator, gave his version of the affair which led to the court-martial of Colonel Alexander S. Williams at San Diego in April, 1926.

Final preparations for a public hearing on the Bureau of Weights and Measures, to include testimony that the poor of the city were victimized through short-weight sales of necessities, were concluded yesterday by the Hofstadter legislative inquiry, and the hearing was set for this morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of April 3 there was an editorial entitled "Washington, the Huguenot," treating somewhat in detail the French ancestor of Washington by the name of Nicholas Martiau.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 13 -- Although held to only three hits by Jimmy Samuels, who was starting his first game for Princeton, the Fordham baseball team defeated the Tigers this afternoon, 3 to 1. Ken Auer, who went the route for Fordham, held Princeton to five singles, striking out six and walking only two.

ALBANY, April 13 -- On the eve of the legislative investigation of the State Administration, which will begin tomorrow, Governor Roosevelt tonight offered his cooperation to the fiscal leaders of the Legislature, Senator Hewitt of Cayuga and Assemblyman Porter of Essex, who conferred with him.

The New York Association of Music School Settlements presented last night at the Town Hall a program called "musical milestones" consisting of "masterpieces composed expressly for the musical experience of youth." About 125 young instrumentalists and 80 young choristers took part in the program, which had for its piece de resistance the suite for string orchestra composed by the Viennese Hanns Jelinek that won the prize of $500 in the association's competition.

A mother and five of her children perished last night in a fire that raged through the upper floors of a six-story tenement at 57 Lewis Street, in the heart of the crowded lower east side. A 60-year-old woman, who was so severely burned that she had to be taken to the Gouverneur Hospital, and about twenty aged persons were rescued by firemen.

CINCINNATI, April 13 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds could not overcome Malone today and the Chicago Cub pitcher scored a 3-to-2 victory in a pitchers' battle with Owen Carroll. The result tied the series thus far at a game each.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 13 -- Here, as in other parts of the East where coaches and college crews are trying to prepare for the opening of racing seasons, the inhabitants are still looking for Spring.

Covering the war epoch and the diplomatic embroglios of a frantic Europe, the third volume of "The Memoirs of Prince von Biilow" will be published on May 6 by Little, Brown. The new volume will deal with the years 1909 to 1919. Discussing the course pursued by Bethmann-Hollweg, who succeeded him as Imperial Chancellor, von Biilow says:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 13 -- With cheers and enthusiasm, more than two-thirds of the membership of the House of Representatives refused to recognize Governor Parnell's order dissolving the special session of the Legislature and met here today to attempt to enact legislation for governmental economy.

LONDON, April 13 -- The stock markets generally were firm today. British Government funds continued strong and many industrials moved in favor of the holders. International Nickel and Brazilian Traction were active in the Anglo-American group.

Questionnaires were distributed yesterday to taxicab operating companies at the first hearing of the Board of Taxi Control, held at City Hall. They ask the number of cabs owned and operated by the companies, average bookings, drivers employed, , with comparative figures for 1930, when, the Mayor's Taxicab Commission, headed by Frank P. Walsh, made its report.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Here are the utterances of the speaker at the Jefferson Day celebration by Democratic leaders of the nation here today, some of the speeches being made at a midday luncheon and others at a formal dinner this evening:

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A proposal made by former Governor Smith that the United States shall forget, for the next twenty years all about the debts owed it by European nations and write off as paid each year from the principal of the debts, 25 per cent of the gross value of American exports bought by the debtor nations, was an outstanding feature of the Democratic Jefferson Day dinner tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Joseph Callaux, former Premier of France, in a letter received today by Chairman Somers, expressed himself, as in "complete agreement" with the House Coinage Committee's advocacy of an international monetary conference.

A new electrical flashing device, by means of which a wave of light is sent along a row of lamps without the need of any costly mechanical moving parts, is expected to effect large economies in railroad signaling systems, moving street signs, traffic lights and in other fields.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Senator Fess, when he today received three women prohibition repeal advocates, congratulated his callers on "taking a strand rather than straddling."

SAN PEDRO, Cal., April 13 (AP) -- Ten battleships thundered out the climactic phase of force battle practice today, winding up the most comprehensive single tactical effort ever attempted by the United States fleet.

A card party in aid of the Carroll Club will take place this afternoon in the Japanese Roof Garden of the St. Regis. The proceeds will be used in carrying on the charitable activities of the club, which provides an educational and recreational program for young business women.
To the Editor of The New YorK Times: Governor Roosevelt, in his radio talk last week, suggested several remedies for dealing with our economic crisis:

BERLIN, April 13 -- Prices advanced in brisk trading on the Boerse today. The public at large reappeared in the market and the buying orders overcame yesterday's disappointment when the resumption of official quotations failed to influence demand.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The government's largest peace-time deficit has slipped over the $2,000,000,000 mark.

The Rochester Red Wings, four-year International League champions, inaugurated the 1932 season at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday by defeating Jersey City in a tense ten-inning battle, 4 to 3. A crowd of 6,000, including Governor Moore who opened the game by tossing out the first ball, saw the contest.
ANDOVER, Mass., April 13 -- Andover Academy lost its opening game to the Tufts freshman baseball team today, 15 to 7.

BOSTON, April 13 -- No provision was made today for redemption of the $23,500,000 note issue of the Boston Metropolitan District Commission which, will fall due tomorrow, the Public Utilities Commission failing to approve a bid of approximately $24,000,000 made by a banking syndicate headed by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation of New York.

CHICAGO, Apirl 13 -- Receivership for the Middle West Utilities Company, a $2,500,000,000 holding company, appeared probable tonight after further conferences between bankers and Samuel Insull, builder of the vast utility enterprise. Bankers said it was doubtful that the company could arrange to meet its financial problems, foremost of which is a $10,000,000 note maturity on June 1.

DENVER, April 13 (AP) -- Governor Murray charged here today that money was being spent to "buy" Democratic convention votes for Governor Roosevelt, and spiked reports that he was abandoning his own campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The price trend in commodities was lower yesterday, some of the improvement of recent days in wheat and cotton being canceled. Moderate reaction was also noted in rubber, hides, silk and cocoa, while coffee and sugar turned up. In the spot trading butter and silk established new lows for the year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me to make a few remarks of a general nature on the stand you have been taking regarding the Illtimed restrictions leveled against the educational progress of the country. In particular I have in mind your editorial "Educational Crusaders."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 13 -- After a lapse of eighteen years, the Atlantic City Horse Show came back today in a perfect setting. No similar event can boast so huge a show ring as the Auditorium, with stables practically at the ringside and an ideal outside course for hunters.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The political roll-call of the States, an outstanding feature of the meeting today of Democratic leaders from all parts of the country, showed the Democrats claiming every State in the Union except Maine, Vermont, Pennsylvania and Iowa, and in the case of the last two the concession was with reservations.

Anatol Shulkin is a charter member of the small band of artiste known as An American Group, which has taken over, for a term of years, the gallery in the Barbizon-Plaza. Although isolated examples of his work have been seen from time to time in exhibitions involving all of the painters in this group, the present is Mr. Shulkin's first one-man show.
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- St. Louis outhit Chicago today, but the rejuvenated White Sox bunched their blows, and took advantage of a Brown error to win their second straight game, 7 to 3.

Replying yesterday to charges that the Hospital Department was "robbing" physicians in city hospitals of their proper fees in workmen's compensation cases, Dr. J.G. "William Greeff, Commissioner of Hospitals, said that five months ago he had asked changes in the department's charter that would allow city doctors to collect fees in compensation cases just as do physicians in private hospitals.

CLEVELAND, April 13 -- All payments of money into or out of the office of County Treasurer L.G. Collister ceased late today as State examiners took charge of the office under authority of a grand jury subpoena by County Prosecutor P.L. A. Leighley.

Supreme Court Justice Ford signed yesterday an order directing the officers of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers to appear in Special Term, Part One of the Supreme Court today and show cause why the books of the union should not be audited before the trial of the $7,500,000 accounting suit is begun.

Mount McKinley is a tremendous mountain in a savage wilderness. There have been many attempts to climb it, but only Archdeacon STUCK and his party gained the top of the higher peak. Another effort will hold the attention of mountaineers and may have scientific value.

BALTIMORE, April 13 (AP) -- The Orioles defeated the Buffalo Bisons, 6 to 4, in the first game of the season today before a crowd held to 3,000 by cold weather. Ferrell and Detore hit homers for the visitors, while Packard made one for the Orioles.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., April 13 -- The members' amateur shooting-dog stake of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club, finished this afternoon near Basking Ridge, was captured by Rex's John, white and liver pointer dog, owned and handled by J.H. Longnecker of Philadelphia.
PEIPING, April 13 -- Conditions are so disquieting in Manchuria that the city of Harbin is reported to be like a keg of powder, as in 1929 and last September.

All but four of the thirty-two pieces of jewelry valued at $305,100 that were stolen on Jan. 21 when three men invaded the home of Harry Glemby, wealthy manufacturer of hair goods, at 22 East Sixty-seventh Street, were recovered yesterday by the police, together with a dozen other pieces which also were believed to have been stolen.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 13 -- Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt arrived today from New York to join Mrs. Vanderbilt in The Homestead. This afternoon they entertained informally for tea in their suites.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 13 -- Eldon Trimingham, "Commodore of Bermuda Skippers," justified local yachtsmen's faith in his ability today when he took his Viking across the finish line first in the second of the series of international six-meter yacht races, scoring six points and taking the lead in the point standing with a total of ten points for two races.

NEWARK, N.J., April 13 -- Vice Chancellor Alonzo Church announced today that he had removed Harry G. Hendricks as receiver for the Earl Radio Corporation, and had directed the arrest of Hendricks on a charge of contempt of court in allegedly appropriating to his own use money of the Earl Corporation.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 13 (AP) -- Returns from 1,736 of 2,049 precincts in Nebraska's primary election yesterday gave tonight for Democratic Presidential preference: Roosevelt 79,544, Garner 23,381, Murray 21,352.

An article in The National Municipal Review describes "The Fate of the Pinchot Relief Program." Items have appeared in the newspapers from time to time indicating that the Governor's spear no longer has the penetrating quality it once had, even in the Pennsylvania House of Representatives, but the whole tale of his latest passage at arms is here told for the first time.

Movement of prices on yesterday's financial markets was less positive than of late. Stocks rose or fell within unusually narrow limits; changes in important shares were for the most part fractional. A similar spirit of uncertainty, or hesitancy, or whatever it may be called, prevailed in the bond market.

The opening of "Angelina Moves In," the Hale Francisco comedy formerly called "Whisky Blanc," is definitely announced for Tuesday night of next week at the Forrest Theatre. Suzanne Caubaye and Mrs. Jacques Martin will head the cast, which also will include Katherine Revner, William Ingersoll, Gerald Kent, Antoinette Rochte, Robert Brister and William Melville.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 13 -- Army's nine shut out Swarthmore, 2 to 0, today. Bob Landry, Cadet pitcher, was steady throughout and let Swarthmore down with two hits, widely scattered. He struck out nine men. Sipler allowed seven safe drives.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The House wet bloc leaders tonight had 96 names on the petition by which they hope to force a record vote on 2.75 per cent beer.

READING, Pa., April 13 (AP) -- Jim Poole's single in the tenth inning, after Partridge and F. Bennett walked, broke up the Reading-Montreal contest. Partridge scoring to beat the visitors, 5 to 4, today. Cold weather kept the attendance to about 3,500.

Bill rates were cut again by dealers in their quest for offerings by the banks, all dates being slashed 1/2 of 1 per cent, which, on top of similar reductions of 1/4 on Tuesday and last Saturday, possibly is the deepest cut in so short a period on record. At present levels, rates are the lowest since last September.
MADRID, April 13 (AP) -- All Spain began tonight to celebrate the first anniversary of the republic under the tricolor, which replaced the banner of the Bourbon, kings on April 14, 1931.

The prosecution closed its case in General Sessions yesterday against Patrick Comerford and John Walsh, officials of the International Union of Operating Engineers, composed of hoisting engine operators, on a conspiracy indictment accusing them of trying to compel a sub-contractor to buy cinders from a concern they favored and refuse those being delivered by another concern.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Four utterances, two of them in the speech of former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York, made a historic occasion of the Jefferson Day Democratic celebration in the Capital under the auspices of the party's national committee today and tonight.

MOSCOW. April 13 -- Joseph Stalin, V.M. Molotoff and C. Voroshiloff, members of the Soviet Political Bureau, and other high Communists stood in Red Square this afternoon at the burial of Professor Michael Nikolaivitch Pokrovsky, the leading Soviet historian and Marxian philosopher.

Business on the Stock Exchange fell off sharply yesterday as pressure against the market relaxed somewhat. Fluctuations were narrow and, although many stocks went into new low ground again, the net declines were small on the average. The market's tendency to steady itself was encouraging to Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A break in the nonpartisan accord on the tax bill seemed almost inevitable tonight because of the failure of Secretary Mills to lay before the Senate Finance Committee specific substitute proposals for the "inequities" complained of by the administration in the House measure.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A wide range of subjects was discussed by Jefferson Day speakers here today and tonight. In brief, these were the chief utterances:

April Collections Viewed as Fair. Early indications are that collections from retailers on the April 10 due date will shape up as "fair," according to comments of garment trade credit men. The improvement in retail trade last week helped to make a somewhat better showing than was anticipated, although many accounts continue in a slow condition, with manufacturers nursing them along.

State of New Jersey. Official advices from the New Jersey State House Commission yesterday were that the State would not be in the market next month with $21,000,000 of bonds as had been indicated in press dispatches from Trenton. It was explained that the State was not pressed for funds.
Not So Easy as It Looks. Revenue-raising has its cycles like business. Economists have noted that in hard times the tendency is away from the tax end of the scale toward the fee end.
LONDON, April 13 -- Closer cooperation among the chief North Atlantic shipping companies may emerge from the regular half yearly conference which begins here tomorrow.

While the rate of steel operations has fallen from 22 to 21 per cent of ingot capacity in the last week, there are indications of a better feeling in the industry, according to the weekly review by The Iron Age. This publication emphasizes the presence of "a few bright spots."

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- In the presence of the widow of Woodrow Wilson, the three Democrats who have been nominated for President by their party since the last Democratic Chief Executive left office, many other notable persons and a gathering of several thousand citizens, Newton D. Baker of Cleveland.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Presidential politics trailed close in the wake of yesterday's State-wide primaries. Democratic leaders prepared to put the official party stamp upon Senator James Hamilton Lewis as "favorite son" candidate for the Presidential nomination, meanwhile indicating that Governor Roosevelt of New York was favored as second choice.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 13 (AP) -- A plot by which New York gangsters hoped to free four men sentenced for a $3,200 payroll robbery was disclosed tonight by police after the four had been hurried to the State prison at Wethersfield under heavy guard.

Pursuing a policy of diversifying the banking affiliations of the General Foods Corporation, stockholders yesterday elected as directors George W. Davison, president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, and S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company.
SCHENECTADY, April 13 (AP) -- Short, the little terrier whose bark was heard around the world, is to receive a medal for his accomplishment.

GENEVA, April 13 -- Monday, June 13, has been tentatively fixed for the opening of the Lausanne reparations conference. Though the date is nearly settled it cannot be contended that any progress has been made in arranging a program.

April showers gave way yesterday to Winter weather which brought snow flurries and chilling winds to New York, heavy snowfalls in up-State New York and Pennsylvania and a near-blizzard in parts of Ohio.

Although "Foreign Affairs," which was acted at the Avon last evening, is not an amusing play, it looks and sounds like an amusing play. That is the strange thing about it. If you peered at it through the glazed eyes of reverie, thinking of other things, you would probably confuse it with light amusement.
CHARLOTTES VILLE, Va., April 13 -- Exercises at Monticello this afternoon incident to the celebration of Thomas Jefferson's birthday were marked by simplicity.
LONDON, April 13 -- Put to a free vote in the House of Commons the new bill to egalize Sunday movie performances, subject to local approval, passed its second reading tonight by 235 to 217 votes.

A $20 note, positively identified as part of the $50,000 with which Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh tried vainly to ransom his son from the kidnappers who have held the child since March 1, was found here yesterday, but it proved of doubtful value as a clue.

From Massachusetts comes a brief sketch of the preparations that the State has been carrying on for the trout season. Over a half million trout, the greater percentage of which are over six inches, will have been stocked by the middle of next month in State streams.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Wet planks in political party platforms, wet candidates and resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment were demanded in resolutions adopted today by the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.

The New York Board of Trade, following a long discussion yesterday at a luncheon in the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue, adopted a report favoring legislation to make a resale price maintenance effective. Opponents of the report, who were defeated by a vote of 10 to 6, held that the action of the board would place the body on record as approving price fixing.

FINEHURST, N.C., April 13 -- The elimination of Bryan Grant of Atlanta, former national clay court champion, in the fourth round of the men's singles today by Dr. Eugene McCauliff of New York was the first upset in the fourteenth North and South tennis championships.

LOS ANGELES, April 13 -- More than two hundred and fifty women athletes will compete in the Olympic Games in Los Angeles from July 30 to Aug. 14, it was announced today by heads of the local organizing committee.

MANHASSET, L.I., April 13 -- Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady of New York entertained today with a luncheon at Inisfada, her country home, for officers and directors of the National Board of Girl Scouts, who are attending the semi - annual business meeting.

People who feared that this Presidential campaign was going to be stale, flat and unprofitable left "AL" SMITH out of their reckoning. His speech at the Jefferson dinner in Washington last night did more than flutter the dovecotes. It made even the eagles of the party hide their heads under their wing in fright.

NEWARK, N.J., April 13 -- Expressing the wish that he could send to jail the "higher-ups" in the union "who misdirect and misguide the members," Vice Chancellor Alonzo Church found Jersey City Local 45 of the Ironworkers' Union guilty of contempt of court today and fined it $2,500.

Conditions in modern social and industrial life have placed the responsibility for vocational guidance upon the public school, Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, declares in another instalment of his annual report, made public yesterday.

Another reduction in wages is being considered by the principal companies in the steel industry and will be put into effect soon unless there is a substantial improvement in business. A decrease in the compensation of salaried employes, from the highest to the lowest, will accompany or precede the cut in the wages of labor, according to the plans considered.

ALBANY, April 13 -- A decision to plan for an economic conference at the Capitol during the first week of June was the chief result of a meeting today of Governor Roosevelt's advisory committee on unemployment problems, with the Governor in attendance.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company attained new peaks in gross and net operating income in 1931 and also new peaks in the gas and electric departments as measured both in volume and dollar value of sales, A.F. Hockenbeamer, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting in San Francisco on Tuesday.

Under the Glass-Steagall bill this country has "gone a long way toward inflation preparedness," according to Paul Gourrich, economist of Kuhn, Loeb Co., who addressed the Taylor Society at the Hotel Lexington last evening.

Tuberculosis is one of the most common diseases, yet, because of a misconception on the part of physicians as to its diagnosis and a lack of proper knowledge on the part of patients as to its first symptoms, scarcely any cases of the disease are discovered in the early stages, it was declared yesterday by Dr. James Alexander Miller, director of the Bellevue Hospital Tuberculosis Service.

The Millions Without Work. The world's idle workers are estimated by the Geneva Labor Office at somewhere between 20,000,000 and 25,000,000. With two dependents for every person out of work, this would make the total population affected by unemployment between 60,000,000 and 75,000,000.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 14 -- Two upsets today sent Everett G. Livesay, left-handed golfer from Columbus, Ohio, and John E. Hines of Garden City, L.I., into the final round of the Mason and Dixon golf tournament. They will meet in the 36-hole final tomorrow.
MADRID, April 14 (AP) -- Industrial and commercial activity came almost to a full stop throughout the nation today as Republican Spain celebrated its first birthday in fine Spring weather.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 14 (AP) -- Clifford Frazier, a lawyer and Quaker of Greensboro, was nominated for Governor on a "bone-dry" platform by the State Republican Convention today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Senator Reed of Pennsylvania, a foe of cancellation of the foreign debts, not only disapproves of the proposal made by Alfred E. Smith at the Jefferson Day dinner in Washington yesterday, but also thinks that Mr. Smith made a confusing statement of the case.

A memorandum handed down yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Second Department, in Brooklyn, on the application by the city for a further stay of the injunction against independent bus operation in Manhattan and Queens called on Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly to advise the court of the present status of bus franchise matters before the Board of Estimate.

New York had an added touch of jungle life yesterday when a large python, at present attached to the Ringling circus, started to indiscriminately bite the hands that feed it. It attacked both a keeper and the star aerialist before overpowering numbers returned it to a more peaceful frame of mind and a steel cage.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Cotton consumed during March was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 488,655 bales of lint and 54,229 bales of linters, compared with 450,018 and 52,764 in February this year and 490,509 and 64,003 in March last year.

NEWARK, N.J., April 14 -- Featuring a smashing batting punch, with power distributed right down the lineup, the Newark Bears overwhelmed the Toronto Leafs, 13 to 2, in the second game of the series today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I too am a former admirer of Governor Roosevelt who was deeply chagrined at his recent radio speech on the $2,000,000,000 loan. His reasoning was so palpably unsound that had it come from a less exalted source, as THE TIMES has well said, it could not be considered otherwise than that of a demagogue.

Though Admiral BRISTOL is retiring, he will be America's Admiral chiefly for what he did on land. Distinguished as was his naval career, culminating in command of the Asiatic Fleet, his name will be remembered in our diplomatic history for a unique achievement.

The record of a four-year trip around the world in a home-made 34-foot yawl is told in "Around the World Single-Handed," by Harry Pidgeon, published today by Appleton. Pidgeon built his boat in Los Angeles, stowed away plenty of food and water, and set out across the Pacific.

LONDON, April 14 -- Miss Joyce Wethered, England's foremost woman golfer, will emerge from retirement to captain the British team against the United States in the first official women's matches between the two nations to be played at Wentworth, Surrey, May 21.

The Class D polo forces of Squadron C retained the Colonel's trophy, offered annually, by defeating three teams of the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club, 18 to 3 1/2, last night at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn. The count marked the collective score in three two-period games.
Following is the comment of the press of the country on ex-Governer Smith's Jefferson Day address in Washington:

Nowhere was more pain caused by the Smith speech than in the inner circles of Tammany. Its great minds now feel compelled to make a political choice, and nothing could be more distasteful to them. Their previous plans were Knocked all askew by the insubordinate and irrepressible " AL " SMITH.

With the Literary Digest prohibition poll in its semi-final stage, the latest tabulation made public yesterday revealed that while North Carolina had joined Kansas in the dry column the wet voters were still out-balloting the drys by almost three to one.

BERLIN, April 14 -- The Boerse continued to advance today, even more stocks than yesterday being carried up by the general rise due to the return of the public to the market. Even among bonds gains of 5 per cent were recorded. The upward movement was supported by reports that the Keichsbank might reduce the discount rate next week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article published this morning in regard to diamonds synthetically made by Dr. McKee of Columbia University, while perhaps correct in essence, may create an erroneous impression to the public in regard to the effect on the diamond industry and diamond prices.

With testimony that an ivestigation of the Bureau of Weights and Measures during two months of 1930 showed 1,384 indications of laxity in the 1,374 cases the bureau handled, more than one to a case, Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, made his first direct attack upon Mayor Walker yesterday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 14 (AP) -- All those known to have been killed in the explosion and fire at the new State office building today were building trade workers and residents of Columbus.

The Public Service Commission, in an opinion made public yesterday, declined to take any steps to reduce the electric light rates charged by the New York Edison system until there had been a "fair trial period" of the rates now in effect. The decision was rendered on the complaint made by the Washington Heights Taxpayers' Association.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Gratification that a past feeling of distrust of Latin-American governments toward the United States "has been in a considerable measure allayed," was expressed before the Senate today by Senator Bingham of Connecticut in a Fan-American Day address.

SYRACUSE, April 14 -- Proposals for Hawaiian governmental reforms, which are before Congress as a result of racial troubles, brought to a head by the Massie case, were condemned by Dean Karl C. Leebrick of Syracuse University at the opening session today of the Institute on United States Colonies and Dependencies.

LONDON, April 14. -- Andrew W. Mellon had his real initiation as a foreign diplomat tonight when he was guest of honor at the traditional dinner that the Pilgrims Society of Great Britain always gives for a newly arrived United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James's.

LONDON, April 14 -- Lord Sankey, leading conciliator at last year's round-table conference, today broke his long silence on Indian affairs by expressing unreserved approval of the British Government's recent policy.

RENO, Nev., April 14 -- Mrs. Maya de Chrapovitsky Auchincloss has taken up residence in Reno, for the purpose, she admitted tonight, of seeking a divorce from Hugh. D. Auchincloss. She said her suit would charge incompatibility, but she would not discuss any specific details of her proposed charges.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 14 -- Max Myers of Cleveland was elected president of the National-American Wholesale Lumber Association at the closing session of its annual convention here today. He succeeds Arthur E. Lane of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A unified national banking system, confining its activities to commercial banking and holding a tight rein on speculation, was advocated today by Governor Meyer of the Federal Reserve Board before a House Banking and Currency subcommittee.

The last examination of the Bank of United States, started in June, 1930, and concluded two months later, four months before the bank closed, showed that the institution's surplus had been wiped out and that unless drastic changes in personnel and policies were made the depositors' funds would have been endangered, Max D. Steuer, special prosecutor, declared yesterday at the trial of Joseph A. Eroderick, State Superintendent of Banks.

LONDON, Friday, April 15 (AP) -- Alfred E. Smith's suggestion for a twenty-year postponement of foreign debt payments to the United States was received today by some London newspapers with favorable editorial expressions, but the comment was not general.

PLYMOUTH, Vt., April 14 -- The kerosene lamps which furnished the light when John Coolidge administered the oath of office as President to his son Calvin nine years ago will no longer see service in the Coolidge Summer home.

As the result of a last-hour rally, the share market showed a net gain yesterday in average prices for the second time in thirteen trading days. Transactions on the Stock Exchange made a total of 1,700,000 shares, compared with 1,091,180 shares on Wednesday.
PARIS, April 14 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
From a leading American economist, who is at the same time a practical man of affairs, THE TIMES has received the following: I am often asked about the chance and time of...

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh issued a statement last night declaring that "it is still of the utmost importance" that neither they nor their agents in negotiations for the recovery of their kidnapped son be followea or questioned about their movements.

LONDON, April 14 -- The Liberal News Chronicle, which throughout all the recent disarmament and other international conferences has shown itself one of the firmest friends of the United States, takes the administration of that country severely to task tonight over the latest developments in the Lindbergh case.

CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Sam Gray allowed the Chicago White Sox only five hits, all singles, today and the St. Louis Browns captured their first victory in three games, 3 to 0. Gray was seldom in danger and pitched to only thirty-one batters.

ATLANTC CITY, N.J., April 14 -- Sparkling competition today marked the second day of the Atlantic City horse show as the contestants became more at home in their new environment. Two more enthusiastic gatherings viewed the battles for the ribbons among some of the most noted show horses of the Eost and Middle West during the afternoon and evening sessions.

Opinion among local Democrats was divided yesterday as to the effect of former Governor Alfred E. Smith's Jefferson Day dinner speech at Washington on his candidacy and that of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for President.

Mme. Ernestine Schumann-Heink has recovered from her recent illness and is ready to fill her engagements, her managers announced yesterday, after she had sent word from Chicago, where she arrived several days ago. Mme. Schumann-Heink was in a hospital at Stevens Point, Wis., for some time.

GENEVA, April 14. -- There is sound reason to expect that Turkey will become the fifty-sixth member of the League of Nations during the September Assembly, and possibly even next month when the special session of the Assembly resumes.
AMMAN, Transjordania, April 14 -- Bedouins are crossing the frontier into Transjordania -- gaunt men of the desert, ragged, starving, in a state of pitable distress.

An exhibition of 'Paintings in France and Virginia," by Berkeley Williams Jr., is current at the Montross Gallery, 785 Fifth Avenue, and will remain through April 23. Like so many other American artists, Mr. Williams, a native of Richmond, decided upon a finishing course overseas.

How far yesterday's general recovery in the markets was occasioned by the announcement of a concerted Reserve system policy for further easing of the credit position, and how far to natural rebound from the prolonged forcing-down of prices, is perhaps debatable.

By her researches among fine and half-forgotten vocal literature of all periods and by her discriminating championship of new works. Eva Gauthier has long since established her unique place as a singer of distinguished programs. That given in the Town Hall last night was no exception.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 14 -- The appointment of Dr. Dana Gardner Munro, United States Minister to Haiti, as Professor of Latin-American History and Affairs in the School of Public and International Affairs of Princeton University was announced here today at the Spring meeting of the board of trustees.
BERLIN, April 14 -- Chancellor Bruening left for Geneva tonight to take part in the disarmament discussions and to pave the way for the deliberations of the Lausanne conference.

BOSTON, April 14 -- Refusal by the State Department of Public Utilities to take action on the petition of the trustees of the Boston Metropolitan District for approval of a $24,000,000 issue of long-term bonds for refunding the loan required for retirement of the preferred stock of the Boston Elevated Railway, resulted today in the defaulting of the $23,500.000 note issue negotiated last August.

For all practical purposes, only four nations need be considered in estimating the possible effect of Governor SMITH'S proposal to deal with Europe's war debts. These four, England, France, Italy and Belgium, owe 93 per cent of the amount due us, and a still higher percentage, if a doubtful asset of $192,000,000, representing funds we advanced to Russia, is excluded from the count.

LONDON, April 14 -- The stock markets were irregular today, early Continental buying ceasing in the afternoon. A certain amount of bear covering was in progress. The Stock Exchange will be closed on Saturday.

Improvement in outside markets stimulated trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices advanced to the highest levels of the month. After early unsettled fluctuations because of weakness in securities, the market developed resistance and July moved up to within 2 points of 6 1/2 cents a pound. The list closed at the top at net gains of 10 to 12 points.

BOSTON, April 14 (AP) -- The first step in the rebuilding of the Boston Bruins was made tonight when the management of the National Hockey League team purchased Billy Burch, veteran centre, from the New York Americans in a straight cash transaction.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 14 -- An explosion of undetermined origin which rocked downtown Columbus at 2:30 P.M. today, followed by fire, partly wrecked Ohio's new $5,000,000 State office building in the civic centre and caused the death of at least five men and more or less severe injuries to 75 more of 140 workmen busy in the structure.

Jerome D. Travers, the Bobby Jones of golf twenty years ago, has decided to turn his skill and fame into capital by following the foot-steps of George Von Elm and becoming a "business man golfer," it was learned yesterday.

PARIS, April 14 -- Since accounts published in Paris are as yet fragmentary, the press makes no comment today on Alfred E. Smith's suggestion for reducing war debts by granting credit in proportion to European imports from the United States.

PITTSBURGH, April 14 -- Courageous and proper advertising at this time by every strong bank in the country would tremendously encourage public confidence, Edwin Bird Wilson, national financial advertiser and president of Edwin Bird Wilson. Inc., of New York, asserted at the closing luncheon today of the Pittsburgh Advertising Club's fifth annual advertising exposition and conference.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A suit to nullify the Interstate Commerce Commission's approval of acquisition of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway by the Southern Pacific has been entered in the Federal District Court in Frankfort, Ky., by the Missouri Pacific Railroad and its subsidiary, the Texas Pacific Railway, the commission was advised by the court today.
