PINEHURST, N.C., April 14 -- Three Philadelphia players and one from Boston, all favorites, advanced to the semi-finals of the women's singles in the North and South tennis tournament today. Rain in the afternoon halted the quarter-finals of the men's singles.

BERLIN, April 14 -- The dissolution of Adolf Hitler's Nazi storm detachments proceeded virtually without violence or resistance to the police today, the biggest private army Germany has ever seen disbanding quietly.

Nearly $20,000 was realized by the United States Customs authorities yesterday at the auction of articles seized by Federal officers and unclaimed at the Custom House. The articles included nearly 800 cases of champagne, several cases of assorted liquors and miscellaneous items such as clay statuary, snake skins, fiber skirts, golf sticks and moving picture film.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 14 (AP) -- A little fleet of tall-sailed yachts will put out from St. Petersburg Saturday at 1 P.M. with a Coast Guard Convoy bound for Havana in the third renewal of the St. Petersburg-Havana international yacht race.
ST. LOUIS, April 14 (AP) -- Pittsburgh gave the St. Louis Cardinals their first defeat this season today, the Pirates getting fifteen hits in an uphill battle to win, 5 to 4.

Samuel Insull warned investors yesterday in the three big Chicago utility companies not to confuse the Middle West Utilities Company, the Insull Utility Investments and the Corporation. Securities Company with their own companies, which, he said, should not be the object of any misapprehension.
Reports published yesterday of the resignation of Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown of New York University were denied in a statement issued last night by Harold O. Voorhis, university secretary.

HAVANA, April 14 -- The three students whose case Senator Borah brought up before the United States Senate on Monday went on trial before a court-martial today on charges of illegal possession of explosives.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the World War we were asked to plant, "war gardens" to help meet the food problem. I did and had enough for myself and neighbors. I read of no plans to plant "depression gardens" around New York City, as some other cities are considering.
BERLIN, April 14 (AP) -- Police raided 150 gathering places of the National Socialist storm troops today, carrying out President von Hindenburg's decree for the dissolution of the organization.

Lavelle (Buddy) Ensor, one of the country's leading riders a decade ago, was granted a license to ride on the local tracks yesterday at the meeting of the Jockey Club. Ensor began a come-back last Winter in Cuba and also rode many winners in Florida.

The Revolution of the North American Colonies furnished much of the inspiration for the revolt of Latin America from Spain, Dr. Orestes Ferrara, Cuban Ambassador to the United States, said yesterday at the celebration of Pan-American Day at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Consumer Jury Sets Lower Prices. Prices lower than the store anticipated were designated by a jury of twelve consumers for the anniversary sale of the 125th Street store of L.M. Blumstein, it was announced yesterday by Chester Brown, sales promotion director.

Out of the mass of proposals for temporary reduction of the pay of Federal employes, two rival schemes have now emerged. The House committee proposes a flat cut of 11 per cent in all salaries, with an exemption of $1,000. This would leave the pay of some 345,000 civil employes in the lower brackets unaffected by the change; the enlisted personnel of the army and navy would be entirely excluded.

TRENTON, N.J., April 14 -- Under a bill signed today by Governor Moore, a law becoming effective July 1 will provide unlimited reciprocity for motor vehicles from other States in which a similar privilege is granted to New Jersey vehicles. Under the present statute, motor trucks from other States are allowed to operate in New Jersey for fifteen days without a license and pleasure cars for ninety days.

Arrangements were made yesterday for the sale of a New York Stock Exchange membership at $81,000, an increase of $1,000 from the last previous sale, which was at the lowest price since 1924. The highest figure this year was $175,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 14 -- The final accounting in the estate of Charles A. Gould, president of the Gould Coupler Company, who died on Jan. 6, 1926, was filed here today by the Bankers' Trust Company, Mrs. Celia Gould Milne, a daughter, and Richard T. Greene, who are the executors and trustees.
MADRID, April 14 -- Spain celebrated today the first anniversary of the Republic with rejoicing and ceremonies and virtually no disorder.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The search for means to get business steadily on the upward grade went ahead as usual today at the Capitol and the White House. At an early hour, President Hoover had the affairs of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation up with Charles G. Dawes, its president, and Eugene Meyer, chairman of the board.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- A proposal that all "permanent improvement" construction items be eliminated from the budget and financed on a "long-time credit basis" was made in the Senate today by Senator Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan.
NEW YORK. The Cuban Ambassador, Orestes Ferrara, is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 14 -- The final accounting in the estate of Mary Harrison McKee of North Street, Greenwich, daughter of Benjamin Harrison, former President, was accepted today by Judge William C. Rungee in probate court. The value was put at $1,810,361.

BOWIE, Md., April 14 -- The Southern Maryland and Agricultural Association's meeting came to an end today with a charity program, the feature of which was won by Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Stepenfetchit, a chestnut son of The Porter and Sobranje, which ran only four times last year.

Daylight saving will be observed this Summer in seven countries, fifteen States, in the Union, in nearly all of the cities and towns of New York State and through the whole of Massachusetts, Rhode Island and New Jersey, according to an annual survey by the Merchants' Association, the results of which were made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A tax on spirituous liquors would bring $1,000,000,000 into the treasury, Senato Bingham and former Senator Wadsworth today told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee conducting hearings on wet bills.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Business will get better when business men make it better, Dr. Paul H. Nystrom of Columbia University told delegates to the annual convention of the American Association of Advertising Agencies today.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 14 -- Eldon Trimingham of Bermuda again triumphed with his yacht Viking, piloting the craft across the finish line today ahead of his American and Bermuda rivals to win the third race of the international six-meter series for the Prince of Wales Trophy.

PARIS, April 14. -- When Secretary Stimson arrives here tomorrow he will find much to talk about, but it would surprise every one, especially the French officials, if he finds himself in agreement with the French viewpoint on any vital subjects concerning the two countries unless he talks about the gold standard.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Amid applause, but without prefatory eulogy of President Hoover or his administration, the Republican State Committee at a meeting here today adopted this resolution by unanimous vote:

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Friday, April 15 (AP) -- Royal Naval Reserves were called out today and two squadrons of mounted volunteers were brought into Auckland as a precautionary measure after fierce rioting by the unemployed last night.

BOSTON, April 14 (AP) -- Mayor James M. Curley today rose to the defense of Governor Roosevelt, saying the New York Governor had not done anything to justify the assertion, that he has attempted to array "class against class."

In one of the largest deals reported in the Housbrouck Heights section of New Jersey this year the Hasbrouck Heights Hospital Association has purchased through C. Carlton Colyer, Inc., the five-story Cathcart Gardens Apartments at 125 Terrace Avenue and will remodel the building immediately for its own use.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- New high levels for wheat futures since Nov. 19 were established today on the Board of Trade here after a brief period of hesitation early. At no time did the active futures drop below yesterday's final prices, and the undertone of pessimism that had prevailed then gave way to a feeling of great confidence.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 14 -- The Nassau County Board of Supervisors today authorized a $5,000,000 long term bond issue to take care of two projects authorized by referenda in 1930 and to complete its road development plans. The rate of interest is not to exceed 6 per cent.

The apartment house at 1,239 East Thirty-fifth Street was sold by the Margit Realty Corporation. Walter Jung, president, to a client of Fred C. Faupel, broker, for investment. The same broker sold the one-family dwelling at 4,019 Hubbard Place for the Capital Foundation Corporation.

In his travels around the world, CHARLIE CHAPLIN must meet many curious admirers who want to know what his next picture will toe about. He told a reporter in Singapore not long ago that it " might be about the world crisis," because he was learning much of that subject.

The violoncello concert composed by Frederick Stock for Alfred Wallenstein, and dedicated to him, was played by that virtuoso and first 'cellist of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the concert given under Sir Thomas Beecham's direction last night in Carnegie Hall.

ALBANY, April 14. -- On the eve of the Democratic State Committee meeting here tomorrow to elect sixteen delegates to the National Convention, Governor Roosevelt announced that he would not go to Chicago as a delegate and would yield to no pressure exerted with a view to having him accept a place on the delegation.

The Southern Pacific Company yesterday assumed corporate control of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway (Cotton Belt) and announced that it would guarantee a loan of $18,000,000 to the smaller line conditionally granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
The Columbia rowing squad departed from routine yesterday on the Harlem River and held two three-quarter mile races under the direction of Coach Richard J. Glendon during the six-mile workout.

HONOLULU, April 14 -- All the pathos of the Ala Moana assault case was brought today into the trial of Mrs. Granville Fortesoue, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, her son-in-law, and the two navy enlisted men, E.J. Lord and A.G. Jones, for the killing of a native athlete, Joseph Kahahawai, when Clarence Darrow called Lieutenant Massie as the first witness for the defense.

Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars and some of his pets delivered a lecture last night in the Jade Room of the Waldorf. While the angels and cupids looked down from the ceiling in astonishment, rattlesnakes reached out wistfully to touch retired Generals, and gila monsters made gestures toward the navy.

More than a dozen actors, writers and producers spoke on a nationwide hook-up yesterday in protest against the proposed 10 per cent tax on theatre tickets when they addressed a meeting under the auspices of the New York Exchange Club, in cooperation with the National Alliance of the Theatre, at the Hotel McAlpin.

PEORIA, Ill., April 14 -- With ten persons under arrest and confessions allegedly obtained from six of them, the police said tonight that the roundup of the gang which kidnapped Dr. James W. Parker on March 13 and held him a prisoner for eighteen days was complete.

Although there has been a somewhat better showing by cities outside of New York, especially in the South, the total of bank clearings for the country continues to run as far below last year as it has in preceding months. The aggregate for twenty-two cities in the week ended on Wednesday was $4,671,572,000, a drop of 41.2 per cent from last year, according to R.G. Dun Co.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted and the note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure.

In the belief that the time to write biography is when the subject is still alive or is survived by men who knew him, Dane Coolidge has written short lives of twelve gun-carrying pioneers of the old Southwest out of material given him by the men themselves or by men who were their intimates.

PARIS, April 14 -- Opening irregular, the Bourse rallied today, showing strength throughout, with closing prices near yesterday's levels. Suez Canal and some other leaders were in demand, so that final prices were on the side of gains. The volume of transactions remained light.

CINCINNATI, April 14 (AP) -- A fiverun first inning assault, featured by triples from the bats of Babe Herman and Mickey Heath, was too much for the Chicago Cubs to overcome today and they lost, 5-3 to the Cincinnati Reds, who took the lead in the series, two games to one.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 -- John Barnes Miller, chairman of the board of directors and former president of the Southern California Edison Company, died this evening in the Good Samaritan Hospital of blood-poisoning.

The Annalist Index of Business Activity shows a further moderate decline. The preliminary figure for March is 61.7, as against 62.6 for February and 62.8 for January. The main factors in the decline were further decreases, to new low records for the depression to date, in the adjusted indices of freight carloadings, steel ingot production, electric power production and pig iron production.

Among the passengers who will sail for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Conte Grande today are several members of the Metropolitan Opera Company, including Armando Borgioli, baritone; Francesco Merli, tenor, and Giuseppe Conca, conductor.

DETROIT, April 14 (AP) -- Detroit evened its opening series with Cleveland at one victory each by winning today's game, 3 to 1. Whitlow Wyatt had the best of a pitching duel with Willis Hudlin, allowing only four hits, while the Tigers got seven, including a home run by Charley Gehringer in the sixth with none on.

It is not so much the amount contributed as it is the spirit in which it is given that makes a benefaction worthy, Cardinal Hayes told thousands of volunteer solicitors last night at St. Patrick's Cathedral in a special service preliminary to the opening next Sunday of the annual appeal of the Catholic Charties for funds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For the past two years the American people have been deceived by the mirage created by hot-air vaporings on the chill atmosphere surrounding those in want. The air has been filled with unfulfilled prophecies of prosperity just around the corner.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Negotiations to bring about a meeting of important North American silver producers and the Government of India, to formulate an exporters' marketing agreement are progressing, Marshall W. Tuthill of New York, reported to the House Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures today.

BERLIN, April 14 -- The Centrist Germania, the only paper commenting on Alfred E. Smith's proposal, says that the plan should not be over looked in Europe, despite its peculiarities, since the twenty-year moratrium with sinking fund arrangements proposed by Mr. Smith would come very near to cancellation of debts, although it would not have the same psychological effect.

Miss Dorothy Locke of the Salle d'Armes Vince last night won the women's national individual fencing championship at the Fencers Club. She succeeds to the title held by her clubmate, Miss Marion Lloyd. Miss Lloyd finished third, second place going to Miss Muriel Guggolz, also of the Salle d'Armes Vince.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Eleven heads of administrative departments at the Capital received a hearing today at the opening session of the Joint Legislative Committee which is to investigate the State departments. Only one, Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- After an economist and men connected with finance had testified before the Ways and Means Committee today in favor of inflation of the currency for immediate payment of the $2,000,000,000 soldiers' bonus, a House vote on the Patman bill embodying it was conceded by Democratic leaders as practically certain.

Announcement that the first two weeks of the Block-Aid effort had resulted in the collection of $274,435,74 was followed yesterday by the statement that the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee may have to drop nearly 15,000 men and women after May 1 unless the Block-Aiders make such drastic reduction unnecessary.
John Martinick twirled a no-hit norun game yesterday as the Alexander Hamilton High School baseball team blanked Samuel J. Tilden High, 2 to 0, on the latter's diamond in Brooklyn.

Approximately 15,000 Old Master Brew Bricks, were seized yesterday by cynical prohibition agents, who supposed that they were being sold to the public merely for use in making beer, by Universal Malt Products, Inc., 36 West Twentieth Street, where the raid was made.

A drop in time money quotations and the discounts on commercial paper represented the market's adjustment to the easy money policy of the Reserve Bank. All maturity money was dropped to 2 1/2 per cent, bid, from 2 3/4, while 3 1/2 was the prevailing rate for prime-name, short term business paper, a decline of 1/4.

And where the blue was, lo! the rosiest, red. At the Democratic high jinks on Wednesday Dr. Pangloss read reports dripping with joy and confidence from every State but Vermont. The omission is inexplicable and can be attributed only to neglect or prejudice.

Directors of the Columbia Gas and Electric Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, payable in convertible 5 per cent preference stock, against 37 1/2 cents a share in preference stock paid in the previous quarter.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- The financial affairs of the Middle West Utilities Company, a $2,500,000,000 holding concern organized by Samuel Insull in peak-price days, reached a climax here today with the films of a bill for receivership in the United States District Court.

Sinclair Lewis galled on the North German Lloyd liner Dresden yesterday expressing deep regret at the passing of his friend H.L. Mencken from the ranks of conviviality. Mr. Lewis's remarks were accepted as part of a game which he and Mr. Mencken, the editor of The American Mercury, have been playing for some years, the moves of which have always been made on shipboard, either leaving New York or returning to it.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A new obstacle to speedy action on the billion-dollar tax bill developed today. It was party politics.

ABOUT this time every year most of the baseball owners harbor a suspicion that they should have trained their teams in Labrador. A bold magnate may try it some time and have the satisfaction of seeing his team get off to a fast start on skates in the baseball campaign.

The increase of $100,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, shown yesterday in the report of the Federal Reserve System as of Wednesday, reflected the first week's operations of the Federal Reserve's new policy of controlled credit expansion.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 14 -- Hampered somewhat by the high winds and cold weather which have been bothering all the crews of the East, Princeton this week is putting the finishing touches to its varsity for the opening race of the season here Saturday against Navy.

Two Negroes attacked the driver of a mail truck with hammers last night in an attempt to steal a load of registered mail. They were captured by patrolmen of the radio motor patrol after they had hidden in a tenement at 437 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn.

A hearing on the Capper-Kelly bill now in Congress, to relieve producers from the provisions of the antitrust laws against making contracts with retailers to fix the resale price of branded or trade-marked goods, was held here yesterday at the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at the last meeting of a three-day session of the commerce committee of the American Bar Association.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 (AP) -- Colonel Robert H. Sillman, hero of the capture of Manila and commander of the Twenty-seventh Infantry in Siberia during the World War, died today at the Letterman General Hospital on the San Francisco Presidio.
Although the weather always plays an important part in any sport, it will be the chief factor in whether or not hundreds of anglers greet the official opening of the trout season today in New Jersey.

The 37 East Fifty-seventh Street Corporation, Luther C. Brown, president, yesterday announced plans for a sixteen-story office, showroom and store building at 61-63 East Fifty-seventh Street. It will be designed to house art and antique furniture dealers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been coming to New York for many years and have watched with awe and admiration the replacing of the old buildings by wonderful new ones, but there is one landmark I am delighted to find still untouched.

LONDON, April 14 -- The accumulated discontent and differences of the last year among the shipping companies had a thorough airing today when the semi-annual meeting of the North Atlantic Shipping Conference began here.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Democrats celebrated the birth of Thomas Jefferson yesterday, but the Republicans celebrated it today. They explained that their visible and unanimous cheerfulness sprang from the veiled attack made by Alfred E. Smith upon Franklin D. Roosevelt at the Jefferson Day dinner in Washington.
PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- Penn's varsity tennis team, captained by Bill Colton of Forest Hills, L.I., opened its season today by defeating Haverford College, 9 to 0.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Glass banking bill, greatly modified, especially in those features which were held by some to be deflationary, will be reported to the Senate Saturday, according to opinions expressed today by members of the Banking and Currency Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended April 13, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,629,000,000, an increase of $29,000,000 compared with the preceding week and $709,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

LONDON, April 14 -- For about an hour in the House of Commons tonight Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, "boosted Britain," revealing some new facts from the dossiers of his Whitehall office. A recent charge by Andre Siegfried that the British were foolish and decadent was his tilting post.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A hundred million dollars was tossed into the face of the depression by the Federal Reserve Banks in the week ended on April 13, as the Reserve System opened its long expected credit expansion drive.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 14 (AP) -- The Ohio National Guard tonight moved into the Eastern Ohio bituminous coal mine strike area, where one man was killed today and more than a score of others injured in rioting.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 14 -- A large field rode with Mrs. Fay Ingalls, M.F.H. of the Bath County hunt, this morning on the last drag of the season.

How Nicholas C. Partos, organizer of several realty corporations and head of a drug store chain, equipped stock salesmen with "leads" on prospective investors in the Hungarian colonies about the city was revealed yesterday to Judge Corrigan and the jury at the General Sessions larceny trial of Partos and Ellis A. Laskey, his former accountant.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Discontinuance of the Panama Railroad Steamship Line, as urged by a number of private American steamship companies and agitated in Congress, was opposed today by Governor Harry Burgess of the Panama Canal. who has come here to urge before Congress retention of the line.

TOKYO, April 14 -- It is officially stated here that Japan will not participate in discussions at Geneva regarding Shanghai terms. In the Japanese view the Shanghai conference is neither closed nor deadlocked, but has been postponed.

Arrangements have been made to extend the maturity of the $50,000,000 bank loans of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., and $21,250,000 bank loans of the United Gas Corporation for one year, it was announced late yesterday at the offices of the Electric Bond and Share Company.

Vincent Astor's yacht, the Nourmahal, returned yesterday from a cruise to the Galapagos and islands in the far South Seas, bringing specimens for the New York Aquarium and private collections. The yacht was docked at Pier 59, North River, where Mr. Astor and Charles M. Breder of the Aquarium met her and went aboard.
Increases in gasoline prices were announced yesterday in various sections of the country, continuing the upward readjustment that was started recently after the advance in crude oil prices.

Vincent Astor's yacht, the Nourmahal, returned yesterday from a cruise to the Galapagos and islands in the far South Seas, bringing specimens for the New York Aquarium and private collections. The yacht was docked at Pier 59, North River, where Mr. Astor and Charles M. Breder of the Aquarium met her and went aboard.
Increases in gasoline prices were announced yesterday in various sections of the country, continuing the upward readjustment that was started recently after the advance in crude oil prices.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 14 (AP) -- Henry L. Stevens Jr., national commander of the American Legion, in a statement today declared action taken at the Legion's last national convention "clearly restrains" the organization "from asking for the immediate payment of the adjusted service certificates."

A seasonal gain of from 5 to 15 per cent in general construction during this quarter over the first quarter of 1932 is forecast by the F.W. Dodge Corporation. The company, however, expects little improvement in the construction trend until the continued decline in bond issues has been arrested.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The principal obstacle to selection of Samuel Untermyer as counsel for the Senate Banking and Currency Committee in its stock market inquiry appeared to have been eliminated tonight, as a result of press reports that John L. Hall of Boston, his principal rival for the position, would not serve.

Henry E. Schnackenberg, a life member and former vice president and instructor of the Art Students' League, will oppose John Sloan for the presidency of that organization at a special election to be held in the League Gallery next Wednesday evening, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, April 15 -- Secretary of State Stimson arrived here this morning, modestly avowing that he had come to Europe simply to get information on the disarmament conference at Geneva and, if possible, "to get behind and push."

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Open market activity of the Federal Reserve System to ease credit by throwing additional funds on the market through purchase of government securities marks the fourth time since the World War that this policy has been employed.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- The speedy cancellation, or drastic reduction, of war debts and reparations as an essential step in bringing prosperity back to the world was called for here tonight by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University and of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, in an address before the Economic Club of Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- The Yankees, by a five-run rally in the seventh inning today, came from behind to take a three-run lead over the Athletics, but the Mackmen did some rallying in their own behalf, tying the score in the eighth and winning in the ninth, 9 to 8, while about 5,000 fans found warmth and comfort in the unexpected triumph of their favorites.
OKLAHOMA CITY, April 15 (AP). -- Governor William H. (Alfalfa Bill))'. Murray of Oklahoma challenged Governor Roosevelt of New York today to explain how he would aid the "little man."

A man, a woman, a boy and a girl were burned to death early this morning in a fire that routed sixteen families from their beds in an oldstyle apartment building at 1,630 Bathgate Avenue, the Bronx, and sent them to the front and rear fire escapes, where they huddled together screaming, waiting for firemen to come and help them to the ground.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Means for strengthening the position of the United States in international financing and in foreign trade were considered simultaneously this afternoon at two separate meetings of government officials at the State Department.

The Terminal Railroad Association of St. Louis reported a net loss of $189,031 for 1931, against a net income of $14,621, or 44 cents a share, for 1930. Gross revenue was $7,767,451, against $10,140,836.
DETROIT, April 15 (AP) -- Earl Whitehill held the Cleveland Indians to three hits today, but it was a close squeeze for the Detroit Tigers to win the last of a three-game series, 3 to 2.
NEW YORK. Gordon Selfridge and his daughter, the Vicomtesse de Sibour, are arriving next week on the Majestic and will be at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Two American photographers, both of the first rank and yet differing in every characteristic save radical integrity, are now holding one-man shows in New York. Paul Strand, Alfred Stieglitz's most talented pupil, is exhibiting at An American Place and Man Ray, the necromancer among contemporary camera workers, holds the stage at Julien Levy's.

The pictorial version of Ivor Novello's comedy, "The Truth Game," is the chief diversion at the Capitol. It is quite an amusing sketch, which might have been even more effective if some of the incidents had a semblance of plausibility. But often Robert Montgomerry as Max Clement behaves very much like William Haines did in "Brown of Harvard."

Probably many young people today have never laid eyes on a chaperon and scarcely know what the word means. The passing of the chaperon is due largely, of course, to the hard-won but now matter-of-course independence of modern young women.

Columbia's freshman crew went through, its final workout yesterday on the Harlem River in preparation for the meeting with the Kent School eight at Kent, Conn., today. It will be the freshmen's first race of the season.

Edward Kossove, formerly general manager of the Cornel Drug Store Corporation, which went into the hands of a receiver in March, 1930, testified yesterday for the State at the General Sessions trial of Nicholas C. Partos, president and organizer of the durg store chain and other corporations, and Ellis A. Laskey, accountant for Partos, on an indictment charging the theft of $612 from a woman investor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Aggressive Armaments" pointed to the crucial issue before the Disarmament Conference and hinted at the only solution which the present state of public opinion in all the nations is likely to accept.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Receivers were appointed today for the Middle West Utilities Company and several of its subsidiaries. It was the first step in remodeling the vast financial structure built by Samuel Insull on a basis of public utility concerns.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 15 (AP) -- While State officials continued their investigation tonight on the theory that a bomb caused the explosion yesterday in the new State office building in which eight men were killed, scores injured and $1,000,000 damage done to the $6,000,000 structure, experts said that a preliminary investigation did not show that high explosives were used.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 15 -- Speakers on Philippine independence at the final meeting of the Institute on United States Colonies and Dependencies, held here today in connection with the School of Citizenship at Syracuse University, favored freedom for the islands in line with the definite action begun by Congress

The annual appeal of the Catholic Charities begins tomorrow and the word "courage" leads the way. If a thing is easy to do, no courage is required. The thing is admittedly even more difficult than last year, as the challenging conditions of last year were more difficult than those of any preceding year.

ALBANY, April 15 -- Preliminary hearings before the legislative committee investigating possible economies in the State departments came to a close today, after six more department heads appeared before that body. Eleven appeared before the committee at the opening session yesterday.

In a highly laudatory letter to Jerome D. Travers, former amateur star, who on Thursday announced his intention of becoming a "business man golfer," Stacey Bender, president of the Metropolitan Golf Association, yesterday took occasion to point a way out for golfers who may come under the future surveillance of the new standing and conduct committee of that organization.

BERLIN, April 15. -- German imports in March tumbled to the average monthly level for the year 1880, causing the surplus of exports to rise to nearly double the February surplus. Exports decreased only slightly, but normally exports would have increased considerably and imports remained unchanged at this season.

The adjusted Index of carded cotton cloth production shows a further decrease to 87.8 for the "week ended April 9 from 88.7 for the preceding week and 88.9 for the corresponding week last year. Persistent lack of demand for cotton goods has led to the announcement of additional curtailment of printcloth output, and it is expected that similar plans in respect to sheeting output will be formulated shortly.

In the treatment of mental, psychic and nervous disorders psychoanalysis alone cannot give the physician a complete account of the conditions causing the disturbances, it was said last night by Professor Adolf Meyer noted psychiatrist of Johns Hopkins University, in a lecture at the New York Academy of Medicine.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Reduction of security transactions on the New York Stock Exchange to the "vanishing point" if the quarter of 1 per cent stock transfer tax becomes law as part of the billion-dollar revenue bill, was predicted today before the Senate Finance Committee by Richard Whitney, president of the Exchange.

Mr. CURRY and his company put through a smooth performance at Albany. He modestly symbolized his position as leading man by making himself such in the list of delegates at large. If Governor SMITH comes second, that proximity in space betokens no corresponding nearness to Mr. CURRY'S business and bosom.
GENEVA, April 15 -- Secretary Stimson's arrival in Geneva tomorrow for a stay of two or three weeks is giving rise to great curiosity and interest.

COLONEL JACOB RUPPERT, a big-time diamond capitalist who has gone in for the back-to-the-land movement in baseball, went out to view what he hopes will be his model farm in Newark a few days ago. It was the formal opening of the Spring sowing season on the Ruppert acres in New Jersey.
AUCKLAND, April 15 (AP) -- "If this goes on I shall read the riot act," the Mayor of Auckland declared tonight after new clashes between the unemployed and the forces of law and order.

Letters from President Hoover, Governor Roosevelt, Mayor Walker, former Governor Alfred E. Smith, George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, and William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, commending the celebration of Parents' Day on May 8 have been received by Uncle Robert, under whose direction exercises will be held on the Mall in Central Park, and were made public yesterday by him.

Price trend in commodities was irregularly lower yesterday, some of the gain of recent days in the grains and cotton neing canceled. Coffee, sugar, hides and silk also declined. Spot rubber established a new low for the year at 2.95 cents. Provisions and metals were steady.

The first report of the Northeastern Public Service Company, organized on July 1, 1931, as an indirect subsidiary of the National Electric Power Company as the result of the reorganization of Atlantic Public Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries, excluding railway, bus and ice properties and the Union Waterworks Company, shows $34,261,997 total assets on Dec. 31, 1931.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- With domestic exports valued at $2,377,981,786 in 1931, the United States continued to lead all other exporting nations, and New York retained its position as the country's principal exporting State with shipments worth $426,230,960, compared with $695,800,402 in 1930, according to a compilation made public today by the Department of Commerce.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 15 -- Performing brilliantly in both his first and second heats, High Island Treve, Belton blue English setter, owned by Fred Ewing of Greenwich, Conn., today captured the junior all-age derby, the featured event of the first day of the three-day trials of the Orange County Field Trial Club.

Harlem is just discovering the depression and the Negroes are trying to "sing themselves out of the trouble, just as they always do," Julia Mood Peterkin, whose novel, "Scarlet Sister Mary," won the Pulitzer Prize in 1928, and whose newest book, "Bright Skin," has just been published, said yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, April 15 (AP) -- Pola Negri, Polish screen and stage actress, will marry "a wealthy Chicago man" in July or August.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Conflicting influences -- dust storms in Western Kansas and Nebraska and Southern Saskatchewan and the official forecast for probable showers over a good part of the Winter wheat belt -- resulted today in a highly nervous market for wheat on the Board of Trade.
NEWARK, N.J., April 15 -- The Newark Bears, after winning the first two games of the season, lost to the Toronto Leafs today, 8 to 1.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment is the best way to solve the national prohibition problem. Senator Wagner of New York declared today at a hearing on the liquor laws before a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Cardinal Hayes, Mayor Walker, Fire Commissioner John J. Dorman, Fire Chief John J. McElligott, Judge Alfred J. Talley and the Rev. Patrick F. O'Connor will be the speakers at the annual communion breakfast of the Holy Name Society of the city Fire Department to be held tomorrow morning at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, April 15 -- Sir Herbert Samuel, the Home Secretary, told Parliament today the serious increase in crime in Great Britain since the war was causing great concern. Speaking on the work of his department, he pointed out burglaries and breaking and entering offenses had risen from 3,000 in 1913 to 8,000 last year in the London area, the latter figure being 2,300 more than in 1930 and 3,400 more than in 1929.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15. -- William A. Gray, an attorney, who represented Governor Pinchot as special counsel before the Legislature's Public Utilities Investigating Committee last year, has been invited to conduct the Senate investigation into the New York Stock Exchange and short selling, it was reported here tonight.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 15. -- Ellsworth Vines of Pasadena, Cal., national champion, and Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, member of the national doubles championship team, will meet tomorrow in the final of the men's singles in the fourteenth annual North and South tennis championship.

Industrial activity has been holding its own, if not improving slightly, and orders continue to come in, from the retailer to the wholesaler and from the wholesaler to the manufacturer, on a hand-to-mouth basis, according to the weekly reviews of trade and business.

LONDON, April 15. -- The stock markets were quiet, although firm today, after "Walter Runciman's trade survey, while there was a better feeling concerning Germany's position as a result of President Hindenburg's coerce dissolving Hitler's "Brown Army."

To the Editor of The New York Times: George Foster Peabody, in a letter to the editor of THE TIMES, defends the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The excuse for the creation of the corporation is that it saves the business of the country by keeping the banks liquid.
BERKELEY, Cal., Apr. 15 (AP). -- Ben Eastman of quarter and half mile fame, and Bob Kiesel, sophomore sprint ace, will feature a track meet tomorrow between Stanford and the University of California.

The "Penny Game Rooms,' set up in vacant stores on the east side as recreation places for children, have established their value as factors in solving the juvenile delinquency problem, it was reported yesterday at a meeting of the Lower East Side Community Council at 632 East Fifth Street.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- Carey Selph's hard drive down the leftfield foul line with the bases full in the thirteenth inning gave the Chicago White Sox a 4-to-3 victory over the St. Louis Browns today and three victories in the four-game series.

A strike of longshoremen was called yesterday morning on the piers of three coastwise steamship lines when wage reductions of 8 and 10 cents an hour on regular and overtime employment respectively were made effective. Through the intervention of the International Longshoremen's Association most of the strikers were unionized immediately and announced their determination to remain away from the piers until the companies agreed to renew the old wage scale.

Lily Pons, Bemamino Gigli and Ezio Pinza took their season's leave of Metropolitan subscribers at the opera last evening in Bellini's "La Sonnambula." The Misses Doninelli and Bourskaya and Messrs d'Angelo and paltrinieri were in the cast, and Mr. Serafin conducted the melodious classic.

The 1932 graduating class of 390 young men from the technical school conducted by the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen at 20 West Forty-fourth Street received diplomas last night at Town Hall. Magnus W. Alexander, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, made an address on the "competitive economic mechanism under which our nation has reached its high state of develpment."

The annual Rainbow Ball for the benefit of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children will take place tonight in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Many dinners will precede the event which is being given this year with a view toward reopening Highfields, the convalescent home for crippled children which the association has maintained for several years at Long Ridge, Conn.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 15 -- Eldon Trimingham, Bermuda yachts man, who won two previous races in the competition, finished in last place today with his Viking in the fourth and final contest of the international six-meter series but captured the event and the Prince of Wales Cup.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Miss Julia Clifford Lathrop, first head of the Federal Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor and internationally known for her child-welfare work, died tonight at the Rockford Hospital, in Rockford, Ill., after an operation.

BERLIN, April 15 (AP). -- Adolf Hitler embarked today upon his program to fight the dissolution of his huge army of storm troops by announcing that he would retain the best lawyers he could find to contest the legality of the emergency decree that dissolved them.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A warning to radio advertisers that government regulation of the radio industry would result unless there are changes in present programs was voiced by Representative Davis of Tennessee today before the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

ALBANY, April 15 -- Control of the Democratic State organization today passed quietly into the hands of John F. Curry and a group of up-State leaders, friendly to Tammany Hall, at a history-making meeting of the State committee this afternoon.

Peggy Fears, who produced "Child of Manhattan," will leave for California in a week or so, according to announcement. There she will confer with John Colton regarding his play, "Saint Wench," which Miss Fears contemplates producing early next season. She will be accompanied on the journey by Helen Menken, who will have the leading role.

Hamilton Institute defeated James Monroe High, 3 to 0, on Monroe Field yesterday. All the Hamilton runs were made in the second inning. A double by McKeever and a triple by Byrnes were mainly responsible for the three tallies.

Mayor Walker issued an appeal yesterday to the city's business, financial and professional leaders to join him in launching what he hopes will he a nation-wide demonstration to bring about amendment of the Volstead act to make beer available as a source of tax revenue.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- Robert Darnall, former University of Michigan star, tonight shattered his own Pennsylvania State senior 50-yard free-style swimming record in retaining the title in the Penn A.C. tank. Darnall beat Bill Stinson, captain of the University of Pennsylvania team the past season, by six inches, in 0:24 4-10.

BERRYVILL.E, Va., April 15 (AP). -- Former Governor Byrd said in a formal statement tonight that approval of his prohibition referendum platt "by the extreme dry leaders as well as, the extreme wet leaders" indicated to him that an "amendment to make possible a legal vote can be adopted quickly."

Arthur J. McClure of 784 Park Avenue, a lawyer with offices at 32 Broadway, died early yesterday morning in Bellevue Hospital as the result of injuries suffered in a fall from his seat in a taxicab while on his way home from the Racquet and Tennis Club, Fifty-second Street and Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Against the advice of Eugene Meyer, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, a House banking and currency subcommittee tonight decided to report favorably, probably tomorrow, a bill which would direct the Reserve Board to take steps to raise commodity prices to a predetermined level and keep them there.
Before 8 o'clock yesterday morning along the Saddle River above Hohokus hundreds of anglers were ready to greet the opening of another trout season in New Jersey.

The quarter century history of the Free Synagogue, including its record of constructive social service, was discussed yesterday by Dr. Stephen S. Wise, its founder and rabbi, in connection with its twenty-fifth anniversary celebration at Carnegie Hall tomorrow morning.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 15. -- When the Western Electric Company recently moved to purchase the Gray Telephone Pay Station Company, whose patents give it a virtual worldwide monopoly of automatic telephone stations, the Gray Company, according to a long letter issued today by its chairman, Alfred Spencer Jr., stopped negotiations almost before they were begun, explaining the company was not for sale in any circumstances.

GENEVA, April 15 -- Two hours after Secretary of State Stimson enters Geneva tomorrow the Far Eastern war will return, to the stage here in circumstances delicate enough to require his immediate attention. Upon the attitude he takes will depend largely whether Japan will then bow to or be bowed to by the League of Nations in a matter of some importance.

The Federal Government does not intend to borrow more new money after July 1 and will not bring out long-term bonds, but will stick to the short-term market, Alien M. Pope, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America and executive vice president of the First National Old Colony Corporation, told members of the New York group of the association at a luncheon yesterday in the Bankers Club.

RICHMOND, Va., April 15. -- Bishop James Cannon Jr., dry leader, declared before the convention of the Virginia Anti-Saloon League this afternoon that he was in "substantial agreement" with the scheme advocated by former Governor Byrd to provide for a national referendum on prohibition.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- National planning has been shown by successive events of the last three years to be an urgent necessity, speakers agreed at the opening session here today of the American Academy of Political and Social Science.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 15. -- The Princeton varsity crew, with the same boating which has been used for the past three weeks, took a very light workout of scarcely four miles today as final preparation for its opening race of the season tomorrow against the Navy.
MARDAN, India, April 15 -- All roads leading to the Peshawar and Charsadda districts were blockaded by troops from noon today. Pickets placed bridges across the Kabul and Swat Rivers.

The Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the thirteen months ended on Jan. 31 a net loss of $22,010,172 after taxes, interest, depreciation, depletion and other charges. This contrasted with a net profit of $12,026,424 in 1930 after deduction of a $7,607,695 reserve for the decline in investments in other companies and inventory adjustments of $2,579,883.
CLEVELAND, April 15 -- Charting business sentiment is the latest statistical achievement of Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company.

Two policemen were injured and three women and five men were arrested yesterday in one of two riots in front of Home Relief Bureaus established by the city. The police who dealt with the rioters attributed the trouble to Communists.

AUCKLAND. N.Z., April 15. -- For the second night in succession residents of this important dominion port spent a night of terror while a mob of unemployed indulged in an orgy of window-smashing, looting and battling with the police.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 15. -- Everett G. Livesay, southpaw veteran from Columbus, Ohio, today won the Mason and Dixon golf tournament by defeating John E. Hines of Garden City, L.I., 6 and 4, in the thirty-six-hole final round.
R. Dana Skinner, formerly chief economist with Young Ottlay, has joined the executive staff of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- President Hoover submitted to the House Economy Committee tonight a 31-page draft of proposed legislation to reduce Federal expenditures by $200,000,000.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 15 (AP) -- Friends of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Brodsky said tonight their 9-year-old daughter, Hilda, was kidnapped on her way to school today and is probably being held for ransom.

A reorganization plan for the Tubize Chatillon Corporation, which would simplify the capital structure and clear up hack dividends on the Series A preferred stock, will be voted on by the stockholders at a special meeting on May 16, it was announced yesterday.

Charges of a nation-wide conspiracy to fasten a "racket" on every large city and counter-charges of "malicious propaganda" and attempts to disrupt the union were exchanged yesterday as Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler reserved decision on the motion of fifteen dissenting members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, for an audit of the books of the local and an examination before trial of Howell H. Broach, international president, and officers of the local.

George Puccinelli drove in five runs with two home runs over the left field fence to lead the Rochester Red Wings to their second straight victory over Jersey City, 12 to 7, at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday.

With a bright prospect for sunny weather and with six well-filled races, the Metropolitan Jockey Club will open the local racing season at Jamaica today. The $5,000 added Paumonok Handicap, the day's feature, seldom has seen named a field of higher class since the four top weights, among others, have accepted the imposts assigned, thus indicating a contest which should make for a brilliant inaugural.

The Metropolitan Opera Association, which announced three weeks ago that it had lost more than $500,000 during the twenty-four-week season which ends tonight, and that another season was doubtful, announced last night that there would be another season, reduced to sixteen weeks, at prices reduced approximately to those of ten year ago.

The battle between Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt and former Governor Alfred E. Smith for the Democratic nomination for President, which has grown in bitterness since Mr. Smith's veiled criticism of his opponent in his Jefferson Day speech at Washington, has shifted to Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, each of which States will have a primary election on April 26.

PARIS, April 15. -- Trading was quiet on the Bourse today, but the tone was firm. Interest centred on Wall Street and the progress of the Vnited States anti-deflation policy. The dollar remained weak and failed to rise above the gold transfer point. Sterling dropped to 95.37 1/2.
BALTIMORE, April 15 (AP) -- Fourteen hits, five of which were home runs, enabled the Buffalo Bisons to march to their second straight victory over the Orioles today. The score was 8 to 4.

The War-Against-Depression Campaign, which has undertaken to find 1,000,000 jobs for wage-earners, announced that 510,673 jobs had been found up to noon yesterday. The day's total was 6,573 jobs in seventy-four communities in twenty-seven States.

A wreath was placed at the base of the Titanic Tower on the Seamen's Church Institute at 25 South Street and a vested choir of twelve seamen sang yesterday noon at memorial services on the twentieth anniversary of the sinking of the White Star liner Titanic with a loss of 1,517 lives.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor announces that the index number of wholesale prices for the week ending April 9 stands at 65.7, as compared with 65.9 for the week ending April 2.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 15. -- Underselling claims and misleading advertising and, in the field of legislation, the proposed sales tax, price-fixing control and copyright-design laws menace business today, Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of the Namm Store in Brooklyn, told the personnel division of the Providence Retail Trade Board tonight at the Narragansett Hotel here.

Pinnell Heads Color Group. Charles Pinnell of Fred Butterfield Co. was elected president of the Textile Color Card Association at the seventeenth annual meeting of the organization here yesterday. Formation of a committee to cooperate with the New England Manufacturing Jewelers and Silversmiths' Association for the selection and coordination of jewelry and costume colors was announced in the report of Margaret Hayden Rorke, managing director.

A sweeping advance, which embraced virtually every section of the bond market on the Stock Exchange, lifted prices 1 to 6 points for a long list of issues. In many instances losses of the last few days were wiped out. This was particularly true of domestic corporation issues, notably the rails.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Improved morale among business men was reported to President Hoover today by E.C. Sams of New York, president of the J.G. Penney Company, Inc.

ST. LOUIS, April 15 (AP) -- Although they outhit the Pirates, the St. Louis Cardinals used five pitchers in a futile effort to stop the Pittsburgh Pirates today, dropping the final game of the series, 9 to 7.

John H. Curtis, the Norfolk boat builder who has had four conferences with Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh since leaving his home last Sunday, returned to Norfolk yesterday with the "information" and "belief" that the aviator's kidnapped baby son is safe.

HONOLULU, April 15 -- Because of the illness of Clarence Darrow, chief counsel for the defense, the Fortescue-Massie trial was adjourned until tomorrow. Mr. Darrow ate something which disagreed with him and was unable to appear in court today.

The advance in gasoline prices which began in the Middle West earlier in the week swung into the East yesterday as several of the major companies announced increases in the tank car, tank wagon and service station prices. Companies which made announcements were the Standard Oil Company of New York, Standard Oil of New Jersey, Richfield Oil, Warner-Quinlan and Atlantic Refining.

A Federal investigation of so-called gift enterprise promoters, who are said to have offered 50,000,000 tickets for sale at 50 cents each as a charity proposition, through the membership of four national fraternal orders, and to have received more than two-thirds of the proceeds, has been begun by George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney.

In the historic armory of the old Seventh Regiment, now known officially as the 107th Regiment Infantry, N.Y.N.G., at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, a Spring military ball was given last night under the auspices of the Field Music Association of the regiment.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- President Hoover is convinced that the economic situation in the nation is improving.

Twenty-one members of the Structural Iron Workers' Union of Jersey, City, Local 45, were charged with murder in an indictment returned yesterday by the Hudson County grand jury as the result of the fatal beating of W. Thomas Harrison, a non-union worker, on Feb. 27.

BALTIMORE, April 15 (AP) -- Baltimore County officers tonight received orders from the County Commissioners to permit no bookmakers to operate tomorrow at the twenty-fourth running of My Lady's Manor, first of the three major events of the Maryland cross-country racing season.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., April 15. -- The Hill school opened its Spring track season today by defeating the Temple University freshmen, 83 2-3 to 42 1-3. Captain Keller of Hill won two firsts and a third for a total of eleven points.

After advancing to the highest levels of the month and nearly a half-cent above the low point reached a week ago, prices on the Cotton Exchange reacted in the last hour yesterday and closed with a loss of 8 to 11 points.

In President BUTLER'S speech, before the Economic Club of Chicago yesterday one finds another exposure of the folly of our protective tariff. This is the more remarkable coming from a Republican who has accepted, until now, the protectionist doctrines of his party.

Resuming hostilities with the Phillies after the two-day respite that followed their misadventures on opening day, the Giants appeared to be moving handsomely toward ample revenge at the Polo Grounds yesterday when one well-directed shot upset everything, including the finest of calculations by John McGraw.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has been stated in some of the newspaper accounts of the tragic death of the late John A. Mobley of Houston, Texas, that he either fell or jumned from the window of his room at the Pennsylvania Hotel in the early morning hours of Wednesday, April 13.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A bill for uniform pensions for dependents of veterans of all wars will be pressed in the House, Chairman Gasque of the Pensions Committee said today in announcing that he had asked the Rules Committee for a special rule to expedite the measure.

Taking with them documents representing months of investigation into the activities of Mayor Walker and his close political associates, Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, and three of his assistants left New York yesterday for a week-end conference at Mr. Seabury's home at East Hampton, L.I.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The best way to obtain recognition on the Senate floor is to "get up and start talking," Senator Copeland announced today during debate. He was surprised to learn that he had lost the floor, and so advised Vice President Curtis.

Caustic comments on the activities of the executive officers of the Bank of United States, coupled with official warnings that unless drastic changes in policy were followed the bank might crash, were furnished to Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, by his examiners three months before the bank was closed, it was shown yesterday at Mr. Broderick's trial by Max D. Steuer, special prosecutor.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 15. -- A "Red Army" of 25,000 was being organized today to fight for Premier J. T. Lang of New South Wales if necessary, presumably in his struggle against the Commonwealth over the State taxes and finance.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 15 -- Tommy Hayes, gunman, and two of his bodyguards, "Willie G." Wilbert and "Pretty Boy" Lechler, were killed about 1 o'clock this morning' by machine gunners, who pursued their two automobiles and ran them down separately near Granite City and in Madison, Ill.

An indictment charging he extorted $400 from an officer of a realty corporation in 1928 was handed up by the grand jury yesterday against Martin Fullam, 36 years old, of 147 East Eighty-second Stret, an inspector in the Manhattan Bureau of Buildings.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Railroads of the country today joined in the fight against the Shipstead bill to authorize issuance of bonds up to $500,000,000 for completing river and harbor projects now or hereafter authorized.

STOCKHOLM, April 15. -- Three of Ivar Kreuger's associates -- Carl Lange, auditor, and Sven Huldt and Victor Holm, employed as inspectors -- were arrested here tonight on information given to the police by the committee investigating the affairs of the Kreuger Toll enterprises.

In the manner of Sherlock Holmes demonstrating his deductive method to Dr. Watson, Surrogate Wingate of Brooklyn determined the question yesterday as to which died first in the case of a husband and wife who were accidentally asphyxiated.

Although new State and municipal issues scheduled for award next week show a considerable increase over this week's calendar, the total is well under the weekly average for the year to date. Next week fifty-two issues aggregating $13,855,924 will be up for bids, compared with $5,906,685 this week and a weekly average of $21,035,722 since Jan. 1.

With two of the teams strengthened, the four entrants in the open championship will resume play tonight at Squadron A Armory in that section of the national indoor polo championships. Yale meets Los Nanduces and the Optimists play the Riding Club on this next to last evening of the title tournaments.

The threatening gestures by Yale's baseball team to snatch victory from Columbia yesterday at Baker Field finally materialized in the closing stages, and the Elis slipped through to a 2-1 verdict. One run in the eighth and another in the ninth gave the Blue its triumph, Joe Maine crossing the plate with the deciding tally.

ALBANY, April 15 (AP) -- A Canadian grain syndicate with resources said to aggregate $60,000,000 has signed a ten-year lease for a grain elevator to be built at the port of Albany. The Canadian interests were represented by A.R. Roberts of Toronto, who said that incorporation papers have been drawn for the Albany Elevator Company, which will be the syndicate's operating unit here.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 15 (AP). -- The creation of a "judicial council" to coordinate the work of New York State courts was advocated here today by Daniel J. Kenefick of Buffalo, former Supreme Court Justice and one of the speakers before Governor Roosevelt's commission on administration of justice.

GENEVA, April 15 -- The failure of the great powers to authorize through the League of Nations Council Tuesday the relief measures that its financial committee urged, bore the fruit today which the committee had predicted. Greece and Bulgaria decided themselves to take measures involving a much greater loss for their bond holders.

CADIZ, Ohio, April 15 (AP) -- Despite the presence of Ohio National Guardsmen, another life was lost today as disorders flared again in the Eastern Ohio bituminous coal field, scene of numerous strikes.

The reports of 150 Class I railroads and seventeen switching and terminal companies to the Interstate Commerce Commission show that while net operating income dropped sharply in the first two months of the year, the reduction in February alone was held to $5,700,000.

The trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday was slower than on the previous day, but prices continued to advance. There was a further improvement in Wall Street sentiment, indicating a better feeling all around. Fluctuations were comparatively narrow.

Felix Lacnenea-Heude, former assistant general manager of the French Line in the United States, will sail today on the motorship Lafayette for Havre on his way to Martinique to be general manager of the passenger service to the West Indies, Mexico and Central America.

SYRACUSE, April 15 -- The State Industrial Board conducted a hearing in the Department of Labor offices today on proposed amendments to the industrial code, imposing new requirements upon employers in the canning industry who want to work women more than the regulation ten hours a day during the rush season from June 25 to Aug. 5.

AUCKLAND, Saturday, April 16 (Canadian Press). -- The Mayor of this city issued an order today prohibiting all public meetings, in the face of threats by unemployed to hold an assembly oh Sunday and following two days of street rioting and looting.

Passing of a Famous Sleuth. One must go back to PINKERTON to find a figure comparable to WILLIAM J. BURNS. His reputation was made as a young man in the Secret Service by successful pursuit of counterfeiters -- perhaps the most astute of all criminals.

The shortest speech "AL" SMITH ever made was when the one-day's-rest-in-seven law was under debate in the New York State Legislature when he was in the Assembly. The canning interests did not want to be subjected to the rigors of that law. They pleaded the seasonal character of the industry, arguing that the farm women were accustomed to work overtime in the Summer months.

The canning interests did not want to be subjected to the rigors of that law. They pleaded the seasonal character of the industry, arguing that the farm women were accustomed to work overtime in the Summer months.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 15 (AP) -- A photograph of Pluto, the new "Planet X," which was taken in 1914 at Harvard, but remained unrecognized for nearly eighteen years, is reported in the bulletin of the Harvard Observatory.

With an entry of 256 players representing eight States and a number of foreign countries, the second annual amateur championship of the American Ping-Pong Association got under way last night in the ball room of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Mr. EUGENE MEYER'S testimony with regard to the results of the Reconstruction Finance undertaking was of a character to bring hope to discouraged souls. Not only did bank suspensions fall in March to a small total (apparently, less than in any month since 1930), but the credit resources of closed banks which reopened last month were actually greater than those of the banks that closed.

CINCINNATI, April 15 (AP) -- Wally Hilcher, Cincinnati recruit, received a chance as a starting pitcher for the Reds today and was pounded by the Chicago Cubs who won the series final, 8 to 2, to even the four-game engagement at two victories each.

The Columbus Railway, Power and Light Company, which purchased re-recently some public utilities contiguous to its properties in Southern Ohio, announced yesterday that it would soon offer $4,500,000 of ten-year 5 1/2 per cent secured convertible gold bonds through a syndicate headed by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation.

A book four feet high, with pages that spread six feet and that turn automatically, will be used to record facsimiles of the signatures of all residents of the city who aid its Washington Bicentennial Commission by paying $1 to sign the honor scroll, according to plans announced yesterday at a meeting of captains of the Manhattan Patriots' Roll-Call at the Commodore.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 15 -- The largest and most enthusiastic gathering of the week was in attendance tonight at the third evening session of the Atlantic City horse show, and the applause for the winners and for the contestants over the jumps was a positive indication that the show has taken a strong hold on this famous resort.

Spurred by the blunt warning of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, that it was growing weary of protecting "emergency" bus operation in Manhattan and Queens from the injunction obtained by a taxpayer nearly two years ago, the Board of Estimate was preparing yesterday to approve a form of bus contract for Queens not later than next Friday.

Shoved into the path of a local train coming into the northbound platform of the B.M.T. subway station at Fourteenth Street, Mrs. Regina Sussman, 33 years old, of 906 Avenue L. Brooklyn, was injured seriously about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
CHICAGO, April 15. -- Following is the tevt of the address delivered by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler tonight before the Economic Club of Chicago:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 15 (AP) -- Three men were arrested by the police today on charges connected with the investigation into the affairs of Ivar Kreuger, Swedish industrialist who killed himself March 12 in Paris.

On ADOLF HITLER'S part it is quick thinking to discover that HINDENBURG and BRUENING were acting under orders from Paris when they took steps to break up the Hitlerite storm battalions. Yet he has so persistently described the German President and Chancellor as tools of French Imperialism that the new charge will create no stir.

The St. Louis Southwestern Railway (Cotton Belt) today will notify holders of its $20,727,750 first and consolidated 4 per cent bonds of an offer to meet their maturity on June 1 with $500 cash and $500 principal amount of general and refunding 5 per cent Series A bonds.
TOKYO, Saturday, April 16 -- Korekiyo Takahashi, Minister of Finance, foreshadows a policy of currency inflation in a statement issued to Japanese newspapers, in which he says:

Although a nominal market prevailed, time money quotations dropped 1/2 of 1 per cent to 2@ 2 1/2. This is the second cut of 1/2 in as many days, and, while bank money was offered at 2 1/2. there were no bids and no trades. Stock Exchange call money continued at 2 1/2 per cent, street trades at 1 1/2@2 and Federal funds at 1/8. Acceptances and commercial paper markets were quiet and unchanged.

Harry C. Perry, chief clerk of the City Court, who recently explained that his bank deposits of more than $135,000 in six years were due chiefly to loans by friends and not to any improper activity, was charged in Supreme Court proceedings yesterday with having demanded $50 to file a judgment for which the legal fee was $3.

The budget total for 1933 may exceed the high mark of $631,000,000 set in the 1932 budget, unless the city adopts a more drastic economy and retrenchment policy than it has pursued to date. Controller Berry declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the senior officers and trustees of the savings banks of Manhattan and Brooklyn held in the Hotel Astor

While commending former Governor Smith for presenting the plan for a twenty-year postponement of foreign debt payments, Rafael Del Castillo Jr.. exporter and importer, of 16 Beaver Street, said yesterday that the plan outlined in Washington was similar in principle to a moratorium plan he had prepared and submitted to the White House and to numerous political and financial leaders last Fall.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 15 -- Mrs. W.H. Cotton gave a tea this afternoon at the Casino. Mrs. Daniel A. Freeman Jr., with Miss Margaret Banes, Mr. and Mrs. George N. Ostrander, Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Day and Colonel and Mrs. J. Wray Cleveland, and Mr. and Mrs. J.M. Rath, with Mr. and Mrs. C. F. Allstadt, were others in tea groups this afternoon, stopping at the Casino after a round of golf.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with much interest the article in the Sunday TIMES by Sir Thomas Beecham on radio music and orchestral broadcasting.

MOSCOW. BEFORE attempting to compare the current Five-Year Plan of the U.S.S.R. (which really is only a four-and-a-quarter-year plan, because it began in October, 1928, and is now scheduled to be "completed" at the end of 1932) with the new plan (Jan. 1, 1933-Dec. 31, 1937), it is necessary to make some explanations of the nature and purpose of the first plan, which do not seem to have been fully understood abroad.

SOUTHBORO, Mass., April 16. -- The Holy Cross freshman baseball team shut out St. Mark's, 9 to 0, today. Frank Britt led the offensive for the victors, getting four hits in four tries, including a home run and a triple. Sline allowed the losers only four hits.

DELVING into fantasies of the dream world, the many committees arranging the pageant "Adventure" for the Charity Carnival on May 3 in Madison Square Garden have evolved a series of spectacular episodes that are expected to eclipse in brilliance the pageants arranged in the past for the carnival's beneficiary, the Judson Health Centre.

EASTON, Pa., April 16. -- Lafayette handed the Yale baseball team its first defeat of the season today when Captain Bob Wilcox singled with Glenn on second and Socolow on first in the tenth inning to break up the game and give the Maroon a 5-to-4 victory.

TOKYO. TAKE a walk in Tokyo any Sunday morning and on every vacant lot you will find urchins playing a ball game of sorts. Cross Hibiya Park in front of the Imperial Hotel any noon and you will find it congested with business youths spending three-quarters of their lunch hour pitching and catching balls, which the police, in the interest of public safety, have ordained shall be technically soft.

THE kowtow has come back. Abolished in China when Henry Pu Yi, the Boy Emperor, was dethroned two decades ago, it was revived recently at the ceremony marking his installation as dictator of the new Manchurian State, Manchoukuo.

Governor Roosevelt is assured of at least thirty-nine out of New York State's ninety-four votes in the Democratic National Convention even in the face of opposition by Tammany, according to a check made yesterday by his supporters, following the election of the delegates at large by the State committee in Albany on Friday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The political stability of our country is astonishing when one considers the evidence of actual want and the prevailing discontent as shown by both the news and the correspondence columns of our newspapers, with their numerous panaceas for the cure of our social and industrial ills.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Devere Alien's letter to THE TIMES he infers that Representative Ross Collins of Mississippi "has probably been misled by those who have adduced data bearing on the use of toxic gases in the World War."
LOS ANGELES, April 14. -- Southern California is all excited over a proposition arbitrarily to conserve the State's oil output which comes to a vote at the May 3 election via the referendum route.

PARIS, April 15. -- Frenchmen who nowadays are pondering political matters have one puzzling subject for thought. Frankly put, the question is: Why is Premier Andre Tardieu, one of the most brilliant statesmen in the world today and one who is striving so energetically to better the present distressing state of affairs, failing so signally to get anywhere?

Information charging twenty-six physicians with violation of the terms of their medicinal whisky prescriptions were filed in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday. Two of the accused physicians are women. Two of the defendants are from Queens County, the others reside in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, April 14. -- What is left of self-respecting Republicanism is looking for strong leadership which can reorganize the party in Illinois. That is one of the consequences of last Tuesday's election, in which little more than one-third of the votes cast in the Republican primary were sufficient to nominate Len Small, former Governor and defeated candidate for renomination four years ago.

MOSCOW, March 30. -- A New England institution is taking root in Russian soil and Moscow housewives have found a new thing to stand in line for -- American-style baked beans. They are canned with pork and tomato sauce and have made their appearance within the past two weeks.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 16. (Canadian Press). -- Imports into Canada exceeded exports in March by $16,906,278, but a favorable trade balance of $8,584,784 was shown for the year ended on March 31, according to figures issued by the Department of National Revenue.

THE AMERICAN JITTERS: A YEAR OF THE SLUMP" is notable for two reasons: it contains a deal of excellent reporting, as Stanley Walker, a connoisseur of good news writing, has indicated, and it offers a graph upon which the intellectual pilgrimage of a social critic of real stubborn integrity may be traced through twelve months of heavy pressure.

WITH a festive series of divertissements progressing from dinner to a late supper dance, the annual Toc H entertainment aboard the liner Berengaria on the night of May 2, is being heralded as one of the outstanding fetes of the Spring season.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Simultaneously with the announcement by the Commerce Department today that exports in March had increased by $2,061,000 over the preceding month, officials considered the application of Section 338 of the tariff act to put an end to discrimination by foreign governments against American products.

ON with the prints of 1932! This season they make a wide appeal to the imagination. Some masquerade as woolens, as a result of the treatment of broken lines and designs made to imitate rough weaves. These lend themselves best to the type of dress, or ensemble, in which one is at the same time smart and inconspicuous.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 16. -- Yale's lacrosse team made a good start in its first intercollegiate contest of the season today, defeating University of Pennsylvania, 3 to 2, in a game marked by close defensive tactics on the part of both teams.

MR. WILLIAMS, who is the editor of The Commonweal, a well-known Catholic laymen's weekly, has written this book, as he says, "to prove that in spite of -- perhaps in a large measure because of -- the tremendous out- break of religious strife in the 1928 Presidential campaign o o o religious liberty is unimpaired in the United States and is developing toward the fullest possible expression achievable in an imperfect world."

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Vice President Curtis will be the honor guest and principal speaker at the opening session Monday night of the Forty-first Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution, and envoys of France, Germany, Poland, Great Britain and the Netherlands will take part.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. THE most "rumored" person in town at the moment is Greta Garbo. She will sign with M-G-M; she will not sign; she will go back to Sweden; she will go to another organization; all these and more, all with the explanation that they are "inside tips," float up and down the Boulevard.

Winning the New York State Rifle Association competition, final event of the championship series, at the Wingate Athletic Field range yesterday, Jamaica High School's marksmen captured the city P.S.A.L. Spring rifle-shooting title for the fourth year in succession.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., April 16. -- The program for discussion at the twelfth annual session of the Institute of Politics, which will open on July 28 and continue until Aug. 25, was made public today by Dr. Harry A. Garfield, president of Williams College and chairman of the institute.

PARIS. ONE has heard a great deal about a "new manner" of Francois Mauriac, and one has heard it ascribed to a spiritual change in the writer. It is no secret, since he has written about it himself, that M. Mauriac, who has always been tormented by religious problems, has for two years been a convert to the strictest form of Catholicism.
