BEEUX, March 17, 1932. IT would be interesting and instructive to know whatever persuaded the direction of the Staatsoper that Herbert Windt's two-act opera, "Andromache," could be a profitable investment from any point of view.

BOSTON, April 16. -- The Yankees' first formal operations of the year in Boston today tended to send the inhabitants fleeing in all directions. They overwhelmed the Red Sox, 14 to 4; slamming thirteen hits in the first four innings and climaxing their slugging with homers by Byrd and Ruth in the seventh.

The policy of controlled expansion of credit upon which the Federal Reserve System entered last week means that the provisions of the Glass-Steagall bill, permitting the Reserve Banks to back circulation by government securities, will be called into use in the near future.

HANKOW, March 20. -- Though Hankow has played the part of spectator in the Sino-Japanese conflict, it has been that of a spectator in an uneasy and uncomfortable seat. Anti-Japanese feeling here has been run- ning high, and the presence of the barricaded and wired Japanese Concession has kept alive the great danger of a repetition of the Shanghai clash.
HELSINGFORS, Finland, April 16. -- Finland's wet law continues to have the effect of reducing the arrests for drunkenness.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 16. -- Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, today won the men's singles in the fourteenth annual North and South tennis championships, defeating in the final Eilsworth Vines of Pasadena, Cal., national champion, in a fiveset contest, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 1.

WHAT has Japan achieved in Manchuria during the past seven months of fighting? Her objectives have been clear throughout; they are unaltered today. From the standpoint of actual accomplishment, she has succeeded in setting in motion agencies for the consolidation of her influence and for the recognition of specific rights written into treaties with China, but contested by China as invalid. Furthermore, she has strengthened her military position as against that of the Soviets.

IN the bloody and blood-curdling career of Jonquin Murrieta, who terrorized California in the years of 1850-1853. Walter Noble Burns, whose "Saga of Billy the Kid" attained widespread popularity a few years ago, has found a subject made to his hand.

HERR MAX SCHMELING is finally achieving complete recognition as world's heavyweight champion. He has been jeered in two towns on his exhibition tour. That's the last test, as Tunney, Dempsey and earlier champions could have told him.

Our tacit American assumption that college education is a kind of forcible feeding process, which the student necessarily resists with all his strength and his wits clangs out at last in inescapable and ironic undertone through reports of the workings of the new plan at the University of Chicago.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., April 16. -- Vice President Charles Curtis declared here tonight that there were signs indicating that economic conditions were changing for the better and that confidence was on the way.
PHILADELPHIA, April 16. -- Prince- ton's varsity golf team was defeated by Morion Cricket Club stars over a windswept course today, 11 to 7.

ALBANY, April 16. -- Twenty-four hours after the battle, fought here yesterday, which resulted in the elimination of Governor Roosevelt as a controlling factor in the affairs of his own party in this State, politicians at the Capitol still marveled at the ease with which the victory of John F. Curry, Tammany leader, was accomplished and pondered over the consequences from the overturn in leadership.

ROME, March 18, 1932. EARLY one afternoon a few days ago Arturo Toscanini was seen pacing restlessly back and forth before the Teatro Quirino in Rome. He had come to the city on a brief errand from the village near by where he is undergoing treatment for his arm, and had to return before nightfall.

EXCEPT that it is the land where Persian rugs (some of them) are made, that it was the home of Hafiz and Orriar, that its warlike rulers once overran Eastern Europe, and that there are valuable oil deposits in some parts, little else of Persia is known by the average person.

ARE the old political parties doomed? Can they hope to survive in the new era? Perhaps they can and will, but the breakdown of party discipline is one of the significant phenomena of these hectic days in the realm of government.

BEAR MOUNTAIN and West Point are favorite objectives for New York motorists at all times, but especially in the Spring. The terrain of Palisades Interstate Park, which includes Bear Mountain, is rugged and hilly, with occasional sparkling lakes, while the scenery along the Hudson River is truly magnificent, affording some of the finest views in the Eastern States.

A mystery arose yesterday in the case of the $305,105 jewel robbery at the home of Harry G. Glemby, 22 East Sixty-seventh Street, on Jan. 21, when it was revealed that the real identity of one of the five suspects now held was being hidden under the false name of "Helen Smith."

Jerry Rauschkolb, veteran right-hander, pitched City College to a 4-to-3 victory over Rutgers University yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium. It was C.C.N.Y.'s second victory of the season, and its first victory over the Scarlet in three years.

SHANGHAI, March 21. -- The widespread condemnation of the Kuomintang party, leading in some cases to actual violence, has caused the party pundits to awaken rudely from their feeling of security -- a false security based upon the fact that for several years they have successfully suppressed all other political parties in China.

Victories by the Abraham Lincoln, James Madison and Textile High teams, which enabled them to remain in a triple tie for first place, and the surprising triumph of Alexander Hamilton High's foilsmen over George Washington High, defending city P.S.A.L. fencing champion, featured the eighth series of matches in the title competition at the Washington Irving High School gymnasium yesterday.

One county oratorical champion, fourteen semi-finalists and seven junior high school borough champions were selected last week in the National Oratorical Contest which THE NEW YORK TIMES conducts in the metropolitan area.

BEFORE watches appeared on wrists and clocks were common place, long before radio flashes and copper wire bad been taught to ladle out split seconds for general consumption, each man reckoned his own time as best he could.

IT is always a pleasure to welcome additions to that long series of panels of thoughtful biographical and psychological exposition that is Gamaliel Bradford's peculiar gift to American letters. He has, by assiduous and impartial labor, carved for himself a unique and unchallenged niche in the curious edifice of our contemporary literature.

Lew M. Fields and others of his family have surrendered to Ernest Flagg of Dongan Hills. S.I., a lease of the two-story building at 620 West Forty-seventh Street, which was to expire on May 1, 1953, the tenants having defaulted in the $6,500 annual rental and in the payment of taxes and water rents.

ROLAND YOUNG, who also ap- pears in "This Is the Night," was born in London, the son of an architect. He showed an early aptitude for draftsmanship, and it was decided that he should follow in his father's career. But while his drawing abilities were incontestably good, his mathematical inclinations were negligible.
AUCKLAND. N.Z, April 16 (Canadian Press) . -- Auckland was like a besieged city tonight as a result of rioting by the unemployed during the last few days.
Thirty events, twenty-two of them one-day tournaments, are on the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association schedule for the coming season, according to the list of dates announced yesterday.

MADRID. THROUGHOUT four and a half centuries of exile from his adopted country the Spanish Jew has remained a figure in history. Now the news goes abroad that the Spanish Republic has proclaimed absolute liberty for the Jews to return to Spain, while in the Cortes orators have paid tribute to the memory and trials of the exiles.

The New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, has placed on exhibition 272 of its best portraits and beginning with those of the old Dutch families of New York has rearranged them in chronological order. Some of the earliest family portraits were painted in 1660.

ALBANY, April 16. -- Officials representing foreign governments, the United States, the State of New York and leading shipping and industrial interests will join in the dedication of the port of Albany -- the newest seaport in the world -- on June 6 and 7.

Preaching yesterday at Temple Emanu-El on the Sabbath before Passover, known in Jewish tradition as the Great Sabbath, Rabbi Samuel Schulman termed the day "the great judgment day of the values of our civilization," and declared it emphasized the ethical character of the Jewish religion.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 16. -- The Cornell chapter of Phi Beta Kappa chose fifty-one new members at the annual elections today. The list includes three graduate students, thirty-two seniors and sixteen juniors, as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Nobile Giacomo De Martino, Ambassador of Italy, entertained at dinner tonight in honor of the Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. Ogden L. Mills. His guests included Count Laszlo Szechenyi, the Minister of Hungary, the Minister of Greece and Mme.

VIENNA, April 14. -- The failure of the London Conference to take even a first step toward the realization of the Danubian plan and the postponement by the League Council until May of action on loans which Austria and Hungary urgently need to tide them over their immediate financial difficulties have forced these two countries to take immediate measures to help themselves.

New York Girl Scouts presented a "Bicentennial of Fashion" at the Washingtonia Educational Exhibit at the Arnold Constable store yesterday afternoon. They appeared in gowns of the Colonial period and dresses of the last two centuries, including those of 1812, 1840, 1860, the bicycle costume of 1895 and the attire of the present day.

Confined to his room as punishment for misbehavior at school, 10-year-old William Schneider, son of William R. Schneider, a commission merchant, who lives at 56 Waldorf Court in the Fiske Terrace section of Flatbush, Brooklyn, committed suicide yesterday morning by hanging himself from a hook on his door.

Conditions in New York today "are almost the same" as forty years ago when he was fighting vice and Tammany corruption, the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, described once by Joseph H. Choate as "the moral ruler of the town," said yesterday in a statement issued through the Society for the Prevention of Crime.

PARIS. WHILE this is being written (Tuesday evening, April 5) Paris is in the midst of a twenty-four-hour "strike" of all the amusement enterprises. For the first time in the decades since the motion pictures were in- vented there is not a film to be seen.

CADIZ, Ohio, April 16 (AP). -- More troops were sent tonight to the strifetorn Eastern Ohio mine field, where strike disorders during the week cost the lives of two men and resulted in injuries to many others.

THE broadcasters are glad that 1932 is a Presidential year. They have looked up the records at the Capitol which reveal both parties spent $1,078,685 for broadcasting during the 1928 campaign. Of this amount the Democrats spent $592,184 and the Republicans paid $486,501 for broadcast speeches by President Hoover and Republican orators.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- President Hoover explained in a statement issued today for the information of the public his plan for government economy as contained in his omnibus bill which was submitted to the House Economy Committee yesterday and was under consideration by that group today.

EARTHQUAKES and volcanic eruptions are evidences that the forces which began shaping the earth 3,000,000,000 years ago are still at work. For all the rigidity of what we call terra firma, mountains are still heaving, continents are still tilting, bedrock is still trembling, while beneath all the primal magma is still welling.

LIFE is all one column of figures after another in these days of government economy for Colonel James Clawson Hoop, Director of the Bureau of the Budget. And these columns of figures stretch from the Treasury Building to the White House, up to Capitol Hill and back again, as Uncle Sam is engaged in his annual circus act -- part acrobatics, part legerdemain and part juggling -- known as "balancing the budget."

JANE ADDAMS has named JULIA LATHROP as one of the "most useful women in the whole country." But the civilized world might have been included in the appraisement, for what Miss LATHROP has done for childhood and womanhood in America has had its influence in other lands and given her a place among the foremost women of her day on the earth.
WASHINGTON. FEAR that war might cut off the supply of parachute cloth has been eliminated with demonstrations at the Bureau of Standards that domestic cotton materials will equal silk in performance.

MELBOURNE, April 14. -- The Commonwealth of Australia is slowly but surely winning its campaign to compel Premier Lang to pay the debts of New South Wales. Mr. Lang continues to resist and will fight bitterly every inch of the way, but foreign observers should keep the dispute in proper perspective.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Arthur M. Hyde, Secretary of Agriculture, leading dry in President Hoover's Cabinet, said today that the right to vote on the Eighteenth Amendment should not be denied to the people.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- An appeal for rejection of the proposed consolidation of all railroad property in the East into four separate systems was made by the Railway Labor Executives' Association in a brief filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

VIENNA, April 3. -- The recent peasant rioting in Wolfsberg, Carinthia, when a mob of peasants attacked a police court with axes in an attempt to rescue men charged with participation in an anti-tax riot, has led to the revelation of the existence of a secret terrorist society of peasants called the Nachbar Notgemeinschaft (Comradeship of Neighbors in Need), Which it is said has spread throughout Carinthia.

Weighing in with eight errors, four of which sent three runs hurtling into the laps of the astonished Braves in the ninth inning, the Giants continued their amazing inverted pennant flight at the Polo Grounds yesterday by dropping the first game of a series with Bill McKechnie's men by a score of 5 to 4.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., April 16. -- Mayor Walker of New York was guest of honor tonight at a dinner dance held at Briarcliff Lodge. Members of the committee who welcomed the Mayor included:

THE accounts of the Scala Thea- tre in Milan will show a deficit of about $125,000 for the past season, according to reports in the London press. This is held to be due to the production at great expense of a large number of operas which in many cases were withdrawn after a few nights' run.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP). -- H. E. Terry, a veteran guide at the Capitol, has discovered that sightseers want to look at Senator Huey Long of Louisiana and Speaker Jack Garner of Texas.

This week's rowing regatta marks the first meeting between the oldest college navy and the newest. It Is a regatta to be held at Derby, Conn., on Yale's Housatonic course between Yale's navy and the crews of Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HUNTINGTON. L.I., April 16. -- Miss Blanche Elliott of the Whitcomb Gun Club carried off the high gun honors at the special women's invitation handicap trap-shooting tournament conducted by the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today.

Consider the eel -- if for no better reason than because Dr. EMMELINE MOORE, Investigator of Fish Culture for the Conservation Department of the State of New York, gave a talk over the radio recently on these most patriotic, self-sacrificing and altogether amazing creatures. Consider, if you will, a single specimen which has spent many happy years in the pond above the dam at old Bill Bascom's place.

HERE, undoubtedly, is satire attempted in the grand manner, a prose Dunciad inhabited by maliciously distorted caricatures and gargoyles, a personal attack by means of invective and ridicule of the kind which from Aristophanes to "Point Counter Point" has added spice to literature.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP). -- Lefty Grove's pitching and three home runs, hit by Cramer. Simmons and Cochrane, combined to give the Athletics a 1-to-2 victory over Washington today, the Senators sustaining their first defeat of the season.

SEVERAL card parties in aid of philanthropic enterprises will take place in the near future. Members of the Women's Auxiliary of the Polyclinic Hospital will hold their annual Spring card party on Tuesday afternoon on board the Augustus for the purpose of augmenting their funds in aid of needy patients. Tea will be served.

OTTAWA, April 16 (Canadian Press). -- Care of Canada's veterans of the great war costs the country about $55,000,000 annually, the Minister of Health, Dr. Murray MacLaren, stated today in forecasting an announcement in the House of Commons next week of legislation concerning the ex-service men.

ISTANBUL, April 15. -- As soon as the news reached Turkey that the great European powers were contemplating a Danubian Federation, immediately suspicion was aroused in governmental circles; for it was felt that the realization of such a federation would be the death-knell of the Balkan union for which Turkey had striven ever since it settled its differences with Greece.

MADRID, April 15.v -- Almost any one, on the face of it, would like to step into the shoes of a king, so perhaps it is permissible to draw a comparison between the king and the man who for just one year has been wearing his shoes. That the boots once belonged to the dashing A: so makes the comparison even more interesting.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16. -- Prohibition faces a crisis in the Pennsylvania primary of April 26, dry leaders are warning the church vote in this State. F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, has informed some of the usual contributors to the cause that the primary here "will have as great a part in the ultimate outcome of prohibition as any event since prohibition was enacted."

Deposits in the 146 savings banks in New York State gained $9,185,782 in March, but showed a net loss of $8,379,944 for the first quarter of this year, due to a decrease of approximately $19,000,000 in January, according to figures announced yesterday by the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York.

An improved cash position, scanty profits or deficits from merchandising and the acquisition through purchase of their own stocks in the open market proved outstanding features of statements by individual stores on their operations for 1931 which have recently made their appearance.

Into what recesses does not the intruding finger of "progress" poke? About two years ago, according to The Journal of the American Judicature Society, the bar began to be interested in that field delicately called "public relations." Hide-bound traditions keep the medical profession from "selling itself" to the public, but in a world of propaganda why should lawyers be shy to reveal their merits?

A conclusive victory was gained by swimmers of P.S. 82, Manhattan, at the annual elementery school championships of the Public School Athletic League, which drew a record number of 505 contenders to the 75-foot City College pool yesterday. The winners amassed a total of 25 points, while the team of P.S. 11, Manhattan, followed with 18 points.

SHANGHAI, March. 18. -- The League of Nations Commission, now investigating the connection between the recent battles here between Japan and China and the events of the last six months in Manchuria, is confronted with a perplexing set of facts and declarations.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Hailed as perhaps the most important banking legislation since the creation of the Federal Reserve System, the remodeled Glass banking bill was completed today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, which instructed Senator Glass to introduce the measure in the Senate on Monday with a favorable report.

Published yesterday on the eve of the annual Catholic charities drive throughout the Archdiocese of New York, which will begin today and end on April 25, the organization's annual report revealed that in the past year 309,413 persons were cared for and served by the organization and the 212 Catholic charitable agen- cies whose work it coordinates and supervises.

LONDON, March 27. SINCE it was first instituted, the office of Poet Laureate of England has been the occasion of much controversy and some- times of ridicule. Several attempts have been made to abolish it on the ground that it was itself anomalous or that there was none fitted to hold it, but the English love of tradition has somehow preserved it through the centuries.

MR. DENISON offers us an interpretation of American history in terms of winds, storms, currents and dynamos. Parallel with the material struggle for survival which bulks so large in all history there is, he reminds us a stupendous Battle of Ideas.

SHANGHAI, March 21. -- Difficulties of coping with bandits, Communists, bad transportation and grafting officials are not the only major problems of the administrators of the Flood Relief Commission, which despite war and turmoil has gone steadily ahead attempting to alleviate some of the distress in the Yangtse Valley.

DALLAS, April 14. -- Genuine alarm over the Red menace has gripped a number of good Texans and is making them demand a criminal syndicalism law such as California and a few other States have. The "menace" is a little slow in making itself felt.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 16. -- Penn State opened its baseball season today by defeating Swarthmore, 9 to 8.

Two New York City boys, Arthur Winmill and Tom Choate, likely will take care of the bulk of the catching assignments for the St. Mark's School nine this Spring. Both are among the leading members of the Southboro, Mass., school's baseball squad.

Registering its winning run in the tenth inning after two outs had been made, the Fordham University baseball nine scored its second triumph of the 1932 campaign by vanquishing the strong Manhattan College team, 5 to 4, at Fordham Field yesterday before a crowd of 3,000 spectators.

FROM the time, 1873, that Major Walter Wingfield in- vented the game of lawn tennis, upon which he be- stowed that curious, sesquipedalian Greek name of Sphairistike, so dear to the heart of Punch, millions have swung a racquet at an inflated ball without knowing whence came the name of the game, the method by which it is scored, exactly when it was introduced into America and numerous other pertinent points of unexplained origin.

A rare collection of paintings, tapestries and art objects from the collection of the Marchioness Curzon of Kedleston will be offered at auction next Friday evening at the American Art Association-Andersen Galleries, Inc. Lady Kedleston inherited many of the items from the celebrated collections of the late Baron Alfred de Rothschild at Halton and Seamore Place.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The Folger Shakespeare Library, erected by the late Henry Clay Folger, president of the Standard Oil Company of New York, and bequeathed by him in trust to the trustees of Amherst College, will be dedicated next Saturday, the birthday of Shakespeare.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 16. -- A plan which will at all times give "a job to every one who is willing and able to do decent work" is proposed in a pamphlet, entitled, "The Abolition of Unemployment," published here today by Frank D. Graham, Professor of Economics and Social Institutions at Princeton University and an authority on international trade and finance.
REPORTS from members of the radio audience indicate that they want to hear more of the Groldman Band concerts this Summer than they did last year.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 12. -- The forgotten tale of a youthful Bermudian shipmaster's heroic death, nearly a century ago, was recalled when workmen engaged in demolishing an old house found a marble memorial tablet which for years had been dong duty as a hearthstone in front of an open fireplace.

Development of uses for by-products of the food industry's new quick-freezing process, is the next problem to be tackled by research engineers in the grocery field, Clarence Birdseye, inventor of the quick-freezing process which bears his name and director of research for Frosted Foods, Inc., subsidiary of the General Foods Corporation, told THE TIMES yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 16. -- State police today ordered a search for Hilda Brodsky, 8-year-old daughter of a reputedly well-to-do dry goods and notions wholesaler, who disappeared under mysterious circumstances yesterday morning while on her way to school.

HONOLULU, April 16. -- The shot which rocked the Territorial Government and focused the eyes of the nation on Hawaii was fired by the pistol in the hand of Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, submarine officer of the United States Navy.
WASHINGTON, April 16. -- As usual in recent weeks, no marked change was shown in general business conditions in most American markets reviewed in the weekly survey of the Department of Commerce.
The management of the twenty-three-story Dixie Hotel, in West Forty-third Street, has been taken over by the Southworth Management Corporation, of which Roy S. Hubbell is president.

DETROIT. ABNORMAL conditions produce abnormal effects. That is the only explanation motor manufacturers have to offer for the present situation with respect to motor car prices. None questions that the price situation in the industry is abnormal.
EXETER, N.H., April 16. -- In its opening game today Exeter defeated Huntington School, 18 to 6. In the second inning Exeter scored ten runs.

TOKYO, April 16. -- A Japanese Na- tional Socialist party was formed last night along the lines of the Nazi organization in Germany through the secession from the Social Democratic party of its secretary, Katsumaro Akamatsu, and 45 per cent of its executive committee.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 16. -- With eight groups participating, six of them contestants, the annual theatre tournament of the Westchester Drama Association will be presented on Wednesday, Thursday and Saturday evenings at the Westchester County Centre here.

THE Independents of America still function as a Spring tonic for a public that above all else enjoys enjoying itself. They may take themselves seriously, but only very seldom are they solemn about being serious; in consequence the exhibition rooms heretofore have furnished a welcome antidote to the poisonous depression of the outer world.

THIS is an interesting novel, and naturally so, for Ilia Ehrenbourg, its author, is an undeniably talented and sometimes even brilliant writer. But his literary talent is uneven and unstable. He has tried all imaginable forms, from journalism and essays to poetry (in which latter he proved to be undeniably gifted).
WITHIN the last generation, however, certain new weapons have been developed to a point where frontier defenses no longer constitute an adequate safeguard against invasion.

BERLIN, April 15. -- Hitlerism, which dominates the political scene in Germany, has by its own fanaticism aroused such an intensity of feeling that it is rarely that one comes upon a serious attempt at dispassionate appraisal.

Henry E. Schnackenberg, a life member and former vice president and instructor of the Art Students' League, who will oppose John Sloan for the presidency of that organize- tion at a special election in the league gallery next Wednesday eve- ning.

TINY radio waves are entrancing ethereal explorers, from Marconi to the amateur ex- perimenter. These waves that measure only a few feet in length are called ultra-short or micro-rays. Some refer to them as being quasi-optical because, in general, they act like light rays.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16. -- If this nation is to rid itself of "a creeping paralysis" alike of government and business, American history of the next quarter of a century must reverse two outstanding principles which have dominated politics and economics of the last twenty-five years, Dr. Glenn Frank, president of the University of Wisconsin, asserted in an address tonight at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science.

MEMPHIS, April 14. -- In spite of the campaigns, proclamations, legislation and threats urging and demanding reduced cotton acreage. Spring in the mid-South finds the cotton farmers plowing and planting with prospects of almost as big a crop as the disastrous bumper yield of last year.

Business men confronted with shrinking markets can work out their own salvation without help from the government, according to Henry Ward Beer, former trial counsel for the Federal Trade Commission and active opponent of proposals for liberalizing present anti-trust statutes.

TODAY. 10:30 A.M. -- Patrick Cardinal Hayes and Mayor Walker head the speakers' list at the communion breakfast of the Fire Department to be broadcast from the Hotel Astor by WOR. This hour-and-a-half pre gram also brings to the microphone Fire Commissioner John J. Dorman, Fire Chief John J. McElligott former Justice Alfred Talley and the Rev. Patrick J. Connor.

When our Secretary of State goes to the headquarters of the League of Nations less than two months before the Republican National Convention and then and there unisolates himself for a month to discuss with the statesmen of other countries world problems in which the United States has a common in- , terest, he must get credit for bravery.

RICHMOND, April 14. -- A lively and at times acrimonious controversy has arisen over a remark made by an Englishwoman in an address to a literary club near London, and the newspapers, particularly those in Richmond, are being flooded with indignant communications.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 16. -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club lacrosse team triumphed over the New York Lacrosse Club, 10 to 0, on the victor's field today. The winners displayed a powerful attack and fast passing combined with excellent stick work enabled them to pain a commanding advantage early in the encounter.

IT is a matter of record that an interviewer once asked Sir Arthur Sullivan, the composer, whether the words or the music of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas came first. Sir Arthur turned on him sharply and snapped:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 16. -- Several surprises were scored in the annual Harvard Spring handicap track meet in the Harvard Stadium today. Outstanding in the upsets was the defeat of Captain Eugene E. Record in the 120-yard high hurdle and 220-yard low hurdle races by John Grady, a junior, who ran from scratch.

TORONTO, Ont., April 16. -- The Ontario Department of Mines reports that the gold mines of the Province in March gained in quantity of ore milled, compared with the total in February, but were slightly below the figures for January. The value of the gold recovered was considerably in excess of either of the first two months of the year.
AFTER half a century of oblivion, Mascagni's two-act operatic idyl "Pinotta" was finally given its premiere at the San Remo Theatre in San Remo, Italy, last month.

VICKI BAUM, who has seen her ''Grand Hotel" trans- formed from novel to play and from play to a motion picture, expressed great elation yes- terday when commenting upon the production. In her suite on the twenty-fourth floor of the St. Moritz, overlooking Central Park, her rooms filled with roses, Miss Baum dis- cussed stories, pictures and Holly- wood.

Behind the survey of world conditions from the pen of Sir AUSTEN CHAMBERLAIN, which THE TIMES publishes today, stands the authority of an experienced statesman. When he speaks with gratification and almost amazement of the great and successful effort which the British have made to set their public finances in order, it is from the standpoint of a man who has himself twice been Chancellor of the Exchequer.

BOSTON, April 14. -- Vermont is in the midst of a "beautility" campaign. The term may not be new, but it is novel in the Green Mountain State, It stands for the combination of beauty and utility in the interest of the general welfare. Its promoters believe in the utility of beauty.

BALTIMORE, April 16. -- Benjamin Leslie Behr of Chicago gained a second leg on the Harford Hunt Challenge Cup as his aged chestnut gelding. Brose Hover, romped home ahead of a field of eight other horses to win the twenty-fourth running of My Lady's Manor point-to-point to- day.

THOSE creatures of Vicki Baum's fecund imagination -- Grusinskaya, the alluring danc- er; Baron Von Gaigern, the handsome and immaculately clad thief; Preysing, the hard-fisted, sensual textile manufacturer; Flaemmchen, the coquettish stenographer; Otto Kringelein, the obsequious bookkeeper, who has been told that he has one foot in the grave, and others -- have been brought vividly to life again at the Astor in the film version of "Grand Hotel."

LOS ANGELES, Cal., April 16. -- W. K. Kellogg, cereal manufacturer and sportsman, has offered to the State of California his ninety-eight pure-bred Arabian horses, the 800acre ranch near Ponoma where they are kept and an endowment of $600,000 to propagate their strain.

PARIS, April 9, 1932. FOLLOWING Jacques Rouche's In recent resignation from his post as general director of the Paris Opera and the threat of the closing of France's first lyrical stage, the French Government has granted an additional subsidy of 3,000,000 francs to the Opera.

LODON. SOMEBODY has been complaining about Cleopatra's Needle again. It is a sister of the Egyptian obelisk in Central Park, New York, but it has had a far more adventurous career than New York's obelisk has had.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Approval of a three-year loan of $10,996,331 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad Company was sought in an application filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

THIS country today is sick and tired of listening to political campaign orators who tell us what is the matter with us. Few, if any, of them know what the cure is. Of recent months I have heard no cure advanced, but I have heard the old complaint explained all over again with a few trimmings here, and there.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 16. -- Holding the ball in its opponent's territory most of the time, the Rutgers lacrosse team trounced Lehigh, 25 to 0 on Neilson Field today. Frenchy Julien lead the Scarlet scorers with seven goals, while Latimer was second with five.
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The United States cannot pay the soldiers' bonus in full without grave consequences. A few years ago it might have been done, but conditions have changed.

THE notion of making old-fashioned gardens is strong in the hearts of George Washington's countrymen in this bicentennial year. It is a pretty notion. It appeals to patriotic sentiment. It attracts those who find charm in the antique and the quaint.

BERKELEY, Cal., April 16. -- Stanford won its ninth successive annual track victory over California today, but the final score was overshadowed by brilliant sprint performances by Bob Kiesel and an "iron man" feat by Ben Eastman.

The breakdown of modern home life has thrown greater responsibilities upon the junior high schools in training the adolescent child than ever before. Dr. Benjamin Veit, district superintendent in charge of junior high schools, said yesterday at the second annual city-wide conference of the Junior High School Principals' Association at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. The conference, dedicated "in the service of youth," was attended by more than 2,000 educators.

THAT too many cooks spoil the broth has been disproved by the highly specialized kitchen organization of the modern American hotel. Hotel cookery is as old as the culinary art in Europe but service to 5,000 persons a day from one kitchen gives "the back of the house" an entirely new aspect, and the chef an entourage of a hundred or more persons.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 16. -- With the budget and other essential legislation still pending, the Porto Rican Legislature continued in session today with the clock stopped since before last midnight, when the session was to have ended.

OMAHA, April 14. -- There is not much zest to the opening of Spring work on the farm. In whatever direction he turns the farmer can see nothing much but a season of hard labor with pretty slim pickings at the end. He isn't disposed to find much cheer even in a stronger wheat market due to reports of Winter damage.

WITH the completion recently of one of the most beautiful lighthouses on American shores -- that which marks the entrance to San Francisco's municipal yacht harbor -- a striking example of Old World design has been made to serve today's needs.

Price trend in commodity markets was lower yesterday. Although the losses were not great they were sufficiently spread throughout the list to have created a heavy market at the week-end. Losses were reported in the grains, cotton, hides, coffee and cocoa, while silk, and sugar were firm. Rubber also showed improvement.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 16. -- A sensational upset marked the final session of the Atlantic City horse show tonight when a new queen was crowned in the five-gaited saddle horse grouping and a famous favorite dethroned in the upheaval.

Waldo H. Heinrichs, American war ace, has just been appointed general secretary of the Jerusalem Young Men's Christian Association and will sail Tuesday on the Excalibur to take charge of the $1,000,000 plant nearing completion and which will be dedicated in the Fall.

POSTMASTER GENERAL WALTER F. BROWN stated recently before the House Postoffice Committee that he was in favor of an air mail monopoly. The result, he said, would be more efficient service and less cost to the government.

HERE are something less than forty of Mr. Chesterton's little pieces, assembled under a title that betokens his infinite variety and recalls even his physical presence, hale and burly as that of the Miller of Dee; and, in the best sense, he has a golden thumb and loves to wiggle it in the face of the world.

THE teakettle at the Art Students' League bubbles just so long and then the lid blows off. This time the row is over the mordant German satirist, George Grosz. John Sloan, who has been president of the Art Students' League for about a year and a half, wanted to sign up Grosz as a member of the faculty.

PERHAPS some sort of parable might be made on the subject of the Christschall label, now that the records bearing it, after establishing a very favorable reputation for themselves abroad, seem to be making very definite headway in this country.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., April 16. -- The Hill School baseball team defeated the Girard College nine today, 15 -- 6. The game was called at the end of the seventh inning.

The Way Out. A book heartily to be recommended is Phineas Z. Slingsby's "What Next and How Soon?" We can recall among recent publications no bolder attempt to face the grave problems which beset the world today. From the long list of world crises discussed in this inspired book we may quote three or four leading items.

Butter. Receipts, 7,432 packages. The market cleared very closely Friday afternoon. Buyers were on hand early Saturday morning looking for fresh supplies. There was quite a keen shortage and prices were bid up 1/2c on nearly all grades. Most of the wholesale business in extras was at 20c with a car of 90 score selling at 19c, and other grades ranged down about as quoted.
Opportune hitting by Columbia's baseball team gave the Blue and White a 4-3 victory over Harvard yesterday at Baker Field in a contest that saw Ray White and Charley Devens in a pitchers' duel.

WASHINGTON, Pa., April 16. -- William Wolff Smith, general counsel of the Veterans' Bureau, today collapsed under the sharp cross examination of the House Military Affairs Committee after definitely stating that so long as he remains with the government he would return his army retirement pay to the treasury.

STOCKHOLM, April 16 (AP). -- The experts examining the books of Ivar Kreuger said today that only he knew the truth concerning the origin of the forged Italian bonds, which were printed in English and ostensibly signed by the Italian Monopolies Board.
DETROIT, April 16 (AP). -- The Tigers pulled an extra-inning game out of the fire today by scoring two runs in the twelfth to defeat the Browns, 3 to 2.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 16. -- Princeton got away to a good start in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League today by winning from Dartmouth, 12 to 9. Cold weather interfered with the fielding and pitching on both teams, Miller and Bowman, the starting moundsmen, failing midway in the battle.

Doubt that the proposal of former Governor Alfred E. Smith for the cancellation of foreign governmental debts up to the amount of 25 per cent of the value of the purchase of American products by each country would appeal to the general public was expressed yesterday by General John F. O'Ryan.

Government extravagance in the nation, States and municipalities and excessive taxation in the past ten years were assailed by Colonel Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, in a radio address broadcast from Chicago last night.

MACBETH GALLERY -- "Forty Years of American Art," an exhibition arranged to celebrate the fortieth anniversary of this gallery, which was opened in April, 1892, by William Macbeth. While it would be manifestly impossible fully to illustrate so long and vital a span with the aid of but thirty-five canvases, the examples shown have been admirably selected.

WHENEVER dramatic critics are under fire, as they have been frequently this season, the assumption is that in some inscrutable fashion they should be business agents of the theatre. Sometimes they are abused for their artistic myopia.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- "Let's have no more dinners; they are more dangerous than conventions," said a Southern Senator the day after the Democratic National Committee dinner here this week in honor of the birthday of Thomas Jefferson.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 16. -- Stonedale, M. McGiffin's chestnut gelding, which won the Piedmont cup at Llangollen last Fall, was ridden to victory by J.R. Ryan to capture the Midleburg cup in the twelfth annual running of the race on the estate of D.C. Hands, near Middleburg, today.
MOSCOW, April 15. -- What the world wants to know about the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics is, What is the five-year plan really doing? Not programs, not statistics or estimates, but facts.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 16. -- Peggy Tudor, a black-and-white setter, triumphed in the annual all-age stake of the Orange County Field Trial Club today, putting forth one of the most remarkable performances that any field trial dog has shown in the East this year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Rev. R.H. White suggests that the abolition of the liquor trades in England would provide ample funds with which to pay the interest on the debt of Great Britian to the United States.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 16. -- Equipoise, brilliant C.W. Whitney 4-year-old, today showed 20,000 opening-day racing fans here that his return to form at Bowie was not merely temporary as he ran off with the $10,000 added Harford Handicap in easy fashion.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra, in association with the League of Composers, will present at the Metropolitan Opera House Wednesday evening Arnold Schon- berg's choral work, "Gurre-Lieder,' conducted by Leopold Stokowski. The presentation concludes the New York series of ten concerts given by the Philadelphia Orchestra.

A statistical analysis of American divorce made by Dr. ALFRED CAHEN suggests that the break-down of the American family is not measured by the 200,000 divorces granted and the 500,000 men, women and children directly affected. Desertion rivals divorce in frequency.

Airplanes have been used to sow grain, but an equally novel use recently was made of them when a consignment of tennis balls was dropped from the air, thus saving a tennis tournament from coming to a premature end. Play had been under way for some time at the River Oaks Club in Texas when the supply was found to be short.

THE next fortnight will bring many notable weddings, among them one abroad that is of great interest here, that of Lady Eileen Forbes to the Earl of Dumfries on the morning of April 26 in Clonguish Parish Church, Newtown Forbes, Irish Free State.

THOUGH a step or two north of Columbus Circle, and therefore outside the province of what is left of the New York theatre, the good cities of Montreal, Toronto, Hamilton and Change-atCalgary-for-Vancouver have indulged this season in a practically feverish supply of dramatic works.
GENEVA, April 15. -- There are few more lovely or interesting homes anywhere than the Chateau de Bessinge which Secretary Stimson is occupying during his stay here.

Four midtown civic associations joined yesterday in the protest movement against parades on Fifth Avenue. The movement was started some time ago by the Fifth Avenue Association, on the ground that they were detrimental to business.
WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Owen D. Young has declared his opposition to immediate payment of the veterans' bonus through inflation of the currency, sending a telegram to Representative Patman of Texas.

A stock and production control board, or chart, which is particularly adaptable for use by smaller manufacturing plants and which in actual practice has proved successful, was described yesterday by E. Bartlett Headden, service manager and head of the planning department of the Motor Improvements Company, manufacturers of the Purolator oil filter.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 16. -- The Army nine buried Bucknell under a 19-to-2 score for its third straight victory today. The Cadets unlimbered a heavy attack, punishing three of the college hurlers and piling up sixteen safe drives.

The distribution of circulars and entry blanks for the 1932 Bermuda ocean race provided the outstanding development of the week in yachting circles. These circulars, giving final conditions for the event, one of the most important off-shore races of the Summer, had been awaited with some impatience, their appearance having been delayed unusually long this year.

MOSCOW, April 16. -- The harshest tone yet taken hare toward Japan's Manchurian adventure characterizes the leading editorial today in the newspaper Pravda under the headline, "Warning to Provocateurs."

DECORATORS as well as connoisseurs will be interested in the new Italian Hall at the Brooklyn Museum, which has just been rearranged and formally opened. While the rooms have been on view for some time, the complete installation of furniture, tapestries, ceramics and paintings has only recently been made.

IF what this town has been waiting for is an idea of the plot of "Caviar and Wine," which is hardly credible, what with the new baseball season and everything. The Evening Transcript of Boston obliged on Wednesday afternoon in some detail, as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- A new and determined effort to exclude all tariffs from the tax bill will be made by Senator Hull of Tennessee when the Senate Finance Committee begins executive sessions next week to pass upon the various proposals in the House measure.

It seems essential that in the remaking of our civilization our young people be inspired and led by teachers who themselves are characterized by freedom in thought and activity with respect to their social and economic responsibilities; teachers who refuse to be deprived of their political rights; teachers who are further characterized by sound scholarship and ability to express themselves in a creative fashion, either artistically or socially.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Records of short sale operations, compiled by the New York Stock Exchange from reports filed by something like 2,500 brokers, were received late today at the office of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

Germany is determined to pay her debts, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, former president of the Reichsbank, said last night in an address from Berlin, heard in the United States over a National Broadcasting Company network.

JERUSALEM, April 15. -- This coming week in Palestine will be one of merry-making and at the same time a cause for great anxiety. The most important Moslem feast of the year, Kurban Bairam, begins tomorrow and lasts four days; and it is to be followed by the traditional Palestinian Moslem holiday of Nebi Musa.
Nearly 300 members of the fresh men and sophomore classes of Bar nard College took part yesterday afternoon in the twenty-ninth annual Greek Games pageant in the college gymnasium.

IT is not only the Actor's Fund that is the beneficiary of the "Theatre in Art" exhibition, now on view at the Sidney Ross Gallery; for, although the pecuniary profits are "earmarked" for this worthy cause, there are other profits of immeasurable value accruing from it to the cause of the dance.

THERE was a certain moment when by virtue of budgetary circumstances, of military circumstances and of technical circumstances -- there was a moment when there did not exist a single big battleship, not a single submarine, not a single military airplane, when there was no heavy artillery.

CHICAGO, April 16. -- Senator Lester J. Dickinson of Iowa, a stanch supporter of the Hoover Administration and a dry, was chosen today to be the keynoter and temporary chairman of the Republican National Convention, which meets in Chicago in June.

MOSCOW, March 30. -- There is a rising tide of Americans streaming into Moscow with the idea of living and working in Russia for a time, either for the adventure of it or because of a lacic of jobs at home. Sometimes they get jobs here and sometimes they don't, but in any case they form a difficult problem for the government, whose policy is now one of non-encouragement to this sort of thing.

An evening of "new music" given recently in Berlin presented for the first time works by younger members of the Schonberg-Pfitzner-Schreker schools. Gerhard Frommel's three songs were described as turning wistfully back to Schumann for their inspiration; Hermann Ambrosius's piano-pieces to Heller.

A NEW story of actual experiences in the Arctic, told by a resident of long standing, is announced for publication early in May by the Macmillan Company. The title of the book is "Thirty Years in the Golden North," and the author is Jan Welzl, a Czech by birth and a locksmith by trade, who decided to seek his fortune in the Far North.

OTTAWA, April 14. -- With resignation not unmixed with relief that it is no worse, Canadians have accepted the new budget, which is to take an extra $55,000,000 from them in Federal taxation and thus increase by some 16 per cent their obligations to the Dominion Treasury.
KNOEDLER GALLERIES -- Exhibition of military and naval portraits, opening tomorrow and reviewed in the news columns today. "Achille de Gas," by Degas, is reproduced on this page.

GERMANY, in proposing to inttiate a vast plan of public works to provide jobs for the unemployed, looks to a program adopted by a number of other nations. France and Italy are already spending large sums in building roads and for other improvements.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is an interesting fact that original titles to Union Pacific Railroad and other lands in Kansas were granted by the government in many cases, over the signature of A. Lincoin, with the stipulation that should any mineral values be discovered on these lands such values would revert to the government.

Fluctuations in the indices making up THE NEW YORK TIMES Weekly Business Index have narrowed further, but the main tendency is still toward lower levels. The preliminary combined index for the week ended April 9 is 59.9, as against 60.2 for the preceding week, all of the components except the adjusted index of steel mill activity having registered slight decreases.

The heavy demand for United States Government bonds last week, which resulted in the largest turnover in the group on the Stock Exchange in eight years, enabled all the active issues to enter new high ground for the year. Sales for the week reached $26,707,900, an amount which was last exceeded by $34,464,230 for the week ended on June 14, 1924.

The New York University freshman, baseball team beat James Madison High yesterday on the Madison diamond, 3 to 0. Held scoreless for three innings, the Violet yearlings tallied in the fourth when Kaufman singled, advanced on Marmelo's sacrifice and registered on Nelkin's single.

THE flood of volumes on Russia of last year is equaled this year by a similar deluge of books on Germany. Just as the observations on Russia represented primarily the reactions of each author to the Soviet problem, so the literature on Germany represents the reactions of each author to the problem of Germany in Europe -- or, more concretely expressed, to the problem of relations between Germany and France.

In spite of a two-day rally or Thursday and Friday, prices of commodifies on the local Exchanges failed to wipe out in all lines the earlier losses for the week. Sugar, Santos coffee, rubber and silver closed with grains, while cocoa, Rio coffee, hides and wool tops closed with losses.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., April 14. -- Oklahoma's sulphurous Governor, Alfalfa Bill Murray, returned home last week long enough to remove the Republican member of the State Highway Commission, Lew Wentz, but the bare announcement does not tell the half of it.

SOMETHING of an aura of mystery has ever clung about those two words, "poetry" and "poet." Poetry has seemed to be something apart from all other exercises of the mind, and loftier; to have in it ingredients that are not of this world; the poet has appeared to be one walking different roads than his fellows, the while communing with presences not within their ken.

PRAGUE, April 3. -- A delegation of the International Workers Help has today put before the Minister of Justice a report on the conditions which it has observed in the Czechoslovak province of Ruthenia, which is described as passing through a period of more terrible starvation than has been experienced by either India or China.

ROBERT YOUNG and Maureen O'Sullivan have been added to the cast of "Strange Interlude" at the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studios. Norma Shearer and Clark Gable head the cast of this picturization of the Eugene O'Neill stage play, under the direction of Robert Z. Leonard.
THIRTEEN American elm trees, planted at points on Long Island visited by George Washington 142 years ago, will be dedicated to him during the coming week.

CHICAGO, April 15. ABRILLIANT spurt of dramatic activity will take place on the forlorn Rialto of this town next week. Walter Hampden will bring his revival of "Cyrano de Bergerac" to the Blackstone Theatre on Sunday night, and Katharine Cornell will establish her company in "The Barretts of Wimpole Street" at the Harris Theatre the following evening.
Signs of improvement in metropolitan realty conditions were noted last week and the announcement of some real building operations provided another element of encouragement.

Dress lines were especially active in the wholesale markets here this week, with cotton garments featured above all other types, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the Independent Merchandising Bureau, Inc. Demand for millinery was confined to straws with medium or brief brims.

IT is a commonplace that law does not keep pace with our changing morality, and the present is always readily shocked at conditions that obtained in the preceding generation. Take the question of authors' rights, which today have acquired a sanctity in the public eye that is matched almost completely by our laws.

BERLIN, April 16. -- Following the dissolution of Adolf Hitler's "Brown Army," President von Hindenburg in a letter today requested General Groener, Minister of Defense and the Interior, to investigate carefully whether other parties had organizations of a similar nature.

MAN stands on this microscopic earth, gazes up at the myriad stars and out upon the billowing oceans and the tossing trees -- gazes and wonders. For some thousands of years he has been wondering. A few hundred years ago he began tearing bits of the universe apart to see of what it is made and measuring its manifestations.

Lieutenants Paul D. Meyers and Lucian Tribus of the Aviation Division, New York National Guard, were flying over Miller Field about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon when they saw a man and two women clinging to an overturned canoe in the choppy waters of lower New York Bay, about a mile off the Staten Island shore.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra, conducted by Leopold Stokowski, will bring its present New York season to an end on Wednesday evening with the first performance here of Arnold Schonberg's "Gurre-Lieder." This work, one of Schbnberg's most significant compositions, was given its first American performances at the concerts of the Philadelphia Orchestra in Philadelphia on April 8, 9 and 10.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 16. -- Nine racing yachts, bound for Havana, sailed into the Gulf of Mexico late today before an increasing southeasterly breeze, after being almost becalmed during the first two hours of the third annual international race between St. Petersburg and the Cuban capital.

DETROIT, April 16. -- As a result of the city's financial condition the Detroit Institute of Art will close July 1 for the fiscal year 1932-1933, unless private funds are provided, it is announced by Clyde H. Burroughs, secretary of the art commission.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP). -- Allotment of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad to the New York Central System and the New Jersey Central to the Baltimore Ohio in any plan of railroad consolidation was urged today in a brief of the three trunk line railroads.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 16. -- Brown opened its home season today by defeating Boston University, 7 to 4. Weafer, Boston University's pitching ace, retired after six innings after Brown had touched him for nine hits and five runs. Bowie pitched great ball for Brown, allowing Boston University only five hits.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 13. -- Porto Rico Democrats will hold a convention on April 23 to elect delegates to the national convention at Chicago. An effort will be made to have the delegation instructed to cast the island's six votes for Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt.

APART from the native Indians the American people are altogether a composite of immigrants and of the descendants of immigrants. The story of our country from this angle is the story of three centuries of migration to our shores from almost every other part of the world.

From whatever point of view one may look at it, an event occurred in our public life last week which is truly extraordinary. A single utterance by a single man caught the attention of the whole nation and changed the entire current of political discussion. This came at a time when the theory was never so strong that the individual withers, while the race, or the mass, is more and more.

District Attorney Charles B. McLaughlin of the Bronx has ordered a grand jury investigation of the fire that occurred early yesterday morning in a tenement house at 1,630 Bathgate Avenue as two more children succumbed to burns in Morrisania Hospital, bringing the toll of victims to six dead and one injured.

BUDAPEST, March 21. THE second half of Budapest's current season has brought two great successes, which in turn have bestowed fresh laurels upon two Hungarian authors of distinguished accomplishment. They are, respectively, "The World Record," a three-act comedy by El- mer Boros, and "The Fire Bird," a crime play by Zilahy.

Domestic corporation bonds as a group extended their gains on the Stock Exchange in heavy trading, while United States Government and foreign loans closed irregular. Government issues were sharply higher for the week; the corporation issues, substantially so, and foreign loans, slightly easier on the average.

MOSCOW. AMERICAN motion pictures -- Amerikanski kartinyi -- are popular these days in Soviet Russia. They carry no "message," depict no social struggle, have no special propaganda. But the people in Russia do not nave the opportunity of seeing the latest American productions.

IT was a favorite charge against the Germans during the World War that they were fatally unable to understand the psychology of other peoples. That charge was certainly true in great measure and it was a considerable factor in Germany's final defeat.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 16. -- Harvard's varsity rugby team scored a surprising 15-to-3 victory over a hitherto undefeated Princeton team on Soldiers Field today. Princeton's Jayvees scored a 6-to-0 victory over the Harvard junior varsity in a pre- liminary contest.

KENT, Conn., April 16. -- The Kent School eight-oared crew won its second race of the season against collegians by defeating the Columbia freshmen today on the Housatonic by three-quarters of a length.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 16. -- Dr. Robert C. Clothier, who took office as president of Rutgers University on March 1, would be inaugurated at a formal ceremony on Saturday morning, June 11, the day of Rutgers' commencement, Dr. Carl R. Woodward, assistant to the president, announced today.

KINGSTON, R.I., April 16. -- Rhode Island State College opened its baseball season today by overwhelming Northeastern University, 16 to 5. Martynick, Rhode Island hurler, fanned eleven men and in addition knocked out a home run.

Followers of field trial sport are looking forward to the trials which will be held next Autumn by the Eastern Amateur Pointer and Setter Winners' Association. This organization, which was formed only last Winter, promises to become an active and important factor in the sport.

ELDORADO, Ark., April 16. -- Support of immediate bonus payments was promised today by Senator Hattie M. Caraway and Representatives Tilman B. Parks and Heartsill Ragon in messages from "Washington, to Ross V. Hall, contact officer of the local post of Veterans of Foreign Wars.

MATTHEW A. SENSON, the Negro who made eight trips into the Arctic with Robert E. Peary, and finally in 1909 stood on the top of the world, visited THE NEW YORK TIMES radio station a few days ago and reminisced as he inspected the short-wave equipment which picked up messages relayed from the Norge over the North Pole and Byrd in the south polar regions.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 16. -- Showing decided superiority in the field events, the University of North Carolina field and track team this afternoon defeated the midshipmen of the Naval Academy, 65 to 61.

QUESTIONS of real import to the the private flier as well as to the air transport operator were brought out at the meeting of the National Association of State Aircraft Officials, held in Detroit in connection with the National Aircraft Show.

While Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, was conferring at his home in East Hampton, L.I., yesterday with three members of his staff on the public examination of Mayor Walker other assistants in the committee headquarters in the State Building were going over Board of Education contracts for furniture awarded during the last four years.

PARIS. ONE of the best things about the new Paris fashions is their universal character. There are clothes to suit every purse and every figure. The flapper is no more favored than the matron; and women of 40, or over, can dare to be their age and still remain chic and attractive.

A BEAUTIFUL ship's model recently built for Sir James Marr of Sunderland, England, and lent to the Sunderland Museum, recalls a stirring epoch in the heroic days of sail, a day when England's white-winged clipper ships were to be found on every sea.

Charging the Federal Government with profiteering at the expense of World War veterans through loans on adjusted compensation certificates. Henry L. Stevens, commander of the American Legion, yesterday demanded immediate lowering of the interest rates on such loans and condemned as "outrageous" proposals to reduce veterans' hospital costs.

MR. WOODRUFF'S book on England, unlike his American jeu d'esprit ("Plato's American Republic") knows too much to be funny. The absurdities he sets out to play with are his own calamities. Socrates, urbane and smooth as ever in manner, loses a little of his detachment in his absorption with social and economic questions.

AS frost gives way to budding flowers and robins begin to sing again, many sedate business and professional men slyly perfect their plans to run away with circuses. As most of these truants take to clowning when the circus tenting season opens about May 1 and as, in circus vernacular, a "beginning" clown is invariably known as a "First-of-May," these clowning elders are "First-of-Mays" around the big-top.

ONCE more the "northwest passage," which for nearly 500 years held the attention of explorers. Those mariners sought the short way to India and the Far East by going north of the Arctic Circle, by cutting across the top of the world.

WARSAW, April 16. -- The suppression of Adolf Hitler's "army" in Danzig will be demanded by the Polish Government. Dr. Pappee, the Polish High Commissioner there, is coming to Warsaw to confer with the government regarding the steps to be taken in Danzig and Geneva in case the Danzig Senate should refuse to follow the example of the German Government.

HAVERFORD, Pa., April 16. -- While a biting wind swept the track, Lehigh defeated Haverford's track men by 71 to 55 today. Chandler, the visitors' captain, accounted for first place in the 440-yard and 220-yard events.

BARBIZON-PLAZA -- An Ameri- can Group presents the first one-man show of its highly gifted member, Anatol Shulkin, who deserves a place in the front rank of our contemporary painters. It is a pleasure here to record one of the outstanding "arrivals" of the season.

After being fairly steady in early trading yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined again and the list closed at the bottom, 5 to 8 points lower than on Friday. For a time, the improvement in outside markets caused short covering, but the action of both stocks and grains in the last hour brought cotton under more selling pressure, liquidation of the May position particularly and some hedging by spot houses supplying contracts.

An increase of more than 300 per cent in the license fees assessed against broadcasting stations for the use of copyrighted music is proposed by the American Society of Authors, Composers and Publishers, it was disclosed yesterday by E.C. Mills, general manager of the society.

LONDON. FOR the twelfth time Montagu Collet Norman has been elected governor of the Bank of England. His is a record of long and repeatedly renewed service in an exacting office, absolutely without precedent in the history at Threadneedle Street, where, for two centuries, the bank has stood as a fortress of finance.
MILTON, Mass., April 16. -- Harvard's freshman baseball team won its second straight game, blanking Milton Academy, 9 to 0, today.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- I wish to emphasize that the adjusted service certificates issued to veterans of the World War Represent the government's confession of a debt for services rendered: they are not "bonus" certificates.

The Appellate Division, in a three-to-two decision given out yesterday, ordered a trial on a question of whether the Borough President should be compelled to issue a curb-lowering permit for a driveway across the sidewalk to provide a parking space on vacant property at 15-19 West Forty-third Street.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1931 a profit of $3,848,827 after depreciation, taxes and other charges but before depletion and inventory and metal adjustments. A charge of $1,768,502 was made against the surplus account for inventory and metal adjustments, compared with a similar charge of $7,626,825 in the report for 1930.

Another Wet Vote. The article published in THE TIMES special feature section entitled "A Dry Indictment," by Mrs. Emily Post, should be read by every man in this country. Mrs. Post shows a spirit of courage and frankness which is the rarest thing in our country today, and it is a matter of satisfaction that somebody has come out with such a vigorous statement.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., April 16. -- Cornelia Otis Skinner, a member of the class of '22 at Bryn Mawr College, will portray Queen Elizabeth, the most important character in the long pageant that will open Bryn Mawr's May Day festivities on May 6-7, it was announced today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 16. -- The Army lacrosse team overpowered Dartmouth today 8 to 1. The Cadets were on top throughout and had it not been for the fine work of Shea in goal for the Green there might have been more Army tallies.

FOR those who have come to rely on the concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium as their chief musical fare in New York during the Summer the announcement that these concerts will be presented this year as usual will be decidedly comforting.

Plans for the "beer parade" suggested by Mayor Walker as a nation-wide demonstration on May 14 grained momentum yesterday as telegrams and letters began to pour into his office from prominent organizations and individuals who endorsed the idea and offered their help in making the demonstration impressive.
The City College junior varsity baseball team won its third victory in a row at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, defeating Textile High School, 1 -- 0, in a game limited to five innings by agreement.

The reproduction of Mount Vernon now being constructed in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, for the New York Bicentennial Commission will be fully completed, even to the broad lawn sloping from the portico down to the lake and the formal Colonial gardens in the rear, by April 26, two months to a day from the breaking of ground, officials in charge of the work said yesterday.

Restriction such as no other nation has ever placed on its merchant marine is favored by the two bills introduced by Senator Hiram Johnson and now in committee, according to William H. Chandler, traffic manager of the Merchants' Association of New York.

MILWAUKEE, April 14. -- Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, in a fine demonstration of strength, not only captured Wisconsin's twenty-six delegates to the Democratic National Convention, but put the La Follette crowd in a hole in the election April 5.
GENEVA, April 16. -- Secretary Stimson arrived here this morning and his coming is regarded as of the utmost importance for two reasons, if not for more.

After four years, which meant a great deal of time spent in mastering the fundamentals, Miss Dorothy Locke accounted for one of the outstanding performances in women's sports when she became the national foils champion in the tourney held during the past week.

The potential influence of fixed investment trusts in the affairs of large corporations was revealed in Washington last week when Distributors Group, Inc., one of the two largest sponsors of these trusts, made public its complete list of holdings for the first time.

LONDON, April 15. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, will present the annual budget to the House of Commons on Tuesday, and as this always dramatic hour of British politics approaches the hopes of the people that they are going to have the income tax rate reduced are rapidly diminishing.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., April 16. -- The Senior Promenade, most important class social function of the year at Vassar College, was held there tonight.

SEATTLE, April 16. -- Seeking to measure cosmic rays on Mount McKinley, Allen Carpe, E.P. Beckwith and Theodore Koven. New York engineers and mountain climbers, sailed today for Alaska. There they will occupy the most northerly high mountain stations in a world-wide survey of the cosmic rays conducted by Dr. A.H. Compton of the University of Chicago, and the Carnegie Institute of Washington.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, April 16 (Canadian Press). -- General Jan Smuts, Opposition leader in the South African House of Assembly, in a telephone conversation today with J. H. Thomas, Dominions Secretary in the British Cabinet, expressed the hope the moderation which has so...

The private hospitals of the city are cooperating admirably with public ones in taking care of the unusual demands for beds produced by the depression, Dr. J.G. William Greeff, Commissioner of the Department of Hospitals, said last night at the dinner at the Plaza, beginning the celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Hospital for Joint Diseases.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP). -- A favorable foreign trade balance for March of $25,000,000 was announced by the Commerce Department today.

The decline in the stock market that began on Feb. 19 and gathered momentum after March 8 was the ninth liquidating movement in the bear market which started in the Autumn of 1929. In previous depressions, there were from five to seven distinct selling movements in securi- ties.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended April 9 increased sharply over the preceding week, which included only five business days in some cities, but they were 7.8 per cent below the same week last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Although disappointed that the rally was so short-lived, Wall Street attached little importance to yesterday's slow decline on the Stock Exchange. The market opened slightly higher and acted as if the advance of Thursday and Friday was to be extended.

A UNIQUE and colorful entertainment has been planned for the annual Spring production of the Neighborhood Playhouse, which will he held on Friday night in the Della Robbia room of the Vanderbilt. The entertainment will comprise a varied program of Latin-American and Negro folk music and dancing, in conjunction with which there will be a dinner dance.

An alert Villanova baseball team took advantage of five New York University misplays and scored a 6-to-3 victory at Ohio Field yesterday. The errors helped Villanova score its first four runs, enough to win the game. A crowd of 1,500 saw the Violet go down to defeat for the first time in three starts this season.
MUSIC is not a real profession, Arthur Honegger, the com- poser, told a TIMES representa- tive in Paris.

The performance of "Tannhauser" yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House was given before one of the largest audiences of the season, a packed and attentive house that gave singer and conductor an ovation richly deserved.

The Tiffany Studios of 391 Madison Avenue, where for more than half a century, since their founding by Louis Comfort Tiffany, octogenarian artist and philanthropist, some of the outstanding stained glass work, memorials and ecclesiastical art work has been created, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 16. -- Indications that rain would develop in the West and Southwest over the Winter wheat belt, with scattered showers in Eastern Kansas and Nebraska, dominated the wheat market today on the Board of Trade here. Prices at no time rose above Friday's finish and with persistent selling by scattered longs, locals and commission houses, the market dropped about 1 1/2 cents from the previous close before aggressive support developed.

TWO pictures with out-of-the-way locations, one Greenland and the other the Malay Peninsula, will be made this year by Universal. The first of these, to be called tentatively "Iceberg," calls for a special expedition, to be headed by Dr. Arnold Fanck, explorer and motion picture director.

More people than usual are today interested in municipal economy. The depression, the drop in real estate values and conditions in the bond market have combined to make it a lively issue in hundreds of communities throughout the country. The National Municipal Review has just published a report of the effect of these factors on city budgets and municipal policies in twenty-five of the largest of these cities.

One of the season's records was broken twice and another tied at the eighth series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx swimming championship of the Public School Athletic League in the seventy-five-foot pool of George Washington High School yesterday.

DUBLIN, April 16. -- A sensation was caused in labor circles today by the publication of a circular by the W.R. Jacob Biscuit Manufacturing Company, the second largest individual employer of labor in Ireland, which amounted to a virtual ultimatum that, if the Free State seceded from the British Commonwealth of Nations, the firm would dispense with the services of 1,500, or half of its staff.

The centennial of the opening of Union Square will be celebrated next Saturday at 10 A.M. with the dedication of the new bandstand and a concert by the Department of Sanitation Band. It will be followed with singing by a massed chorus of 1,500 pupils of the Washington Irving High School.

Salt-water fishermen as well as trout anglers expect to complete one of the best of the early season weekends today. There were many who started from the city and suburban points for upper New York State streams, and Connecticut attracted many trout seekers to the Ten Mile River in New Haven County and to the Rippowan yesterday.

PREPARATION of America's huge fleet of motor vehicles for Spring will be influenced this year by the fact that the aggregate mileage registered on their odometers is higher than it would be under less stringent economic conditions.

To the Art Editor: WHAT I wonder is this: Is It possible in so big and ponderous a city to sweep formality aside (in this much talked about business of mural paintings for Rockefeller Centre) and be simple enough to achieve a certain life and gayety and humanity which might actually breathe the breath of life into that deadliest of things -- American mural painting?

GENEVA, April 16. -- The delicate diplomatic situation created here by the breakdown of the Shanghai armistice negotiations grew more delicate throughout today. The is- sues involved became sharper, but the outcome remained in doubt, with Japan stiffening, the League Waiting nervously and Secretary Stim son pondering.

CHICAGO, April 16 (AP). -- Negotiations for a wage contract, to supplant the one which expired March 31, were broken off today by the joint wage scale conference of Illinois union miners and coal operators. Neither group has planned another move in the settling of differences.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Vanity is one of the stumbling-blocks which bar the way to a return to better times. Above all other vanities is the vanity of the buyer. Cost signifies the value of everything added to the American home -- apparel, furniture, works of art-- for every housewife loves to outshine her neighbor and every successful business man loves to display his substance.

STEATFORD-ON-AVON. THERE have been three important events at Stratford-on-Avon.
