The first was the birth of William Shakespeare an April 23, 1564, the second was the opening of the Memorial Theatre exactly 315 years after that date and the third was the destruction of the theatre by fire on May 5, 1926.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 16. -- The Sand Hills Garden Club of Augusta entertained the visiting members of the Garden Club of America at high tea this afternoon at the club after their return from Aiken.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 16. -- The gold "R" for participation in non-athletic extra-curricular activities had been awarded to seventy- three Rutgers undergraduates, it was announced today by A. Paul Burton of Camden, chairman of the Association of Campus Activities.

PITTSBURGH, April 14. -- With the primaries less than two weeks away, Joseph F. Guffey, former Democratic National Committeeman and leader of the Roosevelt-for-President forces in this State, repeats with a greater show of confidence than ever his claim maintained for nearly a year that the New York Governor will win sixty-six of Pennsylvania's seventysix delegates to the national conven- tion.

Seven months ago the Japanese seized Mukden as the first step in a campaign designed to safeguard their interests in Manchuria. That objective is not yet attained. Tokyo has promised the League of Nations that it will withdraw its Manchurian forces to their original stations inside of the railroad zone as soon as circumstances will permit.

James Butler's Questionnaire, crack son of Sting, set a new weight-carrying record for the Paumonok Handicap when he won decisively under 130 pounds as the Metropolitan racing reason opened at Jamaica yesterday. Galloping strongly to the cheers of 10,000 persons.
CHICAGO, April 16 (AP). -- The Chicago White Sox today went into undisputed possession of first place in the American League as a result of their 5-to-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

Concurrently with the beginning of the operation of eighteen-hour trains between this city and Chicago by the New York Central and the Pennsylvania this Summer, the Chesapeake Ohio and the Baltimore Ohio Railroads will provide for the first time artificially cooled passenger trains between these points, it was disclosed in railroad circles yesterday.

Several hundred of the younger members of society thronged the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton last night at the Rainbow Ball, which was given for the benefit of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children. The ball, an event of the Spring for years, always enlists debutantes of the season and other young people who as members of committees are responsible for many of the features.

ANNAPOLIS. Md., April 16. -- Although confronted by a stubborn defense, the Navy lacrosse team defeated Western Maryland College today, 10 to 2. The first half saw the middies display their best offensive, when they scored six times.

COLBY, Kan., April 16 (AP). -- After confessing that he had kidnapped and killed Dorothy Hunter, 8-yearold Selden (Kan.) schoolgirl, Richard Read, 53 years old, was saved from mob vengeance today by Sheriff McGinley of Thomas County.

THE first festival of modern American chamber music at Yaddo, Saratoga Springs, N.Y., will bring together composers, crit- ics, music patrons, conductors and artists. Three concerts have been arranged, two for Saturday, April 30, and one for Sunday, May 1.

TWO models of the new DC Vaux 80, built by the Continental-De Vaux Company, were displayed recently at a private exhibit held at the Detroit plant of Continental Motors Corporation. The models were a convertible roadster and a custom sedan. The new cars have streamlined bodies and the six-cylinder "Red Seal" Continental-De Vaux engine, which is said to develop eighty horsepower and is cushioned in live rubber to eliminate vibration.

Dr. John F. Condon alone has been able to establish direct contact with the kidnappers of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's infant son, it was disclosed yesterday by Colonel Henry Breckinridge, the aviator's friend and legal adviser.

A BURGLAR who enters several houses and steals, with rare discrimination, the most valuable portable articles in them, and who subsequently restores his loot, placing each article in the exact spot from which it was taken, is something of a novelty.

PARIS, April 15. -- The art of Versailles has been brought to Paris for a special exposition which is proving quite a social affair at the Orangerie in the garden of the Tuileries. The showing is especially interesting to Americans.

ACCORDING to Mr. Barretto the chief trouble with many of the children of pleasure who contributed to the devastating nature of the 1929 crash was that they were only pleasure's adopted children. They had only recently become accustomed to her ways and had taken them up with the whole-hearted enthusiasm people are apt to devote to any novelty.

CHICAGO, April 16. -- The financial reverse that has overtaken Samuel Insull, who rose from a $1.25-a-week office boy in London to director of an American empire of electric power, was emphasized again today with the placing in receivership of his two big investment trusts, Insull Utility Investment, Inc., and the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago, by Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley in the United States District Court.

PARIS, April 16.-- Opening firm today, the Bourse lapsed into dullness and substantial losses were recorded. The arrest of three associates of the late Ivar Kreuger wase rise to numerous rumors which affected the market, already deprived of activity partly because of the closing of the London Stock Exchange for the day.

THE improved level of trade was fairly well maintained for the week. Woman's apparel and accessories attracted the best business. Men's wear lines were slow for the most part. Demand for home furnishings was confined to occasional pieces and to low-priced floor coverings.

THE third volume of the official history of the Royal Air Force during the World War continues in that fine tradition of clear thinking and bold interpretation that are the heritage of the genius of the late Sir Walter Raleigh, the editor of the first volume.

Two pamphlets, one on "Preparations for Marriage: a Bibliography" and the other on "Outlines of Marriage Instructions," have been issued for circulation among the clergy and laity, especially young people, of the Protestant Episcopal Church, it was revealed yesterday.

PROBABLY the most famous words ever spoken in Africa, certainly the most dramatic words, were the four the explorer Stanley uttered when he came face to face, at Ujiji, with the frail, worn man whom he had crossed oceans and jungles to seek at the anxious world's behest.

NOT so long ago the burning question of the hour was how to meet the inevitable social holocaust which would result from exposing young women to the dangers of higher education. By the turn of the century, however, it had been discovered that, in general, the study of the classics and advanced mathematics had not strained unduly the minds of the girls in college.

PROBABLY the most famous words ever spoken in Africa, certainly the most dramatic words, were the four the explorer Stanley uttered when he came face to face, at Ujiji, with the frail, worn man whom he had crossed oceans and jungles to seek at the anxious world's behest.

NOT so long ago the burning question of the hour was how to meet the inevitable social holocaust which would result from exposing young women to the dangers of higher education. By the turn of the century, however, it had been discovered that, in general, the study of the classics and advanced mathematics had not strained unduly the minds of the girls in college.

IT has always been a matter of curiosity, and frequently of annoyance, to me that so many of the strange and ancient rules, practical and abstract, which govern the profession of play-acting should have been able to survive into an otherwise fairly logical age.

YANKEETOWN, Fla., April 11. TOBY'S COMEDIANS, "not a word, not a gesture that can or will, offend any one," have recently concluded a one-week campaign of entertainment, education and elevation in this village of two hundred drama-lovers on the banks of the Withlacootchee River.

WAY for the circus! Spring comes, and the circus, new-born from Winter quarters, springs forth with all its perennial lure as fresh and strong and universal as that of the Spring itself. And so, too, come the books about it, almost as perennial as their theme.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 16 (AP). -- Up on Shooters Hill, where but for George Washington the National Capitol might be today, Masons of America will unite May 12 to dedicate a great temple of granite, their memorial to the first President and fellow-craftsman.

IN the announcement, carried several days ago by the daily papers, that London's Mr. Cochran would arrive in New York this week on a visit, there was, it turns out, more significance than appeared on the surface. It is a known fact that, for some time and through periods of good fortune and bad, Mr. Cochran has cherished a desire to produce shows on Broadway.
NEW YORK. The Marquise d'Amodio, her daughter, Mme. George Delattre, and Don Julio d'Amodio, now at the Pierre, will sail on the Majestic Friday and will go to their home in Paris.

Next Thursday will be the 150th anniversary of the birth of Friedrich Froebei. To the ideas and principles set in motion or largely adapted by this German educator we owe much that seems most modern to us in education today; much of the emphasis on "activity" that forms the core of so-called progressive education.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 16. -- Cornell's lacrosse team came from behind to defeat Princeton, 3 to 2, on a muddy field here today. It was Cornell's first start of the season, and the Ithacans revealed a strong offense throughout the game.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., April 16. -- The Johns Hopkins lacrosse team overwhelmed Swarthmore by 16 -- 3 today. Lorny Guild Hopkins attack man, scored seven goals.

The Middle West Utilities Company, Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago, three of the Insull companies that have been petitioned into receivership, had pledged at the end of 1931 $439,634,815 of their investments and borrowed securities with banks to secure or partly secure loans and notes aggregating $112,548,425.

PARIS, April 16. -- The French press on the whole today finds little reason to derive satisfaction from Secretary Stimson's visit yesterday, although most newspapers pay tribute to the frankness and cordiality evinced by Premier Tardieu and the Secretary.
STOCKHOLM, April 16. -- One of the greatest series of forgeries In history was charged against Ivar Kreuger today by the experts committee inquiring into his companies.

All of the markets were quiet yesterday and price movements were irregular. The brightest spot in the entire financial picture was the uniformly strong tone of domestic corporation bonds. These not only extended their recent advances, but their purchase at steadily rising prices seemed to reflect a revived investment demand.

NATIVE musicians, dancers, costumes and instruments will help to convert the Delia Robbia Room of the Vanderbilt Hotel Into a tropical (or semi-tropical) country on Friday evening, April 22, when the Neighborhood Playhouse presents as its annual Spring production authentic Latin-American, Caribbean and Negro entertainment, not in a formal concert ball, but at a dinner cabaret where such musicians usually appear.
ANDOVER, Mass., April 16. -- Andover dropped its second game today to the Boston University freshmen, 7 to 2. In the seventh the freshmen sent across four runs.
Residential properties led in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday. Several garage and taxpayer parcels also were transferred.
LONDON, April 16. -- We have put our bouse in order we have balanced our budget and ceased to borrow. So far, good.

LONDON, April 16. -- The Stock Exchange was closed today and will be closed on the next two Saturdays for structural alterations. Next week the American prices will be re- ceived an hour later than usual, as daylight saving starts here tomor- row.

Should the Hare Philippine bill, passed last week by the House of Representatives, or some similar measure be enacted into law, the world will witness the novel spectacle of a people having independence thrust upon them.

THE civilization whose rapidly approaching demise Dr. Briffault signalizes and rejoices in is not one of the many civilizations which constitute in their rise and fall the Spenglerian pulse-beat of history. In Eastern and Middle Asia the Spengler scheme takes note of several such civilizations, earlier than what used to be called the "dawn of history."

PHILADELPHIA, April 16. -- Pennsylvania started the defense of its Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League championship by easily defeating Cornell on Franklin Field today, 8 to 2. This was the first league game for each team and also the opening contest of the season for the Ithacans.
CINCINNATI, April 16 (AP). -- Cincinnati's Reds scored their first shutout victory of the season today, Si Johnson blanking the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5 to 0, in the opening game of a series.

LONDON. IN the Spring number of The Book Window, Arthur Rackham, the veteran book illustrator, discusses the craft of which he is a distinguished practitioner. He reminds us that the appearances of the characters of Dickens, as we conceive them, were really created by the artists who illustrated his novels.

THE Isle of Man, according to a recent announcement, is facing a crisis with the threatened extinction of its tailless Manx cats. Lovers of the not only grieve because he is being spirited away by conscienceless tourists, but they mourn his lack of pep.

Bonds called last week for redemption before their maturity dates were chiefly those of issues with sinking fund requirements. Other additions to the list of those to be redeemed in April, as well as in future months, were few, and none of them was large.

The recent pilgrimage of university, students to Kentucky mines, the student strike at Columbia University and the delegation sent by American students to the Disarmament Conference at Geneva, raise the question whether American students are likely to enter the political arenas as students in many other nations have for years.

QUEER things happen in the air. Their number streams distantly into the past, for they have been happening ever since man first took to the air. Sometimes they are amusing and incidental. Sometimes they spell disaster, sometimes averted, sometimes not.

NEW HAVEN, April 16. -- Awards of 178 fellowships and scholarships were made today by the Yale Graduate School. The selections were made from more than one thousand applicants. Fellowships for research were awarded to thirty-seven and ninetysix received fellowships for graduate study leading to higher degrees.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 16. -- Bunching hits in the fourth and fifth innings, the Naval Academy baseball team defeated Western Maryland College here today, 11 to 5. Although each team made a like number of bits, better fielding and two effec- tive twirlers aided the Navy.

Strong opposition to the proposal for reduction of salaries of government employes as a means of balancing the national budget was voiced by Representative Fiorello H. La Guardia at a dinner of Ellis Island employes at the Hotel Roosevelt last night.
